Genesis 1:1 In the beginning, God created the universe and the earth.
Genesis 1:2 The earth wasn't finished yet.
The matter of the earth was present but not yet formed or inhabited, and it was dark,
and God's Spirit was there, hovering over the unformed earth.
Genesis 1:3 God then created light by saying "Let there be light!"
Genesis 1:4 God saw that the light was good
and caused the light to travel through the darkness of space.
Genesis 1:5 He called the time when it is bright "day",
and the time when it is dark "night". The first ever evening and morning passed—the first day of all of history.
Genesis 1:6 And God said: "Let there be an atmosphere to separate Earth from the rest of creation."
Genesis 1:7 So God made the atmosphere
between the unformed Earth
and the rest of the universe that was still being formed,
and the Earth was separated from the rest of the universe.
Genesis 1:8 He called the atmosphere "the sky".
Evening and morning then came, the second day.
Genesis 1:9 God said "Let the oceans and land of the earth appear and take their proper places."
And it was immediately so.
Genesis 1:10 And God called the oceans "the sea"
and the dry ground "land",
and God saw that it was good.
Genesis 1:11 And God said, “Let the earth sprout every sort of plant.
Let there be all types of grasses, herbs, and trees, including those that produce fruit.
Let the plants produce seeds that grow into the same species of plant.”
After God said this, the earth was filled with plant life.
Genesis 1:12 The earth then produced lush plant life. It brought forth all types of grasses and herbs, each with seeds that would reproduce its own kind. It also brought forth trees that produced fruit, each with its own seeds that would reproduce its own kind. God saw that this was good.
Genesis 1:13 Evening and morning passed; it was the third day.
Genesis 1:14 God then said, "Let there be sources of light in the sky to separate day from night. Let them serve as indicators for marking holy days, seasons, days, and years.
Genesis 1:15 Let them shine in the sky to illuminate the earth." And so it was.
Genesis 1:16 God created two great sources of light: the sun, the greater light, to govern the day, and the moon, the lesser light, to govern the night. He also created the stars.
Genesis 1:17 God placed these sources of light in the sky to shine upon the earth,
Genesis 1:18 and to govern the day and the night, and to separate the light from the darkness. God saw that this was good.
Genesis 1:19 Evening and morning passed; it was the fourth day.
Genesis 1:20 God also said, "Let the waters teem with every type of living creature, and let birds fly above the earth, across the sky."
Genesis 1:21 So God created the great sea monsters and every other living creature that moves, with which the waters teem, each according to its species. He also created every winged bird according to its species. God saw that this was good.
Genesis 1:22 God blessed them, saying, "Be fruitful, multiply, and fill the waters of the seas. And let the birds multiply on the earth."
Genesis 1:23 Evening and morning passed; it was the fifth day.
Genesis 1:24 God said, "Let the earth bring forth living creatures according to their kinds: cattle, creatures that move along the ground, and wild animals, each according to its species." And so it was.
Genesis 1:25 God made the wild animals of the earth according to their species, the cattle according to their species, and all creatures that move along the ground according to their species. God saw that this was good.
Genesis 1:26 Then God said, "Let Us make man in Our image, according to Our likeness. Let them have dominion over the fish of the sea, over the birds of the sky, over the cattle, over all the earth, and over every creature that moves along the ground."
Genesis 1:27 So God created man in His own image; in the image of God, He created him. He created them male and female.
Genesis 1:28 God blessed them and said to them, "Be fruitful and multiply. Fill the earth and subdue it. Have dominion over the fish of the sea, over the birds of the sky, and over every living creature that moves on the earth."
Genesis 1:29 Then God said, "Look, I have given you every seed-bearing plant on the face of the entire earth, and every tree whose fruit contains seed. These will be your food.
Genesis 1:30 And to every beast of the earth, to every bird of the sky, and to every creature that moves along the ground—everything that has the breath of life in it—I have given every green plant for food." And so it was.
Genesis 1:31 God looked at everything He had made, and indeed, it was very good. Evening and morning passed; it was the sixth day.
Genesis 2:1 So, the universe and the earth, and all that fills them, were finished.
Genesis 2:2 By the seventh day, God had finished all the work of creation He had been doing. He ceased His work on the seventh day, resting from everything He had made.
Genesis 2:3 And God blessed the seventh day and made it holy, because on that day He had finished all His work of creation.
Genesis 2:4 This is the historical account of the universe and the earth at their creation, at the time when the Lord God made the universe and the earth.
Genesis 2:5 There was no plant yet growing in the field, nor had any herb of the region sprouted. For the Lord God had not yet caused rain to fall upon the earth, and there was no man to cultivate the land.
Genesis 2:6 Instead, a spring of water would rise up from the earth, watering the entire surface of the ground.
Genesis 2:7 So the Lord God formed man from the dust of the ground, and He breathed into his face the breath of life, and thus man became a living soul.
Genesis 2:8 Then the Lord God had planted a garden of delight from the beginning in the East, and there He placed the man whom He had formed.
Genesis 2:9 And the Lord God caused to grow from the ground every tree that was pleasing to the eye and good for food. He also placed the tree of life in the middle of the garden, and the tree of the knowledge of good and evil.
Genesis 2:10 A river flowed out of the place of delight to water the garden, and from there it divided into four branches.
Genesis 2:11 The name of the first is Pishon; it is the one that flows around the entire land of Havilah, where gold is found.
Genesis 2:12 The gold of that land is of excellent quality. Bdellium (a fragrant resin) and the onyx stone are also found there.
Genesis 2:13 The name of the second river is Gihon; it is the one that flows around the entire land of Cush (Ethiopia).
Genesis 2:14 The name of the third river is Tigris; it flows eastward toward Assyria. The fourth river is the Euphrates.
Genesis 2:15 Therefore, the Lord God took the man and placed him in the Garden of Delight to cultivate and keep it.
Genesis 2:16 And the Lord God gave the man this command, saying: "From every tree of the garden you may freely eat.
Genesis 2:17 But from the tree of the knowledge of good and evil you shall not eat; for on the day that you eat from it, you will surely die."
Genesis 2:18 Then the Lord God said: "It is not good for man to be alone. I will make him a helper suitable for him."
Genesis 2:19 So, the Lord God, having formed out of the ground all the beasts of the earth and all the birds of the sky, brought them to Adam to see what he would call them. And whatever Adam called each living creature, that was its name.
Genesis 2:20 Adam gave names to all the livestock, and to the birds of the sky, and to all the beasts of the field. But for Adam himself, no suitable helper was found.
Genesis 2:21 So the Lord God caused a deep sleep to fall upon Adam. And while he was sleeping, God took one of his ribs and then closed up the flesh in its place.
Genesis 2:22 And the Lord God formed the rib, which He had taken from Adam, into a woman, and He brought her to Adam.
Genesis 2:23 Then Adam said: "This at last is bone of my bones and flesh of my flesh! She shall be called 'Woman' because she was taken out of Man."
Genesis 2:24 Therefore, a man will leave his father and his mother and be united to his wife, and they will become one flesh.
Genesis 2:25 And the man and his wife were both naked, but they felt no shame.
Genesis 3:1 Now, the serpent was the most cunning creature among all the animals the Lord God had made on the earth. It came to the woman and said, 'Why did God give you a command that you should not eat from *any* tree in this entire garden?' —the serpent twisted God's actual prohibition, making it sound like they were forbidden from everything.
Genesis 3:2 The woman answered the serpent, 'We may eat the fruit from the trees throughout this garden;'
Genesis 3:3 but from the fruit of the tree that stands in the very center of the garden, God has strictly commanded us not to eat, nor even to touch it—an addition the woman made to God's original command—lest we die.'
Genesis 3:4 But the serpent said to the woman, 'No, you will not die at all!'
Genesis 3:5 For God knows that on the very day you eat from it, your eyes will be opened, and you will become like gods, knowing both good and evil, just as He does.'
Genesis 3:6 Therefore, the woman saw that the tree was good for food, and that it was beautiful to the eyes, and that it was delightful to look at. She then took some of its fruit and ate it; and she also gave some to her husband, and he ate it.
Genesis 3:7 And the eyes of both of them were indeed opened, not to wisdom but to shame; and when they realized they were naked, they sewed fig leaves together and made coverings for themselves to hide their nakedness.
Genesis 3:8 And when they heard the voice of the Lord God, Who was walking about in the garden during the cool afternoon breeze, Adam and his wife immediately hid themselves from the presence of the Lord God, concealing themselves among the trees of the garden.
Genesis 3:9 And the Lord God called to Adam and said to him, 'Where are you?'
Genesis 3:10 He answered, 'I heard Your voice in the garden, and I was afraid because I was naked, so I hid myself.'
Genesis 3:11 And God said to him, 'Who told you that you were naked, unless it was because you had eaten from the very tree about which I commanded you not to eat?'
Genesis 3:12 And Adam said, 'The woman You gave to be my companion—she gave me fruit from the tree, and I ate it.'
Genesis 3:13 And the Lord God said to the woman, 'What is this that you have done?' And she replied, 'The serpent cleverly deceived me, and so I ate.'
Genesis 3:14 And the Lord God said to the serpent, 'Because you have done this, you are cursed above all living creatures and all beasts of the earth. You shall crawl on your belly, and you shall metaphorically eat the dust of the earth—meaning, you shall always be humbled and defeated—all the days of your life.'
Genesis 3:15 I will put enmities, a spiritual warfare, between you and the woman, and between your offspring and her offspring. She, the Woman, shall crush your head—a prophecy of Mary and her Son, Jesus Christ, triumphing over you—and you, in turn, shall lie in wait for her heel, attempting to wound Him.
Genesis 3:16 To the woman He also said, 'I will greatly multiply your sorrows and your painful conceptions. In great pain you shall give birth to children; and you shall be subject to your husband's authority, and he shall rule over you.'
Genesis 3:17 And to Adam He said, 'Because you listened to the voice of your wife, and ate from the tree concerning which I specifically commanded you, "You shall not eat from it," therefore, the very ground is now cursed because of your deed. You shall eat from it only through hard labor and toil all the days of your life.'
Genesis 3:18 Thorns and thistles shall the earth bring forth for you, and you shall eat the wild plants of the field to survive.
Genesis 3:19 By the sweat of your face you shall eat bread, until you return to the very ground from which you were taken; for you are dust, and to dust you shall return in death.
Genesis 3:20 And Adam called the name of his wife 'Eve'—meaning 'life-giver'—because she would be the mother of all who live.
Genesis 3:21 And the Lord God also made garments of animal skins for Adam and his wife, and He clothed them with these, providing a more lasting covering than their fig leaves and foreshadowing future atonement.
Genesis 3:22 And the Lord God said, 'Behold, Adam has now become like one of Us—meaning, like the divine beings in heaven—by knowing good and evil in a fallen way. Now, therefore, lest he reach out his hand and also take from the Tree of Life, and eat, and live forever in this fallen state—'
Genesis 3:23 Therefore, the Lord God sent Adam out from the Garden of Eden—the Garden of Pleasure—so that he might work the very ground from which he was taken, as a consequence of his sin.
Genesis 3:24 And so He drove Adam out; and at the eastern side of the Garden of Pleasure, He stationed Cherubim and a flaming sword that turned every way, to guard the path to the Tree of Life and prevent humanity from reaching it in their fallen state.
Genesis 4:1 Adam knew his wife, Eve. She conceived and gave birth to Cain, saying, "I have gotten a man through God."
Genesis 4:2 Again, she gave birth to his brother, Abel. Abel became a shepherd of sheep, while Cain was a tiller of the ground.
Genesis 4:3 After a period of many days, Cain brought an offering to the Lord from the produce of the earth.
Genesis 4:4 Abel also offered from the firstborn of his flock and from their fat portions. The Lord looked with favor upon Abel and his offering.
Genesis 4:5 But upon Cain and his offering, He did not look with favor. Cain became extremely angry, and his face fell.
Genesis 4:6 Then the Lord said to Cain, "Why are you angry? Why has your face fallen?"
Genesis 4:7 If you do what is right, will you not be accepted? But if you do not do what is right, sin is waiting at the door, and its desire is for you, but you must master it.
Genesis 4:8 Cain then spoke to his brother Abel, saying, "Let us go out to the field." When they were in the field, Cain attacked his brother Abel and murdered him.
Genesis 4:9 Then the Lord said to Cain, "Where is your brother Abel?" He answered, "I do not know. Am I my brother's keeper?"
Genesis 4:10 And He said to him, "What have you done? The voice of your brother's blood is crying out to me from the earth!"
Genesis 4:11 Now, therefore, you are cursed from the earth, which has opened its mouth to receive your brother's blood from your hand.
Genesis 4:12 When you cultivate the ground, it will no longer yield its produce to you. You shall be a restless wanderer on the earth.
Genesis 4:13 And Cain said to the Lord, "My punishment is too great for me to bear."
Genesis 4:14 Behold, today you are driving me from the face of the earth, and from your presence I shall be hidden. I shall be a restless wanderer on the earth, and whoever finds me will kill me."
Genesis 4:15 Then the Lord said to him, "Not so! If anyone kills Cain, he will suffer vengeance seven times over." And the Lord put a protective mark on Cain, so that no one who found him would kill him.
Genesis 4:16 So Cain went out from the presence of the Lord and lived as an exile in the land of Nod, to the east of Eden.
Genesis 4:17 Cain knew his wife, and she conceived and gave birth to Enoch. Cain then built a city and named it Enoch, after his son.
Genesis 4:18 To Enoch was born Irad. Irad begot Maviael. Maviael begot Mathusael, and Mathusael begot Lamech.
Genesis 4:19 Lamech took two wives. The name of the first was Ada, and the name of the second was Sella.
Genesis 4:20 Ada gave birth to Jabal. He became the father of those who dwell in tents and keep livestock.
Genesis 4:21 His brother's name was Jubal. He was the father of all who play the lyre and the pipe.
Genesis 4:22 Sella also gave birth to Tubalcain, who was an instructor and smith in every kind of bronze and iron work. The sister of Tubalcain was Noema.
Genesis 4:23 Then Lamech said to his wives, Ada and Sella: "Hear my voice, wives of Lamech; listen to my speech. For I have killed a man who wounded me, and a young man who bruised me."
Genesis 4:24 If vengeance for Cain was sevenfold, then for Lamech it will be seventy-sevenfold.
Genesis 4:25 Adam knew his wife again, and she gave birth to a son and named him Seth, saying, "God has appointed for me another child in place of Abel, whom Cain murdered."
Genesis 4:26 To Seth also a son was born, whom he named Enos. It was then that people began to invoke the name of the Lord.
Genesis 5:1 This is the record of Adam's lineage. At the time when God created mankind, He made him in God's own likeness.
Genesis 5:2 He created them as male and female. He blessed them, and He called their collective name 'Mankind' (Adam), at the time they were created.
Genesis 5:3 Adam lived for one hundred and thirty years, and then he begot a son in his own image and likeness, whom he named Seth.
Genesis 5:4 After he begot Seth, Adam lived for eight hundred more years, during which time he also begot other sons and daughters.
Genesis 5:5 Adam lived for a total of nine hundred and thirty years, and then he died.
Genesis 5:6 Seth also lived for one hundred and five years, and then he begot Enos.
Genesis 5:7 After he begot Enos, Seth lived for eight hundred and seven more years, during which time he also begot other sons and daughters.
Genesis 5:8 Seth lived for a total of nine hundred and twelve years, and then he died.
Genesis 5:9 Enos lived for ninety years, and then he begot Cainan.
Genesis 5:10 After he begot Cainan, Enos lived for eight hundred and fifteen more years, during which time he also begot other sons and daughters.
Genesis 5:11 Enos lived for a total of nine hundred and five years, and then he died.
Genesis 5:12 Cainan lived for seventy years, and then he begot Malaleel.
Genesis 5:13 After he begot Malaleel, Cainan lived for eight hundred and forty more years, during which time he also begot other sons and daughters.
Genesis 5:14 Cainan lived for a total of nine hundred and ten years, and then he died.
Genesis 5:15 Malaleel lived for sixty-five years, and then he begot Jared.
Genesis 5:16 After he begot Jared, Malaleel lived for eight hundred and thirty more years, during which time he also begot other sons and daughters.
Genesis 5:17 Malaleel lived for a total of eight hundred and ninety-five years, and then he died.
Genesis 5:18 Jared also lived for one hundred and sixty-two years, and then he begot Enoch.
Genesis 5:19 After he begot Enoch, Jared lived for eight hundred more years, during which time he also begot other sons and daughters.
Genesis 5:20 Jared lived for a total of nine hundred and sixty-two years, and then he died.
Genesis 5:21 Enoch lived for sixty-five years, and then he begot Methuselah.
Genesis 5:22 And Enoch walked closely with God. After he begot Methuselah, Enoch lived for three hundred more years, during which time he also begot other sons and daughters.
Genesis 5:23 Enoch lived for a total of three hundred and sixty-five years.
Genesis 5:24 Enoch continued to walk closely with God, and then he was no longer seen, because God took him from the earth.
Genesis 5:25 Methuselah also lived for one hundred and eighty-seven years, and then he begot Lamech.
Genesis 5:26 After he begot Lamech, Methuselah lived for seven hundred and eighty-two more years, during which time he also begot other sons and daughters.
Genesis 5:27 Methuselah lived for a total of nine hundred and sixty-nine years, and then he died.
Genesis 5:28 Lamech lived for one hundred and eighty-two years, and then he begot a son.
Genesis 5:29 He named the boy Noah, saying, 'This son will bring us comfort from our toil and from the hard labor of our hands, which comes from the earth that the Lord God has cursed.'
Genesis 5:30 After he begot Noah, Lamech lived for five hundred and ninety-five more years, during which time he also begot other sons and daughters.
Genesis 5:31 Lamech lived for a total of seven hundred and seventy-seven years, and then he died.
Genesis 5:32 When Noah was five hundred years old, he became the father of Shem, Ham, and Japheth.
Genesis 6:1 And when human beings began to multiply on the earth, and they had given birth to daughters,
Genesis 6:2 the sons of God saw that the daughters of men were beautiful, and they chose wives for themselves from all of them whom they desired.
Genesis 6:3 And God said, "My Spirit will not always strive within man, because man is merely flesh. Therefore, his days will be limited to one hundred and twenty years."
Genesis 6:4 Now, giants were on the earth in those days—and even after—when the sons of God had relations with the daughters of men, and they bore children. These were the mighty ones of ancient times, men of renown and fame.
Genesis 6:5 But God saw that the wickedness of man was great on the earth, and that every intention of the thoughts of his heart was only evil continually and without ceasing.
Genesis 6:6 And God regretted that He had made man on the earth. He was grieved in His heart by man's evil.
Genesis 6:7 God said, "I will blot out man whom I have created from the face of the earth—from man to beast, from creeping thing to the birds of the sky—for I regret that I have made them."
Genesis 6:8 But Noah found grace and favor in the sight of the Lord.
Genesis 6:9 These are the generations of Noah: Noah was a just man, blameless and upright in his generations; Noah walked with God.
Genesis 6:10 And Noah begot three sons: Shem, Ham, and Japheth.
Genesis 6:11 The earth, however, was corrupt before God; the earth was filled with iniquity and violence.
Genesis 6:12 When God saw that the earth was corrupted (for all flesh had corrupted its way upon the earth—their moral path was depraved),
Genesis 6:13 God said to Noah, "The end of all flesh has come before me; for the earth is filled with iniquity and violence because of them. And behold, I will destroy them with the earth."
Genesis 6:14 Make yourself an ark of smooth, polished gopher wood. You shall make rooms in the ark, and you shall pitch it with asphalt inside and out to make it watertight.
Genesis 6:15 And this is how you shall make it: The length of the ark shall be three hundred cubits, its width fifty cubits, and its height thirty cubits. (A cubit is approximately 18 inches, so about 450 feet long, 75 feet wide, 45 feet high).
Genesis 6:16 You shall make a window for the ark, and you shall finish it to a cubit above; and the door of the ark you shall set in its side. You shall make lower, second, and third decks in it.
Genesis 6:17 For behold, I, myself, am bringing a flood of waters upon the earth, to destroy all flesh in which is the spirit of life from under the sky. Everything that is on the earth shall die.
Genesis 6:18 But I will establish My covenant with you; and you shall go into the ark, you, your sons, your wife, and your sons' wives with you.
Genesis 6:19 And from every living thing of all flesh, you shall bring two of every sort into the ark, to keep them alive with you; they shall be male and female.
Genesis 6:20 Of birds after their kind, and of livestock after their kind, of every creeping thing of the earth after its kind, two of every sort shall come to you, so they may live.
Genesis 6:21 And you shall take for yourself every sort of food that is eaten, and you shall gather it into the ark. And it shall be food for you and for them.
Genesis 6:22 Thus Noah did; according to all that God had commanded him, so he did.
Genesis 7:1 The Lord then spoke to Noah, saying, "Go into the ark, you and your whole household. I have seen that you are righteous before me in this generation."
Genesis 7:2 "From all of the clean animals, take seven pairs—a male and a female of each. But from the unclean animals, take only two—one male and one female of each."
Genesis 7:3 "And from the birds of the sky, take seven pairs of each, a male and a female. This is so that their offspring may be preserved on the face of the entire earth after the flood."
Genesis 7:4 "For in exactly seven days, I will send rain upon the earth for forty days and forty nights. I will then wipe out every living thing that I have made from the face of the earth."
Genesis 7:5 So Noah did everything that the Lord had commanded him to do.
Genesis 7:6 Noah was six hundred years old when the floodwaters began to swell over the earth.
Genesis 7:7 Noah entered the ark because of the floodwaters. His sons, his wife, and his sons' wives also entered with him.
Genesis 7:8 All the animals, both clean and unclean, and all the birds, and all the creeping creatures that move upon the earth—
Genesis 7:9 —they entered the ark with Noah, two by two, a male and a female of each, just as the Lord had commanded Noah.
Genesis 7:10 After the seven days had passed, the floodwaters began to swell over the earth.
Genesis 7:11 In the six hundredth year of Noah’s life, on the seventeenth day of the second month of that year, all the subterranean fountains of the great deep burst forth. At the same time, the floodgates of the sky were opened wide.
Genesis 7:12 And heavy rain fell upon the earth for forty days and forty nights without stopping.
Genesis 7:13 On that same day, Noah, and his sons Shem, Ham, and Japheth, along with Noah's wife and his three daughters-in-law, all entered the ark.
Genesis 7:14 With them went every kind of wild animal, every kind of domestic animal, every kind of creeping creature that moves on the earth, and every kind of bird and winged creature—all of them according to their own species.
Genesis 7:15 They entered the ark with Noah, two by two, from every living creature that had the breath of life in it.
Genesis 7:16 Those that entered were male and female from every kind of living creature, just as the Lord had commanded Noah. Then the Lord himself shut the door securely behind Noah.
Genesis 7:17 The flood continued for forty days upon the earth. The waters swelled, lifting the ark high, so it was raised up from the ground.
Genesis 7:18 The waters became exceedingly mighty and covered everything on the surface of the earth. But the ark floated securely on the surface of the waters.
Genesis 7:19 The waters prevailed with extreme might over the earth. All the high mountains that were under the entire sky were completely covered by the flood.
Genesis 7:20 The water rose fifteen cubits (about twenty-two feet) above the highest mountains, completely submerging them.
Genesis 7:21 Every living creature that moved on the earth perished: all birds, all wild animals, all domestic beasts, all creeping creatures that crawled on the earth, and all mankind.
Genesis 7:22 Everything on dry land that had the breath of life in its nostrils died.
Genesis 7:23 God wiped out every living thing that was on the surface of the earth, from man to domestic animal, and all creeping creatures, and all birds of the sky. They were all utterly destroyed from the earth. Only Noah remained alive, along with those who were with him in the ark.
Genesis 7:24 The waters covered the earth and remained at their height for one hundred and fifty days.
Genesis 8:1 But the Lord took Noah and all the living creatures and all the cattle that were with him in the ark to heart. He sent a powerful wind across the earth, and the floodwaters began to recede.
Genesis 8:2 And the underground springs that supplied the floodwaters were closed, and the floodgates of the sky were shut. The rain from the sky was stopped.
Genesis 8:3 The waters continued to recede from the earth, constantly flowing back and forth. After one hundred and fifty days, they began to significantly diminish.
Genesis 8:4 And in the seventh month, on the twenty-seventh day of the month, the ark came to rest on the mountains of Ararat (which are in Armenia).
Genesis 8:5 However, the waters continued to recede and diminish until the tenth month. On the first day of the tenth month, the tops of the mountains became visible.
Genesis 8:6 And it happened that after forty days had passed, Noah opened the window of the ark that he had made, and he released a raven.
Genesis 8:7 The raven flew out and did not return to the ark, as it waited for the waters upon the earth to dry completely.
Genesis 8:8 Then Noah also sent out a dove after the raven, to see if the waters had subsided from the surface of the earth.
Genesis 8:9 But the dove could not find any place to rest its foot, because the waters still covered the entire surface of the earth. So it returned to Noah in the ark. Noah reached out his hand, took the dove, and brought it back inside the ark.
Genesis 8:10 Noah waited for seven more days, and again he released the dove from the ark.
Genesis 8:11 And the dove came back to him in the evening, carrying a fresh olive branch with green leaves in its beak. So Noah understood that the waters had finally receded from the earth.
Genesis 8:12 Noah waited for seven more days, and then he released the dove again. This time, it did not return to him.
Genesis 8:13 Therefore, in the six hundred and first year of Noah's life, in the first month, on the first day of that month, the waters had receded from the earth. Noah opened the covering of the ark, looked out, and saw that the surface of the land was dry.
Genesis 8:14 In the second month, on the twenty-seventh day of the month, the entire earth was dry.
Genesis 8:15 Then God spoke to Noah, saying:
Genesis 8:16  'Come out of the ark, you and your wife, and your sons and your sons' wives with you.
Genesis 8:17  'Bring out with you all the living creatures that are with you, from every kind of flesh: the birds, the cattle, and all the creeping things that crawl upon the earth. Go forth onto the earth, and grow in number, and multiply upon it.' 
Genesis 8:18 So Noah went out, and his wife, and his sons, and his sons' wives with him.
Genesis 8:19 And all the living creatures, all the creeping things, and all the birds, everything that moves upon the earth, came out of the ark according to their kinds.
Genesis 8:20 Then Noah built an altar to the Lord. And taking from every clean animal and every clean bird, he offered burnt offerings on the altar.
Genesis 8:21 And the Lord smelled the pleasing aroma of the sacrifice, and He said in His heart: 'Never again will I curse the earth because of humans, for the intention and the inclination of the human heart are prone to evil from its youth. Therefore, I will never again strike down every living thing as I have done.
Genesis 8:22  'For all the days the earth endures, planting and harvest, cold and heat, summer and winter, and day and night shall never cease.' 
Genesis 9:1 God blessed Noah and his sons, and said to them, "Be fruitful and multiply, and fill the entire earth."
Genesis 9:2 And your powerful presence and authority shall be upon all the animals of the land, and upon all the birds of the sky, with all the creatures that move upon the earth; all the fish of the sea are now given into your control.
Genesis 9:3 Every moving, living thing will be food for you. Just as I gave you the green plants before the flood, I have now given you all these things to eat.
Genesis 9:4 But you shall not eat the flesh of an animal with its blood still in it, because its life is in its blood.
Genesis 9:5 For I will certainly demand an account for the blood that holds your life; I will demand it from every wild beast, and from the hand of man. Indeed, from the hand of every man and his brother, I will demand an account for the life of a human being.
Genesis 9:6 Whoever sheds human blood, his blood shall also be shed in return; for indeed, God made man in His own divine image and likeness.
Genesis 9:7 But as for you, be fruitful and multiply; spread out over the earth and fill it.
Genesis 9:8 Then God spoke to Noah and to his sons who were with him, saying:
Genesis 9:9 "Behold, I am now establishing my solemn covenant with you and with your descendants who will come after you."
Genesis 9:10 "And with every living creature that is with you—the birds, the livestock, and every wild beast of the earth that is with you—all that came out of the ark, and indeed, all the living creatures of the earth."
Genesis 9:11 "I establish my covenant with you: never again shall all living creatures be cut off by the waters of a flood; nor shall there ever again be a flood to destroy the entire earth."
Genesis 9:12 And God said, "This is the sign of my solemn covenant, which I now give between me and you, and between me and every living creature that is with you, for all future generations:"
Genesis 9:13 "I will place my rainbow in the clouds, and it will be a sign of the covenant between me and the entire earth."
Genesis 9:14 "And whenever I bring clouds over the sky, my rainbow will appear in those clouds."
Genesis 9:15 "And I will remember my covenant that is between me and you, and with every living creature that possesses life; never again shall the waters of a flood destroy all living creatures."
Genesis 9:16 "So the rainbow will be in the clouds, and I will look at it and remember the everlasting covenant, which was established between God and every living creature of all flesh upon the earth."
Genesis 9:17 And God said to Noah, "This is the sign of the covenant which I have established between me and all living creatures upon the entire earth."
Genesis 9:18 The sons of Noah who came out of the ark were Shem, Ham, and Japheth. Ham is the one who became the father of Canaan.
Genesis 9:19 These three are the sons of Noah, and from these three, the entire earth was populated.
Genesis 9:20 Noah, a farmer, was the first to cultivate the land and he planted a vineyard.
Genesis 9:21 He drank some wine and became drunk, and was lying uncovered inside his tent.
Genesis 9:22 And when Ham, the father of Canaan, saw his father's nakedness, he went out and told his two brothers.
Genesis 9:23 But Shem and Japheth took a cloak, laid it on both their shoulders, and walking backward, they covered their father's nakedness. Their faces were turned away so they did not see their father's nakedness.
Genesis 9:24 When Noah awoke from his wine and learned what his younger son—Ham—had done to him,
Genesis 9:25 He said, "Cursed be Canaan! He shall be the lowest of servants to his brothers."
Genesis 9:26 Then he said, "Blessed be the Lord God of Shem! And Canaan shall be his servant."
Genesis 9:27 "May God enlarge Japheth, and may he dwell in the tents of Shem; and Canaan shall also be his servant."
Genesis 9:28 Noah lived for three hundred and fifty years after the great flood.
Genesis 9:29 And all the days of Noah's life were nine hundred and fifty years; then he died.
Genesis 10:1 These are the descendants of Noah's sons, Shem, Ham, and Japheth. Children were born to them after the great flood that reset humanity.
Genesis 10:2 The sons of Japheth were Gomer, Magog, Madai, Javan, Tubal, Mosoch, and Thiras.
Genesis 10:3 The sons of Gomer were Aschenez, Riphath, and Thogorma.
Genesis 10:4 The sons of Javan were Elisa, Tharsis, Cetthim, and Dodanim.
Genesis 10:5 From these descendants, the peoples of the nations spread out to their own lands, each according to their language, their families, and their nations.
Genesis 10:6 The sons of Ham were Chus, Mesraim, Phuth, and Chanaan.
Genesis 10:7 The sons of Chus were Saba, Hevila, Sabatha, Regma, and Sabatacha. The sons of Regma were Saba and Dadan.
Genesis 10:8 Furthermore, Chus was the father of Nemrod. This Nemrod began to be a mighty leader on the earth.
Genesis 10:9 He was a powerful hunter, a great man in the sight of the Lord. For this reason, it became a saying: 'Like Nemrod, a powerful hunter in the sight of the Lord.'
Genesis 10:10 The beginning of his kingdom was Babylon, and Arach, and Achad, and Chalanne, in the land of Sennaar.
Genesis 10:11 From that land, Assur went forth, and he built Ninive, and its city squares, and Calach.
Genesis 10:12 He also built Resen, which is between Ninive and Calach. This is a great city.
Genesis 10:13 Indeed, Mesraim was the father of Ludim, Anamim, Laabim, and Nephthuim.
Genesis 10:14 And also Phetrusim and Casluim, from whom the Philisthiim and Caphtorim descended.
Genesis 10:15 And Chanaan was the father of Sidon, his firstborn son, and also Hethæum.
Genesis 10:16 And also the Jebusæum, Amorrhæum, and Gergesæum.
Genesis 10:17 Also the Hevæum, Aracæum, and Sinæum.
Genesis 10:18 And the Aradium, Samaræum, and Hamathæum. After this, the peoples of the Chananæans spread out.
Genesis 10:19 The territory of Chanaan extended from Sidon, going towards Gerara as far as Gaza, and then to Sodom, Gomorrham, Adama, and Seboim, reaching as far as Lesa.
Genesis 10:20 These are the descendants of Ham, organized by their family groups, languages, regions, and nations.
Genesis 10:21 And children were also born to Shem, who was the father of all the descendants of Heber, and the elder brother of Japheth.
Genesis 10:22 The sons of Shem were Ælam, Assur, Arphaxad, Lud, and Aram.
Genesis 10:23 The sons of Aram were Us, Hul, Gether, and Mes.
Genesis 10:24 Indeed, Arphaxad was the father of Sala, and from Sala, Heber was born.
Genesis 10:25 To Heber, two sons were born. The name of one was Phaleg, because in his days the peoples of the earth were divided and spread out. And his brother's name was Jectan.
Genesis 10:26 This Jectan was the father of Elmodad, Salaph, Asarmoth, and Jare.
Genesis 10:27 And Aduram, Uzal, and Decla.
Genesis 10:28 And Ebal, Abimaël, and Saba.
Genesis 10:29 And Ophir, Hevila, and Jobab. All these were the sons of Jectan.
Genesis 10:30 Their dwelling place extended from Messa, as one travels towards Sephar, a mountain in the east.
Genesis 10:31 These are the descendants of Shem, according to their family groups, languages, regions, and nations.
Genesis 10:32 These are the family groups descended from Noah, according to their peoples and nations. From these, the nations of the earth spread out and divided after the great flood.
Genesis 11:1 At that time, everyone on the whole earth spoke the same language, using the same words and expressions.
Genesis 11:2 As people migrated from the east, they discovered a vast plain in the land called Shinar and chose to settle there.
Genesis 11:3 Then people said to each other, 'Let us make bricks and burn them very thoroughly to make them strong.' They used these bricks instead of stones, and they used bitumen, a natural asphalt, as their mortar.
Genesis 11:4 They also said, 'Come, let us build a great city for ourselves, and a tower that reaches so high it seems to touch the sky. This will establish our name and legacy, preventing us from being scattered across the face of the whole world.'
Genesis 11:5 But then the Lord came down from His sublime dwelling —not because He needed to, but to observe the city and the tower that the children of Adam were building.
Genesis 11:6 And the Lord said, 'See, they are one people, and they all speak a single language. This is only the beginning of what they plan to do; they will not stop pursuing their intentions until they have achieved them through their actions.'
Genesis 11:7 Then He said, 'Come, let Us —the Holy Trinity— descend and there confuse their language, so that no one will be able to understand what his neighbor is saying.'
Genesis 11:8 And in this way, the Lord scattered them from that place across the face of the whole earth. Because of this, they stopped building the city.
Genesis 11:9 That is why the place was called Babel —meaning 'confusion'— because there the Lord confused the language of the entire world. From that place, the Lord scattered them across the face of all the regions of the earth.
Genesis 11:10 These are the descendants of Shem. Shem was one hundred years old when his son Arphaxad was born, two years after the great flood.
Genesis 11:11 After Arphaxad was born, Shem lived for another five hundred years, and during this time, he fathered other sons and daughters.
Genesis 11:12 Arphaxad lived for thirty-five years, and then he became the father of Sala.
Genesis 11:13 After Sala was born, Arphaxad lived for another three hundred and three years, and he fathered other sons and daughters.
Genesis 11:14 Sala lived for thirty years, and then he became the father of Heber.
Genesis 11:15 After Heber was born, Sala lived for another four hundred and three years, and he fathered other sons and daughters.
Genesis 11:16 Heber lived for thirty-four years, and then he became the father of Peleg.
Genesis 11:17 After Peleg was born, Heber lived for another four hundred and thirty years, and he fathered other sons and daughters.
Genesis 11:18 Peleg lived for thirty years, and then he became the father of Reu.
Genesis 11:19 After Reu was born, Peleg lived for another two hundred and nine years, and he fathered other sons and daughters.
Genesis 11:20 Reu lived for thirty-two years, and then he became the father of Serug.
Genesis 11:21 After Serug was born, Reu lived for another two hundred and seven years, and he fathered other sons and daughters.
Genesis 11:22 Serug lived for thirty years, and then he became the father of Nahor.
Genesis 11:23 After Nahor was born, Serug lived for another two hundred years, and he fathered other sons and daughters.
Genesis 11:24 Nahor lived for twenty-nine years, and then he became the father of Terah.
Genesis 11:25 After Terah was born, Nahor lived for another one hundred and nineteen years, and he fathered other sons and daughters.
Genesis 11:26 Terah lived for seventy years, and then he became the father of Abram, Nahor, and Haran.
Genesis 11:27 Now, these are the descendants of Terah. Terah was the father of Abram, Nahor, and Haran. And Haran became the father of Lot.
Genesis 11:28 However, Haran died in the land where he was born, in Ur of the Chaldeans, while his father Terah was still alive.
Genesis 11:29 Abram and Nahor both took wives. Abram’s wife was named Sarai. Nahor’s wife was named Milcah, who was the daughter of Haran —meaning Milcah was also Haran's daughter, and the sister of Iscah.
Genesis 11:30 However, Sarai was infertile and unable to have children.
Genesis 11:31 So Terah gathered his son Abram, and his grandson Lot —who was Haran's son— and his daughter-in-law Sarai, who was Abram's wife. He led them out of Ur of the Chaldeans, intending to travel to the land of Canaan. But when they reached a place called Haran, they settled there instead.
Genesis 11:32 Terah lived for a total of two hundred and five years, and he died in Haran.
Genesis 12:1 The Lord said to Abram, "Go out from your country, and away from your relatives, and away from your father's household. Come instead into the land that I will show you."
Genesis 12:2 "I will make you into a great nation, and I will bless you, and I will make your name great, and you will be a blessing for others."
Genesis 12:3 "I will bless those who bless you, and I will curse those who curse you. Through you, all the families of the earth will receive blessings."
Genesis 12:4 So Abram immediately went out just as the Lord had commanded him; Lot went with him. Abram was seventy-five years old when he went out from Haran, ready to begin his journey of faith.
Genesis 12:5 Abram also took Sarai his wife, and Lot his brother's son, and all their possessions which they had acquired, and all the people they had gained while in Haran. They set out to go into the land of Canaan. And when they came into the land of Canaan,
Genesis 12:6 Abram passed through the land as far as the place called Shechem, to the prominent valley. At that time, the Canaanites were living in that land, presenting an initial challenge for Abram.
Genesis 12:7 Then the Lord appeared to Abram and said to him, "I will give this very land to your descendants." So Abram, in an act of worship and thanksgiving, built an altar there to the Lord, who had appeared to him.
Genesis 12:8 From there, he moved on to the mountain which was to the east of Bethel. He pitched his tent there, having the city of Bethel on his west and the city of Ai on his east. He also built another altar there to the Lord and called upon the name of the Lord, continuing his journey of faith and worship.
Genesis 12:9 And Abram journeyed further, continuing to move toward the southern regions of the land.
Genesis 12:10 However, a severe famine occurred in the land where Abram was. So Abram went down into Egypt to reside there as a foreigner, for the famine in the land had become extremely severe.
Genesis 12:11 When he was about to enter Egypt, he said to Sarai his wife, "I know that you are a very beautiful woman."
Genesis 12:12 "When the Egyptians see you, they will surely say, 'She is his wife.' Then they will kill me to take you, but they will spare your life."
Genesis 12:13 "Please say that you are my sister, so that it may go well with me because of you, and that my life may be spared on account of your beauty."
Genesis 12:14 So when Abram had entered Egypt, the Egyptians saw that the woman was exceedingly beautiful, just as Abram had feared.
Genesis 12:15 And the princes of Pharaoh saw her and praised her to Pharaoh. Then the woman was taken into Pharaoh's house, an act which would later bring divine judgment.
Genesis 12:16 And because of Sarai, Pharaoh treated Abram well. Abram received sheep, oxen, male donkeys, menservants, maidservants, and camels, enriching him greatly.
Genesis 12:17 But the Lord, in His divine intervention, struck Pharaoh and his entire household with severe plagues because of Sarai, Abram's wife, revealing her true relationship to Abram.
Genesis 12:18 So Pharaoh called Abram and, angered by the deception, said, "What is this you have done to me? Why did you not tell me that she was your wife?"
Genesis 12:19 "Why did you say, 'She is my sister,' leading me to take her as my wife? Now, here is your wife. Take her and go, leave my land!"
Genesis 12:20 And Pharaoh gave orders to his men concerning Abram, and they escorted him out, along with his wife and all that he had acquired while in Egypt.
Genesis 13:1 So Abram went up from Egypt, with his wife and all their possessions. Lot also went with him to the southern region.
Genesis 13:2 Now Abram was very rich with gold, silver, and many livestock.
Genesis 13:3 He returned by the same route he had taken from the south, all the way to Bethel, to the place where he had first pitched his tent between Bethel and Ai.
Genesis 13:4 It was where he had built an altar earlier, and there Abram worshipped the Lord, invoking His name.
Genesis 13:5 However, Lot, who was traveling with Abram, also had his own flocks, tents, and herds.
Genesis 13:6 The land could not sustain them living together, because their possessions were so many that they could not dwell in the same area.
Genesis 13:7 This led to a quarrel between Abram’s herdsmen and Lot’s herdsmen. At that time, the Canaanites and the Perizzites also inhabited the land.
Genesis 13:8 So Abram said to Lot, “Please, let there be no quarreling between you and me, nor between my herdsmen and your herdsmen, for we are brothers.”
Genesis 13:9 “Is not the whole land before you? Please separate yourself from me. If you choose the left, I will go to the right. If you choose the right, I will go to the left.”
Genesis 13:10 So Lot, raising his eyes, saw the entire region of the Jordan Plain, which was completely irrigated—this was before the Lord destroyed Sodom and Gomorrah. It was like the Garden of the Lord, and like Egypt as you go toward Zoar.
Genesis 13:11 Therefore, Lot chose for himself the entire Jordan Plain, and he moved eastward, and they were separated from one another.
Genesis 13:12 Abram remained in the land of Canaan, while Lot settled in the cities near the Jordan and pitched his tents as far as Sodom.
Genesis 13:13 Now the men of Sodom were exceedingly wicked, and they were great sinners against the Lord.
Genesis 13:14 And after Lot had separated from him, the Lord said to Abram, “Lift your eyes and look from the place where you now are, to the north, to the south, to the east, and to the west.”
Genesis 13:15 “For all the land that you see, I will give to you and to your descendants forever.”
Genesis 13:16 “And I will make your descendants like the dust of the earth. If anyone can number the dust of the earth, then your descendants will also be numbered.”
Genesis 13:17 “Arise, walk through the land in its length and in its breadth, for I am about to give it to you.”
Genesis 13:18 So Abram moved his tent and came to dwell by the Oak of Mamre, which is in Hebron, and there he built an altar to the Lord.
Genesis 14:1 Now, it happened during the time of Amraphel, who was king of Sennaar; and Arioch, who was king of Pontus; and Chedorlaomer, who was king of the Elamites; and Tidal, who was king of nations—
Genesis 14:2 —all these kings gathered together in the Forest Valley, which is now known as the Salt Sea.
Genesis 14:3 All of these rulers came together in the Forest Valley, which is the Salt Sea.
Genesis 14:4 For twelve years, these kings from the Forest Valley had served Chedorlaomer, but in the thirteenth year, they rebelled against him.
Genesis 14:5 So, in the fourteenth year, Chedorlaomer came with the kings who were allied with him. They attacked the Rephaim people in Ashteroth Karnaim, and the Zuzim people were with them, and also the Emim people in Shaveh Kiriathaim,
Genesis 14:6 and they also attacked the Horite people in the mountains of Seir, extending all the way to the plains of Paran, which is in the wilderness.
Genesis 14:7 Then, turning back, they arrived at the spring of Misphat, which is also called Kadesh. There, they struck down all the territory of the Amalekite people, and also the Amorite people who were living in Hazazonthamar.
Genesis 14:8 Then the king of Sodom, the king of Gomorrah, the king of Admah, the king of Zeboiim, and the king of Bela—which is also called Zoar—marched out. They arranged their battle lines against Chedorlaomer and his allies in the Forest Valley,
Genesis 14:9 —they were facing Chedorlaomer, king of the Elamites, Tidal, king of nations, Amraphel, king of Sennaar, and Arioch, king of Pontus. It was four kings against five.
Genesis 14:10 The Forest Valley had many tar pits. So, the kings of Sodom and Gomorrah fled, and their soldiers fell into the pits. Those who remained alive ran away into the mountains.
Genesis 14:11 The victorious kings took all the possessions of Sodom and Gomorrah, and all their provisions of food, and then they left.
Genesis 14:12 They also took Lot, Abram's brother's son, and all his possessions from Sodom, and then they left.
Genesis 14:13 Then, one of the people who had escaped from the battle came and reported all this to Abram the Hebrew. Abram was living in the valley of Mamre the Amorite, who was a brother of Eshcol and a brother of Aner. These men, Mamre, Eshcol, and Aner, were allied with Abram.
Genesis 14:14 When Abram heard that his brother's son, Lot, had been captured, he immediately assembled his three hundred and eighteen trained servants, who had been born in his household. He then pursued the kings' army all the way to Dan.
Genesis 14:15 He divided his men into groups and attacked the enemy by night. He struck them down and pursued them all the way to Hobah, which is located to the north of Damascus.
Genesis 14:16 Abram recovered all the captured possessions. He also brought back Lot, his nephew, along with Lot's possessions, and all the women and the people who had been taken captive.
Genesis 14:17 After Abram returned from defeating Chedorlaomer and the kings who were with him, the king of Sodom went out to meet him in the valley of Shaveh, which was known as the King's Valley.
Genesis 14:18 But then, Melchizedek, who was king of Salem, and also a priest of God Most High, came out. He brought bread and wine for Abram.
Genesis 14:19 He blessed Abram, saying, 'May Abram be blessed by God Most High, who created the universe and the earth!'
Genesis 14:20 And blessed be God Most High, who protected you and delivered your enemies into your power!' And then Abram gave Melchizedek a tenth of all the spoils he had recovered.
Genesis 14:21 Then the king of Sodom said to Abram, 'Give me the people who were rescued, but you may keep all the remaining possessions for yourself.'
Genesis 14:22 Abram replied to the king of Sodom, 'I raise my hand in an oath to the Lord God Most High, the One who possesses the universe and the earth—'
Genesis 14:23 —I will not take anything that belongs to you, not even a single thread or a sandal strap. I do this so that you cannot say, 'I am the one who made Abram rich.'
Genesis 14:24 However, I will not take anything for myself, except for the food my young men have already eaten. But as for Aner, Eshcol, and Mamre, the men who came with me, they will certainly take their rightful share of the spoils.

Genesis 15:1 After these things, the Lord God spoke to Abram, appearing to him in a vision. He said: 'Do not be afraid, Abram, for I am your protector, and your reward will be exceedingly great.'
Genesis 15:2 Abram responded: 'Lord God, what can You give me? I am going on without an heir, and the one who manages my household, Eliezer of Damascus, is the only one who could inherit from me.'
Genesis 15:3 And Abram added: 'You have given me no children, and behold, a servant born in my house is now my heir.'
Genesis 15:4 Immediately, the Lord's word came to him, saying: 'This man will not be your heir. Instead, one who comes forth from your own body — he will be your heir.'
Genesis 15:5 Then God led Abram outside and said to him: 'Look up at the sky and count the stars, if you can.' And He said to him: 'So numerous will your descendants be.'
Genesis 15:6 Abram believed God, and it was credited to him as righteousness.
Genesis 15:7 Then God said to him: 'I am the Lord, Who brought you out from Ur of the Chaldeans, to give you this land so that you may possess it.'
Genesis 15:8 But Abram said: 'Lord God, how can I know that I will possess it?'
Genesis 15:9 And the Lord responded, saying: 'Bring Me a three-year-old heifer, a three-year-old female goat, a three-year-old ram, also a turtledove, and a young pigeon.'
Genesis 15:10 So Abram brought all these to God. He cut the animals in half down the middle and laid each half opposite the other half. But he did not cut the birds in half.
Genesis 15:11 Then birds of prey came down on the carcasses, and Abram drove them away.
Genesis 15:12 As the sun was setting, a deep sleep fell upon Abram, and a great, dreadful darkness enveloped him.
Genesis 15:13 And it was said to him: 'Know for certain that your descendants will be foreigners in a land not their own. They will be enslaved and afflicted for four hundred years.'
Genesis 15:14 'Nevertheless, I will judge the nation whom they will serve. And after this, they will come out with great possessions.'
Genesis 15:15 'But you yourself will go to your ancestors in peace, buried in a good old age.'
Genesis 15:16 'And in the fourth generation, they will return here, for the iniquity of the Amorites is not yet complete enough for them to be dispossessed.'
Genesis 15:17 So when the sun had set, and it was very dark, behold, a smoking brazier and a flaming torch appeared, passing between the halves of the divided animals.
Genesis 15:18 On that very day, the Lord made a covenant with Abram, saying: 'To your descendants I will give this land, from the river of Egypt all the way to the great river Euphrates—'
Genesis 15:19 '—including the land of the Kenites, the Kenizzites, and the Kadmonites,'
Genesis 15:20 '—and the Hittites, the Perizzites, and the Rephaim,'
Genesis 15:21 '—and the Amorites, the Canaanites, the Girgashites, and the Jebusites.'
Genesis 16:1 Sarai, Abram's wife, had not borne him any children. Now, she had an Egyptian maidservant named Hagar.
Genesis 17:1 It came to pass that when Abraham was ninety-nine years old, the Lord appeared to him and said to him: “I am God Almighty. Walk and live your life in My presence, and strive for perfection.”
Genesis 17:2 I will establish My covenant between Me and you, and I will multiply your descendants beyond measure.
Genesis 17:3 Abram fell down, prostrate on his face, and God continued to speak to him, saying:
Genesis 17:4 “I am He, and this is My covenant with you: you will be the father of many nations.”
Genesis 17:5 “Your name will no longer be called Abram. Instead, your name will be Abraham, because I have made you the father of many nations.”
Genesis 17:6 “I will make you incredibly fruitful, and I will make you into many nations, and kings will come forth from you.”
Genesis 17:7 “And I will establish My covenant between Me and you, and your descendants after you, throughout their generations, as an everlasting covenant: that I may be your God, and the God of your descendants after you, forever.”
Genesis 17:8 “And I will give to you and your descendants the land where you now live as an alien—all the land of Canaan—as an everlasting possession, and I will be their God.”
Genesis 17:9 God also said to Abraham: “You, therefore, shall keep My covenant, you and your descendants after you throughout their generations.”
Genesis 17:10 “This is My covenant, which you shall observe, between Me and you, and your descendants after you: every male among you shall be circumcised.”
Genesis 17:11 “You shall circumcise the flesh of your foreskin, and it will be a visible sign of the covenant between Me and you.”
Genesis 17:12 “Every male among you, in your generations, shall be circumcised when he is eight days old, including those born in your household and those bought with money, who are not of your direct lineage.”
Genesis 17:13 “Both those born in your household and those bought with money must be circumcised. My covenant will be visibly marked in your flesh as an everlasting covenant.”
Genesis 17:14 “Any uncircumcised male, whose foreskin has not been circumcised, that soul shall be cut off from his people, because he has broken My covenant and rendered it null and void.”
Genesis 17:15 God also said to Abraham: “As for Sarai your wife, you shall not call her Sarai; rather, her name shall be Sarah.”
Genesis 17:16 “I will bless her, and indeed, I will give you a son by her. I will bless her so that she will become the mother of nations, and kings of peoples will be born from her.”
Genesis 17:17 Abraham fell on his face and laughed within his heart, saying to himself: “Will a son indeed be born to a man who is a hundred years old? And will Sarah, who is ninety years old, actually give birth?”
Genesis 17:18 And Abraham said to God: “Oh, that Ishmael might live and thrive in Your presence!”
Genesis 17:19 Then God said: “No, truly, Sarah your wife will bear you a son, and you shall name him Isaac. I will establish My covenant with him as an everlasting covenant, and with his descendants after him.”
Genesis 17:20 “And concerning Ishmael, I have also heard your prayer. Behold, I will bless him, and I will make him fruitful, and I will multiply him exceedingly. He will become the father of twelve princes, and I will make him into a great nation.”
Genesis 17:21 “But My covenant I will establish with Isaac, whom Sarah will bear to you at this appointed time, in the coming year.”
Genesis 17:22 When God had finished speaking with Abraham, He then ascended from him.
Genesis 17:23 So Abraham took Ishmael his son, and all those born in his household, and all those whom he had bought—every male among the men of his household—and he circumcised the flesh of their foreskins immediately on that very day, just as God had commanded him.
Genesis 17:24 Abraham was ninety-nine years old when he circumcised the flesh of his foreskin.
Genesis 17:25 And Ishmael his son was thirteen years old when he was circumcised.
Genesis 17:26 On that very same day, Abraham was circumcised, and Ishmael his son with him.
Genesis 17:27 And all the men of his household—both those born in his house, and those bought with money, and even foreigners living among them—were circumcised with him at the same time.
Genesis 18:1 The Lord then appeared to him in the valley of Mamre, as he sat at the door of his tent during the hottest part of the day.
Genesis 18:2 And when he lifted his eyes, three men stood near him. When he saw them, he ran from the door of his tent to meet them, and bowed down to the ground.
Genesis 18:3 And he said: "My Lord, if I have found favor in your sight, do not pass by your servant."
Genesis 18:4 Let me bring a little water, and you may wash your feet and then rest yourselves under this tree.
Genesis 18:5 And I will bring a piece of bread, so you can refresh yourselves. After that, you may continue on your way, because that is why you have turned aside to your servant." And they said: "Do as you have spoken."
Genesis 18:6 Abraham hurried to his tent to Sarah, and said to her: "Quickly, take three measures of fine flour, knead it, and make flat bread."
Genesis 18:7 And he himself ran to the herd and took from there a very tender and choice calf, and gave it to a young man, who quickly prepared and cooked it.
Genesis 18:8 He also brought butter and milk, and the calf which he had prepared, and set them before them. But he himself stood by them under the tree.
Genesis 18:9 And when they had eaten, they said to him: "Where is Sarah your wife?" He responded: "Behold, she is in the tent."
Genesis 18:10 And one of them said to him: "I will surely return to you at this time next year, if life continues as it is, and your wife Sarah will have a son." When Sarah heard this, she laughed to herself behind the door of the tent.
Genesis 18:11 Now both Abraham and Sarah were old and advanced in age, and Sarah had ceased to have the monthly custom of women.
Genesis 18:12 So Sarah laughed to herself, saying: "After I have become old, and my master is also old, shall I indeed have pleasure, or bear a child?"
Genesis 18:13 And the Lord said to Abraham: "Why did Sarah laugh, saying: 'Shall I truly bear a child, being an old woman?'"
Genesis 18:14 Is anything too difficult for God? I will return at the same time next year, if life continues as it is, and Sarah will have a son.
Genesis 18:15 Sarah denied it, saying: "I did not laugh," because she was terrified. The Lord said: "It is not so; but you did laugh."
Genesis 18:16 Then, when the men rose from there, they looked toward Sodom. And Abraham walked with them, accompanying them on their way.
Genesis 18:17 And the Lord said: "Shall I hide from Abraham what I am about to do?"
Genesis 18:18 For Abraham will surely become a great and very powerful nation, and in him, all the nations of the earth will be blessed.
Genesis 18:19 For I know him, that he will command his children and his household after him to keep the way of the Lord and to do righteousness and justice, so that the Lord may bring upon Abraham everything He has spoken to him.
Genesis 18:20 Therefore, the Lord said: "The outcry against Sodom and Gomorrah has greatly increased, and their sin has become exceedingly grievous."
Genesis 18:21 I will go down and see if they have indeed carried out the full measure of the outcry that has come to me, or if it is not so; so that I may know with certainty.
Genesis 18:22 So the men turned away from there and went toward Sodom. But Abraham still stood before the Lord.
Genesis 18:23 And Abraham approached and said: "Will you truly destroy the righteous along with the wicked?"
Genesis 18:24 If there are perhaps fifty righteous people in the city, will you destroy them? And will you not spare the place for the sake of the fifty righteous people who are in it?
Genesis 18:25 Far be it from you to do such a thing as this, to slay the righteous with the wicked, so that the righteous are treated like the wicked. Far be it from you! Shall not the Judge of all the earth do what is just?
Genesis 18:26 And the Lord said: "If I find fifty righteous people in Sodom within the city, I will spare the entire place for their sake."
Genesis 18:27 And Abraham responded and said: "Behold, I have dared to speak to my Lord, though I am but dust and ashes."
Genesis 18:28 What if there are five fewer than fifty righteous people? Will you destroy the entire city because of those five?" And He said: "I will not destroy it if I find forty-five there."
Genesis 18:29 And he spoke to Him again: "What if forty righteous people are found there?" He said: "I will not strike it for the sake of the forty."
Genesis 18:30 Then he said: "Please, Lord, do not be angry if I speak again: what if thirty righteous people are found there?" He answered: "I will not do it if I find thirty there."
Genesis 18:31 And he said: "Since I have begun, I will speak to my Lord again: what if twenty righteous people are found there?" He said: "I will not destroy it for the sake of the twenty."
Genesis 18:32 Then he said: "I beg you, Lord, do not be angry if I speak just one more time: what if ten righteous people are found there?" He answered: "I will not destroy it for the sake of the ten."
Genesis 18:33 And the Lord departed after He had finished speaking with Abraham, and Abraham returned to his own place.
Genesis 19:1 Two angels arrived in the city of Sodom in the evening. Lot was sitting at the city gate, where people conducted legal and civic matters. When he saw them, he stood up and went out to meet them, bowing down with his face to the ground as a sign of deep respect and humility.
Genesis 19:2 And Lot said, 'Please, sirs, come to your servant's house and stay the night there. You can wash your feet, and then depart on your journey in the morning.' But they replied, 'No, we will stay in the public square.'
Genesis 19:3 But Lot urged them strongly, so they turned aside and entered his house. He prepared a feast for them, baking unleavened bread, and they ate.
Genesis 19:4 Before they lay down to sleep, the men of the city of Sodom surrounded the house—every single person, from the youngest boy to the oldest man.
Genesis 19:5 They called out to Lot and said to him, 'Where are the men who came to your house tonight? Bring them out to us, so that we may know them intimately in a sinful way.'
Genesis 19:6 Lot went out to them, closing the door behind him, and said,
Genesis 19:7 'Please, my brothers, do not act so wickedly.'
Genesis 19:8 'Look, I have two virgin daughters. I will bring them out to you, and you may do to them whatever you please. But do nothing to these men, for they have come under the protection of my roof.'
Genesis 19:9 But they shouted back, 'Stand back!' And again they said, 'You came here as a foreigner, and now you want to judge us? We will treat you worse than we will treat them!' And they pressed violently against Lot, and were already close to breaking down the door.
Genesis 19:10 Then the men inside (the angels) stretched out their hands, pulled Lot back into the house, and shut the door.
Genesis 19:11 And they struck the men outside with blindness, from the youngest to the oldest, so that they could not find the door anymore.
Genesis 19:12 Then the angels said to Lot, 'Do you have anyone else here who belongs to you? Your son-in-law, your sons, your daughters, and everyone else who is yours—bring them out of this city.'
Genesis 19:13 'For we are about to destroy this place, because the outcry against them has grown so great before the Lord, who has sent us to destroy them.'
Genesis 19:14 So Lot went out and spoke to his future sons-in-law, who were going to marry his daughters. He said, 'Get up, get out of this place, because the Lord is about to destroy this city.' But he seemed to them to be joking.
Genesis 19:15 When the dawn was breaking, the angels urged Lot, saying, 'Get up! Take your wife and your two daughters who are here with you, so that you do not perish along with the city in its wickedness.'
Genesis 19:16 When Lot hesitated, the angels grasped his hand, his wife's hand, and the hands of his two daughters, because the Lord had mercy on him. They led him out and placed him outside the city.
Genesis 19:17 When they had led them outside, one of the angels said, 'Escape for your life! Do not look back behind you, and do not stop anywhere in the surrounding plain. Escape to the mountains, so that you do not perish along with everyone else!'
Genesis 19:18 And Lot said to them, 'Oh no, my Lord, please do not make me do that!'
Genesis 19:19 'Look, your servant has found favor in your sight, and you have shown great mercy to me by saving my life. But I cannot escape to the mountains, for fear that some evil might overtake me there, and I will die.'
Genesis 19:20 'See, there is this nearby town to which I can flee, and it is a small one. Please, let me escape there so that my life may be saved, for it is indeed a very small town.'
Genesis 19:21 And the angel said to him, 'See, I have granted your request in this matter as well, that I will not overthrow the town for which you have pleaded.'
Genesis 19:22 'Hurry and escape there, because I can do nothing until you arrive there.' That is why the name of that city was called Zoar, meaning 'small.'
Genesis 19:23 The sun had risen over the earth when Lot entered Zoar.
Genesis 19:24 Then the Lord rained down sulfur and fire upon Sodom and Gomorrah—from the Lord, out of the sky.
Genesis 19:25 And He overthrew those cities, and all the surrounding plain, along with all the inhabitants of the cities, and every living thing growing on the ground.
Genesis 19:26 But Lot's wife looked back behind him, and she was turned into a pillar of salt.
Genesis 19:27 But Abraham, rising early in the morning, went to the place where he had previously stood before the Lord.
Genesis 19:28 And he looked out toward Sodom and Gomorrah, and across the entire land of that region. He saw smoke ascending from the earth, like the smoke from a furnace.
Genesis 19:29 When God overthrew the cities of that region, He remembered Abraham, and rescued Lot from the destruction of the cities where he had lived.
Genesis 19:30 Then Lot went up out of Zoar and settled in the mountains, with his two daughters, because he was afraid to stay in Zoar. He lived in a cave, he and his two daughters with him.
Genesis 19:31 And the older daughter said to the younger, 'Our father is old, and there is no man left in this land to come in to us according to the custom of all the earth, to take us as wives and have children with us.'
Genesis 19:32 'Come, let us make our father drunk with wine, and let us lie with him, so that we may preserve offspring through our father.'
Genesis 19:33 So they gave their father wine to drink that night. Then the older daughter went in and lay with her father, but he did not know when she lay down or when she got up.
Genesis 19:34 The next day, the older daughter said to the younger, 'See, I lay with my father last night. Let us make him drunk with wine tonight as well, and you go in and lie with him, so that we may preserve offspring through our father.'
Genesis 19:35 So they gave their father wine to drink that night also. And the younger daughter went in and lay with him, but he also did not know when she lay down or when she got up.
Genesis 19:36 Thus, Lot's two daughters conceived children by their father.
Genesis 19:37 The older daughter gave birth to a son and named him Moab. He is the ancestor of the Moabites to this very day.
Genesis 19:38 The younger daughter also gave birth to a son and named him Ben-Ammi, which means 'son of my people.' He is the ancestor of the Ammonites to this very day.
Genesis 19:39 null
Genesis 19:40 null
Genesis 20:1 Abraham then departed from that place and journeyed into the land to the south. He settled between Kadesh and Shur, and then lived for a time as a foreign visitor in Gerar.
Genesis 20:2 He said about Sarah, his wife, 'She is my sister.' So Abimelech, the king of Gerar, sent for Sarah and took her for himself.
Genesis 20:3 But God came to Abimelech in a dream during the night and said to him, 'Indeed, you will certainly die because of the woman you have taken, for she is already married to another man.'
Genesis 20:4 But Abimelech had not had relations with her, and he said, 'Lord, will You destroy an innocent and righteous people?'
Genesis 20:5 Did he not himself tell me, 'She is my sister,' and did she herself not say, 'He is my brother'? I did this with a sincere heart and clean hands, believing them.
Genesis 20:6 And God said to him, 'Yes, I also know that you acted with a sincere heart, and therefore I prevented you from committing this sin against Me. I did not permit you to have relations with her.'
Genesis 20:7 Now, therefore, restore the man's wife — Abraham's wife — because he is a prophet of God, and he will intercede for you, and your life will be spared. But if you are unwilling to return her, know that you yourself will certainly die, along with everyone and everything belonging to you.
Genesis 20:8 Immediately, Abimelech got up in the night and called all his servants. He related everything that had been said to them, and all the people became very fearful.
Genesis 20:9 Then Abimelech called Abraham and said to him, 'What is this that you have done to us? What offense have we committed against you that you would bring such a great sin upon me and my kingdom? You have done deeds to us that should never have been done.'
Genesis 20:10 And Abimelech said to Abraham, 'What possible reason did you have for doing this?'
Genesis 20:11 Abraham answered, 'I was afraid, thinking to myself, 'Perhaps there is no reverence for God in this place, and they would kill me to take my wife.''
Genesis 20:12 Moreover, she is truly my sister; she is my father's daughter, though not my mother's, and I married her.
Genesis 20:13 When God called me to leave my father's house, I said to her, 'Do this favor for me: in every place we go, you must say, 'He is my brother.''
Genesis 20:14 So Abimelech took flocks and herds, male and female servants, and gave them to Abraham; and he gave back Sarah, his wife, to him.
Genesis 20:15 And Abimelech said, 'Look, my land is at your disposal; live wherever you wish.'
Genesis 20:16 And to Sarah he also said, 'Look, I have given a thousand pieces of silver to your brother. Let this be a public vindication for you among all who witnessed this, and wherever you go, let it be a reminder of what happened.'
Genesis 20:17 So Abraham prayed to God, and God healed Abimelech, his wife, and his female servants so that they were able to conceive children.
Genesis 20:18 For the Lord had indeed sealed every womb in Abimelech's household because of Sarah, Abraham's wife.
Genesis 21:1 The Lord had remembered Sarah, just as He promised. And He brought to pass everything He had spoken.
Genesis 21:2 And she conceived and gave birth to a son in her old age, at the very time God had predicted to her.
Genesis 21:3 And Abraham called the name of his son, whom Sarah had borne to him, Isaac.
Genesis 21:4 And he circumcised Isaac on the eighth day, just as God had commanded him.
Genesis 21:5 Abraham was one hundred years old when his son Isaac was born to him.
Genesis 21:6 And Sarah said, "God has given me a reason to laugh! Everyone who hears about this will laugh with me."
Genesis 21:7 And again she said, "Who would have believed Abraham when he said that Sarah would nurse a child, and that she would give birth to him in her old age?"
Genesis 21:8 So the boy grew, and he was weaned from his mother's milk. And Abraham made a great feast on the day of his weaning.
Genesis 21:9 But when Sarah saw the son of Hagar, the Egyptian woman, making fun of Isaac her son,
Genesis 21:10 she said to Abraham, "Cast out this slave-woman and her son, for the son of this slave-woman shall not inherit along with my son Isaac."
Genesis 21:11 This matter seemed very difficult to Abraham because it involved his son.
Genesis 21:12 But God said to him, "Do not let this seem harsh to you concerning the boy and your slave-woman. Whatever Sarah has said to you, listen to her voice, for in Isaac your lineage will be called forth."
Genesis 21:13 But I will also make the son of the slave-woman into a great nation, because he is your descendant too.
Genesis 21:14 So Abraham rose early in the morning, and took bread and a bottle of water, and put them on her shoulder, and he sent the boy with her. Then he sent her away. And when she had gone, she wandered in the wilderness of Beersheba.
Genesis 21:15 And when the water in the bottle was used up, she cast the boy under one of the trees that were there.
Genesis 21:16 Then she went and sat down opposite him, as far away as an arrow can be shot. For she said, "I will not see the boy die." And as she sat opposite him, she lifted her voice and wept.
Genesis 21:17 Now God heard the voice of the boy. And the Angel of God called to Hagar from the sky, saying, "What troubles you, Hagar? Do not be afraid, for God has heard the voice of the boy from the place where he is."
Genesis 21:18 Rise, take the boy, and hold his hand, for I will make him into a great nation.
Genesis 21:19 Then God opened her eyes, and she saw a well of living water. So she went and filled the bottle and gave the boy to drink.
Genesis 21:20 And God was with him, and he grew, and he lived in the wilderness, becoming a young archer.
Genesis 21:21 And he lived in the desert of Paran, and his mother found him a wife from the land of Egypt.
Genesis 21:22 At that same time, Abimelech and Phicol, the commander of his army, spoke to Abraham, saying, "God is with you in all that you do."
Genesis 21:23 Therefore, swear to me now by God that you will not deal falsely with me, nor with my descendants, nor with my lineage. But according to the kindness I have shown to you, you will show kindness to me and to the land in which you have lived as a foreigner.
Genesis 21:24 And Abraham said, "I will swear."
Genesis 21:25 Then Abraham complained to Abimelech about a well of water which Abimelech's servants had taken by force.
Genesis 21:26 And Abimelech answered, "I do not know who did this. You did not tell me anything, and I did not hear of it until today."
Genesis 21:27 So Abraham took sheep and cattle and gave them to Abimelech. And both of them made a covenant.
Genesis 21:28 And Abraham set aside seven ewe-lambs from the flock.
Genesis 21:29 And Abimelech said to him, "What do these seven ewe-lambs mean, which you have set aside?"
Genesis 21:30 And he said, "You shall accept these seven ewe-lambs from my hand, that they may be a witness for me that I dug this well."
Genesis 21:31 Because of this reason, that place was called Beersheba, which means 'well of the oath', because there both of them swore an oath.
Genesis 21:32 So they made a covenant in Beersheba. Then Abimelech and Phicol, the commander of his army, rose up and returned to the land of the Philistines.
Genesis 21:33 And Abraham planted a tamarisk tree in Beersheba, and there he called upon the name of the Lord, the Eternal God.
Genesis 21:34 And he sojourned in the land of the Philistines for many days.
Genesis 22:1 After these things had happened, God put Abraham to the test. God said to him, 'Abraham! Abraham!' Abraham answered, 'Here I am.'
Genesis 22:2 God said, 'Take your son, your only son, Isaac—the son whom you love—and go to the land of vision. There, offer him as a burnt offering upon one of the mountains that I will show you.'
Genesis 22:3 So, Abraham got up before dawn and saddled his donkey. He took two of his servants with him, and his son Isaac. Abraham cut the wood for the burnt offering and then set off for the place God had told him about.
Genesis 22:4 On the third day of their journey, Abraham looked up and saw the place in the distance.
