Genesis 22:5 Abraham told his servants, 'You two stay here with the donkey. My son and I will go up to the mountain to worship, and then we will come back to you.' —This implies Abraham's faith that Isaac would be returned to him.
Genesis 22:6 Then Abraham took the wood for the burnt offering and laid it upon his son Isaac’s shoulders. Abraham himself carried the fire and the knife in his hands. And so, the two of them walked on together.
Genesis 22:7 Isaac spoke to his father Abraham, saying, 'My father!' Abraham answered, 'What is it, my son?' Isaac said, 'Here are the fire and the wood, but where is the lamb for the burnt offering?'
Genesis 22:8 Abraham replied, 'My son, God Himself will provide the lamb for the burnt offering.' And so, the two of them walked on together.
Genesis 22:9 When they arrived at the place God had shown him, Abraham built an altar there. He arranged the wood upon it. Then, Abraham bound his son Isaac and placed him on the altar, on top of the wood.
Genesis 22:10 Abraham then reached out his hand and took the knife, ready to sacrifice his son.
Genesis 22:11 But behold, an angel of the Lord called to him from the sky, saying, 'Abraham! Abraham!' Abraham answered, 'Here I am!'
Genesis 22:12 The angel said, 'Do not lay a hand on the boy, and do not do anything to him! Now I know that you truly revere God, for you did not withhold your only son from Me.'
Genesis 22:13 Abraham looked up and saw a ram behind him, caught by its horns in a thicket. So Abraham took the ram and offered it as a burnt offering instead of his son.
Genesis 22:14 Abraham called the name of that place, 'The Lord Will Provide.' —Using the prophetic sense of 'sees'. That is why, to this day, people say, 'On the mountain, the Lord will provide.'
Genesis 22:15 Then the angel of the Lord called to Abraham a second time from the sky,
Genesis 22:16 saying, 'By Myself I have sworn, declares the Lord. Because you have done this and have not withheld your only son—'
Genesis 22:17 '—I will surely bless you and multiply your descendants as countless as the stars in the sky and the sand on the seashore. Your descendants will possess the gates of their enemies.'
Genesis 22:18 'Through your offspring, all the nations of the earth will be blessed, because you have obeyed My voice.'
Genesis 22:19 Then Abraham returned to his servants, and together they went to Beersheba. And Abraham settled there.
Genesis 22:20 After these events, Abraham received a message, saying, 'Listen! Your brother Nahor’s wife, Milcah, has also given birth to sons!'
Genesis 22:21 These are their names: Huz, his firstborn, Buz, his brother, and Kemuel, who became the father of the Aramean people.
Genesis 22:22 Also Chesed, Hazo, Pildash, Jidlaph, and Bethuel. It was from Bethuel that Rebekah was born.
Genesis 22:23 These eight sons Milcah bore to Nahor, Abraham’s brother.
Genesis 22:24 His concubine, whose name was Reumah, also bore children: Tebah, Gaham, Tahash, and Maacah.
Genesis 23:1 And Sarah lived for one hundred and twenty-seven years.
Genesis 23:2 And she died in the city of Arbee, which is Hebron in the land of Canaan. So Abraham came to mourn and to weep for her.
Genesis 23:3 After Abraham had finished with his duties concerning the deceased, he spoke to the sons of Heth, saying:
Genesis 23:4 “I am a foreigner and a sojourner among you. Grant me a place to bury my dead among you, so that I can bury my deceased wife.”
Genesis 23:5 And the sons of Heth answered Abraham, saying:
Genesis 23:6 “Listen to us, my lord. You are a mighty leader sent by God among us. Bury your dead in the best of our burial places. No one among us will refuse you from burying your dead in his own burial place.”
Genesis 23:7 Abraham then stood up and bowed down respectfully before the people of the land, that is, the sons of Heth.
Genesis 23:8 And he spoke to them, saying, “If you are truly willing for me to bury my dead, then hear me and intercede for me with Ephron, the son of Zohar.”
Genesis 23:9 “Tell him to give me the double-chambered cave that he owns at the far end of his field. He must sell it to me for its full price in silver, in your presence, so that I may possess it as a burial place.”
Genesis 23:10 Now Ephron was dwelling among the sons of Heth. And Ephron answered Abraham in the hearing of all those who were entering the gate of his city, saying:
Genesis 23:11 “By no means, my lord! I give you the field itself, and the cave which is in it, freely to you. In the presence of the sons of my people, you may bury your dead.”
Genesis 23:12 Abraham then bowed down before the people of the land.
Genesis 23:13 And he spoke to Ephron in the hearing of the people of the land, saying, “I beg you, hear me! I will give you money for the field. Accept it from me, and so I may bury my dead there with you.”
Genesis 23:14 And Ephron answered him:
Genesis 23:15 “My lord, hear me. The land is valued at one hundred talents of silver. What is that amount between you and me? Just bury your dead.”
Genesis 23:16 When Abraham heard this, he weighed out the money that Ephron had demanded: one hundred shekels of silver, according to the standard public weight.
Genesis 23:17 And so, Ephron's field, which contained the double-chambered cave facing Mamre, was legally transferred. Both the field itself, the cave, and all the trees within its boundaries, were legally confirmed.
Genesis 23:18 It was transferred to Abraham as a permanent possession, witnessed by the sons of Heth and all who entered the gate of that city.
Genesis 23:19 And so Abraham buried Sarah his wife in the double-chambered cave of the field that faced Mamre, which is Hebron in the land of Canaan.
Genesis 23:20 And the field, along with the cave within it, was legally confirmed to Abraham by the sons of Heth as a permanent burial possession.
Genesis 24:1 Abraham was now very old and had lived many years, and the Lord had blessed him in everything he did and possessed.
Genesis 24:2 He said to his senior servant, the one in charge of his entire household, and who managed all of Abraham's possessions:
Genesis 24:3 He said to him, 'Swear an oath by the Lord, the God of the universe and the earth, that you will not choose a wife for my son from the daughters of the Canaanites, among whom I now live.
Genesis 24:4 Instead, you must go to my own country and to my own relatives, and there you will find a wife for my son, Isaac.'
Genesis 24:5 The servant replied, 'But what if the woman is unwilling to follow me back to this land? Must I then take your son back to the land you came from?'
Genesis 24:6 Abraham responded, 'Under no circumstances are you to take my son back there!'
Genesis 24:7 The Lord, the God of the universe, who took me from my father's house and from the land where I was born—He is the one who spoke to me and swore an oath, saying: 'I will give this land to your descendants.'
Genesis 24:8 He himself will send His angel ahead of you, and you will successfully find a wife there for my son.
Genesis 24:9 However, if the woman is unwilling to follow you, then you will be released from this oath. Just do not take my son back to that place.'
Genesis 24:10 So the servant placed his hand under the thigh of Abraham, his master, and swore an oath to him concerning this matter.
Genesis 24:11 Then the servant took ten camels from his master's herd and brought with him a selection of his master's finest goods. He then set out for Mesopotamia, traveling toward the city of Nahor.
Genesis 24:12 When he had finished praying, he said: 'Lord, God of my master Abraham, I beg you, grant me success today, and show covenant faithfulness to my master Abraham.'
Genesis 24:13 'Look, I am standing here beside this well of water, and the daughters of the city's inhabitants will soon come out to draw water.'
Genesis 24:14 'May it be that the young woman to whom I say, "Please lower your jar so I can drink," and who then replies, "Drink, and I will also water your camels"—that she is the one you have prepared for your servant Isaac. By this sign, I will know that you have shown steadfast love to my master.'
Genesis 24:15 He had barely finished speaking when, behold, Rebekah appeared. She was the daughter of Bethuel, son of Milcah, who was the wife of Nahor, Abraham’s brother. She carried a water jar on her shoulder.
Genesis 24:16 The young woman was exceptionally beautiful, a pure virgin, and no man had ever been with her. She went down to the spring, filled her jar, and then started to come back up.
Genesis 24:17 The servant hurried to meet her and said: 'Please, let me drink a little water from your jar.'
Genesis 24:18 She immediately replied, 'Drink, my lord.' She quickly lowered her jar to her arm and gave him a drink.
Genesis 24:19 After he had finished drinking, she said: 'I will also draw water for your camels until they have all had enough to drink.'
Genesis 24:20 So she quickly emptied her jar into the watering trough, and then ran back to the well to draw more water, and she continued drawing for all his camels.
Genesis 24:21 The man watched her in silence, wanting to know if the Lord had truly made his journey successful, or not.
Genesis 24:22 After the camels had finished drinking, the man took out two gold nose rings, together weighing two shekels, and two gold bracelets, weighing ten shekels.
Genesis 24:23 Then he asked her, 'Whose daughter are you? Please tell me: Is there room in your father's house for us to spend the night?'
Genesis 24:24 She answered, 'I am the daughter of Bethuel, son of Milcah, whom she bore to Nahor.'
Genesis 24:25 She added, saying: 'We have plenty of straw and fodder, and also space for you to spend the night.'
Genesis 24:26 The man bowed his head and worshipped the Lord,
Genesis 24:27 saying: 'Blessed be the Lord, the God of my master Abraham, who has not withheld His covenant faithfulness and His truth from my master. He has led me directly to the house of my master's brother!'
Genesis 24:28 So the young woman ran off and reported everything she had heard in her mother's household.
Genesis 24:29 Now Rebekah had a brother named Laban, and he quickly rushed out to the man at the spring.
Genesis 24:30 When he saw the nose rings and bracelets on his sister's hands, and heard all the words she recounted, he came to the man who was still standing by the camels, near the water spring.
Genesis 24:31 And he said, 'Come in, blessed of the Lord! Why are you standing outside? I have prepared the house, and a place for your camels.'
Genesis 24:32 So Laban brought the man into the house. He then unloaded the camels, gave straw and fodder to the camels, and provided water for washing his feet and the feet of the men who had come with him.
Genesis 24:33 When food was set before him, he said, 'I will not eat until I have spoken my message.' Laban replied to him, 'Speak.'
Genesis 24:34 Then he said, 'I am Abraham's servant.'
Genesis 24:35 And the Lord has greatly blessed my master, so that he has become very prosperous. He has given him flocks and herds, silver and gold, male and female servants, camels and donkeys.
Genesis 24:36 And Sarah, my master's wife, bore a son to my master, even after she was already old. My master has given everything he owns to that son.
Genesis 24:37 My master made me swear an oath, saying: 'You must not choose a wife for my son from the daughters of the Canaanites, in whose land I am living;'
Genesis 24:38 'but you are to go to my father's house, and choose a wife for my son from among my relatives.'
Genesis 24:39 And I said to my master, 'What if the woman is unwilling to come with me?'
Genesis 24:40 He replied, 'The Lord, in whose presence I live and walk, will send His angel with you and will make your journey successful. And you will find a wife for my son from my own relatives and from my father's household.'
Genesis 25:1 Abraham, for his part, married again, and took a wife named Keturah.
Genesis 25:2 She bore for him Zamran, Jecsan, Madan, Madian, Jesboc, and Sue.
Genesis 25:3 Jecsan, for his part, begot Saba and Dadan. The sons of Dadan were Rassum, Lugum, and Lemin.
Genesis 25:4 Furthermore, the sons of Madian were Epha, Opher, Henoch, Abida, and Eldaa. All these were descendants through Keturah.
Genesis 25:5 And Abraham gave all that he possessed to Isaac.
Genesis 25:6 But to the sons of his concubines, he gave gifts, and he separated them from Isaac, his son, while he was still living, sending them toward the eastern region.
Genesis 25:7 Now the days of Abraham's life, which he lived, were one hundred seventy-five years.
Genesis 25:8 And being fully aged, he died in a good old age, full of days, and was gathered to his people.
Genesis 25:9 And Isaac and Ishmael, his sons, buried him in the cave of Machpelah, which is situated opposite Mamre, in the field of Ephron, the son of Seor the Hethite.
Genesis 25:10 Abraham had purchased this cave from the sons of Heth: there he was buried, and Sarah his wife.
Genesis 25:11 And after his death, God blessed Isaac, his son. Isaac then lived near the Well of Vision.
Genesis 25:12 These are the generations of Ishmael, Abraham’s son, whom Hagar the Egyptian, Sarah’s handmaid, bore to Abraham.
Genesis 25:13 And these are the names of Ishmael's sons, according to their names and their generations: Ishmael’s firstborn was Nabajoth, then Cedar, Adbeel, Masma,
Genesis 25:14 and Massa, and Iduma, and Massa (this is a repeated name or variant spelling in the text),
Genesis 25:15 and Badad, and Thema, and Jetur, and Naphis, and Cedma.
Genesis 25:16 These are the sons of Ishmael, and these are their names by their towns and their encampments—twelve princes of their tribes.
Genesis 25:17 And the years of Ishmael’s life were one hundred thirty-seven. He then weakened, died, and was gathered to his people.
Genesis 25:18 From Havila to Hemath, as far as one comes to Sur, which faces Egypt as one journeys towards the Assyrians—he died in the presence of all his brethren.
Genesis 25:19 These also are the generations of Isaac, Abraham’s son: Abraham begot Isaac.
Genesis 25:20 When Isaac was forty years old, he married Rebecca, the daughter of Bathuel the Syrian from Mesopotamia, the sister of Laban the Syrian.
Genesis 25:21 Isaac then implored the Lord for his wife, because she was barren. The Lord heard him, and Rebecca, his wife, conceived.
Genesis 25:22 But the children struggled violently within her womb. She said, “If this is how it will be for me, why was it necessary to conceive?” And she went to consult the Lord.
Genesis 25:23 And the Lord responded: “Two nations are in your womb, and two peoples will be divided from your body. One people will overcome the other people, and the older will serve the younger.”
Genesis 25:24 When the time for her to give birth arrived, behold, there were twins in her womb.
Genesis 25:25 The first one who came out was reddish, and entirely hairy like a cloak. And his name was called Esau.
Genesis 25:26 After him came his brother, whose hand grasped Esau’s heel. And therefore, his name was called Jacob. Isaac was sixty years old when they were born to him.
Genesis 25:27 Now the boys grew up. Esau became a skilled hunter, a man of the field. Jacob, however, was a simple man, dwelling in tents.
Genesis 25:28 Isaac loved Esau, because he ate of his game. And Rebecca loved Jacob.
Genesis 25:29 Now Jacob cooked a stew. And when Esau came in from the field, weary,
Genesis 25:30 he said, “Give me some of that red dish, for I am extremely famished.” For this reason, his name was called Edom (meaning 'red').
Genesis 25:31 To him Jacob said, “Sell me your birthright first.”
Genesis 25:32 He replied, “Look, I am about to die. What good will a birthright be to me?”
Genesis 25:33 And Jacob said, “Swear to me then.” Esau swore, and sold his birthright to Jacob.
Genesis 25:34 And so, Jacob gave him bread and the lentil stew. Esau ate, and drank, and rose up, and went away, showing little regard for having sold his birthright.
Genesis 25:35 Now a famine occurred in the land, following the previous famine that had occurred in the days of Abraham. And Isaac went to Abimelech, the king of the Philistines, in Gerar.
Genesis 25:36 And the Lord appeared to him and said, “Do not go down to Egypt, but remain in the land which I will tell you about.
Genesis 25:37 Journey as a stranger in this land, and I will be with you, and I will bless you. For to you and to your offspring I will give all these regions, fulfilling the oath which I swore to Abraham your father.
Genesis 25:38 And I will multiply your offspring like the stars of the sky. And I will give all these regions to your descendants. And all the nations of the earth will be blessed through your offspring,
Genesis 25:39 because Abraham obeyed My voice, and kept My precepts and My commandments, and observed My ceremonies and rituals.”
Genesis 25:40 So Isaac remained in Gerar.
Genesis 26:1 Now there was a famine in the land—a new one, after the previous famine that had happened during the time of Abraham. And so Isaac went to Abimelech, the king of the Philistines, in Gerar.
Genesis 26:2 And the Lord appeared to Isaac, saying: 'Do not go down to Egypt; instead, stay in the land that I will show you.'
Genesis 26:3 Live as a temporary resident in this land, and I will be with you, and I will bless you. For to you and to your descendants, I will give all these lands, fulfilling the oath that I swore to Abraham, your father.
Genesis 26:4 And I will multiply your descendants, making them as numerous as the stars of the sky. And I will give all these lands to your descendants. And through your offspring, all the nations of the earth will be blessed,
Genesis 26:5 because Abraham obeyed My voice, and kept My commands and My ordinances, and observed My ceremonies and rituals.
Genesis 26:6 So Isaac remained in Gerar.
Genesis 26:7 When the men of that place asked him about his wife, he replied, 'She is my sister.' For he was afraid to admit that she was his wife by marriage, thinking that they might kill him because of her great beauty.
Genesis 26:8 After many days had passed, and while he was living there, Abimelech, the king of the Philistines, looked out through a window and saw Isaac caressing Rebecca, his wife.
Genesis 26:9 And calling Isaac, he said to him: 'It is clear that she is your wife. Why did you lie, saying she was your sister?' Isaac replied, 'I was afraid that I might die because of her.'
Genesis 26:10 And Abimelech said: 'What is this that you have done to us? Any one of my people could have slept with your wife, and you would have brought great guilt upon us.'
Genesis 26:11 And he commanded all his people, saying: 'Whoever touches this man or his wife will surely be put to death.'
Genesis 26:12 Now Isaac sowed seed in that land, and in that same year, he harvested a hundredfold. And the Lord blessed him abundantly.
Genesis 26:13 And the man became great, and he continued to prosper and grow, until he became very wealthy and powerful.
Genesis 26:14 For he possessed many flocks of sheep, and herds of cattle, and a large household of servants. Therefore, the Philistines envied him.
Genesis 26:15 All the wells that the servants of his father, Abraham, had dug, Abimelech had stopped up by filling them with earth.
Genesis 26:16 Finally, he warned Isaac himself to leave his territory, saying: 'Go away from us, for you have become much too powerful for us.'
Genesis 26:17 So Isaac moved away from there, and after setting up his tents in the valley of Gerar, he lived there.
Genesis 26:18 He again dug out the wells that had been dug in the days of his father Abraham, and which the Philistines had stopped up after Abraham's death. And he called them by the same names that his father had called them before.
Genesis 26:19 And Isaac's servants dug in the valley, and they found a well of flowing water.
Genesis 26:20 But even there, the herdsmen of Gerar quarreled with Isaac's herdsmen, saying, 'The water is ours!' Therefore, he named that well 'Quarrel', because they had disputed with him there.
Genesis 26:21 They also dug another well, and they quarreled over that one as well. So he named it 'Enmity'.
Genesis 26:22 Moving on from there, he dug another well, and for this one, there was no contention. Therefore, he named it 'Broad Places', saying: 'Now the Lord has made room for us, and given us a spacious place, so that we may flourish and increase in the land.'
Genesis 26:23 From that place, he went up to Beersheba.
Genesis 26:24 And the Lord appeared to him on that very night, saying: 'I am the God of Abraham, your father. Do not be afraid, for I am with you. I will bless you and multiply your descendants for the sake of Abraham, My servant.'
Genesis 26:25 So he built an altar there, and called upon the name of the Lord. Then he pitched his tent there, and his servants dug a well.
Genesis 26:26 And Abimelech came to him from Gerar, along with Ahuzzath, his friend, and Phicol, the commander of his army.
Genesis 26:27 And Isaac said to them: 'Why have you come to me, a man whom you hated, and whom you drove away from among you?'
Genesis 26:28 They replied: 'We clearly saw that the Lord is with you, and therefore we said to ourselves: "Let there now be an oath between us and you, and let us make a covenant together," – an agreement of peace.'
Genesis 26:29 'that you will do us no harm, just as we intended no harm against you. Instead, we sent you away in peace, because you were greatly blessed by the Lord.'
Genesis 26:30 So Isaac prepared a feast for them, and they ate and drank.
Genesis 26:31 And rising early in the morning, they swore an oath to one another. Then Isaac sent them away, and they returned to their own land.
Genesis 26:32 On that very same day, Isaac's servants came to tell him about the well they had dug, saying, 'We have found water!'
Genesis 26:33 And he called it 'Abundance'. Therefore, the city was called Beersheba from that name, even to this present day.
Genesis 26:34 Now when Esau was forty years old, he took wives: Judith, the daughter of Beeri the Hittite, and Basemath, the daughter of Elon the Hittite.
Genesis 26:35 Both of whom caused bitterness and sorrow to the spirit of Isaac and Rebecca.
Genesis 27:1 Now it came to pass, when Isaac had become old and his eyes had grown so dim that he could no longer see, he called Esau, his firstborn son, and said to him: 'My son.'
Genesis 27:2 Esau answered: 'Here I am.' Isaac then said: 'Look, I am now an old man, and I do not know the day of my death.'
Genesis 27:3 Therefore, take your hunting weapons—your quiver and your bow—and go out into the field. When you catch something by hunting,
Genesis 27:4 make me a stew from it, just as you know I like it, and bring it to me, so I may eat. After that, my soul will bless you before I die.
Genesis 27:5 Rebecca, however, had overheard when Isaac spoke to Esau, his son. So when Esau had gone out into the field to hunt and bring back what he had caught,
Genesis 27:6 Rebecca said to Jacob, her son: 'I heard your father speaking with your brother Esau, saying:'
Genesis 27:7 'Bring me some of your game, and make me a meal so I may eat it, and then I will bless you before the Lord before I die.'
Genesis 27:8 'Now therefore, my son, listen to my counsel, which I am commanding you to follow.'
Genesis 27:9 'Go to the flock and bring me two of the best young goats, so I may prepare a meal from them for your father, the kind he enjoys eating.'
Genesis 27:10 'When you bring them in and he eats them, he will bless you before he dies.'
Genesis 27:11 Jacob answered her: 'You know my brother Esau is a hairy man, but I have smooth skin.'
Genesis 27:12 'If my father touches me and feels my skin, I am afraid he will think I am trying to deceive him, and then I will bring a curse upon myself instead of a blessing.'
Genesis 27:13 His mother said to him: 'Upon me be that curse, my son. Only listen to my voice and go and bring what I have told you.'
Genesis 27:14 So he went and brought them and gave them to his mother. She then prepared the food, just as she knew his father liked it.
Genesis 27:15 Then she dressed Jacob in Esau's best clothes, which she kept with her in the house. She also covered his hands and the smooth part of his neck with the skins of the young goats.
Genesis 27:16 She said to him: 'Bring this to your father, so that when he eats, he may bless you.'
Genesis 27:17 So he brought it to his father. When Isaac had eaten, he said: 'Who are you, my son?'
Genesis 27:18 Jacob answered: 'I am Esau, your firstborn. I have done as you commanded me. Rise up, sit down, and eat of my game, so that your soul may bless me.'
Genesis 27:19 Isaac said: 'How is it, my son, that you were able to find it so quickly?'
Genesis 27:20 Jacob answered: 'It was God's will that what I sought quickly came before me.'
Genesis 27:21 Isaac said: 'Come closer here, so that I may touch you, my son, and determine whether you are truly Esau or not.'
Genesis 27:22 Jacob came closer to his father. Isaac, having felt him, said: 'The voice, indeed, is the voice of Jacob, but the hands are the hands of Esau.'
Genesis 27:23 And he did not recognize him, because his hairy hands resembled those of his elder son Esau. So Isaac blessed him.
Genesis 27:24 And he said: 'Are you truly my son Esau?'
Genesis 27:25 Jacob answered: 'I am.' Then Isaac said: 'Bring it to me, so I may eat of your game, my son, and my soul may bless you.'
Genesis 27:26 When Jacob brought it and Isaac had eaten, Isaac then brought out wine. After he had drunk it,
Genesis 27:27 he said to Jacob: 'Come near me and kiss me, my son.'
Genesis 27:28 Jacob came near and kissed him. As soon as Isaac smelled the fragrance of his garments, he blessed him and said: 'Look, the smell of my son is like the smell of a field full of crops, a field which the Lord has blessed.'
Genesis 27:29 'May God give you of the dew of the sky and of the richness of the earth, an abundance of grain and of new wine.'
Genesis 27:30 'May peoples serve you, and tribes bow down before you. Be lord over your brothers, and may your mother's sons bow down before you.'
Genesis 27:31 'Whoever curses you, let him be cursed; and whoever blesses you, let him be filled with blessings.'
Genesis 27:32 Scarcely had Isaac finished speaking these words, and Jacob had just gone out, when Esau arrived, returning from his hunt.
Genesis 27:33 After preparing a fine meal, he brought it to his father, saying: 'Arise, my father, and eat of your son's game, so that your soul may bless me.'
Genesis 27:34 Isaac was utterly terrified, and amazed beyond belief, saying: 'Who then was it who just now brought me game, and I ate everything before you came? And I blessed him — and he will remain blessed.'
Genesis 27:35 When Esau heard his father's words, he cried out with a loud and bitter cry, and said: 'Bless me too, my father!'
Genesis 27:36 But Isaac said: 'Your brother came deceitfully and took away your blessing.'
Genesis 27:37 Esau answered: 'He is rightly named Jacob, for he has now supplanted me a second time. First he took away my birthright, and now he has taken away my blessing too!' And again he said to his father: 'Have you not reserved a blessing for me as well?'
Genesis 27:38 Isaac answered: 'I have made him your master, and all his brothers I have subjected to his service. I have sustained him with grain and wine. And for you, my son, what more can I do?'
Genesis 27:39 Esau said to him: 'Have you only one blessing, father? Please, bless me also.' And as he wailed and wept,
Genesis 27:40 Isaac was moved and said to him: 'Behold, your blessing shall be from the richness of the earth and from the dew of the sky above.'
Genesis 28:1 So Isaac called Jacob, and he gave Jacob his blessing. Then Isaac gave Jacob a command, saying: "Do not take a wife from the people of Canaan."
Genesis 28:2 Instead, go and journey to Mesopotamia in Syria, to the house of Bethuel, your mother’s father. From there, take a wife for yourself from among the daughters of Laban, your uncle.
Genesis 28:3 And may Almighty God bless you, cause you to grow, and make you fruitful, so that you may become a vast assembly of peoples.
Genesis 28:4 And may He give you the blessings that Abraham received, and to your descendants after you. This is so you may possess the land where you are a sojourner—the land He promised to your grandfather, Abraham.
Genesis 28:5 So after Isaac had sent Jacob away, Jacob went to Mesopotamia in Syria, to Laban, the son of Bethuel the Aramean, who was the brother of Rebecca, Jacob's mother.
Genesis 28:6 Now Esau saw that his father had blessed Jacob and sent him to Mesopotamia in Syria to get a wife from there. He also heard that after the blessing, Isaac had commanded Jacob, saying: "Do not take a wife from the daughters of Canaan."
Genesis 28:7 Esau also saw that Jacob had obeyed his parents and had gone to Mesopotamia in Syria.
Genesis 28:8 So Esau understood that the daughters of Canaan were not pleasing to his father, Isaac.
Genesis 28:9 Therefore, Esau went to Ishmael and took Mahalath, the daughter of Ishmael, Abraham’s son, and the sister of Nebaioth, as a wife in addition to the wives he already had.
Genesis 28:10 So Jacob set out from Beersheba and traveled towards Haran.
Genesis 28:11 When he came to a certain place where he intended to spend the night because the sun had set, he took one of the stones lying there, placed it under his head, and lay down to sleep in that same spot.
Genesis 28:12 Then he had a dream: he saw a ladder set up on the earth, and its top reached to the universe itself, where God dwells beyond the created cosmos. He also saw the angels of God ascending and descending on it.
Genesis 28:13 And behold, the Lord was standing above the ladder, saying to him: "I am the Lord, the God of Abraham, your father, and the God of Isaac. The land on which you are sleeping, I will give to you and to your descendants."
Genesis 28:14 Your descendants will be like the dust of the earth, and you will spread out to the west, and to the east, and to the north, and to the south. And all the families of the earth will be blessed through you and through your descendants.
Genesis 28:15 And behold, I will be your protector wherever you go, and I will bring you back to this land. I will not leave you until I have fulfilled everything I have spoken to you.
Genesis 28:16 When Jacob awoke from his sleep, he said: "Surely the Lord is present in this place, and I did not know it."
Genesis 28:17 He was afraid and said: "How awesome is this place! This is nothing less than the house of God, and the gateway to the spiritual realm, beyond the created sky."
Genesis 28:18 So Jacob rose early in the morning, took the stone he had placed under his head, set it up as a monument, and poured oil on top of it.
Genesis 28:19 And he called the name of that place Beth-el, which was formerly called Luz.
Genesis 28:20 Jacob also made a solemn vow, saying: "If God will be with me and protect me on the journey I am taking, and give me bread to eat and clothing to wear,
Genesis 28:21 and if I return safely to my father’s house, then the Lord will truly be my God."
Genesis 28:22 "And this stone, which I have set up as a monument, will be a house of God. Of all the things you give me, I will faithfully return a tenth to you."
Genesis 29:1 So Jacob continued on his journey and arrived in the land of the eastern peoples. There, he saw a well in a field with three flocks of sheep resting beside it. The shepherds used this well to water their flocks, and its opening was covered by a large stone.
Genesis 29:2 For it was from this well that the shepherds usually watered their animals. But they would only roll the stone away from the well's opening once all the flocks were gathered together, and after watering them, they would put the stone back in its place.
Genesis 29:3 Jacob then asked them, "Brothers, where are you from?" They answered, "We are from Haran."
Genesis 29:4 He then asked them, "Do you know Laban, the son of Nahor?" They replied, "We know him."
Genesis 29:5 Jacob asked, "Is he doing well?" They answered, "He is well, and look, his daughter Rachel is coming now with her flock."
Genesis 29:6 Jacob said to the shepherds, "It is still bright daylight, and it's not yet time to bring the animals back to their pens for the night. You should water the sheep and then take them back to the pastures."
Genesis 29:7 But the shepherds replied, "We cannot do that until all the flocks have gathered, and we all together roll the stone away from the opening of the well so we can water the animals."
Genesis 29:8 While Jacob was still speaking, Rachel arrived with her father's sheep, for she was a shepherdess and cared for the flock herself.
Genesis 29:9 When Jacob saw Rachel, the daughter of Laban—his mother's brother—and Laban's sheep, he immediately went up to the well. He single-handedly rolled away the stone from the opening and watered Laban's entire flock.
Genesis 29:10 Then Jacob kissed Rachel and, overcome with emotion, he began to weep loudly.
Genesis 29:11 He told her that he was a relative of her father, and that he was Rebekah's son. Rachel then ran quickly to tell her father this news.
Genesis 29:12 When Laban heard the news about Jacob, he immediately ran out to meet him. He embraced and kissed him, then brought him to his house. Jacob recounted everything that had happened during his journey.
Genesis 29:13 After hearing everything, Laban said, "You are truly my own flesh and blood." So Jacob stayed with Laban for a full month.
Genesis 29:14 After that month, Laban said to him, "Just because you are my relative, should you work for me for free? Tell me, what wages do you expect to receive?"
Genesis 29:15 Now, Laban had two daughters. The older one was named Leah, and the younger one was named Rachel.
Genesis 29:16 Leah's eyes were weak, or perhaps not as striking, but Rachel was beautiful in form and had a lovely appearance.
Genesis 29:17 Jacob loved Rachel deeply, so he said to Laban, "I will serve you for seven years in exchange for your younger daughter, Rachel."
Genesis 29:18 Laban answered, "It is better that I give her to you than to another man. So stay here with me."
Genesis 29:19 So Jacob served Laban for seven years for Rachel. Because of the great love he had for her, those seven years seemed to him like only a few days.
Genesis 29:20 Then Jacob said to Laban, "Give me my wife, for the time of my service is completed, and I wish to be with her as my wife."
Genesis 29:21 Laban then gathered all the men of that place and held a wedding feast.
Genesis 29:22 But in the evening, Laban took his daughter Leah and brought her to Jacob, and Jacob went in to her, believing she was Rachel.
Genesis 29:23 When morning came, Jacob realized that it was Leah. He said to Laban, "What have you done to me? Did I not serve you for Rachel? Why have you deceived me like this?"
Genesis 29:24 Laban answered, "It is not the custom in our country to give the younger daughter in marriage before the older one."
Genesis 29:25 Laban continued, "Complete the week of celebration for this marriage, and then I will also give you Rachel, but in return, you must serve me for another seven years."
Genesis 29:26 Jacob agreed to this arrangement. After he had completed the week for Leah's wedding, Laban gave him his daughter Rachel to be his wife.
Genesis 29:27 And Laban also gave his servant girl Bilhah to his daughter Rachel as her maidservant.
Genesis 29:28 So Jacob also went in to Rachel as his wife, and he loved Rachel much more deeply than Leah. He then served Laban for another seven years as agreed.
Genesis 29:29 Now, the Lord saw that Leah was unloved, or at least less loved than Rachel. So God enabled her to conceive children, while Rachel remained unable to bear children.
Genesis 29:30 Leah conceived and bore a son, and she named him Reuben, saying, "The Lord has seen my humiliation. Now, surely my husband will love me."
Genesis 29:31 She conceived again and bore a second son, and she named him Simeon, explaining, "Because the Lord heard that I was unloved, He has given me this son."
Genesis 29:32 She conceived a third time and bore another son, and she said, "Now this time, my husband will surely be joined to me in affection, because I have borne him three sons." Therefore, she named him Levi.
Genesis 29:33 She conceived again and bore a fourth son, and she said, "This time I will praise the Lord." Therefore, she named him Judah. After this, she stopped bearing children for a time.
Genesis 30:1 Seeing that Rachel was barren and had not given birth, she became jealous of her sister, Leah. So she said to Jacob, 'Give me children, or else I will die!'
Genesis 30:2 Jacob became angry with Rachel and answered her directly. He said, 'Am I in the place of God, who has made you unable to bear children?'
Genesis 30:3 Rachel said to him, 'Look, here is my maidservant, Bilhah. Go to her and have relations with her. Let her give birth to a child that I can claim as my own, so that I may have children through her.'
Genesis 30:4 So Rachel gave Jacob her maidservant, Bilhah, as a concubine. Jacob then had relations with her.
Genesis 30:5 Bilhah conceived and gave birth to a son.
Genesis 30:6 Rachel said, 'God has judged my cause fairly, and He has heard my voice by giving me a son.' For this reason, she named the child Dan, which means 'judge'.
Genesis 30:7 Bilhah conceived again and gave birth to a second son.
Genesis 30:8 Rachel then declared, 'I have wrestled with my sister in a mighty struggle from God, and I have overcome her.' So she named him Naphtali, meaning 'my wrestling'.
Genesis 30:9 When Leah saw that she had stopped bearing children, she took her maidservant, Zilpah, and gave her to Jacob as a concubine.
Genesis 30:10 When Zilpah had relations with Jacob, she conceived and gave birth to a son.
Genesis 30:11 Leah exclaimed, 'What good fortune has come!' For this reason, she named him Gad, meaning 'fortune' or 'troop'.
Genesis 30:12 Zilpah, Leah’s maidservant, also gave birth to a second son.
Genesis 30:13 And Leah said, 'How happy I am! Women will now call me blessed!' For this reason, she named him Asher, meaning 'happy' or 'blessed'.
Genesis 30:14 One day, during the wheat harvest, Reuben went out into the field and found mandrakes. He brought them to his mother, Leah. Then Rachel said to Leah, 'Please give me some of your son’s mandrakes.'
Genesis 30:15 Leah answered her, 'Is it not enough that you have taken away my husband? Now you want to take my son’s mandrakes too?' Rachel then said, 'Very well, Jacob will sleep with you tonight in exchange for your son's mandrakes.'
Genesis 30:16 When Jacob returned from the field in the evening, Leah went out to meet him. She told him, 'You are to come to me tonight, because I have hired you with my son’s mandrakes.' So he slept with her that night.
Genesis 30:17 God listened to Leah’s prayers, and she conceived and gave birth to a fifth son.
Genesis 30:18 Leah declared, 'God has given me my reward, because I gave my maidservant to my husband.' So she named him Issachar, meaning 'reward'.
Genesis 30:19 Leah conceived again and gave birth to a sixth son.
Genesis 30:20 She said, 'God has provided me with a good dowry. Now my husband will honor me, because I have given him six sons.' So she named him Zebulun.
Genesis 30:21 After this, Leah gave birth to a daughter and named her Dinah.
Genesis 30:22 Then the Lord remembered Rachel. He listened to her prayers and opened her womb.
Genesis 30:23 She conceived and gave birth to a son, saying, 'God has taken away my disgrace of barrenness.'
Genesis 30:24 She named him Joseph, meaning 'may He add,' saying, 'May the Lord add another son to me.'
Genesis 30:25 After Joseph was born, Jacob said to Laban, 'Let me go, so that I may return to my own land and my homeland.'
Genesis 30:26 'Give me my wives and my children, for whom I have served you, so that I may leave. You know well how I have served you.'
Genesis 30:27 Laban replied to him, 'If I have found favor in your eyes, please stay. I have learned by divination that the Lord has blessed me because of you.'
Genesis 30:28 Then Laban said, 'Name your wages for me, and I will pay them.'
Genesis 30:29 Jacob answered, 'You yourself know how I have served you, and how your livestock have fared under my care.'
Genesis 30:30 'For the little you had when I arrived has increased greatly, and the Lord has blessed you wherever I went. Now, when will I be able to provide for my own household as well?'
Genesis 30:31 Laban then asked, 'What shall I give you?' Jacob replied, 'You don't need to give me anything upfront. But if you will agree to what I am asking, I will again tend and keep your flocks.'
Genesis 30:32 'Today I will go through all your flocks and separate every speckled and spotted animal, and every dark-colored sheep among the lambs, and every spotted and speckled goat among the goats. These will be my wages.'
Genesis 30:33 'My honesty will be evident for me tomorrow, when you come to inspect my wages in your presence. Any animal that is not speckled or spotted, or any sheep that is not dark-colored, if found among my animals, will be considered stolen.'
Genesis 30:34 Laban replied, 'Very well! Let it be as you have said, and I will gladly do it.'
Genesis 30:35 However, that same day, Laban secretly separated all the male goats that were striped or spotted, and all the female goats that were speckled or spotted, and every dark-colored lamb among the sheep. He put them in the care of his sons.
Genesis 30:36 Then he put a distance of three days' journey between himself and Jacob. Jacob continued to tend the rest of Laban's flocks.
Genesis 30:37 But Jacob took fresh branches of poplar, almond, and plane trees. He then peeled strips of bark from them, exposing the white wood underneath, while other parts remained dark.
Genesis 30:38 He placed these peeled branches in the watering troughs, where the flocks came to drink. The animals would look at the striped branches when they came to drink, and they would conceive while looking at them.
Genesis 30:39 As a result, the flocks conceived in front of the branches and gave birth to offspring that were striped, speckled, and spotted.
Genesis 30:40 Jacob then separated the flocks and made sure that all of Laban’s dark-colored and spotted animals faced the striped branches in the troughs. He thus caused all of Laban’s flocks to become striped, speckled, and spotted.
Genesis 31:1 Jacob heard Laban's sons saying that Jacob had taken everything that belonged to their father, and from what was their father's, Jacob had made himself all these riches.
Genesis 31:2 Jacob also noticed Laban's demeanor, and it was not favorable toward him, as it had been on previous days.
Genesis 31:3 And the Lord said to Jacob, "Return to your ancestral land, to your family, and I will be with you."
Genesis 31:4 So Jacob sent for Rachel and Leah, calling them to the field where his flocks were grazing.
Genesis 31:5 He said to them, "I see that your father's disposition towards me is no longer what it was in previous days. Yet, the God of my father has remained with me."
Genesis 31:6 And you both know that I have served your father with all my strength.
Genesis 31:7 But your father has repeatedly cheated me, changing my wages ten times; yet God did not allow him to cause me any harm.
Genesis 31:8 If ever he declared, 'The speckled ones will be your wages,' then all the sheep would bear speckled young. But if he said, 'The striped ones,' then all the flocks would bear striped young.
Genesis 31:9 In this way, God has taken away your father's flocks and given them to me.
Genesis 31:10 For when the sheep were conceiving, I lifted my eyes in a dream and saw that the male goats mounting the ewes were speckled, striped, and mottled.
Genesis 31:11 And in that dream, the angel of God called to me, "Jacob!" And I answered, "Here I am."
Genesis 31:12 He said, "Look up and see all the male goats mounting the ewes are speckled, mottled, and striped. I have observed everything Laban has done to you."
Genesis 31:13 "I am the God of Bethel, where you consecrated a stone pillar and made a solemn vow to me. Now, arise and leave this land, and return to the land where you were born."
Genesis 31:14 Rachel and Leah responded, "Do we have any remaining share or inheritance in our father's household?"
Genesis 31:15 "Did he not treat us as strangers, sell us into marriage, and then spend all the money that was due to us?"
Genesis 31:16 "All the wealth and possessions that God has taken from our father now belong to us and our children. Therefore, do everything God has commanded you."
Genesis 31:17 So Jacob prepared to depart. He put his children and wives on camels and set out.
Genesis 31:18 He made haste to go to his father Isaac in the land of Canaan, taking with him all his possessions, all his flocks, and everything he had acquired in Mesopotamia.
Genesis 31:19 Meanwhile, Laban had gone to shear his sheep, and Rachel secretly took her father's household idols.
Genesis 31:20 Jacob kept his departure a secret from Laban the Aramean, by not telling him that he was fleeing.
Genesis 31:21 After he and all he possessed had departed and crossed the river, Jacob set his course toward Mount Gilead.
Genesis 31:22 On the third day, Laban was informed that Jacob had fled.
Genesis 31:23 So Laban took his kinsmen with him and pursued Jacob for seven days, finally overtaking him on Mount Gilead.
Genesis 31:24 That night, Laban saw the Lord in a dream, who said to him, "Be careful not to speak anything harsh or threatening to Jacob."
Genesis 31:25 Jacob had already pitched his tent on the mountain. When Laban arrived with his companions, they also pitched their tents on the same Mount Gilead.
Genesis 31:26 Laban then said to Jacob, "Why have you done this? Why did you secretly lead away my daughters as if they were captives taken by the sword?"
Genesis 31:27 "Why did you not tell me, so that I could have sent you off with joy and songs, accompanied by tambourines and harps?"
Genesis 31:28 "You did not even allow my daughters and their children to kiss their father goodbye. You have acted foolishly and thoughtlessly."
Genesis 31:29 "I have the power to do you great harm. But the God of your father said to me yesterday, 'Be careful not to speak anything harsh or threatening to Jacob.'"
Genesis 31:30 "Alright, granted, you left because of your longing for home and your distress. But why did you steal my household gods?"
Genesis 31:31 Jacob replied, "Because I was afraid that you might forcefully take your daughters away from me."
Genesis 31:32 "If you find your gods with anyone here, that person shall die. In the presence of our kinsmen, examine whatever you find among my belongings and take it." Jacob said this, unaware that Rachel had stolen them.
Genesis 31:33 So Laban went into Jacob's tent, then Leah's tent, and then the tents of both maidservants, but he found nothing. When he entered Rachel's tent,
Genesis 31:34 Rachel, quickly, had hidden the idols under the camel's saddle on which she was sitting. And after he had searched all parts of the tent and found nothing,
Genesis 31:35 she said, "Do not be angry, my lord, that I cannot rise in your presence, for I am experiencing a woman's customary condition." In this way, she deceived her father, and he did not find what he was looking for.
Genesis 31:36 Then Jacob became angry and argued with Laban. He said, "What is my offense? What is my sin that you have pursued me so fiercely?"
Genesis 31:37 "After you have thoroughly searched through all my possessions, what have you found here that belongs to your household? Place it here before my kinsmen and your kinsmen, and let them judge between us."
Genesis 31:38 "I have been with you for twenty years. Your ewes and female goats were never barren, and I never ate the rams from your flock."
Genesis 31:39 "I never showed you an animal torn by wild beasts; I always bore the burden of such loss myself. Whatever was stolen, you demanded compensation from me."
Genesis 31:40 "By day, I was tormented by the scorching heat, and by night, by the bitter frost. Sleep often fled from my eyes."
Genesis 32:1 Jacob continued on his journey. Angels of God met him along the way.
Genesis 32:2 When Jacob saw them, he said, "This is God's camp!" So he named that place Mahanaim—meaning "Two Camps".
Genesis 32:3 Jacob then sent messengers ahead to his brother Esau in the land of Seir, the country of Edom, before he arrived.
Genesis 32:4 He gave them this instruction: "Tell my lord Esau: 'Your servant Jacob says this: "I have lived as a foreigner with Laban and stayed there until today."
Genesis 32:5 " 'I have oxen, donkeys, sheep, and both male and female servants. I am sending this message to my lord now, so that I may find favor in your sight.' "
Genesis 32:6 The messengers returned to Jacob, saying, "We went to your brother Esau, and look, he is coming to meet you, and he has four hundred men with him."
Genesis 32:7 Jacob was extremely frightened. He divided the people who were with him, along with the flocks, herds, and camels, into two separate groups.
Genesis 32:8 He said, "If Esau attacks one group and destroys it, then at least the other remaining group will be saved."
Genesis 32:9 Then Jacob prayed, "O God of my father Abraham and God of my father Isaac, O Lord, You told me, 'Return to your land and to the place of your birth, and I will be good to you.'"
Genesis 32:10 "I am unworthy of all the acts of mercy and the faithfulness You have shown to your servant. I crossed this Jordan River with nothing but my staff, and now I am returning with these two large groups of people and animals."
Genesis 32:11 "Please, rescue me from the hand of my brother Esau, because I am very afraid of him. I fear that he may come and attack me, slaughtering both mothers and children alike."
Genesis 32:12 "You Yourself promised that You would do good to me and multiply my descendants like the sand of the sea, which is so numerous it cannot be counted."
Genesis 32:13 That night, after he had settled down to sleep, Jacob took some of his possessions to be a gift for his brother Esau.
Genesis 32:14 The gift consisted of two hundred female goats and twenty male goats, two hundred ewes and twenty rams,
Genesis 32:15 thirty female camels and their young, forty cows and ten bulls, and twenty female donkeys with ten of their young.
Genesis 32:16 He gave these animals to his servants, dividing them into separate groups. He then instructed his servants, "Go on ahead of me, and leave a clear space between each group of animals."
Genesis 32:17 He commanded the first servant, saying, "If my brother Esau meets you and asks, 'Whose servant are you? Where are you going? And to whom do these animals belong that you are driving?'"
Genesis 32:18 "You are to answer, 'They belong to your servant Jacob. They are a gift sent to my lord Esau, and Jacob himself is coming right behind us.'"
Genesis 32:19 He gave the same instructions to the second servant, and to the third, and to all those who followed with the animal groups, saying, "Speak these exact same words to Esau when you encounter him."
Genesis 32:20 "And be sure to add, 'Your servant Jacob is also coming right behind us.' " Jacob thought to himself, "I will appease him with these gifts that are going ahead of me. After that, when I see his face directly, perhaps he will receive me kindly and be reconciled with me."
Genesis 32:21 So the gifts went ahead of him, and Jacob spent that night in the camp.
Genesis 32:22 That very night, Jacob got up, took his two wives, his two female servants, and his eleven children, and crossed the ford of the Jabbok River.
Genesis 32:23 After he had sent them across the river, he sent over all his possessions as well.
Genesis 32:24 Jacob remained alone on the other side. Then, a man wrestled with him until dawn.
Genesis 32:25 When the man saw that he could not overpower Jacob, he touched Jacob’s hip socket, and immediately Jacob's hip was dislocated as they wrestled.
Genesis 32:26 The man said, "Let me go, for the dawn is breaking." But Jacob replied, "I will not let you go unless you bless me."
Genesis 32:27 The man then asked him, "What is your name?" He answered, "Jacob."
Genesis 32:28 The man said, "Your name will no longer be called Jacob, but Israel, because you have struggled with God and with men, and have overcome." This new name signifies "He struggles with God" or "God strives."
Genesis 32:29 Jacob asked him, "Please tell me your name." But the man replied, "Why do you ask for my name?" And He blessed Jacob right there in that place.
Genesis 32:30 Jacob named that place Penuel—meaning "Face of God"—saying, "I have seen God face to face, and yet my life has been preserved."
Genesis 32:31 The sun rose upon him just as he was passing Penuel, and he was limping because of his hip.
Genesis 32:32 For this reason, to this very day, the children of Israel do not eat the sinew that is on the hip socket—the one that had shrunk in Jacob's thigh—because the man had touched the sinew of Jacob's hip, and it had shrunken.
Genesis 33:1 Jacob looked up, and there was Esau approaching. With Esau were four hundred men, which was cause for Jacob's immediate alarm.
Genesis 33:2 Jacob then divided his children among Leah and Rachel, and also among their two servant women, arranging them for protection.
Genesis 33:3 He placed the two servant women and their children at the very front of the procession; Leah and her children were placed behind them; and Rachel and Joseph, his most beloved, were placed last, in the safest position.
Genesis 33:4 But Jacob himself went ahead of them, bowing himself to the ground seven times in extreme submission, doing so until his brother Esau came close to him.
Genesis 33:5 Then Esau ran to meet his brother. He embraced him, put his arms around his neck, and kissed him, and they both wept.
Genesis 33:6 Esau looked up and saw the women and children. He asked Jacob, "Who are these with you?" Jacob replied, "These are the children that God has graciously given to your servant."
Genesis 33:7 Then the servant women and their children came forward, and they all bowed down to Esau.
Genesis 33:8 Next, Leah and her children came forward, and they likewise bowed down. Finally, Rachel and Joseph came forward and bowed down to Esau.
Genesis 33:9 Esau then asked, "What do you mean by all these droves and herds that I met on the way?" Jacob replied, "I hope to find favor in your sight, my lord."
Genesis 33:10 Esau said to him, "I have enough, my brother. Keep what is yours. I am well-provided for."
Genesis 33:11 Jacob replied, "No, I beg you, if I have truly found favor in your eyes, then please accept this gift from my hand. For to see your face is like seeing the face of God, and you have received me graciously."
Genesis 33:12 Please accept the blessing, this gift that I have brought for you, because God has been gracious to me and has given me everything I need and more." So Jacob urged him, and Esau took the gift.
Genesis 33:13 Jacob kept urging him, and Esau finally accepted it.
Genesis 33:14 Esau then said, "Let's set out and go. I will go along with you to Seir."
Genesis 33:15 Jacob replied, "My lord knows that the children are tender, and that the flocks and herds nursing their young are a burden to me. If I drive them too hard for even one day, all the animals will die."
Genesis 33:16 So please, my lord, go on ahead of your servant. I will follow slowly, at the pace of the livestock and the children, until I come to you in Seir."
Genesis 33:17 Esau said, "Let me at least leave some of my people with you to help on the journey." But Jacob replied, "What need is there for that, my lord? I am content with your kindness and protection for all these things."
Genesis 33:18 So Esau turned back that day and went his way toward Seir.
Genesis 33:19 Meanwhile, Jacob journeyed to Succoth, where he built a house for himself and made temporary shelters for his livestock. Therefore, he called the place Succoth, which means 'Shelters' or 'Booths'.
Genesis 33:20 Jacob then traveled safely to the city of Shechem, which is in the land of Canaan, after returning from Paddan-aram in Syria. He camped near the city.
Genesis 33:21 There, he bought a plot of land where he had pitched his tents from the sons of Hamor, Shechem's father, for one hundred pieces of money, or 'qesitas' in the ancient currency.
Genesis 33:22 He erected an altar there and called it El-Elohe-Israel, which means 'God, the God of Israel the Most Powerful'.
Genesis 34:1 Dina, the daughter of Leah and Jacob, went out to visit the women of that land.
Genesis 34:2 When Shechem saw her, he was the son of Hamor the Hivite, and ruler of that land. He desired her strongly, seized her, and then violently raped her.
Genesis 34:3 Afterward, his affections became fixed on Dina, Jacob’s daughter. He loved the girl and spoke to her with words meant to soothe her heart.
Genesis 34:4 So Shechem spoke to his father Hamor, saying, 'Get this girl for me as a wife.'
Genesis 34:5 Jacob, however, heard the news that his daughter Dina had been violently disgraced. His sons were out in the fields tending the sheep at the time. So he remained silent, waiting for them to come home.
Genesis 34:6 Then Hamor, Shechem's father, came out to Jacob to speak with him about the matter.
Genesis 34:7 When Jacob’s sons returned from the field, they heard what had been done. They were deeply enraged by the despicable act committed against Dina and the family’s honor in Israel, which was an intolerable crime.
Genesis 34:8 Then Hamor spoke to them, saying, 'My son Shechem has set his heart on your daughter. Please, give her to him in marriage. Let us form a bond of kinship between our families.'
Genesis 34:9 'Give your daughters to us, and take our daughters for yourselves as wives. Then you can live among us.'
Genesis 34:10 'The land is at your disposal. You may cultivate it, engage in trade, and acquire property within it.'
Genesis 34:11 Shechem then said to Dina's father and brothers, 'Grant me this favor, please. Whatever you ask of me, I will give you.'
Genesis 34:12 'Demand as great a bride-price and gifts as you wish. I will gladly provide whatever you determine, as long as you give me the girl to be my wife.'
Genesis 34:13 Jacob's sons answered Shechem and his father Hamor deceitfully, speaking out of anger and a desire for vengeance, because Shechem had defiled their sister Dina.
Genesis 34:14 They told them, 'We cannot do this, nor can we give our sister to a man who is uncircumcised. That would be a disgrace to us.'
Genesis 34:15 'We will only form an alliance and friendship with you on this condition: if you are willing to become like us, and every male among you is circumcised.'
Genesis 34:16 'Then we will both take your daughters as wives and give our daughters to you. We will live among you, and we will become one people.'
Genesis 34:17 'But if you men refuse to be circumcised, then we will take our daughter back and leave your land.'
Genesis 34:18 Their words seemed good to Hamor and to his son Shechem.
Genesis 34:19 The young man Shechem did not delay, but immediately did what had been commanded. He loved the girl very much, and he was the most respected and honored in all his father's house.
Genesis 34:20 Then Hamor and his son Shechem went to the gate of their city and spoke to the people there.
Genesis 34:21 'These men are peaceful toward us and wish to settle in our land. Let them conduct business and cultivate the land; it is spacious and vast enough for everyone. There is no reason why we should not take their daughters as wives and give our daughters to them.'
Genesis 34:22 'There is only one condition by which this friendship and alliance can be established: if all our males are circumcised, just as they themselves are circumcised.'
Genesis 34:23 'Their wealth, their livestock, and all their possessions will become ours. We only agree to this condition, and then we will live together with them as one people.'
Genesis 34:24 All the men who came out of the city gate agreed to their proposal, and every male among them was circumcised.
Genesis 34:25 Now on the third day, when the pain from their wounds was most intense, two of Jacob’s sons, Simeon and Levi, Dina's full brothers, each took his sword. They entered the city boldly and killed all the males.
Genesis 34:26 They also killed Hamor and his son Shechem. Then they took Dina from Shechem's house and departed.
Genesis 34:27 The other sons of Jacob rushed upon the slain and plundered the city as an act of vengeance for the rape of their sister.
Genesis 34:28 They took all the sheep, cattle, and donkeys, as well as everything that was in the city and in the fields.
Genesis 34:29 They carried away all the young children and the women as captives, and they plundered everything else.
Genesis 34:30 Then Jacob said to Simeon and Levi, 'You have brought trouble upon me and made me odious to the Canaanites and the Perizzites, the inhabitants of this land. My numbers are few compared to theirs. If they gather together and attack me, both I and my entire household will be destroyed.'
Genesis 34:31 But they answered, 'Should our sister have been treated like a harlot?'
Genesis 35:1 God also said to Jacob: 'Get up and go up to Bethel, and live there. Make an altar there to God, the One who appeared to you when you were fleeing from your brother Esau.'
Genesis 35:2 Jacob then spoke to his household and all his people, saying: 'Cast away the foreign gods that are among you, and cleanse yourselves, and change your garments to symbolize your purification.'
Genesis 35:3 'Then get up, and let us go up to Bethel, so we can make an altar there to God. He heard me on the day of my trouble and has been a companion on my journey.'
Genesis 35:4 So they gave to Jacob all the foreign gods they had, and the earrings that were in their ears – items often associated with pagan practices or amulets. Jacob buried these beneath the terebinth tree near the city of Shechem.
Genesis 35:5 When they had departed, the terror of the Lord gripped all the surrounding cities, and no one dared to pursue them.
Genesis 35:6 So Jacob came to Luz, which is in the land of Canaan, and it was also known by the name Bethel. He and all his people were with him.
Genesis 35:7 And he built an altar there, and he called the name of that place 'God of Bethel' – meaning that God truly dwelt there. For it was there that God had appeared to him when he was fleeing from his brother.
Genesis 35:8 At that time, Deborah, Rebecca's nurse, died and was buried under an oak tree at Bethel. The name of that place was then called 'Oak of Weeping,' marking a place of great sorrow for Jacob's family.
Genesis 35:9 God appeared to Jacob again after he had returned from Mesopotamia of Syria, and He blessed him.
Genesis 35:10 God said: 'Your name will no longer be called Jacob, but Israel will be your name.' And indeed, He called his name Israel.
Genesis 35:11 And God said to him: 'I am God Almighty. Be fruitful and multiply. Both nations and a company of nations shall come from you, and kings shall come forth from your body.'
Genesis 35:12 'And the land which I gave to Abraham and Isaac, I will give to you and to your descendants after you.'
Genesis 35:13 Then God departed from him in the very place where He had spoken with him.
Genesis 35:14 Jacob then set up a stone pillar in the place where God had spoken with him, pouring a drink offering over it and anointing it with oil to consecrate the spot.
Genesis 35:15 And he called the name of that very place, Bethel.
Genesis 35:16 Having journeyed from Bethel, they came to the land of Ephrath. While there, Rachel was giving birth, and she experienced a very difficult labor.
Genesis 35:17 After severe pains, the midwife said to her: 'Do not fear, you will also have this son.'
Genesis 35:18 As her life was ebbing away, and she was already dying, she called his name Benoni, which means 'Son of my sorrow.' But his father called him Benjamin, meaning 'Son of the right hand,' to give him a name of blessing instead.
Genesis 35:19 So Rachel died and was buried on the road to Ephrath, which is Bethlehem.
Genesis 35:20 Jacob set up a pillar over her grave. This pillar marks Rachel's monument even to the present day.
Genesis 35:21 Journeying from there, Israel (Jacob) pitched his tent beyond the Tower of Eder.
Genesis 35:22 While Jacob was dwelling in that region, Reuben went and slept with Bilhah, his father's concubine – a grave sin that deeply dishonored his father. This act did not escape Jacob's knowledge, and it would have serious consequences later. Now, the sons of Jacob were twelve in number.
Genesis 35:23 The sons of Leah were: Reuben, the firstborn; and Simeon, and Levi, and Judah, and Issachar, and Zebulun.
Genesis 35:24 The sons of Rachel were: Joseph, and Benjamin.
Genesis 35:25 The sons of Bilhah, Rachel's handmaid, were: Dan, and Naphtali.
Genesis 35:26 The sons of Zilpah, Leah's handmaid, were: Gad, and Asher. These are the sons of Jacob who were born to him in Mesopotamia of Syria, in the land of Paddan-Aram.
Genesis 35:27 And Jacob also came to his father Isaac at Mamre, the city of Arba – which is Hebron. This was the place where both Abraham and Isaac had lived as sojourners, continuing the patriarchs' journey of faith.
Genesis 35:28 Isaac's life spanned one hundred and eighty years.
Genesis 35:29 Worn out by old age and full of years, Isaac died and was gathered to his people – a phrase indicating his peaceful passing into the afterlife. He was buried by his sons Esau and Jacob, marking a moment of reconciliation for them.
Genesis 36:1 This is the family line of Esau, who is also known as Edom.
Genesis 36:2 Esau took his wives from among the daughters of Canaan: Ada, the daughter of Elon the Hittite; and Oholibamah, the daughter of Ana, who was the daughter of Zibeon the Hivite.
Genesis 36:3 Also Basemath, the daughter of Ishmael, who was the sister of Nebaioth.
Genesis 36:4 These were the sons born to Esau: Eliphaz was born from Ada, and Reuel from Basemath.
Genesis 36:5 Also, from Oholibamah were born: Jeush, Jaalam, and Korah. These are the sons of Esau, who were born to him in the land of Canaan.
Genesis 36:6 Esau took his wives, his sons and daughters, and all the people of his household, along with all his possessions, his livestock, and everything he had acquired in the land of Canaan. And he went to another region, moving away from his brother Jacob.
Genesis 36:7 Indeed, they were so wealthy that they could not live together in the same place. The land where they were staying as temporary residents could not support them both because of their many livestock.
Genesis 36:8 So Esau settled in Mount Seir. He is also known as Edom, and this region became known by his name.
Genesis 36:9 This is the family line of Esau, the ancestor of Edom, who lived in Mount Seir:
Genesis 36:10 These are the names of Esau's sons: Eliphaz, the son of Ada, Esau's wife; and Reuel, the son of Basemath, Esau's wife.
Genesis 36:11 The sons of Eliphaz were: Teman, Omar, Zepho, Gatam, and Kenaz.
Genesis 36:12 And Timna was a concubine of Eliphaz, Esau's son, and she bore Amalek to him. These were the descendants of Ada, Esau's wife.
Genesis 36:13 The sons of Reuel were: Nahath, Zerah, Shammah, and Mizzah. These were the descendants of Basemath, Esau's wife.
Genesis 36:14 These also were the sons of Oholibamah, daughter of Ana, who was the daughter of Zibeon—Esau's wife: to whom she bore Jeush, Jaalam, and Korah.
Genesis 36:15 These are the chiefs (or tribal leaders) from the sons of Esau: from the sons of Eliphaz, Esau's firstborn: Chief Teman, Chief Omar, Chief Zepho, Chief Kenaz,
Genesis 36:16 Chief Korah, Chief Gatam, Chief Amalek. These are the chiefs from Eliphaz in the land of Edom, and these are the descendants of Ada.
Genesis 36:17 These also are the sons of Reuel, Esau's son: Chief Nahath, Chief Zerah, Chief Shammah, Chief Mizzah. These are the chiefs from Reuel in the land of Edom; these are the descendants of Basemath, Esau's wife.
Genesis 36:18 These also are the sons of Oholibamah, Esau's wife: Chief Jeush, Chief Jaalam, Chief Korah. These are the chiefs from Oholibamah, the daughter of Ana, Esau's wife.
Genesis 36:19 These are the sons of Esau, and these are their chiefs. He is Edom, and these are his family lines.
Genesis 36:20 These are the sons of Seir the Horite, the inhabitants of that land: Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, and Anah,
Genesis 36:21 and Dishon, and Ezer, and Dishan. These are the Horite chiefs, the sons of Seir, in the land of Seir.
Genesis 36:22 The sons of Lotan were: Hori and Hemam. And Lotan's sister was Timna (the one who became Eliphaz's concubine).
Genesis 36:23 The sons of Shobal were also: Alvan, Manahath, Ebal, Shepho, and Onam.
Genesis 36:24 The sons of Zibeon were also: Aiah and Anah. This is the same Anah who found hot springs in the desert while pasturing the donkeys of his father Zibeon.
Genesis 36:25 The children of Anah were: Dishon and Oholibamah, Anah's daughter (who became Esau's wife).
Genesis 36:26 The sons of Dishon were: Hemdan, Eshban, Ithran, and Cheran.
Genesis 36:27 The sons of Ezer were also: Bilhan, Zaavan, and Akan.
Genesis 36:28 The sons of Dishan were: Uz and Aran.
Genesis 36:29 These are the Horite chiefs: Chief Lotan, Chief Shobal, Chief Zibeon, Chief Anah,
Genesis 36:30 Chief Dishon, Chief Ezer, Chief Dishan. These are the Horite chiefs who ruled in the land of Seir.
Genesis 36:31 These are the kings who reigned in the land of Edom before any king reigned over the children of Israel.
Genesis 36:32 Bela, the son of Beor, reigned in Edom. And the name of his city was Dinhabah.
Genesis 36:33 When Bela died, Jobab, the son of Zerah, from Bozrah, reigned in his place.
Genesis 36:34 When Jobab also died, Husham, from the land of the Temanites, reigned in his place.
Genesis 36:35 When he also died, Hadad, the son of Bedad, reigned in his place. He was the one who defeated Midian in the region of Moab. And the name of his city was Avith.
Genesis 36:36 When Hadad died, Samlah, from Masrekah, reigned in his place.
Genesis 36:37 When he also died, Shaul, from Rehoboth on the River, reigned in his place.
Genesis 36:38 When Shaul died, Baal-hanan, the son of Achbor, reigned in his place.
Genesis 36:39 When he also died, Hadar reigned in his place. And the name of his city was Pau. His wife's name was Mehetabel, the daughter of Matred, who was the daughter of Me-zahab.
Genesis 36:40 These are the names of the chiefs of Esau, listed according to their families, their places of dwelling, and their specific names: Chief Timna, Chief Alvah, Chief Jetheth,
Genesis 37:1 Jacob settled in the land of Canaan, which was the same land where his father had lived as a foreigner.
Genesis 37:2 This is the family record of Jacob. Joseph was sixteen years old, and though still a boy, he was tending the flock with his brothers. He was working with the sons of Bilhah and Zilpah, who were his father's wives. Joseph reported very serious misconduct about his brothers to his father.
Genesis 37:3 Israel (Jacob) loved Joseph more than all his other sons, because Joseph had been born to him in his old age. So Jacob made for him a long, intricately designed tunic.
Genesis 37:4 When his brothers saw that their father loved Joseph more than all of them, they hated him and could not speak a single peaceful word to him.
Genesis 37:5 It happened that Joseph also had a dream, which he told his brothers about, and because of this, they hated him even more.
Genesis 37:6 And he said to them: "Listen to this dream that I had."
Genesis 37:7 "I imagined us tying up sheaves of grain in the field. And it was as if my sheaf rose up and stood upright, and your sheaves gathered around it and bowed down to my sheaf."
Genesis 37:8 His brothers replied: "Will you truly be our king? Or will you really rule over us?" Because of his dreams and his words, they hated him even more.
Genesis 37:9 He also had another dream, which he told his father and his brothers, saying: "I dreamed that the sun and the moon and eleven stars were bowing down to me."
Genesis 37:10 When he told this to his father and his brothers, his father scolded him and said: "What does this dream mean that you have seen? Will I and your mother and your brothers truly bow down to you on the earth?"
Genesis 37:11 So his brothers envied him, but his father quietly considered the meaning of the matter.
Genesis 37:12 Therefore, his brothers went to pasture their father's flocks in Shechem.
Genesis 37:13 Then Israel said to Joseph: "Your brothers are pasturing the sheep in Shechem. Come, I will send you to them." And Joseph replied, "I am ready to go."
Genesis 37:14 Jacob said: "Go, and see if all is well with your brothers and the sheep, and bring me back word of what is happening." So Joseph was sent from the valley of Hebron and came to Shechem.
Genesis 37:15 And a man found him wandering in the field and asked him what he was looking for.
Genesis 37:16 He replied: "I am looking for my brothers. Tell me where they are pasturing the flocks."
Genesis 37:17 The man said to him: "They have moved on from this place. I heard them saying, 'Let us go to Dothan.'" So Joseph went after his brothers and found them in Dothan.
Genesis 37:18 When they saw him from a distance, before he came near them, they plotted to kill him.
Genesis 37:19 And they said to one another: "Look, here comes the dreamer."
Genesis 37:20 "Now then, come, let us kill him and throw him into an old cistern. Then we can say, 'A terrible wild beast devoured him,' and we will see what good his dreams will do him."
Genesis 37:21 But Reuben heard this and tried to rescue him from their hands, saying: "Let us not take his life."
Genesis 37:22 "Do not shed his blood, but throw him into this cistern, which is in the wilderness, and keep your hands free of his blood." Reuben said this intending to rescue Joseph from their hands and return him to his father.
Genesis 37:23 Therefore, when Joseph came to his brothers, they immediately stripped him of the tunic he was wearing, the intricately designed tunic.
Genesis 37:24 And they threw him into the old cistern, which had no water in it.
Genesis 37:25 And as they sat down to eat bread, they saw Ishmaelite travelers coming from Gilead, their camels carrying spices, balm, and myrrh, on their way to Egypt.
Genesis 37:26 Then Judah said to his brothers: "What benefit is it to us if we kill our brother and conceal his blood?"
Genesis 37:27 "It is better that he be sold to the Ishmaelites, so that our hands are not defiled by his blood. After all, he is our brother and our own flesh." His brothers agreed.
Genesis 37:28 As Midianite merchants passed by, they pulled Joseph out of the cistern and sold him to the Ishmaelites for twenty pieces of silver. These Ishmaelites then took him to Egypt.
Genesis 37:29 When Reuben returned to the cistern and did not find the boy, he tore his clothes in anguish.
Genesis 37:30 He reported to his brothers, saying: "The boy is gone! And I, where can I go now?"
Genesis 37:31 Then they took Joseph's tunic and dipped it in the blood of a slaughtered goat.
Genesis 37:32 They sent the tunic to their father with the message: "We found this. See if it is your son's tunic or not."
Genesis 37:33 When he recognized it, he said: "It is my son's tunic! A terrible wild beast has eaten him; a beast has devoured Joseph."
Genesis 37:34 And tearing his clothes, he mourned for his son for a very long time.
Genesis 37:35 All his children gathered to comfort their father, but he refused to be comforted and said: "I will go down to my son, mourning, into the underworld of the dead." And he continued weeping.
Genesis 37:36 Meanwhile, the Midianites sold Joseph in Egypt to Potiphar, an official of Pharaoh, who was the commander of the royal guard.
