Genesis 38:1 At that time, Judah left his brothers. He turned aside and went to stay with a man from Adullam, whose name was Hirah.
Genesis 38:2 There he saw the daughter of a Canaanite man named Shuah. He took her as his wife and then went in to her.
Genesis 38:3 She conceived and bore a son, and Judah called his name Er.
Genesis 38:4 Again she conceived and bore a son, and she called his name Onan.
Genesis 38:5 She bore a third son, whom she named Shelah. Judah himself was in Canaan when Shelah was born.
Genesis 38:6 Then Judah took a wife for his firstborn son, Er. Her name was Tamar.
Genesis 38:7 But Er, Judah's firstborn, was wicked in the sight of the Lord, and the Lord put him to death.
Genesis 38:8 Therefore, Judah said to Onan: 'Go in to your brother's wife and perform the duty of a brother-in-law to her, and raise up offspring for your brother.'
Genesis 38:9 But Onan knew that the offspring would not be considered his own. So, when he went in to his brother's wife, he spilled his semen on the ground, so that he would not raise up offspring in his brother's name.
Genesis 38:10 And for this reason, the Lord struck him down, because he did such a detestable thing.
Genesis 38:11 Therefore, Judah said to Tamar, his daughter-in-law: 'Remain a widow in your father's house until my son Shelah grows up.' Judah was actually thinking that Shelah also might die, just as his brothers had. So, Tamar went and remained in her father's house.
Genesis 38:12 After many days, Shuah's daughter, Judah's wife, died. When the period of mourning was over, Judah went up to Timnah to his sheep shearers, along with his friend Hirah, the Adullamite, who was the shepherd of his flock.
Genesis 38:13 And it was told to Tamar: 'Your father-in-law is going up to Timnah to shear his sheep.'
Genesis 38:14 So, she took off her widow's garments, covered herself with a veil, and disguised herself. Then she sat at the fork in the road that leads to Timnah, because she saw that Shelah was grown up, yet she had not been given to him as a wife.
Genesis 38:15 When Judah saw her, he thought she was a harlot, because she had covered her face.
Genesis 38:16 He turned aside to her on the way and said: 'Let me come in to you,' not knowing that she was his daughter-in-law. She answered: 'What will you give me if you come in to me?'
Genesis 38:17 He answered: 'I will send you a young goat from the flock.' She replied: 'Will you give me a pledge until you send it?'
Genesis 38:18 Judah said: 'What pledge shall I give you?' She answered: 'Your signet ring, your bracelet, and your staff that is in your hand.' So he gave her what she asked, and went in to her. And she conceived by him.
Genesis 38:19 As soon as he had departed, she rose and went away, and taking off her disguise, she put on her widow's garments again.
Genesis 38:20 Then Judah sent the young goat by his friend Hirah, the Adullamite shepherd, so that he might retrieve the pledge from the woman. But Hirah could not find her.
Genesis 38:21 He asked the men of that place: 'Where is the harlot who was sitting at the fork in the road?' They answered: 'There has been no harlot in this place.'
Genesis 38:22 So, Hirah returned to Judah and said to him: 'I could not find her. Moreover, the men of that place told me that there had been no harlot sitting there.'
Genesis 38:23 Judah said: 'Let her keep the items then, lest we become a laughingstock. I sent the young goat, and you could not find her.'
Genesis 38:24 About three months later, it was told to Judah: 'Your daughter-in-law Tamar has committed harlotry, and behold, she is found to be with child.' Judah said: 'Bring her out, that she may be burned.'
Genesis 38:25 As she was being led out to be executed, she sent to her father-in-law, saying: 'By the man to whom these things belong, by him I am pregnant.' She added: 'Please recognize whose signet ring, bracelet, and staff these are.'
Genesis 38:26 When Judah recognized them, he said: 'She is more righteous than I, because I did not give her to my son Shelah.' And he did not lie with her again.
Genesis 38:27 Now, at the time of her delivery, it was discovered that she had twins in her womb.
Genesis 38:28 And as she was giving birth, one of the babies put out a hand. The midwife tied a scarlet thread on its hand, saying: 'This one will come out first.'
Genesis 38:29 But he drew back his hand, and then his brother came out. And the midwife said: 'Why have you made a breach for yourself?' So, for this reason, his name was called Perez.
Genesis 38:30 After him, his brother came out, on whose hand was the scarlet thread. And his name was called Zerah.

Genesis 39:1 Joseph had been brought to Egypt. Potiphar, an officer of Pharaoh and captain of the royal guard—not necessarily a eunuch in the literal sense, but a high-ranking court official—bought him from the Ishmaelites who had brought him there.
Genesis 39:2 The Lord was with Joseph, and he prospered in all that he did. He lived in the house of his Egyptian master.
Genesis 39:3 Potiphar saw that the Lord was with Joseph, and that God guided all of Joseph’s work to success.
Genesis 39:4 Because of this, Joseph found favor with Potiphar and became his personal attendant. Potiphar placed Joseph in charge of his entire household and all his possessions.
Genesis 39:5 From the moment Potiphar appointed Joseph over his house and over all that he owned, the Lord blessed the Egyptian’s household because of Joseph. The Lord’s blessing multiplied everything that belonged to Potiphar, both in his house and in his fields.
Genesis 39:6 Potiphar no longer had to worry about anything, except the food he ate. Joseph was handsome in face and appearance.
Genesis 39:7 After a long time, Potiphar’s wife cast her eyes upon Joseph and said, "Sleep with me."
Genesis 39:8 But Joseph refused, and said to her, "Look, my master does not know what he has in his house, and he has entrusted everything he owns to me."
Genesis 39:9 "No one in this house is greater than I am. He has not denied me anything except you, because you are his wife. How then could I do such a wicked thing and sin against my God?"
Genesis 39:10 She pressed him day after day, but he refused to agree. He would not even lie down with her or spend time with her anymore.
Genesis 39:11 So one day Joseph went into the house to do his work, and none of the household servants were inside.
Genesis 39:12 But she grabbed his cloak, saying, "Sleep with me!" Joseph left his cloak in her hand, fled, and ran outside.
Genesis 39:13 When the woman saw that his cloak was in her hands and that he had run away,
Genesis 39:14 she called her household servants and said to them, "Look! My husband brought this Hebrew man here to mock us. He came into my room, saying, 'Sleep with me!' And when I screamed,"
Genesis 39:15 "and he heard my voice crying out, he left his cloak with me and ran outside."
Genesis 39:16 So she laid his cloak beside her until her husband came home.
Genesis 39:17 She spoke to him with the very same words, saying, "The Hebrew servant whom you brought to us came in to mock me."
Genesis 39:18 "And when he heard me crying out, he left his cloak with me and fled outside."
Genesis 39:19 When Joseph’s master heard his wife’s words—especially hearing the exact same story she told him—he became very angry.
Genesis 39:20 So he had Joseph thrown into the prison where the king’s prisoners were held. And there Joseph remained, shut away.
Genesis 39:21 But the Lord was with Joseph, and He extended His mercy to him, granting him favor in the eyes of the prison warden.
Genesis 39:22 The warden put Joseph in charge of all the prisoners who were held in custody. Whatever needed to be done there was done under Joseph’s supervision.
Genesis 39:23 The warden did not carefully oversee anything that was entrusted to Joseph, because the Lord was with Joseph, and the Lord directed all his work.
Genesis 39:24 After these events, it happened that two of Pharaoh’s officials, his chief cupbearer and his chief baker, offended their lord, the king of Egypt.
Genesis 39:25 Pharaoh was angry with them both—the cupbearer and the baker—
Genesis 39:26 and he put them in the prison of the captain of the royal guard, the very place where Joseph was imprisoned.
Genesis 39:27 The captain of the royal guard assigned Joseph to serve them, and he did so.
Genesis 39:28 So they remained in custody for a considerable time.
Genesis 39:29 One night, both of them—the cupbearer and the baker—had a dream, each with its own specific meaning. Each man dreamed his own dream.
Genesis 39:30 When Joseph came to them in the morning and saw that they were distressed,
Genesis 39:31 he asked them, "Why are your faces sadder than usual today?"
Genesis 39:32 They answered, "We had dreams, and there is no one here to interpret them for us."
Genesis 39:33 Joseph said to them, "Do not interpretations belong to God? Please, tell me what you dreamed."
Genesis 39:34 So the chief cupbearer told Joseph his dream. He said, "In my dream, I saw a vine."
Genesis 39:35 "On the vine were three branches, which began to bud, then blossomed, and then ripened into clusters of grapes."
Genesis 39:36 "I held Pharaoh’s cup in my hand. I took the grapes, pressed them into the cup I was holding, and then handed the cup to Pharaoh."
Genesis 39:37 Joseph answered, saying, "This is the interpretation of your dream: The three branches represent three days."
Genesis 39:38 "Within three days, Pharaoh will lift up your head—meaning, he will restore you to your former position. You will then hand him his cup, just as you used to do when you were his cupbearer."
Genesis 39:39 "Only remember me when things go well for you, and show me kindness. Mention me to Pharaoh and get me out of this prison."
Genesis 39:40 "For I was stolen away from the land of the Hebrews, and here I am, innocent, thrown into this pit of a prison."
Genesis 40:1 After all this, two royal officials of the King of Egypt—his chief butler and his chief baker—committed a sin against their lord, the king.
Genesis 40:2 Pharaoh became very angry with these two royal officials, the chief butler and the chief baker. He had them sent to the prison in the house of the captain of the guard, which was the very place where Joseph was being held captive.
Genesis 40:3 The captain of the guard placed these two officials under Joseph's care, and Joseph began to serve them. All the tasks performed in that part of the prison fell under Joseph's responsibility.
Genesis 40:4 For some time, these men were kept under Joseph's watch. Joseph visited them frequently while they were in custody, ensuring they were served as instructed.
Genesis 40:5 One night, both the butler and the baker, who were prisoners of the King of Egypt, each had a dream. Each dream held a specific interpretation for the one who dreamed it.
Genesis 40:6 When Joseph came to them in the morning, he noticed that both of them looked sad and troubled.
Genesis 40:7 So he asked them, "Why do you both look so much sadder than usual today?"
Genesis 40:8 They answered him, saying, "We both had dreams, and there is no one here to interpret them for us." Joseph then said to them, "Doesn't the power to interpret dreams belong to God alone? Please tell me your dreams, and I will seek His understanding."
Genesis 40:9 So the chief butler told Joseph his dream, saying, "In my dream, I saw a vine directly in front of me.
Genesis 40:10 On this vine, there were three branches. As I watched, it slowly budded, then blossomed, and finally, ripe grapes appeared on the clusters.
Genesis 40:11 I held Pharaoh's cup in my hand. I took the grapes, squeezed their juice directly into the cup I was holding, and then presented the drink to Pharaoh."
Genesis 40:12 Joseph replied, "This is the meaning of your dream: the three branches represent three days from now.
Genesis 40:13 Within three days, Pharaoh will lift up your head, meaning he will restore you to your former position. You will then give him his cup, just as you used to do when you served as his butler before."
Genesis 40:14 "Only remember me when things go well for you. Show kindness to me by mentioning me to Pharaoh so that you can get me out of this prison.
Genesis 40:15 For I was stolen away from the land of the Hebrews, and even here, I have done nothing to deserve being thrown into this pit."
Genesis 40:16 When the chief baker saw that Joseph had interpreted the dream so skillfully, he said, "I also had a dream. In my dream, I had three baskets of baked goods on my head.
Genesis 40:17 In the topmost basket, there were all kinds of baked goods that Pharaoh usually eats, and the birds were eating them out of the basket on my head."
Genesis 40:18 Joseph responded, "This is the interpretation of your dream: the three baskets represent three days from now.
Genesis 40:19 Within three days, Pharaoh will lift off your head, meaning he will execute you and hang your body on a tree. Then the birds of the sky will tear at your flesh."
Genesis 40:20 And so it happened that on the third day, which was Pharaoh's birthday, he gave a great feast for all his servants. At this feast, he remembered the chief butler and the chief baker.
Genesis 40:21 He restored the chief butler to his office, and once again the butler presented the cup to Pharaoh.
Genesis 40:22 But he had the chief baker hanged, just as Joseph had interpreted their dreams for them.
Genesis 40:23 Despite this, the chief butler did not remember Joseph. Instead, he completely forgot about him.
Genesis 41:1 After two full years had passed, Pharaoh had a dream. He dreamt he was standing by the Nile River,
Genesis 41:2 And suddenly, in his dream, seven beautiful, well-fed cows came up out of the river. They were grazing in a marshy place.
Genesis 41:3 Then, seven other cows emerged from the river, but these were ugly and scrawny. They began to graze right next to the beautiful cows on the riverbank.
Genesis 41:4 The ugly and scrawny cows then devoured the seven beautiful, well-fed cows. Pharaoh woke up from his dream.
Genesis 41:5 He then fell asleep again and had another dream. In this dream, seven heads of grain, full and beautiful, were growing on a single stalk.
Genesis 41:6 Then, seven other heads of grain, thin and scorched by the east wind, grew up on a different stalk.
Genesis 41:7 These thin heads of grain devoured all the beauty of the full, first heads of grain. Pharaoh woke up from his sleep and understood that these dreams were from God.
Genesis 41:8 When morning came, Pharaoh was deeply troubled by the dream. He sent for all the magicians and wise men of Egypt, and he told them his dream, but none of them could interpret it for him.
Genesis 41:9 Then, the chief cupbearer, remembering Joseph, spoke up and said, 'I must confess my fault to you now.'
Genesis 41:10 'When Pharaoh was angry with me and the chief baker, you had us put in prison in the house of the captain of the guard.'
Genesis 41:11 'One night, both he and I each had a dream, and each of our dreams had a mysterious meaning.'
Genesis 41:12 'There was a young Hebrew man there, a servant of that same captain of the guard. When we told him our dreams, he interpreted them for us.'
Genesis 41:13 'And everything happened exactly as he predicted: I was restored to my position, and the other man was hanged.'
Genesis 41:14 Immediately, at the king's command, Joseph was quickly brought out of the prison dungeon. They shaved him and changed his clothes, then brought him to Pharaoh.
Genesis 41:15 Pharaoh said to Joseph, 'I have had a dream, and there is no one who can interpret it for me. But I have heard that you are able to interpret dreams with great wisdom.'
Genesis 41:16 Joseph answered Pharaoh, saying, 'It is not within my power, but God Himself will give Pharaoh a favorable answer.'
Genesis 41:17 So Pharaoh recounted what he had seen, saying, 'I dreamt that I was standing on the bank of the Nile River.'
Genesis 41:18 'And suddenly, seven very beautiful and extremely well-fed cows came up out of the river. They grazed in the marshy places and remained standing near me.'
Genesis 41:19 'Then, seven other cows came up, thin and extremely scrawny, with dried-out hides. I have never seen such ugly cows in all the land of Egypt.'
Genesis 41:20 'These scrawny cows devoured and consumed the first, fat, and beautiful cows.'
Genesis 41:21 'Even after they had eaten them, there was no sign in their appearance that they had eaten at all; they remained as gaunt and scrawny as before. Then I woke up.'
Genesis 41:22 'And again, I saw another dream: Seven heads of grain, full and excellent, were growing on a single stalk.'
Genesis 41:23 'Then, seven other heads of grain grew up, thin and scorched by the east wind, producing only meager kernels.'
Genesis 41:24 'These thin heads of grain devoured the beauty of the first ones. I have told this to the magicians, but there is no one who can interpret it.'
Genesis 41:25 Joseph answered Pharaoh, 'Pharaoh's dreams are one and the same; God has revealed to Pharaoh what He is about to do.'
Genesis 41:26 'The seven beautiful cows and the seven full heads of grain represent seven years of abundant harvests. The interpretation of both dreams is the same.'
Genesis 41:27 'And the seven thin and scrawny cows that came up after them, as well as the seven thin heads of grain scorched by the east wind, represent seven years of famine that are coming.'
Genesis 41:28 'This is what I have told Pharaoh: God has shown you what is soon to happen.'
Genesis 41:29 'Behold, seven years are coming, years of great abundance throughout all the land of Egypt.'
Genesis 41:30 'These will be followed by seven other years of such severe famine that all the previous abundance in the land of Egypt will be completely forgotten. The famine will utterly consume the land.'
Genesis 41:31 'There will be no remaining sign of the former abundance because of the severity of the famine that follows, which will utterly consume the entire land.'
Genesis 41:32 'The fact that you saw the same matter in a second dream means that the word is firmly established by God, and He will swiftly bring it to pass.'
Genesis 41:33 'Therefore, let Pharaoh now find a wise and discerning man and appoint him over the land of Egypt.'
Genesis 41:34 'Let this man appoint overseers in every city to gather and store a fifth part of all the produce of the land of Egypt during the coming seven years of abundance.'
Genesis 41:35 'Let all the surplus grain, which will be sufficient for the five years of famine, be stored in the cities and kept securely.'
Genesis 41:36 'Let this grain be ready for the seven years of famine that will come upon Egypt, so that the land may not be ruined by scarcity.'
Genesis 41:37 Pharaoh and all his officials were pleased with this advice.
Genesis 41:38 Then Pharaoh said to his officials, 'Can we find anyone else like this man, in whom the Spirit of God is present?'
Genesis 41:39 So Pharaoh said to Joseph, 'Since God has shown you all that you have spoken, surely I will not be able to find anyone wiser or with such discernment as you.'
Genesis 41:40 'You shall be in charge of my household, and all my people will obey your every command. Only in the royal throne itself will I be greater than you.'
Genesis 42:1 Jacob saw that grain and food were being sold in Egypt. He asked his sons, "Why are you just sitting here doing nothing?"
Genesis 42:2 He continued, "I have heard that food is available for purchase in Egypt. Go down there and buy what we need to survive, so that we do not die of starvation."
Genesis 42:3 So ten of Joseph's brothers went down to Egypt to buy grain for themselves and their families.
Genesis 42:4 But Jacob did not want to send Benjamin, Joseph's younger brother, with his other brothers. He was afraid that something terrible might happen to him on the journey.
Genesis 42:5 The sons of Israel arrived in Egypt along with many others who had also come to buy food, because the land of Canaan was suffering greatly from the famine.
Genesis 42:6 Joseph, as it happened, was the governor of the entire land of Egypt, and he was the one selling grain to all the people. When his brothers came before him, they bowed down with their faces to the ground in reverence.
Genesis 42:7 Joseph saw them and immediately remembered the dreams he had once had about them. He spoke harshly to them, as if they were strangers, asking, "Where do you come from?" They replied, "From the land of Canaan, to buy necessities for life."
Genesis 42:8 Joseph recognized them, but they did not recognize him.
Genesis 42:9 He held them there for a short time and then said, "You are spies! You have come to find the vulnerable points of this land."
Genesis 42:10 But they answered him, "No, my lord, that is not true. Your servants have only come to buy food."
Genesis 42:11 "We are all the sons of one man; we are honest people. We have not come here to do any harm."
Genesis 42:12 Joseph said to them, "No! You have indeed come to discover the vulnerable parts of this land."
Genesis 42:13 They replied, "Your servants are twelve brothers, sons of one man in the land of Canaan. The youngest is currently with our father, and another brother is no longer with us."
Genesis 42:14 Joseph, testing them, said, "This confirms what I said: You are spies!"
Genesis 42:15 "By this method, you will be tested. I swear by the life of Pharaoh himself, you will not leave this place until your youngest brother comes here."
Genesis 42:16 "Send one of you back to bring him here. The rest of you will be kept imprisoned until what you have said can be proven true or false."
Genesis 42:17 And so he held them in custody for three days.
Genesis 42:18 On the third day, he brought them out of the prison and said to them, "Do this one thing, and you will live, for I fear God."
Genesis 42:19 "If you truly are honest people, then let one of your brothers be kept bound in the prison. The rest of you may go and take the grain you have purchased back to your homes."
Genesis 42:20 "Then bring your youngest brother to me so I can verify your claims. If you do this, you will not die." They did as he had instructed.
Genesis 42:21 They spoke to each other, saying, "We truly deserve to suffer this, because we sinned against our brother Joseph. We saw the distress of his soul when he pleaded with us, but we refused to listen to him. That is why this tribulation has come upon us now."
Genesis 42:22 Reuben said to them, "Did I not tell you, 'Do not sin against the boy'? But you would not listen to me! Now, surely, the price for his blood is being demanded of us."
Genesis 42:23 They did not know that Joseph understood everything they were saying, because he was speaking to them through an interpreter.
Genesis 42:24 Joseph turned away from them for a moment and wept. Then he turned back and spoke to them. He took Simeon and had him bound in chains right there in front of their eyes.
Genesis 42:25 Joseph then gave orders for their sacks to be filled with grain. He also commanded that each man's money be secretly returned to his sack and that they be given provisions for their journey. His servants did exactly as he instructed.
Genesis 42:26 So the brothers loaded the grain onto their donkeys and departed.
Genesis 42:27 As one of them opened his sack to feed his donkey at the lodging place, he saw his money right there at the mouth of the sack.
Genesis 42:28 He cried out to his brothers, "My money has been returned to me! Look, it is right here in my sack!" They were astonished and troubled, asking each other, "What is this that God has done to us?"
Genesis 42:29 When they arrived back to their father Jacob in the land of Canaan, they told him everything that had happened to them, saying:
Genesis 42:30 "The lord of the land spoke harshly to us and accused us of being spies in his territory."
Genesis 42:31 "We told him, 'We are honest men; we are not plotting against anyone.'"
Genesis 42:32 "We are twelve brothers, sons of one father. One of us is no longer living, and the youngest is currently with our father in the land of Canaan."
Genesis 42:33 "Then he said, 'By this I will prove that you are honest people: leave one of your brothers with me. Take the necessary food for your households and go on your way.'"
Genesis 42:34 "Then bring your youngest brother to me, so I can know that you are not spies. Then you can have your imprisoned brother back, and you will be free to trade in this land.'"
Genesis 42:35 As they were telling this, they emptied their sacks. And behold, each man found his own pouch of money inside his sack! They and their father were terrified when they saw this.
Genesis 42:36 Jacob cried out, "You have left me without my children! Joseph is no more, Simeon has been kept from me, and now you want to take Benjamin away! All these misfortunes have fallen upon me!"
Genesis 42:37 Reuben responded to him, "You may kill my two sons if I do not bring Benjamin back to you. Entrust him into my care, and I myself will bring him back."
Genesis 42:38 But Jacob insisted, "My son will not go down to Egypt with you. His brother Joseph is dead, and he is the only son of Rachel left to me. If any harm were to befall him on this journey you are making, you would bring my gray hairs down to the grave in sorrow."

Genesis 43:1 The famine continued to grow more severe in all the land.
Genesis 43:2 After they had eaten all the grain they had brought back from Egypt, Jacob told his sons, "Go back to Egypt and buy a little more food for us."
Genesis 43:3 Judah answered his father, "The man warned us with a solemn oath, saying, 'You will not see my face again unless your youngest brother is with you.'"
Genesis 43:4 "So if you are willing to send Benjamin with us, we will go down and buy food for you."
Genesis 43:5 "But if you refuse to send him, we will not go down, because, as we have told you many times, that man explicitly warned us, saying, 'You will not see my face unless your youngest brother is with you.'"
Genesis 43:6 Israel, also known as Jacob, said to them, "Why have you brought such trouble upon me by telling that man you had another son?"
Genesis 43:7 But they answered, "The man questioned us very carefully about our family lineage, asking if our father was still alive, and if we had another brother. We answered him exactly according to what he asked. How could we possibly know that he would demand, 'Bring your brother with you?'"
Genesis 43:8 Judah also said to his father, "Send the young man with me, so that we can leave right away. Then we can all live and not die of starvation—not only us, but also you and our little children."
Genesis 43:9 "I will guarantee the young man's safety. Hold me personally responsible for his life. If I do not bring him back to you and present him before you, then I will bear the guilt forever."
Genesis 43:10 "If we had not delayed so much, we could have already gone and come back a second time."
Genesis 43:11 So their father Israel said to them, "If it must be this way, then do what you must. Take some of the best produce of the land in your bags, and take a gift to the man: a little balm, a little honey, some gum tragacanth, some myrrh, some pistachios, and some almonds."
Genesis 43:12 "Also, take double the amount of money with you, and take back the money that you found in your sacks. Perhaps it was put there by mistake."
Genesis 43:13 "And take your brother Benjamin with you, and go back to the man."
Genesis 43:14 "May my all-powerful God grant you mercy before the man, and may he send back your other brother, whom he is holding, along with this Benjamin. As for me, I feel as though I am already bereaved and childless."
Genesis 43:15 So the men took the gifts, and double the money, and Benjamin. They set off for Egypt and stood before Joseph.
Genesis 43:16 When Joseph saw them with Benjamin, he instructed the steward of his house, saying, "Bring these men into the house. Slaughter an animal and prepare a feast, for they are to dine with me at noon."
Genesis 43:17 The steward did exactly as Joseph commanded him and brought the men into Joseph's house.
Genesis 43:18 But the men, once brought inside, were afraid. They said, "We have been brought in because of the money that was returned in our sacks the first time. They want to frame us and violently seize us, taking us and our donkeys as slaves."
Genesis 43:19 Therefore, they approached the steward of Joseph's house and spoke to him at the entrance.
Genesis 43:20 (Continuing from the previous verse) "O sir, we really did come down here the first time to buy food."
Genesis 43:21 "But when we returned to the inn and opened our sacks, we found each man's money right there at the mouth of his sack. We have now brought it back, exactly the same weight."
Genesis 43:22 "We have also brought other money with us to buy more food. We truly do not know who put the money in our sacks the first time."
Genesis 43:23 But the steward replied, "Peace be with you. Do not be afraid. Your God, and the God of your father, must have given you treasure in your sacks. I assure you, I received your money the first time." Then he brought Simeon out to them.
Genesis 43:24 After he had brought the men into the house, he brought water for them to wash their feet and provided fodder for their donkeys.
Genesis 43:25 They prepared their gifts until Joseph arrived at noon, for they had heard that they were to eat the meal there.
Genesis 43:26 When Joseph came into his house, they presented him with the gifts they held in their hands, and they bowed down before him, with their faces to the ground.
Genesis 43:27 He greeted them kindly and asked, "Is your aged father, whom you spoke of to me, well? Is he still alive?"
Genesis 43:28 They replied, "Your servant, our father, is well and still alive." Then they bowed down and prostrated themselves again before him.
Genesis 43:29 And Joseph, looking up, saw his brother Benjamin, his own mother's son, and asked, "Is this your youngest brother, about whom you told me?" Then he added, "May God be gracious to you, my son."
Genesis 43:30 Joseph hurried away and went into his private room, because his heart was deeply moved with tender affection for his brother, and he began to weep. He went into his chamber and wept there.
Genesis 43:31 After he had washed his face and composed himself, he came out and said, "Serve the food."
Genesis 43:32 They served Joseph by himself, and his brothers by themselves, and the Egyptians who ate with him by themselves—because Egyptians could not eat with Hebrews, as such a shared meal was considered detestable to the Egyptians.
Genesis 43:33 So the brothers were seated before Joseph, arranged from the eldest to the youngest. All of them were astonished, looking at each other in wonder.
Genesis 43:34 Joseph then had portions of food taken from his own table and given to them. Benjamin's portion was five times larger than any of the others. And they drank and feasted joyfully with him.
Genesis 44:1 Joseph then gave his house steward a command, saying: 'Fill their sacks with as much grain as they can carry, and put each man's money on top, in his sack.'
Genesis 44:2 'But my own silver cup, and the money for it, you are to put into the mouth of the youngest man’s sack.'
Genesis 44:3 When they woke up in the morning and loaded their donkeys, they left the city.
Genesis 44:4 Now, after they had gone a short distance, Joseph called his house steward and said: 'Get up and pursue those men! When you catch them, ask: Why have you repaid good with evil?'
Genesis 44:5 'The cup you have stolen is the one my master drinks from and uses for divination. You have done a very wicked thing.'
Genesis 44:6 The steward pursued them, caught up, and said all the words Joseph had commanded him.
Genesis 44:7 They replied: 'Why does our lord speak to his servants this way? Far be it from us to do such a thing!'
Genesis 44:8 'We brought back to you from the land of Canaan the money we found at the top of our sacks. How could we steal silver or gold from your master's house?'
Genesis 44:9 'If the cup is found with any of your servants, let that man die, and the rest of us will become your master's servants.'
Genesis 44:10 The steward replied: 'Let it be as you say. The man with whom it is found will become my servant, but you others will be innocent.'
Genesis 44:11 So they quickly lowered their sacks to the ground and each man opened his.
Genesis 44:12 The steward searched, starting with the oldest and going down to the youngest, and he found the cup in Benjamin’s sack.
Genesis 44:13 Immediately, they tore their clothes in grief, loaded their donkeys again, and returned to the city.
Genesis 44:14 So Judah and his brothers entered Joseph’s house while he was still there. They prostrated themselves before him on the ground.
Genesis 44:15 Joseph asked them: 'Why did you want to act this way? Do you not know that no one like me can divine what is hidden?'
Genesis 44:16 Judah replied: 'What can we say to our lord? What can we speak? Or how can we respond justly? God has found the iniquity of your servants. Look, all of us are now servants of our lord, both we and the man with whom the cup was found.'
Genesis 44:17 Joseph answered: 'Far be it from me to do that! The man who stole the cup, he alone will be my servant. But you others, go up freely to your father.'
Genesis 44:18 Then Judah approached him and said: 'Please, my lord, let your servant speak a word in your hearing, and do not be angry with your servant, for you are as powerful as Pharaoh himself.'
Genesis 44:19 'My lord asked us, saying: Do you have a father or a brother?'
Genesis 44:20 'And we answered him: We have an aged father, and a young boy born to him in his old age. His brother is dead, and he alone is left of his mother's children, and our father truly loves him.'
Genesis 44:21 'You also said to your servants: Bring him down to me, so I may look at him.'
Genesis 44:22 'We replied: The boy cannot leave his father. If he were to leave, his father would die.'
Genesis 44:23 'And you said to your servants: Unless your youngest brother comes with you, you will not see my face again.'
Genesis 44:24 'So when we went up to your servant, our father, we told him everything our lord had said.'
Genesis 44:25 'And our father said: Go back and buy us a little grain.'
Genesis 44:26 'To which we said: We cannot go. If our youngest brother comes down with us, then we will go together. Otherwise, without him, we do not dare to see the man’s face.'
Genesis 44:27 'To this our father replied: You yourselves know that I had two sons by my wife.'
Genesis 44:28 'One left, and you said: A wild beast devoured him. And until the present day, you do not know where he is.'
Genesis 44:29 'If you also take this one, and anything happens to him on the journey, you will bring my gray hairs down to the grave in sorrow.'
Genesis 44:30 'Therefore, if I go to your servant, our father, and the boy is not with me—whose very life is bound up with his father's—'
Genesis 44:31 'when he suddenly sees that the boy is not there, he will die. And your servants will bring his gray hairs down to the grave in sorrow.'
Genesis 44:32 'I myself guaranteed the boy's safety to my father, saying: If I do not bring him back to you, I will be guilty of sin against my father for all my days.'
Genesis 44:33 'Now therefore, I beg you, let your servant remain here as a servant in your place, instead of the boy, and let the boy go up with his brothers.'
Genesis 44:34 'For I cannot return to my father without the boy, lest I see the calamity that would overcome my father.'
Genesis 45:1 Joseph could no longer control his emotions in front of everyone present. So, he ordered everyone to leave, so that no outsider would be there when he spoke with his family.
Genesis 45:2 Then Joseph cried out loudly, weeping, and the Egyptians heard it, and all of Pharaoh’s household heard it.
Genesis 45:3 He said to his brothers, "I am Joseph. Is my father still alive?" But they could not answer him, because they were terrified.
Genesis 45:4 Then he said to his brothers, "Come closer to me." And when they came closer, he said, "I am Joseph, your brother, whom you sold into Egypt."
Genesis 45:5 Do not be distressed or blame yourselves for selling me into this region. God, in His divine plan, sent me ahead of you to preserve your lives.
Genesis 45:6 For it has been two years since the famine began in this land, and there are still five more years to come during which neither plowing nor harvesting will be possible.
Genesis 45:7 God sent me ahead of you so that you might be preserved on the earth, and that you might have food to keep yourselves alive.
Genesis 45:8 So it was not by your doing, but by God’s design, that I was sent here. He has made me like a father to Pharaoh, lord over his entire household, and ruler over all the land of Egypt.
Genesis 45:9 Hurry, go up to my father and tell him: 'Your son Joseph says this: God has made me lord over all the land of Egypt. Come down to me; do not delay!'
Genesis 45:10 You will live in the land of Goshen, and you will be near me—you, your children, your grandchildren, your sheep, your cattle, and everything you own.
Genesis 45:11 There I will provide for you (for there are still five years of famine ahead), so that you, your household, and everything you own will not suffer want.
Genesis 45:12 Behold, your own eyes, and the eyes of my brother Benjamin, see that it is my own mouth speaking to you.
Genesis 45:13 Tell my father of all my glory in Egypt, and everything you have seen. Hurry and bring him down to me.
Genesis 45:14 Then Joseph threw his arms around his brother Benjamin’s neck and wept; and Benjamin likewise wept upon his neck.
Genesis 45:15 Joseph then kissed all his brothers and wept over each one of them. After this, his brothers finally dared to speak with him.
Genesis 45:16 News spread quickly through Pharaoh’s palace that Joseph’s brothers had arrived, and Pharaoh and all his officials were very pleased.
Genesis 45:17 And Pharaoh said to Joseph, "Command your brothers to load their pack animals and set out for the land of Canaan."
Genesis 45:18 "Let them bring your father and all their relatives back here to me. I will give them all the best of Egypt, so they may enjoy the richness of the land."
Genesis 45:19 "Also command them to take wagons from the land of Egypt for themselves, their little ones, and their wives, and to bring your father quickly."
Genesis 45:20 "Do not worry about any of your belongings, because all the finest things in Egypt will be yours."
Genesis 45:21 The sons of Israel did as they were instructed. Joseph gave them wagons, according to Pharaoh’s command, and also provisions for their journey.
Genesis 45:22 To each of them, he also gave a set of new clothes. But to Benjamin, he gave three hundred pieces of silver and five sets of new clothes.
Genesis 45:23 He also sent his father ten donkeys loaded with the best products of Egypt, and ten female donkeys loaded with grain, bread, and other food supplies for his journey.
Genesis 45:24 So he sent his brothers away, and as they departed, he told them, "Do not quarrel on the journey."
Genesis 45:25 So they went up from Egypt and arrived in the land of Canaan, to their father Jacob.
Genesis 45:26 They told him, saying, "Joseph is alive! And he is the ruler over all the land of Egypt!" When Jacob heard this, it was as if he awoke from a deep sleep, and he did not believe them.
Genesis 45:27 But when they recounted all the words Joseph had spoken to them, and when he saw the wagons and all the supplies Joseph had sent, Jacob’s spirit was revived.
Genesis 45:28 And Jacob said, "It is enough! My son Joseph is still alive! I will go and see him before I die."

Genesis 46:1 So Israel set out with everything he owned. He came to the place called the Well of the Oath. There, he offered sacrifices and called upon the God of his father, Isaac.
Genesis 46:2 And God spoke to him through a vision at night, saying, 'Jacob! Jacob!' And he answered, 'Here I am.'
Genesis 46:3 God said to him, 'I am the Almighty God of your father. Do not be afraid to go down into Egypt, for there I will make you into a great nation.'
Genesis 46:4 I myself will go down with you into Egypt, and I will surely bring you back from there. And Joseph himself will be there to close your eyes when you die.'
Genesis 46:5 So Jacob rose up from the Well of the Oath. His sons then carried him, his children, and his wives in the wagons that Pharaoh had sent to transport the old man.
Genesis 46:6 They also took all the possessions he had acquired in the land of Canaan. So Jacob and all his offspring together came into Egypt.
Genesis 46:7 His sons, his grandsons, his daughters, and his granddaughters—all of his offspring he brought with him to Egypt.
Genesis 46:8 These are the names of the sons of Israel who went into Egypt: Jacob himself and his children. His firstborn was Reuben.
Genesis 46:9 The sons of Reuben were Hanoch, Pallu, Hezron, and Carmi.
Genesis 46:10 The sons of Simeon were Jemuel, Jamin, Ohad, Jachin, Zohar, and Shaul—who was the son of a Canaanite woman.
Genesis 46:11 The sons of Levi were Gershon, Kohath, and Merari.
Genesis 46:12 The sons of Judah were Er, Onan, Shelah, Perez, and Zerah. However, Er and Onan had died in the land of Canaan. The sons born to Perez were Hezron and Hamul.
Genesis 46:13 The sons of Issachar were Tola, Puah, Jashub, and Shimron.
Genesis 46:14 The sons of Zebulun were Sered, Elon, and Jahleel.
Genesis 46:15 These are the sons of Leah, whom she bore to Jacob in Mesopotamia of Syria, and Dinah was also his daughter. All the souls of males and females were thirty-three.
Genesis 46:16 The sons of Gad were Zephon, Haggi, Shuni, Ezbon, Eri, Arodi, and Areli.
Genesis 46:17 The sons of Asher were Imnah, Ishvah, Ishvi, and Beriah. Their sister was Serah. The sons of Beriah were Heber and Malchiel.
Genesis 46:18 These are the sons of Zilpah, whom Laban gave to his daughter Leah. And these Jacob bore to her, a total of sixteen souls.
Genesis 46:19 The sons of Rachel, Jacob's wife, were Joseph and Benjamin.
Genesis 46:20 And sons were born to Joseph in the land of Egypt, whom Asenath, the daughter of Potiphera, priest of Heliopolis, bore to him: Manasseh and Ephraim.
Genesis 46:21 The sons of Benjamin were Bela, Becher, Ashbel, Gera, Naaman, Ehi, Rosh, Muppim, Huppim, and Ard.
Genesis 46:22 These are the sons of Rachel, whom Jacob bore to her, all of them fourteen souls.
Genesis 46:23 The sons of Dan were Hushim.
Genesis 46:24 The sons of Naphtali were Jahzeel, Guni, Jezer, and Shillem.
Genesis 46:25 These are the sons of Bilhah, whom Laban gave to his daughter Rachel. And Jacob bore these to her, all of them seven souls.
Genesis 46:26 All the souls who entered Egypt with Jacob, those who came from his loins, excluding his sons' wives, were sixty-six in total.
Genesis 46:27 As for Joseph's sons, who were born to him in the land of Egypt, there were two souls. All the souls of Jacob's household who entered Egypt were seventy in total.
Genesis 46:28 Jacob sent Judah ahead of him to Joseph, to announce his coming and for Joseph to meet him in Goshen.
Genesis 46:29 Joseph then harnessed his chariot and went up to meet his father in Goshen. As soon as he saw him, he rushed to embrace him, and wept while holding him.
Genesis 46:30 And Israel said to Joseph, 'Now I will be glad to die, since I have seen your face, and I leave you alive and well.'
Genesis 46:31 Then Joseph said to his brothers and to all his father's household, 'I will go up and tell Pharaoh, and I will say to him: My brothers and my father's household, who were in the land of Canaan, have come to me.'
Genesis 46:32 And these men are shepherds of sheep; they are keepers of livestock. They have brought their flocks, their herds, and everything they possess with them.
Genesis 46:33 So when Pharaoh calls you and asks, 'What is your occupation?'
Genesis 46:34 You shall answer: 'Your servants have been shepherds from our youth until now, both we and our fathers.' You must say this so that you may dwell in the land of Goshen, because all shepherds are an abomination to the Egyptians.
Genesis 47:1 Joseph then arrived and informed Pharaoh, saying, "My father and my brothers, with their sheep, their herds, and all their possessions, have come from the land of Canaan. Look, they are now settled in the land of Goshen."
Genesis 47:2 And he presented five of his brothers before the king.
Genesis 47:3 Pharaoh asked them, "What is your work?" They answered, "Your servants are shepherds of sheep, both we and our fathers before us."
Genesis 47:4 They added, "We have come to live in your land, for your servants' flocks can find no pasture in Canaan because the famine is very severe. We therefore ask you to command your servants to settle in the land of Goshen."
Genesis 47:5 Pharaoh then said to Joseph, "Your father and your brothers have come to you."
Genesis 47:6 The land of Egypt is before you. Make them live in the very best area, and give them the land of Goshen. And if you know there are any capable men among them, appoint them as overseers of my own livestock.
Genesis 47:7 Joseph then brought his father Jacob and presented him before the king, and Jacob blessed Pharaoh.
Genesis 47:8 Pharaoh asked him, "How many are the days of the years of your life?"
Genesis 47:9 Jacob answered, "The days of my pilgrimage have been one hundred and thirty years. They have been few and difficult, and they have not reached the length of the years of my fathers' lives during which they sojourned."
Genesis 47:10 And blessing the king again, he departed.
Genesis 47:11 Joseph then gave his father and his brothers a possession in Egypt, in the very best places of the land, in the land of Rameses, just as Pharaoh had commanded.
Genesis 47:12 And he nourished them and his entire father's household, providing food for each one.
Genesis 47:13 In all the land, bread was lacking, and the famine prevailed throughout the world. Both Egypt and the land of Canaan were failing due to the scarcity of food.
Genesis 47:14 Joseph purchased all the money of the Egyptians and Canaanites from them in exchange for the grain they bought. And he gathered all that money into the king's treasury.
Genesis 47:15 When the money ran out, all the Egyptians came to Joseph, saying, "Give us food! Why should we die before you, now that our money has failed?"
Genesis 47:16 He replied to them, "Give your livestock, and I will give you food."
Genesis 47:17 So they brought their livestock to Joseph. And he gave them food in exchange for their horses, sheep, cattle, and donkeys. He sustained them for that entire year by exchanging their livestock for food.
Genesis 47:18 They came again in the second year, saying, "We cannot hide from our lord that, with our money exhausted and our livestock transferred to you, we have nothing left to offer except our bodies and our land."
Genesis 47:19 "Why should we die while you watch, both we and our land? Buy us and our land with food, and we and our fields will become servants of the king. Provide for us so that we can sow seed, and not die, nor our land become desolate."
Genesis 47:20 So Joseph bought all the land of Egypt, as each person sold their possessions because of the severity of the famine. And he made it subject to Pharaoh.
Genesis 47:21 And he moved all the people into the cities, from one end of Egypt to the other.
Genesis 47:22 The lands of the priests were exempt, for they had been given to them by the king. They also received a fixed allowance of food each year, and therefore they were not compelled to sell their possessions.
Genesis 47:23 Joseph then said to the people, "Look, as you see, Pharaoh has bought both you and your land. Take seeds for yourselves, and sow the fields."
Genesis 47:24 When you gather the harvest, you will give a fifth part to the king. The four remaining parts will be yours for seed, and for food for your families and your children.
Genesis 47:25 They answered, "Our salvation is in your hands. May our lord only look favorably upon us, and we will gladly serve the king."
Genesis 47:26 From that day until the present day, a fifth part is paid to the kings throughout all the land of Egypt, except for the land of the priests, which remained free.
Genesis 47:27 So Israel lived in Egypt, in the land of Goshen. And they took possession of it, increased, and multiplied greatly.
Genesis 47:28 And Jacob lived in the land of Egypt for seventeen years. So all the days of his life were one hundred and forty-seven years.
Genesis 47:29 As the time of his death drew near, he called his son Joseph and said to him, "If I have found favor in your sight, put your hand under my thigh, that you may show me kindness and fidelity, and not bury me in Egypt.
Genesis 47:30 But let me rest with my fathers, and carry me out of this land, and bury me in the tomb of my ancestors." Joseph answered him, "I will do as you have commanded."
Genesis 47:31 And Jacob said, "Swear to me." And Joseph swore to him. Then Israel, turning towards the head of his bed, worshipped God.
Genesis 48:1 After these things had happened, Joseph was told that his father, Jacob, was very ill. So he took his two sons, Manasseh and Ephraim, and went to see him.
Genesis 48:2 And it was announced to the old man, Jacob: 'Look, your son Joseph is coming to you!' And Jacob, strengthening himself, sat up in his bed.
Genesis 48:3 And Jacob said to Joseph: 'God Almighty appeared to me in Luz, which is in the land of Canaan, and blessed me,
Genesis 48:4 and said: 'I will make you fruitful and multiply you, and I will make you into a multitude of peoples. And I will give this land to you and to your descendants after you, as an eternal possession.'
Genesis 48:5 Now, your two sons who were born to you in the land of Egypt before I came to you here, they are counted as my own. Ephraim and Manasseh shall be mine, just as Reuben and Simeon are mine.
Genesis 48:6 But the rest of your children whom you have had after them shall be yours, and they will be named after their brothers in their inheritances.
Genesis 48:7 When I was returning from Mesopotamia, Rachel died beside me in the land of Canaan, on the journey itself, as I was coming to Ephrath. There was only a short distance left on the road to reach Bethlehem. Therefore, I buried her there.
Genesis 48:8 Now Jacob, seeing Joseph's sons, said: 'Who are these young men?'
Genesis 48:9 Joseph answered him: 'They are my sons, whom God has given me in this place.' And Jacob said: 'Bring them closer to me, so that I may bless them.'
Genesis 48:10 Now, Jacob's eyes were dim because of his old age, and he could not see clearly from a distance. So he brought them close to himself, kissed and embraced them.
Genesis 48:11 He said to Joseph: 'I thought I would never see your face again; but God has shown me even your descendants.'
Genesis 48:12 And when Joseph had moved his sons from their father's lap, he bowed down with his face to the ground.
Genesis 48:13 And Joseph took Ephraim in his right hand, to place him at Jacob's left, and Manasseh in his left hand, to place him at Jacob's right, and brought both of them close to his father.
Genesis 48:14 But Jacob, extending his right hand, placed it upon the head of Ephraim, the younger brother, and his left hand upon the head of Manasseh, the older brother, crossing his hands.
Genesis 48:15 And he blessed Joseph, and said: 'May God, in whose presence my fathers Abraham and Isaac walked, the God who has fed me from my youth until this very day, bless them:
Genesis 48:16 May the Angel who has redeemed me from all evils bless these boys. May my name be invoked upon them, and the names of my fathers, Abraham and Isaac, too. And may they grow into a multitude upon the earth.'
Genesis 48:17 Now when Joseph saw that his father had placed his right hand upon the head of Ephraim, he was displeased. So he took hold of his father's hand, wishing to move it from Ephraim's head to Manasseh's head,
Genesis 48:18 saying: 'Not like that, Father, because this one is the firstborn. Place your right hand upon his head.'
Genesis 48:19 But Jacob refused, saying: 'I know, my son, I know. He, Manasseh, will also become a people, and he will be multiplied. But his younger brother, Ephraim, will be greater than he, and his descendants will grow into a multitude of nations.'
Genesis 48:20 And he blessed them that day, saying: 'Through you, Israel will be blessed, and it will be said: 'May God make you like Ephraim and like Manasseh.'' And he placed Ephraim before Manasseh.
Genesis 48:21 Then Jacob said to Joseph: 'Behold, I am about to die. But God will be with you, and He will bring you back to the land of your fathers.'
Genesis 48:22 'Moreover, I am giving you one portion more than your brothers, which I took from the hand of the Amorite with my sword and with my bow.'
Genesis 49:1 Then Jacob called his sons to him, and he said to them: 'Gather around me, so I may tell you what will happen to you in the last days of history.'
Genesis 49:2 'Gather around me and listen, you sons of Jacob; listen to Israel your father.'
Genesis 49:3 'Reuben, my firstborn, you were my strength, the first fruit of my vigor, excelling in dignity and in power.'
Genesis 49:4 'You were unstable, poured out like water; you shall no longer excel, for you went up to your father’s bed and defiled my couch.'
Genesis 49:5 'Simeon and Levi are brothers, and their weapons are instruments of violence and injustice.'
Genesis 49:6 'May my soul never enter into their schemes, nor may my glory be united with their assembly, for in their rage, they killed men, and in their self-will, they destroyed walls (cities).'
Genesis 49:7 'Cursed be their anger, because it was fierce; and their indignation, because it was cruel. I will divide them throughout Jacob and disperse them within Israel.'
Genesis 49:8 'Judah, your brothers shall praise you: your hand shall be on the necks of your enemies; the sons of your father shall bow down to you.'
Genesis 49:9 'Judah is a lion's cub; you have gone up, my son, to seize the prey. You crouched down and lay like a lion, and like a lioness—who dares to rouse him?'
Genesis 49:10 'The scepter shall not be taken away from Judah, nor a ruler from his descendants, until He comes for whom it is reserved, and He shall be the expectation of the nations (the Messiah).'
Genesis 49:11 'He shall tie his donkey's colt to the vine, and his donkey to the choicest vine. He will wash his robes in wine, and his garments in the blood of grapes, signifying abundant prosperity.'
Genesis 49:12 'His eyes are brighter (more sparkling) than wine, and his teeth whiter than milk (signifying health and beauty).'
Genesis 49:13 'Zebulun shall dwell by the seashore; he shall be a haven for ships, and his border shall reach as far as Sidon.'
Genesis 49:14 'Issachar is a strong donkey, lying down between two burdens (or territories).'
Genesis 49:15 'He saw that rest was good, and that the land was pleasant, so he bowed his shoulder to bear burdens, and became a servant (of tribute).'
Genesis 49:16 'Dan shall judge his people, as one of the other tribes of Israel.'
Genesis 49:17 'May Dan be a serpent by the way, a viper in the path, that bites the horse's heels so that its rider falls backward, acting with cunning and surprise.'
Genesis 49:18 'I await your salvation, O Lord (a sudden prayer of Jacob).'
Genesis 49:19 'Gad, a troop shall press upon him (attack him), but he shall press upon their rear (or overcome them in the end).'
Genesis 49:20 'Asher, his bread shall be rich (or abundant and fertile), and he shall yield dainties (luxurious food) for kings.'
Genesis 49:21 'Naphtali is a swift deer (or a hind let loose), uttering beautiful words (or giving good tidings).'
Genesis 49:22 'Joseph is a fruitful son, a fruitful son by a spring, a beautiful young plant whose branches run over the wall (meaning his offspring will spread far).'
Genesis 49:23 'The archers provoked him, contended with him, and shot at him with bitter arrows (representing the malice of his enemies).'
Genesis 49:24 'But his bow remained strong, and the strength of his arms was made firm by the hands of the Mighty One of Jacob—from there came the Shepherd, the Stone of Israel (referring to God's protection of Joseph and a prophetic reference to Christ).'
Genesis 49:25 'The God of your father shall be your helper, and the Almighty shall bless you with blessings from the universe above (rain and dew), with blessings from the deep (springs and fertile ground) below, with blessings of the breasts and of the womb (fertility and numerous offspring).'
Genesis 49:26 'The blessings of your father are stronger than the blessings of my fathers (forefathers), reaching even to the desired summits of the everlasting hills (representing lasting and abundant prosperity).'
Genesis 49:27 'Benjamin is a ravenous wolf; in the morning, he devours the prey, and in the evening, he divides the spoils (indicating a warlike and fierce tribe).'
Genesis 49:28 'All these are the twelve tribes of Israel, and this is what their father spoke to them, blessing each one according to his own specific blessing (or prophecy).'
Genesis 49:29 And he charged them, saying: 'I am about to be gathered to my people (to die); bury me with my fathers in the double cave, which is in the field of Ephron the Hethite,'
Genesis 49:30 'near the cave that is in the field of Machpelah, opposite Mamre, in the land of Canaan, which Abraham purchased, along with the field, from the sons of Heth, as a burial possession (a place of rest for the family).'
Genesis 49:31 'There they buried Abraham and Sarah his wife; there they buried Isaac and Rebekah his wife; and there Leah was buried.'
Genesis 49:32 When he had finished giving instructions to his sons, he drew his feet up onto the bed, and he died, and was gathered to his people (his ancestors who had passed on).
Genesis 50:1 Joseph saw his father was dead, and he fell upon his father's face, weeping and kissing him.
Genesis 50:2 Then he ordered his servants, the physicians, to embalm his father with spices.
Genesis 50:3 After these orders, they completed the task. Forty days passed—this was the usual custom for embalmed bodies. And all of Egypt mourned for him for seventy days.
Genesis 50:4 When the mourning period was finished, Joseph spoke to Pharaoh’s household, saying, "If I have found favor in your eyes, please speak to Pharaoh on my behalf:
Genesis 50:5 My father made me swear, saying, 'I am about to die. In my tomb, which I dug for myself in the land of Canaan, there you will bury me.' Therefore, I ask to go up and bury my father, and then I will return."
Genesis 50:6 Pharaoh said to him, "Go up and bury your father, as you have sworn to him."
Genesis 50:7 So Joseph went up to bury his father. With him went all the elders of Pharaoh's household and all the leading elders of the land of Egypt,
Genesis 50:8 along with Joseph's household, his brothers, and all his relatives. Only their little children, their flocks, and their herds, which they had left in the land of Goshen, remained behind.
Genesis 50:9 They also had chariots and horsemen in their procession, and it was a very great company.
Genesis 50:10 When they came to the Threshing Floor of Atad, which is located beyond the Jordan, they celebrated the funeral rites with great and intense lamentation, observing seven days of mourning there.
Genesis 50:11 When the inhabitants of the land of Canaan saw the mourning at the Threshing Floor of Atad, they said, "This is a profound mourning for the Egyptians." For this reason, the place was named Planctus Aegypti, which means 'Mourning of the Egyptians'.
Genesis 50:12 Thus, Jacob’s sons did just as he had commanded them.
Genesis 50:13 They carried him into the land of Canaan and buried him in the cave of Machpelah, which Abraham had bought from Ephron the Hittite, along with the field, as a burial possession facing Mamre.
Genesis 50:14 After burying his father, Joseph returned to Egypt with his brothers and all the company that had gone with him.
Genesis 50:15 After their father's death, Joseph's brothers were afraid and said to one another, "What if Joseph still holds a grudge against us and repays us for all the harm we did to him?"
Genesis 50:16 So they sent a message to Joseph, saying, "Your father gave us this command before he died,
Genesis 50:17 'Please forgive your brothers' wickedness and the sin they committed against you.' It was indeed evil, but now we implore you to forgive this iniquity, for we are the servants of your father’s God." When he heard these words, Joseph wept.
Genesis 50:18 Then his brothers themselves came to him, prostrating themselves on the ground, and said, "We are your servants."
Genesis 50:19 Joseph answered them, "Do not be afraid. Am I in God’s place, to oppose His will?"
Genesis 50:20 You intended evil against me, but God turned it into good, so that He might exalt me as you see today, and save many people.
Genesis 50:21 Therefore, do not be afraid. I will provide for you and your little children." So he comforted them and spoke to them with kind words.
Genesis 50:22 So Joseph lived in Egypt, he and his father's household. He lived for one hundred and ten years.
Genesis 50:23 He lived to see Ephraim's children of the third generation. The children of Machir, Manasseh's son, were also born and received into Joseph's family.
Genesis 50:24 After these events, Joseph spoke to his brothers, saying, "After my death, God will certainly visit you and lead you out of this land to the land which He swore to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob."
Genesis 50:25 And he made them swear, saying, "When God visits you, make sure you carry my bones with you from this place."
Genesis 50:26 Then Joseph died, having completed the span of his life at one hundred and ten years old. And after he was embalmed with spices, he was placed in a sarcophagus in Egypt.
Exodus 1:1 These are the names of the sons of Israel who migrated into Egypt with Jacob, each one entering with his own household:
Exodus 1:2 Reuben, Simeon, Levi, Judah,
Exodus 1:3 Issachar, Zebulun, and Benjamin,
Exodus 1:4 Dan, Naphtali, Gad, and Asher.
Exodus 1:5 All the descendants who came forth from Jacob were seventy in number, counting Jacob himself; Joseph, however, was already residing in Egypt.
Exodus 1:6 And so Joseph died, and all of his brothers, and all that entire generation of his relatives passed away.
Exodus 1:7 But the sons of Israel grew greatly in numbers, multiplying like seeds sown in the earth; they filled the entire land of Egypt.
Exodus 1:8 In the meantime, a new king arose over Egypt, one who did not know or remember Joseph's contributions and legacy.
Exodus 1:9 He spoke to his own people, saying, 'Look, the nation of the sons of Israel is numerous, and they are becoming stronger than we are.'
Exodus 1:10 Come, let us deal cunningly with them, lest they multiply further, and if war breaks out against us, they might join our enemies, fight against us, and then depart from our land entirely.
Exodus 1:11 Therefore, the Egyptians appointed taskmasters over them to oppress the Israelites with heavy burdens. The Israelites then built storage cities for Pharaoh: Pithom and Raamses.
Exodus 1:12 But the more the Egyptians oppressed them, the more the Israelites multiplied and grew. This caused the Egyptians to despise the sons of Israel even more,
Exodus 1:13 and they afflicted them with harsh servitude in every kind of work.
Exodus 1:14 They made their lives bitter with hard labor in mortar and bricks, and with all types of forced labor in the fields, imposing every kind of heavy agricultural work upon them.
Exodus 1:15 Then the king of Egypt spoke to the Hebrew midwives—one of whom was named Shiphrah, and the other Puah—
Exodus 1:16 commanding them: 'When you attend to the Hebrew women in childbirth, and the time for delivery comes: if it is a son, you must kill him; but if it is a daughter, you may let her live.'
Exodus 1:17 However, the midwives feared God more than the king. They did not do as the king of Egypt commanded, but allowed the male children to live.
Exodus 1:18 So the king summoned the midwives and asked them, 'Why have you done this, allowing the male children to live?'
Exodus 1:19 They answered Pharaoh: 'The Hebrew women are not like the Egyptian women; they are strong and give birth quickly, and they have already delivered before we midwives can even arrive to assist them.'
Exodus 1:20 Therefore, God dealt kindly with the midwives and blessed them; and the people of Israel continued to increase and grew exceedingly strong.
Exodus 1:21 And because the midwives feared God, He built up their households and gave them families of their own.
Exodus 1:22 So Pharaoh then gave a command to all his people, saying, 'Every son who is born to the Hebrews, you must throw into the Nile River; but every daughter, you may let live.'
Exodus 2:1 A man from the tribe of Levi married a woman from the very same tribe of Levi.
Exodus 2:2 She conceived and bore a son. When she saw that he was a healthy and beautiful child, she hid him for three months.
Exodus 2:3 When she could no longer hide him, she took a basket made of reeds and waterproofed it with tar and pitch. She placed the baby in it and set it among the reeds by the bank of the river.
Exodus 2:4 And the baby's sister stood at a distance, watching to see what would happen to him.
Exodus 2:5 Then Pharaoh's daughter went down to bathe in the river, while her attendants walked along the river's bank. When she saw the basket among the reeds, she sent one of her servants to get it. When the basket was brought to her and opened, she saw the crying baby inside. She felt compassion for him and said, "This is one of the Hebrew children."
Exodus 2:6 Then the baby's sister spoke to Pharaoh's daughter, "Do you want me to go and call a Hebrew nurse for you, so she can nurse the baby for you?"
Exodus 2:7 Pharaoh's daughter replied, "Go." So the girl went and called the baby's mother.
Exodus 2:8 Pharaoh's daughter said to her, "Take this child and nurse him for me, and I will pay you your wages." So the woman took the child and nursed him.
Exodus 2:9 When the child had grown up, his mother gave him back to Pharaoh's daughter. She adopted him as her own son and named him Moses, explaining that she had drawn him out of the water.
Exodus 2:10 In those days, after a long time had passed, Moses went out to his people, the Hebrews. He saw their suffering and watched an Egyptian man striking one of his Hebrew kinsmen.
Exodus 2:11 He looked around carefully, and when he saw no one else was around, he struck down the Egyptian and buried him in the sand.
Exodus 2:12 The next day, when Moses went out again, he saw two Hebrew men quarreling. He said to the one who was in the wrong, "Why are you striking your fellow man?"
Exodus 2:13 The man replied, "Who appointed you a ruler and a judge over us? Do you mean to kill me as you killed the Egyptian yesterday?" Moses became afraid and said to himself, "How did this deed become known?"
Exodus 2:14 When Pharaoh heard this report, he sought to kill Moses. But Moses fled from Pharaoh's presence and settled in the land of Midian, sitting by a well.
Exodus 2:15 The priest of Midian had seven daughters. They came to draw water and fill the watering troughs to water their father's flock.
Exodus 2:16 Other shepherds would often come and drive them away from the well. But Moses rose to their defense, and after drawing water himself, he watered their sheep for them.
Exodus 2:17 When they returned to Reuel, their father, he asked them, "Why have you come back sooner than usual today?"
Exodus 2:18 They answered, "An Egyptian man rescued us from the shepherds and even drew water for us, then watered our sheep."
Exodus 2:19 Reuel said, "Where is he now? Why did you leave him there? Go and invite him to come eat a meal with us."
Exodus 2:20 So Moses agreed and swore to stay with Reuel. Reuel then gave Zipporah, his daughter, to be Moses' wife.
Exodus 2:21 She bore him a son, whom Moses named Gershom, explaining that he had been a sojourner in a foreign land.
Exodus 2:22 Later, she bore another son, whom Moses named Eliezer, saying, "For the God of my father has been my helper, and delivered me from Pharaoh's hand."
Exodus 2:23 After a very long time, the king of Egypt died. But the children of Israel continued to groan under their oppressive labor. They cried out, and their cry for help from their labor went up to God.
Exodus 2:24 God heard their groaning and remembered His solemn covenant that He had established with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.
Exodus 2:25 The Lord looked upon the children of Israel, and He truly acknowledged their plight.
Exodus 3:1 Moses was shepherding the sheep belonging to Jethro, his father-in-law, who was the priest of Midian. He led the flock deep into the desert and came to Horeb, the mountain of God.
Exodus 3:2 Then the Lord God appeared to him in a flame of fire coming out of the middle of a bush. Moses saw that the bush was burning with fire, yet it was not consumed or destroyed.
Exodus 3:3 And Moses said to himself: "I will go and see this great sight, to understand why the bush does not burn away."
Exodus 3:4 When the Lord saw that Moses was moving closer to investigate, God called to him from the middle of the bush, saying: "Moses, Moses!" And Moses answered: "Here I am."
Exodus 3:5 Then God said: "Do not come any closer here. Take off the sandals from your feet, for the place on which you are standing is holy ground."
Exodus 3:6 He continued: "I am the God of your father, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob." Moses covered his face because he did not dare to look directly at God.
Exodus 3:7 And the Lord God said: "I have clearly seen the suffering of my people in Egypt. I have heard their cry because of the harshness of those who are over them in their work. I know their pain,
Exodus 3:8 and so I have come down to deliver them from the power of the Egyptians and to lead them out of that land into a good and spacious land—a land flowing with milk and honey. This is the land of the Canaanites, Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites.
Exodus 3:9 The cry of the children of Israel has indeed reached me, and I have seen how the Egyptians oppress them.
Exodus 3:10 Therefore, come now, and I will send you to Pharaoh, so that you may lead my people, the children of Israel, out of Egypt.
Exodus 3:11 And Moses said to God: "Who am I, that I should go to Pharaoh and lead the children of Israel out of Egypt?"
Exodus 3:12 God said: "I will be with you. And this will be the sign that I have sent you: When you have led the people out of Egypt, you will offer sacrifice to God on this very mountain."
Exodus 3:13 Moses then said to God: "Look, when I go to the children of Israel and tell them, 'The God of your fathers has sent me to you,' and they ask me, 'What is His name?'—what shall I tell them?"
Exodus 3:14 God said to Moses: "I AM WHO I AM." He added: "Thus you shall say to the children of Israel: 'The One Who Is—has sent me to you.'"
Exodus 3:15 God also said to Moses: "Thus you shall say to the children of Israel: 'The Lord God of your fathers, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob, has sent me to you.' This is My name forever, and this is My memorial to all generations.
Exodus 3:16 Go and gather the elders of Israel. Tell them: 'The Lord God of your fathers, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob, has appeared to me, saying: I have indeed visited you and seen everything that has happened to you in Egypt.
Exodus 3:17 And I have said that I will lead you out of the afflictions of Egypt into the land of the Canaanites, Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites—a land flowing with milk and honey.'
Exodus 3:18 They will listen to your voice. Then you and the elders of Israel shall go to the king of Egypt and tell him: 'The Lord God of the Hebrews has summoned us. Let us go on a journey of three days into the wilderness, so that we may offer sacrifice to the Lord our God.'
Exodus 3:19 But I know that the king of Egypt will not let you go, unless it is by a mighty hand.
Exodus 3:20 For I will stretch out My hand and strike Egypt with all My wonders, which I will perform in their midst. And after these things, he will let you go.
Exodus 3:21 I will give this people favor in the sight of the Egyptians, so that when you depart, you will not leave empty-handed.
Exodus 3:22 Instead, you will plunder the Egyptians. You will take from them silver articles and gold articles, and clothing. You will put these upon your sons and your daughters, and thus you will strip Egypt of its riches.
Exodus 4:1 Moses answered the Lord, saying: "They will not believe me, nor will they listen to what I say. Instead, they will insist: 'The Lord never appeared to you.'"
Exodus 4:2 The Lord then asked Moses: "What is that you are holding in your hand?" Moses answered: "A staff."
Exodus 4:3 And the Lord said: "Throw it on the ground." Moses threw it down, and it turned into a serpent. Moses immediately fled from it.
Exodus 4:4 Then the Lord said: "Reach out your hand and grasp its tail." Moses stretched out his hand, seized it, and held it. The serpent then returned to being a staff in his hand.
Exodus 4:5 The Lord said: "Do this so that they may believe that the Lord, the God of their fathers—the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob—has truly appeared to you."
Exodus 4:6 The Lord spoke again, saying: "Now, put your hand inside your cloak." When Moses placed his hand inside, he pulled it out, and it was leprous, white as snow.
Exodus 4:7 And He said: "Put your hand back into your cloak." Moses put it back, and when he drew it out of his cloak, it was restored, just like his other flesh.
Exodus 4:8 The Lord said: "If they do not believe you, nor listen to the message of the first sign, they will then believe the message of the second sign."
Exodus 4:9 "But if they do not believe even these two signs, nor listen to your voice, then take water from the river and pour it on the dry ground. What you draw from the river will turn into blood."
Exodus 4:10 Moses said: "Oh, please, Lord! I am not an eloquent speaker. I haven't been from yesterday, nor the day before, and not even since you began speaking to your servant. I am slow of speech and tongue."
Exodus 4:11 The Lord said to him: "Who gave humans their mouths? Or who made them mute or deaf, or able to see or blind? Was it not I, the Lord?"
Exodus 4:12 "Now, go! I will be with your mouth and will teach you what you are to say."
Exodus 4:13 But Moses replied: "Oh, please, Lord! Send someone else to whom you intend to send."
Exodus 4:14 The Lord became angry with Moses and said: "Is not Aaron, your brother, a Levite? I know that he is eloquent. Look, he is coming out to meet you, and when he sees you, he will be glad."
Exodus 4:15 "Speak to him, and put my words in his mouth. I will be with your mouth and with his mouth, and I will show both of you what you must do."
Exodus 4:16 "He will speak for you to the people, and he will be your mouth. You, in turn, will be like God for him, guiding him in what pertains to God."
Exodus 4:17 "Also, take this staff in your hand, with which you will perform the miraculous signs."
Exodus 4:18 Moses went and returned to Jethro, his father-in-law, and said to him: "I need to go back to my brothers in Egypt to see if they are still alive." Jethro said to him: "Go in peace."
Exodus 4:19 The Lord then said to Moses in Midian: "Go, and return to Egypt, for all those who sought to kill you are dead."
Exodus 4:20 So Moses took his wife and his sons and set them upon a donkey. He returned to Egypt, carrying the staff of God in his hand.
Exodus 4:21 And the Lord said to Moses: "When you return to Egypt, be sure to perform all the wonders that I have put in your power before Pharaoh. However, I will harden his heart, and he will not let the people go."
Exodus 4:22 "And you shall say to him: 'Thus says the Lord: Israel is My firstborn son.'"
Exodus 4:23 "'Let My son go, so that he may serve Me. If you refuse to let him go, behold, I will kill your firstborn son.'"
Exodus 4:24 It came to pass on the way, at a lodging place, that the Lord met Moses and intended to kill him.
Exodus 4:25 Immediately, Zipporah took a sharp flint knife and circumcised the foreskin of her son. She then touched Moses' feet with it and said: "You are a bridegroom of blood to me."
Exodus 4:26 So the Lord departed from him. For after she spoke the words "bridegroom of blood," the Lord immediately let him go.
Exodus 4:27 And the Lord said to Aaron: "Go into the desert to meet Moses." So Aaron went, and he met him at the mountain of God and kissed him.
Exodus 4:28 And Moses told Aaron all the words of the Lord with which He had sent him, and all about the miraculous signs which He had commanded him to perform.
Exodus 4:29 So Moses and Aaron went and gathered all the elders of the children of Israel.
Exodus 4:30 And Aaron spoke all the words that the Lord had said to Moses, and he performed the miraculous signs before the people.
Exodus 4:31 And the people believed. They heard that the Lord had visited the children of Israel and had seen their affliction, and they bowed down and worshipped.
Exodus 5:1 After these events, Moses and Aaron came and spoke to Pharaoh, saying, "The Lord, the God of Israel, says this: Release my people, so they may offer a sacrifice to me in the desert."
Exodus 5:2 But Pharaoh replied, "Who is the Lord that I should listen to His voice and release Israel? I do not know the Lord, and I will not release Israel."
Exodus 5:3 Moses and Aaron said to him, "The God of the Hebrews has called upon us to go a three-day journey into the desert, to offer sacrifice to the Lord our God. We must do this, lest He strike us with plague or with the sword."
Exodus 5:4 Pharaoh replied to them, "Why, Moses and Aaron, do you distract the people from their labors? Go back to your own burdens."
Exodus 5:5 Pharaoh then said, "Look, the people of the land are numerous, as you can see. Think how much worse it will be if they stop working."
Exodus 5:6 Therefore, on that very day, Pharaoh commanded the taskmasters over the people and their foremen, saying:
Exodus 5:7 "You will no longer give straw to the people for making bricks, as you did before. Instead, they must go and gather straw for themselves."
Exodus 5:8 "And you will impose upon them the same quota of bricks that they previously made; you are not to reduce it in any way. For they are idle, and because of this, they cry out, saying, 'Let us go and offer sacrifice to our God.'"
Exodus 5:9 "Let the men's work be made heavier, and let them complete it; and let them not pay attention to false words."
Exodus 5:10 So the taskmasters and foremen went out to the people and said, "Thus says Pharaoh: I will not give you straw."
Exodus 5:11 "Go yourselves and gather straw wherever you can find it. Nevertheless, your quota of the former work will not be reduced at all."
Exodus 5:12 So the people were scattered throughout all the land of Egypt to gather straw.
Exodus 5:13 And the taskmasters urged them on, saying, "Complete your daily work, just as before, when you were given straw."
Exodus 5:14 So the foremen of the sons of Israel, whom Pharaoh's taskmasters had appointed over them, were beaten. The taskmasters asked them, "Why have you not completed the required number of bricks today, just as yesterday and the day before yesterday?"
