Numbers 1:19 just as the Lord had commanded them to do. This census took place in the desert of Sinai.
Numbers 1:20 From the tribe of Reuben, Israel's firstborn son, the count was taken. They were enumerated by their lineages and families, by their ancestral households, and by the names of each head. All the males who were twenty years old and older, capable of going out to war,
Numbers 1:21 numbered forty-six thousand five hundred.
Numbers 1:22 From the sons of Simeon, enumerated by their lineages and families, by their ancestral households, and by the names of each head. All the males who were twenty years old and older, capable of going out to war,
Numbers 1:23 numbered fifty-nine thousand three hundred.
Numbers 1:24 From the sons of Gad, enumerated by their lineages and families, by their ancestral households, and by the names of each individual. All those who were twenty years old and older, capable of going out to war,
Numbers 1:25 numbered forty-five thousand six hundred and fifty.
Numbers 1:26 From the sons of Judah, enumerated by their lineages and families, by their ancestral households, and by the names of each individual. All those who were twenty years old and older, capable of going out to war,
Numbers 1:27 numbered seventy-four thousand six hundred.
Numbers 1:28 From the sons of Issachar, enumerated by their lineages and families, by their ancestral households, and by the names of each individual. All those who were twenty years old and older, capable of going out to war,
Numbers 1:29 numbered fifty-four thousand five hundred.
Numbers 1:30 From the sons of Zebulon, enumerated by their lineages and families, by their ancestral households, and by the names of each individual. All those who were twenty years old and older, capable of going out to war,
Numbers 1:31 numbered fifty-seven thousand four hundred.
Numbers 1:32 From the sons of Joseph—specifically from the sons of Ephraim—enumerated by their lineages and families, by their ancestral households, and by the names of each individual. All those who were twenty years old and older, capable of going out to war,
Numbers 1:33 numbered forty thousand five hundred.
Numbers 1:34 From the sons of Manasseh, enumerated by their lineages and families, by their ancestral households, and by the names of each individual. All those who were twenty years old and older, capable of going out to war,
Numbers 1:35 numbered thirty-two thousand two hundred.
Numbers 1:36 From the sons of Benjamin, enumerated by their lineages and families, by their ancestral households, and by the names of each individual. All those who were twenty years old and older, capable of going out to war,
Numbers 1:37 numbered thirty-five thousand four hundred.
Numbers 1:38 From the sons of Dan, enumerated by their lineages and families, by their ancestral households, and by the names of each individual. All those who were twenty years old and older, capable of going out to war,
Numbers 1:39 numbered sixty-two thousand seven hundred.
Numbers 1:40 From the sons of Asher, enumerated by their lineages and families, by their ancestral households, and by the names of each individual. All those who were twenty years old and older, capable of going out to war,
Numbers 2:1 And the Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron, giving them instructions:
Numbers 2:2 The sons of Israel are to set up their tents, each man in his own camp, divided by their regiments and under their own tribal banners. These camps are to be arranged all around the tabernacle of the covenant, facing it.
Numbers 2:3 On the eastern side, towards the sunrise, the tribe of Judah shall pitch their camp, organized by their own divisions. The leader of the sons of Judah will be Nahshon, the son of Amminadab.
Numbers 2:4 The total count of all the fighting men from his tribe was seventy-four thousand six hundred.
Numbers 2:5 Immediately next to them, the tribe of Issachar shall pitch their tents. Their leader is Nathanael, the son of Zuar.
Numbers 2:6 The total count of all the fighting men from his tribe was fifty-four thousand four hundred.
Numbers 2:7 Next to these camps will be the tribe of Zebulun. Their leader is Eliab, the son of Helon.
Numbers 2:8 The total count of all the fighting men from his tribe was fifty-seven thousand four hundred.
Numbers 2:9 The total number counted in the camp of Judah—which includes Judah, Issachar, and Zebulun—was one hundred eighty-six thousand four hundred fighting men, all organized by their divisions. These are the first groups that will set out when the camp moves.
Numbers 2:10 To the south, the camp of the sons of Reuben will be stationed. Their leader is Elizur, the son of Shedeur.
Numbers 2:11 The total count of all the fighting men from his tribe was forty-six thousand five hundred.
Numbers 2:12 Immediately next to them, the tribe of Simeon shall pitch their tents. Their leader is Shelumiel, the son of Zurishaddai.
Numbers 2:13 The total count of all the fighting men from his tribe was fifty-nine thousand three hundred.
Numbers 2:14 Next to these camps will be the tribe of Gad. Their leader is Eliasaph, the son of Deuel.
Numbers 2:15 The total count of all the fighting men from his tribe was forty-five thousand six hundred fifty.
Numbers 2:16 The total number counted in the camp of Reuben—which includes Reuben, Simeon, and Gad—was one hundred fifty-one thousand four hundred fifty fighting men, all organized by their divisions. These are the second groups that will set out when the camp moves.
Numbers 2:17 Then the tabernacle of the covenant will move, along with the camp of the Levites, who are responsible for it. The Levites' camp will be positioned in the very center of all the other tribes' camps. Just as they carefully set up their camps, so too they will carefully take them down, each individual following their specific place and designated order.
Numbers 2:18 To the west, the camp of Ephraim will be stationed. Their leader is Elishama, the son of Ammihud.
Numbers 2:19 The total count of all the fighting men from his tribe was forty thousand five hundred.
Numbers 2:20 Immediately next to them, the tribe of Manasseh shall pitch their tents. Their leader is Gamaliel, the son of Pedahzur.
Numbers 2:21 The total count of all the fighting men from his tribe was thirty-two thousand two hundred.
Numbers 2:22 Next to these camps will be the tribe of Benjamin. Their leader is Abidan, the son of Gideon.
Numbers 2:23 The total count of all the fighting men from his tribe was thirty-five thousand four hundred.
Numbers 2:24 The total number counted in the camp of Ephraim—which includes Ephraim, Manasseh, and Benjamin—was one hundred eight thousand one hundred fighting men, all organized by their divisions. These are the third groups that will set out when the camp moves.
Numbers 2:25 To the north, the camp of Dan will be stationed. Their leader is Ahiezer, the son of Ammishaddai.
Numbers 2:26 The total count of all the fighting men from his tribe was sixty-two thousand seven hundred.
Numbers 2:27 Immediately next to them, the tribe of Asher shall pitch their tents. Their leader is Pagiel, the son of Ocran.
Numbers 2:28 The total count of all the fighting men from his tribe was forty-one thousand five hundred.
Numbers 2:29 Next to these camps will be the tribe of Naphtali. Their leader is Ahira, the son of Enan.
Numbers 2:30 The total count of all the fighting men from his tribe was fifty-three thousand four hundred.
Numbers 2:31 The total number counted in the camp of Dan—which includes Dan, Asher, and Naphtali—was one hundred fifty-seven thousand six hundred fighting men, all organized by their divisions. These are the last groups that will set out when the camp moves.
Numbers 2:32 This is the grand total of the sons of Israel who were numbered and organized by their armies: six hundred three thousand five hundred fifty fighting men.
Numbers 2:33 However, the Levites were not counted among the fighting men of the sons of Israel, just as the Lord had commanded.
Numbers 2:34 Therefore, the sons of Israel did everything exactly as the Lord had commanded Moses. This is how they pitched their tents for camp, and this is how they marched out, each group organized by their divisions, families, and households.
Numbers 3:1 These are the priestly lineages of Aaron, and these are the descendants of Moses. These records begin from the day the Lord spoke to Moses on Mount Sinai.
Numbers 3:2 These are the names of Aaron’s sons: Nadab, his firstborn, then Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.
Numbers 3:3 These are the names of Aaron’s sons, who were consecrated as priests. Their hands were formally initiated for the sacred office, so they could carry out the duties of the priesthood.
Numbers 3:4 Nadab and Abihu, however, died when they offered unauthorized fire before the Lord in the desert of Sinai. They died without leaving any children. Therefore, Eleazar and Ithamar carried out the priestly duties in the presence of their father, Aaron.
Numbers 3:5 And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying:
Numbers 3:6 Bring forward the tribe of Levi. Place them before Aaron the priest, so they can assist him and attend to the duties that pertain to worship.
Numbers 3:7 They must also guard the sacred vessels of the Tabernacle of the Testimony and everything pertaining to the ceremonies, to serve the children of Israel.
Numbers 3:8 They will be responsible for all the duties related to the worship in the Tabernacle, and for the service of the children of Israel.
Numbers 3:9 You are to assign the Levites to Aaron and his sons, so they can assist them in their service.
Numbers 3:10 But Aaron and his sons, you shall appoint them to oversee all the sacred duties of the priesthood. Any outsider who approaches to perform these duties will be put to death.
Numbers 3:11 And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying:
Numbers 3:12 Behold, I have chosen the Levites from among the children of Israel, in place of every firstborn male who opens the womb among the children of Israel. So the Levites shall be considered mine.
Numbers 3:13 For every firstborn belongs to me. From the day I struck down all the firstborn in the land of Egypt, I consecrated for myself everything firstborn in Israel, from man to beast. They are mine. I am the Lord.
Numbers 3:14 And the Lord spoke to Moses in the desert of Sinai, saying:
Numbers 3:15 Count the sons of Levi according to their ancestral households and families. Count every male from one month old and upward.
Numbers 3:16 So Moses counted the sons of Levi, just as he had been commanded.
Numbers 3:17 These were the sons of Levi, by their names: Gershon, Kohath, and Merari.
Numbers 3:18 The sons of Gershon were Libni and Shimei.
Numbers 3:19 The sons of Kohath were Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel.
Numbers 3:20 The sons of Merari were Mahli and Mushi. These are the clans of Levi according to their households and families.
Numbers 3:21 From Gershon came the clans of Libni and Shimei; these are the families of the Gershonites.
Numbers 3:22 Those counted among the males, from one month old and upward, numbered seven thousand five hundred.
Numbers 3:23 These Gershonites would pitch their tents behind the Tabernacle, to the west.
Numbers 3:24 The chief of the Gershonite households was Eliasaph, son of Lael.
Numbers 3:25 Their responsibilities included guarding the Tabernacle of the Covenant, its covering, and the curtains that are at the entrance of the Tabernacle of the Covenant.
Numbers 3:26 Also, the curtains of the courtyard, and the curtain at the entrance of the courtyard of the Tabernacle, all that pertains to the altar, the ropes of the Tabernacle, and all the vessels of its furnishings.
Numbers 3:27 From Kohath came the clans of the Amramites, the Izharites, the Hebronites, and the Uzzielites. These are the Kohathite families according to their clans.
Numbers 3:28 All the males counted, from one month old and upward, numbered eight thousand six hundred. Their specific duty was the care of the sanctuary.
Numbers 3:29 The sons of Kohath would pitch their tents on the south side of the Tabernacle.
Numbers 3:30 The chief of the Kohathite households was Elizaphan, son of Uzziel.
Numbers 3:31 Under their care were the Ark, the table of showbread, the lampstand, the altars, the vessels of the sanctuary used for ministry, and the veil (separating the Holy Place from the Holy of Holies).
Numbers 3:32 And the chief of all the Levitical chiefs was Eleazar, son of Aaron the priest. He had oversight over those who were responsible for the sanctuary’s care.
Numbers 3:33 From Merari came the clans of the Mahlites and the Mushites. These are the Merarite families according to their clans.
Numbers 3:34 Those counted among the males, from one month old and upward, numbered six thousand two hundred.
Numbers 3:35 The chief of the Merarite households was Zuriel, son of Abihail. These would pitch their tents to the north of the Tabernacle.
Numbers 3:36 Under their care were the frames of the Tabernacle, its bars, its pillars, its bases, and all its associated vessels and furnishings.
Numbers 3:37 Also the pillars of the courtyard all around with their bases, their tent pegs, and their ropes.
Numbers 3:38 Moses and Aaron, and the males from the priestly lineage of Kohath (Aaron’s sons), made their camp before the Tabernacle, that is, to the east. They guarded the sacred ceremonies of the sanctuary on behalf of the children of Israel.
Numbers 3:39 All the Levite males, whom Moses and Aaron counted according to the word of the Lord, by their families, from one month old and upward, numbered twenty-two thousand.
Numbers 3:40 And the Lord said to Moses: 'Count all the firstborn males among the children of Israel, from one month old and upward, and you will have the total number of them.'
Numbers 4:2 Take a census of the sons of Kohath from among the Levites, according to their families and their ancestral houses,
Numbers 4:3 Count all those from thirty years old and above, up to fifty years old, who are qualified to enter and perform sacred service in the Tabernacle of the Covenant.
Numbers 4:4 This, then, is the sacred duty of the sons of Kohath regarding the Tabernacle of the Covenant: the Holy of Holies.
Numbers 4:5 Aaron and his sons shall enter when the camp is to move. They will take down the veil that is before the entrance, and with it, they will cover the Ark of the Testimony.
Numbers 4:6 On top of the Ark, they will place a covering of blue material, and then they will put the carrying poles through its rings.
Numbers 4:7 They will also cover the table of the showbread—and its items, and its offerings, and its cups, and its bowls for pouring libations—with a blue cloth.
Numbers 4:8 And over that, they will spread a scarlet covering, which they will then cover with a protective covering of blue skins. Then they will insert its carrying poles.
Numbers 4:9 They will also take the lampstand for the lights, along with its lamps, its snuffers, its trays for wicks, and all its oil vessels, which pertain to its sacred service.
Numbers 4:10 They will wrap all these items together in a blue covering and place them on a cart.
Numbers 4:11 The golden altar, and the garment with which it is covered during divine service, and the anointing oil, and the incense of composition, and all the vessels that pertain to its ritual,
Numbers 4:12 they will wrap in blue coverings and place on the cart.
Numbers 4:13 They will remove the ashes from the altar and then cover it with a purple garment.
Numbers 4:14 And they will place over it all the items used in its service: specifically, the fire pans, the meat forks, the three-pronged hooks, the shovels, and the fire baskets. They will cover all the altar's vessels together with a protective covering of blue skins, and then they will insert the carrying poles.
Numbers 4:15 Once Aaron and his sons have finished covering the sanctuary and all its items, as the camp journeys are completed, then the sons of Kohath will enter to carry them. However, they must not touch the items of the sanctuary directly, lest they die. These are the burdens of the sons of Kohath regarding the Tabernacle of the Covenant.
Numbers 4:16 The duty of Eleazar, son of Aaron the priest, includes the care of the oil for the lamps, and the incense of composition, and the perpetual sacrifice, and the anointing oil. He is responsible for all things within the Tabernacle and all the vessels of the sanctuary.
Numbers 4:17 And the Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron, saying:
Numbers 4:18 Do not allow the multitude of the clan of Kohath to perish from among the Levites.
Numbers 4:19 Instead, do this for them, so that they may live and not die when they approach the Holy of Holies. Let Aaron and his sons go in and assign each one to his specific sacred service and to his various burdens.
Numbers 4:20 They must not enter to see the sacred things that are properly arranged in the sanctuary, lest they die.
Numbers 4:21 And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying:
Numbers 4:22 Take a census of the sons of Gershon also, according to their ancestral houses and their families.
Numbers 4:23 Count all those from thirty years old and above, up to fifty years old, who are qualified to enter and perform sacred service in the Tabernacle of the Covenant.
Numbers 4:24 This is the duty of the families of the Gershonites: to carry and guard the following:
Numbers 4:25 the curtains of the Tabernacle, and the Tabernacle of the Covenant itself, the covering for it, and the outer blue protective covering which is placed on top of it,
Numbers 4:26 and the hangings for the courtyard, and the curtain for its entrance, and the ropes all around, and whatever pertains to its use and sacred service.
Numbers 4:27 According to the command of Aaron and his sons, the sons of Gershon shall carry and perform sacred service in all these matters. They are not permitted to carry any burden that has not been commanded.
Numbers 4:28 This is the duty of the families of the Gershonites in the Tabernacle of the Covenant, and their chief is Eleazar, the son of Aaron the priest.
Numbers 4:29 You shall also enumerate the sons of Merari according to their families and their ancestral houses.
Numbers 4:30 Count all those from thirty years old and above, up to fifty years old, all who are qualified to enter and perform sacred service in the Tabernacle of the Covenant.
Numbers 4:31 These are their burdens: the boards of the Tabernacle, and its carrying bars, and its pillars with their bases,
Numbers 4:32 and the pillars of the courtyard all around with their bases, and the pegs, and the ropes. All these vessels and utensils shall be delivered by name—meaning, each item will be specifically assigned for carrying.
Numbers 4:33 This is the duty of the families of the Merarites and their sacred service in the Tabernacle of the Covenant. Their chief is Ithamar, the son of Aaron the priest.
Numbers 4:34 So Moses and Aaron and the leaders of the assembly took a census of the sons of Kohath, according to their families and their ancestral houses,
Numbers 4:35 counting all those from thirty years old and above, up to fifty years old, who are qualified to enter into the sacred service of the Tabernacle of the Covenant.
Numbers 4:36 And those found by number, according to their families, were two thousand seven hundred fifty.
Numbers 4:37 This is the number of the families of the Kohathites, all who perform sacred service in the Tabernacle of the Covenant, whom Moses and Aaron enumerated according to the command of the Lord through Moses.
Numbers 4:38 The sons of Gershon were also enumerated according to their families and their ancestral houses,
Numbers 4:39 counting all those from thirty years old and above, up to fifty years old, all who are qualified to enter and perform sacred service in the Tabernacle of the Covenant.
Numbers 4:40 And those found by number, according to their families and their ancestral houses, were two thousand six hundred thirty.
Numbers 5:1 The Lord spoke to Moses, saying:
Numbers 5:2 “Command the children of Israel to remove from their camp everyone who has a serious skin disease, everyone who has an uncontrolled discharge of fluids, and everyone who has become ritually defiled by touching a dead body.”
Numbers 5:3 “You must remove both men and women from the camp. This is so they will not ritually defile their camp, since I Myself dwell among them.”
Numbers 5:4 The children of Israel did exactly this; they expelled those people from the camp, just as the Lord had commanded Moses.
Numbers 5:5 The Lord spoke to Moses, saying:
Numbers 5:6 “Speak to the children of Israel: When a man or a woman commits any of the sins that people commonly commit, and thereby acts unfaithfully against the Lord, that person is guilty.
Numbers 5:7 They must confess the sin they committed. They must repay in full what they took through their wrongdoing, adding a fifth part (20%) to it, and give it to the person they wronged.”
Numbers 5:8 “But if there is no close relative to receive the repayment, then the payment that is owed must be given to the Lord, and it will belong to the priest, in addition to the ram of atonement offered for that specific offense.”
Numbers 5:9 “Every contribution of sacred offerings that the children of Israel bring to the priest will belong to him.
Numbers 5:10 And whatever anyone offers, it will be for the priest. Indeed, if anyone gives something to the priest, all of it will belong to him.”
Numbers 5:11 The Lord spoke to Moses, saying:
Numbers 5:12 “Speak to the children of Israel, and say to them: If a man’s wife has gone away from him and been intimate with another man,
Numbers 5:13 and her husband cannot know about it because the adultery was kept secret and hidden, and there is no witness, and she has not been caught in the act:
Numbers 5:14 but a spirit of jealousy and contention comes upon the husband, and he suspects his wife, whether she has actually been defiled or not:
Numbers 5:15 then the man must bring his wife to the priest, and he must bring an offering for her: a tenth of an ephah of barley flour. He must not pour oil on it nor put frankincense on it, because it is an offering of jealousy, and an offering for a transgression, intended to bring the adultery to light.”
Numbers 5:16 “So the priest will take her and present her before the Lord.
Numbers 5:17 The priest will take holy water in an earthenware vessel and put a little dust from the floor of the tabernacle into it.”
Numbers 5:18 “When the priest has presented the woman before the Lord, he will uncover her head and place the offering of remembrance — the offering of jealousy — upon her hands. The priest himself will hold in his hand the bitter waters, which bring a curse.
Numbers 5:19 Then the priest will make her swear an oath and say to her: ‘If no other man has been intimate with you, and if you have not been defiled by leaving your husband, then you will be innocent from these bitter waters and the curse they carry.’”
Numbers 5:20 “‘But if you have turned away from your husband and been defiled, and you have been intimate with another man:’
Numbers 5:21 ‘then you will be subject to this curse: May the Lord make you an object of execration and an example among all your people; may He cause your thigh to waste away and your belly to swell.’
Numbers 5:22 ‘May your belly swell up with a tumor and your thigh rot away.’ And the woman must say, ‘Amen, amen.’
Numbers 5:23 “Then the priest will write these curses in a scroll, and he will wash them into the bitter waters.
Numbers 5:24 And he will give the woman the bitter waters to drink. When she has drunk them, if she is defiled and has been caught in adultery, having scorned her husband: then her belly will swell up, and her thigh will waste away, and the woman will become an object of execration among her people.”
Numbers 5:25 “But if she has not been defiled, she will be unharmed and will be able to bear children.”
Numbers 5:26 “This is the law concerning jealousy: if a woman turns away from her husband and becomes defiled, and her husband, moved by a spirit of jealousy, brings her before the Lord;
Numbers 5:27 —even if she drinks the bitter waters that carry the curse—if the woman is not actually defiled, she will remain unharmed by these bitter waters and their curse.
Numbers 5:28 But if she has been defiled and caught in adultery, her belly will swell up with a tumor, and her thigh will waste away, and the woman will become an object of execration among her people.
Numbers 5:29 This is the law of jealousy, which applies to a husband if he is stirred by a spirit of jealousy against his wife,
Numbers 5:30 or if a woman turns away from her husband and becomes defiled.
Numbers 5:31 Then the man will present his wife to the priest, and she will immediately drink the waters of the curse, and if she is innocent, she will not be found guilty of the sin.”
Numbers 6:1 Then the Lord God spoke to Moses and said:
Numbers 6:2 “Speak to the children of Israel and say to them: If any man or woman makes a special vow to dedicate themselves to the Lord through a Nazirite vow,
Numbers 6:3 they must completely separate themselves from wine and strong drink. They must not drink vinegar made from wine or from strong drink. They must not drink any juice pressed from grapes, and they must not eat fresh grapes or dried grapes. This is a total abstinence from anything made from the vine.
Numbers 6:4 For the entire duration of their Nazirite consecration to the Lord, they must not eat anything that comes from the grapevine, from the seeds to the skin.
Numbers 6:5 During the entire time of their vow, no razor is to touch their head. They are to remain holy by growing out the hair of their head, until the days of their dedication to the Lord are completed.
Numbers 6:6 For the entire period of their consecration, they must not go near a dead body.
Numbers 6:7 They must not make themselves unclean, even if their father, mother, brother, or sister dies. This is because the mark of their God’s consecration is upon their head, making them especially sacred.
Numbers 6:8 Throughout the entire time of their separation for the Lord, they are to be holy to the Lord God.
Numbers 6:9 If someone unexpectedly and accidentally dies next to them, the consecrated head of the Nazirite becomes defiled. On the day of their purification, they must shave their head.
Numbers 6:10 On the eighth day, they must bring two turtledoves or two young pigeons to the priest at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting.
Numbers 6:11 The priest will then offer one bird as a sacrifice for sin and the other as a burnt offering. The priest will make atonement for them, for the sin they committed by being near the dead person, and on that day, the priest will reconsecrate their head.
Numbers 6:12 They must then rededicate their days of separation to the Lord and offer a male lamb in its first year as a sin offering. All the previous days of their vow are invalidated, because their consecration was defiled.
Numbers 6:13 “This is the law for the Nazirite: When the days of their consecration are completed, they must be brought to the entrance of the Tent of Meeting,
Numbers 6:14 and they must offer their sacrifices to the Lord: a male lamb in its first year, without blemish, for a burnt offering; a female lamb in its first year, without blemish, for a sin offering; and one ram, without blemish, for a peace offering.
Numbers 6:15 Also, a basket of unleavened bread made with fine flour mixed with oil, and unleavened wafers spread with oil, along with their grain offerings and drink offerings.
Numbers 6:16 The priest will present these offerings before the Lord, performing the sin offering and the burnt offering first.
Numbers 6:17 The priest will then sacrifice the ram as a peace offering to the Lord, along with the basket of unleavened bread, and its accompanying grain offerings and drink offerings as is customary.
Numbers 6:18 Then the Nazirite will shave off the hair of their consecrated head at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting. They will take the shaved hair, which is a sign of their consecration, and put it on the fire that is under the peace offering.
Numbers 6:19 The priest will take a boiled shoulder of the ram, one unleavened cake from the basket, and one unleavened wafer, and place them on the hands of the Nazirite after their head has been shaved.
Numbers 6:20 The priest will wave these offerings before the Lord; they are a holy portion for the priest, just like the consecrated breast and the separated thigh are. After this ritual, the Nazirite is permitted to drink wine again.
Numbers 6:21 “This is the law for the Nazirite concerning their vow and their offerings to the Lord, including the hair of their head. This is what they must offer, beyond what their means allow. According to the vow they have thoughtfully made, so they must carry out their consecration.”
Numbers 6:22 Then the Lord God spoke to Moses and said:
Numbers 6:23 “Speak to Aaron and his sons, instructing them on how to bless the children of Israel. Say to them:
Numbers 6:24 May the Lord God bless you and keep watch over you.
Numbers 6:25 May the Lord God make His face shine upon you and be gracious to you.
Numbers 6:26 May the Lord God lift up His countenance upon you and give you true peace.
Numbers 6:27 This is how they will invoke My name over the children of Israel, and I, the Lord God, will personally bless them.”
Numbers 6:28 Then the Lord God spoke to Moses after He had finished all His commands, saying:
Numbers 6:29 “This is the offering of the leaders of Israel on the day the altar was dedicated and anointed for its sacred purpose. They brought twelve carts, twelve oxen—one ox for each cart, and one ox for each leader.
Numbers 6:30 And they presented these offerings before the Lord God.
Numbers 6:31 Then the Lord God said to Moses: 'Accept these from them, and they are to be used for the service of the Tent of Meeting. You are to give them to the Levites, according to each one’s specific service.'
Numbers 6:32 So Moses received the carts and the oxen, and he gave them to the Levites.
Numbers 6:33 He gave two carts and four oxen to the sons of Gershon, for their specific duties.
Numbers 6:34 He gave four carts and eight oxen to the sons of Merari, for their specific duties.
Numbers 6:35 But to the sons of Kohath he gave no carts or oxen, because their duty was to carry the holy things of the sanctuary on their shoulders, without any vehicles.
Numbers 6:36 Therefore, the leaders brought these offerings for the dedication of the altar on the very day it was anointed.
Numbers 6:37 On the first day, Nahshon, son of Amminadab, the leader of the tribe of Judah, presented his offering.
Numbers 6:38 His offering consisted of: one silver plate weighing one hundred and thirty shekels, and one silver basin weighing seventy shekels, according to the holy sanctuary standard. Both were filled with fine flour mixed with oil, as a grain offering.
Numbers 6:39 Also, one small gold pan, weighing ten shekels, full of incense.
Numbers 6:40 And for a burnt offering: one young bull from the herd, one ram, and one male lamb in its first year.
Numbers 7:1 It came to pass on the very day when Moses completed the Tabernacle, and set it up, and consecrated it with oil, and made all its sacred vessels holy by anointing them,
Numbers 7:2 the tribal leaders of Israel, who were the heads of their ancestral houses and in charge of the numbered men, brought their offerings.
Numbers 7:3 Their offerings before the Lord were six covered wagons and twelve oxen. Two of the tribal leaders offered one wagon, and each leader offered one ox, and they handed them over to the Levites, with each Levite family receiving a portion.
Numbers 7:4 And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying:
Numbers 7:5  'Receive these offerings from them, because they will be used for the service of the Tabernacle of the Testimony. You shall give them to the Levites, to each group according to their specific duty.' 
Numbers 7:6 So Moses took the wagons and the oxen, and he handed them over to the Levites.
Numbers 7:7 He gave two wagons and four oxen to the sons of Gershon, according to the requirements of their service.
Numbers 7:8 And he gave four wagons and eight oxen to the sons of Merari, according to the requirements of their service, under the direct supervision of Ithamar, the son of Aaron the priest.
Numbers 7:9 But to the sons of Kohath, he gave no wagons or oxen; for it was their duty to carry the most holy objects of the Tabernacle on their shoulders.
Numbers 7:10 Therefore, the tribal leaders brought their offerings for the dedication of the altar on the very day it was consecrated.
Numbers 7:11 And the Lord said to Moses, 'Each tribal leader shall bring his dedication offering for the altar on a separate day.' 
Numbers 7:12 So, on the first day, Nahshon, the son of Amminadab from the tribe of Judah, brought his offering.
Numbers 7:13 His offering consisted of: a silver dish weighing one hundred and thirty shekels (measured by the sanctuary standard), and a silver bowl weighing seventy shekels, according to the same sanctuary standard. Both vessels were filled with fine flour mixed with oil for the grain offering, along with frankincense.
Numbers 7:14 Also, a golden spoon weighing ten shekels, filled with frankincense.
Numbers 7:15 And a male goat for the sin offering.
Numbers 7:16 Two oxen, one ram, and five one-year-old male lambs for the peace offering. This was the entire offering from Nahshon, the son of Amminadab.
Numbers 7:17 On the second day, Nathanael, the son of Zuar from the tribe of Issachar, brought his offering.
Numbers 7:18 His offering consisted of: a silver dish weighing one hundred and thirty shekels (measured by the sanctuary standard), and a silver bowl weighing seventy shekels, according to the same sanctuary standard. Both vessels were filled with fine flour mixed with oil for the grain offering, along with frankincense.
Numbers 7:19 Also, a golden spoon weighing ten shekels, filled with frankincense.
Numbers 7:20 And a male goat for the sin offering.
Numbers 7:21 Two oxen, one ram, and five one-year-old male lambs for the peace offering. This was the entire offering from Nathanael, the son of Zuar.
Numbers 7:22 On the third day, Eliab, the son of Helon and leader of the sons of Zebulun, brought his offering.
Numbers 7:23 His offering consisted of: a silver dish weighing one hundred and thirty shekels (measured by the sanctuary standard), and a silver bowl weighing seventy shekels, according to the same sanctuary standard. Both vessels were filled with fine flour mixed with oil for the grain offering, along with frankincense.
Numbers 7:24 Also, a golden spoon weighing ten shekels, filled with frankincense.
Numbers 7:25 And a male goat for the sin offering.
Numbers 7:26 Two oxen, one ram, and five one-year-old male lambs for the peace offering. This was the entire offering from Eliab, the son of Helon.
Numbers 7:27 On the fourth day, Elizur, the son of Shedeur and leader of the sons of Reuben, brought his offering.
Numbers 7:28 His offering consisted of: a silver dish weighing one hundred and thirty shekels (measured by the sanctuary standard), and a silver bowl weighing seventy shekels, according to the same sanctuary standard. Both vessels were filled with fine flour mixed with oil for the grain offering, along with frankincense.
Numbers 7:29 Also, a golden spoon weighing ten shekels, filled with frankincense.
Numbers 7:30 And a male goat for the sin offering.
Numbers 7:31 Two oxen, one ram, and five one-year-old male lambs for the peace offering. This was the entire offering from Elizur, the son of Shedeur.
Numbers 7:32 On the fifth day, Shelumiel, the son of Zurishaddai and leader of the sons of Simeon, brought his offering.
Numbers 7:33 His offering consisted of: a silver dish weighing one hundred and thirty shekels (measured by the sanctuary standard), and a silver bowl weighing seventy shekels, according to the same sanctuary standard. Both vessels were filled with fine flour mixed with oil for the grain offering, along with frankincense.
Numbers 7:34 Also, a golden spoon weighing ten shekels, filled with frankincense.
Numbers 7:35 And a male goat for the sin offering.
Numbers 7:36 Two oxen, one ram, and five one-year-old male lambs for the peace offering. This was the entire offering from Shelumiel, the son of Zurishaddai.
Numbers 7:37 On the sixth day, Eliasaph, the son of Deuel and leader of the sons of Gad, brought his offering.
Numbers 7:38 His offering consisted of: a silver dish weighing one hundred and thirty shekels (measured by the sanctuary standard), and a silver bowl weighing seventy shekels, according to the same sanctuary standard. Both vessels were filled with fine flour mixed with oil for the grain offering, along with frankincense.
Numbers 7:39 Also, a golden spoon weighing ten shekels, filled with frankincense; and a male goat for the sin offering.
Numbers 7:40 Two oxen, one ram, and five one-year-old male lambs for the peace offering. This was the entire offering from Eliasaph, the son of Deuel.
Numbers 8:1 The Lord then spoke to Moses, giving him these instructions:
Numbers 8:2 “Tell Aaron these instructions: When you prepare the lamps in the Tabernacle, make sure that the light from the seven lamps shines forward, illuminating the area directly in front of the lampstand.”
Numbers 8:3 Aaron carried out these instructions. He lit the lamps on the lampstand so that they faced forward and illuminated the area in front of it, exactly as the Lord had commanded Moses.
Numbers 8:4 This is how the lampstand was made: it was hammered out of pure gold, both its base and its branches, all of it with intricate carved work. The lampstand was crafted exactly according to the design that the Lord had shown to Moses.
Numbers 8:5 The Lord then spoke to Moses, giving him further instructions:
Numbers 8:6 “Take the Levites from among all the people of Israel and purify them through a ritual cleansing.
Numbers 8:7 You shall purify them according to this ritual: sprinkle the water of purification upon them. They must shave off all the hair on their bodies; then they are to wash their clothes and cleanse themselves completely.
Numbers 8:8 After this, they are to bring a young bull from the herd, along with its grain offering of fine flour mixed with oil. You are also to take another young bull as a sin offering for them.
Numbers 8:9 You are to bring the Levites before the Tabernacle of the Testimony, and then you are to assemble the entire community of the people of Israel.
Numbers 8:10 When you present the Levites before the Lord, all the people of Israel shall lay their hands upon them, dedicating them.
Numbers 8:11 Aaron shall then present the Levites before the Lord as a special wave offering from the people of Israel, so that the Levites may perform their service for Me in the Tabernacle.
Numbers 8:12 The Levites, in turn, are to lay their hands on the heads of the young bulls. One bull is to be offered as a sin offering, and the other as a burnt offering to the Lord, to make atonement for the Levites.
Numbers 8:13 You are to present the Levites before Aaron and his sons, and then you will consecrate them as a special offering to the Lord.
Numbers 8:14 Thus, you will separate the Levites from among the rest of the people of Israel, so that the Levites will be exclusively Mine.
Numbers 8:15 After these rituals, the Levites may enter the Tabernacle of the Testimony to serve Me. You are to purify and consecrate them in this manner as a special offering to the Lord, because they have been given to Me as a unique possession from among the people of Israel.
Numbers 8:16 I have accepted them as a replacement for all the firstborn among the people of Israel, for every first male child that opens the womb.
Numbers 8:17 For all the firstborn among the people of Israel are Mine, both of humans and animals. From the day I struck down every firstborn in the land of Egypt, I set them apart as holy for Myself.
Numbers 8:18 And now, I have taken the Levites as substitutes for all the firstborn of the people of Israel.
Numbers 8:19 I have given the Levites to Aaron and his sons as a special gift, so that they may perform service for Me on behalf of the people of Israel in the Tabernacle of the Covenant. They are also to make atonement and pray for the people, so that no plague may strike the community if any Israelite should presumptuously approach the Sanctuary without authorization.”
Numbers 8:20 So Moses and Aaron, and the entire community of the people of Israel, performed all these instructions concerning the Levites, just as the Lord had commanded Moses.
Numbers 8:21 The Levites underwent purification and washed their clothes. Aaron then presented them before the Lord as an offering, making atonement for them.
Numbers 8:22 After this, the Levites began their service in the Tabernacle of the Testimony before Aaron and his sons, exactly as the Lord had commanded Moses concerning the Levites.
Numbers 8:23 The Lord then spoke to Moses, giving him further instructions:
Numbers 8:24 “This is the law for the Levites: from twenty-five years of age and older, they shall begin their service and perform duties in the Tabernacle of the Covenant.
Numbers 8:25 But when they reach fifty years of age, they shall no longer serve actively, and they will cease from their regular work.
Numbers 8:26 However, they may assist their younger brothers in the Tabernacle of the Testimony, helping to guard what has been entrusted to them. They shall only perform duties of oversight, but they are not to perform the active service of the Tabernacle itself. This is how you are to regulate the Levites concerning their assigned duties and responsibilities.”
Numbers 8:27 The Lord then spoke to Moses, giving him instructions:
Numbers 8:28 “Speak to the people of Israel and tell them: When you enter the land where you will dwell, which I am giving to you,
Numbers 8:29 and you present an offering to the Lord—whether a burnt offering or a sacrifice, fulfilling vows or making a voluntary offering, or during your appointed festivals—to create a pleasing aroma to the Lord from cattle or sheep:
Numbers 8:30 Whoever offers a peace offering must also present a grain offering with it. This grain offering must be one-tenth of an ephah of fine flour mixed with one-quarter of a hin of oil.
Numbers 8:31 And for the drink offering, they are to provide wine in the same measure as the oil, one-quarter of a hin.
Numbers 8:32 This applies to each individual sheep, ram, goat, calf, and ox, and all other animals that are offered as sacrifices.
Numbers 8:33 According to the number of sacrificial animals, the same proportion of fine flour and wine for the drink offerings shall be given for each one.
Numbers 8:34 Every native-born Israelite and every foreigner who lives among you shall perform these rituals according to the same law.
Numbers 8:35 There shall be one law for you and for the resident foreigner, and the same ordinances shall apply to all.
Numbers 8:36 The Lord then spoke to Moses, saying:
Numbers 8:37 “Speak to the people of Israel and tell them: When you enter the land of Canaan, and you eat from the food of that land,
Numbers 8:38 you are to set aside the first portion of your dough as an offering to the Lord.
Numbers 8:39 From the first of your dough, just as you give a portion from your threshing floors, so too shall you give an offering to the Lord.
Numbers 8:40 You are to present this first portion of your dough as an offering to the Lord throughout all your generations.”
Numbers 9:1 The Lord spoke to Moses in the Sinai desert, in the first month of the second year after the Israelites had left the land of Egypt, saying this to him:
Numbers 9:2 “You, the children of Israel, are to keep the Passover at its proper time.
Numbers 9:3 You must do this on the fourteenth day of that same month, following all of its proper ceremonies and legal requirements.”
Numbers 9:4 So Moses commanded the children of Israel to keep the Passover.
Numbers 9:5 They kept it in the Sinai desert on the fourteenth day of the first month, in the evening. The children of Israel did everything exactly as the Lord had commanded Moses.
Numbers 9:6 However, some men were ritually unclean because they had touched a dead body, and so they were not able to keep the Passover on its designated day. These men came to Moses and Aaron,
Numbers 9:7 and they said: “We are unclean because we touched a dead body. Why should we be prevented from offering the Lord’s sacrifice at its proper time, along with the rest of the children of Israel?”
Numbers 9:8 Moses answered them: “Wait here so I can consult the Lord to see what He commands about your situation.”
Numbers 9:9 Then the Lord spoke to Moses, saying:
Numbers 9:10 “Speak to the children of Israel and tell them: If any man among you, or among your descendants, becomes unclean by touching a dead body, or if he is far away on a journey, he may still keep the Passover for the Lord.
Numbers 9:11 He shall keep it in the second month, on the fourteenth day of that month, in the evening. They must eat it with unleavened bread and bitter herbs.
Numbers 9:12 They must not leave any of it until morning, nor break any of its bones. They must observe all the ceremonies of the Passover exactly as prescribed.
Numbers 9:13 But if a man is clean and is not on a journey, and still fails to keep the Passover, that person will be cut off from his people. Because he did not offer the Lord’s sacrifice at its proper time, that man will bear the guilt of his sin.
Numbers 9:14 If a resident foreigner or a temporary visitor among you desires to keep the Passover for the Lord, he must do so according to its ceremonies and legal requirements. You shall have the same law for both the resident foreigner and the native-born person.”
Numbers 9:15 Now, on the day the Tabernacle was set up, a cloud covered it. And from evening until morning, there appeared over the Tabernacle something like the appearance of fire.
Numbers 9:16 This is how it remained continuously: by day, the cloud covered it, and by night, it had the appearance of fire.
Numbers 9:17 Whenever the cloud that was over the Tabernacle moved away, then the children of Israel would set out on their journey. And wherever the cloud settled, there they would set up their camp.
Numbers 9:18 At the Lord’s command they would set out, and at His command they would pitch their tents. As long as the cloud remained over the Tabernacle, they stayed in that same place.
Numbers 9:19 If the cloud stayed over it for many days, the children of Israel observed the Lord’s command and did not move on.
Numbers 9:20 If the cloud was over it for only a few days, they remained at the Lord’s command, and at His command they would set out.
Numbers 9:21 If the cloud remained from evening until morning, and then departed in the morning, they would set out. Or if it departed after a day and a night, they would move their camp by following it.
Numbers 9:22 Whether the cloud stayed over the Tabernacle for two days, or a month, or a longer period of time, the children of Israel remained in the same place and did not move on. But as soon as it departed, they would move their camp.
Numbers 9:23 They set up their tents at the Lord’s command and journeyed at His command. They observed the Lord’s commands, just as the Lord had spoken through Moses.
Numbers 10:1 The Lord God then spoke to Moses, saying:
Numbers 10:2 “Make two trumpets for yourself, made of hammered silver. You shall use them to call the community together when it is time for the camp to move.”
Numbers 10:3 “When you sound them, the entire assembly of people will gather before you at the entrance of the tent of the covenant.”
Numbers 10:4 “If only one trumpet makes a sound, then only the leaders—the heads of the thousands of Israel—will come to you.”
Numbers 10:5 “But if you make a long, repeated sound with the trumpets, then those who are camped on the east side will begin to move.”
Numbers 10:6 “At the second sound, made in the same manner, those who are camped on the south side will prepare their camp to move. And the others will do likewise.”
Numbers 10:7 “However, when the people are to be gathered together, the trumpet sound will be a simple call, not a repeated one.”
Numbers 10:8 “And Aaron's sons, who are priests, shall sound the trumpets. This shall be a lasting ordinance for your generations.”
Numbers 10:9 “If you go out to battle in your land against enemies who are fighting against you, you shall sound a strong call with the trumpets. Then the Lord your God will remember you, and you will be delivered from the hands of your enemies.”
Numbers 10:10 “Also, on your days of celebration, and on your feast days, and at the beginning of your months, you shall sound the trumpets over your burnt offerings and over the peace offerings. They will serve as a reminder for you before your God. I am the Lord your God.”
Numbers 10:11 In the second year, on the second month, on the twentieth day of the month, the cloud lifted from over the tabernacle of testimony.
Numbers 10:12 So the sons of Israel began their journeys, group by group, from the desert of Sinai. And the cloud settled down in the wilderness of Paran.
Numbers 10:13 The first groups to move their camps did so according to the Lord's command, through Moses.
Numbers 10:14 And so the sons of Judah set out by their divisions. Nahshon, the son of Amminadab, was their prince.
Numbers 10:15 In the tribe of the sons of Issachar, Nethanel, the son of Zuar, was the prince.
Numbers 10:16 In the tribe of the sons of Zebulun, Eliab, the son of Helon, was the prince.
Numbers 10:17 Then the tabernacle was taken down, and the sons of Gershon and Merari carried it.
Numbers 10:18 Next, the sons of Reuben set out by their divisions and their families. Their prince was Elizur, the son of Shedeur.
Numbers 10:19 In the tribe of the sons of Simeon, Shelumiel, the son of Zurishaddai, was the prince.
Numbers 10:20 In the tribe of the sons of Gad, Eliasaph, the son of Deuel, was the prince.
Numbers 10:21 And the sons of Kohath also set out, carrying the sanctuary. This was so that by the time they arrived at the designated stopping place, the tabernacle would already be set up.
Numbers 10:22 Then the sons of Ephraim set out by their divisions and their families. Their prince was Elishama, the son of Ammihud.
Numbers 10:23 In the tribe of the sons of Manasseh, Gamaliel, the son of Pedahzur, was the prince.
Numbers 10:24 In the tribe of the sons of Benjamin, Abidan, the son of Gideoni, was the prince.
Numbers 10:25 Lastly, those who formed the rear guard for all the camps were the sons of Dan, who set out by their divisions. Their prince was Ahiezer, the son of Ammishaddai.
Numbers 10:26 In the tribe of the sons of Asher, Pagiel, the son of Ocran, was the prince.
Numbers 10:27 In the tribe of the sons of Naphtali, Ahira, the son of Enan, was the prince.
Numbers 10:28 These were the movements of the sons of Israel, by their divisions, as they set out on their journeys.
Numbers 10:29 Moses then said to Hobab, the son of Reuel the Midianite, his father-in-law: “We are setting out for the place that the Lord is going to give us. Come with us, and we will do good to you, because the Lord has promised good things to Israel.”
Numbers 10:30 But Hobab replied: “I will not come with you. Instead, I will return to my own land, where I was born.”
Numbers 10:31 But Moses urged him, saying: “Please do not leave us! For you know the places in the desert where we ought to camp, and you can be our guide.”
Numbers 10:32 “And if you come with us, whatever good things the Lord gives to us, we will give to you as well.”
Numbers 10:33 So they set out from the mountain of the Lord, a three-day journey. And the ark of the covenant of the Lord went before them for three days, providing and searching out places for them to camp.
Numbers 10:34 “And the cloud of the Lord was over them by day when they traveled.”
Numbers 10:35 And whenever the ark was lifted up to move, Moses would say: “Arise, Lord, and may your enemies be scattered! May those who hate you flee from your presence!”
Numbers 10:36 “And when it was set down, he would say: ‘Return, Lord, to the countless thousands of Israel's army!’”
Numbers 11:1 The people began to complain against the Lord, as if they were lamenting their hardship. When the Lord heard this, He became very angry. A fire then ignited among them, consuming the outskirts of their camp.
Numbers 11:2 So the people cried out to Moses, and Moses prayed to the Lord for them. The fire was then extinguished.
Numbers 11:3 So the name of that place was called "Burning", because the Lord's fire had been kindled against them there.
Numbers 11:4 But the mixed multitude of people who had come up with them were filled with intense cravings. And the children of Israel also wept, saying: "Who will give us meat to eat?"
Numbers 11:5 We remember the fish we used to eat for free in Egypt! We recall the cucumbers, melons, leeks, onions, and garlic.
Numbers 11:6 But now our appetites are dry and weak. Our eyes see nothing but this manna.
Numbers 11:7 The manna itself looked like coriander seed, and its appearance was like crystalline dew.
Numbers 11:8 The people would go out to gather it, then grind it in handmills or crush it in mortars. They would cook it in pots and make cakes from it that tasted like bread made with oil.
Numbers 11:9 And when the dew fell upon the camp at night, the manna would descend with it.
Numbers 11:10 Moses then heard the people weeping throughout their families, each person at the entrance of their tents. The Lord's fury became intense, and Moses himself was also greatly displeased by their behavior.
Numbers 11:11 And Moses said to the Lord: "Why have You afflicted Your servant? Why have I not found grace in Your sight, that You would lay the burden of all these people upon me?"
Numbers 11:12 Did I conceive all these people? Or did I give birth to them, that You should tell me: 'Carry them in your arms, as a nurse carries a baby, and bring them to the land which You swore to their fathers'?
Numbers 11:13 Where can I get meat to give to all these people? For they are weeping before me, saying: 'Give us meat, so we may eat'.
Numbers 11:14 I cannot bear all this burden of the people by myself, because it is too heavy for me.
Numbers 11:15 If You are going to continue dealing with me like this, I beg You, please kill me now—if I have found favor in Your eyes—so I may not see my own troubles and misery any further.
Numbers 11:16 And the Lord said to Moses: "Gather for Me seventy men from the elders of Israel, men whom you know to be elders and leaders of the people. Bring them to the entrance of the Tabernacle of the Covenant, and have them stand there with you."
Numbers 11:17 And I will come down and speak with you there. I will take some of the Spirit that is upon you and put it upon them, so that they may bear the burden of the people with you, and you will not be burdened alone.
Numbers 11:18 And to the people you shall say: 'Sanctify yourselves for tomorrow, for you shall eat meat. For you have complained, saying: "Who will give us meat to eat? It was better for us in Egypt!" Now, the Lord will give you meat, and you shall eat it'.
Numbers 11:19 You will eat it not for just one day, nor for two, or five, or ten, or even twenty days,
Numbers 11:20 but for an entire month of days, until it comes out of your nostrils and becomes sickening to you. This will happen because you have despised the Lord, who is in your midst, and have wept before Him, saying: 'Why did we ever leave Egypt?'
Numbers 11:21 And Moses said: "There are six hundred thousand footmen among these people, among whom I stand. Yet You say: 'I will give them meat to eat for an entire month'?"
Numbers 11:22 Even if flocks of sheep and herds of cattle were slaughtered, would they be enough for their food? Or if all the fish of the sea were gathered together, would they satisfy them?
Numbers 11:23 To which the Lord answered: "Is the Lord's power limited? Now you shall see whether My word will be fulfilled in action or not."
Numbers 11:24 So Moses went out and reported the Lord's words to the people. He gathered seventy men from the elders of Israel and made them stand around the Tabernacle.
Numbers 11:25 And the Lord came down in the cloud and spoke to Moses. He took some of the Spirit that was upon Moses and placed it upon the seventy elders. And when the Spirit rested upon them, they prophesied, and did not cease afterward.
Numbers 11:26 Two men, however, had remained in the camp. One was named Eldad and the other Medad, and the Spirit rested upon them, for they had also been listed among the elders, but had not gone out to the Tabernacle. When they prophesied in the camp,
Numbers 11:27 a young man ran and reported to Moses, saying: "Eldad and Medad are prophesying in the camp!"
Numbers 11:28 Immediately, Joshua, the son of Nun, Moses' assistant and one of his chosen men, said: "My Lord Moses, forbid them!"
Numbers 11:29 To him Moses replied: "Are you jealous for my sake? I wish that all the Lord's people would prophesy, and that the Lord would put His Spirit upon them all!"
Numbers 11:30 After this, Moses and the elders of Israel returned to the camp.
Numbers 11:31 Then a wind came from the Lord, which swept quails from the sea and brought them to the camp. They were scattered for a distance of a day's journey all around the camp, and lay about two cubits (around three feet) high on the surface of the earth.
Numbers 11:32 So the people rose up all that day, all that night, and all the next day, and gathered the quails. Even he who gathered the least collected ten homers (about 60 bushels). They then spread them out all around the camp to dry.
Numbers 11:33 While the meat was still between their teeth and had not yet been consumed, the Lord's anger was stirred against the people, and He struck them with an exceedingly great plague.
Numbers 11:34 So the name of that place was called "Graves of Craving", because there they buried the people who had craved meat with such intensity.
Numbers 11:35 From the Graves of Craving, they journeyed to Hazeroth and remained there.
Numbers 12:1 Then Miriam and Aaron began speaking against Moses because of his Ethiopian wife. They asked, 'Why did he marry an Ethiopian woman?'
Numbers 12:2 They continued, 'Has the Lord spoken only through Moses? Has He not also spoken through us?' The Lord heard what they said.
Numbers 12:3 Now Moses was a very humble man, more humble than anyone else on the earth.
Numbers 12:4 Immediately the Lord spoke to Moses, Aaron, and Miriam, saying, 'Go out, you three, to the Tent of Meeting.' So they went out.
Numbers 12:5 The Lord descended in a pillar of cloud and stood at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting. He called Aaron and Miriam. When both of them had come forward,
Numbers 12:6 He said to them, 'Hear My words: If there is a prophet among you who speaks for the Lord, I will appear to him in a vision, or I will speak to him in a dream.'
Numbers 12:7 But My servant Moses is not like that, for he is most faithful in all My house.
Numbers 12:8 For I speak to him face to face, and plainly, not through dark sayings and riddles. Moreover, he sees the very form of the Lord. Why then were you not afraid to speak against My servant Moses?
Numbers 12:9 And the Lord was angry with them and departed.
Numbers 12:10 The cloud also departed from above the Tent of Meeting. And behold, Miriam was suddenly white with leprosy like snow. When Aaron looked at her and saw she was completely covered with leprosy,
Numbers 12:11 He said to Moses, 'I beg you, my lord, do not hold this sin against us, which we foolishly committed and in which we sinned.'
Numbers 12:12 'Let her not be like a stillborn child, that comes out dead from its mother’s womb with its flesh already half-consumed.'
Numbers 12:13 Then Moses cried out to the Lord, saying, 'O God, I beg You, heal her!'
Numbers 12:14 The Lord answered him, 'If her father had spat in her face, would she not have been ashamed for at least seven days? Let her be separated for seven days outside the camp, and then she will be brought back.'
Numbers 12:15 So Miriam was excluded from the camp for seven days. And the people did not move on until Miriam was brought back.
Numbers 12:16 After this, they moved on from Hazeroth and encamped in the desert of Paran.
Numbers 13:1 The Lord spoke to Moses, saying:
Numbers 13:2 “Send men to explore the land of Canaan, which I am about to give to the children of Israel. Send one leader from each tribe.”
Numbers 13:3 So Moses sent them from the wilderness of Paran, as commanded by the Lord. All of these men were leaders from among the children of Israel. These are their names:
Numbers 13:4 From the tribe of Reuben, Shammua, the son of Zaccur.
Numbers 13:5 From the tribe of Simeon, Shaphat, the son of Hori.
Numbers 13:6 From the tribe of Judah, Caleb, the son of Jephunneh.
Numbers 13:7 From the tribe of Issachar, Igal, the son of Joseph.
Numbers 13:8 From the tribe of Ephraim, Hosea, the son of Nun.
Numbers 13:9 From the tribe of Benjamin, Palti, the son of Raphu.
Numbers 13:10 From the tribe of Zebulun, Gaddiel, the son of Sodi.
Numbers 13:11 From the tribe of Joseph, representing the tribe of Manasseh, Gaddi, the son of Susi.
Numbers 13:12 From the tribe of Dan, Ammiel, the son of Gemalli.
Numbers 13:13 From the tribe of Asher, Sethur, the son of Michael.
Numbers 13:14 From the tribe of Naphtali, Nahbi, the son of Vophsi.
Numbers 13:15 From the tribe of Gad, Geuel, the son of Machi.
Numbers 13:16 These are the names of the men whom Moses sent to explore the land. Moses also changed the name of Hosea, the son of Nun, to Joshua.
Numbers 13:17 Moses then gave them instructions: “Go up through the South, and when you reach the mountainous region,
Numbers 13:18 observe what kind of land it is. Also, observe the people who live there: are they strong or weak? Are they few in number or many?
Numbers 13:19 Are their cities fortified with walls or unwalled? Where do they live—in tents or in towns?
Numbers 13:20 Is the land fertile or barren? Are there trees in it or not? Be courageous and bring back some of the fruit of the land. Now it was the season when the first grapes were beginning to ripen.”
Numbers 13:21 So they went up and explored the land, from the wilderness of Zin all the way to Rehob, toward the entrance to Hamath.
Numbers 13:22 They went up into the South and came to Hebron, where Ahiman, Sheshai, and Talmai, the descendants of Anak, lived. Hebron had been built seven years before Zoan, the city in Egypt.
Numbers 13:23 They came as far as the Valley of Eshcol. There, they cut down a branch with a single cluster of grapes, which two men carried on a pole between them. They also took some pomegranates and figs from that place.
Numbers 13:24 That place was named Eshcol (meaning “valley of the cluster”) because of the cluster of grapes that the children of Israel carried from there.
Numbers 13:25 The explorers of the land returned after forty days.
Numbers 13:26 They came back to Moses and Aaron and to the entire assembly of the children of Israel, in the wilderness of Paran, at Kadesh.
Numbers 13:27 They brought the fruit of the land to them and to the whole congregation.
Numbers 13:28 And they reported to Moses, saying: “We went into the land to which you sent us, and it truly flows with milk and honey, as these fruits demonstrate.
Numbers 13:29 But the people who live in it are very strong; the cities are very large and fortified. Moreover, we saw descendants of Anak there.
Numbers 13:30 The Amalekites live in the south; the Hittites, Jebusites, and Amorites dwell in the mountainous regions; and the Canaanites occupy the area by the sea and along the Jordan River.”
Numbers 13:31 Caleb quieted the people who were murmuring against Moses and said: “Let us go up immediately and take possession of the land, for we will certainly be able to conquer it.”
Numbers 13:32 But the other men who had gone with him as explorers said: “We cannot go up against these people, because they are too strong for us.”
Numbers 13:33 So they spread a discouraging report among the children of Israel about the land they had explored, saying: “The land which we surveyed devours its inhabitants. The people whose stature we observed are exceptionally tall.
Numbers 13:34 There we saw monstrous beings, descendants of Anak—a race of giants. In comparison to them, we appeared like grasshoppers in our own eyes.”
Numbers 13:35 Then the whole congregation murmured against Moses and Aaron, and the people wept and cried all that night.
Numbers 13:36 All the children of Israel complained against Moses and Aaron, saying: “If only we had died in Egypt, or if only we would perish here in this wilderness!
Numbers 13:37 Why has the Lord brought us to this land, only for us to fall by the sword? Our wives and children will be led away as captives. Wouldn’t it be better for us to return to Egypt?”
Numbers 13:38 And one said to another: “Let us appoint a new leader and return to Egypt.”
Numbers 13:39 Upon hearing this, Moses and Aaron fell prostrate before the entire assembly of the children of Israel.
Numbers 13:40 However, Joshua, the son of Nun, and Caleb, the son of Jephunneh, who themselves had also been among the explorers, tore their clothes. They spoke to the entire congregation of the children of Israel, saying: “The land which we surveyed is an exceptionally good land.”
Numbers 14:1 So the entire assembly cried out in a loud voice. And they wept all throughout that night.
Numbers 14:2 All the sons of Israel grumbled and complained against Moses and Aaron, saying: "If only we had died in Egypt, or if only we had perished in this desert!"
Numbers 14:3 "Why has the Lord brought us into this land only for us to fall in battle? Our wives and our children will be taken captive there. Wouldn't it be better for us to return to Egypt?"
Numbers 14:4 They also began to say to one another: "Let's choose a new leader for ourselves, and then we can return to Egypt."
Numbers 14:5 When Moses and Aaron heard this, they fell face down on the ground before the entire assembly of the sons of Israel.
Numbers 14:6 But Joshua, the son of Nun, and Caleb, the son of Jephone—who were also among those who had explored the land—tore their clothing in distress.
Numbers 14:7 And speaking to the whole assembly of the sons of Israel, they said: "The land which we have explored is exceedingly good and bountiful."
Numbers 14:8 "If the Lord is gracious to us, He will bring us into that land and give us that land, which flows with milk and honey."
Numbers 14:9 "Do not rebel against the Lord! And do not fear the people of this land, because we can surely devour them as if they were mere bread. All their protection has departed from them. The Lord is with us, so do not be afraid!"
Numbers 14:10 But when the whole assembly cried out again and wanted to overwhelm Joshua and Caleb with stones, the glory of the Lord appeared over the tabernacle of testimony before all the sons of Israel.
Numbers 14:11 And the Lord said to Moses: "How long will this people revile Me? How long will they refuse to believe Me, despite all the miraculous signs that I have performed before their eyes?"
Numbers 14:12 "Therefore, I will strike them with a pestilence and consume them. But I will make you into a great and more powerful nation than this one."
Numbers 14:13 And Moses said to the Lord: "But what if the Egyptians hear of this? They are the very people from among whom You brought out this nation!"
Numbers 14:14 "And what about the inhabitants of this land? They have heard that You, Lord, are in the midst of this people, and that Your face is seen among them in the present moment, and that Your cloud protects them, and that You go before them in a pillar of cloud by day and in a pillar of fire by night."
Numbers 14:15 "If You kill this people as if they were a single man, then the nations who have heard Your great reputation will say:"
Numbers 14:16 "'He could not bring the people into the land that He had sworn to give them, and therefore He killed them in the wilderness.'"
Numbers 14:17 "Therefore, let Your strength, O Lord, be magnified, just as You swore, saying:"
Numbers 14:18 "The Lord is patient and full of great mercy, taking away iniquity and wicked deeds. Yet He does not declare the guilty innocent, for He visits the sins of the fathers upon the children, even to the third and fourth generation."
Numbers 14:19 "Forgive, I beg You, the sin of this people according to the greatness of Your mercy, just as You have been gracious to them from their departure out of Egypt all the way to this place."
Numbers 14:20 The Lord said: "I have forgiven them according to your word."
Numbers 14:21 "As I live — and the glory of the Lord will fill the entire earth —"
Numbers 14:22 "Nevertheless, all the men who have seen My majesty, and the miraculous signs that I performed in Egypt and in the wilderness—and who have tested Me now these ten times, and have not obeyed My voice—"
Numbers 14:23 "they shall not see the land for which I swore an oath to their fathers. Not one of those who have reviled Me shall ever look upon it."
Numbers 14:24 "But My servant Caleb, because he was filled with a different spirit and fully followed Me, him I will bring into this land which he explored. And his offspring shall possess it."
Numbers 14:25 "Now, since the Amalekites and the Canaanites dwell in the valleys, tomorrow you must turn around and depart into the wilderness by the way of the Red Sea."
Numbers 14:26 And the Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron, saying:
Numbers 14:27 "How long will this wicked assembly grumble against Me? I have heard the complaints of the sons of Israel."
Numbers 14:28 "Therefore, tell them: 'As I live,' says the Lord, 'just as you have spoken in My hearing, so will I do to you.'"
Numbers 14:29 "In this very wilderness, your corpses shall fall. All of you who were counted, from twenty years old and above, and who grumbled against Me,"
Numbers 14:30 "none of you shall enter the land over which I raised My hand in an oath to make you dwell in it, except Caleb, the son of Jephone, and Joshua, the son of Nun."
Numbers 14:31 "But your little ones, about whom you said they would become plunder for the enemies, these I will bring in. So they shall see the land that you despised."
Numbers 14:32 "Your own corpses, however, shall lie here in this wilderness."
Numbers 14:33 "And your children shall wander as shepherds in the wilderness for forty years, and they shall bear the punishment for your infidelity, until your fathers' corpses are consumed and gone in the desert."
Numbers 14:34 "According to the number of the forty days in which you explored the land—a year shall be counted for each day. For forty years, you shall bear the punishment for your iniquities, and you will experience My vengeful justice."
Numbers 14:35 "Because just as I have spoken, so will I do to this entire wicked assembly that has risen up against Me. In this wilderness, they shall waste away and die."
Numbers 14:36 So then, all the men whom Moses had sent to explore the land, and who, upon returning, had made the entire assembly grumble against him by speaking evil about the land—
Numbers 14:37 these men died, struck down by a plague in the sight of the Lord.
Numbers 14:38 But Joshua, the son of Nun, and Caleb, the son of Jephone, alone remained alive out of all those who had gone to explore the land.
Numbers 14:39 And Moses spoke all these words to all the sons of Israel, and the people mourned intensely.
Numbers 14:40 And behold, rising early in the morning, they went up to the top of the mountain and said: "We are ready to go up to the place about which the Lord spoke, for we have sinned."
Numbers 15:1 And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying:
Numbers 15:2 Speak to the children of Israel and tell them this: 'When you have entered the land where you will live, the land that I am giving to you,
Numbers 15:3 and you make an offering to the Lord—whether a burnt offering or a sacrifice to fulfill a vow, or a freewill offering, or one presented during your solemn feasts to produce a most pleasing aroma to the Lord from cattle or from sheep:
Numbers 15:4 those who offer the sacrifice must present a grain offering of fine flour. It will be a tenth part of an ephah, mixed with oil, of which the measure shall be a fourth part of a hin.
Numbers 15:5 And they shall give wine for a drink offering of the same measure as the oil for the burnt offering or for the sacrifice. This is for each lamb sacrificed.
Numbers 15:6 If the offering is from rams, they shall offer fine flour, two tenths of an ephah, mixed with oil, one third part of a hin.
Numbers 15:7 And for the drink offering, they shall offer wine of the same measure—a third part of a hin—as a most pleasing aroma to the Lord.
Numbers 15:8 But when you offer a bull as a burnt offering, or a sacrifice to fulfill a vow, or as a peace offering:
Numbers 15:9 then for each bull, you shall give a grain offering of fine flour, three tenths of an ephah, mixed with oil, half a hin.
Numbers 15:10 And you shall offer wine for the drink offering, of the same measure, as a burnt offering of most pleasing aroma to the Lord.
Numbers 15:11 You shall do this
Numbers 15:12 for each bull, and for each ram, and for each lamb, and for each goat.
Numbers 15:13 Both the native-born and the resident alien shall perform these rituals according to the same custom.
Numbers 15:14 If any of the foreigners who live among you wish to offer a burnt offering or a sacrifice to the Lord, they shall do it exactly as you do.
Numbers 15:15 There will be one ordinance for you and for the proselytes who are resident aliens; it will be equally acceptable to God.
Numbers 15:16 There will be one law and one judgment for both you and for those who reside as strangers among you.
Numbers 15:17 And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying:
Numbers 15:18 Speak to the children of Israel and tell them this: 'When you have entered the land into which I am bringing you,
Numbers 15:19 and you eat from the food of that region, you shall set aside the first portions for the Lord.
Numbers 15:20 From the food you eat, you shall offer the first fruits, just as you do from your threshing floors.
Numbers 15:21 You shall give the first portions of your food to the Lord.
Numbers 15:22 Now, if you unintentionally sin and do not observe all the commandments that the Lord has spoken to Moses—
Numbers 15:23 all that the Lord commanded you through Moses, from the day He began to give commandments and thereafter—
Numbers 15:24 and if the entire community has forgotten something and sinned, then they shall offer a young bull from the herd as a burnt offering and a most pleasing aroma to the Lord, along with its proper grain offering and drink offering, as the ceremonies require. They shall also offer a male goat as a sin offering.
Numbers 15:25 And the priest shall make atonement for the entire community of the children of Israel, and they will be forgiven. This is because they sinned unintentionally, and they have brought their incense offering to the Lord along with their sacrifices and drink offerings for their sin.
Numbers 15:26 And the entire people of the children of Israel, and the resident aliens who live among them, shall be forgiven, because it was an unintentional fault on the part of the whole people.
Numbers 15:27 But if an individual person sins unintentionally, that person shall offer a one-year-old female goat without blemish as a sin offering.
Numbers 15:28 And the priest shall make atonement for that person who sinned unintentionally before the Lord. He shall obtain forgiveness for them, and it will be forgiven.
Numbers 15:29 There shall be one law for all who sin unintentionally, both for the native-born and for the resident alien.
Numbers 15:30 But if anyone, whether native-born or a resident alien, acts presumptuously (that is, with arrogant defiance against God), then because that person has rebelled against the Lord, they shall be cut off from their people.
Numbers 15:31 For they have despised the Word of the Lord and made His commandment void. Therefore, that person shall be utterly destroyed and shall bear the guilt of their iniquity.
Numbers 15:32 It happened that while the children of Israel were in the desert, a man was gathering wood on the Sabbath day.
Numbers 15:33 Those who found him gathering wood brought him to Moses and Aaron and the entire community.
Numbers 15:34 They put him in custody, because they did not know what should be done to him.
Numbers 15:35 And the Lord said to Moses: 'That man must surely be put to death. The entire community shall stone him with rocks outside the camp.'
Numbers 15:36 So when they brought him outside the camp, the entire community pelted him with rocks, and he died.
Numbers 15:37 And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying:
Numbers 15:38 Speak to the children of Israel and tell them that they are to make for themselves fringes on the corners of their cloaks throughout their generations, and that they are to put a cord of blue on the fringe of each corner.
Numbers 15:39 When they see these fringes, they are to remember all the commandments of the Lord. They are not to stray after their own thoughts and their eyes, which lead them to spiritual unfaithfulness by lusting after various things.
Numbers 15:40 Instead, they should remember the commandments of the Lord and do them, and so be holy to your God.
Numbers 16:1 Listen now: Korah, the son of Izhar, who was the son of Kohath, who was the son of Levi— along with Dathan and Abiram, who were sons of Eliab, and Hon, who was the son of Peleth, who was the son of Reuben— these men rebelled against Moses.
Numbers 16:2 Also, two hundred and fifty other leaders from the sons of Israel joined them. These men were respected members of the council and were called by their names during times of assembly.
Numbers 16:3 These men gathered together against Moses and Aaron, and they said: 'It is enough that you two are in charge. The whole community of the people is holy, and the Lord is present among all of them. So why do you elevate yourselves above the Lord's people?'
Numbers 16:4 When Moses heard this, he fell face down to the ground in an act of deep reverence and supplication.
Numbers 16:5 Then, speaking to Korah and the entire assembly, Moses said: 'Tomorrow morning, the Lord will show who truly belongs to Him and whom He has made holy. And those whom He has chosen will be allowed to approach Him.'
Numbers 16:6 So this is what you must do: Korah, and all your followers, take your censers.
Numbers 16:7 Place fire in them and put incense on top. Tomorrow, you will offer these before the Lord. Then, whoever the Lord chooses, that person will be the holy one. You sons of Levi are being much too presumptuous.
Numbers 16:8 Moses also said to Korah: 'Listen, sons of Levi!'
Numbers 16:9 'Is it not enough for you that the God of Israel has separated you from all the rest of the people and brought you close to Himself to serve Him in the worship of the Tabernacle, performing the duties for the community?'
Numbers 16:10 'And now, are you also claiming the priesthood for yourselves?'
Numbers 16:11 'Because of this, your entire assembly is actually standing against the Lord. For what has Aaron done that you should complain against him?'
Numbers 16:12 Moses sent a summons for Dathan and Abiram, the sons of Eliab. But they replied: 'We will not come!'
