Numbers 16:13 'Is it not enough for you that you have brought us out of a land flowing with milk and honey, only to kill us in this desert, unless you also try to lord it over us?'
Numbers 16:14 'Indeed, you have not brought us into a land flowing with milk and honey, nor have you given us possession of fields and vineyards! Are you trying to blind us as well? We will not come!'
Numbers 16:15 Moses became very angry and said to the Lord: 'Do not accept their offerings! You know that I have never taken even a single donkey from them, nor have I ever harmed any of them.'
Numbers 16:16 Moses then said to Korah: 'You and your entire congregation are to stand separately before the Lord tomorrow, and Aaron will also stand separately.'
Numbers 16:17 Let each one of you take his censer, put incense on it, and offer two hundred and fifty censers before the Lord. Aaron is also to hold his censer.
Numbers 16:18 So each man took his censer, put fire in it, and then placed incense on top. They all stood at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting, along with Moses and Aaron.
Numbers 16:19 Korah had gathered the entire community against them at the entrance of the Tent.
Numbers 16:20 Then the glory of the Lord appeared over the entire community.
Numbers 16:21 And the Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron, saying:
Numbers 16:22 'Separate yourselves from the midst of this community, so that I may instantly destroy them.'
Numbers 16:23 They both fell face down and said: 'Oh, most mighty God of the spirits of all humankind! Will you be angry with everyone for the sin of just one man?'
Numbers 16:24 The Lord then spoke to Moses, saying:
Numbers 16:25 'Command all the people to separate themselves from the tents of Korah, Dathan, and Abiram.'
Numbers 16:26 Moses then said to the crowd: 'Go away from the tents of these wicked men, and do not touch anything that belongs to them, so that you are not swept away in their sins.'
Numbers 16:27 So the people moved away from the tents of Korah, Dathan, and Abiram on every side. Meanwhile, Dathan and Abiram had come out and were standing at the entrance of their own tents, along with their wives, their children, and all their young and old family members.
Numbers 16:28 And Moses said: 'By this sign, you will know that the Lord has sent me to do all these things that you see, and that I have not devised them on my own authority.'
Numbers 16:29 'If these men die a natural death, the way all people die, and if they are punished by a common human affliction, then the Lord has truly not sent me.'
Numbers 16:30 'But if the Lord does something completely new— if the earth opens its mouth and swallows them and everything that belongs to them, and they go down alive into the realm of the dead— then you will know for certain that these men have blasphemed the Lord.'
Numbers 16:31 Immediately, as soon as Moses finished speaking, the ground under their feet split apart.
Numbers 16:32 The earth opened its mouth and swallowed them with their tents and all their possessions.
Numbers 16:33 So they went down alive into the realm of the dead. The earth closed over them, and they perished from among the community.
Numbers 16:34 All the people of Israel who stood around them, fearing this destruction, fled, crying out: 'Lest the earth swallow us too!'
Numbers 16:35 But a fire also came out from the Lord and killed the two hundred and fifty men who were offering incense.
Numbers 16:36 The Lord spoke to Moses, saying:
Numbers 16:37 'Command Eleazar, the son of Aaron the priest, to take the censers that are lying in the fire, and scatter the fire from them here and there, because the censers have become holy.'
Numbers 16:38 'For they became holy because they were used by these sinners in their deaths. So order them to be hammered into thin plates and fastened to the altar. This is because the incense was offered before the Lord, and so it became holy, to serve as a sign to the sons of Israel.'
Numbers 16:39 So Eleazar the priest took the bronze censers which had been used by those men whom the Lord's fire had consumed, and he hammered them into thin plates and fastened them to the altar.
Numbers 16:40 This was done to serve as a permanent reminder to the sons of Israel, so that no unauthorized person— meaning, anyone not from the lineage of Aaron— would dare to approach to offer incense before the Lord, lest a similar fate happen to him, just as it happened to Korah and his entire assembly, exactly as the Lord had told Moses.
Numbers 17:17:1 The Lord then spoke to Moses, saying:
Numbers 17:17:2 Command Eleazar, the son of Aaron the priest, to take the censers from the burning place, and scatter the ashes far away from this place, because they have become holy.
Numbers 17:17:3 —for they put their lives in danger—those who had sinned. The Lord has shown His favor.
Numbers 17:17:4 And from these censers, they are to make thin plates and fasten them to the altar, because they were offered in the Lord's fire and made holy. Therefore, they will serve as a sign for the children of Israel.
Numbers 17:17:5 No unauthorized person may take up incense to burn before the Lord, nor may they become like Korah and all his company. The Lord had already spoken about this.
Numbers 17:17:6 So Eleazar the priest commanded his son to take the bronze censers in which those whom the Lord's fire had consumed had offered their sacrifice. He was to flatten them into plates and fasten them to the altar.
Numbers 17:17:7 These were to be a memorial for the children of Israel, so that no outsider who is not from the lineage of Aaron would approach to offer incense to the Lord, lest he suffer a fate like Korah. This is what the Lord had said to Moses.
Numbers 17:17:8 Nevertheless, the entire congregation of the children of Israel complained against Moses and Aaron the next day, saying: "You have killed the Lord's people!"
Numbers 17:17:9 When the assembly had gathered against them, and Moses and Aaron saw the congregation's tents were being pulled down by the people, a cloud began to cover them, and the glory of the Lord appeared.
Numbers 17:17:10 Moses and Aaron then entered the tabernacle of testimony.
Numbers 17:17:11 And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying:
Numbers 17:17:12 "Get away from the midst of this congregation, and I will destroy them immediately." Moses and Aaron fell on their faces in supplication.
Numbers 17:17:13 Moses then said to Aaron: "Take a censer and put fire from the altar upon it. Place incense on it, and go quickly to the people to make atonement for them. For the Lord's wrath has already gone out, and a plague is raging."
Numbers 17:17:14 Aaron did as Moses had said, and he ran into the midst of the congregation. He saw that the plague had already begun among the people. He then offered the incense, performing atonement.
Numbers 17:17:15 And standing between the dead and the living, he prayed for them. And the plague was stopped.
Numbers 17:17:16 But fourteen thousand seven hundred people had already perished, in addition to those who had died in Korah's rebellion.
Numbers 17:17:17 Aaron then returned to Moses at the entrance of the tabernacle of testimony, after the plague had been stopped.
Numbers 17:17:18 The Lord spoke to Moses, saying:
Numbers 17:17:19 "Speak to the children of Israel and take from them one rod for each of their ancestral tribes, from all the leaders of their tribes, twelve rods in total. You are to write each man's name on his rod.
Numbers 17:17:20 But you are to write Aaron's name on the rod for the tribe of Levi. Each leader of the ancestral tribes will give one rod for his tribe.
Numbers 17:17:21 You are to place these rods in the tabernacle of testimony, before the ark of the covenant—where I speak with you.
Numbers 17:17:22 The rod that I see sprout, that is the one I have chosen for myself, to put an end to the complaints of the children of Israel that they are grumbling against you.
Numbers 17:17:23 Moses then spoke to the children of Israel, and all the leaders gave him a single rod for each of their tribes and ancestral lines. There were twelve rods, not counting Aaron's rod.
Numbers 17:17:24 Moses then placed the rods before the Lord in the tabernacle of testimony.
Numbers 17:17:25 The next day, when Moses returned, he found that Aaron's rod, for the house of Levi, had sprouted. It had put forth leaves, and from its clusters, flowers had already burst forth, which would ripen into almonds.
Numbers 17:17:26 Moses then brought out all the rods from the presence of the Lord to all the children of Israel. They all saw them, and each man took back his own rod.
Numbers 17:17:27 The Lord then said to Moses: "Return Aaron's rod to the tabernacle of testimony, so that it may be kept there as a sign for the rebellious children of Israel. This way, their complaints against Me will cease, and they will not die."
Numbers 17:17:28 And Moses did exactly as the Lord had commanded him.
Numbers 17:18:1 The Lord then spoke to Aaron: "You and your sons, and your father's house with you, will bear the responsibility for any offense against the sanctuary. And you and your sons together will bear the responsibility for the sins of your priesthood."
Numbers 17:18:2 "Also, take your brethren from the tribe of Levi, from your ancestral line, with you. They are to be joined to you and serve you. But you and your sons are the ones who will serve in the tabernacle of testimony itself."
Numbers 17:18:3 "They will keep watch, according to your commands, over everything that pertains to the service of the tabernacle. However, they must not approach the vessels of the sanctuary or the altar, lest both they and you die."
Numbers 17:18:4 "They are to be with you and keep watch over the duties of the tabernacle and all its ceremonies. No unauthorized person may join you."
Numbers 17:18:5 "You yourselves are to keep watch over the duties of the sanctuary and the service of the altar, so that wrath may not again arise against the children of Israel."
Numbers 17:18:6 "Look, I have given you your brethren the Levites from among the children of Israel. I have given them as a gift to the Lord, so that they may serve in the ministries of the tabernacle of the covenant."
Numbers 17:18:7 "But you and your sons are to keep your priesthood, and all that pertains to the ritual of the altar and the veil. All things that are done within the sanctuary will be ministered by priests alone. No unauthorized person will approach you."
Numbers 17:18:8 The Lord then spoke to Aaron: "Look, I have given you the responsibility for My sacred offerings. All that is set apart as holy by the children of Israel, I have given to you and your sons for your duty, by a perpetual right."
Numbers 17:18:9 "Therefore, these are what you will receive from those things that are consecrated and offered to Me. All that is set apart by the children of Israel, I have given to you and your sons and daughters, by a perpetual right. You are to eat the most holy portions."
Numbers 17:18:10 "You are to eat them in the sanctuary. Only males may eat from them, because they are holy to you."
Numbers 17:18:11 "But the separated firstfruits of all the gifts of the children of Israel, and their offerings and donations, I have given to you and to your sons and your daughters by a perpetual right. Everyone in your household who is clean may eat from them."
Numbers 17:18:12 "All the best oil, and wine, and grain, whatever they offer to the Lord, I have given to you."
Numbers 18:1 The Lord then spoke to Aaron, saying: "You, your sons, and your entire ancestral house with you, will bear the moral responsibility for the purity of the sanctuary. And you and your sons together will be accountable for the sins of your priesthood."
Numbers 18:2 "But also take your brothers from the tribe of Levi—your ancestral tribe—with you. They are to be joined with you and minister to you. However, you and your sons alone will minister in the Tabernacle of the Testimony."
Numbers 18:3 "They will keep watch, obeying your instructions and performing all the work of the Tabernacle. However, they are strictly forbidden from approaching the sacred vessels of the sanctuary or the altar, lest they die, and you too, by allowing such a profanation."
Numbers 18:4 "They will be with you and keep watch over the duties of the Tabernacle and all its ceremonies. No unauthorized person—no one not appointed for this sacred service—may approach you."
Numbers 18:5 "You are to keep watch over the duties of the sanctuary and the service of the altar. Do this so that My righteous anger may no longer break out against the children of Israel."
Numbers 18:6 "For I Myself have given your brothers, the Levites, from among the children of Israel. I have handed them over as a special gift to the Lord, so that they may serve in the ministries of the Tabernacle of the Covenant."
Numbers 18:7 "But you and your sons are to guard your priesthood for all the service of the altar and the veil, and everything that is within these sacred spaces. Through this consecrated service, I have given you the priesthood. Any unauthorized person who approaches these sacred things will surely die."
Numbers 18:8 The Lord then spoke further to Aaron, saying: "Behold, I have given you the charge over the first-offerings of My blessings—all things consecrated by the children of Israel. I allot these to you and your sons by virtue of your perpetually consecrated office."
Numbers 18:9 "Therefore, these are the things you will receive from those that are consecrated and offered to the Lord: every offering, every sacrifice, and whatever is rendered to Me for sin and for trespass, and whatever belongs to the most holy things. This will be yours and your sons'."
Numbers 18:10 "You will eat these in the sanctuary. Only males may eat of them, because they are consecrated specifically for you."
Numbers 18:11 "Also, the first-offerings of all your gifts and everything the children of Israel offer, I have given to you and your sons and your daughters by a perpetual right. Anyone who is ritually clean in your household may eat of them."
Numbers 18:12 "All the choicest part of the oil, and of the wine, and of the grain—whatever they offer to the Lord as first-fruits—I have given to you."
Numbers 18:13 "Whatever first grows in the land and is brought to the Lord will be yours. Everyone in your household who is ritually clean may eat of it."
Numbers 18:14 "Every devoted thing—whatever has been consecrated to utter destruction or exclusion from common use in Israel—will be yours."
Numbers 18:15 "Everything that opens the womb of all flesh that they offer to the Lord, whether of humans or of animals, and the firstborn of men and of beasts, will be yours."
Numbers 18:16 "However, for the firstborn of humans, you must receive a redemption price. Unclean animals will be redeemed with money: from one month old, at a value of six shekels of silver, according to the standard weight of the sanctuary. A shekel has twenty *obols*—or *gerahs*."
Numbers 18:17 "But the firstborn of an ox, or a sheep, or a goat, you shall not have redeemed, because they are consecrated to the Lord. You will only pour their blood upon the altar, and you yourselves may eat their meat."
Numbers 18:18 "And this meat will be consecrated to you, just like the consecrated breast and the right shoulder are given to you."
Numbers 18:19 "All the consecrated first-offerings that the children of Israel offer to the Lord, I have given to you and your sons and your daughters by a perpetual right. This is an everlasting covenant of salt—a sacred, unbreakable agreement—before the Lord, for you and your sons."
Numbers 18:20 The Lord also spoke to Aaron: "You will possess nothing in their land, nor will you have any inheritance among them, for I am your portion and your inheritance among the children of Israel."
Numbers 18:21 "But to the children of Levi, I have given all the tithes in Israel as their inheritance, for the service by which they minister to Me in the Tabernacle of the Covenant."
Numbers 18:22 "This is so that the children of Israel may no longer approach the Tabernacle directly and thereby incur the sin that brings death."
Numbers 18:23 "Only the Levites will serve Me in the Tabernacle of the Covenant, and they will bear their own sins related to this service—meaning they will be held accountable for any failures in their duties. This will be an everlasting sacred ordinance throughout your generations. They will possess nothing else as property, for their unique role,"
Numbers 18:24 "They will be content with the offering of tithes, which I have set apart for their use and necessities."
Numbers 18:25 The Lord then spoke to Moses, saying:
Numbers 18:26 "Command the Levites, and declare to them: When you receive the tithes from the children of Israel, which I have given to you for your needs, you must set apart from them a first-offering for the Lord. This is to be the tenth part of the tithe you received."
Numbers 18:27 "This will be reckoned to you as an offering of first-fruits, just as if it were from the threshing floor or from the winepress."
Numbers 18:28 "Thus, from all the first-offerings that you receive, present a first-offering to the Lord, and give it to Aaron the priest."
Numbers 18:29 "From all the sacred gifts and tithes, you will consecrate to the Lord the choicest and the very best part."
Numbers 18:30 "And you are to say to them: 'If you eat the rich and choice portions from these offerings, you will not incur sin, because neither you nor your sons will be defiled by eating that which is sacred, provided you have properly offered the Lord's choicest portion beforehand.'"
Numbers 18:31 "You and your households may eat these offerings in any of your dwelling places, because it is your reward for your service in the Tabernacle of the Testimony."
Numbers 18:32 "You will not incur sin concerning this matter—meaning eating the portion given to you—provided you do not profane the first-offerings of the children of Israel, which are consecrated to the Lord. If you profane them, you will surely die."
Numbers 19:1 The Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron, giving them this instruction:
Numbers 19:2 “This is the ordinance for a specific offering which the Lord has established: Command the children of Israel to bring you a red heifer that is without blemish, and which has no imperfection, and which has never had a yoke placed upon it.
Numbers 19:3 And you shall give it to Eleazar the priest, who shall lead the heifer outside the camp and sacrifice it in the sight of everyone.
Numbers 19:4 And Eleazar will dip his finger into its blood and sprinkle some of the blood seven times towards the front of the Tent of Meeting.
Numbers 19:5 Then, in Eleazar’s sight, the heifer shall be burned completely: its hide, its flesh, its blood, and its dung shall all be consumed by the fire.
Numbers 19:6 And the priest shall take cedar wood, hyssop, and scarlet yarn dyed twice, and throw them into the fire that is burning the heifer.
Numbers 19:7 Afterward, the priest must wash his clothes and bathe his body with water; only then may he enter the camp. However, he will remain ritually unclean until evening.
Numbers 19:8 Similarly, the one who burned the heifer must also wash his clothes and bathe his body with water, and he too will remain ritually unclean until evening.
Numbers 19:9 Then, a ritually clean man shall gather the ashes of the heifer and pour them out outside the camp in a very clean place. These ashes are to be kept by the congregation of the children of Israel to prepare the water of purification for sprinkling—because the heifer was burned as a sin offering to remove uncleanness.
Numbers 19:10 And the man who carried the ashes must wash his clothes, and he too will be ritually unclean until evening. This ordinance shall be a perpetual statute for the children of Israel and for the foreigners who live among them.
Numbers 19:11 Whoever touches the dead body of a human being will become ritually unclean for seven days because of that contact.
Numbers 19:12 Such a person must purify himself with this water on the third day and on the seventh day; only then will he be clean. If he is not purified on the third day, then he will not be made clean on the seventh day either.
Numbers 19:13 Anyone who touches a dead human body and does not purify himself with this mixture of water will defile the Lord’s Tent of Meeting and must be cut off from Israel. Because the water of purification was not sprinkled upon him, he remains ritually unclean, and his uncleanness stays upon him.
Numbers 19:14 This is the law concerning a man who dies within a tent: Everyone who enters that tent, and all the objects within it, will become ritually defiled for seven days.
Numbers 19:15 Any open vessel that does not have a lid or a covering sealed upon it will also become ritually unclean.
Numbers 19:16 If anyone in the open field touches a person who has died naturally, or a person who has been killed, or touches someone dead in any other manner, that person will be ritually unclean for seven days.
Numbers 19:17 For the unclean person, some of the ashes from the burnt offering made for sin must be taken and mixed with running spring water in a vessel.
Numbers 19:18 Then a ritually clean person shall dip a sprig of hyssop into this mixture and sprinkle it on the tent and all its furnishings, and on the people who were in the tent, and on anyone who touched a dead body—whether it was buried, or killed, or merely human bones, or a grave.
Numbers 19:19 And the ritually clean person shall sprinkle the unclean person on the third day and on the seventh day. After being purified on the seventh day, the unclean person must wash his own clothes and bathe himself, and then he will be ritually clean by evening.
Numbers 19:20 But if anyone who is ritually unclean is not purified by this prescribed rite, that person will be cut off from the assembly of the people. This is because he has defiled the Lord’s Holy Sanctuary by remaining unclean, and the water of purification was not sprinkled on him. Such a person remains ritually unclean.
Numbers 19:21 This shall be an enduring, lawful commandment. The person who sprinkles the water of purification must wash his clothes. And anyone who merely touches the water of purification will become ritually unclean until evening.
Numbers 19:22 Whatever the ritually unclean person touches will become ritually unclean; and any person who touches that unclean person will also become ritually unclean until evening.

Numbers 19:24

Numbers 19:40 
Numbers 20:1 The children of Israel, the whole multitude of them, entered the desert of Sin in the first month. The people settled in Kadesh, and there, Mary—the sister of Moses and Aaron—died and was buried.
Numbers 20:2 But when the multitude needed water, they gathered together against Moses and Aaron.
Numbers 20:3 They argued with Moses and said, "We wish we had died with our brothers before the Lord!"
Numbers 20:4 Why did you bring the assembly of the Lord into this wilderness, for us and our livestock to die here?
Numbers 20:5 Why did you make us leave Egypt and bring us to this terrible place? It is a place where nothing can be sown, and there are no fig trees, no grapevines, no pomegranates, and no water!
Numbers 20:6 So Moses and Aaron left the multitude and went to the Tent of the Covenant. They fell face down on the ground, crying out to the Lord and saying, "Lord God, we have cried out to You, saying: Your people are perishing!" And the glory of the Lord appeared over them.
Numbers 20:7 And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying:
Numbers 20:8 Take the staff, and gather the people—you and Aaron your brother. Speak to the rock in front of them, and it will give them water. When you bring forth water from the rock, the whole multitude and their livestock will drink.
Numbers 20:9 So Moses took the staff from before the Lord, just as the Lord had commanded him.
Numbers 20:10 Then, after gathering the crowds before the rock, Moses said to them, "Listen, you rebels and unbelievers! Do you think we can bring water out for you from this rock?"
Numbers 20:11 Then Moses lifted his hand and struck the rock with his staff twice. A great abundance of water gushed out, so much that the people and their livestock drank.
Numbers 20:12 And the Lord said to Moses and Aaron, "Because you did not trust Me enough to show My holiness before the children of Israel, you will not lead these people into the land that I will give them."
Numbers 20:13 This is the Water of Contradiction, where the children of Israel argued against the Lord, and where His holiness was manifested among them.
Numbers 20:14 In the meantime, Moses sent messengers from Kadesh to the king of Edom to say this: "Your brother Israel sends this message: You know all the hardship that has come upon us."
Numbers 20:15 Our fathers went down into Egypt, and we lived there for a long time. The Egyptians afflicted both us and our fathers.
Numbers 20:16 And we cried out to the Lord, and He heard us and sent an angel who led us out of Egypt. Now, here we are, in the city of Kadesh, right at the edge of your territory.
Numbers 20:17 We beg you, allow us to pass through your land. We will not go through the fields or vineyards; we will not drink water from your wells. We will travel only on the public road and will not turn right or left until we have passed through your borders.
Numbers 20:18 Edom answered him, "You shall not pass through my land; otherwise, I will come out against you with weapons."
Numbers 20:19 And the children of Israel said, "We will go along the beaten path. And if we or our livestock drink any of your water, we will pay you for it. We only ask that you let us pass through quickly."
Numbers 20:20 But Edom replied, "You will not be allowed to pass." And immediately, he came out to meet them with a vast army and great strength.
Numbers 20:21 Edom refused to let Israel pass through his territory, so Israel turned away from him.
Numbers 20:22 After they moved their camp from Kadesh, they came to Mount Hor, which is on the border of the land of Edom.
Numbers 20:23 There, on Mount Hor, at the borders of the land of Edom, the Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron, saying:
Numbers 20:24 Take Aaron and gather him to his people—meaning, he will die. For he will not enter the land that I have given to the children of Israel, because he was disobedient to My command at the Water of Contradiction.
Numbers 20:25 Take Aaron and his son Eleazar, and lead them up to Mount Hor.
Numbers 20:26 When you have stripped the father of his vestments, dress his son Eleazar in them. Aaron will then be gathered to his people—he will die there.
Numbers 20:27 Moses did just as the Lord had commanded, in front of the whole multitude, and they went up Mount Hor.
Numbers 20:28 And when Moses stripped Aaron of his garments, he dressed his son Eleazar in them.
Numbers 20:29 Aaron died there, on the summit of the mountain. Then Moses and Eleazar came down from the mountain.
Numbers 21:1 When the Canaanite king of Arad, who lived in the south, heard that Israel was coming by the way of the spies, he fought against them and gained a partial victory over them.
Numbers 21:2 So Israel made a solemn vow to the Lord and said, 'If You deliver this people into my hand, I will utterly destroy their cities.'
Numbers 21:3 And the Lord heard Israel's prayers and delivered the Canaanites to them. Israel utterly destroyed them and their cities, and they named that place Hormah, which means 'utterly destroyed and consecrated to God'.
Numbers 21:4 And they set out from Mount Hor, taking the road that leads to the Red Sea, in order to go around the land of Edom. The people became impatient due to the long journey and the hardships.
Numbers 21:5 And speaking against God and against Moses, they said, 'Why have you led us out of Egypt, only for us to die in this wasteland? There is no bread here, and no water. Our souls are disgusted by this very light food' —referring to the manna God miraculously provided.
Numbers 21:6 For this reason, the Lord sent fiery serpents among the people, which bit them, and many of the Israelites died.
Numbers 21:7 Therefore, the people came to Moses and said, 'We have sinned, because we have spoken against the Lord and against you. Pray that He may take away these serpents from us.' And Moses prayed for the people.
Numbers 21:8 And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying, 'Make a bronze serpent, and set it up as a standard. Whoever is bitten, when he looks at it, will live.'
Numbers 21:9 So Moses made a bronze serpent and set it up as a standard. When those who were bitten looked at it, they were healed.
Numbers 21:10 And the children of Israel set out and encamped in Oboth.
Numbers 21:11 From there, they journeyed and pitched their tents in Ije-Abarim, in the wilderness that faces Moab, towards the eastern side.
Numbers 21:12 And from there, they set out and came to the valley of Zered.
Numbers 21:13 From there they departed and encamped beyond the Arnon River, which is in the wilderness and flows from the border of the Amorites. For the Arnon is the border of Moab, lying between the Midianites and the Amorites.
Numbers 21:14 Therefore, it is said in the book of the Wars of the Lord: 'As He did at the Red Sea, so He did at the torrents of Arnon.'
Numbers 21:15 The channels of the torrents curved down to the land of the cities, extending all the way to the borders of Moab.
Numbers 21:16 From there they came to the well; this is the well about which the Lord spoke to Moses, saying, 'Gather the people, and I will give them water.'
Numbers 21:17 Then Israel sang this song: 'Spring up, O well! Let the people sing to it.'
Numbers 21:18 This is the well that the princes dug, and which the leaders of the people prepared, guided by the Lawgiver —Moses— and with their staffs. From the wilderness of Mattanah, they went to Nahaliel.
Numbers 21:19 From Nahaliel, they went on to Bamoth.
Numbers 21:20 From Bamoth, they traveled to the valley that is in the region of Moab, on the summit of Pisgah, overlooking the desert.
Numbers 21:21 And Israel sent messengers to Sihon, king of the Amorites, saying:
Numbers 21:22 'Allow us to pass through your land. We will not turn aside through your fields or through your vineyards. We will not drink water from your wells. But we will travel along the King's Highway until we have passed through your borders.'
Numbers 21:23 But Sihon did not permit Israel to pass through his borders. Instead, he gathered a large army, went out against them into the wilderness, came to Jahaz, and fought against them.
Numbers 21:24 And Israel struck him down with the edge of the sword and took possession of his land from the Arnon River to the Jabbok River, and up to the children of Ammon. For the boundary of the Amorites at the Jabbok River was a strong and fortified boundary.
Numbers 21:25 So Israel took all his cities and dwelt in the cities of the Amorites, specifically in Heshbon and its surrounding villages.
Numbers 21:26 For Heshbon had been the city of Sihon, king of the Amorites, who had fought against the former king of Moab and taken all his land from his hand as far as the Arnon River.
Numbers 21:27 Therefore, people speak in a proverb, saying: 'Come to Heshbon! Let it be rebuilt, and let the city of Sihon be restored!'
Numbers 21:28 For fire went forth from Heshbon, a flame from the city of Sihon, and it devoured Ar of Moab, along with the inhabitants of the high places of Arnon.
Numbers 21:29 Woe to you, Moab! You are ruined, O people of Chemosh —your national god—! He gave his sons who fled, and his daughters, into captivity to Sihon, king of the Amorites.
Numbers 21:30 Their yoke was broken from Heshbon even to Dibon. They perished as far as Nophah and as far as Medeba.
Numbers 21:31 So Israel dwelt in the land of the Amorites.
Numbers 21:32 And Moses sent men to spy out Jazer, and they captured its villages and took possession of its inhabitants.
Numbers 21:33 Then they turned and went up by the way to Bashan. And Og, the king of Bashan, with all his people, came out to meet them at Edrei and fought against them.
Numbers 21:34 And the Lord said to Moses, 'Do not fear him, for I have delivered him, and all his people, and his land into your hand. You shall do to him as you did to Sihon, king of the Amorites, who lived in Heshbon.'
Numbers 21:35 So they struck down Og and his sons and all his people until not a single survivor remained, and they took possession of his land.
Numbers 22:1 The Sons of Israel then broke camp and set up their tents in the plains of Moab, on the other side of the Jordan River, directly opposite Jericho.
Numbers 22:2 Now Balak, the son of Zippor, saw everything that the Sons of Israel had done to the Amorites.
Numbers 22:3 Moab was greatly afraid and was terrified at the sight of the people because there were so many of them.
Numbers 22:4 So they said to the elders of Midian: 'This people will now consume all of our surrounding lands, just as an ox eats grass down to its roots.' At that time, Balak, the son of Zippor, was king in Moab.
Numbers 22:5 So Balak sent messengers to Balaam, the son of Beor, a diviner who lived by the river in the land of the sons of Ammab, to call him and say: 'Behold, a people has come out of Egypt who now cover the face of the earth, and they are settled directly opposite me.'
Numbers 22:6 'Therefore, come now and curse this people for me, because they are stronger than I am. Perhaps then I will be able to strike them and drive them out of my land. For I know that whoever you bless is blessed, and whoever you curse is cursed.'
Numbers 22:7 So the elders of Moab and the elders of Midian went, carrying the fee for divination in their hands. When they came to Balaam and told him all the words of Balak,
Numbers 22:8 he answered: 'Stay here tonight, and I will tell you whatever the Lord says to me.' So they stayed with Balaam.
Numbers 22:9 God came to Balaam and said to him: 'Who are these men with you?'
Numbers 22:10 Balaam answered: 'Balak, the son of Zippor, the king of the Moabites, has sent word to me,' -
Numbers 22:11 saying: 'Behold, a people has come out of Egypt and now covers the face of the earth. Come and curse them for me, so that perhaps I can fight against them and drive them out.'
Numbers 22:12 And God said to Balaam: 'Do not go with them, and do not curse the people, because they are blessed.'
Numbers 22:13 Balaam rose early in the morning and said to Balak's officials: 'Go back to your own land, because the Lord has forbidden me to come with you.'
Numbers 22:14 The officials returned and told Balak: 'Balaam refused to come with us.'
Numbers 22:15 Again, Balak sent more messengers, and they were more numerous and more honorable than the first ones.
Numbers 22:16 When they came to Balaam, they said: 'This is what Balak, the son of Zippor, says: Please do not let anything stop you from coming to me!'
Numbers 22:17 'I will bestow great honor upon you, and whatever you wish, I will give you. Come, therefore, and curse this people for me.'
Numbers 22:18 Balaam answered: 'Even if Balak were to give me his house full of silver and gold, I could not change the word of the Lord, my God, to speak anything, great or small, contrary to it.'
Numbers 22:19 'Please, you also stay here tonight, so that I may know what the Lord will say to me again.'
Numbers 22:20 So God came to Balaam at night and said to him: 'If these men have come to call you, then get up and go with them. Nevertheless, only do what I command you.'
Numbers 22:21 Balaam rose early in the morning, saddled his donkey, and went with the officials of Moab.
Numbers 22:22 And God was angry at him for going. The Angel of the Lord stood in the way against him. Balaam was riding on his donkey, and he had two servants with him.
Numbers 22:23 The donkey saw the Angel standing in the road with a drawn sword, and it turned off the road and went into the field. Balaam began to beat it, trying to force it back onto the road.
Numbers 22:24 Then the Angel stood in a narrow path between two walls, where vineyards were enclosed.
Numbers 22:25 When the donkey saw the Angel, it pressed itself against the wall and crushed Balaam's foot against it. And he beat it again.
Numbers 22:26 The Angel then passed further on and stood in an even narrower place, where there was no room to turn either to the right or to the left.
Numbers 22:27 When the donkey saw the Angel standing there, it collapsed under Balaam, who was riding it. Balaam became even more furious and beat its side with a stick.
Numbers 22:28 Then the Lord opened the mouth of the donkey, and it spoke: 'What have I done to you? Why have you beaten me these three times already?'
Numbers 22:29 Balaam answered: 'Because you have made a fool of me! If only I had a sword, I would kill you!'
Numbers 22:30 The donkey said: 'Am I not your own donkey, on which you have ridden all your life until this very day? Have I ever done such a thing to you before?' He answered: 'No, never.'
Numbers 22:31 Immediately, the Lord opened Balaam's eyes, and he saw the Angel standing in the road with a drawn sword, blocking his way. And Balaam bowed down, prostrating himself on the ground in worship.
Numbers 22:32 And the Angel said: 'Why have you beaten your donkey these three times already? I have come to stand against you, because your way is perverse and contrary to my will.'
Numbers 22:33 'If the donkey had not turned aside from the road, I would have killed you and spared its life.'
Numbers 22:34 Balaam said: 'I have sinned, for I did not know that you were standing in my way. Now, if it displeases you, I will turn back.'
Numbers 22:35 The Angel said to Balaam: 'Go with these men, but only speak what I command you.'
Numbers 22:36 So Balaam went with Balak's officials. When Balak heard that Balaam was coming, he went out to meet him in the city of the Moabites, which is situated on the border of the Arnon River.
Numbers 22:37 And Balak said to Balaam: 'Did we not send messengers to you to call you? Why did you not come to me immediately? Do you truly believe that I cannot reward you with enough honor?'
Numbers 22:38 Balaam answered him: 'Behold, I am here now. Can I speak anything more than what God puts into my mouth?'
Numbers 22:39 So they went together and came to the city that was on the outermost borders of his kingdom.
Numbers 22:40 So Balak sacrificed oxen and sheep, and he sent some of the meat to Balaam and to the officials who were with him.
Numbers 23:1 Balaam then said to Balak, 'Build seven altars for me here' — these were for the pagan sacrifices Balaam was about to perform — 'and prepare seven young bulls and seven rams for them.'
Numbers 23:2 Balak did exactly what Balaam had told him. He placed a young bull and a ram on each of the seven altars for sacrifice.
Numbers 23:3 Balaam then said to Balak, 'Stay here by your burnt offering for a little while. I am going to see if the Lord will meet me; whatever He reveals to me, I will tell you.'
Numbers 23:4 So Balaam went off quickly. And God met him.
Numbers 23:5 And the Lord spoke to Balaam, putting a specific message into his mouth. The Lord said, 'Go back to Balak, and this is what you are to say.'
Numbers 23:6 Balaam returned and found Balak still standing by his burnt offering, along with all the leaders of the Moabites.
Numbers 23:7 Then Balaam delivered his prophetic message, saying: 'Balak, the king of the Moabites, brought me here from Aram, from the mountains in the east. He told me, "Come, put a curse on Jacob's people! Hurry, denounce Israel!"'
Numbers 23:8 But how can I curse those whom God Himself has not cursed? How can I denounce those whom the Lord has not denounced?
Numbers 23:9 From these high rocks, I see the people of Israel; from these hills, I look upon them. They are a people who will live apart, unique and distinct, and they will not be counted among the other nations.
Numbers 23:10 Who could possibly count the countless descendants of Jacob, or number even a quarter of the people of Israel? May my own soul die the death of the righteous, and may my final end be like theirs!
Numbers 23:11 Balak then said to Balaam, 'What are you doing? I brought you here to curse my enemies, but instead, you have blessed them!'
Numbers 23:12 Balaam answered him, 'Do I not have to speak exactly what the Lord puts into my mouth and commands me to say?'
Numbers 23:13 Then Balak said, 'Come with me to another place, from where you can see only a part of the Israelites, but not all of them. Perhaps from there you can curse them for me.'
Numbers 23:14 So Balak led Balaam to a high lookout point, the summit of Mount Pisgah. There, Balak built another seven altars and placed a young bull and a ram on each.
Numbers 23:15 Balaam said to Balak, 'Stay here by your burnt offering, while I go to meet with the Lord again.'
Numbers 23:16 And when the Lord met Balaam, He again put a specific message into his mouth. The Lord said, 'Go back to Balak, and this is what you are to say to him.'
Numbers 23:17 Balaam returned and found Balak still standing by his burnt offering, with the leaders of Moab assembled with him.
Numbers 23:18 When Balaam announced his return, Balak immediately asked, 'What has the Lord spoken this time?'
Numbers 23:19 Then Balaam delivered his prophetic message, saying: 'God is not a mere man, that He should lie; nor is He a son of man, that He should change His mind or regret His decisions.'
Numbers 23:20 Has God said something, and He will not do it? Has He spoken a word, and He will not bring it to pass?
Numbers 23:21 God sees no iniquity in Jacob, and He sees no evil or trouble in Israel to curse them for.
Numbers 23:22 The Lord their God is with them, and the joyful shout of their King's triumph is heard among them.
Numbers 23:23 For there is no magic spell that can work against Jacob, nor any divination that can succeed against Israel.
Numbers 23:24 At the proper time, it will be said of Jacob and Israel, 'See what great things God has accomplished for them!'
Numbers 23:25 Balak said to Balaam, 'What is this you are doing? You are neither cursing them, nor are you blessing them!'
Numbers 23:26 Balaam answered him, 'Did I not tell you that whatever the Lord commands, that is what I must speak?'
Numbers 23:27 Then Balak said to him, 'Come, I will lead you to yet another place. Perhaps from there, it will finally please God to let you curse them for me.'
Numbers 23:28 So Balak led Balaam to the very top of Mount Peor, which overlooks the desolate wilderness.
Numbers 23:29 Balaam said to Balak, 'Build seven more altars for me here, and prepare seven young bulls and seven rams again.'
Numbers 23:30 Balak did exactly as Balaam had earnestly requested, placing a young bull and a ram on each of the altars.
Numbers 23:31 When Balaam saw that it truly pleased the Lord to bless Israel, he no longer went off by himself, as was his custom, to seek divination or omens. Instead, he fixed his gaze toward the wilderness,
Numbers 23:32 and as he looked up, he saw Israel encamped, tribe by tribe. Then the Spirit of God powerfully came upon him,
Numbers 23:33 and Balaam delivered his prophetic message, saying: 'This is the declaration of Balaam, son of Beor; the declaration of the man whose spiritual eyes have been opened by God;'
Numbers 23:34 He declares what he heard of the words of God, who saw the vision of the Almighty while in a trance, receiving divine light and revelation.
Numbers 23:35 How beautiful are your dwelling places, O Jacob! How lovely are your tents, O Israel!
Numbers 23:36 They are like lush valleys stretching out, like gardens beside flowing rivers, like the tents that the Lord Himself has pitched, like cedar trees standing tall by abundant waters.
Numbers 23:37 Water will flow abundantly from their buckets, and their descendants will spread out like abundant waters, growing and multiplying.
Numbers 23:38 Their king shall be more exalted than Agag—a symbol of powerful, hostile rulers—and his kingdom shall be lifted up in greatness.
Numbers 23:39 God brought them out of Egypt, and His strength is like the immense power of a wild ox.
Numbers 23:40 They shall devour the nations that are their enemies, they shall crush their bones, and pierce them through with their arrows.
Numbers 24:1 Balaam realized that the Lord intended to bless Israel. So, unlike his previous attempts, he did not go out to look for omens or divination; instead, he directed his gaze towards the wilderness.
Numbers 24:2 He lifted his eyes and saw Israel encamped, tribe by tribe. Then, the Spirit of God came powerfully upon him.
Numbers 24:3 He then delivered his prophetic message, saying:
Numbers 24:4 “This is the oracle of Balaam, son of Beor. This is the oracle of the man whose spiritual eyes have been opened.”
Numbers 24:5 “This is the oracle of one who hears the words of God, who sees visions from the Almighty. He falls into a trance, yet his spiritual eyes are opened to divine revelations.”
Numbers 24:6 “How beautiful are your tents, O Jacob, and your dwellings, O Israel.”
Numbers 24:7 “They are like shaded valleys, like gardens beside flowing rivers. They are like the dwellings the Lord Himself has set up, like cedars growing near abundant waters.”
Numbers 24:8 “Water will flow from his buckets, ensuring abundant prosperity. His offspring will spread widely, like many waters. His king will be exalted above Agag, and his kingdom will be lifted high.”
Numbers 24:9 “He lies down like a lion, and like a lioness, none dare awaken him. Blessed is he who blesses you, and cursed is he who curses you.”
Numbers 24:10 Enraged, Balak clapped his hands in anger at Balaam and said, “I called you to curse my enemies, but instead, you have blessed them these three times!”
Numbers 24:11 “Therefore, flee back to your own home! I had promised you great honor, but the Lord Himself has deprived you of that honor.”
Numbers 24:12 Balaam answered, “Did I not tell your messengers, whom you sent to me before, saying:”
Numbers 24:13 “‘Even if Balak were to give me his house full of silver and gold, I cannot go beyond the command of the Lord my God to speak anything, whether small or great, on my own authority. I can only speak what God says.’”
Numbers 24:14 “Nevertheless, now I am going back to my own people. But first, I will advise you on what this people, Israel, will do to your people in the last days.”
Numbers 24:15 Then he delivered his prophetic message once more, saying: “This is the oracle of Balaam, son of Beor. This is the oracle of the man whose spiritual eyes have been opened.”
Numbers 24:16 “This is the oracle of one who hears the words of God, who understands the knowledge of the Most High, and who sees visions from the Almighty. He falls into a trance, yet his eyes remain open to divine revelations.”
Numbers 24:17 “I see him, but not in this present time. I behold him, but not nearby. A star will rise from Jacob, and a scepter will emerge from Israel. He will crush the leaders of Moab and destroy all the sons of Seth.”
Numbers 24:18 “Edom will become his possession, and Seir will be his inheritance. Israel will act with great strength.”
Numbers 24:19 “From Jacob will come a ruler who will destroy the remnant that survives from the city.”
Numbers 24:20 When Balaam saw Amalek, he delivered his prophetic message, saying: “Amalek was once the foremost among the nations, but its end will be utter destruction.”
Numbers 24:21 He also saw the Kenites, and delivering his prophetic message, he said: “How strong is your dwelling place! You have set your nest securely in the rock.”
Numbers 24:22 “Nevertheless, you too will be plundered and carried away, until Asshur takes you captive.”
Numbers 24:23 And again, he delivered his prophetic message, saying: “Alas! Who will survive when God brings these things to pass?”
Numbers 24:24 “Warships will come from Italy, and they will afflict Asshur and also the Hebrews. And they themselves, the invaders, will perish in the end.”
Numbers 24:25 Then Balaam rose up and returned to his own place. Balak also departed by the way he had come.
Numbers 25:1 The people of Israel settled in the region of Sittim, and they committed grave sin by engaging in fornication with the daughters of Moab.
Numbers 25:2 These women then invited the Israelite men to the sacrifices offered to their pagan gods. And the Israelite men ate the sacrificial food and worshipped these false gods.
Numbers 25:3 In this way, Israel consecrated themselves to Baal-Peor, a false god of the Moabites. Because of this, the Lord became very angry with them.
Numbers 25:4 Then the Lord said to Moses: 'Take all the leaders of the people who have committed this sin, and execute them publicly before the sun, by hanging them up for all to see. Do this so that my fierce anger may be turned away from the people of Israel.'
Numbers 25:5 And so, Moses said to the judges of Israel: 'Let each of you, with your own hand, kill those among your kinsmen who have consecrated themselves to Baal-Peor.'
Numbers 25:6 And behold, while Moses and the entire assembly of the sons of Israel were weeping in repentance at the entrance of the tabernacle, one of the sons of Israel went openly before his brothers to a Midianite prostitute.
Numbers 25:7 When Phinehas, the son of Eleazar, who was the son of Aaron the priest, saw this sinful act, he rose from the midst of the congregation and took a spear in his hand.
Numbers 25:8 He followed the Israelite man into the tent where the sin was being committed, and he pierced both of them through at the same time—the man and the woman, right through their reproductive organs. Immediately, the plague among the sons of Israel stopped.
Numbers 25:9 Before the plague stopped, twenty-four thousand people had been killed.
Numbers 25:10 Then the Lord spoke to Moses, saying:
Numbers 25:11 'Phinehas, the son of Eleazar, the son of Aaron the priest, has turned my divine wrath away from the sons of Israel. He did this because he was stirred up with my own divine zeal against them. And because of his action, I did not destroy the sons of Israel as I was angry enough to do.'
Numbers 25:12 'Therefore, tell him: Behold, I am giving him my covenant of peace.'
Numbers 25:13 'This covenant will be for him and for his descendants after him, a perpetual covenant of the priesthood. This is because he was zealous for his God, and in doing so, he made atonement for the wickedness of the sons of Israel.'
Numbers 25:14 Now the name of the Israelite man who was killed with the Midianite prostitute was Zimri, the son of Salu. He was a leader of a family and a tribe within Simeon.
Numbers 25:15 And the name of the Midianite woman who was killed with him was Cozbi, the daughter of Zur, who was a noble chieftain of the Midianites.
Numbers 25:16 Then the Lord spoke to Moses, saying:
Numbers 25:17 'Consider the Midianites your enemies, and you must strike them down.'
Numbers 25:18 'You must strike them down because they also acted hostilely against you. They deceived you through the idol Peor, and through Cozbi, the daughter of a Midianite leader, who was one of their own, and who was killed on the day of the plague because of the wickedness involving Peor.'
Numbers 26:1 After that great plague, in which so many had died, the Lord God spoke to Moses and to Eleazar, Aaron’s son, who was the priest.
Numbers 26:2 Take a census of all the people of Israel, starting from twenty years old and upwards, counting them according to their family lines and households. Include everyone who is able to go out to war.
Numbers 26:3 So Moses and Eleazar the priest spoke in the plains of Moab, beside the Jordan River, opposite Jericho, to all those who were twenty years old and upwards, just as the Lord God had commanded them.
Numbers 26:4 These are the names of the sons of Israel, who had come out of the land of Egypt. Reuben was the firstborn of Israel.
Numbers 26:5 The sons of Reuben were: Hanoch, from whom came the family of the Hanochites; Pallu, from whom came the family of the Palluites;
Numbers 26:6 Hezron, from whom came the family of the Hezronites; and Carmi, from whom came the family of the Carmites.
Numbers 26:7 These were the families of the tribe of Reuben. Their registered number was forty-three thousand, seven hundred and thirty men.
Numbers 26:8 The son of Pallu was Eliab.
Numbers 26:9 The sons of Eliab were Nemuel, Dathan, and Abiram. These are the Dathan and Abiram who were prominent leaders in the assembly, and who rebelled against Moses and Aaron during Korah’s rebellion, when they rebelled against the Lord God.
Numbers 26:10 The earth then opened up and swallowed them and Korah, in the midst of their destruction, at the time when the fire consumed two hundred and fifty men. That was a great and fearsome warning from God.
Numbers 26:11 However, the sons of Korah did not die.
Numbers 26:12 The sons of Simeon, according to their families, were: Nemuel, from whom came the family of the Nemuelites; Jamin, from whom came the family of the Jaminites; Jachin, from whom came the family of the Jachinites;
Numbers 26:13 Zerah, from whom came the family of the Zerahites; and Shaul, from whom came the family of the Shaulites.
Numbers 26:14 These were the families of the tribe of Simeon. Their total registered number was twenty-two thousand, two hundred men.
Numbers 26:15 The sons of Gad, according to their families, were: Zephon, from whom came the family of the Zephonites; Haggi, from whom came the family of the Haggites; Shuni, from whom came the family of the Shunites;
Numbers 26:16 Ozni, from whom came the family of the Oznites; Eri, from whom came the family of the Erites;
Numbers 26:17 Arod, from whom came the family of the Arodites; and Areli, from whom came the family of the Arelites.
Numbers 26:18 These were the families of the tribe of Gad. Their registered number was forty thousand, five hundred men.
Numbers 26:19 The sons of Judah were Er and Onan. Both of them died in the land of Canaan.
Numbers 26:20 The remaining sons of Judah, according to their families, were: Shelah, from whom came the family of the Shelanites; Perez, from whom came the family of the Perezites; and Zerah, from whom came the family of the Zerahites.
Numbers 26:21 Furthermore, the sons of Perez were: Hezron, from whom came the family of the Hezronites; and Hamul, from whom came the family of the Hamulites.
Numbers 26:22 These were the families of the tribe of Judah. Their registered number was seventy-six thousand, five hundred men.
Numbers 26:23 The sons of Issachar, according to their families, were: Tola, from whom came the family of the Tolaites; Puvah, from whom came the family of the Puvahites;
Numbers 26:24 Jashub, from whom came the family of the Jashubites; and Shimron, from whom came the family of the Shimronites.
Numbers 26:25 These were the families of the tribe of Issachar. Their registered number was sixty-four thousand, three hundred men.
Numbers 26:26 The sons of Zebulun, according to their families, were: Sered, from whom came the family of the Seredites; Elon, from whom came the family of the Elonites; and Jahleel, from whom came the family of the Jahleelites.
Numbers 26:27 These were the families of the tribe of Zebulun. Their registered number was sixty thousand, five hundred men.
Numbers 26:28 The sons of Joseph, according to their families, were Manasseh and Ephraim.
Numbers 26:29 The sons of Manasseh were: Machir, from whom came the family of the Machirites. Machir was the father of Gilead, from whom came the family of the Gileadites.
Numbers 26:30 These are the sons of Gilead: Iezer, from whom came the family of the Iezerites; and Helek, from whom came the family of the Helekites;
Numbers 26:31 Asriel, from whom came the family of the Asrielites; and Shechem, from whom came the family of the Shechemites;
Numbers 26:32 Shemida, from whom came the family of the Shemidaites; and Hepher, from whom came the family of the Hepherites.
Numbers 26:33 Moreover, Zelophehad, the son of Hepher, had no sons, but only daughters. Their names were: Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Tirzah.
Numbers 26:34 These were the families of the tribe of Manasseh. Their registered number was fifty-two thousand, seven hundred men.
Numbers 26:35 The sons of Ephraim, according to their families, were: Shuthelah, from whom came the family of the Shuthelahites; Becher, from whom came the family of the Becherites; and Tahan, from whom came the family of the Tahanites.
Numbers 26:36 Furthermore, the son of Shuthelah was Eran, from whom came the family of the Eranites.
Numbers 26:37 These were the families of the sons of Ephraim. Their registered number was thirty-two thousand, five hundred men. These are all the sons of Joseph, according to their families.
Numbers 26:38 The sons of Benjamin, according to their families, were: Bela, from whom came the family of the Belaites; Ashbel, from whom came the family of the Ashbelites; Ahiram, from whom came the family of the Ahiramites;
Numbers 26:39 Shephupham, from whom came the family of the Shephuphamites; and Hupham, from whom came the family of the Huphamites.
Numbers 26:40 The sons of Bela were Ard and Naaman, from whom came the families of the Ardites and the Naamanites. These were the families of Benjamin, according to their families. Their registered number was forty-five thousand, six hundred men.
Numbers 27:1 The daughters of Zelophehad approached. He was the son of Hepher, the son of Gilead, the son of Machir, the son of Manasseh, who was the son of Joseph. These were their names: Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Tirzah.
Numbers 27:2 They stood before Moses, Eleazar the priest, and all the leaders of the people at the entrance of the Tabernacle of the Covenant, and they spoke:
Numbers 27:3 Our father died in the desert. He was not among those who rebelled against the Lord with Korah. Instead, he died for his own sins, just like all of his generation in the desert. He had no sons.
Numbers 27:4 Why should our father's name be cut off from his family just because he had no son? Give us a land inheritance among our father’s relatives.
Numbers 27:5 So Moses brought their legal case before the Lord for judgment.
Numbers 27:6 And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying:
Numbers 27:7 The daughters of Zelophehad are speaking correctly. Give them a land inheritance among their father’s relatives, and let them inherit his portion of the land.
Numbers 27:8 Also, you must speak to the sons of Israel regarding this law: If a man dies without a son, his inheritance will pass to his daughter.
Numbers 27:9 If he has no daughter, then his brothers will inherit from him.
Numbers 27:10 But if he has no brothers, you will give his inheritance to his father's relatives.
Numbers 27:11 And if his father also has no relatives, then the inheritance will be given to those who are nearest to him in family relationship. This will be a holy and permanent law for the sons of Israel.
Numbers 27:12 Then the Lord said to Moses: "Go up this Abarim mountain, and from there, look at the land that I am about to give to the sons of Israel."
Numbers 27:13 When you have seen it, you will be gathered to your ancestors in death, just as your brother Aaron was gathered.
Numbers 27:14 This is because you offended Me in the Desert of Sin during the contention of the multitude, and you did not show My holiness before the people at the waters.
Numbers 27:15 And Moses responded:
Numbers 27:16 "May the Lord, the God of the spirits of all humankind, appoint a man to be over this multitude of people."
Numbers 27:17 "Let this man go out before them and come in before them, and let him lead them out and bring them in, so that the congregation of the Lord may not be like sheep without a shepherd."
Numbers 27:18 Then the Lord said to Moses: "Take Joshua, the son of Nun, a man in whom the Spirit is present, and lay your hand upon him."
Numbers 27:19 "He will stand before Eleazar the priest and all the assembly of the sons of Israel. You are to give him instructions in the hearing of everyone."
Numbers 27:20 "And you will give him some of your authority and honor, so that all the congregation of the sons of Israel may obey him."
Numbers 27:21 "If anything needs to be done, Eleazar the priest will consult the Lord for him, using the Urim and Thummim. Joshua, and all the sons of Israel with him, along with the rest of the multitude, will go out and come in according to Eleazar's judgment and divine answers from the Lord."
Numbers 27:22 So Moses did just as the Lord had commanded. He took Joshua and presented him before Eleazar the priest and all the assembly of the people.
Numbers 27:23 And Moses laid his hands on Joshua's head, ordaining him just as the Lord had commanded.
Numbers 28:1 And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying to him:
Numbers 28:2 “Command the children of Israel and tell them: ‘You must offer my sacred gifts to me at their appointed times. These offerings include the bread and the burnt sacrifices that produce a pleasing aroma.’”
Numbers 28:3 “These are the sacrifices you must offer: two perfect, year-old male lambs each day as a perpetual burnt offering.”
Numbers 28:4 “One lamb in the morning, and the other in the evening.”
Numbers 28:5 “And for the grain offering, a tenth of an ephah of fine flour mixed with a quarter of a hin of pure olive oil.”
Numbers 28:6 “This is the perpetual burnt offering, the same as what you offered on Mount Sinai, which produced a pleasing aroma and was a sacrifice made by fire to the Lord.”
Numbers 28:7 “For their drink offerings, you must pour out a quarter of a hin of strong wine for each lamb in the Lord's sanctuary.”
Numbers 28:8 “And you will offer the other lamb in the evening, according to the ritual of the morning sacrifice and its drink offerings—you must offer them both together.”
Numbers 28:9 “On the Sabbath day, you must offer two perfect, year-old male lambs, along with two-tenths of an ephah of fine flour mixed with olive oil, as a grain offering, and its drink offerings.”
Numbers 28:10 “These are the burnt offerings for each Sabbath, in addition to the regular daily burnt offering and its drink offering.”
Numbers 28:11 “Also, at the beginning of each month—on the New Moon—you must offer a burnt offering to the Lord: two young bulls, one ram, and seven perfect, year-old male lambs.”
Numbers 28:12 “And for the grain offering with each bull, three-tenths of an ephah of fine flour mixed with olive oil. And with the one ram, two-tenths of an ephah of fine flour mixed with olive oil.”
Numbers 28:13 “And with each lamb, one-tenth of an ephah of fine flour mixed with olive oil. This is a burnt offering that produces a pleasing aroma, a sacrifice made by fire to the Lord.”
Numbers 28:14 “Their drink offerings will be as follows: half a hin of wine for each bull, a third of a hin for the ram, and a quarter of a hin for each lamb. This will be the perpetual burnt offering that you must offer each month throughout the year.”
Numbers 28:15 “And you must also offer one male goat as a sin offering, in addition to the perpetual burnt offering and its drink offerings.”
Numbers 28:16 “In the first month, on the fourteenth day of the month, is the Lord's Passover.”
Numbers 28:17 “And on the fifteenth day of that same month, there will be a solemn feast. For seven days, unleavened bread must be eaten.”
Numbers 28:18 “On the first day of this feast, there will be a sacred assembly, and you must not do any ordinary work.”
Numbers 28:19 “You must offer a burnt offering to the Lord: two young bulls, one ram, and seven perfect, year-old male lambs.”
Numbers 28:20 “And for their grain offering of fine flour mixed with olive oil, three-tenths of an ephah for each bull, and two-tenths of an ephah for the ram.”
Numbers 28:21 “And for each of the seven lambs, one-tenth of an ephah.”
Numbers 28:22 “And one male goat as a sin offering, to make atonement for you.”
Numbers 28:23 “You must offer these in addition to the regular morning burnt offering.”
Numbers 28:24 “In this same way, you must offer all of these, for seven days, each day, as a sacrifice made by fire to the Lord, a pleasing aroma. This is in addition to the daily burnt offering and its drink offerings.”
Numbers 28:25 “And on the seventh day, there will be a sacred assembly, and you must not do any ordinary work.”
Numbers 28:26 “Also, on the day of the firstfruits, when you bring a new grain offering to the Lord after your weeks have passed, there will be a sacred assembly, and you must not do any ordinary work on it.”
Numbers 28:27 “You must offer a burnt offering that produces a pleasing aroma to the Lord: two young bulls, one ram, and seven perfect, year-old male lambs.”
Numbers 28:28 “And for their grain offering of fine flour mixed with olive oil, three-tenths of an ephah for each bull, and two-tenths of an ephah for the ram.”
Numbers 28:29 “And one-tenth of an ephah for each of the seven lambs.”
Numbers 28:30 “Also, one male goat, which is to be sacrificed as a sin offering, to make atonement for you.”
Numbers 28:31 “You must offer all of these, along with the perpetual burnt offering, its grain offering, and its drink offerings, making sure they are all perfect.”
Numbers 29:1 In the seventh month of the year, on the first day of that month, you shall have a holy festival. No work of any kind that makes you a servant of anyone but God shall be done on that day, because it is the Day of Trumpets, a day of loud blasts and shofar calls.
Numbers 29:2 And you shall offer a burnt offering to the Lord, which is a sweet aroma to Him. This offering shall consist of one young bull from the herd, one ram, and seven male lambs, each a year old and without blemish.
Numbers 29:3 Along with these, for the meal offering that accompanies them, you shall prepare three-tenths of an ephah of fine flour mixed with oil for each young bull. And for each ram, you shall prepare two-tenths of an ephah of fine flour mixed with oil.
Numbers 29:4 And for each of the seven male lambs, you shall prepare one-tenth of an ephah of fine flour mixed with oil.
Numbers 29:5 You shall also offer one male goat as a sin offering, so that atonement may be made for you.
Numbers 29:6 These offerings are in addition to the monthly burnt offering and its associated meal offering. They are also in addition to the daily perpetual burnt offering and its meal offering, along with their usual drink offerings. All these offerings are to be made according to their prescribed ritual and are a sweet aroma to the Lord.
Numbers 29:7 On the tenth day of this seventh month, you shall have a holy and solemn assembly— this is the Day of Atonement. You shall humble yourselves by fasting and repentance, and you shall do no work of any kind that makes you a servant of anyone but God on that day.
Numbers 29:8 Then you shall offer a burnt offering to the Lord, which is a sweet aroma to Him: one young bull from the herd, one ram, and seven male lambs, each a year old and without blemish.
Numbers 29:9 For the meal offering that accompanies them, you shall prepare three-tenths of an ephah of fine flour mixed with oil for each young bull, and two-tenths of an ephah of fine flour prepared in the same way for each ram.
Numbers 29:10 And one-tenth of an ephah of fine flour mixed with oil for each of the seven male lambs.
Numbers 29:11 You shall also offer one male goat as a sin offering. This is in addition to the sin offering regularly made for atonement, and in addition to the daily perpetual burnt offering, its meal offering, and their drink offerings.
Numbers 29:12 On the fifteenth day of this seventh month, you shall have another holy and solemn assembly— this is the Feast of Tabernacles. You shall do no work of any kind that makes you a servant of anyone but God on that day, but you shall celebrate the Lord's festival for seven days.
Numbers 29:13 You shall offer a burnt offering to the Lord, which is a sweet aroma to Him: thirteen young bulls from the herd, two rams, and fourteen male lambs, each a year old and without blemish.
Numbers 29:14 For the meal offering that accompanies them, you shall prepare three-tenths of an ephah of fine flour mixed with oil for each young bull, and two-tenths of an ephah of fine flour for each ram.
Numbers 29:15 And one-tenth of an ephah of fine flour mixed with oil for each of the fourteen male lambs.
Numbers 29:16 You shall also offer one male goat as a sin offering. This is in addition to the daily perpetual burnt offering, its meal offering, and its drink offering.
Numbers 29:17 On the second day of the festival, you shall offer twelve young bulls from the herd, two rams, and fourteen male lambs, each a year old and without blemish.
Numbers 29:18 And for their meal offerings and drink offerings, these shall be prepared for each individual young bull, ram, and lamb, according to their prescribed number and ritual.
Numbers 29:19 You shall also offer one male goat as a sin offering. This is in addition to the daily perpetual burnt offering, its meal offering, and its drink offering.
Numbers 29:20 On the third day of the festival, you shall offer eleven young bulls, two rams, and fourteen male lambs, each a year old and without blemish.
Numbers 29:21 And for their meal offerings and drink offerings, these shall be prepared for each individual young bull, ram, and lamb, according to their prescribed number and ritual.
Numbers 29:22 You shall also offer one male goat as a sin offering. This is in addition to the daily perpetual burnt offering, its meal offering, and its drink offering.
Numbers 29:23 On the fourth day of the festival, you shall offer ten young bulls, two rams, and fourteen male lambs, each a year old and without blemish.
Numbers 29:24 And for their meal offerings and drink offerings, these shall be prepared for each individual young bull, ram, and lamb, according to their prescribed number and ritual.
Numbers 29:25 You shall also offer one male goat as a sin offering. This is in addition to the daily perpetual burnt offering, its meal offering, and its drink offering.
Numbers 29:26 On the fifth day of the festival, you shall offer nine young bulls, two rams, and fourteen male lambs, each a year old and without blemish.
Numbers 29:27 And for their meal offerings and drink offerings, these shall be prepared for each individual young bull, ram, and lamb, according to their prescribed number and ritual.
Numbers 29:28 You shall also offer one male goat as a sin offering. This is in addition to the daily perpetual burnt offering, its meal offering, and its drink offering.
Numbers 29:29 On the sixth day of the festival, you shall offer eight young bulls, two rams, and fourteen male lambs, each a year old and without blemish.
Numbers 29:30 And for their meal offerings and drink offerings, these shall be prepared for each individual young bull, ram, and lamb, according to their prescribed number and ritual.
Numbers 29:31 You shall also offer one male goat as a sin offering. This is in addition to the daily perpetual burnt offering, its meal offering, and its drink offering.
Numbers 29:32 On the seventh day of the festival, you shall offer seven young bulls, two rams, and fourteen male lambs, each a year old and without blemish.
Numbers 29:33 And for their meal offerings and drink offerings, these shall be prepared for each individual young bull, ram, and lamb, according to their prescribed number and ritual.
Numbers 29:34 You shall also offer one male goat as a sin offering. This is in addition to the daily perpetual burnt offering, its meal offering, and its drink offering.
Numbers 29:35 On the eighth day of the festival, you shall have a sacred and solemn assembly. This marks the conclusion of the Feast of Tabernacles. You shall do no work of any kind that makes you a servant of anyone but God on that day.
Numbers 29:36 You shall then offer a burnt offering to the Lord, which is a sweet aroma to Him: one young bull, one ram, and seven male lambs, each a year old and without blemish.
Numbers 29:37 And for their meal offerings and drink offerings, these shall be prepared for each individual young bull, ram, and lamb, according to their prescribed number and ritual.
Numbers 29:38 You shall also offer one male goat as a sin offering. This is in addition to the daily perpetual burnt offering, its meal offering, and its drink offering.
Numbers 29:39 These are the offerings you shall present to the Lord during your appointed festivals. They are to be offered in addition to any votive offerings, which are pledges made to God, and any freewill offerings, which are given voluntarily, whether they are burnt offerings, meal offerings, drink offerings, or peace offerings.
Numbers 29:40 And so Moses explained to the children of Israel everything that the Lord had commanded him to tell them.
Numbers 30:1 Moses then spoke to the leaders of the tribes of the children of Israel, saying, "This is the directive which the Lord has commanded:"
Numbers 30:2 "If any man makes a vow to the Lord, or binds himself by a sworn oath, he must not break his promise. Instead, he must fulfill everything that he has spoken with his own mouth."
Numbers 30:3 "If any woman makes a vow to the Lord, and binds herself by an oath, while she is a young woman living in her father's household:"
Numbers 30:4 "If her father learns of the vow his daughter has made, and the oath by which she has bound herself, and he remains silent about it—then she will be held accountable for her vow, and she must carry out everything she has promised."
Numbers 30:5 "But if her father hears about it and immediately forbids it, then her vows and oaths will be invalid; she will not be bound by anything, because her father has forbidden it."
Numbers 30:6 "If a woman takes a husband, and she has made a vow, or has let something pass from her mouth by which she binds herself by an oath:"
Numbers 30:7 "If her husband, upon hearing it, remains silent and does not forbid it on the day he hears it, then the woman who made the vow will be held accountable for it; she must fulfill whatever she has promised."
Numbers 30:8 "But if, as soon as he hears it, her husband forbids it and invalidates her vow and the word that had come from her mouth, then the Lord will be merciful to her, and she will not be held accountable."
Numbers 30:9 "Any vow made by a widow or a divorced woman, whatever she has spoken from her mouth, will be binding and valid."
Numbers 30:10 "If a woman makes a vow while living in her husband's house, and binds herself with an oath:"
Numbers 30:11 "If her husband hears it, and remains silent, and does not forbid the promise, then she will be held accountable for her vow, and she must fulfill it."
Numbers 30:12 "But if, upon hearing it, her husband immediately invalidates her vows and the words by which she had bound her soul, then they will be void; and the Lord will be merciful to her, so she will not be bound."
Numbers 30:13 "All vows and oaths by which a woman has consecrated herself or bound her soul will be subject to her husband's decision, whether they are to be valid or invalidated."
Numbers 30:14 "If her husband hears it, and remains silent, and postpones action until the next day, then the woman's vows will be binding, and she must fulfill her oaths. This is because he heard them and remained silent."
Numbers 30:15 "But if he immediately forbids it, he will invalidate her vows, and the words spoken from her lips, and the oaths by which she had bound her soul. Then the Lord will be merciful to her, and she will be free from the obligation."
Numbers 30:16 "This is the law concerning vows, which the Lord established for Moses: defining the relationship between a husband and wife, and between a father and his daughter who is a young woman, still living in her father's household."
Numbers 31:1 The Lord God then spoke to Moses, saying:
Numbers 31:2 "You must exact vengeance for the children of Israel against the Midianites. After you do this, you will die and join your ancestors."
Numbers 31:3 Immediately Moses spoke to the people, saying: "Arm men from among you for battle. They must go and execute the Lord's vengeance against Midian."
Numbers 31:4 "From each tribe of Israel, you will send a thousand men to war."
Numbers 31:5 So out of the thousands of Israel, a thousand from each tribe were sent—twelve thousand in total, prepared for battle.
Numbers 31:6 Moses sent them with Phinehas, the son of Eleazar the priest. Phinehas carried the holy vessels and the trumpets for sounding the battle cry.
Numbers 31:7 When they had fought against Midian and conquered them, they killed all the male inhabitants.
Numbers 31:8 They also killed the kings of Midian: Evi, Rekem, Zur, Hur, and Reba—all five leaders of that nation. Additionally, they killed Balaam, the son of Beor, with the sword.
Numbers 31:9 The children of Israel captured their women and their little ones. They also took all their cattle, all their flocks, and everything they could possess, carrying away all the plunder.
Numbers 31:10 And they burned all the cities, villages, and fortified camps of Midian with fire.
Numbers 31:11 Then, dividing the spoils and everything they had captured—both people and animals—they brought them to Moses, and to Eleazar the priest, and to the whole assembly of the children of Israel, to their camp in the plains of Moab, beside the Jordan River across from Jericho.
Numbers 31:12 Moses, Eleazar the priest, and all the leaders of the assembly went out to meet them.
Numbers 31:13 Moses became angry with the leaders of the army, the tribunes (commanders of a thousand men), and the centurions (commanders of a hundred men), who were returning from the war.
Numbers 31:14 He asked them: "Why have you kept all the women alive?"
Numbers 31:15 "These are the very women who, at Balaam’s instigation, deceived the children of Israel. They led you to betray the Lord in the matter of Peor, which resulted in twenty-three thousand men of the people being killed."
Numbers 31:16 "Therefore, kill every male among the little ones, and kill every mother who has known a man by sleeping with him."
Numbers 31:17 "But keep all the young girls and all the women who have not known a man through sexual intercourse alive for yourselves."
Numbers 31:18 "Moreover, you must remain outside the camp for seven days. Whoever has killed a person or touched a dead body must purify himself on the third and seventh day."
Numbers 31:19 "You must also purify yourselves, along with all your plunder: clothing, articles made of skins, woven goats' hair, and anything made of wood."
Numbers 31:20 The Lord then spoke to Moses, saying:
Numbers 31:21 "This is the law of purification that the Lord has commanded."
Numbers 31:22 "Anything that is gold, silver, bronze, iron, tin, or lead—"
Numbers 31:23 "and everything that can endure fire—you must pass it through fire, and it will be made clean. And whatever cannot withstand fire must be purified with water."
Numbers 31:24 "And on the seventh day, you must wash your clothes, and then you will be clean. After that, you may enter the camp."
Numbers 31:25 The Lord then spoke to Moses, saying:
Numbers 31:26 "Separate the spoils—everything that has been captured, from people to livestock—and divide it into two parts. One part will go to those who went to war, and the other to the entire multitude of the people."
Numbers 31:27 "From the half belonging to the soldiers, you must take one out of every five hundred—from both people and from cattle, donkeys, and sheep."
