Numbers 31:28 "This portion belongs to the Lord, taken from those who fought. You will give it to Eleazar the priest, because these are the Lord’s firstfruits (the first offerings)."
Numbers 31:29 "From the half belonging to the children of Israel—that is, from what pertains to the multitude and the rest of the people—you will take one out of every fifty, from both people and from cattle, donkeys, sheep, and all living creatures. You will give this portion to the Levites, who stand guard over the Lord's tabernacle."
Numbers 31:30 Moses and Eleazar did exactly as the Lord had commanded.
Numbers 31:31 The total plunder, apart from what each individual soldier took for himself, amounted to six hundred seventy-five thousand sheep,
Numbers 31:32 seventy-two thousand cattle,
Numbers 31:33 sixty-one thousand donkeys,
Numbers 31:34 and thirty-two thousand human souls of the female sex, who had never lain with a man.
Numbers 31:35 The portion for those who had gone to war was thirty-three thousand seven hundred fifty sheep.
Numbers 31:36 From these, seventy-five sheep were designated as the Lord's portion.
Numbers 31:37 Of the cattle, there were thirty-six thousand, and from these, seventy-two were designated as the Lord's portion.
Numbers 31:38 Of the donkeys, there were thirty thousand five hundred, and from these, sixty-one were designated as the Lord's portion.
Numbers 31:39 Of the human souls, there were fifteen thousand one hundred, and from these, thirty-two were designated as the Lord's portion.
Numbers 31:40 And Moses gave to Eleazar the priest, to the Levites, and to the entire multitude of Israel, the divided portions just as the Lord had commanded.
Numbers 32:1 Now the descendants of Reuben and Gad owned an immense amount of livestock. When they saw the regions of Jazer and Gilead, they recognized that these lands were very suitable for their herds.
Numbers 32:2 So they came to Moses, to Eleazar the priest, and to the leaders of the assembly, and they spoke to them.
Numbers 32:3 They spoke concerning Ataroth, Dibon, Jazer, Nemra, Heshbon, Elealeh, Sibmah, Nebo, and Beon.
Numbers 32:4 This is the land that the Lord conquered before the eyes of the assembly of Israel—it is a very fertile land for the pasturing of our immense herds.
Numbers 32:5 Therefore, we beg you: if we have found favor in your sight, please give this land to us, your servants, as our possession. Do not make us cross the Jordan River.
Numbers 32:6 Moses then said to the descendants of Gad and Reuben: 'Are your brothers going to war, while you yourselves remain here?'
Numbers 32:7 Why are you discouraging the minds of the other descendants of Israel, preventing them from daring to cross into the land that the Lord is about to give them?
Numbers 32:8 Your fathers did the same thing when I sent them from Kadesh-barnea to explore the promised land.
Numbers 32:9 When they went up as far as the Valley of Eshcol and surveyed the entire land, they turned away the hearts of the descendants of Israel, so that they would not enter the borders that the Lord had given them.
Numbers 32:10 Therefore, the Lord became angry and swore an oath, saying:
Numbers 32:11 Surely none of these men of this evil generation will see the land that I solemnly promised by oath to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob—because they refused to follow Me completely.
Numbers 32:12 Except for Caleb, the son of Jephunneh the Kenizzite, and Joshua, the son of Nun; only these two completely fulfilled the command of the Lord.
Numbers 32:13 And so, the Lord's anger burned against Israel. He made them wander for thirty-eight years through the desert, until that entire generation who had done evil in His sight had completely perished.
Numbers 32:14 And look, you have now followed in your fathers' footsteps, a new generation of sinful men, only to further increase the Lord's burning fury against Israel.
Numbers 32:15 For if you refuse to follow Him, He will abandon us all again in this desert, and you will bring ruin upon this entire people.
Numbers 32:16 But they came closer and said to Moses: 'We will only build sheepfolds for our immense herds and construct walled cities for our little ones and our families.'
Numbers 32:17 But we ourselves will arm ourselves and go forward, prepared for battle, before the other descendants of Israel. We will lead them into their allotted places. We will leave our children and our families in fortified cities because of the ambushes of the inhabitants of this land.
Numbers 32:18 We will not return to our homes until all the other descendants of Israel have taken possession of their full inheritance.
Numbers 32:19 Furthermore, we will not ask for any additional land beyond the Jordan, because we already have our full possession here, on the eastern side of the river.
Numbers 32:20 Moses responded to them: 'If you truly do what you promise, and if you go forth, ready for battle, before the Lord, to fight—'
Numbers 32:21 '—And every armed man among you crosses the Jordan, until the Lord has completely overthrown His enemies—'
Numbers 32:22 '—and the land is subdued before you; then you may return. You will be held blameless before the Lord and before Israel. And you will truly possess these regions that you have chosen, by the Lord’s authority.'
Numbers 32:23 But if you do not do what you say, then without a doubt, you will be sinning against the Lord. And be assured: your sin will certainly find you out and catch you.
Numbers 32:24 Therefore, build your cities for your children and your families, and construct sheepfolds and stables for your immense herds. But most importantly, fulfill what you have promised.
Numbers 32:25 The descendants of Gad and Reuben responded to Moses: 'We, your servants, will do exactly as our lord commands.'
Numbers 32:26 Our children, our wives, our immense herds, and all our other livestock will remain in the cities of Gilead.
Numbers 32:27 But your servants, every one of us prepared for battle, will cross over before the Lord into the conflict, just as our lord has spoken.
Numbers 32:28 Moses therefore gave these instructions concerning them to Eleazar the priest, to Joshua the son of Nun, and to the chiefs of the family units within each tribe of Israel.
Numbers 32:29 He said: 'If the descendants of Gad and Reuben cross the Jordan with you, all of them prepared for battle, and if the land is subdued before you, then you are to give them the land of Gilead as their possession.'
Numbers 32:30 But if they are unwilling to cross the Jordan with you, armed for battle, into the land of Canaan, then they will forfeit their request for Gilead. Instead, they must then receive their portion among you, within the land of Canaan itself, just like the other tribes.
Numbers 32:31 The descendants of Gad and Reuben responded, saying: 'Just as the Lord has spoken to His servants through you, so we will do.'
Numbers 32:32 We will cross over, armed, to the land of Canaan. And only after we have helped to secure the possession for the other tribes beyond the Jordan, will we then return to our own possession on this side of the Jordan.
Numbers 32:33 So Moses gave to the descendants of Gad and Reuben, and to half the tribe of Manasseh, the son of Joseph, the kingdom of Sihon, king of the Amorites, and the kingdom of Og, king of Bashan. This included all the land with its surrounding cities.
Numbers 32:34 And the descendants of Gad built or rebuilt the cities of Dibon, Ataroth, and Aroer.
Numbers 32:35 They also built Atroth-shophan, Jazer, and Jogbehah.
Numbers 32:36 They also built Beth-nimrah and Beth-haran as walled cities, and constructed sheepfolds for their immense herds.
Numbers 32:37 But the descendants of Reuben built or rebuilt Heshbon, Elealeh, and Kiriathaim.
Numbers 32:38 They also rebuilt Nebo and Baal-meon, giving them new names, and they rebuilt Sibmah. They were assigning new names to all the cities they rebuilt or constructed.
Numbers 32:39 Furthermore, the descendants of Machir, the son of Manasseh, went into Gilead and devastated it, killing all the Amorite inhabitants who lived there.
Numbers 32:40 Therefore, Moses gave the region of Gilead to Machir, the son of Manasseh, and his descendants settled there.
Numbers 33:1 These are the stages of the journey for the sons of Israel.
They departed from Egypt, organized by their family groups and tribes,
under the leadership and guidance of Moses and Aaron.
Numbers 33:2 Moses recorded these stages of their journey, each one changing at the Lord’s command,
listing every encampment.
Numbers 33:3 They departed from Rameses in the first month.
It was the fifteenth day of that first month, on the day after the Passover observance,
while all the Egyptians watched.
Numbers 33:4 The Egyptians were busy burying their firstborn children,
whom the Lord had struck down throughout Egypt.
Through these judgments, the Lord had exacted vengeance upon their gods.
Numbers 33:5 Then the sons of Israel departed from Rameses
and set up camp in Succoth.
Numbers 33:6 From Succoth, they journeyed to Etham,
which is located at the very edge of the wilderness.
Numbers 33:7 Departing from there, they came and encamped before Pi-Hahiroth,
which faces Baal-Zephon,
and they set up their camp opposite Migdol.
Numbers 33:8 Journeying from Pi-Hahiroth,
they passed through the midst of the sea into the wilderness.
They traveled for three days through the wilderness of Etham
and then encamped in Marah.
Numbers 33:9 From Marah, they came to Elim.
In Elim, there were twelve springs of water and seventy palm trees.
They then set up camp beside these waters.
Numbers 33:10 Departing from Elim,
they established their camp beside the Red Sea.
Numbers 33:11 From the Red Sea, they proceeded into the Wilderness of Sin.
Numbers 33:12 From the Wilderness of Sin,
they journeyed to Dophkah.
Numbers 33:13 From Dophkah,
they arrived at Alush.
Numbers 33:14 Departing from Alush, they traveled
and set up camp in Rephidim.
In this place, the people had no water to drink.
Numbers 33:15 From Rephidim, they journeyed into the Wilderness of Sinai.
Numbers 33:16 From the Wilderness of Sinai,
they came to Kibroth-Hattaavah, which means 'the graves of craving'.
Numbers 33:17 From Kibroth-Hattaavah,
they journeyed to Hazeroth.
Numbers 33:18 From Hazeroth,
they arrived at Rithmah.
Numbers 33:19 From Rithmah,
they journeyed to Rimmon-Perez.
Numbers 33:20 From Rimmon-Perez,
they arrived at Libnah.
Numbers 33:21 From Libnah,
they journeyed to Rissah.
Numbers 33:22 From Rissah,
they arrived at Kehelathah.
Numbers 33:23 From Kehelathah,
they journeyed to Mount Shepher.
Numbers 33:24 From Mount Shepher,
they arrived at Haradah.
Numbers 33:25 From Haradah,
they journeyed to Makheloth.
Numbers 33:26 From Makheloth,
they arrived at Tahath.
Numbers 33:27 From Tahath,
they journeyed to Terah.
Numbers 33:28 From Terah,
they arrived at Mithkah.
Numbers 33:29 From Mithkah,
they journeyed to Hashmonah.
Numbers 33:30 From Hashmonah,
they arrived at Moseroth.
Numbers 33:31 From Moseroth,
they journeyed to Bene-Jaakan.
Numbers 33:32 From Bene-Jaakan,
they arrived at Hor-Hagidgad.
Numbers 33:33 From Hor-Hagidgad,
they journeyed to Jotbathah.
Numbers 33:34 From Jotbathah,
they arrived at Ebronah.
Numbers 33:35 From Ebronah,
they journeyed to Ezion-Geber.
Numbers 33:36 From Ezion-Geber,
they journeyed to the Wilderness of Zin, which is Kadesh.
Numbers 33:37 From Kadesh,
they journeyed to Mount Hor, which is on the border of the land of Edom.
Numbers 33:38 When Aaron the priest ascended Mount Hor, as the Lord commanded,
it was in the thirty-ninth year after the sons of Israel’s departure from the land of Egypt,
in the fifth month, on the first day of that month.
Numbers 33:39 Aaron was one hundred and twenty-three years old,
and there, on that mountain, he died.
Numbers 33:40 The Canaanite king of Arad, who lived in the Negeb—the southern part of the land of Canaan—
had heard that the sons of Israel were approaching.
Numbers 34:1 The Lord then spoke to Moses, saying:
Numbers 34:2 Give a command to the children of Israel and say to them: 'When you enter the land of Chanaan, and it falls to you by lot as your possession, it will be marked by these specific boundaries:
Numbers 34:3 The southern part of the border will be marked out from the wilderness of Sin, which is opposite Edom. This border will extend along the width of the eastern Salt Sea, which is also known as the Dead Sea.
Numbers 34:4 The border will then curve around to the south, opposite the Ascent of Scorpions. It will pass into Senna, and reach Cadesbarne. From there, it will extend to the town named Adar and continue as far as Asemona.
Numbers 34:5 Finally, circling from Asemona, the border will follow the Brook of Egypt and will extend to the edge of the western sea.
Numbers 34:6 The western boundary will also extend from this sea all the way to the Great Sea—the Mediterranean Sea. This will be your coastline.
Numbers 34:7 Furthermore, the northern side will be defined from the Great Sea, all the way to Mount Altissimus.
Numbers 34:8 From Mount Altissimus, it will reach as far as Emath. From the borders of Emath, it will extend to Sedada.
Numbers 34:9 The borders will continue as far as Sephron and will reach the town of Enan. This will be your boundary on the northern side.
Numbers 34:10 From there, the borders will be directed towards the eastern side, from the town of Enan as far as Sephama.
Numbers 34:11 And from Sephama, they will descend to Rabla, opposite the spring. They will then reach as far as the eastern Sea of Cenereth, also known as the Sea of Galilee.
Numbers 34:12 The border will extend to the Jordan River and to the Salt Sea—the Dead Sea. This will be your land all around its borders.
Numbers 34:13 Moses then commanded the children of Israel, saying: 'This is the land that you will possess by lot, and which the Lord has commanded to be given to the nine tribes and the half-tribe of Manasseh.
Numbers 34:14 For the tribe of Ruben, according to its families, and the tribe of Gad, according to its clans, and also the half-tribe of Manasseh, have already received their portion of the land.
Numbers 34:15 This portion of land is beyond the Jordan River, opposite Jericho, on the eastern side.
Numbers 34:16 The Lord then spoke to Moses, saying:
Numbers 34:17 These are the names of the men who will divide the land for you: Eleazar the priest, and Josue, the son of Nun.
Numbers 34:18 A prince will also be appointed for each of the tribes.
Numbers 34:19 These are their names: For the tribe of Juda, Caleb, the son of Jephone.
Numbers 34:20 For the tribe of Simeon, Samuel, the son of Ammiud.
Numbers 34:21 For the tribe of Benjamin, Elidad, the son of Chaselon.
Numbers 34:22 For the tribe of Dan, Bocci, the son of Jogli.
Numbers 34:23 For the sons of Joseph, for the tribe of Manasseh, Haniel, the son of Ephod.
Numbers 34:24 For the tribe of Ephraim, Camuel, the son of Sephtan.
Numbers 34:25 For the tribe of Zabulon, Elisaphan, the son of Pharnach.
Numbers 34:26 For the tribe of Issachar, Phaltiel, the prince, the son of Ozan.
Numbers 34:27 For the tribe of Aser, Ahiud, the son of Salomi.
Numbers 34:28 For the tribe of Nephthali, Phedael, the son of Ammiud.
Numbers 34:29 These are the men whom the Lord commanded to distribute the land of Chanaan to the children of Israel.
Numbers 35:1 The Lord spoke to Moses in the plains of Moab, by the Jordan River, opposite Jericho, saying:
Numbers 35:2 “Command the children of Israel that out of their inherited lands, they are to give the Levites cities to live in, along with their surrounding pasture lands.
Numbers 35:3 So that the Levites may dwell in these towns, and the pasture lands may be for their cattle and all their other livestock.
Numbers 35:4 These pasture lands, extending from the city walls outwards, are to reach one thousand paces in every direction.
Numbers 35:5 Therefore, they shall have one thousand paces to the east, one thousand to the south, one thousand to the west, and one thousand to the north, with the city located in the center.
Numbers 35:6 Among these cities that you will give to the Levites, six are to be designated as cities of refuge, where anyone who has killed another person may flee for safety. In addition to these six, you are to give them forty-two other cities.
Numbers 35:7 Thus, all the cities together, including their pasture lands, will total forty-eight.
Numbers 35:8 From the inherited lands of the children of Israel, you shall give these cities, taking more from the larger tribes and less from the smaller tribes, according to their possessions.
Numbers 35:9 The Lord then spoke to Moses, saying:
Numbers 35:10 “Speak to the children of Israel and tell them: ‘When you have crossed the Jordan River into the land of Canaan,
Numbers 35:11 you shall designate certain cities to be cities of refuge, so that anyone who has unintentionally shed blood —that is, killed someone without intent— may flee to them for safety.
Numbers 35:12 These cities will be places of safety for you, so that the avenger of blood —the victim’s relative— does not pursue and kill the one who has caused the death before he has had the chance to stand trial before the assembly.
Numbers 35:13 Of these cities that you are to designate as cities of refuge, three are to be located east of the Jordan River, and three are to be located in the land of Canaan.
Numbers 35:14 These six cities of refuge will stand ready; anyone who has shed blood —even if unintentionally— may flee to them.
Numbers 35:15 Both the children of Israel, as well as any foreigners or temporary residents living among you, shall have access to these same places of refuge, so that anyone who has unintentionally shed blood may flee to them.
Numbers 35:16 If anyone strikes another person with an iron instrument, and the person who was struck dies, then the attacker is guilty of murder; the murderer himself must be put to death.
Numbers 35:17 If someone throws a stone, and it strikes a person and that person dies, then the thrower is guilty of murder; he must be put to death.
Numbers 35:18 If he strikes with a wooden object and that person dies, he is guilty of murder; he must be put to death.
Numbers 35:19 The avenger of blood —the victim’s relative— is to kill the murderer; as soon as he catches him, he is to execute him.
Numbers 35:20 If someone pushes another person out of hatred, or throws something at them with hostile intent—
Numbers 35:21 —or strikes him with a hostile hand, and that person dies, then the attacker is a murderer. The avenger of blood, as soon as he finds him, is to execute him.
Numbers 35:22 But if someone does any of these things by accident, not out of hatred, and without any hostile intent—
Numbers 35:23 —for example, if a person accidentally drops a stone that could kill someone, without intending to hit anyone, or without even seeing anyone there, and it falls upon someone who then dies:
Numbers 35:24 —if this happens by accident, and the person who caused the death was not an enemy of the deceased, nor did he intend any harm to him:
Numbers 35:25 Then the assembly shall judge the case. The person who caused the death, having been found innocent of intentional murder, will be protected from the avenger of blood. He must return to the city of refuge to which he had fled and must remain there until the death of the High Priest, who was anointed with the holy oil.
Numbers 35:26 However, if the one who has fled to a city of refuge goes outside the boundaries of that city and its pasture lands,
Numbers 35:27 and the avenger of blood finds him outside the limits of the city of refuge, and kills him, the avenger will not be guilty of murder.
Numbers 35:28 For the one who caused the death must remain in the city of refuge until the death of the High Priest; only after the High Priest’s death may he return to his own inherited land and property.
Numbers 35:29 These regulations shall be a sacred and binding ordinance for you throughout all your generations and in all the places where you dwell.
Numbers 35:30 If anyone kills a person, the murderer shall be put to death only upon the testimony of two or three witnesses. No one is to be put to death on the testimony of a single witness alone.
Numbers 35:31 You shall not accept any ransom or payment from a person who is guilty of murder in exchange for his life; the murderer himself must be put to death immediately.
Numbers 35:32 Nor shall you accept any ransom to allow a person who has fled to a city of refuge to return to his home before the death of the High Priest.
Numbers 35:33 Do not pollute the land where you live with bloodshed. The land is polluted by blood, and it cannot be cleansed or atoned for except by the blood of the person who shed it.
Numbers 35:34 You must cleanse the land where you live from this pollution, for I, the Lord, will dwell among you. Indeed, I am the Lord, who makes His dwelling among the children of Israel.
Numbers 36:1 The chiefs of the Gilead families approached. These were the descendants of Machir, Manasseh’s son, from the lineage of Joseph’s sons. They spoke before Moses, and before the leaders of Israel, who were the heads of their families. They said:
Numbers 36:2 Our Lord, the Commander of all, the Lord, had commanded you to distribute the land by lot among the sons of Israel. He also commanded that you give to the daughters of Zelophehad, our kinsman, their father’s inherited land.
Numbers 36:3 Now, if these daughters marry anyone from a different tribe, then their inherited land will transfer to the tribe to which their new family belongs. This would reduce the amount of land allotted to our own tribe.
Numbers 36:4 Furthermore, when the Jubilee comes—that is, the fifty-fifth year of remission of debts and return of land—their inherited land will become permanently joined to the inheritance of that other tribe. It will permanently pass out of our possession and ownership.
Numbers 36:5 Moses responded to the sons of Israel according to the word of the Lord, saying: “The tribe of the sons of Joseph has spoken correctly in this matter.”
Numbers 36:6 This is the Lord’s decree, which He has commanded concerning the daughters of Zelophehad. He said: “Let them marry whomever they wish, but only to a man from their own tribe and their own family lineage, not to a man from another tribe.”
Numbers 36:7 This is so that the inherited lands of the sons of Israel do not get mixed up or transferred from one tribe to another. Instead, each man should take a wife from his own clan and lineage.
Numbers 36:8 Any woman who receives inherited land as her possession must marry a man from within her own clan, so that the land does not transfer to another tribe, but remains with her ancestral tribe.
Numbers 36:9 This ensures that no inherited land is transferred from one tribe to another, but that each tribe keeps its own inherited possessions.
Numbers 36:10 Just as the Lord had commanded Moses, the daughters of Zelophehad did exactly that.
Numbers 36:11 So Mahlah, Tirzah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Noah—the daughters of Zelophehad—got married. They married their cousins on their father’s side.
Numbers 36:12 They married within the family clan of Manasseh, which was from the lineage of Joseph’s son. And so, their inherited land remained within the tribe and family clan of their father.
Numbers 36:13 These are the commands and legal decrees that the Lord commanded through Moses to the sons of Israel, in the plains of Moab, across the Jordan River, opposite Jericho.
Deuteronomy 1:1 These are the words that Moses spoke to all the people of Israel who were on the other side of the Jordan River. They were in the wilderness, on the plain across from the Red Sea, between Paran and Tophel, and Laban, and Hazeroth, and Dizahab.
Deuteronomy 1:2 It was an eleven-day journey from Mount Horeb, by way of Mount Seir, to Kadesh-barnea.
Deuteronomy 1:3 In the fortieth year after they left Egypt, on the first day of the eleventh month, Moses spoke to the children of Israel everything that the Lord had commanded him to tell them.
Deuteronomy 1:4 This was after Moses had defeated Sihon, the king of the Amorites, who lived in Heshbon, and Og, the king of Bashan, who lived in Astaroth and Edrei.
Deuteronomy 1:5 On the other side of the Jordan, in the land of Moab, Moses began to explain the Law, saying:
Deuteronomy 1:6 “The Lord our God spoke to us at Mount Horeb, saying, ‘You have stayed on this mountain for long enough.
Deuteronomy 1:7 Turn around now, and set out for the mountain country of the Amorites, and for all their neighboring lands—the plains, the highlands, the lowlands, the Negev, and the seacoast—all the land of the Canaanites, and Lebanon, as far as the great River Euphrates.
Deuteronomy 1:8 See, I have given this land to you. Go in now and take possession of it, the land that the Lord swore to your fathers—Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob—that He would give to them and to their descendants after them.’
Deuteronomy 1:9 “At that time, I spoke to you and said, ‘I cannot bear the burden of leading you by myself.
Deuteronomy 1:10 The Lord your God has multiplied your numbers, and today you are as many as the stars in the sky.
Deuteronomy 1:11 May the Lord God of your fathers increase your numbers a thousand times more, and bless you, just as He has promised you.
Deuteronomy 1:12 I alone am not able to bear the burden of your affairs, your heavy load, and your disputes.
Deuteronomy 1:13 Choose wise, discerning, and experienced men from each of your tribes, and I will appoint them as your leaders.’
Deuteronomy 1:14 You answered me then, ‘What you propose to do is good.’
Deuteronomy 1:15 So I took the wise and prominent men from your tribes and appointed them as leaders over you: commanders of thousands, hundreds, fifties, and tens, and also officers for your tribes, to instruct you in all matters.
Deuteronomy 1:16 I then commanded your judges, saying, ‘Hear the cases between your people, and judge fairly between a man and his brother, or between a man and a foreigner.
Deuteronomy 1:17 You shall not show favoritism in judgment; you must hear both the small and the great equally, and you must not fear any man, for the judgment belongs to God. If any case is too difficult for you, you are to bring it to me, and I will hear it.’
Deuteronomy 1:18 I commanded you at that time concerning all the things you were to do.
Deuteronomy 1:19 So, after we left Horeb, we traveled through that vast and terrifying wilderness you yourselves saw, following the road to the mountain region of the Amorites, just as the Lord our God commanded us. When we reached Kadesh-barnea,
Deuteronomy 1:20 I said to you, ‘You have now arrived at the mountain region of the Amorites, which the Lord our God is giving to us.
Deuteronomy 1:21 Look, the Lord your God has given you this land. Go up and take possession of it, just as the Lord God of your fathers has told you. Do not be afraid or discouraged by anything.’
Deuteronomy 1:22 But all of you came near me and said, ‘Let us send men ahead to scout the land for us and bring back a report about the route we should take and the cities we will encounter.’
Deuteronomy 1:23 This idea seemed good to me, so I selected twelve men from among you, one from each tribe.
Deuteronomy 1:24 They went up into the hill country and came to the Valley of Eshcol, where they explored the land.
Deuteronomy 1:25 They gathered some of the land’s fruit as proof of its richness and brought it back to us, saying, ‘The land the Lord our God is giving us is indeed good.’
Deuteronomy 1:26 But you refused to go up, and instead you rebelled against the command of the Lord our God.
Deuteronomy 1:27 You complained in your tents, saying, ‘The Lord must hate us! That is why He brought us out of the land of Egypt—to deliver us into the hands of the Amorites to destroy us.
Deuteronomy 1:28 Where are we supposed to go? Our fellow Israelites have filled our hearts with fear by saying, “The people there are stronger and taller than we are; the cities are large, with walls reaching to the sky! And we even saw the Anakim, the giants, there!”’
Deuteronomy 1:29 Then I said to you, ‘Do not be terrified or afraid of them.
Deuteronomy 1:30 The Lord your God, who goes before you, will Himself fight for you, just as you saw Him do for you in Egypt.
Deuteronomy 1:31 And in the wilderness—where you yourselves saw—the Lord your God carried you, just as a father carries his son, all along the path you traveled until you reached this place.
Deuteronomy 1:32 Yet, despite all this, you still did not believe in the Lord your God,
Deuteronomy 1:33 who went ahead of you on your journey to find you a place to camp. He showed you the way to go by fire at night and by a pillar of cloud by day.
Deuteronomy 1:34 When the Lord heard the sound of your complaints, He became angry and swore an oath, saying:
Deuteronomy 1:35 ‘Not one of the men of this evil generation shall see the good land that I swore to give to your fathers,
Deuteronomy 1:36 except for Caleb, the son of Jephunneh. He alone shall see it, and I will give him and his descendants the land on which he has walked, because he has fully followed the Lord.’
Deuteronomy 1:37 Because of you, the Lord also became angry with me and said, ‘Even you, Moses, shall not enter there.
Deuteronomy 1:38 But Joshua, the son of Nun, your assistant, he will enter there in your place. Encourage him and strengthen him, for he is the one who will lead the people of Israel to inherit the land.
Deuteronomy 1:39 Also your little children, about whom you said they would become captives, and your children who today do not know the difference between good and evil—they are the ones who will enter the land. I will give the land to them, and they shall possess it.
Deuteronomy 1:40 But as for you, turn back now and travel into the wilderness by the way of the Red Sea.’
Deuteronomy 2:1 And we turned back, journeying into the wilderness by the way that leads to the Red Sea, as the Lord had commanded me. And we circled around Mount Seir for many days.
Deuteronomy 2:2 Then the Lord spoke to me: "You have circled this mountain long enough.
Deuteronomy 2:3 Now turn and go northward.
Deuteronomy 2:4 And give this command to the people, saying: 'You will be passing through the territory of your brothers, the descendants of Esau, who live in Seir, and they will be afraid of you. Be very careful,
Deuteronomy 2:5 do not provoke them to battle. For I will not give you any of their land, not even a foot of ground, because I have given Mount Seir as a possession to the descendants of Esau.
Deuteronomy 2:6 You must buy food from them with money to eat. And you must also buy water from them with money to drink.
Deuteronomy 2:7 For the Lord your God has blessed you in all the work of your hands. He has known your journey, how you have traveled through this great wilderness for forty years, and you have lacked nothing.'
Deuteronomy 2:8 So when we had passed through the territory of our brothers, the descendants of Esau, who live in Seir, by way of the Arabah road from Elath and Ezion-geber, we then arrived at the wilderness of Moab.
Deuteronomy 2:9 Then the Lord said to me: "Do not treat the Moabites as enemies, nor provoke them to battle. For I will not give you any of their land as a possession, because I have given Ar as a possession to the descendants of Lot."
Deuteronomy 2:10 (The Emim were the first inhabitants there, a great, powerful, and tall people, just like the Anakim.
Deuteronomy 2:11 Like the Anakim, they were also considered Rephaim, and the Moabites called them Emim.
Deuteronomy 2:12 The Horites used to live in Seir, but the descendants of Esau drove them out, destroying them, and then settled in their place. This was just as Israel would do in the land of their own possession, which the Lord had given to them.)
Deuteronomy 2:13 Now then, get up and cross the Wadi Zered.
Deuteronomy 2:14 The time from when we departed Kadesh-barnea until we crossed the Wadi Zered was thirty-eight years. This was the time until the entire generation of fighting men had perished from the camp, just as the Lord had sworn they would.
Deuteronomy 2:15 Indeed, the hand of the Lord was against them to eliminate them from the camp.
Deuteronomy 2:16 So after all the fighting men had perished, dying out from among the people,
Deuteronomy 2:17 the Lord spoke to me, saying:
Deuteronomy 2:18 "Today you are to cross the boundary of Moab, near the city named Ar.
Deuteronomy 2:19 And you will approach the Ammonites. Do not harass them nor provoke them to battle, for I will not give you any of the land of the Ammonites as a possession, because I have given it as a possession to the descendants of Lot.
Deuteronomy 2:20 (That land was also considered a land of giants. In ancient times, giants lived there, whom the Ammonites called Zamzummim,
Deuteronomy 2:21 a great, powerful, and tall people, like the Anakim. The Lord destroyed them before the Ammonites, and the Ammonites settled in their place.
Deuteronomy 2:22 This was just as He had done for the descendants of Esau, who live in Seir, when He destroyed the Horites before them and they took possession. This remains true to this very day.
Deuteronomy 2:23 As for the Avvim who lived in villages as far as Gaza, the Caphtorim, who came out from Caphtor, destroyed them and settled in their place.)
Deuteronomy 2:24 Get up now and cross the Wadi Arnon. Look, I have delivered Sihon, king of Heshbon, the Amorite, and his land into your hand. Begin to take possession, and engage in battle against him.
Deuteronomy 2:25 This very day, I will begin to put the dread and terror of you upon all the peoples who live under the sky. So that when they hear your name, they will tremble and be astonished, and feel anguish like a woman in labor.
Deuteronomy 2:26 So I sent messengers from the wilderness of Kedemoth to Sihon, king of Heshbon, with words of peace, saying:
Deuteronomy 2:27 'Let me pass through your land. I will keep to the main road, not turning off to the right or to the left.
Deuteronomy 2:28 Sell us food for money, so we may eat. And give us water for money, so we may drink.
Deuteronomy 2:29 Only let us pass through, just as the descendants of Esau who live in Seir, and the Moabites who live in Ar, did for us,
Deuteronomy 2:30 until we cross the Jordan River and enter the land that the Lord our God is about to give us.'
Deuteronomy 2:31 But Sihon, king of Heshbon, refused to let us pass through. For the Lord your God had hardened his spirit and made his heart obstinate, so that he might be delivered into your hands, just as you see today.
Deuteronomy 2:32 Then Sihon came out against us, he and all his people, to fight at Jahaz.
Deuteronomy 2:33 And the Lord our God delivered him to us, and we struck him down, along with his sons and all his people.
Deuteronomy 2:34 At that time, we captured all his cities, and we utterly destroyed all the inhabitants of those cities—men, women, and children. We left no survivors.
Deuteronomy 2:35 Only the livestock we took as plunder, and the spoils from the cities we captured, were spared.
Deuteronomy 2:36 From Aroer, which is on the edge of the Wadi Arnon, and from the town that is in the valley, as far as Gilead, there was not a single village or city that could escape us.
Deuteronomy 2:37 The Lord our God delivered everything to us, except for the land of the Ammonites, which we did not approach. And all along the Wadi Jabbok, as well as the cities in the hill country, and all the places that the Lord our God had forbidden us to touch.
Deuteronomy 2:1 Then we turned back, and set out into the wilderness by the way that leads to the Red Sea, just as the Lord had told us. And we circled Mount Seir for many days.
Deuteronomy 2:2 And the Lord spoke to me, saying:
Deuteronomy 2:3 You have circled this mountain long enough. Now turn and go towards the north.
Deuteronomy 2:4 And command the people, saying: 'You are about to pass through the territory of your brothers, the sons of Esau, who live in Seir. They will be afraid of you.'
Deuteronomy 2:5 Be very careful not to provoke them. For I will not give you any of their land, not even a single foot of ground, because I have given Mount Seir to Esau as his possession.
Deuteronomy 2:6 You shall buy food from them with money and eat it. You shall also buy water from them with money and drink it.
Deuteronomy 2:7 The Lord your God has blessed you in all the work of your hands. He knows your journey, how you have traveled through this great wilderness for forty years. You have lacked nothing.
Deuteronomy 2:8 So we passed by our brothers, the sons of Esau, who lived in Seir, by way of the Arabah road from Elath and Ezion-geber. Then we came to the wilderness of Moab.
Deuteronomy 2:9 And the Lord said to me: 'Do not fight against the Moabites, nor engage in battle with them. For I will not give you any of their land as a possession, because I have given Ar to the sons of Lot as their possession.'
Deuteronomy 2:10 The Emim once lived there, a people great and strong, and as tall as the Anakim.
Deuteronomy 2:11 Like the Anakim, they were also considered giants. The Moabites called them Emim.
Deuteronomy 2:12 The Horites previously lived in Seir. The sons of Esau drove them out and destroyed them, and lived in their place, just as Israel did in the land of their possession, which the Lord gave to them.
Deuteronomy 2:13 'Now rise up and cross over the Zered Brook.' So we crossed over the Zered Brook.
Deuteronomy 2:14 The time that we traveled from Kadesh-barnea until we crossed the Zered Brook was thirty-eight years. This was until the entire generation of fighting men from the camp had perished, just as the Lord had sworn.
Deuteronomy 2:15 Indeed, the hand of the Lord was against them, to destroy them from among the camp.
Deuteronomy 2:16 So after all the fighting men had perished, dying in the camp,
Deuteronomy 2:17 the Lord spoke to me, saying:
Deuteronomy 2:18 'Today you are to pass through the territory of Moab, that is, the city named Ar.
Deuteronomy 2:19 And when you come near the Ammonites—the sons of Ammon—do not provoke them, nor engage in battle with them. For I will not give you any of the land of the Ammonites as a possession, because I have given it to the sons of Lot as their possession.'
Deuteronomy 2:20 That land was also considered a land of giants. Giants once lived there, whom the Ammonites called Zamzummim,
Deuteronomy 2:21 a people great and strong, and as tall as the Anakim. The Lord destroyed them before the Ammonites, and the Ammonites took their place and settled in their land.
Deuteronomy 2:22 Just as He had done for the sons of Esau, who live in Seir, when He destroyed the Horites before them and gave their land to them, which they have possessed to this very day.
Deuteronomy 2:23 The Avvim also, who lived in villages as far as Gaza, were destroyed by the Caphtorim, who came out from Caphtor, and settled in their place.
Deuteronomy 2:24 'Rise up, and cross over the Arnon River. Behold, I have delivered Sihon, the Amorite king of Heshbon, and his land into your hand—meaning, I have given you victory over him. Begin to take possession and wage war against him.'
Deuteronomy 2:25 'Today I will begin to put the dread and fear of you upon all the peoples who live under the entire sky. So that when they hear of your name, they will tremble and be in anguish like a woman in labor.'
Deuteronomy 2:26 So I sent messengers from the wilderness of Kedemoth to Sihon, the king of Heshbon, with words of peace, saying:
Deuteronomy 2:27 'Let me pass through your land. I will travel only along the main road. I will not turn aside to the right or to the left.'
Deuteronomy 2:28 'Sell us food for money, so we may eat. Sell us water for money, and so we will drink.'
Deuteronomy 2:29 'Only allow us passage through your land, just as the sons of Esau who live in Seir and the Moabites who live in Ar did for us, until we cross the Jordan River and enter the land that the Lord our God is giving to us.'
Deuteronomy 2:30 But Sihon, the king of Heshbon, would not allow us passage. Because the Lord your God had made his spirit stubborn and hardened his heart—so that he would resist us—so that he might be delivered into your hand, as you see today.
Deuteronomy 2:31 And the Lord said to me: 'Behold, I have begun to deliver Sihon and his land to you. Begin to take possession.'
Deuteronomy 2:32 Then Sihon came out against us with all his people for battle at Jahaz.
Deuteronomy 2:33 And the Lord our God delivered him to us. And we defeated him, his sons, and all his people.
Deuteronomy 2:34 We captured all his cities at that time, utterly destroying every city—men, women, and children. We left no survivors in them.
Deuteronomy 2:35 Except for the plunder we took and the livestock, we kept nothing from the spoils of the cities we captured for ourselves.
Deuteronomy 2:36 From Aroer, which is on the bank of the Arnon River, and from the city that is in the valley, as far as Gilead, there was no village or city that could escape us. The Lord our God delivered them all to us.
Deuteronomy 2:37 Except for the land of the Ammonites, which we did not approach—that is, all along the Jabbok River, and the cities in the mountains, and all the places that the Lord our God had forbidden us to touch.
Deuteronomy 3:1 So we turned and went up the road towards Bashan. Og, the King of Bashan, came out to meet us, with all his army prepared for battle; they stood ready to fight at Edrei.
Deuteronomy 3:2 The Lord God then spoke to me, saying, 'Do not be afraid of him, for I have already delivered him, along with all his people and his entire land, into your hands. You will do to him exactly what you did to Sihon, the king of the Amorites, who ruled from Heshbon.'
Deuteronomy 3:3 So the Lord our God truly delivered Og, the king of Bashan, and his entire army into our hands. We utterly defeated him until no one was left alive.
Deuteronomy 3:4 At that specific time, we conquered all his cities. These were sixty walled cities, encompassing the whole region of Argob, which was part of Og's kingdom in Bashan.
Deuteronomy 3:5 All these cities were fortified, protected by very high walls, strong gates, and reinforcing bars, in addition to many, countless unwalled towns surrounding them.
Deuteronomy 3:6 And we completely wiped them out, just as we had done to Sihon, the king of Heshbon. We utterly destroyed every city, killing every man, woman, and child.
Deuteronomy 3:7 However, we took all the livestock and the spoils from the cities for ourselves.
Deuteronomy 3:8 So, at that time, we took the land from the two Amorite kings who were east of the Jordan River. This territory stretched from the Arnon Stream all the way to Mount Hermon,
Deuteronomy 3:9 Mount Hermon is called Sirion by the Sidonians and Senir by the Amorites.
Deuteronomy 3:10 We took all the cities of the plain, and the entire regions of Gilead and Bashan, extending to Salcah and Edrei, which were royal cities in Og's kingdom of Bashan.
Deuteronomy 3:11 Truly, only Og, the king of Bashan, remained from the last of the giant races. His enormous iron bed was on display in Rabbath of the Ammonites. It measured nine cubits long and four cubits wide, according to the common measure of a man's cubit. (This means it was about 13.5 feet long and 6 feet wide, indicating his immense stature.)
Deuteronomy 3:12 At that specific time, we took possession of this land. It stretched from Aroer, which is located by the Arnon Stream, including half of the mountainous region of Gilead and its cities, all of which I assigned to the tribes of Reuben and Gad.
Deuteronomy 3:13 The remaining part of Gilead, and all of Bashan, which was Og's kingdom, I assigned to the half-tribe of Manasseh. This included the entire region of Argob. All of Bashan was known as the land of the Rephaim, or 'giants'.
Deuteronomy 3:14 Jair, a descendant of Manasseh, took possession of the entire region of Argob, extending all the way to the borders of Geshur and Maacah. He renamed Bashan after himself, calling it Havoth Jair—meaning 'Jair's settlements'—a name it still bears today.
Deuteronomy 3:15 To Machir, I also gave the land of Gilead.
Deuteronomy 3:16 And to the tribes of Reuben and Gad, I gave a portion of the land of Gilead, extending as far as the Arnon Stream. This included the middle of the stream itself, acting as a boundary, and extended up to the Jabbok Stream, which marked the border of the Ammonites.
Deuteronomy 3:17 I also gave them the plain, the desert areas, the Arabah valley, and the Jordan River itself, including the region of Chinnereth, stretching all the way to the Sea of the Desert, which is the very salty Dead Sea. This eastern boundary extended to the foothills of Pisgah.
Deuteronomy 3:18 At that time, I gave you these instructions, saying: 'The Lord your God has given you this land as your inheritance. So, all you valiant warriors, arm yourselves and march ahead of your Israelite brothers.
Deuteronomy 3:19 Your wives, little children, and livestock—and I know you have many of them—can stay safely in the cities I have given you.
Deuteronomy 3:20 You must continue until the Lord grants peace and rest to your brothers, just as He has given it to you. This means until they also take possession of the land that the Lord your God is about to give them on the other side of the Jordan River. Only then will each of you be free to return to the land and property I have given you.'
Deuteronomy 3:21 At that same time, I also instructed Joshua, saying: 'You have personally witnessed everything the Lord your God did to these two Amorite kings. He will do the same to all the kingdoms you are about to enter.
Deuteronomy 3:22 Do not be afraid of them, because the Lord your God Himself will fight on your behalf.
Deuteronomy 3:23 At that moment, I also pleaded with the Lord, saying:
Deuteronomy 3:24 'Lord God, You are the One who began to reveal Your majesty and Your mighty power to Your servant. There is no other God in the universe, nor anywhere on the earth, who can perform the works You do, or display Your strength.
Deuteronomy 3:25 Please allow me to cross over and see this excellent land beyond the Jordan River, that magnificent mountain range, and the region of Lebanon.'
Deuteronomy 3:26 But the Lord was angry with me because of your transgressions, and He would not listen to my plea. He said to me:
Deuteronomy 3:27 'That is enough for you. Do not speak to me about this matter again.
Deuteronomy 3:28 Go up to the summit of Pisgah, and from there, look out with your own eyes towards the west, north, south, and east, and truly see the land. For you will not be crossing this Jordan River.
Deuteronomy 3:29 Instead, give instructions to Joshua. Strengthen him and encourage him, because he is the one who will lead this people, and he is the one who will divide the land that you are now seeing among them.' So we (the Israelites) remained settled in the valley directly opposite Beth-peor.
Deuteronomy 3:1 And we turned and went up the road to Bashan. And Og, the king of Bashan, came out against us—he and all his people—to fight us at Edrei.
Deuteronomy 3:2 And the Lord said to me, 'Do not fear him, for I have delivered him and all his people and all his land into your hand. You shall do to him just as you did to Sihon, the king of the Amorites, who lived in Heshbon.'
Deuteronomy 3:3 So the Lord our God delivered Og, the king of Bashan, and all his people into our hands. We struck him down until not a single person remained alive.
Deuteronomy 3:4 At that time, we captured all of his cities—there wasn't a single town that escaped us. We took sixty cities, all the region of Argob, which was part of Og's kingdom in Bashan.
Deuteronomy 3:5 All these cities were fortified with very high walls, and strengthened with the most secure walls and gates, besides countless other towns that had no walls at all.
Deuteronomy 3:6 And we utterly destroyed them, just as we did to Sihon, the king of Heshbon. We completely destroyed every city, including the men, women, and little children.
Deuteronomy 3:7 However, we took all the plunder and livestock for ourselves.
Deuteronomy 3:8 At that time, we took the land of the two kings of the Amorites who were across the Jordan River, from the Arnon Torrent all the way to Mount Hermon.
Deuteronomy 3:9 The Sidonians call Mount Hermon 'Sirion,' but the Amorites call it 'Senir'.
Deuteronomy 3:10 We took all the cities of the plain, and all the land of Gilead and Bashan, as far as Salecah and Edrei, which were cities of Og's kingdom in Bashan.
Deuteronomy 3:11 Only Og, the king of Bashan, remained of the remnant of the Rephaim giants. His sarcophagus can be seen in Rabbah of the Ammonites; it is nine cubits long and four cubits wide, measured by the standard cubit of a man's forearm.
Deuteronomy 3:12 At that time, we took possession of that land from Aroer, which is by the Arnon Torrent. I gave the middle part of the hill country of Gilead and its cities to the tribes of Reuben and Gad.
Deuteronomy 3:13 And the rest of Gilead and all of Bashan, which was Og's kingdom, I gave to the half-tribe of Manasseh, which included all the region of Argob. All of Bashan is called 'the land of the Rephaim' —the land of the giants.
Deuteronomy 3:14 Jair, a son of Manasseh, took possession of all the region of Argob, as far as the borders of Geshur and Maachah. He named Bashan, Avoth Jair —that is, 'The Villages of Jair'—after himself, a name that remains to this very day.
Deuteronomy 3:15 And to Machir I gave Gilead.
Deuteronomy 3:16 And to the tribes of Reuben and Gad I gave land from Gilead as far as the Arnon Torrent—the middle of the torrent serving as their boundary—and up to the Jabbok Torrent, which is the boundary of the Ammonites.
Deuteronomy 3:17 I also gave them the plain of the desert, and the Jordan River, and the borders of Chinnereth—which is the Sea of Galilee—as far as the Sea of the Arabah, which is the Salt Sea, or Dead Sea, eastward below the slopes of Pisgah.
Deuteronomy 3:18 At that time, I commanded you, saying: 'The Lord your God has given you this land to possess. All you strong men must arm yourselves and cross over before your Israelite brothers.'
Deuteronomy 3:19 But your wives, your little ones, and your livestock—which I know you have in great abundance—shall remain in the cities that I have given you.
Deuteronomy 3:20 You shall remain there until the Lord grants rest to your brothers, just as He has given it to you, and until they also possess the land that the Lord your God is about to give them across the Jordan. Then each of you may return to his own possession, which I have given you.'
Deuteronomy 3:21 And to Joshua I commanded at that time, saying: 'Your own eyes have seen everything that the Lord your God has done to these two kings. So will He do to all the kingdoms into which you are about to cross.'
Deuteronomy 3:22 'Do not fear them, for the Lord your God Himself will fight for you.'
Deuteronomy 3:23 At that time, I also pleaded with the Lord, saying:
Deuteronomy 3:24 'Lord God, You have begun to show Your servant Your greatness and Your mighty hand! For there is no other God above You, in the universe and on earth, who can perform such works and powerful deeds like Yours.'
Deuteronomy 3:25 'Please let me cross over and see this good land beyond the Jordan, and this excellent mountain, and Lebanon.'
Deuteronomy 3:26 But the Lord was angry with me because of you, and He did not listen to me. Instead, He answered, 'Enough for you! Do not speak to Me any further about this matter.'
Deuteronomy 3:27 'Go up to the top of Pisgah, and look around with your eyes to the west, and to the north, and to the south, and to the east, and see it! For you shall not cross this Jordan River.'
Deuteronomy 3:28 'But command Joshua, and encourage him, and strengthen him, because he himself shall go before this people, and he shall distribute to them the land that you are about to see.'
Deuteronomy 3:29 So we remained in the valley opposite Beth-peor.
Deuteronomy 4:1 And now, Israel, listen carefully to the commands and judgments which I am teaching you today. Obey them, so that you may live and enter and take possession of the land which the Lord, the God of your fathers, is about to give you.
Deuteronomy 4:2 You shall not add anything to the word which I speak to you, nor shall you take anything away from it. Instead, you must keep the commands of the Lord your God, which I am giving to you.
Deuteronomy 4:3 Your own eyes have seen what the Lord did against Baal-Peor, where the Israelites worshipped pagan gods. The Lord destroyed all the men who followed those false gods, removing them from your midst.
Deuteronomy 4:4 But you, who clung faithfully to the Lord your God, are all alive to this very day.
Deuteronomy 4:5 Behold, I have taught you commands and judgments, just as the Lord my God commanded me to do. My purpose is for you to follow these laws in the land which you are about to enter and possess.
Deuteronomy 4:6 Therefore, keep these laws and fulfill them. For this will be your wisdom and your understanding in the sight of all the surrounding nations. When they hear all these commands, they will declare, 'This truly is a wise and understanding people; a great nation!'
Deuteronomy 4:7 There is no nation so great that has gods drawing so near to it, as the Lord our God is present to all who call upon Him with sincere hearts.
Deuteronomy 4:8 And what other nation is so renowned and glorious, that it has such ceremonies, just judgments, and an entire body of law like the one I am setting before you today?
Deuteronomy 4:9 Therefore, guard yourself and your soul diligently. Do not forget the words that your own eyes have witnessed, and do not let them fade from your heart throughout all the days of your life. You must teach them to your children and to your grandchildren—that is, the generations to come.
Deuteronomy 4:10 Remember the day when you stood before the Lord your God in Horeb, Mount Sinai, when the Lord said to me: 'Gather the people to Me, so they may hear My words. In this way, they will learn to reverence and obey Me all the time that they live on the earth, and they will teach their children to do the same.'
Deuteronomy 4:11 And you approached the foot of that mountain, which burned with fire up to the visible sky. There was also deep darkness, thick clouds, and a dense mist upon it.
Deuteronomy 4:12 The Lord spoke to you from the midst of that fire. You heard the sound of His words clearly, but you did not see any physical form or likeness of Him.
Deuteronomy 4:13 And He declared His covenant to you, commanding you to keep the Ten Words—meaning the Ten Commandments. He then wrote them on two stone tablets.
Deuteronomy 4:14 The Lord also commanded me at that time to teach you the ceremonies and the judgments which you ought to perform in the land which you are about to possess.
Deuteronomy 4:15 Therefore, diligently guard your souls and pay close attention. Remember that you saw no likeness or image on the day when the Lord spoke with you in Horeb from the midst of the fire.
Deuteronomy 4:16 Be careful, lest perhaps you be deceived and make for yourselves a carved likeness of anything: an image of a male or a female person.
Deuteronomy 4:17 Or a likeness of any beasts that are on the earth, or of any birds flying under the sky.
Deuteronomy 4:18 Or of any creeping things that move on the earth, or of any fish that dwell beneath the earth and in the waters.
Deuteronomy 4:19 Be careful also, lest perhaps, lifting your eyes to the sky, you see the sun, the moon, and all the stars of the sky—the entire host of heaven—and being deceived by error, you adore them and worship them. These are things which the Lord your God created for the service of all the nations that are under the sky; they are not to be worshipped.
Deuteronomy 4:20 But the Lord took you and led you out of the iron furnace of Egypt, a place of hard labor and oppression. He did this so that you might be for Him a people of inheritance—His very own possession—as you are on this present day.
Deuteronomy 4:21 The Lord also became angry with me because of your complaints and your words of rebellion. He swore that I would not cross the Jordan River, nor enter that excellent land which He is about to give you.
Deuteronomy 4:22 Behold, I will die in this land, and I will not cross the Jordan. But you will cross over and you will possess the land.
Deuteronomy 4:23 Beware lest you ever forget the covenant of the Lord your God, which He made with you. Do not make for yourselves a carved likeness of any of those things which the Lord has forbidden.
Deuteronomy 4:24 For the Lord your God is a consuming fire—He is passionate and severe against sin. He is a jealous God who will not tolerate idolatry.
Deuteronomy 4:25 If you beget children and grandchildren, and you remain for a long time in the land, and then, being deceived, you make for yourselves a carved likeness of anything, committing evil before the Lord your God, so as to provoke Him to anger—
Deuteronomy 4:26 I call the sky and the earth to witness against you today: you will quickly perish from the land which you are about to possess after crossing the Jordan. You will not remain in it for a very long time, but the Lord will stir you up and scatter you among all the nations.
Deuteronomy 4:27 And you will remain few in number among the nations to which the Lord will have led you into exile.
Deuteronomy 4:28 And there, in exile, you will serve gods made of wood and stone. These are idols that cannot see, nor hear, nor eat, nor smell anything.
Deuteronomy 4:29 But if, when you are in exile, you seek the Lord your God, you will find Him. This will happen only if you seek Him with all your heart, and with all the tribulation and distress of your soul.
Deuteronomy 4:30 After all the things that we have spoken of above happen to you—after you experience these calamities—in the latter days you will return to the Lord your God, and you will listen to His voice.
Deuteronomy 4:31 Because the Lord your God is a merciful God, He will not abandon you, nor will He utterly destroy you. He will not forget the covenant which He swore to your fathers.
Deuteronomy 4:32 Inquire about the ancient days that were before you, from the day when God created mankind on the earth. Ask from one end of the sky to the other, if such a word as this has ever happened, or if such a thing has ever been heard?
Deuteronomy 4:33 Did any people ever hear the voice of God speaking from the midst of a fire, as you heard, and yet lived to tell of it?
Deuteronomy 4:34 Or has God ever attempted to go in and take for Himself a nation from the midst of other nations? He did this through trials, signs, and wonders, and by strong warfare, and an outstretched hand, and a high arm, and terrible visions—just as the Lord your God did for you in Egypt, right before your very eyes.
Deuteronomy 4:35 All of this happened so that you might know that the Lord Himself is God, and that there is no other God besides Him.
Deuteronomy 4:36 From the sky above, He made you hear His voice, so that He might teach you. And on the earth, He showed you His great fire, and you heard His powerful voices from the midst of the fire.
Deuteronomy 4:37 It was because He loved your fathers, and chose their offspring after them, that He led you out. He went before you with His great power from Egypt.
Deuteronomy 4:38 He did this to destroy nations greater and stronger than you as you entered their land. He brought you in and gave you their land as a possession, as you see on this present day.
Deuteronomy 4:39 Know therefore today, and consider in your heart, that the Lord Himself is God in the heavens above and on the earth below. There is truly no other God.
Deuteronomy 4:40 Therefore, keep His commands and precepts which I am giving to you today. This is so that it may be well with you and with your children after you, and that you may remain for a long time upon the land which the Lord your God is about to give you.
Deuteronomy 4:1 Now, Israel, listen to the statutes and ordinances that I am teaching you today. If you obey them, you will live, and you will enter and possess the land—the promised land—which the Lord God of your fathers is about to give to you.
Deuteronomy 4:2 You must not add to the word that I speak to you, nor take anything away from it. Instead, you must keep the commandments of the Lord your God, which I am commanding you today.
Deuteronomy 4:3 Your own eyes have seen everything that the Lord did against Baal-Peor. The Lord completely destroyed all of his worshipers from among you.
Deuteronomy 4:4 But you, who held fast to the Lord your God, all of you are still alive to this very day.
Deuteronomy 4:5 Look, I have taught you statutes and ordinances, just as the Lord my God commanded me. You are to obey them in the land that you are about to enter and possess.
Deuteronomy 4:6 Therefore, observe and perform them. For this will be your wisdom and your understanding in the sight of the nations. When they hear all these statutes, they will say, 'Indeed, this great nation is a wise and understanding people.'
Deuteronomy 4:7 For there is no other great nation that has gods so near to them, as our God is near to all who call upon Him.
Deuteronomy 4:8 And what other nation has statutes, ceremonies, and ordinances that are as righteous as all these which I set before your eyes today?
Deuteronomy 4:9 Therefore, be careful and diligently guard your soul. Do not forget the words that your own eyes have seen, and do not let them depart from your heart all the days of your life. You are to teach them to your children and your grandchildren.
Deuteronomy 4:10 —especially on the day that you stood at Horeb before the Lord your God, when the Lord said to me, 'Gather the people to Me, so that they may hear My words. They are to learn to fear Me all the time that they live on the earth, and they are to teach their children.'
Deuteronomy 4:11 And you approached the base of the mountain, which was burning with fire up to the sky, surrounded by darkness, cloud, and deep gloom.
Deuteronomy 4:12 Then the Lord spoke to you from the midst of the fire. You heard the sound of His words, but you did not see any form or likeness.
Deuteronomy 4:13 And He declared to you His covenant—His ten words, the Ten Commandments—which He wrote on two tablets of stone.
Deuteronomy 4:14 And at that time, the Lord commanded me to teach you the ceremonies and ordinances that you were to perform in the land which you are about to possess.
Deuteronomy 4:15 Therefore, guard your souls very carefully. For you saw no form or likeness on the day when the Lord spoke to you at Horeb from the midst of the fire.
Deuteronomy 4:16 Be careful that you are not deceived into making for yourselves any carved image, any likeness of any figure, whether male or female.
Deuteronomy 4:17 Be careful not to make any likeness of any animals that are on the earth, or of any birds that fly under the sky.
Deuteronomy 4:18 or of any creeping things that move on the ground, or of any fish that live in the waters beneath the earth.
Deuteronomy 4:19 And beware, lest you lift your eyes to the sky and see the sun and the moon and all the stars of the universe—all the celestial bodies—and be led astray by error to worship and serve them. For the Lord your God created these for the service of all the nations under the sky.
Deuteronomy 4:20 But the Lord took you and brought you out of the iron furnace of Egypt—a metaphor for severe oppression—so that you might be His inheritance, His own people, as you are this present day.
Deuteronomy 4:21 Furthermore, the Lord was angry with me because of your words, and He swore that I would not cross the Jordan River, nor enter that excellent land which He is about to give to you.
Deuteronomy 4:22 But I will die in this land; I will not cross the Jordan. You yourselves will cross over and possess it.
Deuteronomy 4:23 Be careful not to forget the covenant of the Lord your God, which He made with you. And do not make for yourselves any carved image of anything that the Lord has commanded you not to make.
Deuteronomy 4:24 For the Lord your God is a consuming fire, a jealous God.
Deuteronomy 4:25 If you beget children and grandchildren, and you remain a long time in the land, and then you are deceived into making for yourselves any carved image, committing evil in the sight of the Lord your God, so as to provoke Him to anger:
Deuteronomy 4:26 I call today the universe and the earth to witness against you. You will quickly perish from the land that you are about to possess after crossing the Jordan. You will not remain in it for a very long time, but you will be utterly destroyed and brought to nothing.
Deuteronomy 4:27 And the Lord will scatter you among all the nations, and you will remain few in number among the nations to which the Lord will lead you.
Deuteronomy 4:28 There you will serve gods made of wood and stone, which neither see, nor hear, nor eat, nor smell.
Deuteronomy 4:29 But if you seek the Lord your God there, you will find Him, provided that you search for Him with all your heart and with all the tribulation of your soul.
Deuteronomy 4:30 After all these things that have been foretold come upon you, in the last days you will return to the Lord your God, and you will listen to His voice.
Deuteronomy 4:31 For the Lord your God is a merciful God; He will not abandon you, nor will He utterly destroy you, nor will He forget the covenant which He swore to your fathers.
Deuteronomy 4:32 Indeed, inquire of the days of old, which were before you, from the day that God created mankind on the earth, from one end of the universe to the other. Has such a thing ever happened, or has anything similar ever been heard?
Deuteronomy 4:33 Has any people ever heard the voice of God speaking from the midst of the fire, as you have heard, and remained alive?
Deuteronomy 4:34 Or has God ever attempted to go and take for Himself a nation from the midst of other nations, by trials, by signs and wonders, by a strong hand and an outstretched arm, and by great terrors, just as the Lord your God did for you in Egypt, before your very eyes?
Deuteronomy 4:35 This was so that you might know that the Lord Himself is God, and there is no other besides Him.
Deuteronomy 4:36 From the heavens, He made you hear His voice, so that He might teach you. And on the earth, He showed you His great fire, and you heard His voice from the midst of the fire.
Deuteronomy 4:37 Because He loved your fathers, and chose their descendants after them, He therefore brought you out, going before you with His great power, from Egypt.
Deuteronomy 4:38 He did this to destroy many nations, even those mightier than you, at your entrance. He brought you in and gave their land to you as a possession, as you see this present day.
Deuteronomy 4:39 Know therefore today, and consider in your heart, that the Lord Himself is God in the heavens above, and on the earth below, and there is no other.
Deuteronomy 4:40 Therefore, keep His statutes and His commandments, which I am commanding you today, so that it may be well with you and with your children after you, and that you may remain for a long time on the land which the Lord your God is about to give to you.
Deuteronomy 5:1 Moses then summoned all of Israel and said to them: 'Listen, O Israel, to the commandments and judgments which I am speaking in your hearing today; learn them and keep them through your actions.'
Deuteronomy 5:2 The Lord Our God made a covenant with us on Mount Horeb.
Deuteronomy 5:3 He did not make this covenant with our fathers, but with us, all of us who are alive here today.
Deuteronomy 5:4 Face to face He spoke with you on the mountain out of the midst of the fire,
Deuteronomy 5:5 I stood between the Lord and you at that time, as a mediator and announcer of His words, to declare to you the word of the Lord; for you were afraid of the fire and did not go up the mountain.
Deuteronomy 5:6 I am the Lord your God, who led you out of the land of Egypt, out of the house of slavery.
Deuteronomy 5:7 You shall not have other gods standing before Me.
Deuteronomy 5:8 You shall not make for yourself any carved image, nor any likeness of anything that is in the universe above, or that is on the earth beneath, or that is in the waters under the earth.
Deuteronomy 5:9 You shall not adore them, nor shall you worship them; for I am the Lord your God, a jealous God, repaying the iniquity of the fathers upon the children, even to the third and fourth generation of those who hate Me,
Deuteronomy 5:10 and showing mercy to thousands of those who love Me and keep My commandments.
Deuteronomy 5:11 You shall not use the name of the Lord your God in vain; for He will not leave unpunished anyone who takes His name for a useless purpose.
Deuteronomy 5:12 Observe the Sabbath day to keep it holy, just as the Lord your God commanded you.
Deuteronomy 5:13 For six days you shall work and perform all your labor.
Deuteronomy 5:14 But the seventh day is the Sabbath of the Lord your God. On it you shall do no work, neither you, nor your son, nor your daughter, nor your male servant, nor your female servant, nor your ox, nor your donkey, nor any of your animals, nor the stranger who is within your gates; so that your male and female servants may rest just as you do.
Deuteronomy 5:15 Remember that you were a slave in Egypt, and that the Lord your God led you out from there with a strong hand and an outstretched arm; therefore the Lord your God commanded you to keep the Sabbath day.
Deuteronomy 5:16 Honor your father and your mother, just as the Lord your God commanded you, so that you may live long and that it may be well with you in the land that the Lord your God is about to give you.
Deuteronomy 5:17 You shall not murder.
Deuteronomy 5:18 You shall not commit adultery.
Deuteronomy 5:19 You shall not steal.
Deuteronomy 5:20 You shall not bear false witness against your neighbor.
Deuteronomy 5:21 You shall not covet your neighbor's wife; you shall not covet his house, his field, his male servant, his female servant, his ox, his donkey, or anything else that belongs to him.
Deuteronomy 5:22 These words the Lord spoke to all your assembly on the mountain out of the midst of the fire, the cloud, and the thick darkness, with a loud voice, adding nothing more. And He wrote them on two stone tablets, which He then gave to me.
Deuteronomy 5:23 But when you heard the voice from the midst of the darkness, and saw the mountain burning, all the leaders of your tribes and your elders approached me.
Deuteronomy 5:24 And you said: 'Behold, the Lord our God has shown us His majesty and His greatness. We have heard His voice from the midst of the fire, and we have proven today that a person can live even when God speaks with them.'
Deuteronomy 5:25 'Now therefore, why should we die? For this great fire will consume us. If we hear the voice of the Lord our God any longer, we will die!'
Deuteronomy 5:26 'For who is there among all flesh that has heard the voice of the living God speaking from the midst of the fire, as we have heard, and has been able to live?'
Deuteronomy 5:27 'You yourself, Moses, rather, go near and hear all that the Lord our God says to you, and then you speak to us; and we will listen and do them.'
Deuteronomy 5:28 When the Lord heard these words, He said to me: 'I have heard the voice of the words which this people have spoken to you; they have spoken everything well.'
Deuteronomy 5:29 'Oh, that they would have this mindset, to fear Me and keep all My commandments at all times, so that it may be well with them and their children forever!'
Deuteronomy 5:30 'Go and tell them: "Return to your tents."'
Deuteronomy 5:31 'But you, Moses, stand here with Me, and I will speak to you all the commandments, and the ceremonies, and the judgments, which you shall teach them, so that they may perform them in the land which I am about to give to them as a possession.'
Deuteronomy 5:32 Therefore be diligent to keep and do what the Lord your God has commanded you; you shall not turn aside to the right hand or to the left.
Deuteronomy 5:33 Instead, you shall walk in the way which the Lord your God has commanded you, so that you may live, and that it may be well with you, and that you may have abundant success in possessing the land.
Deuteronomy 5:5:1 Moses called together all the people of Israel and said to them: "Listen, O Israel, to the statutes and ordinances that I am speaking for you to hear today, so that you may learn them and carry them out through your actions."
Deuteronomy 5:5:2 "The Lord our God made a covenant with us at Horeb."
Deuteronomy 5:5:3 "He did not make this covenant with our fathers, but with us—all of us who are still alive and present here today."
Deuteronomy 5:5:4 "He spoke with you face to face on the mountain, from the midst of the fire."
Deuteronomy 5:5:5 "I was standing as a mediator between the Lord and you at that time, to announce His words to you, for you were afraid of the fire and did not go up the mountain."
Deuteronomy 5:5:6 "I am the Lord your God, who led you out of the land of Egypt, out of the house of slavery."
Deuteronomy 5:5:7 "You shall have no other gods before Me."
Deuteronomy 5:5:8 "You shall not make for yourself a graven image, nor any likeness of anything that is in the sky above, or that is on the earth below, or that is in the waters beneath the earth."
Deuteronomy 5:5:9 "You shall not adore them, nor shall you worship them, for I am the Lord your God, a jealous God, who punishes the iniquity of the fathers upon the children, to the third and fourth generation of those who hate Me."
Deuteronomy 5:5:10 "And shows mercy to thousands of those who love Me and keep My precepts."
Deuteronomy 5:5:11 "You shall not take the name of the Lord your God in vain, for neither shall he be unpunished who takes His name lightly or uses it for empty things."
Deuteronomy 5:5:12 "Observe the Sabbath day, to keep it holy, as the Lord your God has commanded you."
Deuteronomy 5:5:13 "For six days you shall labor and do all your work."
Deuteronomy 5:5:14 "But the seventh day is the Sabbath, that is, a day of rest for the Lord your God. On it you shall not do any work, neither you, nor your son, nor your daughter, nor your male or female servant, nor your ox, nor your donkey, nor any of your livestock, nor the stranger who is within your gates, so that your male and female servant may rest as well as you."
Deuteronomy 5:5:15 "Remember that you also were a slave in Egypt, and the Lord your God led you out from there with a strong hand and an outstretched arm. Therefore, the Lord your God commanded you to observe the Sabbath day."
Deuteronomy 5:5:16 "Honor your father and your mother, as the Lord your God has commanded you, that you may live a long time, and that it may go well with you in the land which the Lord your God will give you."
Deuteronomy 5:5:17 "You shall not kill."
Deuteronomy 5:5:18 "You shall not commit adultery."
Deuteronomy 5:5:19 "You shall not steal."
Deuteronomy 5:5:20 "You shall not bear false witness against your neighbor."
Deuteronomy 5:5:21 "You shall not covet your neighbor's wife; you shall not covet his house, his field, his male servant, his female servant, his ox, his donkey, nor anything that belongs to him."
Deuteronomy 5:5:22 "These are the words which the Lord spoke to all your assembly on the mountain, from the midst of the fire, and the cloud, and the darkness, with a great voice, and He added nothing more. And He wrote these ten commandments on two stone tablets and delivered them to me."
Deuteronomy 5:5:23 "Now, when you heard the voice from the midst of the darkness, and saw the mountain burning, all the leaders of your tribes and your elders approached me and said:"
Deuteronomy 5:5:24 "Behold, the Lord our God has shown us His majesty and greatness. We have heard His voice from the midst of the fire, and we have seen today that a man can live even when God speaks with him."
Deuteronomy 5:5:25 "Now therefore, why should we die, and why should this great fire consume us? For if we hear the voice of the Lord our God any more, we shall die."
Deuteronomy 5:5:26 "For what flesh is there, that has heard the voice of the living God from the midst of the fire, as we have heard it, and could live?"
Deuteronomy 5:5:27 "You, Moses, go near, and hear all that the Lord our God shall say, and then speak to us; we will hear and we will do it."
Deuteronomy 5:5:28 "And when the Lord heard these words, He said to me: 'I have heard the voice of the words of this people, which they have spoken to you. They have spoken well in all that they have said.'"
Deuteronomy 5:5:29 "'Who will grant them this mind, that they may fear Me, and keep all My commandments at all times, so that it may go well with them and with their children forever?'"
Deuteronomy 5:5:30 "Go, and tell them: 'Return to your tents.'"
Deuteronomy 5:5:31 "But you, Moses, stand here by Me, and I will speak to you all the commandments, and the statutes, and the ordinances, which you shall teach them, so that they may observe them in the land that I am giving them as a possession."
Deuteronomy 5:5:32 "Therefore, be careful to do exactly as the Lord your God has commanded you: you shall not turn aside to the right hand or to the left."
Deuteronomy 5:5:33 "But you shall walk in the way which the Lord your God has commanded you, so that you may live and that it may go well with you, and that you may remain a long time in the land which you are going to possess."
Deuteronomy 6:1 These are the commands, and the ceremonies, and the laws
which the Lord your God has commanded me to teach you,
so that you may do them in the land which you are about to enter and possess.
Deuteronomy 6:2 This is so that you may fear the Lord your God
and keep all His commands and precepts which I give you today—
you, and your children, and your grandchildren—all the days of your life,
and so that your days may be long upon the land.
Deuteronomy 6:3 Hear, O Israel, and be careful to do them,
so that it may be well with you, and that you may multiply greatly,
just as the Lord God of your fathers has promised you a land flowing with milk and honey.
Deuteronomy 6:4 Hear, O Israel: The Lord our God, the Lord is one.
Deuteronomy 6:5 You shall love the Lord your God with all your heart, and with all your soul, and with all your strength.
Deuteronomy 6:6 And these words, which I command you today, shall be in your heart.
Deuteronomy 6:7 You shall tell them to your children
and you shall meditate on them when you sit in your house, and when you walk on the road,
and when you lie down, and when you rise up.
Deuteronomy 6:8 You shall bind them as a sign on your hand,
and they shall be as frontlets [phylacteries] between your eyes.
Deuteronomy 6:9 And you shall write them on the doorposts of your house and on your gates.
Deuteronomy 6:10 Therefore, when the Lord your God brings you into the land
concerning which He swore to your fathers, Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob,
and He gives you great and good cities, which you did not build,
Deuteronomy 6:11 and houses full of all good things, which you did not furnish,
and cisterns which you did not dig, and vineyards and olive groves, which you did not plant,
Deuteronomy 6:12 and you eat and are satisfied,
Deuteronomy 6:13 be careful lest you forget the Lord, who brought you out of the land of Egypt, out of the house of bondage.
Deuteronomy 6:14 You shall fear the Lord your God; you shall serve Him, and swear by His Name.
