Deuteronomy 6:15 You shall not go after other gods of any of the peoples who are around you.
Deuteronomy 6:16 For the Lord your God is a jealous God in your midst—
a God who demands your exclusive worship and fidelity—
lest the wrath of the Lord your God be kindled against you
and He destroy you from the face of the land.
Deuteronomy 6:17 You shall not put the Lord your God to the test, as you tested Him at Massah [the place of testing].
Deuteronomy 6:18 So that you may do what is pleasing and good in the sight of the Lord your God,
that it may be well with you, and that you may enter and possess the good land, concerning which the Lord swore to your fathers.
Deuteronomy 6:19 He will cast out all your enemies before you, just as He has promised.
Deuteronomy 6:20 When your son asks you in the future, saying:
"What do these testimonies, and these ceremonies, and these laws mean, which the Lord our God has commanded us?"
Deuteronomy 6:21 Then you shall say to him: "We were slaves of Pharaoh in Egypt,
and the Lord brought us out of Egypt with a mighty hand.
Deuteronomy 6:22 And the Lord performed great and terrible signs and wonders in Egypt
against Pharaoh and all his household, before our very eyes.
Deuteronomy 6:23 And He brought us out from there, to bring us in, and to give us the land
concerning which He swore to our fathers.
Deuteronomy 6:24 And the Lord commanded us all these laws, so that we should fear the Lord our God,
for our good always, as it is today.
Deuteronomy 6:25 And He will be merciful to us if we are careful to observe and do all these commands
before the Lord our God, just as He has commanded us.
Deuteronomy 7:1 When you enter the land that the Lord your God will give you to possess, and He has destroyed many nations before you—the Hittites, and the Girgashites, and the Amorites, and the Canaanites, and the Perizzites, and the Hivites, and the Jebusites—these are seven nations much larger and stronger than you.
Deuteronomy 7:2 And the Lord your God has delivered them to you, and you have struck them down. You must utterly destroy them. You shall not make any treaty with them, nor show them any mercy.
Deuteronomy 7:3 Nor shall you join them through marriage. You shall not give your daughter to their son, nor shall you take their daughter for your son.
Deuteronomy 7:4 For they would turn your son away from following Me, and he would rather serve foreign gods. Then the Lord's anger will burn against you, and He will quickly destroy you.
Deuteronomy 7:5 Instead, you shall do this to them: you must tear down their altars, shatter their statues, cut down their sacred groves, and burn their carved idols with fire.
Deuteronomy 7:6 For you are a holy people to the Lord your God. The Lord your God has chosen you to be a special people for Himself, out of all the peoples who are on the face of the earth.
Deuteronomy 7:7 It was not because you were greater in number than any other nation that the Lord joined Himself to you and chose you, for you were the fewest of all peoples.
Deuteronomy 7:8 But it was because the Lord loved you and kept the oath that He swore to your fathers that He brought you out with a strong hand and redeemed you from the house of slavery, from the hand of Pharaoh, the king of Egypt.
Deuteronomy 7:9 Know then that the Lord your God, He is God—a mighty and faithful God, who keeps His covenant and shows mercy to those who love Him and observe His commandments, to a thousand generations.
Deuteronomy 7:10 But He immediately repays those who hate Him by utterly destroying them, and He does not delay to repay the one who hates Him—He promptly gives him what he deserves.
Deuteronomy 7:11 Therefore, keep the commandments and the ceremonies, and the judgments that I am commanding you today to perform.
Deuteronomy 7:12 If you listen to these judgments and carefully observe and perform them, then the Lord your God will also keep for you the covenant and the mercy which He swore to your fathers.
Deuteronomy 7:13 And He will love you, and multiply you, and bless the fruit of your womb, and the fruit of your land—your grain, and your wine, your oil, and the increase of your cattle and the lambs of your flock in the land that He swore to your fathers to give you.
Deuteronomy 7:14 You will be blessed above all peoples. There will be no barrenness among you, neither male nor female, whether among your people or your livestock.
Deuteronomy 7:15 The Lord will remove from you every sickness, and He will not bring upon you any of the dreadful diseases of Egypt, which you know so well, but He will inflict them upon all your enemies.
Deuteronomy 7:16 And you shall devour all the peoples whom the Lord your God will deliver to you. Your eye shall not pity them, nor shall you serve their gods, for that would become a ruin for you—a snare.
Deuteronomy 7:17 If you should say in your heart: "These nations are more numerous than I am; how can I destroy them?"
Deuteronomy 7:18 Do not fear them, but remember what the Lord your God did to Pharaoh and to all the Egyptians.
Deuteronomy 7:19 Remember the great plagues which your eyes saw, and the signs and wonders, and the strong hand, and the outstretched arm by which the Lord your God brought you out. So will the Lord do to all the peoples whom you fear.
Deuteronomy 7:20 Moreover, the Lord your God will send hornets among them, until all who remain and have hidden themselves from you in flight are destroyed to death.
Deuteronomy 7:21 You shall not fear them, because the Lord your God is in your midst—a great and terrible God.
Deuteronomy 7:22 He Himself will consume these nations before you little by little, and piece by piece. You will not be able to destroy them all at once, so that the beasts of the earth do not increase against you in great numbers.
Deuteronomy 7:23 And the Lord your God will deliver them into your sight and will destroy them with a great confusion until they are utterly wiped out.
Deuteronomy 7:24 He will deliver their kings into your hands, and you shall blot out their names from under the sky. No one will be able to resist you until you have crushed them.
Deuteronomy 7:25 You shall burn their carved images with fire. Do not covet the silver and gold that is on them, nor take anything from them for yourself, lest you be ensnared by it. For it is an abomination to the Lord your God.
Deuteronomy 7:26 And you shall not bring anything from an idol into your house, lest you become accursed like it. You shall utterly detest it as filth and abomination, and flee from it as defilement, for it is something dedicated to destruction.

Deuteronomy 8:null All the commandments that I am giving you today, you must keep and obey. You must do this so that you may live and become many in number. This is how you will be able to enter and take possession of the land that the Lord your God swore to give to your fathers.
Deuteronomy 8:2 null
Deuteronomy 8:null And you must remember the entire journey through which the Lord your God led you for forty years through the desert. He did this to humble you and to test you. This was to determine what was truly in your heart: whether you would keep His commandments or not.
Deuteronomy 8:3 null
Deuteronomy 8:null He humbled you with hunger and then gave you manna to eat—food that neither you nor your fathers had ever known. He did this to show you that a human being does not live by bread alone, but by every word that comes from the mouth of the Lord your God.
Deuteronomy 8:4 null
Deuteronomy 8:null Throughout those forty years, your clothing did not wear out from age, and your feet did not swell or blister.
Deuteronomy 8:5 null
Deuteronomy 8:null This was so you would understand that just as a person trains his son, so the Lord your God trained you.
Deuteronomy 8:6 null
Deuteronomy 8:null Therefore, you must keep the commandments of the Lord your God, walk in His ways, and fear Him.
Deuteronomy 8:7 null
Deuteronomy 8:null For the Lord your God is bringing you into an excellent land—a land of rivers, streams, and springs, where water gushes forth from the depths in its valleys and mountains.
Deuteronomy 8:8 null
Deuteronomy 8:null It is a land of wheat, barley, and vineyards, where fig trees, pomegranates, and olive groves grow. It is a land flowing with oil and honey.
Deuteronomy 8:9 null
Deuteronomy 8:null In that land, you will eat your bread without any scarcity, and you will enjoy an abundance of all things. Its rocks contain iron, and from its mountains, you will mine copper ore.
Deuteronomy 8:10 null
Deuteronomy 8:null When you have eaten and are satisfied, you must bless the Lord your God for the excellent land that He has given you.

Deuteronomy 8:13 null
Deuteronomy 8:null And you acquire herds of cattle and flocks of sheep, and an abundance of silver and gold and all sorts of other possessions.
Deuteronomy 8:14 null
Deuteronomy 8:null Do not let your heart become proud and then forget the Lord your God, who led you out of the land of Egypt, from the house of slavery.
Deuteronomy 8:15 null
Deuteronomy 8:null He was your guide in that great and terrifying wilderness, where there were fiery serpents and scorpions, and venomous snakes, and a thirst where there was no water at all. Yet it was He who brought forth streams of water from the hardest rock.
Deuteronomy 8:16 null
Deuteronomy 8:null It was He who fed you manna in the wilderness, which your fathers had not known. He humbled you and tested you, so that in the end, He might do good to you.
Deuteronomy 8:17 null

Deuteronomy 8:18 null
Deuteronomy 8:null Instead, remember the Lord your God, for it is He who gives you the strength to fulfill His covenant—the covenant He swore to your fathers, as is evident today.
Deuteronomy 8:19 null
Deuteronomy 8:null But if you forget the Lord your God, and follow other gods, and serve them, and worship them, then I solemnly warn you today that you will truly perish.

Deuteronomy 8:null Just as the nations that the Lord destroyed before you, so also will you perish if you are disobedient to the Lord your God.
Deuteronomy 8:1 All the commandments which I give to you today, you must keep and do, so that you may live and multiply. And you will enter and possess the land, which the Lord swore to your fathers.
Deuteronomy 8:2 And you will remember all the journey through which the Lord your God led you for forty years through the desert, so that He might humble you and test you. This was to reveal what was truly in your heart, whether you would keep His commandments or not.
Deuteronomy 8:3 He humbled you with scarcity and gave you manna to eat, which neither you nor your fathers had known. This was to show you that humanity does not live by bread alone, but by every word that comes from the mouth of the Lord.
Deuteronomy 8:4 Your clothing did not wear out at any time, and your sandals did not tear on your feet throughout those forty years.
Deuteronomy 8:5 So you must know that just as a father disciplines his son, so the Lord your God disciplined you.
Deuteronomy 8:6 You are to keep the commandments of the Lord your God, walk in His ways, and revere Him.
Deuteronomy 8:7 For the Lord your God will bring you into a good land—a land of flowing streams, springs, and deep waters that emerge from valleys and mountains.
Deuteronomy 8:8 A land of wheat, barley, and vineyards, where figs, pomegranates, and olives—from which oil is pressed—will grow.
Deuteronomy 8:9 A land of oil and honey, where you will eat your bread without any scarcity, and you will enjoy the abundance of all things, with no scarcity whatsoever.
Deuteronomy 8:10 So that you may eat and be satisfied, and bless the Lord your God for the excellent land which He has given to you.
Deuteronomy 8:11 Be very careful never to forget the Lord your God and neglect His commandments, judgments, and ceremonies, which I command you today.
Deuteronomy 8:12 Lest after you have eaten and are satisfied, you build beautiful houses and settle in them—
Deuteronomy 8:13 and your flocks of sheep and herds of cattle have multiplied, and your abundance of silver, gold, and all possessions has grown—
Deuteronomy 8:14 and your heart becomes proud, causing you to forget the Lord your God, who led you out of the land of Egypt, out of the house of slavery.
Deuteronomy 8:15 He led you through that great and terrible desert, where there were fiery serpents, scorpions, and vipers, and a land without water. He brought forth water for you from the hardest rock.
Deuteronomy 8:16 And He fed you with manna in the wilderness, which your fathers had not known. He sustained and tested you with these trials so that, in the end, He might show you His mercy.
Deuteronomy 8:17 You must not say in your heart, 'My own strength and the might of my hand have provided all these things for me.'
Deuteronomy 8:18 Instead, you must remember the Lord your God, for it is He who gives you the strength to possess this land. He does this to fulfill His covenant, which He swore to your fathers, just as it is being fulfilled today.
Deuteronomy 8:19 But if you forget the Lord your God and follow foreign gods, serving and worshipping them, behold, I declare to you now that you will utterly perish.
Deuteronomy 8:20 Just as the Lord destroyed the nations when you entered their land, so you also will perish if you are disobedient to the Lord your God.
Deuteronomy 9:1 Listen, Israel: Today you will cross over the Jordan River. You are going to take possession of nations that are very great and strong, and their cities are huge, with walls built up to the sky.
Deuteronomy 9:2 You will encounter a great and towering people, the sons of Anak, whom you already know, and about whom you have heard it said: 'Who can stand against the sons of Anak?'
Deuteronomy 9:3 Understand this today: The Lord your God Himself will cross over before you, like a consuming fire. He will crush these nations, and He will destroy and overthrow them before your very eyes. He will quickly wipe them out, and you will drive them out swiftly.
Deuteronomy 9:4 Do not say in your heart, when the Lord your God has destroyed these nations before you, that He brought you in to possess this land because of your own righteousness. Instead, the Lord will destroy them as you enter the land because of the wickedness of those nations.
Deuteronomy 9:5 You are not entering to take possession of their lands because of your own righteousness or the uprightness of your heart. It is because those nations have sinned wickedly that He will destroy them as you enter. This is also so that He may fulfill His promise, which He swore to your fathers Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.
Deuteronomy 9:6 Know, therefore, that the Lord your God is not giving you this excellent land to possess because of your own righteousness. This is because you are a stubborn people, hard-headed and unyielding.
Deuteronomy 9:7 Remember, and do not forget, how you provoked the Lord your God to anger in the wilderness. From the day you left Egypt until you arrived at this very place, you have always contended with the Lord, opposing His will.
Deuteronomy 9:8 For even at Horeb, you provoked Him to anger, and the Lord was so furious that He wanted to destroy you entirely.
Deuteronomy 9:9 This was when I went up the mountain to receive the stone tablets—the tablets of the covenant that the Lord had made with you. I remained on the mountain for forty days and forty nights, during which I ate no bread and drank no water.
Deuteronomy 9:10 Then the Lord gave me two stone tablets, written with the very finger of God. These contained all the words He had spoken to you on the mountain from the midst of the fire, when the people were gathered together.
Deuteronomy 9:11 And when the forty days and forty nights had passed, the Lord gave me the two stone tablets, the tablets of the covenant.
Deuteronomy 9:12 Then the Lord said to me: 'Get up and go down from here quickly, because your people, whom you brought out of Egypt, have sinned. They have very quickly abandoned the way that I commanded them, and they have made a molten idol for themselves.'
Deuteronomy 9:13 And again, the Lord said to me: 'I see that this people is stubborn and unyielding.'
Deuteronomy 9:14 'Let me alone, so that I may crush them and erase their name from under the sky. Then I will make you into a nation much greater and stronger than this one is.'
Deuteronomy 9:15 So, as I came down from the mountain, which was burning fiercely, and held the two tablets of the covenant in my hands, I saw that you had sinned against the Lord your God. You had made yourselves a molten calf, and you had quickly abandoned His way that He had shown you.
Deuteronomy 9:16 And I threw both tablets from my hands, shattering them before your very eyes.
Deuteronomy 9:17 Then I fell down and lay prostrate before the Lord for forty days and forty nights. I ate no food and drank no water, because of all the sins you had committed, by which you had sinned against the Lord and provoked Him to wrath.
Deuteronomy 9:18 For I was afraid of His fierce anger and indignation, with which He was stirred up against you, wanting to destroy you. But the Lord listened to me on this occasion as well, and relented.
Deuteronomy 9:19 Even against Aaron, the Lord was intensely angry, wanting to destroy him. And I interceded for him also.
Deuteronomy 9:20 Also, at Taberah, and at Massah, and at the graves of craving, you provoked the Lord with your complaints and desires.
Deuteronomy 9:21 It was also when the Lord sent you from Kadesh-barnea, saying: 'Go up and take possession of the land which I have given to you.' Yet you despised the command of the Lord your God, and you did not believe Him, nor were you willing to listen to His voice.
Deuteronomy 9:22 From the day you left Egypt until this very place, you have always been rebellious against the Lord.
Deuteronomy 9:23 And when the Lord sent me from Kadesh-barnea, saying, 'Go up and take possession of the land that I have given you,' you despised the command of the Lord your God. You did not believe Him, nor were you willing to listen to His voice.
Deuteronomy 9:24 Again, I fell down and lay prostrate before the Lord for forty days and forty nights, just as I had previously, so that He would not destroy you.
Deuteronomy 9:25 And I prayed to the Lord, saying: 'O Lord God, do not destroy Your people and Your inheritance, whom You redeemed in Your great power and led out of Egypt with a mighty hand.'
Deuteronomy 9:26 'Remember Your servants Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. Do not look upon the stubbornness of this people, nor their wickedness, nor their sin.'
Deuteronomy 9:27 'Otherwise, the inhabitants of the land from which You brought us out might say: 'The Lord was not able to bring them into the land He promised them, and He hated them; therefore, He led them out and killed them in the wilderness.''
Deuteronomy 9:28 'Yet they are Your people and Your inheritance, whom You brought out with Your great strength and with Your outstretched arm.'
Deuteronomy 9:29 These are the words which the Lord spoke to Moses on Mount Sinai.
Deuteronomy 9:1 Hear this, O Israel! You are about to cross the Jordan River this very day to dispossess nations far greater and stronger than yourselves, possessing immense cities with walls so fortified they seem to touch the very sky.
Deuteronomy 9:2 You will face a people of immense stature, dwelling behind high walls. These are the Anakim, whom you already know and have heard about, a lineage so mighty that no one, however strong, has ever been able to resist them.
Deuteronomy 9:3 Therefore, know this day that the Lord your God Himself will go before you. He is a consuming and devouring fire, and He Himself will utterly crush them and swiftly destroy them before your very eyes. You will drive them out and swiftly annihilate them, just as the Lord has promised you.
Deuteronomy 9:4 Do not say in your heart, once the Lord your God has destroyed them before you: 'It is because of my own righteousness that the Lord has brought me in to possess this land.' Understand instead that it is because of the wickedness of those nations that the Lord drives them out from before you.
Deuteronomy 9:5 For you are not entering to possess their land because of your own righteousness or the uprightness of your heart. Rather, it is because those nations acted wickedly, and also so that the Lord might fulfill His word, which He solemnly promised to your fathers Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.
Deuteronomy 9:6 Know therefore that it is not because of your own righteousness that the Lord your God is giving you this excellent land as a possession, for you are truly a stiff-necked people, stubbornly resistant to His will.
Deuteronomy 9:7 Remember this and never forget how you provoked the Lord your God to anger in the wilderness. From the very day you departed from Egypt until you reached this present place, you have continually contended against the Lord.
Deuteronomy 9:8 Indeed, even at Horeb you provoked the Lord to anger, and His wrath became so great that He intended to destroy you completely.
Deuteronomy 9:9 I recall when I ascended the mountain to receive the stone tablets, the very tablets of the covenant which the Lord had made with you. I remained on the mountain for forty days and forty nights, during which I neither ate bread nor drank water.
Deuteronomy 9:10 And the Lord gave me two stone tablets inscribed by the finger of God, containing all the words that He had spoken to you on the mountain from the midst of the fire, when He addressed the people directly.
Deuteronomy 9:11 And when the forty days and forty nights had passed, the Lord gave me the two stone tablets, the tablets of the covenant.
Deuteronomy 9:12 Then the Lord said to me: 'Arise, and descend from here quickly, for your people, whom you brought out of Egypt, have thoroughly corrupted themselves. They have swiftly departed from the path I commanded them, and they have made for themselves a molten idol.'
Deuteronomy 9:13 And again the Lord said to me: 'I perceive that this people is indeed stiff-necked and rebellious.'
Deuteronomy 9:14 'Leave Me alone now, that I may utterly crush them and blot out their name from under the entire sky. Then I will make you into a nation far greater and stronger than this one.'
Deuteronomy 9:15 So I turned and began to descend from the mountain, which was burning with fire, carrying the two tablets in my two hands.
Deuteronomy 9:16 And there I saw that you had sinned against the Lord your God, and had made for yourselves a molten calf. You had swiftly departed from His way which He had clearly shown to you.
Deuteronomy 9:17 Therefore, I threw down the two tablets from my hands and shattered them before your very eyes, as a sign of the covenant you had broken.
Deuteronomy 9:18 Then I prostrated myself before the Lord, just as before, for forty days and forty nights, neither eating bread nor drinking water, all on account of your great sin—the sin by which you had offended the Lord and done evil in His sight, provoking His burning anger.
Deuteronomy 9:19 For I was terrified by the fierce anger and indignation with which He was enraged against you, and by His desire to utterly destroy you. Yet, the Lord listened to me even on this occasion.
Deuteronomy 9:20 The Lord was also exceedingly angry with Aaron, intending to destroy him. And I interceded for Aaron as well.
Deuteronomy 9:21 As for the heinous idol you had made—that calf—I burned it with fire, then ground it into small pieces, pulverizing it into dust. I then scattered this dust into the torrent that flowed down from the mountain.
Deuteronomy 9:22 Even at Taberah, and at Massah, and at Kibroth-hattaavah, you again provoked the Lord to anger with your incessant complaints and desires.
Deuteronomy 9:23 And when the Lord sent you from Kadesh-barnea, saying: 'Go up and take possession of the land which I have given to you,' you refused to go up. Instead, you were disobedient to the command of the Lord your God, showing disbelief in His word.
Deuteronomy 9:24 Indeed, you have been rebellious against the Lord from the very first day I began to know you.
Deuteronomy 9:25 And so, I lay prostrate before the Lord for forty days and forty nights, during which I continually pleaded with Him not to destroy you, just as He had threatened to do.
Deuteronomy 9:26 And as I prayed, I said: 'O Lord God, do not destroy Your people and Your inheritance, whom You have redeemed by Your magnificent power, and whom You led out of Egypt with a mighty hand.'
Deuteronomy 9:27 'Remember Your servants, Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. Do not regard the stubbornness of this people, nor their wickedness, nor their sin.'
Deuteronomy 9:28 'Otherwise, the inhabitants of the land from which You brought us out might say: "Because the Lord was unable to bring them into the land He promised them, and because He hated them, He led them out into the wilderness to kill them."
Deuteronomy 9:29 'Yet, they are Your people and Your inheritance, whom You brought out with Your great strength and Your outstretched arm.'
Deuteronomy 9:30 This verse is a duplicate of verse 11 in the Clementine Vulgate. According to the text, it says: 'And when the forty days and forty nights had passed, the Lord gave me the two stone tablets, the tablets of the covenant.'
Deuteronomy 9:31 This verse is a duplicate of verse 13 in the Clementine Vulgate. Following the text: 'And again the Lord said to me: "I perceive that this people is indeed stiff-necked and rebellious."'
Deuteronomy 9:32 This verse is a duplicate of verse 14 in the Clementine Vulgate. According to the text: '"Leave Me alone now, that I may utterly crush them and blot out their name from under the entire sky. Then I will make you into a nation far greater and stronger than this one."'
Deuteronomy 9:33 This verse is a duplicate of verse 15 in the Clementine Vulgate. Translating the given text: 'So I turned and began to descend from the mountain, which was burning with fire, carrying the two tablets in my two hands.'
Deuteronomy 9:34 This verse is a duplicate of verse 16 in the Clementine Vulgate. The text states: 'And there I saw that you had sinned against the Lord your God, and had made for yourselves a molten calf. You had swiftly departed from His way which He had clearly shown to you.'
Deuteronomy 9:35 This verse is a duplicate of verse 17 in the Clementine Vulgate. Translating directly: 'Therefore, I threw down the two tablets from my hands and shattered them before your very eyes, as a sign of the covenant you had broken.'
Deuteronomy 9:36 This verse is a duplicate of verse 18 in the Clementine Vulgate. The text is: 'Then I prostrated myself before the Lord, just as before, for forty days and forty nights, neither eating bread nor drinking water, all on account of your great sin—the sin by which you had offended the Lord and done evil in His sight, provoking His burning anger.'
Deuteronomy 9:37 This verse is a duplicate of verse 19 in the Clementine Vulgate. Following the text: 'For I was terrified by the fierce anger and indignation with which He was enraged against you, and by His desire to utterly destroy you. Yet, the Lord listened to me even on this occasion.'
Deuteronomy 9:38 This verse is a duplicate of verse 20 in the Clementine Vulgate. It states: 'The Lord was also exceedingly angry with Aaron, intending to destroy him. And I interceded for Aaron as well.'
Deuteronomy 9:39 This verse is a duplicate of verse 21 in the Clementine Vulgate. The text reads: 'As for the heinous idol you had made—that calf—I burned it with fire, then ground it into small pieces, pulverizing it into dust. I then scattered this dust into the torrent that flowed down from the mountain.'
Deuteronomy 9:40 This verse is a duplicate of verse 22 in the Clementine Vulgate. Translating: 'Even at Taberah, and at Massah, and at Kibroth-hattaavah, you again provoked the Lord to anger with your incessant complaints and desires.'
Deuteronomy 10:1 At that time, the Lord said to me: "Carve out two tablets of stone for yourself, just like the first ones were, and come up to me on the mountain; and you will also make a wooden ark."
Deuteronomy 10:2 "And I will write on these tablets the very same words that were on the first ones, which you broke; and you will place these new tablets in the ark."
Deuteronomy 10:3 So I made an ark from acacia wood, and I carved out two tablets of stone in the exact likeness of the first ones, and I went up onto the mountain, holding them in my hands.
Deuteronomy 10:4 And He wrote on these tablets, just as He had written before, the ten words—the Ten Commandments—which the Lord had spoken to all of you on the mountain from the midst of the fire when all the people were gathered; and then He gave these tablets to me.
Deuteronomy 10:5 And I, having returned from the mountain, placed the tablets in the ark which I had made, just as the Lord had commanded me; and those tablets have remained there in the ark to this very day.
Deuteronomy 10:6 Now the children of Israel moved their camp from Beeroth of the sons of Jaacan to Moserath; it was there that Aaron died and was buried. And Eleazar, his son, served in the priesthood in his place.
Deuteronomy 10:7 From there, departing from Moserath, they came to Gadgad; and from Gadgad they moved on to Jotbathah, a place known for its many waters.
Deuteronomy 10:8 At that very time, the Lord set apart the tribe of Levi to carry the ark of the Lord's covenant, and to stand before Him in dedicated service, and to bless the people in His name, a role that continues even to this present day.
Deuteronomy 10:9 Therefore, the tribe of Levi has no share or inheritance alongside their brothers, because the Lord Himself is their inheritance and possession, just as the Lord your God spoke to them.
Deuteronomy 10:10 And I, as before, stood on the mountain for forty days and forty nights; and the Lord heard my prayer even concerning this matter, and He did not wish to destroy you.
Deuteronomy 10:11 And the Lord then said to me: "Arise, and go before the people, so that they may enter and take possession of the land which I swore to their fathers I would give to them."
Deuteronomy 10:12 And now, O Israel, what does the Lord your God ask of you, but that you fear the Lord your God—meaning, hold Him in reverential awe—and walk in His ways, and love Him, and serve the Lord your God with your whole heart and with your whole soul?
Deuteronomy 10:13 What He asks is that you keep the commandments of the Lord and His ordinances, which I command you today, so that it may be well with you.
Deuteronomy 10:14 Behold, the Lord your God owns the entire universe, and the highest heavens beyond our comprehension, the earth, and everything that exists in it.
Deuteronomy 10:15 Yet, despite His infinite dominion, the Lord took delight in your fathers and loved them; and He chose their descendants after them—that is, all of you—from all the peoples of the earth, just as it is proven even to this very day.
Deuteronomy 10:16 Therefore, spiritually circumcise the foreskin of your heart, meaning, cut away all that is sinful and worldly, and do not stiffen your neck in stubbornness any longer.
Deuteronomy 10:17 Because the Lord your God, He alone is the God of all gods and the Lord of all lords, a great, mighty, and awe-inspiring God, who shows no partiality and takes no bribes.
Deuteronomy 10:18 He executes justice for the orphan and the widow, and He loves the stranger, giving him food and clothing.
Deuteronomy 10:19 Therefore, you also must love strangers, because you yourselves were once strangers in the land of Egypt.
Deuteronomy 10:20 You shall fear the Lord your God, and you shall serve Him alone; you shall cling to Him, and you shall swear by His holy name.
Deuteronomy 10:21 He is your praise, and your God, who has done for you all these great and awe-inspiring things that your very eyes have seen.
Deuteronomy 10:22 Your fathers went down to Egypt with only seventy souls, and behold, now the Lord your God has multiplied you until you are as numerous as the stars of the universe.
Deuteronomy 10:1 At that time, the Lord said to me: 'Cut for yourself two stone tablets, just like the first ones you broke, and come up to me on the mountain. And then make a wooden ark, a special box to hold these new tablets.'
Deuteronomy 10:2 And I will write on these new tablets the same words that were on the first ones you shattered. Then, you will place these tablets inside the ark you made.
Deuteronomy 10:3 So I constructed the ark from acacia wood, and I carved two stone tablets, just like the original ones. Then, I ascended the mountain, carrying these two tablets with me.
Deuteronomy 10:4 And the Lord wrote on these tablets the ten sacred commands, exactly as He had written them the first time. These were the very words the Lord spoke to you on the mountain, from the heart of the fire, when all the people were gathered. And then He gave them to me.
Deuteronomy 10:5 Then, I descended from the mountain and returned to you. I placed the tablets inside the ark that I had made, and they have remained there to this very day, just as the Lord had commanded me.
Deuteronomy 10:6 Now, the sons of Israel moved their camp from Beeroth Bene Jaakan and came to Moserah. It was there that Aaron died and was buried, and his son Eleazar took his place as priest.
Deuteronomy 10:7 From Moserah, they journeyed to Gudgodah, and from Gudgodah, they moved to Jotbathah, a land where there were streams and running water.
Deuteronomy 10:8 At that particular time, the Lord set apart the tribe of Levi. They were designated to carry the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord, to stand before Him in service, and to bless the people in His name, a role they continue to fulfill to this present day.
Deuteronomy 10:9 This is why the Levites did not receive a share of the land or an inheritance alongside their fellow tribes. For the Lord Himself is their inheritance and their portion, just as the Lord your God told them.
Deuteronomy 10:10 As for me, I stood on the mountain for forty days and forty nights, just as I had done before. And the Lord listened to my pleas even on this occasion, and He chose not to destroy you, the people.
Deuteronomy 10:11 Then the Lord said to me: 'Rise, and lead the people forward, so that they may enter and take possession of the land that I swore to give to their ancestors.'
Deuteronomy 10:12 And now, O Israel, what does the Lord your God truly ask of you? Is it not to revere the Lord your God, to walk in all His ways, to love Him, and to serve the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul?
Deuteronomy 10:13 What He asks is that you keep the commandments of the Lord and His ceremonies, which I am giving to you today, so that things may go well for you and you may prosper.
Deuteronomy 10:14 Behold, the Lord your God is the Creator and Owner of the sky, and even the highest heavens, the earth, and everything that exists within it. All belongs to Him.
Deuteronomy 10:15 Nevertheless, the Lord desired to bind Himself to your ancestors and He loved them. And He chose their descendants after them—that is, you—from all the nations, as is clearly evident today.
Deuteronomy 10:16 Therefore, circumcise the foreskin of your heart, meaning, cut away all spiritual impurities and harden your neck no longer against God’s will. Do not be stubborn.
Deuteronomy 10:17 For the Lord your God is indeed the God of all lesser gods, and the Lord of all earthly rulers. He is a great, mighty, and awe-inspiring God who shows no partiality and cannot be bribed.
Deuteronomy 10:18 He renders justice for the orphan and the widow. He loves the foreigner and provides him with food and clothing.
Deuteronomy 10:19 So you too must love foreigners, for you yourselves were once foreigners in the land of Egypt.
Deuteronomy 10:20 You shall revere the Lord your God, and Him alone you shall serve. To Him you shall hold fast, and by His name alone you shall swear your oaths.
Deuteronomy 10:21 He is your praise and your God, the one who performed these great and awesome deeds for you, which your own eyes have witnessed.
Deuteronomy 10:22 Your ancestors went down into Egypt with only seventy people. But now, behold, the Lord your God has multiplied you until you are as numerous as the stars in the sky.
Deuteronomy 10:23 I will not give further commandments concerning this among you now, because all your deeds are known to me, and all your thoughts are hidden from no one and known to me.
Deuteronomy 10:24 I will not speak further about this among you, for all your deeds are already accomplished and known, and all your thoughts are known to me and cannot be hidden.
Deuteronomy 10:25 If you devise any schemes against me, I will no longer tolerate this, and will not grant you any further reprieve.
Deuteronomy 10:26 I will grant you whatever you desire concerning this, provided that you are not against me.
Deuteronomy 10:27 Even if you sin, I will grant you forgiveness for this.
Deuteronomy 10:28 I will not grant you this, however, if you are stubborn and refuse to listen to my word.
Deuteronomy 10:29 I will not grant you this, if you are idolaters and worship false idols.
Deuteronomy 10:30 I will not grant you this, if you are blasphemous and lie under false oaths.
Deuteronomy 10:31 I will not grant you this, if you are impious and shed innocent blood.
Deuteronomy 10:32 I will not grant you this, if you are fornicators and commit adultery.
Deuteronomy 10:33 I will not grant you this, if you are greedy and acquire money unjustly.
Deuteronomy 10:34 I will not grant you this, if you are proud and despise your neighbor.
Deuteronomy 10:35 I will not grant you this, if you are envious and rejoice at the misfortunes of others.
Deuteronomy 10:36 I will not grant you this, if you are slanderers and secretly harm your neighbor.
Deuteronomy 10:37 I will not grant you this, if you are quick to anger and injure your neighbor in your wrath.
Deuteronomy 10:38 I will not grant you this, if you are contentious and cause harm to your neighbor in disputes.
Deuteronomy 10:39 I will not grant you this, if you are rebellious and rise up against me and against my law.
Deuteronomy 10:40 I will not grant you this, if you are faithless and do not believe in me and in my words.
Deuteronomy 11:1 Therefore, you will love the Lord your God, and keep His commandments, His rituals, His judgments, and His instructions at all times.
Deuteronomy 11:2 Understand today what your children did not know or experience, because they did not see the discipline of the Lord your God. They did not see His great deeds, His mighty hand, and His outstretched arm—
Deuteronomy 11:3 —the signs and wonders He performed in the midst of Egypt against Pharaoh, its king, and against all of his land.
Deuteronomy 11:4 You also saw what He did to the Egyptian army, their horses, and their chariots: how He covered them with the waters of the Red Sea when they pursued you. The Lord destroyed them, and that destruction continues to this very day.
Deuteronomy 11:5 You saw what He did for you in the desert until you came to this very place.
Deuteronomy 11:6 And you saw what happened to Dathan and Abiram, the sons of Eliab, who was the son of Reuben. The earth opened its mouth and swallowed them with their households, their tents, and all their possessions that they had in the midst of Israel.
Deuteronomy 11:7 Your own eyes have seen all the great works that the Lord performed.
Deuteronomy 11:8 Therefore, keep all His commandments which I command you today, so that you may live, multiply, and go in to possess the land to which you are heading.
Deuteronomy 11:9 And you will live in it for many days—a land that the Lord promised with an oath to your fathers and their descendants, a land flowing with milk and honey.
Deuteronomy 11:10 For the land you are entering to possess is not like the land of Egypt, from which you came. There, after sowing your seed, you had to irrigate it by foot, like a vegetable garden.
Deuteronomy 11:11 But this land is mountainous and has plains, and it relies on rain from the sky.
Deuteronomy 11:12 The Lord your God always watches over it, and His eyes are upon it from the beginning of the year to its end.
Deuteronomy 11:13 Therefore, if you obey My commandments which I command you today—that you love the Lord your God and serve Him with all your heart and with all your soul—
Deuteronomy 11:14 —then I will give rain to your land at its proper time, both the early and the late rains, so that you may gather your grain, your wine, and your oil.
Deuteronomy 11:15 I will also provide grass in your fields for your livestock, so that you may eat and be satisfied.
Deuteronomy 11:16 Be careful, lest your heart be deceived, and you turn away from the Lord to serve foreign gods and worship them.
Deuteronomy 11:17 Otherwise, the Lord will be angry with you and shut up the sky, so that no rain will fall, and the earth will not yield its produce. Then you will quickly perish from the excellent land that the Lord is giving you.
Deuteronomy 11:18 Therefore, lay these words of mine in your hearts and in your souls. Tie them as a sign on your hands and place them between your eyes as a reminder.
Deuteronomy 11:19 Teach them to your children, that they may meditate on them when you sit in your house, when you walk on the road, when you lie down, and when you rise up.
Deuteronomy 11:20 You shall also write them on the doorposts and gates of your house.
Deuteronomy 11:21 Do this so that your days and the days of your children may be multiplied in the land that the Lord swore to your fathers to give them, for as long as the sky stretches over the earth.
Deuteronomy 11:22 For if you carefully keep all these commandments that I am giving you today, and carry them out, so that you love the Lord your God, and walk in all His ways, and cling to Him—
Deuteronomy 11:23 —then the Lord will drive out all these nations before you, and you will dispossess them, even those nations that are larger and stronger than you.
Deuteronomy 11:24 Every place that your foot steps upon will be yours. Your territory will extend from the desert and Lebanon, from the River Euphrates to the western sea.
Deuteronomy 11:25 No one will be able to stand against you. The Lord your God will put the dread and fear of you upon all the land that you are about to tread upon, just as He promised you.
Deuteronomy 11:26 See, I am setting before you today a blessing and a curse.
Deuteronomy 11:27 The blessing will come if you obey the commandments of the Lord your God, which I am giving you today.
Deuteronomy 11:28 The curse will come if you do not obey the commandments of the Lord your God, but turn aside from the way that I am showing you today, and follow other gods whom you have not known.
Deuteronomy 11:29 When the Lord your God brings you into the land that you are going to possess, you shall set the blessing on Mount Gerizim and the curse on Mount Ebal.
Deuteronomy 11:30 These mountains are across the Jordan, along the road that leads toward the sunset, in the land of the Canaanites who live in the plains opposite Gilgal, near the valley of Moreh which rises from the opposite side.
Deuteronomy 11:31 For you are about to cross the Jordan to take possession of the land that the Lord your God is giving you. You will hold it and live in it.
Deuteronomy 11:32 Therefore, be careful to diligently observe all the rituals and judgments that I am setting before you today.
Deuteronomy 11:1 Therefore, you must love the Lord your God. You must also keep His commands, rituals, ordinances, and statutes at all times.
Deuteronomy 11:2 Understand this today: I am not speaking to your children, who have not known and have not seen the instruction of the Lord your God. They did not see His great deeds, His strong hand, and His outstretched arm.
Deuteronomy 11:3 They did not see the miracles and works He performed in the midst of Egypt against Pharaoh the king, and against all of his land.
Deuteronomy 11:4 They did not see what He did to the army of the Egyptians, to their horses and chariots. They did not see how the waters of the Red Sea covered them when they were pursuing you, and how the Lord utterly destroyed them, even to this present day.
Deuteronomy 11:5 They did not see what He did for you in the wilderness, until you came to this place.
Deuteronomy 11:6 They did not see what happened to Dathan and Abiram, the sons of Eliab, who was the son of Reuben. They did not see how the earth opened its mouth and swallowed them, along with their tents and all their possessions which they had in the midst of Israel.
Deuteronomy 11:7 Indeed, your very own eyes have seen all the great works of the Lord which He performed.
Deuteronomy 11:8 Therefore, keep all the commands that I am giving you today, so that you may live and multiply. You will then enter and possess the land to which you are going.
Deuteronomy 11:9 This is so you may live long lives in the land that the Lord swore to your fathers and to their descendants to give them—a land flowing with milk and honey.
Deuteronomy 11:10 For the land you are entering to possess is not like the land of Egypt, from which you came. In Egypt, you sowed your seed and watered the dry ground with your foot, like a garden that is irrigated by hand or foot-powered pumps.
Deuteronomy 11:11 But this land is mountainous and has level plains, and it relies on rain from the sky.
Deuteronomy 11:12 The Lord your God always watches over this land. His eyes are upon it from the beginning of the year to its very end.
Deuteronomy 11:13 Therefore, if you obey my commands that I am giving you today, so that you love the Lord your God and serve Him with all your heart and with all your soul,
Deuteronomy 11:14 then I will give rain to your land at its proper time—the early rain and the latter rain. This is so you may gather your grain, your wine, and your oil.
Deuteronomy 11:15 I will also provide green pasture in your fields, so that your livestock may eat and you yourselves may be satisfied.
Deuteronomy 11:16 Beware lest your heart be deceived and you turn away from the Lord. Do not serve foreign gods and worship them.
Deuteronomy 11:17 Otherwise, the Lord's anger will burn against you. He will close the sky so that no rain comes down, and the land will not yield its fruit. You will quickly perish from the excellent land which the Lord is about to give you.
Deuteronomy 11:18 Therefore, place these words of mine in your hearts and in your souls. Tie them as a sign on your hands for a constant reminder, and place them between your eyes as a visible token.
Deuteronomy 11:19 Teach them to your children, so that they may always ponder these words. Speak of them when you sit in your house, when you walk on the way, when you lie down, and when you rise up.
Deuteronomy 11:20 Also, write them on the doorposts and on the gates of your house.
Deuteronomy 11:21 This is so that your days and the days of your children may be multiplied in the land which the Lord swore to your fathers to give them, as long as the sky hangs over the earth—which means forever.
Deuteronomy 11:22 For if you keep these commands that I am giving you and perform them, so that you love the Lord your God and walk in all His ways, holding fast to Him,
Deuteronomy 11:23 then the Lord will drive out all these nations before your presence. You will possess them, even though they are much greater and stronger than you.
Deuteronomy 11:24 Every place that your foot treads upon will be yours. Your boundaries will extend from the wilderness and Lebanon, from the great river Euphrates, even to the western sea—the Mediterranean.
Deuteronomy 11:25 No one will be able to stand against you. The Lord your God will put the dread and fear of you upon all the land that you are about to tread upon, just as He promised you.
Deuteronomy 11:26 I am setting before you today a blessing and a curse.
Deuteronomy 11:27 A blessing, if you obey the commands of the Lord your God that I am giving you today.
Deuteronomy 11:28 But a curse, if you do not obey the commands of the Lord your God, and instead turn aside from the way that I am now showing you. This curse will come if you walk after foreign gods whom you do not know.
Deuteronomy 11:29 Therefore, when you enter the land that the Lord your God is about to give you, you shall pronounce the blessing on Mount Gerizim and the curse on Mount Ebal.
Deuteronomy 11:30 These mountains are beyond the Jordan, following the road that leads westward, in the land of the Canaanites who dwell in the plains opposite Gilgal. This Gilgal is near the valley that extends far inward.
Deuteronomy 11:31 For you are about to cross the Jordan to possess the land that the Lord your God is giving you, and you will hold it.
Deuteronomy 11:32 Therefore, observe and fulfill all the rituals and ordinances that I am setting before you today.
Deuteronomy 12:1 These are the commandments, the regulations, and the rulings
which you must carefully observe in the land that the Lord God of your fathers is about to give you to possess—
for as long as you live on that land.
Deuteronomy 12:2 You must completely demolish every place where the nations you are about to dispossess have worshipped their false gods—
whether on high mountains, or on hills, or under every lush, leafy tree.
Deuteronomy 12:3 You must tear down their altars, and shatter their sacred statues.
Cut down their groves of false worship, and burn their idols with fire.
And completely erase the names of those gods from those places.
Deuteronomy 12:4 You must not worship the Lord your God in that manner.
Deuteronomy 12:5 Instead, you must go to the specific place that the Lord your God chooses from all your tribes
to establish His name there and to make His dwelling permanent—
that is the only place you must go to worship Him.
Deuteronomy 12:6 And in that place alone, you are to offer your burnt offerings and your sacrificial victims,
your tithes and the firstfruits of your labor,
your vowed offerings and your freewill offerings,
along with the firstborn of your cattle and your sheep.
Deuteronomy 12:7 And there, in the presence of the Lord your God, you are to eat your sacred meals and rejoice
in everything you have accomplished, you and your households,
for the Lord your God has blessed you in all these things.
Deuteronomy 12:8 You must not continue to do there—in the Promised Land—what we do here today in the wilderness,
where everyone does what seems right in his own eyes.
Deuteronomy 12:9 For up until this present time, you have not yet reached the place of rest
and the possession that the Lord your God is about to give you.
Deuteronomy 12:10 You will cross the Jordan River and settle in the land that the Lord your God is about to give you,
so that you may be at rest from all your enemies on every side.
Then you will live in that land without any fear.
Deuteronomy 12:11 And there will be one specific place that the Lord your God will choose for His name to dwell permanently.
To that one place alone, you must bring everything I command you:
your burnt offerings, your sacrifices, your tithes, the firstfruits of your labor,
and whatever you have vowed to the Lord.
Deuteronomy 12:12 And you are to feast there before the Lord your God, you and your sons and daughters,
your male and female servants, and the Levites who live in your towns,
because the Levites have no other allotted portion or possession with you.
Deuteronomy 12:13 Be careful not to offer your burnt offerings in just any place you see fit.
Deuteronomy 12:14 Instead, you must offer your oblations only in the place that the Lord chooses in one of your tribes,
and there you must do everything I command you today.
Deuteronomy 12:15 However, if you find yourself hungry and wish to eat meat, you may eat as much as your soul desires,
in all your towns, except for those animals that are offered as sacrifices to the Lord—these you are permitted to eat.
Deuteronomy 12:16 Only, you must not consume the blood. Instead, you must pour it out on the ground like water.
Deuteronomy 12:17 You will not be allowed to eat in your own towns the tithe of your grain, wine, and oil,
nor the firstborn of your herds and flocks, nor anything you have vowed as an offering,
nor any freewill offering, nor the firstfruits of your labor.
Deuteronomy 12:18 Instead, you must eat these things before the Lord your God
in the place that the Lord your God chooses—you and your son and daughter, your male and female servant,
and the Levite who lives in your towns.
And you will rejoice and be refreshed before the Lord your God in all the work of your hands.
Deuteronomy 12:19 Be careful not to neglect the Levite throughout all the time you are living as a sojourner in your land.
Deuteronomy 12:20 When the Lord your God enlarges your territory, just as He has promised you,
and you desire to eat meat, because your soul longs for it,
Deuteronomy 12:21 and if the chosen place, where the Lord your God has placed His name, is too far away for you to bring your sacrifices to,
then you may slaughter any of your cattle or sheep that the Lord has given you, just as I have commanded you.
And you may eat the meat in your own towns, according to all that your soul desires.
Deuteronomy 12:22 You may eat it just as you would eat a gazelle or a deer; anyone, whether ritually clean or unclean,
may eat it together, freely.
Deuteronomy 12:23 Only be very careful not to eat the blood; for the blood is their life itself.
And for that reason, you must not consume the life of the meat.
Deuteronomy 12:24 Instead, you must pour it out on the ground like water.
Deuteronomy 12:25 If you do what is displeasing to the Lord, and what is evil in His sight,
it will go well for you and for your children after you.
Deuteronomy 12:26 Therefore, the holy things that you have consecrated and vowed to the Lord,
your assembly must take up, and you must come to the place that the Lord chooses.
Deuteronomy 12:27 And you are to offer your burnt offerings, both the meat and the blood, on the altar of the Lord your God.
As for the meat of your other sacrifices, it shall be slaughtered,
and its blood will be poured out upon the altar.
Deuteronomy 12:28 Observe and obey all these things that I command you today,
so that it may go well for you and for your children after you forever,
when you do what is good and pleasing in the sight of the Lord your God.
Deuteronomy 12:29 When the Lord your God cuts off the nations before you, whom you are going in to dispossess,
and you have driven them out and settled in their land,
Deuteronomy 12:30 be careful that you are not ensnared by their ways, after they have been destroyed from before you.
Do not inquire about how they worshipped their gods, saying to yourself, 'I will do the same.'
Deuteronomy 12:31 You must not act in that manner toward the Lord your God.
For they have committed against their gods all the abominable practices that the Lord detests,
even burning their own sons and daughters in the fire as offerings.
Deuteronomy 12:32 Everything that I command you, that alone you must do for the Lord your God.
You must not add anything to it, nor take anything away from it.
Deuteronomy 12:1 These are the commands and the judgments that you must obey in the land that the Lord God of your ancestors is about to give you. You are to possess this land and live upon it for as long as you are able.
Deuteronomy 12:2 You must completely destroy all the places where the nations you are about to dispossess have worshipped their gods: on the highest mountains, on the hills, and under every leafy tree.
Deuteronomy 12:3 Tear down their altars, smash their idols, cut down their sacred groves, and burn their carved images with fire. You must erase the very names of their gods from those places.
Deuteronomy 12:4 You must not do anything like this to the Lord your God.
Deuteronomy 12:5 Instead, you must come to the specific place that the Lord your God will choose out of all your tribes, to establish His Name there and to dwell there.
Deuteronomy 12:6 There, you are to offer your burnt offerings and your sacrifices, your tithes and the firstfruits of your labor, your vowed offerings and your freewill offerings, and the firstborn of your cattle and your sheep.
Deuteronomy 12:7 And you will eat there in the presence of the Lord your God, and you will rejoice with all that you have accomplished, you and your households, for all the ways in which the Lord your God has blessed you.
Deuteronomy 12:8 You must not do there what we do here today, where each person does whatever seems right in their own eyes.
Deuteronomy 12:9 For up to the present time, you have not yet come to the rest and the possession of the land that the Lord your God is about to give you.
Deuteronomy 12:10 You will cross the Jordan River and dwell in the land that the Lord your God is about to give you, so that you may find rest from all your enemies on every side and live without any fear.
Deuteronomy 12:11 In the place that the Lord your God will choose to establish His Name there, you are to bring all that I command you: your burnt offerings and your sacrifices, your tithes and the firstfruits of your labor, and whatever you have vowed to the Lord.
Deuteronomy 12:12 And you will feast there before the Lord your God, you and your sons and daughters, your male and female servants, and the Levite who lives within your gates, because he has no portion or inheritance with you.
Deuteronomy 12:13 Be careful not to offer your burnt offerings in every place you might see.
Deuteronomy 12:14 But only in the place that the Lord will choose in one of your tribes are you to offer your burnt offerings, and there you must do all that I command you.
Deuteronomy 12:15 Nevertheless, in every city you may slaughter and eat meat according to all the desire of your soul, from whatever the Lord your God has blessed you with, whether it is ritually clean or ritually unclean. You may eat it as you would a gazelle or a deer.
Deuteronomy 12:16 Only do not eat the blood; instead, you must pour it out upon the ground like water.
Deuteronomy 12:17 You will not be permitted to eat in your towns the tithe of your grain, or your wine, or your oil, nor the firstborn of your herds and your flocks, nor any of the offerings you have vowed, or your freewill offerings, or the firstfruits of your labor.
Deuteronomy 12:18 Instead, you must eat them before the Lord your God in the place that the Lord your God will choose: you, and your son, and your daughter, your male and female servants, and the Levite who dwells in your cities. And you will rejoice and be refreshed before the Lord your God in all that you accomplish.
Deuteronomy 12:19 Be careful not to neglect the Levite at any time while you are dwelling in your land.
Deuteronomy 12:20 When the Lord your God expands your territory, just as He promised you, and you desire to eat meat—whatever your soul longs for—you will then have the permission to slaughter and eat it according to the blessing of the Lord your God, and according to every desire of your soul.
Deuteronomy 12:21 If the place that the Lord your God has chosen to establish His Name there is too far away, you may slaughter from your herds and your flocks, which the Lord has given you, just as I have commanded you. You may eat it in your own cities, according to every desire of your soul.
Deuteronomy 12:22 You may eat from them just as you would eat a gazelle or a deer: both the ritually clean and the ritually unclean alike may partake.
Deuteronomy 12:23 Only be careful not to eat the blood, for the blood is their life, and therefore you must not eat the life with the meat.
Deuteronomy 12:24 You must not eat it, but you are to pour it out on the ground like water.
Deuteronomy 12:25 You must not eat it, so that it may go well with you and with your children after you, when you do what is pleasing before the Lord.
Deuteronomy 12:26 But your vowed offerings and your freewill offerings that you have made to the Lord, you must take and bring to the place that the Lord will choose.
Deuteronomy 12:27 There you will offer your burnt offerings—both the meat and the blood—upon the altar of the Lord your God. You will pour the blood of the sacrifices at the base of the altar, and lay the meat itself upon the altar.
Deuteronomy 12:28 Be diligent to observe and listen to all that I command you, so that it may always go well with you and with your children after you, when you do what is good and pleasing in the sight of the Lord your God.
Deuteronomy 12:29 When the Lord your God has destroyed before you the nations into whose land you are going to possess, and you have driven them out and settled in their land,
Deuteronomy 12:30 Be careful not to imitate their customs after they have been scattered before you. Do not even inquire how they worshipped their gods, saying to yourself, 'Just as these nations worshipped their gods, so will I worship them too.'
Deuteronomy 12:31 You must not act in this way towards the Lord your God, for they have done to their gods all the abominable practices that the Lord detests, even offering their sons and daughters and burning them with fire.
Deuteronomy 12:32 Everything that I command you, this alone you must do for the Lord your God. You must neither add to it nor take away from it.
Deuteronomy 13:1 If a prophet, or someone who sees visions or has dreams, arises among you and declares a sign or a wonder to you,
Deuteronomy 13:2 and what he said actually happens, and then he says to you, "Let us go and follow other gods, gods you do not know, and let us serve them,"
Deuteronomy 13:3 you shall not listen to the words of that prophet or dreamer. For the Lord your God is testing you, so that it may be clearly seen whether you love Him with all your heart and with all your soul, or not.
Deuteronomy 13:4 You must follow the Lord your God, and you must revere Him, and keep His commands. Listen to His voice, serve Him, and hold fast to Him.
Deuteronomy 13:5 But that prophet or dreamer, you must put him to death. Because he spoke words to turn you away from the Lord your God, Who brought you out of the land of Egypt and redeemed you from the house of slavery. He sought to drive you from the way the Lord your God commanded you, and he would not let you hear God's commands. You must remove this evil from your midst.
Deuteronomy 13:6 If your brother, the son of your mother, or your son, or your daughter, or the wife who shares your bed, or your friend whom you love as your own soul, secretly tries to persuade you, saying, "Let us go and serve other gods," gods whom neither you nor your fathers have known—
Deuteronomy 13:7 gods of the peoples who are around you, whether they are near or far, from one end of the earth to the other—
Deuteronomy 13:8 you must not agree with him, nor listen to him. Your eye must not show pity for him, you must not spare him, and you must not hide his sin.
Deuteronomy 13:9 Instead, you must immediately put him to death. Your hand shall be the first upon him to kill him, and afterward, the hands of all the people.
Deuteronomy 13:10 Stones shall cover him and bring about his death. This is because he wanted to draw you away from the Lord your God, Who brought you out of the land of Egypt, from the house of slavery.
Deuteronomy 13:11 So that all of Israel, hearing about this, may fear and never again do anything of this kind.
Deuteronomy 13:12 If you hear in one of your cities, which the Lord your God is giving you to inhabit, some people saying,
Deuteronomy 13:13 "Worthless men—literally 'sons of Belial'—have gone out from among you and have turned away the inhabitants of their city, saying, 'Let us go and serve other gods whom you have not known,'"
Deuteronomy 13:14 then you must inquire, investigate diligently, and ask about every detail with the utmost truthfulness. If it is certain, and the detestable act is proven true among you,
Deuteronomy 13:15 you must immediately strike the inhabitants of that city with the edge of the sword, and you must utterly destroy it, and all that is in it, even its livestock.
Deuteronomy 13:16 And all the plunder of that city you shall gather into the middle of its open square and burn the city with all its goods as a complete offering to the Lord your God. It shall remain a perpetual mound of ruins and shall never be built again.
Deuteronomy 13:17 Let nothing of the cursed thing cling to your hand, so that the Lord may turn from the fierceness of His anger and show you mercy, and multiply you as He swore to your fathers,
Deuteronomy 13:18 if you listen to the voice of the Lord your God and keep all His commandments which I command you today, to do what is right in the sight of the Lord your God.
Deuteronomy 14:1 You are truly children of the Lord your God. Therefore, you must not cut yourselves, nor must you shave your heads as a sign of mourning for the dead.
Deuteronomy 14:2 This is because you are a holy people, belonging to the Lord your God. The Lord chose you specifically to be His own treasured people, distinct from all other nations on the face of the earth.
Deuteronomy 14:3 You must not eat anything that is an abomination.
Deuteronomy 14:4 These are the animals you may eat: an ox, a sheep, and a goat.
Deuteronomy 14:5 Also, you may eat the deer, the roe deer, the wild ox, the tragelaphus (a type of mountain goat or antelope), the oryx, the giraffe, and the bison.
Deuteronomy 14:6 You may eat every animal that has a completely split hoof and that also chews the cud.
Deuteronomy 14:7 However, among those that chew the cud or have a split hoof, you must not eat these: the camel, the hare, and the hyrax. Although they chew the cud, their hooves are not fully divided, making them unclean for you.
Deuteronomy 14:8 Also, the pig is unclean for you. Though it has a divided hoof, it does not chew the cud. You must not eat their meat, and you must not touch their dead bodies.
Deuteronomy 14:9 From all the creatures that live in the water, you may eat these: anything that has both fins and scales.
Deuteronomy 14:10 But anything that does not have both fins and scales, you must not eat, because it is unclean.
Deuteronomy 14:11 You may eat all clean birds.
Deuteronomy 14:12 However, you must not eat these birds: the eagle, the griffon vulture, and the sea eagle.
Deuteronomy 14:13 Also the kite, and all kinds of vultures.
Deuteronomy 14:14 And every kind of raven.
Deuteronomy 14:15 Also the ostrich, the horned owl, the seagull, and every kind of hawk.
Deuteronomy 14:16 The little owl, the ibis, and the swan.
Deuteronomy 14:17 The night heron, the cormorant, and all kinds of raven.
Deuteronomy 14:18 Also the heron, and all kinds of plover, as well as the hoopoe and the bat.
Deuteronomy 14:19 Furthermore, every winged insect that also crawls on the ground will be unclean for you, and it must not be eaten.
Deuteronomy 14:20 You may eat anything that is clean.
Deuteronomy 14:21 You must not eat any animal that has died a natural death. You may give it to a foreigner who lives within your towns, and he may eat it, or you may sell it to a non-Israelite. This is because you are a holy people, belonging to the Lord your God. Also, you must never boil a young goat in its mother's milk.
Deuteronomy 14:22 You must set aside a tithe—a tenth—of all the produce from your fields that grows each year in the land.
Deuteronomy 14:23 You must eat this tithe—your tithe of grain, new wine, and olive oil, and the firstborn of your cattle and sheep—in the presence of the Lord your God, at the specific place He will choose for His Name to be invoked. This practice will teach you to revere the Lord your God at all times.
Deuteronomy 14:24 If the journey is too long for you, and the place the Lord your God has chosen is very far away, so that you cannot carry your tithe there—or if the distance makes it impractical to transport it directly—
Deuteronomy 14:25 then you may convert all of your tithes into money. Tie the silver or gold securely in your hand, and travel to the place the Lord your God has chosen.
Deuteronomy 14:26 With that money, you may buy whatever you desire: cattle, sheep, wine, or strong drink, or anything else your heart longs for. You are to eat and drink there in the presence of the Lord your God, and you and your entire household are to rejoice together.
Deuteronomy 14:27 Be sure not to neglect the Levite who lives within your towns, because he does not have an inherited portion or land ownership among you.
Deuteronomy 14:28 At the end of every three years, you must bring out the entire tithe of your produce from that year and store it within your towns.
Deuteronomy 14:29 Then the Levite, who has no inherited portion or land with you, and the foreigner, the orphan, and the widow who live within your towns, will come and eat until they are satisfied. Do this so that the Lord your God may bless you in all the work of your hands that you undertake.
Deuteronomy 14:1 You are children of the Lord your God, so you must not wound yourselves or shave your heads for the dead.
Deuteronomy 14:2 Because you are a holy people to the Lord your God, and He has chosen you to be His own special people from all the nations on earth.
Deuteronomy 14:3 Do not eat anything that is detestable.
Deuteronomy 14:4 These are the animals you are permitted to eat: an ox, a sheep, and a goat,
Deuteronomy 14:5 a stag, a gazelle, a roebuck, a wild goat, an ibex, a wild ox, and a chamois.
Deuteronomy 14:6 You may eat any animal that has a completely split hoof and chews the cud.
Deuteronomy 14:7 But among those that chew the cud or have a split hoof but not both, you must not eat these: the camel, the rabbit, and the rock badger, because they chew the cud but do not have a completely split hoof. They are unclean for you.
Deuteronomy 14:8 The pig is also unclean for you, because it has a split hoof but does not chew the cud. You must not eat their meat or touch their dead bodies.
Deuteronomy 14:9 From all the creatures that live in the water, you may eat everything that has fins and scales.
Deuteronomy 14:10 But anything that does not have fins and scales you must not eat, because it is unclean for you.
Deuteronomy 14:11 You may eat all birds that are clean.
Deuteronomy 14:12 But these are the birds you must not eat: the eagle, the vulture, and the osprey,
Deuteronomy 14:13 the kite, the falcon, and any kind of buzzard or kite,
Deuteronomy 14:14 and any kind of raven,
Deuteronomy 14:15 the ostrich, the screech owl, the seagull, and any kind of hawk,
Deuteronomy 14:16 the little owl, the great owl, and the swan,
Deuteronomy 14:17 the pelican, the cormorant, and the purple heron,
Deuteronomy 14:18 the stork, any kind of heron, the hoopoe, and the bat.
Deuteronomy 14:19 All winged insects that crawl on the ground are unclean for you and must not be eaten.
Deuteronomy 14:20 You may eat all other clean winged creatures.
Deuteronomy 14:21 Do not eat anything that dies naturally. You may give it to a foreigner living within your city gates to eat, or you may sell it to a non-Israelite, because you are a holy people to the Lord your God. You must not cook a young goat in its mother’s milk.
Deuteronomy 14:22 You must set aside a tithe—one tenth—of all the produce that grows annually from your fields.
Deuteronomy 14:23 And you shall eat your tithe of grain, new wine, and olive oil, and the firstborn of your cattle and sheep, in the presence of the Lord your God at the special place He chooses to make His name dwell there. You shall do this so that you may learn to revere the Lord your God always.
Deuteronomy 14:24 But if the journey is too far for you, and the special place the Lord your God chooses is too distant for you to carry your tithe, because the Lord your God has blessed you abundantly and the amount is too great,
Deuteronomy 14:25 then you may sell your produce, take the money with you, and go to the special place the Lord your God chooses.
Deuteronomy 14:26 With that money, you may buy anything you desire—cattle, sheep, wine, or strong drink—and you and your household shall eat and rejoice in the presence of the Lord your God.
Deuteronomy 14:27 And do not neglect the Levite who lives within your city gates, because he has no share or inheritance of land among you.
Deuteronomy 14:28 At the end of every third year, you must bring out the tithe—one tenth—of all your produce from that year and store it within your city gates.
Deuteronomy 14:29 Then the Levite, who has no share or inheritance of land among you, and the foreigner, the orphan, and the widow who live within your city gates, may come and eat and be satisfied. Do this so that the Lord your God may bless you in everything you put your hand to.
Deuteronomy 15:1 Every seven years, you must bring about a complete release of all debts—this is the Sabbatical year, for the forgiveness of debts.
Deuteronomy 15:2 And this is the specific rule for that debt release: Every creditor who has lent anything to his debtor must release it. He is not to demand repayment from his debtor, for it is the Lord's designated time for debt release.
Deuteronomy 15:3 You may demand payment from a foreigner and a sojourner, but from your own Hebrew kinsman and neighbor, you must not demand back what you have lent.
Deuteronomy 15:4 This is to happen, unless it so happens that there is no needy person among you—for the Lord your God will bless you abundantly in the land He is about to give you as your inheritance.
Deuteronomy 15:5 Provided, however, that you truly listen to the voice of the Lord your God and diligently keep all His commandments which I am giving you today.
Deuteronomy 15:6 Then the Lord your God will bless you, just as He promised. And you will lend money to many nations, but you yourself will not need to borrow from anyone; you will rule over many nations, but no one will rule over you.
Deuteronomy 15:7 If, however, there is ever a poor person among your kinsmen within any of your towns in the land that the Lord your God is giving you, you must not harden your heart or close your hand to him.
Deuteronomy 15:8 Instead, you must generously open your hand to him and lend him whatever he needs, according to his necessity.
Deuteronomy 15:9 Be careful that you do not secretly harbor any wicked thought and say in your heart: 'The seventh year, the year of debt release, is drawing near.' And then you turn your eyes away from the poor, and refuse to lend him anything. Beware that he does not cry out against you to the Lord, and it become a sin for you.
Deuteronomy 15:10 Instead, you must give to him; and do so without a grudging spirit, so that you may relieve him in his needs. For because of this very thing, the Lord your God will bless you in all your work and in everything your hand undertakes.
Deuteronomy 15:11 For the poor will never cease to exist in your land. Therefore, I command you and say: You must open your hand generously to your brother, to the needy, and to the poor who live with you in the land.
Deuteronomy 15:12 If your Hebrew brother or sister sells himself or herself to you and serves you for six years, then in the seventh year, you must set them free.
Deuteronomy 15:13 And when you set them free, you must not send them away empty-handed.
Deuteronomy 15:14 Instead, you must provide generously for him from your flock, from your threshing floor, and from your winepress, with which the Lord your God has helped you.
Deuteronomy 15:15 Remember that you yourselves were also enslaved in the land of Egypt, and the Lord your God delivered you. Therefore, I am giving you this commandment today.
Deuteronomy 15:16 But if they do not wish to leave, and answer, 'I will not leave, because I love you and your household, and I am content with you,' then this is what you must do.
Deuteronomy 15:17 You shall then take an awl and pierce their ear through the door of your house, and they will be your servant forever. You shall do the same for your female servant also.
Deuteronomy 15:18 Do not consider it a hardship to set them free from you, for they have served you for six years, having earned double the wages of a hired worker. And the Lord your God will bless you in everything you do.
Deuteronomy 15:19 All the firstborn males that are born from your herds and your flocks—whatever is male, you must consecrate to the Lord your God. You shall not put the firstborn calves to work, nor shall you shear the firstborn lambs.
Deuteronomy 15:20 You and your household shall eat them each year in the presence of the Lord your God, in the specific place that the Lord chooses.
Deuteronomy 15:21 But if the animal has a defect—if it is lame, or blind, or has any other serious blemish—you must not sacrifice it to the Lord your God.
Deuteronomy 15:22 Instead, you may eat it within your own towns, both the ritually unclean and the clean among you, just as one would eat a gazelle or a deer.
Deuteronomy 15:23 You must only be careful not to eat their blood; instead, you must pour it out on the ground like water.
Deuteronomy 15:1 In the seventh year, you are to enact the year of release—this is the Sabbatical year for cancelling debts.
Deuteronomy 15:2 This is how the year of release is to be observed: Every creditor who has lent money to his neighbor must not demand its repayment from his fellow Israelite. This is because it is the Lord's designated year for releasing debts.
Deuteronomy 15:3 From a foreigner, you may still demand repayment. But from your fellow Israelite, you must not demand what is owed to you.
Deuteronomy 15:4 And there should be no poor among you—provided you fully obey the Lord your God, He will bless you in the land He is about to give you as your inheritance.
Deuteronomy 15:5 This will only happen if you truly listen to the voice of the Lord your God and diligently keep all His commandments that I am giving you today.
Deuteronomy 15:6 The Lord your God will truly bless you, just as He has promised. You will lend to many nations, but you yourselves will never need to borrow from anyone. You will rule over many nations, and no one will ever rule over you.
Deuteronomy 15:7 If one of your fellow Israelites living within the gates of your city—in the land the Lord your God is about to give you—becomes poor, you must not harden your heart or close your hand against the needy person.
Deuteronomy 15:8 Instead, you must open your hand generously to him and lend him whatever he needs to fully satisfy his needs.
Deuteronomy 15:9 Be careful that no evil thought creeps into your mind, leading you to say in your heart: 'The seventh year—the year of release—is approaching,' and then you turn your eyes away from your poor Israelite brother, unwilling to lend him anything. If you do this, he will cry out to the Lord against you, and it will be counted as a sin for you.
Deuteronomy 15:10 Instead, you must give to him, and do so cheerfully and without reluctance. Then the Lord your God will bless you in all your work and in everything you do with your hands.
Deuteronomy 15:11 For there will always be poor people in the land. That is why I am commanding you to open your hand generously to your needy Israelite brother and to the poor who dwell with you in the land.
Deuteronomy 15:12 If your fellow Hebrew man or woman sells himself or herself to you as a servant and serves you for six years, then in the seventh year, you must set them free.
Deuteronomy 15:13 When you set them free, you must not send them away empty-handed.
Deuteronomy 15:14 Instead, you must provide generously for them from your flock, from your threshing floor, and from your winepress—from all the ways the Lord your God has blessed you.
