Deuteronomy 15:15 Remember that you yourselves were once slaves in Egypt, and the Lord your God freed you. That is why I am giving you this commandment today.
Deuteronomy 15:16 But if the servant says to you, 'I do not want to leave,' because he loves you and your household, and he is well off with you,
Deuteronomy 15:17 Then you must take an awl and pierce his ear through the door—this is a sign of his permanent commitment. He will then serve you for the remainder of his life. You must do the same for your female servant.
Deuteronomy 15:18 It should not seem burdensome to you when you set them free, because for six years they served you for twice the wage of a hired worker. If you follow these commands, the Lord your God will bless you in everything you do.
Deuteronomy 15:19 You must consecrate all the firstborn males born to your cattle and your flock to the Lord your God. You must not use the firstborn of your bulls for work, nor shear the firstborn of your sheep.
Deuteronomy 15:20 Each year, you and your household must eat them before the Lord your God in the special place that the Lord chooses for His worship.
Deuteronomy 15:21 However, if there is any blemish in the animal—if it is lame, or blind, or has any serious defect—you must not sacrifice it to the Lord your God.
Deuteronomy 15:22 Instead, you may eat it within your own city gates, just as you would any other meat, whether it comes from a ritually clean or unclean animal.
Deuteronomy 15:23 Only be sure not to eat its blood, but pour it out on the ground like water, as a sign of respect for life.
Deuteronomy 16:1 Observe the month of fresh crops —the first month of the religious year, Abib— and celebrate the Passover solemnity to the Lord your God. For in this very month, the Lord your God brought you out of Egypt by night.
Deuteronomy 16:2 And you shall offer the Passover sacrifice to the Lord your God from your flocks and herds, in the sacred place which the Lord your God will choose for His name to dwell.
Deuteronomy 16:3 You shall not eat anything leavened with it. For seven days, you shall eat unleavened bread —the bread of your affliction— because you came out of Egypt in haste. This is so you will remember the day you left the land of Egypt for all the days of your life.
Deuteronomy 16:4 No leaven shall be found in all your territory for seven days. And none of the meat that was sacrificed in the evening on the first day shall remain until morning.
Deuteronomy 16:5 You will not be permitted to sacrifice the Passover in just any of your cities that the Lord your God is giving to you.
Deuteronomy 16:6 Instead, in the special place that the Lord your God will choose for His name to dwell, there you shall sacrifice the Passover in the evening at sunset, at the exact time you came out of Egypt.
Deuteronomy 16:7 And you shall cook and eat it in the place which the Lord your God will choose. Then, in the morning, you shall return and go to your tents.
Deuteronomy 16:8 For six days, you shall eat unleavened bread. And on the seventh day, there shall be a solemn assembly for the Lord your God; you shall do no work.
Deuteronomy 16:9 You shall count seven weeks for yourself. From the day you first put the sickle to the standing grain, you shall count seven full weeks.
Deuteronomy 16:10 Then you shall celebrate the Feast of Weeks to the Lord your God, bringing a freewill offering from your hand, which you shall give according to the blessing that the Lord your God has bestowed upon you.
Deuteronomy 16:11 And you shall rejoice before the Lord your God: you, your son, your daughter, your male and female servants, the Levite who lives within your gates, and the foreigner, the orphan, and the widow who reside among you, in the place which the Lord your God will choose for His name to dwell.
Deuteronomy 16:12 And remember that you were once a slave in Egypt. You shall therefore keep and do all the things that I have commanded you.
Deuteronomy 16:13 You shall celebrate the Feast of Tabernacles —the Festival of Booths— for seven days, when you have gathered in your produce from your threshing floor and your winepress.
Deuteronomy 16:14 And you shall rejoice in your feast: you, your son, your daughter, your male and female servants, the Levite, the foreigner, the orphan, and the widow who live within your gates.
Deuteronomy 16:15 For seven days you shall celebrate the feast for the Lord your God in the place which the Lord will choose. And the Lord your God will bless you in all your produce and in all the work of your hands, and you shall be completely joyful.
Deuteronomy 16:16 Three times in a year, every male among you shall appear before the Lord your God in the place He will choose: at the Feast of Unleavened Bread, at the Feast of Weeks, and at the Feast of Tabernacles. No one shall appear empty-handed in the presence of the Lord.
Deuteronomy 16:17 But each one shall offer what he has, according to the blessing of the Lord his God which He has given him.
Deuteronomy 16:18 You shall appoint judges and magistrates in all your gates —that is, in every town— which the Lord your God is giving you, throughout your tribes, so that they may judge the people with righteous judgment.
Deuteronomy 16:19 You shall not show partiality, nor accept bribes. For bribes blind the eyes of the wise and corrupt the words of the righteous.
Deuteronomy 16:20 You shall pursue justice, and only justice, so that you may live and possess the land which the Lord your God is giving you.
Deuteronomy 16:21 You shall not plant any sacred tree or grove —used for idol worship— near the altar of the Lord your God, which you shall make for yourself.
Deuteronomy 16:22 Nor shall you erect any sacred pillar or idol, for the Lord your God detests these things.
Deuteronomy 16:1 Observe the month of Abib—the month of new things and the beginning of spring—and you shall celebrate the Passover in honor of the Lord your God, because in this very month of Abib, the Lord your God led you out of Egypt during the night.
Deuteronomy 16:2 Therefore, you shall offer the Passover sacrifice of sheep and oxen to the Lord your God in the specific place the Lord your God will choose for His name to reside there.
Deuteronomy 16:3 You shall not eat any leavened bread with it. For seven days you shall eat unleavened bread, as has been commanded to you. This is the bread of affliction, because you left Egypt in great haste. You shall do this so that you may remember the day of your departure from the land of Egypt all the days of your life.
Deuteronomy 16:4 No leaven shall be seen anywhere in all your territory for these seven days. Also, none of the flesh from what was sacrificed on the first evening shall remain until the next morning.
Deuteronomy 16:5 You will not be permitted to sacrifice the Passover lamb in just any of your cities that the Lord your God is giving you.
Deuteronomy 16:6 Instead, you must offer the Passover sacrifice in the specific place that the Lord your God will choose for His name to dwell. There you shall sacrifice the Passover offering in the evening, at sunset, the very time you departed from Egypt.
Deuteronomy 16:7 You shall cook and eat it in the place the Lord your God will choose. Then, in the morning, you may return and go to your own tents or homes.
Deuteronomy 16:8 For six days you shall eat unleavened bread. But on the seventh day, because it is a solemn assembly for the Lord your God, you shall not do any work.
Deuteronomy 16:9 You shall count seven full weeks for yourself, beginning from the day you first put the sickle to the standing grain—from that day you shall count seven weeks.
Deuteronomy 16:10 Then you shall celebrate the Feast of Weeks to the Lord your God, offering a spontaneous gift from your hand, which you shall give to the Lord your God in proportion to the blessing He has given you.
Deuteronomy 16:11 And you shall feast before the Lord your God—you, your son, your daughter, your male and female servants, the Levite who lives within your gates, and the foreign resident, the orphan, and the widow who live with you—all in the place that the Lord your God will choose for His name to dwell there.
Deuteronomy 16:12 And remember that you were once slaves in Egypt. Therefore, you shall carefully observe and do these specific commands.
Deuteronomy 16:13 You shall celebrate the Feast of Tabernacles for seven days, after you have gathered in the harvest from your threshing floor and your winepress.
Deuteronomy 16:14 You shall rejoice in your feast—you, your son, your daughter, your male and female servants, the Levite, the foreign resident, the orphan, and the widow who live within your gates.
Deuteronomy 16:15 For seven days you shall keep the feast for the Lord your God in the place the Lord will choose, because the Lord your God will bless you in all your harvest and in all the work of your hands, so you will be entirely full of joy.
Deuteronomy 16:16 Three times a year, all your males shall appear before the Lord your God in the place He will choose: at the Feast of Unleavened Bread, at the Feast of Weeks, and at the Feast of Tabernacles. No one shall appear empty-handed before the Lord.
Deuteronomy 16:17 Instead, each person shall offer what they are able to give, in proportion to the blessing that the Lord their God has bestowed upon them.
Deuteronomy 16:18 You shall appoint judges and officials in all your towns that the Lord your God is giving you, throughout all your tribes. These officials are to judge the people with righteous judgments.
Deuteronomy 16:19 They shall not be swayed to one side or another. You shall not show partiality to anyone, nor accept bribes, because bribes blind the eyes of the wise and corrupt the words of the righteous.
Deuteronomy 16:20 You shall wholeheartedly pursue only what is just and right, so that you may live and possess the land that the Lord your God is giving you.
Deuteronomy 16:21 You shall not plant any sacred pole or any tree of worship beside the altar of the Lord your God that you will build for yourself.
Deuteronomy 16:22 Nor shall you set up for yourself any sacred stone pillar, for these practices are detestable to the Lord your God.
Deuteronomy 17:1 You must not offer to the Lord your God any ox or sheep that has a blemish or any other defect. For such an offering is detestable to the Lord your God.
Deuteronomy 17:2 If there is found among you, in one of your cities that the Lord your God is giving you to dwell in, a man or a woman who does what is evil in the sight of the Lord your God and breaks His covenant with you—
Deuteronomy 17:3 by going and serving other gods and worshipping them—whether it be the sun, or the moon, or any of the celestial bodies in the sky—which I have not commanded you to do or to worship.
Deuteronomy 17:4 And if this is reported to you, and you hear of it, then you must inquire diligently into the matter. If it is found to be true, and such a detestable thing has indeed occurred within the land of Israel,
Deuteronomy 17:5 you shall bring out that man or that woman who has committed such an evil and wicked act to the gates of your city, and they shall be stoned to death with rocks.
Deuteronomy 17:6 At the testimony of two or three witnesses, the person who is to be put to death shall die; no one shall be executed on the testimony of a single witness against him.
Deuteronomy 17:7 The hands of the witnesses shall be the first to cast stones against him, in order to execute him, and afterward the hands of all the people. In this way, you shall purge this evil from among you and your community.
Deuteronomy 17:8 If you find that judgment is too difficult and ambiguous for you in a legal case—whether it be a dispute between blood and blood (concerning murder), or cause and cause (a legal claim), or leprosy and leprosy (a ritual purity question)—and you see that the words of judgment vary within your gates;
Deuteronomy 17:9 then you shall arise and go up to the specific place that the Lord your God will choose to establish His presence and authority.
Deuteronomy 17:10 You shall then come to the priests of the Levitical lineage and to the judge who is serving at that time. You shall inquire of them, and they will declare to you the truth of the judgment and the proper decision.
Deuteronomy 17:11 And you shall do whatever they tell you, those who preside over the place which the Lord has chosen, and whatever they teach you according to His law. You shall follow their judgment and not turn aside from their decision, neither to the right hand nor to the left.
Deuteronomy 17:12 But the person who acts with arrogance, refusing to obey the command of the priest who ministers there at that time before the Lord your God, or the judgment of the judge—that person shall die. You shall thus purge this evil from Israel.
Deuteronomy 17:13 And all the people who hear of it will be struck with fear, and they will never again act with such arrogance or disregard for authority.
Deuteronomy 17:14 When you enter the land that the Lord your God is giving you, and you possess it and live in it, and then you say in your hearts: 'I will set a king over me, just as all the nations around me have kings'—
Deuteronomy 17:15 you may indeed appoint as king over you the one whom the Lord your God will choose from among your own brothers. You may not place a foreigner, who is not one of your own brothers, as king over you.
Deuteronomy 17:16 But once he is appointed, he must not acquire many horses for himself, nor cause the people to return to Egypt to obtain more horses for his military strength—especially since the Lord has commanded you that you must never again return by that way to Egypt.
Deuteronomy 17:17 He must not acquire many wives for himself, lest they turn his heart away from God and His commandments. Nor must he accumulate for himself excessive amounts of silver and gold.
Deuteronomy 17:18 But after he takes his place on the throne of his kingdom, he shall write for himself a copy of this law—this Book of Deuteronomy—in a scroll, taking the exemplar directly from the priests of the Levitical tribe.
Deuteronomy 17:19 He shall keep this copy with him, and he shall read it all the days of his life, so that he may learn to fear the Lord his God and to carefully observe all the words and statutes of this law that are commanded in it.
Deuteronomy 17:20 In this way, his heart will not be lifted up in pride above his brothers, and he will not turn aside from these commandments, either to the right or to the left. This is so that he and his sons may reign for a long time over Israel.
Deuteronomy 17:1 You shall not sacrifice to the Lord your God any ox or sheep that has a blemish or any defect, because such an offering would be an abomination to the Lord your God.
Deuteronomy 17:2 If a man or woman is found among you, in any of your cities that the Lord your God is giving you, who does evil in the sight of the Lord your God, and has transgressed His covenant,
Deuteronomy 17:3 so that they go and serve other gods and worship them—whether the sun, or the moon, or any of the host of the sky—
Deuteronomy 17:4 and if this has been reported to you, and when you hear of it, you inquire diligently, and you find it to be true, and such an abomination has been committed in Israel,
Deuteronomy 17:5 then you shall bring out that man or woman who committed this wicked deed to the gates of your city, and they shall be stoned to death.
Deuteronomy 17:6 At the mouth of two or three witnesses, the one who is to be put to death shall die; no one shall be executed on the testimony of a single witness against them.
Deuteronomy 17:7 The hands of the witnesses shall be the first upon them to put them to death, and afterward the hands of all the people, so that you may remove the evil from your midst.
Deuteronomy 17:8 If you perceive that a judgment is too difficult and ambiguous for you—concerning matters of bloodshed, or legal cases, or leprosy cases—and you see that the words of the judges within your gates are varying,
Deuteronomy 17:9 then rise and go up to the place that the Lord your God will choose;
Deuteronomy 17:10 and you shall come to the Levitical priests and to the judge who will be in office at that time. You shall inquire of them, and they will declare to you the truth of the judgment.
Deuteronomy 17:11 And you shall do whatever they tell you, those who preside in the place that the Lord will choose, and whatever they teach you according to His law;
Deuteronomy 17:12 and you shall follow their ruling, and you shall not deviate from it to the right or to the left.
Deuteronomy 17:13 But if anyone acts presumptuously, unwilling to obey the command of the priest who ministers to the Lord your God at that time, or the ruling of the judge, that man shall die. So you shall remove the evil from Israel.
Deuteronomy 17:14 And all the people shall hear and fear, and never again shall they swell with pride.
Deuteronomy 17:15 When you have entered the land that the Lord your God is giving you, and have taken possession of it, and dwell in it, and you say, "I will set a king over me, just as all the nations around me have,"
Deuteronomy 17:16 you shall surely appoint as king over you the one whom the Lord your God will choose from among your brothers. You may not set a man of another nation over you as king, who is not your brother.
Deuteronomy 17:17 He shall not acquire many horses for himself, nor shall he lead the people back to Egypt to increase his cavalry, especially since the Lord has commanded you never to return by that way again.
Deuteronomy 17:18 He shall not have many wives, who might entice his heart away, nor shall he accumulate immense quantities of silver and gold.
Deuteronomy 17:19 And when he sits on the throne of his kingdom, he shall take a copy of this law, written for himself, from the Levitical priests;
Deuteronomy 17:20 he shall keep it with him and read it all the days of his life, so that he may learn to fear the Lord his God and diligently keep all the words and ceremonies of this law which are commanded.
Deuteronomy 18:1 The priests, the Levites, and all those from the tribe of Levi, will not have a portion or an inheritance among the other tribes of Israel; instead, they shall live on the offerings and sacrifices made to the Lord.
Deuteronomy 18:2 They shall not receive any other property from their brothers, the other tribes of Israel, because the Lord Himself is their inheritance and their possession, just as He promised them.
Deuteronomy 18:3 This is the customary right of the priests from the people who offer sacrifices: whether they sacrifice an ox or a sheep, they shall give the priest the shoulder, both cheeks, and the stomach.
Deuteronomy 18:4 They shall give the priest the first-fruits of their grain, their wine, and their olive oil, and the first sheared wool from their sheep.
Deuteronomy 18:5 For the Lord your God has chosen the tribe of Levi from all your tribes, so that they may stand to serve and minister in the name of the Lord, both they and their descendants forever.
Deuteronomy 18:6 If a Levite leaves one of your cities, wherever he may be living in any part of Israel, and he desires to come to the place which the Lord will choose for His worship,
Deuteronomy 18:7 he shall minister in the name of the Lord his God, just like all his fellow Levite brothers who are standing there at that time before the Lord.
Deuteronomy 18:8 He shall receive the same portion of food and offerings as them, apart from what he already possesses from the sale of his ancestral property or his dwelling in his hometown.
Deuteronomy 18:9 When you enter the land that the Lord your God is giving you, be careful not to imitate the detestable practices of those nations already living there.
Deuteronomy 18:10 Let no one be found among you who offers their son or daughter as a sacrifice by fire, nor anyone who consults oracles, or practices divination, or interprets omens, or observes dreams, or is a sorcerer,
Deuteronomy 18:11 nor one who casts spells, nor one who consults spirits of the dead (necromancers), nor a diviner, nor one who seeks answers from the deceased.
Deuteronomy 18:12 For all who do these things are detestable to the Lord, and because of these detestable practices, He will drive those nations out before you as you enter the land.
Deuteronomy 18:13 You shall be blameless and wholehearted in your relationship with the Lord your God.
Deuteronomy 18:14 These nations whose land you are about to possess listen to diviners and those who interpret omens. But the Lord your God has not permitted you to do such things, having given you a different teaching.
Deuteronomy 18:15 The Lord your God will raise up for you a Prophet from among your own people, from your brothers, just like me—Moses. You must listen to Him.
Deuteronomy 18:16 This is exactly what you asked of the Lord your God at Horeb when the assembly was gathered, and you said, 'Let me not hear the voice of the Lord my God again, nor see this great fire anymore, lest I die!'
Deuteronomy 18:17 And the Lord said to me, 'What they have said is good and correct.'
Deuteronomy 18:18 'I will raise up for them a Prophet from among their brothers, one like you, Moses. I will put My words in His mouth, and He will speak to them everything that I command Him.'
Deuteronomy 18:19 'But whoever will not listen to His words, which He speaks in My name, I Myself will hold that person accountable.'
Deuteronomy 18:20 However, any prophet who, out of pride, presumes to speak a word in My name that I have not commanded him to speak, or who speaks in the name of other gods, that prophet shall be put to death.
Deuteronomy 18:21 If you should ask yourself, 'How will we know if a message is truly from the Lord or not?'
Deuteronomy 18:22 You will have this sign: If what the prophet proclaims in the name of the Lord does not come true or if his message is confused and contradictory, then the Lord has not spoken it. Instead, the prophet has spoken it out of pride and presumption. Therefore, you need not fear him nor heed his words.
Deuteronomy 18:1 The Levitical priests, and indeed all men who are from that same tribe of Levi, will not be allowed to have an allotted portion of land or an inheritance among the rest of the people of Israel. Instead, they will live by eating from the sacrifices offered to the Lord and from His offerings.
Deuteronomy 18:2 They shall not receive anything else from the possessions of their Israelite brothers, because the Lord Himself is their inheritance, just as He promised them.
Deuteronomy 18:3 This is what the priests have a right to receive from the people, and from those who offer sacrifices: whether they sacrifice a bull or a sheep, they will give the priest the shoulder, both of the jaws, and the stomach.
Deuteronomy 18:4 They shall also receive the first fruits of the grain, the wine, and the oil, along with the first shearings of the sheep's wool for their own use.
Deuteronomy 18:5 For the Lord your God has specifically chosen him, from all your tribes, to stand and to serve in the Name of the Lord, both he and his sons forever.
Deuteronomy 18:6 If a Levite comes out of one of your cities, from any part of Israel where he has been living, and he comes to the place which the Lord has chosen to establish His presence,
Deuteronomy 18:7 then he shall serve in the Name of the Lord his God, just like all his fellow Levite brothers who stand there at that time before the Lord.
Deuteronomy 18:8 He will receive the same portion of food as they do, apart from what he has inherited from his family's city.
Deuteronomy 18:9 When you enter the land that the Lord your God is giving you, be careful not to imitate the detestable practices of those pagan nations.
Deuteronomy 18:10 Let no one be found among you who makes his son or his daughter pass through the fire, or one who consults diviners, or one who observes omens and auguries, nor any sorcerer,
Deuteronomy 18:11 nor one who casts spells, nor one who consults spirits, nor a fortuneteller, nor one who seeks truth from the dead.
Deuteronomy 18:12 For the Lord detests all these practices, and it is because of such crimes that He will destroy these nations before you when you enter the land.
Deuteronomy 18:13 You shall be perfect and without blemish before the Lord your God.
Deuteronomy 18:14 These nations, whose land you are about to possess, listen to soothsayers and diviners; but you, however, have a different teaching from the Lord your God.
Deuteronomy 18:15 The Lord your God will raise up for you a Prophet from among your own people, from your brothers, just like me—Moses is speaking here. You shall listen to Him.
Deuteronomy 18:16 This is exactly what you requested from the Lord your God at Horeb, when the assembly was gathered, and you said: "Let me no longer hear the voice of the Lord my God, and let me not see this immense fire any longer, lest I die."
Deuteronomy 18:17 And the Lord said to me, "They have spoken well in all they said."
Deuteronomy 18:18 "I will raise up a Prophet for them from among their brothers, just like you, and I will put My words in His mouth, and He will speak to them everything that I command Him."
Deuteronomy 18:19 "But whoever will not listen to the words that He speaks in My Name, I Myself will take vengeance upon him."
Deuteronomy 18:20 "However, a prophet who, revealing pride, presumes to speak words in My Name that I have not commanded him to speak, or who speaks in the name of foreign gods, that prophet shall be put to death."
Deuteronomy 18:21 If you think in your heart: "How can I know which word the Lord has not spoken?"
Deuteronomy 18:22 This is the sign you will have: If a prophet, speaking in the Name of the Lord, predicts something and that thing does not happen, that is a word which the Lord has not spoken. Rather, the prophet uttered it out of his own proud spirit. Therefore, you shall not be afraid of him.
Deuteronomy 19:1 When the Lord your God completely destroys the nations from the land He is giving to you, and when you have taken possession of their land and settled in their cities and homes,
Deuteronomy 19:2 then you are to designate three cities in the middle of your land—the land the Lord your God is giving you as your inheritance.
Deuteronomy 19:3 You must make the roads to these cities clear and maintain them, and you shall divide the entire territory of your land, which the Lord your God gives you as an inheritance, into three districts. These three cities of refuge will be distributed among these districts.
Deuteronomy 19:4 This is the law for a slayer who will flee to one of these cities and live: anyone who strikes his neighbor accidentally, without any prior malice or hatred towards him,
Deuteronomy 19:5 For example, if someone goes into the forest with his neighbor to cut wood, and as he swings the ax to fell a tree, the ax head accidentally flies off the handle, slips from his hand, and strikes his neighbor, killing him—such a person may flee to one of these cities of refuge and live.
Deuteronomy 19:6 Otherwise, the avenger of the slain, burning with rage, might pursue him and overtake him on the road, striking him dead. This would be a grave injustice, as the person is not deserving of death because he had no prior malice or hatred towards the one he accidentally killed.
Deuteronomy 19:7 Therefore, I command you to designate these three cities for yourselves.
Deuteronomy 19:8 And when the Lord your God enlarges your territory, as He swore to your ancestors, and gives you all the land He promised them,
Deuteronomy 19:9 (This will happen only if you are careful to obey all these commandments and do what I am instructing you today, which is to love the Lord your God and walk in His ways at all times.)
Deuteronomy 19:10 then you must add three more cities of refuge to these, making the total number six, to double the initial three cities.
Deuteronomy 19:11 This is so that innocent blood will not be shed in the middle of your land, which the Lord your God is giving you as an inheritance, and thus make you guilty of bloodshed.
Deuteronomy 19:12 But if someone, driven by hatred for his neighbor, lies in wait, ambushes him, and strikes him dead, and then flees to one of these cities of refuge,
Deuteronomy 19:13 then the elders of his own city must send for him, seize him from the city of refuge, and hand him over to the avenger of blood, who will ensure he is put to death.
Deuteronomy 19:14 You must not move your neighbor's boundary markers, which were set by your ancestors in the land you will possess—the land the Lord your God is giving you as your inheritance.
Deuteronomy 19:15 A single witness is not sufficient to condemn anyone for any crime or wrongdoing. Every charge must be confirmed by the testimony of two or three witnesses.
Deuteronomy 19:16 If a malicious witness comes forward and testifies falsely against another person, accusing him of a transgression or a crime,
Deuteronomy 19:17 then both individuals involved in the dispute must stand before the Lord, in the presence of the priests and judges who are serving at that time.
Deuteronomy 19:18 The judges must investigate the matter thoroughly. If they find that the witness is indeed false and has lied against his fellow Israelite,
Deuteronomy 19:19 then you shall do to him exactly what he intended to do to his brother. In this way, you will purge that evil from your midst.
Deuteronomy 19:20 The others will hear of this judgment and be struck with fear, ensuring that such evil acts are not committed again in your midst.
Deuteronomy 19:21 Show no pity. The rule shall be: a life for a life, an eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth, a hand for a hand, and a foot for a foot.
Deuteronomy 20:1 When you go out to fight your enemies, and you see their large armies with many horses and chariots, don't be afraid of them. The Lord your God is with you, the very God who brought you out of the land of Egypt.
Deuteronomy 20:2 When you are about to go into battle, a priest will stand nearby and speak to the people.
Deuteronomy 20:3 He will say to them: 'Listen, O Israel! Today you are going into battle against your enemies. Do not be faint of heart. Do not be afraid, do not panic, and do not be terrified by them.'
Deuteronomy 20:4 Because the Lord your God is right there with you, and He Himself will fight on your behalf against your adversaries.
Deuteronomy 20:5 After the priest has finished speaking, the officers will then say to the people: 'Is there any man here who has built a new house and has not yet dedicated it? Let him return home now, so that he does not die in battle, and another man dedicates his house instead.'
Deuteronomy 20:6 'Is there any man here who has planted a vineyard and has not yet enjoyed its first harvest? Let him return home now, so that he does not die in battle and another man gets to enjoy his first harvest.'
Deuteronomy 20:7 'Is there any man here who has become engaged to a woman but has not yet married her? Let him return home now, so that he does not die in battle and another man marries her.'
Deuteronomy 20:8 The officers will then add this instruction and speak to the people: 'Is there any man here who is afraid and faint-hearted? Let him return home now, so that his brothers' hearts do not also become afraid and tremble like his own.'
Deuteronomy 20:9 Once everyone has heard these instructions and is ready for battle, then you must appoint officers: commanders over thousands, commanders over hundreds, and other leaders for the army.
Deuteronomy 20:10 When you approach a city to attack it, you must first offer it terms of peace.
Deuteronomy 20:11 If the city agrees to accept your terms and opens its gates to you, then all the people who live in it will be spared, and they will serve you as forced laborers, paying tribute.
Deuteronomy 20:12 But if the city refuses to make peace with you and instead chooses to wage war, then you must lay siege to it.
Deuteronomy 20:13 And when the Lord your God delivers that city into your hand, you must strike down every male in it with the edge of the sword.
Deuteronomy 20:14 However, you may take for yourselves the women, the young children, the livestock, and all other belongings found in the city as plunder. You are permitted to use these spoils of your enemies, which the Lord your God has given to you.
Deuteronomy 20:15 This is how you must deal with all the cities that are located very far from you. These are the cities that are not among those you are destined to conquer and claim as your permanent land.
Deuteronomy 20:16 However, in the cities within the land that the Lord your God is giving to you as an inheritance, you must not allow anything that breathes to remain alive.
Deuteronomy 20:17 Instead, you must utterly destroy these peoples—the Hittites, the Amorites, the Canaanites, the Perizzites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites—just as the Lord your God has commanded you.
Deuteronomy 20:18 Otherwise, they will teach you to imitate all the abominable practices that they perform for their idols, and you will then sin against the Lord your God.
Deuteronomy 20:19 When you lay siege to a city for a long time, surrounding it with fortifications in order to capture it, do not cut down its fruit-bearing trees. You must not use an axe to destroy them, for a tree provides wood and food, and it is not a human being who can fight against you in battle.
Deuteronomy 20:20 However, if there is a tree that is not a fruit-bearing tree, but a wild tree that is suitable for building, you may cut it down. Use these trees to construct siege engines and other works until the city is captured.
Deuteronomy 20:1 When you go out to battle against your enemies, and you see that they have many horses and chariots, and a greater army than you do, do not be afraid of them. For the Lord your God is with you—the same God who led you out from the land of Egypt.
Deuteronomy 20:2 When the battle is about to begin, the priest shall step forward before the battle lines and speak to the people, saying:
Deuteronomy 20:3 Listen, O Israel! Today you are going out to fight against your enemies. Let your hearts not be afraid, do not fear, do not yield, and do not be terrified by them.
Deuteronomy 20:4 Because the Lord your God is in your midst, and He Himself will fight for you against your adversaries.
Deuteronomy 20:5 Then the officers in the army shall proclaim in a loud voice, so that the people can hear: "Has anyone built a new house but not yet dedicated it? Let him go and return to his home, lest he die in battle and another man dedicate it."
Deuteronomy 20:6  "Has anyone planted a vineyard but not yet harvested its fruit? Let him go and return to his home, lest he die in battle and another man harvest it."
Deuteronomy 20:7  "Has anyone become engaged to a woman but not yet married her? Let him go and return to his home, lest he die in battle and another man marry her."
Deuteronomy 20:8 And the officers shall add, speaking further to the people: "Who is a man who is fearful and fainthearted? Let him go and return to his home, lest he fill the hearts of his brothers with terror and make them afraid too."
Deuteronomy 20:9 When all these announcements have been made and the people have been commanded to prepare for battle, then the leaders of the companies shall lead the army.
Deuteronomy 20:10 When you approach a city to attack it, you shall first offer it terms of peace.
Deuteronomy 20:11 If the city accepts your offer and opens its gates to you, then all the people who are in it shall become your servants and pay tribute to you.
Deuteronomy 20:12 But if it refuses to make peace and a treaty with you, and begins to wage war against you, then you shall besiege it.
Deuteronomy 20:13 And when the Lord your God delivers it into your hand, you shall strike down every male within it with the edge of the sword.
Deuteronomy 20:14 But the women, children, livestock, and everything else in the city—all its plunder—you shall take for yourselves. You may eat the spoils of your enemies, which the Lord your God has given to you.
Deuteronomy 20:15 This is what you shall do to all the cities that are very far from you, and which are not among the cities you are about to receive as your own possession.
Deuteronomy 20:16 However, concerning these cities that are given to you as a possession—the ones within the promised land—you shall not let anyone remain alive who breathes.
Deuteronomy 20:17 Instead, you must utterly destroy them with the edge of the sword: the Hittites, Amorites, Canaanites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites, just as the Lord your God has commanded you.
Deuteronomy 20:18 Do this so that they may not teach you to imitate their idolatrous practices, and thereby cause you to sin against the Lord your God.
Deuteronomy 20:19 When you besiege a city for a long time, surrounding it with fortifications in order to capture it, you shall not cut down its fruit trees, nor lay waste to the region with an axe. For the tree is wood, not a man, and therefore it cannot fight against you.
Deuteronomy 20:20 But if there is a tree that is not a fruit-bearing tree, but a wild tree suitable for work—meaning it produces timber—you may cut it down and use it to build siege works until you capture the city that is fighting against you.
Deuteronomy 21:1 If a man is found murdered in the land that the Lord your God will give you to possess, lying dead in the open fields, and the identity of the one who struck him dead is unknown:
Deuteronomy 21:2 Then your elders and judges must go out and measure the distance from where the corpse lies to the nearest surrounding towns.
Deuteronomy 21:3 And the elders of the city that is found to be the closest to the body must take a young heifer from the herd, one that has never been put under a yoke or used for any work.
Deuteronomy 21:4 They shall bring the heifer to a rugged valley that has never been plowed or sown with seed, and there they shall break its neck.
Deuteronomy 21:5 Then the priests of the Levitical lineage (for the Lord your God has chosen them to minister to Him, and to bless in His name, and by their word every dispute and every matter of clean or unclean is to be judged) shall come forward.
Deuteronomy 21:6 And the elders of that city which was found closest to the murdered man shall wash their hands over the heifer whose neck was broken in the valley.
Deuteronomy 21:7 And they shall declare: "Our hands did not shed this blood, nor did our eyes witness it.
Deuteronomy 21:8 Be merciful, O Lord, to Your people Israel, whom You have redeemed; and do not allow innocent blood to remain among Your people Israel." And so the guilt of the blood shall be atoned for.
Deuteronomy 21:9 Thus you shall remove the guilt of innocent blood from among you, when you have done what the Lord commands.
Deuteronomy 21:10 If you go out to fight against your enemies, and the Lord your God delivers them into your power, and you take them as captives of war:
Deuteronomy 21:11 And if you see a beautiful woman among the captives, and you desire her, and wish to take her as your wife:
Deuteronomy 21:12 You must bring her into your house. She shall then shave all the hair from her head, and she must trim her nails (these actions are part of a purification ritual for a non-Israelite woman).
Deuteronomy 21:13 And she shall remove the clothing in which she was captured. She must then sit in your house and mourn her father and mother for one full month. After this period, you may go in to her, and sleep with her; and you shall be her husband, and she shall be your wife.
Deuteronomy 21:14 But if afterwards you no longer desire to have her as your wife, you must let her go free. You shall not sell her for money, nor shall you treat her as a slave, because you have humbled her (by taking her as a wife and then rejecting her).
Deuteronomy 21:15 If a man has two wives, one dearly loved and the other hated, and both have borne him children, and the firstborn son happens to be the son of the hated wife:
Deuteronomy 21:16 Then, when he divides his inheritance among his sons, he may not treat the son of the loved wife as the firstborn, preferring him over the son of the hated wife, who is indeed the true firstborn.
Deuteronomy 21:17 Instead, he must acknowledge the son of the hated wife as the firstborn, and give him a double portion of all that he possesses. For that son is the first fruit of his strength, and the right of the firstborn belongs to him.
Deuteronomy 21:18 If a man has a stubborn and rebellious son who does not listen to the words of his father or his mother, and though corrected, stubbornly refuses to obey:
Deuteronomy 21:19 His father and mother shall both take hold of him and bring him before the elders of the city, at the city gate where judgments are made.
Deuteronomy 21:20 And they shall say to the elders: "This son of ours is stubborn and rebellious; he refuses to listen to our commands, and he is given over to gluttony and drunkenness."
Deuteronomy 21:21 Then all the people of that city shall stone him with stones, and he shall die. You must remove this evil from among you, so that all of Israel may hear and be filled with fear (and learn from his example).
Deuteronomy 21:22 When a man has committed a sin worthy of death, and he has been put to death and then hung on a tree (as a public display):
Deuteronomy 21:23 His corpse shall not remain on the tree overnight. You must bury him on the same day, because anyone hung on a tree is cursed by God. Do not defile the land that the Lord your God is giving you as an inheritance.
Deuteronomy 21:1 If a man is found slain in the land—the territory the Lord your God is giving you to possess—lying in a field, and it is not known who killed him,
Deuteronomy 21:2 then your elders and your judges must go out and measure the distance from the place where the body lies to the nearest towns.
Deuteronomy 21:3 Whichever town they determine is the closest, the elders of that town must take a heifer from the herd—one that has never been used for work, neither pulling a yoke nor an plow.
Deuteronomy 21:4 They must lead the heifer to a rugged valley that has never been tilled or sown with seeds, and there, in the dry riverbed, they must break the heifer’s neck.
Deuteronomy 21:5 Then the priests, who are from the tribe of Levi, must approach—because the Lord your God chose them to minister to Him and to bless in the name of the Lord, and by their word, every matter, both clean and unclean, is to be judged.
Deuteronomy 21:6 And all the elders of that town, which is nearest to the slain man, must wash their hands over the heifer whose neck was broken in the valley.
Deuteronomy 21:7 Then they must declare: 'Our hands did not shed this blood, nor did our eyes witness this crime.'
Deuteronomy 21:8 They must pray: 'Be merciful, O Lord, to Your people Israel, whom You have redeemed. Do not hold the guilt of this innocent blood against Your people Israel.' And the guilt of that blood will be forgiven them—it will be expiated for them.
Deuteronomy 21:9 Thus, you will remove the guilt of innocent blood from among you, when you do what the Lord has commanded.
Deuteronomy 21:10 When you go out to battle against your enemies, and the Lord your God delivers them into your hand, and you take captives—
Deuteronomy 21:11 and you see among the captives a beautiful woman, and you desire her and want to take her as your wife—
Deuteronomy 21:12 you must bring her into your house. She must shave her head and trim her nails.
Deuteronomy 21:13 She must remove the clothes in which she was captured and remain in your house, mourning her father and mother for one full month. After that period, you may go in to her, lie with her, and she will be your wife, and you her husband.
Deuteronomy 21:14 But if you no longer desire her, you must let her go free. You are not to sell her for money, nor oppress her by force, because you have humbled her—taken away her former dignity.
Deuteronomy 21:15 If a man has two wives, one who is loved and another who is disliked, and both bear him sons, but the firstborn son is from the disliked wife, and the second son is from the loved wife—
Deuteronomy 21:16 when he divides his inheritance among his sons, he cannot make the son of the loved wife the firstborn, preferring him over the son of the disliked wife, who is the true and legitimate firstborn.
Deuteronomy 21:17 Instead, he must acknowledge the firstborn son of the disliked wife by giving him a double portion of all he possesses. For that son is the first of his strength, and the rights of the firstborn belong to him.
Deuteronomy 21:18 If a man has a stubborn and rebellious son who does not listen to the words of his father or his mother, and even when corrected, he scorns to obey—
Deuteronomy 21:19 his father and mother must both take hold of him and bring him to the elders of his town, at the gate where judicial matters are heard.
Deuteronomy 21:20 They must say to the elders: 'This son of ours is stubborn and rebellious; he refuses to listen to our warnings. He is given to gluttony, drunkenness, and wild feasts.'
Deuteronomy 21:21 Then all the people of his town must stone him to death. You must remove this evil from among you, and all Israel, hearing of it, will be struck with fear.
Deuteronomy 21:22 If a man has committed a sin worthy of death and is executed, and afterward his body is hanged on a tree—
Deuteronomy 21:23 his corpse must not remain on the tree overnight. You must bury him the same day. For a hanged man is cursed by God, and you must not defile your land, which the Lord your God is giving you as an inheritance.
Deuteronomy 22:1 If you see your fellow Israelite’s ox or sheep wandering astray, you must not ignore it or walk away as if it does not concern you. Instead, you must make sure to bring it back to him.
Deuteronomy 22:2 Even if your fellow Israelite is not nearby, or you do not know him, you must bring the animal into your own house. It must stay with you until your fellow Israelite asks for it, and then you must return it to him.
Deuteronomy 22:3 You must do the same for a donkey, a piece of clothing, and any lost thing belonging to your fellow Israelite that you find. You must not neglect any such thing.
Deuteronomy 22:4 You must not see your fellow Israelite’s donkey or ox collapsed on the road and walk by as if it does not concern you. Instead, you must help the animal get back up.
Deuteronomy 22:5 A woman must not wear men’s clothing, nor may a man wear women’s clothing. Whoever does such things is an abomination to God.
Deuteronomy 22:6 If, while walking along the road, you find a bird’s nest in a tree or on the ground with a mother bird sitting on her young or on her eggs, you must not take the mother along with the young.
Deuteronomy 22:7 Instead, you must let the mother bird fly away, and then you may take the young for yourself. This command ensures your well-being and a long life.
Deuteronomy 22:8 When you build a new house, you must build a parapet wall around the edge of the roof. This is to prevent anyone from falling off the roof, so that you do not incur the guilt of bloodshed in your home.
Deuteronomy 22:9 You must not plant your vineyard with two different kinds of seeds. If you do, both the crop you sow and the produce from the vines will be declared holy and therefore forbidden to you.
Deuteronomy 22:10 You must not plow with an ox and a donkey yoked together.
Deuteronomy 22:11 You must not wear clothing made of wool and linen woven together.
Deuteronomy 22:12 You must make tassels on the four corners of the cloak you wear.
Deuteronomy 22:13 If a man takes a wife, and after having relations with her, he comes to hate her,
Deuteronomy 22:14 and he accuses her of a terrible crime and slanders her, saying, 'I took this woman as my wife, and when I had relations with her, I found no evidence that she was a virgin!'
Deuteronomy 22:15 then the girl’s parents and her witnesses must gather the evidence of her virginity and bring it to the elders of the city, who are seated at the city gate.
Deuteronomy 22:16 And they must say to the elders, 'We gave our daughter to this man as his wife. Now he hates her,
Deuteronomy 22:17 and has accused her of a terrible crime, saying, 'I found your daughter was not a virgin.' But here is the evidence of my daughter’s virginity!—and they must spread the garment before the elders of the city.
Deuteronomy 22:18 Therefore, the elders of that city must take the man and publicly beat him. They must also fine him one hundred silver shekels, which they must give to the girl’s father,
Deuteronomy 22:19 because he slandered an Israelite virgin. He will not be permitted to divorce her for the rest of his life.
Deuteronomy 22:20 However, if the accusation he made is true, and no evidence of virginity is found in the girl,
Deuteronomy 22:21 then they must bring her out to the entrance of her father’s house, and the men of her city must stone her to death. She has committed an outrage in Israel by defiling herself through fornication while still in her father’s house. You must remove this evil from your midst.
Deuteronomy 22:22 If a man is found lying with another man’s wife, both of them—the adulterer and the adulteress—must be put to death. You must remove this evil from Israel.
Deuteronomy 22:23 If a man finds a virgin girl who is betrothed to another man within a city, and he lies with her,
Deuteronomy 22:24 you must bring both of them to the city gate and stone them to death. The girl must die because she did not cry out for help, even though she was in the city. The man must die because he violated his neighbor’s betrothed wife. You must remove this evil from your midst.
Deuteronomy 22:25 But if a man finds a betrothed girl in the open country and seizes her and lies with her, then only the man who lay with her must be put to death.
Deuteronomy 22:26 The girl is innocent and deserves no punishment of death, because this crime is like a man ambushing and murdering another man. That is how the girl suffered.
Deuteronomy 22:27 She was alone in the open country, she cried out, but there was no one to rescue her.
Deuteronomy 22:28 If a man finds a virgin girl who is not betrothed, and he seizes her and lies with her, and they are discovered,
Deuteronomy 22:29 the man who lay with her must pay the girl’s father fifty silver shekels. He must also take the girl as his wife, because he violated her, and he will not be permitted to divorce her for the rest of his life.
Deuteronomy 22:30 A man must not marry his father’s wife, nor may he have sexual relations with her.
Deuteronomy 22:1 You must not see your kinsman's ox or sheep wandering away and ignore it as if it isn't your concern. Instead, you must bring it back to your kinsman.
Deuteronomy 22:2 But if your kinsman isn't nearby, or if you don't know who the owner is, then you must bring the animal to your own house. Keep it with you there until your kinsman comes looking for it, and then you must return it to him.
Deuteronomy 22:3 You must do the same for your kinsman's donkey, or his garment, or any other lost property of your kinsman. If you find something, you must not neglect it or pretend you didn't see it.
Deuteronomy 22:4 You must not see your kinsman's donkey or ox collapsed on the road and just walk by as if it's none of your business. Instead, you must help him lift it up.
Deuteronomy 22:5 A woman must not wear men's clothing, nor must a man wear women's clothing. For all who do these things are utterly detestable in the sight of God.
Deuteronomy 22:6 If you find a bird's nest on the road, or in a tree, or on the ground, with the mother bird sitting on chicks or eggs, you must not take the mother with her young.
Deuteronomy 22:7 But you must allow the mother to fly away, and then you may take the young for yourself, so that it may go well with you and you may live a long time.
Deuteronomy 22:8 When you build a new house, you must build a parapet or railing around your roof. This is to ensure that if someone falls from it, the guilt of bloodshed will not rest upon your house.
Deuteronomy 22:9 You must not sow your vineyard with two different kinds of seed. If you do, the entire harvest—both the crop you planted and the fruit of the vineyard—will become consecrated for God, meaning it will be forfeited.
Deuteronomy 22:10 You must not plow with an ox and a donkey harnessed together.
Deuteronomy 22:11 You must not wear clothing woven from wool and linen together.
Deuteronomy 22:12 You must make cords or tassels on the four corners of the cloak with which you cover yourself.
Deuteronomy 22:13 If a man takes a wife, and after having relations with her, he comes to hate her,
Deuteronomy 22:14 and then he invents disgraceful accusations against her, saying: "I took this woman as my wife, and when I went in to her, I did not find in her the signs of her virginity—meaning, proof that she was a virgin before our marriage."
Deuteronomy 22:15 Then the father and mother of the young woman must take the proof of her virginity and bring it with them to the elders of the city, who sit in the gate for judgment.
Deuteronomy 22:16 And the father will say: "I gave my daughter to this man as his wife, but now he hates her,"
Deuteronomy 22:17 and he has falsely accused her, saying: "I did not find your daughter to be a virgin." But here is the proof of my daughter's virginity." And they will spread the garment before the elders of the city.
Deuteronomy 22:18 Then the elders of that city must take that man and punish him with lashes.
Deuteronomy 22:19 Moreover, they must fine him one hundred pieces of gold, which he must give to the young woman's father. This is because he defamed a virgin of Israel with a wicked accusation. He must also continue to have her as his wife and will not be permitted to divorce her for all the days of his life.
Deuteronomy 22:20 But if the accusation is true, and the proofs of virginity were not found in the young woman:
Deuteronomy 22:21 Then they must bring her out to the entrance of her father's house, and the men of her city must stone her to death. This is because she committed an outrageous act in Israel by committing fornication while in her father's house. Thus, you must remove such wickedness from among you.
Deuteronomy 22:22 If a man is caught sleeping with another man's wife, both of them must die—that is, both the adulterer and the adulteress. Thus, you must remove such wickedness from Israel.
Deuteronomy 22:23 If a young woman, a virgin, is engaged to a man, and someone finds her in the city and has relations with her:
Deuteronomy 22:24 Both of them must be brought to the gate of that city, and they must be stoned to death. The young woman must die because she did not cry out for help, even though she was in the city. The man must die because he violated his kinsman's betrothed wife. Thus, you must remove such wickedness from among you.
Deuteronomy 22:25 However, if a man finds an engaged young woman in the open country and seizes her and has relations with her, then only the man must die.
Deuteronomy 22:26 The young woman will suffer no punishment and is not guilty of death. This is because she is like a man who is ambushed by a robber and violently attacked—just so, the young woman suffered this violence.
Deuteronomy 22:27 She cried out for help, but there was no one to rescue her.
Deuteronomy 22:28 If a man finds a young virgin woman who is not engaged, and he seizes her and has relations with her, and he is caught in the act:
Deuteronomy 22:29 Then the man who had relations with her must give the young woman's father fifty pieces of silver. He must also take her as his wife, because he violated her, and he will not be permitted to divorce her for all the days of his life.
Deuteronomy 22:30 A man must not take his father's wife as his own, nor uncover her father's nakedness. This means he must not have sexual relations with her.
Deuteronomy 23:1 A man who has had his testicles crushed or cut off, or his penis cut off, shall not enter the assembly of the Lord’s people.
Deuteronomy 23:2 A mamzer—that is, a child born from an unchaste woman or an illicit union—shall not enter the assembly of the Lord, not even to the tenth generation.
Deuteronomy 23:3 The Ammonites and the Moabites shall not enter the assembly of the Lord, not even to the tenth generation, and even beyond that, forever.
Deuteronomy 23:4 This is because they did not come out to meet you with bread and water on the road when you were coming out of Egypt. And also because they hired Balaam, the son of Beor, from Mesopotamia of Syria, to curse you.
Deuteronomy 23:5 However, the Lord your God would not listen to Balaam, and He turned Balaam’s curse into a blessing for you, because the Lord loved you.
Deuteronomy 23:6 You shall never make peace with them, nor any alliance, forever.
Deuteronomy 23:7 You shall not detest an Edomite, because he is your brother. Nor shall you detest an Egyptian, because you were once an immigrant in his land.
Deuteronomy 23:8 The children who are born to them in the third generation may enter the assembly of the Lord.
Deuteronomy 23:9 When you go out to battle against your enemies, you shall guard yourself from every wicked thing.
Deuteronomy 23:10 If there is any man among you who has become unclean from a nocturnal emission—a wet dream—he shall go outside the camp and shall not return until he has washed himself with water.
Deuteronomy 23:11 And after sunset, having washed away all impurity, he may re-enter the camp.
Deuteronomy 23:12 You shall have a designated place outside the camp for the necessities of nature, a place suitable for cleanliness.
Deuteronomy 23:13 You shall also have a digging tool among your provisions, and when you sit outside the camp for defecation, you shall dig in the ground and cover whatever you have expelled.
Deuteronomy 23:14 For the Lord your God walks in the midst of your camp to deliver you and to hand over your enemies to you. Therefore, your camp must be holy, and nothing indecent or impure shall appear in it, lest God abandon you.
Deuteronomy 23:15 If a servant who has fled his master seeks refuge with you, you shall not hand him over to his master.
Deuteronomy 23:16 Instead, he shall remain with you in the place that pleases him and in one of your cities, wherever he desires. You shall not oppress him.
Deuteronomy 23:17 There shall be no harlot among the daughters of Israel, nor any male prostitute among the sons of Israel.
Deuteronomy 23:18 You shall not bring the wages of a prostitute, nor the price of a dog, into the house of the Lord your God, no matter what you have vowed. For both of these are detestable to the Lord your God.
Deuteronomy 23:19 You shall not lend money to your brother at interest, nor grain, nor any other thing.
Deuteronomy 23:20 But you may lend to a foreigner. To your brother, however, you shall lend without charging interest, so that the Lord your God may bless you in all your work in the land which you are entering to possess.
Deuteronomy 23:21 When you make a vow to the Lord your God, you shall not delay fulfilling it. For the Lord your God will surely require it of you, and if you delay, it will be counted as a sin for you.
Deuteronomy 23:22 If you choose not to make a promise by vowing, you will be without sin.
Deuteronomy 23:23 Whatever has come out of your lips, you shall keep and perform, just as you promised to the Lord your God, for you spoke it of your own free will and with your own mouth.
Deuteronomy 23:24 When you enter your neighbor’s vineyard, you may eat grapes as much as you like to satisfy yourself, but you shall not carry any away from the vineyard.
Deuteronomy 23:25 If you enter your friend’s standing grain field, you may pluck heads of grain and rub them in your hand, but you shall not use a sickle to harvest his grain.
Deuteronomy 24:1 If a man takes a wife and marries her, but she does not find favor in his eyes because he has found some indecency in her—a shameful act that makes her displeasing to him—then he must write a certificate of divorce for her, put it in her hand, and send her out of his house.
Deuteronomy 24:2 And when she has left him and gone from him, and taken another husband,
Deuteronomy 24:3 and if that second husband also dislikes her and gives her a certificate of divorce, sending her out of his house—or if this second husband dies,
Deuteronomy 24:4 then her first husband cannot take her back as his wife, because she has been defiled and has become abominable before the Lord. You must not allow such a sin to pollute your land, which the Lord your God is about to give you as an inheritance.
Deuteronomy 24:5 When a man takes a new wife, he shall not go out to war, nor shall any public duty be imposed upon him. He must be free from any obligation at home for one year, and he shall make his wife whom he has taken happy.
Deuteronomy 24:6 You shall not take the lower and upper millstones as a pledge—the grinding equipment necessary for daily bread—nor a fulling mill; for that would be taking a man's very livelihood as a pledge, which is like taking his soul.
Deuteronomy 24:7 If a man is found kidnapping one of his brothers from the children of Israel, and selling him, or if he is found exploiting him for profit, that kidnapper must die. You are to remove this evil from among you.
Deuteronomy 24:8 Be very careful to observe the laws concerning leprosy. Do everything the Levitical priests instruct you, just as I commanded them, and fulfill their instructions fully.
Deuteronomy 24:9 Remember what the Lord your God did to Miriam—Moses' sister—on the way when you came out of Egypt.
Deuteronomy 24:10 When you lend money to your neighbor, you shall not enter his house to take a pledge from him.
Deuteronomy 24:11 Instead, you must stand outside, and he himself shall bring you what he has as a pledge.
Deuteronomy 24:12 If, however, the borrower is a poor man, his pledge shall not remain with you overnight.
Deuteronomy 24:13 You must return it to him at sunset, so that he may sleep in his garment and bless you. This act of justice will be counted to you before the Lord your God.
Deuteronomy 24:14 You shall not deny payment to a poor and needy hired servant, whether he is one of your own brothers or an alien residing with you in your land.
Deuteronomy 24:15 But on the very same day, you must pay him his wages before the sun sets, for he is poor and depends on that money for his very life. If you do not pay him, he may cry out to the Lord against you, and it will be counted as a sin to you.
Deuteronomy 24:16 Fathers shall not be put to death for their children, nor shall children be put to death for their fathers. Each person shall die for his own sin.
Deuteronomy 24:17 You shall not pervert the justice due to an alien or an orphan, nor shall you take a widow's garment as a pledge.
Deuteronomy 24:18 But remember that you were once slaves in Egypt, and the Lord your God delivered you from there. Therefore, I command you to do this thing—to show justice and mercy to the vulnerable.
Deuteronomy 24:19 When you reap your harvest in your field and forget a sheaf of grain there, do not go back to get it. Leave it for the alien, the orphan, and the widow, so that the Lord your God may bless you in all the work of your hands.
Deuteronomy 24:20 When you beat your olive trees to gather their fruit, do not go over the branches a second time. Leave whatever remains on the trees for the alien, the orphan, and the widow.
Deuteronomy 24:21 When you gather the grapes from your vineyard, do not collect the remaining clusters. You must allow them to go to the alien, the orphan, and the widow.
Deuteronomy 24:22 Remember that you also were slaves in Egypt, and for that reason, I command you to do this thing—to care for the needy as you were once cared for.
Deuteronomy 24:1 If a man takes a woman as his wife and marries her,
and she does not find favor in his eyes because of some indecency or moral defect discovered in her,
then he is to write a bill of divorce.
He must give this document into her hand,
and then he is to send her out of his house.
Deuteronomy 24:2 And when she has gone out from him and departed,
and then has joined herself in marriage to another man,
Deuteronomy 24:3 and that man also comes to detest her,
and has written her a bill of divorce, and given it into her hand, and sent her out of his house—
or if that man has died certainly,
Deuteronomy 24:4 then the former husband will not be able to take her back as his wife,
because she is now defiled, and has become an abomination before the Lord.
You must not bring such a sin upon the land
which the Lord your God is giving you to possess.
Deuteronomy 24:5 If a man has recently married a wife,
he shall not go out to war, nor shall any compulsory service be imposed upon him.
Instead, he shall be free from all obligations at his home for one year,
so that he may bring joy to the wife whom he has taken.
Deuteronomy 24:6 You shall not take as security the lower or upper millstone,
nor the implements of a fuller (which are essential for his work),
because by doing so, one pledges a person's very means of life itself.
Deuteronomy 24:7 If a man is caught kidnapping one of his brothers from among the children of Israel,
and then sells him for a price, having received money for him,
that man shall be taken away and put to death.
Thus, you shall remove this evil from your midst.
Deuteronomy 24:8 Take careful heed that you do not contract the plague of leprosy.
You must do everything that the priests of the Levitical lineage have taught you.
You shall diligently fulfill and carry out everything according to what I have commanded them.
Deuteronomy 24:9 Remember what the Lord your God did to Miriam (the sister of Moses) on the journey,
when you were coming out of Egypt.
Deuteronomy 24:10 When you lend money to your neighbor,
you shall not enter his house to take a pledge (or collateral).
Deuteronomy 24:11 Instead, you shall stand outside,
and he himself shall bring out to you whatever he has for a pledge.
Deuteronomy 24:12 If he is a poor man,
the pledge (such as a garment needed for warmth) shall not remain with you overnight.
Deuteronomy 24:13 But you shall immediately return it to him in the evening,
so that when he sleeps in his own garment, he may bless you.
This act of mercy will be counted as righteousness for you before the Lord your God.
Deuteronomy 24:14 You shall not oppress a poor and needy hired servant,
whether he is one of your own people,
or a foreigner who dwells with you in your land.
Deuteronomy 24:15 But on the very same day, you shall pay him his wages before the sun sets,
because he is poor and depends on it to sustain his very life.
Otherwise, he might cry out against you to the Lord,
and it will be counted as a sin for you.
Deuteronomy 24:16 A father shall not be put to death for the sin of his son,
nor shall a son be put to death for the sin of his father.
Each person shall die for his own sin.
Deuteronomy 24:17 You shall not pervert the justice due to a foreigner or an orphan,
nor shall you take a widow's garment as a pledge (for it is her only covering).
Deuteronomy 24:18 Remember that you yourselves were slaves in Egypt,
and the Lord your God delivered you from there (from your slavery).
Therefore, I command you to do this thing (to care for the vulnerable).
Deuteronomy 24:19 When you reap your harvest in your field,
and have forgotten a sheaf of grain and left it behind,
you shall not return again to take it.
Instead, you shall leave it for the foreigner, the orphan, and the widow to gather,
so that the Lord your God may bless you in all the work of your hands.
Deuteronomy 24:20 When you beat down the fruit from your olive trees,
you shall not go back again to gather what remains on the branches.
Instead, you shall leave it for the foreigner, the orphan, and the widow.
Deuteronomy 24:21 When you gather the grapes from your vineyard,
you shall not collect the remaining clusters of grapes.
Instead, you shall leave them for the resident foreigner, the orphan, and the widow.
Deuteronomy 24:22 Remember that you yourselves were also slaves in Egypt,
and therefore I command you to do this thing (to care for the needy).
Deuteronomy 25:1 If a legal dispute arises between men, and a judgment is needed to resolve it, and the judges render a just verdict, declaring the guilty party condemned and the innocent party absolved:
Deuteronomy 25:2 If the guilty party is deserving of physical punishment, the judge must have him laid down and beaten with rods in his presence, according to the severity of his sin and the manner of the beating.
Deuteronomy 25:3 The punishment must not exceed forty blows, so that your brother, the one receiving the punishment, is not too severely disgraced and disfigured beyond what is humanely bearable.
Deuteronomy 25:4 You must not muzzle an ox while it is threshing your grain in the threshing floor, for it deserves to eat from the fruits of its labor.
Deuteronomy 25:5 When brothers live together and one of them dies without having children, his widow must not marry an outsider. Instead, her late husband’s brother must marry her to raise up an heir for his deceased brother's lineage, and the firstborn son they have together will be named after the deceased brother.
Deuteronomy 25:6 If the brother refuses to marry his deceased brother’s wife, as he is legally bound to do, the woman must go to the city gate and appeal to the elders, declaring: 'My husband’s brother refuses to perpetuate his brother’s name in Israel, and he will not take me as his wife.'
Deuteronomy 25:7 The elders will immediately summon him and question him. If he replies: 'I do not wish to marry her as my wife:'
Deuteronomy 25:8 Then the woman must approach him in the presence of the elders, and she will remove his sandal from his foot, and spit in his face, saying: 'This is what happens to the man who refuses to build up his brother’s household and continue his legacy.'
Deuteronomy 25:9 And in Israel, his family name will forever be known as 'the house of the one who lost his sandal,' marking his failure to fulfill his duty.
Deuteronomy 25:10 If two men are fighting, and the wife of one of them tries to rescue her husband from the stronger man by reaching out her hand and grabbing his private parts:
Deuteronomy 25:11 You must cut off her hand, showing her no pity for such an indecent and aggressive act.
Deuteronomy 25:12 You must not keep two different kinds of weights in your bag, a heavier one for buying and a lighter one for selling, for such dishonesty is an abomination.
Deuteronomy 25:13 And you must not have two different kinds of measures in your house, a larger one for buying and a smaller one for selling.
Deuteronomy 25:14 You must always have honest and accurate weights and measures. This practice will ensure you live a long time in the land that the Lord your God is giving you.
Deuteronomy 25:15 For the Lord your God detests anyone who commits such injustices, for He is fundamentally opposed to all wickedness and dishonesty.
Deuteronomy 25:16 You must not keep two different kinds of weights in your bag, a heavier one for buying and a lighter one for selling, for such dishonesty is an abomination.
Deuteronomy 25:17 Remember what the Amalekites did to you on your journey when you were coming out of Egypt.
Deuteronomy 25:18 Remember how they attacked you along the way, striking down all the stragglers at the very rear of your column who were exhausted and faltering, while you were hungry and thirsty, and they did this without any fear of God.
Deuteronomy 25:19 Therefore, when the Lord your God grants you rest from all your enemies surrounding you in the land He is giving you as an inheritance, you must completely wipe out the memory of the Amalekites from under the sky. Make sure you never forget this command.
Deuteronomy 26:1 When you finally enter the land that the Lord your God is giving you to possess, and you have taken it over and settled down there to live in it:
Deuteronomy 26:2 you are to take some of the first fruits of all the produce of your land that you harvest from the land the Lord your God has given you. Put them in a basket, and go to the specific place that the Lord your God will choose for His Name to be praised and invoked there.
Deuteronomy 26:3 And you shall go to the priest who is ministering in those days, and you shall say to him: "I declare today before the Lord your God that I have come into the land for which the Lord swore to our fathers that He would give it to us."
Deuteronomy 26:4 And the priest will take the basket from your hand and place it before the altar of the Lord your God.
Deuteronomy 26:5 And you shall speak and say in the presence of the Lord your God: "A wandering Aramean was my father Jacob, who went down into Egypt and lived there as an alien with a very small number of people. He grew there into a great nation, powerful and of immense multitude."
Deuteronomy 26:6 "And the Egyptians afflicted us and persecuted us, imposing heavy burdens upon us."
Deuteronomy 26:7 "And we cried out to the Lord God of our fathers, and He heard us. He looked upon our affliction, our toil, and our distress."
Deuteronomy 26:8 "And He led us out of Egypt with a strong hand and an outstretched arm, with signs, and with wonders, and with great terror."
Deuteronomy 26:9 "And He brought us into this place and gave us this land, a land flowing with milk and honey."
Deuteronomy 26:10 "And therefore, now I offer the first fruits of the produce of the land which the Lord has given me." And you shall place them down in the presence of the Lord your God, and you shall adore the Lord your God.
Deuteronomy 26:11 And you shall rejoice in all the good things that the Lord your God has given to you and to your household—you, and the Levite, and the foreigner who lives among you.
Deuteronomy 26:12 When you have finished setting aside the tenth part of all your produce, during the third year, which is the year for tithing, you shall give it to the Levite, and to the foreigner, and to the orphan, and to the widow, so that they may eat within your towns and be fully satisfied.
Deuteronomy 26:13 And you shall speak in the presence of the Lord your God: "I have taken the holy portion from my house and have given it to the Levite, and to the foreigner, and to the orphan, and to the widow, just as You commanded me, neither going beyond Your commands nor forgetting them."
Deuteronomy 26:14 "I have not eaten any of it while in mourning, nor have I set aside any of it for any unclean purpose, nor have I given any of it for the dead. I have obeyed the voice of the Lord my God, and I have done everything just as You commanded me."
Deuteronomy 26:15 "Look down from Your holy sanctuary, from Your exalted dwelling place in the heavens (the spiritual realm), and bless Your people Israel, and the land You have given us, just as You swore to our fathers, a land flowing with milk and honey."
Deuteronomy 26:16 Today the Lord your God has commanded you to perform these statutes and judgments. Therefore, you must carefully keep and fulfill them with all your heart and with all your soul.
Deuteronomy 26:17 You have chosen the Lord today to be your God, and to walk in His ways, and to keep His ceremonies, and His commands, and His judgments, and to obey His voice.
Deuteronomy 26:18 And the Lord has chosen you today to be His own special people, just as He promised you, and to carefully keep all His commands.
Deuteronomy 26:19 And He will make you higher than all the nations He has created, in praise, and in name, and in His glory, so that you may be a holy people to the Lord your God, just as He has promised.
Deuteronomy 26:1 When you enter the land that the Lord your God is giving you as an inheritance to possess, and you have taken hold of it and settled there,
Deuteronomy 26:2 you shall take some of the first of all the produce of your land that you harvest from your soil, and put it in a basket, and you shall go to the special place where the Lord your God has chosen for His Name to be invoked and worshiped.
Deuteronomy 26:3 and present yourself to the priest who is serving during that time, and declare to him: 'Today I openly declare before the Lord your God that I have entered the land concerning which the Lord swore an oath to our fathers that He would give it to us.'
Deuteronomy 26:4 The priest shall then take the basket from your hand, and place it before the altar of the Lord your God.
Deuteronomy 26:5 Then you shall speak and say in the presence of the Lord your God: 'An Aramean (Laban) once afflicted my ancestor, Jacob, who was a wanderer about to perish. He went down into Egypt and lived there as an alien with only a small group. But there he grew into a great, strong, and countless nation.
Deuteronomy 26:6 Then the Egyptians afflicted us and persecuted us by imposing heavy burdens upon us.
Deuteronomy 26:7 So we cried out to the Lord, the God of our fathers, and He heard us and saw our humility, our suffering, and our oppression.
Deuteronomy 26:8 and He brought us out of Egypt with a mighty hand and an outstretched arm, amidst terrifying acts, and great signs and wonders.
Deuteronomy 26:9 He led us to this very place and gave us this land, a land flowing with milk and honey—a land of abundant blessings.
Deuteronomy 26:10 Therefore, I now bring the firstfruits of the land that You, O Lord, have given me.' You shall then place them before the Lord your God, and you shall worship the Lord your God.
Deuteronomy 26:11 And you shall rejoice in all the good things that the Lord your God has given to you and your household, together with the Levite and the foreign visitor who lives among you.
Deuteronomy 26:12 When you have finished setting aside the tithe of all your produce in the third year, the year of tithing, you shall give it to the Levite, the foreign visitor, the orphan, and the widow, so that they may eat within your towns and be satisfied.
Deuteronomy 26:13 Then you shall say in the presence of the Lord your God: 'I have removed the sacred portion from my house and have given it to the Levite, the foreign visitor, the orphan, and the widow, just as You commanded me. I have not violated Your commandments, nor have I forgotten Your precepts.'
Deuteronomy 26:14 I have not eaten any of it while I was in mourning, nor set aside any of it for an unclean purpose, nor offered any of it to the dead. I have obeyed the voice of the Lord my God and have done everything as You commanded me.
Deuteronomy 26:15 Look down from Your holy dwelling, from the exalted heavens—Your dwelling place—and bless Your people Israel, and the land You have given us, as You swore to our fathers—a land flowing with milk and honey.
Deuteronomy 26:16 Today, the Lord your God commands you to observe these statutes and ordinances. You are to keep and fulfill them with all your heart and with all your soul.
Deuteronomy 26:17 Today you have declared the Lord to be your God, that you may walk in His ways, keep His rituals, and observe His statutes and ordinances, and obey His voice.
Deuteronomy 26:18 And the Lord has declared you today to be His own treasured people, just as He promised you, so that you may keep all His commandments.
Deuteronomy 26:19 and that He may set you high above all the nations He has made, for His own praise, name, and glory, and that you may be a holy people to the Lord your God, just as He has declared.

Deuteronomy 27:1 Moses and the elders of Israel gave this commandment to the people, saying, "Obey every command that I am giving to you today."
