Deuteronomy 27:2 When you cross the Jordan River to enter the land that the Lord your God is giving to you, you are to set up large stones for yourselves, and you are to coat them with plaster.
Deuteronomy 27:3 And upon these stones, you are to write down all the words of this law. Do this after you have entered the land that the Lord your God is giving to you—a land flowing with milk and honey, just as He swore to our ancestors.
Deuteronomy 27:4 Therefore, when you have crossed the Jordan, set up these stones—which I am commanding you today—on Mount Ebal, and you are to coat them with plaster.
Deuteronomy 27:5 And there, on Mount Ebal, you are to build an altar to the Lord your God from stones that have not been cut by any iron tool.
Deuteronomy 27:6 Use stones that are naturally rough and whole. And on this altar, you are to offer burnt offerings to the Lord your God.
Deuteronomy 27:7 You are also to sacrifice peace offerings, and you will eat them there, celebrating in the presence of the Lord your God.
Deuteronomy 27:8 And you are to write clearly and legibly upon these stones all the words of this law.
Deuteronomy 27:9 Then Moses and the Levitical priests spoke to all of Israel, saying, "Listen closely and pay attention, O Israel. Today, you have become the people of the Lord your God."
Deuteronomy 27:10 Therefore, you must keep His commandments and His sacred rituals, which I am giving to you today.
Deuteronomy 27:11 Moses also commanded the people on that very day, saying:
Deuteronomy 27:12 These tribes are to stand on Mount Gerizim to bless the people once you have crossed the Jordan: Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Joseph, and Benjamin.
Deuteronomy 27:13 And these tribes, by contrast, are to stand on Mount Ebal to declare curses: Reuben, Gad, Asher, Zebulun, Dan, and Naphtali.
Deuteronomy 27:14 Then the Levites are to declare this and say in a loud voice to every man of Israel:
Deuteronomy 27:15 Cursed is the man who makes an idol, whether carved or cast, an abomination to the Lord—something made by the hands of craftsmen—and then sets it up in a hidden place. And all the people are to answer and say, 'Amen!'
Deuteronomy 27:16 Cursed is the one who dishonors his father or his mother. And all the people are to say, 'Amen!'
Deuteronomy 27:17 Cursed is the one who moves his neighbor's boundary marker. And all the people are to say, 'Amen!'
Deuteronomy 27:18 Cursed is the one who misleads a blind person who is lost on the road. And all the people are to say, 'Amen!'
Deuteronomy 27:19 Cursed is the one who perverts justice for a foreigner, an orphan, or a widow. And all the people are to say, 'Amen!'
Deuteronomy 27:20 Cursed is the one who sleeps with his father's wife, thereby uncovering his father's nakedness. And all the people are to say, 'Amen!'
Deuteronomy 27:21 Cursed is the one who sleeps with any animal. And all the people are to say, 'Amen!'
Deuteronomy 27:22 Cursed is the one who sleeps with his sister, whether she is his father's daughter or his mother's daughter. And all the people are to say, 'Amen!'
Deuteronomy 27:23 Cursed is the one who sleeps with his mother-in-law. And all the people are to say, 'Amen!'
Deuteronomy 27:24 Cursed is the one who secretly strikes down his neighbor. And all the people are to say, 'Amen!'
Deuteronomy 27:25 Cursed is the one who accepts a bribe to kill an innocent person. And all the people are to say, 'Amen!'
Deuteronomy 27:26 Cursed is the one who does not uphold the words of this law, nor fully carry them out through his actions. And all the people are to say, 'Amen!'
Deuteronomy 27:1 Moses and the elders of Israel then gave instructions to the people, saying, 'Keep every command that I am giving to all of you today.'
Deuteronomy 27:2 When you cross the Jordan River to enter the land that the Lord your God is about to give you, you must set up large stones for yourselves and cover them with a smooth coating of lime,
Deuteronomy 27:3 and on these stones, you are to write all the words of this law once you have crossed over, so that you may truly enter the land which the Lord your God is giving you—a land of abundance, flowing with milk and honey—just as the Lord swore to your ancestors.
Deuteronomy 27:4 Therefore, as soon as you have crossed the Jordan, you must set up these stones, which I command you today, on Mount Ebal. You shall also prepare them by covering them with lime,
Deuteronomy 27:5 and there, on Mount Ebal, you are to build an altar to the Lord your God using stones that have not been touched by any iron tool or cut into shape.
Deuteronomy 27:6 You shall build the altar of the Lord your God from these unworked, natural stones, and upon it, you will offer burnt sacrifices to the Lord your God.
Deuteronomy 27:7 You will also offer peace offerings, which you will eat there, and rejoice in the presence of the Lord your God.
Deuteronomy 27:8 And on these stones, you shall write all the words of this law clearly and distinctly, so that everyone can read them.
Deuteronomy 27:9 Then Moses, along with the priests from the tribe of Levi, spoke to all of Israel, saying: 'Listen closely and pay attention, O Israel! For today, you have officially become the people of the Lord your God.'
Deuteronomy 27:10 Therefore, you are to keep His commandments and His ceremonies, which I am giving to you today.
Deuteronomy 27:11 Moses also commanded the people on that same day, saying:
Deuteronomy 27:12 When you have crossed the Jordan, these tribes shall stand on Mount Gerizim to bless the people: Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Joseph, and Benjamin.
Deuteronomy 27:13 And in contrast, these tribes shall stand on Mount Ebal to declare curses: Reuben, Gad, Asher, Zebulun, Dan, and Naphtali.
Deuteronomy 27:14 Then the Levites shall proclaim and declare in a loud voice to every man of Israel:
Deuteronomy 27:15 'Cursed be the man who makes a graven or molten image—an abomination to the Lord, the work of artisans' hands—and sets it up in secret.' And all the people shall respond and say, 'Amen.'
Deuteronomy 27:16 'Cursed be he who treats his father or mother with contempt.' And all the people shall say, 'Amen.'
Deuteronomy 27:17 'Cursed be he who moves his neighbor’s landmark or property boundary.' And all the people shall say, 'Amen.'
Deuteronomy 27:18 'Cursed be he who misleads a blind person on their journey.' And all the people shall say, 'Amen.'
Deuteronomy 27:19 'Cursed be he who perverts justice for the foreigner, the orphan, or the widow.' And all the people shall say, 'Amen.'
Deuteronomy 27:20 'Cursed be he who sleeps with his father’s wife, uncovering his father’s nakedness.' And all the people shall say, 'Amen.'
Deuteronomy 27:21 'Cursed be he who has sexual relations with any animal.' And all the people shall say, 'Amen.'
Deuteronomy 27:22 'Cursed be he who sleeps with his sister, whether his father’s daughter or his mother’s daughter.' And all the people shall say, 'Amen.'
Deuteronomy 27:23 'Cursed be he who sleeps with his mother-in-law.' And all the people shall say, 'Amen.'
Deuteronomy 27:24 'Cursed be he who strikes his neighbor in secret, intending harm.' And all the people shall say, 'Amen.'
Deuteronomy 27:25 'Cursed be he who accepts a bribe to shed innocent blood.' And all the people shall say, 'Amen.'
Deuteronomy 27:26 'Cursed be he who does not uphold the words of this law and fails to perform them completely.' And all the people shall say, 'Amen.'
Deuteronomy 28:1 If you truly listen to the voice of the Lord your God, so that you keep and obey all of His commandments which I am giving to you today, then the Lord your God will raise you higher than all the nations that are on the earth.
Deuteronomy 28:2 And all these blessings will come upon you and they will overtake you, if you actually listen to His commandments.
Deuteronomy 28:3 You will be blessed in the city, and blessed in the field.
Deuteronomy 28:4 Blessed will be the children born to you, and the produce of your land, and the offspring of your livestock: the flocks of your sheep and the herds of your cattle.
Deuteronomy 28:5 Blessed will be your storehouse and your provisions.
Deuteronomy 28:6 You will be blessed when you come in and when you go out.
Deuteronomy 28:7 The Lord will cause your enemies who rise up against you to be utterly defeated before your eyes. They will come against you on one path, but they will flee from you on seven paths, unable to stand against you.
Deuteronomy 28:8 The Lord will send His blessing upon your storehouses and upon all the work of your hands. And He will bless you in the land that the Lord your God is giving to you.
Deuteronomy 28:9 The Lord will establish you for Himself as a holy people, just as He swore to you, if you truly keep the commandments of the Lord your God and walk in His ways.
Deuteronomy 28:10 And all the peoples of the earth will see that the Name of the Lord is invoked over you—meaning you belong to Him and are under His divine protection—and they will fear you.
Deuteronomy 28:11 The Lord will cause you to abound with every good thing: with children born to you, and with the offspring of your livestock, and with the produce of your land, which the Lord swore to your fathers to give to you.
Deuteronomy 28:12 The Lord will open His good treasure house, the sky, to give rain to your land in its proper season. And He will bless all the work of your hands, and you will lend to many nations, and you yourself will not need to borrow from anyone.
Deuteronomy 28:13 The Lord will make you the head and not the tail; and you will always be above, and never below, if you actually listen to the commandments of the Lord your God, which I am commanding you today, and if you keep and obey them.
Deuteronomy 28:14 And you must not turn away from the words that I am commanding you today, either to the right or to the left, so that you do not follow other gods or worship them.
Deuteronomy 28:15 But if you refuse to listen to the voice of the Lord your God, so that you keep and obey all His commandments and statutes, which I am commanding you today, then all these curses will come upon you and they will overtake you.
Deuteronomy 28:16 You will be cursed in the city, and cursed in the field.
Deuteronomy 28:17 Cursed will be your storehouse and your provisions.
Deuteronomy 28:18 Cursed will be the children born to you, and the produce of your land, the flocks of your sheep and the herds of your cattle.
Deuteronomy 28:19 You will be cursed when you come in and cursed when you go out.
Deuteronomy 28:20 The Lord will send upon you famine and thirst, and frustration and defeat in all the work you undertake, until He crushes you and quickly destroys you because of the wickedness of your ways, by which you have abandoned Me.
Deuteronomy 28:21 The Lord will afflict you with a persistent plague until He consumes you from the land into which you are going to possess it.
Deuteronomy 28:22 The Lord will strike you with a wasting disease, with fever and chills, with burning fever and scorching heat, and with blight and mildew that destroy your crops; and these will pursue you until you perish.
Deuteronomy 28:23 And the sky above you will be like bronze, meaning it will give no rain, and the earth that you walk on will be like iron, meaning it will be hard and barren.
Deuteronomy 28:24 The Lord will give as rain for your land from the sky, dust and ashes; from the sky these will descend upon you until you are destroyed.
Deuteronomy 28:25 The Lord will cause you to be defeated before your enemies. You will go out against them on one path, but flee on seven paths, and you will be scattered among all the kingdoms of the earth.
Deuteronomy 28:26 And your dead body will be food for all the birds of the sky and for the beasts of the earth, and there will be no one to bury you.
Deuteronomy 28:27 The Lord will strike you with the boils of Egypt, and with festering sores, and with scabies and persistent itching, so that you cannot be cured.
Deuteronomy 28:28 The Lord will strike you with madness, and with blindness, and with confusion of mind.
Deuteronomy 28:29 And you will grope around at noon, just as a blind person gropes in darkness, and you will not find your way. At all times you will suffer injustice and be oppressed by violence, and there will be no one to rescue you.
Deuteronomy 28:30 You will take a wife, but another man will lie with her. You will build a house, but not live in it. You will plant a vineyard, but not gather its grapes.
Deuteronomy 28:31 Your ox will be slaughtered before your eyes, and you will not eat its meat. Your donkey will be stolen right before your eyes and not be returned to you. Your sheep will be given to your enemies, and there will be no one to help you.
Deuteronomy 28:32 Your sons and your daughters will be given over to another people while your eyes see it happen, and your eyes will waste away longing for them with no hope, and there will be no strength in your hand to prevent it.
Deuteronomy 28:33 The produce of your land and all your hard work, a people whom you do not know will eat. And you will always suffer injustice and be oppressed all your days.
Deuteronomy 28:34 Your eyes will grow dim from longing for what you expect to see but never will, and you will be filled with horror at everything you witness.
Deuteronomy 28:35 The Lord will strike you with terrible boils on your knees and on your thighs, and you will not be able to be cured, from the sole of your foot to the crown of your head.
Deuteronomy 28:36 The Lord will lead you and your king, whom you set over yourselves, to a nation that neither you nor your fathers have known. And there you will serve other gods, made of wood and stone.
Deuteronomy 28:37 And you will become an object of astonishment, and a proverb, and a derisive tale among all the peoples to whom the Lord has brought you.
Deuteronomy 28:38 You will sow much seed in the ground, but gather little, because locusts will devour everything.
Deuteronomy 28:39 You will plant vineyards and cultivate them, but you will not drink their wine, nor will you gather anything from them, because they will be devoured by pests.
Deuteronomy 28:40 You will have olive trees throughout all your territory, but you will not anoint yourselves with their oil, because their olives will fall off and perish before they can be harvested.
Deuteronomy 28:1 If you truly listen to the voice of the Lord your God and carefully keep all His commandments, which I am giving you today, the Lord your God will raise you up above all the other nations on the earth.
Deuteronomy 28:2 And all these blessings will come upon you and find you, if you genuinely listen to the commandments of the Lord your God.
Deuteronomy 28:3 You will be blessed in the city, and you will be blessed in the countryside.
Deuteronomy 28:4 Blessed will be the children born to you, the produce from your land, and the offspring of your livestock—your flocks of sheep and herds of cattle.
Deuteronomy 28:5 Blessed will be your baskets and your storage bins.
Deuteronomy 28:6 You will be blessed when you come in, and blessed when you go out.
Deuteronomy 28:7 The Lord will hand over your enemies, those who rise against you; they will be defeated right before your eyes. They will come against you by one road, but they will flee from you in seven different directions.
Deuteronomy 28:8 The Lord will command blessings upon you in your storage bins and in everything you do with your hands. He will bless you in the land that the Lord gives to you.
Deuteronomy 28:9 The Lord will establish you as His holy people, just as He swore to you He would. This will happen if you keep the commandments of the Lord your God and walk in His ways.
Deuteronomy 28:10 All the peoples of the earth will see that you are called by the name of the Lord, and they will be in awe of you.
Deuteronomy 28:11 The Lord will grant you abundant prosperity in children, in the offspring of your livestock, and in the produce of your land, in the land that the Lord swore to your fathers He would give you.
Deuteronomy 28:12 The Lord will open His rich storehouse, the sky, to send rain on your land in its proper season. He will bless all the work of your hands. You will lend to many nations, but you will not need to borrow from any.
Deuteronomy 28:13 The Lord will make you the head and not the tail; you will always be at the top and never at the bottom. This will be true if you genuinely listen to the commandments of the Lord your God that I am giving you today, and are careful to keep and do them.
Deuteronomy 28:14 Do not turn away from any of the words I am commanding you today, either to the right or to the left, so that you do not go after other gods or worship them.
Deuteronomy 28:15 But if you do not genuinely listen to the voice of the Lord your God and are not careful to keep all His commandments and statutes, which I am giving you today, then all these curses will come upon you and find you.
Deuteronomy 28:16 You will be cursed in the city, and you will be cursed in the countryside.
Deuteronomy 28:17 Cursed will be your baskets and your storage bins.
Deuteronomy 28:18 Cursed will be the children born to you, the produce from your land, and the offspring of your cattle and sheep.
Deuteronomy 28:19 You will be cursed when you come in, and cursed when you go out.
Deuteronomy 28:20 The Lord will send upon you curses of famine, thirst, and frustration in everything you attempt to do, until He crushes you and swiftly destroys you because of the evil you have done in forsaking Him.
Deuteronomy 28:21 The Lord will strike you with plague until He completely removes you from the land you are entering to possess.
Deuteronomy 28:22 The Lord will strike you with wasting disease, fever and inflammation, scorching heat, drought, blight, and mildew. These will pursue you until you perish.
Deuteronomy 28:23 The sky above your head will be like bronze, and the ground beneath your feet will be like iron.
Deuteronomy 28:24 The Lord will send dust and ashes raining down from the sky upon your land instead of rain, until you are utterly destroyed.
Deuteronomy 28:25 The Lord will cause you to be defeated before your enemies. You will march out against them by one road, but you will flee from them in seven different directions. You will be scattered throughout all the kingdoms of the earth.
Deuteronomy 28:26 Your corpses will become food for all the birds of the sky and the wild animals of the earth, with no one to bury them.
Deuteronomy 28:27 The Lord will strike you with the boils of Egypt, with tumors, with festering sores, and with an incurable itch and rash.
Deuteronomy 28:28 The Lord will strike you with madness, blindness, and confusion of mind.
Deuteronomy 28:29 At noon, you will grope around like a blind person fumbling in the darkness, unable to find your way. You will be constantly wronged and oppressed by violence, with no one to rescue you.
Deuteronomy 28:30 You will marry a woman, but another man will sleep with her. You will build a house, but you will not get to live in it. You will plant a vineyard, but you will not gather its grapes.
Deuteronomy 28:31 Your ox will be slaughtered before your very eyes, but you will not eat any of its meat. Your donkey will be stolen from you, right before your eyes, and it will not be returned to you. Your sheep will be given to your enemies, and there will be no one to help you.
Deuteronomy 28:32 Your sons and daughters will be given over to another people, and you will watch it happen, your eyes failing with longing for them day after day. You will be powerless to do anything.
Deuteronomy 28:33 A people you do not know will eat the produce of your land and all the fruits of your labor. You will be constantly wronged and oppressed for the rest of your days.
Deuteronomy 28:34 You will be driven mad by what you see with your own eyes.
Deuteronomy 28:35 The Lord will strike you with painful, incurable boils on your knees and legs. These sores will cover you from the sole of your foot to the top of your head.
Deuteronomy 28:36 The Lord will lead you and the king you set over you to a nation that neither you nor your ancestors have known. There you will serve other gods made of wood and stone.
Deuteronomy 28:37 You will become an object of horror, a proverb, and a byword among all the peoples to whom the Lord will scatter you.
Deuteronomy 28:38 You will sow much seed in your fields, but you will harvest little, because locusts will devour it all.
Deuteronomy 28:39 You will plant and cultivate vineyards, but you will not drink the wine or gather the grapes, because worms will eat them.
Deuteronomy 28:40 You will have olive trees throughout your territory, but you will not anoint yourself with the oil from them. This is because your olives will drop off and perish before they ripen.
Deuteronomy 29:1 These are the words of the sacred covenant that the Lord commanded Moses to establish with the children of Israel in the land of Moab. This covenant was made in addition to the earlier one He had already established with them on Mount Horeb.
Deuteronomy 29:1 These are the terms of the covenant which the Lord commanded Moses to establish with the children of Israel in the land of Moab, in addition to the covenant He had already made with them at Mount Horeb.
Deuteronomy 29:2 Then Moses called all of Israel together and said to them: “You yourselves saw everything the Lord did in the land of Egypt to Pharaoh, and to all his servants, and to all his land,
Deuteronomy 29:3 including the great trials your eyes witnessed—the signs and the immense wonders.
Deuteronomy 29:4 But the Lord did not give you a heart that could truly understand, nor eyes that could truly see, nor ears that could truly hear, until this very day.
Deuteronomy 29:5 I led you for forty years through the desert, and your clothes did not wear out, nor did your sandals become old and worn on your feet.
Deuteronomy 29:6 You did not eat bread, nor did you drink wine or strong drink, so that you would know that I am the Lord your God.
Deuteronomy 29:7 You came to this place, and Sihon, the king of Heshbon, and Og, the king of Bashan, came out to fight us, and we defeated them.
Deuteronomy 29:8 Then we took their land and gave it as an inheritance to Reuben, Gad, and half the tribe of Manasseh.
Deuteronomy 29:9 Therefore, keep the words of this covenant and do them, so that you may prosper in everything you undertake.
Deuteronomy 29:10 All of you stand here today before the Lord your God: your leaders, your tribes, your elders, and your officials,
Deuteronomy 29:11 all the people of Israel, together with your wives and children, and the foreigners living among you in your camps, from those who cut wood to those who draw water.
Deuteronomy 29:12 You are here to enter into the covenant of the Lord your God, and into the oath which the Lord your God is establishing with you today.
Deuteronomy 29:13 He is doing this so that He may establish you as His own people, and that He Himself may be your God, just as He promised you, and just as He swore to your fathers, Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.
Deuteronomy 29:14 I am not making this covenant with its oaths and confirmations only with you who are present today,
Deuteronomy 29:15 but also with all who are present here with us and with those who are not present today, which refers to your future generations.
Deuteronomy 29:16 For you yourselves know how we lived in the land of Egypt, and how we passed through the midst of the nations during your journey here.
Deuteronomy 29:17 And you saw their detestable things and their idols—their wooden and stone images, and their silver and gold, which they worshipped.
Deuteronomy 29:18 Beware lest there be among you a man or woman, or a family or tribe, whose heart turns away from the Lord our God today, to go and serve the gods of those nations. Beware lest there be among you a root that sprouts forth poison and bitterness.
Deuteronomy 29:19 If anyone hears the words of this oath and then blesses himself in his own heart, saying, 'I will have peace, even though I walk according to the stubbornness of my heart'—thinking that this will allow him to remove the sin of the drunken from the thirsty, meaning, to cause others to stumble by his own sin—
Deuteronomy 29:20 then the Lord will not be willing to forgive him. Instead, the Lord's anger and jealousy will burn against that man, and all the curses written in this book will rest upon him. The Lord will utterly blot out his name from under the sky.
Deuteronomy 29:21 The Lord will set him apart for destruction from all the tribes of Israel, according to all the curses and oaths written in this book of the Law.
Deuteronomy 29:22 The generation to come, and the children born after you, and the foreigner who comes from a distant land, will see the plagues of that land and the diseases with which the Lord has afflicted it.
Deuteronomy 29:23 They will see that the whole land is sulfur and salt and burning fire, so that it cannot be sown, nor can anything sprout, nor can any plant grow in it—just like the overthrow of Sodom, Gomorrah, Admah, and Zeboiim, which the Lord overthrew in His fierce anger and wrath.
Deuteronomy 29:24 And all the nations will ask: 'Why did the Lord do this to this land? What is the meaning of this immense wrath and indignation of His fury?'
Deuteronomy 29:25 And they will answer: 'Because they abandoned the covenant of the Lord, which He made with their fathers when He brought them out of the land of Egypt;'
Deuteronomy 29:26 'and they served other gods and worshipped them—gods they did not know, and gods the Lord had not assigned to them.'
Deuteronomy 29:27 Therefore, the fierce anger of the Lord was kindled against this land, to bring upon it all the curses that are written in this book;
Deuteronomy 29:28 and He cast them out of their land in wrath, and in fierce anger, and in great indignation, and hurled them into another land, as is evident today.
Deuteronomy 29:29 The secret things belong to the Lord our God; but the things that are revealed belong to us and to our children forever, so that we may carry out all the words of this Law.
Deuteronomy 29:30 When all these words that are written—both the blessing and the curse—come upon you, and you reflect on them in your heart among all the nations where the Lord your God has scattered you,
Deuteronomy 29:31 and when you return to Him and obey His commands, just as I am commanding you today, you and your children, with all your heart and with all your soul:
Deuteronomy 29:32 then the Lord your God will restore your fortunes and have compassion on you. He will gather you again from all the peoples among whom He had scattered you.
Deuteronomy 29:33 Even if you have been dispersed to the farthest reaches under the sky, from there the Lord your God will gather you and bring you back.
Deuteronomy 29:34 He will bring you into the land that your fathers possessed, and you will possess it. And He will bless you and make you more numerous than your fathers were.
Deuteronomy 29:35 The Lord your God will circumcise your heart and the heart of your descendants, so that you may love the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul, that you may live.
Deuteronomy 29:36 And the Lord will turn all these curses upon your enemies and upon those who hate you and persecute you.
Deuteronomy 29:37 But you will return, and you will listen to the voice of the Lord your God, and you will do all the commands that I am giving you today.
Deuteronomy 29:38 And the Lord your God will make you abound in prosperity in all the work of your hands, and in the offspring of your body, and in the produce of your livestock, and in the fruitfulness of your land, and in the abundance of all your possessions. For the Lord will again delight in you for all good things, just as He delighted in your fathers.
Deuteronomy 29:39 This will happen, however, only if you listen to the voice of the Lord your God, and keep His commands and His ceremonies which are written in this Law, and if you return to the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul.
Deuteronomy 29:40 For this commandment which I am giving you today is not too difficult for you, nor is it far away, nor is it impossible.
Deuteronomy 30:1 Therefore, when all these words come upon you—all the blessings and all the curses which I have placed before you—and you then seriously consider them in your heart, while you are among all the nations where the Lord your God has scattered you,
Deuteronomy 30:2 and when you have returned to the Lord your God, and have obeyed His commandment with your entire being, just as I am commanding you today—both you and your children—with all your heart and with all your soul,
Deuteronomy 30:3 then the Lord your God will restore your fortunes, and He will have compassion on you. He will gather you again from all the nations among whom He previously scattered you.
Deuteronomy 30:4 Even if you have been scattered to the farthest ends of the world, from there the Lord your God will gather you and bring you back.
Deuteronomy 30:5 He will bring you back into the land that your ancestors possessed, and you will own it once again. You will be more prosperous and more numerous than your ancestors ever were.
Deuteronomy 30:6 The Lord your God will circumcise your heart, and the hearts of your descendants, so that you may love the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul, in order that you may truly live.
Deuteronomy 30:7 Then all these curses will turn upon your enemies, and upon those who hate you and persecute you.
Deuteronomy 30:8 But you will return and listen to the voice of the Lord your God, and you will carry out all the commandments that I am giving you today.
Deuteronomy 30:9 And the Lord your God will make you abound in every work of your hands: in the children of your womb, in the offspring of your livestock, and in the abundance of your land, as well as in the generosity of all things.
Deuteronomy 30:10 For the Lord will delight again over you for your good, just as He delighted over your ancestors,
Deuteronomy 30:11 if only you listen to the voice of the Lord your God and keep His commandments and His ceremonies, which are written in this law, and you return to the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul.
Deuteronomy 30:12 For this commandment that I am giving you today is not too difficult for you, nor is it far away. It is not in the sky, so that you should have to say, "Who among us can ascend to the sky for us, and bring it down to us, so that we may hear it and do it?"
Deuteronomy 30:13 Nor is it beyond the sea, so that you should complain and say, "Who among us can cross the sea for us, and bring it to us, so that we may hear it and do it?"
Deuteronomy 30:14 Instead, the word is very near you, in your mouth and in your heart, so that you may do it.
Deuteronomy 30:15 Consider that today I have set before you life and good, and conversely, death and evil.
Deuteronomy 30:16 This choice is so that you may love the Lord your God, and walk in His ways, and keep His commandments, ceremonies, and judgments, so that you may live and multiply. And He will bless you in the land that you are entering to possess.
Deuteronomy 30:17 But if your heart turns away, and you refuse to listen, but instead are deceived by error to worship foreign gods and serve them,
Deuteronomy 30:18 then I declare to you today that you will surely perish. You will not remain for long in the land that you are crossing the Jordan to enter and possess.
Deuteronomy 30:19 I call the universe and the earth as witnesses against you today, that I have set before you life and death, blessing and curse.
Deuteronomy 30:20 Therefore, choose life, so that both you and your descendants may live. And this means you must love the Lord your God, obey His voice, and cling to Him. For He Himself is your life and the length of your days, so that you may dwell in the land that the Lord swore to your ancestors—Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob—to give to them.
Deuteronomy 31:1 Moses went and spoke all these words to all of Israel.
Deuteronomy 31:2 And he said to them: "I am one hundred and twenty years old today. I cannot lead you anymore, and the Lord has told me, 'You will not cross this Jordan River.'"
Deuteronomy 31:3 "The Lord your God Himself will go before you. He will destroy these nations in your sight, and you will take possession of their land. And this Joshua will go before you, just as the Lord has commanded."
Deuteronomy 31:4 "And the Lord will do to them as He did to Sihon and Og, the kings of the Amorites, and to all their lands, which He utterly destroyed."
Deuteronomy 31:5 "Therefore, when He has destroyed even these nations and delivered them over to you, you will do to them exactly as I have commanded you."
Deuteronomy 31:6 "Be strong and courageous. Do not fear them, nor be terrified by their presence, because the Lord your God Himself is your leader. He will not abandon you, nor will He ever forsake you."
Deuteronomy 31:7 Moses then called Joshua and said to him in front of all Israel: "Be strong and courageous, for you will lead this people into the land that the Lord swore to their fathers to give them. And you will divide it among them by lot."
Deuteronomy 31:8 "And the Lord, who is your leader, He Himself will be with you. He will not abandon you, nor will He ever forsake you. Do not be afraid, nor be dismayed."
Deuteronomy 31:9 So Moses wrote down this entire law and delivered it to the priests, the sons of Levi, who carried the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord, and to all the elders of Israel.
Deuteronomy 31:10 He then commanded them, saying: "At the end of every seven years, in the year of release, during the Feast of Tabernacles—which is the time of the Sabbatical year—"
Deuteronomy 31:11 "When all of Israel gathers to appear before the Lord your God in the holy place He chooses, you shall read the words of this entire law before all of Israel, with everyone listening intently."
Deuteronomy 31:12 "Gather the people: men, women, children, and the foreigners living within your towns—so that they may listen, learn, and fear the Lord your God, and diligently observe all the words of this law, carrying them out in their actions."
Deuteronomy 31:13 "And their children, who do not yet know the Law, may hear it and learn to fear the Lord your God all the days you live in the land you are crossing the Jordan to inhabit."
Deuteronomy 31:14 The Lord then said to Moses: "Look, the days of your death are near. Call Joshua, and stand with him in the Tent of Meeting—the Tabernacle of Testimony—so that I may give him his charge." So Moses and Joshua went and stood inside the Tent of Meeting.
Deuteronomy 31:15 And the Lord appeared there in a pillar of cloud, which stood directly over the entrance of the Tabernacle.
Deuteronomy 31:16 The Lord then said to Moses: "Behold, you will soon lie down with your fathers in death. And this people, when they settle in the land they are about to enter, will rise up and commit spiritual adultery by pursuing foreign gods. They will abandon Me there and break the covenant I have made with them."
Deuteronomy 31:17 "And My wrath will burn fiercely against them on that day. I will abandon them and hide My face from them, and they will be utterly consumed. All sorts of evils and afflictions will find them, so that on that day, they will say: 'Surely, because God is not with me, these evils have come upon me.'"
Deuteronomy 31:18 "But I will certainly hide My face from them on that day because of all the evils they have committed, for they will have pursued foreign gods."
Deuteronomy 31:19 "Now therefore, write down this song for yourselves, and teach it to the children of Israel. Have them memorize it and sing it, so that this song may serve as a perpetual witness for Me against the children of Israel."
Deuteronomy 31:20 "For I will bring them into the land which I swore to their fathers—a land flowing with milk and honey. They will eat, be satisfied, and grow prosperous. But then they will turn to foreign gods and serve them. They will invalidate My covenant and mock it."
Deuteronomy 31:21 "And when many evils and afflictions find them, this song will stand as a witness against them, for it will reveal their inner thoughts and what they were planning even before it happened. For I know their intentions, even now, while they are still living in the desert land."
Deuteronomy 31:22 So Moses wrote that song on that very day and taught it to the children of Israel.
Deuteronomy 31:23 And He—the Lord—gave a charge to Joshua, the son of Nun, saying: "Be strong and courageous, for you will lead the children of Israel into the land which I promised them by oath, and I will be with you."
Deuteronomy 31:24 Therefore, after Moses had finished writing all the words of this entire law in a scroll,
Deuteronomy 31:25 He commanded the Levites, who carried the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord, saying:
Deuteronomy 31:26 "Take this Book of the Law and place it beside the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord your God, so that it may remain there as a witness against you."
Deuteronomy 31:27 "For I know your stubbornness and your hard-headed obstinacy. Even while I am still alive and walking among you, you have always been contentious against the Lord. How much more rebellious will you be after I am dead!"
Deuteronomy 31:28 "Gather to me all the elders of your tribes and all your officials, so that I may speak these words in the hearing of everyone, and call the sky and the earth to witness against them."
Deuteronomy 31:29 "For I know that after my death, you will act wickedly and quickly turn aside from the path that I have commanded you. And evils will certainly befall you in the latter days, because you will do evil in the sight of the Lord, provoking Him to anger with the work of your own hands—your idols."
Deuteronomy 31:30 So Moses spoke the words of this song in the hearing of the entire assembly of Israel, and he completed it fully.
Deuteronomy 31:1 And Moses went, and he spoke all these words to the whole nation of Israel.
Deuteronomy 31:2 He said to them, 'I am one hundred and twenty years old today, and I can no longer lead you out or bring you in, especially since the Lord has already told me that I will not cross this Jordan River.'
Deuteronomy 31:3 So the Lord your God Himself will go across before you, and He Himself will destroy all these nations in front of you so that you can take possession of their lands. And Joshua, here, will cross over ahead of you, just as the Lord has promised.
Deuteronomy 31:4 And the Lord will deal with these nations just as He dealt with Sihon and Og, the kings of the Amorites, and with all of their land, whom He utterly destroyed.
Deuteronomy 31:5 Therefore, when He delivers even these nations to you, you shall do to them just as I have commanded you.
Deuteronomy 31:6 Be strong and take courage! Do not be afraid, nor be terrified by their armies, because the Lord your God Himself is your leader. He will not leave you, nor will He ever abandon you.
Deuteronomy 31:7 Then Moses called Joshua and said to him in the sight of all Israel, 'Be strong and courageous, for you shall bring this people into the land that the Lord swore to their fathers that He would give them, and you shall divide it among them by lot.'
Deuteronomy 31:8 And the Lord, who is your leader, He Himself will go before you. He Himself will accomplish this task, and He will not leave you nor abandon you. Do not be afraid, nor be terrified.
Deuteronomy 31:9 So Moses wrote this entire Law and delivered it to the priests, the sons of Levi, who carried the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord, and to all the elders of Israel.
Deuteronomy 31:10 And he commanded them, saying, 'After every seven years, in the year of remission —the year of release from debts—, during the Feast of Tabernacles,'
Deuteronomy 31:11 'When all of Israel comes to appear before the presence of the Lord your God in the specific place that the Lord will choose, you shall read this entire Law aloud for all of Israel to hear.'
Deuteronomy 31:12 'Gather the people—men, women, children, and the foreigners who live within your towns—so that they may hear and learn to fear the Lord your God, and carefully observe all the words of this Law.'
Deuteronomy 31:13 'And so that their children, who have not yet learned the Law, may hear it and learn to fear the Lord your God all the days you live in the land that you are crossing the Jordan to possess.'
Deuteronomy 31:14 Then the Lord said to Moses, 'Behold, the days of your death are near. Call Joshua, and both of you present yourselves in the Tent of Testimony so that I may give him commands.'
Deuteronomy 31:15 So Moses and Joshua went and presented themselves in the Tent of Testimony.
Deuteronomy 31:16 And the Lord appeared there in a pillar of cloud, which stood over the entrance of the Tent of Testimony.
Deuteronomy 31:17 Then the Lord said to Moses, 'Behold, you are about to die and join your fathers. And this people will then rise up and commit spiritual fornication by chasing after foreign gods in the land they are entering to inhabit. They will abandon Me and break the covenant that I have made with them.'
Deuteronomy 31:18 And My furious anger will be kindled against them on that day. I will abandon them and hide My face from them, and they will become prey. Many evils and afflictions will befall them, so much so that they will say on that day, 'Surely these evils have befallen me because God is not with me.'
Deuteronomy 31:19 Now therefore, write this song for yourselves and teach it to the children of Israel, so that they may remember it and sing it, and so that this song may serve as a witness for Me against the children of Israel.
Deuteronomy 31:20 For when they enter the land that I swore to their fathers—a land flowing with milk and honey—and they eat, become full, and grow prosperous, they will then abandon the Lord their God and break His covenant.
Deuteronomy 31:21 And when such a multitude of evils and afflictions befalls them, then the testimony of this song will serve as a reminder to them. For I truly know their thoughts, which are even now present in their hearts, even before I bring them into the land which I promised to many with an oath.
Deuteronomy 31:22 So Moses wrote down the song and taught it to the children of Israel.
Deuteronomy 31:23 And He —God— commanded Joshua, the son of Nun, and said, 'Be strong and courageous, for you shall bring the children of Israel into the land that I swore to give them, and I will be with you.'
Deuteronomy 31:24 So after Moses finished writing all the words of this Law in a scroll,
Deuteronomy 31:25 he gave a command to the Levites, who carried the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord, saying:
Deuteronomy 31:26 'Take this book of the Law and place it beside the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord your God, so that it may remain there as a witness against you.'
Deuteronomy 31:27 'For I know your obstinacy and your extreme stubbornness. Even while I am still alive with you today, you have always acted rebelliously against the Lord. How much more will you do so when I am dead?'
Deuteronomy 31:28 'Gather to me all the elders of your tribes and your officers, and I will speak these words in their hearing, and I will call the universe and the earth to witness against them.'
Deuteronomy 31:29 'For I know that after my death you will act wickedly and quickly turn aside from the path that I commanded you. And evils will surely befall you in the latter days, because you will do evil in the sight of the Lord and provoke Him to anger through the idols that you have made with your own hands.'
Deuteronomy 31:30 So Moses spoke the words of this song in the hearing of the entire assembly of Israel, and he completed it even to the end.
Deuteronomy 32:1 O you heavens, hear what I am about to say. Let the entire earth listen to the words from My mouth.
Deuteronomy 32:2 May My teaching pour down like the rain, refreshing and abundant. May My words flow gently like the dew. May it be like a heavy shower upon tender plants, and like drops upon the green grass.
Deuteronomy 32:3 For I will proclaim the Name of the Lord. Ascribe greatness to our God!
Deuteronomy 32:4 God's works are perfect, and all His ways are just judgments. He is a faithful God, without any iniquity—He is righteous and upright.
Deuteronomy 32:5 They have sinned against Him, and they are not His pure children, but rather a wicked and perverse generation.
Deuteronomy 32:6 Is this how you repay the Lord, you foolish and unwise people? Is He not your Father, who possesses you, who made you, and who formed you?
Deuteronomy 32:7 Remember the ancient days, consider each past generation. Ask your father, and he will tell you; ask your elders, and they will explain it to you.
Deuteronomy 32:8 When the Most High divided the nations, when He separated the descendants of Adam, He set the boundaries for the peoples according to the number of the children of Israel.
Deuteronomy 32:9 For the Lord's portion is His people: Jacob is the designated portion of His inheritance.
Deuteronomy 32:10 He found him in a deserted land, in a place of horror and vast wilderness. He led him around, and taught him, and guarded him like the pupil of His own eye.
Deuteronomy 32:11 Like an eagle that stirs its young to fly, hovering over them, it spreads its wings, takes them up, and carries them on its shoulders.
Deuteronomy 32:12 The Lord alone was his guide; and there was no foreign god with him.
Deuteronomy 32:13 He established him on the high land, so that he might eat the fruits of the fields, so that he might draw honey from the rock, and oil from the hardest stone.
Deuteronomy 32:14 He provided butter from the herd, and milk from the sheep, with the fat of lambs and rams of Bashan, and goats, with the finest wheat. And he drank the pure blood of the grape, the most unmixed wine.
Deuteronomy 32:15 But the Beloved grew fat and kicked back against Him. He grew fat, became plump, and became broad. He abandoned God, his Maker, and departed from God, his Savior.
Deuteronomy 32:16 They provoked Him to jealousy with foreign gods, and they stirred Him to anger with their abominations.
Deuteronomy 32:17 They sacrificed to demons, and not to God—to gods they did not know. They were new, recently introduced gods, whom their fathers had not worshipped.
Deuteronomy 32:18 You have forsaken God who begot you, and you have forgotten the Lord, your Creator.
Deuteronomy 32:19 The Lord saw this, and He was provoked to anger, because His sons and His daughters provoked Him.
Deuteronomy 32:20 And He said: 'I will hide My face from them, and I will see what their end will be. For they are a perverse generation, and children who are unfaithful.'
Deuteronomy 32:21 They provoked Me with what was not God, and they roused Me to anger with their worthless idols. So I will provoke them with what is not a people, and I will irritate them with a foolish nation.
Deuteronomy 32:22 For a fire has been kindled by My wrath, and it will burn to the lowest depths of hell itself. It will devour the earth with its harvest, and consume the very foundations of the mountains.
Deuteronomy 32:23 I will heap evils upon them, and I will exhaust My arrows against them.
Deuteronomy 32:24 They will be consumed by hunger, and the birds of prey will devour them with the bitterest bite. I will send against them the teeth of wild beasts, with the fury of creeping things that crawl upon the earth.
Deuteronomy 32:25 Outside, the sword will bring desolation, and inside, terror. Both young men and virgins, infants and old men alike, will perish.
Deuteronomy 32:26 And I said: 'Where is their offspring? I will cause their memory to cease from among men.'
Deuteronomy 32:27 But I postponed it because of the wrath of their enemies, lest their foes become arrogant and say: 'Our hand is mighty, and it was not the Lord who did all these things.'
Deuteronomy 32:28 For they are a nation without counsel and without understanding.
Deuteronomy 32:29 Oh, that they were wise, that they understood, and that they would foresee their latter end!
Deuteronomy 32:30 How could one man pursue a thousand, and two put ten thousand to flight, unless their God had sold them off, and the Lord had shut them up?
Deuteronomy 32:31 For their god is not like our God—even our enemies judge this to be true.
Deuteronomy 32:32 Their vine comes from the vine of Sodom and from the fields of Gomorrah. Their grapes are grapes of gall, and their clusters are most bitter.
Deuteronomy 32:33 Their wine is the venom of dragons, and the incurable poison of asps.
Deuteronomy 32:34 Are not these things stored up with Me, and sealed in My treasuries?
Deuteronomy 32:35 Vengeance belongs to Me, and I will repay them in due time, when their foot slips. The day of their destruction is near, and their appointed times hasten to come.
Deuteronomy 32:36 For the Lord will judge His people, and He will have compassion on His servants. He will see that their power is weakened, and that those who were imprisoned have failed, and that the remaining ones have been consumed.
Deuteronomy 32:37 And He will say: 'Where are their gods, in whom they placed their trust?'
Deuteronomy 32:38 'Those who ate the fat of their sacrifices and drank the wine of their libations, let them arise and help you! Let them protect you in your time of need!'
Deuteronomy 32:39 See now that I alone am He, and there is no other God besides Me. I kill, and I make alive. I strike, and I heal. There is no one who can deliver out of My hand.
Deuteronomy 32:40 I will lift My hand to the heavens and declare: 'As I live forever!'
Deuteronomy 32:1 Listen, you created universe, to what I speak. Let the earth hear the words that come from My mouth.
Deuteronomy 32:2 Let My teaching be absorbed like gentle rain, and My words distill like dew, like showers upon the tender grass, and like drops upon the growing plants.
Deuteronomy 32:3 For I will proclaim the name of the Lord God. Therefore, give all glory and majesty to our God!
Deuteronomy 32:4 All of God’s works are perfect, and all of His ways are just. God is faithful and without any evil; He is righteous and upright.
Deuteronomy 32:5 They have sinned against Him, and are not truly His children, but instead are stained by their perversity: a generation that is crooked and twisted.
Deuteronomy 32:6 Is this how you repay the Lord, you foolish and unwise people? Is He not your Father, who possesses you, and made you, and created you into existence?
Deuteronomy 32:7 Remember the days of old. Consider each generation, one after another. Ask your father, and he will tell you. Ask your elders, and they will explain it to you.
Deuteronomy 32:8 When the Most High God divided the nations, when He separated the children of Adam, He established the boundaries of the peoples according to the number of the children of Israel.
Deuteronomy 32:9 For the Lord’s portion is His people; Jacob is the measuring line of His inheritance.
Deuteronomy 32:10 He found them in a desert land, in a place of terrifying emptiness and vast desolation. He surrounded them and taught them, and He guarded them as the apple of His eye.
Deuteronomy 32:11 Like an eagle stirring up its nest, teaching its young to fly, hovering over them, it spreads its wings, takes them up, and carries them on its shoulders.
Deuteronomy 32:12 The Lord alone was their leader, and there was no foreign god with them.
Deuteronomy 32:13 He set them on the high places of the earth so that they might eat the produce of the fields, and that they might suck honey from the rock, and oil from the hardest stone.
Deuteronomy 32:14 He gave them butter from the herd, and milk from the sheep, with the fat of lambs and rams from Bashan, and goats, with the finest wheat marrow. They drank the purest blood of the grape, which is wine.
Deuteronomy 32:15 But My beloved Israel grew fat and kicked against Me! Having grown fat, being well-fed, and expanding in prosperity, they abandoned God their Maker and turned away from God their Savior.
Deuteronomy 32:16 They provoked Him to jealousy with foreign gods, and they stirred Him to anger with their abominations.
Deuteronomy 32:17 They sacrificed to demons, not to God—to gods they did not know, newly arrived ones, recently come into being, whom their fathers had not worshipped.
Deuteronomy 32:18 You forgot God, who gave birth to you; you forgot the Lord, your Creator.
Deuteronomy 32:19 The Lord saw this, and He was moved to anger, because His sons and daughters provoked Him.
Deuteronomy 32:20 And He said: 'I will hide My face from them, and I will see what their end will be. For they are a perverse generation, and they are unfaithful children.'
Deuteronomy 32:21 They provoked Me to jealousy with that which was not God, and they angered Me with their empty idols. So I will provoke them with a people who are not a people, and I will anger them with a foolish nation.
Deuteronomy 32:22 For a fire has been kindled in My wrath, and it will burn to the lowest depths of hell. It will devour the earth with its harvest, and it will consume the foundations of the mountains.
Deuteronomy 32:23 I will heap evils upon them, and I will exhaust My arrows against them.
Deuteronomy 32:24 They will be consumed by famine, and birds will devour them with the bitterest bite. I will send the teeth of wild beasts among them, with the furious venom of creeping things upon the earth, even serpents.
Deuteronomy 32:25 Outside, the sword will destroy them, and inside, terror will consume them—both young men and virgins, infants with old men.
Deuteronomy 32:26 And I said: 'Where are they now? I will make their memory cease from among humanity.'
Deuteronomy 32:27 But I held back My judgment because of the anger of their enemies, lest the adversaries become arrogant and say: 'Our own powerful hand did all this, and not the Lord.'
Deuteronomy 32:28 For they are a nation without counsel and without understanding.
Deuteronomy 32:29 If only they were wise, and understood, and would consider their latter end!
Deuteronomy 32:30 How could one man pursue a thousand, and two men put ten thousand to flight? Is it not because their God has sold them, and the Lord has delivered them up?
Deuteronomy 32:31 For their gods are not like our God; even our enemies themselves are witnesses of this.
Deuteronomy 32:32 For their vine is from the vine of Sodom and from the fields of Gomorrah. Their grapes are grapes of bitterness, and their clusters are most bitter.
Deuteronomy 32:33 Their wine is the venom of dragons, and the incurable poison of vipers.
Deuteronomy 32:34 Are not these things stored up with Me, and sealed in My treasures?
Deuteronomy 32:35 Vengeance belongs to Me, and I will repay them in due time, when their foot slips. For the day of their destruction is near, and the appointed times are hastening to come.
Deuteronomy 32:36 For the Lord will judge His people, and He will have compassion on His servants when He sees that their power is gone, and that both the imprisoned and the free have vanished and are consumed.
Deuteronomy 32:37 And He will say: 'Where are their gods, in whom they placed their trust?'
Deuteronomy 32:38 Those who ate the fat of their sacrifices and drank the wine of their libations: 'Let them arise and help you, and protect you in your time of need!'
Deuteronomy 32:39 See now that I alone am God, and there is no other God besides Me. I kill, and I make alive. I wound, and I heal. And there is no one who can rescue from My hand.
Deuteronomy 32:40 For I will lift My hand to the created universe and declare: 'As I live forever!'
Deuteronomy 33:1 This is the final blessing that Moses, the man of God, gave to the children of Israel just before his death.
Deuteronomy 33:2 And Moses said: "The Lord God came from Mount Sinai—the place of the Law—and dawned upon us from Mount Seir, and revealed Himself from Mount Paran, bringing with Him thousands of His holy angels.
Deuteronomy 33:3 Truly, He loved His people Israel. All of His holy ones are in His powerful hand, and those who approach Him and follow His ways will receive His divine teaching.
Deuteronomy 33:4 Moses gave us the Law—His divine instruction—as a spiritual inheritance for all the descendants of Jacob.
Deuteronomy 33:5 And there will be a King among the upright people of Israel when the leaders of the tribes gather together.
Deuteronomy 33:6 Moses blessed the tribe of Reuben: "May Reuben live and not perish, even if their numbers remain small among the other tribes."
Deuteronomy 33:7 And this is the blessing for Judah: "Hear, O Lord, the plea of Judah, and bring him back to his people after battle. Let his hands fight powerfully for him, and may You be his helper against all his enemies."
Deuteronomy 33:8 And to Levi, Moses said: "Your spiritual perfection and Your divine teaching belong to Your holy man—the high priest—whom You tested during trials and judged at the waters of Meribah, where the people contended against You."
Deuteronomy 33:9 "The Levites, for Your sake, were willing to disregard their own father and mother, and to disown their own brothers. They did this because they guarded Your holy words and diligently kept Your covenant."
Deuteronomy 33:10 "They will teach Your judgments to Jacob and Your Law to Israel. They will offer incense as a pleasing aroma when Your presence is manifested, and they will offer burnt offerings on Your altar."
Deuteronomy 33:11 "Bless, O Lord, the strength of the tribe of Levi, and accept the sacred works of their hands. Strike down their enemies so they may never rise against them again."
Deuteronomy 33:12 And to Benjamin, Moses said: "The beloved of the Lord shall dwell securely in His presence. He will remain there as in a sacred chamber all the day, and the Lord will rest between his shoulders, protecting him."
Deuteronomy 33:13 And to Joseph, Moses said: "May his land be blessed by the Lord, producing fruit from the heavens—from the rains and the dew—and from the deep waters that lie beneath the earth."
Deuteronomy 33:14 "May his land be blessed with the finest fruits ripened by the sun and the moon, with the choicest produce from the ancient mountains and the fruit of the everlasting hills."
Deuteronomy 33:15 "May the blessing of Him who appeared in the burning bush come upon the head of Joseph, and upon the crown of him who was set apart from his brothers—meaning Jacob's favored son."
Deuteronomy 33:16 "His glory is like the firstborn bull, his horns are like the horns of a wild ox. With them he shall push the nations to the ends of the earth. These are the thousands of Ephraim, and these are the thousands of Manasseh—Joseph's two tribes."
Deuteronomy 33:17 And to Zebulun, Moses said: "Rejoice, Zebulun, as you go out for commerce, and rejoice, Issachar, in your settled dwelling places."
Deuteronomy 33:18 "They will summon peoples to the sacred mountain to offer sacrifices of righteousness there. For they will draw from the abundance of the seas as if it were milk, and discover the hidden treasures buried in the sand—resources from the coast."
Deuteronomy 33:19 And to Gad, Moses said: "Blessed is he who enlarges Gad's territory! He lies down like a lion, ready to seize his prey—both arm and crown—from his enemies."
Deuteronomy 33:20 "He chose his own best portion of land, for there a leader's share was reserved for him. He marched with the chiefs of the people. He executed the Lord God's justice for Israel and His righteous decrees with Him, joining his forces with the thousands of the other tribes."
Deuteronomy 33:21 And to Dan, Moses said: "Dan is a young lion, a lion's cub springing forth from Bashan."
Deuteronomy 33:22 And to Naphtali, Moses said: "Naphtali is abundantly satisfied with the Lord's favor and full of His blessing. He will possess the coastal region to the south."
Deuteronomy 33:23 And to Asher, Moses said: "Blessed be Asher above all sons! May he be favored by his brothers, and may he dip his foot in oil—symbolizing abundant olive oil from his land."
Deuteronomy 33:24 "His shoes will be made of iron and bronze, providing strength. As your days of youth are, so shall your days of old age be—full of vigor and blessing."
Deuteronomy 33:25 There is no God like the God of Israel, who rides across the universe to come to your aid, majestic in His clouds.
Deuteronomy 33:26 His dwelling is in the highest heavens, and His everlasting arms support you from beneath. He drove out your enemy before you and commanded, 'Destroy them!'
Deuteronomy 33:27 So Israel dwelt securely, alone and without fear. The fountain of Jacob—meaning his descendants—lived in a land of grain and new wine, and the skies above watered it with dew.
Deuteronomy 33:28 Blessed are you, O Israel! Who is like you, a people saved by the Lord God? He is the shield of your help and the sword of your glory. Your enemies will deny your power, but you will tread upon their necks.
Deuteronomy 34:1 Moses then went up from the plains of Moab to Mount Nebo, to the top of Pisgah, which is opposite Jericho. The Lord showed him all the land of Gilead as far as Dan,
Deuteronomy 34:2 all of Naphtali, the land of Ephraim and Manasseh, and all the land of Judah, stretching as far as the western sea, which is the Mediterranean.
Deuteronomy 34:3 and the southern region of the land, along with the whole plain of Jericho, known as the city of palm trees, stretching all the way to Zoar.
Deuteronomy 34:4 The Lord then said to him: "This is the land that I swore to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob that I would give to their descendants. You have seen it with your own eyes, but you will not cross over into it."
Deuteronomy 34:5 So Moses, the servant of the Lord, died there in the land of Moab, in obedience to the Lord's command.
Deuteronomy 34:6 And He buried him in a valley in the land of Moab, opposite Beth-peor. No one knows the exact location of his burial place to this very day.
Deuteronomy 34:7 Moses was one hundred and twenty years old when he died. His eyesight had not dimmed, nor had his physical strength diminished.
Deuteronomy 34:8 The children of Israel mourned for him in the plains of Moab for thirty days, and the days of mourning and lamentation for Moses were thus completed.
Deuteronomy 34:9 Joshua, the son of Nun, was filled with the spirit of wisdom because Moses had laid his hands upon him. The children of Israel obeyed him, doing exactly as the Lord had commanded Moses.
Deuteronomy 34:10 And there has not arisen a prophet in Israel since like Moses, whom the Lord knew face to face—meaning, in intimate, direct communication.
Deuteronomy 34:11 This refers to all the miraculous signs and wonders which the Lord sent him to perform in the land of Egypt against Pharaoh, against all his servants, and against all his land.
Deuteronomy 34:12 It also refers to the entire display of God's strong hand and the great and terrible things that Moses performed in the sight of all Israel.
Joshua 1:1 Now, it came to pass that after the death of Moses, the servant of God, God spoke to Joshua, the son of Nun, who had been Moses' assistant, saying:
Joshua 1:2 My servant Moses is dead. Now, you and all the people with you must get up and cross this Jordan River into the land that I am giving to the children of Israel.
Joshua 1:3 Every single place that your foot steps upon, I will give to you, just as I promised Moses.
Joshua 1:4 From the desert and from Lebanon, stretching all the way to the great Euphrates River—all the land of the Hittites, all the way to the Great Sea in the west—that will be your territory's boundary.
Joshua 1:5 No one will be able to stand against you throughout your entire life. Just as I was with Moses, so I will be with you; I will not abandon you, nor will I ever desert you.
Joshua 1:6 Be strong and courageous! For you are the one who will divide by lot this land among this people—the land which I swore to their ancestors I would give to them.
Joshua 1:7 Only be very strong and very courageous! So that you carefully observe and faithfully do everything in the entire Law that My servant Moses commanded you. Do not turn from it, neither to the right nor to the left, so that you may act wisely in everything you do.
Joshua 1:8 Do not let this Book of the Law ever depart from your mouth. Instead, meditate on it day and night, so that you may diligently observe and do everything that is written in it. Then you will make your way prosperous, and you will understand and succeed.
Joshua 1:9 Listen! I am commanding you right now: Be strong and courageous! Do not be afraid, and do not be terrified! Because the Lord your God is with you everywhere you go, no matter what you face.
Joshua 1:10 And Joshua then gave orders to the leaders of the people, saying:
Joshua 1:11 Go through the camp and command the people, saying: 'Prepare your provisions, because after three days, you will cross the Jordan River and go in to take possession of the land which the Lord your God is giving to you.'
Joshua 1:12 Joshua also spoke to the Reubenites, the Gadites, and half the tribe of Manasseh,
Joshua 1:13 Remember the word that Moses, the servant of the Lord, commanded you, saying: 'The Lord your God has given you rest and this entire land.'
Joshua 1:14 Your wives, your children, and your livestock will remain in the land that Moses gave to you beyond the Jordan River. But all of you, every strong, armed man, will cross over ahead of your brothers, fully equipped for battle, and you will help them,
Joshua 1:15 until the Lord gives rest to your brothers, just as He has given it to you, and they themselves take possession of the land that the Lord your God is giving to them. Then you may return to your own land, the land of your inheritance, and settle there, the land which Moses, the servant of the Lord, gave to you beyond the Jordan River, on the east side.
Joshua 1:16 And they responded to Joshua, saying: 'We will do everything that you have commanded us, and wherever you send us, we will go.
Joshua 1:17 Just as we obeyed Moses in everything, so we will also obey you. Only let the Lord your God be with you, just as He was with Moses.
Joshua 1:18 Anyone who rebels against your authority and does not obey all the words that you command him will be put to death. Only you must be strong and act with courage.
Joshua 2:1 So Joshua, the son of Nun, sent two men secretly from Shittim as spies. He commanded them: "Go and observe the land, especially the city of Jericho." The two men departed and entered the house of a harlot named Rahab, and they lodged there.
Joshua 2:2 It was reported to the king of Jericho, with the message: "Look, some men from the children of Israel have entered this place tonight to spy out the land."
Joshua 2:3 So the king of Jericho sent a message to Rahab, saying: "Bring out the men who have entered your house, because they are spies, and they have come to survey all the land."
Joshua 2:4 The woman, however, had taken the men and hidden them. She then spoke this way: "Indeed, men came to me, but I did not know from where they were coming."
Joshua 2:5 When the city gates were about to be closed in the dark, they left. I do not know where they went. Pursue them quickly, and you will surely overtake them.'"
Joshua 2:6 She, however, had made the men go up to the roof of her house and hidden them under stalks of flax.
Joshua 2:7 Indeed, those who had been sent by the king pursued them along the road that leads to the Jordan, all the way to the fords. As soon as the pursuers went out, the city gates were immediately closed.
Joshua 2:8 But before the spies lay down to sleep, Rahab went up to them on the roof and said:
Joshua 2:9 "I know that the Lord God has given you this land, and that your terror has fallen upon us. Indeed, a great fear of you has seized all the inhabitants of these lands."
Joshua 2:10 "We have heard how the Lord dried up the waters of the Red Sea for you when you came out of Egypt. We also heard what you did to the two kings of the Amorites, Sihon and Og, who were on the other side of the Jordan, whom you utterly destroyed."
Joshua 2:11 "And from that moment, no courage has remained within us, because we were terrified by your impending arrival. For the Lord your God, He alone is God in the universe above and on the earth below."
Joshua 2:12 "Now therefore, swear to me by the Lord that just as I have shown kindness to you, so also you will show kindness to my father's household. And give me a sure sign, a true promise,"
Joshua 2:13 "—that you will save my father, my mother, my brothers, my sisters, and all that belongs to them, and that you will deliver our lives from death."
Joshua 2:14 The men answered her: "Our lives for yours, even unto death, if you do not betray this matter of ours. When the Lord delivers this land to us, we will show you kindness and faithfulness."
Joshua 2:15 Then she let them down by a rope through the window, because her house was built into the city wall, and she lived in the wall itself.
Joshua 2:16 And she said to them: "Go to the mountain, so that the men sent to pursue you do not encounter you. Hide there for three days until they have returned. Then, you may go on your way."
Joshua 2:17 The spies said to her: "We will be free from this oath, by which you have bound us, under certain conditions,
Joshua 2:18 —if, when we enter the land, you tie this scarlet thread in the window through which you let us down. You must also gather your father, your mother, your brothers, and all your relatives into your house."
Joshua 2:19 "If anyone goes outside the doors of your house, his blood will be on his own head, and we will be innocent. But if anyone inside the house with you is harmed, their blood will be on our heads."
Joshua 2:20 "However, if you betray this matter of ours, then we will also be free from this oath by which you have made us swear."
Joshua 2:21 She replied: "As you have spoken, so let it be." Then she sent them away, and when they had gone, she tied the scarlet cord in the window.
Joshua 2:22 The men then went to the mountain and remained there for three days, until those who had pursued them returned. For the pursuers searched along all the roads but did not find them.
Joshua 2:23 After three days, the two men returned. They descended from the mountain, crossed the Jordan River, and came to Joshua, the son of Nun. They recounted to him everything that had happened to them,
Joshua 2:24 and said: "The Lord has truly delivered all this land into our hands, for all its inhabitants are trembling in fear because of us."
Joshua 2:1 So Joshua, the son of Nun, secretly sent two men as spies from the region of Settim. He instructed them: “Go, and carefully observe the land, especially the city of Jericho.” So they went and entered the house of a woman who was a harlot, named Rahab, and they stayed there with her.
Joshua 2:2 And it was reported to the king of Jericho that some men from the children of Israel had come there that night to spy out the land.
Joshua 2:3 So the king of Jericho sent a message to Rahab, saying: “Bring out the men who have entered your house, for they are spies who have come to examine the whole land.”
Joshua 2:4 But the woman took the men and hid them. She then spoke: “It is true, some men did come to me, but I did not know where they were from.
Joshua 2:5 When the city gate was about to be shut in the darkness of evening, the men left. I do not know where they went. Pursue them quickly, and you will surely overtake them.”
Joshua 2:6 Now, the woman had actually made the men go up to the roof of her house and had hidden them under stalks of flax that were laid out there.
Joshua 2:7 The king’s men went out after them on the road that leads to the fords of the Jordan River. Immediately after the king’s men left, the city gate was closed.
Joshua 2:8 Before the spies lay down to sleep, Rahab went up to them on the roof and spoke, saying:
Joshua 2:9 “I know that the Lord has given this land over to you, and that our terror has fallen upon you. Indeed, the fear of you has completely disheartened all the inhabitants of this land.
Joshua 2:10 We have heard how the Lord dried up the waters of the Red Sea for you when you came out of Egypt. We also heard what you did to the two kings of the Amorites who were across the Jordan, Sihon and Og, whom you utterly destroyed.
Joshua 2:11 Since no one else is coming into this land, we are terrified and dismayed. Indeed, the fear of you has fallen upon all its inhabitants. For the Lord your God, He is God in the sky above, and on the earth below.
Joshua 2:12 Now therefore, I ask you, swear to me by the Lord, because I have shown mercy to you, that you also will show mercy to my father’s household. Give me a sure sign—
Joshua 2:13 that you will spare my father, my mother, my brothers, my sisters, and all who belong to them, and deliver our lives from death.”
Joshua 2:14 The men answered her: “May our lives be pledged for yours in death, if only you do not betray this agreement of ours. When the Lord delivers this land to us, we will show you mercy and faithfulness.”
Joshua 2:15 So she let them down by a rope through the window, for her house was built into the city wall.
Joshua 2:16 And she said to them: “Go to the mountains, lest those who were sent to capture you might find you. Hide there for three days until they return. After that, you can go on your way.”
Joshua 2:17 The spies then said to her: “We will be released from this oath which you have made us swear,
Joshua 2:18 if, when we enter this land, you tie this scarlet rope in the window through which you let us down, and if you gather your father, your mother, your brothers, and all your relatives into your house.
Joshua 2:19 If anyone from your family ventures outside the doors of your house, his death will be his own responsibility—we will be innocent. However, if we are betrayed by you, then this word of our promise will become null and void.”
Joshua 2:20 And she answered: “May it be as you have spoken.” So she sent them away, and they left. Then she tied the scarlet rope in the window.
Joshua 2:21 So they departed and came to the mountain pass, and they remained there for three days until those who had pursued them returned. The pursuers had searched along every road, but they found nothing.
Joshua 2:22 Then the two men returned. They came down from the mountain, crossed the Jordan River, and came to Joshua, the son of Nun. They recounted to him everything that had happened to them.
Joshua 2:23 They said: “The Lord has indeed delivered all the land into our hands! And all its inhabitants are terrified with fear of us.”
Joshua 2:24 They declared: “The Lord has truly given all the land into our hands, for all its inhabitants are utterly demoralized by the fear of us.”
Joshua 3:1 Joshua rose from sleep during the night and moved the camp from Shittim. He, along with all the children of Israel, came to the Jordan River, and they remained there for three days, waiting to begin their crossing.
Joshua 3:2 After three days, officials went throughout the camp,
Joshua 3:3 and commanded them, saying: 'When you see the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord your God, carried by the priests from the tribe of Levi, you also must get up and follow in their footsteps.'
Joshua 3:4 'But keep a distance of about two thousand cubits (which is roughly half a mile) between yourselves and the Ark. This way you can see it from afar and know by which path you should go, because you have never passed this way before.'
Joshua 3:5 Then Joshua said to the people: 'Sanctify yourselves, for tomorrow the Lord will perform wonders among you.'
Joshua 3:6 And he said to the priests: 'Take up the Ark of the Covenant and go before the people.' So they took it up, as commanded, and carried it.
Joshua 3:7 Then the Lord said to Joshua: 'Today I will begin to exalt you in the sight of all Israel, so that they may know that just as I was with Moses, so I will be with you.'
Joshua 3:8 'You, therefore, command the priests who carry the Ark of the Covenant and tell them: 'When you step into the edge of the water of the Jordan, stand still in the Jordan River.''
Joshua 3:9 Then Joshua said to the children of Israel: 'Come here, and listen to the words of the Lord your God.'
Joshua 3:10 And again he said: 'By this you shall know that the Lord, the living God, is among you, and that He will certainly drive out before you the Canaanites, the Hittites, the Hivites, the Perizzites, the Girgashites, the Amorites, and the Jebusites.'
Joshua 3:11 'Behold, the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord of all the earth will go before you through the Jordan River.'
Joshua 3:12 'Now therefore, choose twelve men from the tribes of Israel, one man from each tribe.'
Joshua 3:13 'And when the feet of the priests who carry the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord of all the earth touch the waters of the Jordan, the waters that flow downstream will be cut off and will fail. But the waters coming down from upstream will stand still, gathering into a single heap.'
Joshua 3:14 So the people left their tents to cross the Jordan, and the priests who carried the Ark of the Covenant went before them.
Joshua 3:15 When they had come as far as the Jordan, and the feet of the priests who carried the Ark were dipped into the very edge of the water (for the Jordan River at that time overflowed all its banks during the season of the wheat harvest),
Joshua 3:16 the waters flowing downstream stood still in one place, rising up like a mountain, far away at the city of Adam, which is on the side of Zaretan. And those waters that flowed further down toward the Dead Sea, which is the Salt Sea, completely drained away.
Joshua 3:17 Meanwhile, the people crossed over opposite Jericho. And the priests who carried the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord stood firmly on dry ground in the middle of the Jordan River, while all the people passed over on the dry riverbed, until everyone had crossed the Jordan.
Joshua 3:18 When everyone had completely crossed over, the Lord spoke to Joshua, saying:
Joshua 3:19 'Choose twelve men, one from each tribe,'
Joshua 3:20 'and command them to take twelve very hard stones from the middle of the Jordan Riverbed, from the very place where the priests' feet stood. You shall place these stones in the location of the camp where you are going to pitch your tents tonight.'
Joshua 3:21 So Joshua called the twelve men whom he had chosen from the children of Israel, one from each tribe,
Joshua 3:22 and he said to them: 'Go before the Ark of the Lord your God to the middle of the Jordan, and each of you take up a stone on your shoulder, according to the number of the tribes of the children of Israel,
Joshua 3:23 'Let this be a sign among you. And when your children ask you tomorrow, saying, 'What do these stones mean?'
Joshua 3:24 'then you shall tell them: 'The waters of the Jordan were cut off before the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord when it crossed over. For this reason these stones are set as a memorial for the children of Israel forever.''
Joshua 3:25 So the children of Israel did just as Joshua commanded. They carried twelve stones from the middle of the Jordan Riverbed, just as the Lord had told him, according to the number of the tribes of the children of Israel, to the place where they had pitched their camp. There they set them down.
Joshua 3:26 Joshua also set up another twelve stones in the middle of the Jordan Riverbed, where the feet of the priests who carried the Ark of the Covenant had stood. And those stones are there to this very day.
