Joshua 21:14 and Jattir, and Eshtemoa, and Holon, and Debir, and Ain, and Juttah, and Beth-Shemesh, each with their pasture lands. That makes nine cities from these two tribes.
Joshua 21:15 From the tribe of Benjamin, they received Gibeon and Geba, Anathoth and Almon, each with their pasture lands. That makes four cities.
Joshua 21:16 All these cities for the sons of Aaron, the priests, totalled thirteen, each with its surrounding pasture lands.
Joshua 21:17 Now for the remaining Levites of the Kohathite families, from the tribe of Ephraim, they gave Shechem—a city of refuge in the mountainous region of Ephraim—along with its pasture lands. Also Gezer with its pasture lands,
Joshua 21:18 and Kibzaim with its pasture lands, and Beth-Horon with its pasture lands. That makes four cities.
Joshua 21:19 From the tribe of Dan, they received Eltekeh, and Gibbethon, and Aijalon, and Gath-Rimmon, each with their pasture lands. That makes four cities.
Joshua 21:20 From the half-tribe of Manasseh, they received Taanach and Gath-Rimmon, each with their pasture lands. That makes two cities.
Joshua 21:21 All these cities, totalling ten with their pasture lands, were given to the other, non-priestly, sons of Kohath.
Joshua 21:22 For the sons of Gershon, from the clan of Levi, from the other half-tribe of Manasseh, they received Bezer—a city of refuge—and Bosra with its pasture lands.
Joshua 21:23 And from the tribe of Issachar, they received Kishion and Daberath, and Jarmuth, and En-Gannim, each with their pasture lands. That makes four cities.
Joshua 21:24 This verse seems to be a slight textual variant of the previous one, listing cities for Issachar. It means: From the tribe of Issachar, they received Kishion, Daberath, Jarmuth, and En-Gannim, each with their pasture lands. That makes four cities.
Joshua 21:25 From the tribe of Asher, they received Mishal, and Abdon, and Helkath, and Rehob, each with their pasture lands. That makes four cities.
Joshua 21:26 From the tribe of Naphtali, they received Kedesh in Galilee—a city of refuge—and Hammoth-Dor, and Kartan, each with their pasture lands. That makes three cities.
Joshua 21:27 All these cities for the sons of Gershon, according to their families, totalled thirteen cities with their pasture lands.
Joshua 21:28 For the sons of Merari, Levites according to their families, from the tribe of Zebulun, they received Jokneam, and Kartah, and Rimmon, and Nahalal, each with their pasture lands. That makes four cities.
Joshua 21:29 From the tribe of Reuben, they received Bezer, and Jahaz, and Kedemoth, and Mephaath, each with their pasture lands. That makes four cities.
Joshua 21:30 From the tribe of Gad, they received Ramoth in Gilead—a city of refuge—and Mahanaim, and Heshbon, and Jazer, each with their pasture lands. That makes four cities.
Joshua 21:31 These are the cities for the sons of Merari according to their clans, totalling twelve cities.
Joshua 21:32 All the cities of the Levites, within the possession of the sons of Israel, amounted to forty-eight cities, each with its surrounding pasture lands.
Joshua 21:33 These were the specific cities, each with their pasture lands all around them.
Joshua 21:34 And the Lord gave them rest on every side, just as he had sworn to their fathers. The children of Israel took possession of the entire land and settled in it.
Joshua 21:35 No enemy dared to resist them; rather, all the surrounding nations were subjected to their rule.
Joshua 21:36 Not one thing failed of all the good promises the Lord had spoken to the house of Israel. Everything was fulfilled.
Joshua 21:37 These are the cities which the Lord gave to the sons of Israel,
Joshua 21:38 according to the division of the four tribes listed above.
Joshua 21:39 And the Lord gave them peace in all their borders, and He removed their enemies from them, just as He had sworn to their fathers.
Joshua 21:40 Everything was fulfilled, just as the Lord had sworn. And the Lord gave them their land.
Joshua 22:1 Then Joshua called the descendants of Reuben, and the descendants of Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh.
Joshua 22:2 And he said to them: "You have done everything that Moses, the servant of the Lord, commanded you. You have also obeyed me in all things.
Joshua 22:3 You have not abandoned your brothers for a very long time, even to this present day, guarding the command of the Lord your God.
Joshua 22:4 Now, therefore, return and go to your homes in the land you possess, which Moses, the servant of the Lord, gave to you across the Jordan River."
Joshua 22:5 "But be careful to diligently keep and completely fulfill the commandment and the law that Moses, the servant of the Lord, commanded you: that you love the Lord your God, and walk in all His ways, and observe His commands, and cling to Him, and serve Him in all worship and in every work."
Joshua 22:6 And Joshua blessed them and sent them away. So they returned to their homes.
Joshua 22:7 Moses had also given a possession in Bashan to half of the tribe of Manasseh. And therefore, to the remaining half-portion, Joshua gave an inheritance among their other brothers on the west side of the Jordan River. When he sent them away to their homes, and had blessed them,
Joshua 22:8 he said to them: "Return to your settlements with much wealth and riches, with silver and gold, bronze and iron, and many garments. Divide the spoil taken from your enemies with your brothers."
Joshua 22:9 So the sons of Reuben, and the sons of Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh returned and departed from the sons of Israel, from Shiloh, which is located in the land of Canaan. They went to enter Gilead, the land of their possession, which they had obtained according to the command of the Lord through Moses.
Joshua 22:10 When they came to the Jordan River banks, in the land of Canaan, they built a very large altar near the Jordan.
Joshua 22:11 And the sons of Israel heard a widely spread report that the sons of Reuben and Gad and the half-tribe of Manasseh had built an altar in the land of Canaan, on the banks of the Jordan, facing the sons of Israel.
Joshua 22:12 And all the sons of Israel gathered at Shiloh, intending to go up and fight against them.
Joshua 22:13 Meanwhile, they sent Phinehas, the son of Eleazar the priest, to the sons of Reuben and Gad and the half-tribe of Manasseh, in the land of Gilead.
Joshua 22:14 And with him were ten princes, one from each of the tribes of Israel, men who were heads of their families.
Joshua 22:15 When they came to the sons of Reuben and Gad and the half-tribe of Manasseh in the land of Gilead, they spoke to them, saying:
Joshua 22:16 "Thus says the entire assembly of the Lord: 'What is this transgression? Why have you abandoned the Lord, the God of Israel, by building a sacrilegious altar, and withdrawing from His worship?'"
Joshua 22:17 "Is it not enough for us that we sinned at Baal-Peor, and the wickedness remains to this present day, and because of this a plague came upon the Lord's people?
Joshua 22:18 And if you today abandon the Lord, tomorrow His wrath will rage against all of Israel."
Joshua 22:19 "But if you think that the land you possess is unclean, cross over to the land where the Lord's Tabernacle is, and live among us. Only do not depart from the Lord and from our fellowship by building an altar other than the altar of the Lord our God.
Joshua 22:20 Did not Achan, the son of Zerah, commit a transgression against the Lord's command, and His wrath fell upon all the people of Israel? And he was just one man, and if only he had perished alone in his wickedness!"
Joshua 22:21 And the sons of Reuben and Gad and the half-tribe of Manasseh answered the princes of Israel's delegation:
Joshua 22:22 "The Lord, the Mighty God! The Lord, the Mighty God! He Himself knows, and Israel, you also understand: if with an intention of transgression or contempt for the Lord we have erected this altar, do not spare us.
Joshua 22:23 Rather, let Him Himself take vengeance on you. And if we did this with the intention of placing burnt offerings and sacrifices and peace offerings upon it, may we be accursed.
Joshua 22:24 But we acted out of concern, fearing this, and considering what your children might say to our children in the future: 'What do you have to do with the Lord, the God of Israel?'
Joshua 22:25 The Lord has placed a boundary between us and you, O sons of Reuben and Gad, the Jordan River. And therefore, you have no part in the Lord.' And thus your children might turn our children away from worshipping the Lord.
Joshua 22:26 For this reason, we said: 'Let us build an altar for ourselves, not for burnt offerings, nor for offering sacrifices,
Joshua 22:27 but as a witness between us and you, and our descendants, that we may serve the Lord and frequently observe His worship with burnt offerings and sacrifices and peace offerings.' This way, your children will never again say to our children: 'You have no share in the Lord.'"
Joshua 22:28 "And if ever they wish to say this, you will answer them: 'Behold the altar of the Lord which our fathers made, not for burnt offerings, nor for sacrifices, but as a witness for us and for you.'"
Joshua 22:29 "Far be it from us to depart from the Lord, and to abandon His worship, by building an altar for offering burnt offerings, and sacrifices, and peace offerings, apart from the altar of the Lord our God, which is established before His Tabernacle."
Joshua 22:30 When they heard this, Phinehas the priest, and the princes of the Israelite delegation who were with him, were appeased.
Joshua 22:31 And Phinehas, the son of Eleazar the priest, said to the Reubenites and Gadites and the half-tribe of Manasseh: "Today we know that the Lord is with us, because you have not followed this counsel of transgression, and you have delivered the sons of Israel from the hand of the Lord."
Joshua 22:32 And Phinehas, the son of Eleazar the priest, and the princes returned from the sons of Reuben and Gad, from the land of Gilead, to the land of Canaan, to the sons of Israel, and reported the words to them.
Joshua 22:33 And the report pleased all who heard it. And they praised God, and no longer attempted to go up against them and fight.
Joshua 22:34 And the sons of Reuben and Gad and the half-tribe of Manasseh built the altar, and they called it "Witness", because it was a witness that the Lord Himself is God.
Joshua 22:1 Then Joshua called for the Reubenites, the Gadites, and half of the tribe of Manasseh,
Joshua 22:2 and said to them: "You have done everything that Moses, the Lord's servant, commanded you; and you have also obeyed me in everything I commanded you.
Joshua 22:3 You have not abandoned your brothers for a long time, even until this very day, carefully observing the commands of the Lord your God.
Joshua 22:4 Now, therefore, return and go to your homes, to the land of your inheritance which Moses, the Lord's servant, gave you beyond the Jordan River.
Joshua 22:5 However, make sure you carefully observe and fulfill the command and the law that Moses, the Lord's servant, commanded you: to love the Lord your God, to walk in all His ways, to keep His commands, and to hold fast to Him, serving Him with all your heart and with all your soul.
Joshua 22:6 Joshua then called them together and blessed them.
Joshua 22:7 And to the two tribes and the half-tribe of Manasseh, Moses had given an inheritance in Bashan. Because of this, Joshua gave the other half of Manasseh their share of the land on the other side of the Jordan River, on the western side.
Joshua 22:8 And when he sent them away and commanded them to go to their homes, he said to them: "Return to your homes with much wealth and riches, with silver and gold and bronze and iron and many garments. Divide the spoils of your plunder with your brothers.
Joshua 22:9 So the sons of Reuben and the sons of Gad and half of the tribe of Manasseh returned and departed from the other sons of Israel, from Shiloh which is in Canaan. They went to enter Gilead, the land of their inheritance, which they had obtained according to the command of the Lord through Moses.
Joshua 22:10 When they came to the Jordan's banks, in the land of Canaan, they built a very large altar by the Jordan.
Joshua 22:11 And the other sons of Israel heard a report, saying: "The sons of Reuben, Gad, and half of the tribe of Manasseh have built an altar opposite the land of Canaan, in the region of the Jordan, facing the other sons of Israel."
Joshua 22:12 When they heard this, all the sons of Israel gathered at Shiloh, intending to go up and fight against them.
Joshua 22:13 However, they first sent Phinehas, the son of Eleazar the priest, to the sons of Reuben, Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh in the land of Gilead.
Joshua 22:14 They also sent ten chiefs with him, one from each tribe, who were heads of their families from all the tribes of Israel.
Joshua 22:15 When these men came to the sons of Reuben, Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh in the land of Gilead, they spoke to them,
Joshua 22:16 saying: "This is what the entire assembly of the Lord commands: 'What is this transgression by which you have violated the command of the Lord God of Israel, building a sacrilegious altar and turning away from His worship?'
Joshua 22:17 Is the sin of Peor not enough for you, for which, even to this present day, a great plague and calamity came upon the Lord's people?
Joshua 22:18 And now you are again abandoning the Lord, so that tomorrow His wrath will be stirred up against all Israel?
Joshua 22:19 If you think the land of your inheritance is unclean, then cross over to the land where the Lord's Tabernacle is, and live among us. Do not build another altar besides the altar of the Lord our God.
Joshua 22:20 Did not Achan, the son of Zerah, violate the Lord's command, and His wrath fell upon all Israel? He was only one man, and would that he alone had perished in his wickedness!"
Joshua 22:21 Then the sons of Reuben, Gad, and half of the tribe of Manasseh answered the chiefs of the Israelite delegation,
Joshua 22:22 saying: "The Lord God knows, and let Israel itself understand: If we built this altar with an intention of transgression or contempt for the Lord, may He not spare us today!
Joshua 22:23 But if we did it with the intention of placing burnt offerings, sacrifices, or peace offerings upon it, may He Himself investigate and judge.
Joshua 22:24 Did we not rather do this with a certain thought and concern, saying: 'Lest perhaps your sons say to our sons tomorrow: What do you have to do with the Lord God of Israel?
Joshua 22:25 The Lord has set the Jordan River as a boundary between us and you, O sons of Reuben and sons of Gad. Therefore, you have no portion in the Lord. And by this occasion, your sons might turn our sons away from fearing the Lord.
Joshua 22:26 Therefore we said: 'Let us build ourselves an altar, not for burnt offerings nor for sacrificing victims,
Joshua 22:27 but as a witness between us and you and our descendants and yours, that we may serve the Lord and fulfill His worship, and that we may continually offer burnt offerings and peace offerings. This is so that your sons may never say to our sons tomorrow: You have no portion in the Lord.'
Joshua 22:28 And if they should desire to say so, our sons will respond to them: 'Behold the altar of the Lord, which our fathers made, not for burnt offering, nor for sacrifice, but as a witness for us and for you.'
Joshua 22:29 Far be this wickedness from us, that we should withdraw from the Lord and abandon His worship, by building an altar for burnt offerings and sacrifices and peace offerings, other than the altar of the Lord our God, which is before His Tabernacle!"
Joshua 22:30 When Phinehas the priest and the chiefs of the Israelite delegation who were with him heard these things, they were appeased. And they understood that the sons of Reuben, Gad, and half of the tribe of Manasseh had not built the altar out of their own design, but out of fear of future generations separating from God.
Joshua 22:31 Then Phinehas, the son of Eleazar the priest, said to them: "Now we know that the Lord is with us, because you are not guilty of this crime, and you have delivered the sons of Israel from the hand of the Lord."
Joshua 22:32 So Phinehas and the chiefs returned from the sons of Reuben and Gad, from the land of Gilead, to the land of Canaan, to the other sons of Israel, and reported their words to them.
Joshua 22:33 The report pleased all who heard it. And the sons of Israel praised God, and they no longer spoke of going up and fighting against them and destroying the land of their inheritance.
Joshua 22:34 And the sons of Reuben and Gad called the altar they had built "Witness," because it was a witness that the Lord Himself is God.
Joshua 23:1 Much later, after the Lord had given Israel a time of peace from all their surrounding enemies, and Joshua had grown old, and his age had advanced significantly,
Joshua 23:2 Joshua called together all of Israel—their elders, their leaders, their judges, and their officers. He then said to them: "I have become old, and my life's journey has advanced and moved forward past my youth.
Joshua 23:3 You yourselves have seen all the Lord your God has done for this nation, and for all the nations around you. You have seen how He Himself fought for you.
Joshua 23:4 Now, because He has divided among you the assigned portions of all these lands, from the Jordan River to the Great Sea (the Mediterranean), and from where the sun rises in the east to where it sets in the west, and has given them to you by lot, just as the Lord your God commanded you,
Joshua 23:5 The Lord your God Himself will drive them out before you. He will overturn them from your path, and you will take possession of their lands, just as He promised you.
Joshua 23:6 Therefore, strengthen yourselves and be careful to keep and perform all that is written in the book of the Law of Moses. Do not deviate from these commands, neither to the right nor to the left.
Joshua 23:7 Do not even mix with these nations that remain among you. Do not mention the names of their false gods, nor swear by them, nor serve them, nor worship them.
Joshua 23:8 Instead, cling steadfastly to the Lord your God, just as you have done up to this present day.
Joshua 23:9 And then, the Lord will drive out before you great and very strong nations. No one will be able to resist you.
Joshua 23:10 One man among you will pursue a thousand men. This will happen because the Lord your God Himself will fight for you, just as He promised.
Joshua 23:11 Just be sure of this: that you love the Lord your God.
Joshua 23:12 But if you choose to turn away and cling to the remnants of these nations that are among you, and join yourselves to them, and intermarry with them,
Joshua 23:13 know for certain that then the Lord your God will not drive them out from before you. Instead, they will become for you a pit and a snare, a stumbling block at your side, and thorns in your eyes, until He removes you and utterly destroys you from this good land that He has given you.
Joshua 23:14 Behold, today I am going the way of all the earth (meaning, I am about to die). And you know in all your heart and in all your soul that not one of all the good promises which the Lord your God spoke concerning you has failed; not one of them has proven void.
Joshua 23:15 But just as all the good things that the Lord your God spoke to you have been fulfilled in deed, both good and evil, so also the Lord will bring upon you every evil He has spoken, until He removes you and utterly destroys you from this good land that He has given you.
Joshua 23:16 When you transgress the covenant of the Lord your God, which He made with you, and you serve foreign gods and worship them, immediately the wrath of the Lord will rise against you. You will then swiftly be removed from this good land that He has given you.
Joshua 24:1 Joshua gathered all the tribes of Israel together in Shechem. He called all the elders, leaders, judges, and officers of the people to come, and they stood before the presence of the Lord.
Joshua 24:2 Then Joshua said to all the people: "Thus says the Lord, the God of Israel: 'Your ancestors, including Terah, the father of Abraham and Nahor, lived across the Euphrates River from the very beginning, and they worshipped false gods.
Joshua 24:3 But I took your father Abraham from the region of Mesopotamia and led him into the land of Canaan. I gave him many descendants, and I gave him Isaac.
Joshua 24:4 To Isaac I gave Jacob and Esau. I gave Esau the land of Mount Seir to possess as his own, but Jacob and his sons eventually went down into Egypt.
Joshua 24:5 Then I sent Moses and Aaron, and I punished Egypt with many miraculous signs and wonders.
Joshua 24:6 And I brought you and your fathers out of Egypt, and you arrived at the sea. The Egyptians pursued your fathers with chariots and cavalry all the way to the Red Sea.
Joshua 24:7 You cried out to the Lord, and He placed a thick darkness between you and the Egyptians. Then He brought the sea over them and drowned them. Your own eyes saw what I did in Egypt. Afterwards, you lived in the wilderness for a very long time.
Joshua 24:8 Then I brought you into the land of the Amorites, who lived on the other side of the Jordan River. When they fought against you, I gave them into your hands, and you took possession of their land and utterly destroyed them.
Joshua 24:9 Then Balak, the son of Zippor, king of Moab, rose up and fought against Israel. He sent for and summoned Balaam, the son of Beor, to put a curse on you.
Joshua 24:10 But I refused to listen to Balaam. Instead, I used him to bless you, and so I delivered you from Balak's power.
Joshua 24:11 Then you crossed the Jordan River and came to Jericho. The men of Jericho fought against you, along with the Amorites, Perizzites, Canaanites, Hittites, Girgashites, Jebusites, and Hivites. But I delivered them into your hands.
Joshua 24:12 I sent the hornets before you, and they drove out the two kings of the Amorites from their lands—not by your own sword, nor by your bow.
Joshua 24:13 I gave you a land for which you had not labored, and cities that you had not built, so that you might live in them. I also gave you vineyards and olive groves that you did not plant.
Joshua 24:14 Now therefore, fear the Lord and serve Him with an undivided and most sincere heart. Cast away from among you the false gods that your fathers served in Mesopotamia and in Egypt, and serve the Lord only.
Joshua 24:15 But if it seems wrong to you to serve the Lord, then choose for yourselves today whom you will serve instead: either the gods that your fathers served in Mesopotamia, or the gods of the Amorites, in whose land you are now living. But as for me and my household, we will serve the Lord.
Joshua 24:16 Then the people answered and said: "It is unthinkable for us to abandon the Lord and serve other gods!
Joshua 24:17 For the Lord our God is the one who brought us and our fathers out of the land of Egypt, from the house of slavery. He performed mighty signs before our very eyes and preserved us throughout all the journey we undertook, and among all the peoples through whom we passed.
Joshua 24:18 He also drove out all the nations from before us, even the Amorites who lived in the land that we were entering. Therefore, we too will serve the Lord, for He alone is our God."
Joshua 24:19 Then Joshua said to the people: "You will not be able to serve the Lord truly, because He is a holy God, a strong God, and a jealous God. He will not overlook your wicked deeds or your sins.
Joshua 24:20 If you abandon the Lord and serve foreign gods, He will turn against you, bring disaster upon you, and utterly destroy you, even after all the good He has done for you."
Joshua 24:21 But the people said to Joshua, "No! We will certainly serve the Lord!"
Joshua 24:22 Joshua then said to the people, "You yourselves are witnesses against yourselves that you have chosen the Lord to serve Him." And they answered, "We are witnesses."
Joshua 24:23 Then Joshua said, "Now, therefore, remove the foreign gods that are among you, and turn your hearts fully to the Lord, the God of Israel."
Joshua 24:24 The people said to Joshua, "We will serve the Lord our God, and we will obey His voice."
Joshua 24:25 So Joshua made a covenant with the people on that day, and he laid out statutes and ordinances for them in Shechem.
Joshua 24:26 Joshua wrote all these words in the book of the Law of the Lord. Then he took a very large stone and set it up there under the oak tree that was by the sanctuary of the Lord.
Joshua 24:27 And he said to all the people: "Look, this stone will be a witness against you, for it has heard all the words that the Lord spoke to us. It will stand as a reminder, lest you later deny and lie to the Lord your God."
Joshua 24:28 So Joshua sent the people away, each person to their own inherited land.
Joshua 24:29 After these events, Joshua, the son of Nun, the servant of the Lord, died at the age of one hundred and ten years.
Joshua 24:30 They buried him within the borders of his own inherited land at Timnath-serah, which had been given to him in the hill country of Ephraim, on the north side of Mount Gaash.
Joshua 24:31 Israel served the Lord throughout all the days of Joshua, and throughout all the days of the elders who outlived Joshua and who had known all the great works that the Lord had done for Israel.
Joshua 24:32 The bones of Joseph, which the children of Israel had carried up from Egypt, they buried in Shechem, in the portion of the field that Jacob had bought from the sons of Hamor, the father of Shechem, for one hundred young lambs. This place became the possession of the descendants of Joseph.
Joshua 24:33 Eleazar also, the son of Aaron, died. They buried him in Gibeah, the town of his son Phinehas, which had been given to him in the hill country of Ephraim.
Joshua 24:1 Joshua gathered all the tribes of Israel together in Shechem, and he called all their elders, their leaders, their judges, and their officers to assemble. And they presented themselves before the presence of the Lord.
Joshua 24:2 Then Joshua spoke to all the people, saying, 'Thus says the Lord, the God of Israel: 'Your ancestors lived beyond the River Euphrates from the earliest times. This included Terah, the father of Abraham and Nahor. And they served other gods there.''
Joshua 24:3 So I took your ancestor Abraham from the land of Mesopotamia and brought him into the land of Canaan. I gave him many descendants, and I gave him Isaac.
Joshua 24:4 And to Isaac I gave Jacob and Esau. To Esau I gave Mount Seir to possess as his own, but Jacob and his sons went down into Egypt.
Joshua 24:5 Then I sent Moses and Aaron, and I struck Egypt with many miraculous signs and wonders, just as it is written. And I led you and your ancestors out of Egypt.
Joshua 24:6 And you came to the sea. The Egyptians pursued your ancestors with chariots and horsemen all the way to the Red Sea.
Joshua 24:7 Then your ancestors cried out to the Lord. He put darkness between you and the Egyptians, and He brought the sea over them and drowned them. Your own eyes saw what I did in Egypt, and you lived in the wilderness for a long time.
Joshua 24:8 Then I brought you into the land of the Amorites, who lived beyond the Jordan River. When they fought against you, I handed them over into your power, and you took possession of their land, and I destroyed them before you.
Joshua 24:9 Then Balak, the son of Zippor, who was the king of Moab, arose and fought against Israel. He sent for and summoned Balaam, the son of Beor, so that he might curse you.
Joshua 24:10 But I would not listen to Balaam. Instead, I blessed you completely, and I delivered you from his hand.
Joshua 24:11 Then you crossed the Jordan River and came to Jericho. The men of Jericho fought against you, as did the Amorites, the Perizzites, the Canaanites, the Hittites, the Girgashites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites. But I delivered them into your power.
Joshua 24:12 I sent hornets before you, and they drove out the two kings of the Amorites from their places, not by your sword or by your bow.
Joshua 24:13 And I gave you a land for which you had not toiled, and cities that you had not built, so that you might live in them. And I gave you vineyards and olive groves that you did not plant, from which you now eat.
Joshua 24:14 Now, therefore, fear the Lord and serve Him with a perfect heart and with truth. Remove the gods whom your ancestors served in Mesopotamia and in Egypt, and serve the Lord alone.
Joshua 24:15 But if it seems evil to you to serve the Lord, then choose for yourselves today whom you wish to serve. Will it be the gods whom your ancestors served in Mesopotamia, or the gods of the Amorites in whose land you now live? As for me and my household, we will serve the Lord.
Joshua 24:16 And the people answered and said: 'Far be it from us that we should abandon the Lord and serve foreign gods!'
Joshua 24:17 For the Lord our God is He who brought us and our ancestors out of the land of Egypt, out of the house of slavery. He performed great signs before our eyes and protected us on every road by which we traveled and among all the peoples through whom we passed.
Joshua 24:18 And He drove out all the nations, including the Amorites, the inhabitants of the land into which we entered. Therefore, we also will serve the Lord, because He Himself is our God.
Joshua 24:19 Then Joshua said to the people: 'You will not be able to serve the Lord, for He is a holy God, and a strong, jealous God. He will not forgive your wicked deeds and your sins.'
Joshua 24:20 If you forsake the Lord and serve foreign gods, He will turn against you and afflict you. He will utterly destroy you, after He has done so much good for you.
Joshua 24:21 But the people said to Joshua: 'By no means! We will indeed serve the Lord!'
Joshua 24:22 And Joshua said to the people: 'You yourselves are witnesses that you have chosen the Lord for yourselves, to serve Him.' And they responded: 'We are witnesses!'
Joshua 24:23 Now, therefore, he said, 'Remove the foreign gods that are among you, and turn your hearts towards the Lord, the God of Israel.'
Joshua 24:24 And the people said to Joshua: 'We will serve the Lord our God, and we will obey His voice.'
Joshua 24:25 So on that day, Joshua made a covenant with the people and established for them statutes and ordinances in Shechem.
Joshua 24:26 And he wrote all these words in the book of the Law of the Lord. He also took a large stone and set it up there under the oak tree that was in the sanctuary of the Lord.
Joshua 24:27 And he said to all the people: 'Behold, this very stone will be a witness against you. For it has heard all the words of the Lord which He has spoken to you. Therefore, do not deny Him afterwards and lie to the Lord your God.'
Joshua 24:28 Then Joshua sent the people away, each to his own inheritance.
Joshua 24:29 After these events, Joshua, the son of Nun, the servant of the Lord, died, being one hundred and ten years old.
Joshua 24:30 And they buried him within the boundaries of his own inherited land in Timnath-serah, which is in the hill country of Ephraim, on the north side of Mount Gaash.
Joshua 24:31 And Israel served the Lord throughout all the days of Joshua, and during the days of the elders who lived for a long time after Joshua, and who had known all the works of the Lord that He had done for Israel.
Joshua 24:32 Also, the bones of Joseph, which the children of Israel had brought up from Egypt, they buried in Shechem, in the portion of land that Jacob had purchased from the sons of Hamor, the father of Shechem, for a hundred pieces of silver. And it became the inheritance of the sons of Joseph.
Joshua 24:33 Eleazar, the son of Aaron, also died. And they buried him in Gibeah of Phinehas, his son, which had been given to him in the hill country of Ephraim.
Judges 1:1 After the death of Joshua, the sons of Israel consulted the Lord, asking: 'Who among us will go up first against the Canaanites, and be the leader of the war?'
Judges 1:2 And the Lord said: 'Judah will go up; behold, I have given the land into his power.'
Judges 1:3 And Judah said to Simeon, his brother: 'Come with me into my allotted territory, and fight against the Canaanites, so that I also may go with you into your allotted territory and help you.' And Simeon went with him.
Judges 1:4 So Judah went up, and the Lord gave the Canaanites and the Perizzites into their power. And they struck down ten thousand men in Bezek.
Judges 1:5 And they found Adoni-Bezek in Bezek, and fought against him, and struck down the Canaanites and the Perizzites who were with him.
Judges 1:6 But Adoni-Bezek fled, and they pursued him and captured him. They then cut off the tips of his hands and his feet.
Judges 1:7 And Adoni-Bezek said: 'Seventy kings, with the tips of their hands and feet cut off, gathered the scraps of food under my table. As I have done to them, so God has now repaid me.' Then they brought him to Jerusalem, and he died there.
Judges 1:8 The sons of Judah then attacked Jerusalem and captured it. They put to the sword all they found in it, and then burned the city walls with fire.
Judges 1:9 And after these things, they went down to fight against the Canaanites who lived in the mountainous region, and to the south, and in the lowlands.
Judges 1:10 Judah then went against the Canaanites who lived in Hebron (which was anciently called Kirjath-Arba), and struck down Sheshai, and Ahiman, and Talmai.
Judges 1:11 And from there he proceeded to the inhabitants of Debir, whose ancient name was Kirjath-Sepher, which means 'the city of books'.
Judges 1:12 And Caleb said: 'Whoever strikes down Kirjath-Sepher and captures it, I will give him Achsah, my daughter, as his wife.'
Judges 1:13 And Othniel, the son of Kenaz, Caleb's younger brother, captured it. So Caleb gave him Achsah, his daughter, as his wife.
Judges 1:14 As she went with Othniel, she urged her husband to ask her father for a field. She then dismounted from her donkey with a sigh of desire. And Caleb asked her: 'What do you want?'
Judges 1:15 And she replied: 'Give me a special gift. You have given me dry land; now also grant me springs of water.' So Caleb gave her the upper spring and the lower spring.
Judges 1:16 Now the children of the Kenite, Moses' relative by marriage, went up from the City of Palms (Jericho) with the sons of Judah into the Wilderness of Judah, which is to the south of Arad, and they lived there with them.
Judges 1:17 Then Judah went with Simeon, his brother, and they struck down the Canaanites who lived in Zephath, and utterly destroyed them. So the name of the city was called Hormah.
Judges 1:18 Judah also captured Gaza with its territory, and Ashkelon with its territory, and Ekron with its territory.
Judges 1:19 And the Lord was with Judah, and they drove out the inhabitants of the mountainous region. But they could not drive out the inhabitants of the valleys, because those had many iron chariots with scythes.
Judges 1:20 And they gave Hebron to Caleb, just as Moses had said, and from there he drove out the three sons of Anak.
Judges 1:21 But the sons of Benjamin did not drive out the Jebusites who inhabited Jerusalem, so the Jebusites have lived with the sons of Benjamin in Jerusalem until the present day.
Judges 1:22 The house of Joseph also went up against Bethel, and the Lord was with them.
Judges 1:23 For when they were besieging the city that was called Luzah (whose name in ancient times was Bethel),
Judges 1:24 they saw a man coming out of the city, and they urged him, saying: 'Show us the entrance to the city, and we will show you mercy.'
Judges 1:25 And when he showed them, they struck down the city with the edge of the sword. But they let that man and all his relatives go free.
Judges 1:26 That man then went to the land of the Hittites and built a city there, and called its name Luzah. That is its name to this present day.
Judges 1:27 Manasseh also did not drive out the inhabitants of Beth-Shean and Taanach with their surrounding villages, nor the inhabitants of Dor, Ibleam, and Megiddo with their surrounding villages. So the Canaanites began to live among them.
Judges 1:28 But after Israel became strong, they made the Canaanites subject to tribute, and were unwilling to drive them out completely.
Judges 1:29 Ephraim also did not kill the Canaanites who lived in Gezer, so the Canaanites lived among them in Gezer.
Judges 1:30 Zebulun did not drive out the inhabitants of Kitron and Nahalol. Instead, the Canaanites lived among them and became subject to tribute.
Judges 1:31 Asher also did not drive out the inhabitants of Acco, nor of Sidon, Ahlab, Achzib, Helbah, Aphik, or Rehob.
Judges 1:32 So they lived among the Canaanites, the inhabitants of the land, and did not subdue them.
Judges 1:33 Naphtali also did not drive out the inhabitants of Beth-Shemesh and Beth-Anath. So they lived among the Canaanites, the inhabitants of the land, and the inhabitants of Beth-Shemesh and Beth-Anath became subject to tribute to them.
Judges 1:34 And the Amorites confined the sons of Dan to the mountainous region and did not allow them to come down to the plains.
Judges 1:35 And the Amorites lived in Mount Heres (which means 'clay-mountain' or 'sun-mountain'), in Aijalon, and Shaalbim. But the power of the house of Joseph was strong enough, so they became subject to tribute to them.
Judges 1:36 Now the territory of the Amorites extended from the Ascent of Akrabbim (Scorpion Pass), from Sela (Petra), and the higher places above it.
Judges 1:1 After Joshua died, the children of Israel asked the Lord, saying: "Who among us should go up first against the Canaanites, and lead us in this war?"
Judges 1:2 And the Lord replied: "The tribe of Judah will go up first. Understand this: I have already given this land into their power."
Judges 1:3 So the tribe of Judah said to the tribe of Simeon, their kinsman: "Come with me into the territory that was allotted to my tribe, and let us fight against the Canaanites there. In return, I will also go with you into the territory allotted to your tribe." And the tribe of Simeon went with them.
Judges 1:4 So the tribe of Judah went into battle, and the Lord delivered the Canaanites and the Perizzites into their power. They struck down ten thousand men at a place called Bezek.
Judges 1:5 They found the king of Bezek, Adonibezek, in the city of Bezek and fought against him, striking down the Canaanites and Perizzites.
Judges 1:6 Adonibezek fled, but they pursued and captured him. Then they cut off the thumbs of his hands and the great toes of his feet.
Judges 1:7 Adonibezek then said: "Seventy kings, whom I had mutilated by cutting off their thumbs and great toes, used to gather the scraps from under my table. As I have done to them, so God has now done to me." They brought him to Jerusalem, and he died there.
Judges 1:8 After this, the sons of Judah attacked Jerusalem. They captured it, put everyone they found in it to the sword, and burned the entire city with fire.
Judges 1:9 After taking Jerusalem, they went down to fight against the Canaanites who lived in the mountainous regions, the southern lands, and the plains.
Judges 1:10 The tribe of Judah went against the Canaanites who lived in Hebron. (Hebron was formerly called Kirjath-Arba, meaning 'the city of Arba, the father of the giants.') There, they struck down Sheshai, Ahiman, and Talmai—three of the Anakim, who were giants.
Judges 1:11 From there, they went against the inhabitants of Debir, whose old name was Kirjath-Sepher, which means "the city of books" or "the city of letters."
Judges 1:12 Then Caleb said: "Whoever attacks Kirjath-Sepher and captures it, to that man I will give Achsah, my daughter, to be his wife."
Judges 1:13 And so Othniel, the son of Kenaz (who was Caleb's younger brother, and thus Othniel's uncle), attacked and captured it. In fulfillment of his promise, Caleb gave him Achsah, his daughter, as his wife.
Judges 1:14 As she was being led away to her husband, Achsah urged Othniel to ask her father for a field. Then, as she sat on her donkey, she sighed, perhaps in expectation or anxiety. Caleb asked her, "What is it you want?"
Judges 1:15 But she replied: "Please give me a special gift, a blessing for my inheritance. You have given me land in the arid south. Now, please add also some watered land." So Caleb gave her both the upper and lower springs of water.
Judges 1:16 Now, the descendants of the Kenite, who were relatives of Moses (from his father-in-law Jethro's lineage), had gone up from Jericho, "the City of Palm Trees." They went with the sons of Judah into the desert region, south of Arad, and settled there among them.
Judges 1:17 So the tribe of Judah then went with the tribe of Simeon, their kinsman, and they struck down the Canaanites who lived in Zephath. They utterly destroyed the city and its inhabitants, and the city was then called Hormah, meaning "destruction."
Judges 1:18 The tribe of Judah passed through Gaza, Ashkelon, and Ekron, as well as their surrounding territories. (This implies they didn't fully conquer and hold these Philistine strongholds).
Judges 1:19 The Lord was with the tribe of Judah, and they conquered the inhabitants of the mountainous regions. However, they were unable to drive out the inhabitants of the valleys, because those people were equipped with chariots made of iron.
Judges 1:20 They gave Hebron to Caleb, just as Moses had promised, and Caleb successfully drove out from there the three sons of Anak.
Judges 1:21 However, the sons of Benjamin did not drive out the Jebusite inhabitants of Jerusalem. So, the Jebusites continued to live alongside the sons of Benjamin in Jerusalem, right up to the time this account was written.
Judges 1:22 The tribes descended from Joseph (Ephraim and Manasseh) also went up to attack Bethel, and the Lord was with them.
Judges 1:23 They sent spies to reconnoiter the city, which had previously been called Luz.
Judges 1:24 The spies saw a man leaving the city and said to him: "Show us how to enter the city, and we will show you mercy."
Judges 1:25 When he showed them an entrance, they attacked the city and put all its inhabitants to the sword. But they allowed that man and his entire family to depart unharmed.
Judges 1:26 That man went to the land of the Hittites, where he built a city and called it Luz. That has remained its name even to the present day.
Judges 1:27 But the tribe of Manasseh did not drive out the inhabitants of Beth-Shan, Taanach, Dor, Ibleam, or Megiddo, nor the inhabitants of their surrounding villages. Instead, the Canaanites continued to live among them in those places.
Judges 1:28 When the people of Israel grew stronger, they indeed subjected the Canaanites to forced labor and tribute. However, they were unwilling to completely drive them out as God had commanded.
Judges 1:29 Likewise, the tribe of Ephraim did not drive out the Canaanites who lived in Gezer, so the Canaanites continued to live alongside them in Gezer.
Judges 1:30 The tribe of Zebulun did not drive out the inhabitants of Kitron or Nahalol. Instead, the Canaanites lived among them and became forced laborers.
Judges 1:31 The tribe of Asher did not drive out the inhabitants of Acco, Sidon, Ahlab, Achzib, Helbah, Aphik, or Rehob.
Judges 1:32 So the Asherites lived among the Canaanite inhabitants of the land, failing to drive them out.
Judges 1:33 Naphtali also did not drive out the inhabitants of Beth-Shemesh or Beth-Anath. Instead, they lived among the Canaanite inhabitants of the land, and the people of Beth-Shemesh and Beth-Anath became their forced laborers.
Judges 1:34 The Amorites, however, confined the sons of Dan to the mountainous regions, not allowing them to come down into the plains.
Judges 1:35 The Amorites remained in Mount Heres (which means "Mount of Pottery"), in Aijalon, and in Shaalbim. However, the influence and power of the House of Joseph eventually grew stronger, and they forced these Amorites to become their tribute-paying laborers.
Judges 1:36 The boundary of the Amorites extended from the Ascent of Akrabbim, continuing through Sela and beyond. (This indicates the southern extent of their power or where the Israelites contained them).
Judges 2:1 And the Angel of the Lord went up from Gilgal to the place of weeping, and He said: 'I led you out of Egypt and brought you into the land that I swore to give to your fathers. And I promised that I would never break My covenant with you, for all time;'
Judges 2:2 'provided only that you would not make a covenant with the inhabitants of this land, but instead, you were to tear down their altars. Yet you refused to obey My voice. Why did you do this?'
Judges 2:3 Therefore, I also refused to drive them out from before you. Instead, they will be a snare to you, and their gods will become a stumbling block for you.'
Judges 2:4 And when the Angel of the Lord spoke all these words to all the sons of Israel, they raised their voices and wept aloud.
Judges 2:5 And they called the name of that place 'The Place of Weepers', and there they offered sacrifices to the Lord.
Judges 2:6 Therefore, Joshua dismissed the sons of Israel, and each man went to his own allotted land to take possession of it.
Judges 2:7 And the people served the Lord all the days that Joshua lived, and all the days of the elders who continued to live long after Joshua, and who had seen all the powerful works that the Lord had done for Israel.
Judges 2:8 But Joshua, the son of Nun, the servant of the Lord, died when he was one hundred and ten years old.
Judges 2:9 And they buried him within the borders of his allotted territory, in Timnath-Serah, in the hill country of Ephraim, on the north side of Mount Gaash.
Judges 2:10 And all that generation was gathered to their fathers through death. Then another people arose after them, who did not know the Lord, nor the powerful works that He had done for Israel.
Judges 2:11 And the sons of Israel did evil in the sight of the Lord, and they began to serve the Baals.
Judges 2:12 And they abandoned the Lord, the God of their fathers, who had led them out of the land of Egypt. They followed after foreign gods, choosing from among the gods of the peoples who lived around them, and they worshipped these false gods. In doing so, they provoked the Lord to anger.
Judges 2:13 And they abandoned the Lord and served Baal and the Astartes.
Judges 2:14 And the Lord, being angry with Israel, handed them over to plunderers, who stole from them. He sold them into the hands of their enemies who lived around them, and they were no longer able to resist their adversaries.
Judges 2:15 But wherever they wanted to go, the hand of the Lord turned against them, just as He had spoken and sworn to them. And they were greatly afflicted and suffered severely.
Judges 2:16 Then the Lord raised up judges, who delivered them from the hands of their devastators.
Judges 2:17 But they refused to listen even to the judges. Instead, they prostituted themselves with foreign gods and worshipped them. They quickly abandoned the way that their fathers had walked, and though they heard the commands of the Lord, they did everything contrary to them.
Judges 2:18 And when the Lord raised up judges, during the days of these judges, the Lord was moved to pity because of the groans of those who were oppressed and afflicted by their tormentors.
Judges 2:19 But after the death of a judge, they again returned to their evil ways and did things much worse than their fathers had done, following foreign gods, serving them, and worshipping them. They did not abandon their corrupt practices, nor the stubborn path in which they had grown accustomed to walk.
Judges 2:20 And the wrath of the Lord burned against Israel, and He said: 'Because this nation has transgressed My covenant, which I commanded their fathers, and they refused to obey My voice;'
Judges 2:21 'I also will no longer drive out from before them any of the nations that Joshua left remaining, not having caused them to perish completely;'
Judges 2:22 'so that through them I may test Israel, to see whether they will keep the way of the Lord and walk in it, as their fathers did, or not.'
Judges 2:23 Therefore, the Lord allowed all these nations to remain. He did not immediately drive them out, nor did He deliver them into the hand of Joshua.
Judges 2:1 And the Angel of the Lord came up from Gilgal to 'The Place of Weeping', and He declared: "I brought you out of Egypt and led you into the land which I swore to your fathers, and I promised that I would never make My covenant with you void forever:"
Judges 2:2 "However, you were not to make a treaty with the inhabitants of this land, but you were to tear down their altars. Yet you refused to listen to My voice. Why have you done this?"
Judges 2:3 "Therefore, I also decided not to drive them out from before you, so that they would be a snare to you, and their gods would be a stumbling block to you."
Judges 2:4 And when the Angel of the Lord spoke these words to all the children of Israel, they raised their voices and wept aloud.
Judges 2:5 And the name of that place was called 'The Place of Weeping', and they offered sacrifices there to the Lord.
Judges 2:6 So Joshua sent the people away, and each went to his own inheritance to take possession of it.
Judges 2:7 And the people served the Lord all the days of Joshua, and all the days of the elders who lived for a long time after him, who had known all the works of the Lord that He had done for Israel.
Judges 2:8 Now Joshua, the son of Nun, the servant of the Lord, died when he was one hundred and ten years old.
Judges 2:9 And they buried him in the land of his inheritance, in Timnath-serah, in the hill country of Ephraim, north of Mount Gaash.
Judges 2:10 And all that generation was gathered to their fathers—meaning they died off—and another people arose who did not know the Lord, nor the works that He had done for Israel.
Judges 2:11 And the children of Israel did evil in the sight of the Lord, and they served the Baals—false gods.
Judges 2:12 And they abandoned the Lord, the God of their fathers, who had led them out of the land of Egypt, and they followed other gods, from among the gods of the peoples who lived around them, and they worshipped them. And they provoked the Lord to anger.
Judges 2:13 They forsook the Lord, and served Baal and Astarte.
Judges 2:14 So the Lord became angry with Israel, and He delivered them into the hands of plunderers who plundered them. He also delivered them into the hands of all their surrounding enemies, so that they could not stand against their adversaries.
Judges 2:15 Wherever they wanted to go, the hand of the Lord was against them to their detriment, just as He had spoken and sworn to them. And they were greatly distressed.
Judges 2:16 Nevertheless, the Lord raised up judges, who delivered them from the hands of those who devastated them.
Judges 2:17 But they would not listen to these judges either; instead, they committed spiritual fornication with other gods and worshipped them. They quickly turned away from the path their fathers had walked, who had listened to the commandments of the Lord; they did everything contrary.
Judges 2:18 And whenever the Lord raised up judges, in those days the Lord would relent and be moved to pity because of their groaning under those who oppressed and afflicted them. For He would not permit them to be tormented further.
Judges 2:19 But after the judge died, they would turn back and act even worse than their fathers had done, following other gods, serving them, and worshipping them. They would not abandon their evil practices, nor the stubborn way they had accustomed themselves to walk.
Judges 2:20 So the Lord's anger was kindled against Israel, and He said: "Because this people has made My covenant void, which I commanded their fathers, and they have refused to listen to My voice,"
Judges 2:21 "I also will no longer drive out from before them any of the nations that Joshua had left behind when he died,"
Judges 2:22 "so that through them I may test Israel, to see whether they will keep the way of the Lord and walk in it, as their fathers kept it, or not."
Judges 2:23 Therefore, the Lord allowed all these nations to remain, and He did not quickly drive them out, nor did He deliver them into the hand of Joshua.
Judges 3:1 These are the nations that the Lord God allowed to remain in the land—specifically, so that through them He could train the Israelites, especially those who had not personally experienced the wars in Canaan.
Judges 3:2 God's purpose was that at least the future generations of the Israelites would learn and be taught how to fight effectively against their enemies.
Judges 3:3 These nations included: the five lords of the Philistines; all the Canaanites; the Sidonians; and the Hivites who lived in the region of Mount Lebanon, stretching from Mount Baal-hermon all the way to the entrance of Hamath.
Judges 3:4 And these nations were specifically left so that the Israelites would be tested through them. This would reveal whether they truly loved and obeyed the commandments of the Lord God, which He had given to their ancestors through Moses, or if they would disobey Him.
Judges 3:5 Therefore, the sons of Israel began to live among the Canaanites, the Hittites, the Amorites, the Perizzites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites.
Judges 3:6 They began to take the daughters of these foreign peoples as wives, and they gave their own daughters to the sons of these peoples, and then they began to serve the gods of these nations.
Judges 3:7 The sons of Israel committed evil in the sight of the Lord God. They forgot the Lord their God and began to serve the Baals and the Astartes—false gods and goddesses of the surrounding nations.
Judges 3:8 So, the Lord God's anger was kindled against Israel. He delivered them into the hand of Cushan-Rishathaim, the king of Mesopotamia. The Israelites served this king for eight years.
Judges 3:9 Then the sons of Israel cried out to the Lord God for help. The Lord God raised up a deliverer for them who saved them—specifically, Othniel, the son of Kenaz, who was the younger brother of Caleb.
Judges 3:10 The Spirit of the Lord God came upon Othniel, and he judged and led Israel. He went out to war, and the Lord God delivered Cushan-Rishathaim, the king of Syria, into his hand. Othniel then utterly prevailed over him.
Judges 3:11 After this victory, the land had peace for forty years. Then Othniel, the son of Kenaz, died.
Judges 3:12 But again, the sons of Israel continued to commit evil in the sight of the Lord God. Because they sinned against Him, the Lord God strengthened Eglon, the king of Moab, to be their enemy.
Judges 3:13 Eglon gathered the sons of Ammon and Amalek to join him. He went and attacked Israel, and they took possession of the City of Palms—Jericho.
Judges 3:14 So the sons of Israel served Eglon, the king of Moab, for eighteen years.
Judges 3:15 And afterward, they cried out to the Lord God for help. The Lord God raised up a deliverer for them named Ehud, the son of Gera, from the tribe of Benjamin. Ehud was a left-handed man, using both hands as if they were his right. The sons of Israel sent gifts to Eglon, the king of Moab, through Ehud.
Judges 3:16 Ehud had made for himself a double-edged sword, about a cubit (a Roman palm, or 7-9 inches) in length, with the hilt in the middle. He fastened it under his clothing on his right thigh—making it unusual for a right-handed guard to search for it there.
Judges 3:17 Ehud presented the gifts to Eglon, the king of Moab. Now, King Eglon was an exceedingly fat man.
Judges 3:18 After Ehud had finished presenting the gifts, he sent away the companions who had come with him.
Judges 3:19 Ehud himself returned from Gilgal, where the idols were, and he said to the king, “I have a secret message for you, O King.” The king responded, “Silence!” And all who were around him then left the room.
Judges 3:20 So Ehud went in to him. The king was sitting alone in his cool, summer upper room. Ehud then said, “I have a message from God for you.” Immediately, the king stood up from his throne.
Judges 3:21 Then Ehud extended his left hand, drew the sword from his right thigh, and plunged it into the king's belly with such force,
Judges 3:22 that the hilt followed the blade into the wound, and the fat closed around the blade. Ehud did not pull the sword out; he left it completely embedded there. Immediately, the contents of the king's bowels came out through the wound.
Judges 3:23 Ehud then went out through the porch, having closed and locked the doors of the upper room behind him.
Judges 3:24 After he had left, the king's servants came in. Seeing the doors of the upper room closed, they said, “He is probably relieving himself in the cool, summer room.”
Judges 3:25 They waited for a long time until they became embarrassed. When they saw that no one was opening the doors, they took a key, opened the doors, and found their lord lying on the floor, dead.
Judges 3:26 But while they were waiting, Ehud escaped. He passed by the idols in the place where they were, evading capture, and came to Seirath.
Judges 3:27 Immediately upon his arrival, he blew a trumpet in the mountains of Ephraim. The sons of Israel descended with him, with Ehud leading the way.
Judges 3:28 He said to them, “Follow me, for the Lord God has delivered our enemies, the Moabites, into our hands!” So they went down with him and seized the fords of the Jordan River that led toward Moab, preventing anyone from crossing over.
Judges 3:29 At that time, they struck down about ten thousand Moabite men, all strong and valiant warriors; not one of them could escape.
Judges 3:30 So Moab was humbled on that day under the hand of Israel. And the land had peace for eighty years.
Judges 3:31 After Ehud, there was Shamgar, the son of Anath. He struck down six hundred Philistine men with an ox-goad—a long stick with a sharp point used to drive oxen. He also delivered Israel.
Judges 3:32 But the sons of Israel again committed evil in the sight of the Lord God. So the Lord God abandoned them into the hand of Jabin, the king of Canaan, who reigned in Hazor. The commander of his army was Sisera, who lived in Harosheth-Ha-goiim—meaning, 'Harosheth of the Gentiles' or 'Nations'.
Judges 3:33 The sons of Israel cried out to the Lord God, because Jabin had cruelly oppressed them for twenty years. He possessed nine hundred iron chariots, and he had severely afflicted the Israelites.
Judges 3:34 Now, Deborah, a prophetess and the wife of Lappidoth, was judging Israel at that time.
Judges 3:35 She used to sit under a palm tree, which was named after her, located between Ramah and Bethel in the mountains of Ephraim. The sons of Israel would come up to her for every legal judgment and dispute.
Judges 3:36 Deborah sent and called for Barak, the son of Abinoam, from Kedesh-Naphtali. She said to him, “The Lord God of Israel has commanded you: Go, lead an army to Mount Tabor, and take with you ten thousand men from the sons of Naphtali and the sons of Zebulun.
Judges 3:37 I will bring Sisera, the commander of Jabin’s army, with his chariots and all his multitude, to you at the Kishon River. And I will deliver them into your hand.”
Judges 3:38 Barak said to her, “If you come with me, I will go; but if you refuse to come with me, I will not go.”
Judges 3:39 She said to him, “I will certainly go with you. However, the victory will not be to your honor, for Sisera will be delivered into the hand of a woman.” So Deborah arose and went with Barak to Kedesh.
Judges 3:40 And Barak gathered Naphtali and Zebulun in Kedesh. He went up with ten thousand fighting men, having Deborah with him as his companion.
Judges 4:1 After Ehud, the son of Jemini, died, the sons of Israel again offended the Lord through their evil actions.
Judges 4:2 The Lord then allowed Jabin, king of Canaan, to conquer them. Jabin ruled from Hazor. His army's commander was Sisara, who lived in Haroseth Goim.
Judges 4:3 The sons of Israel cried out to the Lord for help, because King Jabin had nine hundred iron chariots and had severely oppressed them for twenty years.
Judges 4:4 Now, during that time, a prophetess named Deborah, wife of Lapidoth, was leading the people of Israel as their judge.
Judges 4:5 She sat under a palm tree that was named after her, located between Ramah and Bethel in the mountains of Ephraim. The sons of Israel would come up to her for every legal case and dispute.
Judges 4:6 She sent a message, summoning Barak, son of Abinoam, from Kedesh-naphtali. She told him: "The Lord, the God of Israel, has given a command: 'Go and lead an army up to Mount Tabor. Take with you ten thousand men from the tribes of Naphtali and Zebulun.'"
Judges 4:7 "I will draw Sisara, the commander of Jabin's army, with his chariots and all his forces, to the Kishon Stream, to meet you there. I will then deliver them into your hands."
Judges 4:8 Barak replied to her: "If you come with me, I will go. But if you are unwilling to come with me, then I will not go."
Judges 4:9 She answered him: "I will certainly go with you. But on this mission, the glory of victory will not be yours, because Sisara will be delivered into the hand of a woman." So Deborah arose and went with Barak to Kedesh.
Judges 4:10 Barak then called together the tribes of Zebulun and Naphtali, and he marched up with ten thousand fighters, taking Deborah with him.
Judges 4:11 Now Heber the Kenite had previously separated from the other Kenites, his brothers, who were descendants of Hobab, Moses' father-in-law. Heber had pitched his tents near the valley called Sennim, which was close to Kedesh.
Judges 4:12 It was reported to Sisara that Barak, son of Abinoam, had ascended Mount Tabor.
Judges 4:13 Immediately, Sisara gathered all his nine hundred iron chariots and his entire army from Haroseth Goim, and led them to the Kishon Stream.
Judges 4:14 Deborah then said to Barak: "Arise! This is the day in which the Lord has given Sisara into your hand. Behold, the Lord is going before you!" So Barak descended from Mount Tabor with his ten thousand men.
Judges 4:15 And the Lord threw Sisara, all his chariots, and his entire multitude into a panic before Barak's sword. The rout was so complete that Sisara leaped down from his chariot and fled on foot.
Judges 4:16 Barak pursued the fleeing chariots and the army all the way to Haroseth Goim. And the entire host of the enemy fell by the sword, until they were utterly destroyed.
Judges 4:17 Sisara, however, fleeing on foot, arrived at the tent of Jael, the wife of Heber the Kenite. This was because there was a peace treaty between Jabin, king of Hazor, and the house of Heber the Kenite.
Judges 4:18 Jael then came out to meet Sisara and said to him: "Come in, my lord, come in to me, do not be afraid." When he had entered her tent, she covered him with a rug.
Judges 4:19 Sisara said to her: "Please give me a little water to drink, for I am thirsty." So she opened a skin of milk, gave him a drink, and covered him again.
Judges 4:20 Sisara then told her: "Stand at the entrance of the tent. If anyone comes asking you, saying: 'Is there anyone here?' you are to answer: 'There is no one.'"
Judges 4:21 So Jael, Heber's wife, took a tent peg, and taking a hammer, she quietly and cautiously went in. She placed the tent peg against his temple, and then struck the hammer forcefully, driving the peg into his brain as he slept soundly. In this way, he died.
Judges 4:22 And behold, Barak was coming, pursuing Sisara. Jael came out to meet him and said to him: "Come, and I will show you the man you are looking for." When he entered her tent, he saw Sisara lying dead, with the tent peg driven into his temple.
Judges 4:23 So on that day, God brought low Jabin, the king of Canaan, before the sons of Israel.
Judges 4:24 And the sons of Israel continued to advance, growing stronger day by day in their resistance against Jabin, king of Canaan, until they completely destroyed him.
Judges 4:1 After Ehud, their deliverer, had died, the people of Israel again committed sins before the Lord God.
Judges 4:2 So the Lord God handed them over to the power of Jabin, the king of Canaan, who reigned in Hazor. This king possessed nine hundred iron chariots, a formidable military force. He tyrannically oppressed the people of Israel for twenty years.
Judges 4:3 The people of Israel then cried out to the Lord God, because this king had oppressed them most cruelly for those twenty years, especially with his nine hundred iron chariots providing him such military dominance.
Judges 4:4 At that time, Deborah, a prophetess and the wife of Lapidoth, was exercising leadership over the people of Israel.
Judges 4:5 She sat under a palm tree, which was known by her name, located between Ramah and Bethel in the hill country of Ephraim. The people of Israel would come to her there for every legal judgment and to receive her wisdom.
Judges 4:6 Deborah sent for and summoned Barak, the son of Abinoam, from Kedesh-Naphtali. She said to him, 'The Lord God of Israel commands you: Go and lead an army to Mount Tabor, taking with you ten thousand men from the tribes of Naphtali and Zebulun.'
Judges 4:7 'And I, the Lord God, will draw Sisera, the commander of Jabin's army, along with his chariots and all his forces, to meet you at the Kishon River. Then I will deliver them into your hand, granting you victory.'
Judges 4:8 Barak replied to her, 'If you go with me, I will go to battle. But if you refuse to come, I will not proceed.'
Judges 4:9 Deborah said to him, 'I will certainly go with you. However, the glory of this victory will not be yours, because Sisera will be delivered into the hand of a woman instead.' So Deborah arose and went with Barak to Kedesh.
Judges 4:10 Barak then sent for the men of Zebulun and Naphtali, and he marched up with ten thousand men, with Deborah personally leading them.
Judges 4:11 Now Heber the Kenite, whose people were descendants of Hobab, the father-in-law of Moses and traditionally allies of Israel, had separated himself from the other Kenites, his brethren. He had pitched his tents in the valley called Zaanaim, which was near Kedesh.
Judges 4:12 It was reported to Sisera that Barak, the son of Abinoam, had gone up with his forces to Mount Tabor.
Judges 4:13 So Sisera gathered all his nine hundred iron chariots and his entire army from Harosheth, a city of the Gentiles. He led them to the Kishon River.
Judges 4:14 Then Deborah said to Barak, 'Arise! For this is the very day on which the Lord God has delivered Sisera into your hand. Behold, the Lord God Himself goes before you in battle!' So Barak descended from Mount Tabor, and his ten thousand men with him.
Judges 4:15 And the Lord God struck terror into Sisera, his entire chariot force, and his whole army, causing them to be defeated by the edge of Barak's sword. Sisera himself, in desperation, leaped down from his chariot and fled on foot.
Judges 4:16 Barak pursued the fleeing chariots and the army all the way to Harosheth, the city of the Gentiles. The entire multitude of the enemy was slain; not a single one was left alive.
Judges 4:17 Sisera, still fleeing, arrived at the tent of Jael, the wife of Heber the Kenite. He sought refuge there because there was a treaty of peace between Jabin, the king of Hazor, and the house of Heber the Kenite, making it seemingly a safe haven.
Judges 4:18 So Jael went out to meet Sisera and said to him, 'Come in, my lord, do not be afraid.' When he entered her tent, she covered him with a rug for concealment and comfort.
Judges 4:19 He said to her, 'Please give me a little water, for I am very thirsty.' But she opened a skin of milk and gave him to drink, a gesture of great hospitality. After he drank, she covered him again.
Judges 4:20 Then Sisera instructed her, 'Stand at the entrance of the tent. If anyone comes asking you, saying, 'Is anyone here?' you must answer, 'No one is here.'
Judges 4:21 But Jael, Heber's wife, took a tent peg and a hammer. She quietly and cautiously approached Sisera, who was deeply overcome by sleep and exhaustion, and placed the tent peg against his temple. She then drove the peg through his head and into the ground with the hammer, and so he died.
Judges 4:22 Just then, Barak arrived, pursuing Sisera. Jael went out to meet him and said, 'Come, and I will show you the man you are seeking.' So he went into her tent and saw Sisera lying dead, with the tent peg driven into his temple.
Judges 4:23 Thus, on that day, God thoroughly humbled Jabin, the king of Canaan, before the people of Israel, demonstrating His power and faithfulness.
Judges 4:24 And the people of Israel, after this decisive victory, continued to press more and more upon Jabin, the king of Canaan, until he and his kingdom were utterly destroyed.
Judges 5:1 And so, on that day, Deborah and Barak, the son of Abinoam, sang this song, saying:
Judges 5:2 For the people of Israel willingly offered themselves for battle—those who did not fear to fight—for this, praise the Lord!
Judges 5:3 Hear this, O kings! And pay attention, O princes! I will sing to the Lord! I myself will sing praises, making melody to the Lord, the God of Israel!
Judges 5:4 Lord, when You marched forth from Seir, when You advanced from the lands of Edom, the earth shook, and the skies poured down their water.
Judges 5:5 The mountains melted away at the presence of the Lord, even Sinai itself trembled at the presence of the Lord, the God of Israel.
Judges 5:6 In the days of Shamgar, son of Anath, and in the days of Jael, the main roads were deserted. Those who used to travel on them now walked through winding, secluded paths.
Judges 5:7 The strong men—the leaders—in Israel ceased to lead; they rested, until Deborah arose, until a mother arose in Israel to guide them.
Judges 5:8 The Lord chose new wars and personally overturned the gates of the enemies. Not a shield or a spear was seen among the forty thousand warriors of Israel.
Judges 5:9 My heart loves the leaders of Israel, who willingly risked themselves. Bless the Lord!
Judges 5:10 You who ride on shining donkeys, you who sit in judgment, and you who travel along the roads—speak of these events!
Judges 5:11 Where the water-drawers sing loudly, there let them recount the righteous acts of the Lord and His strength in Israel. Then the Lord's people went down to the city gates, prepared for battle.
Judges 5:12 Arise, arise, Deborah! Arise, arise, and sing your song! Arise, Barak, and capture your captives, O son of Abinoam!
Judges 5:13 Then the remnant of the people turned to the Lord. The mighty leader came down to me; the Lord’s people stood among the strong.
Judges 5:14 From Ephraim, their root, came those against Amalek; and after you, Benjamin, among your people. From Machir came down leaders, and from Zebulun came those who began to lead the army.
Judges 5:15 The commanders of Issachar were with Deborah and Barak. How the strongest warrior was scattered, his feet ran headlong into the valley! Among the clans of Reuben, great divisions and arguments were found.
Judges 5:16 Why did you sit among the sheepfolds, listening to the whistling of the flocks? Among the clans of Reuben, great divisions and arguments were found.
Judges 5:17 Gilead stayed beyond the Jordan. Dan remained by his ships. Asher dwelt by the seashore and remained in his harbors.
Judges 5:18 But Zebulun and Naphtali risked their lives even unto death, on the high ground of Merom.
Judges 5:19 The kings came, and they fought. The kings of Canaan fought in Taanach, by the waters of Megiddo, but they carried off no plunder.
Judges 5:20 From the sky, they were fought against! The stars themselves, remaining in their order and course, fought against Sisera.
Judges 5:21 The torrent of Kishon swept away their bodies—the torrent of Cadumim, the torrent of Kishon! My soul, trample down the mighty!
Judges 5:22 The hooves of the horses beat rapidly, as the strongest warriors fled in a frenzy.
Judges 5:23 “Curse Meroz,” said the Angel of the Lord. “Curse its inhabitants, because they did not come to the aid of the Lord, to the aid of His strong warriors!”
Judges 5:24 May Jael, the wife of Heber the Kenite, be blessed above all women, and may she be blessed within her tent.
Judges 5:25 He asked for water, and she gave him milk; in a noble bowl, she offered him curdled milk.
Judges 5:26 She reached out her left hand for a tent peg, and her right hand for a workman’s hammer. She struck Sisera, finding a vulnerable spot on his head, and pierced his temples.
Judges 5:27 Between her feet, he sank down, he collapsed, and he died. Between her feet, he lay, and he perished.
Judges 5:28 Through the window, Sisera's mother looked out, and wailed, lamenting through her tears: “Why is his chariot so slow to return? Why have the wheels of his chariots delayed?”
Judges 5:29 One of her wise noblewomen answered her, and she herself repeated these words to the other women:
Judges 5:30 “Perhaps he is now dividing the spoils! Sisera is taking as plunder the most beautiful and varied garments, and necklaces and richly colored jewels are being placed around his neck.”
Judges 5:31 May all Your enemies perish in this way, O Lord! But may those who love You shine like the sun when it rises in its full glory. And the land had rest for forty years.
Judges 5:1 On that day, Deborah and Barak, the son of Abinoem, sang this song, saying:
Judges 5:2 You, the people, offered yourselves willingly to fight. For this, bless the Lord.
Judges 5:3 Listen, you kings! Pay attention, you rulers! It is I, I myself, who will sing to the Lord; I will make music for the Lord, the God of Israel.
Judges 5:4 Lord, when you came forth from Seir, when you marched from the region of Edom, the earth shook violently. The skies also dripped, and the clouds poured down water.
Judges 5:5 The mountains flowed, trembling before the face of the Lord. Mount Sinai itself trembled before the face of the Lord, the God of Israel.
Judges 5:6 In the days of Shamgar, the son of Anath, and in the days of Jael, the main roads were deserted. Those who used to travel on them instead walked on winding, hidden paths, avoiding the public routes.
Judges 5:7 The brave warriors in Israel had ceased fighting; they had rested, until Deborah rose up. She rose as a mother figure to guide Israel.
Judges 5:8 When new wars came, the Lord chose to fight. He Himself overthrew the gates of the enemies. But among the forty thousand warriors of Israel, no shield or spear was seen in their hands; they were unarmed.
Judges 5:9 My heart loves the leaders of Israel, the ones who willingly put themselves in danger. For this, bless the Lord.
Judges 5:10 You who ride on shining donkeys, you who sit in judgment, and you who travel on the roads, speak of these events.
Judges 5:11 There, where they gathered to declare the righteous acts of the Lord and the just deeds of His mighty warriors in Israel, the people of the Lord then went down to the city gates and fought the enemy.
Judges 5:12 Arise, arise, Deborah! Arise, arise, and speak the song of victory! Arise, Barak, and take your captives, O son of Abinoem!
Judges 5:13 Then the remnant of the people of the Lord came down with the mighty ones. The Lord gave me leaders over the powerful people.
Judges 5:14 From Ephraim, they marched against the Amalekites. After you, O Benjamin, came against your own peoples, O Amalek. From Machir, leaders descended to join the fight, and from Zebulun came those who led the army.
Judges 5:15 The princes of Issachar were with Deborah and Barak. The men of Issachar followed in the footsteps of Deborah and Barak, directing their forces into the valley. But among the divisions of Reuben, there were great hesitations of heart.
Judges 5:16 Why did you sit among the two sheepfolds, listening to the whistles of the flocks, Reuben? Among the divisions of Reuben, there were great internal questionings and indecisions of heart.
Judges 5:17 Gilead stayed across the Jordan River and remained there. Why did Dan linger by his ships? Asher settled on the seashore and remained in his harbors, not joining the battle.
Judges 5:18 But Zebulun and Naphtali risked their lives, offering themselves to death, in the region of Merom.
Judges 5:19 The kings came and fought. The kings of Canaan fought at Taanach, near the waters of Megiddo. But they took no plunder of silver; they gained nothing from their looting.
Judges 5:20 From the sky, the battle was waged against them. The stars, remaining in their fixed order and moving in their courses, fought against Sisara.
Judges 5:21 The Kishon River swept away their dead bodies; that ancient river, the Kishon River. My soul, trample down the mighty warriors!
Judges 5:22 The hooves of the horses pounded furiously, as the mightiest warriors fled in a frenzy.
Judges 5:23 “Curse Meroz!” said the Angel of the Lord. “Curse its inhabitants, because they did not come to the aid of the Lord, to help Him alongside the mightiest warriors.”
Judges 5:24 May Jael, the wife of Heber the Kenite, be blessed above all women. May she be blessed within her tent, in her home.
Judges 5:25 He asked for water, but she gave him milk. In a bowl fit for a prince, she offered him curdled milk or butter, a thick, rich drink.
Judges 5:26 She reached out her left hand for a tent peg, and her right hand for a workman's hammer. She struck Sisara, seeking to inflict a wound to his head, and pierced through his temples.
Judges 5:27 Between her feet he sank down, he faltered, and then he died. Between her feet he collapsed, and there he lay lifeless.
Judges 5:28 Through the window, Sisara's mother looked out and cried loudly. From the rooftop, she spoke, saying: “Why is his chariot so long in returning? Why have the hoofbeats of his chariots been delayed?”
Judges 5:29 One of her wisest wives answered her, and she too spoke to her mother's words, providing an explanation:
Judges 5:30 “Perhaps he is now dividing the plunder. There will be the most beautiful of garments, and brightly embroidered cloths, to adorn the necks of the captives. For each man, there will be a single spoil to take home.”
Judges 5:31 May all your enemies perish in this way, O Lord! But may those who love you shine forth like the sun, going out in its full strength. And so, the land had peace for forty years.
Judges 6:1 But the sons of Israel did what was evil in the sight of the Lord, and because of this, He delivered them into the power of Midian for seven years.
Judges 6:2 And they were severely oppressed by Midian. Because of this, the sons of Israel made for themselves caves in the mountains, hollows in the ground, and many fortified strongholds.
Judges 6:3 Whenever Israel had sown their crops, Midian and Amalek and the other peoples from the East would invade their land.
Judges 6:4 They would spread out and devastate the entire region, destroying everything as far as Gaza. They would leave nothing for the people of Israel to eat, neither sheep, oxen, nor donkeys.
Judges 6:5 For they themselves would come with their tents and their entire herds, and like swarms of locusts, they would fill up the land. The men and their camels were innumerable, and wherever they went, they devastated everything.
Judges 6:6 And so, Israel was brought very low and humbled before Midian. And the sons of Israel cried out to the Lord for help.
Judges 6:7 And when they had cried out to the Lord because of Midian,
