Judges 6:8 the Lord sent a prophet to them, who spoke these words: "Thus says the Lord, the God of Israel: 'I made you ascend from the land of Egypt and led you out of that house of slavery.
Judges 6:9 I rescued you from the power of the Egyptians and from the power of all your enemies who afflicted you. I drove them out from before you and gave their land to you.
Judges 6:10 And I said: "I am the Lord your God. Do not fear the gods of the Amorites, in whose land you are now living." But you would not listen to My voice.'"
Judges 6:11 Now the Angel of the Lord came and sat under an oak tree that was in Ephra, which belonged to Joas, the father of the family of Ezri. And his son, Gideon, was threshing and cleaning wheat in a winepress to hide it from the Midianites.
Judges 6:12 The Angel of the Lord appeared to him and said: "The Lord is with you, O mighty warrior."
Judges 6:13 And Gideon said to Him: "Please, my Lord, if the Lord is with us, why have all these things happened to us? Where are all His miracles that our fathers told us about, saying: 'The Lord led us out of Egypt?' But now the Lord has abandoned us and delivered us into the power of Midian."
Judges 6:14 And the Lord looked at him and said: "Go in this strength of yours, and you will deliver Israel from the power of Midian. Know for certain that I Myself have sent you."
Judges 6:15 And Gideon, responding, said: "Please, my Lord, how shall I deliver Israel? Behold, my family is the poorest in Manasseh, and I am the least significant in my father's house."
Judges 6:16 And the Lord said to him: "I will be with you. And you will strike down Midian as if they were only one man."
Judges 6:17 And Gideon said: "If I have found favor in your sight, give me a sign to prove that it is You who are speaking to me."
Judges 6:18 "Do not depart from here until I return to You and bring my offering and set it before You." And He replied: "I will wait for your return."
Judges 6:19 So Gideon went in and prepared a young goat, and from an ephah of flour, he made unleavened bread. He put the meat in a basket and the broth in a pot. Then he brought it all out and offered it under the oak tree.
Judges 6:20 And the Angel of the Lord said to him: "Take the meat and the unleavened bread, and place them on that rock, and pour the broth over them." And when he had done so,
Judges 6:21 the Angel of the Lord stretched out the tip of the staff that He held in His hand and touched the meat and the unleavened bread. Then fire came out from the rock and consumed the meat and the unleavened bread, and the Angel of the Lord vanished from his sight.
Judges 6:22 And when Gideon saw that it had been the Angel of the Lord, he said: "Alas, my Lord God! For I have seen the Angel of the Lord face to face!"
Judges 6:23 And the Lord said to him: "Peace be with you. Do not fear; you will not die."
Judges 6:24 So Gideon built an altar there to the Lord, and he called it "The Lord is Peace" (Yahweh Shalom), even to this present day. This occurred while he was still in Ephra, which belonged to the family of Ezri.
Judges 6:25 That same night, the Lord said to him: "Take a bull from your father's herd, and another bull that is seven years old. Then tear down the altar of Baal that your father has, and cut down the sacred grove of trees that is around it."
Judges 6:26 "And build an altar to the Lord your God on the top of this rock, the very one upon which you made your offering earlier. Then, using the wood that you cut down from the sacred grove, offer a burnt offering."
Judges 6:27 So Gideon took ten men from among his servants and did just as the Lord had commanded him. But because he was afraid of his father's household and the men of that city, he would not do it by day; instead, he completed everything during the night.
Judges 6:28 And when the men of his city rose early in the morning, they saw that the altar of Baal had been destroyed, the sacred grove cut down, and a bull offered as a sacrifice on the altar that had just been built.
Judges 6:29 And they said to one another: "Who did this?" And when they investigated to find the one responsible for the deed, it was said: "Gideon, the son of Joas, did all these things."
Judges 6:30 And they said to Joas: "Bring out your son here, so that he may die, because he destroyed the altar of Baal and cut down the sacred grove."
Judges 6:31 But Joas responded to them: "Are you going to avenge Baal and fight for him? Whoever opposes him, let him die before tomorrow's light arrives. If Baal is a god, let him avenge himself on the one who tore down his altar."
Judges 6:32 From that day forward, Gideon was called Jerobaal, which means "Baal Contends," because Joas had said: "Let Baal contend with him, because he tore down his altar."
Judges 6:33 Then all of Midian, and Amalek, and the peoples from the East gathered together. They crossed the Jordan River and camped in the Valley of Jezreel.
Judges 6:34 But the Spirit of the Lord came upon Gideon, strengthening him for battle. And Gideon blew the trumpet, summoning the house of Abiezer to follow him.
Judges 6:35 He also sent messengers throughout all of Manasseh, and they too followed him. And he sent others into Asher, Zebulun, and Naphtali, and they came to meet him.
Judges 6:36 And Gideon said to the Lord: "If You truly intend to save Israel by my hand, as You have spoken,
Judges 6:37 behold, I will place a fleece of wool on the threshing floor. If there is dew only on the fleece, and the ground all around it is dry, then I will know that You will deliver Israel by my hand, as You have spoken."
Judges 6:38 And it happened just so. For when Gideon rose early the next morning and squeezed the fleece, he wrung out enough dew from the fleece to fill a bowl with water.
Judges 6:39 And Gideon said again to the Lord: "Do not let your anger burn against me, Lord, if I try just one more time, seeking a sign with the fleece. I pray that only the fleece may be dry this time, and all the ground around it be wet with dew."
Judges 6:40 And God did so that night as he had requested. Only the fleece was dry, and all the ground around it was covered with dew.
Judges 6:1 The children of Israel did what was evil in the sight of the Lord. Therefore, the Lord gave them into the power of Midian for seven years.
Judges 6:2 The Midianites severely oppressed them, and they gained complete dominance over Israel.
Judges 6:3 Whenever Israel had planted their crops, Midian, Amalek, and the other Eastern peoples would invade.
Judges 6:4 They would establish their camps against Israel, and they would eat up everything that was sown in the land, all the way to Gaza. Nothing would be left in Israel for sustenance, neither for their livestock, nor sheep, nor cattle.
Judges 6:5 For all of them would come with their flocks and their tents, like a multitude of locusts. As they swarmed in, they would devastate everything.
Judges 6:6 So Israel was greatly humbled and brought low before Midian.
Judges 6:7 And Israel cried out to the Lord, pleading for help against the Midianites.
Judges 6:8 The Lord sent a prophet to them, who spoke these words: 'Thus says the Lord, the God of Israel: I caused you to come up out of Egypt, and I led you out of the house of slavery.'
Judges 6:9 'I rescued you from the power of the Egyptians and from the power of all your enemies. I drove them out from before you, and I gave you their land.'
Judges 6:10 'And I said: I am the Lord your God. Do not fear the gods of the Amorites, in whose land you live. But you have not obeyed my voice.'
Judges 6:11 Now the Angel of the Lord came and sat under an oak tree which was in Ephra, and which belonged to Joas, of the family of Ezri. His son, Gideon, was threshing and cleaning wheat in a winepress, so that he could hide it from the Midianites.
Judges 6:12 The Angel of the Lord appeared to him and said: 'The Lord is with you, O mightiest of warriors!'
Judges 6:13 Gideon then said to him: 'Please, my Lord, if the Lord is with us, why has all this trouble come upon us? Where are all His wondrous works, which our fathers told us about, saying: "The Lord brought us out of Egypt"? But now the Lord has abandoned us and delivered us into the power of Midian.'
Judges 6:14 The Lord looked at him and said: 'Go in this strength of yours, and you shall deliver Israel from the power of Midian. Know for certain that I Myself have sent you.'
Judges 6:15 Gideon replied: 'Please, my Lord, how can I deliver Israel? Behold, my family is the humblest in Manasseh, and I am the least in my father's house.'
Judges 6:16 The Lord then said to him: 'I will be with you. You shall strike down Midian as if they were a single man.'
Judges 6:17 Gideon said: 'If I have found favor in your sight, then give me a sign that it is truly you who speaks with me.'
Judges 6:18 'Do not leave here until I return to you, bringing my offering and presenting it to you.' The Angel replied: 'I will wait for your return.'
Judges 6:19 So Gideon went in and cooked a young goat, and from a measure of flour he made unleavened bread. He put the meat in a basket and poured the broth out into a pot separately. He brought it all out under the oak tree and offered it to the Angel.
Judges 6:20 The Angel of the Lord said to him: 'Take the meat and the unleavened bread and place them upon that rock, and pour the broth over them.' When Gideon had done so,
Judges 6:21 the Angel of the Lord extended the tip of the staff that He held in His hand, and touched the meat and the unleavened bread. Fire then rose from the rock and consumed the meat and the unleavened bread. And the Angel of the Lord vanished from his sight.
Judges 6:22 When Gideon saw that it was indeed the Angel of the Lord, he cried out: 'Alas for me, O Lord God! For I have seen the Angel of the Lord face to face!'
Judges 6:23 But the Lord said to him: 'Peace be with you. Do not be afraid. You shall not die.'
Judges 6:24 So Gideon built an altar there to the Lord, and he called it 'The Lord is Peace' (or 'Yahweh Shalom'). It stands even to this present day in Ephra, where the family of Ezri lives.
Judges 6:25 On that very night, the Lord said to Gideon: 'Take your father's bull, and another bull that is seven years old. Tear down the altar of Baal that belongs to your father, and cut down the sacred grove that is around it.'
Judges 6:26 'Then build an altar to the Lord your God on the top of this rock, upon which you previously placed your offering. Take the wood from the sacred grove that you have cut down, and offer a burnt offering.'
Judges 6:27 So Gideon took ten men from among his servants and did as the Lord had commanded him. However, because he was afraid of his father's household and the men of that city, he did not want to do it by day. Instead, he made sure to complete everything by night.
Judges 6:28 When the men of the city rose early in the morning, they saw that the altar of Baal was torn down, the sacred grove was cut down, and the bull had been offered as a sacrifice on the altar that had just been built.
Judges 6:29 They said to one another: 'Who did this?' When they inquired diligently to find the one who had done it, it was told to them: 'Gideon, the son of Joas, did all these things.'
Judges 6:30 They then said to Joas: 'Bring out your son so that he may die! For he has torn down the altar of Baal and cut down the sacred grove!'
Judges 6:31 Joas answered those who were speaking against him: 'Will you fight for Baal? Will you contend on his behalf? Whoever stands up for him shall die before morning! If he is a god, let him contend for himself against the one who destroyed his altar!'
Judges 6:32 From that day on, Gideon was called Jerobaal (which means, 'Let Baal contend'), because Joas had said: 'Let Baal contend with him, since he tore down his altar.'
Judges 6:33 Then all of Midian, Amalek, and the peoples of the East gathered together. They crossed the Jordan River and camped in the valley of Jezrael.
Judges 6:34 But the Spirit of the Lord empowered Gideon. He sounded the trumpet, calling the household of Abiezer to follow him.
Judges 6:35 He also sent messengers throughout all Manasseh, and they too were called to follow him. He sent messengers to Asher, Zebulun, and Naphtali, and they came out to meet him.
Judges 6:36 Gideon then said to God: 'If you are truly going to save Israel by my hand, as you have spoken,'
Judges 6:37 'I will place this fleece of wool on the threshing floor. If there is dew only on the fleece, and all the ground around it is dry, then I will know that you will deliver Israel by my hand, as you have spoken.'
Judges 6:38 And so it happened. When he rose early the next morning, he squeezed the fleece and found a bowl full of dew.
Judges 6:39 Gideon spoke to God again: 'Do not be angry with me, Lord, if I test you just one more time, seeking a sign with the fleece. Let only the fleece be dry, and let all the surrounding ground be wet with dew.'
Judges 6:40 And God did so that night as Gideon had requested. Only the fleece was dry, and there was dew on all the ground around it.
Judges 7:1 Jerubbaal, who was also called Gideon, and all the people with him rose during the night. They then set up their camp next to the Spring of Harad. The Midianite camp was located to the north of them, visible in the valley before them.
Judges 7:2 Then the Lord spoke to Gideon, saying: 'The people with you are too numerous. I will not hand Midian over to them, lest Israel boast against me and say: "I was delivered by my own strength."
Judges 7:3 Now, speak to the people and proclaim in everyone's hearing: 'Whoever is fearful and afraid, let him return home.' So, twenty-two thousand men returned from Mount Galaad, and ten thousand remained.
Judges 7:4 And the Lord said to Gideon: 'There are still too many people. Lead them down to the waters, and there I will test them. Concerning whomever I tell you, "This one shall go with you," that one shall go. But whomever I forbid, that one shall return home.'
Judges 7:5 When he had led them down to the waters, the Lord said to Gideon: 'All who lap up the waters with their tongues, just as dogs lap, you shall separate them to one side. Likewise, do the same for every one who kneels to drink.'
Judges 7:6 So, the number of those who lapped from their hand to their mouth was three hundred men. However, all the rest of the multitude had knelt on their knees to drink.
Judges 7:7 And the Lord said to Gideon: 'With these three hundred men who lapped the waters, I will deliver you and give Midian into your hand. But all the rest of the multitude shall return to their homes.'
Judges 7:8 So, Gideon took the provisions and all the armor from the rest of the men. He then ordered all the other Israelites to return to their tents, while he himself, with the three hundred men, prepared for battle. The Midianite camp was below them in the valley.
Judges 7:9 That same night, the Lord said to him: 'Arise and go down into the camp, for I have delivered them into your hand.'
Judges 7:10 But if you are afraid to go down alone, then go down with Phara, your servant.
Judges 7:11 And when you hear what they are saying, then your hands will be strengthened, and you will go down to the battle more confidently. So, he himself and Phara, his servant, went down to the part of the camp where the armed scouts were stationed.
Judges 7:12 Now, the Midianites, the Amalekites, and all the peoples from the East were spread out in the valley, as numerous as a swarm of locusts. Their camels were also innumerable, like the sand that lies on the seashore.
Judges 7:13 When Gideon arrived, he heard someone telling a dream to his companion. Among other things they were conversing about, this man recounted: 'I saw a dream. It seemed to me as if a barley loaf of bread was rolling down and came into the camp of Midian. And when it reached a tent, it struck it and overturned it, completely throwing it down.'
Judges 7:14 The man to whom he was speaking answered, saying: 'This is nothing other than the sword of Gideon, the son of Joas, a man of Israel! The Lord has delivered Midian and all its camp into his hands.'
Judges 7:15 And when Gideon had heard the dream and its interpretation, he immediately worshiped God. He then returned to the camp of Israel and said: 'Arise, for the Lord has delivered the camp of Midian into our hands!'
Judges 7:16 He divided the three hundred men into three companies. To all of them, he gave trumpets in their hands, empty jars, and torches inside the jars.
Judges 7:17 And he said to them: 'Whatever you see me do, that is what you are to do. Follow your leader. Act exactly as I act.'
Judges 7:18 When I blow the trumpet, then you also, all around the camp, are to blow. And you are to say: 'The Lord's and Gideon's!'
Judges 7:19 So, Gideon and the three hundred men who were with him entered the part of the camp just after the middle watch of the night, right after the first guards had been stationed. They blew their trumpets and broke the jars they held among themselves.
Judges 7:20 When the trumpets had sounded in the three places, and the jars were broken, they held the torches in their left hands and the trumpets in their right hands, shouting: 'The sword of the Lord and of Gideon!'
Judges 7:21 Every man stood in his place all around the camp of Midian. All those in the camp were thrown into confusion, shouting and fleeing in terror.
Judges 7:22 And with only the three hundred men sounding their trumpets, the Lord turned every man's sword against his fellow, and they were slaughtered by mutual killing. They fled as far as Beth-shettah, and to the edge of Abel-meholah, near Tabbath.
Judges 7:23 Then, Israel, with men from Naphtali, Asher, and all Manasseh, were called out and pursued Midian.
Judges 7:24 And Gideon sent messengers throughout all the hill country of Ephraim, saying: 'Come down to meet Midian and seize the water crossings as far as Beth-barah and the Jordan River.' So, all of Ephraim was called out, and they seized the water crossings as far as Beth-barah and the Jordan.
Judges 7:25 They captured two Midianite leaders, Oreb and Zeb. They killed Oreb at the Rock of Oreb, and Zeb at the Winepress of Zeb. And while they pressed Gideon from Midian, they cut off the heads of Oreb and Zeb and brought them to Gideon across the Jordan.
Judges 7:1 So Jerubbaal, who is Gideon, rose very early, and his entire army with him. They set up their camp near the spring of Harod. The Midianite camp, by contrast, was to the north, in the valley known for its prominence.
Judges 7:2 The Lord then said to Gideon, "You have too many men with you. I will not hand the Midianites over to such a large army, because if I did, the people of Israel might boast against me, saying, 'We saved ourselves by our own strength!'"
Judges 7:3 "Therefore, speak to the people and make this declaration for everyone to hear: 'Whoever is fearful and afraid, let him turn back now.'" So, twenty-two thousand men returned from Mount Gilead, leaving only ten thousand behind.
Judges 7:4 The Lord spoke to Gideon again, saying, "There are still too many men. Lead them down to the water, and I will test them for you there. Those about whom I tell you, 'This one shall go with you,' shall go. But everyone about whom I tell you, 'This one shall not go,' shall return."
Judges 7:5 So when Gideon led the men down to the water, the Lord said to him, "Everyone who laps the water with his tongue, like a dog laps, you shall set aside by himself. Also, set aside everyone who kneels down to drink."
Judges 7:6 The number of men who lapped the water by bringing it to their mouths with their hands was three hundred. All the remaining men in the army drank by kneeling down.
Judges 7:7 And the Lord said to Gideon, "With these three hundred men who lapped the water, I will save you and deliver the Midianites into your hand. Let all the rest of the army return to their own homes."
Judges 7:8 So Gideon took the provisions for the remaining people, as well as their trumpets, and sent all the rest of the Israelites back to their tents. Gideon himself, with only the three hundred men, prepared for battle. The Midianite camp was situated below them in the valley.
Judges 7:9 That very night, the Lord said to Gideon, "Get up! Go down into the enemy camp, for I have already delivered them into your hands."
Judges 7:10 "However, if you are afraid to go down by yourself, then go down with your servant, Pharah."
Judges 7:11 "And when you hear what they are saying, then your hands will be strengthened, and you will go into battle with more confidence." So Gideon and his servant Pharah went down to the edge of the camp where the armed guards were positioned.
Judges 7:12 The Midianites, the Amalekites, and all the peoples from the East were spread out across the valley, as numerous as a swarm of locusts. Their camels were likewise countless, like the grains of sand on the seashore.
Judges 7:13 When Gideon reached the camp, he heard one man telling his neighbor a dream. The man was saying, "I had a dream, and behold, a humble loaf of barley bread came tumbling into the Midianite camp, struck a tent, and completely overturned it to the ground!"
Judges 7:14 The man he was speaking to replied, "This dream can mean nothing other than the sword of Gideon, the son of Joash, an Israelite man! God the Lord has delivered Midian and their entire army into his hands."
Judges 7:15 When Gideon heard the dream and its interpretation, he immediately worshipped God. He then returned to the camp of Israel and said, "Arise! For the Lord has delivered the Midianite camp into our hands!"
Judges 7:16 Gideon divided the three hundred men into three separate companies. He gave each man a trumpet, an empty pitcher, and a torch to be hidden inside the pitcher.
Judges 7:17 And he said to them, "Watch me carefully, and do exactly as I do. When I go to the edge of the enemy camp, whatever I do there, you must imitate."
Judges 7:18 "When my trumpet sounds, along with the trumpets of everyone with me, then you also, all around the camp, must blow your trumpets and shout, 'A sword for the Lord and for Gideon!'"
Judges 7:19 So Gideon and the three hundred men with him entered the enemy camp just as the middle watch of the night was beginning, right after the guards had been posted. Immediately, they blew their trumpets and smashed the pitchers, revealing the bright torches.
Judges 7:20 and they all cried out, "A sword for the Lord and for Gideon!"
Judges 7:21 Each man stood in his position surrounding the enemy camp. All the Midianite soldiers were utterly terrified, crying out and fleeing in confusion.
Judges 7:22 As the three hundred men kept blowing their trumpets, the Lord caused all the Midianite soldiers in the camp to turn their swords against one another and strike each other down with mutual wounds.
Judges 7:23 Then, the men of Israel from Naphtali, Asher, and all of Manasseh, who had previously been sent home, were called to gather and pursue the fleeing Midianites.
Judges 7:24 Gideon also sent messengers throughout all the hill country of Ephraim, saying, "Come down to intercept the Midianites and seize the water crossings as far as Beth-barah and the Jordan River!" So, all the men of Ephraim gathered together with a great cry and secured the water crossings of the Jordan.
Judges 7:25 They captured two Midianite chiefs, Oreb and Zeb. They killed Oreb at the Rock of Oreb and Zeb at the Winepress of Zeb. Then, continuing their pursuit of the Midianites, they brought the severed heads of Oreb and Zeb to Gideon, who was waiting beyond the Jordan River.
Judges 8:1 Then the men of Ephraim came to Gideon, very angry. They demanded of him, "What is this action you have taken? You did not call us to come with you when you went to fight against Midian!" They strongly argued with him and criticized him.
Judges 8:2 Gideon responded to them: "What have I done that could compare to what you have accomplished? Is not the gleaning done by Ephraim better than the full harvest of Abiezer?"
Judges 8:3 God Himself delivered the princes of Midian, Oreb and Zeb, into your hands! How could anything I have done compare to that great deed of yours? After Gideon spoke this, their anger towards him subsided.
Judges 8:4 Gideon then reached the Jordan River and crossed it, along with the three hundred men who were with him. They were all exhausted but still in pursuit of the enemy.
Judges 8:5 He said to the men of Succoth: "Please give bread to the people who are with me, because they are weary. This way we can continue to pursue Zebah and Zalmunna, the kings of Midian, who are still fleeing."
Judges 8:6 But the officials of Succoth replied: "Do you already have the hands of Zebah and Zalmunna in your power? Are they already captured? How can we give food to your army now?"
Judges 8:7 Gideon answered: "Because of this, when the Lord delivers Zebah and Zalmunna into my hands, I will crush your flesh with thorns and thistles from the wilderness."
Judges 8:8 From there, he went up to Penuel and spoke to its men in the same manner. The men of Penuel also gave him the same reply as the men of Succoth.
Judges 8:9 So Gideon told them as well: "When I return victorious, I will tear down this tower of yours."
Judges 8:10 Now Zebah and Zalmunna were resting with their entire army, which numbered fifteen thousand men. These were all that remained from the vast camp of the Midianites, as one hundred twenty thousand warriors had already been killed.
Judges 8:11 Gideon went up by the route of the tent-dwellers, to the east of Nobah and Jogbehah. He struck the enemy camp when they felt secure and unsuspecting.
Judges 8:12 Zebah and Zalmunna fled, but Gideon pursued them and captured them, having thrown their entire army into a panic.
Judges 8:13 As Gideon returned from the battle, before sunrise,
Judges 8:14 he seized a young man from the men of Succoth. He questioned him, asking for the names of the leaders and elders of Succoth, and the young man wrote down seventy-seven men.
Judges 8:15 Then Gideon went to the men of Succoth and said: "Here are Zebah and Zalmunna! These are the men concerning whom you mocked me, saying: 'Is the hand of Zebah and Zalmunna already in your grasp, that we should give bread to your weary men?'"
Judges 8:16 So Gideon took the elders of the city, along with thorns and thistles from the wilderness. With these, he punished and taught the men of Succoth a painful lesson.
Judges 8:17 He also tore down the tower of Penuel and killed the inhabitants of that city.
Judges 8:18 Then Gideon asked Zebah and Zalmunna: "What kind of men were those whom you killed at Tabor?" They replied: "They were like you, each one appearing as a king's son."
Judges 8:19 Gideon said to them: "They were my sons, my own brothers, whom you murdered! As the Lord lives, if you had spared their lives, I would not kill you now."
Judges 8:20 Then he turned to Jether, his firstborn son, and said: "Arise, and kill them!" But Jether did not draw his sword, because he was afraid, for he was still a mere boy.
Judges 8:21 Zebah and Zalmunna then said to Gideon: "You yourself, arise and kill us. For a man's strength is according to his age." So Gideon rose and killed Zebah and Zalmunna, and he took the ornaments from the necks of their camels.
Judges 8:22 Then all the men of Israel said to Gideon: "Rule over us, you and your son and your grandson, because you have delivered us from the hand of Midian."
Judges 8:23 But Gideon said to them: "I will not rule over you, nor will my son rule over you. The Lord alone will rule over you."
Judges 8:24 And Gideon said to them: "I have one request to make of you. Give me the earrings from your plunder." (For the Ishmaelites, who were the Midianites, were accustomed to wearing golden earrings.)
Judges 8:25 They replied: "We will gladly give them!" So they spread out a cloak, and each man threw into it the earrings from his plunder.
Judges 8:26 The weight of the golden earrings that Gideon had requested was seventeen hundred shekels of gold. This was besides the ornate crescents, pendants, and purple garments that the kings of Midian usually wore, and also the chains from the camels' necks.
Judges 8:27 Gideon made an ephod from this gold and placed it in his city, Ophrah. All of Israel committed spiritual adultery by worshiping it there, and it became a snare and ruin for Gideon and his entire household.
Judges 8:28 So Midian was humbled before the sons of Israel and could no longer lift their heads in pride. The land enjoyed peace for forty years, throughout the time Gideon governed them.
Judges 8:29 Then Jerubbaal, who was Gideon the son of Joash, went and lived in his own house.
Judges 8:30 Gideon had seventy sons, who were his direct offspring, for he had many wives.
Judges 8:31 His concubine, whom he kept in Shechem, also bore him a son, whose name was Abimelech.
Judges 8:32 Gideon, the son of Joash, died at a good old age. He was buried in the tomb of Joash his father, in Ophrah of the family of the Abiezrites.
Judges 8:33 After Gideon died, the sons of Israel turned away from God and committed spiritual adultery with the Baals. They established a covenant with Baal-berith, promising to worship him as their god.
Judges 8:34 They did not remember the Lord their God, who had delivered them from the hand of all their surrounding enemies.
Judges 8:35 Nor did they show kindness to the household of Jerubbaal, that is, Gideon, in return for all the good he had done for Israel.
Judges 8:1 The men of Ephraim said to Gideon, "What is this thing you have done? You did not call us when you went out to fight against Midian." And they argued with him very vehemently because of this.
Judges 8:2 To them, he replied, "What could I have done that was like what you have done? Is not the gleaning of Ephraim better than the full harvest of Abiezer?"
Judges 8:3 God has delivered into your hands the princes of Midian, Oreb and Zeb. What could I have done that was like what you have accomplished? When he had spoken these words, their anger, with which they had been swelling, subsided.
Judges 8:4 Gideon then came to the Jordan River, and he crossed over, along with the three hundred men who were with him. They were exhausted and hungry.
Judges 8:5 And he said to the men of Succoth, "Please give bread to the people who are with me, because they are faint and extremely hungry. I am pursuing Zebah and Zalmunna, the kings of Midian."
Judges 8:6 The princes of Succoth replied, "Are the hands of Zebah and Zalmunna already in your power, that we should give bread to your army?"
Judges 8:7 Gideon said, "Because of this, when the Lord has delivered Zebah and Zalmunna into my hands, I will tear your flesh with the thorns and thistles of the wilderness."
Judges 8:8 From there, he also went up to Penuel and spoke to them in a similar way. The men of Penuel responded to him just as the men of Succoth had replied.
Judges 8:9 And he also said to them, "When I return victorious, I will destroy this tower."
Judges 8:10 Zebah and Zalmunna, however, were resting with their entire army, all fifteen thousand men who remained of all the eastern forces. Indeed, one hundred twenty thousand fighting men had already been slain.
Judges 8:11 And Gideon went up by the way of those who lived in tents, on the east side of Nobah and Jogbehah, and he struck the enemy's camp, because they felt secure.
Judges 8:12 Zebah and Zalmunna fled, and Gideon pursued them and captured them, throwing their entire army into confusion.
Judges 8:13 Gideon returned from the battle before the sun rose.
Judges 8:14 He seized a young man from the men of Succoth and questioned him about the names of the princes and elders of Succoth. The young man wrote down seventy-seven men.
Judges 8:15 Then he came to the men of Succoth and said, "Here are Zebah and Zalmunna, about whom you taunted me, saying, 'Are the hands of Zebah and Zalmunna already in your power, that we should give bread to your weary men?'"
Judges 8:16 So he took the elders of the city, and the thorns and thistles of the wilderness, and with them, he threshed and crushed the men of Succoth.
Judges 8:17 He also pulled down the tower of Penuel, killing its inhabitants.
Judges 8:18 And he said to Zebah and Zalmunna, "What kind of men were those whom you killed at Tabor?" They replied, "They were like you, each one appearing like a son of a king."
Judges 8:19 To them, he said, "They were my brothers, the sons of my mother. As the Lord lives, if you had spared them, I would not kill you now."
Judges 8:20 Then he said to Jether, his firstborn son, "Rise and kill them." But he did not draw his sword, because he was afraid, for he was still a boy.
Judges 8:21 Zebah and Zalmunna said, "Rise yourself and kill us, for a man's strength is according to his age." So Gideon rose and killed Zebah and Zalmunna, and he took the ornaments and the golden chains from their camels.
Judges 8:22 Then all the men of Israel said to Gideon, "Rule over us, you, and your son, and your grandson, because you have delivered us from the hand of Midian."
Judges 8:23 To them, he said, "I will not rule over you, nor will my son rule over you. The Lord alone will rule over you."
Judges 8:24 And he said to them, "I have one request to ask of you: give me the earrings from your plunder." For the Ishmaelites had golden earrings.
Judges 8:25 They replied, "We will gladly give them." Spreading out a cloak, they each threw into it the earrings they had been able to seize.
Judges 8:26 The weight of the golden earrings that he had requested was one thousand seven hundred shekels of gold, besides the ornaments, necklaces, and the purple garments that the kings of Midian had worn, and the chains from the camels.
Judges 8:27 Gideon made an ephod from it and placed it in his city, Ophrah. And all of Israel prostituted themselves after it—worshipping this idol—and it became a ruin for Gideon and for all his house.
Judges 8:28 So Midian was humbled before the sons of Israel, and they could not lift up their heads any longer. And the land had rest for forty years, during the time Gideon ruled.
Judges 8:29 So Jerubbaal, the son of Joash, went and lived in his own house.
Judges 8:30 He had seventy sons who were born from his own body, for he had many wives.
Judges 8:31 And his concubine, whom he had in Shechem, bore him a son named Abimelech.
Judges 8:32 Gideon, the son of Joash, died in a good old age and was buried in the tomb of Joash his father, in Ophrah of the family of Abiezrites.
Judges 8:33 After Gideon died, the sons of Israel turned away and prostituted themselves after the Baals. They set up Baal-Berith as their god.
Judges 8:34 They did not remember the Lord their God, who had delivered them from the hand of all their enemies all around them.
Judges 8:35 Nor did they show kindness to the house of Jerubbaal, that is, Gideon, in return for all the good that he had done for them.
Judges 8:36 At that time, Abimelech, the son of Jerubbaal, went to Shechem, to the brothers of his mother, and spoke to them and to all the relatives of his mother's family, saying:
Judges 8:37 "Which is better for you: that seventy men, all the sons of Jerubbaal, rule over you, or that one man rule over you? Consider also that I am your bone and your flesh."
Judges 8:38 The brothers of his mother spoke concerning him all these words to all the men of Shechem, and they inclined their hearts toward Abimelech, saying, "He is our brother."
Judges 8:39 They gave him seventy shekels of silver from the temple of Baal-Berith. With this money, he hired worthless and reckless men, and they followed him.
Judges 8:40 Then he came to his father's house in Ophrah and killed his brothers, the sons of Jerubbaal—seventy men—on one stone. Only Jotham, the youngest son of Jerubbaal, remained alive, because he had hidden himself.
Judges 9:1 Abimelech, who was the son of Jerubaal, went to Shechem, to his mother’s brothers. He spoke to them and to all the family of his mother’s father, saying:
Judges 9:2 “Tell the men of Shechem to listen carefully to what I say: Which is better for you—that seventy men rule over you, all the sons of Jerubaal, or that one man rule over you? Also, remind them that I am your own flesh and blood, your brother.”
Judges 9:3 His mother’s brothers then spoke all these words about Abimelech to all the men of Shechem. And the hearts of the men of Shechem were inclined toward Abimelech, for they said, “He is our brother, after all.”
Judges 9:4 And so they gave him seventy pieces of silver from the temple of Baal-Berith. With this silver, Abimelech hired worthless and wandering men, and they followed him.
Judges 9:5 Abimelech then went to his father’s house in Ophrah. There, on a single stone, he killed his brothers, the seventy sons of Jerubaal. Only Jotham, Jerubaal’s youngest son, remained alive because he had hidden himself.
Judges 9:6 So all the men of Shechem and all the families of the city of Millo gathered together. They went and made Abimelech king beside the oak tree that stood in Shechem.
Judges 9:7 When this was told to Jotham, he went and stood on the top of Mount Gerizim. He raised his voice and cried out, saying, “Listen to me, you men of Shechem, and may God listen to you!”
Judges 9:8 “Once, the trees went out to anoint a king over themselves. They said to the olive tree: ‘Rule over us.’
Judges 9:9 But the olive tree answered: ‘Can I give up my oil, by which both God and men are honored, and go to wave over the other trees?’
Judges 9:10 Then the trees said to the fig tree: ‘Come, you, and rule over us.’
Judges 9:11 But the fig tree answered them: ‘Can I give up my sweetness and my excellent fruit, and go to wave over the other trees?’
Judges 9:12 Then the trees spoke to the vine: ‘Come, and rule over us.’
Judges 9:13 But the vine answered: ‘Can I give up my wine, which gladdens both God and men, and go to wave over the other trees?’
Judges 9:14 Then all the trees said to the bramble: ‘Come, and rule over us.’
Judges 9:15 And the bramble answered them: ‘If you truly wish to anoint me as your king, then come and rest in my shadow. But if not, then let fire come out from the bramble and consume the cedars of Lebanon.’
Judges 9:16 “Now then, if you have acted with sincerity and truth, and have dealt well with Jerubaal and his household, and have given him a fitting reward for the injuries he endured from you —
Judges 9:17 he who fought for you, who put his life in danger to deliver you from the hand of Midian —
Judges 9:18 and yet you have risen up today against my father’s household, and have killed his seventy sons upon one stone, and have made Abimelech, the son of his maidservant, king over the men of Shechem, simply because he is your brother —
Judges 9:19 if therefore you have acted with sincerity and truth today with Jerubaal and his household, then rejoice today in Abimelech, and let him also rejoice in you.
Judges 9:20 But if you have not, then let fire come out from Abimelech and consume the inhabitants of Shechem and the house of Millo. And let fire come out from Shechem and from the house of Millo and consume Abimelech.”
Judges 9:21 When Jotham had finished cursing them, he fled to Beer, and he stayed there because of his brother Abimelech.
Judges 9:22 So Abimelech reigned over Israel for three years.
Judges 9:23 Then God sent an evil spirit to cause trouble between Abimelech and the inhabitants of Shechem. And the men of Shechem began to detest him.
Judges 9:24 This happened so that the evil done against Jerubaal’s sons might come to pass, and their blood would be avenged upon Abimelech, their brother, and upon the other Shechemites who had helped him kill his brothers.
Judges 9:25 And the men of Shechem set ambushes against him on the tops of the mountains. While they lay in wait for his coming, they committed robberies, taking plunder from those who passed by. This was reported to Abimelech.
Judges 9:26 But then Gaal, the son of Ebed, came with his brothers and moved into Shechem. At his arrival, the inhabitants of Shechem were encouraged.
Judges 9:27 They went out into the fields, harvested their vineyards, and trod the grapes in the winepresses. They then held feasts, and entering the temple of their god, they ate and drank together, and they cursed Abimelech.
Judges 9:28 Gaal, the son of Ebed, cried out: “Who is Abimelech, and who are we in Shechem, that we should serve him? Is he not the son of Jerubaal? And isn’t Zebul his officer? Serve the men of Hamor, the founder of Shechem! Why should we serve this man?
Judges 9:29 If only I were given charge of this people, I would remove Abimelech! I would then say to Abimelech: ‘Gather your army and come out!’”
Judges 9:30 When Zebul, the ruler of the city, heard the words of Gaal, the son of Ebed, he became very angry.
Judges 9:31 He secretly sent messengers to Abimelech, saying: “Look, Gaal, the son of Ebed, has come to Shechem with his brothers, and he is stirring up the city against you.
Judges 9:32 Therefore, rise up at night with your people and lie in wait in the fields.
Judges 9:33 At first light, as the sun rises, rush upon the city. And when Gaal and his people come out against you, then do to him whatever you can.”
Judges 9:34 So Abimelech rose up at night with all his army, and they set ambushes near Shechem in four companies.
Judges 9:35 And Gaal, the son of Ebed, went out and stood at the entrance of the city gate. Then Abimelech and all the army with him rose up from their ambush.
Judges 9:36 Gaal saw the people and said to Zebul: “Look, a multitude is coming down from the mountains!” But Zebul answered him: “You are seeing the shadows of the mountains as if they were men’s heads, and you are being deceived by this error.”
Judges 9:37 Again, Gaal said: “Look, troops are coming down from the center of the land, and one company is coming by the road that looks toward the Diviners’ Oak.”
Judges 9:38 Then Zebul said to him: “Where is your mouth now, with which you said: ‘Who is Abimelech, that we should serve him?’ Is this not the very people you despised? Go out now and fight against him!”
Judges 9:39 So Gaal went out, with the people of the city watching, and fought against Abimelech.
Judges 9:40 But Abimelech pursued him. Gaal was put to flight and wounded, and many dead bodies lay slaughtered all the way to the city gate.
Judges 9:1 Abimelech, the son of Jerubbaal, went to Shechem to his mother's brothers. He spoke to them and to all the relatives of his mother's household, saying:
Judges 9:2 "Please, speak to all the leaders of Shechem: Which is better for you: that seventy men, all the sons of Jerubbaal, rule over you, or that one man rules over you? Remember also that I am your own flesh and blood."
Judges 9:3 So his mother's brothers spoke all these words about him to all the leaders of Shechem. Their hearts were swayed to follow Abimelech, for they said: "He is our own flesh and blood, our brother."
Judges 9:4 Then they gave him seventy pieces of silver from the treasury of the temple of Baalphakor. With this money, he hired worthless and vagrant men, and they followed him.
Judges 9:5 He went to his father's house in Ephra and killed his brothers, the seventy sons of Jerubbaal, on one stone. But Joatham, the youngest son of Jerubbaal, remained alive, because he had hidden himself.
Judges 9:6 Then all the men of Shechem and all the citizens of the city of Mello gathered together. They went and made Abimelech their king beside the oak tree that stood in Shechem.
Judges 9:7 When this was told to Joatham, he went and stood on the top of Mount Garizim. He raised his voice and cried out, saying: "Listen to me, you men of Shechem, and may God listen to you."
Judges 9:8 "The trees once went out to anoint a king over themselves. They said to the olive tree, 'Rule over us!'"
Judges 9:9 "But the olive tree answered: 'Can I truly leave my rich oil, which both God and men use, to go and be exalted among the trees?'"
Judges 9:10 "Then the trees said to the fig tree: 'Come and rule over us!'"
Judges 9:11 "But the fig tree answered: 'Can I truly leave my sweetness and my excellent fruits to go and be moved about among the other trees?'"
Judges 9:12 "So the trees spoke to the grapevine: 'Come and rule over us!'"
Judges 9:13 "But the grapevine answered: 'Can I truly leave my wine, which makes God and men joyful, to go and serve among the other trees?'"
Judges 9:14 "Then all the trees said to the bramble: 'Come and rule over us!'"
Judges 9:15 "And the bramble answered them: 'If you truly want to make me your king, then come and take shelter in my shadow. But if not, let fire come out of the bramble and consume the cedars of Lebanon!'"
Judges 9:16 "Now therefore, if you have acted rightly and without sin by making Abimelech your king, and if you have dealt well with Jerubbaal and his household, and if you have repaid him for the good deeds he did for you, for he fought for you,"
Judges 9:17 "and risked his own life to deliver you from the power of Midian,"
Judges 9:18 "yet you have risen up against my father's household today and killed his seventy sons on one stone. You have made Abimelech, the son of his maidservant, king over the men of Shechem, simply because he is your brother."
Judges 9:19 "If, then, you have acted justly and without sin towards Jerubbaal and his household today, then rejoice in Abimelech, and let him also rejoice in you."
Judges 9:20 "But if you have acted wickedly, let fire come out from Abimelech and consume the men of Shechem and the city of Mello. And let fire come out from the men of Shechem and from the city of Mello and consume Abimelech!"
Judges 9:21 After Joatham had cried out these words, he fled and went to Bera, and lived there, fearing Abimelech, his brother.
Judges 9:22 So Abimelech reigned over Israel for three years.
Judges 9:23 Then the Lord sent a destructive spirit between Abimelech and the inhabitants of Shechem. They began to betray him.
Judges 9:24 This was so that the wickedness of killing the seventy sons of Jerubbaal would come upon them. Their blood would be avenged upon Abimelech, their brother who had killed them, and upon the men of Shechem who had helped him in his deeds.
Judges 9:25 The men of Shechem set up ambushes against him on the mountain peaks. While they waited for people in the passes, they committed robbery with no one stopping them.
Judges 9:26 Now Gaal, the son of Obed, came with his brothers and moved into Shechem. The inhabitants of Shechem welcomed him.
Judges 9:27 They went out into the fields, plundered the vineyards, and trampled the winepresses. They then held feasts in the temple of their god, eating and drinking together, and they cursed Abimelech.
Judges 9:28 Then Gaal, the son of Obed, cried out: "Who is Abimelech, and who are we in Shechem, that we should serve him? Is he not the son of Jerubbaal? And isn't Zebul his servant? Serve the men of Emor, the father of Shechem! Why should we serve him?"
Judges 9:29 "If only this people were under my command, I would remove Abimelech from your midst!" He then dared Abimelech: "Gather your army and come!"
Judges 9:30 When Zebul, the city's leader, heard the words of Gaal, the son of Obed, he became very angry.
Judges 9:31 He secretly sent messengers to Abimelech, saying: "Behold, Gaal, the son of Obed, has come to Shechem with his brothers and is stirring up the city against you."
Judges 9:32 "Therefore, rise up at night with the people who are with you and lie in ambush in the field."
Judges 9:33 "Then, at dawn, when the sun rises, rush upon the city. And when he and his people come out against you, do to him whatever you can."
Judges 9:34 So Abimelech rose up with all his army by night and set ambushes near Shechem in four companies.
Judges 9:35 Gaal, the son of Obed, went out and stood at the entrance of the city gate. Then Abimelech and all the army with him rose up from their ambush.
Judges 9:36 Gaal saw the people and said to Zebul: "Look! People are descending from the mountains!" Zebul answered him: "You are seeing the shadows of the mountains as if they were men's heads, and you are being deceived by this error."
Judges 9:37 Again Gaal said: "Look, people are descending from the highest point of the land, and one company is coming by the road that looks towards the diviners' oak."
Judges 9:38 Zebul answered him: "Where is your boasting now, when you said: 'Who is Abimelech that we should serve him?' Is this not the very people you despised? Go out now and fight against them!"
Judges 9:39 So Gaal went out, leading the citizens of Shechem, and fought against Abimelech.
Judges 9:40 Abimelech pursued him and put him to flight. Many fell wounded, all the way to the city gate.
Judges 10:1 After these events, Thola arose as a new leader in the nation of Israel. He was the son of Phua, who was Abimelech's paternal uncle. Thola was a man from the tribe of Issachar, and he lived in Samir, in the mountains of Ephraim.
Judges 10:2 He judged Israel for twenty-three years. Then he died and was buried in Samir.
Judges 10:3 After Thola, Jair the Galaadite arose. He judged Israel for twenty-two years.
Judges 10:4 He had thirty sons, who rode on thirty donkey colts. He also possessed thirty cities, which were named after him, 'Havoth Jair.' These cities retain that name to the present day in the land of Galaad.
Judges 10:5 Then Jair died and was buried in Camon.
Judges 10:6 But the children of Israel again did evil in the sight of the Lord. They served Baalim and Astaroth, and the gods of Syria, Sidon, Moab, the children of Ammon, and the Philistines. They abandoned the Lord and did not serve Him.
Judges 10:7 So the Lord became angry with Israel and delivered them into the hands of the Philistines and the children of Ammon.
Judges 10:8 For eighteen years, all the children of Israel who were beyond the Jordan—in the land of the Amorrhites, in Galaad—were afflicted and crushed.
Judges 10:9 The oppression was so severe that they even crossed the Jordan and ravaged Juda, Benjamin, and Ephraim. Israel became greatly distressed.
Judges 10:10 Then the children of Israel cried out to the Lord, saying, 'We have sinned against You, for we have forsaken the Lord our God and have served Baalim.'
Judges 10:11 And the Lord said to the children of Israel, 'Did I not deliver you from the Egyptians, the Amorrhites, the children of Ammon, and the Philistines?'
Judges 10:12 'When the Sidonians, Amalech, and the Chananæans oppressed you, you cried out to Me, and I delivered you from their hand.'
Judges 10:13 'Yet you have forsaken Me and served strange gods. Therefore, I will no longer deliver you.'
Judges 10:14 'Go and invoke the gods whom you have chosen. Let them deliver you in the time of your distress.'
Judges 10:15 Then the children of Israel said to the Lord, 'We have sinned; do to us whatever pleases You. Only deliver us now.'
Judges 10:16 And they cast away the strange gods from their midst and served the Lord, who was moved by their miseries.
Judges 10:17 Immediately, the children of Ammon were gathered together in Galaad and encamped there. When the children of Israel saw them, they also gathered in Maspha.
Judges 10:18 And the princes of Galaad said, each to his neighbor, 'Whoever among us first begins to fight against the children of Ammon shall be the leader of the people of Galaad.'
Judges 11:1 There was a man named Jephthah the Gileadite, a very strong warrior. He was the son of a prostitute woman, and Gilead was his father.
Judges 11:2 But when Gilead’s lawful wife had borne sons, and these sons grew up, they drove Jephthah out. They said, 'You will not be allowed to inherit anything in our father’s house, because you are the son of another woman.'
Judges 11:3 So Jephthah fled from his brothers and lived in the land of Tob. There, desperate men gathered to him, and they went out on raids with him.
Judges 11:4 After many days passed, the Ammonites began to fight against Israel.
Judges 11:5 As the Ammonites continued their advance, the elders of Gilead went to Jephthah in the land of Tob,
Judges 11:6 and said to him, 'Come, and be our leader so you can fight against the Ammonites.'
Judges 11:7 Jephthah answered them, 'Was it not you who hated me and drove me from my father’s house? Why have you come to me now, only when you are in trouble?'
Judges 11:8 The elders of Gilead said to Jephthah, 'For this reason, we have indeed come to you now. If you go with us and fight against the Ammonites, you will be the head of all who live in Gilead.'
Judges 11:9 Jephthah said to them, 'If you bring me back to fight for you against the Ammonites, and if the Lord gives them into my hand, then I will be your leader.'
Judges 11:10 The princes of Gilead said to Jephthah, 'The Lord, who hears these things, will be the judge and witness of our agreement.'
Judges 11:11 So Jephthah went with the princes of Gilead, and all the people made him their leader and commander. Then Jephthah repeated all his intentions and terms before the Lord in Mizpah.
Judges 11:12 Then Jephthah sent messengers to the king of the Ammonites with a message from him, saying: 'What conflict do you have with me, that you have come against me to lay waste my land?'
Judges 11:13 The king of the Ammonites answered Jephthah: 'Because Israel took my land when they came up from Egypt, from the Arnon to the Jabbok and to the Jordan River. Now therefore, restore those lands to me peacefully.'
Judges 11:14 Jephthah again sent messengers back to the king of the Ammonites,
Judges 11:15 to tell him: 'This is what Jephthah says: Israel did not take the land of Moab, nor the land of the Ammonites.'
Judges 11:16 Instead, when they were coming out of Egypt, they traveled through the wilderness to the Red Sea and then came to Kadesh.
Judges 11:17 Then Israel sent messengers to the king of Edom, saying, 'Allow me to pass through your land.' But Edom’s king would not agree to their requests. They also sent to the king of Moab, who likewise denied them passage. So Israel remained in Kadesh.
Judges 11:18 So Israel circled around the wilderness and all the land of Edom and Moab, and they came to the eastern side of the land of Moab. They camped beyond the Arnon River, because they did not want to enter the territory of Moab. Indeed, the Arnon forms the border between Moab and the Amorites.
Judges 11:19 Therefore, Israel sent messengers to Sihon, king of the Amorites, who reigned in Heshbon, and they said to him: 'Allow us to pass through your land to our own river.'
Judges 11:20 But even Sihon, not trusting that Israel would merely pass through his territory, gathered a large army and came to Jahaz, where he resisted them.
Judges 11:21 Then the Lord God of Israel delivered Sihon with all his army into the hand of Israel, who struck him down and took possession of all the land of the Amorite inhabitants of that region.
Judges 11:22 And all the territory of the Amorites, from the Arnon River to the Jabbok River, and from the wilderness to the Jordan River.
Judges 11:23 Therefore, the Lord God of Israel overthrew the Amorites, who dwelt in the land of Canaan, before His people Israel. And now, do you intend to possess it yourself?
Judges 11:24 Do you not possess by right whatever your god Chemosh allows you to possess? So, whatever the Lord our God victoriously obtained, shall that not become our possession?
Judges 11:25 Are you perhaps better than Balak, the son of Zippor, king of Moab? Or can you command anything against him?
Judges 11:26 When Israel lived in Heshbon and its villages, and in Aroer and its villages, and in all the cities along the Jordan River, for three hundred years—why did you not attempt anything regarding this matter during all that time?
Judges 11:27 Therefore, I have not sinned against you, but you are acting wickedly against me by bringing war upon me. May the Lord, the Judge, decide this day between Israel and the Ammonites.
Judges 11:28 But the king of the Ammonites would not agree to the words that Jephthah had sent to him through messengers.
Judges 11:29 Therefore, the Spirit of the Lord came upon Jephthah, and he marched through Gilead and Manasseh, even Mizpah of Gilead, and from there he crossed over to the Ammonites.
Judges 11:30 Then Jephthah made a solemn vow to the Lord, saying: 'If You will indeed deliver the Ammonites into my hands,'
Judges 11:31 then whatever comes out of the doors of my house to meet me, when I return in peace from the Ammonites, will be a burnt offering to the Lord.'
Judges 11:32 So Jephthah went over to the Ammonites to fight against them, and the Lord delivered them into his hand.
Judges 11:33 And he struck them down from Aroer all the way to Minnith, capturing twenty cities, and even to Abel-keramim, which was filled with vineyards, with an exceedingly great slaughter. Thus, the Ammonites were humbled before the Israelites.
Judges 11:34 Now when Jephthah returned to his house in Mizpah, his only daughter came out to meet him with tambourines and dances, for she was the first to come to meet him. Indeed, she was his only daughter.
Judges 11:35 When he saw her, he tore his clothes and cried out: 'Alas, my daughter! You have truly undone me, and you yourself are undone, for I have opened my mouth with a vow to the Lord, and I cannot go back on it!'
Judges 11:36 To him, she replied: 'My father, if you have opened your mouth to the Lord with a vow, then do to me whatever you have promised, since by this, the Lord’s vengeance has been fully accomplished against your enemies through you.'
Judges 11:37 Then she said to her father: 'Grant me only this one thing that I ask: let me go for two months so I can wander the mountains and lament my virginity with my companions.'
Judges 11:38 He replied to her, 'Go.' And he sent her away for two months. So she departed with her companions and bewailed her virginity in the mountains.
Judges 11:39 When the two months were over, she returned to her father, and he did to her as he had vowed. And she had never known a man. From that time on, a custom spread throughout Israel and became established:
Judges 11:40 that after a year’s cycle, the daughters of Israel would gather together and lament the daughter of Jephthah the Gileadite for four days.
Judges 11:2 Gilead's legitimate wife bore him sons. When these sons grew up, they drove Jephthah away, telling him: "You cannot inherit anything in our father's house because your mother was a prostitute."
Judges 11:3 So Jephthah fled from his brothers and lived in the land of Tob. There, desperate and impoverished men gathered around him and became his followers, engaging in raids with him.
Judges 11:4 A short time later, the Ammonites began to wage war against the people of Israel.
Judges 11:5 As the war intensified, the elders of Gilead went to the land of Tob to summon Jephthah back to them.
Judges 11:6 They said to him: "Come and become our leader, and fight against the Ammonites for us."
Judges 11:7 Jephthah replied to them: "Were you not the ones who hated me and drove me out from my father's house? Why do you come to me now, only when you are forced by necessity?"
Judges 11:8 But they said to Jephthah: "For this very reason we have come to you now—so that you may go with us and fight against the Ammonites, and you will become the head over all who live in Gilead."
Judges 11:9 Jephthah then said to them: "If you have truly come to me so that I may fight for you against the Ammonites, and if the Lord hands the enemy into my power, will I truly be your leader?"
Judges 11:10 They answered him: "The Lord, who hears these words, He Himself is the arbiter and witness, that what we have promised, we will fulfill in deed."
Judges 11:11 So Jephthah went with the elders of Gilead, and all the people made him their leader and commander. Jephthah then spoke all his solemn words and promises before the Lord in Mizpah.
Judges 11:12 Jephthah then sent messengers to the king of the Ammonites, to say in his name: "What dispute is between us, that you have come against me to lay waste to my land?"
Judges 11:13 To them, the king of Ammon replied: "Because Israel took away my land when they came up from Egypt, from the borders of the Arnon River all the way to the Jabbok River and the Jordan River. Therefore, return it to me now peacefully."
Judges 11:14 Jephthah, in turn, sent messengers again to the king of the Ammonites.
Judges 11:15 He commanded them to tell the Ammonite king: "Jephthah says this: Israel did not take away the land of Moab, nor the land of the Ammonites."
Judges 11:16 "Instead, when they came out of Egypt, they traveled through the wilderness to the Red Sea, and then they came to Kadesh."
Judges 11:17 "Israel sent messengers to the king of Edom, saying: 'Allow me to pass through your land.' But he refused to agree to their requests. They also sent to the king of Moab, who likewise scorned to grant them passage. So Israel remained in Kadesh."
Judges 11:18 "And so, Israel went around all the land of Edom and the land of Moab, and they came to the eastern side of the land of Moab. They camped beyond the Arnon River, and they did not wish to enter the territory of Moab, because the Arnon River was indeed the border of the land of Moab."
Judges 11:19 "Therefore, Israel sent messengers to Sihon, king of the Amorites, who lived in Heshbon, and they said to him: 'Allow us to pass through your land all the way to the river.'"
Judges 11:20 "But he also did not allow Israel to pass through his territory. Instead, he gathered his army, went out against them at Jahaz, and strongly resisted them in battle."
Judges 11:21 "And the Lord God of Israel delivered Sihon with all his army into the hand of Israel. Israel defeated him and took possession of all the land of that region's Amorite inhabitants."
Judges 11:22 "And they possessed all his territory, from the Arnon River to the Jabbok River, and from the wilderness to the Jordan River."
Judges 11:23 "So then, the Lord God of Israel drove out the Amorites, with His people Israel fighting against them. And now you, Ammonites, want to take possession of their land, which is now ours?"
Judges 11:24 "Do you not possess by right whatever Chemosh, your god, has given you? So also, what the Lord our God has victoriously obtained, shall pass into our possession."
Judges 11:25 "Unless perhaps you are greater than Balak, son of Zippor, king of Moab, or you can command him to do something."
Judges 11:26 "For three hundred years, Israel has lived in Heshbon and its surrounding villages, and in Aroer and its villages, and in all the cities along the Jordan River. Why, during all this time, have you not attempted anything about this matter?"
Judges 11:27 "Therefore, I have not sinned against you. Rather, you are acting wickedly against me by bringing unjust wars upon me. May the Lord, the Judge, decide today between Israel and the Ammonites."
Judges 11:28 But the king of the Ammonites refused to listen to the words that Jephthah had sent to him through his messengers.
Judges 11:29 Then the Spirit of the Lord came upon Jephthah, empowering him. He passed through Gilead and Manasseh, then through Mizpah of Gilead, and from there he advanced against the Ammonites.
Judges 11:30 And Jephthah made a solemn vow to the Lord, saying: "If You will deliver the Ammonites into my hand,"
Judges 11:31 "Then whoever comes out first from the doors of my house to meet me when I return in peace from the Ammonites, that person I will offer up as a burnt offering to the Lord." This vow indicates a human sacrifice, a forbidden practice, which Jephthah misunderstands as pleasing to God.
Judges 11:32 So Jephthah crossed over to the Ammonites to fight against them, and the Lord delivered them into his hand.
Judges 11:33 He struck them down from Aroer all the way to Minnith, capturing twenty cities, and continuing as far as Abel-Keramim, which means "plain of the vineyards," inflicting an exceedingly great slaughter upon them. Thus, the Ammonites were subdued by the people of Israel.
Judges 11:34 When Jephthah returned to his house in Mizpah, his only daughter came out to meet him, celebrating with tambourines and dances. She was his only child; he had no other sons or daughters.
Judges 11:35 When he saw her, he tore his clothes and cried out: "Oh, my daughter! You have brought me to despair, and you yourself are in despair! I have opened my mouth in a solemn vow to the Lord, and I cannot go back on it."
Judges 11:36 To him, she replied: "My father, if you have opened your mouth in a vow to the Lord, do to me whatever you have promised, since the Lord has granted you victory and vengeance over your enemies."
Judges 11:37 She then said to her father: "Grant me only this one request: let me go for two months to wander among the mountains and mourn my virginity with my companions."
Judges 11:38 He answered her: "Go." And he sent her away for two months. When she had gone with her companions, she wept over her virginity in the mountains.
Judges 11:39 When the two months were completed, she returned to her father, and he did to her as he had vowed. She had known no man, remaining a virgin. From that time on, a custom prevailed in Israel and was observed:
Judges 11:40 That year after year, the daughters of Israel would gather together and lament for the daughter of Jephthah the Gileadite, for four days.
Judges 12:1 The men from the tribe of Ephraim then gathered themselves and crossed to the northern region, confronting Jephthah. They demanded: "Why did you go to war against the Ammonites, and not call us to come with you? You will not get away with this insult to our honor; we will burn you and your entire household with fire!"
Judges 12:2 Jephthah replied to them: "My people and I endured fierce battles against the Ammonites. And when I desperately called for your help, you did not provide any assistance."
Judges 12:3 Seeing that you were unwilling to offer any assistance, I risked my life and went against the Ammonites. The Lord delivered them into my hands. Why, then, have you come today to fight against me?
Judges 12:4 Jephthah then said to all the men of Gilead: "The conflict is now between me, all of you, and Ephraim. For they have said, 'You Gileadites are nothing but runaways from among Ephraim and Manasseh!'"
Judges 12:5 Therefore, the Gileadites occupied all the fords of the Jordan River, through which the men of Ephraim were expected to return. When any man from Ephraim approached them there and said, "Please let me cross over,"
Judges 12:6 The Gileadites would ask him, "Are you an Ephraimite?" When he answered, "No, I am not," they would say, "Then say 'Shibboleth'—"a word that means 'ear of grain'. If he pronounced it differently from how it sounded to their ears, he was immediately seized and killed at the Jordan River fords. At that time, forty-two thousand men from Ephraim died in this way.
Judges 12:7 So Jephthah the Gileadite judged Israel for six years. Then he died and was buried in his city, Gilead.
Judges 12:8 After him, Abesan from Bethlehem judged Israel.
Judges 12:9 He had thirty sons and thirty daughters. He sent his daughters out to be married, and brought wives for his sons from outside his family. He judged Israel for seven years.
Judges 12:10 Then he died and was buried in Bethlehem.
Judges 12:11 Ahialon the Zebulunite succeeded him and judged Israel for eight years.
Judges 12:12 Then he died and was buried in Zebulun.
Judges 12:13 After him, Abdon, the son of Hillel, from Pirathon, judged Israel.
Judges 12:14 He had forty sons and thirty grandsons, and they rode on seventy young donkeys—a sign of their wealth and status. He judged Israel for eight years.
Judges 12:15 Then he died and was buried in Pirathon, in the land of Ephraim, on the mount of the Amalekites.
Judges 13:1 The sons of Israel once again did evil in the sight of the Lord God. So He delivered them into the power of the Philistines for forty long years.
Judges 13:2 Now there was a man from Zorah, from the tribe of Dan, whose name was Manoah. His wife was barren, and she had not been able to bear any children.
Judges 13:3 Then an angel of the Lord appeared to Manoah's wife and told her: "You are barren and without children, but you are going to conceive and give birth to a son."
Judges 13:4 "Therefore, be careful not to drink any wine or strong drink, and do not eat anything unclean."
Judges 13:5 "For you will conceive and give birth to a son whose head no razor blade shall touch. This is because he will be a Nazirite, consecrated to the Lord God from his very birth, from his mother's womb. And he himself will begin to deliver Israel from the power of the Philistines."
Judges 13:6 So the woman went and told her husband, saying: "A man of God came to me, with an angelic appearance, very awe-inspiring. When I asked him where he was from and what his name was, he refused to tell me."
Judges 13:7 "Instead, he responded with this: 'Behold, you will conceive and give birth to a son. Be careful not to drink wine or strong drink, and do not eat anything unclean, because the boy will be a Nazirite of God from his mother's womb until the day of his death.'"
Judges 13:8 So Manoah prayed to the Lord God, saying: "Oh, please, Lord, let the man of God whom You sent come to us again, and teach us what we ought to do for the boy who is about to be born."
Judges 13:9 And the Lord God heard Manoah's prayer. Again, the angel of the Lord appeared to his wife while she was sitting in the field. But Manoah, her husband, was not with her.
Judges 13:10 When she saw the angel, she hurried and ran to her husband, announcing to him: "Look, the man whom I saw before has appeared to me again!"
Judges 13:11 Manoah arose and followed his wife. When they came to the man, Manoah asked him: "Are you the one who spoke with this woman?" And he answered: "I am."
Judges 13:12 Manoah then asked him: "When your message is fulfilled, what do you want the boy to do? Or by what rules should he live?"
Judges 13:13 The angel of the Lord answered Manoah: "From everything I told your wife, he must abstain."
Judges 13:14 "Whatever comes from the grapevine he shall not eat. He must not drink wine or strong drink, and he shall not eat anything unclean. All that I commanded, he must observe."
Judges 13:15 Manoah then said to the angel of the Lord: "Please, stay a little while, and we will prepare a young goat for you."
Judges 13:16 The angel of the Lord answered him: "Even if you compel me, I will not eat your food. But if you wish to offer a burnt offering, offer it to the Lord God." Manoah did not realize that it was an angel of the Lord.
Judges 13:17 Manoah then said to the angel of the Lord: "What is your name, so that when your message is fulfilled, we may honor you?"
Judges 13:18 To this, he responded: "Why do you ask my name? It is wondrous, beyond understanding."
Judges 13:19 So Manoah took a young goat and a grain offering, and he placed them on a rock, offering them to the Lord God, who performs wondrous acts.
Judges 13:20 As the flame ascended from the altar toward the sky, the angel of the Lord also ascended in the flame. When Manoah and his wife saw this, they fell face down to the ground.
Judges 13:21 The angel of the Lord did not appear to them again. Then Manoah understood that it had been an angel of the Lord.
Judges 13:22 And he said to his wife: "We will surely die, because we have seen God."
Judges 13:23 His wife responded to him: "If the Lord God had wished to kill us, He would not have accepted the burnt offering and grain offering from our hands, nor would He have shown us all these things, nor would He have told us what is to come."
Judges 13:24 So the woman gave birth to a son, and she named him Samson. The boy grew, and the Lord God blessed him.
Judges 13:25 And the Spirit of the Lord God began to be with him in the camp of Dan, between Zorah and Eshtaol.
Judges 14:1 Samson then went down to Timnah. There, he saw a young woman who was one of the daughters of the Philistines.
Judges 14:2 He returned and told his father and his mother, saying: 'I saw a young woman in Timnah, one of the daughters of the Philistines. So now, get her for me as my wife.'
Judges 14:3 His father and mother said to him: 'Is there not a young woman among the daughters of your relatives, or among all your people, so that you would take a wife from among the uncircumcised Philistines?' But Samson said to his father: 'Get this one for me, because she pleases my eyes.'
Judges 14:4 But his parents did not know that this was from the Lord, who was seeking an opportunity against the Philistines. For at that time, the Philistines ruled over Israel.
Judges 14:5 So Samson went down with his father and mother to Timnah. When they came to the vineyards near the town, a young lion roared and sprang out against him.
Judges 14:6 Then the Spirit of the Lord came mightily upon Samson, and he tore the lion apart as if it were a young goat, even though he had nothing in his hand. He did not want to tell his father or his mother what he had done.
Judges 14:7 He went down again and spoke with the young woman who had pleased his eyes.
Judges 14:8 After some days, when he returned to take her as his wife, he turned aside to see the lion's carcass. And behold, there was a swarm of bees in the lion's mouth, and a honeycomb.
Judges 14:9 When he had taken the honeycomb from the lion's body, he ate some as he walked. When he came to his father and mother, he gave some to them, and they ate it. But he did not want to tell them that he had taken the honey from the lion's body.
Judges 14:10 So his father went down to the young woman's house. Samson then held a wedding feast there, for it was customary for young men to do so.
Judges 14:11 When the local citizens saw him, they gave him thirty companions.
Judges 14:12 Samson said to them: 'I will propose a riddle to you. If you can solve it for me within the seven days of the feast and tell me the correct answer, I will give you thirty linen garments and thirty changes of clothing.'
Judges 14:13 'But if you cannot solve it, then you will give me thirty linen garments and thirty changes of clothing.' They replied: 'Propose your riddle so we can hear it.'
Judges 14:14 So he said to them: 'Out of the eater came something to eat, and out of the strong came something sweet.' And they could not solve the riddle for three days.
Judges 14:15 When the fourth day came, they said to Samson's wife: 'Coax your husband and get him to tell you what the riddle means. Otherwise, we will burn you and your father's house with fire. Were we invited to this wedding just to be impoverished?'
Judges 14:16 So Samson's wife wept before him and said: 'You hate me and do not love me! That is why you have not told me the riddle you proposed to my countrymen!' He replied: 'I wouldn't even tell my own father and mother, so why should I tell you?'
Judges 14:17 Yet she wept before him for the remaining seven days of the feast. At last, on the seventh day, overcome by her nagging, he told her. She immediately told all her countrymen the answer.
Judges 14:18 So before the sun set on the seventh day, the men of the city said to him: 'What is sweeter than honey? And what is stronger than a lion?' He said to them: 'If you had not plowed with my heifer, you would not have solved my riddle.'
Judges 14:19 Then the Spirit of the Lord came mightily upon Samson, and he went down to Ashkelon. There, he killed thirty men. He took their spoils and gave their garments to those who had solved the riddle. Then, in a fit of intense rage, he returned to his father's house.
Judges 14:20 But Samson's wife was given to his companion, who had been his best man.

Judges 15:1 Now, after some time had passed, during the wheat harvest, Samson visited his wife, bringing a young goat as a gift. And he said: 'I am going into my wife's room.' But her husband (Samson's father-in-law) did not allow him to.
Judges 15:2 And her father-in-law, Samson's father-in-law, said: 'I thought you truly hated her, so I gave her to your friend. But look, her younger sister is more beautiful! Take her instead.'
Judges 15:3 Samson replied: 'From this moment on, no Philistine can blame me for anything. I will certainly bring harm upon you people.'
Judges 15:4 So Samson went and caught three hundred foxes. He then tied their tails together, two by two, and placed a torch between each pair of tied tails.
Judges 15:5 He lit the torches, then released the foxes so they would run through the Philistine fields. Immediately, the crops caught fire—both the harvested grain that was already stacked, and the grain still standing in the stalks. Thus, the entire Philistine region was consumed by fire.
Judges 15:6 The Philistines asked, 'Who did this?' They were told: 'Samson, the son-in-law of the man from Timnah, because he took Samson's wife and gave her to another man.' So the Philistines went up and killed her and her father by fire.
Judges 15:7 Samson said to them: 'Since you have done such a cruel thing, I will not rest until I have had my revenge on you.'
Judges 15:8 Then he struck them with a mighty blow, causing them to be crippled and fall. Afterward, he went down and stayed in the cave of the rock of Etam.
Judges 15:9 Therefore, the Philistines went up into the land of Judah and camped at Lehi—which means 'Jawbone Hill'.
Judges 15:10 The men of the tribe of Judah asked them: 'Why have you come up against us?' The Philistines answered: 'We have come to tie up Samson and make him pay for what he has done to us.'
Judges 15:11 So three thousand men from Judah went down from the rock of Etam and said to Samson: 'Don't you know that the Philistines rule over us? Why did you want to do this to us?' He replied: 'Just as they did to me, so I did to them.'
Judges 15:12 They said: 'We have come to tie you up and hand you over to the Philistines.' Samson said to them: 'Swear to me that you yourselves will not kill me.'
Judges 15:13 They responded: 'No, we will not kill you; we will only tie you up and hand you over.' So they tied him with two new ropes and took him from the rock of Etam.
Judges 15:14 When he came to the place called Jawbone Hill, and the Philistines rushed to meet him, shouting in triumph, the Spirit of the Lord suddenly came upon Samson with overwhelming power. His ropes became like burned flax, which easily comes apart at the touch of fire. His bonds simply melted away from his hands.
Judges 15:15 He found a fresh jawbone of a donkey lying there. Grabbing it, he used it to kill a thousand men.
Judges 15:16 And Samson said: 'With the jawbone of a donkey, indeed, with the jawbone of a young donkey, I have killed a thousand men!'
Judges 15:17 When he had finished speaking these words, he threw the jawbone from his hand and called that place Ramath-Lehi, which means 'Jawbone Elevation' or 'Hill of the Jawbone'.
Judges 15:18 But then a terrible thirst oppressed him. He cried out to the Lord, saying: 'You, Lord, have given this great deliverance into the hand of your servant. And now, look, I am dying of thirst and will fall into the hands of these uncircumcised enemies!'
Judges 15:19 So the Lord opened a spring from a hollow place in the jawbone (or perhaps, a hollow in Lehi itself), and water flowed out from it. After Samson drank from it, his spirit was revived, and he regained his strength. Because of this, that place was called En-hakkore, meaning 'Spring of the One Who Calls,' which is at Jawbone Hill, even to this present day.
Judges 15:20 And Samson judged Israel for twenty years during the time of the Philistines' dominance.
