Judges 15:1 After some days had passed, when the wheat harvest was finished, Samson returned to visit his wife, bringing her a young goat. And he said to her father, “I am going to my wife in her room.”
Judges 15:2 Her father answered him, “I truly believed that you hated her, and therefore I gave her to your friend. But look, she has a younger sister who is more beautiful than her; take her instead of your wife.”
Judges 15:3 Samson then said to him, “I am innocent concerning the Philistines at this time, for I will surely bring them trouble anyway.”
Judges 15:4 And he went and began to catch three hundred foxes. He tied their tails together in pairs and placed a torch between each pair of tails.
Judges 15:5 He lit the torches on fire, then released the foxes into the Philistines’ grain fields. The flames immediately burned up the standing grain, both in the fields and in the vineyards and olive groves, causing widespread destruction.
Judges 15:6 Then the Philistines asked, “Who did this?” And they were told, “Samson, the son-in-law of the man from Timnah, because he took his wife and gave her to another man.” So the Philistines went up and burned her and her father with fire.
Judges 15:7 Samson said to them, “Since you have done this, I will surely take revenge on you for this injustice, and then I will be satisfied.”
Judges 15:8 And he struck them down with a mighty blow, crushing them from thigh to shin. Then he went down and stayed in the cave in the rock of Etam.
Judges 15:9 Then the Philistines went up into the land of Judah and camped in a place that was later called Lehi, which means 'Jawbone,' where their army had gathered.
Judges 15:10 The tribe of Judah asked them, “Why have you come up against us?” They answered, “We have come to tie up Samson and hand him over to the Philistines, for he has done evil things to us.”
Judges 15:11 So three thousand men from Judah went down to the cave in the rock of Etam, where they tied Samson up and delivered him to the Philistines.
Judges 15:12 When they reached the place of Lehi, the Philistines rushed to meet him, shouting. But the Spirit of the Lord powerfully came upon Samson, and the ropes that bound him became like flax threads consumed by fire, and his loosened restraints fell from his hands.
Judges 15:13 He then found a fresh jawbone of a donkey, which was lying there at that time, and he took it up and killed a thousand men with it.
Judges 15:14 And Samson said, “With the jawbone of a donkey, with the jawbone of a young donkey, I have completely defeated them and struck down a thousand men.”
Judges 15:15 When he had finished speaking these words, he threw the jawbone from his hand and called the name of that place Ramath Lehi, which means 'Jawbone Heights' —a memorial to his victory.
Judges 15:16 Then, being intensely thirsty, he cried out to the Lord and said, “You have granted this great deliverance into the hand of your servant. And now, behold, I am dying of thirst and will fall into the hands of the uncircumcised Philistines.”
Judges 15:17 So God opened a hollow place in the jawbone at Lehi, and water came out from it. Samson drank, and his spirit was revived, and he regained his strength. Because of this, the name of that spring was called En Hakkore, meaning 'Spring of Him Who Called,' and it is known by that name to this very day.
Judges 15:18 And Samson judged Israel for twenty years during the time of the Philistines’ rule.
Judges 15:19 Samson then went to Gaza, and there he saw a prostitute, and he went in to her.
Judges 15:20 And when they had laid down, he drew his sword and killed them. And when he drew swords to enter—this phrasing is notably ambiguous in the Clementine Vulgate—they knew.
Judges 16:1 Samson traveled to Gaza. While there, he saw a harlot, and he went in to be with her.
Judges 16:2 When the Philistines heard about this, they immediately shut the city gates. They posted guards there all night, waiting silently, planning to kill Samson when he tried to escape in the morning. However, Samson slept only until the middle of the night. Rising at midnight, he seized the city gates along with both doorposts and the heavy crossbar. He hoisted the entire assembly onto his shoulders, carrying it all the way to the top of the mountain that overlooks Hebron.
Judges 16:3 After these events, Samson fell in love with a woman named Delilah, who lived in the Sorek valley.
Judges 16:4 The Philistine lords came to Delilah and said to her, “Deceive Samson. Find out from him what makes him so incredibly strong, and how we might overcome him, so we can bind and subdue him. Each of us will give you eleven hundred pieces of silver if you succeed.”
Judges 16:5 So Delilah spoke to Samson, “Please tell me, what is the secret of your exceptional strength, and what could bind you to hold you captive?”
Judges 16:6 Samson answered her, “If I am bound with seven fresh, undried bowstrings that have been twisted together, I will become weak, just like any other man.”
Judges 16:7 Then the Philistine lords brought her seven such bowstrings, still fresh as he had described, and she used them to bind him.
Judges 16:8 Some Philistine men were lying in ambush in her bedroom. Delilah cried out to Samson, “The Philistines are upon you, Samson!” But he snapped the bonds as easily as a thread of tow breaks when it touches fire. The secret of his strength remained unknown.
Judges 16:9 Delilah said to him, “See? You have mocked me and told me lies! Now, please tell me truly how you can be bound.”
Judges 16:10 Samson answered her, “If I am bound with new ropes that have never been used for any work, I will become weak, just like any other man.”
Judges 16:11 So Delilah bound him with new ropes and again cried out, “The Philistines are upon you, Samson!” while the men lay hidden in the bedroom. But he snapped the ropes off his arms as if they were mere threads.
Judges 16:12 Delilah then said to Samson, “How long will you keep deceiving me and telling me lies? Tell me how you can be overcome!” He replied, “If you weave the seven braids of my head into the fabric on the loom, and then fasten it down with a peg into the ground, I will become weak and just like any other man.”
Judges 16:13 So Delilah did this; she wove his seven braids into the fabric and fastened it with a peg to the ground. Then she cried out to him, “The Philistines are upon you, Samson!” He awoke from his sleep and pulled out the peg, along with the loom and the fabric.
Judges 16:14 Then Delilah said to him, “How can you claim to love me when your heart isn't truly with me? You have lied to me three times, and you still refuse to tell me the secret of your extraordinary strength.”
Judges 16:15 Because she was so bothersome to him, constantly pressing him with her pleas and questions day after day, his soul became distressed to the point of death.
Judges 16:16 He finally revealed his whole heart to her and said, “No razor has ever touched my head, because I have been a Nazirite, consecrated to God, from my mother’s womb. If my head were shaved, my strength would depart from me, I would become weak, all my power would leave me, and I would be just like any other man.”
Judges 16:17 When Delilah saw that he had fully revealed his heart to her, she sent a message to the Philistine lords, saying, “Come up once more, for he has now opened his whole heart to me.” So they came up, bringing the money they had promised.
Judges 16:18 Delilah made Samson sleep with his head resting on her lap. Then she called for a barber and had him shave off the seven braids of Samson’s head. Delilah then began to torment him, and his strength immediately departed from him.
Judges 16:19 She cried out to him, “The Philistines are upon you, Samson!” He woke from his sleep, thinking to himself, “I will go out as I did before and shake myself free.” But he did not know that the Lord had departed from him.
Judges 16:20 So the Philistines seized him. They immediately gouged out his eyes and led him down to Gaza. They bound him with bronze chains and put him in prison, making him grind grain.
Judges 16:21 However, his hair had already begun to grow back.
Judges 16:22 The Philistine lords gathered together to offer a great sacrifice to their god Dagon and to celebrate, saying, “Our god has delivered Samson, our enemy, into our hands.”
Judges 16:23 And when the people saw him, they also praised their god, saying the same thing: “Our god has delivered into our hands our enemy, who devastated our land and killed so many of us.”
Judges 16:24 Overflowing with joy and feasting with great enthusiasm, they commanded that Samson be called to entertain them. When he was brought from the prison, he performed for them, and they made him stand between two pillars.
Judges 16:25 Then Samson said to the boy who was guiding him, “Let me feel the pillars that support this entire house, so I can lean against them and rest for a moment.”
Judges 16:26 The house was full of men and women; all the Philistine lords were present, and on the roof, about three thousand men and women were watching Samson entertain them.
Judges 16:27 Samson then called out to the Lord, saying, “Lord God, remember me, I beg you. Strengthen me just this once more, my God, so that I may take revenge on my enemies for my two eyes.”
Judges 16:28 Then, gripping the two central pillars that supported the house, one with his right hand and the other with his left, he declared, “Let my soul die with the Philistines!”
Judges 16:29 With all his might, he pushed the pillars, and immediately the house collapsed, bringing down all the lords and everyone else who was in it. So Samson killed many more people at his death than he had killed during his entire life.
Judges 16:30 Then his brothers and all his family came down, took his body, and buried him between Zorah and Eshtaol, in the tomb of Manoah, his father. Samson had judged Israel for twenty years.
Judges 16:1 Samson also traveled to the city of Gaza, and there he saw a harlot woman, and he went in to her.
Judges 16:2 When the Philistines heard, and knew that Samson had come to Gaza, they surrounded him, and laid in wait by the city gates all night. They were silent, saying to themselves: "We will ambush him until morning, and then we will kill him."
Judges 16:3 But Samson remained there until midnight. Then he arose, and took hold of both doors of the city gate, along with their posts and the bar, and he placed them on his shoulders and carried them to the top of the mountain that faces Hebron.
Judges 16:4 After this, Samson fell in love with a woman who lived in the Valley of Sorek, and her name was Delilah.
Judges 16:5 The lords of the Philistines came to her and said: "Deceive him, and learn from him where his great strength lies, and how we might overcome him and bind him to afflict him. We, for our part, will each give you eleven hundred pieces of silver."
Judges 16:6 So Delilah said to Samson: "Tell me, I beg you, where your greatest strength lies, and what could bind you so that you could not escape."
Judges 16:7 And Samson said to her: "If I am bound with seven fresh cords, not yet dried, such as new bowstrings are usually made, then I will become weak, and be like any other man."
Judges 16:8 So the lords of the Philistines brought her seven ropes, like cords, not yet dry, with which she bound him.
Judges 16:9 While men lay hidden with her in the bedroom, she cried out: "The Philistines are upon you, Samson!" And he snapped the cords as a strand of flax is snapped if it touches fire. And his strength was still unknown.
Judges 16:10 Then Delilah said to Samson: "Look, you have mocked me and spoken falsely! At least now tell me how you ought to be bound."
Judges 16:11 Samson answered her: "If I am bound with new ropes that have never been used for work, then I will become weak, and be like any other man."
Judges 16:12 So Delilah bound him with new ropes and cried out: "The Philistines are upon you, Samson!" (The men were hidden with her in the bedroom.) And he snapped them like thread in his hands.
Judges 16:13 And Delilah said to Samson: "How long will you mock me and speak falsely? Show me how you can be bound!" Samson answered her: "If I weave the seven locks of my head with the warp, and fasten them with a peg into the ground, then I will become weak, and be like any other man."
Judges 16:14 So Delilah fastened them with a peg and a nail into the ground. And she said to him: "The Philistines are upon you, Samson!" But he rose from sleep, and pulled out the peg and the warp threads.
Judges 16:15 And Delilah said to him: "How can you say that you love me, when your heart is not with me? Three times you have lied to me, and you refused to tell me where your greatest strength lies."
Judges 16:16 And when she became troublesome, and tormented him with her words day after day, and wore down his spirit to the point of death,
Judges 16:17 he opened his whole heart to her and said: "A razor has never touched my head, for I am a Nazirite, that is, consecrated to God from my mother's womb. If my head were shaven, my strength would depart from me, and I would become weak and be like any other man."
Judges 16:18 And when Delilah saw that he had opened his whole heart to her, she sent word to the lords of the Philistines and commanded them, saying: "Come up just once more, because now he has revealed his whole heart to me." So they came up, bringing the money with them.
Judges 16:19 And she made him sleep on her lap. While he was in a deep sleep, she had his head shaven of its seven locks. And she began to afflict him and push him away, for his strength had departed from him.
Judges 16:20 And she said: "The Philistines are upon you, Samson!" He, roused from sleep, said: "I will go out and shake myself free, just as I have done before." But he did not know that the Lord had departed from him.
Judges 16:21 So the Philistines seized him, and immediately gouged out his eyes, and led him down to Gaza, bound with chains. They put him in prison and made him grind grain.
Judges 16:22 Now his shaven hair had begun to grow back again.
Judges 16:23 Now the lords of the Philistines gathered together to offer magnificent sacrifices to their god Dagon, and to feast, saying: "Our god has delivered our enemy Samson into our hands!"
Judges 16:24 When the citizens saw this, they praised their god, saying the same things: "Our god has delivered our enemy into our hands, who devastated our land and killed many of us!"
Judges 16:25 And as they were rejoicing and became even more joyful after the meal, they commanded that Samson be called to entertain them. So they brought him from prison, and he entertained them. Then they made him stand between two pillars.
Judges 16:26 And he said to the boy who was leading him by the hand: "Let me go, so that I may touch the pillars on which the whole house rests, and rest a little while."
Judges 16:27 Now the house was full of men and women, and all the lords of the Philistines were in that place. There were also about three thousand men and women on the roof, watching Samson entertain.
Judges 16:28 Then, calling upon the Lord, he said: "Lord God, remember me, and restore my former strength to me now, my God, so that I may avenge myself on my enemies, and take one vengeance for the loss of my eyes."
Judges 16:29 And Samson took hold of both pillars on which the whole house rested. He grasped one with his right hand and the other with his left, and he leaned with all his might.
Judges 16:30 And he said: "Let my soul die with the Philistines!" Then, pushing the pillars with great force, the house collapsed upon the lords and upon all the multitude who were there. And he killed many more in his death than he had killed in his life.
Judges 16:31 Then his brothers and all his relatives went down and took his body. They buried him between Zorah and Eshtaol, in the tomb of Manoah his father. And Samson had judged Israel for twenty years.
Judges 17:1 There was a man from the mountains of Ephraim whose name was Micah.
Judges 17:2 He said to his mother: 'The eleven hundred pieces of silver that you stole, and about which you cursed a thief while I heard you—look, I have them. They are with me. I've given them back to you.' To which his mother replied: 'May the Lord bless you, my son.'
Judges 17:3 So he gave back the eleven hundred pieces of silver to her. But his mother said to him: 'I have consecrated and vowed this silver to the Lord with my own hand, so that you may make an idol—both carved and cast—out of it. Now I entrust it to you.'
Judges 17:4 So the mother gave the money back to her son, who then gave it to a craftsman—both a carver and a metalworker—who made from it an idol, both carved and cast. And it was placed in Micah's house.
Judges 17:5 Micah then set up a shrine in his house, which was like a small temple. He also made an ephod and household idols (teraphim). He consecrated one of his sons, and that son became his priest.
Judges 17:6 In those days, there was no king ruling over Israel. Instead, everyone did whatever they thought was right in their own eyes.
Judges 17:7 There was also a young man from Bethlehem in Judah, from that tribe's family line. He was a Levite, but was living there as a temporary resident.
Judges 17:8 He traveled away from his city of Bethlehem, and set out to live wherever he could find a place. As he was traveling through the mountains of Ephraim, he came to Micah's house.
Judges 17:9 Micah asked him: 'Where do you come from?' He answered him: 'I am a Levite from Bethlehem in Judah, and I am going to live wherever I can, and wherever seems suitable to me.'
Judges 17:10 Micah then said: 'Stay with me, and be a father and a priest to me. And I will give you ten pieces of silver each year, two sets of garments, and your food.' So he stayed with him.
Judges 17:11 And the Levite accepted his offer as if he were a son, and held him in high regard.
Judges 17:12 Micah formally consecrated the young man (as a priest), and the young man then served Micah as his priest, living in his house.
Judges 17:13 And Micah said: 'Now I know that the Lord will bless me, because I have a Levite serving as priest.'
Judges 18:1 In those days, no king ruled over the nation of Israel. The tribe of Dan was still looking for a territory to settle in and make their home, because up to that time, they had not yet received their own land among the other tribes as an inheritance.
Judges 18:2 So the descendants of Dan sent five of their bravest men from their kinsmen in Zorah and Eshtaol, so these men could spy out the land and investigate it thoroughly. The leaders of Dan told them, “Go and examine the land.” When these men reached the hill country of Ephraim, and entered the house of a man named Micah, they rested there for a time.
Judges 18:3 While they were near Micah’s house, they recognized the voice of the young Levite. So, they turned aside a bit from their path and asked him, “Where are you from?” He replied, “I am from Bethlehem of Judah, and I am a Levite.”
Judges 18:4 Then they asked him, saying, “Please, consult the Lord for us, so we may know if the mission we are on will be successful, and if our plans will turn out as we desire.”
Judges 18:5 The Levite replied to them, “Go in peace. The Lord will make your journey prosperous, and your way will be under His protection.”
Judges 18:6 So the five men continued their journey and arrived at Laish. They saw the people living there securely, following the custom of the Sidonians, carefree and lacking nothing. There was no one to trouble them with any demands, and they were far from Sidon, not intermingling with any other people.
Judges 18:7 When the men returned to their kinsmen in Zorah and Eshtaol, they were asked what they had done. They answered,
Judges 18:8 “Rise up, and let us go up against them. For we have seen a land that is very fertile and spacious beyond measure. Come, let there be no delay! Let us go up and take possession of it, for it will require no difficult work.”
Judges 18:9 God has given us a very fertile land, with very wide territories for our inheritance.”
Judges 18:10 Then the five spies said, “When you go, you will come to a secure people, living in a spacious land. God has given it into your hands—a place where there is no lack of anything that is on the earth.”
Judges 18:11 So, from the tribe of Dan, that is, from Zorah and Eshtaol, six hundred men set out, armed with weapons for war.
Judges 18:12 They went up and encamped in Kiriath-jearim of Judah. Because of this, that place was called Mahaneh-dan, meaning 'Camp of Dan,' until the present day. It is located behind Kiriath-jearim.
Judges 18:13 From there, they passed on into the hill country of Ephraim. When they reached Micah’s house,
Judges 18:14 the five men who had previously been sent to spy out the land of Laish said to their kinsmen, “Do you know that in these houses there is an ephod, and household idols, and a carved image, and a molten image? Consider what you should do.”
Judges 18:15 And when they had turned aside a little, they came to the house of the young Levite, who was in Micah’s house. And they greeted him.
Judges 18:16 Then the six hundred men, as they were armed, stood before the entrance.
Judges 18:17 But the five men who had been the first spies went up, entered Micah’s house, and took the ephod, the household idols, the carved image, and the molten image. Meanwhile, the priest stood by the entrance, along with the six hundred armed men who were prepared for battle.
Judges 18:18 So, they went in and took the ephod, the household idols, the carved image, and the molten image. Then the priest said to them, “What are you doing?”
Judges 18:19 They replied to him, “Be silent, and put your hand over your mouth. Come with us and be a father and a priest for us. Which is better for you: to be a priest for the house of just one man, or to be a priest for a whole tribe and a family group in Israel?”
Judges 18:20 And the priest was pleased, so he took the ephod, the household idols, and the carved image, and went with the Danites, in the middle of the armed crowd.
Judges 18:21 As they proceeded on their way, they made sure their little children, their livestock, and all their valuable possessions went ahead of them for safety.
Judges 18:22 By the time they had moved a little distance from Micah’s house, those who lived in Micah’s house heard that their brothers, the Danites, were carrying off everything they had, along with their priest.
Judges 18:23 So they cried out and pursued the Danites, and when they overtook Micah, they severely rebuked him for what had happened.
Judges 18:24 Micah, responding with a tearful voice, said, “You have taken away my gods, which I made for myself, and you have taken my priest, and all that I have. And yet you ask, ‘What is wrong?’”
Judges 18:25 The men of Dan said to him, “Do not argue with us, and let no one hear you crying out, lest fierce men attack you and you lose your life, and the lives of all your household.”
Judges 18:26 And so, the Danites continued on their journey. When Micah saw that they were stronger than he and his men, he turned back and returned to his house.
Judges 18:27 Meanwhile, the Danites took what Micah had made, and they kept his priest. They then went to Laish, to a people who were at peace and secure. The Danites struck them down with the edge of the sword and burned the entire city with fire.
Judges 18:28 There was no one to help them, because they lived far from Sidon and had no alliance with any other people, either of a city or of the countryside. The place was in a valley that belonged to Beth-rehob. So the Danites built a new city and lived in it.
Judges 18:29 And the city was named Dan, after the name of their ancestor, who was a son of Israel. Previously, the city had been called Laish.
Judges 18:30 And the children of Dan set up for themselves the carved image. Jonathan, the son of Gershom, the son of Moses, and his descendants became priests for the tribe of Dan, serving there until the day of the captivity of the land.
Judges 18:31 So Micah’s idol remained with them for all the days that the house of God was in Shiloh.
Judges 19:1 It happened then in those days, when there was no king in Israel (which signified a time of great moral and social disorder), that a certain Levite man, a sojourner, was living on the side of Mount Ephraim. This Levite took for himself a concubine as a wife from Bethlehem of Judah.
Judges 19:2 She left him, and returned to her father's house in Bethlehem of Judah, and remained with him for four months.
Judges 19:3 So her husband went to her, intending to bring her back by speaking kindly to her, taking with him a servant and two donkeys. She received him and brought him into her father's house. When her father-in-law saw him, he rejoiced at his arrival.
Judges 19:4 And his father-in-law urged him to stay, and he remained with him for three days, eating and drinking and sleeping there together.
Judges 19:5 On the fourth day, as he rose early in the morning, he intended to depart. But his father-in-law said to him: "Refresh your spirits a little with food, and then you may leave."
Judges 19:6 So they sat and ate and drank together. And the girl's father said to her husband: "Please, stay here today and enjoy yourself."
Judges 19:7 But he rose, preparing to leave. And his father-in-law began to restrain him again, so he stayed there overnight once more.
Judges 19:8 Rising early on the fifth day to depart, his father-in-law said to him: "Please, refresh your spirits, and wait a little while until the day passes and it declines towards evening." And they both ate together.
Judges 19:9 When the Levite rose to leave with his concubine-wife and his servant, his father-in-law, the girl's father, said to him: "Look, the day is already drawing towards its end, and night is approaching. Stay with me today and overnight. Behold, the sun is already setting; spend the night here and enjoy yourself. And tomorrow morning you may depart and go to your own house."
Judges 19:10 He refused. Instead, he immediately set out and came opposite Jebus, which is Jerusalem, having with him two loaded donkeys, and his concubine-wife and his servant.
Judges 19:11 As they were now near Jebus, a great part of the day had passed, and the twilight (the time of gathering darkness) had fallen. And the servant boy said to his master: "Please come, let us turn aside into this city of the Jebusites and stay in it."
Judges 19:12 His master answered him: "We will not enter the town of this foreign people, who are not from Israel, but we will pass on as far as Gibeah."
Judges 19:13 And he added: "Come, let us pass through to one of the other places, and stay in Gibeah, or in Ramah."
Judges 19:14 So they passed on, and when the sun was already setting, they entered Gibeah, which is in the tribe of Benjamin.
Judges 19:15 When they had entered there, they sat in the city square, and no one was willing to receive them into their house for lodging, so that they might spend the night.
Judges 19:16 And behold, an old man appeared, returning from his work in the fields in the evening. He himself was also from Mount Ephraim and was living as a sojourner in Gibeah. The men of that city, however, were sons of Belial (meaning, utterly wicked and lawless men).
Judges 19:17 And lifting his eyes, he saw the sojourning traveler sitting in the city square, and he said to him: "Where do you come from? And where are you going?"
Judges 19:18 He replied: "We are traveling from Bethlehem of Judah as far as the side of Mount Ephraim, from which place I also come. We went to Bethlehem of Judah, and now we are returning from there, going to my own house. And there is no one who will receive us into his house."
Judges 19:19 "We have hay and fodder for our donkeys, and bread and wine for my use and for your female servant (my concubine-wife), and for the boy who is with you. We lack nothing except hospitality."
Judges 19:20 To him the old man said: "Peace be with you. Whatever you need shall be provided by my care. Only, please, do not remain in the square."
Judges 19:21 And he brought him into his house and provided fodder for the donkeys. After they had washed their feet, they received food.
Judges 19:22 After they were refreshed and cheerful, behold, the men of that city, sons of Belial (wicked men), surrounded the house and began to pound on the doors, shouting to the old master of the house, saying: "Bring out the man who has come into your house, so that we may sexually abuse him."
Judges 19:23 And the old man went out to them and said: "No, my brothers, do not do this evil, for this man has come into my house as my guest. And cease from this depravity."
Judges 19:24 "I have a virgin daughter, and this man has his concubine-wife. I will bring them out, and you may shame them and do to them whatever pleases you. Only, I beg of you, do not commit this wicked act against this man."
Judges 19:25 But they refused to listen and tried to force their way to the man. Seeing this, the man seized his concubine-wife and brought her out to them. They abused her sexually, and throughout the entire night, they violently raped her in turn. And when it was already dawning, they released her.
Judges 19:26 The woman came in the morning and collapsed at the door of the house where her husband was staying, and there she died.
Judges 19:27 And her husband opened the door in the morning, and went out to set out on his journey, and found his concubine-wife lying at the door, with her hands on the threshold.
Judges 19:28 And he said to her: "Get up, and let's go." But she did not answer, for she lay there dead. The man, realizing it was a corpse, took her up and placed her on the donkey, and returned to his house.
Judges 19:29 When he had returned there, he took a knife, and with her bones, he divided his concubine-wife into twelve parts. And he sent these parts into all the territories of Israel.
Judges 19:30 When all who saw this saw it, they said: "Nothing like this has ever happened in Israel since the day our fathers came up out of the land of Egypt, even until the present day. Consider this, men, take counsel, and speak your minds."
Judges 19:1 It happened in those days, when Israel had no king and was ruled by judges, that there was a Levite man, living in the mountainous region of Ephraim. He took a concubine wife from Bethlehem in Judah.
Judges 19:2 His concubine became angry with him and left him, returning to her father’s house in Bethlehem in Judah. She remained there with him for four months, or even longer.
Judges 19:3 Her husband then rose up and went to her, intending to bring her back by speaking kindly to her, and to take her with him. He had with him a servant and two donkeys. When the woman received him, she led him into her father’s house. When her father saw him, they rejoiced and celebrated his arrival.
Judges 19:4 The father-in-law, the woman's father, kept him for three days. During this time, the Levite ate and drank with him, and stayed at his house. On the fourth day, he rose up in the night, intending to leave.
Judges 19:5 But his father-in-law said to him, "Please, refresh your spirit a little, and taste some bread, and then you may leave."
Judges 19:6 So the Levite sat down, and both he and his father-in-law ate and drank together. Then the girl's father said to his son-in-law, "I beg you, stay here today, and let us enjoy ourselves together."
Judges 19:7 But when the Levite prepared to leave in the morning, his father-in-law urged him, saying, "Refresh your spirit, and stay here until evening." So both of them ate and drank again.
Judges 19:8 The man rose up to leave with his wife and servant. But his father-in-law again said to him, "Please, strengthen yourself, I beg you, and stay here today also. See, the sun is setting, and the day is now turning into darkness. Stay with me, eat and drink, and tomorrow morning when it becomes light, you may leave and go to your home."
Judges 19:9 But he refused. Instead, he immediately continued on his way and departed. He came opposite Jebus, which is Jerusalem, having with him his two saddled donkeys and his concubine.
Judges 19:10 Now they had approached Jebus, and night was upon them. The servant said to his master, "Please come, let us turn aside into the city of the Jebusites and stay there overnight."
Judges 19:11 But his master answered him, "We will not turn aside into a city of foreigners, who are not of Israel, but we will pass on to Gibeon."
Judges 19:12 And he added, "Come, let us hurry to one of these cities, and we will stay there, either in Gibeah or in Ramah."
Judges 19:13 So they passed by Jebus and continued on their way. The sun set for them near Gibeah, which is in the tribe of Benjamin.
Judges 19:14 They turned aside to Gibeah to stay there. When they had entered, they sat down in the city square, but no one offered them hospitality.
Judges 19:15 And behold, an old man was coming from his work in the fields in the evening. He, too, was from the mountainous region of Ephraim and was living as a sojourner in Gibeah. But the men of that region were sons of Belial—meaning wicked men—and they were unwilling to receive any guest.
Judges 19:16 Lifting his eyes, the old man saw the traveling man in the city square. He said to him, "Where are you coming from? And where are you going?"
Judges 19:17 The man answered, "I am traveling from Bethlehem in Judah to the innermost parts of the mountainous region of Ephraim, which is where I am from. I went to Bethlehem in Judah, and now I am returning from there, striving to reach my home. Yet, no one receives me into his house."
Judges 19:18 "We have straw and fodder for our donkeys, and bread and wine for our own use, and for your female servant and your male servant. We lack nothing, except this one thing: that you take us in as guests."
Judges 19:19 The old man said to him, "Peace be with you. All that you desire, I have at hand. Only, I beg you, do not stay in the city square."
Judges 19:20 So he brought him into his house and gave fodder to his donkeys. The travelers then washed their feet, and they ate and drank.
Judges 19:21 While they were refreshing themselves and feasting, suddenly the men of the city, sons of Belial—meaning lawless men—surrounded the house. They struck the door, crying out to the old master of the house, saying, "Bring out the man who has entered your house, so that we may abuse him."
Judges 19:22 The old man went out to them and said, "No, my brothers, no, I beg you, do not commit this wickedness, because this man has entered my house. Cease from this shameful act."
Judges 19:23 "Here is my virgin daughter, and here is his concubine. I will bring them out to you, so you may humble them and do to them whatever pleases you. Only, I beg you, do not commit this wicked act against the man."
Judges 19:24 But the men would not listen. They continued with their incitement and wanted to humiliate the man by force, having seized his concubine. Seeing this, the man took hold of his concubine and threw her out the door. They took her, abused her all night, and treated her with indignities until morning.
Judges 19:25 And they let her go as the day departed. But the woman, in the morning when it was already growing light, came to the door of the house where her husband was staying, and there she collapsed.
Judges 19:26 And she lay dead before the feet of her husband. He opened the door and went out, intending to prepare for his journey. He found the corpse of his wife lying on the threshold before the house, with her hands spread out over the threshold.
Judges 19:27 Thinking she was resting, he said to her, "Get up and walk." When no one responded, and realizing that she was dead, he lifted her up and placed her on the donkey. Then he returned to his home.
Judges 19:28 When he had entered his house, he seized a knife and cut the corpse of his wife, along with her bones, into twelve pieces. He then sent these pieces into all the borders of Israel.
Judges 19:29 And as such things were carried through each and every region, everyone who saw it cried out, "Nothing like this has ever happened, nor has anything like it been seen, from the day the children of Israel came out of the land of Egypt until this present day. Men, consider this matter, consult together, and speak what seems right to you."
Judges 19:30 And it was as if all of them had said with one voice, "Such a terrible and horrifying thing has never happened in Israel!"

Judges 20:1 Then all the sons of Israel went out, from Dan all the way to Beersheba in the south, and from the land of Gilead in the east.
They gathered as one man before the Lord in Mizpah, in a solemn assembly.
Judges 20:2 All the leading men of the people came, and all the tribes of Israel formed an assembly of God's people.
There were four hundred thousand foot soldiers, all experienced men of war.
Judges 20:3 Without delay, even the sons of Benjamin heard that the sons of Israel had gone up to Mizpah.
Judges 20:4 Then the sons of Israel said: "Tell us, how did this wickedness happen?"
Judges 20:5 The Levite, the husband of the dishonored concubine, responded: "I came to Gibeah of the Benjaminites with my concubine so we could stay there for the night.
Judges 20:6 But behold, the men of that city rose up against me.
They intended to burn down my house, to violate my concubine, and to brutally kill her.
Judges 20:7 When I saw that she had been horribly abused throughout the entire night, I finally let her go, dead, at the doorstep of my house.
Judges 20:8 So I took her, and cut her into pieces, and sent her to all the borders of your inheritance throughout Israelite territory.
I did this because no one had even considered what a wicked deed was committed, and no such thing has ever happened in Israel before.
Judges 20:9 Behold, you are all here, sons of Israel.
Decide what you ought to do.
Judges 20:10 Let us take ten men out of every hundred from all the tribes of Israel, and a hundred out of every thousand, and a thousand out of every ten thousand.
These men will prepare provisions for the army.
Then the rest of the army will go and strike the city of Gibeah of Benjamin, because they have committed such a disgraceful thing in Israel.
Judges 20:11 So all Israel assembled against the city as one man, with the same mind and purpose.
Judges 20:12 And they sent messengers to all the tribe of Benjamin, saying: "Why has such wickedness been found among you?"
Judges 20:13 Hand over the men of Gibeah, those sons of Belial (a term for worthless and wicked men), who committed this atrocity, so they may die and evil may be removed from Israel."
But the Benjaminites were unwilling to listen to the commands and words of their brothers, the sons of Israel.
Instead, they gathered together from their cities to help the inhabitants of Gibeah.
Judges 20:14 And those counted from the cities of Benjamin who had come armed for battle were twenty-six thousand men.
This number did not include the inhabitants of Gibeah, who were seven hundred very strong men.
Judges 20:15 From all these people, there were six hundred chosen men who used both hands as if they were their right hand (meaning they were ambidextrous or extremely skilled).
They hurled stones with slings so precisely that not a single one would miss its target.
Judges 20:16 Apart from these, there were also found among the men of Israel four hundred thousand fighting men, that is, warriors, who were all ready for battle.
Judges 20:17 These were the ones who had gathered in one place.
Judges 20:18 Then the sons of Israel came and consulted the Lord, saying: "Who among us shall go up first to battle against the sons of Benjamin?"
To them the Lord responded: "Judah will go up first."
Judges 20:19 Immediately the sons of Israel rose early in the morning and encamped near Gibeah.
Judges 20:20 And going out from there to battle against Benjamin, they arrayed themselves for battle against them near Gibeah.
Judges 20:21 And the sons of Benjamin came out from Gibeah and on that day killed twenty-two thousand men of the sons of Israel.
Judges 20:22 Again, the sons of Israel, trusting in the Lord their God and in their own might and courage, arrayed their battle line in the same place where they had fought before.
Judges 20:23 And they went up and wept before the Lord until evening.
They consulted Him, saying: "Should I go up again to battle against the sons of Benjamin, my brothers, or not?"
To them He responded: "Go up against them."
Judges 20:24 And when the sons of Israel went up against the sons of Benjamin on the next day, they fought.
Judges 20:25 And Benjamin came out from the gates of Gibeah, and again offered them battle.
They killed eighteen thousand men of Israel, all of them fighting men.
Judges 20:26 Therefore all the sons of Israel went up to the city of Bethel.
They wept before the Lord, sitting there until evening, and they afflicted themselves with fasting on that day.
They offered burnt offerings and peace offerings before Him.
Judges 20:27 And they inquired of Him concerning their deliverance and welfare.
In those days, the Ark of the Covenant of God was in Bethel,
Judges 20:28 and Phinehas, the son of Eleazar, the son of Aaron, was in charge of the house of God (the sanctuary).
And they consulted the Lord and said: "Should we go out again to battle against Benjamin our brothers, or should we stop?"
The Lord said to them: "Go up, for tomorrow I will deliver them into your hands."
Judges 20:29 So the sons of Israel rose up on the next day and went against Gibeah, and surrounded it.
Judges 20:30 And for a third time, they arrayed their battle lines against Benjamin, in their divisions, just as before.
Judges 20:31 But the sons of Benjamin boldly came out of the city and arrayed themselves to meet them.
They began to wound and kill some of the people, just as on the first and second days.
These were those who were fleeing from all the cities, and going along the highway and through various places, so that they killed about thirty men.
Judges 20:32 The Benjaminites hoped that they would rout them as before.
But while the Israelites pretended to flee, the Benjaminites, pursuing them, were drawing some away from the highway towards the city, and others into the fields.
Judges 20:33 But the sons of Israel gathered all their forces together at the place called Baal-tamar.
And their ambush was gradually revealing itself from its hiding places, that is, from the hidden area of Gibeah.
Judges 20:34 So ten thousand chosen warriors from all Israel came against Gibeah, and the battle began to rage fiercely.
But Benjamin did not understand that destruction was imminent for them.
Judges 20:35 And the Lord struck Benjamin down before the sons of Israel.
On that day, they killed twenty-five thousand one hundred men of Benjamin, all of them fighting men.
Judges 20:36 For the sons of Benjamin realized that the sons of Israel, by turning in flight from them, were making way for the ambush which Israel had set.
Judges 20:37 Then those who were in ambush suddenly rushed upon Gibeah, and spread out as they passed through.
They killed everyone in the city with swords.
Judges 20:38 Now the signal given by the army of Israel was that after they had captured the city, they would set it on fire, so that it would burn high up into the sky and indicate their impending victory.
Judges 20:39 And when the sons of Israel were already engaged in battle, Benjamin also began to see that smoke was rising from the city.
They now clearly knew the disaster that had previously been hidden from them.
Judges 20:40 And indeed, those who had feigned flight, seeing this, resisted Benjamin more strongly.
The Benjaminites, terrified, began to flee towards the city, but this did not help them.
Nor could they escape from being killed by those who had already captured the city.
Judges 20:1 Therefore, all the children of Israel came out from Baala, and they gathered as one unified man, from Dan to Beersheba, and even from the land of Gilead, before the Lord in Mizpah.
Judges 20:2 And all the chiefs of the Israelite tribes, and the tribes themselves, stood in the assembly of God's people. There were four hundred thousand armed foot soldiers, ready for battle.
Judges 20:3 Now the children of Benjamin heard that the children of Israel had gone up to Mizpah.
Judges 20:4 And immediately, the Levite, the husband of the murdered woman, spoke: 'This is an abominable thing,' he said, 'and an execrable crime that has been perpetrated in Israel. My concubine and I were in Gibeah, which is in the tribe of Benjamin, to spend the night. And behold, the men of that city surrounded us, intending to kill me, and they violently killed my concubine, so that she died.'
Judges 20:5 They burst into my home, seized my concubine, and violently abused her until she died.
Judges 20:6 Therefore, I divided her dead body into twelve parts and sent them into all the borders of Israel, so that the atrocity and the unspeakable evil committed in Israel would become known to everyone.
Judges 20:7 Now, behold, all of you, children of Israel, discern what you ought to do about this.
Judges 20:8 And all the people rose up as one unified man, saying: 'We will not go to our tents, nor will any of us return to his home.'
Judges 20:9 'But this is the plan that we ought to take now against Gibeah:'
Judges 20:10 'Let ten men be chosen out of every hundred throughout all the tribes of Israel, and a hundred out of a thousand, and a thousand out of ten thousand, to bring provisions for the army. Then the fighters can inflict upon Gibeah of Benjamin what it deserves.'
Judges 20:11 So, all the men of Israel assembled against the city as one unified man, and with one mind.
Judges 20:12 And they sent messengers to the entire tribe of Benjamin, to say: 'Why has such a great crime been perpetrated among you?'
Judges 20:13 'Hand over the men of Gibeah who committed this vile deed and crime, so that they may die, and evil may be removed from Israel.' But the sons of Benjamin were unwilling to listen to the words of their Israelite brothers.
Judges 20:14 Instead, they gathered from all their cities into one place, and together they resolved to come out against those attacking them.
Judges 20:15 There were twenty-five thousand armed fighters from the tribe of Benjamin, besides the seven hundred very strong men who were inhabitants of Gibeah.
Judges 20:16 Among all those gathered, there were seven hundred very strong men who could fight with either hand as well as with their right, and they could accurately hurl stones with slings, able to strike a single hair without missing.
Judges 20:17 From the rest of Israel also, apart from the children of Benjamin, there were four hundred thousand armed fighters, all of them men of war.
Judges 20:18 They rose up and came to the house of God, that is, to Bethel, and consulted Him, saying: 'Who among our army should go up first to battle against the sons of Benjamin?' The Lord answered: 'Judah will go up first.'
Judges 20:19 And immediately they rose up in the night and encamped near Gibeah.
Judges 20:20 And when the army of Israel had arrayed itself against Benjamin, they began the battle against them.
Judges 20:21 And the children of Benjamin came out of Gibeah and killed eighteen thousand very strong men from the children of Israel.
Judges 20:22 From this, the children of Israel gathered courage again, resolving to fight in the same place where they had first engaged in battle.
Judges 20:23 And they went up and wept before the Lord until night, and consulted Him, saying: 'Should we proceed further to battle against our brothers, the sons of Benjamin, or should we stop?' To them He responded: 'Go up against them.'
Judges 20:24 And when they had advanced on the second morning, to battle against the sons of Benjamin,
Judges 20:25 the sons of Benjamin came out from the gates of Gibeah and killed eighteen thousand more very strong, armed men from the children of Israel who were ready for battle.
Judges 20:26 Because of this, all the children of Israel came to the house of God, and sitting there, they wept before the Lord. They fasted on that day until evening and offered burnt offerings and peace offerings to Him.
Judges 20:27 And they consulted the Lord in those days, for the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord was there.
Judges 20:28 And Phinehas, the son of Eleazar, the son of Aaron, stood before it. And they inquired: 'Should we proceed further to battle against our brothers, the sons of Benjamin, or should we stop?' The Lord said: 'Go up, for tomorrow I will deliver them into your hands.'
Judges 20:29 Therefore, the children of Israel set ambushes all around the city of Gibeah.
Judges 20:30 And when the battle had been joined against Benjamin for the third time, just as it had been once and twice before,
Judges 20:31 and the Benjaminites had come out of the city, taking their usual route, they pursued those fleeing and killed about thirty men, just as before. The Israelites thought they were defeated, and Benjamin could now escape from their hands.
Judges 20:32 However, those who were hidden in ambush in the nearby places around Gibeah, when they saw the Israelites fleeing toward Gibeah, and the Benjaminites fighting in the same way they themselves were fleeing, said: 'Let us flee, and not pursue any further, lest we be wounded in the same place as them.'
Judges 20:33 But those who had been in ambush, when they saw the Benjaminites were actually defeated (and retreating into the trap), rushed upon them from behind and killed twenty-five thousand of their men.
Judges 20:34 And when they had come out from Gibeah for battle, they began to kill from among them up to seven hundred men.
Judges 20:35 And the Lord delivered Benjamin into the hands of Israel on that day. And they killed twenty-five thousand one hundred men from them, all of whom were warriors.
Judges 20:36 For the children of Israel had given ground to Benjamin, and the Benjaminites thought they had won. But those who were hidden in ambush, the messengers and warriors, had concealed themselves around Gibeah, and all were ready for the fight.
Judges 20:37 And when the children of Israel went away as if defeated, and Benjamin pursued them in their flight (for all those who were fleeing had retreated to Gibeah), those who were in the hidden places near Gibeah rushed upon them and began to kill them.
Judges 20:38 And it came to pass that, while they were pursuing the fleeing Israelites, those who were in ambush raised a signal from their hidden positions, so that the fleeing Israelites would know that the whole city was now in their power.
Judges 20:39 And they came out and occupied the city, and they killed all who were in it with the edge of the sword.
Judges 20:40 And when Benjamin saw the city occupied, and the fires from the city were now ascending into the sky, they understood that they were defeated.
Judges 21:1 The sons of Israel had also sworn an oath at Mizpah, saying, "None of us will give his daughter in marriage to a man from the tribe of Benjamin."
Judges 21:2 And all the people came to the House of God at Shiloh, and remained there until evening before the Lord, and they raised their voices and began to wail with great weeping, saying:
Judges 21:3 Why, O Lord, God of Israel, has this evil happened to Your people, that one tribe should be cut off from Israel?
Judges 21:4 The next day, rising early, they built an altar there, and offered up burnt offerings and peace offerings.
Judges 21:5 And they said, "Who is there from all the tribes of Israel who did not come up to the Lord at Mizpah?" For they had bound themselves with a solemn oath to kill those who had not come up.
Judges 21:6 And they grieved over their brother Benjamin, and said, "One tribe has been destroyed from Israel!"
Judges 21:7 From where will they find wives? For we all swore a common oath that we would not give our daughters to them.
Judges 21:8 Therefore they said, "Who is there from all the tribes of Israel who did not come up to the Lord at Mizpah?" And behold, it was found that the inhabitants of Jabesh-Gilead had not come to that place.
Judges 21:9 At that time, when the Israelites were in Shiloh, none of the people from Jabesh-Gilead had been found among them.
Judges 21:10 So the sons of Israel sent there ten thousand of their strongest men, and gave them this command: "Go and strike down the inhabitants of Jabesh-Gilead with the edge of the sword, both their wives and their little children."
Judges 21:11 And this is what you must observe: Every male, and every woman who has known a man, you are to kill; but save the virgins alive to become wives for Benjamin.
Judges 21:12 And from Jabesh-Gilead, four hundred virgins were found who had not known a man's bed, and they brought them to the camp at Shiloh, in the land of Canaan.
Judges 21:13 And they sent messengers to the sons of Benjamin, who were in the rock of Rimmon, and promised them peace.
Judges 21:14 So the sons of Benjamin came at that time, and wives were given to them from the women of Jabesh-Gilead who had been saved; but no more wives were found to be given to the remaining men, as there weren't enough.
Judges 21:15 And all the sons of Israel grieved over Benjamin, because the Lord had allowed one tribe to be diminished from His people.
Judges 21:16 And the elders said, "What shall we do about the rest of the men who have not received wives? For all the women of Benjamin were killed."
Judges 21:17 And they held this opinion: "Let Benjamin endure, and let one tribe remain in Israel, so that it may not be utterly destroyed."
Judges 21:18 But we cannot give them wives from our daughters, for we are bound by this oath: 'Cursed be he who gives a wife from his daughters to Benjamin.'
Judges 21:19 And they remembered the solemn festival of the Lord, which was celebrated every year in Shiloh. This city is located north of Bethel, on the east side of the road leading from Bethel to Shechem, and south of the town of Lebonah.
Judges 21:20 And they commanded the sons of Benjamin, saying, "Go and hide yourselves in the vineyards."
Judges 21:21 And when you see the daughters of Shiloh come out to perform their dances, then suddenly come out from the vineyards, and each of you seize a wife for yourselves from the daughters of Shiloh, and then go to the land of Benjamin.
Judges 21:22 And when their fathers and their brothers come and begin to complain to us, we will say to them: 'Forgive them, for these men did not take them by right of war or as spoils of victory. Rather, you implicitly gave them to them when we begged on their behalf. Therefore, you are free from the guilt of your oath of not giving your daughters.'
Judges 21:23 So the sons of Benjamin did as they had been instructed: and according to their number, each man seized a wife for himself from those who were accustomed to perform the dances. Then they went into their own possession, and built up cities, and lived in them.
Judges 21:24 And so, at that time, each of the sons of Israel returned to his own tribe and family, and they went out from that place, each to his own tent.
Judges 21:25 In those days there was no king in Israel; but each man did what seemed right in his own eyes, leading to chaos and ungodly acts.
Ruth 1:1 During the time when the judges ruled the land, there was a great famine in the land of Israel. So, a man from Bethlehem in Judah left his home to live as a foreigner in the country of Moab, along with his wife and his two sons.
Ruth 1:2 The man’s name was Elimelech, and his wife’s name was Naomi. They had two sons, one named Mahlon and the other Chilion. They were Ephrathites, from Bethlehem in Judah.
Ruth 1:3 Naomi’s husband, Elimelech, died there in Moab. So, she was left with her two sons.
Ruth 1:4 Her sons took wives from among the Moabite women. One wife was named Orpah, and the other was named Ruth. They lived in Moab for about ten years.
Ruth 1:5 Then both Mahlon and Chilion also died. So, Naomi was left without her two sons and her husband, completely alone.
Ruth 1:6 Naomi then decided to return from the country of Moab to her homeland, along with her two daughters-in-law. She had heard that the Lord God had visited His people in Judah and had given them food.
Ruth 1:7 So, she and her two daughters-in-law set out from the place where they had been living as foreigners. They were already on their way back to the land of Judah.
Ruth 1:8 Naomi said to her two daughters-in-law, 'Go, return each of you to your mother’s house. May the Lord God deal kindly with you, just as you have dealt kindly with your dead husbands and with me.'
Ruth 1:9 'May the Lord God grant each of you rest and peace in the home of a future husband whom you will marry.' Then she kissed them goodbye, and they began to weep loudly.
Ruth 1:10 They said to her, 'No, we will go with you to your people.'
Ruth 1:11 But Naomi answered them, 'Turn back, my daughters. Why would you come with me? Do I still have sons in my womb who could become your husbands?'
Ruth 1:12 'Go back, my daughters, go your way. For I am too old to have a husband. Even if I were to say, “I have hope,” even if I were to become pregnant tonight and give birth to sons—'
Ruth 1:13 'would you wait until they grew up? Would you refrain from marrying for them? No, my daughters, please don’t. For my distress is far greater than yours, because the Lord has turned against me.'
Ruth 1:14 Again, they wept loudly. Orpah kissed her mother-in-law goodbye and returned to her own people. But Ruth clung to Naomi.
Ruth 1:15 Then Naomi said to Ruth, 'Look, your sister-in-law has gone back to her own people and to her gods. You should go back with her.'
Ruth 1:16 But Ruth replied, 'Do not urge me to leave you or to turn back from following you. For wherever you go, I will go, and wherever you live, I will live. Your people shall be my people, and your God shall be my God.'
Ruth 1:17 'Where you die, I will die, and there I will be buried. May the Lord God do to me and more also, if anything but death separates you and me.'
Ruth 1:18 When Naomi saw that Ruth was determined to go with her, she stopped arguing with her or trying to persuade her otherwise.
Ruth 1:19 So, the two of them went on until they came to Bethlehem. When they arrived in the city, the entire city was stirred because of them, and the women exclaimed, 'Can this be Naomi?'
Ruth 1:20 She replied to them, 'Do not call me Naomi, which means 'pleasant.' Instead, call me Mara, which means 'bitter.' For the Almighty God has filled me with much bitterness and sorrow.'
Ruth 1:21 'I went out from here full, but the Lord God has brought me back empty. Why do you call me Naomi, when the Lord God has humbled me, and the Almighty God has brought calamity upon me?'
Ruth 1:22 So Naomi returned with her daughter-in-law Ruth, the Moabitess, from the country of Moab. They arrived in Bethlehem at the beginning of the barley harvest.
Ruth 2:1 Now Naomi had a relative of her husband, a man of great influence and noble lineage, from the family of Elimelech, named Boaz. This man possessed significant wealth and social standing.
Ruth 2:2 And Ruth, the Moabite woman, said to her mother-in-law, "If you permit it, I will go into a field and gather the fallen grain that the reapers leave behind, wherever I may find favor with a landowner." To this Naomi responded, "Go, my daughter." This act of gleaning was a provision for the poor.
Ruth 2:3 So she went out, and coming to a field, she gathered the grain behind the reapers. It just so happened that the field belonged to the man named Boaz, who was from the family of Elimelech. This was truly providential.
Ruth 2:4 And behold, Boaz himself was coming from Bethlehem. He said to the reapers, "The Lord be with you." And they responded to him, "May the Lord bless you." This exchange showed the respectful and pious nature of their community.
Ruth 2:5 Then Boaz said to the young man who was in charge of the reapers, "Whose young woman is this?" He noticed her as a stranger in his field.
Ruth 2:6 To whom the young man responded, "This is the young Moabite woman who came with Naomi from the region of Moab." Her foreign origin was known.
Ruth 2:7 "And she asked to gather the grain behind the reapers' footsteps, and to glean among the gathered sheaves. And since we came here, until now, she has diligently persevered in the field, and she has not even returned home for a moment." This demonstrated Ruth's exceptional work ethic.
Ruth 2:8 Then Boaz said to Ruth, "Listen, my daughter, do not go into another field to gather grain, nor depart from this place. Instead, stay close to my young women." This was a direct offer of protection and special privilege.
Ruth 2:9 "And wherever my reapers have finished, follow after them. For I have commanded my young men not to bother you. Rather, when you are thirsty, go to the water vessels and drink from the water from which my young men also drink." Boaz extended hospitality beyond mere permission.
Ruth 2:10 She, falling on her face and prostrating herself on the ground, said, "How have I deserved this, that I should find such favor in your eyes, I who am a mere foreigner?" Ruth's humility was evident.
Ruth 2:11 To whom Boaz responded, "All things have been reported to me: what you have done for your mother-in-law after the death of your husband, and how you left your parents and your native land, and came to a people whom you did not know before." Boaz was aware of her virtuous actions.
Ruth 2:12 "May the Lord repay you for your work, and may you receive a full reward from the Lord God of Israel, to whom you have come and under whose protective wings you have taken refuge." Boaz's blessing recognized her conversion to the God of Israel.
Ruth 2:13 And she said, "I have found favor in your eyes, my lord, for you have comforted me and spoken kindly to the heart of your handmaid, though I am not even like one of your own servants." She felt unworthy of such generosity.
Ruth 2:14 And Boaz said to her, "When it is time for the midday meal, come here, and eat some bread, and dip your morsel in the vinegar." So she sat beside the reapers, and he offered her bread, and she ate and was satisfied, and took some of the leftovers to save for later.
Ruth 2:15 And she rose up to continue gleaning. Boaz then commanded his young men, saying, "Even if she wishes to glean among the sheaves already gathered, do not hinder her." This was an extraordinary allowance for a gleaner.
Ruth 2:16 "But rather, from your own gathered sheaves, intentionally throw out some grain and leave it for her, so that she may collect it without any shame, and no one should rebuke her." This made her task easier and more dignified.
Ruth 2:17 So she gleaned in the field until evening. And she beat out the grain she had gathered to separate it from the stalks, and she found it amounted to about an ephah of barley. This was a substantial amount, thanks to Boaz's generosity.
Ruth 2:18 And carrying what she had collected, she returned to the city and showed it to her mother-in-law. Moreover, she brought forth and gave Naomi some of the leftover food with which she herself had been satisfied earlier. Ruth's constant care for Naomi was clear.
Ruth 2:19 And her mother-in-law said to her, "Where did you glean today, and where did you do your work? Blessed be he who had mercy on you." She told Naomi where she had worked, and she said the name of the man under whom she had worked was Boaz.
Ruth 2:20 To whom Naomi responded, "May he be blessed by the Lord, because he has shown the same kindness, as before, now also to the living and to the dead." Naomi was referring to the potential preservation of their family line. And she added, "The man is our close relative, and from our family." This revealed Boaz's role as a potential kinsman-redeemer.
Ruth 2:21 And Ruth said, "Furthermore, he also commanded me this: that I should stay close to his reapers until all the harvest is completely finished." Boaz's protection and provision were ongoing.
Ruth 2:22 To whom her mother-in-law said, "It is better, my daughter, that you go out to glean with his young women, lest you suffer any trouble or harassment in another field." Naomi wisely advised Ruth to remain under Boaz's protection.
Ruth 2:23 So she remained with the young women of Boaz and gleaned until both the barley harvest and the wheat harvest were finished. Ruth obediently continued her work, patiently awaiting God's plan.
Ruth 3:1 Then Naomi, her mother-in-law, said to her, "My daughter, shouldn't I find you a safe place to settle down, and provide for you?"
Ruth 3:2 "Look, Boaz, with whom you worked in the field, he is a relative of ours, and tonight he is winnowing barley at the threshing floor."
Ruth 3:3 "So, wash yourself, anoint yourself with oil, and put on your best clothes, and go down to the threshing floor. Do not let any man see you until he has finished eating and drinking."
Ruth 3:4 "When he lies down to sleep, observe the place where he sleeps. Then go and uncover the covering at his feet, and lie down there. And he will then take action regarding your situation, and he will then depart."
Ruth 3:5 Ruth replied, "Whatever you command me, I will do."
Ruth 3:6 So she went down to the threshing floor and did everything her mother-in-law had commanded her.
Ruth 3:7 When Boaz had eaten and drunk and was in good spirits, and had gone to lie down at the edge of the threshing floor, Ruth came secretly. She uncovered the covering at his feet and lay down there to sleep.
Ruth 3:8 And it happened in the middle of the night: the man was startled and became agitated, and he saw a woman lying at his feet.
Ruth 3:9 And he said to her, "Who are you?" She answered, "I am Ruth, your handmaid. Spread the corner of your cloak over your handmaid, for you are a near kinsman and have the right to redeem me."
Ruth 3:10 He said, "Blessed are you by the Lord, my daughter! This latter kindness you have shown is even greater than the former, because you have not pursued young men, whether poor or rich."
Ruth 3:11 "Do not fear, therefore; whatever you ask of me, I will do for you. For all the people who dwell in the gate of my city know that you are a virtuous woman."
Ruth 3:12 "And I do not wish to hinder this plan, for there is a kinsman nearer than I who has the first right of redemption."
Ruth 3:13 "Stay here tonight, and when morning comes, if he wishes to take you as his wife, it is well. But if he does not wish to take you, I will certainly take you, as the Lord lives! Sleep here until morning."
Ruth 3:14 So she slept at his feet until near daybreak, and rose before people could recognize one another. And Boaz said, "Be careful that no one knows you came here."
Ruth 3:15 And again he said, "Spread out your shawl with which you are covered, and hold it with both hands." When she had spread it out and held it, he measured out six measures of barley and placed it upon her. And she then went into the city.
Ruth 3:16 And she came to her mother-in-law, who said to her, "How did you fare, my daughter?" And she told her everything the man had done for her.
Ruth 3:17 And she said, "He gave me these six measures of barley, and he said, 'Do not return empty-handed to your mother-in-law.'"
Ruth 3:18 Then Naomi said, "Wait, my daughter, until we see what outcome this matter will have. For the man will not rest until he has completed his word and settled the business today."
