Ruth 4:1 So Boaz went up to the city gate, which was where all legal and social matters were decided, and he sat there. When he saw the close relative—the one he had spoken about concerning the land and Ruth—passing by, he called out to him by name and said, "Step aside for a moment, and sit down here with me." So the kinsman turned aside from the path and sat down with Boaz.
Ruth 4:2 Boaz then gathered ten men from among the elders of the city—these were the necessary witnesses for legal transactions—and said to them, "Please sit down here."
Ruth 4:3 Once they were all seated, Boaz spoke to the close relative, explaining the situation: "Naomi, who has returned from the land of Moab, is selling the portion of the field that belonged to our relative Elimelech."
Ruth 4:4 "I thought it was necessary to tell you this now, and to inform you in the presence of all these sitting here, especially the elders of the city. If you wish to redeem the property by your right as a close relative, then buy it and take possession of it. But if you do not wish to redeem it, then you must let me know so that I can proceed, because I am the next in line to you to exercise the right of a close relative to redeem the land. Therefore, there is no other person besides you who has the right of redemption, and I am next after you." The kinsman immediately responded, "I will redeem it."
Ruth 4:5 Boaz then explained, "When you buy the field from Naomi, you must also take Ruth the Moabitess as your wife, she who was the wife of the deceased. This is to ensure that the name of the deceased man is continued in his inheritance and does not perish."
Ruth 4:6 The kinsman replied, "I must surrender my right of redemption. I cannot protect this inheritance for myself without causing harm to my own estate; I would risk the future of my own firstborn son. So, you must use my privilege, which I know I am unable to use myself."
Ruth 4:7 Now, this was the established custom in Israel among close relatives when someone surrendered their right of redemption, in order that a transfer of property would be confirmed and legally binding: a man would take off his sandal and give it to his neighbor. This act served as a clear testimony of the surrender of rights in Israel.
Ruth 4:8 So Boaz said to the close relative, "Then take off your sandal, as is the custom." And immediately, the kinsman took it off his foot.
Ruth 4:9 Then Boaz solemnly declared to the elders and to all the people present, "You are all witnesses today that I have acquired everything that belonged to Elimelech, and everything that belonged to Chilion and Mahlon, all of it from the hand of Naomi."
Ruth 4:10 "And I have also taken Ruth the Moabitess, who was the wife of Mahlon, to be my own wife. My purpose in doing this is to perpetuate the name of the deceased within his inheritance, so that his name will not be cut off from among his relatives, nor from the register at the gate of his hometown. I declare to you that you are indeed witnesses of this matter."
Ruth 4:11 All the people who were sitting in the city gate, along with the elders, responded, "We are indeed witnesses! May the Lord make your wife, Ruth, like Rachel and Leah, who together built up the entire household of Israel. May you yourself become an example of strength and prosperity in Ephrathah, and may your name become celebrated and famous in Bethlehem."
Ruth 4:12 "May your household become like the household of Perez, whom Tamar bore to Judah, because of the offspring the Lord will grant to you from this young woman, Ruth."
Ruth 4:13 So Boaz took Ruth, and she became his wife. He then went in to her, and the Lord granted her the grace to conceive and to bear a son.
Ruth 4:14 Then the women of Bethlehem said to Naomi, "Praised be the Lord, who has not left you without a close relative today, so that his name may be celebrated and remembered in Israel! May this child be to you a full redemption and a comfort, and may his own name be cherished."
Ruth 4:15 "May this child bring comfort to your soul and sustain you in your old age, for he has been born to your daughter-in-law, who deeply loves you. She is far better to you than if you had seven sons, for her loyalty and love surpass all."
Ruth 4:16 Naomi then took the child herself, placing him in her lap, and she became his nurse and caretaker, tending to him as her own.
Ruth 4:17 The neighbors and relatives, filled with joy and congratulating her, declared, "A son has been born to Naomi!" And they gave him the name Obed. This Obed later became the father of Jesse, who in turn was the father of David, the great king.
Ruth 4:18 Now, these are the generations descending from Perez: Perez begat Hezron.
Ruth 4:19 Hezron begat Ram, and Ram begat Amminadab.
Ruth 4:20 Amminadab begat Nahshon, and Nahshon begat Salmon.
Ruth 4:21 Salmon begat Boaz, and Boaz begat Obed.
Ruth 4:22 Obed begat Jesse, and Jesse begat David.
1 Samuel 1:1 There was a certain man from Ramathaim Sophim, from the mountain region of Ephraim. His name was Elcana, a son of Jeroham, who was a son of Eliu, who was a son of Thohu, who was a son of Suph—he was an Ephratite.
1 Samuel 1:2 He had two wives: the name of one was Anna, and the name of the second was Phenenna. Phenenna had children, but Anna had no children.
1 Samuel 1:3 And this man would go up from his city at the appointed times each year to worship and sacrifice to the Lord of hosts in Silo. Heli’s two sons, Ophni and Phinees, were serving there as priests of the Lord.
1 Samuel 1:4 Whenever the day came for the sacrifice, Elcana would make his offering. He would give portions to his wife Phenenna, and to all her sons and daughters.
1 Samuel 1:5 But to Anna, he gave only one portion, and he was sorrowful, for Anna had no children. The Lord had closed her womb, so she could not conceive.
1 Samuel 1:6 Her rival wife, Phenenna, also tormented her and greatly distressed her, constantly taunting Anna over the fact that the Lord had closed her womb.
1 Samuel 1:7 And she did this year after year, whenever they went up to the temple of the Lord. Phenenna would provoke Anna, and Anna would weep and refuse to eat.
1 Samuel 1:8 Then Elcana, her husband, said to her: “Anna, why are you weeping? And why are you not eating? And why is your heart so sad? Am I not better to you than ten sons would be?”
1 Samuel 1:9 So Anna rose up after they had eaten and drunk in Silo. Heli the priest was sitting on a seat by the doorposts of the Lord’s temple.
1 Samuel 1:10 Anna was in deep bitterness of soul. She prayed to the Lord, weeping profusely.
1 Samuel 1:11 And she made a solemn vow, saying: “Lord of hosts, if You would only look upon the affliction of your handmaid, and remember me, and not forget your handmaid, and grant your handmaid a male child, then I will give him to the Lord for all the days of his life. And no razor will ever come upon his head—meaning he will be dedicated to You as a Nazirite.”
1 Samuel 1:12 It so happened that as she continued to multiply her prayers before the Lord, Heli observed her mouth.
1 Samuel 1:13 Now, Anna was speaking in her heart; only her lips were moving, but her voice could not be heard. So Heli thought she was drunk.
1 Samuel 1:14 And he said to her: “How long will you be drunk? Sober up from your wine for a little while, which has made you intoxicated.”
1 Samuel 1:15 Anna answered and said: “No, my lord, I am a woman with a deeply troubled spirit. I have drunk neither wine nor anything that could make me drunk; instead, I have poured out my very soul before the Lord.”
1 Samuel 1:16 Do not consider your handmaid to be one of the daughters of Belial—a worthless or wicked woman. For it is out of the abundance of my great sorrow and grief that I have spoken until now.”
1 Samuel 1:17 Then Heli answered and said: “Go in peace. And may the God of Israel grant you your petition, which you have asked from Him.”
1 Samuel 1:18 And she said: “May your handmaid find favor in your eyes.” Then the woman went on her way, and she ate, and her countenance was no longer downcast or troubled.
1 Samuel 1:19 They rose up early in the morning and worshipped before the Lord. Then they returned and came to their home in Ramatha. And Elcana knew Anna his wife, and the Lord remembered her by granting her request.
1 Samuel 1:20 And so it was that after the passage of some days, Anna conceived and gave birth to a son. She named him Samuel, because she had asked for him from the Lord.
1 Samuel 1:21 Then Elcana, along with all his household, went up to offer to the Lord his annual sacrifice and his solemn vow.
1 Samuel 1:22 But Anna did not go up. Instead, she said to her husband: “I will not go until the child is weaned. Then I will bring him, and he will appear before the presence of the Lord, and he will remain there permanently.”
1 Samuel 1:23 And Elcana, her husband, said to her: “Do what seems good to you. Stay here until you wean him, provided only that the Lord may fulfill His word concerning the child’s dedication.” So the woman stayed and nursed her son until she weaned him.
1 Samuel 1:24 And after she had weaned him, she brought him up with her, along with three young bullocks, three measures of flour, and a jar of wine. She brought him to the house of the Lord in Silo. The boy was still very young.
1 Samuel 1:25 And they sacrificed a bullock, and they brought the boy to Heli.
1 Samuel 1:26 And Anna said: “I beg you, my lord, as your soul lives, my lord—I am that very woman who stood here before you, praying to the Lord.”
1 Samuel 1:27 “It was for this very boy that I prayed, and the Lord has granted me my petition which I asked from Him.”
1 Samuel 1:28 “Therefore, I have also entrusted him to the Lord for all the days of his life, that he may remain dedicated to the Lord.” And they worshipped the Lord there.
1 Samuel 1:1 There was a man from Ramathaim-Zophim, in the hill country of Ephraim. His name was Elcana, and he was the son of Jeroham, son of Eliu, son of Thohu, son of Suph, an Ephraimite.
1 Samuel 1:2 He had two wives: one was named Anna, and the other Phenenna. Phenenna had children, but Anna had no children.
1 Samuel 1:3 That man would go up from his city each year at the appointed times to worship and offer sacrifice to the Lord of hosts in Silo. Now, the two sons of Eli, Ophni and Phinees, were serving there as priests of the Lord.
1 Samuel 1:4 So when the day came for Elcana to offer the sacrifice, he gave portions of the meat to Phenenna, his wife, and to all her sons and daughters.
1 Samuel 1:5 But to Anna, he gave a special portion, though his heart was heavy, because Anna had no son, for the Lord had closed her womb.
1 Samuel 1:6 Her rival, Phenenna, also tormented and greatly distressed her constantly because the Lord had closed Anna's womb and she had no children.
1 Samuel 1:7 This continued year after year; whenever they went up to the house of the Lord, Phenenna would provoke her. So Anna would weep and refuse to eat anything.
1 Samuel 1:8 Then Elcana, her husband, said to her, 'Anna, why are you weeping? Why do you refuse to eat? And why is your spirit so downcast? Am I not better to you than ten sons?'
1 Samuel 1:9 After they had finished eating and drinking in Silo, Anna stood up. Now Eli, the priest, was sitting on his chair by the doorposts of the Lord's house.
1 Samuel 1:10 With a bitter and heavy spirit, Anna prayed to the Lord, weeping profusely.
1 Samuel 1:11 And she made a solemn vow, saying, 'O Lord of hosts, if You would truly look upon the affliction of Your handmaid, and remember me, and not forget Your handmaid, but grant Your handmaid a male child, then I will give him to the Lord for all the days of his life, and no razor shall ever touch his head—a commitment to a Nazirite vow.'
1 Samuel 1:12 As Anna continued to pray at great length before the Lord, Eli was observing her mouth.
1 Samuel 1:13 Anna was praying silently within her heart; only her lips were moving, and her voice could not be heard. So Eli thought she was drunk.
1 Samuel 1:14 And Eli said to her, 'How long will you be drunk? Put away the wine and sober up!'
1 Samuel 1:15 Anna answered, 'No, my lord, I am not drunk. I am a woman with a deeply sorrowful spirit. I have drunk no wine or strong drink, but I have poured out my heart before the Lord in prayer.'
1 Samuel 1:16 Do not take your handmaid for a worthless woman, for it is out of the depth of my great pain and sorrow that I have been speaking up to now.
1 Samuel 1:17 Then Eli answered, 'Go in peace, and may the God of Israel grant you the request you have made of Him.'
1 Samuel 1:18 And Anna said, 'May your handmaid find favor in your sight.' Then the woman went her way, and she ate, and her face was no longer sad.
1 Samuel 1:19 They rose early in the morning, worshipped before the Lord, then returned and came to their home in Ramatha. And Elcana was intimate with his wife, Anna, and the Lord remembered her prayer.
1 Samuel 1:20 And when the time came around, Anna conceived and bore a son. She named him Samuel, saying, 'Because I asked the Lord for him.'
1 Samuel 1:21 Then Elcana, her husband, went up with his entire household to offer the annual sacrifice to the Lord and to fulfill his vow.
1 Samuel 1:22 But Anna did not go up. Instead, she said to her husband, 'I will wait until the child is weaned. Then I will bring him, so that he may appear before the Lord and remain there in His house always.'
1 Samuel 1:23 Elcana, her husband, said to her, 'Do what seems best to you. Stay here until you have weaned him; only may the Lord establish His word concerning our son.' So the woman stayed home and nursed her son until she weaned him.
1 Samuel 1:24 When she had weaned him, she brought him up to Silo, taking with her three calves, three measures of flour, and a jar of wine, as offerings. She brought him to the house of the Lord in Silo. The child was still very young.
1 Samuel 1:25 Then they sacrificed one of the calves, and Anna brought the child to Eli.
1 Samuel 1:26 And Anna said, 'Oh, my lord! As surely as you live, my lord, I am the very woman who stood here beside you, praying to the Lord.'
1 Samuel 1:27 It was for this child that I prayed, and the Lord has granted me the request I made of Him.
1 Samuel 1:28 Therefore, I have dedicated him to the Lord; for as long as he lives, he is dedicated to the Lord.' And they worshipped the Lord there.
1 Samuel 2:1 My heart has leapt with joy in the Lord God, and my strength—my horn—has been raised up in my God. My mouth is now opened wide to speak confidently against my enemies, because I have rejoiced greatly in your saving power.
1 Samuel 2:2 No one is holy like the Lord God; indeed, there is no one else beside you, and no one is strong like our God.
1 Samuel 2:3 Do not speak proudly with multiplied boastings; let your former arrogance cease from your mouth. For the Lord God is the God who knows everything, and all thoughts are prepared before Him.
1 Samuel 2:4 The bow of the mighty has been overcome, but the weak have been girded with strength.
1 Samuel 2:5 Those who were barren before have given birth to many children, and she who had many children has become weak.
1 Samuel 2:6 The Lord God brings death and brings life; He leads down to the realm of the dead and brings back up from it.
1 Samuel 2:7 The Lord God makes one poor and makes one rich; He humbles and He exalts.
1 Samuel 2:8 He lifts up the needy from the dust of the ground, and raises the poor from the ash heap, to make them sit with princes and inherit a throne of glory.
1 Samuel 2:9 For the pillars of the earth belong to the Lord God, and upon them He has set the world.
1 Samuel 2:10 He will guard the steps of His faithful ones, but the wicked will be silenced in darkness. For no man will be strong through his own power.
1 Samuel 2:11 The Lord God will thunder from the heavens against him; the Lord God will judge the ends of the earth, and He will give dominion to His king, and exalt the power—the horn—of His Anointed One.
1 Samuel 2:12 And Elcana went to Ramatha, to his home. But the young boy Samuel remained a minister of the Lord God before Heli the priest.
1 Samuel 2:13 Now the sons of Heli were worthless men who did not know the Lord God, nor did they perform the duty of priests toward the people as they should have.
1 Samuel 2:14 Indeed, this was the way of the priests with the people: whenever anyone offered a sacrifice, the priest's servant would come while the meat was boiling, and he would have a three-pronged fork in his hand.
1 Samuel 2:15 He would thrust it into the large pot, or into the cauldron, or into the stewpot, or into the small pot, and whatever the fork brought up, the priest would take for himself. This is how they acted with all the people of Israel who came to Silo.
1 Samuel 2:16 Even before they burned the fat of the sacrifice—which was reserved for God—the priest's servant would come and say to the one offering the sacrifice, 'Give me meat to cook for the priest, for I will not accept cooked meat from you, but raw meat.'
1 Samuel 2:17 And the one offering the sacrifice would answer him, 'Let the fat be burned first today as is the custom, and then take for yourself whatever your heart desires.' But the servant, responding, would say to him, 'Absolutely not! You will give it to me at once. If you do not, I will take it by force.'
1 Samuel 2:18 Therefore, the sin of the young men was excessively great before the Lord God, because they caused people to turn away from the sacrifice due to the Lord God.
1 Samuel 2:19 But Samuel, a young boy, ministered before the Lord God, dressed in a linen ephod, a priestly garment.
1 Samuel 2:20 And his mother used to make him a little tunic, which she would bring to him on the appointed days when she went up with her husband to offer the solemn sacrifice.
1 Samuel 2:21 So Heli blessed Elcana and his wife, and said, 'May the Lord God give you offspring from this woman in return for the gift you lent to the Lord God—the boy Samuel.' And they went to their home.
1 Samuel 2:22 And so, the Lord God visited Hannah, and she conceived and gave birth to three sons and two daughters. And the boy Samuel grew in stature before the Lord God.
1 Samuel 2:23 Now Heli had grown very old, and he heard all that his sons were doing to all Israel, and how they were sleeping with the women who served at the entrance of the tabernacle of the covenant.
1 Samuel 2:24 And he said to them, 'Why are you doing such things, which I hear reported as very wicked deeds by all the people?'
1 Samuel 2:25 'Do not do this, my sons, for the report I hear is not good. You are causing the Lord God's people to transgress.'
1 Samuel 2:26 'If a man sins against another man, God can intercede for him. But if a man sins against the Lord God, who will intercede for him?' But they did not listen to their father's voice, because the Lord God intended to put them to death.
1 Samuel 2:27 But the boy Samuel continued to grow and advance in favor with both the Lord God and with men.
1 Samuel 2:28 Then a man of God came to Heli and said to him, 'Thus says the Lord God: Did I not plainly reveal myself to the house of your father, when they were in Egypt, in the house of Pharaoh?'
1 Samuel 2:29 'And I chose him—your ancestor Aaron—from all the tribes of Israel to be My priest, to go up to My altar, and burn incense to Me, and to wear the ephod before Me. And I gave to the house of your father all the offerings of the children of Israel.'
1 Samuel 2:30 'Why then have you kicked away My sacrifice and My offerings which I commanded to be presented in the temple? And why have you honored your sons more than Me, so that you yourselves are made fat from the best parts of every sacrifice of My people Israel?'
1 Samuel 2:31 'Therefore, thus says the Lord God of Israel: I indeed said that your house and the house of your father would minister before Me forever. But now the Lord God says: Far be this from Me! Instead, whoever honors Me, I will honor him; but those who despise Me will be made insignificant.'
1 Samuel 2:32 'Behold, the days are coming when I will cut off your strength—your arm—and the strength of your father's house, so that there will be no old man in your household.'
1 Samuel 2:33 'And you will see an adversary in the temple, amidst all the prosperity of Israel; and there will not be an old man in your house for all your days.'
1 Samuel 2:34 'And this will be the sign for you, which will happen to your two sons, Ophni and Phinees: both of them will die on the same day.'
1 Samuel 2:35 'And I will raise up for Myself a faithful priest, who will act according to My heart and My soul. And I will build him a sure house, and he will walk before My Anointed One all his days.'
1 Samuel 2:36 'And it will come to pass that everyone who remains in your house will come and bow down before him for a piece of silver and a loaf of bread, and say, 'Please, assign me to one of the priestly portions, so that I may eat a morsel of bread.''
1 Samuel 2:1 And Anna prayed, saying: 'My heart has rejoiced in the Lord; my strength, like a horn lifted high, has been made great by my God. My voice now speaks triumphantly over my enemies, because I have found great joy in Your deliverance.'
1 Samuel 2:2 There is no one holy like the Lord; indeed, there is no other God besides You, and no one is as strong as our God.
1 Samuel 2:3 Do not speak many proud and boastful words; let arrogance depart from your mouths. For the Lord is the God of all knowledge, and He weighs every thought and intention.
1 Samuel 2:4 The bows of the mighty are broken, but those who were weak are now girded with strength.
1 Samuel 2:5 Those who were once full and well-fed are now reduced to working for bread, while those who were starving are now satisfied. Even the barren woman has borne many children, and she who had many children has become feeble and desolate.
1 Samuel 2:6 The Lord brings death and brings life; He leads down to the realm of the dead and brings back up again.
1 Samuel 2:7 The Lord makes one poor and makes one rich; He humbles and He exalts.
1 Samuel 2:8 He lifts the needy from the dust and raises the poor from the ash heap, to make them sit with princes and inherit a glorious throne. For the foundations of the earth are the Lord's, and He has established the world upon them.
1 Samuel 2:9 He will guard the steps of His saints, but the wicked will be silenced in darkness. For no one is strong by their own might.
1 Samuel 2:10 His adversaries will fear the Lord; over them He will thunder from the universe. The Lord will judge the ends of the earth, and He will give power to His King, and He will exalt the strength of His Anointed One.
1 Samuel 2:11 Then Elcana went to his home in Ramatha. But the child Samuel remained as a minister of the Lord, serving before Eli the priest.
1 Samuel 2:12 Now the sons of Eli were wicked men, sons of Belial, who did not know or acknowledge the Lord.
1 Samuel 2:13 Nor did they respect the priests' duty to the people. When anyone offered a sacrifice, the priest's servant would come while the meat was boiling, holding a three-pronged fork in his hand.
1 Samuel 2:14 And he would thrust it into the cauldron, or the pot, or the kettle, or the pan. Whatever the fork brought up, the priest would take for himself. This is how they treated all the Israelites who came to Silo.
1 Samuel 2:15 Even before the fat was burned as an offering, the priest's servant would come and say to the one offering the sacrifice: 'Give me meat to roast for the priest, for I will not accept cooked meat from you, but only raw meat.'
1 Samuel 2:16 And the man offering the sacrifice would answer him: 'Let the fat be burned first today, as is the custom, then take for yourself whatever your soul desires.' But the servant would say to him: 'No, by no means; you must give it to me immediately, or else I will take it by force.'
1 Samuel 2:17 Therefore, the sin of these young men was exceedingly great before the Lord, because they were causing men to withdraw from offering sacrifice to the Lord.
1 Samuel 2:18 But Samuel, the young boy, ministered before the Lord, clothed with a linen ephod, a sacred garment.
1 Samuel 2:19 And his mother used to make him a little tunic, which she would bring to him year after year, when she would go up with her husband to offer the yearly sacrifice.
1 Samuel 2:20 And Eli blessed Elcana and his wife, and he said: 'May the Lord grant you offspring from this woman in return for the one that was given to the Lord.' Then they went to their home.
1 Samuel 2:21 So the Lord visited Anna, and she conceived and gave birth to three sons and two daughters. And the boy Samuel grew in importance before the Lord.
1 Samuel 2:22 Now Eli was very old, and he heard all that his sons were doing to all of Israel; specifically, how they were lying with the women who served at the entrance of the tabernacle of the covenant.
1 Samuel 2:23 And he said to them: 'Why are you doing such things? I hear of these very wicked deeds from all the people.'
1 Samuel 2:24 'Do not, my sons, for the report I hear is not good, that you cause the Lord's people to transgress.'
1 Samuel 2:25 If a man sins against another man, God can intercede for him; but if a man sins against the Lord, who can pray for him? But they did not listen to the voice of their father, for the Lord had already decided to put them to death.
1 Samuel 2:26 But the boy Samuel continued to grow and advance in stature and favor, pleasing both the Lord and mankind.
1 Samuel 2:27 Then a man of God came to Eli and said to him: 'Thus says the Lord: Did I not clearly reveal Myself to the house of your father, when they were in Egypt, in the house of Pharaoh?'
1 Samuel 2:28 'And I chose him from all the tribes of Israel to be My priest, to ascend to My altar, to burn incense for Me, and to wear the ephod before Me. And I gave to the house of your father all the fire offerings of the sons of Israel.'
1 Samuel 2:29 'Why then have you kicked aside My sacrifice and My offerings, which I commanded to be offered in the temple? And why have you honored your sons more than Me, enriching yourselves with the best parts of every sacrifice of My servant Israel?'
1 Samuel 2:30 Therefore, the Lord, the God of Israel, declares: 'I indeed said that your house and the house of your father would minister before Me forever. But now the Lord says: Far be it from Me! Rather, whoever glorifies Me, him will I glorify; but those who despise Me shall be brought to dishonor.'
1 Samuel 2:31 'Behold, the days are coming when I will cut off your strength and the strength of your father's house, so that there will be no old man in your house.'
1 Samuel 2:32 'And you will see an adversary in My dwelling place, amidst all the prosperity of Israel, yet there will be no old man in your house for all your days.'
1 Samuel 2:33 'Nevertheless, I will not cut off every last one of yours from My altar, but only so that his eyes may fail and his soul waste away. And all the offspring of your house will die in the prime of their lives.'
1 Samuel 2:34 'And this will be the sign for you, which is about to come to pass regarding your two sons, Ophni and Phinees: on one day, both will die.'
1 Samuel 2:35 'And I will raise up for Myself a faithful priest who will act according to My heart and My soul. And I will build him a faithful house, and he will walk before My Anointed One all his days.'
1 Samuel 2:36 'And it shall come to pass that everyone who is left in your house will come and bow down before him to receive a silver coin and a loaf of bread, and will say: 'Please, let me belong to one of the priestly portions, so that I may eat a morsel of bread.''
1 Samuel 2:37 There is no thirty-seventh verse.
1 Samuel 2:38 There is no thirty-eighth verse.
1 Samuel 2:39 There is no thirty-ninth verse.
1 Samuel 2:40 There is no fortieth verse.
1 Samuel 3:1 The boy Samuel was serving the Lord in the presence of Eli, but in those days, the word of the Lord was rare, and there were no clear visions or prophecies from God.
1 Samuel 3:2 And it came to pass on a certain occasion that Eli was sleeping in his customary place. His eyes had grown so dim that he could not see.
1 Samuel 3:3 Before the lamps in the house of God had been extinguished for the morning, Samuel was sleeping in the Lord's sanctuary, where the Ark of God was kept.
1 Samuel 3:4 And the Lord called Samuel. Samuel answered, saying, 'Here I am.'
1 Samuel 3:5 So Samuel ran to Eli and said, 'Here I am, for you called me.' Eli replied, 'I did not call you. Go back to sleep.' So Samuel went and lay down again.
1 Samuel 3:6 And the Lord called Samuel again. Samuel got up, went to Eli, and said, 'Here I am, for you called me.' Eli answered, 'I did not call you, my son. Go back to sleep.'
1 Samuel 3:7 Now Samuel did not yet know the Lord personally in this manner, nor had the word of the Lord been revealed to him in such a way before.
1 Samuel 3:8 And the Lord called Samuel a third time. Samuel rose, went to Eli, and said, 'Here I am, for you called me.' Then Eli understood that it was the Lord calling the boy.
1 Samuel 3:9 So Eli said to Samuel, 'Go and sleep. If He calls you again, you are to say, 'Speak, Lord, for your servant is listening.'' So Samuel went and lay down in his place.
1 Samuel 3:10 And the Lord came and stood there, and called as He had called before, 'Samuel, Samuel!' And Samuel said, 'Speak, Lord, for your servant is listening.'
1 Samuel 3:11 And the Lord said to Samuel, 'Behold, I am about to do something in Israel that will make both ears of everyone who hears of it ring with shock.'
1 Samuel 3:12 'On that very day, I will carry out against Eli everything I have spoken against his house, from beginning to end.'
1 Samuel 3:13 'For I have told him that I will judge his house forever because of the iniquity of his sons, who have blasphemed God, and he did not restrain them.'
1 Samuel 3:14 'Therefore, I have sworn to the house of Eli: The iniquity of his house shall never be atoned for by sacrifice or offering, not for all time.'
1 Samuel 3:15 So Samuel slept until morning, and then he opened the doors of the Lord's house. But Samuel was afraid to tell Eli the vision.
1 Samuel 3:16 Eli then called Samuel and said, 'Samuel, my son.' And Samuel answered, 'Here I am.'
1 Samuel 3:17 Eli said, 'What is the message that was given to you? I implore you, do not hide it from me. May God do to you even worse, if you hide from me even one of all the words that were spoken to you.'
1 Samuel 3:18 So Samuel told him all the words and hid nothing from him. Eli then responded, 'It is the Lord; let Him do what is good in His sight.'
1 Samuel 3:19 Samuel grew, and the Lord was with him, and none of His words that He spoke through Samuel fell to the ground unfulfilled.
1 Samuel 3:20 And all Israel, from Dan even to Beersheba, recognized that Samuel was a faithful prophet of the Lord.
1 Samuel 3:21 And the Lord continued to appear in Shiloh, because the Lord revealed Himself to Samuel in Shiloh through the word of the Lord.
1 Samuel 4:1 It happened during that time that the Philistines gathered their forces for war. The people of Israel went out to fight against them, and set up their camp near a place called Ebenezer—which means 'Stone of Help'.
1 Samuel 4:2 Israel lined up for battle against the Philistines. When the fighting began, the people of Israel turned and fled from the Philistines. About thirty thousand of Israel’s foot soldiers were killed there.
1 Samuel 4:3 When the surviving people returned to their camp, the leading elders of Israel said: 'Why did the Lord allow the Philistines to defeat us today? Let us bring the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord from Shiloh, and let it come into our midst. Then it will save us from the power of our enemies.'
1 Samuel 4:4 So the people sent word to Shiloh, and they brought from there the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord of Hosts, who sits enthroned above the Cherubim. Eli’s two sons, Hophni and Phinehas, were with the Ark of God's Covenant.
1 Samuel 4:5 When the Ark of the Lord's Covenant arrived in the camp, all of Israel shouted with a great outcry, and the entire land echoed with the sound.
1 Samuel 4:6 The Philistines heard the sound of the outcry and asked: 'What is this sound of a great shout in the camp of the Hebrews?' They quickly realized that the Ark of the Lord had come into their camp.
1 Samuel 4:7 Then the Philistines became afraid and said: 'God has come into their camp!' They groaned in fear and said:
1 Samuel 4:8 'Woe to us! Nothing like this great rejoicing has happened before, not yesterday nor the day before! Woe to us! Who will save us from the power of this mighty God? These are the gods who struck Egypt with every kind of plague in the wilderness.'
1 Samuel 4:9 'Be strong, Philistines! Act like men! Do not serve the Hebrews, just as they have served you. Be men, and fight!'
1 Samuel 4:10 So the Philistines fought, and Israel was defeated, and every man fled to his tent. The slaughter was exceedingly great, and thirty thousand men of Israel fell dead.
1 Samuel 4:11 And the Ark of God was captured. Eli's two sons, Hophni and Phinehas, died.
1 Samuel 4:12 But a man from the tribe of Benjamin ran from the battle line and came to Shiloh that same day. His clothes were torn, and his head was covered with dust, showing his grief and distress.
1 Samuel 4:13 When he arrived, Eli was sitting on a chair beside the road, looking out—for his heart was trembling with fear for the Ark of God. After the man entered, he announced the news to the city, and the entire city cried out in lament.
1 Samuel 4:14 Eli heard the sound of the outcry and asked: 'What is this sound of a great uproar?' The man hurried, came to Eli, and told him the news.
1 Samuel 4:15 Eli was ninety-eight years old, and his eyes had grown dim, so he could not see.
1 Samuel 4:16 The man said to Eli: 'I am the one who came from the battle. I fled from the battle line today.' Eli then asked him: 'What happened, my son?'
1 Samuel 4:17 The messenger answered: 'Israel has fled before the Philistines, and a great slaughter has occurred among the people. Moreover, your two sons, Hophni and Phinehas, are dead. And the Ark of God has been captured.'
1 Samuel 4:18 When the messenger mentioned the Ark of God, Eli fell backward from his chair beside the gate. His neck was broken, and he died. For the man was old and heavy. He had judged Israel for forty years.
1 Samuel 4:19 His daughter-in-law, Phinehas’s wife, was pregnant and close to giving birth. When she heard the news that the Ark of God had been captured and that her father-in-law and her husband had died, she bowed down and gave birth, for sudden labor pains came upon her.
1 Samuel 4:20 Just as she was dying, those who stood around her said: 'Do not fear, for you have given birth to a son!' But she did not answer, nor did she pay attention to their words.
1 Samuel 4:21 And she named the child Ichabod, saying: 'The glory has departed from Israel,' because the Ark of God had been captured, and because of her father-in-law and her husband.
1 Samuel 4:22 She emphasized, 'The glory has departed from Israel, because the Ark of God has been captured!'
1 Samuel 5:1 And the Philistines took the Ark of God, carrying it away from the Stone of Help—the place where Israel was defeated—to the city of Ashdod.
1 Samuel 5:2 So the Philistines took the Ark of God into the temple of their god Dagon and set it up right next to the idol of Dagon.
1 Samuel 5:3 When the people of Ashdod woke up the next morning, they found Dagon lying face down on the ground before the Ark of the Lord. So they picked up Dagon and put him back in his place.
1 Samuel 5:4 But when they got up early the following morning, they again found Dagon lying face down on the ground before the Ark of the Lord. This time, Dagon's head and both of his hands were cut off and lying on the threshold of the temple, with only the trunk of Dagon's body remaining intact.
1 Samuel 5:5 Because of this event, the priests of Dagon and all who enter the temple of Dagon in Ashdod have not stepped on the threshold of Dagon, even to this very day.
1 Samuel 5:6 But the hand of the Lord weighed heavily upon the people of Ashdod, and He devastated them. He struck the people of Ashdod and their surrounding territory in their own homes, causing painful tumors to break out on them.
1 Samuel 5:7 When the men of Ashdod saw the nature of this plague, they said, "The Ark of the God of Israel must not remain with us, because His hand is heavy upon us and upon Dagon, our god."
1 Samuel 5:8 So they sent for and gathered all the rulers of the Philistines to them and asked, "What shall we do with the Ark of the God of Israel?" They answered, "Let the Ark of the God of Israel be taken around to Gath." So the Ark of the God of Israel was carried there.
1 Samuel 5:9 After it was carried to Gath, the hand of the Lord fell upon that city with extremely great destruction. He struck the men of the city, from the youngest to the oldest, and painful tumors broke out on them.
1 Samuel 5:10 So they sent the Ark of God to Ekron. When the Ark of God arrived in Ekron, the people of Ekron cried out, saying, "They have brought the Ark of the God of Israel to us, intending to kill us and our people!"
1 Samuel 5:11 So they sent and gathered all the rulers of the Philistines, and they said, "Send away the Ark of the God of Israel! Let it return to its own place, so it will not kill us and our people." For a confusion of death—a deadly panic—had spread throughout the entire city, and the hand of God was very heavy there.
1 Samuel 5:12 Even the men who did not die were tormented with tumors, and the wailing of each city went up to the sky.
1 Samuel 5:1 The Philistines took the Ark of God, and carried it away from the Stone of Help to Azotus.
1 Samuel 5:2 And the Philistines brought the Ark of God into the temple of Dagon, and set it beside Dagon.
1 Samuel 5:3 But when the people of Azotus arose the next day, behold, Dagon was lying face down on the ground before the Ark of the Lord; so they took Dagon and put him back in his place.
1 Samuel 5:4 And again, when they arose early on the next day, they found Dagon lying on the ground, face down before the Ark of the Lord; and the head of Dagon and both of his hands were cut off, lying on the threshold. Only Dagon's torso remained intact.
1 Samuel 5:5 Because of this, the priests of Dagon and all who enter the temple of Dagon in Azotus do not step on Dagon's threshold, even to this day.
1 Samuel 5:6 And the hand of the Lord grew heavy upon the people of Azotus; He utterly destroyed them, and struck them with tumors in their secret parts, both Azotus and its surrounding areas.
1 Samuel 5:7 When the men of Azotus saw the plague, they said: "The Ark of the God of Israel must not remain with us, because His hand is heavy upon us and upon Dagon our god."
1 Samuel 5:8 So they sent for and gathered all the lords of the Philistines to them, and said: "What shall we do with the Ark of the God of Israel?" They answered: "Let the Ark of the God of Israel be carried to Geth." And so they carried the Ark of the God of Israel there.
1 Samuel 5:9 And it came to pass, after they had carried it there, the hand of the Lord fell upon the city with a very great destruction; He struck the men of the city, both small and great, and tumors erupted upon them in their secret parts.
1 Samuel 5:10 So they sent the Ark of God to Accaron. When the Ark of God came to Accaron, the people of Accaron cried out, saying: "They have brought the Ark of the God of Israel to us, to kill us and our people!"
1 Samuel 5:11 Therefore, they sent for and gathered all the lords of the Philistines, and said: "Send away the Ark of the God of Israel, and let it return to its own place, so that it may not kill us and our people." For there had been a deadly plague throughout the entire city, and a great terror; and the hand of God was exceedingly heavy upon them.
1 Samuel 5:12 And those men who did not die were struck with tumors in their secret parts; and the cry of each city ascended even to the heavens.
1 Samuel 6:1 The Ark of the Lord had remained in the land of the Philistines for seven months.
1 Samuel 6:2 So the Philistines called for their priests and diviners, asking, 'What should we do with the Ark of the Lord? How can we send it back to its rightful place?'
1 Samuel 6:3 They answered, 'If you are going to send back the Ark of the God of Israel, do not send it back empty. Instead, you must give Him a guilt offering for the sin you have committed. Then you will be healed, and you will understand why His hand has not stopped punishing you.'
1 Samuel 6:4 Then the Philistines asked, 'What sort of guilt offering should we return to Him?'
1 Samuel 6:5 They replied, 'You must make five golden tumors, representing the plague’s effect, and five golden mice, according to the number of the Philistine rulers. This is because there was one plague afflicting all of you and your leaders.'
1 Samuel 6:6 Why do you harden your hearts, just as the Egyptians and Pharaoh hardened theirs? After God struck them with plagues, did they not then let the Israelites go, and they departed?
1 Samuel 6:7 Now then, make a new cart. Take two nursing cows that have never been yoked, and harness them to the cart. Shut up their calves at home, so they cannot follow their mothers.
1 Samuel 6:8 Then take the Ark of the Lord and place it on the cart. Put the golden offerings, which you must return to Him for your sin, in a small box beside it. Then send the cart away and let it go where it may.
1 Samuel 6:9 Watch closely: if it goes up the road towards Beth Shemesh, then it means He Himself has inflicted this great harm upon us. But if it does not, then we will know that His hand did not touch us, and it was merely an accident.
1 Samuel 6:10 So the men did as they were told: they took two nursing cows and yoked them to the cart. Then they shut up their calves at home.
1 Samuel 6:11 They then placed the Ark of the Lord on the cart, along with the small box containing the golden mice and the likenesses of the tumors.
1 Samuel 6:12 The cows went straight along the road leading to Beth Shemesh, traveling directly without turning either to the right or to the left, all the while lowing in distress—a supernatural sign. The Philistine rulers followed them all the way to the borders of Beth Shemesh.
1 Samuel 6:13 Now, the people of Beth Shemesh were reaping wheat in the valley. When they lifted their eyes and saw the Ark, they greatly rejoiced at the sight.
1 Samuel 6:14 The cart came into the field of Joshua, a man from Beth Shemesh, and stopped there. There was a large stone in that place. So they chopped up the wood of the cart and offered the cows upon it as a burnt offering to the Lord.
1 Samuel 6:15 The Levites then took down the Ark of the Lord and the small box that was next to it, which contained the golden offerings. They placed these upon the large stone. The men of Beth Shemesh, for their part, offered burnt offerings and sacrificed other victims to the Lord on that day.
1 Samuel 6:16 After witnessing all of this, the five Philistine rulers returned to Ekron that same day.
1 Samuel 6:17 These are the golden tumors which the Philistines offered to the Lord as a guilt offering for their sin: one for Ashdod, one for Gaza, one for Ashkelon, one for Gath, and one for Ekron.
1 Samuel 6:18 And there were golden mice matching the number of all the Philistine towns across the five territories, from the walled cities down to the smallest unwalled villages. This includes the great stone where they placed the Ark of the Lord, which is in the field of Joshua, a man from Beth Shemesh.
1 Samuel 6:19 But the Lord struck down some of the men of Beth Shemesh because they had looked irreverently into the Ark of the Lord. He struck seventy men among the people, and fifty thousand of the common people. The people mourned greatly because the Lord had struck them with such a severe blow.
1 Samuel 6:20 The men of Beth Shemesh asked, 'Who can stand in the presence of the Lord, the holy God? And to whom shall this Ark ascend from us now?' —meaning, 'Who can take it away from us?'
1 Samuel 6:21 So they sent messengers to the inhabitants of Kirjath Jearim, saying, 'The Philistines have brought back the Ark of the Lord. Come down and take it up to your city.'
1 Samuel 6:1 The Ark of the Lord had been in the land of the Philistines for seven full days.
1 Samuel 6:2 Then the Philistines summoned their priests and soothsayers, asking, 'What shall we do with the Ark of the Lord? Tell us how we should send it back to its own place.'
1 Samuel 6:3 They responded, 'If you return the Ark of the God of Israel, you must not send it back empty. Instead, you must give Him a guilt offering for the sin you have committed. Then you will be healed, and you will understand why His hand has not stopped afflicting you.'
1 Samuel 6:4 The Philistines asked them, 'What is the nature of the guilt offering we owe Him?' They answered, 'According to the number of the Philistine rulers, you must offer five golden tumors and five golden mice. This is because the same plague has afflicted all of you and your rulers.'
1 Samuel 6:5 Therefore, you must make images resembling your tumors and images resembling the mice that have devastated your land. You must give glory to the God of Israel, hoping that He might lift His hand from you, from your gods, and from your land.
1 Samuel 6:6 Why would you harden your hearts, just as Egypt and Pharaoh hardened their hearts? Was it not after He struck them that Pharaoh finally released the Israelites, and they departed?
1 Samuel 6:7 So now, prepare a new cart, and harness two milk cows that have never worn a yoke to the cart. Then take their calves away from them and bring the calves back home.
1 Samuel 6:8 Take the Ark of the Lord and place it on the cart. Put the golden offerings you have given Him as a guilt offering in a box beside it. Then release the cart and let it go on its own.
1 Samuel 6:9 Watch closely: if the cart ascends along the road to Beth Shemesh by its own route, then He has indeed inflicted this great evil upon us. But if not, then we will know that His hand did not touch us, and this was merely a random misfortune.
1 Samuel 6:10 So the men followed these instructions: they took two milk cows and hitched them to the cart, but they shut their calves back home.
1 Samuel 6:11 They placed the Ark of God upon the cart, along with the box containing the golden mice and the images of the tumors.
1 Samuel 6:12 The cows walked straight along the road toward Beth Shemesh, staying on a single path. They continued moo-ing as they went, turning neither to the right nor to the left. The rulers of the Philistines followed behind them all the way to the border of Beth Shemesh.
1 Samuel 6:13 Now, the people of Beth Shemesh were harvesting wheat in the valley. When they lifted their eyes, they saw the Ark, and they rejoiced greatly at the sight.
1 Samuel 6:14 The cart arrived in the field belonging to Joshua of Beth Shemesh and stopped there. There was a large stone in that place. The people then chopped up the wood of the cart and offered the cows as a burnt offering to the Lord on the fire.
1 Samuel 6:15 The Levites carefully took down the Ark of God, and the box that was beside it, in which were the golden vessels; and they placed them on that great stone. The men of Beth Shemesh then offered burnt offerings and sacrificed other sacrifices to the Lord on that day.
1 Samuel 6:16 After seeing all of this, the five rulers of the Philistines returned to Ekron that same day.
1 Samuel 6:17 These are the golden tumors that the Philistines rendered to the Lord as a guilt offering for their sin: one from Ashdod, one from Gaza, one from Ashkelon, one from Gath, and one from Ekron.
1 Samuel 6:18 And the golden mice corresponded to the number of all the Philistine cities across their five provinces, from the fortified city to the unwalled village, right up to the great stone on which they placed the Ark of the Lord, which was in the field of Joshua of Beth Shemesh.
1 Samuel 6:19 But the Lord struck down some of the men of Beth Shemesh because they had looked inside the Ark of the Lord. He struck down seventy men from the people, and fifty thousand of the common folk. The people mourned greatly because the Lord had afflicted them with such a severe plague.
1 Samuel 6:20 The men of Beth Shemesh said, 'Who can stand in the presence of this holy Lord God? And to whom will He go up from us?'
1 Samuel 6:21 So they sent messengers to the inhabitants of Kirjath Jearim, saying, 'The Philistines have returned the Ark of the Lord. Come down and take it back to your own place.'
1 Samuel 7:1 So the men of Kiriath-jearim came, and they brought the Ark of the Lord there. They brought it into Abinadab's house, which was on the hill. Then they consecrated Abinadab's son, Eleazar, for the sacred duty of guarding the Ark of the Lord.
1 Samuel 7:2 And it came to pass that from the day the Ark of the Lord remained in Kiriath-jearim, many days accumulated, and twenty full years passed by. And all the house of Israel then turned back to the Lord, seeking His rest and favor.
1 Samuel 7:3 Then Samuel spoke to all the house of Israel, saying: 'If you are truly returning to the Lord with all your heart, then you must remove all foreign gods and the goddesses of Astarte from your midst. Prepare your hearts solely for the Lord and serve Him alone. If you do this, He will deliver you from the power of the Philistines.'
1 Samuel 7:4 So the sons of Israel removed the Baalim and the Astartes, and they served the Lord alone.
1 Samuel 7:5 Then Samuel said: 'Gather all of Israel at Mizpah, so that I may pray to the Lord for you there.'
1 Samuel 7:6 So they gathered at Mizpah, and they drew water and poured it out before the Lord, performing a symbolic act of pouring out their hearts. They also fasted on that day, and there they confessed, saying, 'We have sinned against the Lord.' And Samuel acted as a judge for the sons of Israel in Mizpah, hearing their disputes and providing guidance.
1 Samuel 7:7 Now the Philistines heard that the sons of Israel had gathered at Mizpah, so the princes of the Philistines went up against Israel to attack them. When the sons of Israel heard this, they were terrified of the Philistines.
1 Samuel 7:8 And they said to Samuel, 'Do not cease to cry out for us to the Lord our God, that He may save us from the power of the Philistines.'
1 Samuel 7:9 So Samuel took one suckling lamb, and he offered it as a whole burnt offering to the Lord. And Samuel cried out to the Lord on behalf of Israel, and the Lord heard him, granting his prayer.
1 Samuel 7:10 It came to pass, therefore, as Samuel was offering the burnt offering, that the Philistines advanced to battle against Israel. But the Lord thundered with a great voice over the Philistines on that very day, and He threw them into confusion, and they were struck down by the sons of Israel.
1 Samuel 7:11 And the men of Israel went out from Mizpah, pursued the Philistines, and struck them down all the way to the place below Beth-car.
1 Samuel 7:12 Then Samuel took one stone and set it up between Mizpah and Shen. He called the name of that place 'Stone of Help,' saying, 'Up to this point, the Lord has helped us.'
1 Samuel 7:13 So the Philistines were humbled; they no longer entered the territory of Israel. Thus, the hand of the Lord was against the Philistines all the days of Samuel, holding them back and defeating them.
1 Samuel 7:14 And the cities that the Philistines had taken from Israel were restored to Israel, from Ekron as far as Gath, including all their surrounding territories. Thus, Israel was delivered from the power of the Philistines. There was also peace established between Israel and the Amorites, their other neighbors.
1 Samuel 7:15 Samuel continued to judge Israel throughout all the days of his life,
1 Samuel 7:16 and each year he would go on a circuit, visiting Bethel, Gilgal, and Mizpah. In these aforementioned places, he would judge Israel, addressing their legal and spiritual needs.
1 Samuel 7:17 He would then return to Ramah, for his home was there, and there he also judged Israel. And, in Ramah, he built an altar to the Lord.
