1 Samuel 7:1 Therefore, the men of Kiriath-jearim came, and they brought the ark of the Lord. They carried it into the house of Abinadab, which was situated on the hill, and they consecrated his son Eleazar to guard the ark of the Lord.
1 Samuel 7:2 From the day that the ark of the Lord remained in Kiriath-jearim, many days passed—twenty years had already gone by. And all the house of Israel turned their hearts toward the Lord for guidance and peace.
1 Samuel 7:3 Samuel then said to all the house of Israel: 'If you truly return to the Lord with all your heart, then remove the foreign gods from your midst, and take away the idols of Astaroth from your lands. Prepare your hearts solely for the Lord and serve Him alone, and He will deliver you from the power of the Philistines.'
1 Samuel 7:4 So the sons of Israel put away the idols of Baal and Astaroth, and they served the Lord alone.
1 Samuel 7:5 Samuel then said, 'Gather all of yourselves at Mizpah, so that I may pray to the Lord on your behalf.'
1 Samuel 7:6 So they gathered at Mizpah. They drew water and poured it out before the Lord as a sign of their repentance, and they fasted on that day. And they confessed there, saying, 'We have sinned against the Lord.' And Samuel presided over the sons of Israel in judgment at Mizpah, guiding them in justice and righteousness.
1 Samuel 7:7 Now, the Philistines heard that the sons of Israel were gathered at Mizpah, and the rulers of the Philistines came up to attack Israel. When the sons of Israel heard this, they became very afraid at the approach of the Philistines.
1 Samuel 7:8 And the sons of Israel said to Samuel, 'Do not stop crying out to the Lord our God on our behalf, that He may save us from the power of the Philistines!'
1 Samuel 7:9 Then Samuel took a single suckling lamb and offered it as a whole burnt offering, completely consumed, to the Lord. And Samuel cried out to the Lord on behalf of Israel, and the Lord heard his prayer.
1 Samuel 7:10 Now, as Samuel was offering the burnt offering, the Philistines pressed hard in battle against Israel. But on that very day, the Lord thundered with a mighty voice over the Philistines. They were thrown into utter confusion and were struck down by the sons of Israel.
1 Samuel 7:11 So the sons of Israel went out from Mizpah and pursued the Philistines. They struck them down all the way to the place just below Beth-car.
1 Samuel 7:12 Then Samuel took a single stone and set it between Mizpah and Shen, and he named that place 'The Stone of Help.' He declared, 'Up to this very moment, the Lord has continually helped us!'
1 Samuel 7:13 Thus, the Philistines were completely humbled and no longer ventured into the territories of Israel. Indeed, the mighty hand of the Lord was against the Philistines throughout all the days that Samuel lived.
1 Samuel 7:14 Furthermore, the cities that the Philistines had taken from Israel, from Ekron to Gath, along with their surrounding lands, were all restored to Israel. And Israel was delivered from the power of the Philistines. Peace was also established between Israel and the Amorites.
1 Samuel 7:15 And Samuel continued to judge and guide Israel throughout all the days of his life.
1 Samuel 7:16 Year after year, he would travel in a circuit to Bethel, Gilgal, and Mizpah, and he would judge Israel in those same places.
1 Samuel 7:17 Then he would return to Ramah, for his home was there. And there he also judged Israel, and he built an altar there dedicated to the Lord.
1 Samuel 8:1 Now it came to pass that when Samuel became old, he then appointed his own sons to be judges over the people of Israel.
1 Samuel 8:2 And the name of his firstborn son was Joel, and the name of his second son was Abia. These two were judges in Bersabee.
1 Samuel 8:3 But his sons did not walk in Samuel's ways of righteous judgment. Instead, they turned aside after greed, accepting bribes and perverting justice.
1 Samuel 8:4 Therefore, all the elders of Israel gathered themselves together and came to Samuel in Rama.
1 Samuel 8:5 And they said to him: "Behold, you have grown old, and your sons do not walk in your ways. Now therefore, appoint for us a king to govern us, just as all the nations around us have kings."
1 Samuel 8:6 This word displeased Samuel, because they had said: "Give us a king to govern us." And Samuel prayed to the Lord about this matter.
1 Samuel 8:7 Then the Lord said to Samuel: "Listen to the voice of the people in all that they say to you. For they have not rejected you as their leader; rather, they have rejected Me, so that I should not reign over them as their true King."
1 Samuel 8:8 According to all their works which they have done, from the day I brought them out of Egypt even to this very day— just as they have forsaken Me and served other gods— so also are they doing to you, My servant Samuel.
1 Samuel 8:9 Now therefore, listen to their voice. Nevertheless, solemnly warn them, and declare to them the rights of the king who shall reign over them.
1 Samuel 8:10 So Samuel spoke all the words of the Lord to the people who had asked him for a king.
1 Samuel 8:11 And he said: "This will be the nature of the king who is to reign over you: He will take your sons and appoint them for his chariots and make them his horsemen, and they will run before his chariots as heralds."
1 Samuel 8:12 And he will appoint for himself commanders of thousands and commanders of fifties, and those to plow his fields and to reap his harvests, and to make his instruments of war and his chariots.
1 Samuel 8:13 He will also take your daughters and make them perfumers, and cooks, and bakers for his royal household.
1 Samuel 8:14 He will take your best fields, and your vineyards, and your olive groves, and give them to his servants.
1 Samuel 8:15 He will also take a tenth of your seed and of your vineyards, to give to his eunuchs and his servants.
1 Samuel 8:16 He will take your male and female servants, and your best young men, and your donkeys, and put them to his own work.
1 Samuel 8:17 He will take a tenth of your flocks, and you yourselves will be his servants, serving him directly.
1 Samuel 8:18 And you will cry out in that day because of your king whom you have chosen for yourselves, and the Lord will not hear you in that day, because you have asked for a king for yourselves.
1 Samuel 8:19 But the people refused to listen to the voice of Samuel. Instead, they said: "No, this is not so; but a king shall be over us!"
1 Samuel 8:20 They continued: "And we will be like all the other nations, and our king will judge us, and he will go out before us and fight our battles for us."
1 Samuel 8:21 And Samuel heard all the words of the people, and he spoke them in the ears of the Lord.
1 Samuel 8:22 And the Lord said to Samuel: "Listen to their voice and appoint a king over them." Then Samuel said to the men of Israel: "Each man among you, return to his own city." This was to prepare for the selection of the king.
1 Samuel 8:1 Now it happened that when Samuel had grown old, he appointed his sons to be judges over Israel.
1 Samuel 8:2 His firstborn son was named Joel, and his second son was named Abiah. They were serving as judges in Beersheba.
1 Samuel 8:3 But his sons did not follow his ways. Instead, they turned to pursue greed, accepted bribes, and twisted justice.
1 Samuel 8:4 Therefore, all the elders of Israel gathered and came to Samuel in Ramah.
1 Samuel 8:5 And they said to him: 'Look, you have grown old, and your sons are not following your example. So now, appoint a king for us to govern us, just as all the other nations have.'
1 Samuel 8:6 This request displeased Samuel because they had said, 'Give us a king to govern us.' So Samuel prayed to the Lord.
1 Samuel 8:7 But the Lord said to Samuel: 'Listen to everything the people are telling you. For they have not rejected you, but they have rejected Me from being their King.'
1 Samuel 8:8 Just as they have done all their evil deeds from the day I brought them out of Egypt until this very day—forsaking Me and serving foreign gods—so they are doing to you now.
1 Samuel 8:9 So now, listen to what they say. But solemnly warn them and tell them about the ways of the king who will reign over them.
1 Samuel 8:10 So Samuel told all the words of the Lord to the people who had asked him for a king.
1 Samuel 8:11 And he said: 'This will be the manner of the king who will rule over you: He will take your sons and assign them to his chariots, making them his horsemen and his runners to go before his chariots.'
1 Samuel 8:12 He will also appoint for himself commanders of thousands and commanders of fifties. He will make your sons his field workers, to plow his ground and to reap his harvest, and to make his weapons and chariots.
1 Samuel 8:13 He will also take your daughters to be perfumers, cooks, and bakers for him.
1 Samuel 8:14 He will take your best fields, vineyards, and olive groves, and give them to his own servants.
1 Samuel 8:15 He will also take a tenth of your grain and of your vineyards to give to his officials and servants.
1 Samuel 8:16 He will take your male servants and female servants, your finest young men, and your donkeys, and use them for his own work.
1 Samuel 8:17 He will take a tenth of your flocks, and you yourselves will become his slaves.
1 Samuel 8:18 And you will cry out in that day because of your king whom you have chosen for yourselves, but the Lord will not answer you in that day.
1 Samuel 8:19 But the people refused to listen to Samuel. They said: 'Absolutely not! There must be a king over us.'
1 Samuel 8:20 We want to be like all the other nations. Our king will govern us, he will go out before us, and he will fight our battles for us.
1 Samuel 8:21 Samuel heard all the words of the people and reported them to the Lord.
1 Samuel 8:22 Then the Lord said to Samuel: 'Listen to what they say, and appoint a king over them.' So Samuel said to the men of Israel: 'Everyone may now return home to his own city.'
1 Samuel 8:23 Now there was a man from the tribe of Benjamin named Kish, the son of Abiel, who was the son of Zeror, the son of Becorath, the son of Aphiah. He was a mighty man of valor from Benjamin.
1 Samuel 8:24 He had a son named Saul, a handsome young man. There was no man among the Israelites more handsome than he; he stood a head taller than any of the people.
1 Samuel 8:25 Now the donkeys of Kish, Saul’s father, had gone astray. So Kish said to Saul his son: 'Take one of the servants with you, go and search for the donkeys.'
1 Samuel 8:26 They passed through the hill country of Ephraim, then through the land of Shalishah, but they found nothing. Next, they passed through the land of Shaalim, but the donkeys were not there. Then they passed through the land of Benjamin, and found nothing.
1 Samuel 8:27 When they reached the land of Zuph, Saul said to his servant who was with him: 'Come, let us turn back, lest my father, having stopped worrying about the donkeys, should now become anxious about us.'
1 Samuel 8:28 The servant replied: 'Look, there is a man of God in this city, a very respected man. Everything he says certainly comes true. So now, let us go there. Perhaps he can tell us where to go to find what we came for.'
1 Samuel 8:29 Saul then said to his servant: 'But if we go, what can we give the man of God? We have run out of bread in our bags, and we have no present to give to the man of God. We have nothing at all.'
1 Samuel 8:30 Again, the servant answered Saul and said: 'Look, I happen to have a fourth of a shekel of silver with me. Let’s give that to the man of God so he can tell us where to go.'
1 Samuel 8:31 This is how people used to speak in Israel: when someone went to inquire of God, they would say, 'Come, let us go to the seer.' For the one who is now called a prophet was formerly called a seer.
1 Samuel 8:32 Saul then said to his servant: 'That’s a good idea; come, let us go.' So they went to the city where the man of God was.
1 Samuel 8:33 As they were going up the hill to the city, they met young women coming out to draw water, and they asked them: 'Is the seer here?'
1 Samuel 8:34 They answered them: 'Yes, he is right ahead of you. Hurry now! He came to the city today because there is a sacrifice for the people on the high place.'
1 Samuel 8:35 As soon as he arrives, the people will eat. For they do not eat until he comes and blesses the sacrifice, and then those who are invited eat. So go up now, because today you will find him.
1 Samuel 8:36 So they went up to the city. As they were entering the city, Samuel was coming out to meet them, on his way up to the high place.
1 Samuel 8:37 Now the Lord had secretly informed Samuel the day before Saul came, saying:
1 Samuel 8:38 About this time tomorrow I will send you a man from the land of Benjamin, and you shall anoint him to be commander over My people Israel. He will save My people from the power of the Philistines, for I have seen My people’s affliction, and their cry has reached Me.
1 Samuel 8:39 When Samuel saw Saul, the Lord said to him: 'There is the man of whom I spoke to you! This one shall rule over My people.'
1 Samuel 8:40 Then Saul approached Samuel in the middle of the gate and said: 'Please tell me, where is the house of the seer?'
1 Samuel 9:1 There was a man from the tribe of Benjamin whose name was Kish. He was the son of Abiel, who was the son of Zeror, who was the son of Bechorath, who was the son of Aphiah. Kish was also the son of a certain Benjamite man who was mighty in strength.
1 Samuel 9:2 Kish had a son whose name was Saul. Saul was an excellent and good man, and there was no one among the sons of Israel more handsome than him. From his shoulders upwards, he was taller than all the people.
1 Samuel 9:3 However, some of the donkeys belonging to Kish, Saul's father, had wandered off and were lost. So Kish said to his son Saul: 'Take one of the young servants with you, go out, and search for the donkeys.'
1 Samuel 9:4 They traveled through the hill country of Ephraim, and then through the land of Shalisha, but they didn't find the donkeys there. They then crossed through the land of Shaalim, but the donkeys were not there either. Next, they went through the land of Benjamin itself, but they found nothing.
1 Samuel 9:5 When they arrived in the land of Zuph, Saul said to his servant who was with him: 'Come, let's go back now.' 'Otherwise, my father might stop worrying about the lost donkeys and start worrying about us instead.'
1 Samuel 9:6 The servant answered him: 'Look, there's a man of God in this city. He is a very respected prophet.' 'Everything he says comes true, exactly as he says it.' 'Let's go there now; perhaps he can tell us about our journey and where to find the donkeys.'
1 Samuel 9:7 Saul then said to his servant: 'But if we go, what can we give the man?' 'We've run out of bread in our bags, and we have no small gift to offer to this man of God.' 'We don't have anything at all left.'
1 Samuel 9:8 The servant replied to Saul again and said: 'Look, I have a quarter of a shekel of silver with me.' 'I can give that to the man of God so he can tell us where to go.'
1 Samuel 9:9 In earlier times, this was the custom in Israel: when people went to consult God, they would say: 'Come, let's go to the seer.' This is because the one who is called a 'prophet' today was formerly called a 'seer'.
1 Samuel 9:10 Saul said to his servant: 'Your suggestion is an excellent one. Come, let's go.' So they went to the city where the man of God was living.
1 Samuel 9:11 As they were climbing the hill leading up to the city, they met some young women coming out to draw water. Saul and his servant asked them: 'Is the seer here in this place?'
1 Samuel 9:12 The young women answered them: 'Yes, he is! He's just ahead of you.' 'Hurry now, because today the people are making a sacrifice at the high place, and he will be there.'
1 Samuel 9:13 As soon as you enter the city, you will find him at once, before he goes up to the high place to eat the sacrificial meal. The people will not eat until he arrives and blesses the sacrifice. Only then will those who have been invited to the feast eat. So go up now, because you will certainly find him today.
1 Samuel 9:14 So they went up to the city. As they were entering the city, behold, Samuel was coming out to meet them on his way to the high place.
1 Samuel 9:15 Now, the Lord had revealed a message to Samuel just one day before Saul arrived, saying:
1 Samuel 9:16 'At this very time tomorrow, I will send you a man from the land of Benjamin.' 'You are to anoint him as the chosen leader over My people, Israel.' 'He himself will deliver My people from the hand of the Philistines, because I have looked upon My people's suffering, and their cry for help has reached Me.'
1 Samuel 9:17 When Samuel saw Saul approaching, the Lord said to him: 'Behold the man of whom I spoke to you!' 'This is the one who will rule over My people, Israel.'
1 Samuel 9:18 Saul then approached Samuel, right in the middle of the city gate, and asked: 'Please tell me, where is the house of the seer?'
1 Samuel 9:19 Samuel answered Saul, saying: 'I am the seer you are looking for!' 'Go up ahead of me to the high place so you can eat the sacrificial meal with me today.' 'I will send you on your way tomorrow morning, and I will reveal to you everything that is on your heart—the things you are concerned about.'
1 Samuel 9:20 And as for the donkeys you lost three days ago, don't worry about them, because they have already been found. Now, to whom will all the best things of Israel belong in the future? Is it not to you and to all the household of your father?
1 Samuel 9:21 Saul answered, saying: 'Am I not a Benjamite, from the smallest tribe in Israel?' 'And is not my family the least significant among all the families of the tribe of Benjamin?' 'Why, then, do you speak such words to me, suggesting I am worthy of such honor?'
1 Samuel 9:22 Then Samuel took Saul and his servant and led them into the banquet hall. He gave them the most honored place among all those who had been invited to the feast, which included about thirty men.
1 Samuel 9:23 Samuel then said to the cook: 'Bring the portion of the meat that I specifically told you to set aside separately.'
1 Samuel 9:24 So the cook brought the choice cut—a leg or shoulder portion—and placed it before Saul. Samuel said: 'Look, this is what was reserved. Set it before you and eat, for it was intentionally kept for you when I invited the people to this sacrificial meal.' So Saul ate with Samuel on that day.
1 Samuel 9:25 Afterward, they came down from the high place into the town, and Samuel spoke with Saul on the rooftop of his house.
1 Samuel 9:26 They rose very early in the morning, and as the sun began to rise, Samuel called to Saul on the rooftop, saying: 'Get up now, so I can send you on your way.' Saul then rose, and both he and Samuel went outside the city.
1 Samuel 9:27 As they were going down to the edge of the city, Samuel said to Saul: 'Tell your servant to go on ahead of us.' 'But you, stand still for a little while, so I can reveal to you the word of the Lord.'
1 Samuel 10:1 Samuel took a small flask of oil and poured it over Saul’s head. He then kissed Saul, showing his acceptance and loyalty. Samuel said to Saul: "See, the Lord has anointed you—this means you are chosen and set apart—to be a prince over His inheritance, which is the nation of Israel."
1 Samuel 10:2 As soon as you leave me today, you will find two men near Rachel’s tomb—which is located in the southern part of Benjamin’s territory. They will tell you: 'The donkeys you went searching for have been found.' And then they will add: 'Look, your father has stopped worrying about the donkeys and is now anxious about you all, saying: "What should I do about my son?"'
1 Samuel 10:3 When you leave that place and travel a bit further, you will arrive at the oak of Tabor. Three men will meet you there, on their way to worship God in Bethel. Two of them will be carrying young goats, one will be carrying three loaves of bread, and another will be carrying a flask of wine.
1 Samuel 10:4 They will greet you, and then they will offer you two loaves of bread, which you must accept from their hands.
1 Samuel 10:5 After this, you will come to the hill of God—a place where the Lord is worshipped. There is a Philistine garrison stationed there. When you enter the city, you will meet a group of prophets coming down from the high place of worship. They will have a psaltery, a drum, a flute, and a harp playing before them, and they will be prophesying—meaning they will be in a state of inspired worship, singing, and possibly speaking under divine influence.
1 Samuel 10:6 Then the Spirit of the Lord will powerfully rush upon you. You will prophesy with them, and you will be completely changed into a different kind of man—one fit for the role of king.
1 Samuel 10:7 So when all these signs come to pass for you, act decisively and do whatever you find necessary to do, because the Lord is with you.
1 Samuel 10:8 Then you will go down to Gilgal before me—for I will indeed come down to meet you there—so that you may offer burnt offerings and sacrifice peace offerings. You must wait for seven days until I come to you, and then I will show you what you are to do.
1 Samuel 10:9 So when Saul turned to leave Samuel, God gave him a new heart—a changed inner disposition suitable for his new calling. And all these signs Samuel foretold came to pass on that very day.
1 Samuel 10:10 When Saul and his servant arrived at the hill, suddenly a company of prophets met him. The Spirit of the Lord powerfully rushed upon him, and he began to prophesy among them.
1 Samuel 10:11 All who had known Saul previously, recently or in the past, heard that he was prophesying with the prophets, and they said to one another in surprise: "What has happened to Kish’s son? Is Saul also among the prophets now?"
1 Samuel 10:12 Then one from the crowd answered and said, understanding the spiritual source of prophecy: "And who is the father of all prophets but God?" For this reason, it became a common proverb: "Is Saul also among the prophets?"
1 Samuel 10:13 When he finished prophesying, he went to the high place of worship.
1 Samuel 10:14 Saul's uncle then asked him and his servant: "Where did you go?" They answered: "We were looking for the donkeys. When we couldn't find them, we came to Samuel."
1 Samuel 10:15 Saul’s uncle said: "Tell me, what did Samuel say to you?"
1 Samuel 10:16 Saul replied to his uncle: "He merely told us that the donkeys had been found." But concerning the matter of the kingship, which Samuel had discussed with him, Saul did not tell his uncle anything.
1 Samuel 10:17 Then Samuel summoned all the people of Israel to assemble before the Lord at Mizpah.
1 Samuel 10:18 And he said to the children of Israel: "Thus says the Lord, the God of Israel: 'I myself brought Israel out of Egypt, and I rescued you from the power of the Egyptians and from the power of all the kingdoms and those who oppressed you.'"
1 Samuel 10:19 "But today you have rejected your God—the very One who alone has saved you from all your troubles and distresses. Instead, you have said: 'No, we insist, set a king over us.' Therefore, now present yourselves before the Lord, arranged by your tribes and by your family units."
1 Samuel 10:20 So Samuel had all the tribes of Israel come forward, and by the casting of lots, the tribe of Benjamin was chosen.
1 Samuel 10:21 Then Samuel brought forward the tribe of Benjamin by its clans, and the lot fell on the Matrite family. Finally, by lot, Saul, the son of Kish, was chosen. But when they looked for him, he could not be found.
1 Samuel 10:22 So they further inquired of the Lord: "Will the man indeed come forward here?" The Lord answered: "Look, he is hiding among the baggage."
1 Samuel 10:23 So they ran and brought him out from there. When Saul stood among the people, he was taller than everyone else, from the shoulder upward, an imposing figure.
1 Samuel 10:24 Then Samuel said to all the people: "Do you not see the one whom the Lord has chosen? There is no one like him among all the people!" And all the people shouted with great acclaim, saying: "Long live the King!"
1 Samuel 10:25 Then Samuel spoke to the people about the rights and duties of the kingship, which he then wrote in a book and laid up before the Lord as a permanent record. After this, Samuel sent all the people away, each person returning to their own home.
1 Samuel 10:26 Saul also went home to Gibeah, and a company of men whose hearts God had touched went with him, becoming his loyal followers.
1 Samuel 10:27 But some worthless men—called "sons of Belial"—said: "How can this man save us?" They despised him and did not bring him customary gifts to honor him as king. However, Saul wisely pretended not to hear their insults.
1 Samuel 10:1 Then Samuel took a small flask of oil, poured it over Saul's head, and then kissed him, saying: "Look, the Lord has anointed you as prince over His own people, His inheritance."
1 Samuel 10:2 When you leave me today, you will meet two men near Rachel's tomb, in the territory of Benjamin, towards the south. They will say to you: 'The donkeys you went to search for have been found.' And behold, your father has found the donkeys, and he is worried about you both, and has stopped thinking about the donkeys.
1 Samuel 10:3 And when you have gone on from there, and passed further, and come to the oak of Tabor, three men will meet you there, going up to God at Bethel. One will be carrying three young goats, another, three loaves of bread, and another, a flask of wine.
1 Samuel 10:4 They will greet you and offer you two loaves of bread, and you shall take them from their hand.
1 Samuel 10:5 After this, you will come to the hill of God, where the Philistine garrison is located. And when you enter the city there, you will meet a company of prophets coming down from the high place. Before them will be a psaltery, a drum, a flute, and a lyre, and they themselves will be prophesying.
1 Samuel 10:6 Then the Spirit of the Lord will rush upon you, and you will prophesy with them, and you will be changed into another man.
1 Samuel 10:7 Therefore, when these signs come to pass for you, do whatever your hand finds to do, because the Lord is with you.
1 Samuel 10:8 And you shall go down before me to Gilgal — for I myself will come down to you there — and you shall offer burnt offerings and sacrifices of peace offerings. You shall wait seven days, until I come to you, and I will show you what to do.
1 Samuel 10:9 So when he turned his back on him to depart, God changed his heart for him; and all these signs came to pass on that day.
1 Samuel 10:10 And they came to the hill, and behold, a company of prophets met him; and the Spirit of the Lord rushed upon him, and he prophesied in their midst.
1 Samuel 10:11 All who knew him previously — for a long time — heard that he had prophesied with the prophets, and they said to one another: 'What is this that has happened to the son of Kish? Is Saul also among the prophets?'
1 Samuel 10:12 And one of the crowd responded, saying: 'And who is *their* father then?' — meaning, who are *those* prophets' fathers, that they should be prophets? — For this reason, it became a common saying: 'Is Saul also among the prophets?'
1 Samuel 10:13 And when he had finished prophesying, he went to the high place.
1 Samuel 10:14 Then Saul’s uncle said to him and to his servant boy: 'Where did you go?' They answered: 'To look for the donkeys. And when we couldn't find them, we came to Samuel.'
1 Samuel 10:15 And Saul’s uncle said: 'Tell me what Samuel said to you.'
1 Samuel 10:16 And Saul said to his uncle: 'He told us that the donkeys had been found.' But concerning the matter of the kingdom, he did not tell him what Samuel had said to him.
1 Samuel 10:17 Then Samuel called the people together to the Lord at Mizpah.
1 Samuel 10:18 And he said to the children of Israel: 'Thus says the Lord, the God of Israel: I brought Israel up out of Egypt, and I delivered you from the hand of the Egyptians, and from the hand of all the kingdoms that oppressed you.'
1 Samuel 10:19 'But today you have rejected your God, who alone saved you from all your troubles and distresses. And you have said: "No, but set a king over us!" Now therefore, present yourselves before the Lord by your tribes and by your thousands.'
1 Samuel 10:20 So Samuel brought forward all the tribes of Israel, and the lot fell to the tribe of Benjamin.
1 Samuel 10:21 Then he brought forward the tribe of Benjamin by its clans, and the lot fell to the clan of Matri. And it came down to Saul, the son of Kish. But they searched for him, and he could not be found.
1 Samuel 10:22 So they inquired further of the Lord, asking if the man had come there. And the Lord answered: 'Behold, he is hidden among the baggage.'
1 Samuel 10:23 So they ran and brought him from there. And when he stood among the people, he was taller than any of the people from his shoulders upward.
1 Samuel 10:24 And Samuel said to all the people: 'Do you see whom the Lord has chosen, that there is no one like him among all the people?' Then all the people shouted and said: 'Long live the King!'
1 Samuel 10:25 Then Samuel explained to the people the rights and duties of the kingdom, and he wrote it in a book and laid it up before the Lord. And Samuel sent all the people away, each man to his own home.
1 Samuel 10:26 But Saul also went home to Gibeah; and with him went valiant men, whose hearts God had touched.
1 Samuel 10:27 However, some wicked men said: 'How can this man save us?' And they despised him and brought him no presents. But he pretended not to hear.
1 Samuel 11:1 Nahash the Ammonite advanced and began to fight against Jabesh Gilead. Then all the men of Jabesh said to Nahash: "Make a covenant with us, and we will serve you."
1 Samuel 11:2 And Nahash the Ammonite answered them: "I will make this covenant with you, but only if I may gouge out all of your right eyes, and make you a public disgrace in all of Israel."
1 Samuel 11:3 And the elders of Jabesh said to him: "Give us seven days so that we may send messengers throughout all the borders of Israel. And if there is no one who can defend us, then we will surrender to you."
1 Samuel 11:4 So the messengers came to Gibeah, the city of Saul, and spoke these words in the hearing of the people. And all the people raised their voice and wept.
1 Samuel 11:5 And behold, Saul was coming, following his oxen from the field. And he said: "What troubles the people, that they weep?" And they told him the words of the men of Jabesh.
1 Samuel 11:6 And the Spirit of the Lord rushed upon Saul when he heard these words, and his anger burned fiercely.
1 Samuel 11:7 And he took a pair of oxen and cut them into pieces, then sent them throughout all the borders of Israel by the hand of messengers, saying: "Whoever does not come out and follow Saul and Samuel, the same will be done to his oxen." And the fear of the Lord fell upon the people, and they came out as one man.
1 Samuel 11:8 And he counted them at Bezek. And the sons of Israel were three hundred thousand men, but the men of Judah were thirty thousand.
1 Samuel 11:9 And they said to the messengers who had come: "Thus you shall say to the men of Jabesh Gilead: 'Tomorrow, deliverance will be yours when the sun grows hot'"—meaning, after the morning attack. So the messengers came and announced it to the men of Jabesh, and they rejoiced.
1 Samuel 11:10 And the men of Jabesh said: "Tomorrow we will come out to you, and you may do to us whatever seems good to you."
1 Samuel 11:11 And it happened on the next day: Saul divided the people into three companies, and they entered the midst of the Ammonite camp during the morning watch, and struck down the Ammonites until the day grew hot. But the remaining Ammonites were scattered, so that not two of them were left together.
1 Samuel 11:12 And the people said to Samuel: "Who is this who said: 'Saul shall not reign over us?' Give us those men, and we will put them to death."
1 Samuel 11:13 And Saul said: "No man shall be put to death this day, because today the Lord has worked deliverance in Israel."
1 Samuel 11:14 Then Samuel said to the people: "Come, and let us go to Gilgal, and there let us renew the kingdom."
1 Samuel 11:15 And all the people went to Gilgal, and there they anointed Saul as king before the Lord in Gilgal. And there they offered peace offerings before the Lord. And Saul and all the men of Israel rejoiced there exceedingly.
1 Samuel 11:1 Nahash the Ammonite marched up and began to fight against Jabesh-Gilead. All the men of Jabesh then said to Nahash: 'Make a covenant with us, and we will be your servants.'
1 Samuel 11:2 Nahash the Ammonite answered them: 'I will make this covenant with you only on the condition that I gouge out every one of your right eyes, and so make you a disgrace throughout all of Israel.'
1 Samuel 11:3 The elders of Jabesh then said to Nahash: 'Give us seven days so we can send messengers throughout all the territories of Israel. If no one comes to defend us, then we will surrender to you.'
1 Samuel 11:4 So the messengers came to Gibeah, Saul's city, and spoke these words in the hearing of the people. And all the people raised their voices and wept aloud because of the impending threat.
1 Samuel 11:5 And behold, Saul was coming back, following his oxen from the field. Saul asked: 'What troubles the people that they are weeping?' And they recounted to him the words of the messengers from Jabesh.
1 Samuel 11:6 Then the Spirit of the Lord came powerfully upon Saul when he heard these words, and his righteous anger burned fiercely.
1 Samuel 11:7 And he took a yoke of oxen, cut them into pieces, and sent them throughout all the territories of Israel by the hand of the messengers, saying: 'Whoever does not come out and follow Saul and Samuel, so shall it be done to his oxen!' Then the fear of the Lord fell upon the people, and they came out as one unified force.
1 Samuel 11:8 And he mustered them at Bezek. There were three hundred thousand men from the northern tribes of Israel, and thirty thousand men from the tribe of Judah.
1 Samuel 11:9 And they said to the messengers who had come: 'Thus you shall say to the men of Jabesh-Gilead: "Tomorrow, when the sun grows hot, you will have deliverance and safety."' So the messengers came and reported this to the men of Jabesh, and they rejoiced greatly.
1 Samuel 11:10 Then the men of Jabesh said to the Ammonites, misleading them: 'Tomorrow we will come out to you, and you may do with us whatever you please.'
1 Samuel 11:11 And it came to pass on the next day: Saul arranged his army into three companies. They entered the middle of the Ammonite camp during the morning watch—the time just before dawn—and struck down the Ammonites until the heat of the day. Those who remained alive were so thoroughly scattered that not even two of them were left together.
1 Samuel 11:12 Then the people, emboldened by victory, said to Samuel: 'Who is it that said, "Saul shall not reign over us"? Hand them over to us, and we will put them to death!'
1 Samuel 11:13 But Saul, in his triumph, said: 'No man shall be put to death this day, for today the Lord has brought about this great deliverance and salvation for Israel.'
1 Samuel 11:14 Then Samuel said to the people: 'Come, let us go to Gilgal, a place of historical significance, and there let us publicly affirm the kingship.'
1 Samuel 11:15 So all the people went to Gilgal, and there they formally anointed Saul king before the Lord in Gilgal. And there they offered peace offerings before the Lord, a sign of their renewed covenant. Saul rejoiced there, and all the men of Israel rejoiced with him exceedingly.

1 Samuel 12:1 Samuel then addressed all of the people of Israel. He told them: 'I have heard all that you have asked me for, and I have set a king over you.'
1 Samuel 12:2 'And now the king leads you. As for me, I have grown old and grey, but my sons are still among you. I have lived my life among you, from my youth until this very day.'
1 Samuel 12:3 'Speak about me now before the Lord and before His anointed one, the king. Have I ever taken anyone's ox or donkey? Have I ever defrauded anyone or oppressed them? Have I ever taken a bribe from anyone and then ignored their case? If so, tell me, and I will restore it to you today.'
1 Samuel 12:4 They all replied: 'You have not defrauded us, nor have you oppressed us, nor have you taken anything from anyone's hand!'
1 Samuel 12:5 Then Samuel said to them: 'The Lord is a witness against you, and His anointed one is a witness today, that you have found nothing wrong in my conduct.' And they said: 'He is a witness!'
1 Samuel 12:6 Samuel then said to the people: 'The Lord, who made Moses and Aaron into leaders, is the same God who led our ancestors out of the land of Egypt.'
1 Samuel 12:7 'Therefore, stand now, so that I may contend with you in judgment before the Lord, concerning all the gracious deeds which the Lord performed for you and for your ancestors.'
1 Samuel 12:8 'Remember how Jacob went down into Egypt, and your ancestors cried out to the Lord? And the Lord sent Moses and Aaron, and they led your ancestors out of Egypt and settled them in this place.'
1 Samuel 12:9 'But then they forgot the Lord their God. So He handed them over into the power of Sisara, the commander of the army of Hasor, and into the power of the Philistines, and into the power of the king of Moab, and these nations fought against them.'
1 Samuel 12:10 'Then your ancestors cried out to the Lord, saying: "We have sinned, for we have abandoned the Lord and served the Baalim and the Astaroth. Now therefore, deliver us from the hand of our enemies, and we will serve You!"'
1 Samuel 12:11 'So the Lord sent Jerobaal, and Badan, and Jephte, and Samuel, and He delivered you from the hand of your enemies all around, and you lived in security.'
1 Samuel 12:12 'But when you saw that Naas, the king of the children of Ammon, was coming against you, you said to me: "No, we must have a king reign over us!" You said this even though the Lord your God was already your King!'
1 Samuel 12:13 'Now therefore, behold your king, whom you have chosen and for whom you have asked. Behold, the Lord has set a king over you.'
1 Samuel 12:14 'If you fear the Lord, and serve Him, and listen to His voice, and do not rebel against the command of the Lord, then both you and your king who rules over you will follow the Lord your God.'
1 Samuel 12:15 'But if you do not listen to the voice of the Lord, and if you rebel against the words of the Lord, then the hand of the Lord will be against you and against your ancestors —meaning the previous generation of kings and leaders.'
1 Samuel 12:16 'But now, stand still and see this great thing which the Lord is about to do before your eyes.'
1 Samuel 12:17 'Is it not the time of the wheat harvest today? This is a time of year when it does not rain. I will call upon the Lord, and He will send thunder and rain. And you will know and see that you have done great evil in the sight of the Lord by asking for a king for yourselves.'
1 Samuel 12:18 So Samuel cried out to the Lord, and the Lord sent thunder and rain on that very day. And all the people feared the Lord and Samuel greatly.
1 Samuel 12:19 And all the people said to Samuel: 'Pray for your servants to the Lord your God, so that we may not die! For we have added to all our other sins this evil, that we asked for a king for ourselves.'
1 Samuel 12:20 Samuel then said to the people: 'Do not be afraid! You have indeed done all this evil, but nevertheless, do not turn away from following the Lord. Instead, serve the Lord with all your heart.'
1 Samuel 12:21 'And do not turn aside after empty things, which will not profit you nor deliver you, for they are empty idols.'
1 Samuel 12:22 'For the Lord will not forsake His people for His great Name's sake. This is because the Lord has sworn to make you His own people.'
1 Samuel 12:23 'Far be it from me to commit this sin against the Lord, that I should cease to pray for you! And I will teach you the good and the right way.'
1 Samuel 12:24 'Therefore, fear the Lord and serve Him in truth and with all your heart. For you have seen how many great things He has done for you.'
1 Samuel 12:25 'But if you continue in wickedness, both you and your king will perish together.'
1 Samuel 13:1 Saul was in the first year of his effective reign when he began to rule, and he reigned for two years.
1 Samuel 13:2 And Saul chose for himself three thousand men from Israel. Two thousand of them were with Saul in Machmas and in the mountains of Bethel, and one thousand were with Jonathan in Gabaa of Benjamin. The rest of the people, he sent each man back to his own tent.
1 Samuel 13:3 And Jonathan struck the garrison of the Philistines that was in Gabaa. When the Philistines heard of it, Saul sounded the trumpet throughout all the land, saying: "Let the Hebrews hear this!"
1 Samuel 13:4 And all Israel heard such a report: "Saul has struck the garrison of the Philistines, and Israel has aroused the hatred of the Philistines." So the people were summoned to Saul in Galgala.
1 Samuel 13:5 Furthermore, the Philistines gathered to fight against Israel: thirty thousand chariots, and six thousand cavalry, and the rest of their common people were as numerous as the sand on the seashore. They went up and encamped in Machmas, to the east of Bethaven.
1 Samuel 13:6 However, when the men of Israel saw that they were hard-pressed, and that the people were in distress, they hid themselves in caves, and in dense thickets, and among the rocks, and in hidden places, and in cisterns.
1 Samuel 13:7 Some of the Hebrews even crossed the Jordan into the land of Gad and Galaad. While Saul was still in Galgala, all the people trembled in fear, following him.
1 Samuel 13:8 And Saul waited for seven days, according to the appointed time Samuel had established. But Samuel did not come to Galgala, and the people began to scatter from him.
1 Samuel 13:9 Therefore, Saul said: "Bring me the burnt offering and the peace offerings." And he offered the burnt offering.
1 Samuel 13:10 When he had just finished offering the burnt offering, behold, Samuel was coming. And Saul went out to meet him to greet him.
1 Samuel 13:11 And Samuel said to him: "What have you done?" Saul answered: "Because I saw that the people were scattering from me, and you had not come according to the appointed days, and the Philistines had gathered in Machmas,
1 Samuel 13:12 I said to myself: 'Now the Philistines will come down against me in Galgala, and I have not appeased the face of the Lord through prayer and sacrifice.' Therefore, I dared to transgress and offered the sacrifice."
1 Samuel 13:13 And Samuel said to Saul: "You have acted foolishly. You have not kept the commandments of the Lord your God, which He commanded you. For if you had not done this, the Lord would now have established your kingdom over Israel forever.
1 Samuel 13:14 But now, your kingdom will not last. The Lord has sought for Himself a man after His own heart, and the Lord has appointed him to be a leader over His people, because you have not kept what the Lord commanded."
1 Samuel 13:15 And Samuel rose up and went from Galgala to Gabaa of Benjamin. And the rest of the people went up after Saul, who was meeting with the people that remained from among the strongest men.
1 Samuel 13:16 And Saul numbered the people who were found with him, about six hundred men.
1 Samuel 13:17 And a company of the Philistines went up to pass through the pass of Machmas.
1 Samuel 13:18 Now one part of them was in Bethoron, and another went to Ephra into the land of Sual, and the third went on towards the boundary above the valley of Oheb.
1 Samuel 13:19 There was not a single blacksmith to be found in all the land of Israel, because the Philistines had ensured that the Hebrews would not be able to make a sword or a spear.
1 Samuel 13:20 Instead, all the men of Israel had to go down to the Philistines, so that each man could sharpen his plowshare, and his mattock, and his axe, and his hoe.
1 Samuel 13:21 And the edges of their plowshares, and mattocks, and three-pronged spears, and axes were dull. And they were sharpened by the Philistines' oxen goads.
1 Samuel 13:22 And when the day of battle arrived, no sword or spear was found in the hand of all the people who were with Saul and Jonathan, except for Saul and his son Jonathan.
1 Samuel 13:23 Now a garrison of the Philistines went out to cross over to Madian.
1 Samuel 14:1 Some days later, it happened that Jonathan, son of Saul, said to his young armor-bearer, "Come, let us cross over to the Philistine outpost that is across the valley." Jonathan, however, did not wish to tell his father about this plan.
1 Samuel 14:2 Meanwhile, Saul was staying on the outskirts of Gibeah, under a pomegranate tree in Migron. The men with him numbered about six hundred.
1 Samuel 14:3 Ahiah, son of Ahitub, brother of Ichabod, who was the son of Phinehas, who was the son of Eli, the Lord’s priest in Shiloh, was wearing the ephod. But even the people did not know where Jonathan had gone.
1 Samuel 14:4 There were two prominent rocky crags on either side of the pass Jonathan intended to use to cross over to the Philistine outpost. These jagged rocks looked like sharp teeth, steep on both sides. One was named Bozez, and the other Sene.
1 Samuel 14:5 One crag jutted out to the north, facing Michmas, and the other faced south, opposite Gibeah.
1 Samuel 14:6 Then Jonathan said to his young armor-bearer, "Come, let us cross over to the outpost of these uncircumcised Philistines. Perhaps the Lord will act on our behalf. For it is not difficult for the Lord to bring salvation, whether by means of many soldiers or by only a few."
1 Samuel 14:7 And his armor-bearer said to him, "Do whatever seems good to you. Go wherever you wish, for I am with you, just as you desire."
1 Samuel 14:8 Then Jonathan said, "Look, we are crossing over to these men, and when we show ourselves to them,"
1 Samuel 14:9 "if they say to us, 'Wait until we come to you,' then we will stay where we are and not climb up to them."
1 Samuel 14:10 "But if they say, 'Come up to us,' then we will climb up, because that will be a sign for us that the Lord has delivered them into our hands."
1 Samuel 14:11 So both of them showed themselves to the Philistine outpost, and the Philistines said, "Look! The Hebrews are coming out of the caves where they have been hiding!"
1 Samuel 14:12 Then the men of the outpost called out to Jonathan and his armor-bearer, saying, "Come up to us, and we will show you a thing or two!" Jonathan then said to his armor-bearer, "Follow me, for the Lord has delivered them into the hand of Israel."
1 Samuel 14:13 So Jonathan climbed up, using both his hands and his feet, with his armor-bearer right behind him. The Philistines fell before Jonathan, and his armor-bearer killed those who were close behind him.
1 Samuel 14:14 In that first attack, Jonathan and his armor-bearer killed about twenty men in a very small area of land—roughly the space a yoke of oxen could plow in half a day.
1 Samuel 14:15 A great panic spread through the Philistine camp and across the fields. All the men who had gone out to plunder were stunned and fled, trembling with fear. Even the soldiers at the outpost and the raiders themselves were struck with terror.
1 Samuel 14:16 Saul’s watchmen in Gibeah of Benjamin saw that the Philistine multitude was routed and scattered, fleeing in every direction.
1 Samuel 14:17 Then Saul said to the people with him, "Check and see who among us has left." When they checked, they found that Jonathan and his armor-bearer were not there.
1 Samuel 14:18 Then Saul said to Ahiah, "Bring the Ark of God near." —For the Ark of God was with the children of Israel on that day.
1 Samuel 14:19 While Saul was still speaking to the priest, the commotion in the Philistine camp grew louder and more intense. So Saul said to the priest, "Withdraw your hand! Stop consulting the Ark!"
1 Samuel 14:20 Then Saul and all the people who were with him raised a war cry and rushed to the battle scene. There, they found the Philistines’ swords were turned against each other, and a very great slaughter was underway.
1 Samuel 14:21 Furthermore, the Hebrews who had been with the Philistines for some time—having even gone up with them into their camp—now turned back to join the Israelites who were with Saul and Jonathan.
1 Samuel 14:22 All the Israelites who had hidden themselves in the hill country of Ephraim, hearing that the Philistines were fleeing, joined them in the pursuit. So the number of fighting men grew to about ten thousand.
1 Samuel 14:23 Thus, the Lord saved Israel on that day. The battle, however, continued all the way to Beth-aven.
1 Samuel 14:24 The men of Israel were exhausted that day, because Saul had bound the people with an oath, saying, "Cursed be the man who eats any food before evening, before I have avenged myself on my enemies!" So none of the people tasted any food.
1 Samuel 14:25 All the common people of the land came into a forest where there was wild honey on the ground.
1 Samuel 14:26 When the people entered the forest, they saw honey dripping everywhere, yet no one put a hand to his mouth to eat it, for the people feared the oath.
1 Samuel 14:27 Jonathan, however, had not heard when his father put the oath on the people. So he stretched out the end of the staff that was in his hand, dipped it into a honeycomb, and put his hand to his mouth. Immediately, his eyes brightened, and his strength returned.
1 Samuel 14:28 Then one of the people replied, "Your father solemnly bound the people with an oath, saying, 'Cursed be the man who eats any food today!' That is why the people are so faint."
1 Samuel 14:29 Jonathan then said, "My father has brought trouble upon the land. See how my eyes brightened and my strength returned just because I tasted a little of this honey!"
1 Samuel 14:30 "How much greater a blow might have been struck against the Philistines if the people had been allowed to eat freely from the spoils they found, instead of being starved!"
1 Samuel 14:31 On that day, they struck down the Philistines from Michmas all the way to Aijalon. By then, the people were utterly exhausted.
1 Samuel 14:32 The people then rushed greedily for the spoils. They took sheep, oxen, and calves, slaughtered them directly on the ground, and ate the meat with the blood still in it—a violation of God’s Law.
1 Samuel 14:33 Then someone reported to Saul, "Look, the people are sinning against the Lord by eating meat with the blood still in it!" He replied, "You have transgressed! Roll a large stone here to me at once!"
1 Samuel 14:34 Saul then said, "Go out among the people and tell them, 'Each man is to bring his ox or his ram to me at once, and slaughter it here, and eat it. Do not sin against the Lord by eating meat with the blood still in it!'" So every one of the people brought his ox with his own hand to Saul and slaughtered it there.
1 Samuel 14:35 Saul also built an altar to the Lord. This was the first altar he built to the Lord.
1 Samuel 14:36 Then Saul said, "Let us go down after the Philistines by night and plunder them until morning, and let us not leave a single man among them." The people replied, "Do whatever seems good to you." But the priest said, "Let us come near to God here to inquire of Him."
1 Samuel 14:37 So Saul inquired of the Lord, "Shall I pursue the Philistines? Will You deliver them into the hand of Israel?" But the Lord did not answer him on that day.
1 Samuel 14:38 Then Saul said, "Gather all the chiefs and leaders of the people here, and find out how this sin occurred today."
1 Samuel 14:39 He swore an oath, "As the Lord, the Savior of Israel, lives, if this sin was committed by my own son Jonathan, he must surely die without fail!" But none of the people answered him.
1 Samuel 14:40 Then he said to all Israel, "You stand on one side, and I and my son Jonathan will stand on the other side." The people responded to Saul, "Do what seems good to you."
1 Samuel 15:1 Samuel said to Saul: "The Lord sent me on a mission to anoint you as king over His people, Israel. Therefore, you must listen to the voice of the Lord now."
1 Samuel 15:2 "Thus says the Lord of Armies: 'I have carefully observed all that Amalek did to Israel, specifically how they ambushed and fought against them on their journey when they came up out of Egypt.'"
1 Samuel 15:3 "Now, therefore, go and attack Amalek. Utterly destroy everything they possess; do not spare them. You must kill every person—from man to woman, from small child to infant—and every animal—ox and sheep, camel and donkey."
1 Samuel 15:4 So Saul gave orders to the people and counted them all, numbering them carefully: there were two hundred thousand foot soldiers, and ten thousand men from the tribe of Judah.
1 Samuel 15:5 When Saul arrived at the city of Amalek, he set up an ambush in the wadi, the valley floor near the city.
1 Samuel 15:6 And Saul said to the Kenites: "Go now, depart, and separate yourselves from among the other Amalekites, so that I do not destroy you along with them. For you showed kindness to all the children of Israel when they came up from Egypt." So the Kenites departed from among the Amalekites.
1 Samuel 15:7 So Saul attacked Amalek from Havilah all the way to Shur, which lies opposite Egypt.
1 Samuel 15:8 He captured Agag, the king of Amalek, alive, but all the rest of the people he put to death with the edge of the sword.
1 Samuel 15:9 But Saul and the people spared Agag, and they spared the best of the flocks of sheep and herds of cattle, and the finest garments, and the rams—indeed, everything that was valuable. They did not want to destroy these. However, all the worthless and weak animals, they did kill.
1 Samuel 15:10 Then the word of the Lord came to Samuel, saying:
1 Samuel 15:11 "I am deeply grieved that I have made Saul king, for he has turned away from me and has not carried out my commands." Samuel was greatly saddened by this news, and he cried out to the Lord all through the night.
1 Samuel 15:12 When Samuel rose early in the morning to go to Saul, people reported to Samuel, saying: "Saul went to Carmel, and there he set up a triumphal monument for himself. Then he turned back, passed on, and went down to Gilgal."
1 Samuel 15:13 When Samuel came to Saul, Saul said to him, "May you be blessed by the Lord! I have carried out the Lord's command."
1 Samuel 15:14 But Samuel said, "Then what is this sound of sheep bleating in my ears, and the lowing of cattle that I hear?"
1 Samuel 15:15 Saul answered, "They brought them from the Amalekites, for the people spared the best of the sheep and cattle to offer as sacrifices to the Lord your God. The rest we utterly destroyed."
1 Samuel 15:16 Then Samuel said to Saul, "Stop! Let me tell you what the Lord said to me last night." And Saul said to him, "Speak."
1 Samuel 15:17 And Samuel said: "Though you considered yourself small and insignificant in your own eyes, were you not made the leader of the tribes of Israel? And the Lord anointed you king over Israel."
1 Samuel 15:18 "And the Lord sent you on a mission, saying: 'Go and utterly destroy the sinful Amalekites, and fight against them until they are completely annihilated.'"
1 Samuel 15:19 "Why then did you not obey the voice of the Lord? Instead, you turned to the plunder and did what was evil in the sight of the Lord!"
1 Samuel 15:20 Saul said to Samuel: "But I did obey the voice of the Lord! I went on the mission the Lord sent me on. I brought back Agag, the king of Amalek, and I utterly destroyed the Amalekites!"
1 Samuel 15:21 "But the people took from the spoil, from among the sheep and cattle, the very best of those things that were designated for utter destruction, with the intention of sacrificing them to the Lord your God in Gilgal."
1 Samuel 15:22 And Samuel said: "Does the Lord truly desire burnt offerings and sacrifices, rather than obedience to His voice? For indeed, to obey is better than to offer animal sacrifices, and to listen attentively is better than to offer the fat of rams."
1 Samuel 15:23 "For rebellion is like the sin of divination, and stubbornness is like the wickedness of idolatry. Therefore, because you have rejected the word and command of the Lord, the Lord has rejected you from being king over Israel."
1 Samuel 15:24 Then Saul said to Samuel: "I have sinned, because I transgressed the command of the Lord and your instructions. I did this because I feared the people, and I listened to their voices more than to God's."
1 Samuel 15:25 "Now therefore, I beg you, forgive my sin and return with me, so that I may worship the Lord."
1 Samuel 15:26 And Samuel said to Saul: "I will not return with you, for you have rejected the command of the Lord, and the Lord has rejected you from being king over Israel."
1 Samuel 15:27 As Samuel turned to leave, Saul grabbed the edge of his robe, and it tore.
1 Samuel 15:28 And Samuel said to him: "Just as this robe is torn, the Lord has torn the kingdom of Israel away from you today, and He has given it to a neighbor of yours who is better than you."
1 Samuel 15:29 Furthermore, the Eternal and Victorious One in Israel does not lie, nor does He change His mind, for He is not a man who feels regret or alters His plans.
1 Samuel 15:30 And Saul said: "I have sinned. But please honor me now before the elders of my people and before Israel, and return with me, so that I may worship the Lord your God."
1 Samuel 15:31 So Samuel turned back and followed Saul, and Saul worshipped the Lord.
1 Samuel 15:32 Then Samuel said: "Bring me Agag, the king of the Amalekites." And Agag, who was very well-fed, was brought to him, and he was trembling. Agag said: "Surely the bitterness of death has passed now"—meaning he thought the danger was over.
1 Samuel 15:33 And Samuel said: "Just as your sword has made many women childless, so now your mother will be childless among women." Then Samuel cut Agag into pieces before the Lord in Gilgal.
1 Samuel 15:34 Then Samuel went to Ramah, but Saul went up to his house in Gibeah of Saul.
1 Samuel 15:35 Samuel never saw Saul again until the day of his death. However, Samuel continued to grieve deeply for Saul. And the Lord was sorrowful that He had made Saul king over Israel.
1 Samuel 15:1 And Samuel said to Saul: "The Lord Himself sent me on a mission to anoint you as king over His people, Israel. Therefore, now listen to the voice of the Lord."
1 Samuel 15:2 The Lord of armies declares this: 'I have carefully recalled all that Amalec did to Israel, how he resisted him on the way when he came up out of Egypt.'
1 Samuel 15:3 'Now therefore go and attack Amalec, and utterly destroy all that belongs to him. Do not spare him, but put to death every person, from man to woman, from little child to nursing infant. Also put to death every ox and sheep, every camel and donkey.'
1 Samuel 15:4 So Saul summoned the people and counted them, as if they were lambs. There were two hundred thousand foot soldiers, and ten thousand men from Judah.
1 Samuel 15:5 And when Saul came to the city of Amalec, he set an ambush in the valley—along the dry riverbed.
1 Samuel 15:6 Then Saul said to the Kenites: 'Go, and depart from Amalec, lest by chance I should involve you with them in their destruction. For you showed kindness to all the children of Israel when they came up out of Egypt.' So the Kenites departed from the midst of Amalec.
1 Samuel 15:7 Saul then attacked Amalec from Havilah all the way to Shur, which faces Egypt.
1 Samuel 15:8 And he seized Agag, the king of Amalec, alive. But he put all the ordinary people to death with the edge of the sword.
1 Samuel 15:9 But Saul and his people spared Agag, as well as the best of the flocks of sheep and herds of cattle, and the garments, and the rams—indeed, everything that was good and valuable. They did not want to utterly destroy these things. But everything that was vile and contemptible, that they utterly destroyed.
1 Samuel 15:10 Now the word of the Lord came to Samuel, saying:
1 Samuel 15:11 'I regret that I made Saul king, because he has forsaken me and has not carried out my commands. Samuel was deeply saddened by this, and he cried out to the Lord all that night.
1 Samuel 15:12 When Samuel rose in the night to go to Saul in the morning, it was reported to Samuel, by someone, that Saul had come to Carmel, and had set up a triumphant arch for himself, and had then turned back and gone to Gilgal.
1 Samuel 15:13 So Samuel came to Saul. And Saul was offering a burnt offering to the Lord from the first-fruits of the spoil that he had brought back from Amalec.
1 Samuel 15:14 And Samuel said: "What then is this bleating of the flocks that echoes in my ears, and the lowing of the herds that I hear?"
1 Samuel 15:15 And Saul said: "They brought these things from Amalec. For the people spared the best sheep and cattle, so that they might be sacrificed to the Lord your God. The rest, however, we utterly destroyed."
1 Samuel 15:16 Then Samuel said to Saul: "Allow me, and I will declare to you what the Lord has spoken to me during the night." And Saul said to him: "Speak."
1 Samuel 15:17 And Samuel said: "Although you may have been small in your own estimation, were you not made the head over the tribes of Israel? And the Lord anointed you king over Israel.
1 Samuel 15:18 And the Lord sent you on a journey and said: 'Go and put to death the sinners of Amalec, and you shall fight against them until their complete destruction.'
1 Samuel 15:19 Why then did you not listen to the voice of the Lord? Instead, you turned to plunder and did what was evil in the eyes of the Lord.
1 Samuel 15:20 And Saul said to Samuel: "Indeed, I did listen to the voice of the Lord. I walked in the way by which the Lord sent me, and I brought back Agag, the king of Amalec, and I utterly destroyed Amalec.
1 Samuel 15:21 But the people took from the spoils some sheep and cattle, the very best of those that were to be slain, in order to sacrifice them to the Lord your God in Gilgal."
1 Samuel 15:22 But Samuel said: "Does the Lord desire burnt offerings and sacrifices, and not rather that His voice be obeyed? Truly, to obey is better than to offer sacrifices, and to listen is better than to offer the fat of rams.
1 Samuel 15:23 For rebellion is like the sin of divination, and stubbornness is like the wickedness of idolatry. Therefore, because you have rejected the word of the Lord, the Lord has also rejected you from being king over Israel."
1 Samuel 15:24 Then Saul said to Samuel: "I have sinned, because I have violated the command of the Lord and your words, fearing the people and obeying their voice."
1 Samuel 15:25 "Now therefore, I beg you, forgive my sin, and return with me, so that I may worship the Lord."
1 Samuel 15:26 And Samuel said to Saul: "I will not return with you, because you have cast aside the word of the Lord, and the Lord has cast you aside from being king over Israel."
1 Samuel 15:27 And as Samuel turned to go away, Saul seized the edge of his cloak, and it tore.
1 Samuel 15:28 And Samuel said to him: "The Lord has torn the kingdom of Israel away from you today, and has given it to a neighbor of yours who is better than you."
1 Samuel 15:29 Furthermore, the Victorious One in Israel—that is, God—will not relent, and will not be swayed by repentance. For He is not a man that He should be swayed by repentance.
1 Samuel 15:30 And Saul said: "I have sinned. But honor me now before the elders of my people and before Israel, and return with me, so that I may worship the Lord your God."
1 Samuel 15:31 So Samuel returned and followed Saul, and Saul worshipped the Lord.
1 Samuel 15:32 And Samuel said: "Bring Agag, the king of Amalec, to me." And Agag was brought to him—Agag was very fat and trembling, and he said: "Surely the bitterness of death is now past?"
1 Samuel 15:33 And Samuel said: "Just as your sword made women childless, so your mother will be childless among women." And Samuel cut Agag into pieces before the Lord in Gilgal.
1 Samuel 15:34 Then Samuel went to Ramah. But Saul went up to his own house in Gibeah of Saul.
1 Samuel 15:35 And Samuel never saw Saul again until the day of his death. Nevertheless, Samuel mourned for Saul, and the Lord regretted that He had made Saul king over Israel.
1 Samuel 16:1 The Lord then said to Samuel: "How long will you mourn for Saul, since I have already rejected him from reigning over Israel? Fill your horn with oil, and come, so I may send you to Jesse, the man from Bethlehem. For I have prepared a king for Myself among his sons."
1 Samuel 16:2 Samuel replied: "How can I go? For Saul will hear about it and will kill me." The Lord answered: "Take a calf from the herd with you in your hand, and say: 'I have come to offer a sacrifice to the Lord.'"
1 Samuel 16:3 And invite Jesse to the sacrifice. Then I will show you what you must do, and you shall anoint the one whom I point out to you.
1 Samuel 16:4 So Samuel did exactly as the Lord had told him. He arrived in Bethlehem. The elders of the city were astonished at his coming; they hurried to meet him and asked: "Is your arrival for peace?"
1 Samuel 16:5 Samuel said: "Yes, it is for peace. I have come to offer a sacrifice to the Lord. Sanctify yourselves and come with me so I may perform the sacrifice." So he sanctified Jesse and his sons, and invited them to the sacrifice.
1 Samuel 16:6 When they had entered, Samuel saw Eliab. And Samuel thought to himself: "Surely this is the Lord's Anointed One, standing here before the Lord."
1 Samuel 16:7 But the Lord said to Samuel: "Do not look at his appearance or at the height of his stature, because I have rejected him. For I do not judge according to what a human judges: a human sees what is visible, but the Lord looks at the heart."
1 Samuel 16:8 Then Jesse called Abinadab and brought him before Samuel. But Samuel said: "The Lord has not chosen this one either."
1 Samuel 16:9 Next, Jesse brought Shamma. And Samuel said: "The Lord has not chosen this one either."
1 Samuel 16:10 So Jesse brought seven of his sons before Samuel. But Samuel said to Jesse: "The Lord has not chosen any of these."
1 Samuel 16:11 Then Samuel asked Jesse: "Are all your sons here?" Jesse answered: "There is still the youngest one left, and he is tending the sheep." Samuel said to Jesse: "Send for him and bring him here, because we will not sit down to eat until he comes."
1 Samuel 16:12 So Jesse sent for him and brought him in. Now he was ruddy, with beautiful eyes and a handsome face. And the Lord said: "Arise, anoint him, for this is he."
1 Samuel 16:13 Then Samuel took the horn of oil and anointed him in the presence of his brothers. And the Spirit of the Lord was powerfully present with David from that day forward. Then Samuel arose and went back to Ramah.
1 Samuel 16:14 Now the Spirit of the Lord had departed from Saul, and an evil spirit tormented him, sent by the Lord to afflict him.
1 Samuel 16:15 Saul's servants said to him: "Behold, an evil spirit from God is tormenting you."
1 Samuel 16:16 "Let our lord command your servants who are before you to seek out a man who is skilled at playing the lyre, so that when the evil spirit from God seizes you, he may play with his hand, and you may find relief."
1 Samuel 16:17 Saul said to his servants: "Then provide me with a man who plays well, and bring him to me."
1 Samuel 16:18 Then one of the young men answered and said: "Behold, I have seen a son of Jesse the Bethlehemite who is skilled in playing, and a mighty man of valor, and a warrior, and prudent in speech, and a handsome man. And the Lord is with him."
1 Samuel 16:19 So Saul sent messengers to Jesse, saying: "Send me David your son, who is with the sheep in the pastures."
1 Samuel 16:20 Then Jesse took a donkey laden with bread, a skin of wine, and a young goat, and sent them by the hand of David his son to Saul, as a gift.
1 Samuel 16:21 So David came to Saul and stood before him. Saul loved him dearly, and David became his armor-bearer.
1 Samuel 16:22 Saul then sent word to Jesse, saying: "Let David remain in my service, for he has found favor in my eyes."
1 Samuel 16:23 Therefore, whenever the evil spirit from the Lord came upon Saul, David would take up his lyre and play with his hand. Then Saul would be refreshed and feel better, for the evil spirit would leave him.
1 Samuel 16:1 And the Lord said to Samuel: 'How long will you mourn for Saul? —I have already rejected him from reigning over Israel. Fill your anointing horn with oil, and come, so that I may send you to Jesse the Bethlehemite, for I have chosen for myself a king from among his sons.'
1 Samuel 16:2 And Samuel said: 'How can I go? For Saul will hear of it, and he will kill me.' And the Lord said: 'Take a young heifer from the herd with you in your hand, and say: 'I have come to offer a sacrifice to the Lord.''
1 Samuel 16:3 And you shall invite Jesse to the sacrifice, and I will show you what to do. You are to anoint the one whom I show you.
1 Samuel 16:4 So Samuel did as the Lord commanded him. And he came to Bethlehem, and the elders of the city were astonished. They came to meet him and asked: 'Is your coming peaceful?'
1 Samuel 16:5 And he said: 'It is peaceful. I have come to offer a sacrifice to the Lord. Purify yourselves, and come with me to the sacrifice' —this involves ritual cleansing. So Jesse purified himself and his sons, and invited them to the sacrifice.
1 Samuel 16:6 When they came in, Samuel saw Eliab and thought: 'Surely the Lord's Anointed is before Him!' —Samuel initially judged by outward appearance.
1 Samuel 16:7 But the Lord said to Samuel: 'Do not look at his appearance or his height, for I have rejected him. I do not judge as man judges. For man sees what is visible, but the Lord sees the heart.'
1 Samuel 16:8 Then Jesse called Abinadab and brought him before Samuel. And Samuel said: 'The Lord has not chosen this one either.'
1 Samuel 16:9 Then Jesse brought Shammah, of whom Samuel said: 'The Lord has not chosen this one either.'
1 Samuel 16:10 So Jesse brought his seven sons before Samuel. And Samuel said to Jesse: 'The Lord has not chosen any of these.'
1 Samuel 16:11 Then Samuel said to Jesse: 'Are these all your sons who remain?' And Jesse replied: 'There still remains the youngest, and he is tending the sheep.' And Samuel said to Jesse: 'Send for him and bring him here, for we will not sit down to eat until he comes here.'
1 Samuel 16:12 So Jesse sent and brought him in. He was reddish, with beautiful eyes, and a handsome appearance. And the Lord said: 'Arise, anoint him, for this is the one.'
1 Samuel 16:13 Then Samuel took the horn of oil and anointed him in the presence of his brothers. And the Spirit of the Lord came upon David mightily from that day forward. Then Samuel arose and went to Ramah.
1 Samuel 16:14 Now the Spirit of the Lord had departed from Saul, and an evil spirit sent by the Lord tormented him —this doesn't imply God is evil but rather that He allowed or ordained this affliction as a consequence of Saul's disobedience.
1 Samuel 16:15 And Saul's servants said to him: 'Behold, an evil spirit from the Lord is tormenting you.'
1 Samuel 16:16 'Let our lord command, and your servants will search for someone who can play the lyre well. Then, when the evil spirit from the Lord takes hold of you, he can play with his hand, and you will be relieved' —the music would soothe and distract, perhaps creating a more peaceful internal state.
1 Samuel 16:17 And Saul said to his servants: 'Find me now someone who plays well, and bring him to me.'
1 Samuel 16:18 Then one of the young men answered and said: 'Behold, I have seen a son of Jesse the Bethlehemite, who is skilled in playing the lyre, and he is a mighty warrior, and a man of war, and prudent in speech, and a handsome man. And the Lord is with him' —this is high praise, acknowledging David's diverse talents and God's favor.
1 Samuel 16:19 So Saul sent messengers to Jesse, saying: 'Send me your son David, who is with the sheep.'
1 Samuel 16:20 So Jesse took an ass loaded with bread, and a flask of wine, and a young goat, and sent them by the hand of David his son to Saul —these were gifts appropriate for a vassal presenting his son to a king.
1 Samuel 16:21 And David came to Saul and stood before him. And Saul loved him greatly, and he became his armor-bearer —this was an important position of trust and proximity to the king.
1 Samuel 16:22 And Saul sent word to Jesse, saying: 'Let David remain in my service, for he has found favor in my sight' —meaning, he has pleased me or I am pleased with him.
1 Samuel 16:23 Therefore, whenever the evil spirit from the Lord seized Saul, David would take his lyre and play it with his hand. Then Saul would be refreshed and feel better, for the evil spirit would depart from him.
1 Samuel 16:24 Now the Philistines gathered their armies for battle. They assembled at Socoh, which belongs to Judah, and they encamped between Socoh and Azekah, in Ephes-dammim.
1 Samuel 16:25 Saul and the men of Israel assembled and came to the Valley of Elah, and they drew up their battle line against the Philistines.
1 Samuel 16:26 The Philistines stood on a mountain on one side, and Israel stood on a mountain on the other side. And there was a valley between them.
1 Samuel 16:27 Then a champion came out of the Philistine camp, named Goliath, from Gath. His height was six cubits and a span —approximately nine feet nine inches tall.
1 Samuel 16:28 He had a bronze helmet on his head, and he was clothed with a scale-armor breastplate. The weight of his breastplate was five thousand shekels of bronze —approximately one hundred and twenty-five pounds of bronze.
1 Samuel 16:29 And he had bronze greaves on his legs, and a bronze shield was carried between his shoulders.
1 Samuel 16:30 The shaft of his spear was like a weaver's beam, and his spearhead weighed six hundred shekels of iron —approximately fifteen pounds. And his armor-bearer went before him.
1 Samuel 16:31 Then he stood and cried out to the armies of Israel, and said to them: 'Why have you come out and drawn up for battle? Am I not a Philistine, and you servants of Saul? Choose a man for yourselves, and let him come down to me for single combat!'
1 Samuel 16:32 'If he is able to fight with me and defeat me, then we will be your servants. But if I prevail and defeat him, then you will be our servants, and you will serve us.'
1 Samuel 16:33 And the Philistine said: 'I have defied the armies of Israel today! Give me a man, that we may fight in single combat!'
1 Samuel 16:34 When Saul and all Israel heard these words from the Philistine, they were dismayed and greatly afraid —the challenge was terrifying due to Goliath's immense size and weaponry.
1 Samuel 16:35 Now David was the son of an Ephrathite man from Bethlehem in Judah. His name was Jesse, and he had eight sons. And in the days of Saul, the man Jesse was old and well advanced in years among men —this clarifies Jesse's age and prominence in his community.
1 Samuel 16:36 And Jesse's three oldest sons had gone after Saul to the battle. Their names were: the firstborn Eliab, the second Abinadab, and the third Shammah.
1 Samuel 16:37 David was the youngest. So while the three oldest followed Saul,
1 Samuel 16:38 David had gone away and returned from Saul's service. He went back to feed his father's flock in Bethlehem —this explains why David was not immediately present at the battle, indicating a period of time has passed.
1 Samuel 16:39 And the Philistine came forward morning and evening. He stood challenging for forty days —this emphasizes the prolonged terror and the immense pressure on the Israelite army.
1 Samuel 16:40 Then Jesse said to David his son: 'Take for your brothers this ephah of roasted grain, and these ten loaves of bread. And hurry to the camp to your brothers.'
1 Samuel 17:1 Now the Philistines gathered their armies for battle. They assembled at Socho in Judah, and they set up their camp between Socho and Azeca, in the territory of Ephesdammim.
1 Samuel 17:2 But Saul and the men of Israel gathered together. They came to the Valley of Terebinth and set up their camp opposite the Philistines.
1 Samuel 17:3 The Philistines stood on a mountain on one side, and Israel stood on a mountain on the other side. A valley was between them.
1 Samuel 17:4 Then a mighty warrior came out from the Philistine camp, whose name was Goliath, from Gath. He was six cubits and a palm in height—an incredible height for a man.
1 Samuel 17:5 A bronze helmet was on his head, and he wore a coat of scaled armor. The weight of his armor was five thousand shekels of bronze.
1 Samuel 17:6 Bronze greaves were on his legs, and a bronze shield protected his shoulders.
1 Samuel 17:7 The shaft of his spear was like a weaver's beam, and his spearhead weighed six hundred shekels of iron. His shield-bearer walked before him.
1 Samuel 17:8 He stood and shouted at the battle lines of Israel, saying to them: "Why have you come out prepared for battle? Am I not a Philistine, and are you not servants of Saul? Choose a man from among yourselves, and let him come down for single combat."
1 Samuel 17:9 "If he can fight with me and defeat me, then we will be your servants. But if I overpower him and defeat him, then you will be our servants and you will serve us."
1 Samuel 17:10 And the Philistine added: "I have defied the armies of Israel today! Give me a man, and I will enter into single combat with him!"
1 Samuel 17:11 When Saul and all Israel heard these words from the Philistine, they were greatly troubled and became very afraid.
1 Samuel 17:12 Now David was the son of an Ephrathite man from Bethlehem in Judah, whose name was Jesse. Jesse had eight sons. And during the time of Saul, this man was old and advanced in years among men.
1 Samuel 17:13 And Jesse's three eldest sons had gone to battle with Saul. Their names were: the firstborn Amnadab, the second Abinadab, and the third Shammah.
1 Samuel 17:14 But David was the youngest. So the three eldest had followed Saul.
1 Samuel 17:15 David had gone and returned from Saul to tend his father's flock in Bethlehem.
1 Samuel 17:16 The Philistine came forward morning and evening. And he stood there for forty days, challenging them daily.
1 Samuel 17:17 Now Jesse said to his son David: "Take this ephah of parched grain for your brothers, and these ten loaves of bread. And hurry to the camp, to your brothers."
1 Samuel 17:18 "And these ten cheeses you shall bring to the commander (tribune). And visit your brothers, see how they are doing, and bring back word from them."
1 Samuel 17:19 Now Saul, and his men, and all the men of Israel, were in the Valley of Terebinth, engaged in war against the Philistines.
1 Samuel 17:20 So David rose early in the morning, leaving the flock with a keeper for his father. And taking the provisions, he went as Jesse had commanded him. He arrived at the camp just as the army was going out to the battle line and shouting the war cry.
1 Samuel 17:21 And Israel and the Philistines had drawn up their battle lines, arrayed line against line.
1 Samuel 17:22 David left the things he had brought in the care of the baggage keeper. He ran to the battle line and asked his brothers how they were doing.
