1 Samuel 17:23 While he was still speaking, behold, that mighty warrior named Goliath, the Philistine from Gath, was coming up from the Philistine camp. And he spoke according to his previous words, and David heard him.
1 Samuel 17:24 Now all the men of Israel, when they saw the man, fled from his presence and were greatly afraid.
1 Samuel 17:25 And everyone said to his neighbor: "Have you seen this man who has come up? He has certainly come up to defy Israel. The man who strikes him down will be greatly enriched by the king, and the king will give him his daughter, and he will make his father's house free from tribute in Israel."
1 Samuel 17:26 And David said to the men who stood by him, saying: "Who is this uncircumcised Philistine, who has defied the armies of the living God? And what will be the reward for the man who strikes him down and removes this disgrace from Israel?"
1 Samuel 17:27 And the people repeated to him the former words, saying: "These things will be given to the man who strikes him down."
1 Samuel 17:28 Now Amnadab, his eldest brother, heard him speaking to the others. And he became angry with David, and he said: "Why have you come down here? And to whom have you left those few sheep in the wilderness? I know your pride and the wickedness of your heart, because you have come down only to see the battle."
1 Samuel 17:29 And David said: "What have I done now? Was it not just a question?"
1 Samuel 17:30 And he turned away from Amnadab and spoke to another man with the same question as before. And the people gave him the same answer as before.
1 Samuel 17:31 Now the words which David spoke were heard. And they were reported in the presence of Saul. And when Saul heard, he sent for him.
1 Samuel 17:32 And David said to Saul: "Let no one's heart fail because of this. I, your servant, will go and fight against this Philistine."
1 Samuel 17:33 And Saul said to David: "You are not able to stand against this Philistine, nor to fight against him. For you are but a boy, and he has been a warrior from his youth."
1 Samuel 17:34 And David said to Saul: "Your servant was tending his father's flock as a shepherd. And when a lion or a bear came and carried off a ram from the middle of the flock,"
1 Samuel 17:35 "I would pursue it and strike it down, and rescue the ram from its mouth. And if it rose up against me, I would seize its jaw, and choke it, and kill it."
1 Samuel 17:36 "Indeed, your servant has killed both a lion and a bear. Therefore, this uncircumcised Philistine I will destroy just like one of them, because he has defied the armies of the living God."
1 Samuel 17:37 And David added: "The Lord, who rescued me from the paw of the lion and from the paw of the bear, He himself will rescue me from the hand of this Philistine." And Saul said to David: "Go, and may the Lord be with you."
1 Samuel 17:38 And Saul clothed David with his own garments. And he put a bronze helmet on his head, and he clothed him with a coat of mail.
1 Samuel 17:39 And David girded his sword over his garments. He began to try walking, for he was not accustomed to it. And David said to Saul: "I cannot go with these, for I am not accustomed to them." And he took them off.
1 Samuel 17:40 And he took his staff, which he always held in his hands. And he chose for himself five smooth stones from the stream. And he put them in his shepherd's bag which he had with him. And he held his sling in his hand, and he went forward against the Philistine.
1 Samuel 17:1 Now the Philistines gathered their armies for war. They assembled in Socco of Judah, setting up their camp between Socco and Azeca, in a place called Ephes Dammim.
1 Samuel 17:2 Saul and the men of Israel also gathered. They came to the Valley of Terebinth and arranged their battle lines, preparing to fight against the Philistines.
1 Samuel 17:3 The Philistines stood on a mountain on one side, and the Israelites stood on a mountain on the other side, with a valley separating them.
1 Samuel 17:4 Then a special champion warrior came out of the Philistine camp. His name was Goliath, and he was from the city of Gath. He was an enormous man, measuring six cubits and a palm in height—a massive giant.
1 Samuel 17:5 He had a bronze helmet on his head, and he wore a coat of scale-armor made of bronze, which weighed five thousand shekels of bronze.
1 Samuel 17:6 He wore bronze greaves on his legs, and a bronze buckler shield was on his shoulders.
1 Samuel 17:7 The shaft of his spear was like a weaver’s beam, and the iron head of his spear weighed six hundred shekels of iron. His shield-bearer walked ahead of him.
1 Samuel 17:8 Goliath stood and shouted to the Israelite battle lines, saying, “Why have you come out to prepare for battle? Am I not a Philistine, and are you not servants of Saul? Choose a man from among yourselves to come down and fight me in single combat.”
1 Samuel 17:9 He continued, “If he can fight against me and defeat me, then we will be your servants. But if I overcome him and defeat him, then you will be our servants and serve us.”
1 Samuel 17:10 The Philistine also added, “I have openly defied the Israelite armies today! Give me a man, and let us fight each other!”
1 Samuel 17:11 When Saul and all Israel heard these words from the Philistine, they were terrified, and they greatly feared him.
1 Samuel 17:12 Now David was the son of an Ephrathite man from Bethlehem in Judah, whose name was Jesse. Jesse had eight sons, and he himself was an old man, advanced in years among men.
1 Samuel 17:13 Jesse’s three oldest sons had gone with Saul to the battle. Their names were Eliab, the firstborn; Abinadab, the second; and Shamma, the third.
1 Samuel 17:14 David was the youngest. So while the three oldest sons followed Saul to battle,
1 Samuel 17:15 David had left the military service and returned from Saul’s camp to shepherd his father’s flock in Bethlehem.
1 Samuel 17:16 The Philistine champion, Goliath, would come forward every morning and evening. He took his stand and issued his challenge for forty days.
1 Samuel 17:17 Then Jesse said to his son David, “Take this ephah of roasted grain and these ten loaves of bread for your brothers. Hurry and bring them to your brothers in the camp.”
1 Samuel 17:18 He continued, “Also, take these ten cheeses to the captain. See how your brothers are doing, and bring back a report of their welfare and what is happening there.”
1 Samuel 17:19 Now Saul, and Jesse's sons, and all the men of Israel, were in the Valley of Terebinth, fighting against the Philistines.
1 Samuel 17:20 So David got up early in the morning. He left the flock with a keeper and, laden with supplies, went as Jesse had commanded him. He came to the camp, just as the army was going out to the battle line and shouting the battle cry.
1 Samuel 17:21 Both Israel and the Philistines had drawn up their battle lines, arrayed against each other.
1 Samuel 17:22 David left his baggage, which was his responsibility, with the keeper of the supplies. He then ran to the battle lines and asked his brothers if everything was well with them.
1 Samuel 17:23 While he was still speaking with them, the champion warrior appeared. It was Goliath by name, the Philistine from Gath, emerging from the Philistine battle line. He spoke the very same defiant words as before, and David heard them.
1 Samuel 17:24 All the Israelites who saw the man fled from his presence, fearing him greatly.
1 Samuel 17:25 And each one said to his neighbor, “Have you seen this man who has come up? He has come up to defy Israel. The king has promised to greatly enrich the man who defeats him, give him his daughter in marriage, and make his father’s house exempt from taxes in Israel.”
1 Samuel 17:26 David then said to the men standing with him, “Who is this uncircumcised Philistine who dares to defy the armies of the living God?”
1 Samuel 17:27 The people repeated the same words to him, saying, “This is what the king will do for the man who defeats him.”
1 Samuel 17:28 Now Eliab, his oldest brother, heard him speaking to the others. Eliab’s anger burned against David, and he said, “Why have you come down here? And with whom have you left those few sheep in the wilderness? I know your pride and the evil intention of your heart, for you have come down only to see the battle!”
1 Samuel 17:29 David replied, “What have I done now? Was it not just a question?”
1 Samuel 17:30 He turned away from Eliab and asked another man. He spoke according to the same question, and the people answered him as they had before.
1 Samuel 17:31 When David’s words were heard, they were reported to Saul. And when Saul heard about them, he sent for David.
1 Samuel 17:32 David said to Saul, “Let no man’s courage fail because of this giant. I, your servant, will go and fight against this Philistine.”
1 Samuel 17:33 Saul said to David, “You are not strong enough to stand against this Philistine or fight against him. You are just a youth, while he has been a warrior since his adolescence.”
1 Samuel 17:34 David replied to Saul, “I was my father’s shepherd of the flock. When a lion or a bear came and snatched a lamb from the middle of the flock,
1 Samuel 17:35 I pursued it, attacked it, and rescued the lamb from its mouth. If it rose up against me, I would grab its jaw, strike it, and kill it.
1 Samuel 17:36 Indeed, I have killed both a lion and a bear. This uncircumcised Philistine will be like one of them! Let him go and take away the defiance from Israel, because who is this uncircumcised man who dares to curse the army of the living God?”
1 Samuel 17:37 David also added, “The Lord, who rescued me from the paw of the lion and from the paw of the bear, He Himself will rescue me from the hand of this Philistine.” And Saul said to David, “Go, and may the Lord be with you.”
1 Samuel 17:38 Then Saul dressed David in his own armor. He placed a bronze helmet on David’s head and clothed him with a coat of mail.
1 Samuel 17:39 David buckled Saul’s sword over his own clothes and tried to walk, but he found he could not, because he had never worn such things before. So David said to Saul, “I cannot walk in these, for I am not accustomed to them.” And he took them off.
1 Samuel 17:40 Then he took his staff, which he always carried in his hand. He chose five smooth stones from the stream bed and put them in his shepherd’s bag, which he had with him, and his sling was in his hand. And so he went forward against the Philistine.
1 Samuel 18:1 It came to pass that when David finished speaking with Saul, Jonathan’s soul was bound to David’s soul, and Jonathan loved him as his own soul.
1 Samuel 18:2 Saul took David into his service that day and no longer allowed him to return to his father’s house.
1 Samuel 18:3 So Jonathan and David made a covenant of friendship, for Jonathan loved David as his own soul.
1 Samuel 18:4 And Jonathan took off the cloak he was wearing and gave it to David, along with his other garments, even his sword, bow, and belt.
1 Samuel 18:5 Moreover, David went out wherever Saul sent him, and he acted wisely. So Saul placed him over the men of war, and he was accepted in the eyes of all the people, and in the eyes of Saul’s servants.
1 Samuel 18:6 When David returned after killing the Philistine, the women came out from all the cities of Israel, singing in choruses and rejoicing to meet King Saul, with tambourines and musical instruments.
1 Samuel 18:7 And the women sang playfully, saying: 'Saul has struck down a thousand, and David ten thousand!'
1 Samuel 18:8 But Saul was exceedingly angry, and this saying displeased him. And he said: 'They have given David ten thousand, and to me they have given only a thousand. What more is left for him to have, except the kingdom itself?'
1 Samuel 18:9 Therefore, Saul suspected David from that day forward.
1 Samuel 18:10 But on the next day, an evil spirit from the Lord seized Saul, and he raved inside his house. David, meanwhile, played the lyre with his hand as he did every day, and a spear was in Saul’s hand.
1 Samuel 18:11 And Saul threw the spear, thinking and saying: 'I will pin David to the wall!' But David dodged away from him twice.
1 Samuel 18:12 And Saul feared David, because the Lord was with him, and had departed from Saul.
1 Samuel 18:13 Therefore Saul removed him from his presence and made him a tribune and commander over a thousand men. And David went out and came in before the people.
1 Samuel 18:14 In all his ways, David conducted himself wisely, and the Lord was with him.
1 Samuel 18:15 So Saul saw that David conducted himself very wisely, and he began to fear him greatly.
1 Samuel 18:16 But all Israel and Judah loved David, because he went out and came in before them.
1 Samuel 18:17 Then Saul said to David: 'Behold, my elder daughter Merob, I will give her to you as a wife. Only be a strong man and fight the Lord’s battles.' Saul, however, was thinking, saying: 'Let not my hand be against him, but let the hand of the Philistines be against him.'
1 Samuel 18:18 And David said to Saul: 'Who am I? Or what is my life? Or what is my father’s family in Israel, that I should become the king’s son-in-law?'
1 Samuel 18:19 But it came to pass that at the time when Merob, Saul’s daughter, should have been given to David, she was instead given to Hadriel the Meholathite as his wife.
1 Samuel 18:20 Now Michol, Saul’s other daughter, loved David. And it was reported to Saul, and it pleased him.
1 Samuel 18:21 And Saul said: 'I will give her to him, that she may be a snare to him, and that the hand of the Philistines may be against him.' So Saul said to David: 'You shall be my son-in-law a second time!'
1 Samuel 18:22 And Saul commanded his servants: 'Speak to David in secret, saying: "Behold, the king loves you, and all his servants love you. Now therefore, you can become the king’s son-in-law!"'
1 Samuel 18:23 And Saul’s servants spoke these words in David’s ears. And David said: 'Does it seem a small thing to you to be the king’s son-in-law? Yet I am a poor and humble man.'
1 Samuel 18:24 And Saul’s servants reported to him, saying: 'This is what David has said.'
1 Samuel 18:25 And Saul said: 'Speak thus to David: "The king desires no dowry except one hundred foreskins of the Philistines, so that there may be vengeance against the king’s enemies."' But Saul was thinking to deliver David into the hands of the Philistines.
1 Samuel 18:26 When his servants reported to David the words that Saul had spoken, the offer pleased David, so that he might become the king’s son-in-law. And the days appointed for the dowry had not yet passed.
1 Samuel 18:27 So David arose and went with his men, and he struck down two hundred men from the Philistines. And he brought their foreskins and counted them out to the king, so that he might become the king’s son-in-law. Therefore, Saul gave him Michol his daughter as a wife.
1 Samuel 18:28 And Saul saw and understood that the Lord was with David, and that Michol, Saul’s daughter, truly loved him.
1 Samuel 18:29 And Saul increased his fear of David even more. And Saul became an enemy of David all his days.
1 Samuel 18:30 And the princes of the Philistines went out to battle. And as often as they went out, David conducted himself more wisely than all of Saul’s servants, and his name became exceedingly famous.
1 Samuel 19:1 Now King Saul spoke to his son Jonathan and to all his personal attendants, giving them orders to kill David.
1 Samuel 19:2 But Jonathan, King Saul’s son, truly loved David. So Jonathan told David, saying, 'My father Saul is trying to kill you. So be careful tomorrow morning. You must stay hidden and conceal yourself.
1 Samuel 19:3 I will go out and stand with my father in the field where you are hiding. I will speak to my father about you, and whatever I find out, I will tell you.'
1 Samuel 19:4 So Jonathan spoke good things about David to his father Saul. He said to the king, 'Let not the king sin against his servant David, because he has not sinned against you. In fact, his actions have been very beneficial to you.
1 Samuel 19:5 He risked his own life and struck down the Philistine giant, Goliath. Through him, the Lord granted a great victory to all Israel. You saw it and rejoiced. Why then would you sin by shedding innocent blood, by killing David, who is without fault?'
1 Samuel 19:6 When Saul heard Jonathan’s words, he swore an oath, saying, 'As the Lord lives, David will not be killed.'
1 Samuel 19:7 So Jonathan called David and told him all these things. Then Jonathan brought David to Saul, and David was in Saul’s presence again, just as he had been before, for the past several days.
1 Samuel 19:8 Then war broke out again. David went out and fought against the Philistines. He struck them with a great defeat, and they fled from his presence.
1 Samuel 19:9 But an evil spirit from the Lord came upon Saul while he was sitting in his house with his spear ready in his hand. David was playing music with his hand (the lyre).
1 Samuel 19:10 Saul tried to pin David to the wall with the spear. But David dodged Saul, and the spear struck the wall. David fled and escaped that very night.
1 Samuel 19:11 Saul sent his executioners to David’s house to keep watch over him and kill him in the morning. But David’s wife Michol told him, saying, 'Unless you save yourself tonight, tomorrow morning you will die.'
1 Samuel 19:12 So Michol let David down through a window. He left immediately, fled, and escaped.
1 Samuel 19:13 Now Michol took a household idol (a teraphim), placed it on the bed, put goat’s hair at its head, and covered it with a cloak.
1 Samuel 19:14 When Saul sent his messengers to seize David, they were told, 'He is sick.'
1 Samuel 19:15 Saul sent the messengers again to see David, saying, 'Bring him up to me on the bed, so that he may be killed.'
1 Samuel 19:16 When the messengers came in, behold, there was the idol on the bed, with the goat’s hair at its head.
1 Samuel 19:17 Then Saul said to Michol, 'Why have you deceived me in this way, and let my enemy escape?' Michol answered Saul, 'Because he himself threatened me, saying: 'Let me go, or I will kill you.''
1 Samuel 19:18 So David fled and was saved. He came to Samuel in Ramatha and told him everything that Saul had done to him. Then he and Samuel went and stayed in Najoth.
1 Samuel 19:19 It was reported to Saul, saying, 'Behold, David is in Najoth in Ramatha.'
1 Samuel 19:20 So Saul sent his executioners to seize David. When they saw the company of prophets prophesying, with Samuel standing as their leader, the Spirit of God came upon Saul’s executioners as well, and they too began to prophesy.
1 Samuel 19:21 When this was reported to Saul, he sent other messengers, and they also began to prophesy. Even more angered, Saul sent a third group of messengers, and they too began to prophesy.
1 Samuel 19:22 So Saul himself went to Ramatha and came as far as the great well that is in Socho. He asked, saying, 'Where are Samuel and David?' And he was told, 'Behold, they are in Najoth in Ramatha.'
1 Samuel 19:23 And as he went on to Najoth in Ramatha, the Spirit of God came upon him too, and he walked on, prophesying, until he arrived in Najoth in Ramatha.
1 Samuel 19:24 He even stripped off his own garments and prophesied with the others before Samuel. He lay there unclothed for that entire day and night. That is why the proverb came about: 'Is Saul also among the prophets?'
1 Samuel 19:2 But Jonathan, King Saul’s son, loved David very much. So Jonathan secretly sent word to David, saying: “My father, King Saul, is seeking to kill you. Therefore, I beg you, be on your guard tomorrow morning. You must go into hiding, and remain concealed.”
1 Samuel 19:3 “And I myself will go out and stand beside my father in the open field, wherever he may happen to be. I will speak to my father about you, and whatever I discover, I will report back to you immediately.”
1 Samuel 19:4 So Jonathan spoke well of David to his father, King Saul. He pleaded with him, saying: “Let not the king commit a sin against his own faithful servant David. For David has committed no sin against you, and indeed, his deeds have been very beneficial to you.”
1 Samuel 19:5 “David risked his very life and went into battle, striking down the Philistine giant. By his hand, the Lord brought about a great victory for all of Israel. You saw it then, and you greatly rejoiced. Why then would you sin against innocent blood, and kill David, who is truly without fault?”
1 Samuel 19:6 King Saul listened to the earnest plea of Jonathan. And so King Saul swore an oath, declaring: “As the Lord lives, David shall not be put to death.”
1 Samuel 19:7 Then Jonathan called David, and told him all of these words. And Jonathan brought David to King Saul, and David remained in his presence, serving him just as he had done on previous days.
1 Samuel 19:8 Then war broke out yet again. So David went out and fought against the Philistines, striking them down with such a devastating blow that they fled in terror from his presence.
1 Samuel 19:9 And then, again, an evil spirit from the Lord troubled King Saul. He was sitting in his house with his spear in his hand, while David was playing his lyre and singing hymns to soothe him.
1 Samuel 19:10 King Saul sought to pin David to the wall with his spear. But David quickly moved away from Saul’s presence, and Saul’s spear struck the wall instead. David immediately fled, and he was saved from death that very night.
1 Samuel 19:11 So King Saul sent his messengers to David’s house to keep watch over him through the night, intending to kill him in the morning. David’s wife, Michal, secretly informed him, saying: “Unless you make your escape this very night, you will surely be dead by tomorrow.”
1 Samuel 19:12 So Michal helped David escape by letting him down through a window. He immediately departed, fled for his life, and managed to escape.
1 Samuel 19:13 Michal then took a household idol, a *teraphim*, and placed it on the bed. She put a network of goat hair at its head to mimic human hair, and then covered the idol with a garment to make it look like a sleeping person.
1 Samuel 19:14 When King Saul sent messengers to seize David, they were given the answer: “He is sick in bed.”
1 Samuel 19:15 King Saul sent the messengers back to see David, commanding: “Bring him here to me, even in his bed, so that I may put him to death myself.”
1 Samuel 19:16 But when the messengers arrived, behold, they found only the household idol lying on the bed, with the network of goat hair at its head.
1 Samuel 19:17 King Saul then confronted Michal, saying: “Why have you so shamelessly deceived me and allowed my enemy to escape?” Michal answered Saul: “Because he threatened me directly, saying: ‘Let me go, or else I will kill you.’”
1 Samuel 19:18 In the meantime, David, having fled for his life, was saved. He came to the prophet Samuel in Ramath, and told him everything that King Saul had done to him. Then David and Samuel went to Najoth in Ramath and stayed there together.
1 Samuel 19:19 And it was reported to King Saul, saying: “Behold, David is in Najoth in Ramath.”
1 Samuel 19:20 So King Saul sent messengers to seize David. But when they arrived and saw the company of prophets engaged in prophetic utterance, with Samuel standing over them as their leader, the Spirit of the Lord also came upon King Saul’s messengers, and they too began to prophesy.
1 Samuel 19:21 But when this was reported to King Saul, he sent yet another group of messengers. They also began to prophesy when they arrived. And a third time King Saul sent messengers, and they too began to prophesy. At this, King Saul became extremely angry, and he himself departed for Ramath.
1 Samuel 19:22 And he came as far as the great well that is in Socho. He then inquired, asking: “In what place are Samuel and David?” And one of the men there told him: “Behold, they are in Najoth, in Ramath.”
1 Samuel 19:23 So King Saul went there to Najoth in Ramath. And the Spirit of the Lord also came upon him. As he walked along the way, he continued prophesying until he reached Najoth in Ramath.
1 Samuel 19:24 And he too stripped himself of his royal garments, and prophesied before Samuel. He lay there naked, prostrate on the ground, for that entire day and all through the night. This is why the proverb came into being: “Is Saul also counted among the prophets?”
1 Samuel 20:1 But David fled from Naioth, which is in Ramah. He then came before Jonathan and asked: "What have I done? What is my sin, and what is my iniquity against your father, that he is seeking my very life?"
1 Samuel 20:2 Jonathan answered him: "Far be it from you to think that! You shall not die. For my father does nothing, whether great or small, without first revealing it to me. Why then would my father hide this matter from me? It is not as you think."
1 Samuel 20:3 But David swore again and said: "Your father knows very well that I have found favor in your eyes. He said to himself, 'Jonathan must not know this, lest he be grieved.' Truly, as the Lord lives, and as your soul lives, there is only a step between me and death."
1 Samuel 20:4 Jonathan then said to David: "Whatever your soul desires, I will do for you."
1 Samuel 20:5 David said to Jonathan: "Behold, tomorrow is the new moon festival, and I cannot eat with the king. I must be absent."
1 Samuel 20:6 "Therefore, let me go, so that I may hide in the field until the evening of the third day."
1 Samuel 20:7 "If your father asks for me, you shall answer him: 'David earnestly requested me to let him go to Bethlehem, his own city, because there is a solemn sacrifice there for all his relatives.'"
1 Samuel 20:8 "If he says, 'It is well,' then your servant is safe. But if he becomes angry, know for certain that his evil intent is fixed."
1 Samuel 20:9 "Therefore, deal mercifully with your servant, for you have brought me, your servant, into a covenant of the Lord with you. If there is any iniquity in me, kill me yourself; do not bring me to your father."
1 Samuel 20:10 Jonathan said to him: "Far be it from you to think that! For if I should certainly know that evil has been determined by my father to come upon you, I myself will tell you."
1 Samuel 20:11 David said to Jonathan: "Who will inform me if your father answers you harshly?"
1 Samuel 20:12 Jonathan said to David: "Come, let us go out into the field." So both of them went out into the field.
1 Samuel 20:13 Then Jonathan said to David: "May the Lord, the God of Israel, be a witness! I will diligently question my father. If there is anything good concerning David, I will surely send word to you and reveal it to you without delay."
1 Samuel 20:14 "This I say: may you never perish." —meaning, may your life and lineage be preserved.
1 Samuel 20:15 "Or if my house perishes, when the Lord has brought evil upon the earth against all the enemies of David,"
1 Samuel 20:16 "may Jonathan himself be cast off from your sight forever. But you also shall show the Lord's mercy to your servant forever, and you shall not kill me."
1 Samuel 20:17 Jonathan therefore made David swear again, because he loved him; for he loved him as his own soul.
1 Samuel 20:18 Jonathan also said to him: "Tomorrow is the new moon festival, and you will be missed."
1 Samuel 20:19 "Indeed, your seat will be empty. On the third day, you must hurry and come to the place where you hid yourself on the day of the appointed meeting, and you will sit by the stone whose name is Ezel."
1 Samuel 20:20 "And I will shoot three arrows beside it, as if I were shooting at a target."
1 Samuel 20:21 "Behold, I will send a boy, saying to him, 'Go, fetch me the arrows.' If I say to the boy, 'Behold, the arrows are within reach of you, pick them up,' then you come to me. For there is peace for you, and no harm is intended, as the Lord lives."
1 Samuel 20:22 "But if I speak thus to the boy: 'Behold, the arrows are beyond you,' then go quickly, because the Lord has sent you away."
1 Samuel 20:23 "And concerning this word, which we have spoken, you and I, may the Lord be between me and you forever."
1 Samuel 20:24 So David hid himself in the field. When the new moon festival day came, the king sat down to eat bread.
1 Samuel 20:25 The king sat in his customary place, which was by the wall. Jonathan rose, and Abner sat at Saul's side, but David's place appeared empty.
1 Samuel 20:26 And Saul said nothing on that day, because he supposed that something had happened by chance, that perhaps David was not ritually clean nor purified.
1 Samuel 20:27 But when the second day after the new moon festival dawned, David was still absent from the king's table. Saul then said to Jonathan, his son: "Why has the son of Jesse not come to the meal, neither yesterday nor today?"
1 Samuel 20:28 Jonathan answered Saul: "David earnestly requested me to let him go to Bethlehem."
1 Samuel 20:29 "He said: 'Let me go, because there is a family sacrifice in the city, and my brother has commanded me to be there. So now, if I have found favor in your eyes, I will go quickly and see my brothers.' For this reason, he has not come to the king's table."
1 Samuel 20:30 Then Saul became angry with Jonathan and said to him: "You son of a perverse and rebellious woman, do I not know that you love the son of Jesse to your own shame and to the shame and disgrace of your mother?"
1 Samuel 20:31 "For as long as the son of Jesse lives upon the earth, neither you nor your kingdom will be established. Now, therefore, send and bring him to me, for he is a son deserving of death."
1 Samuel 20:32 Jonathan answered Saul, his father, and said: "Why should he die? What has he done?"
1 Samuel 20:33 Then Saul raised his spear against Jonathan to strike him. And Jonathan understood that his father was determined to kill David.
1 Samuel 20:34 So Jonathan rose from the table in furious anger and did not eat bread on the second day of the new moon festival meal. For he was grieved for David, because his father had disgraced him.
1 Samuel 20:35 When morning dawned, Jonathan came into the field according to David's word, and a small boy was with him.
1 Samuel 20:36 He said to his boy: "Go, fetch me the arrows that I shoot." As the boy ran, Jonathan shot an arrow beyond the boy.
1 Samuel 20:37 So the boy came to the place of the arrow that Jonathan had shot. And Jonathan cried out after the boy's back, saying: "Behold, the arrow is beyond you!"
1 Samuel 20:38 And Jonathan cried out after the boy's back, saying: "Hurry quickly, do not stand still!" So the boy of Jonathan gathered the arrows and brought them to his master.
1 Samuel 20:39 However, the boy knew absolutely nothing of the matter; only Jonathan and David understood the secret plan.
1 Samuel 20:40 Then Jonathan gave his weapons to the boy and said to him: "Go, carry them into the city."
1 Samuel 21:1 David then arrived in Nob, where he met Ahimelech the priest. Ahimelech was surprised to see David and he asked him: 'Why are you alone? Is no one else with you?'
1 Samuel 21:2 David responded to Ahimelech the priest, saying: 'The king has given me a secret order, and he said to me: “No one is to know about the mission I am on, or what I commanded you.” So I sent my young men to a certain place and told them to hide there.'
1 Samuel 21:3 Now, if you have any provisions on hand, please give me something. Even five loaves of bread would be enough, or whatever you can find.
1 Samuel 21:4 The priest answered David, saying: 'I don’t have any ordinary bread here. I only have the consecrated bread—the Bread of the Presence. You may have it only if your young men are ritually pure, especially if they have abstained from contact with women.'
1 Samuel 21:5 David answered the priest, saying: 'Indeed, as for women, we have kept ourselves from them since yesterday and the day before, ever since we departed. My young men are ritually clean. Furthermore, even if this particular journey made us unclean, it will be made holy today by our commitment to holiness.'
1 Samuel 21:6 So Achimelech gave him the Bread of the Presence, because there was no other bread there except for that Bread of the Presence, which had been removed from before the Lord so that fresh, hot bread could be put in its place.
1 Samuel 21:7 Now, one of Saul’s servants happened to be there that day, confined in the tabernacle of the Lord. His name was Doëg the Idumaean, and he was in charge of Saul’s many camels.
1 Samuel 21:8 David then said to Ahimelech: 'Do you have a spear or a sword here on hand? For I did not bring my sword or my weapons with me, because the king’s mission required haste.'
1 Samuel 21:9 The priest replied: 'The sword of Goliath the Philistine, whom you killed in the Valley of Elah, is here. It is wrapped in a cloth behind the ephod. If you want to take it, take it, for there is no other sword here except this one.' David then exclaimed: 'There is none like it! Give it to me!'
1 Samuel 21:10 So David rose and fled that day from Saul. He went to King Achis of Gath.
1 Samuel 21:11 King Achis’s servants said to him: 'Isn’t this David, the king of his land? Isn’t he the one people sang about in their dances, saying: 'Saul has struck down a thousand, and David ten thousand!''
1 Samuel 21:12 David took these words to heart and became very afraid of King Achis of Gath.
1 Samuel 21:13 So he changed his behavior in front of them and pretended to be mad while in their hands. He scratched on the doors of the city gate, and his saliva ran down his beard.
1 Samuel 21:14 King Achis then said to his servants: 'Look, you can see this man is insane. Why have you brought him to me?'
1 Samuel 21:15 'Do we not have enough madmen of our own that you should bring this one to me? Is this fellow to enter my house?'
1 Samuel 21:16 David therefore departed from there and fled to the cave of Adullam. When his brothers and all his father’s household heard about it, they went down to him there.
1 Samuel 21:17 And everyone who was in distress, or overwhelmed by debt, or bitter in spirit, gathered to him. He became their leader, and about four hundred men were with him.
1 Samuel 21:18 David then went from there to Mizpah of Moab and said to the king of Moab: 'Please let my father and mother stay with you until I know what God will do for me.'
1 Samuel 21:19 And he left them with the king of Moab, and they stayed with him for all the days that David was in the stronghold.
1 Samuel 21:20 Then Gad the prophet said to David: 'Do not stay in the stronghold. Depart and go into the land of Judah.' So David departed and went to the forest of Hereth.
1 Samuel 21:21 Saul heard that David and the men with him had been discovered. Saul himself was then staying in Gibeah, sitting under the tamarisk tree on the high place in Ramah, with his spear in his hand, and all his servants were standing around him.
1 Samuel 21:22 Saul then said to all his servants who stood around him: 'Listen now, you sons of Benjamin! Will the son of Jesse give all of you fields and vineyards? Will he make all of you commanders of a thousand and commanders of a hundred?'
1 Samuel 21:23 'For all of you have conspired against me, and no one tells me why my son has made a covenant with the son of Jesse. And there is no one among you who pities me or informs me that my son has stirred up my servant against me, to lie in wait for me, as is clear today.'
1 Samuel 21:24 But Doëg the Idumaean, who was standing with Saul’s servants, answered and said: 'I saw the son of Jesse coming to Nob, to Ahimelech, the son of Ahitub the priest.'
1 Samuel 21:25 'He consulted the Lord for him, and gave him bread, and also gave him the sword of Goliath the Philistine.'
1 Samuel 21:26 So the king sent for Ahimelech the priest, the son of Ahitub, and for all the house of his father, the priests who were in Nob. They all came to the king.
1 Samuel 21:27 Saul then said: 'Listen, son of Ahitub!' He answered: 'Here I am, my lord.'
1 Samuel 21:28 And Saul said to him: 'Why have you conspired against me, you and the son of Jesse? You gave him bread and a sword, and you consulted God for him, so that he would rise up against me as an ambush, even to this very day.'
1 Samuel 21:29 Ahimelech answered the king, saying: 'And who among all your servants is as faithful as David, who is also the king’s son-in-law? He carries out your commands and is honored in your house.'
1 Samuel 21:30 'Did I only begin to consult God for him today? Far be it from me! Let not the king suspect anything against his servant, or against all the house of my father. For your servant knew nothing at all of this, neither more nor less.'
1 Samuel 21:31 And the king said: 'You shall surely die, Ahimelech, you and all the house of your father!'
1 Samuel 21:32 The king then said to the guards standing around him: 'Go, and kill the priests of the Lord! Because their hand is with David, and knowing that he had fled, they did not inform me.' But the king’s servants were unwilling to lay their hands on the priests of the Lord.
1 Samuel 21:33 Then the king said to Doëg: 'You turn and kill the priests!' And Doëg the Idumaean turned and himself killed the priests. He slaughtered on that day eighty-five men who wore the linen ephod.
1 Samuel 21:34 And Nob, the city of the priests, he struck with the edge of the sword—men and women, children and infants, oxen, donkeys, and sheep—all by the edge of the sword.
1 Samuel 21:35 However, one son of Ahimelech, son of Ahitub, whose name was Abiathar, escaped and fled to David.
1 Samuel 21:36 And he reported to David that Saul had killed the priests of the Lord.
1 Samuel 21:37 And David said to Abiathar: 'I knew on that day, when Doëg the Idumaean was there, that he would surely report it to Saul. I am responsible for the loss of all the lives in your father’s house.'
1 Samuel 21:38 'Stay with me, do not be afraid. For wherever my life goes, your life will go with me.'
1 Samuel 21:39 Then David was informed, saying: 'Look, the Philistines are fighting against Keilah, and they are plundering the threshing floors!'
1 Samuel 21:40 So David consulted the Lord, saying: 'Shall I go and strike down these Philistines?' And the Lord said to David: 'Go, strike down the Philistines, and save Keilah.'
1 Samuel 21:1 David therefore came to Nob to see Achimelech, the high priest. Achimelech was startled when David arrived, and he said to him, 'Why are you all by yourself? Why is there no one with you?'
1 Samuel 21:2 David said to Achimelech the high priest, 'The king has given me a secret mission and told me: 'No one is to know about the mission I have sent you on, nor the instructions I have given you.' I have also arranged for my young men to meet me at a specified location.'
1 Samuel 21:3 Now then, if you have any food available, give me at least five loaves of bread, or whatever else you can find.
1 Samuel 21:4 The priest answered David, saying, 'I don't have any ordinary bread available, but only the holy showbread, which is consecrated to God. Are the young men pure, especially from having been with women?'
1 Samuel 21:5 David answered the high priest, saying, 'Indeed, as for women, we have kept ourselves from them since we began our journey yesterday and the day before. The young men's bodies have been kept ritually pure. Normally, our journey would be defiled, but even our mission will be considered holy today because of the sacred nature of our work, as long as our bodies remain pure.'
1 Samuel 21:6 So the high priest gave David the holy bread because there was no other bread available there. It was only the showbread, which had been taken from before the Lord's presence in the tabernacle, so that fresh, hot bread could be put in its place.
1 Samuel 21:7 Now, on that very day, one of Saul's servants was present there inside the tabernacle of the Lord. His name was Doëg the Edomite, and he was the chief over Saul's many herdsmen.
1 Samuel 21:8 Then David said to Achimelech, 'Do you have a spear or a sword here that I can take? I didn't bring my own sword or my weapons with me, because the king's mission was too urgent for any delays.'
1 Samuel 21:9 The high priest replied, 'Look, the sword of Goliath the Philistine, whom you killed in the Valley of Elah, is here. It is wrapped in a cloth behind the priestly ephod. If you want to take it, then take it, for there is no other sword here. Only that one.' David then exclaimed, 'There is no other sword like it! Give it to me!'
1 Samuel 21:10 So David then got up and fled that very day from King Saul's presence. He went to Achish, who was the king of Gath.
1 Samuel 21:11 But the servants of King Achish said to him, 'Is this not David, who is like a king in his own land? Was it not to this very man that they sang in the dances, saying: 'Saul has struck down his thousands, but David his ten thousands?'
1 Samuel 21:12 David took these words seriously and stored them in his heart, and he became very afraid of King Achish of Gath.
1 Samuel 21:13 So David changed his behavior in front of them and feigned madness while they held him. He began to scribble on the city gate doors, and his saliva ran down his beard.
1 Samuel 21:14 Achish then said to his servants, 'Look, you can see the man is mad! Why have you brought him to me?'
1 Samuel 21:15 'Do I not have enough madmen of my own that you would bring this man here to act like a lunatic in front of me? Should such a man be allowed into my royal residence?'
1 Samuel 21:16 So David fled from Gath and came to the cave of Adullam.
1 Samuel 22:1 So David fled from Gath and took refuge in the cave of Adullam. When his brothers and all of his father's household heard of his hiding place, they went down to him there.
1 Samuel 22:2 Everyone who was in a difficult situation, burdened by debt, or bitter in spirit gathered to him. And David became their leader. About four hundred men were with him.
1 Samuel 22:3 From there, David went to Mizpah in Moab. He said to the king of Moab, "Please let my father and my mother stay here with you, until I know what God will do for me" —seeking protection for his parents in his ancestral homeland.
1 Samuel 22:4 So David left them with the king of Moab, and his parents remained there with the king all the time David was in his places of refuge.
1 Samuel 22:5 But the prophet Gad said to David, "Do not remain in this place of refuge. Leave immediately and go into the land of Judah." So David left and went into the forest of Hareth.
1 Samuel 22:6 Saul heard that David and the men with him had been discovered. At that time, Saul was staying in Gibeah, sitting under a prominent tree in the grove near Ramah, with his spear in his hand, and all his servants were standing around him.
1 Samuel 22:7 He said to his servants who stood around him, "Listen now, you sons of Benjamin! Will the son of Jesse—David—give all of you fields and vineyards, and make all of you commanders of thousands and commanders of hundreds?"
1 Samuel 22:8 "You have all conspired against me, and no one informs me that my own son, Jonathan, has made a covenant with the son of Jesse! Is there no one among you who feels for my cause, or who will tell me that my son has stirred up my own servant David against me, inciting him to lie in ambush for me even to this very day?"
1 Samuel 22:9 But Doeg the Edomite, one of Saul's servants who was standing there, answered, "I saw the son of Jesse—David—in Nob with Ahimelech the priest, son of Ahitub."
1 Samuel 22:10 "Ahimelech consulted the Lord on David's behalf, gave him provisions, and also gave him the sword of Goliath the Philistine."
1 Samuel 22:11 So the king sent for Ahimelech the priest, son of Ahitub, and for all his father's household—all the priests who were in Nob. They all came to the king.
1 Samuel 22:12 And Saul said, "Listen, son of Ahitub." Ahimelech responded, "Here I am, my lord."
1 Samuel 22:13 Saul then said to him, "Why have you conspired against me, you and the son of Jesse, David? You gave him bread and a sword, and you consulted God on his behalf, so that he might rise up against me as an ambusher even to this very day!"
1 Samuel 22:14 Ahimelech responded to the king, saying, "Who among all your servants is as faithful as David? He is also the king's son-in-law, obedient to your command, and held in honor in your own household. He is above reproach."
1 Samuel 22:15 "Have I only just today begun to consult the Lord on his behalf? Absolutely not! Let not the king suspect his servant, nor any of my father's household, of any wrongdoing. For I, your servant, knew nothing at all about this matter, neither great nor small."
1 Samuel 22:16 Then the king declared, "You will surely die, Ahimelech—you and all of your father's household."
1 Samuel 22:17 Then the king said to the guards who were standing around him, "Turn and kill the priests of the Lord! Their hands are with David, for they knew he had fled but did not inform me." But the king's servants refused to raise their hands to strike down the priests of the Lord.
1 Samuel 22:18 Then the king said to Doeg, "You turn and attack the priests!" So Doeg the Edomite turned, attacked the priests, and on that day killed eighty-five men who wore the sacred linen ephod.
1 Samuel 22:19 Nob, the city of the priests, was also utterly destroyed by the sword. Doeg put to death men and women, children and infants, oxen, donkeys, and sheep—everything in the city.
1 Samuel 22:20 But one son of Ahimelech, son of Ahitub, escaped. His name was Abiathar, and he fled to David.
1 Samuel 22:21 Abiathar informed David that Saul had murdered the priests of the Lord.
1 Samuel 22:22 David said to Abiathar, "I knew it that day! When Doeg the Edomite was there, I knew he would undoubtedly report everything to Saul. I am responsible for the deaths of everyone in your father's household."
1 Samuel 22:23 "Stay with me; do not be afraid. For whoever seeks my life also seeks your life, and you will be safe here with me."
1 Samuel 22:1 David then left that place, and took refuge in the cave of Adullam. When his brothers and his father's entire household heard about this, they went down to join him there.
1 Samuel 22:2 All those who were in distress gathered around him, all who were burdened by any kind of debt or trouble, and all who felt their lives were bitter; and David became their leader. There were about four hundred men with him.
1 Samuel 22:3 From there, David went to Mizpah in Moab, and he said to the king of Moab: "Please allow my father and my mother to stay with you, until I know what God will do for me."
1 Samuel 22:4 So David left them with the king of Moab, and they stayed with him for all the days that David was in his stronghold.
1 Samuel 22:5 Then Gad the prophet said to David: "Do not remain in this stronghold; depart and go into the land of Judah." So David left and came into the forest of Hereth.
1 Samuel 22:6 Now Saul heard that David had been discovered, along with the men who were with him. At that time, Saul was staying in Gibeah, sitting under a tamarisk tree on a high place in Ramah, with his spear in his hand, and all his servants were standing around him.
1 Samuel 22:7 Saul said to his servants who stood around him: "Listen, I beg you, sons of Jemini! Will the son of Jesse give all of you fields and vineyards, and make all of you commanders of thousands and commanders of hundreds?
1 Samuel 22:8 Why have all of you conspired against me? No one among you reports to me that my son has made a covenant with the son of Jesse. No one among you grieves for me or informs me that my son has incited my servant to ambush me, as he has done even to this very day."
1 Samuel 22:9 Then Doeg the Edomite, who was standing there and was the chief among Saul's servants, answered and said: "I saw the son of Jesse in Nob, with Ahimelech, the son of Ahitub, the high priest.
1 Samuel 22:10 Ahimelech consulted the Lord for him, and also gave him provisions and even the sword of Goliath the Philistine."
1 Samuel 22:11 So the king sent for Ahimelech the priest, the son of Ahitub, and for his father's entire household, the priests who were in Nob. They all came to the king.
1 Samuel 22:12 Saul said: "Listen, son of Ahitub!" And he answered: "I am ready, my lord."
1 Samuel 22:13 Saul said to him: "Why have you conspired against me, you and the son of Jesse? You gave him bread and a sword, and you consulted God for him, so that he might rise up against me as an enemy, as an ambusher, even to this day?"
1 Samuel 22:14 Ahimelech answered the king, saying: "And who among all your servants is as faithful as David? He is the king's son-in-law, always ready to obey your command, and honored in your own household!
1 Samuel 22:15 Is this the first time I began consulting God for him? Absolutely not! Let the king not suspect anything against his servant, nor against my father's entire household; for your servant knew nothing about this matter, neither little nor much."
1 Samuel 22:16 And the king said: "You shall surely die, Ahimelech, you and all of your father's household!"
1 Samuel 22:17 Then the king said to his bodyguards, who stood around him: "Turn around and kill the priests of the Lord, because their loyalty is with David; they knew he had fled, yet they did not inform me." But the king's servants refused to raise their hands against the Lord's priests.
1 Samuel 22:18 So the king said to Doeg: "You turn, and fall upon the priests!" And Doeg the Edomite turned, and he attacked the priests, killing on that day eighty-five men who wore the linen ephod, a sacred garment worn by priests.
1 Samuel 22:19 He also struck Nob, the city of the priests, with the edge of the sword, killing men and women, children and nursing infants, as well as oxen, donkeys, and sheep, all by the edge of the sword.
1 Samuel 22:20 However, one son of Ahimelech, the son of Ahitub, escaped. His name was Abiathar, and he fled to David.
1 Samuel 22:21 He reported to David that Saul had killed the Lord's priests.
1 Samuel 22:22 David said to Abiathar: "I knew on that day, when Doeg the Edomite was there, that he would surely report it to Saul. I am responsible for the loss of all the lives of your father's household.
1 Samuel 22:23 Stay with me; do not be afraid. For whoever seeks my life will also seek your life, and with me, you will be safe."
1 Samuel 23:1 Then people brought news to David, saying: "Listen! The Philistines are attacking Keilah, and they are looting the threshing floors."
1 Samuel 23:2 So David consulted the Lord, saying: "Should I go and strike down these Philistines?" And the Lord said to David: "Go, and you will strike down the Philistines, and you will save Keilah."
1 Samuel 23:3 But the men who were with David said to him: "Look, we are afraid even here in Judah. How much more will we be afraid if we go to Keilah and face the armies of the Philistines?"
1 Samuel 23:4 So David again consulted the Lord. And the Lord answered him and said: "Rise up, and go to Keilah, because I will deliver the Philistines into your hand."
1 Samuel 23:5 Therefore David and his men went to Keilah, and he fought against the Philistines, and he drove off their livestock, and he struck them with a great slaughter; and so David saved the inhabitants of Keilah.
1 Samuel 23:6 Now it happened that when Abiathar, the son of Ahimelech, fled to David in Keilah, he was carrying the ephod in his hand.
1 Samuel 23:7 And it was reported to Saul that David had come to Keilah, and Saul said: "God has delivered him into my hands, for he is shut in, having entered a city that has gates and bars."
1 Samuel 23:8 And Saul commanded all the people to go down to war in Keilah and to besiege David and his men.
1 Samuel 23:9 However, David, when he knew that Saul was secretly preparing evil against him, said to Abiathar the priest: "Bring the ephod here."
1 Samuel 23:10 And David said: "O Lord God of Israel, Your servant has heard the report that Saul seeks to come to Keilah to destroy the city on account of me."
1 Samuel 23:11 "Will the men of Keilah deliver me into his hands? And will Saul come down, as Your servant has heard? O Lord God of Israel, tell Your servant."
1 Samuel 23:12 And the Lord said: "They will deliver you."
1 Samuel 23:13 So David and his men, about six hundred of them, rose up and went out from Keilah, and they wandered about, uncertain where to go. And it was reported to Saul that David had fled from Keilah, so he halted his journey.
1 Samuel 23:14 But David remained in the wilderness, in very fortified places; he also remained on the desert mountain of Ziph. So Saul searched for him every day, but God did not deliver him into his hands.
1 Samuel 23:15 And David saw that Saul had come out to seek his life. Now David was in the wilderness of Ziph, in the forest.
1 Samuel 23:16 Then Jonathan, Saul's son, rose up and went to David in the forest, and he strengthened David's hand in God, and said to him:
1 Samuel 23:17 "Do not be afraid, for the hand of Saul my father will not seize you. You will reign over Israel, and I will be second to you. Even my father Saul knows this."
1 Samuel 23:18 So David and Jonathan made a covenant before the Lord. And David remained in the forest, but Jonathan returned to his home.
1 Samuel 23:19 Now the Ziphites went up from David to Saul in Gibeah, saying: "Is not David hiding among us in the very strongholds in the forest, on the hill of Hachilah, which is to the right of the desert?"
1 Samuel 23:20 "Now then, if your soul desires to come down, come down. It is our duty to deliver him into the king's hands."
1 Samuel 23:21 And Saul said: "May you be blessed by the Lord, because you have felt sorrow for my plight."
1 Samuel 23:22 "Go therefore, and prepare yourselves, and find out and carefully observe the place where he stays, or who has seen him; or if he is truly there, let someone make me know his exact location."
1 Samuel 23:23 "Observe closely and know all the hiding places in which he hides, and return to me at a certain place, so that I may go with you. For if he is in the land, I will search for him among all the thousands of Judah."
1 Samuel 23:24 So they rose up and went to Ziph ahead of Saul. But David and his men were in the wilderness of Maon, in the plain to the right of Jeshimon.
1 Samuel 23:25 So Saul and his companions went down to search. And when this was reported to David, he went down to the rock and remained in the wilderness of Maon. When Saul heard this, he pursued David into the wilderness of Maon.
1 Samuel 23:26 And Saul went on one side of this mountain, and David with his men on the other side of that mountain. Now David was hurrying to flee from Saul, and Saul with his army was encircling David and his men to capture them.
1 Samuel 23:27 Then a messenger came to Saul, saying: "Hurry and come, for the Philistines have raided the land!"
1 Samuel 23:28 So Saul returned and stopped pursuing David. For this reason, they called that place "The Dividing Rock."
1 Samuel 23:29 Therefore David went up from there and remained in the strongholds of En-Gedi.
1 Samuel 24:1 Now it happened that when Saul returned from pursuing the Philistines, a message was brought to him, saying: 'Indeed, David is in the wilderness of Engedi!'
1 Samuel 24:2 So Saul took three thousand chosen men from all of Israel and went to seek out David and his men, going as far as the most rugged rocks, where the wild goats dwell.
1 Samuel 24:3 And he came to the sheepfolds that were along the way, and there was a cave there. Saul entered it to relieve himself. Now, David and his men were hiding in the inner parts of the cave, deep inside.
1 Samuel 24:4 And David's men said to him: 'Behold, this is the very day of which the Lord spoke to you, saying: 'I will deliver your enemy into your hand, so that you may do to him whatever seems right in your eyes!'' Therefore, David rose up and quietly cut off the hem of Saul's cloak.
1 Samuel 24:5 After this, David's conscience struck him, because he had cut off the hem of Saul's cloak, recognizing it as a disrespectful act against God's anointed.
1 Samuel 24:6 And he said to his men: 'May the Lord be merciful to me, that I should not do this thing to my lord, the Lord's anointed, by laying my hand on him. For he is the Christ—the anointed one—of the Lord!'
1 Samuel 24:7 And David restrained his men with these words, and he did not permit them to rise up against Saul. Meanwhile, Saul rose from the cave and continued on his way.
1 Samuel 24:8 However, David also rose after him and, coming out of the cave, he cried out behind Saul, saying: 'My lord, O King!'
1 Samuel 24:9 And Saul looked behind him. Then David bowed himself with his face to the ground and worshipped, showing profound respect.
1 Samuel 24:10 And David said to Saul: 'Why do you listen to the words of men who speak and say: 'Behold, David seeks your harm?' These are false accusations.
1 Samuel 24:11 Behold, today your own eyes have seen that the Lord delivered you into my hand in the cave. I considered killing you, but my eye spared you; I had compassion on you.
1 Samuel 24:12 And I said: 'I will not lay my hand on my lord, because he is the Christ—the anointed one—of the Lord!'
1 Samuel 24:13 Look rather, my father, and acknowledge this hem of your cloak in my hand. For when I cut off your hem, I refused to lay my hand on you.
1 Samuel 24:14 Understand this, and see that there is no evil in my hand, nor injustice, nor any sin on my part, and I have committed no offense against you. Yet you lie in wait for my very life, to take it away.
1 Samuel 24:15 May the Lord judge between me and you, and may the Lord avenge me against you, but my hand shall not be against you. I will not take justice into my own hands.
1 Samuel 24:16 Just as the old proverb says: 'Wickedness proceeds from the wicked.' But my hand shall not be against you.
1 Samuel 24:17 Whom are you pursuing, O King of Israel? Whom are you pursuing? A dead dog, or a single flea? These are insults, showing how little of a threat I am.
1 Samuel 24:18 May the Lord be judge, and may He judge between me and you. May He see and decide my cause, and deliver me from your hand.
1 Samuel 24:19 Now when David had finished speaking these words to Saul, Saul said: 'Is this your voice, my son David?'
1 Samuel 24:20 And Saul raised his voice and wept aloud.
1 Samuel 24:21 And he said to David: 'You are more righteous than I, for you have rendered good to me, while I have rendered evil to you.'
1 Samuel 24:22 For you have shown today the good things you have done for me: how the Lord delivered me into your hand, and yet you did not kill me.
1 Samuel 24:23 For no one finds his enemy and lets him go on a good way; instead, may the Lord repay you for the good you have done to me today.
1 Samuel 25:1 Samuel died, and all Israel gathered and mourned for him. They buried him at his home in Ramatha. David then got up and went down into the desert of Paran.
1 Samuel 25:2 There was a man in Maon whose possessions were in Carmel. This man was extremely rich; he owned three thousand sheep and a thousand goats. He was in Carmel for the shearing of his flock.
1 Samuel 25:3 The man's name was Nabal, and his wife's name was Abigail. She was a very prudent and good woman, but her husband was a harsh and wicked man. He was of the lineage of Caleb.
1 Samuel 25:4 David heard in the desert that Nabal was shearing his sheep.
1 Samuel 25:5 So David sent ten young men, and said to them: 'Go up to Carmel, and when you come to Nabal, ask him in my name how he fares and wish him peace.'
1 Samuel 25:6 And say this: 'Live well, my brother, and may all things prosper for you, for your whole household, and for all that is yours.'
1 Samuel 25:7 'I have heard that you have shearers. Your shepherds were with us in the desert; we never harmed them, nor was anything lost from them all the days they were with us in Carmel.'
1 Samuel 25:8 'Ask your young men, and they will tell you. Therefore, may my young men find favor in your eyes. Since we have come on a good day, please give whatever you have at hand to your servants and to your son David.'
1 Samuel 25:9 When David's young men came, they spoke all these words to Nabal in David's name, and then they waited in silence.
1 Samuel 25:10 Nabal answered David's servants, saying: 'Who is David? And who is the son of Jesse? Today there are many servants who are running away from their masters!'
1 Samuel 25:11 'Therefore, shall I take my bread, my water, and the meat which I have butchered for my shearers, and give it to men of whom I do not even know where they come from?'
1 Samuel 25:12 So David's young men turned back on their way, and when they came, they reported all of Nabal's words to him.
1 Samuel 25:13 And David said to his men: 'Let each one gird on his sword.' And each one girded on his sword. David also girded on his sword. About four hundred men went up after David, while two hundred remained with the baggage.
1 Samuel 25:14 However, one of the young men told Abigail, Nabal's wife, saying: 'Behold, David sent messengers from the desert to greet our master; but he drove them away with insults.'
1 Samuel 25:15 'And these men were very good to us. They did not afflict us, nor was anything taken from us all the time we were with them in the desert.'
1 Samuel 25:16 'They were like a protective wall to us both night and day, all the days we were with them, while our shepherds were pasturing the sheep.'
1 Samuel 25:17 'Therefore, know now and consider what you should do. For evil is determined against our master and against your whole household. Our master Nabal is such a worthless man that no one can speak to him, so you must act.'
1 Samuel 25:18 So Abigail quickly prepared and took two hundred loaves of bread, two skins of wine, five roasted sheep, five measures of parched corn, a hundred clusters of raisins, and two hundred cakes of figs, and loaded them upon donkeys.
1 Samuel 25:19 And she said to her young men: 'Go on ahead of me; behold, I will follow you.' But she did not tell her husband Nabal about this.
1 Samuel 25:20 As Abigail rode on her donkey and was coming down under the cover of the mountain, David and his men appeared, coming down towards her, and she met them.
1 Samuel 25:21 Now David had been saying to his men: 'Truly, it was in vain that I guarded all that belonged to this man in the desert, and that nothing was lost of all that pertains to him. For he has returned evil to me for good.'
1 Samuel 25:22 'May God do this to David's enemies, and more also, if by morning I leave alive even one male belonging to Nabal, even one who pisses against a wall' —meaning not a single male would survive to urinate on the walls of their home, ensuring total destruction.
1 Samuel 25:23 When Abigail saw David, she hurried and dismounted from her donkey, and she fell before David on her face and prostrated herself on the ground in supplication.
1 Samuel 25:24 And she fell at his feet and said: 'Let this iniquity be upon me alone, my lord. I beg you, let your handmaid speak in your hearing, and please listen to the words of your handmaid.'
1 Samuel 25:25 'Please, my lord, do not take to heart this worthless man Nabal. For as his name is, so he is: 'Nabal' means 'fool,' and foolishness is indeed with him. As for me, your handmaid, I did not see the young men of my lord whom you sent.'
1 Samuel 25:26 'Now therefore, my lord, as the Lord lives and as your soul lives, the Lord has restrained you from shedding blood and has saved your hand from taking vengeance for yourself. And now, let your enemies and those who seek evil for my lord become like Nabal.'
1 Samuel 25:27 'And now, accept this gift, which your handmaid has brought to you, my lord, and give it to the young men who follow you.'
1 Samuel 25:28 'Please forgive the offense of your handmaid. For the Lord will surely make a faithful and enduring house for my lord, because you fight the battles of the Lord, and no evil has been found in you all the days of your life.'
1 Samuel 25:29 'If indeed a man should rise up to pursue you and seek your life, the life of my lord will be bound up in the bundle of the living with the Lord your God, held securely in His protection. But the lives of your enemies, He will sling out as from the hollow of a sling in a whirlwind, scattering them to destruction.'
1 Samuel 25:30 'When therefore the Lord has done for my lord all the good things He has spoken concerning you, and has appointed you leader over Israel —meaning when you become king—'
1 Samuel 25:31 'This will not be a cause for stumbling or a pang of regret in your heart, my lord, that you would have shed blood without cause, or avenged yourself. And when the Lord has dealt well with my lord, you will remember your handmaid.'
1 Samuel 25:32 And David said to Abigail: 'Blessed be the Lord God of Israel, who sent you this day to meet me, and blessed be your counsel.'
1 Samuel 25:33 'And blessed be your wisdom, and blessed are you, who have prevented me this day from going to shed blood and from avenging myself with my own hand.'
1 Samuel 25:34 'Otherwise, as the Lord God of Israel lives, Who has restrained me from doing evil to you: had you not come quickly to meet me, surely by morning, Nabal would not have been left with even one male who pisses against a wall, ensuring total annihilation.'
1 Samuel 25:35 So David received from her hand what she had brought to him, and he said to her: 'Go in peace to your house. Behold, I have heard your voice and respected your plea.'
1 Samuel 25:36 So Abigail came to Nabal, and behold, there was a feast in his house, like the feast of a king. And Nabal's heart was merry, because he was excessively drunk. So she did not tell him anything at all until the morning.
1 Samuel 25:37 But in the morning, when Nabal had sobered up from the wine, his wife told him these things. And his heart died within him from shock, and he became like a stone.
1 Samuel 25:38 And it happened, after about ten days, that the Lord struck Nabal, and he died.
1 Samuel 25:39 When David heard that Nabal was dead, he said: 'Blessed be the Lord, who has judged the cause of my reproach from the hand of Nabal, and has kept His servant from evil, and has returned Nabal's wickedness upon his own head.' So David sent and spoke to Abigail, to take her to himself as a wife.
1 Samuel 25:40 So David's servants came to Abigail at Carmel, and they spoke to her, saying: 'David has sent us to you, to take you to himself as a wife.'
1 Samuel 25:1 Samuel died, and all of Israel gathered together and mourned for him. They buried him at his home in Ramah. David then rose up and went down into the wilderness of Paran.
1 Samuel 25:2 There was a man in the highlands of Maon whose property was in Carmel, and that man was exceedingly wealthy. He had three thousand sheep and one thousand goats, and it so happened that he was shearing his sheep in Carmel.
1 Samuel 25:3 The man’s name was Nabal, and his wife’s name was Abigail. She was a very prudent and good woman. Her husband, however, was hard-hearted and evil, and he was a descendant of Caleb.
1 Samuel 25:4 David heard in the wilderness that Nabal was shearing his sheep.
1 Samuel 25:5 So David sent ten young men and told them: “Go up to Carmel and approach Nabal. Greet him on my behalf with good wishes and peace.”
1 Samuel 25:6 And this is what you are to say: 'May you live long and prosper, and may your household and all that belongs to you also prosper.'
1 Samuel 25:7 'I have just heard that your shepherds are shearing. Do you have my shepherds in Carmel — (meaning, those who have been protecting your flock)?'
1 Samuel 25:8 'They — (my men who have been protecting your flock) — will not be put to shame. Your young men ask you to give whatever you find to your servants and to your son David.'
1 Samuel 25:9 'We have come on a good day. Whatever is at hand, please give it to your servants and to your son David.'
1 Samuel 25:10 So when the young men arrived, they conveyed all these words to Nabal in David’s name, and then they fell silent, waiting for his response.
1 Samuel 25:11 Nabal answered David’s servants, saying: “Who is this David? And who is the son of Jesse? Today, many servants are running away from their masters. — (I won't help such men).”
1 Samuel 25:12 “Am I then to take my bread, my water, and the meat that I have slaughtered for those who are shearing my flock, and give it to men of whom I do not know where they come from? Absolutely not.”
1 Samuel 25:13 So David’s young men turned back and reported all of Nabal’s words to him.
1 Samuel 25:14 Then David said to his young men: “Let each man strap on his sword!” And each man strapped on his sword. David himself also strapped on his sword. About four hundred men went up with David, while two hundred remained behind to guard the supplies.
1 Samuel 25:15 But one of Nabal’s young men had told Abigail, Nabal’s wife, saying: “Behold, David sent messengers from the wilderness to greet our master — (respectfully and with good intent) — but he violently lashed out at them.”
1 Samuel 25:16 “Yet, they were very good men. They caused us no trouble at all, nor did they take anything from our possessions during all the days they were with us when we were in the field.”
1 Samuel 25:17 “They were a wall of protection for us, day and night, throughout all the days we were with them while we were shepherds of the sheep.”
1 Samuel 25:18 “Therefore, now consider and see what you must do, because evil is determined against our master and against all his household. For he himself is such a wicked and worthless man that no one can speak to him — (he will not listen to reason).”
1 Samuel 25:19 So Abigail hurried and took two hundred loaves of bread, two wineskins of wine, five cooked sheep — (rams) — five measures of roasted grain, one hundred clusters of raisins, and two hundred cakes of figs, and she loaded them onto donkeys.
1 Samuel 25:20 She said to her young men: “Go ahead of me; behold, I will follow behind you.” But she did not tell her husband, Nabal, about any of this.
1 Samuel 25:21 As she was riding on the donkey and descending by a hidden path of the mountain, David and his men were coming down toward her, and she met them.
1 Samuel 25:22 Now David had just said: “Surely, it was for nothing that I guarded all this man’s possessions in the wilderness, and nothing was lost of all that belonged to him. Yet he has repaid me evil for good.”
1 Samuel 25:23 “May God do so to David’s enemies, and more also, if by morning I leave a single male alive from all that belongs to him.”
1 Samuel 25:24 When Abigail saw David, she quickly dismounted from her donkey and fell down at David’s feet, bowing low to the ground in reverence and supplication.
1 Samuel 25:25 She fell at his feet and said: “Upon me alone, my lord, let this iniquity fall. I beg you, let your servant speak in your hearing, and please listen to the words of your handmaid.”
1 Samuel 25:26 “Please, my lord, do not take to heart this worthless man, Nabal. For according to his name, he is a fool — (Nabal means 'fool') — and folly is with him. But I, your servant, did not see the young men whom you sent.”
1 Samuel 25:27 “Now therefore, my lord, as the Lord lives and as your soul lives, it is the Lord who has restrained you from coming to bloodshed and from avenging yourself with your own hand. Now let your enemies and those who seek evil for my lord be like Nabal — (worthless and overcome by divine judgment).”
1 Samuel 25:28 “May this blessing, which your servant has brought to you, my lord, be given to your servants who follow you.”
1 Samuel 25:29 “Please forgive the iniquity of your servant. For the Lord will surely make a lasting and faithful house for my lord, because you fight the battles of the Lord, and good things have been found in you all the days of your life.”
1 Samuel 25:30 “If a man rises up to pursue you and seek your life, the life of my lord will be guarded as in a bundle of the living with the Lord your God. But the lives of your enemies will be hurled away like a stone from a sling.”
1 Samuel 25:31 “When the Lord has done for my lord all the good things He has spoken concerning you, and has appointed you leader over Israel, then this will not be a cause for stumbling or a troubled conscience for my lord — (the thought) — that you shed blood needlessly or avenged yourself. And when the Lord has dealt well with my lord, then remember your servant.”
1 Samuel 25:32 David said to Abigail: “Blessed be the Lord, the God of Israel, who sent you today to meet me, and blessed be your counsel!”
1 Samuel 25:33 “And blessed be your wisdom, and blessed be you, who have restrained me today from going to shed blood and from avenging myself with my own hand.”
1 Samuel 25:34 “Otherwise, as surely as the Lord God of Israel lives, who has kept me from doing evil to you, if you had not come quickly to meet me, there would not have been left to Nabal by morning light a single male person — (meaning, every male in his household would have been destroyed).”
1 Samuel 25:35 Then David received from her hand what she had brought to him, and he said to her: “Go up in peace to your house. Behold, I have listened to your voice and I have shown you favor.”
1 Samuel 25:36 Abigail came to Nabal, and behold, he was holding a feast in his house, like the feast of a king. Nabal’s heart was merry, for he was exceedingly drunk. So she did not tell him anything at all until the morning.
1 Samuel 25:37 But in the morning, when Nabal had sobered up from his wine, his wife told him these things. And his heart died within him, and he became like a stone — (paralyzed by fear or a stroke).
1 Samuel 25:38 And about ten days later, the Lord struck Nabal, and he died.
1 Samuel 25:39 When David heard that Nabal was dead, he said: “Blessed be the Lord, who has judged the cause of my reproach from the hand of Nabal, and has kept His servant from evil. He has returned Nabal’s wickedness upon his own head.” So David sent and spoke to Abigail, to take her as his wife.
1 Samuel 25:40 David’s servants came to Abigail at Carmel and spoke to her, saying: “David has sent us to you, to take you as his wife.”
1 Samuel 26:1 But the Ziphites came from the wilderness to Saul, saying: 'Look! David is hiding on the hill of Hachilah, which is opposite the wilderness.'
1 Samuel 26:2 So Saul got up and went down into the wilderness of Ziph, and with him were three thousand men, chosen from Israel, to search for David in the wilderness of Ziph.
1 Samuel 26:3 Saul made his camp on the hill of Hachilah, which is opposite the wilderness, by the road. But David was living in the wilderness at that time, and seeing that Saul had come after him into the wilderness,
1 Samuel 26:4 David sent out scouts, and learned with certainty that Saul had indeed come.
1 Samuel 26:5 So David got up and went to the place where Saul was. He saw the exact place where Saul was sleeping, and Abner, the son of Ner, who was the commander of Saul's army, and Saul sleeping inside his tent, while the rest of the people were encamped all around him.
1 Samuel 26:6 David then said to Ahimelech the Hittite, and to Abishai, son of Zeruiah, Joab's brother, saying: 'Who will go down with me to Saul in the camp?' And Abishai said: 'I will go down with you.'
1 Samuel 26:7 So David and Abishai came to the people by night, and they found Saul lying down and sleeping in his tent, and his spear was stuck in the ground at his head. But Abner and the people were sleeping all around him.
1 Samuel 26:8 Then Abishai said to David: 'God has delivered your enemy into your hand today. Therefore, now I will pierce him with his own spear into the ground, just once, and a second time will not even be needed!'
1 Samuel 26:9 And David said to Abishai: 'Do not kill him; for who can stretch out his hand against the Anointed of the Lord and be innocent?'
1 Samuel 26:10 And David said: 'As the Lord lives! Unless the Lord strikes him down himself, or his day comes for him to die naturally, or he goes down into battle and perishes there;'
1 Samuel 26:11 'Far be it from me to stretch out my hand against the Anointed of the Lord! Now then, take the spear that is at his head, and the jug of water, and let us go.'
1 Samuel 26:12 So David took the spear and the jug of water that was at Saul's head, and they left. And there was no one who saw, or understood what was happening, or woke up; instead, all of them were sleeping, because a deep sleep from the Lord had fallen upon them.
1 Samuel 26:13 When David had crossed to the other side of the valley, and had come to the top of a distant mountain, so that there was a great distance between them,
1 Samuel 26:14 David called out to the people and to Abner, son of Ner, saying: 'Won't you answer, Abner?' And Abner answered and said: 'Who are you, who calls out and disturbs the king?'
1 Samuel 26:15 And David said to Abner: 'Are you not a man of valor? And who is like you in all of Israel? Why then did you not guard your lord the king? For one of the people came in to kill your lord the king!'
1 Samuel 26:16 'This thing that you have done is not good! As the Lord lives, you are men worthy of death, because you did not guard your lord, the Anointed of the Lord! Now then, look where the king's spear is, and where the jug of water was, which was at his head!'
1 Samuel 26:17 And Saul recognized David's voice and said: 'Is this your voice, my son David?' And David said: 'It is my voice, my lord, O King!'
1 Samuel 26:18 And David said: 'Why does my lord pursue his servant? What have I done? Or what evil is in my hand?'
1 Samuel 26:19 'Now therefore, please hear, my lord the King, the words of your servant: If the Lord is inciting you against me, then let Him accept an offering. But if it is men who are doing this, then let them be cursed in the sight of the Lord! For they have driven me out today from living in the inheritance of the Lord, by saying: "Go, serve other gods!"'
1 Samuel 26:20 'And now, let my blood not be poured out on the ground away from the presence of the Lord; for you have come out to search for a single flea, just as one pursues a partridge in the mountains.'
1 Samuel 26:21 And Saul said: 'I have sinned. Return, my son David. For I will never again seek to harm you, because my life was precious in your eyes today. I have acted foolishly, and have greatly erred.'
1 Samuel 26:22 And David answered and said: 'Here is the king's spear! Let one of the young men come over and take it.'
1 Samuel 26:23 'And the Lord will repay to each person according to his righteousness and his faithfulness, because I was unwilling to stretch out my hand against the Anointed of the Lord.'
1 Samuel 26:24 'And just as your life was valued greatly today in my eyes, so may my life be valued greatly in the eyes of the Lord, and may He deliver me from all trouble.'
1 Samuel 26:25 And Saul said to David: 'Blessed are you, my son David! For indeed, you will certainly do great things, and you will surely prevail!' So David went on his way, and Saul returned to his own place.
1 Samuel 26:1 Then the Ziphites came to Saul in Gibeah, saying: "Is David not hiding himself on the hill of Hachila, which is opposite the desert wilderness?"
1 Samuel 26:2 So Saul arose and went down into the desert of Ziph, and with him were three thousand chosen men from Israel, to search for David in the desert of Ziph.
1 Samuel 26:3 And Saul encamped on the hill of Hachila, which is opposite the desert wilderness, by the road. But David was living in the desert. Therefore, David saw that Saul had come after him into the desert.
1 Samuel 26:4 So David sent out scouts, and he learned for certain that Saul had indeed come.
