1 Samuel 26:5 Then David arose and came to the place where Saul was. When David saw the place where Saul was sleeping, and Abner the son of Ner, who was the commander of his army, Saul was sleeping in the middle of the camp, and Abner and the others were all around him.
1 Samuel 26:6 And David said to Ahimelech the Hittite, and to Abishai the son of Zeruiah, Joab’s brother, saying: "Who will go down with me to Saul in the camp?" And Abishai said: "I will go down with you."
1 Samuel 26:7 So David and Abishai came to the people by night, and they found Saul lying down and sleeping in the camp, with his spear fixed in the ground at his head. But Abner and the people were sleeping all around him.
1 Samuel 26:8 And Abishai said to David: "God has delivered your enemy into your hand today. Now therefore, I will pin him to the ground with the spear once, and I will not need a second blow."
1 Samuel 26:9 But David said to Abishai: "Do not kill him. For who can stretch out his hand against the anointed of the Lord and remain innocent?"
1 Samuel 26:10 And David said: "As the Lord lives, either the Lord will strike him down, or his day will come for him to die, or he will perish by going down into battle."
1 Samuel 26:11 May the Lord be merciful to me, that I may not stretch out my hand against the anointed of the Lord. Now therefore, take the spear that is at his head and the jug of water, and let us go.
1 Samuel 26:12 So David took the spear and the jug of water that was at Saul’s head, and they departed. And no one saw or understood or was awake, for they were all sleeping, because a deep sleep from the Lord had fallen upon them.
1 Samuel 26:13 When David had crossed over to the other side and stood on the top of the mountain far away, with a great distance between them:
1 Samuel 26:14 David cried out to the people and to Abner the son of Ner, saying: "Do you not answer, Abner?" And Abner answered and said: "Who are you who cries out and disturbs the king?"
1 Samuel 26:15 And David said to Abner: "Are you not a man? And who is like you in Israel? Why then have you not guarded your lord the king? For one of the people came in to kill your lord the king."
1 Samuel 26:16 This thing that you have done is not good. As the Lord lives, you are men deserving of death, because you have not guarded your lord, the anointed of the Lord. Now therefore, look where the king’s spear is, and where his jug of water was, which was at his head.
1 Samuel 26:17 Then Saul recognized David’s voice and said: "Is this your voice, my son David?" And David said: "It is my voice, my lord the king."
1 Samuel 26:18 And he added, saying: "For what reason does my lord pursue his servant? What have I committed? Or what evil is in my hand?"
1 Samuel 26:19 Now therefore, please hear, my lord the king, the words of your servant: "If the Lord stirs you up against me, let an offering be pleasing to Him. But if men have done this, may they be cursed in the sight of the Lord, for they have driven me out today from dwelling in the inheritance of the Lord, saying: 'Go, serve foreign gods.'"
1 Samuel 26:20 And now, let not my blood be shed on the ground before the Lord. For you have come out to seek my life, as one pursues a leopard in the mountains.
1 Samuel 26:21 And Saul said: "I have sinned. Return, my son David. For I will never again seek your life, because my life was precious in your eyes today. Behold, I have acted foolishly, and I have made many great errors."
1 Samuel 26:22 And David answered and said: "Behold the king’s spear! Let one of the young men come over and take it."
1 Samuel 26:23 And the Lord will repay each man for his righteousness and his faithfulness, because I was unwilling to put forth my hand against the anointed of the Lord.
1 Samuel 26:24 And just as your life was valued greatly in my eyes today, so may my life be valued greatly in the eyes of the Lord, and may He deliver me from all trouble.
1 Samuel 26:25 Then Saul said to David: "Blessed are you, my son David. You will surely accomplish great things, and you will certainly prevail." So David went on his way, and Saul returned to his own place.
1 Samuel 27:1 But David said to himself: 'Eventually, I will be killed by Saul. Wouldn't it be better for me to escape and find safety in the land of the Philistines? Then Saul will give up hope and stop pursuing me throughout all the territory of Israel. This way I will escape from his power.'
1 Samuel 27:2 So David got up and went, along with his six hundred men, to Achish, the son of Maoch, who was the king of Gath.
1 Samuel 27:3 David lived with Achish in Gath, he and his men, each with his own household. David brought his two wives, Achinoam from Jezreel, and Abigail, who had been Nabal's wife from Carmel.
1 Samuel 27:4 When Saul was told that David had fled to Gath, he no longer tried to find him.
1 Samuel 27:5 Then David said to Achish: 'If I have found favor in your sight, please give me a place in one of the towns in this region where I can live. Why should your servant remain with you here in the royal capital?'
1 Samuel 27:6 So on that very day, Achish gave him Ziklag. This is why Ziklag has belonged to the kings of Judah even to this present day.
1 Samuel 27:7 The total time David lived in the territory of the Philistines was one year and four months.
1 Samuel 27:8 David and his men would go up and raid the Geshurites, the Girzites, and the Amalekites. These were the peoples who had lived in that land from ancient times, all the way from Shur to the land of Egypt.
1 Samuel 27:9 David would attack the entire land, leaving no man or woman alive. He would take the sheep, oxen, donkeys, camels, and clothing, then return and come back to Achish.
1 Samuel 27:10 Achish would ask, 'Where did you raid today?' David would answer, 'Against the south of Judah, or against the south of the Jerahmeelites, or against the south of the Kenites.'
1 Samuel 27:11 David would not spare a single man or woman to bring them back to Gath, reasoning: 'Otherwise, they might speak against us and reveal what David truly did.' This was David’s practice for all the time he lived in the land of the Philistines.
1 Samuel 27:12 So Achis believed David, thinking: 'He has truly made himself detestable to his own people, Israel, and so he will be my servant forever.'
1 Samuel 28:1 It happened in those days that the Philistines gathered their armies to fight against Israel. And Achis said to David: "Know this for sure, you and your men will go out with me into the camp."
1 Samuel 28:2 And David said to Achis: "Now you will see what your servant can do." And Achis said to David: "Then I will make you the guardian of my life for all time."
1 Samuel 28:3 Meanwhile, Samuel had died, and all of Israel mourned for him. They buried him in his city, Ramah. And Saul had removed the mediums and diviners from the land.
1 Samuel 28:4 So the Philistines gathered and came and set up camp in Shunem. Saul also gathered all of Israel and came to Gilboa.
1 Samuel 28:5 And Saul saw the Philistine camp and was greatly afraid; his heart was utterly terrified.
1 Samuel 28:6 So he consulted the Lord, but the Lord did not answer him—not through dreams, nor through priests, nor through prophets.
1 Samuel 28:7 And Saul said to his servants: "Find me a woman who possesses a spirit of divination, so I can go to her and consult through her." And his servants said to him: "There is a woman with a spirit of divination in Endor."
1 Samuel 28:8 So Saul disguised himself and put on other clothes. He went with two men, and they came to the woman at night. He said to her: "Divine for me using your spirit, and bring up for me whomever I tell you."
1 Samuel 28:9 And the woman said to him: "Behold, you know what Saul has done, and how he has removed the mediums and diviners from the land. Why then are you setting a trap for my life, so that I may be killed?"
1 Samuel 28:10 And Saul swore to her by the Lord, saying: "As the Lord lives, no harm will come to you because of this matter."
1 Samuel 28:11 And the woman said to him: "Whom shall I bring up for you?" And he said: "Bring up Samuel for me."
1 Samuel 28:12 But when the woman saw Samuel, she cried out with a loud voice and said to Saul: "Why have you deceived me, for you are Saul!"
1 Samuel 28:13 And the king said to her: "Do not be afraid. What did you see?" And the woman said to Saul: "I saw divine beings ascending from the earth."
1 Samuel 28:14 He said to her: "What is his appearance?" And she said: "An old man is ascending, and he is wrapped in a cloak." Then Saul understood that it was Samuel, and he bowed himself to the ground and worshipped.
1 Samuel 28:15 But Samuel said to Saul: "Why have you disturbed me, to bring me up?" And Saul said: "I am in great distress because the Philistines are fighting against me. Moreover, God has departed from me and will no longer hear me, neither through the hand of prophets nor through dreams. Therefore, I have called you to show me what I should do."
1 Samuel 28:16 And Samuel said: "Why do you ask me, since the Lord has departed from you and has gone over to your neighbor?"
1 Samuel 28:17 For the Lord will do to you exactly as He spoke through me: He will tear the kingdom from your hand and give it to your neighbor, David.
1 Samuel 28:18 Because you did not obey the voice of the Lord, nor did you carry out His fierce anger against Amalek—for this reason, the Lord has done to you what you are suffering now.
1 Samuel 28:19 And the Lord will also give Israel, along with you, into the hand of the Philistines. Therefore, tomorrow, you and your sons will be with me, and the Lord will also give the army of Israel into the hand of the Philistines.
1 Samuel 28:20 Immediately, Saul fell full length upon the ground, for he was greatly terrified because of Samuel's words. And he had no strength in him because he had not eaten any food all that day.
1 Samuel 28:21 So the woman came to Saul and saw that he was greatly distressed. And she said to him: "Behold, your handmaid obeyed your voice, and I risked my life to listen to the words you spoke to me."
1 Samuel 28:22 Now therefore, you also obey the counsel of your handmaid. Let me place a morsel of bread before you. Eat it so you may be refreshed and able to travel.
1 Samuel 28:23 But he refused and said: "I will not eat." However, his servants and the woman compelled him, and at last he listened to their voice. He rose from the ground and sat upon the couch.
1 Samuel 28:24 Now the woman had a fatted calf in the house. She hurried and killed it, then she took flour and mixed it and baked unleavened bread under the ashes.
1 Samuel 28:25 And she set it before Saul and before his servants. They ate, and then they rose and traveled that same night.
1 Samuel 28:1 It happened in those days that the Philistines gathered their armies to fight against Israel. Achis then said to David: 'You must know for certain that you and your men will go out with me in the battle camp.'
1 Samuel 28:2 And David said to Achis, 'Now you will see what your servant is able to do.' Achis then said to David, 'Then I will keep you as my personal guard and protect your life every day.'
1 Samuel 28:3 Meanwhile, Samuel had died, and all of Israel mourned for him. They buried him in Ramah, his own city. And Saul had previously removed all the mediums and diviners from the land.
1 Samuel 28:4 So the Philistines gathered and came to encamp in Shunem. But Saul also gathered all of Israel, and they came to Gilboa.
1 Samuel 28:5 And when Saul saw the Philistine camp, he became terrified, and his heart was overwhelmed with fear.
1 Samuel 28:6 So he consulted the Lord, but the Lord did not answer him—neither through dreams, nor through the priests using the Urim and Thummim, nor through prophets.
1 Samuel 28:7 Then Saul said to his servants, 'Search for a woman who has a familiar spirit, and I will go to her to inquire through her.' His servants then told him, 'There is a woman with a familiar spirit in Endor.'
1 Samuel 28:8 So Saul changed his appearance and put on other clothes. Then he, with two men, went and came to the woman by night. And he said to her, 'Perform divination for me by your familiar spirit, and bring up for me the one I will tell you.'
1 Samuel 28:9 And the woman said to him, 'Look, you know what Saul has done and how he has removed the mediums and diviners from the land. Why then are you setting a trap for my life, that I may be killed?'
1 Samuel 28:10 And Saul swore to her by the Lord, saying, 'As the Lord lives, no harm will come to you because of this matter.'
1 Samuel 28:11 Then the woman said, 'Whom shall I bring up for you?' And he replied, 'Bring up Samuel for me.'
1 Samuel 28:12 And when the woman saw Samuel, she cried out with a loud voice. She said to Saul, 'Why have you deceived me? You are Saul!'
1 Samuel 28:13 And the king said to her, 'Do not be afraid. What did you see?' And the woman said to Saul, 'I saw a divine being ascending from the earth.'
1 Samuel 28:14 Then he said to her, 'What is his appearance like?' She replied, 'An old man is coming up, and he is wrapped in a cloak.' And Saul understood that it was Samuel. He then bowed himself to the ground and paid homage.
1 Samuel 28:15 But Samuel said to Saul, 'Why have you disturbed me, causing me to be brought up?' Saul replied, 'I am in great distress. The Philistines are fighting against me, and God has departed from me. He has answered me nothing, neither through prophets nor through dreams. That is why I have called upon you, so you may show me what I am to do.'
1 Samuel 28:16 And Samuel said, 'Why do you consult me, since the Lord has departed from you and has gone over to your neighbor, David?'
1 Samuel 28:17 For the Lord will do to you exactly what He spoke through me. He will tear the kingdom from your hand and give it to your neighbor, David.
1 Samuel 28:18 Because you did not obey the voice of the Lord, nor did you carry out His fierce wrath against Amalek, therefore the Lord has done to you what you now suffer.
1 Samuel 28:19 And the Lord will also give Israel, along with you, into the hand of the Philistines. Tomorrow, you and your sons will be with me in the realm of the dead. And the Lord will deliver the entire army of Israel into the hand of the Philistines.
1 Samuel 28:20 Immediately, Saul fell full length to the ground, terrified by Samuel's words. He had no strength left in him, for he had eaten no food all that day and night.
1 Samuel 28:21 So the woman came to Saul, seeing that he was greatly troubled. She said to him, 'Look, your handmaid obeyed your voice, and I risked my life by performing this for you, and I listened to your words that you spoke to me.'
1 Samuel 28:22 Now, please listen to your handmaid's voice. Let me set a morsel of bread before you, and eat, so that you may regain your strength and be able to travel.
1 Samuel 28:23 But he refused, saying, 'I will not eat.' However, his servants and the woman urged him strongly. At last, yielding to their persistence, he rose from the ground and sat upon the couch.
1 Samuel 28:24 Now the woman had a fattened ox in her house. She quickly killed it and, taking flour, mixed it and baked unleavened bread under the ashes.
1 Samuel 28:25 And she set it before Saul and his servants. When they had eaten, they rose and departed that very night.
1 Samuel 29:1 So the Philistines gathered all their military companies and forces at Aphek, a strategic location for battle. Meanwhile, the army of Israel set up their camp by the spring located in Jezreel, another key tactical position.
1 Samuel 29:2 The Philistine commanders were marching their troops, arrayed by companies of hundreds and thousands. David and his men were marching at the very rear, accompanying King Achis.
1 Samuel 29:3 Then the Philistine commanders asked, 'Who are these Hebrews joining our ranks?' And Achis responded to the Philistine commanders, saying, 'Is this not David, who was a servant of King Saul of Israel? He has been with me for a long time, for days and years, and I have found no fault in him or any sign of disloyalty since he defected to me until this very day.'
1 Samuel 29:4 However, the Philistine commanders became angry with Achis concerning David. They told him, 'Send this man away. Let him return to the place where you assigned him. He must not go down with us into battle, lest he become our adversary during the fight. How else could he regain favor with his own master, Saul, except by turning against us and sacrificing the lives of these very men?'
1 Samuel 29:5 They further questioned, 'Is this not the same David about whom they sang in their dances, saying: Saul has struck down his thousands, but David his tens of thousands?'
1 Samuel 29:6 So Achis called David and said to him, 'As the Lord lives, you are upright, and you have been good in my sight. Your coming and going with me in the camp has been without issue. I have found nothing evil in you from the day you came to me until this very day. However, you do not please the other Philistine commanders.'
1 Samuel 29:7 'Therefore, turn back now and go in peace. Do not displease the eyes of the Philistine commanders by remaining with us.'
1 Samuel 29:8 David then said to Achis, 'What have I done? Or what fault have you found in your servant from the day I have been in your sight until this very day, that I should not come and fight against the enemies of my lord, the king?'
1 Samuel 29:9 Achis answered David and said, 'I know that you are good in my eyes, as blameless as an angel of God. Nevertheless, the Philistine commanders have declared: He shall not go up with us into battle.'
1 Samuel 29:10 'Therefore, depart early in the morning, you and the servants of your lord, the men who came with you. And when you have risen in the night and dawn begins to break, go your way.'
1 Samuel 29:11 So David and his men rose early in the morning to depart at daybreak and return to the land of the Philistines. Meanwhile, the Philistines themselves marched up to Jezreel, ready for battle.
1 Samuel 29:1 The Philistines gathered all their military divisions at Aphek. But Israel set up their camp by the spring in Jezreel.
1 Samuel 29:2 The Philistine lords marched with their armies, organized into groups of hundreds and thousands. David and his men were bringing up the rear of the military column with Achish.
1 Samuel 29:3 And the Philistine commanders said to Achish, "What are these Hebrews doing here?" Achish replied to the Philistine commanders, "Is this not David, who was a servant of Saul, the king of Israel? He has been with me for many days, even years, and I have found nothing wrong in him since he defected to me, up until this very day."
1 Samuel 29:4 Therefore, the Philistine commanders became angry with Achish and said to him, "Let the man go back and stay in the place where you assigned him. He must not go down with us into battle, lest he become hostile towards us when we are engaged in battle. And how else could he appease his master, if not by turning against these very men of ours?"
1 Samuel 29:5 "Is this not the David about whom they sang in their festive dances, saying: 'Saul has slain a thousand, but David has slain ten thousand'?"
1 Samuel 29:6 So Achish called David and said to him, "As the Lord lives, you are upright and good in my sight. Your conduct, both your coming and going among us in the camp, has been above reproach. I have found nothing wrong in you from the day you came to me until this very day. But you are not pleasing to the Philistine commanders."
1 Samuel 29:7 "Therefore, return and go in peace, so that you do not give offense to the Philistine commanders."
1 Samuel 29:8 David then said to Achish, "What wrong have I done? Or what fault have you found in me, your servant, from the day I first came before you until this very day, that I should not be allowed to come and fight against the enemies of my lord, the king?"
1 Samuel 29:9 Achish answered David, "I know you are good in my eyes, like an angel of God. But the Philistine commanders have plainly declared: 'He must not go up with us into battle.'"
1 Samuel 29:10 "Therefore, rise early in the morning, you and your men who came with you. And as soon as you have risen while it is still dark, and then see the first light of day, you must depart."
1 Samuel 29:11 So David and his men rose early that morning to depart from the land of the Philistines. The Philistines, for their part, advanced into Jezreel.
1 Samuel 30:1 When David and his men arrived back at Ziklag on the third day, they found the city completely raided and burned to the ground by fire.
1 Samuel 30:2 Their wives, sons, and daughters—both the young and the old—had been taken away as captives.
1 Samuel 30:3 So David and all the people with him began to weep loudly, crying until they were completely exhausted and had no more tears left to shed.
1 Samuel 30:4 Among those taken captive were David's two wives: Ahinoam of Jezreel and Abigail, who had been Nabal's wife from Carmel.
1 Samuel 30:5 David became terribly distressed because the people began to talk about stoning him, for everyone's spirit was bitter over the loss of their sons and daughters. But David strengthened himself in the Lord, his God.
1 Samuel 30:6 Then David said to Abiathar the priest, son of Ahimelech, 'Bring me the ephod.' So Abiathar brought the ephod to David.
1 Samuel 30:7 And David inquired of the Lord, saying, 'Should I pursue these raiders? Will I overtake them or not?' The Lord replied to him, 'Pursue them: for you will surely overtake them and rescue everyone and everything.'
1 Samuel 30:8 So David went, along with the six hundred men who were with him. And they came to the Wadi Besor, where some of the exhausted men rested there.
1 Samuel 30:9 David continued the pursuit with four hundred men, while the two hundred who were too weary to cross the Wadi Besor remained behind.
1 Samuel 30:10 They found an Egyptian man out in a field and brought him to David. They gave him some bread to eat and water to drink,
1 Samuel 30:11 They also gave him a piece of fig cake and two clusters of raisins. After he ate, his spirit returned to him, and he was revived, because he had not eaten any food or drunk any water for three full days and three full nights.
1 Samuel 30:12 David then asked him, 'Whose servant are you? Where do you come from? And where are you going?' The Egyptian replied, 'I am a young Egyptian man, a servant of an Amalekite. My master abandoned me three days ago because I became ill.'
1 Samuel 30:13 He continued, 'Indeed, we raided the Negev of the Cherethites, and the territory against Judah, and the territory against Caleb, and we burned Ziklag with fire.'
1 Samuel 30:14 David asked him, 'Can you lead me to this raiding party?' The Egyptian answered, 'If you swear to me by God that you will not kill me or hand me over to my master, I will lead you to this party.'
1 Samuel 30:15 So David swore to him. And the Egyptian led him, and there the raiders were, scattered across the entire open country, eating, and drinking, and celebrating as if it were a feast day, because of all the great plunder and spoil they had taken from the land of the Philistines and from the land of Judah.
1 Samuel 30:16 And David attacked them from dawn until the evening of the next day, and not a single one of them escaped, except four hundred young men who had mounted camels and fled.
1 Samuel 30:17 And David recovered everything the Amalekites had taken, from his own wives down to the little ones. They had plundered absolutely nothing of the smaller or larger items, nor of the sons and daughters, nor of the spoil, nor of anything else they had carried off. David had brought everything back.
1 Samuel 30:18 They also drove away all the flocks and herds. And concerning that plunder, they declared, 'This is David's plunder!'
1 Samuel 30:19 When David returned, he came to the two hundred men who had been too weary to follow him, and whom he had made to stay by the Wadi Besor. They came out to meet David and to meet the people who were with him.
1 Samuel 30:20 As David approached the people, he greeted them peacefully.
1 Samuel 30:21 But every wicked and worthless man among the men who had gone with David responded, saying, 'Because they did not go with us, we will not give them any part of the plunder we recovered. Rather, let it be enough for each man to take his wife and children; when they have them, they can leave.'
1 Samuel 30:22 But David said, 'My brothers, you must not do this with what the Lord has given us. He protected us, and delivered the raiders who attacked us into our hands.'
1 Samuel 30:23 Nor should anyone listen to you concerning this matter: for the share will be equal for those who went down to the battle and for those who remained with the supplies. They shall divide it similarly.'
1 Samuel 30:24 And it came to pass that, from that time and up to the present day, this was established as a statute, and a judgment, and a just custom in Israel.
1 Samuel 30:25 So David came to Ziklag and sent some of the plunder to the elders of Judah, his friends, saying, 'Accept this blessing from the Lord's plunder!'
1 Samuel 30:26 He sent portions to those who were in Bethel, to those in Ramoth in the Negev, and to those in Jattir,
1 Samuel 30:27 and to those in Aroer, and to those in Siphmoth, and to those in Eshtemoa,
1 Samuel 30:28 and to those in Racal, and to those in the cities of the Jerahmeelites, and to those in the cities of the Kenites,
1 Samuel 30:29 and to those in Hormah, and to those in Borashan, and to those in Athach,
1 Samuel 30:30 and to those in Hebron, and to all the remaining places in which David himself and his men had lived and traveled.
1 Samuel 30:1 When David and his men returned to Ziklag on the third day, they discovered that the Amalekites had launched a surprise attack into the southern region and Ziklag itself. The Amalekites had raided Ziklag, and they had set the entire place on fire.
1 Samuel 30:2 They had also taken the women captive, and everyone else who was there—from the youngest child to the oldest person. They hadn't killed anyone, but they had taken them all away.
1 Samuel 30:3 So David and his men came to the city, and behold, it had been burned down with fire. Their wives, their sons, and their daughters had been taken captive.
1 Samuel 30:4 Then David and the people who were with him raised their voices and wept until they could no longer shed tears.
1 Samuel 30:5 For David's two wives had also been taken captive: Ahinoam of Jezreel, and Abigail, Nabal the Carmelite's wife.
1 Samuel 30:6 And David was greatly distressed, because the people were planning to stone him. For every man was bitter in his soul over his sons and his daughters. Yet, David strengthened himself in the Lord, his God.
1 Samuel 30:7 Then David said to Abiathar the priest, son of Ahimelech, 'Bring me the ephod.' And Abiathar brought the ephod to David.
1 Samuel 30:8 And David inquired of the Lord, saying, 'Should I pursue these raiders? Will I overtake them, or not?' And the Lord said to him, 'Pursue them, because you will surely overtake them and rescue everyone.'
1 Samuel 30:9 So David went, along with the six hundred men who were with him. They came as far as the Wadi Besor, where some of the men, exhausted, stayed behind.
1 Samuel 30:10 But David pursued with four hundred men, for two hundred men had stayed behind because they were too weak and could not cross the Wadi Besor.
1 Samuel 30:11 And they found an Egyptian man in the field and brought him to David. They gave him bread to eat and water to drink,
1 Samuel 30:12 And they also gave him a piece of fig cake and two clusters of raisins. When he had eaten these, his spirit returned to him and he was refreshed, for he had not eaten bread or drunk water for three days and three nights.
1 Samuel 30:13 Then David said to him, 'Whose are you, and where are you from?' He replied, 'I am a young Egyptian man, a servant of an Amalekite. My master abandoned me because I became ill three days ago.'
1 Samuel 30:14 Indeed, we raided the southern region of the Cherethites, and against Judah, and the southern part of Caleb's territory, and we burned Ziklag with fire.
1 Samuel 30:15 David asked him, 'Can you lead me to this raiding party?' He replied, 'Swear to me by God that you will not kill me, and that you will not hand me over to my master, and I will lead you to this raiding party.'
1 Samuel 30:16 And he led him. And behold, they were spread out over the surface of the entire land, eating and drinking, and celebrating as if it were a festival, because of all the plunder and spoils they had taken from the land of the Philistines and from the land of Judah.
1 Samuel 30:17 And David struck them from dawn until the evening of the next day. No one escaped from them, except four hundred young men who mounted camels and fled.
1 Samuel 30:18 And David rescued everything the Amalekites had taken. David also rescued his two wives.
1 Samuel 30:19 And nothing was missing for them, from the least to the greatest, neither sons nor daughters, nor spoils, nor anything else they had stolen. David brought everything back.
1 Samuel 30:20 And David took all the flocks and herds, and drove them before him. And the people said, 'This is David's plunder.'
1 Samuel 30:21 Then David came to the two hundred men who had been too exhausted to continue and had not been able to cross the Wadi Besor. They came out to meet David and the people who were with him. And when David approached the men, he greeted them peacefully.
1 Samuel 30:22 Then every wicked and evil man among those who had gone with David responded, saying, 'Because they didn't go with us, we will give them nothing from the plunder we rescued. Let each man just take his wife and children and go away.'
1 Samuel 30:23 But David said, 'You shall not do this, my brothers, after the Lord has saved us and delivered into our hands the raiders who attacked us.'
1 Samuel 30:24 And no one will listen to you in this matter. For the share will be equal for the one who goes down to battle and the one who remains with the baggage. They shall divide it equally.
1 Samuel 30:25 And from that day forward, this was established and commanded as a law, and it has set a standard of justice in Israel even to this present day.
1 Samuel 30:26 When David returned to Ziklag, he sent some of the plunder to the elders of Judah, his close associates, saying, 'Receive a blessing from the Lord's plunder.'
1 Samuel 30:27 To those in Bethel, and to those in Ramoth of the Negev (the southern region), and to those in Jattir,
1 Samuel 30:28 And to those in Aroer, and to those in Siphmoth, and to those in Eshtemoa,
1 Samuel 30:29 And to those in Rachal, and to those in the cities of the Jerahmeelites, and to those in the cities of the Kenites,
1 Samuel 30:30 And to those in Hormah, and to those in Bor-ashan, and to those in Athach,
1 Samuel 30:31 And to those in Hebron, and in all the other places where David himself and his men had stayed.
1 Samuel 31:1 The Philistines were fighting against Israel, and the men of Israel fled from the Philistines. Many of them were killed on Mount Gilboa.
1 Samuel 31:2 The Philistines attacked Saul and his sons. They killed Jonathan, Abinadab, and Malchishua, all sons of Saul.
1 Samuel 31:3 The battle raged fiercely around Saul. The archers, skilled with their bows, found him and wounded him severely with their arrows.
1 Samuel 31:4 Saul said to his armor-bearer: "Draw your sword and kill me, so that these uncircumcised Philistines do not come and kill me and make sport of me." But his armor-bearer refused, because he was terrified by the great fear. So Saul took his own sword and fell upon it.
1 Samuel 31:5 When his armor-bearer saw that Saul was dead, he also fell upon his own sword and died with him.
1 Samuel 31:6 So Saul died, along with his three sons, his armor-bearer, and all his men died together on that day.
1 Samuel 31:7 But the men of Israel who were on the other side of the valley, and those beyond the Jordan River, saw that the men of Israel had fled, and that Saul and his sons were dead. They abandoned their cities and fled. Then the Philistines came and settled in those places.
1 Samuel 31:8 On the next day, the Philistines came to strip the bodies of the slain. They found Saul and his three sons lying dead on Mount Gilboa.
1 Samuel 31:9 They cut off Saul's head and stripped him of his armor. Then they sent messengers throughout the Philistine land to announce the news in the temples of their idols and to their people.
1 Samuel 31:10 They placed Saul's armor in the temple of Astaroth, and they hung his body on the wall of Beth-shan.
1 Samuel 31:11 But when the inhabitants of Jabesh-Gilead heard what the Philistines had done to Saul,
1 Samuel 31:12 all their valiant men rose up and marched all night. They took the body of Saul and the bodies of his sons from the wall of Beth-shan. Then they came to Jabesh-Gilead and burned the bodies there.
1 Samuel 31:13 And they took their bones and buried them under a tamarisk tree in Jabesh, and they fasted for seven days.
2 Samuel 1:1 Now, after King Saul had died, David returned from his victory over the Amalekites. He then remained in Ziklag for two days.
2 Samuel 1:2 On the third day, a man appeared, coming from Saul's military camp. His clothes were torn, and dust covered his head, showing his distress and mourning. When he came to David, he fell on his face and prostrated himself in homage.
2 Samuel 1:3 David asked him: "Where do you come from?" And the man replied: "I have escaped from the Israelite camp."
2 Samuel 1:4 And David asked him: "What is this news you bring, what has happened? Tell me." The man said: "The people have fled from the battle, and many have fallen and died. Even King Saul and his son Jonathan have perished."
2 Samuel 1:5 David then asked the young man who was reporting this to him: "How do you know that Saul and his son Jonathan are dead?"
2 Samuel 1:6 And the young man who was bringing him the news said: "By chance, I came upon Mount Gilboa, and there was Saul, leaning upon his spear. The chariots and horsemen of the enemy were drawing closer to him."
2 Samuel 1:7 When Saul looked behind himself, he saw me and called out. When I answered him, saying, 'Here I am,' he spoke to me, saying: 'Kill me, for I am in great distress, and yet my life is still in me.'"
2 Samuel 1:8 He said to me: 'Who are you?' And I said to him: 'I am an Amalekite.'
2 Samuel 1:9 And he spoke to me, saying: 'Kill me, for I am in great distress, and yet my life is still in me.'
2 Samuel 1:10 So I stood over him and killed him, for I knew that he could not survive his fall. Then I took the crown from his head and the bracelet from his arm, and I have brought them here to you, my lord."
2 Samuel 1:11 Then David seized his own clothes and tore them, and all the men who were with him did likewise as a sign of deep mourning.
2 Samuel 1:12 And they mourned, and wept, and fasted until evening over Saul, and over his son Jonathan, and over the people of the Lord, and over the house of Israel, because they had fallen by the sword in battle.
2 Samuel 1:13 Then David asked the young man who had brought him the news: "Where are you from?" He replied: "I am the son of a foreign man, an Amalekite."
2 Samuel 1:14 And David said to him: "Why were you not afraid to lay your hand on the Lord's anointed and kill him?" This means David was asking why the man wasn't afraid to violate God's sacred order.
2 Samuel 1:15 Then David called one of his young men and said: "Go near and execute him." So the young man struck him down, and he died.
2 Samuel 1:16 And David said to the Amalekite: "Your blood is on your own head, for your own mouth testified against you when you said: 'I killed the Lord's anointed.'"
2 Samuel 1:17 Then David chanted this lament over Saul and over his son Jonathan.
2 Samuel 1:18 And he commanded that the children of Judah be taught this lament, which is recorded in the Book of Jashar, a collection of heroic deeds.
2 Samuel 1:19 O, the glory of Israel lies slain upon your mountains, O Gilboa! How have the mighty fallen?
2 Samuel 1:20 Do not declare it in Gath, nor announce it in the streets of Ashkelon, lest the daughters of the Philistines rejoice, lest the daughters of the uncircumcised triumph.
2 Samuel 1:21 O mountains of Gilboa, may no dew or rain fall upon you, nor may there be fields that yield first fruits. For there, the shield of the mighty was cast away, the shield of Saul, as if it had never been anointed with oil for battle.
2 Samuel 1:22 From the blood of the slain, from the fat of the mighty warriors, the arrow of Jonathan never turned back without striking, and the sword of Saul never returned empty.
2 Samuel 1:23 Saul and Jonathan, beloved and beautiful in their lives, even in death they were not separated. They were swifter than eagles, stronger than lions.
2 Samuel 1:24 O daughters of Israel, weep over Saul, who clothed you in scarlet and finery, who adorned your garments with ornaments of gold.
2 Samuel 1:25 How have the mighty fallen in battle? Jonathan lies slain on your high places.
2 Samuel 1:26 I grieve for you, my brother Jonathan. You were exceedingly delightful to me, and your love for me was more precious than the love of women. Just as a mother loves her only son, so I cherished you.
2 Samuel 1:27 How have the mighty fallen, and the weapons of war perished?
2 Samuel 1:1 After Saul had died, David returned from his conquest of the Amalekites, and he stayed in Ziklag for two days.
2 Samuel 1:2 And on the third day, a man appeared. He was coming from Saul's camp. His clothes were torn, and his head was covered with dust. When he came to David, he fell on his face and prostrated himself in homage.
2 Samuel 1:3 David asked him, "Where are you coming from?" The man replied to him, "I have fled from the camp of Israel."
2 Samuel 1:4 David said to him, "What news has happened? Tell me." The man replied, "The people have fled from the battle, and many have fallen and died. Even Saul and his son Jonathan are dead."
2 Samuel 1:5 David said to the young man who was bringing him the news, "How do you know that Saul and his son Jonathan are dead?"
2 Samuel 1:6 The young man who was bringing the news said, "By chance, I came upon Mount Gilboa. Saul was leaning upon his spear, while chariots and horsemen were drawing near to him."
2 Samuel 1:7 "When he looked behind himself, he saw me and called out. I replied, 'Here I am.'"
2 Samuel 1:8 "He said to me, 'Who are you?' I answered him, 'I am an Amalekite.'"
2 Samuel 1:9 "He said to me, 'Stand over me and kill me, because great anguish holds me, and my life is still completely within me.'"
2 Samuel 1:10 "So, standing over him, I killed him, for I knew that he could not live after his fall. I then took the crown from his head and the armlet from his arm, and I have brought them here to you, my lord."
2 Samuel 1:11 Then David took hold of his own clothes and tore them. All the men who were with him did the same.
2 Samuel 1:12 They lamented and wept and fasted until evening over Saul, and over his son Jonathan, and over the Lord's people, and over the house of Israel, because they had died in battle.
2 Samuel 1:13 David then said to the young man who had brought him the news, "Where are you from?" He answered, "I am the son of a foreigner, an Amalekite."
2 Samuel 1:14 David said to him, "Why did you not fear to stretch out your hand to kill the Lord's anointed?"
2 Samuel 1:15 Then David called one of his young men, saying, "Come here and strike him down." The young man struck him, and he died.
2 Samuel 1:16 David said to him, "Your blood is upon your own head. For your own mouth has testified against you, saying, 'I have killed the Lord's anointed.'"
2 Samuel 1:17 David then uttered this lamentation over Saul and over his son Jonathan:
2 Samuel 1:18 He commanded that the sons of Judah should be taught this lamentation, called 'the Bow.' Indeed, it is written in the Book of Jashar:
2 Samuel 1:19 "The glory of Israel is slain upon your mountains! How have the mighty fallen!"
2 Samuel 1:20 "Do not announce it in Gath, nor proclaim it in the streets of Ashkelon, lest the daughters of the Philistines rejoice, lest the daughters of the uncircumcised triumph."
2 Samuel 1:21 "O mountains of Gilboa, may no dew nor rain come upon you, nor fields that bear offerings, for there the shield of the mighty was cast away—the shield of Saul, as if he had not been anointed with oil."
2 Samuel 1:22 "From the blood of the slain, from the fat of the mighty, the arrow of Jonathan never returned without striking, and the sword of Saul never returned empty."
2 Samuel 1:23 "Saul and Jonathan, beloved and beautiful in their lives, in death also they were not divided. They were swifter than eagles, and stronger than lions."
2 Samuel 1:24 "O daughters of Israel, weep over Saul, who clothed you in luxurious scarlet and provided golden ornaments for your garments."
2 Samuel 1:25 "How have the mighty fallen in battle! Jonathan is slain upon your high places!"
2 Samuel 1:26 "I grieve for you, my brother Jonathan, most beautiful, and more beloved than all the love of women, a love that surpassed even romantic love."
2 Samuel 1:27 "How have the mighty fallen, and how have the weapons of war perished!"
2 Samuel 2:1 After this, David consulted the Lord, saying: "Should I go up to one of the cities of Judah?" And the Lord said to him: "Go up." Then David asked again: "Where should I go up?" And the Lord answered him: "To Hebron."
2 Samuel 2:2 So David went up there, along with his two wives: Achinoam from Jezreel, and Abigail, who had been the wife of Nabal of Carmel.
2 Samuel 2:3 And David also brought the men who were with him, each with his family, and they settled in the cities around Hebron.
2 Samuel 2:4 Then the men of Judah came and anointed David there to reign over the house of Judah. And it was reported to David that the men of Jabesh-Gilead had buried Saul.
2 Samuel 2:5 So David sent messengers to the men of Jabesh-Gilead and said to them: "May you be blessed by the Lord, because you showed this kindness to your lord Saul by burying him."
2 Samuel 2:6 And now, may the Lord repay you with kindness and truth. And I myself will also reward you with good because you have done this deed.
2 Samuel 2:7 Therefore, strengthen your hands and be courageous men, for your lord Saul is dead, and the house of Judah has anointed me as their king.
2 Samuel 2:8 However, Abner, the son of Ner, who was the commander of Saul's army, took Ishbosheth, Saul's son, and brought him into a fortified camp.
2 Samuel 2:9 And he made him king over Gilead, and over the Ashurites, and over Jezreel, and over Ephraim, and over Benjamin, and over all of Israel.
2 Samuel 2:10 Ishbosheth, Saul's son, was forty years old when he began to reign over Israel, and he reigned for two years. Only the house of Judah followed David.
2 Samuel 2:11 And the number of days that David reigned in Hebron over the house of Judah was seven years and six months.
2 Samuel 2:12 Then Abner, the son of Ner, and the men of Ishbosheth, Saul's son, went out from the fortified camp to Gibeon.
2 Samuel 2:13 And Joab, the son of Zeruiah, and David's men went out from Hebron. They met them by the pool of Gibeon, and when they had gathered in one place, some sat on one side of the pool, and the others sat on the opposite side.
2 Samuel 2:14 Then Abner said to Joab: "Let the young men rise up and fight before us." And Joab answered: "Let them rise up."
2 Samuel 2:15 So they rose up: twelve men chosen by David, and twelve men from Benjamin who fought for Ishbosheth, Saul's son.
2 Samuel 2:16 And each man grasped his opponent's head and thrust his sword into his adversary, and they all fell down together. So the name of that place was called Helkath Hazzurim, which is in Gibeon.
2 Samuel 2:17 And a very fierce battle took place on that day, and Abner and the men of Israel were struck down by David's men.
2 Samuel 2:18 Now there were three sons of Zeruiah there: Joab, and Abishai, and Asahel. Asahel was as swift of foot as one of the wild gazelles.
2 Samuel 2:19 Asahel pursued Abner and did not turn to the right or to the left, following closely behind Abner.
2 Samuel 2:20 So Abner turned around, looking back, and said: "Are you Asahel?" And he answered: "I am."
2 Samuel 2:21 And Abner said to him: "Turn away from pursuing me and seize one of the younger men, and take his spoils for yourself." But Asahel would not leave him, but continued to press after him.
2 Samuel 2:22 Again Abner spoke to Asahel, saying: "Turn away, do not pursue me, lest I be compelled to strike you down to the ground. Then I would not be able to look your brother Joab in the face."
2 Samuel 2:23 But Asahel, refusing to turn away, was struck by Abner in the stomach, below the armpit, and died there. And everyone who came to the place where Asahel had fallen and died stopped.
2 Samuel 2:24 Then Joab and Abishai pursued Abner. When the sun was setting, they came to the hill of Ammah, which is opposite the valley and the road to the desert of Gibeon.
2 Samuel 2:25 However, the sons of Benjamin gathered together with Abner and formed a single company, standing on the top of a hill.
2 Samuel 2:26 Then Abner cried out to Joab and said: "Will your sword rage until complete destruction? Do you not know that desperation is dangerous? How long will you not tell the people to stop pursuing their brothers?"
2 Samuel 2:27 And Joab said: "As the Lord lives, if you had spoken, all the people would have stopped pursuing their brothers from early morning."
2 Samuel 2:28 Then Joab blew the trumpet, and all the army stopped. They no longer pursued Israel, nor did they fight any more.
2 Samuel 2:29 But Abner and his men marched through the plain all that night. They crossed the Jordan, and after passing through all of Beth-horon, they came to their fortified camp.
2 Samuel 2:30 Joab also returned, abandoning the pursuit of Abner, and gathered all the army. Nineteen men from David's followers were missing, besides Asahel.
2 Samuel 2:31 However, David's men had struck down three hundred and sixty men from Benjamin and from Abner's men, all of whom died.
2 Samuel 2:32 And they took Asahel and buried him in the tomb of his father in Bethlehem. Then Joab and his men traveled all night, and dawn broke for them in Hebron.
2 Samuel 2:1 After these events, David sought guidance from the Lord, asking, 'Should I go up to one of the cities of Judah?' And the Lord spoke to him, saying, 'Go up.' David then asked, 'Where should I go up?' And the Lord said, 'To Hebron.'
2 Samuel 2:2 So David went up, along with his two wives: Ahinoam, the woman from Jezreel, and Abigail, the wife of Nabal the Carmelite.
2 Samuel 2:3 David also brought the men who were with him, each with their own household, and they settled in the various towns within the region of Hebron.
2 Samuel 2:4 Then the men of Judah came and anointed David there to be king over the house of Judah. And it was reported to David that the men of Jabesh-Gilead had buried Saul.
2 Samuel 2:5 So David sent messengers to the men of Jabesh-Gilead, and said to them: 'May you be blessed by the Lord, you who have shown such loyalty to your lord Saul, by burying him.'
2 Samuel 2:6 And now, may the Lord repay you with His grace and faithfulness. Indeed, I myself will also reward you with good, because you have done this deed.
2 Samuel 2:7 Therefore, strengthen your hands, and be strong, courageous men. For your lord Saul is dead, and the house of Judah has anointed me as their king.
2 Samuel 2:8 Now Abner, the son of Ner, who was the commander of Saul’s army, took Ishbosheth, Saul’s son, and brought him through the encampments of Israel.
2 Samuel 2:9 And Abner made Ishbosheth king over Gilead, and over the Geshurites, and over Jezreel, and over Ephraim, and over Benjamin, and over all of the tribes of Israel outside of Judah.
2 Samuel 2:10 Ishbosheth, Saul’s son, was forty years old when he began to reign over Israel, and he reigned for two years. Only the house of Judah followed David.
2 Samuel 2:11 And the total number of days that David reigned in Hebron over the house of Judah was seven years and six months.
2 Samuel 2:12 Then Abner, the son of Ner, along with the servants of Ishbosheth, Saul’s son, went out from Mahanaim to Gibeon.
2 Samuel 2:13 And Joab, the son of Zeruiah, along with David’s servants, went out from Hebron. They met Abner and his men by the Pool of Gibeon, and they sat down, some on one side of the pool, and some on the other.
2 Samuel 2:14 And Abner said to Joab, 'Let the young men rise and play a contest before us.' And Joab responded, 'Let them rise.'
2 Samuel 2:15 So they rose and passed over: twelve men from Benjamin, from the side of Ishbosheth, Saul’s son, and twelve of David’s servants.
2 Samuel 2:16 Each man grabbed his opponent by the head, and they thrust their swords into each other's sides, so they all fell down together and died. And the name of that place was called 'Field of Swords' or 'Field of Sharp Edges' in Gibeon, commemorating this bloody duel.
2 Samuel 2:17 And a very fierce battle ensued on that day, and Abner and the men of Israel were defeated and fled from David’s servants.
2 Samuel 2:18 Now the three sons of Zeruiah were there: Joab, Abishai, and Asahel. And Asahel was as swift of foot as a gazelle in the open fields.
2 Samuel 2:19 Asahel pursued Abner, and he did not turn to the right or to the left from chasing after Abner.
2 Samuel 2:20 So Abner looked back over his shoulder and said, 'Are you Asahel?' And he answered, 'I am.'
2 Samuel 2:21 And Abner said to him, 'Turn aside to the right or to the left, and seize one of the younger men and take his armor and plunder for yourself.' But Asahel was unwilling to turn back from him, and Abner continued to insist that he stop chasing him.
2 Samuel 2:22 Abner spoke again to Asahel, saying, 'Stop pursuing me! I do not want to be forced to strike you down to the ground. If I do, how could I ever face your brother Joab again, knowing I killed his brother?'
2 Samuel 2:23 But Asahel disdained to listen and would not turn aside. So Abner struck him in the stomach with the butt-end of his spear, and Asahel was pierced through and died in that very spot. And all who passed by the place where Asahel’s body lay, stopped and gathered there.
2 Samuel 2:24 However, Joab and Abishai pursued Abner. And the sun had set when they reached the hill of Ammah, which is opposite Giah, on the way to the wilderness of Gibeon.
2 Samuel 2:25 And so the sons of Benjamin gathered together with Abner; they formed one compact fighting unit and took a stand on the top of a small hill.
2 Samuel 2:26 And Abner called out to Joab, saying, 'Will your sword rage on to utter destruction forever? Do you not know that desperation is dangerous? How long will it be until you tell the people to stop pursuing their own brothers, the people of Israel?'
2 Samuel 2:27 And Joab said, 'As the Lord lives, if you had not spoken up, then by morning all the people would have seen that each man would have abandoned his pursuit of his brother.'
2 Samuel 2:28 Then Joab sounded the trumpet, and all the army stood still. They no longer pursued Israel, nor did they fight any longer.
2 Samuel 2:29 But Abner and his men marched through the valley all that night, and they crossed the Jordan River. They journeyed through all of Beth-Horon, and then they came to Mahanaim.
2 Samuel 2:30 Joab also returned from pursuing Abner and gathered all the army. And nineteen men were missing from David’s servants, besides Asahel, who was already accounted for.
2 Samuel 2:31 But David’s servants had struck down three hundred and sixty men from Benjamin and from Abner’s men, and all of those men were dead.
2 Samuel 2:32 Then they took Asahel and buried him in his father’s tomb in Bethlehem. And Joab and the men who were with him marched all night, and the sun rose upon them as they arrived in Hebron.
2 Samuel 3:1 There was a long war between Saul's royal house and David's royal house. David was making progress and becoming stronger, but Saul's royal house was losing power every day.
2 Samuel 3:2 Sons were born to David in Hebron. His firstborn was Amnon, born of Ahinoam from Jezreel.
2 Samuel 3:3 His second son was Chileab, born of Abigail, who had been Nabal the Carmelite's wife. And his third son was Absalom, the son of Maacah, who was the daughter of Talmai, king of Geshur.
2 Samuel 3:4 His fourth son was Adonijah, the son of Haggith. And his fifth son was Shephatiah, the son of Abital.
2 Samuel 3:5 His sixth son was Ithream, born of Eglah, another of David's wives. These sons were all born to David in Hebron.
2 Samuel 3:6 During the war between Saul's royal house and David's royal house, Abner, son of Ner, who was the commander of Saul's army, grew very powerful in support of Saul's house.
2 Samuel 3:7 Now Saul had a concubine named Rizpah, daughter of Aiah. And Ish-bosheth, Saul's son and successor, asked Abner, "Why did you have relations with my father's concubine?"
2 Samuel 3:8 Abner became very angry over Ish-bosheth's words and responded, "Am I a dog's head from Judah? I am the one showing loyalty to the house of your father Saul today, and to his brothers and his friends, and I have not handed you over to David's power. Yet today you accuse me of a sin concerning a woman?"
2 Samuel 3:9 Then Abner swore an oath, saying, "May God do so to Abner, and even more, if I do not act according to what the Lord swore to David and make it happen for him.
2 Samuel 3:10 My goal is to transfer the kingdom from Saul's royal house and establish David's throne over both Israel and Judah, from Dan in the north to Beersheba in the south."
2 Samuel 3:11 Ish-bosheth could not say another word to Abner, because he was afraid of him.
2 Samuel 3:12 So Abner sent messengers to David, on his own behalf, saying, "To whom does the land truly belong?" He also said, "Make a covenant with me, and my hand will be with you, and I will bring all of Israel to you."
2 Samuel 3:13 David replied, "Good. I will make a covenant with you, but I demand one thing from you. You will not see my face unless you first bring Michal, Saul's daughter, when you come to see me."
2 Samuel 3:14 David then sent messengers to Ish-bosheth, Saul's son, saying, "Return my wife Michal to me, whom I acquired as my betrothed by providing one hundred foreskins of the Philistines."
2 Samuel 3:15 So Ish-bosheth sent men and took her away from her husband, Paltiel, the son of Laish.
2 Samuel 3:16 Her husband followed her, weeping, all the way to Bahurim. But Abner said to him, "Go back now; turn around." And so he went back.
2 Samuel 3:17 Abner had also spoken to the elders of Israel, saying, "For a long time now, you have desired David to reign over you.
2 Samuel 3:18 Now therefore, act upon it. For the Lord has spoken concerning David, saying, 'By the hand of my servant David, I will save my people Israel from the hand of the Philistines and from all their enemies.'"
2 Samuel 3:19 Abner also spoke directly to the tribe of Benjamin. Then he went to David in Hebron to report everything that pleased Israel and the entire house of Benjamin.
2 Samuel 3:20 So Abner came to David in Hebron with twenty men. And David prepared a feast for Abner and the men who had come with him.
2 Samuel 3:21 Abner said to David, "I will rise and gather all Israel to you, my lord the king, so that they may make a covenant with you, and you may rule over all of them, just as your heart desires." Then David sent Abner away, and he departed in peace.
2 Samuel 3:22 Just as David's servants and Joab returned from a successful raid, bringing much plunder, they found that Abner was no longer in Hebron. Indeed, David had sent him away, and he had departed in peace.
2 Samuel 3:23 Joab went in to the king and said, "What have you done? Look, Abner came to you; why did you let him leave and depart?
2 Samuel 3:24 You don't know Abner, son of Ner, that he came to you only to deceive you, to find out your movements, your comings and goings, and everything you are doing?"
2 Samuel 3:25 And Joab, having left David's presence, sent messengers after Abner, and they brought him back from the cistern of Sirah, without David knowing it.
2 Samuel 3:26 When Abner returned to Hebron, Joab led him aside to the gate, as if to speak to him privately, and there he struck him in the side, and he died. This was for the blood of Asahel, Joab's brother, whom Abner had killed in battle.
2 Samuel 3:27 After this, David heard the news and declared, "I am innocent, and my kingdom is innocent before the Lord forever, of the blood of Abner, son of Ner.
2 Samuel 3:28 May his blood come upon the head of Joab and upon all his father's house. May there never cease from Joab's house someone with a discharge, or a leper, or one who holds a spindle (a woman's work, implying weakness), or one who falls by the sword, or one who lacks bread."
2 Samuel 3:29 So Joab and Abishai, his brother, killed Abner because he had killed Asahel, their brother, in the battle at Gibeon.
2 Samuel 3:30 Then David commanded Joab and all the people who were with him, "Tear your clothes, put on sackcloth, and mourn before Abner." And King David himself followed the bier.
2 Samuel 3:31 They buried Abner in Hebron. The king raised his voice and wept at Abner's tomb. And all the people also wept.
2 Samuel 3:32 And all the people tried to persuade David to eat some food. But David swore an oath, saying, "May God do so to me, and even more, if I taste bread or anything else before the sun sets."
2 Samuel 3:33 All the people took notice of this, and they were pleased. For everything the king did was pleasing in the sight of all the people.
2 Samuel 3:34 And all the people and all Israel understood that day that the king had not been responsible for the killing of Abner, son of Ner.
2 Samuel 3:35 The king said to his servants, weeping, "Do you not know that a prince, a very great man, has fallen this day in Israel?"
2 Samuel 3:36 David continued, "Even though I am anointed by God, I feel weak and vulnerable today, and these men, the sons of Zeruiah, are too severe for me. May the Lord repay the evildoer according to his wickedness."
2 Samuel 3:37 And all the people and all Israel knew that day that it was not by the king's doing that Abner, son of Ner, was killed.
2 Samuel 3:38 The king had also said to his servants, "Do you not know that a prince and a great man has fallen today in Israel?"
2 Samuel 3:39 Furthermore, I am delicate (vulnerable) today, though I am an anointed king. And these men, the sons of Zeruiah, are too harsh for me. May the Lord repay the one who does evil according to his wickedness.
2 Samuel 3:1 So there was a long war between the royal house of Saul and the royal house of David. David grew in strength and became ever more powerful, while the house of Saul weakened daily.
2 Samuel 3:2 Sons were born to David in Hebron. His firstborn was Amnon, born from Ahinoam, the Jezreelitess.
2 Samuel 3:3 His second son was Chileab, born from Abigail, Nabal the Carmelite's widow. His third son was Absalom, born from Maacah, who was the daughter of Talmai, king of Geshur.
2 Samuel 3:4 His fourth son was Adonijah, born from Haggith. His fifth son was Shephatiah, born from Abital.
2 Samuel 3:5 And his sixth son was Ithream, born from Eglah, another one of David's wives. These sons were all born to David in Hebron, while he reigned there.
2 Samuel 3:6 While the war was ongoing between the house of Saul and the house of David, Abner, son of Ner, who was the commander of Saul's army, acted with increasing defiance on behalf of Saul's house.
2 Samuel 3:7 Now Saul had had a concubine named Rizpah, daughter of Aiah. And Ish-bosheth accused Abner, saying, "Why did you sleep with my father's concubine? That makes you a claimant to his throne."
2 Samuel 3:8 Abner became extremely angry because of Ish-bosheth's words and responded, "Am I a dog's head, deserving of such an insult? This very day I am loyal to Judah! I have shown mercy to the house of your father Saul, and to his brothers and kinsmen, and I haven't handed you over to David's control! Yet you accuse me today of a sin with a woman?"
2 Samuel 3:9 Abner swore an oath, saying, "May God do this to Abner, and more also, if I do not act exactly as the Lord swore to David."
2 Samuel 3:10 "That is, I will transfer the kingdom from the house of Saul and establish David's throne over all of Israel and Judah, from Dan in the north to Beersheba in the south."
2 Samuel 3:11 Ish-bosheth could not answer Abner a single word because he was afraid of him.
2 Samuel 3:12 So Abner immediately sent messengers to David, saying on his own behalf, "To whom does the land truly belong? Make a covenant with me, and behold, I am ready to help you turn all of Israel over to your rule."
2 Samuel 3:13 David replied, "Good, I will make a covenant with you. But I demand one thing from you: you will not see my face unless you first bring Michal, Saul's daughter, when you come to see me."
2 Samuel 3:14 David also sent messengers to Ish-bosheth, Saul's son, saying, "Give me back my wife Michal, whom I betrothed to myself for the price of one hundred Philistine foreskins."
2 Samuel 3:15 So Ish-bosheth sent for her and took her away from her husband, Paltiel, son of Laish.
2 Samuel 3:16 Her husband followed her, weeping as he went, all the way to Bahurim. Abner said to him, "Go back!" So he returned.
2 Samuel 3:17 Abner also spoke to the elders of Israel, saying, "Both yesterday and the day before, you were seeking to have David reign over you."
2 Samuel 3:18 "Now therefore, act upon it, for the Lord has spoken concerning David, saying, 'By the hand of My servant David I will save My people Israel from the hand of the Philistines and from the hand of all their enemies.'"
2 Samuel 3:19 Abner also spoke to the tribe of Benjamin. Then he went to speak to David in Hebron, conveying all that had pleased Israel and the entire tribe of Benjamin.
2 Samuel 3:20 So Abner came to David in Hebron, with twenty men accompanying him. David held a feast for Abner and the men who had come with him.
2 Samuel 3:21 Abner said to David, "I will go now and gather all Israel to you, my lord the king, so that they may make a covenant with you, and you may rule over all of them, just as your heart desires." David then sent Abner away, and he departed in peace.
2 Samuel 3:22 Just then, David's servants and Joab returned from a raid, bringing many spoils with them. Abner, however, was no longer with David in Hebron, because David had sent him away, and he had departed in peace.
2 Samuel 3:23 When Joab arrived, he was told, "Abner, son of Ner, came to the king, and the king sent him away, and he departed in peace."
2 Samuel 3:24 Joab went in to the king and asked, "What have you done? Look, Abner came to you! Why did you send him away so that he just left?"
2 Samuel 3:25 "Don't you know Abner, son of Ner? He came to you only to deceive you, to learn your coming and going, and to discover all your plans."
2 Samuel 3:26 After Joab left David, he sent messengers after Abner, and they brought him back from the well of Sirah, but David did not know about it.
2 Samuel 3:27 When Abner returned to Hebron, Joab took him aside inside the gate, as if to speak to him privately. There, Joab stabbed him in the stomach, and he died, in revenge for the blood of Asahel, Joab's brother.
2 Samuel 3:28 When David heard of it afterward, he declared, "I and my kingdom are innocent before the Lord forever concerning the blood of Abner, son of Ner."
2 Samuel 3:29 "May the guilt for Abner's death fall upon the head of Joab and upon all his father's house. May the house of Joab never lack someone afflicted with a discharge, or a leper, or one who holds a distaff, or one who falls by the sword, or one who lacks bread."
2 Samuel 3:30 So Joab and his brother Abishai killed Abner because Abner had killed their brother Asahel in battle at Gibeon.
2 Samuel 3:31 Then David commanded Joab and all the people who were with him, saying, "Tear your clothes, put on sackcloth, and mourn before Abner." And King David himself followed the bier.
2 Samuel 3:32 When they had buried Abner in Hebron, the king lifted his voice and wept at Abner's tomb. All the people also wept.
2 Samuel 3:33 And the king lamented and said, "Should Abner have died like a fool?"
2 Samuel 3:34 "Your hands were not bound, nor your feet shackled. You fell as a wicked man falls, before treacherous men." And all the people wept over him again.
2 Samuel 3:35 All the people came to offer David food while it was still daylight, but David swore an oath, saying, "May God do this to me and more also, if I taste bread or anything else before the sun sets."
2 Samuel 3:36 All the people understood this, and it pleased them; indeed, everything the king did was pleasing in the sight of all the people.
2 Samuel 3:37 So all the people and all of Israel understood that day that the killing of Abner, son of Ner, had not been the king's doing.
2 Samuel 3:38 The king also said to his servants, "Do you not know that a prince and a great man has fallen this day in Israel?"
2 Samuel 3:39 "And though I am still weak and newly anointed as king, these men, the sons of Zeruiah, are too harsh for me to control. May the Lord repay the evil-doer according to his wickedness."
2 Samuel 4:1 When Saul's son, Ishbaal, heard that Abner had died in Hebron, he lost all courage, and all of Israel was troubled by this news.
2 Samuel 4:2 Now, Saul's son had two captains of his raiding bands: one was named Baanah, and the other was Rechab. They were sons of Rimmon the Beerothite, of the tribe of Benjamin; Beeroth itself was also considered part of Benjamin.
2 Samuel 4:3 The Beerothites had fled to Gittaim and lived there as foreign residents up until that time.
2 Samuel 4:4 Now, Jonathan, Saul's son, had a son who was lame in his feet. He was five years old when the news came from Jezreel about Saul and Jonathan. His nurse picked him up and carried him, but as she hurried to flee, she fell, and he became lame. His name was Mephibosheth.
2 Samuel 4:5 So Rechab and Baanah, the sons of Rimmon the Beerothite, went and came to Ishbaal's house during the heat of the day. Ishbaal was sleeping on his bed at noon.
2 Samuel 4:6 And behold, the doorkeeper of the house, who was cleaning wheat, had fallen asleep. So these men, secretly bringing in their hands through the doorway, struck him in the stomach and fled.
2 Samuel 4:7 For when they had entered the house, he was sleeping on his bed in the inner chamber. They struck him and killed him. Then they took his head and went away by the desert road all night long.
2 Samuel 4:8 They brought the head of Ishbaal to David in Hebron and said to the king: 'Behold, here is the head of Ishbaal, son of Saul, your enemy, who sought to kill you. The Lord has today given our lord the king vengeance on Saul and his descendants.'
2 Samuel 4:9 But David answered Rechab and his brother Baanah, the sons of Rimmon the Beerothite, and said to them: 'As the Lord lives, who has rescued my life from all distress—'
2 Samuel 4:10 '—when someone told me that Saul was dead, thinking he was bringing good news, I seized him and killed him in Ziklag. That man thought he deserved a reward for his message!'
2 Samuel 4:11 'How much more then should I punish you, wicked men, who have killed a righteous man in his own house, on his own bed? Therefore, I will now demand his blood from your hands and remove you from the earth.'
2 Samuel 4:12 Then David commanded his young men, and they killed them. They cut off their hands and feet and hung their bodies over the pool in Hebron. But they took Ishbaal's head and buried it in Abner's tomb in Hebron.
2 Samuel 4:1 But Ishbosheth, who was Saul’s son, heard the news that Abner had been killed in Hebron. Ishbosheth then became utterly powerless to act, and all of Israel became fearful and in turmoil.
2 Samuel 4:2 Now, two men who were commanders of raiding parties were serving Saul’s son. One was named Baanah and the other Rechab; they were the sons of Rimmon the Beerothite, of the tribe of Benjamin—for Beeroth was also accounted as part of Benjamin.
2 Samuel 4:3 The Beerothites had fled to Gittaim and had lived there as foreigners up until that very day.
2 Samuel 4:4 Jonathan, Saul’s son, had a son who was disabled in his feet. He was five years old when the news came from Jezreel about Saul and Jonathan’s deaths. His nurse picked him up and fled, but as she hurried to escape, he fell and became lame. His name was Meribbaal.
2 Samuel 4:5 So, Rechab and Baanah, the sons of Rimmon the Beerothite, set out and went into Ishbosheth’s house during the heat of the day, while he was taking his noonday nap.
2 Samuel 4:6 And behold, the woman who guarded the entrance to the house was sifting wheat and had fallen asleep. So, Rechab and his brother Baanah secretly entered, struck Ishbosheth in the stomach, and then fled.
2 Samuel 4:7 Indeed, when they had entered the house, Ishbosheth was sleeping on his bed in his inner chamber. They struck him and killed him. Then, taking his head, they departed by way of the desert road throughout the entire night.
2 Samuel 4:8 They brought Ishbosheth’s head to David in Hebron and said to the king, “Behold, here is the head of Ishbosheth, the son of Saul, your enemy, who sought your life. Today, the Lord has granted vengeance to my lord the king against Saul and his descendants.”
2 Samuel 4:9 David answered Rechab and his brother Baanah, the sons of Rimmon the Beerothite, and said to them, “As the Lord lives, who has delivered my soul from all distress and trouble—”
2 Samuel 4:10 “—for the man who announced to me that Saul was dead, thinking he was bringing good news, I seized him and killed him in Ziklag. I should have given him a reward for his message, but instead, he died for it.”
2 Samuel 4:11 “How much more, then, when wicked men have murdered an innocent man in his own home, on his own bed, shall I not demand his blood from your hands and utterly remove you from the face of the earth?”
2 Samuel 4:12 So David commanded his young men, and they executed them. They cut off their hands and feet and hung their bodies by the pool in Hebron. But Ishbosheth’s head they took and buried in Abner’s tomb in Hebron.
2 Samuel 5:1 All the tribes of Israel gathered with David in Hebron, and they said: "Look, we are your own kin—your bone and your flesh."
2 Samuel 5:2 Even before now, and for some time past, when Saul was king over us, you were the one who led Israel into battle and brought them back safely. And the Lord Himself spoke to you, saying: "You will shepherd My people, Israel, and you will be a leader over Israel."
2 Samuel 5:3 Then all the elders of Israel also came to King David in Hebron. And King David made a covenant with them in Hebron, in the presence of the Lord. And they anointed David as king over all Israel.
2 Samuel 5:4 David was forty years old when he began his reign, and he reigned for forty years in total.
2 Samuel 5:5 In Hebron, David reigned over Judah alone for seven years and six months. Then in Jerusalem, he reigned for thirty-three years over both all of Israel and Judah.
2 Samuel 5:6 Then the king and all the men who were with him went to Jerusalem, where the Jebusites lived. And the Jebusites said to David: "You will not enter here unless you defeat even the blind and the lame." They were taunting David by saying: "David will not be able to enter here!"
2 Samuel 5:7 But David captured the stronghold of Zion. This stronghold later became known as the City of David.
2 Samuel 5:8 For David had said on that day: "Whoever is able to strike down the Jebusites, let him go up through the water shaft to reach these lame and blind ones who so hate David's soul." Because of this, it is said in a proverb: "The blind and the lame will not enter the house of the Lord." The Jebusites' taunt came back to bite them.
2 Samuel 5:9 So David lived in the stronghold and called it the City of David. And David built up the city around it, from the Millo—a defensive structure—inward.
2 Samuel 5:10 And David continued to prosper and grew ever more powerful, because the Lord, the God of all creation and armies, was with him.
2 Samuel 5:11 Hiram, the king of Tyre, also sent messengers to David, along with cedar timber, and carpenters and stonemasons. And they built a royal palace for David.
2 Samuel 5:12 And David knew with certainty that the Lord had firmly established him as king over all Israel, and that He had greatly exalted David's kingdom over His own people, Israel.
2 Samuel 5:13 After David had come from Hebron to Jerusalem, he also took more wives and concubines from Jerusalem, and sons and daughters were born to him there.
2 Samuel 5:14 And these are the names of the children who were born to him in Jerusalem: Shammua, Shobab, Nathan, and Solomon,
2 Samuel 5:15 Also Ibhar, Elishua, Nepheg, and Japhia,
2 Samuel 5:16 And Elishama, Elioda, and Eliphalet.
2 Samuel 5:17 Now the Philistines heard that David had been anointed king over Israel, and all the Philistines went up to seek out David for battle. When David heard this, he went down to a secure defensive position.
2 Samuel 5:18 But the Philistines came and spread out through the Valley of Rephaim.
2 Samuel 5:19 And David consulted the Lord, saying: "Should I go up against the Philistines? Will You give them into my hand?" And the Lord answered David: "Go up, for I will certainly give the Philistines into your hand."
2 Samuel 5:20 So David came to Baal Perazim, and David struck down the Philistines there. Then David said: "The Lord has broken through my enemies before me, just as a powerful flood breaks through a barrier." Therefore, the name of that place was called Baal Perazim, meaning "Lord of Breakings Through."
2 Samuel 5:21 And the Philistines abandoned their idols there, which David and his men then carried away.
2 Samuel 5:22 But the Philistines came up again, and once more they spread out through the Valley of Rephaim.
2 Samuel 5:23 And David consulted the Lord again, who answered: "You shall not attack them directly. Instead, circle around behind them, and come at them from the direction of the mulberry trees."
2 Samuel 5:24 And when you hear the sound of marching in the tops of the mulberry trees, that will be your signal to launch the attack. For then the Lord Himself will go out before you to strike down the camp of the Philistines.
2 Samuel 5:25 So David did exactly as the Lord had commanded him, and he struck down the Philistines, driving them from Geba all the way to Gezer.
2 Samuel 5:1 So all the leaders and representatives from the tribes of Israel came to David in Hebron, saying to him, 'Look, we are your own flesh and blood, your very kin.'
2 Samuel 5:2 Even before this, when Saul was still king over us, you were the one who led the people of Israel in and out of battle. And the Lord God himself said to you: 'You will shepherd My people Israel, and you will be their true leader.'
2 Samuel 5:3 Therefore, all the elders of Israel also came to King David in Hebron. And David made a solemn covenant with them there in Hebron, in the very presence of the Lord God. Then they publicly anointed David as king over all Israel.
2 Samuel 5:4 David was thirty years old when he began his reign as king, and he reigned for a total of forty years.
2 Samuel 5:5 In Hebron, he reigned over the tribe of Judah for seven years and six months. Afterwards, in Jerusalem, he reigned over all of both Israel and Judah for thirty-three years.
2 Samuel 5:6 Then the king and all the men who were with him went to Jerusalem, to the Jebusites who inhabited that land. The Jebusites defiantly said to David, 'You will not enter this place! Even the blind and the lame can drive you out,' mockingly asserting, 'David will never enter here!'
2 Samuel 5:7 Nevertheless, David successfully captured the stronghold of Zion. This place became known as the City of David.
2 Samuel 5:8 For David had declared on that day: 'Whoever strikes down a Jebusite must ascend through the water shaft and attack these blind and lame ones who are so hated by David's soul.' This is why it is said in a proverb: 'The blind and the lame will not enter the holy place.'
2 Samuel 5:9 So David took up residence in the stronghold, and he named it the City of David. Then David built walls and fortifications all around the city, from the Millo inward.
2 Samuel 5:10 And David continued to prosper, growing in power and becoming highly esteemed, because the Lord God of hosts—the God of armies—was with him.
2 Samuel 5:11 Hiram, the king of Tyre, also sent messengers to David, along with cedar timber, carpenters, and stonemasons. And these skilled craftsmen built a royal palace for David.
2 Samuel 5:12 And David understood that the Lord God had firmly established him as king over all Israel, and that He had greatly exalted his kingdom for the sake of His people Israel.
2 Samuel 5:13 After he came from Hebron, David also took more concubines and wives from Jerusalem. And more sons and daughters were born to him there.
2 Samuel 5:14 These are the names of the children who were born to him in Jerusalem: Shammua, Shobab, Nathan, and Solomon.
2 Samuel 5:15 Ibhar, Elishua, and Nepheg.
2 Samuel 5:16 Japhia, Elishama, Eliada, and Eliphalet.
2 Samuel 5:17 Now the Philistines heard that David had been anointed king over Israel, and all the Philistines came up to seek him out and fight. When David heard this, he went down to his stronghold—a secure place.
2 Samuel 5:18 Meanwhile, the Philistines had come and spread themselves out in the Valley of Rephaim.
2 Samuel 5:19 And David consulted the Lord God, saying, 'Should I go up against the Philistines? Will You hand them over into my power?' The Lord God said to David, 'Go up, for I will surely hand the Philistines over into your power.'
2 Samuel 5:20 So David came to Baal Perazim. There David struck them down and said, 'The Lord God has broken through my enemies before me, just as waters burst forth and divide!' Therefore, the name of that place was called Baal Perazim, meaning 'Lord of Breakthroughs'.
2 Samuel 5:21 And there the Philistines abandoned their idols. David and his men then carried these idols away.
2 Samuel 5:22 But the Philistines came up again and spread themselves out once more in the Valley of Rephaim.
2 Samuel 5:23 And David again consulted the Lord God. He responded, 'Do not go up directly against them. Instead, circle around behind them, and attack them from the front of the balsam trees.'
2 Samuel 5:24 And when you hear the sound of marching in the tops of the balsam trees, then you must rush forward, for at that very moment, the Lord God will go out before you to strike down the Philistine army.
2 Samuel 5:25 So David did just as the Lord God had commanded him. He struck down the Philistines all the way from Geba to Gezer.
