2 Samuel 6:1 So King David gathered together again all the chosen warriors of Israel, thirty thousand of them.
2 Samuel 6:2 David himself went up, and all the people with him, from among the men of Judah, to bring the Ark of God back. This Ark is where the very Name of the Lord of all Creation is called upon, the Lord who is enthroned above the Cherubim.
2 Samuel 6:3 They placed the Ark of God upon a new wagon, and they brought it out from the house of Abinadab, which was located on the hill. Uzzah and Ahio, Abinadab's sons, were driving this new wagon.
2 Samuel 6:4 As they carried it from Abinadab's house—Abinadab being the man who lived on the hill—Ahio walked ahead of the Ark.
2 Samuel 6:5 Meanwhile, King David and all Israel were joyfully celebrating before the Lord with all kinds of musical instruments made of fir wood: with harps, lyres, tambourines, sistrums, and cymbals.
2 Samuel 6:6 But when they arrived at the threshing floor of Nachon, Uzzah reached out his hand to the Ark of God and took hold of it, because the oxen stumbled and had nearly overturned it.
2 Samuel 6:7 And the Lord became angry with Uzzah, and He struck him down there for his rash irreverence. So Uzzah died there beside the Ark of God.
2 Samuel 6:8 David was saddened because the Lord had struck Uzzah in this way. And he named that place 'The Striking of Uzzah,' a name it holds even to this present day.
2 Samuel 6:9 David then greatly feared the Lord on that day, saying: "How can the Ark of the Lord possibly come to me now?"
2 Samuel 6:10 And David decided not to bring the Ark of the Lord into the City of David for himself. Instead, he diverted it to the house of Obed-Edom, the Gittite.
2 Samuel 6:11 So the Ark of the Lord remained in the house of Obed-Edom, the Gittite, for three months. And the Lord blessed Obed-Edom and his entire household.
2 Samuel 6:12 It was reported to King David, with people saying: "The Lord has blessed Obed-Edom and all that belongs to him because of the Ark of God." So David went, and he brought the Ark of God from the house of Obed-Edom into the City of David with great joy.
2 Samuel 6:13 And when those who were carrying the Ark of the Lord had taken six steps, they sacrificed an ox and a ram as offerings to God.
2 Samuel 6:14 And David was dancing with all his might before the Lord. King David was dressed only in a linen ephod, a priestly garment.
2 Samuel 6:15 So David and all the house of Israel brought the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord into Jerusalem with joyful shouting and the blast of the trumpet.
2 Samuel 6:16 And when the Ark of the Lord entered the City of David, Michal, Saul's daughter, looked out through a window. She saw King David leaping and dancing before the Lord, and she despised him in her heart for his undignified behavior.
2 Samuel 6:17 They brought the Ark of the Lord inside and placed it in its designated spot, in the middle of the tent that David had pitched for it. Then David offered burnt offerings and peace offerings before the Lord.
2 Samuel 6:18 When David had finished offering the burnt offerings and the peace offerings, he blessed the people in the Name of the Lord of all Creation.
2 Samuel 6:19 Then he distributed to all the multitude of Israel, to both men and women, a loaf of bread, a portion of roasted meat, and a cake fried in oil to each person. And all the people departed, each to their own home.
2 Samuel 6:20 Then David returned to bless his own household. And Michal, Saul's daughter, came out to meet David and said: "How glorious the King of Israel made himself today! He exposed himself before the servant girls of his own servants, uncovering himself just as a vulgar fellow might shamelessly uncover himself!"
2 Samuel 6:21 And David said to Michal: "I was dancing before the Lord—the One who chose me rather than your father and rather than his entire house, and who commanded me to be a leader over the Lord's people in Israel. I will continue to celebrate and humble myself before the Lord!"
2 Samuel 6:22 I will even humble myself more than I did today, and I will be lowly in my own estimation. Yet, I will be held in honor by these very servant girls about whom you have spoken so scornfully.
2 Samuel 6:23 Therefore, Michal, Saul's daughter, had no child until the day of her death.
2 Samuel 6:1 David gathered again all the chosen men from Israel—30,000 men in total.
2 Samuel 6:2 And David arose and went with all the people who were with him, from the men of Judah, to bring up the Ark of God from that place. The Ark of God is the sacred object upon which the Most Holy Name of the Lord of armies is invoked, who is enthroned above the Cherubim on it.
2 Samuel 6:3 And they placed the Ark of God upon a new cart. Then they took it from the house of Abinadab, which was in Gibeah. Uzzah and Ahio, the sons of Abinadab, drove the new cart.
2 Samuel 6:4 And when they had taken it from the house of Abinadab, which was in Gibeah, Ahio walked in front of the Ark.
2 Samuel 6:5 But David and all of Israel were celebrating before the Lord with all sorts of instruments made of wood: harps, lyres, tambourines, sistrums, and cymbals.
2 Samuel 6:6 After they reached Nachon's threshing floor, the oxen stumbled and turned aside. So Uzzah stretched out his hand to the Ark of God and took hold of it to steady it.
2 Samuel 6:7 And the Lord was angry against Uzzah, and struck him for his rashness—touching the sacred Ark was forbidden—and he died there beside the Ark of God.
2 Samuel 6:8 And David was saddened because the Lord had struck Uzzah, and the name of that place has been called The Striking of Uzzah until the present day.
2 Samuel 6:9 And David was filled with reverential fear for the Lord that day, saying, 'How shall the Ark of the Lord come to me?'
2 Samuel 6:10 And he did not want to bring the Ark of the Lord to himself into the City of David, but diverted it to the house of Obededom the Gittite.
2 Samuel 6:11 Therefore, the Ark of the Lord remained in the house of Obededom the Gittite for three months, and the Lord bestowed blessings upon Obededom and all his household.
2 Samuel 6:12 And it was reported to King David, saying to him, 'The Lord has bestowed blessings upon Obededom and all his possessions because of the Ark of God.' So David went up and brought the Ark of the Lord from the house of Obededom into the City of David with joy.
2 Samuel 6:13 And when those who carried the Ark of the Lord had completed a space of six steps, they offered a bull and a ram as sacrifices—a ritual of purification and dedication.
2 Samuel 6:14 And David was dancing with great fervor before the Lord in worship. David was wearing a linen ephod, a priestly garment.
2 Samuel 6:15 And all of Israel was bringing up the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord with joyful shouts and with the sound of the trumpet.
2 Samuel 6:16 And when the Ark of the Lord came into the City of David, Michal, Saul's daughter, looked out through a window. She saw King David dancing and celebrating, and she scorned him in her heart.
2 Samuel 6:17 And they brought in the Ark of the Lord and set it in its place inside the tent that David had pitched for it. And David offered burnt offerings and peace offerings before the Lord.
2 Samuel 6:18 And when he had finished offering the burnt offerings and peace offerings, he invoked blessings upon the people in the name of the Lord of armies.
2 Samuel 6:19 And he distributed to the entire multitude of Israel, to both men and women, to each a loaf of bread, a portion of roasted beef, and a fried cake made with oil. Then all the people went, each to his own house.
2 Samuel 6:20 And David returned to bless his household. Michal, Saul's daughter, came out to meet David and said sarcastically, 'How splendid the king of Israel was today! He uncovered himself before the servant girls of his servants, as a common jester might uncover himself!'
2 Samuel 6:21 And David said to Michal, 'I was celebrating before the Lord! It was the Lord who chose me instead of your father and all his house. He commanded me to be a leader over the people of the Lord in Israel. Therefore, I will celebrate and rejoice and humble myself before the Lord.'
2 Samuel 6:22 'And I will humble myself even more than before, and I will be humble in my own eyes. And as for the servant girls about whom you spoke, I will be held in honor by them.'
2 Samuel 6:23 Therefore, Michal, Saul's daughter, had no child until the day of her death.
2 Samuel 7:1 It happened that the king was finally settled in his own home, and the Lord had given him peace and rest from all the enemies surrounding him from every side.
2 Samuel 7:2 He said to Nathan the prophet: 'Do you not see that I, David, live in a magnificent palace built with cedar wood, while the Ark of God still resides within mere tent fabrics?'
2 Samuel 7:3 Nathan replied to the king, 'Go ahead and do whatever is in your heart, for the Lord God is truly with you.'
2 Samuel 7:4 However, that very night, the word of the Lord came to Nathan, saying:
2 Samuel 7:5 'Go and say to My servant David: “Thus says the Lord God: Is it truly you who will build a house for Me to dwell in?
2 Samuel 7:6 For I have not lived in a permanent house since the day I brought the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt until this very day. Instead, I have moved around with them, dwelling in a tabernacle and a tent.
2 Samuel 7:7 Throughout all the places where I have traveled with all the children of Israel, did I ever speak a single word to any of the tribal leaders of Israel—whom I appointed to shepherd My people, Israel—saying, 'Why have you not built Me a house of cedar?'
2 Samuel 7:8 Therefore, now, you shall say this to My servant David: 'Thus says the Lord, God of all heavenly powers: I Myself took you from the pastures, where you were following the sheep, to be a prince and leader over My people Israel.
2 Samuel 7:9 And I have been with you in every place you have gone, and I have cut off all your enemies from before you. I have made your name great, like the names of the most powerful and famous rulers on the earth.
2 Samuel 7:10 I will also provide a secure place for My people Israel and establish them there, so that they will live in their own land and no longer be disturbed. Wicked people will not oppress them again, as they did from the beginning,
2 Samuel 7:11 this will be from the time I appointed judges over My people Israel. Furthermore, I will give you rest from all your enemies. And the Lord reveals to you that He Himself will build you a house — a dynasty, a lasting lineage.
2 Samuel 7:12 When your life's days are complete, and you go to rest with your ancestors in death, I will raise up your offspring after you—one who will come from your own body—and I will firmly establish his kingdom.
2 Samuel 7:13 He, your son, is the one who will build a physical house — a Temple — for My name, a place where My presence and glory will be honored. And I will establish the throne of his kingdom, confirming it forever.
2 Samuel 7:14 I will be a Father to him, and he will be My son. If he commits any iniquity, I will correct him with the rod and punishment fitting for human beings, to bring him back to righteousness.
2 Samuel 7:15 But My mercy and steadfast love will not be taken away from him, unlike what happened with Saul, whom I removed from My presence as king.
2 Samuel 7:16 Your dynastic house and your kingdom will endure before Me eternally, and your royal throne will be firmly established forever and ever.
2 Samuel 7:17 According to all these words and this entire vision, Nathan then spoke to David.
2 Samuel 7:18 Then King David went into the Lord’s presence, sat down before Him, and said, 'Who am I, Lord God, and what is my household, that You have brought me to such a high and honorable position?'
2 Samuel 7:19 Yet even this, Lord God, seemed too little in Your sight, for You have also spoken about the future of Your servant’s house for generations to come. This is indeed the profound and lasting destiny You have decreed for mankind, O Lord God.
2 Samuel 7:20 What more can David say to You, Lord God, in addition to this? For You, Lord God, know Your servant intimately.
2 Samuel 7:21 It is because of Your word and according to Your own heart’s desire that You have done all these magnificent things, and have made them known to Your servant.
2 Samuel 7:22 For this reason, You are truly great, O Lord God! There is no one like You, and there is no God apart from You, according to all that we have heard with our own ears throughout history.
2 Samuel 7:23 And what other nation on earth is like Your people Israel, whom You went out to redeem for Yourself as Your own special people, to make a glorious name for Yourself? You performed magnificent and awe-inspiring deeds for them on the earth, by redeeming Your own people out of Egypt, demonstrating Your power before other nations who witnessed it.
2 Samuel 7:24 For You have established Your people Israel for Yourself as a people to endure eternally, and You, Lord God, have truly become their God.
2 Samuel 7:25 Now, therefore, Lord God, confirm the word that You have spoken concerning Your servant and concerning his dynastic house, and make it stand firm eternally; indeed, do as You have spoken.
2 Samuel 7:26 So that Your name may be magnified eternally, and people will say, 'The Lord, God of all heavenly powers, is truly God over Israel!' And may the dynastic house of Your servant David remain stable and enduring before You.
2 Samuel 7:27 For You, Lord God of all heavenly powers, God of Israel, have revealed to Your servant’s hearing, saying, 'I Myself will build you a dynastic house.' Because of this assurance, Your servant has found the confidence in his heart to pray this prayer to You.
2 Samuel 7:28 And now, Lord God, You are God indeed, and Your words are true and faithful. You Yourself have spoken these good promises to Your servant.
2 Samuel 7:29 Therefore, now begin and bless the dynastic house of Your servant, so that it may continue eternally before You. For You, Lord God, have spoken it, and with Your blessing, the dynastic house of Your servant will indeed be blessed forever and ever.
2 Samuel 7:1 It happened when King David had settled in his own house, and the Lord had given him rest on every side from all his enemies, those who were his adversaries—
2 Samuel 7:2 he said to Nathan the prophet: “You see that I live in a house built of cedar wood, but the Ark of God is placed only in the midst of curtains—meaning, a tent.”
2 Samuel 7:3 And Nathan said to the king: “Everything that is in your heart to do, go and do it, because the Lord is with you.”
2 Samuel 7:4 However, on that very night, behold, the word of the Lord came to Nathan, saying:
2 Samuel 7:5 “Go, and speak to my servant David: ‘Thus says the Lord: Is it you who will build me a house to dwell in?’
2 Samuel 7:6 For I have not dwelt in a fixed house from the day I brought the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt until this very day: instead, I have walked about in a tabernacle, and in a tent.
2 Samuel 7:7 Through all the places I have passed with all the children of Israel, did I ever speak to any of the tribes of Israel, whom I commanded to shepherd my people Israel, saying: ‘Why have you not built me a house of cedar?’
2 Samuel 7:8 And now, you shall say these things to my servant David: ‘Thus says the Lord of armies: I took you from the pastures, following the flocks, so that you would be a leader over my people Israel:
2 Samuel 7:9 and I have been with you in everything, wherever you have walked, and I have cut off all your enemies from before your face. And I have made for you a great name, like the name of the great ones who are on the earth.
2 Samuel 7:10 And I will appoint a place for my people Israel, and I will plant them there, and they will dwell under it, and they will no longer be disturbed. Nor will the children of iniquity continue to afflict them, as from the beginning—
2 Samuel 7:11 from the day I appointed judges over my people Israel. And I will give you rest from all your enemies. Furthermore, the Lord declares to you that the Lord himself will make a house—a dynasty—for you.
2 Samuel 7:12 And when your days are completed, and you sleep with your fathers, I will raise up your offspring after you, who will come forth from your body, and I will establish his kingdom.
2 Samuel 7:13 He himself will build a house—the Temple—for my name, and I will establish the throne of his kingdom forever.
2 Samuel 7:14 I will be a father to him, and he will be a son to me. If he does anything wickedly, I will correct him with the rod of men, and with the stripes of the children of men.
2 Samuel 7:15 But my mercy I will not take away from him, as I took it away from Saul, whom I took away from before my face.
2 Samuel 7:16 And your house will be faithful, and your kingdom will endure forever before you, and your throne will be firm perpetually—this promise is fulfilled in your descendant, Christ the Lord.
2 Samuel 7:17 According to all these words, and according to all this vision, thus Nathan spoke to David.
2 Samuel 7:18 Then King David entered and sat before the Lord, and said: “Who am I, O Lord God, and what is my house, that you have brought me to such a greatness?
2 Samuel 7:19 But even this is small in your sight, O Lord God, unless you have also spoken concerning the house of your servant for a long time to come—into eternity. For this is the law of Adam, O Lord God—a universal and enduring decree for humanity.
2 Samuel 7:20 What more then can David add, that he should speak to you? For you know your servant, O Lord God.
2 Samuel 7:21 Because of your word, and according to your own heart, you have done all these great things, so that you might make them known to your servant.
2 Samuel 7:22 Therefore you are magnified, O Lord God, because there is no one like you, nor is there any God besides you, in all that we have heard with our own ears.
2 Samuel 7:23 And what other nation on earth is like your people Israel, whom you went to redeem for yourself as a people, and to establish for yourself a name, and to do for them great and terrible things on the earth, from before the nations you redeemed for yourself out of Egypt?
2 Samuel 7:24 And you have established for yourself your people Israel as an eternal people, and you, O Lord God, have become their God.
2 Samuel 7:25 Now therefore, O Lord God, the word which you have spoken concerning your servant, and concerning his house, raise it up forever, and do as you have spoken.
2 Samuel 7:26 So that your name may be magnified forever, with people saying: 'The Lord of armies is God over Israel.' And the house of your servant David will be stable before you.
2 Samuel 7:27 Because you, O Lord of armies, God of Israel, have revealed in the ear of your servant, saying: ‘I will build a house—a dynasty—for you,’ therefore your servant has found it in his heart to pray this prayer to you.
2 Samuel 7:28 Now therefore, O Lord God, you are God, and your words will be true. You have spoken these good things to your servant.
2 Samuel 7:29 Begin therefore, and bless the house of your servant, that it may be forever before you. Because you, O Lord God, have spoken, and with your blessing the house of your servant will be blessed forever.
2 Samuel 8:1 After these events, David waged war against the Philistines, defeating them and humbling their power. David seized control over their chief city, making them subject to his rule and compelling them to pay tribute.
2 Samuel 8:1 After these events, David attacked the Philistines and utterly subdued them. David then took what the Latin calls 'the bridle of tribute' from Gath, meaning he seized control of this principal Philistine city and its surrounding territories, forcing them into submission and tribute.
2 Samuel 8:2 David also attacked the Moabites, subjecting them to a severe judgment. He measured them out with a rope, as if laying them flat on the ground for execution. He put two-thirds of them to death, sparing only one-third. Thus, Moab became servants of David, compelled to pay him tribute.
2 Samuel 8:3 David also struck Hadadezer, the son of Rehob, who was the king of Zobah. This happened when Hadadezer was on an expedition to extend his dominion all the way to the Euphrates River.
2 Samuel 8:4 David captured a vast military force from Hadadezer: seventeen hundred horsemen and twenty thousand foot soldiers. As a tactical move to prevent their future use in warfare against him, David then crippled all the horses intended for chariots by cutting their leg tendons, except for those needed for one hundred chariots, which he kept.
2 Samuel 8:5 The Syrians from Damascus also came to help Hadadezer, the king of Zobah. But David defeated them too, striking down twenty-two thousand Syrian soldiers.
2 Samuel 8:6 David then established garrisons throughout the region of Damascus in Syria. As a result, Syria became subject to David, obligated to pay him tribute. The Lord God assisted David in every endeavor he undertook.
2 Samuel 8:7 David also took the golden shields that belonged to Hadadezer’s royal officers, and he brought these valuable spoils of war back to Jerusalem.
2 Samuel 8:8 From Betah and Beroth, which were cities belonging to Hadadezer, King David seized a vast quantity of bronze.
2 Samuel 8:9 Then Tou, the king of Hamath, heard the news that David had defeated Hadadezer’s entire army.
2 Samuel 8:10 King Tou then sent his son, Joram, to King David. Joram’s mission was to offer a formal greeting, to congratulate David on his victory, and to express gratitude because David had fought against and defeated Hadadezer. This was a significant act, as King Tou was an enemy of Hadadezer. Joram also brought gifts of silver, gold, and bronze vessels for David.
2 Samuel 8:11 King David consecrated these gifts, along with all the silver and gold he had dedicated from all the nations he had subdued, to the Lord. This act of sanctification meant they were set aside for sacred use in the service of God.
2 Samuel 8:12 These consecrated offerings came from the spoils taken from Syria, Moab, the Ammonites, the Philistines, and the Amalekites. They also included the spoils from Hadadezer, the son of Rehob, king of Zobah.
2 Samuel 8:13 David also gained great renown for himself when he returned from defeating twelve thousand enemies in the Valley of Salt. Although the Latin text says 'Syria,' this victory most likely refers to his conquest of Edom in that southern region, a battle where he struck down twelve thousand.
2 Samuel 8:14 David then established garrisons throughout Idumea, also known as Edom, and as a result, the entire region of Idumea became completely subject to David. And, as before, the Lord God assisted David in every endeavor he undertook.
2 Samuel 8:15 So David reigned as king over all of Israel, and he administered fair judgment and righteousness to all of his people.
2 Samuel 8:16 Now, Joab, the son of Zeruiah, was the commander of David’s army. And Jehoshaphat, the son of Ahilud, served as the royal chronicler, responsible for keeping all official records.
2 Samuel 8:17 Zadok, the son of Ahitub, and Ahimelech, the son of Abiathar, served as the principal priests. Seraiah was the royal secretary, handling official correspondence and state affairs.
2 Samuel 8:18 Benaiah, the son of Jehoiada, was in command of the Cherethites and Pelethites, who were David’s personal elite guard. And David’s sons themselves held high office as royal ministers, called 'priests' in this context, indicating their sacred and prominent role in the kingdom.
2 Samuel 9:1 Now David said, "Is there anyone left from the royal house of Saul, so that I may show kindness to him—fulfilling my covenant with Jonathan?"
2 Samuel 9:2 Now there was a servant from Saul's household, named Ziba. When the king called him, David asked, "Are you Ziba?" And he replied, "I am your servant."
2 Samuel 9:3 And the king asked, "Is there still anyone left from the house of Saul, that I may show him the kindness of God's covenant?" Ziba then said to the king, "Yes, there is still a son of Jonathan alive, but he is lame in both his feet."
2 Samuel 9:4 David then asked, "Where is he?" And Ziba replied, "Behold, he is in the house of Machir, son of Ammiel, in Lo-debar."
2 Samuel 9:5 So King David sent messengers, and they brought him from the house of Machir, son of Ammiel, from Lo-debar.
2 Samuel 9:6 When Mephibosheth (also known as Meribbaal), the son of Jonathan and grandson of Saul, came to David, he fell on his face and paid homage. And David said, "Mephibosheth?" He replied, "Behold, I am your servant."
2 Samuel 9:7 And David said to him, "Do not fear, for I will most certainly show you great kindness for the sake of Jonathan, your father. I will restore to you all the fields that belonged to Saul, your grandfather, and you shall always eat bread at my royal table."
2 Samuel 9:8 He prostrated himself again and said, "What is your servant, that you would show regard for a dead dog such as I am?"
2 Samuel 9:9 Then the king called Ziba, Saul's servant, and said to him, "Everything that belonged to Saul and his entire household, I have now given to your master's son—Mephibosheth."
2 Samuel 9:10 "Therefore, you and your sons and your servants are to work the land for him. You shall bring in the produce so that your master's son may have food to eat and be provided for. Mephibosheth, your master's son, will always eat at my royal table." Now Ziba had fifteen sons and twenty servants.
2 Samuel 9:11 Ziba said to the king, "Just as my lord the king has commanded, so your servant will do. Mephibosheth will eat at your table as one of the king's own sons."
2 Samuel 9:12 Now Mephibosheth had a young son named Micah. And all the household of Ziba became servants to Mephibosheth.
2 Samuel 9:13 So Mephibosheth lived in Jerusalem, because he always ate at the king's table; and he was lame in both feet.
2 Samuel 10:1 It happened after these events that the king of the Ammonites died, and his son Hanun began to reign in his place.
2 Samuel 10:2 And David said, 'I will show kindness to Hanun, the son of Nahash, just as his father showed kindness to me.' So David sent messengers to console him over the death of his father. When David’s servants arrived in the land of the Ammonites,
2 Samuel 10:3 the princes of Ammon spoke to their lord Hanun: 'Do you really believe David has sent these comforters to you out of honor for your father? Is it not rather to spy out our city, to investigate its defenses, and to overthrow it?'
2 Samuel 10:4 So Hanun seized David’s servants, shaved off half of their beards, cut their outer garments off at the middle—up to their buttocks—and then sent them away in disgrace.
2 Samuel 10:5 When this news was reported to David, he sent people to meet them, because the men were greatly humiliated. And David commanded them, saying: 'Remain in Jericho until your beards have grown out, and then you may return.'
2 Samuel 10:6 But when the sons of Ammon realized what they had done to David and that they had made themselves utterly detestable to him, they sent and hired twenty thousand foot soldiers from Aram-Rehob and Aram-Zobah, one thousand men from the king of Maacah, and twelve thousand men from Ish-Tob.
2 Samuel 10:7 When David heard this, he sent Joab and his entire army, which was made up of his most powerful warriors.
2 Samuel 10:8 So the sons of Ammon came out and drew up their battle line at the entrance of the city gate. Meanwhile, the men of Aram-Rehob, Ish-Tob, Maacah, and Zobah were arrayed separately in the open field.
2 Samuel 10:9 When Joab saw that the battle lines were set against him both in front and behind, he chose some of the best men of Israel and arrayed them for battle against the Arameans.
2 Samuel 10:10 He gave the rest of the army to his brother Abishai, who arrayed them in a battle line against the sons of Ammon.
2 Samuel 10:11 And Joab said to Abishai: 'If the Arameans prove too strong for me, then you must come to my aid. But if the sons of Ammon prove too strong for you, then I will come to your aid.'
2 Samuel 10:12 'Be strong! Let us act courageously for our people and for the cities of our God. May the Lord do what is good in His sight.'
2 Samuel 10:13 So Joab and the people with him advanced into battle against the Arameans, who immediately fled from his presence.
2 Samuel 10:14 When the sons of Ammon saw that the Arameans had fled, they also fled from the presence of Abishai and retreated into their city. Then Joab returned from fighting the sons of Ammon and came to Jerusalem.
2 Samuel 10:15 When the Arameans saw that they had been defeated before Israel, they gathered themselves together for a fresh assault.
2 Samuel 10:16 Hadadezer then sent for help and brought out the Arameans who were beyond the Euphrates River, and he brought with them Shobach, the commander of Hadadezer’s army, to lead them.
2 Samuel 10:17 When this was reported to David, he gathered all of Israel, crossed the Jordan River, and came to Helam. The Arameans arrayed their battle lines against David and fought against him.
2 Samuel 10:18 The Arameans fled before Israel, and David killed seven hundred charioteers and forty thousand horsemen from among them. He also struck down Shobach, the commander of their army, who immediately died there.
2 Samuel 10:19 When all the kings who were allies of Hadadezer saw that they had been defeated by Israel, they made peace with Israel and became their servants. After this, the Arameans were afraid to help the sons of Ammon anymore.
2 Samuel 10:1 Now it came to pass after these events, that the king of the Ammonites died, and his son Hanon began to reign in his place.
2 Samuel 10:2 And David said: 'I will show kindness to Hanon, the son of Nahash, just as his father showed kindness to me.' So David sent messengers to comfort him concerning his father. But when David’s servants arrived in the land of the Ammonites,
2 Samuel 10:3 the counselors of the Ammonites said to Hanon, their lord: 'Do you truly believe that David sent men to comfort you out of honor for your father? Or did he send them to spy out, to thoroughly search, and to overthrow our city?'
2 Samuel 10:4 So Hanon took David's servants. He shaved off half of their beards and cut their garments in the middle, down to their buttocks, and then sent them away, inflicting deep shame upon them.
2 Samuel 10:5 And when this humiliating event was reported to David, he sent to meet them, because the men were greatly ashamed. He commanded them, saying: 'Stay in Jericho until your beards have grown back, and then return.'
2 Samuel 10:6 Therefore, the Ammonites, realizing they had become utterly contemptible in David's eyes after their insult, sent and hired twenty thousand foot soldiers from Aram-Rehob and Aram-Zobah. They also hired a thousand men from the king of Maacah and twelve thousand men from Istob.
2 Samuel 10:7 When David heard this, he sent Joab and the entire army of his most valiant men.
2 Samuel 10:8 So the Ammonites went out and drew up their battle line at the entrance of their city gate. Meanwhile, the Arameans from Zobah, Rehob, Istob, and Maacah were positioned separately in the open field.
2 Samuel 10:9 Therefore, Joab, seeing that the enemy battle lines were set against him both in front and in the rear, chose from among all of Israel's most valiant men and drew up his own battle line against the Arameans.
2 Samuel 10:10 The remaining part of the people, he gave to his brother Abishai, who then drew up their battle line against the Ammonites.
2 Samuel 10:11 And Joab said: 'If the Arameans prove stronger than I, you shall come to my aid. But if the Ammonites prove stronger than you, then I will come to your aid.'
2 Samuel 10:12 'Be strong, and let us act bravely for our people and for the cities of our God. May the Lord do what is good in His own sight.'
2 Samuel 10:13 And when the battle began, the Arameans fled before Joab. And the Ammonites, seeing that the Arameans had fled, also fled from Abishai and entered their city. So Joab returned from fighting the Ammonites and came back to Jerusalem.
2 Samuel 10:14 But when the Arameans saw that they had been defeated by Israel, they gathered themselves together in one place.
2 Samuel 10:15 So Hadadezer sent and brought out the Arameans who were beyond the Euphrates River, and he led their army to battle. Shobach, the commander of Hadadezer's army, was over them.
2 Samuel 10:16 And it was reported to David. So he gathered all of Israel, crossed the Jordan River, and came to Helam. There they drew up their battle line against the Arameans and fought against them.
2 Samuel 10:17 And the Arameans fled from before Israel. David killed seven hundred of their charioteers and forty thousand cavalrymen. He also struck Shobach, their army commander, who immediately died there.
2 Samuel 10:18 And all the kings who were under Hadadezer, seeing that they had been defeated by Israel, made peace with Israel and served them. The Arameans were then afraid to help the Ammonites any further.
2 Samuel 10:19 Now it came to pass after these events, that the king of the Ammonites died, and his son Hanon began to reign in his place.
2 Samuel 11:1 Now it happened, as the year turned, at the time when kings typically go out to wage war, David sent Joab, along with his servants and all of Israel. They devastated the Ammonites and laid siege to Rabbah. But David himself remained in Jerusalem.
2 Samuel 11:2 And it happened one evening, David rose from his bed and walked upon the roof of the king's house. From there, he saw a woman washing herself. She was very beautiful.
2 Samuel 11:3 So David sent messengers and inquired who the woman was. And a messenger said to him, 'Is this not Bathsheba, the daughter of Eliam and the wife of Uriah the Hittite?'
2 Samuel 11:4 Then David sent messengers and had her brought to him. She came in to him, and he slept with her. She then immediately purified herself from the uncleanness of her menstrual cycle.
2 Samuel 11:5 And she returned to her house, having conceived a child. And she sent word to David, saying, 'I have conceived.'
2 Samuel 11:6 David then sent word to Joab, saying, 'Send Uriah the Hittite to me.' And Joab sent Uriah to David.
2 Samuel 11:7 When Uriah came to David, David asked him how Joab was doing, how the people were doing, and how the war was going.
2 Samuel 11:8 And David said to Uriah, 'Go to your house and wash your feet.' And when Uriah left the king's house, a portion from the king's table followed him, sent as a gift.
2 Samuel 11:9 But Uriah slept at the entrance of the king's house with all the servants of his lord, and he did not go into his own house.
2 Samuel 11:10 It was reported to David by those who said, 'Uriah did not go into his house.' Then David said to Uriah, 'Have you not just come from a journey? Why did you not go down to your house?'
2 Samuel 11:11 And Uriah said to David, 'The Ark of God, along with Israel and Judah, dwell in tents. And my lord Joab, and the servants of my lord, remain in the open field. How then could I go into my own house to eat and drink and sleep with my wife? By your life, and by the life of your soul, I will not do this thing.'
2 Samuel 11:12 Then David said to Uriah, 'Remain here today, and tomorrow I will send you away.' So Uriah remained in Jerusalem that day and the next.
2 Samuel 11:13 David then called for him and made him eat and drink in his presence, and he made him drunk. But in the evening, Uriah went out and slept on his bed with the servants of his lord, and he did not go down to his own house.
2 Samuel 11:14 So it happened in the morning, David wrote a letter to Joab and sent it by the hand of Uriah.
2 Samuel 11:15 In the letter, he wrote this command: 'Place Uriah in the front line of the fiercest battle. Then, withdraw from him, so that he may be struck down and die.'
2 Samuel 11:16 Therefore, when Joab besieged the city, he placed Uriah in a spot where he knew there were very strong enemy fighters.
2 Samuel 11:17 And the men of the city came out and fought against Joab. Some of the people, David's servants, fell, and Uriah the Hittite also died.
2 Samuel 11:18 So Joab sent and reported to David all the words of the battle.
2 Samuel 11:19 And he commanded the messenger, saying: 'When you have finished reporting all the details of the battle to the king,
2 Samuel 11:20 If any of the king's anger is stirred, and he says, 'Why did you approach the wall to fight? Did you not know that many projectiles are usually thrown down from the wall from above?
2 Samuel 11:21 Who struck down Abimelech, the son of Jerubaal? Did not a woman throw a piece of a millstone down on him from the wall and kill him at Thebez? Why did you approach so close to the wall?' Then you shall say, 'Your servant Uriah the Hittite is also dead.'
2 Samuel 11:22 So the messenger went and came to David and reported to him all that Joab had commanded him.
2 Samuel 11:23 And the messenger said to David: 'The men of the city had the upper hand against us and came out against us in the open field. But we pursued them and drove them back all the way to the gate of the city.
2 Samuel 11:24 And archers shot down from the wall upon your servants, and some of the king's servants died. Indeed, your servant Uriah the Hittite is also dead.'
2 Samuel 11:25 And David said to the messenger, 'Say this to Joab: 'Do not let this matter discourage you, for the outcome of war is unpredictable. The sword strikes now one way, now another. Press your warriors against the city to destroy it, and strengthen their resolve.''
2 Samuel 11:26 Now when Uriah's wife heard that Uriah, her husband, was dead, she mourned for her husband.
2 Samuel 11:27 After her period of mourning was over, David sent for her and brought her into his house. She became his wife and bore him a son. But the thing that David had done displeased the Lord.
2 Samuel 11:1 Now it happened when the new year came—the time when kings typically march out to wage war—that King David sent Joab and his own personal guards with him, along with all the army of Israel. They attacked the Ammonites and laid siege to their city, Rabbah, but King David himself remained behind in Jerusalem.
2 Samuel 11:2 Then one day, as the evening was approaching, King David rose from his bed and walked upon the roof of the king's palace. From there he saw a woman bathing on the roof of her own house. The woman was exceptionally beautiful.
2 Samuel 11:3 So the king sent messengers to inquire who the woman was. And it was reported back to him that she was Bathsheba, the daughter of Eliam, and the wife of Uriah the Hittite.
2 Samuel 11:4 Therefore, King David sent messengers, and they brought her to him. She came in to him and he lay with her. She had just purified herself from her ritual uncleanness, meaning she was fertile. Afterwards, she returned to her house.
2 Samuel 11:5 And the woman conceived a child. She then sent word to King David, saying: 'I have become pregnant.'
2 Samuel 11:6 So King David sent word to Joab, saying: 'Send Uriah the Hittite to me.' And Joab sent Uriah to King David.
2 Samuel 11:7 When Uriah came to King David, David asked him how Joab was, and how the soldiers were, and how the war was progressing.
2 Samuel 11:8 Then King David said to Uriah: 'Go to your house, and wash your feet.' So Uriah departed from the king's house, and the king's servants carried a gift of food after him, as a sign of favor.
2 Samuel 11:9 But Uriah slept outside the gate of the king's house, with all the servants of his lord, and did not go down into his own house.
2 Samuel 11:10 And they reported to King David, saying: 'Uriah did not go down to his house.' King David then said to Uriah: 'Have you not just come from a journey? Why then did you not go down to your house?'
2 Samuel 11:11 Uriah answered King David: 'The Ark of God, and all Israel, and Judah, are living in temporary shelters, and my lord Joab and the servants of my lord are sleeping in the open field. And should I then go into my house to eat and drink and lie with my wife? By your very life, and by the life of your soul, I will not do this thing!'
2 Samuel 11:12 Then King David said to Uriah: 'Stay here also today, and tomorrow I will send you back to the army.' So Uriah stayed in Jerusalem that day, and the next day.
2 Samuel 11:13 And King David invited him to eat and drink in his presence, and made him drunk. But Uriah still went out in the evening and slept on his pallet with the servants of his lord, and did not go down into his own house.
2 Samuel 11:14 So it happened in the morning, King David wrote a letter to Joab and sent it by the hand of Uriah himself.
2 Samuel 11:15 Now in the letter he wrote, he gave these instructions: 'Place Uriah in the front line, where the battle is fiercest. Then withdraw from him, so that he may be struck down and die.'
2 Samuel 11:16 So when Joab was besieging the city, he placed Uriah in a spot where he knew there were the strongest, most valiant enemy soldiers.
2 Samuel 11:17 And the men came out from the city and fought against Joab. Some of the soldiers, servants of King David, fell in battle, and Uriah the Hittite also died.
2 Samuel 11:18 Then Joab sent and reported to King David all the details of the battle.
2 Samuel 11:19 And he commanded the messenger, saying: 'When you have finished reporting all the words of the battle to the king—'
2 Samuel 11:20 '—if perhaps the king should become angry and say: Why did you approach the wall to fight? Did you not know that whatever is thrown from the wall above can easily kill? For example—'
2 Samuel 11:21 '—who killed Abimelech, the son of Jerubaal? Was it not a woman who threw a piece of a millstone upon him from the wall, and killed him in Thebez? Why did you approach so close to the wall? If he asks this, then you are to say: 'Indeed, your servant Uriah the Hittite is also dead.''
2 Samuel 11:22 So the messenger went, and came to King David, and reported to him all that Joab had commanded him.
2 Samuel 11:23 And the messenger said to King David: 'The men of the city overpowered us, and came out against us into the open field. And we fought them all the way to the gate of the city.'
2 Samuel 11:24 'And archers shot arrows upon your servants from the wall, and some of the king's servants died, and indeed, your servant Uriah the Hittite is also dead.'
2 Samuel 11:25 And King David said to the messenger: 'Thus you shall say to Joab: 'Do not let this matter discourage you. For the outcome of war is uncertain; sometimes the sword consumes one man, and sometimes another. Intensify the fight against the city, and overthrow it.' And with these words, David sought to encourage Joab.
2 Samuel 11:26 Now when Uriah's wife heard that Uriah, her husband, was dead, she mourned for her husband.
2 Samuel 11:27 And when her period of mourning was over, King David sent for her and brought her to his house, and she became his wife. Then she bore him a son. But the deed that King David had done was displeasing in the sight of the Lord.
2 Samuel 12:1 The Lord then sent the prophet Nathan to King David. When Nathan came to David, he told him a story: 'There were two men in one city; one was very rich, and the other was very poor.'
2 Samuel 12:2 The rich man owned many, many sheep and cattle.
2 Samuel 12:3 But the poor man had nothing at all, except one tiny lamb. He had bought it and raised it, and it grew up with him and his children. It would eat from his own plate, drink from his own cup, and sleep in his arms; it was like a daughter to him.
2 Samuel 12:4 When a traveler came to the rich man, he refused to take from his own many sheep and cattle to prepare a meal for his guest, whom he had received as a visitor. Instead, he took the lamb of the poor man and prepared it for the person who had come to him.
2 Samuel 12:5 David became very angry and indignant at the man, and he said to Nathan, 'As the Lord lives, the man who did this deserves to die! His action is a capital offense.'
2 Samuel 12:6 'He must repay the lamb fourfold because he did such a thing and showed no mercy.'
2 Samuel 12:7 Then Nathan said to David, 'You are that man! This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says: 'I anointed you king over Israel, and I rescued you from the hand of Saul.'
2 Samuel 12:8 'I gave you your master's house and your master's wives into your possession. I also gave you the kingdom of Israel and Judah. If all this were too little, I would have added even more to you.'
2 Samuel 12:9 'Why then have you despised the word of the Lord by doing evil in My sight? You struck down Uriah the Hittite with a sword, and you took his wife to be your own wife, and you killed him by the sword of the Ammonites.'
2 Samuel 12:10 'Therefore, the sword will never depart from your house from this day forward, because you have despised Me and have taken the wife of Uriah the Hittite to be your own wife.'
2 Samuel 12:11 'This is what the Lord says: 'Behold, I will bring disaster upon you from your own household. I will take your wives and give them to your neighbor before your very eyes, and he will sleep with your wives in the sight of the sun itself, openly and without shame.''
2 Samuel 12:12 'For you acted in secret, but I will do this thing in the sight of all Israel and in the sight of the sun, making your sin publicly known.'
2 Samuel 12:13 And David said to Nathan, 'I have sinned against the Lord.' Nathan then said to David, 'The Lord has also removed your sin; you will not die immediately for it.'
2 Samuel 12:14 'Nevertheless, because by this deed you have given the enemies of the Lord great occasion to blaspheme His name, the child who is born to you will surely die.'
2 Samuel 12:15 Then Nathan returned to his own house. And the Lord struck the child whom Uriah's wife had borne to David, and the child became very ill.
2 Samuel 12:16 David pleaded with the Lord for the child. David fasted by going without food, and he went into his private chamber and lay on the ground all night.
2 Samuel 12:17 So the elders of his household came to him to raise him from the ground, but he refused their help and would not eat any food with them.
2 Samuel 12:18 On the seventh day, the child died. And David's servants were afraid to tell him that the child was dead, for they said, 'Look, while the child was still alive, we spoke to him, and he would not listen to our words. How much more will he afflict himself if we tell him that the boy is dead?'
2 Samuel 12:19 But when David noticed his servants whispering among themselves, he understood that the child was dead. So he asked his servants, saying, 'Is the child dead?' And they answered him, 'He is dead.'
2 Samuel 12:20 Then David arose from the ground, washed himself, anointed himself with oil, and changed his clothing. He went into the house of the Lord and worshiped there. Then he returned to his own house and requested food, and he ate.
2 Samuel 12:21 His servants then said to him, 'What is this thing you have done? While the child was still alive, you fasted and wept. But now that the child is dead, you have risen and eaten bread.'
2 Samuel 12:22 He replied, 'While the child was still alive, I fasted and wept, because I thought to myself: 'Who knows? Perhaps the Lord will have mercy on me, and the child will live.''
2 Samuel 12:23 'But now that the child is dead, why should I continue to fast? Can I bring him back again? I will go to him in death, but he will not return to me in life.'
2 Samuel 12:24 And David comforted Bathsheba, his wife. He went in to her and slept with her. She conceived and gave birth to a son, and he named him Solomon. And the Lord loved this child.
2 Samuel 12:25 And the Lord sent a message by the hand of Nathan the prophet, and he called the child's name Jedidiah (which means 'Beloved of the Lord'), because the Lord loved him.
2 Samuel 12:26 Now Joab was fighting against Rabbah of the Ammonites, and he captured the royal city, which was the capital.
2 Samuel 12:27 And Joab sent messengers to David, saying, 'I have fought against Rabbah and have captured the city's water supply.'
2 Samuel 12:28 'Now, therefore, gather the rest of the people and besiege the city yourself, and capture it. Do this so that when the city is taken, it will not be named after me, but after you.'
2 Samuel 12:29 So David gathered all the people and went against Rabbah. He fought against it and captured it.
2 Samuel 12:30 And David took the crown of their king from his head. Its weight was a talent of gold, and it had precious stones embedded in it. It was then placed upon David's own head. He also carried away a very great amount of plunder from the city.
2 Samuel 12:31 He also brought out the people who were in it and put them to forced labor with saws, with iron picks, and with iron axes. He made them pass through the brick kiln, meaning he subjected them to harsh, enslaving labor, including making bricks. He did this to all the cities of the Ammonites. Then David and all his army returned to Jerusalem.

2 Samuel 13:1 After these events, Absalom, a son of King David, had a very beautiful sister named Tamar. Amnon, another son of King David, then fell deeply in love with her.
2 Samuel 13:2 Amnon became so distressed over his sister Tamar that he fell sick and grew weak. This was because she was a virgin, and it seemed impossible for him to act on his sinful desire for her.
2 Samuel 13:3 Now, Amnon had a friend named Jonadab. Jonadab was the son of Shimeah, who was King David's brother—making him Amnon's cousin. Jonadab was an extremely shrewd and cunning man.
2 Samuel 13:4 Jonadab asked Amnon, 'Why do you look so worn out and thin, O son of the king, day after day? Won't you tell me what's bothering you?' Amnon answered him, 'I am in love with Tamar, the beautiful sister of my brother Absalom.'
2 Samuel 13:5 Then Jonadab said to him, 'Lie down on your bed and pretend to be sick. When your father, King David, comes to visit you, you must say to him: 'Please, let my sister Tamar come and prepare some food for me. Let her make me a special dish so I can eat it from her hand.''
2 Samuel 13:6 So Amnon lay down and pretended to be sick. King David came to visit him. Amnon then said to the king, 'Please, let my sister Tamar come and make two little cakes right before my eyes, so I may eat from her hand.'
2 Samuel 13:7 So King David sent word to Tamar at her home, saying, 'Please go to the house of your brother Amnon and prepare some food for him.'
2 Samuel 13:8 Tamar went to the house of her brother Amnon, who was lying down. She took flour, mixed it, and prepared it right before his eyes. Then she cooked the little cakes.
2 Samuel 13:9 She took what she had cooked and set it before him, but he refused to eat. Amnon then said, 'Send everyone out from me.' So everyone was put out and left the room.
2 Samuel 13:10 Amnon said to Tamar, 'Bring the food into the inner room so I can eat it from your hand.' Tamar then took the little cakes she had made and brought them to her brother Amnon in the inner room.
2 Samuel 13:11 When she offered the food to him so he might eat, he seized her and said, 'Come, my sister, lie with me.'
2 Samuel 13:12 She answered him, 'No, my brother, do not violate me! For such a thing is not allowed in Israel. Do not commit this utterly foolish and wicked act.'
2 Samuel 13:13 For where would I go with my disgrace? And you would be considered like one of the most foolish and wicked men in Israel. Instead, why not speak to the king? He would not deny me to you in marriage, if you asked properly.'
2 Samuel 13:14 But he refused to listen to her pleas. Instead, he overpowered her, disgraced her, and lay with her through force.
2 Samuel 13:15 Then Amnon hated Tamar with an exceedingly great hatred. His hatred for her was greater than the love he had felt for her. And Amnon said to her, 'Get up and leave!'
2 Samuel 13:16 Tamar said to him, 'No! This additional evil of casting me out now is even greater than the evil you have already done to me!' But Amnon refused to listen to her.
2 Samuel 13:17 He called the young man who served him and said, 'Throw this woman out from me and lock the door behind her.'
2 Samuel 13:18 Now, Tamar was wearing a long, full-sleeved tunic, which was the customary garment for royal virgins. So Amnon's servant put her out and locked the door behind her.
2 Samuel 13:19 But Tamar, scattering ashes on her head and tearing the long, full-sleeved tunic she wore, put her hand upon her head and went away, crying out in great distress.
2 Samuel 13:20 Her brother Absalom said to her, 'Was it not your brother Amnon who was with you? Now, then, be silent, my sister. He is your brother. Do not let this matter grieve your heart so much.' So Tamar remained desolate and disgraced in the house of her brother Absalom.
2 Samuel 13:21 Now, King David heard about all these things and became exceedingly angry.
2 Samuel 13:22 However, Absalom did not speak to Amnon, neither for good nor for evil—he did not confront him. For Absalom hated Amnon because he had violated his sister Tamar.
2 Samuel 13:23 It happened after a period of two years that Absalom's sheep were being sheared in Baal Hazor, which is near Ephraim. Absalom then invited all the king's sons to a feast.
2 Samuel 13:24 Absalom came to the king and said to him, 'Behold, your servant's sheep are being sheared. Please, let the king and his servants come to your servant's feast.'
2 Samuel 13:25 But the king said to Absalom, 'No, my son, please, let us not all come, lest we be a burden to you.' Though Absalom urged him, King David refused to go, but he gave Absalom his blessing.
2 Samuel 13:26 Then Absalom said, 'If you will not come, please let my brother Amnon at least come with us.' The king asked him, 'Why should he go with you?'
2 Samuel 13:27 But Absalom pressed the king with his request, so David sent Amnon and all the rest of the king's sons with him.
2 Samuel 13:28 Now Absalom had given orders to his young men, saying, 'Watch closely when Amnon's heart is cheerful with wine, and when I say to you, 'Strike Amnon and kill him!' Do not be afraid! Have I not commanded you? Be strong and show yourselves to be brave men!'
2 Samuel 13:29 So Absalom's young men did to Amnon just as Absalom had commanded them. Then all the other sons of the king rose up, each mounted his mule, and they fled.
2 Samuel 13:30 While they were still on the way, a rumor reached King David, saying, 'Absalom has killed all the king's sons, and not even one of them remains alive!'
2 Samuel 13:31 Then the king arose, tore his royal garments, and fell to the ground. All his servants who stood by him also tore their own garments in sorrow.
2 Samuel 13:32 But Jonadab, the son of Shimeah, David's brother, spoke up and said, 'Let not my lord the king think that all the young men, the king's sons, have been killed. Only Amnon is dead. For this was planned by Absalom from the day that Amnon violated his sister Tamar.'
2 Samuel 13:33 'Therefore, now let not my lord the king take it to heart, thinking: 'All the king's sons are dead.' For only Amnon is dead.'
2 Samuel 13:34 Meanwhile, Absalom had fled. And the young watchman lifted his eyes and looked, and behold, a large company of people were coming by way of the road along the side of the mountain, through the winding paths.
2 Samuel 13:35 Then Jonadab said to the king, 'Behold, the king's sons are coming! It has happened just as I said it would.'
2 Samuel 13:36 As soon as he finished speaking, the king's sons appeared. They raised their voices and wept loudly. And the king also, with all his servants, wept with an exceedingly great lamentation.
2 Samuel 13:37 But Absalom, having fled, went to Talmai, the son of Ammihud, the king of Geshur. So King David mourned for his son Amnon for many days.
2 Samuel 13:38 When Absalom had fled and arrived in Geshur, he remained there for three years.
2 Samuel 13:39 And King David ceased pursuing Absalom, for he had been comforted over Amnon, seeing that he was dead.
2 Samuel 13:40 This verse does not exist in the Clementine Vulgate for 2 Samuel Chapter 13.
2 Samuel 13:1 Now after these events, Absalom, a son of King David, had a very beautiful sister named Tamar. And Amnon, another son of David, fell in love with her.
2 Samuel 13:2 Amnon was so distressed over her that he became sick, wasting away because of Tamar, his sister. For she was a virgin, and it seemed impossible in Amnon's eyes to do anything with her.
2 Samuel 13:3 But Amnon had a friend named Jonadab, the son of Shimeah (David's brother). Jonadab was a very cunning man.
2 Samuel 13:4 Jonadab said to Amnon, 'Why are you so wasted away, son of the king, day after day? Why don't you tell me?' Amnon replied to him, 'I love Tamar, the sister of my brother Absalom.'
2 Samuel 13:5 Jonadab then said to him, 'Lie down on your bed and pretend to be sick. When your father comes to visit you, you must say to him: 'Please let my sister Tamar come and give me food. Let her prepare some warm food in my presence, so I can see it and eat from her hand.'
2 Samuel 13:6 So Amnon lay down and pretended to be sick. The king came to visit him. Amnon then said to the king, 'Please let my sister Tamar come and make two small portions of food in my presence, so I may eat from her hand.'
2 Samuel 13:7 So King David sent word to Tamar at her home, saying, 'Go to your brother Amnon's house and prepare food for him.'
2 Samuel 13:8 Tamar went to the house of her brother Amnon, who was lying down. She took flour, mixed it, and prepared the small portions of food in his sight, cooking them.
2 Samuel 13:9 Then she took what she had cooked and served it to him. But he refused to eat. Amnon said, 'Send everyone away from me!' So all the servants were sent out and left the room.
2 Samuel 13:10 Amnon then said to Tamar, 'Bring the food into the inner room, so I may eat from your hand.' Tamar took the portions she had made and brought them to her brother Amnon in the inner room.
2 Samuel 13:11 As she offered it to him, he seized her and said, 'Come, lie down with me, my sister.'
2 Samuel 13:12 She answered him, 'No, my brother, do not do violence to me! For such a thing is not permitted in Israel; do not commit this foolish act.'
2 Samuel 13:13 'And where would I go to hide my disgrace? And you, my brother, would become like one of the foolish men in Israel. Why not speak to the king instead? He would not refuse to give me to you in marriage.'
2 Samuel 13:14 But he refused to listen to her pleas. Instead, overpowering her, he did violence to her and lay with her.
2 Samuel 13:15 Then Amnon hated Tamar with an exceedingly great hatred, so much that the hatred with which he hated her was greater than the love with which he had loved her before. And Amnon said to her, 'Get up and go away!'
2 Samuel 13:16 Tamar said to him, 'No, this evil of sending me away is greater than the other evil you have already done to me.' But he would not listen to her.
2 Samuel 13:17 He called his servant who attended him and said, 'Throw this woman out from my presence and bolt the door behind her!'
2 Samuel 13:18 Now she was wearing a long, sleeved tunic. For such garments were worn by the virgin daughters of kings. So his servant threw her out and bolted the door behind her.
2 Samuel 13:19 Tamar then sprinkled dust on her head, tore her sleeved tunic, put her hand upon her head, and went away, walking and crying out in distress.
2 Samuel 13:20 Her brother Absalom said to her, 'Was your brother Amnon with you? But now, sister, be silent, for he is your brother. Do not let this matter grieve your heart.' So Tamar remained desolate in her brother Absalom's house.
2 Samuel 13:21 Now King David heard about all these things and was greatly distressed.
2 Samuel 13:22 However, Absalom did not speak to Amnon, neither good nor evil. For Absalom hated Amnon because he had violated his sister Tamar.
2 Samuel 13:23 Now after two full years, Absalom's sheep were being sheared in Baal Hazor, which is near Ephraim. And Absalom invited all the king's sons.
2 Samuel 13:24 Absalom came to the king and said to him, 'Behold, your servant's sheep are being sheared. Please, let the king and his servants come with your servant.'
2 Samuel 13:25 But the king said to Absalom, 'No, my son, please, do not let us all go, lest we be a burden to you.' Though Absalom urged him, David would not go, but he blessed him instead.
2 Samuel 13:26 Absalom said, 'If you will not come, please, let my brother Amnon at least come with us.' The king asked him, 'Why should he go with you?'
2 Samuel 13:27 But Absalom urged him so strongly that David sent Amnon and all the king's other sons with him.
2 Samuel 13:28 Now Absalom had given orders to his young men, saying, 'Watch when Amnon's heart is cheerful from wine. And when I tell you: Strike Amnon and kill him, do not be afraid! Is it not I who command you? Be courageous and be strong men!'
2 Samuel 13:29 So Absalom's young men did to Amnon just as Absalom had commanded. Then all the king's other sons quickly rose, and each one mounted his mule and fled.
2 Samuel 13:30 While they were still on the way, a rumor reached King David, saying, 'Absalom has struck down all the king's sons! Not even one of them remains!'
2 Samuel 13:31 So the king rose, tore his clothes, and fell to the ground. And all his servants who stood by him also tore their clothes.
2 Samuel 13:32 But Jonadab, the son of Shimeah (David's brother), answered and said, 'Let not my lord the king imagine that all the young men, the king's sons, have been killed. Only Amnon is dead. For this was determined by Absalom from the day that Amnon violated his sister Tamar.'
2 Samuel 13:33 Therefore, let not my lord the king take it to heart now, thinking: 'All the king's sons are dead.' For only Amnon is dead.
2 Samuel 13:34 Meanwhile, Absalom had fled. And the young watchman lifted his eyes and looked, and behold, a large crowd of people were coming down the road on the side of the mountain.
2 Samuel 13:35 Jonadab then said to the king, 'Look! The king's sons are coming! What your servant said has happened.'
2 Samuel 13:36 As soon as he finished speaking, the king's sons appeared, and they raised their voices and wept. Even the king and all his servants wept with an exceedingly great lamentation.
2 Samuel 13:37 Absalom, however, fled and went to Talmai, the son of Ammihud, the king of Geshur. So David mourned for his son Amnon for many days.
2 Samuel 13:38 Absalom, after he fled and arrived in Geshur, remained there for three years.
2 Samuel 13:39 And King David ceased from pursuing Absalom, because he had become reconciled to Amnon's death.
2 Samuel 13:40 And Amnon died.
2 Samuel 14:1 Therefore, Joab, the son of Zeruiah, knew that King David’s heart was longing for Absalom.
2 Samuel 14:2 So Joab sent to Tekoa and brought a wise woman from there. He said to her: 'Pretend to be in mourning, and put on the clothes of a mourner. Do not anoint yourself with oil, so that you look like a woman who has been mourning a dead person for a long time.'
2 Samuel 14:3 Then go to the king and speak these exact words to him.' And Joab carefully instructed her on everything she was to say.
2 Samuel 14:4 So the woman from Tekoa came to the king, fell before him to the ground, and bowed down, saying, 'Help me, King!'
2 Samuel 14:5 The king asked her, 'What is troubling you?' She answered, 'Alas! I am a widow, and my husband is dead.'
2 Samuel 14:6 'And your handmaid had two sons. They fought against each other in the field, and there was no one to intervene and separate them. One struck the other and killed him.'
2 Samuel 14:7 'And behold, the whole family has risen up against your handmaid, saying: "Hand over the one who struck his brother, so we may put him to death for the life of his brother whom he killed, and so destroy the heir!" They are seeking to extinguish the only remaining spark of my family, so that my husband will have no name or descendants left on the earth.'
2 Samuel 14:8 The king said to the woman, 'Go to your house, and I will give orders concerning you.'
2 Samuel 14:9 The woman from Tekoa said to the king, 'My lord king, let the guilt be on me and on my father’s house; but may you, O king, and your throne, be free from all blame.'
2 Samuel 14:10 The king said, 'Whoever speaks against you, bring him to me, and he will not bother you again.'
2 Samuel 14:11 She said, 'I beg you, King, remember the Lord your God, so that the avenger of blood may not multiply the killing, and not destroy my son.' The king responded, 'As the Lord lives, not one hair of your son shall fall to the ground!'
2 Samuel 14:12 Then the woman said, 'May your handmaid speak a word to my lord the king.' He said, 'Speak.'
2 Samuel 14:13 The woman then said, 'Why then have you thought of such a thing against the people of God? For in speaking this, the king implicates himself as a sinner, since he does not bring back his own banished son.'
2 Samuel 14:14 'We all must die, and we are like water poured out on the ground, which cannot be gathered up again. Yet God does not desire for a soul to perish, but rather thinks of ways that the banished one may not be utterly cut off.'
2 Samuel 14:15 'Now, therefore, I have come to speak this word to my lord the king, out of fear of the people. And your handmaid thought: "I will speak to the king, perhaps the king will grant his handmaid’s request."'
2 Samuel 14:16 'For the king heard me, and will deliver his handmaid from the power of the man who seeks to banish me, and to completely cut off me and my son from God’s inheritance.'
2 Samuel 14:17 'Your handmaid said: "May the word of my lord the king be like the angel of God, for my lord the king is truly discerning, able to distinguish between good and evil. And may the Lord your God be with you."'
2 Samuel 14:18 The king answered and said to the woman, 'Do not hide from me the word that I am about to ask you.' The woman said, 'Let my lord the king speak.'
2 Samuel 14:19 The king said, 'Is not the hand of Joab with you in all this?' The woman answered and said, 'As your soul lives, my lord king, it is impossible to deviate to the right or to the left from anything my lord the king has said. For you are wise, like an angel of God, to understand all things on the earth.'
2 Samuel 14:20 'Therefore, for this very reason, your servant Joab did this thing: to change the appearance of my speech and plead the case. But you, my lord, are as wise as the wisdom of an angel of God, so you understand all things that happen on earth.'
2 Samuel 14:21 The king then said to Joab, 'Behold, I have granted your request. Go and bring back the young man Absalom.'
2 Samuel 14:22 Joab fell to the ground on his face, bowed down, and blessed the king. Joab said, 'Blessed be the soul of your servant today, because I have found favor in your sight, my lord king, and you have granted your servant’s request.'
2 Samuel 14:23 So Joab arose and went to Geshur, and brought Absalom back to Jerusalem.
2 Samuel 14:24 But the king said, 'Let him return to his own house, and not see my face.' So Absalom returned to his own house and did not see the king’s face.
2 Samuel 14:25 Now, Absalom was the most handsome man in all of Israel, and exceedingly beautiful. From the sole of his foot to the crown of his head, there was no blemish in him.
2 Samuel 14:26 When he cut his hair once a year—because his hair would become very heavy, it would be shorn—the hair from his head weighed two hundred shekels by the royal standard.
2 Samuel 14:27 Three sons were born to Absalom, and one daughter whose name was Tamar, a woman of outstanding beauty.
2 Samuel 14:28 Absalom remained in Jerusalem for two full years and did not see the king’s face.
2 Samuel 14:29 So Absalom sent for Joab, to send him to the king, but Joab refused to come to him. When Absalom sent a second time, and Joab still refused to come,
2 Samuel 14:30 Absalom said to his servants, 'Look, Joab’s field is next to mine, and he has barley there. Go and set it on fire.' So Absalom’s servants set the field on fire.
2 Samuel 14:31 Then Joab came to Absalom at his house and asked, 'Why did your servants set my field on fire?'
2 Samuel 14:32 Absalom answered Joab, 'I sent word to you, saying: "Come to me, so I can send you to the king, to tell him: 'Why did I even come from Geshur? It would have been better for me to stay there.'" So I beg you, let me see the king’s face. If there is any guilt in me, then kill me.'
2 Samuel 14:33 So Joab came to the king and told him everything. Then Absalom was called, and he entered the king’s presence. He bowed down to the ground before the king, and King David kissed Absalom.
2 Samuel 14:1 So Joab, the son of Zeruiah, knew that King David's heart was yearning for Absalom.
2 Samuel 14:2 Joab sent for a wise woman from Tekoa and brought her to him. And he said to her: 'Pretend to be in mourning. Wear mourning clothes and do not put any oil on your body, so that you appear like a woman who has been mourning a dead person for many days.'
2 Samuel 14:3 Then go to the king and speak these words to him.' Joab put the exact words she was to say into her mouth.
2 Samuel 14:4 So when the woman from Tekoa came to the king, she fell before him on her face, bowed down, and said: 'Help me, my King!'
2 Samuel 14:5 The king said to her: 'What troubles you?' She answered: 'Alas, I am a widow, and my husband is dead.'
2 Samuel 14:6 And your handmaid had two sons. They quarreled with each other in the field, and there was no one to separate them. So one struck the other and killed him.
2 Samuel 14:7 And behold, all the relatives rose up against your handmaid, saying: 'Hand over the one who struck his brother, so we may kill him for the life of his brother whom he murdered, and destroy the heir!' They are threatening to wipe out my only remaining family and prevent my husband's name and descendants from continuing on the earth.
2 Samuel 14:8 The king said to the woman: 'Go to your house, and I will give orders concerning you.'
2 Samuel 14:9 The woman from Tekoa said to the king: 'My Lord, my King, let the guilt be on me and on my father's house. But let the king and his throne be innocent.'
2 Samuel 14:10 The king said: 'Whoever speaks against you, bring him to me, and he will not trouble you again.'
2 Samuel 14:11 She said: 'May the king remember the Lord his God, so that the avenger of blood does not multiply his vengeance and by no means kill my son.' The king then swore: 'As the Lord lives, not one hair of your son's head shall fall to the ground!'
2 Samuel 14:12 Then the woman said: 'May your handmaid speak a word to my lord, the king.'
2 Samuel 14:13 He said: 'Speak.' And the woman said: 'Why then do you intend such a thing against the people of God? For in speaking this word, the king condemns himself, because he does not recall his own banished son, Absalom.'
2 Samuel 14:14 We all must die, and we are like water poured out on the ground, which cannot be gathered up again. God does not take away a soul instantly but rather devises ways for the banished to not perish, that they may be brought back.
2 Samuel 14:15 So now, I have come to speak this word to my lord, the king, fearing that perhaps the people might frighten me. And your handmaid said: 'I will speak to the king, if perhaps the king will grant his handmaid's request.'
2 Samuel 14:16 For the king will surely listen and deliver his handmaid from the hand of any man who would try to disinherit both me and my son from the Lord's inheritance.
2 Samuel 14:17 And your handmaid said: 'May the word of my lord the king bring me peace.' For my lord the king is like an angel of God, discerning good and evil. May the Lord your God be with you.
2 Samuel 14:18 The king answered and said to the woman: 'Do not hide from me the word I am about to ask you.'
2 Samuel 14:19 The woman said: 'Let my lord the king speak.' And the king said: 'Is the hand of Joab with you in all this?'
2 Samuel 14:20 The woman answered and said: 'By the life of your soul, my lord the king, nothing you have said turns to the right or to the left from what your handmaid has uttered. For my lord the king, you are as wise as an angel of God, able to understand all things on earth. Your servant Joab himself commanded me, and he himself put all these words into the mouth of your handmaid.'
2 Samuel 14:21 Therefore, I spoke this word to bring about justice in this matter, for your servant Joab instructed me to do so.
2 Samuel 14:22 And your handmaid spoke to my lord the king, as if to fulfill the purpose of these words. For you, my lord the king, are like an angel of God in your understanding of all things. Therefore, do as you see fit in your wisdom.
2 Samuel 14:23 The king then said to Joab: 'See, I have granted your request. Go, bring back the young man Absalom.'
2 Samuel 14:24 Joab fell on his face to the ground, bowed down, and blessed the king. And Joab said: 'Today your servant understands that I have found favor in your eyes, my lord the king, because the king has granted his servant's request.'
2 Samuel 14:25 So Joab brought Absalom back to Jerusalem.
2 Samuel 14:26 The king said: 'Let him return to his own house and not see my face.' So Absalom returned to his house and did not see the king's face.
2 Samuel 14:27 Now, three sons and one daughter were born to Absalom. His daughter's name was Tamar, and she was very beautiful.
2 Samuel 14:28 Absalom remained in Jerusalem for two full years and did not see the king's face.
2 Samuel 14:29 So Absalom sent for Joab, to send him to the king, but Joab refused to come to him. When Absalom sent a second time, Joab still did not come.
2 Samuel 14:30 Then Absalom said to his servants: 'See, Joab's field is next to mine, and it has a barley crop. Go and set it on fire!' So Absalom's servants set the field on fire.
2 Samuel 14:31 Then Joab arose and came to Absalom at his house, and said: 'Why did your servants set my field on fire?'
2 Samuel 14:32 Absalom answered Joab: 'I sent to you, saying: 'Come here, so I may send you to the king to ask him: 'Why did I return from Geshur? It would have been better for me to have remained there.'' Therefore, I beg you, let me see the king's face. If there is any guilt in me, then let him put me to death.'
2 Samuel 14:33 So Joab went to the king and told him. And Absalom was called. He entered the king's presence and bowed down on his face to the ground before the king. And the king kissed Absalom.
2 Samuel 15:1 After these events, Absalom began to act like a king. He provided for himself chariots and horses, and fifty men to run before him.
2 Samuel 15:2 Absalom would rise early in the morning and stand at the entrance of the city gate. When anyone had a dispute to bring before the king for judgment, Absalom would call him over and ask, 'From what city are you?' The man would answer, 'Your servant is from one of the tribes of Israel.'
2 Samuel 15:3 Then Absalom would say to him, 'Your case seems good and just to me, but there is no official appointed by the king to hear your complaint.'
2 Samuel 15:4 Absalom would then add, 'Oh, if only someone would appoint me judge over the land! Then everyone with a dispute could come to me, and I would give them justice.'
2 Samuel 15:5 When anyone approached Absalom to pay him homage, Absalom would extend his hand, take hold of the person, and kiss him.
2 Samuel 15:6 Absalom did this with every Israelite who came to the king for judgment, and he slowly stole the hearts of the people of Israel.
2 Samuel 15:7 After four years of this, Absalom said to King David, 'Let me go to Hebron, so I may fulfill a vow I made to the Lord there.'
2 Samuel 15:8 For your servant made a vow while living in Geshur in Syria, saying: 'If the Lord brings me back to Jerusalem, I will offer a sacrifice to Him.''
2 Samuel 15:9 The king said to him, 'Go in peace.' So Absalom got up and went to Hebron.
2 Samuel 15:10 But Absalom also sent secret messengers throughout all the tribes of Israel, telling them: 'As soon as you hear the sound of the trumpet, declare: "Absalom has become king in Hebron!"'
2 Samuel 15:11 Two hundred men from Jerusalem went with Absalom. They were invited guests, completely unaware of his true intentions and went with sincere hearts.
2 Samuel 15:12 And Ahithophel the Gilonite, who was David's personal advisor, came from his city of Giloh and joined Absalom. The conspiracy became strong, and the number of people gathering with Absalom continually increased.
2 Samuel 15:13 So a messenger came to David, saying: 'The hearts of all Israel are following Absalom!'
2 Samuel 15:14 David then said to all his servants who were with him in Jerusalem: 'Get up, let us flee! Otherwise, there will be no escape for us from Absalom. Hurry and leave, so that he doesn't overtake us, bring disaster upon us, and put the city to the sword.'
2 Samuel 15:15 The king's servants said to him: 'Whatever our lord the king commands, your servants are ready to do it willingly.'
2 Samuel 15:16 So the king went out, along with his entire household and all the people who followed him. But the king left behind ten concubine women to guard the palace.
2 Samuel 15:17 The king went out, and all the people of Israel followed on foot. He stopped at a house that was some distance away from the city.
2 Samuel 15:18 All his servants marched past him; and all the Cherethites and Pelethites, and all the six hundred Gittites who had followed him from Gath, marched on foot before the king.
2 Samuel 15:19 Then the king said to Ittai the Gittite: 'Why are you coming with us? Go back and stay with the new king Absalom, for you are a foreigner and an exile from your own homeland.'
2 Samuel 15:20 You only arrived yesterday, and now should you be forced to wander with us today? I am going wherever I must go. Go back, and take your fellow countrymen with you. May the Lord show you mercy and faithfulness.
2 Samuel 15:21 But Ittai answered the king, saying: 'As the Lord lives, and as my lord the king lives, wherever my lord the king may be, whether it means death or life, there your servant will be!'
2 Samuel 15:22 David said to Ittai: 'Come then, and pass by.' So Ittai the Gittite passed by, with all his men and all the little children who were with him.
2 Samuel 15:23 All the land wept with a loud voice as all the people passed by. The king also crossed the Kidron Valley, and all the people headed toward the road that leads to the desert.
2 Samuel 15:24 And behold, Zadok came, and all the Levites with him, carrying the ark of the covenant of God. They set down the ark of God, and Abiathar also came up, waiting until all the people had finished leaving the city.
2 Samuel 15:25 Then the king said to Zadok: 'Take the ark of God back into the city. If I find favor in the eyes of the Lord, He will bring me back and show me both the ark and His dwelling place.'
2 Samuel 15:26 But if He says, 'I am not pleased with you,' then I am ready; let Him do to me whatever seems good in His sight.'
2 Samuel 15:27 The king also said to Zadok the priest: 'Do you understand? Return to the city in peace. And let your son Ahimaaz and Abiathar's son Jonathan—your two sons—be with you.'
2 Samuel 15:28 'Look, I will hide in the plains of the desert until a message comes from you to inform me.'
2 Samuel 15:29 So Zadok and Abiathar carried the ark of God back to Jerusalem, and they remained there.
