2 Samuel 15:30 Meanwhile, David went up the slope of the Mount of Olives, weeping as he climbed. His head was covered, and he walked barefoot. All the people who were with him also walked with their heads covered, weeping as they went.
2 Samuel 15:31 Someone informed David, saying: 'Ahithophel is among the conspirators with Absalom.' And David said: 'Please, Lord, make the counsel of Ahithophel foolish.'
2 Samuel 15:32 When David reached the top of the mountain, where people worshipped the Lord, suddenly Hushai the Archite met him with his tunic torn and dirt on his head.
2 Samuel 15:33 And David said to him: 'If you come with me, you will be a burden to me.'
2 Samuel 15:34 'But if you return to the city and say to Absalom: "I am your servant, O king! Just as I was your father's servant, so now I will be yours," then you can thwart the counsel of Ahithophel for me.'
2 Samuel 15:35 'You will have Zadok and Abiathar the priests with you there. Every word you hear from the king's household, you must report to Zadok and Abiathar the priests.'
2 Samuel 15:36 'Indeed, they have their two sons with them: Ahimaaz, Zadok's son, and Jonathan, Abiathar's son. Through them, you can send me every message you hear.'
2 Samuel 15:37 So Hushai, David's loyal friend, went back into the city. Just as Hushai entered, Absalom also entered Jerusalem.
2 Samuel 15:1 After these events, Absalom acquired for himself chariots and horsemen, and also fifty men who would run before him, establishing a royal display.
2 Samuel 15:2 And rising early in the morning, Absalom would stand beside the main entrance of the city gate—the place where legal cases were heard. When a man had a dispute and was on his way to the king for judgment, Absalom would call to him and ask: "From what city are you?" The man would reply: "I am your servant, from one of the tribes of Israel."
2 Samuel 15:3 Then Absalom would say to him: "Your case is sound and just, but unfortunately, there is no one appointed by the king to properly hear you."
2 Samuel 15:4 And he would add with a sigh: "If only someone would make me judge over the land! Then everyone with a dispute could come to me, and I would certainly give them justice."
2 Samuel 15:5 And if a person would approach to show him deference—by bowing down—Absalom would extend his hand, take hold of him, and kiss him.
2 Samuel 15:6 Absalom acted in this way with every Israelite who came for judgment, and by doing so, he stole the loyalty of the men of Israel.
2 Samuel 15:7 After four years had passed, Absalom said to the king: "Please allow me to go to Hebron, so that I may fulfill the vow I made to the Lord there."
2 Samuel 15:8 He added: "For while your servant was in Geshur in Syria, I made a vow saying: 'If the Lord brings me back to Jerusalem, I will offer a sacrifice to Him.'"
2 Samuel 15:9 And the king said to him: "Go in peace." So Absalom rose and went to Hebron.
2 Samuel 15:10 But Absalom had secretly sent messengers throughout all the tribes of Israel with this instruction: "As soon as you hear the sound of the trumpet, declare: 'Absalom is now king in Hebron!'"
2 Samuel 15:11 Furthermore, two hundred men from Jerusalem, who had been invited by Absalom, went with him, completely unaware of his secret plot.
2 Samuel 15:12 Achitophel the Gilonite, David's trusted advisor, also came from his city of Giloh and joined Absalom. The conspiracy grew strong, and the number of people gathering with Absalom continually increased.
2 Samuel 15:13 So a messenger came to David, reporting: "The hearts of all Israel have turned completely to Absalom."
2 Samuel 15:14 Then David said to all his servants who were with him in Jerusalem: "Get up, let us flee! Otherwise, there will be no escape for us from Absalom. Hurry and leave, lest he quickly overtake us, surround us, and strike the city with the edge of the sword."
2 Samuel 15:15 The king's servants responded to him: "Whatever our lord the king commands, we, your faithful servants, are ready to do it all."
2 Samuel 15:16 So the king departed, and his entire household followed on foot. However, the king left behind ten concubines to guard the palace.
2 Samuel 15:17 The king and all the people following in his footsteps went out, and then they stopped at a distant house.
2 Samuel 15:18 All his servants passed by him, along with all the Cherethites and all the Pelethites—his personal guard. All six hundred Gittites who had followed him from Gath also passed by before the king.
2 Samuel 15:19 Then the king said to Ittai the Gittite: "Why are you coming with us? Go back and stay with the new king Absalom, for you are a foreigner, and you are an exile from your own land."
2 Samuel 15:20 "You only arrived yesterday, and today you are forced to leave with us? I am going wherever I must go. Return, and take your countrymen with you. May the Lord show you steadfast love and faithfulness."
2 Samuel 15:21 But Ittai replied to the king: "As the Lord lives, and as my lord the king lives, wherever my lord the king may be—whether it leads to death or to life—there your servant will be also."
2 Samuel 15:22 David then said to Ittai: "Come, cross over with us." So Ittai the Gittite passed over, with all his men and all the families with him.
2 Samuel 15:23 And all the inhabitants of the land wept with a loud voice as the entire populace passed over. The king also crossed the Kidron Valley, and all the people headed toward the road leading to the wilderness.
2 Samuel 15:24 And behold, Zadok also came, and all the Levites with him, carrying the Ark of the Covenant of God. They set down the Ark of God, and Abiathar went up and offered sacrifices, until all the people had finished leaving the city.
2 Samuel 15:25 Then the king said to Zadok: "Carry the Ark of God back into the city. If I find favor in the eyes of the Lord, He will bring me back and allow me to see it and His dwelling place again."
2 Samuel 15:26 "But if He says to me: 'I am not pleased with you,' then I am ready; let Him do to me whatever seems good in His sight."
2 Samuel 15:27 The king also said to Zadok the priest: "Do you understand? Return to the city in peace. And your son Ahimaaz, and Jonathan, Abiathar's son—your two sons—let them be with you.
2 Samuel 15:28 Look, I will hide myself by the fords in the wilderness, until a message comes from you to inform me of the situation."
2 Samuel 15:29 So Zadok and Abiathar carried the Ark of God back to Jerusalem and remained there.
2 Samuel 15:30 Meanwhile, David was ascending the slope of the Mount of Olives, weeping as he went. His head was covered, and his feet were bare as a sign of mourning and humiliation. All the people who were with him also ascended with covered heads, weeping.
2 Samuel 15:31 Then it was reported to David: "Ahithophel is among the conspirators with Absalom!" And David prayed: "Please, Lord, make Ahithophel's counsel foolish."
2 Samuel 15:32 As David reached the summit of the mountain—the place where the Lord was worshipped—there, Hushai the Archite came to meet him, with his tunic torn and dust sprinkled on his head as a sign of distress.
2 Samuel 15:33 And David said to him: "If you come with me, you will be a burden to me:
2 Samuel 15:34 But if you return to the city and say to Absalom: 'I am your servant, O king; just as I was your father's servant, so now I will be your servant,' then you can thwart Ahithophel's counsel for me."
2 Samuel 15:35 Furthermore, Zadok and Abiathar, the priests, are there with you. Every word you hear from the king's household, you must report to Zadok and Abiathar the priests.
2 Samuel 15:36 For their two sons are there with them: Zadok's son Ahimaaz, and Abiathar's son Jonathan. Through them, you will send me every message that you hear."
2 Samuel 15:37 So Hushai, David's friend, returned to the city. And Absalom was entering Jerusalem.
2 Samuel 16:1 When King David had gone a little way past the summit of the Mount of Olives, Ziba, the servant of Mephibosheth, appeared before him, coming to meet him. Ziba had with him a pair of donkeys, loaded with two hundred loaves of bread, a hundred clusters of raisins, a hundred baskets of summer fruits, and a wineskin filled with wine.
2 Samuel 16:2 Then the king asked Ziba, 'What is the purpose of these things you have brought?' Ziba answered, 'The donkeys are for your household servants to ride upon. The bread and summer fruits are for your young men to eat, and the wine is for anyone who grows weary and thirsty in the desert to drink.'
2 Samuel 16:3 The king then asked, 'Where is your master's son, Mephibosheth?' And Ziba answered the king, 'He has remained in Jerusalem, saying, 'Today the house of Israel will restore the kingdom of my father to me.'
2 Samuel 16:4 Then the king said to Ziba, 'Everything that belonged to Mephibosheth is now yours.' Ziba replied, 'I bow low and plead that I may find favor in your sight, my lord, O King.'
2 Samuel 16:5 So King David came to Bahurim. And behold, a man from the kindred of the house of Saul came out from there, whose name was Shimei, the son of Gera. He came forward, cursing as he approached.
2 Samuel 16:6 He began throwing stones at David and at all the servants of King David. And all the people, and all the strongest warriors, were walking on his right and on his left side.
2 Samuel 16:7 And this is what Shimei said as he cursed the king: 'Get out! Get out, you man of bloodshed, and you worthless man!'
2 Samuel 16:8 The Lord has brought back upon you all the bloodshed of the house of Saul, because you seized his kingdom. And the Lord has now given the kingdom into the hand of your son Absalom. And behold, your own evil deeds are pressing down upon you, because you are a man of bloodshed.
2 Samuel 16:9 Then Abishai, the son of Zeruiah, said to the king, 'Why should this dead dog curse my lord the king? Let me go over now and cut off his head!'
2 Samuel 16:10 But the king said, 'What business is it of mine or yours, O sons of Zeruiah? Let him curse. For the Lord himself has commanded him to curse David, and who is there who dares to say, 'Why have you done this?'
2 Samuel 16:11 And David said to Abishai and to all his servants, 'Behold, my own son, who came out from my body, seeks my life. How much more so should this Benjaminite be allowed to curse? Let him curse, according to the Lord's command.
2 Samuel 16:12 Perhaps the Lord will look upon my affliction and repay me with good for this cursing I endure today.
2 Samuel 16:13 So David and his companions went on their way. But Shimei walked on the side of the mountain ridge, cursing as he went, and throwing stones at David and scattering dust.
2 Samuel 16:14 And the king and all the people with him arrived, weary, and refreshed themselves there.
2 Samuel 16:15 Meanwhile, Absalom and all the people of Israel with him entered Jerusalem, and Ahithophel was with him.
2 Samuel 16:16 But when Hushai the Archite, David's friend, came to Absalom, he spoke to him, saying, 'Long live the king! Long live the king!'
2 Samuel 16:17 And Absalom said to Hushai, 'Is this how you show loyalty to your friend? Why did you not go with your friend David?'
2 Samuel 16:18 Hushai answered Absalom, 'No, that is not the case. But instead, the one whom the Lord has chosen, and this people, and all of Israel, I will be his servant, and I will remain with him.'
2 Samuel 16:19 And furthermore, whose servant am I? Am I not the servant of your father? Just as I served before your father, so I will serve before you.
2 Samuel 16:20 Then Absalom said to Ahithophel, 'Give your counsel now: what should we do?'
2 Samuel 16:21 And Ahithophel said to Absalom, 'Go in to your father's concubines, whom he left behind to guard the house. For when all Israel hears that you have made yourself utterly detestable to your father, the hands of all who are with you will be strengthened.'
2 Samuel 16:22 So Absalom had a tent pitched on the roof of the palace, and he went in to his father's concubines in the sight of all Israel.
2 Samuel 16:23 Now the counsel that Ahithophel gave in those days was considered as if it were an oracle from the word of God. Such was all the counsel of Ahithophel, both when he was with David and now when he was with Absalom.
2 Samuel 16:1 As King David had gone a little way past the top of the mountain (specifically, the Mount of Olives), Mephibosheth's servant, Ziba, appeared to meet him. Ziba was bringing two saddled donkeys loaded with two hundred loaves of bread, one hundred bunches of raisins, one hundred summer fruits, and a wineskin full of wine.
2 Samuel 16:2 Then the king asked Ziba, "What are these things for?" Ziba replied, "The donkeys are for the king and his household to ride on. The bread and fruit are for your young men to eat, and the wine is for anyone who grows faint in the wilderness to drink."
2 Samuel 16:3 And the king asked, "Where is your master's son, Mephibosheth?" Ziba answered the king, "He has stayed behind in Jerusalem, saying, 'Today the house of Israel will restore my father's kingdom to me.'"
2 Samuel 16:4 Then the king said to Ziba, "Everything that belonged to Mephibosheth is now yours." Ziba replied, "I bow down to you, my lord the king; I pray that I may always find favor in your sight."
2 Samuel 16:5 So King David arrived at Bahurim, and behold, a man from the clan of Saul's family, named Shimei, the son of Gera, came out from there. He was walking along and cursing David as he came.
2 Samuel 16:6 And Shimei threw stones at King David and at all of King David's servants. All the people and all the mighty warriors were walking on the king's right and on his left side.
2 Samuel 16:7 This is what Shimei said as he cursed the king: "Get out! Get out, you man of blood, you worthless man!"
2 Samuel 16:8 The Lord has made you pay back for all the bloodshed of Saul's house, because you seized his kingdom. Now the Lord has given the kingdom into the hand of your son Absalom. Look, your own evil deeds have caught up with you, because you are a man of blood.
2 Samuel 16:9 Then Abishai, the son of Zeruiah, said to the king, "Why should this dead dog curse my lord the king? Let me go over and cut off his head!"
2 Samuel 16:10 But the king said, "What concern is this of yours and mine, you sons of Zeruiah? Let him curse. For the Lord Himself has commanded him to curse David; and who would dare to say, 'Why have you done this?'"
2 Samuel 16:11 And David said to Abishai and to all his servants, "Look, my own son, who came from my own body, is trying to take my life! How much more, then, should this Benjaminite be allowed to curse? Let him curse, for the Lord has commanded it."
2 Samuel 16:12 Perhaps the Lord will look upon my affliction, and the Lord will repay me with good instead of this cursing I receive today.
2 Samuel 16:13 So David and his companions continued on their way. Shimei kept walking along the side of the mountain ridge opposite them, cursing as he went, and throwing stones at King David, and continuously kicking up dust toward him.
2 Samuel 16:14 Thus the king and all the people with him, being tired, arrived at the Jordan River, and they rested there to refresh themselves.
2 Samuel 16:15 Meanwhile, Absalom and all the people of Israel with him had entered Jerusalem, and Ahithophel was with him.
2 Samuel 16:16 Now when Hushai the Archite, David's friend, came to Absalom, he said to him, "Long live the king! Long live the king!"
2 Samuel 16:17 And Absalom said to Hushai, "Is this the loyalty you show your friend? Why did you not go with your friend, King David?"
2 Samuel 16:18 And Hushai answered Absalom, "By no means! Rather, whomever the Lord, and this people, and all of Israel have chosen, I will be with him, and I will remain with him."
2 Samuel 16:19 Furthermore, whom should I serve next? Should it not be his son? Just as I served your father, so I will serve you.
2 Samuel 16:20 Then Absalom said to Ahithophel, "Give us your counsel; what should we do?"
2 Samuel 16:21 And Ahithophel said to Absalom, "Go in to your father's concubines, whom he left behind to guard the house. Then all of Israel will hear that you have made yourself detestable to your father, and the resolve of all who are with you will be strengthened." (This act symbolically and literally cut off any reconciliation with David and asserted Absalom's claim to the throne).
2 Samuel 16:22 So Absalom had a tent pitched on the roof of the palace, and he went in to his father's concubines in the sight of all Israel.
2 Samuel 16:23 Now the counsel that Ahithophel gave in those days was as if one consulted the oracle of God. Such was all of Ahithophel's counsel, both when he was with David and when he was with Absalom. (This highlights Ahithophel's reputation for wisdom and the gravity of his advice).
2 Samuel 17:1 Achitophel then presented his strategy to Absalom: "Let me select twelve thousand men for myself. I will set out this very night and pursue David."
2 Samuel 17:2 "I will attack him while he is weary and exhausted. I will strike him down and scatter all the people who are with him. I will kill only the king."
2 Samuel 17:3 "Then I will bring all of the people back to you, just as a bride returns to her husband. For you are seeking only the life of this one man, and afterward, all the rest of the people will be at peace."
2 Samuel 17:4 This speech pleased Absalom and all the elders of Israel.
2 Samuel 17:5 But Absalom said: "Also call Hushai the Archite, and let us hear what he too has to say."
2 Samuel 17:6 When Hushai came to Absalom, Absalom said to him: "This is what Achitophel has proposed. Should we do what he has suggested, or do you advise against it?"
2 Samuel 17:7 Hushai answered Absalom: "Achitophel’s counsel this time is not good."
2 Samuel 17:8 Hushai added: "You know your father and the men with him, that they are mighty warriors and fiercely determined. They are like a bear robbed of her cubs in the wilderness. And your father is a man of war; he will not stay with the main army."
2 Samuel 17:9 "Perhaps he is now hiding in some cave or in one of these secret places. And when he first strikes, everyone who hears of it will say, 'A great slaughter has fallen upon the people following Absalom!'"
2 Samuel 17:10 "And even the bravest, strongest-hearted man will be filled with fear if he hears that those who are with David are broken. Moreover, all Israel knows that your father is a powerful warrior, and all who are with him are mighty."
2 Samuel 17:11 "Instead, this is the counsel I give: Let all Israel gather to you, from Dan even to Beersheba—a multitude like the sand by the sea. And you yourself will lead them in the middle of them all."
2 Samuel 17:12 "Then we will fall upon him wherever he may be found, and we will cover him as the dew falls upon the earth—so that not even one man who is with him will remain alive."
2 Samuel 17:13 "If he has fled into some city, then all of Israel will surround that city. And we will drag it away with ropes until not even one small stone is found remaining there."
2 Samuel 17:14 Absalom and all the men of Israel said: "The counsel of Hushai the Archite is better than the counsel of Achitophel." For the Lord had commanded that Achitophel's useful counsel be made void, so that the Lord might bring disaster upon Absalom.
2 Samuel 17:15 Hushai then said to Zadok and Abiathar the priests: "This is the counsel Achitophel gave to Absalom and the elders of Israel, and this is the counsel I myself gave."
2 Samuel 17:16 "Now therefore, quickly send word and tell David: 'Do not stay this night in the desert of the plain. But without delay, cross over the Jordan, lest perhaps the king and all the people with him be swallowed up.'"
2 Samuel 17:17 Jonathan and Ahimaaz were waiting by the Rogel Spring. A female servant went and told them the message. And they then set out to carry the message to King David, for they could not be seen entering the city.
2 Samuel 17:18 However, a young man saw them and reported it to Absalom. But the messengers, hurrying quickly, rushed away and entered the house of a man in Bahurim who had a well in his courtyard, and they went down into it to hide.
2 Samuel 17:19 The woman then took a covering and spread it over the mouth of the well, as people usually do to dry grain, so that nothing at all was known of their hiding place.
2 Samuel 17:20 When Absalom's servants came to the woman at her house, they asked: "Where are Ahimaaz and Jonathan?" And the woman answered them: "They hurried across the stream of water." And after they searched and did not find them, they returned to Jerusalem.
2 Samuel 17:21 When those pursuers had left, the two men came up out of the well. They went and informed King David, saying: "Get up, and quickly cross the river! For Achitophel has given this kind of counsel against you."
2 Samuel 17:22 So David rose up, and all the people who were with him, and they crossed the Jordan River before daybreak. Not even one person was left who had not crossed the river.
2 Samuel 17:23 But Achitophel, seeing that his counsel had not been followed, saddled his donkey. He rose and went to his own house and to his own city. After he set his household in order, he hanged himself and died, and he was buried in his father’s tomb.
2 Samuel 17:24 Meanwhile, David arrived at Mahanaim. Absalom, however, crossed the Jordan River, and every man of Israel was with him.
2 Samuel 17:25 Absalom then appointed Amasa in place of Joab over the army. Amasa was the son of a man named Jethra the Israelite, who had gone in to Abigail, the daughter of Nahash and sister of Zeruiah, who had been Joab's mother.
2 Samuel 17:26 And Israel, with Absalom, camped in the land of Gilead.
2 Samuel 17:27 When David came to Mahanaim, three men arrived to support him: Shobi the son of Nahash from Rabbah of the sons of Ammon, and Machir the son of Ammiel from Lo-debar, and Barzillai the Gileadite from Rogelim.
2 Samuel 17:28 They brought bedding and rugs and earthenware vessels. They also brought food supplies: wheat, barley, flour, roasted grain, beans, and lentils.
2 Samuel 17:29 They also brought honey, butter, sheep, and cheese from cattle for David’s use and for the people who were with him. For they had supposed that the people might become hungry and exhausted in the desert.
2 Samuel 17:1 Achitophel then spoke to Absalom: 'Let me choose twelve thousand men for myself, and I will rise up and pursue David this very night.'
2 Samuel 17:2 'I will rush upon him while he is exhausted and weary, and I will strike him down. All the people who are with him will be scattered in terror, and I will strike the king alone.'
2 Samuel 17:3 'I will bring all the people back to you as a bride returns to her husband. For it is only the life of one man that you seek, and then all the people will be at peace.'
2 Samuel 17:4 This plan pleased Absalom and all the elders of Israel.
2 Samuel 17:5 Absalom then said: 'Call Hushai the Archite also, and let us hear what he too has to say.'
2 Samuel 17:6 When Hushai came to Absalom, Absalom said, speaking to him: 'Achitophel has spoken in this manner. Should we follow his advice or not? You advise us.'
2 Samuel 17:7 And Hushai said to Absalom: 'The advice that Achitophel has given this time is not good.'
2 Samuel 17:8 Hushai added: 'You know your father and the men who are with him, that they are very mighty and fierce in spirit, like a bear whose cubs have been taken from her in the wild. And your father is a warrior, and he will not spend the night with the people.'
2 Samuel 17:9 'Perhaps right now he is hiding in some pit or in another secret place. And if even one of your men falls at the very beginning of the battle, the people will hear of it and say, 'There has been a great slaughter among the people who follow Absalom!''
2 Samuel 17:10 'Then even the most courageous man, whose heart is like a lion, will be utterly terrified. For all of Israel knows that your father is a mighty warrior, and that all those who are with him are strong.'
2 Samuel 17:11 'Instead, I advise this plan: Let all Israel gather to you, from Dan all the way to Beersheba, as countless as the sand of the sea. And you, personally, with your army, should go into battle at the head of them.'
2 Samuel 17:12 'Then we will come upon him wherever he may be, and we will fall upon him as the dew falls upon the ground. And we will not leave even one of the men who are with him alive.'
2 Samuel 17:13 'But if he has entered into some city, then all of Israel will surround that city, and we will drag all of its stones into the river, until not even one small stone can be found there.'
2 Samuel 17:14 And it came to pass that Absalom and all the men of Israel said: 'The counsel of Hushai the Archite is better than the counsel of Achitophel.' But it was by the will of the Lord that Achitophel's useful counsel was defeated, so that the Lord might bring evil upon Absalom.
2 Samuel 17:15 Hushai then said to Zadok and Abiathar, the priests: 'Achitophel gave such and such counsel to Absalom and to the elders of Israel. And I gave such and such counsel.'
2 Samuel 17:16 'Now therefore, quickly send a message and report to David, saying: 'Do not stay this night in the desert plains, but cross over quickly, lest perhaps the king and all the people who are with him be swallowed up.''
2 Samuel 17:17 Jonathan and Ahimaaz were standing by the spring of Rogel. A servant girl would go and report to them, and they would then go and report to King David. For they could not be seen entering the city.
2 Samuel 17:18 However, a certain young man saw them and reported it to Absalom. But Jonathan and Ahimaaz hurried and entered the house of a certain man in Bahurim, who had a well in his courtyard, and they went down into it.
2 Samuel 17:19 And the woman took a covering and spread it over the mouth of the well, as if she were drying grain on it. And in this way the message was hidden.
2 Samuel 17:20 When Absalom's servants came to the woman at the house, they said: 'Where are Ahimaaz and Jonathan?' And the woman replied: 'They have crossed the stream of water.' And when they had searched and found them nowhere, they returned to Jerusalem.
2 Samuel 17:21 After their departure, Jonathan and Ahimaaz came up out of the well and went and reported to King David, and they said: 'Rise up and cross the waters quickly! For Achitophel has begun to devise such and such counsel against you.'
2 Samuel 17:22 So David arose, and all the people who were with him. And they crossed the Jordan River until dawn. Not even one person remained who had not crossed the Jordan.
2 Samuel 17:23 Now Achitophel, seeing that his counsel had not been followed, saddled his donkey and arose, and went to his house and to his city. And he hanged himself, and so he died, and was buried in the tomb of his father.
2 Samuel 17:24 But David came to Mahanaim. Furthermore, Absalom crossed the Jordan River, and all the men of Israel were with him.
2 Samuel 17:25 Absalom indeed appointed Amasa in place of Joab over the army. Amasa was the son of a man named Jether, from Israel, who had gone in to Abigail, the daughter of Nahash, the sister of Zeruiah, who was Joab's mother.
2 Samuel 17:26 And Israel, with Absalom, encamped in the land of Gilead.
2 Samuel 17:27 When David came to Mahanaim, Shobi the son of Nahash, from Rabbah of the children of Ammon, and Machir the son of Ammiel, from Lo-debar, and Barzillai the Gileadite, from Rogelim,
2 Samuel 17:28 brought him mattresses, and blankets, and earthenware vessels, and wheat, and barley, and flour, and parched grain, and beans, and lentils,
2 Samuel 17:29 And honey, and butter, and sheep, and cows from the herd. They gave these to David and to the people who were with him, so that they might eat. For they suspected that the people would be hungry, exhausted, and thirsty, having come into the wilderness.
2 Samuel 18:1 David then reviewed his army and appointed commanders and officers over them.
2 Samuel 18:2 David sent one third of the army under the command of Joab. Another third he sent under the command of Abishai, Joab's brother and son of Zeruiah. And the last third he sent under the command of Ittai the Gittite. David said to the whole army, "I will also march out with you."
2 Samuel 18:3 But the army replied, "You must not go out with us! For if we have to flee, the enemy will not care about us. And if half of us fall in battle, they will not care. But you, our king, are like ten thousand of us! It is better for you to stay in the city and help us from there."
2 Samuel 18:4 The king said to them, "Whatever seems best to you, this I will do." So the king stood by the city gate. And the entire army marched out in groups of hundreds and thousands.
2 Samuel 18:5 The king commanded Joab, Abishai, and Ittai, saying, "Deal gently, for my sake, with the young man Absalom." And all the people heard the king give this order about Absalom to all the commanders.
2 Samuel 18:6 So the army went out into the open field against the army of Israel. The battle took place in the forest of Ephraim.
2 Samuel 18:7 There, the army of Israel was defeated by David's soldiers. A great slaughter happened that day, with twenty thousand men killed.
2 Samuel 18:8 The battle spread across the entire region, and the dense forest killed more people than the sword.
2 Samuel 18:9 Absalom happened to encounter David's men. Absalom was riding a mule, and as the mule went under the thick branches of a great oak tree, Absalom's head got caught in the oak. He was left hanging between the sky and the earth, while the mule he was riding continued on its way.
2 Samuel 18:10 A certain man saw this and reported it to Joab, saying, "I saw Absalom hanging in an oak tree."
2 Samuel 18:11 Joab said to the man who reported it to him, "If you saw him, why didn't you strike him to the ground? I would have given you ten silver shekels and a military belt."
2 Samuel 18:12 The man replied to Joab, "Even if you had weighed out a thousand silver shekels into my hand, I would not have laid a hand on the king's son. In our hearing, the king commanded you, Abishai, and Ittai, saying, 'Guard the young man Absalom, so that no one harms him.'"
2 Samuel 18:13 "If I had done such a treacherous thing against his life, the king would surely have found out, and you yourself would have stood against me."
2 Samuel 18:14 Joab said, "I will not wait like this. I will deal with him myself, right here in front of you." He took three javelins in his hand and plunged them into Absalom's heart while he was still struggling and alive.
2 Samuel 18:15 Then ten young men, Joab's armor-bearers, surrounded Absalom. They struck him and finished killing him.
2 Samuel 18:16 Joab then blew the trumpet, signaling an end to the pursuit, and held back the army from chasing the fleeing Israelites. Joab wanted to spare the people.
2 Samuel 18:17 They took Absalom and threw him into a large pit in the forest, and piled a very large heap of stones over him. Then all the remaining soldiers of Israel fled to their tents.
2 Samuel 18:18 Now Absalom, during his lifetime, had erected a monument for himself in the King's Valley. He had said, "I have no son to keep my name alive." So he named the monument after himself, and it is called Absalom's Monument to this very day.
2 Samuel 18:19 Ahimaaz, Zadok's son, then said, "I will run and bring the news to the king that the Lord has avenged him against his enemies."
2 Samuel 18:20 Joab said to him, "You are not the right messenger for this news today. You may deliver a message another day, but today do not carry news, because the king's son is dead."
2 Samuel 18:21 Then Joab said to a Cushite, "Go and tell the king what you have seen." The Cushite bowed to Joab and ran off.
2 Samuel 18:22 Ahimaaz, Zadok's son, still insisted and said to Joab, "But what if I run after the Cushite?" Joab replied, "Why do you want to run, my son? You will not be rewarded for this news."
2 Samuel 18:23 "Regardless," he replied, "I will run!" So Joab said, "Go, run!" Ahimaaz then ran by way of the plain, which was a shortcut, and he overtook the Cushite.
2 Samuel 18:24 Now David was sitting between the two gates of the city. A watchman was positioned on the roof of the gate's tower, and as he looked out, he saw a man running alone.
2 Samuel 18:25 The watchman cried out and informed the king. The king said, "If he is alone, he brings good news." As the runner quickly approached,
2 Samuel 18:26 The watchman saw another man running and called out to the gatekeeper, "Look, another man is running alone!" The king said, "He also brings good news."
2 Samuel 18:27 The watchman said, "I recognize the running style of the first man; it is the stride of Ahimaaz, Zadok's son." The king said, "He is a good man, and he comes with good news."
2 Samuel 18:28 Ahimaaz called out to the king, "All is well!" He bowed before the king with his face to the ground and said, "Blessed be the Lord your God, who has delivered up the men who lifted their hands against my lord the king!"
2 Samuel 18:29 The king asked, "Is the young man Absalom safe?" Ahimaaz replied, "I saw a great commotion when Joab sent your servant, the king's servant, and me. But I do not know what it was about."
2 Samuel 18:30 The king said, "Step aside and stand over here." So he stepped aside and stood.
2 Samuel 18:31 Then, the Cushite arrived. The Cushite said, "Let my lord the king hear the news! For the Lord has avenged you today against all who rose up against you!"
2 Samuel 18:32 The king asked the Cushite, "Is the young man Absalom safe?" The Cushite answered, "May the enemies of my lord the king, and all who rise up against you with evil intent, become like that young man."
2 Samuel 18:33 The king was deeply distressed. He went up to the upper room of the gate and wept. As he walked, he kept saying, "My son Absalom, my son, my son Absalom! If only I had died instead of you, Absalom, my son, my son!"
2 Samuel 18:1 David then gathered all the men who were with him. He organized them into an army and appointed commanders over thousands of men and captains over hundreds.
2 Samuel 18:2 David then divided his fighting men into three parts. One third was under the command of Joab. Another third was under the command of Abishai, Joab’s brother, the son of Zeruiah. The final third was under the command of Ittai the Gittite. The king then spoke to the men, saying, 'I will also go out to fight with you, personally leading the charge.'
2 Samuel 18:3 The men replied, 'No, you must not go with us. If we were forced to retreat, the enemy would not care much about us. And if half of us were to fall in battle, it would not be of great concern to them. This is because you, our King, are worth ten thousand of us. Therefore, it is far better that you stay within the city and give us support from there.'
2 Samuel 18:4 The king said to them, 'I will do whatever seems best to you.' So the king stood beside the gate of the city. All the men then marched out, organized by their hundreds and by their thousands, ready for battle.
2 Samuel 18:5 The king then gave an order to Joab, Abishai, and Ittai. He said, 'For my sake, deal gently with the young man Absalom.' All the fighting men heard the king giving this instruction to all his commanders concerning Absalom.
2 Samuel 18:6 So the men of David went out into the field against the rebel army of Israel. The battle took place in the forest of Ephraim.
2 Samuel 18:7 There, the army of Israel was defeated by David’s servants. On that day, a great slaughter occurred, with twenty thousand men being killed.
2 Samuel 18:8 The battle spread out across the entire face of the land. More men were killed by the forest itself—by its dangers and confusion—than were consumed by the sword in the fighting that day.
2 Samuel 18:9 It happened that Absalom came upon David’s servants while riding a mule. The mule went under a large, low-hanging oak tree, and Absalom’s head became entangled in the branches of the oak. He was left suspended there between the sky and the ground, while the mule he had been riding continued on its way.
2 Samuel 18:10 A certain man saw this occur and reported it to Joab, saying, 'I saw Absalom hanging in an oak tree.'
2 Samuel 18:11 Joab replied, 'If you saw him, why didn’t you strike him down to the ground right there? I would have given you ten shekels of silver and a military belt as a reward.'
2 Samuel 18:12 The man answered Joab, 'Even if you were to weigh out a thousand shekels of silver into my hands, I would not lift my hand against the king’s son. For we all heard the king give you, Abishai, and Ittai this command: ‘Be careful that no one harms the young man Absalom.’'
2 Samuel 18:13 Truly, I would not risk my own life by daring to disregard your orders—and the king would surely find out about this. In that case, you yourself would stand against me for disobeying the king.
2 Samuel 18:14 Joab then said, 'That is not how this will end. I will act in your presence!' He took three spears in his hand and thrust them into Absalom’s heart while Absalom was still alive and hanging in the oak tree.
2 Samuel 18:15 Then ten young men, who were Joab’s armor-bearers, surrounded Absalom. They struck him again and killed him, ensuring his death.
2 Samuel 18:16 Joab then blew the trumpet, signaling an end to the pursuit. He stopped the men from chasing the fleeing Israelites, for Joab wanted to spare the people of Israel from further slaughter.
2 Samuel 18:17 Then David’s men took Absalom and threw his body into a large pit in the forest. They piled a very great heap of stones over him, marking his dishonorable grave. Meanwhile, all the remaining men of Israel who had fought for Absalom fled to their homes and tents.
2 Samuel 18:18 Now, while Absalom was still alive, he had erected a pillar for himself in the King’s Valley. He had said, 'I have no son to keep my name alive, so this pillar will be a monument to my name.' He named the pillar after himself, and it is called to this very day, 'Absalom’s Monument.'
2 Samuel 18:19 Then Ahimaaz, the son of Zadok, said, 'I will run now and bring news to the king—that the Lord has given him victory over his enemies.'
2 Samuel 18:20 But Joab said to him, 'You will not be the messenger today. You may be a messenger on another day, but I do not want you to be the messenger today, because the king’s son is dead, and the news will bring him great sorrow.'
2 Samuel 18:21 Joab then said to a Cushite man, 'Go, tell the king what you have seen.' The Cushite bowed to Joab and quickly ran off.
2 Samuel 18:22 Ahimaaz, the son of Zadok, again urged Joab, saying, 'What prevents me from running after the Cushite man as well?' Joab replied, 'Why would you run, my son? You will not be bringing good news.'
2 Samuel 18:23 Ahimaaz answered, 'Even so, what if I simply run?' And Joab said to him, 'Then run!' So Ahimaaz ran by way of the plain and outran the Cushite man.
2 Samuel 18:24 Now David was sitting between the two inner and outer gates of the city. A lookout man had gone up to the roof of the gate by the wall. When he lifted his eyes and saw a man running alone toward them,
2 Samuel 18:25 he called out and informed the king. The king said, 'If he is alone, then he is bringing good news.' As the man hurried and came closer,
2 Samuel 18:26 the lookout saw another man running. The first lookout called out to the king, saying, 'Look, another man is running alone!' The king replied, 'He, too, is bringing good news.'
2 Samuel 18:27 The lookout then said, 'I recognize the running style of the first man; it is like the running of Ahimaaz, the son of Zadok.' The king said, 'He is a good man, and he comes bringing good tidings.'
2 Samuel 18:28 Ahimaaz then called out and said to the king, 'All is well, O king!' He bowed before the king with his face to the ground and said, 'Blessed be the Lord your God, who has delivered up the men who raised their hands against my lord the king!'
2 Samuel 18:29 The king asked, 'Is the young man Absalom safe?' Ahimaaz answered, 'I saw a great commotion when Joab, your servant, was sending me, your humble servant. I do not know what else happened beyond that.'
2 Samuel 18:30 The king said, 'Stand aside here.' So Ahimaaz stepped aside and stood still.
2 Samuel 18:31 And behold, the Cushite man arrived. He said, 'Let my lord the king hear the news! For the Lord has today granted you justice by delivering you from the hand of all who rose up against you!'
2 Samuel 18:32 The king asked the Cushite man, 'Is the young man Absalom safe?' The Cushite answered, 'May the enemies of my lord the king, and all who rise up against you with evil intent, be as that young man is now.'
2 Samuel 18:33 The king was deeply shaken and distressed. He went up to the room above the gate and wept. As he walked, he spoke, saying, 'My son Absalom, my son, my son Absalom! If only I had died instead of you, Absalom, my son, my son!'
2 Samuel 19:1 It was reported to Joab that the king was weeping, and openly mourning over Absalom.
2 Samuel 19:2 And so, all the joy of the people on that day turned into deep mourning, for everyone heard that the king was heartbroken over his son.
2 Samuel 19:3 The people were unsettled; they entered the city in silence on that day. They were as disquieted as an army that has been defeated, and then flees in shame and confusion.
2 Samuel 19:4 The king kept crying out in a loud voice: “My son Absalom, Absalom my son, my son!”
2 Samuel 19:5 So Joab entered the king’s house, and said to him: “Today, you have made all of your servants ashamed. These are the men who, on this very day, saved your life, and the lives of your sons, and your daughters, and your wives, and your concubines.
2 Samuel 19:6 You love those who hate you, and you hate those who love you. You have shown today that you have no concern for your commanders or for your servants. I truly know this day that if Absalom were alive, and all of us had died, then it would please you.
2 Samuel 19:7 Now get up, go out, and speak words of comfort to your servants. For I swear to you by the Lord, if you do not go out, not even one man will remain with you tonight. And this will be worse for you than all the evils that have befallen you from your youth until this present day.”
2 Samuel 19:8 So the king rose up, and he sat at the city gate. And it was announced to all the people that the king was sitting at the gate. Then all the people came before the king.
2 Samuel 19:9 Meanwhile, the army of Israel had fled, each man to his own tent, their homes.
2 Samuel 19:10 And all the people were contending in all the tribes of Israel, saying: “The king delivered us from the hand of our enemies. He himself rescued us from the hand of the Philistines. And now he has fled from the land because of Absalom.
2 Samuel 19:11 But Absalom, whom we anointed over us as king, is dead in battle. Now then, why are you silent? Why are you not bringing the king back?”
2 Samuel 19:12 But King David sent word to Zadok and Abiathar, the priests, saying: “Speak to the elders of Judah, saying: ‘Why are you the last to bring the king back to his house?
2 Samuel 19:13 You are my brothers, my very own flesh and blood. Why should you be the last to bring the king back?
2 Samuel 19:14 And to Amasa you shall say: ‘Are you not my very own flesh and blood? May God do such to me, and add more to it, if you are not the commander of my army for all days in place of Joab.’ ”
2 Samuel 19:15 And David swayed the hearts of all the men of Judah as if they were one man. So they sent word to the king, saying: “Return, you and all your servants.”
2 Samuel 19:16 So the king returned, and came as far as the Jordan River. And Judah had come to Gilgal to meet the king, so that they might escort him across the Jordan.
2 Samuel 19:17 Then Shimei, the son of Gera, the Benjaminite from Bahurim, hurried and came down with the men of Judah to meet King David.
2 Samuel 19:18 There were a thousand men of Benjamin with him. Also, Ziba, the servant of Saul’s house, and his fifteen sons, and his twenty servants were with him. And they rushed into the Jordan ahead of the king.
2 Samuel 19:19 They crossed the river by ferry boat to carry over the king’s household and to do whatever he commanded. Shimei also, the son of Gera, prostrated himself before the king when he had just crossed the Jordan.
2 Samuel 19:20 He said to the king: “My lord, do not hold my iniquity against me. Let what your servant did perversely on the day my Lord the King departed from Jerusalem not be remembered. Do not take it to heart, O King.
2 Samuel 19:21 For your servant knows that I have sinned. And because of this, behold, I am the first of all the house of Joseph —meaning the northern tribes of Israel— to come down and meet you, my Lord the King.”
2 Samuel 19:22 But Abishai, the son of Zeruiah, answered and said: “Shall not Shimei be put to death for this, because he cursed the Lord’s anointed king?”
2 Samuel 19:23 And David said: “What have I to do with you, sons of Zeruiah? Why do you oppose me today? Shall any man be put to death in Israel today? Do you not know that today I have been established as king over Israel?”
2 Samuel 19:24 And the king said to Shimei: “You shall not die.” And the king swore an oath to him.
2 Samuel 19:25 Mephibosheth, the son of Saul, also came down to meet the king. He had not washed his feet, nor trimmed his beard, nor washed his clothes from the day the king had departed in flight until the day he returned in peace.
2 Samuel 19:26 When he had greeted the king, the king said to him: “Why did you not come with me, Mephibosheth?”
2 Samuel 19:27 And he answered, saying: “My Lord the king, my servant Ziba deceived me. For I said to him, ‘Saddle an ass for me, so I may ride on it and go with the king,’ for I am lame.
2 Samuel 19:28 And he —Ziba— has falsely slandered me to you, my lord the king. But you, my lord the king, are like an angel of God. Do what pleases you.
2 Samuel 19:29 For indeed, the house of my father —Saul's house— was deserving of nothing but death from my lord the king. Yet you placed your servant among those who eat at your own table. So what just reason do I have to still complain to the king?”
2 Samuel 19:30 And the king said: “Why do you speak further? I have said: you and Ziba shall divide the land possessions.”
2 Samuel 19:31 Then Mephibosheth said to the king: “Indeed, let him —Ziba— take everything, now that my Lord the King has returned to his house in peace.”
2 Samuel 19:32 Barzillai the Gileadite also came down from Rogelim, and he crossed the Jordan with the king to escort him and provide for him on his journey.
2 Samuel 19:33 Now Barzillai was very old, eighty years of age. And he had provided sustenance for the king while he stayed at Mahanaim. For he was a very wealthy man.
2 Samuel 19:34 So the king said to Barzillai: “Come with me, so that you may be cared for by me in Jerusalem.”
2 Samuel 19:35 And Barzillai answered the king: “How many days are there in the years of my life, that I should go up with the king to Jerusalem?
2 Samuel 19:36 I am eighty years old today. Can I still discern what is good or bad? Can your servant still delight in food or drink? Can I still hear the voice of male or female singers? Why should your servant be a burden to my Lord the King?
2 Samuel 19:37 Let your servant just escort the king across the Jordan. Do not repay me with this kindness that I cannot fully appreciate.
2 Samuel 19:38 But let your servant return, and I will die in my own city, and be buried beside the tomb of my father and my mother. However, your servant Chimham is here. Let him go with you, my Lord the King, and do for him whatever pleases you.”
2 Samuel 19:39 And the king said: “Let Chimham go with me, and I will do for him whatever pleases you. And anything you request of me, you shall obtain.”
2 Samuel 19:40 Then all the people crossed the Jordan, and the king was in their midst. And when the king returned, he came to Gilgal, and Chimham with him. All the people of Judah had escorted the king, and half of the people of Israel.
2 Samuel 19:1 And it was reported to Joab that the king was weeping and mourning over Absalom.
2 Samuel 19:2 And all the joy of the people turned into mourning on that day, because the people heard that the king was grieving deeply over his son.
2 Samuel 19:3 And the people entered the city in a stealthy manner on that day, just as a people who are ashamed and have fled from battle are accustomed to enter secretly.
2 Samuel 19:4 But the king was crying out, with his face covered, and with a loud voice, saying: "My son Absalom, my son Absalom! Oh, that I had died for you, my son Absalom!"
2 Samuel 19:5 So Joab came to the king in his house and said: "Today you have shamed the faces of all your servants who have fought today for your life, and for the lives of your sons and your daughters, and for the lives of your wives, and for the lives of your concubines."
2 Samuel 19:6 "You love those who hate you, and you hate those who love you. And you have shown today that you care nothing for your commanders and your servants. Indeed, I know now that if Absalom were alive, and all of us had died today, then that would have pleased you."
2 Samuel 19:7 "So now, get up and go out, and speak words of comfort to your servants. For I swear to you by the Lord, that if you do not go out, not even one man will remain with you this night. And this will be worse for you than all the evils that have happened to you from your youth until now."
2 Samuel 19:8 So the king got up and sat in the city gate. And it was announced to all the people that the king was sitting in the gate. Then all the multitude came before the king.
2 Samuel 19:9 Meanwhile, all of Israel had fled to their tents.
2 Samuel 19:10 And all the people were contending throughout all the tribes of Israel, saying: "The king delivered us from the hand of our enemies, and he himself rescued us from the hand of the Philistines. And now he had been forced to flee from the land because of Absalom."
2 Samuel 19:11 "But Absalom, whom we anointed over us, is dead in battle. Now then, why do you not take steps to bring the king back?"
2 Samuel 19:12 Now King David sent word to Zadok and Abiathar, the priests, saying: "Speak to the elders of Judah, saying: 'Why are you the very last to bring the king back to his house?'" For the words of all Israel had reached the king in his house.
2 Samuel 19:13 "And say to Amasa: 'Are you not my bone and my flesh? May God do so to me, and more also, if you are not commander of my army before me at all times instead of Joab.'"
2 Samuel 19:14 And he turned the heart of all the men of Judah as one man. So they sent word to the king, saying: "Return, you and all your servants."
2 Samuel 19:15 So the king returned and came as far as the Jordan River. And Judah came to Gilgal to meet the king, to escort him across the Jordan.
2 Samuel 19:16 But Shimei, the son of Gera, a Benjamite from Bahurim, hurried and came down with the men of Judah to meet King David.
2 Samuel 19:17 And a thousand men of Benjamin were with him. Also Ziba, the servant of Saul's house, with his fifteen sons and twenty servants, were with him. And they rushed into the Jordan, going ahead of the king.
2 Samuel 19:18 And they crossed the ford to help the king's household cross over and to do whatever he commanded. And Shimei himself prostrated himself before the king, after the king had already crossed the Jordan.
2 Samuel 19:19 He said to the king: "Do not count against me, my lord, this iniquity, nor remember what I did wickedly on the day when you departed from Jerusalem, my lord the king. Let your heart not bear a grudge, O king."
2 Samuel 19:20 "For I, your servant, confess my sin. And behold, for this reason, I am the first of all the house of Joseph — meaning the northern tribes of Israel — who has come down today to meet my lord the king."
2 Samuel 19:21 But Abishai, the son of Zeruiah, answered and said: "Shall not Shimei be put to death for this, because he cursed the Lord's anointed?"
2 Samuel 19:22 And David said: "What have I to do with you, sons of Zeruiah, that you should be adversaries to me today? Shall any man be put to death in Israel today? Do I not know today that I am established as king over Israel?"
2 Samuel 19:23 And the king said to Shimei: "You shall not die." And the king swore an oath to him.
2 Samuel 19:24 Mephibosheth, the son of Saul, also came down to meet the king. And he was in mourning, with unwashed feet and an untrimmed beard, from the day the king had departed until the day of his peaceful return.
2 Samuel 19:25 When he came to Jerusalem to meet the king, the king said to him: "Why did you not come with me, Mephibosheth?"
2 Samuel 19:26 He answered and said: "My lord the king, my servant Ziba despised me. For I said to him that he should saddle a donkey for me, so that I might ride upon it and go with the king, because your servant is lame."
2 Samuel 19:27 "And he himself, your servant Ziba, has slandered me to you, my lord the king. But you, O king, are like an angel of God; do what is pleasing to you."
2 Samuel 19:28 "For there was nothing from all my father's house but that which was worthy of death before you. Yet you placed your servant among those who eat at your table. What then do I have to complain about justly? Or what more can I cry out to the king?"
2 Samuel 19:29 And the king said to him: "Why do you speak further? I have decided: You and Ziba divide the land."
2 Samuel 19:30 And Mephibosheth answered the king: "Let him even take everything, since my lord the king has returned to his house in peace."
2 Samuel 19:31 Barzillai the Gileadite also came down from Rogelim and accompanied the king across the Jordan, to go with him beyond the Jordan.
2 Samuel 19:32 Now Barzillai was very old, that is, eighty years old. And he himself had provided for the king while he stayed at Mahanaim, for he was a very great man.
2 Samuel 19:33 And the king said to Barzillai: "Come with me, that you may rest with me in Jerusalem."
2 Samuel 19:34 And Barzillai said to the king: "How many are the days of the years of my life, that I should go up with the king to Jerusalem?"
2 Samuel 19:35 "I am eighty years old today. Can I still discern good from bad? Can your servant taste what I eat or drink? Can I still hear the voice of male and female singers? Why should your servant be a burden to you in all these things?"
2 Samuel 19:36 "Your servant will only tarry a little while across the Jordan. I beg you, let me return and die in my own city, and be buried near the tomb of my father and my mother. Behold, your servant Chimham is here; let him go with you, my lord the king, and do for him whatever pleases you."
2 Samuel 19:37 And the king said: "Let Chimham go with you, and I will do for him whatever pleases you, and everything you ask of me, you shall obtain."
2 Samuel 19:38 When all the people had crossed the Jordan, and the king also crossed over, the king kissed Barzillai and blessed him. And Barzillai returned to his own place.
2 Samuel 19:39 So the king went on to Gilgal, and Chimham with him. All the people of Judah had escorted the king, and half the people of Israel as well.
2 Samuel 19:40 And behold, all the men of Israel came to the king, saying to the king: "Why have our brothers, the men of Judah, stolen you away and brought the king, and his household, and all the men of David with him, across the river?"
2 Samuel 20:1 And behold, there was a lawless man there, named Sheba, the son of Bichri, a Benjaminite. This man blew a trumpet, and cried out, saying: "We have no portion with David, nor do we have any inheritance in the son of Jesse—that is, in David's lineage! Every man, return now to your own homes, O Israel!"
2 Samuel 20:2 So all the other tribes of Israel withdrew their loyalty from David and followed Sheba, the son of Bichri. However, the men of Judah remained completely loyal to their king, from the Jordan River all the way to Jerusalem.
2 Samuel 20:3 When King David arrived at his house in Jerusalem, he took his ten concubine women whom he had left behind to watch over the palace during his flight. Because they had been defiled by Absalom, David placed them in a secluded house, like women in widowhood. He provided them with food and everything they needed, but he never had relations with them again. They remained shut away in this condition until the day they died, living as if they were true widows.
2 Samuel 20:4 Then King David said to Amasa: "Summon all the men of Judah to assemble for me within three days, and make sure that you yourself are present."
2 Samuel 20:5 So Amasa went out to summon Judah, but he delayed much longer than the time the king had set for him to return.
2 Samuel 20:6 Therefore, David said to Abishai: "Now Sheba, the son of Bichri, will do us more harm than Absalom ever did. Take therefore your master's servants—that is, my personal guard—and pursue him, lest he seize fortified cities and escape from us."
2 Samuel 20:7 So Joab's men went out with Abishai, along with the Cherethites, and the Pelethites—that is, David's elite guard—and all the strong warriors. They marched out from Jerusalem to pursue Sheba, the son of Bichri.
2 Samuel 20:8 As they were near the great stone that is in Gibeon, Amasa came to meet them. Now Joab was girded with his military tunic over his usual garment, and around his waist was a tightly fastened belt with a dagger sheathed in it. As he went forward, the dagger immediately fell out of its sheath and to the lower part of his body—unbeknownst to Amasa, this was a deliberate maneuver.
2 Samuel 20:9 And Joab said to Amasa: "Greetings, my brother!" Then with his right hand, Joab took hold of Amasa's beard, as if to kiss him.
2 Samuel 20:10 But Amasa did not notice the sword that Joab held in his left hand. With it, Joab struck him in the side, spilling his intestines out onto the ground. He did not need a second wound; Amasa died immediately. After this, Joab and Abishai, his brother, continued their pursuit of Sheba, the son of Bichri.
2 Samuel 20:11 And one of Joab's servants, standing by Amasa's body, cried out: "Whoever is for Joab, and whoever is for David, let him follow Joab!"
2 Samuel 20:12 Now Amasa was writhing in his own blood in the middle of the road. That man saw that all the people were stopping because of the sight. So he dragged Amasa off the road into a field and covered him with a garment, so that passersby would not stop and hinder the pursuit because of him.
2 Samuel 20:13 Once Amasa was removed from the road, all the men who were following Joab continued their march to pursue Sheba, the son of Bichri.
2 Samuel 20:14 Sheba, however, passed through all the tribes of Israel, going to Abel of Beth-Maachah, and through all the communities of the Berites. There, all the people gathered and followed him.
2 Samuel 20:15 So Joab arrived and besieged Sheba in Abel of Beth-Maachah. They built a siege ramp and a trench around the city. Then all the troops who were with Joab took their positions and began to undermine the city walls.
2 Samuel 20:16 Then a wise woman from the city called out: "Listen! Listen! Speak to Joab! Tell him to come closer, so I may speak with him."
2 Samuel 20:17 When Joab approached, she asked: "Are you Joab?" He answered: "I am." And she said: "Hear the words of your handmaid." He replied: "I am listening."
2 Samuel 20:18 Then she spoke: "There is an old saying, and it is spoken: 'Whoever inquires in Abel, that is how the matter is resolved.'"
2 Samuel 20:19 She continued: "I am among those who seek counsel and pursue peace in Israel. Yet you are trying to overthrow a city, and to destroy a mother in Israel—a principal city. Why would you devastate the inheritance of the Lord?"
2 Samuel 20:20 And Joab answered, saying: "Far be it, far be it from me! This will never happen!"
2 Samuel 20:21 He continued: "That is not the case at all! Rather, a man from the hill country of Ephraim, named Sheba, the son of Bichri, has raised his hand in rebellion against King David. Just hand him over, and we will withdraw from the city." And the woman said to Joab: "Behold, his head will be thrown over the wall to you."
2 Samuel 20:22 So the woman went to all the people and spoke to them with wisdom. Then they cut off the head of Sheba, the son of Bichri, and threw it over the wall to Joab. Joab then blew the trumpet, and all the men dispersed from the city, each returning to his own home. Joab, for his part, returned to Jerusalem to the king.
2 Samuel 20:23 Now Joab was in command of all the army of Israel. Benaiah, the son of Jehoiada, was in command over the Cherethites and the Pelethites—David's personal bodyguards.
2 Samuel 20:24 Adoram was in charge of collecting tribute. Jehoshaphat, the son of Ahilud, was the recorder of official records.
2 Samuel 20:25 Sheva was the secretary. Zadok and Abiathar were the priests.
2 Samuel 20:26 And Ira, the Jairite, was also a priest alongside David, serving as his personal chaplain.
2 Samuel 20:1 It happened then that a wicked man named Sheba, son of Bochri, from the tribe of Benjamin, found a trumpet and blew it, declaring to the people: "We have no portion in David! We have no inheritance in the son of Jesse (meaning King David)! Everyone to your tents, O Israel!" So all the people of Israel turned away from David and followed Sheba, son of Bochri. But the men of Judah remained loyal to their king, accompanying him from the Jordan River all the way to Jerusalem.
2 Samuel 20:2 When David returned to his palace in Jerusalem, the king took the ten concubines whom he had left behind to guard the household. He placed them under house arrest, providing for their sustenance, but he no longer had marital relations with them. They remained confined, living as widows until the day they died.
2 Samuel 20:3 Indeed, when the king arrived at his house in Jerusalem, he took the ten concubine women whom he had sent away to guard the house. He confined them to a house, placing them under guard, and provided them with food. He did not go in to them, and they remained locked away, living like widows until their death.
2 Samuel 20:4 Then the king said to Amasa: "Call the men of Judah for me to gather by the third day, and you must be present there yourself."
2 Samuel 20:5 So Amasa went to summon the men of Judah, but he delayed beyond the appointed time that the king had set for him.
2 Samuel 20:6 And David said to Abishai: "Now Sheba, son of Bochri, will do us more harm than Absalom did. Therefore, take your master's soldiers and pursue him, lest he find fortified cities and escape from us."
2 Samuel 20:7 So Joab's men went out after Abishai, along with the Cherethites, the Pelethites, and all the mighty warriors. They left Jerusalem to pursue Sheba, son of Bochri.
2 Samuel 20:8 When they were near the great stone in Gibeon, Amasa came to meet them. Joab was dressed in his military uniform, and over it, a sword was belted to his waist, sheathed at his side. As he stepped forward, the sword slipped out of its sheath and fell.
2 Samuel 20:9 And Joab said to Amasa: "Greetings, my brother!" Then Joab took Amasa by the beard with his right hand, as if to kiss him.
2 Samuel 20:10 But Amasa did not pay attention to the sword that Joab held in his left hand. Joab then stabbed him in the side, piercing his groin, and spilled his intestines onto the ground. He did not need to strike a second blow, and Amasa died. Then Joab and his brother Abishai continued their pursuit of Sheba, son of Bochri.
2 Samuel 20:11 Meanwhile, one of Joab's young men (soldiers) stood by Amasa's body and said: "Let anyone who is for Joab, and who is for David, follow us!"
2 Samuel 20:12 Now Amasa lay writhing in his blood in the middle of the road. That soldier saw that all the people who were passing by were stopping to look. So he dragged Amasa from the road into a field and covered him with a garment, so that the sight of him would not delay the people who were passing by.
2 Samuel 20:13 Therefore, once Amasa's body was removed from the road, all the men continued on to pursue Sheba, son of Bochri, with Joab and all who were with him.
2 Samuel 20:14 Sheba then traveled through all the tribes of Israel and came to Abel of Beth Maachah and all the Berites. There, many people gathered and followed him.
2 Samuel 20:15 Joab's forces came and besieged Sheba in Abel of Beth Maachah. They surrounded the city, and against its walls, they built a siege ramp. All the multitude that was with Joab began undermining the wall, attempting to cause it to collapse.
2 Samuel 20:16 Then a wise woman cried out from the city: "Listen! Listen! Tell Joab: Come near here, and I will speak with you."
2 Samuel 20:17 When Joab approached her, the woman asked: "Are you Joab?" And he answered: "I am." She said to him: "Hear the words of your servant." And he replied: "I hear."
2 Samuel 20:18 And she said: "There is an old saying among the people who would declare: 'When they seek counsel in Abel, they bring matters to completion.'" (This proverb highlights Abel's reputation as a place of wisdom and resolution.)
2 Samuel 20:19 I am one of those who seek peace and receive a peaceful answer in Israel. So why do you want to destroy a city that is one of the chief cities in Israel? And why do you seek to ruin the inheritance of the Lord (meaning God's people)?
2 Samuel 20:20 And Joab answered, saying: "Far be it from me, far be it from me, that I should destroy or demolish anything!"
2 Samuel 20:21 That is not the case. Instead, a man from the hill country of Ephraim, named Sheba, son of Bochri, has raised his hand against King David. Hand over him alone, and we will withdraw from the city." And the woman said to Joab: "Behold, his head will be thrown over the wall to you."
2 Samuel 20:22 So the woman went to all the people and spoke to them wisely. And they cut off the head of Sheba, son of Bochri, and threw it to Joab. He immediately blew the trumpet, signaling the end of the siege, and they withdrew from the city, each man returning to his own tents. Joab then returned to Jerusalem to the king.
2 Samuel 20:23 Therefore, Joab remained commander over all the army of Israel. Benaiah, son of Jehoiada, was in charge of the Cherethites and the Pelethites (David's elite bodyguard and executioners).
2 Samuel 20:24 Adoram was in charge of the tribute (overseeing forced labor and taxes). Jehoshaphat, son of Ahilud, was the recorder (the royal chronicler or secretary of state).
2 Samuel 20:25 Sheva was the scribe (the secretary who managed royal correspondence and records). And Zadok and Abiathar were the priests (the two high priests serving David).
2 Samuel 20:26 Moreover, Ira the Jairite was also a priest for David (likely a personal or honorary priestly advisor to the king).
2 Samuel 21:1 And a famine came upon the land during the reign of King David, and this famine lasted for three continuous years. King David sought to know the reason, so he consulted the oracle of the Lord for divine instruction. And the Lord revealed: 'This famine is because of Saul, and because of his entire house, which is guilty of shedding innocent blood — a bloodguilt incurred when Saul, in his zeal, massacred the Gibeonites.'
2 Samuel 21:2 So King David called the Gibeonites to him and spoke with them. (Now, the Gibeonites were not from the Israelite people, but were a remnant of the Amorites. The sons of Israel had sworn an oath to them long ago, but Saul, in his misguided zeal for the sons of Israel and Judah, had sought to kill them all.)
2 Samuel 21:3 Then David said to the Gibeonites: 'What must I do for you? And what atonement can be made, so that you may bless the inheritance of the Lord — meaning, the people and land of Israel?'
2 Samuel 21:4 And the Gibeonites answered him: 'It is not a matter of silver or gold for us concerning Saul or his house. Nor do we desire that any specific man of Israel be put to death by our hand.' But they had something else in mind. And David said to them: 'Whatever you ask for, I will do it for you.'
2 Samuel 21:5 They responded to the king: 'Concerning the man who crushed us, who utterly destroyed us, and who planned for us to be completely annihilated — so that we would no longer exist within any of the borders of Israel—'
2 Samuel 21:6 'Let seven men from his sons be given to us. We will then impale them before the Lord in Gibeah of Saul, the very place where Saul, the Lord's chosen king, once lived.' And the king said: 'I will give them to you.'
2 Samuel 21:7 However, the king spared Mephibosheth, the son of Jonathan, who was Saul's son. He did this because of the solemn oath made before the Lord that had existed between David and Jonathan, Saul's son.
2 Samuel 21:8 So King David took two sons of Rizpah, daughter of Aiah, whom she had borne to Saul: Armoni and Mephibosheth. He also took the five sons of Michal, daughter of Saul, whom she had borne to Adriel, the son of Barzillai the Meholathite.
2 Samuel 21:9 And David gave these seven men into the hand of the Gibeonites. They impaled them on the mountain before the Lord. And these seven fell together — they died on the very first days of the harvest, right as the people were beginning to cut the wheat.
2 Samuel 21:10 But Rizpah, daughter of Aiah, took sackcloth and spread it for herself on a rock from the beginning of the harvest season. She stayed there, watching over the bodies, until rain poured down upon them from the sky — signifying God's acceptance of the atonement. During all this time, she did not allow the birds of the sky to rest upon the bodies by day, nor the wild animals of the field to approach them by night.
2 Samuel 21:11 And it was reported to King David what Rizpah, daughter of Aiah, Saul's concubine, had done in her faithfulness.
2 Samuel 21:12 Then David went and took the bones of Saul and the bones of his son Jonathan from the men of Jabesh-Gilead. These men had secretly taken them from the public square of Beth-Shan, where the Philistines had hung them after they killed Saul on Mount Gilboa.
2 Samuel 21:13 And from there, David brought the bones of Saul and the bones of his son Jonathan. He also gathered the bones of those men who had been impaled.
2 Samuel 21:14 And they buried them — meaning, all the bones — with the bones of Saul and his son Jonathan in the land of Benjamin, in Zela, in the tomb of Kish, Saul's father. They carried out everything the king had commanded. After these things were done, God was appeased concerning the land, and the famine ended.
2 Samuel 21:15 Now, it happened again that there was a battle of the Philistines against Israel. David went down, and his servants went with him, and they fought against the Philistines. And during the fighting, David grew weary and exhausted.
2 Samuel 21:16 Then Ishbi-Benob, who was one of the descendants of the giant Rapha, whose spear weighed three hundred shekels of bronze — equivalent to a heavy amount of gold — and who was armed with a new sword, tried to kill King David.
2 Samuel 21:17 But Abishai, the son of Zeruiah, came to David's rescue. He struck the Philistine and killed him. Then the men of David swore an oath to him, saying: 'You shall not go out with us into battle anymore, lest you extinguish the lamp of Israel' — meaning, the very light and hope of our nation.
2 Samuel 21:18 After this, another battle occurred in Gob against the Philistines. At that time, Sibbecai the Hushathite struck down Saph, who was also one of the descendants of the giant Rapha.
2 Samuel 21:19 And again, battle was fought in Gob against the Philistines. In this engagement, Elhanan, the craftsman — whose proper name `Adeodatus faber` means 'God-given artisan' — struck down the Gittite giant, who was surnamed Goliath, and whose spear shaft was so massive it resembled a weaver's beam.
2 Samuel 21:20 There was also another battle in Gath, in which there was a man of great stature. He had six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot — that is, twenty-four digits in total. And he was also one of the descendants of the giant Rapha.
2 Samuel 21:21 And he — this giant — blasphemed Israel, challenging them. And Jonathan, the son of Shimei, David's brother, struck him down.
2 Samuel 21:22 These four — meaning these four giants from the lineage of Rapha who lived in Gath — all fell by the hand of King David and his servants.
2 Samuel 21:1 During David's reign, a famine that lasted continuously for three years occurred. So David inquired of the Lord, seeking His divine answer. The Lord then said: "This famine is because of Saul and his household's bloodguilt, and because he killed the Gibeonites."
2 Samuel 21:2 The king then summoned the Gibeonites and spoke with them. (The Gibeonites, by the way, were not descendants of Israel but were among the remaining Amorites. The sons of Israel had once sworn an oath to them, but Saul, in his zeal for the people of Israel and Judah, had attempted to wipe them out.)
2 Samuel 21:3 David then asked the Gibeonites: "What do you want me to do for you? What atonement can I make so that you may bless the Lord's inheritance—His people and His land—and the famine will end?"
2 Samuel 21:4 The Gibeonites answered him: "Our claim against Saul and his house is not about silver or gold. Nor do we desire that any ordinary Israelite be put to death." David then pressed them again: "What then *do* you want me to do for you?"
2 Samuel 21:5 They answered the king: "Concerning the man who crushed us and cruelly persecuted us with the intent to wipe us out completely from all the borders of Israel—"
2 Samuel 21:6 "—let seven men of his descendants be given to us, so that they may be impaled before the Lord in Gibeon, Saul's city, who was once the Lord's chosen king." The king replied: "I will give them."
2 Samuel 21:7 However, the king spared Mephibosheth, the son of Jonathan (Saul's son), because of the sacred oath sworn before the Lord between David and Jonathan, Saul's son.
2 Samuel 21:8 So the king took the two sons of Rizpah, daughter of Aiah, whom Saul had fathered: Armoni and Mephibosheth. He also took the five sons of Michal, Saul's daughter, whom Hadriel, the son of Barzillai the Meholathite, had fathered.
2 Samuel 21:9 And he gave them into the hands of the Gibeonites, who then impaled them on the mountain before the Lord. These seven died together during the first days of the harvest, right at the beginning of the barley harvest.
2 Samuel 21:10 Rizpah, daughter of Aiah, also took sackcloth for herself and spread it out upon a rock, making a vigil. She stayed there from the beginning of the harvest until the rains finally poured down on the bodies from the sky. During that entire time, she did not allow the birds of the sky to settle on them by day, nor the wild beasts of the field to approach them by night.
2 Samuel 21:11 And it was reported to David what Rizpah, daughter of Aiah, Saul's concubine, had done.
2 Samuel 21:12 David then went and took the bones of Saul and the bones of his son Jonathan from the men of Jabesh-Gilead. These men had previously rescued the bodies, stealing them from the public square of Beth-Shan, where the Philistines had displayed them after killing Saul on Mount Gilboa.
2 Samuel 21:13 From there, David brought the bones of Saul and the bones of his son Jonathan. He also gathered the bones of those who had been impaled by the Gibeonites.
2 Samuel 21:14 And they buried them (the bones of the seven impaled men) along with the bones of Saul and his son Jonathan, in the land of Benjamin, in Zelah, in the tomb of Kish, Saul's father. They carried out everything the king had commanded. After these acts, God was finally appeased for the land of Israel.
2 Samuel 22:1 David spoke this song to the Lord, on the very day the Lord had rescued him from the power of all his enemies, and from the power of Saul.
2 Samuel 22:2 And David said: “The Lord is my strength and my fortified place, my refuge and my savior.
2 Samuel 22:3 My God is my Rock, in Him I will trust. He is my shield, and the horn of my salvation, my high tower, and my sanctuary. My Savior, you will deliver me from injustice.
2 Samuel 22:4 When I call upon the Lord with praise, I will be saved from my enemies.
2 Samuel 22:5 For the waves of death had surrounded me; the destructive currents of iniquity terrified me.
2 Samuel 22:6 The snares of hell encircled me; the traps of death had seized me.
2 Samuel 22:7 In my distress, I called upon the Lord, and cried out to my God. And from His holy temple, He heard my voice, and my cry came to His ears.
2 Samuel 22:8 Then the earth shook and trembled, the foundations of the mountains were stirred, and they were made low, because the Lord was angry with them.
2 Samuel 22:9 Smoke rose from His nostrils, and fire from His mouth devoured; burning coals were ignited by Him.
2 Samuel 22:10 He bowed the sky and came down, and thick darkness was under His feet.
2 Samuel 22:11 And He rode upon a Cherub and flew; He glided upon the wings of the winds.
2 Samuel 22:12 He made darkness His hidden place all around Him, His tent was all around Him: dark water and thick clouds of the sky.
2 Samuel 22:13 From the brilliance before Him, coals of fire were kindled.
2 Samuel 22:14 The Lord thundered from the sky, and the Most High gave forth His voice.
2 Samuel 22:15 He sent forth arrows and scattered them; He sent lightning and put them to flight.
2 Samuel 22:16 Then the ocean floor became visible, and the foundations of the earth were uncovered at the Lord's rebuke, at the blast of the breath of His fury.
2 Samuel 22:17 He reached down from on high and took hold of me; He drew me out of many waters.
2 Samuel 22:18 He rescued me from my mighty enemies, and from those who hated me, because they were too strong for me.
2 Samuel 22:19 They confronted me on the day of my distress, but the Lord became my protector.
2 Samuel 22:20 And He brought me out into a wide-open place; He delivered me because I was pleasing to Him.
2 Samuel 22:21 The Lord will reward me according to my righteousness, and according to the cleanness of my hands, He will repay me.
2 Samuel 22:22 Because I have kept the ways of the Lord, and have not acted wickedly against my God.
2 Samuel 22:23 For all His judgments are before my eyes, and I have not turned His commands away from me.
2 Samuel 22:24 I will be blameless before Him, and I will keep myself from my iniquity.
2 Samuel 22:25 Therefore the Lord will repay me according to my righteousness, and according to the cleanness of my hands in the sight of His eyes.
2 Samuel 22:26 With the holy, You will be holy; and with the mighty, You will be perfect.
2 Samuel 22:27 With the chosen, You will be chosen; and with the perverse, You will be perverse.
2 Samuel 22:28 And You will save the humble people, but You will humble the eyes of the proud.
2 Samuel 22:29 For You, O Lord, are my lamp; and You, O Lord, will illuminate my darkness.
2 Samuel 22:30 For by Your help, I will charge into battle prepared, and by the power of my God, I will leap over any wall.
2 Samuel 22:31 God makes my way perfect; the word of the Lord is proven by fire; He is a shield to all who trust in Him.
2 Samuel 22:32 For who is God except the Lord? And who is strong besides our God?
2 Samuel 22:33 God is the one who has girded me with strength and made my path perfect.
2 Samuel 22:34 He made my feet like those of deer, enabling me to stand firm on my high places.
2 Samuel 22:35 He trains my hands for battle, so that my arms can bend a bow of bronze.
2 Samuel 22:36 You have also given me the shield of Your salvation, and Your gentleness has made me great.
