2 Samuel 22:37 You will make my steps wide beneath me, and my ankles will not falter.
2 Samuel 22:38 I will pursue my enemies and crush them; I will not turn back until I have destroyed them.
2 Samuel 22:39 I will consume them and break them, so that they cannot rise; they will fall beneath my feet.
2 Samuel 22:40 You have girded me with strength for the battle; You have subdued those who rise against me beneath my power.
2 Samuel 23:1 These are the final words of David. David, the son of Jesse, declared them. Thus declared the man who was established by the Anointed One of the God of Jacob, the excellent psalmist of Israel:
2 Samuel 23:2 The Spirit of the Lord has spoken through me, and His word has been on my tongue.
2 Samuel 23:3 The God of Israel has spoken, the Strong One of Israel has spoken to me: 'The Ruler over humanity is a just ruler, ruling in the fear of God.'
2 Samuel 23:4 His rule will be like the morning light when the sun rises without clouds, shining brightly. It will be like the grass that sprouts from the earth after the rains.
2 Samuel 23:5 Indeed, my household is not so great before God, for He has made an eternal covenant with me, firm in all things and secured. For all my salvation and all my desire come from Him, and His covenant will not fail in the future.
2 Samuel 23:6 But all the sons of Belial (worthless men) are like burning thorns that cannot be grasped by hand.
2 Samuel 23:7 And if anyone wishes to touch them, he must be armed with iron and a spear shaft, and they will be utterly consumed by fire in that very place.
2 Samuel 23:8 These are the names of David’s mighty warriors: Isboseth, who sat on the throne, the wisest prince among the top three warriors. He was like a very tender worm in wood, yet he killed eight hundred men in one attack.
2 Samuel 23:9 After him was Eleazar, the son of his uncle Ahohite, one of the three mighty men who were with David when they defied the Philistines, who had gathered there for battle.
2 Samuel 23:10 When the men of Israel had gone up, he stood firm and struck down the Philistines until his hand was weary and stiff from holding his sword. The Lord brought about a great victory on that day, and the people who had fled returned only to plunder the dead.
2 Samuel 23:11 And after him was Semma, the son of Age from Arari. The Philistines had gathered at Lehi; there was a field full of lentils there. When the people fled from the Philistines,
2 Samuel 23:12 He himself stood in the middle of the field and defended it. He struck down the Philistines, and the Lord brought about a great victory.
2 Samuel 23:13 Three of the thirty chief warriors went down and came to David during the rye harvest, into the cave of Odollam. The Philistine army was encamped in the valley of Raphaim.
2 Samuel 23:14 And David was in a stronghold there, while the Philistine outpost was then in Bethlehem.
2 Samuel 23:15 David then expressed a longing, saying, 'If only someone would give me water from the cistern of Bethlehem, which is near the gate!'
2 Samuel 23:16 So the three mighty men broke through the Philistine camp and drew water from the cistern of Bethlehem, which was at the gate. They brought it to David, but David refused to drink it. Instead, he poured it out as an offering to the Lord, saying:
2 Samuel 23:17 'May the Lord be merciful to me, that I should not do this. Should I drink the blood of these men who went risking their very lives?' And he refused to drink it. These three mighty deeds were performed by the strongest warriors.
2 Samuel 23:18 Abisai also, the brother of Joab, son of Sarvia, was a chief among a group of three. He was the one who lifted his spear against three hundred men and killed them, and he was renowned among this group of three.
2 Samuel 23:19 And he was the most powerful among these three, and he became their commander. Nevertheless, he did not reach the status of the first three (the top warriors).
2 Samuel 23:20 Benaiah, the son of Jehoiada, was a very robust man, capable of great deeds, from Cabseel. He struck down two lion-like men of Moab, and he also went down into a cistern and struck down a lion on a snowy day.
2 Samuel 23:21 He also killed an Egyptian man of extraordinary stature, who had a spear in his hand. Benaiah went down to him with a staff, snatched the spear from the Egyptian's hand, and killed him with his own spear.
2 Samuel 23:22 These deeds were done by Benaiah, the son of Jehoiada.
2 Samuel 23:23 And he was renowned among the three powerful ones, who themselves were considered more noble than the thirty other warriors; nevertheless, he did not attain the rank of the first three (top warriors). David made him his privy counselor.
2 Samuel 23:24 Asael, Joab's brother, was among the thirty warriors; Eleanan, the son of his uncle, from Bethlehem.
2 Samuel 23:25 Samma from Harodi, Elica from Harodi.
2 Samuel 23:26 Heles from Palti, Hira, the son of Acces, from Thecua.
2 Samuel 23:27 Abiezer from Anathoth, Mobonnai from Husati.
2 Samuel 23:28 Selmon, an Ahohite; Maharai, a Netophathite.
2 Samuel 23:29 Heled, the son of Banaa, from Netophath; Ithai, the son of Ribai, from Gabaath of the children of Benjamin.
2 Samuel 23:30 Benaiah, a Pharathonite; Hiddai from Nahale Gaas.
2 Samuel 23:31 Abialbon, an Arbathite; Azmaveth from Beromi.
2 Samuel 23:32 Eliaba from Saalboni, along with the sons of Jasen: Jonathan.
2 Samuel 23:33 Samma from Arari, Ahiam, the son of Sarar, from Arari.
2 Samuel 23:34 Eliphelet, the son of Ahasbai, the son of Machati; Eliam, the son of Achitophel, a Gelonite.
2 Samuel 23:35 Hesrai from Carmelo, Pharai from Arbi.
2 Samuel 23:36 Igaal, the son of Nathan, from Soba; Bonni from Gadi.
2 Samuel 23:37 Selec, an Ammonite; Naharai, a Berothite, the armor-bearer of Joab, the son of Sarvia.
2 Samuel 23:38 Ira, a Jethrite; Gareb, a Jethrite.
2 Samuel 23:39 Uriah, the Hethite.
2 Samuel 23:40 In total, there were thirty-seven.
2 Samuel 23:1 These are David's last words. David, Jesse's son, declared this message: The man who was established by the God of Jacob as His anointed ruler, the renowned psalmist of Israel, spoke this revelation.
2 Samuel 23:2 The Spirit of the Lord spoke through me, and His message was on my tongue.
2 Samuel 23:3 The God of Israel spoke to me. The Strong One of Israel declared this truth: The Ruler of all humanity is a just ruler, governing in the reverent fear of God.
2 Samuel 23:4 His rule is like the morning light, shining brightly when the sun rises without clouds. It is like the rain that makes the earth sprout with life.
2 Samuel 23:5 Indeed, my royal house is not so great in God's sight, that He would enter into an eternal covenant with me, steadfast in every way and secured. Yet, this is all my salvation and all my desire; and even if no heir of mine should truly flourish by his own power, God's promise stands.
2 Samuel 23:6 But the wicked are all like thorns that have been torn out, which cannot be gathered by hand. If anyone desires to handle them, he must arm himself with iron and a spear, for they will surely be consumed by fire right where they are found.
2 Samuel 23:7 These are the names of David's mighty warriors. Josheb-basshebeth, the wisest chief among the three, was the same as Adino the Eznite, who with a single attack killed eight hundred men.
2 Samuel 23:8 After him was Eleazar, the son of Dodo the Ahohite, who was among the three mighty warriors with David. They were with David when they defied the Philistines, who had gathered there for battle. When the men of Israel had retreated,
2 Samuel 23:9 Eleazar stood firm and fought the Philistines until his hand grew weary and stiff, clenched to his sword. And the Lord brought about a great victory on that day. The people who had fled then returned, but only to plunder the slain.
2 Samuel 23:10 After Eleazar was Shammah, son of Agee the Hararite. The Philistines had gathered in Lehi, where there was a field full of lentils. When the people fled from the Philistines,
2 Samuel 23:11 Shammah stood his ground in the middle of the field and defended it. He struck down the Philistines, and the Lord brought about a great victory.
2 Samuel 23:12 Three of the thirty chief warriors went down and came to David during harvest time at the cave of Adullam. At that time, the Philistine camp was set up in the Valley of Rephaim.
2 Samuel 23:13 At that time, David was in a stronghold, and a Philistine garrison was in Bethlehem.
2 Samuel 23:14 So David longed for water and said: 'Oh, if only someone would give me a drink from the well of Bethlehem, which is by the city gate!'
2 Samuel 23:15 So the three mighty warriors broke through the Philistine camp and drew water from the well of Bethlehem, which was by the city gate. They brought it to David, but David refused to drink it. Instead, he poured it out as an offering to the Lord,
2 Samuel 23:16 saying: 'May the Lord forbid that I should do this! Shall I drink the blood of these men who went at the risk of their lives?' And because of this, he would not drink it. These were the deeds of the three mighty warriors.
2 Samuel 23:17 Abishai, the brother of Joab, son of Zeruiah, was chief of the three. He was the one who lifted his spear against three hundred men and killed them; he became renowned among the three.
2 Samuel 23:18 He was the first among the three, and much more illustrious than the other two, and he became their commander. Nevertheless, he did not reach the level of the first three mighty warriors.
2 Samuel 23:19 Benaiah, son of Jehoiada, a very mighty man who performed great deeds, came from Kabzeel. He killed two of Moab's most powerful warriors. He also went down into a pit and killed a lion on a snowy day.
2 Samuel 23:20 He also struck down an Egyptian, a man of remarkable stature, who had a spear in his hand. Benaiah went down to him with only a staff, wrestled the spear from the Egyptian's hand, and then killed him with his own spear.
2 Samuel 23:21 These were the deeds of Benaiah, son of Jehoiada, and he became renowned among the three mighty warriors.
2 Samuel 23:22 He was the chief of the thirty, though he did not reach the level of the first three. David appointed him as his chief counselor.
2 Samuel 23:23 Among the thirty were Asahel, Joab's brother, and Elhanan, son of Dodo from Bethlehem.
2 Samuel 23:24 Also, Shammah the Harodite, Elika the Harodite,
2 Samuel 23:25 Helez the Paltite, Ira, son of Ikkesh from Tekoa,
2 Samuel 23:26 Abiezer from Anathoth, Mebunnai the Hushathite,
2 Samuel 23:27 Zalmon the Ahohite, Maharai the Netophathite,
2 Samuel 23:28 Heled, son of Baanah from Netophah, Ittai, son of Ribai from Gibeon of the Benjamites,
2 Samuel 23:29 Benaiah the Pirathonite, Hiddai from the ravines of Gaash,
2 Samuel 23:30 Abi-albon the Arbathite, Azmaveth the Bahurimite,
2 Samuel 23:31 Eliaba the Shaalbonite, Jonathan, son of Jashen,
2 Samuel 23:32 Shammah the Hararite, Ahiam, son of Sharar the Ararite,
2 Samuel 23:33 Eliphelet, son of Ahasbai from Maacah, Eliam, son of Ahithophel the Gilonite,
2 Samuel 23:34 Hezrai the Carmelite, Paarai the Arbite,
2 Samuel 23:35 Igal, son of Nathan from Zobah, Bani the Gadite,
2 Samuel 23:36 Zelek the Ammonite, Naharai the Beerothite, who was the armor-bearer for Joab, son of Zeruiah,
2 Samuel 23:37 Ira the Ithrite, Gareb the Ithrite,
2 Samuel 23:38 Uriah the Hittite—in all, thirty-seven warriors.
2 Samuel 24:1 The Lord’s just anger continued to burn against Israel. He stirred up David to act against them, saying, “Go, take a census of the men of Israel and Judah.”
2 Samuel 24:2 So the king told Joab, the commander of his army: “Go throughout all the tribes of Israel, from Dan in the north to Beersheba in the south, and count the people. I want to know their total number.”
2 Samuel 24:3 But Joab replied to the king: “May the Lord your God increase the number of these people a hundredfold more than they are now! And may my lord the king live to see it with his own eyes. Why, then, does my lord the king want to do this thing?”
2 Samuel 24:4 Yet the king insisted on his command to Joab and the army commanders. So Joab and the generals departed from the king’s presence to take a census of the people of Israel.
2 Samuel 24:5 When they had crossed the Jordan River, they came to Aroer, and to the city that is on the right side of the valley of Gad.
2 Samuel 24:6 From there, they went through Midian and Gilead, and into the lower land, that is, Hodesh. They came to the forested area of the Sun, which is the city of the Sidonians.
2 Samuel 24:7 They then traveled from there, facing Tyre, and through all the land of the Hivites and Canaanites. They finally arrived in the south of Judah, at Beersheba.
2 Samuel 24:8 After surveying all the land, they returned to Jerusalem after nine months and twenty days.
2 Samuel 24:9 Joab reported the number of the registered people to the king: In Israel, there were eight hundred thousand valiant men who could wield a sword. In Judah, there were five hundred thousand fighting men.
2 Samuel 24:10 But David’s conscience troubled him after he had counted the people. So he said to the Lord: “I have sinned greatly in this act. But I beg You, Lord, take away the iniquity of Your servant, for I have acted foolishly.”
2 Samuel 24:11 When David rose in the morning, the word of the Lord came to the prophet Gad, David’s seer, saying:
2 Samuel 24:12 “Go, and speak to David: ‘This is what the Lord says: I offer you three choices. Choose one, and I will bring it upon you.’”
2 Samuel 24:13 When Gad came to David, he reported to him, saying: “Either seven years of famine will come upon your land, or for three months you will flee from your adversaries as they pursue you, or for three days there will be a plague in your land. Now then, decide, and see what answer I should give to the One who sent me.”
2 Samuel 24:14 And David said to Gad: “I am in a very distressed situation. But it is better that I fall into the hand of the Lord, for His compassions are great, rather than into the hand of man.”
2 Samuel 24:15 So the Lord sent a plague upon Israel from that morning until the appointed time. And from Dan to Beersheba, seventy thousand men among the people died.
2 Samuel 24:16 When the angel extended his hand over Jerusalem to destroy it, the Lord had pity on the afflicted people. He said to the angel who was destroying the people: “Enough! Do not extend your hand further.” Now the Lord’s angel was by the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite.
2 Samuel 24:17 And when David saw the angel striking the people, he said to the Lord: “It is I who have sinned, I have acted wickedly. These people are like sheep; what have they done? I beg You, let Your hand be turned against me and against my father’s house.”
2 Samuel 24:18 Now Gad came to David on that day and said to him: “Go up and erect an altar to the Lord on the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite.”
2 Samuel 24:19 So David went up, just as Gad had told him, according to the Lord’s command.
2 Samuel 24:20 Araunah looked up and saw the king and his servants coming toward him. So he went out to meet the king and prostrated himself before him with his face to the ground, showing his respect.
2 Samuel 24:21 And Araunah said: “Why has my lord the king come to his servant?” David replied to him: “To buy the threshing floor from you, so I can build an altar to the Lord and stop the plague of death from affecting the people.”
2 Samuel 24:22 Araunah said to David: “Let my lord the king take and offer whatever pleases him. You have oxen here for a burnt offering, and the threshing sledges, and the yokes of the oxen for wood.”
2 Samuel 24:23 Araunah the king gave all these things to the king. And Araunah said to the king: “May the Lord your God be gracious to you.”
2 Samuel 24:24 But the king replied to him: “No, not as you wish. I will certainly buy it from you for a price. For I will not offer burnt offerings to the Lord my God that cost me nothing.” So David bought the threshing floor and the oxen for fifty silver shekels.
2 Samuel 24:25 And David built an altar there to the Lord, and he offered burnt offerings and peace offerings. And the Lord was moved to mercy for the land, and the plague was lifted from Israel.
1 Kings 1:1 King David had grown old, and he was advanced in years. Even when he was covered with clothing, he could not get warm.
1 Kings 1:2 So his servants said to him: "Let us seek out for our lord, the king, a young virgin maiden. She can stand before the king, keep him warm, and sleep by his side to make our lord the king feel warm."
1 Kings 1:3 So they searched throughout all the borders of Israel for a beautiful young woman. They found Abishag the Shunammite and brought her to the king.
1 Kings 1:4 The young woman was exceptionally beautiful. She cared for the king and ministered to him, but the king did not have sexual relations with her.
1 Kings 1:5 Now Adonijah, the son of Haggith, began to boast, saying: "I will be king." He prepared for himself chariots and horsemen, and fifty men who would run before him.
1 Kings 1:6 His father had never rebuked him at any time by saying: "Why have you done this?" Adonijah himself was also very handsome, being the next oldest son after Absalom.
1 Kings 1:7 He conspired with Joab, the son of Zeruiah, and with Abiathar the priest. They both supported Adonijah and followed him.
1 Kings 1:8 However, Zadok the priest, Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, Nathan the prophet, Shimei, Rei, and David's mighty warriors were not with Adonijah.
1 Kings 1:9 Adonijah then offered sacrifices of sheep, calves, and all the fatlings by the Stone of Zoheleth, which is near the fountain of Rogel. He invited all the king's sons and all the men of Judah who were the king's servants.
1 Kings 1:10 But he did not invite Nathan the prophet, Benaiah, the mighty men, or his brother Solomon.
1 Kings 1:11 So Nathan spoke to Bathsheba, Solomon's mother, saying: "Have you heard that Adonijah, the son of Haggith, has become king, and our lord David knows nothing about it?"
1 Kings 1:12 "Now therefore, come, I will give you advice so that you may save your own life and the life of your son Solomon."
1 Kings 1:13 "Go, and go in to King David, and say to him: 'My lord king, did you not swear to me, your handmaid, saying: "Your son Solomon shall reign after me, and he shall sit on my throne?" Why then does Adonijah reign?'"
1 Kings 1:14 "And while you are still speaking there with the king, I will immediately come in after you and confirm your words."
1 Kings 1:15 So Bathsheba went in to the king in his private chamber. The king had grown very old, and Abishag the Shunammite was ministering to him.
1 Kings 1:16 Bathsheba bowed down and paid homage to the king. The king asked her: "What do you want?"
1 Kings 1:17 She answered, saying: "My lord, you swore by the Lord your God to your handmaid, that your son Solomon would reign after you, and that he himself would sit on your throne."
1 Kings 1:18 "And behold, now Adonijah reigns, and you, my lord king, do not know about it."
1 Kings 1:19 "He has sacrificed many oxen, fatlings, and sheep to all the king's sons, and to Zadok the priest, and to Benaiah the son of Jehoiada. But he did not invite your servant Solomon."
1 Kings 1:20 "But now, my lord king, the eyes of all Israel are upon you, waiting for you to declare who will sit on your throne after you."
1 Kings 1:21 "Otherwise, when my lord the king sleeps with his fathers (meaning, when you die), I and my son Solomon will be considered offenders and will likely be put to death."
1 Kings 1:22 While she was still speaking with the king, Nathan the prophet entered.
1 Kings 1:23 They announced to the king, saying: "Behold, Nathan the prophet!" When he had come in before the king and bowed down before him with his face to the ground,
1 Kings 1:24 Nathan said: "My lord king, have you indeed declared: 'Adonijah shall reign after me, and he himself shall sit upon my throne'?"
1 Kings 1:25 "Because today he went down and sacrificed many oxen, fatlings, and sheep to all the king's sons, and to the commanders of the army, and to Abiathar the priest. And they are eating and drinking before him and shouting: 'Long live King Adonijah!'"
1 Kings 1:26 "But he did not invite me, your servant, nor Zadok the priest, nor Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, nor your servant Solomon."
1 Kings 1:27 "If this declaration has come from my lord the king, why have you not informed me, your servant, who should sit on your throne after you?"
1 Kings 1:28 Then King David answered, saying: "Call Bathsheba to me." When she had come in before the king and stood before him,
1 Kings 1:29 The king swore an oath and said: "As the Lord lives, who has rescued my life from every trouble and distress,"
1 Kings 1:30 "Just as I swore to you by the Lord, the God of Israel, saying: 'Your son Solomon shall reign after me, and he shall sit on my throne in my place,' so I will do this very day."
1 Kings 1:31 Then Bathsheba bowed down with her face to the ground, and paying homage to the king, she said: "May my lord King David live forever!"
1 Kings 1:32 King David also said: "Call Zadok the priest, Nathan the prophet, and Benaiah the son of Jehoiada to me." When they had come in before the king,
1 Kings 1:33 He said to them: "Take with you the servants of your lord, and have my son Solomon ride on my own royal mule, and bring him down to Gihon."
1 Kings 1:34 "And let Zadok the priest and Nathan the prophet anoint him there as king over Israel. Then sound the trumpet and declare: 'Long live King Solomon!'"
1 Kings 1:35 "Then you shall come up after him, and he shall come and sit on my throne, and he himself shall reign in my place. For I have commanded that he be the leader over Israel and over Judah."
1 Kings 1:36 Benaiah, the son of Jehoiada, answered the king, saying: "Amen! May the Lord God of my lord the king confirm this as true!"
1 Kings 1:37 "Just as the Lord was with my lord the king, so may He be with Solomon, and may He make his throne even greater than the throne of my lord King David."
1 Kings 1:38 So Zadok the priest, Nathan the prophet, Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, the Cherethites, and the Pelethites went down. They put Solomon upon King David's own royal mule and brought him to Gihon.
1 Kings 1:39 Then Zadok the priest took a horn of oil from the tabernacle and anointed Solomon. They sounded the trumpet, and all the people shouted: "Long live King Solomon!"
1 Kings 1:40 And all the multitude went up after him, with the people playing flutes and rejoicing with great joy, so much so that the earth echoed from the sound of their shouting.
1 Kings 1:1 King David was now very old and advanced in years. Even when he was covered with blankets, he could not get warm.
1 Kings 1:2 So his servants said to him, "Let us look for a young, virgin girl for our lord the king. Let her serve the king and care for him, and let her sleep close to him to keep our lord the king warm."
1 Kings 1:3 So they searched throughout all the territory of Israel for a beautiful young woman, and they found Abishag, a Shunammite, and brought her to the king.
1 Kings 1:4 The girl was indeed exceedingly beautiful, and she cared for the king and attended to his needs. But the king did not have sexual relations with her.
1 Kings 1:5 Adonijah, the son of Haggith, began to boast, saying, "I will be king!" He prepared for himself chariots and horsemen, and fifty men to run before him as his personal guard.
1 Kings 1:6 His father had never corrected him at any time by asking, "Why are you doing this?" Adonijah himself was also very handsome, and he was the next eldest son after Absalom.
1 Kings 1:7 Adonijah consulted with Joab, the son of Zeruiah, and with Abiathar the priest. They both gave their support to Adonijah and followed him.
1 Kings 1:8 However, Zadok the priest, Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, Nathan the prophet, Shimei, Rei, and David's mightiest warriors did not join Adonijah.
1 Kings 1:9 Adonijah sacrificed sheep, calves, and all the fatlings near the stone of Zoheleth, which is close to the spring of Rogel. He then invited all the king's sons and all the men of Judah who served the king.
1 Kings 1:10 But he did not invite Nathan the prophet, Benaiah, the mightiest warriors, nor his brother Solomon.
1 Kings 1:11 So Nathan said to Bathsheba, Solomon's mother, "Have you not heard that Adonijah, Haggith's son, has made himself king, and our master David does not even know about it?"
1 Kings 1:12 Now then, come, and I will give you advice so that you can save your own life and the life of your son Solomon.
1 Kings 1:13 Go, enter King David's presence, and say to him, "Did you not, my lord the king, swear to me, your handmaid, saying, 'Your son Solomon shall reign after me, and he himself shall sit upon my throne'? How then is Adonijah now reigning as king?"
1 Kings 1:14 While you are still speaking with the king there, I will immediately come in after you and confirm everything you have said.
1 Kings 1:15 So Bathsheba went into the king's chamber. The king was now very old, and Abishag the Shunammite was attending to him.
1 Kings 1:16 Bathsheba bowed low and paid homage to the king. The king asked her, "What do you want?"
1 Kings 1:17 She replied, "My lord, you swore by the Lord your God to your handmaid that your son Solomon would reign after you, and that he himself would sit upon your throne."
1 Kings 1:18 And now, Adonijah is reigning as king, and you, my lord the king, do not even know about it.
1 Kings 1:19 He has sacrificed many oxen, fatlings, and sheep. He has invited all the king's sons, Abiathar the priest, and Joab, the commander of the army. But he did not invite your servant Solomon.
1 Kings 1:20 So now, my lord the king, the eyes of all Israel are looking to you, to declare who will sit on your throne after you.
1 Kings 1:21 Otherwise, when my lord the king passes away and rests with his ancestors, my son Solomon and I will be considered criminals and treated as such.
1 Kings 1:22 While she was still speaking with the king, Nathan the prophet arrived.
1 Kings 1:23 They announced to the king, saying, "Nathan the prophet is here!" When he entered the king's presence, he bowed down with his face to the ground and paid homage.
1 Kings 1:24 Nathan said, "My lord the king, did you say that Adonijah is to reign after you, and that he is to sit upon my throne?"
1 Kings 1:25 For today he went down and sacrificed many oxen, fatlings, and sheep. He invited all the king's sons, the commanders of the army, and Abiathar the priest. And they ate and drank before him, and shouted, 'Long live King Adonijah!'
1 Kings 1:26 But me, your servant, and Zadok the priest, and Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, and your servant Solomon, he did not invite.
1 Kings 1:27 Has this decree truly come from my lord the king? And have you not informed your servant who is to sit on the throne of my lord the king after him?
1 Kings 1:28 King David answered, "Call Bathsheba to me." When she came into the king's presence and stood before him,
1 Kings 1:29 The king took an oath and said, "As the Lord lives, who has delivered my soul from every distress—"
1 Kings 1:30 —just as I swore to you by the Lord, the God of Israel, saying, 'Your son Solomon shall reign after me, and he shall sit upon my throne in my place,' this very day I will carry it out!"
1 Kings 1:31 Then Bathsheba bowed with her face to the earth, paid homage to the king, and said, "May my lord King David live forever!"
1 Kings 1:32 King David then gave an order: "Call to me Zadok the priest, Nathan the prophet, and Benaiah the son of Jehoiada." When they had come into the king's presence,
1 Kings 1:33 The king said to them, "Take with you my royal servants. Set my son Solomon upon my own mule and bring him down to Gihon."
1 Kings 1:34 And let Zadok the priest and Nathan the prophet anoint him there as king over Israel. Then blow the trumpet and shout, 'Long live King Solomon!'
1 Kings 1:35 Then return up here, following him. He is to sit upon my throne, and he himself shall reign in my place, for I have appointed him to be ruler over both Israel and Judah.
1 Kings 1:36 Benaiah, the son of Jehoiada, answered the king, saying, "So be it! May the Lord, the God of my lord the king, confirm it."
1 Kings 1:37 Just as the Lord was with my lord the king, so may He be with Solomon, and may He make his throne even greater than the throne of my lord King David.
1 Kings 1:38 So Zadok the priest, Nathan the prophet, Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, and the Cherethites and Pelethites went down. They set Solomon upon King David's own mule and brought him to Gihon.
1 Kings 1:39 Zadok the priest took a horn of oil from the tabernacle and anointed Solomon. Then they blew the trumpet, and all the people shouted, 'Long live King Solomon!'
1 Kings 1:40 And all the multitude went up after him. The people were playing flutes and rejoicing with great joy, and the earth reverberated with their shouting.
1 Kings 1:1 King David was very old and advanced in years; even when he was covered with many blankets, he could not get warm.
1 Kings 1:2 So his servants said to him: "Let us find a young virgin for our Lord, the king, to take care of him. She can stand before the king, sleeping close to him, and keep our Lord, the king, warm."
1 Kings 1:3 So they searched throughout all the lands of Israel for a beautiful young woman. They found Abishag the Shunammite and brought her to the king.
1 Kings 1:4 The young woman was very beautiful. She took care of the king and served him; however, the king did not have sexual relations with her.
1 Kings 1:5 Now Adonijah, the son of Haggith, began to exalt himself, saying: "I will be king." He prepared chariots and horsemen for himself, along with fifty men to run before him.
1 Kings 1:6 His father, David, had never once rebuked him, asking: "Why have you done this?" Adonijah himself was also very handsome, and he was the next son born after Absalom.
1 Kings 1:7 Adonijah spoke with Joab, the son of Zeruiah, and with Abiathar the priest. They both helped Adonijah and followed him.
1 Kings 1:8 However, Zadok the priest, Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, Nathan the prophet, Shimei, Rei, and the core of David's army were not with Adonijah.
1 Kings 1:9 Then Adonijah sacrificed sheep, calves, and all the fatted animals near the Stone of Zoheleth, which was beside the En Rogel spring. He invited all his brothers, the king's sons, and all the men of Judah, the king's servants.
1 Kings 1:10 But he did not invite Nathan the prophet, Benaiah, nor any of the mighty men, nor his brother Solomon.
1 Kings 1:11 Then Nathan said to Bathsheba, Solomon's mother: "Have you not heard that Adonijah, the son of Haggith, has become king, and our Lord David does not know about it?"
1 Kings 1:12 Now then, come, accept my advice, and save your own life and the life of your son Solomon.
1 Kings 1:13 Go and enter before King David. Say to him: "My Lord, the king, did you not swear to your handmaid, saying: 'Your son Solomon shall reign after me, and he himself shall sit upon my throne'? How then is Adonijah reigning?"
1 Kings 1:14 While you are still speaking there with the king, I will immediately come in after you and confirm your words.
1 Kings 1:15 So Bathsheba went in to the king in his private room. The king was now very old, and Abishag the Shunammite was serving him.
1 Kings 1:16 Bathsheba bowed down and paid homage to the king. The king said to her: "What do you want?"
1 Kings 1:17 She answered him: "My Lord, you swore by the Lord your God to your handmaid: 'Your son Solomon shall reign after me, and he himself shall sit upon my throne.'"
1 Kings 1:18 And now, look, Adonijah is reigning, and you, my Lord, the king, do not know it.
1 Kings 1:19 He has sacrificed many oxen, fatted animals, and sheep, and he has invited all the king's sons, Abiathar the priest, and Joab, the commander of the army. But he did not invite your servant Solomon, nor me, your handmaid.
1 Kings 1:20 Now, my Lord, the king, the eyes of all Israel are upon you, for you to declare to them who shall sit on your throne, my Lord, the king, after you.
1 Kings 1:21 Otherwise, when my Lord, the king, sleeps with his fathers (that is, when he dies), my son Solomon and I will be considered guilty and will suffer the consequences.
1 Kings 1:22 And look, while she was still speaking with the king, Nathan the prophet entered.
1 Kings 1:23 They announced to the king, saying: "Nathan the prophet is here." When he had come in before the king and bowed down before him, with his face to the ground,
1 Kings 1:24 Nathan said: "My Lord, the king, did you say: 'Adonijah shall reign after me, and he himself shall sit upon my throne'?"
1 Kings 1:25 For he went down today and sacrificed many oxen, fatted animals, and sheep. He invited all the king's sons, the commanders of the army, and Abiathar the priest. While they are eating and drinking before him, they are shouting: "Long live King Adonijah!"
1 Kings 1:26 But he did not invite me, your servant, nor Zadok the priest, nor Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, nor your servant Solomon.
1 Kings 1:27 Has this word truly come from my Lord, the king, and you have not informed me, your servant, who should sit on your throne after you?
1 Kings 1:28 King David then answered, saying: "Call Bathsheba for me." When she had come in before the king and stood before him,
1 Kings 1:29 the king swore an oath and said: "As the Lord lives, who has rescued my life from every distress,"
1 Kings 1:30 just as I swore to you by the Lord, the God of Israel, saying: 'Your son Solomon shall reign after me, and he himself shall sit upon my throne in my place,' I will do this very thing today.
1 Kings 1:31 Bathsheba bowed down with her face to the ground and paid homage to the king, saying: "May my Lord, King David, live forever!"
1 Kings 1:32 King David then also said: "Call for me Zadok the priest, Nathan the prophet, and Benaiah the son of Jehoiada." When they had come in before the king,
1 Kings 1:33 he said to them: "Take with you the servants of your master. Have my son Solomon ride on my own mule, and lead him down to Gihon."
1 Kings 1:34 There let Zadok the priest and Nathan the prophet anoint him as king over Israel. Then sound the trumpet and declare: "Long live King Solomon!"
1 Kings 1:35 Then you shall come up after him. He will come and sit upon my throne, and he himself shall reign in my place, for I have commanded that he be ruler over Israel and over Judah.
1 Kings 1:36 Benaiah the son of Jehoiada answered the king, saying: "Amen! May the Lord, the God of my Lord, the king, speak likewise (that is, confirm your word)."
1 Kings 1:37 Just as the Lord was with my Lord, the king, so may He be with Solomon. May He make Solomon's throne even greater than the throne of my Lord, King David.
1 Kings 1:38 So Zadok the priest, Nathan the prophet, Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, and the Cherethites and the Pelethites went down. They put Solomon on King David's mule and brought him to Gihon.
1 Kings 1:39 Then Zadok the priest took a horn of oil from the tabernacle and anointed Solomon. They sounded the trumpet, and all the people shouted: "Long live King Solomon!"
1 Kings 1:40 And all the multitude went up after him. The people played flutes and rejoiced with great joy, so much so that the earth resounded from the loudness of their shouting.
1 Kings 2:1 As the day drew near for King David to die, he gave these final commands to Solomon, his son and successor:
1 Kings 2:2 “I am about to pass from this world, like all people must. So be strong, and act like a true man.
1 Kings 2:3 And faithfully keep the commandments of the Lord your God. Walk in His ways, observe His rituals, His precepts, His judgments, and His testimonies, just as it is written in the Law of Moses. Do this so that you may prosper in everything you undertake, and in every direction you go.
1 Kings 2:4 This is so the Lord may fulfill the promise He made to me, when He said: 'If your descendants faithfully keep My ways and walk before Me in truth, with their whole heart and their whole soul, you will never lack a man to sit on the throne of Israel.'
1 Kings 2:5 “You also know what Joab, the son of Zeruiah, did to me and what he did to the two commanders of the army of Israel: Abner, the son of Ner, and Amasa, the son of Jether. He murdered them, shedding the blood of war in a time of peace, and stained his belt around his waist and his sandals on his feet with the blood of war.
1 Kings 2:6 Therefore, act according to your wisdom, and do not let his gray hair go down to the abode of the dead in peace.
1 Kings 2:7 But to the sons of Barzillai the Gileadite, show kindness. Let them be among those who eat at your table, because they showed me hospitality when I fled from your brother Absalom.
1 Kings 2:8 You also have with you Shimei, the son of Gera, from Bahurim, a Benjaminite, who cursed me with a terrible curse when I was going to the camp. But because he came down with me to the Jordan River, I swore to him by the Lord, saying, 'I will not put you to death with the sword.'
1 Kings 2:9 Therefore, do not let him go unpunished. You are a wise man, and you will know how to bring his gray head down to the abode of the dead with blood.
1 Kings 2:10 So David rested with his ancestors, and he was buried in the City of David.
1 Kings 2:11 The length of David's reign over Israel was forty years: he reigned seven years in Hebron, and thirty-three years in Jerusalem.
1 Kings 2:12 Then Solomon sat on the throne of his father David, and his kingdom was firmly established.
1 Kings 2:13 Adonijah, the son of Haggith, came to Bathsheba, Solomon's mother. She asked him, “Are you coming in peace?” He answered, “I am.”
1 Kings 2:14 Then he added, “I have something to say to you.” She replied, “Speak.”
1 Kings 2:15 He said, “You know that the kingdom was mine, and all Israel expected me to be king. But the kingdom has been taken from me and given to my brother; for it was the Lord's will that it be prepared for him.”
1 Kings 2:16 “Now therefore, I ask one favor from you. Do not refuse my request.” She said to him, “Speak.”
1 Kings 2:17 He said, “Please speak to King Solomon—he cannot refuse you—and ask him to give me Abishag the Shunammite as a wife.”
1 Kings 2:18 Bathsheba replied, “Very well, I will speak to the king on your behalf.”
1 Kings 2:19 So Bathsheba went to King Solomon to speak to him concerning Adonijah. The king rose to meet her and bowed down to her. Then he sat on his throne, and a throne was placed for the king's mother, and she sat at his right hand.
1 Kings 2:20 She said to him, “I have one small request to make of you. Do not refuse my request.” The king said to her, “Ask, my mother, for it is not right that I should refuse your request.”
1 Kings 2:21 Then she said, “Let Abishag the Shunammite be given to your brother Adonijah as a wife.”
1 Kings 2:22 King Solomon answered and said to his mother, “Why do you ask for Abishag the Shunammite for Adonijah? Ask also for the kingdom for him! He is my elder brother, and he has Abiathar the priest and Joab, the son of Zeruiah, supporting him!”
1 Kings 2:23 Then King Solomon swore by the Lord, saying, “May God do to me and more also, if Adonijah has not spoken this word against his own life by making this request!”
1 Kings 2:24 “Now, as the Lord lives, who has established me and seated me on the throne of my father David, and who has made me a lasting dynasty as He promised, Adonijah will surely be put to death this very day!”
1 Kings 2:25 So King Solomon sent Benaiah, the son of Jehoiada, who struck him down, and Adonijah died.
1 Kings 2:26 To Abiathar the priest, the king said, “Go to Anathoth, to your own lands. You deserve to die, but today I will not put you to death, because you carried the Ark of the Lord God before my father David and endured all the hardships my father endured.”
1 Kings 2:27 So Solomon expelled Abiathar from being a priest of the Lord, thereby fulfilling the word of the Lord that He had spoken concerning the house of Eli in Shiloh.
1 Kings 2:28 When the news reached Joab—because Joab had sided with Adonijah and not with Solomon—Joab fled to the tent of the Lord and grasped the horns of the altar, seeking sanctuary.
1 Kings 2:29 It was reported to King Solomon that Joab had fled to the tent of the Lord and was beside the altar. So Solomon sent Benaiah, the son of Jehoiada, saying, “Go, strike him down.”
1 Kings 2:30 Benaiah came to the tent of the Lord and said to Joab, “Thus says the king: 'Come out!'” But Joab replied, “No, I will not come out; I will die here.” So Benaiah reported to the king, saying, “This is what Joab said, and this is how he answered me.”
1 Kings 2:31 The king then said to Benaiah, “Do as he has said; strike him down and bury him. In doing so, you will remove the guilt of the innocent blood that Joab shed from me and from my father's house.”
1 Kings 2:32 “And the Lord will bring his bloodguilt back upon his own head, because he struck down two men more righteous and better than himself. He murdered them with the sword, though my father David knew nothing of it: Abner, the son of Ner, commander of the army of Israel, and Amasa, the son of Jether, commander of the army of Judah.”
1 Kings 2:33 “So their bloodguilt will fall upon the head of Joab and upon the head of his descendants forever. But upon David and his descendants, upon his house, and upon his throne, may there be lasting peace from the Lord forever.”
1 Kings 2:34 So Benaiah, the son of Jehoiada, went up and struck him down and killed him. He was then buried in his own house in the wilderness.
1 Kings 2:35 The king then appointed Benaiah, the son of Jehoiada, over the army in place of Joab, and he appointed Zadok the priest in place of Abiathar.
1 Kings 2:36 The king then sent for Shimei and said to him, “Build yourself a house in Jerusalem and live there, and do not go out from there to any place else.”
1 Kings 2:37 “For on whatever day you go out and cross the Kidron Valley, know for certain that you will surely die. Your blood will be on your own head.”
1 Kings 2:38 Shimei said to the king, “Your word is good. Just as my lord the king has said, so your servant will do.” So Shimei lived in Jerusalem for a long time.
1 Kings 2:39 Now it happened three years later that servants of Shimei ran away to Gath, to Achish, son of Maachah, the king of Gath. And it was reported to Shimei, “Look, your servants are in Gath!”
1 Kings 2:40 So Shimei rose, saddled his donkey, and went to Gath to Achish to search for his servants, and he brought them back from Gath.
1 Kings 2:1 Now the days drew near when David had to die, and he gave a final command to his son Solomon, saying:
1 Kings 2:2 “I am about to go the way of all the earth, the way of all humanity. So be strong now, and show yourself to be a man.
1 Kings 2:3 And keep the observances of the Lord your God. Walk in His ways and keep His ceremonies, His precepts, His judgments, and His testimonies—just as it is written in the Law of Moses. Do this so that you may understand everything you do and everywhere you turn, and that you may prosper.
1 Kings 2:4 And also that the Lord may confirm His word which He spoke concerning me, saying: 'If your sons keep their way and walk before Me in truth, with all their heart and with all their soul, a man from your line shall not be cut off from the throne of Israel.'
1 Kings 2:5 “You also know what Joab, the son of Zeruiah, did to me—what he did to the two commanders of the army of Israel, Abner the son of Ner and Amasa the son of Jether. He killed them, shedding the blood of war in a time of peace, and he put the blood of war on the belt around his waist and on the sandals on his feet.
1 Kings 2:6 So, act according to your wisdom regarding him. Do not allow his gray hairs to go down to the underworld in peace, that is, do not let him die a natural death.
1 Kings 2:7 But to the sons of Barzillai the Gileadite, you must show kindness. Let them eat at your table, because they were there for me when I fled from your brother Absalom.
1 Kings 2:8 You also have with you Shimei, the son of Gera, a Benjaminite from Bahurim. He cursed me with a terrible curse when I went to Mahanaim, the place where I gathered my forces. But because he came down with me to the Jordan River, I swore to him by the Lord, saying: 'I will not put you to death with the sword.'
1 Kings 2:9 Therefore, do not leave him unpunished. But you are a wise man, and you know what you should do to him. Bring his gray hairs down to the underworld with blood, meaning, ensure he faces justice and dies a violent death.
1 Kings 2:10 So David rested with his fathers and was buried in the city of David.
1 Kings 2:11 And the days that David reigned over Israel were forty years: seven years he reigned in Hebron, and thirty-three years he reigned in Jerusalem.
1 Kings 2:12 Then Solomon sat on the throne of David his father, and his kingdom was very firmly established.
1 Kings 2:13 Now Adonijah, the son of Haggith, came to Bathsheba, Solomon's mother. She asked him: 'Is your coming peaceful?' And he answered: 'It is peaceful.'
1 Kings 2:14 And he added: 'I have something to say to you.' At which point she said: 'Speak.'
1 Kings 2:15 He said: 'You know that the kingdom was mine, and all Israel had turned their faces toward me, expecting me to reign. But the kingdom has been transferred, and it has become my brother's, because it was established for him by the Lord.
1 Kings 2:16 Now therefore, I have one request to make of you. Do not refuse my plea.' And Bathsheba said to him: 'Speak.'
1 Kings 2:17 He said: 'I beg you to speak to King Solomon (for he cannot refuse you anything), that he may give me Abishag the Shunammite as my wife.'
1 Kings 2:18 Bathsheba said: 'Very well. I will speak to the king for you.'
1 Kings 2:19 So Bathsheba went to King Solomon to speak to him for Adonijah. And the king rose to meet her, bowed down to her, and then sat on his throne. A chair was placed for the king's mother, and she sat at his right hand.
1 Kings 2:20 And she said to him: 'I have one small request to make of you. Do not refuse my plea.' And the king said to her: 'Ask, my mother; for it is not right that I should refuse you.'
1 Kings 2:21 She said: 'Let Abishag the Shunammite be given to Adonijah your brother as a wife.'
1 Kings 2:22 And King Solomon answered and said to his mother: 'Why do you ask for Abishag the Shunammite for Adonijah? Ask also for the kingdom for him! For he is my older brother, and he has Abiathar the priest and Joab the son of Zeruiah on his side.'
1 Kings 2:23 So King Solomon swore by the Lord, saying: 'May God do so to me and more also, if Adonijah has not spoken this word against his own life, thereby sealing his own doom.'
1 Kings 2:24 And now, as the Lord lives, who has established me and seated me on the throne of David my father, and who has made for me a house, just as He promised—Adonijah shall surely be put to death today.
1 Kings 2:25 So King Solomon sent Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, who struck him down, and he died.
1 Kings 2:26 And to Abiathar the priest, the king said: 'Go to Anathoth, to your own fields. You deserve death, for you are a son of death. But today I will not put you to death, because you carried the Ark of the Lord God before David my father, and you endured hardship in all the difficulties my father endured.'
1 Kings 2:27 So Solomon cast out Abiathar from being a priest of the Lord. This happened so that the word of the Lord, which He spoke concerning the house of Eli in Shiloh, might be fulfilled.
1 Kings 2:28 When the news reached Joab (for Joab had sided with Adonijah, and had not sided with Solomon), he fled to the tabernacle of the Lord and took hold of the horns of the altar.
1 Kings 2:29 It was reported to King Solomon that Joab had fled to the tabernacle of the Lord and was by the altar. And Solomon sent Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, saying: 'Go and strike him down.'
1 Kings 2:30 So Benaiah came to the tabernacle of the Lord and said to him: 'Thus says the king: 'Come out!'' But Joab answered: 'No, I will not come out; I will die here.' So Benaiah reported the words to the king, saying: 'This is what Joab said, and this is how he answered me.'
1 Kings 2:31 And the king said to him: 'Do as he has spoken. Strike him down and bury him, so that you may remove the innocent blood which Joab shed from me and from the house of my father.
1 Kings 2:32 And the Lord will bring his blood back upon his own head because he struck down two men more righteous and better than himself in Israel, without my father David knowing it: Abner the son of Ner, commander of the army of Israel, and Amasa the son of Jether, commander of the army of Judah.
1 Kings 2:33 Their blood shall return upon the head of Joab and upon the head of his descendants forever. But upon David and his descendants, and his house, and his throne, there shall be peace and permanence forever from the Lord.'
1 Kings 2:34 So Benaiah the son of Jehoiada went up and struck him down and killed him. And he was buried in his own house in the wilderness.
1 Kings 2:35 And the king appointed Benaiah the son of Jehoiada over the army in Joab's place. And Zadok the priest he appointed in the place of Abiathar.
1 Kings 2:36 The king also sent and called for Shimei and said to him: 'Build yourself a house in Jerusalem and live there, and do not go out from there anywhere else.
1 Kings 2:37 For on whatever day you go out and cross the Kidron Valley, know for certain that you will surely die. Your blood will be on your own head—meaning, you will be responsible for your own death.'
1 Kings 2:38 And Shimei said to the king: 'The word is good. As my lord the king has spoken, so will your servant do.' So Shimei lived in Jerusalem for many days.
1 Kings 2:39 But it came to pass after three years that two servants of Shimei fled to Achish, the son of Maacah, king of Gath. And it was reported to Shimei, with people saying: 'Behold, your servants are in Gath!'
1 Kings 2:40 So Shimei arose, saddled his donkey, and went to Gath, to Achish, to search for his servants. And he brought them back from Gath.
1 Kings 3:1 Then Solomon made a political and marriage alliance with Pharaoh, the king of Egypt. He took Pharaoh's daughter as his wife and brought her to the City of David to live there until he had finished building his own royal palace, the Temple of the Lord, and the city walls surrounding Jerusalem.
1 Kings 3:2 However, the people were still offering sacrifices in the high places, which were unauthorized altars for worship, because a proper Temple for the Lord had not yet been built in Jerusalem.
1 Kings 3:3 Solomon truly loved the Lord and lived according to the commands of David his father, except for one thing: he also offered sacrifices and burned incense at the high places, rather than exclusively at the tabernacle.
1 Kings 3:4 Therefore, the king went to Gibeon to offer sacrifices there, for it was a particularly prominent high place. Solomon offered a thousand burnt offerings on that altar.
1 Kings 3:5 While in Gibeon, the Lord appeared to Solomon in a dream during the night, saying: 'Ask me for whatever you wish, and I will give it to you.'
1 Kings 3:6 Solomon responded: 'You have shown great and enduring mercy to your servant, my father David, just as he lived before You with truth, justice, and an upright heart. And You have continued to show him Your abundant mercy by giving him a son who now sits on his throne, as is evident today.'
1 Kings 3:7 And now, O Lord God, You have made me, Your servant, king in place of my father David. But I am still very young and inexperienced, and I do not know how to properly govern or lead my people.
1 Kings 3:8 And I, Your servant, am placed among Your chosen people—a vast multitude that cannot be counted or numbered because of their sheer size.
1 Kings 3:9 Therefore, grant to Your servant a listening and discerning heart so that I may be able to govern Your people justly and distinguish between good and evil. For who is truly capable of judging this great and numerous people of Yours?
1 Kings 3:10 The Lord was pleased with Solomon's request because he had asked for such a thing—wisdom to govern.
1 Kings 3:11 So the Lord said to Solomon: 'Because you have made this specific request, and have not asked for a long life, nor for riches, nor for the death of your enemies, but instead have asked for wisdom for yourself to render proper judgment and discern what is right: '
1 Kings 3:12 'Behold, I have granted your request. I have given you a wise and understanding heart, so much so that there has been no one like you before, nor will there be anyone like you who arises after you.'
1 Kings 3:13 'Furthermore, even what you did not ask for, I have given to you: great riches and abundant glory. In fact, no king among all those who lived before you will be your equal.'
1 Kings 3:14 'But if you walk in My ways and keep My commands and precepts, just as your father David did, then I will also grant you a long life.'
1 Kings 3:15 So Solomon awoke and realized that it had been a dream. He then returned to Jerusalem, stood before the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord, and offered burnt offerings and peace offerings to God. He also held a great feast for all his servants.
1 Kings 3:16 At that time, two women who were prostitutes came before the king and stood in his presence.
1 Kings 3:17 One of them said: 'Please, my lord, this woman and I lived together in the same house. I gave birth to a child while she was with me in the room.'
1 Kings 3:18 'And on the third day after I gave birth, she also gave birth. We were alone together; there was no one else in the house with us except the two of us.'
1 Kings 3:19 'But this woman's son died during the night, because she accidentally suffocated him in her sleep.'
1 Kings 3:20 'So she got up in the quiet of the deep night and took my son from my side while I, your handmaid, was asleep, and laid him in her own bosom. Then she put her dead son in my bosom instead.'
1 Kings 3:21 'And when I arose in the morning to nurse my son, he appeared dead. But when I looked at him closely in the daylight, I realized that he was not the son I had given birth to.'
1 Kings 3:22 The other woman replied: 'No, that's not true! Your son is the one who died; my son is alive!' But the first woman insisted: 'You are lying! My son is alive, and your son is dead!' And so they argued back and forth before the king.
1 Kings 3:23 Then the king said: 'This woman claims: "My son is alive, and your son is dead." And the other woman replies: "No, your son is dead, and my son is alive."'
1 Kings 3:24 Then the king added: 'Bring me a sword.' And when a sword was brought before the king,
1 Kings 3:25 he commanded: 'Cut the living child in two, and give half to one woman and half to the other.'
1 Kings 3:26 Then the woman whose son was truly alive, for her heart ached for her child, said to the king: 'Please, my lord, give her the living child, and do not kill him!' But the other woman insisted: 'Let the child be neither mine nor yours; divide him!'
1 Kings 3:27 The king then declared: 'Give the living child to this woman, and do not kill him, for she is truly his mother.'
1 Kings 3:28 So all of Israel heard of the judgment the king had rendered, and they held the king in awe, for they saw that the wisdom of God was in him to administer justice.
1 Kings 3:29 So King Solomon was reigning over all of Israel.
1 Kings 3:30 And these were the chief officials he had: Azariah, son of Zadok the priest,
1 Kings 3:31 Elihoreph and Ahiah, sons of Shisha, were the secretaries; Jehoshaphat, son of Ahilud, was the chancellor, responsible for royal records.
1 Kings 3:32 Benaiah, son of Jehoiada, was in command of the army. Zadok and Abiathar served as high priests.
1 Kings 3:33 Azariah, son of Nathan, was in charge of the regional governors who oversaw the tribute collection. Zabud, son of Nathan, was a priest and also the king's close friend and advisor.
1 Kings 3:34 Ahishar was the supervisor of the royal palace, and Adoniram, son of Abda, was in charge of the forced labor and taxation.
1 Kings 3:35 Solomon also had twelve district governors appointed over all of Israel. They were responsible for providing food supplies for the king and his royal household. Each governor was in charge of providing supplies for one month out of the year.
1 Kings 3:36 Their names were: Ben-Hur, in the hill country of Ephraim.
1 Kings 3:37 Ben-Dekar, in Makaz, Shaalbim, Beth-shemesh, Elon, and Beth-hanan.
1 Kings 3:38 Ben-Hesed, in Arubboth; his region included Socoh and all the land of Hepher.
1 Kings 3:39 Ben-Abinadab, whose district covered all the heights of Dor. He also had Taphath, one of Solomon's daughters, as his wife.
1 Kings 3:40 Baana, son of Ahilud, was in charge of Taanach and Megiddo, and all of Beth-shan, which is near Zarethan, below Jezreel, extending from Beth-shan to Abel-meholah, and even beyond Jokmeam.
1 Kings 3:1 A covenant was made between Solomon and Pharaoh, the king of Egypt. Solomon took Pharaoh's daughter in marriage and brought her into the city of David, Jerusalem. This was until he finished building his own royal palace, the Temple of the Lord, and the wall around Jerusalem.
1 Kings 3:2 However, the people were still sacrificing in the local high places. This was because the house dedicated to the Name of the Lord—the Temple—had not yet been built by that day.
1 Kings 3:3 Solomon loved the Lord, walking according to the precepts of David, his father. His only exception was that he would offer sacrifices and burn incense in the high places.
1 Kings 3:4 So the king went to Gibeon to sacrifice there, for that was the greatest of the local high places. Solomon offered a thousand burnt offerings upon that altar.
1 Kings 3:5 The Lord appeared to Solomon in Gibeon during a night dream, saying: "Ask for whatever you wish that I may give it to you."
1 Kings 3:6 Solomon said: "You have shown great mercy to your servant David, my father, because he walked before You in truth, and justice, and with an upright heart. And You kept for him Your great mercy, giving him a son who sits upon his throne, even today."
1 Kings 3:7 And now, O Lord, my God, You have made your servant king in place of David my father. But I am a mere child, lacking the experience to lead effectively.
1 Kings 3:8 And your servant is in the midst of Your people whom You have chosen—an immense people, so numerous that they cannot be counted or tallied.
1 Kings 3:9 Therefore, give your servant a docile heart, one capable of learning and understanding Your will, so that he may be able to judge Your people and discern between good and evil. For who can truly judge this great people of Yours?
1 Kings 3:10 And the Lord was pleased with what Solomon said, because he had asked for such a thing.
1 Kings 3:11 And the Lord said to Solomon: "Because you have asked for this, and you have not asked for a long life for yourself, nor riches, nor the lives of your enemies, but rather you have asked for wisdom to discern judgment:
1 Kings 3:12 Behold, I have done for you according to your words. I have given you a wise and understanding heart, so much so that there has been no one like you before you, nor shall anyone like you rise after you.
1 Kings 3:13 But also what you did not ask for, I have given to you: namely, riches and glory. This is so that no one among kings shall be like you in all your days.
1 Kings 3:14 If, however, you walk in My ways and keep My precepts and My commandments, just as David your father walked, I will make your days long.
1 Kings 3:15 So Solomon awoke and understood that it had been a dream. He then came to Jerusalem and stood before the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord. He offered burnt offerings and made peace offerings, and then gave a feast for all his servants.
1 Kings 3:16 Then two women, who were prostitutes, came to the king and stood before him.
1 Kings 3:17 One of them said: "Please, my lord, this woman and I lived in one house. I gave birth while she was with me in the bedchamber."
1 Kings 3:18 "On the third day after I gave birth, this woman also gave birth. We were together, and there was no one else with us in the house except for us two."
1 Kings 3:19 "Now the son of this woman died in the night, for she lay upon him while sleeping."
1 Kings 3:20 "And rising in the deep silence of the night, she took my son from my side, your handmaid, while I was sleeping, and placed him in her bosom. But her own son, who was dead, she placed in my bosom."
1 Kings 3:21 "When I arose in the morning to give milk to my son, he was dead. But when I looked at him more carefully and paid attention, I realized that he was not my son, the one I had given birth to."
1 Kings 3:22 The other woman answered: "It is not as you say; rather, your son is dead, and mine lives." And the first woman countered: "You lie! My son lives, and your son is dead." And so they argued before the king.
1 Kings 3:23 And the king said: "This woman says: 'My son lives, and your son is dead.' And that woman answers: 'No, but your son is dead, and my son lives.'"
1 Kings 3:24 Therefore, the king commanded: "Bring me a sword!" And when they had brought a sword before the king,
1 Kings 3:25 He commanded: "Divide the living infant into two parts, and give one part to one woman, and the other part to the other."
1 Kings 3:26 And the woman whose son was alive responded to the king—for her compassion was deeply stirred for her son: "Please, my lord, give her the living infant, and do not kill him!" But the other woman said: "Let him be neither mine nor yours, but let him be divided!"
1 Kings 3:27 The king answered and said: "Give this woman the living infant, and do not kill him. She is his true mother."
1 Kings 3:28 Therefore, all Israel heard the judgment that the king had rendered. And they feared the king, seeing that the wisdom of God was in him to render such judgment.

1 Kings 3:1 Now, when the reign of King Solomon was established and secure, he married the daughter of Pharaoh, the king of Egypt. He brought her to live in the City of David until he could complete building his own royal palace, the Temple of the Lord, and the protective wall around Jerusalem.
1 Kings 3:2 However, the people were still offering sacrifices at various high places throughout the land, because a dedicated Temple to the Lord had not yet been built for His name, not even up to that day.
1 Kings 3:3 Solomon loved the Lord and walked according to the commands of David, his father. However, he himself also sacrificed and burned incense at those high places.
1 Kings 3:4 So the king went to Gibeon to offer sacrifices there, because that particular place was a great high place for worship. Solomon offered a thousand whole burnt offerings upon that altar.
1 Kings 3:5 While he was at Gibeon, the Lord appeared to Solomon in a dream during the night, saying, 'Ask what you desire, and I will give it to you.'
1 Kings 3:6 Solomon answered, 'You have shown great mercy to Your servant David, my father, because he walked before You in truth, in justice, and with a sincere heart. You have also kept Your great mercy for him by giving him a son to sit on his throne, which is as it is this very day.'
1 Kings 3:7 And now, O Lord God, You have made Your servant king in place of David, my father. But I am merely a young man, inexperienced in leadership, and do not know how to carry out my royal duties.
1 Kings 3:8 And Your servant is in the midst of Your chosen people—an immense population that cannot be numbered or counted because of their great multitude.
1 Kings 3:9 Therefore, give to Your servant an understanding and discerning heart, so that I may be able to judge Your people properly and distinguish between good and evil. For who is truly able to judge this immense people of Yours?
1 Kings 3:10 The Lord was pleased with this request, because Solomon had asked for such a thing.
1 Kings 3:11 The Lord said to Solomon, 'Because you have made this request, and have not asked for yourself a long life, nor riches, nor the deaths of your enemies, but instead have asked for wisdom to discern and administer justice—'
1 Kings 3:12 —behold, I have granted your request. I have given you such a wise and understanding heart that there has been no one like you before, nor will there be anyone like you afterward.'
1 Kings 3:13 'Moreover, I have also given you what you did not ask for—namely, riches and glory—to such an extent that no other king will be your equal throughout your entire life.'
1 Kings 3:14 'Furthermore, if you walk in My ways and keep My precepts and My commandments, just as your father David walked, then I will grant you a long life.'
1 Kings 3:15 Then Solomon awoke and understood that it had been a dream. He came to Jerusalem and stood before the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord. He offered whole burnt offerings and sacrificed peace offerings, and then he held a feast for all his servants.
1 Kings 3:16 After these events, two prostitutes came before the king and stood there in his presence.
1 Kings 3:17 One of them said, 'Please, my lord, this woman and I lived in the same house. While we were there, I gave birth to a child with her in the house.'
1 Kings 3:18 Then, on the third day after I gave birth, this woman also gave birth. We were alone together in the house; there was no one else with us, only the two of us.
1 Kings 3:19 But this woman's son died during the night, because she accidentally overlaid him while she was sleeping.
1 Kings 3:20 Then she rose in the middle of the night, while I, Your handmaid, was sleeping. She took my son from my side and laid him in her own bosom. And her own son, who was already dead, she laid in my bosom instead.
1 Kings 3:21 When I arose in the morning to nurse my son, I found him dead. But when I looked at him closely and carefully, I realized that he was not the son I had given birth to.
1 Kings 3:22 The other woman replied, 'No, that is not true! This living child is my son, and your son is the one who is dead.' But the first woman insisted, 'You are lying! My son is alive, and your son is dead.' And so, they argued back and forth before the king.
1 Kings 3:23 The king then said, 'This woman claims, "My son is alive, and your son is dead." And that woman replies, "No, your son is dead, and my son is alive."'
1 Kings 3:24 The king then added, 'Bring me a sword!' So, they brought a sword into the king’s presence.
1 Kings 3:25 He commanded, 'Cut the living infant in two, and give one half to one woman and the other half to the other.'
1 Kings 3:26 Then the woman whose son was truly alive—for her heart was deeply moved with compassion for her son—spoke to the king, saying, 'Please, my lord, give the living infant to her! Do not kill him!' But the other woman declared, 'Let him be neither mine nor yours. Divide him!'
1 Kings 3:27 Then the king gave the command, saying, 'Give the living infant to this woman, and do not kill him, for she is truly his mother.'
1 Kings 3:28 So all Israel heard the judgment that the king had pronounced, and they stood in awe of the king, for they saw that the wisdom of God was in him to administer justice.
1 Kings 4:1 Therefore, King Solomon was the ruler over all of Israel.
1 Kings 4:2 These were his chief officials: Azariah, the son of Zadok, was the priest.
1 Kings 4:3 Elioreph and Ahiah, the sons of Shisha, were scribes. Jehoshaphat, the son of Ahilud, was the royal recorder.
1 Kings 4:4 Benaiah, the son of Jehoiada, was in charge of the army. Zadok and Abiathar were priests.
1 Kings 4:5 Azariah, the son of Nathan, was in charge of those appointed over individual administrative duties. Zabud, the son of Nathan, was a priest and a friend of the king.
1 Kings 4:6 Ahisar was the chief steward of the palace. Adoniram, the son of Abda, was responsible for the forced labor levy.
1 Kings 4:7 Solomon also had twelve district governors over all Israel. They supplied provisions for the king and his household. Each one supplied food for one month of the year.
1 Kings 4:8 And these are their names: Ben-Hur, in the hill country of Ephraim.
1 Kings 4:9 Ben-Dekar, in Makaz, Shaalbim, Beth-Shemesh, Elon, and Beth-Hanan.
1 Kings 4:10 Ben-Hesed, in Arubboth. To him belonged Socoh and all the land of Hepher.
1 Kings 4:11 Ben-Abinadab, whose district was all of Naphath-Dor. He had Taphath, Solomon’s daughter, as his wife.
1 Kings 4:12 Baana, the son of Ahilud, was in Taanach and Megiddo and in all of Beth-Shan which is next to Zarethan, below Jezreel; from Beth-Shan up to Abel-Meholah, opposite Jokmeam.
1 Kings 4:13 Ben-Geber, in Ramoth-Gilead. To him belonged the villages of Jair, the son of Manasseh, in Gilead. Also, the region of Argob which is in Bashan belonged to him; it had sixty large, fortified cities with bronze gates.
1 Kings 4:14 Ahinadab, the son of Iddo, was the governor of Mahanaim.
1 Kings 4:15 Ahimaaz, in Naphtali. He also had Basemath, Solomon’s daughter, as his wife.
1 Kings 4:16 Baana, the son of Hushai, in Asher and Aloth.
1 Kings 4:17 Jehoshaphat, the son of Paruah, in Issachar.
1 Kings 4:18 Shimei, the son of Elah, in Benjamin.
1 Kings 4:19 Geber, the son of Uri, was in the land of Gilead, in the land of Sihon, king of the Amorites, and Og, king of Bashan. He was the sole governor in that region.
1 Kings 4:20 Judah and Israel were countless, like the sand of the sea in multitude. They were eating and drinking and rejoicing.
1 Kings 4:21 Now Solomon held sway over all the kingdoms, from the River Euphrates to the land of the Philistines, as far as the border of Egypt. They presented gifts to him and served him all the days of his life.
1 Kings 4:22 Solomon’s provisions for each day were thirty cori of fine flour and sixty cori of meal,
1 Kings 4:23 along with ten fattened oxen, twenty pasture-fed oxen, and one hundred sheep. This was in addition to a multitude of deer, gazelles, wild game, and fattened fowl.
1 Kings 4:24 For he ruled over all the region beyond the River Euphrates, from Tiphsah even to Gaza, and over all the kings of those regions. And he had peace on every side, all around.
1 Kings 4:25 Judah and Israel lived securely, each one under his own vine and under his own fig tree, from Dan even to Beersheba, all the days of Solomon.
1 Kings 4:26 And Solomon had forty thousand stalls for chariot horses and twelve thousand cavalry horses.
1 Kings 4:27 Those district governors supplied him with provisions, each one for his month, according to what was appointed for him, so that nothing would be lacking from what was due to the king.
1 Kings 4:28 They also brought barley and straw for the horses and other beasts of burden to the place where the king was, according to what was appointed for them.
1 Kings 4:29 God also gave Solomon wisdom and exceedingly great understanding, and a breadth of mind like the sand which is on the seashore.
1 Kings 4:30 And Solomon’s wisdom surpassed the wisdom of all the people of the East and all the Egyptians.
1 Kings 4:31 And he was wiser than all people; wiser than Ethan the Ezrahite, and Heman, and Calcol, and Darda, the sons of Mahol. And he was renowned among all the surrounding nations.
1 Kings 4:32 He also spoke three thousand proverbs, and his songs were one thousand and five.
1 Kings 4:33 He spoke about trees, from the cedar that is in Lebanon to the hyssop that grows out of the wall. He also spoke about animals, birds, creeping things, and fish.
1 Kings 4:34 And people came from all nations to hear the wisdom of Solomon, and from all the kings of the earth who had heard of his wisdom.
1 Kings 4:1 Therefore, King Solomon was the king over all the nation of Israel.
1 Kings 4:2 These were the chief officials Solomon had serving him: Azariah, the son of Zadok, was the priest.
1 Kings 4:3 Elihoreph and Ahia, the sons of Shisha, were the royal secretaries. Jehoshaphat, the son of Ahilud, was in charge of chronicling the kingdom's history.
1 Kings 4:4 Benaiah, the son of Jehoiada, commanded the army. Zadok and Abiathar were the priests.
1 Kings 4:5 Azariah, the son of Nathan, was the chief officer over those who governed the twelve tribes. Zabud, the son of Nathan, was a priest and the king's trusted personal advisor.
1 Kings 4:6 Ahisar was in charge of the royal household, overseeing the palace. And Adoniram, the son of Abda, managed the forced labor and taxes.
1 Kings 4:7 Now Solomon had twelve district governors appointed over all of Israel. Their duty was to provide food supplies for the king and his royal household. Each of these officials, in turn, was responsible for the provisions during one month of the year.
1 Kings 4:8 And these were their names: Ben-Hur was the governor in the hill country of Ephraim.
1 Kings 4:9 Ben-Dekar was the governor in Makaz, Shaalbim, Beth Shemesh, Elon, and Beth-hanan.
1 Kings 4:10 Ben-Hesed was the governor in Arubboth. He was in charge of Socoh and all the land of Hepher.
1 Kings 4:11 Ben-Abinadab was the governor of all Naphath-Dor. He had as his wife Basemath, Solomon's daughter.
1 Kings 4:12 Baana, the son of Ahilud, was the governor in Taanach and Megiddo, and all of Beth-shean, which is near Zarethan, below Jezreel, from Beth-shean to Abel-meholah, and across the Jordan River.
1 Kings 4:13 Ben-Geber was the governor in Ramoth-Gilead. He was responsible for the tent villages of Jair, the son of Manasseh, in Gilead. He was also in charge of the region of Argob in Bashan, which contained sixty large, fortified cities with gates secured by bronze bars.
1 Kings 4:14 Ahinadab, the son of Iddo, was the governor in Mahanaim.
1 Kings 4:15 Ahimaaz was the governor in Naphtali. He also married Basemath, Solomon's daughter.
1 Kings 4:16 Baana, the son of Hushai, was the governor in Asher and Aloth.
1 Kings 4:17 Jehoshaphat, the son of Paruah, was the governor in Issachar.
1 Kings 4:18 Shimei, the son of Elah, was the governor in Benjamin.
1 Kings 4:19 Geber, the son of Uri, was the governor in the land of Gilead, in the territory of Sihon king of the Amorites, and of Og king of Bashan. He alone was the governor over that consolidated region.
1 Kings 4:20 The people of Judah and Israel were countless, as numerous as the sand on the seashore. They were prosperous, eating and drinking, and rejoicing in their safety.
1 Kings 4:21 King Solomon held dominion over all the kingdoms from the great Euphrates River down to the land of the Philistines and as far as the border of Egypt. These nations presented him with gifts and served him throughout his entire life.
1 Kings 4:22 For each day, the food provisions for Solomon's court were thirty measures of fine flour and sixty measures of coarser meal.
1 Kings 4:23 This included ten fattened oxen, twenty oxen from the pastures, and one hundred sheep, not including the vast numbers of deer, gazelles, roebucks, and specially fattened birds that were also consumed.
1 Kings 4:24 Indeed, he held sway over the entire region west of the great Euphrates River, from Tiphsah all the way to Gaza, and over all the kings of those surrounding lands. Thus, he maintained peace on all sides of his dominion.
1 Kings 4:25 Therefore, the people of Judah and Israel lived in great security, each person dwelling peacefully under his own vine and fig tree—a sign of prosperity—from the northern city of Dan all the way to Beersheba in the south, for all of Solomon's days.
1 Kings 4:26 Solomon also had forty thousand stalls for the horses used for his chariots, and he maintained twelve thousand horsemen in his cavalry.
1 Kings 4:27 The aforementioned district governors provided the provisions for King Solomon and for all who ate at his table, each in his own month, ensuring that nothing was lacking.
1 Kings 4:28 They also brought barley and straw for the horses and for the other draft animals to the location where the king was staying, each governor according to his specific assignment.
1 Kings 4:29 Moreover, God granted Solomon immense wisdom and very great understanding, along with an expansive breadth of mind, as vast as the sand on the seashore.
1 Kings 4:30 Solomon's wisdom surpassed the wisdom of all the people of the East and all the wisdom of Egypt.
1 Kings 4:31 He was wiser than all other people, even wiser than Ethan the Ezrahite, Heman, Chalkol, and Darda, the sons of Mahol. His fame for wisdom spread throughout all the surrounding nations.
1 Kings 4:32 He also uttered three thousand proverbs and composed five thousand songs.
1 Kings 4:33 He spoke extensively about all forms of plant life, from the magnificent cedar of Lebanon to the humble hyssop that grows from a wall. He also discoursed on animals of the land, birds of the air, creeping creatures, and fish of the sea.
1 Kings 4:34 People came from all nations to listen to Solomon's wisdom, and kings from all over the earth sent envoys who had heard of his profound understanding.
1 Kings 4:1 So King Solomon was reigning over all of Israel.
1 Kings 4:2 These were the chief officers he had: Azarias, the son of Sadoc, was the priest.
1 Kings 4:3 Elihoreph and Ahia, the sons of Sisa, were the scribes, responsible for royal records; and Josaphat, the son of Ahilud, was the chancellor, managing state affairs.
1 Kings 4:4 Banaias, the son of Jojada, was in command of the army; and Sadoc and Abiathar were the chief priests.
1 Kings 4:5 Azarias, the son of Nathan, was in charge of all the officers appointed over various duties; and Zabud, the son of Nathan, was a priest and a trusted friend of the king.
1 Kings 4:6 Ahisar was the prefect of the royal palace, managing the household; and Adoniram, the son of Abda, was in charge of collecting all the taxes and tribute.
1 Kings 4:7 Solomon also had twelve officers appointed over all of Israel, whose duty was to provide food supplies for the king and his royal household. Each of these officers would provide the necessary provisions for one month of the year.
1 Kings 4:8 And these were their names and their assigned districts: Benhur was in the mountainous region of Ephraim.
1 Kings 4:9 Bendecar was in Macces, and in Saalabim, and Bethsames, and Elon Bethanan.
1 Kings 4:10 Benhesed was in Aruboth; his district included Socho and all the land of Epher.
1 Kings 4:11 Benabinadab had responsibility for all of Nephath Dor. He also had Taphath, Solomon’s daughter, as his wife.
1 Kings 4:12 Bana, the son of Ahilud, was responsible for Thanac and Mageddo, and all of Bethsan, which is near Sarthana, below Jezrahel, stretching from Bethsan all the way to Abelmehula, opposite Jecmaan.
1 Kings 4:13 Bengaber was in Ramoth Galaad; he also controlled the Avoth Jair, the villages belonging to the sons of Manasse in Galaad. His region was Argob, which is in Basan, consisting of sixty large, walled cities, each with bronze gate-bolts.
1 Kings 4:14 Ahinadab, the son of Addo, was the officer for Maanaim.
1 Kings 4:15 Achimaas was in Nephthali; he, too, had taken Basemath, Solomon’s daughter, as his wife.
1 Kings 4:16 Baana, the son of Husai, was in Aser and Baloth.
1 Kings 4:17 Josaphat, the son of Pharue, was in Issachar.
1 Kings 4:18 Semei, the son of Ela, was in Benjamin.
1 Kings 4:19 Geber, the son of Uri, was in the land of Galaad, which was the territory of Sehon, king of the Amorrhaei, and Og, king of Basan; he was the only officer appointed over that land.
1 Kings 4:20 The people of Juda and Israel were as numerous as the sand on the seashore; they were eating and drinking and living in joy.
