1 Kings 4:21 Solomon was reigning over all the kingdoms, holding dominion from the great River (the Euphrates), through the land of the Philistines, and all the way to the border of Egypt. These kingdoms offered him tribute and served him all the days of his life.
1 Kings 4:22 Solomon’s daily provisions were an immense amount: thirty *chori* of fine flour and sixty *chori* of regular flour. (A *chorus* was a large measure, approximately 60 gallons).
1 Kings 4:23 Also, ten fattened oxen, twenty oxen from the pastures, and one hundred rams were provided, in addition to many deer, gazelles, wild oxen, and fattened birds.
1 Kings 4:24 For he ruled over all the region beyond the great River, from Thaphsa all the way to Gaza, and over all the kings of those surrounding regions. He enjoyed peace on every side.
1 Kings 4:25 Throughout all the days of Solomon’s reign, the people of Juda and Israel lived in safety and peace, each person secure under his own vine and fig tree, from the northernmost city of Dan to the southernmost city of Bersabee.
1 Kings 4:26 Solomon also had forty thousand stalls for his chariot horses and twelve thousand horses for his cavalry.
1 Kings 4:27 The aforementioned officers would each, in their assigned month, provide the food supplies for King Solomon and for all who came to his table, ensuring that nothing was ever lacking.
1 Kings 4:28 They also brought barley and straw for the horses and other draft animals to the place where the king resided, according to their assigned duty.
1 Kings 4:29 God also gave Solomon wisdom and exceedingly great understanding, and a breadth of mind as vast as the sand on the seashore.
1 Kings 4:30 Solomon’s wisdom surpassed the wisdom of all the people of the East and all the wisdom of the Egyptians.
1 Kings 4:31 Indeed, he was wiser than all other men; he was wiser than Ethan the Ezrahite, and Heman, Chalchol, and Darda, the sons of Mahol. His fame for wisdom spread throughout all the surrounding nations.
1 Kings 4:32 He spoke three thousand proverbs, and his songs numbered five thousand.
1 Kings 4:33 He discoursed about all kinds of plant life, from the magnificent cedar that grows in Libanus down to the humble hyssop that sprouts from a wall. He also spoke extensively about animals, birds, reptiles, and fish.
1 Kings 4:34 So people came from all nations to hear Solomon’s wisdom, and from all the kings of the earth who had heard of his wisdom.
1 Kings 5:1 Hiram, King of Tyre, sent his servants to King Solomon after hearing that Solomon had been anointed king in place of his father, King David. This was because Hiram had always been a loyal friend to David.
1 Kings 5:2 Solomon then sent a message to Hiram, saying:
1 Kings 5:3 You know that my father David wanted to build a Temple for the Lord his God, but he could not because of the wars that surrounded him. God prevented him until the Lord made all his enemies subject to him.
1 Kings 5:4 But now the Lord my God has given me peace on all sides; there is no adversary, and no evil threatens my kingdom.
1 Kings 5:5 Therefore, I intend to build a Temple for the Lord my God, just as the Lord spoke to my father David, saying: ‘Your son, whom I will place on your throne in your stead, he shall build a house for my Name.’
1 Kings 5:6 Therefore, command your workers to cut down cedar trees from Lebanon for me. My workers will join your workers, and I will pay you whatever wages you determine for your workers. For you know that there is no one among my people who can cut timber as skillfully as the Sidonians and Tyrians.
1 Kings 5:7 When Hiram heard Solomon’s message, he rejoiced greatly and said: 'Blessed be the Lord today, who has given David a most wise son to rule over this great people!'
1 Kings 5:8 Hiram then sent this message back to Solomon: 'I have heard what you commanded me. I will fulfill all your wishes concerning cedar timber and fir timber.'
1 Kings 5:9 My workers will bring the timber down from Lebanon to the sea. I will then bind them into rafts on the sea and transport them to whatever location you specify. There I will unload them, and you may take them. My only condition is that you provide provisions for my household in return.
1 Kings 5:10 Therefore, Hiram provided King Solomon with cedar timber and fir timber, supplying everything Solomon desired.
1 Kings 5:11 In return, Solomon gave Hiram twenty thousand measures of wheat to feed his household, and twenty thousand measures of pure olive oil. Solomon supplied these to Hiram every single year.
1 Kings 5:12 The Lord also gave wisdom to Solomon, just as He had promised him. There was peace between Hiram and Solomon, and the two kings made a formal treaty together.
1 Kings 5:13 King Solomon drafted workers from all of Israel; this forced labor amounted to thirty thousand men.
1 Kings 5:14 He sent them to Lebanon in shifts of ten thousand men each month. This meant they would work one month in Lebanon and then be at home for two months. Adoniram was in charge of this forced labor.
1 Kings 5:15 Solomon also had seventy thousand men who carried burdens and eighty thousand stonecutters working in the mountains.
1 Kings 5:16 This was in addition to the three thousand three hundred overseers whom Solomon had appointed over the work. These overseers were in charge of the workers and supervised the preparations for the construction.
1 Kings 5:17 The king also commanded them to bring large, carefully selected stones for the Temple’s foundation and to prepare them by squaring them.
1 Kings 5:18 The stonecutters of Solomon and Hiram, along with the Giblites, quarried and shaped these stones. They prepared both the timber and the stones for the construction of the Temple.
1 Kings 5:1 And Hiram, king of Tyre, sent his servants to King Solomon, because Hiram had heard that they had anointed Solomon as king in his father's place. Hiram had been King David's friend throughout his life.
1 Kings 5:2 Solomon, in turn, sent a message to Hiram, saying:
1 Kings 5:3 You know the desire of my father, David, and how he was unable to build a temple dedicated to the Name of the Lord his God. This was because of the wars that surrounded him, until the Lord completely subdued his enemies.
1 Kings 5:4 But now the Lord my God has given me peace on every side. There is no adversary, and there are no threats of harm.
1 Kings 5:5 Therefore, I intend to build a temple dedicated to the Name of the Lord my God, just as the Lord spoke to my father, David, saying: 'Your son, whom I will establish on your throne in your place, will himself build a temple dedicated to My Name.'
1 Kings 5:6 So then, command your people to cut down cedar trees from Lebanon for me. My servants will work alongside your servants, and I will pay your servants whatever wages you determine. For you know that there is no one among my people who is skilled at cutting timber as well as the Sidonians are.
1 Kings 5:7 When Hiram heard Solomon's words, he was overjoyed and exclaimed, 'Blessed be the Lord today, who has given David such a wise son to rule over this great people!'
1 Kings 5:8 Then Hiram sent word back to Solomon, saying: 'I have heard what you requested of me. I will fulfill all your desires regarding the cedar and fir timbers.'
1 Kings 5:9 My servants will bring the timbers down from Lebanon to the sea. Then I will bind them into rafts on the sea and tow them to the location you specify for me. There, I will have them disassembled, and you can take them. In return, you will provide food supplies for my royal household.
1 Kings 5:10 So Hiram supplied Solomon with cedar timbers and fir timbers, just as he had desired.
1 Kings 5:11 Solomon, in turn, gave Hiram twenty thousand *cori* (an ancient unit of measure) of wheat as provisions for his royal household, and twenty thousand *cori* of the purest olive oil. Solomon gave these provisions to Hiram each and every year.
1 Kings 5:12 The Lord also granted Solomon wisdom, just as He had promised him. And there was peace between Hiram and Solomon, and the two kings made a formal treaty together.
1 Kings 5:13 Then King Solomon raised a forced labor levy from all of Israel, and this levy consisted of thirty thousand men.
1 Kings 5:14 He sent these men to Lebanon, ten thousand each month in rotation. This arrangement meant that for two months they were in their own homes, and then for the third month, they were in Lebanon. Adoniram was the overseer of this forced labor levy.
1 Kings 5:15 Solomon also had seventy thousand men who carried heavy loads and eighty thousand stonecutters working in the hill country.
1 Kings 5:16 This was in addition to the two hundred and fifty chief overseers who were in charge of each of Solomon's work crews. These overseers pressed the people and ensured the work progressed quickly.
1 Kings 5:17 The king commanded them to quarry large, choice stones, and to prepare them as squared stones, for the foundation of the temple.
1 Kings 5:18 And so, Solomon's skilled workers, along with Hiram's skilled workers and the Giblites, hewed and prepared the timbers and stones, all in readiness for the building of the temple.
1 Kings 6:1 Now it happened in the four hundred and eightieth year after the children of Israel departed from the land of Egypt, in the fourth year of Solomon’s reign over Israel, in the month of Ziph—which is the second month of the year—that he began to build the House for the Lord.
1 Kings 6:2 The House that King Solomon was building for the Lord had a length of sixty cubits, a width of twenty cubits, and a height of thirty cubits.
1 Kings 6:3 And there was a portico in front of the Temple, twenty cubits long—matching the width of the House—and ten cubits wide, extending out from the front of the House.
1 Kings 6:4 And he made narrow, recessed windows in the Temple.
1 Kings 6:5 And he built side chambers—or stories—around the outer walls of the House, making ledges all around.
1 Kings 6:6 The lowest story was five cubits wide, the middle one six cubits wide, and the third story seven cubits wide; for indeed, the outer wall of the House was recessed all around, so that the supporting beams would not have to be fastened into the walls of the House itself.
1 Kings 6:7 And when the House was being built, it was constructed from carefully cut and perfectly finished stones; so that no sound of hammer, axe, or any iron tool was heard in the House while it was being built.
1 Kings 6:8 The entrance to the lowest side chamber was on the right side of the House, and a winding staircase led up to the middle story, and from the middle story up to the third.
1 Kings 6:9 And he built the House, and he finished it; and he covered the House with ceilings—constructed of cedar planks.
1 Kings 6:10 And he built the stories around the entire House, each five cubits high; and he joined the House with cedar planks for these stories.
1 Kings 6:11 Now the word of the Lord came to Solomon, saying:
1 Kings 6:12 Concerning this House that you are building: if you walk in my precepts, and carry out my judgments, and keep all my commandments and walk in them, then I will confirm my word to you, which I spoke to David your father.
1 Kings 6:13 And I will dwell in the midst of the children of Israel, and I will not forsake my people Israel.
1 Kings 6:14 Therefore, Solomon built the House, and he finished it.
1 Kings 6:15 And he built the inner walls of the House with cedar planks, from the floor of the House up to the ceilings, paneling the interior with wood; and he laid the floor of the House with planks of fir wood.
1 Kings 6:16 And at the rear of the House, he built a partition of cedar planks twenty cubits high from the floor to the ceiling; and he made within it the Inner Sanctuary, that is, the Holy of Holies.
1 Kings 6:17 The main part of the House—that is, the Temple proper before the Inner Sanctuary—was fifty cubits long.
1 Kings 6:18 And all the interior of the entire House was covered with cedar planks, decorated with carvings and engravings, with twisted designs and various patterns, both raised and flat.
1 Kings 6:19 And he prepared the Inner Sanctuary in the middle of the House’s interior, to place there the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord.
1 Kings 6:20 Furthermore, the Inner Sanctuary was twenty cubits long, twenty cubits wide, and twenty cubits high; and he covered it with pure gold; and he placed an altar before the Inner Sanctuary and covered it with gold.
1 Kings 6:21 And Solomon covered the interior of the House with pure gold, and he placed gold chains before the Inner Sanctuary, and he covered it—the Inner Sanctuary—with gold.
1 Kings 6:22 And there was nothing in the entire House that was not covered with gold; even the whole altar of the Inner Sanctuary he covered with gold.
1 Kings 6:23 And in the Inner Sanctuary, he made two cherubim—angelic figures—of olive wood, each ten cubits high.
1 Kings 6:24 One wing of the first cherub was five cubits long, and the other wing of the cherub was five cubits long; that is, it was ten cubits from the tip of one wing to the tip of the other wing.
1 Kings 6:25 Likewise, the second cherub also had ten cubits in wing span; the measurement was equal, and the craftsmanship was equal for both cherubim.
1 Kings 6:26 One cherub had a height of ten cubits, and likewise the other cherub.
1 Kings 6:27 And he placed the two cherubim in the middle of the inner Temple; and the cherubim spread out their wings, so that one wing touched one wall, and the wing of the other cherub touched the other wall; and their remaining wings touched each other in the middle of the Temple.
1 Kings 6:28 He also covered the cherubim completely with gold.
1 Kings 6:29 And he carved all the walls of the House all around with various engravings and lathe work, both inside and outside; and he made cherubim, and palm trees, and various sculptured designs, appearing as if raised from the walls.
1 Kings 6:30 And he also covered the floor of the House with gold, both inside and outside.
1 Kings 6:31 And for the entrance of the Inner Sanctuary, he made doors of olive wood; and the doorposts and side panels formed five-sided frames.
1 Kings 6:32 And there were two doors of olive wood; and he engraved and carved on them cherubim, and palm trees, and very prominent decorative figures; and he covered everything with gold, both the cherubim and the palm trees.
1 Kings 6:33 And for the entrance of the main Temple area, he made doorposts of olive wood, having four distinct angles.
1 Kings 6:34 And there were two doors made of fir wood, carved and engraved, which opened—and the two sides of their hinges folded back.
1 Kings 6:35 And he engraved on them cherubim, and palm trees, and very prominent engravings; and he covered everything with gold sheets.
1 Kings 6:36 And he built the inner court with three courses of polished stones and one course of cedar beams.
1 Kings 6:37 In the fourth year, in the month of Ziph, the House of the Lord was founded.
1 Kings 6:38 And in the eleventh year, in the month of Bul—which is the eighth month—the House was finished in all its work, and in all that pertained to it; and he built it in seven years.
1 Kings 6:1 It happened then, four hundred and eighty years after the children of Israel left the land of Egypt—specifically in the second month, which is called Ziph—and in the fourth year of Solomon’s reign over Israel: Solomon began to build the Temple of the Lord.
1 Kings 6:2 The Temple that King Solomon built for the Lord had a length of sixty cubits, a width of twenty cubits, and a height of thirty cubits.
1 Kings 6:3 The entrance porch in front of the main Temple structure was twenty cubits long, matching the width of the Temple itself. This porch extended ten cubits out from the Temple’s main front wall.
1 Kings 6:4 And for the Temple, he made windows with recessed frames.
1 Kings 6:5 He also built side chambers against the walls of the Temple, all around the structure. These side chambers extended around the outer walls of both the main sanctuary and the inner Holy of Holies. He structured these rooms in a circular arrangement.
1 Kings 6:6 The lowest story of these side chambers was five cubits wide. The middle story was six cubits wide, and the third story was seven cubits wide. This widening allowed for a set of stairs to be placed along the outside of the Temple structure. This design ensured that the supporting beams for the side chambers did not need to be inserted into the walls of the main Temple itself.
1 Kings 6:7 When the Temple was being built, it was constructed from stones that had been completely cut and prepared at the quarry. No hammer, ax, or any other iron tool was heard on the site while the Temple was under construction.
1 Kings 6:8 The entrance to the middle side chamber was on the right side of the Temple. People would ascend by a winding staircase to the middle story, and from the middle story to the third story.
1 Kings 6:9 So Solomon built the Temple and completed its construction. He covered the Temple with ceiling panels made from cedar planks.
1 Kings 6:10 He also built the side chambers all around the Temple structure, each five cubits high, and he covered the Temple’s exterior with cedar wood.
1 Kings 6:11 Then the word of the Lord came to Solomon, saying:
1 Kings 6:12 “Concerning this Temple that you are building: if you walk in My commandments, and execute My judgments, and keep all My precepts by walking in them, then I will fulfill My promise to you, which I spoke to David your father.
1 Kings 6:13 I will dwell among the children of Israel, and I will not forsake My people Israel.”
1 Kings 6:14 So Solomon continued to build the Temple, and he completed it.
1 Kings 6:15 Inside the Temple, he built the walls with cedar planks, from the floor of the Temple up to the ceiling. He covered the interior with wood and laid the floor of the Temple with cypress planks.
1 Kings 6:16 And for twenty cubits at the back part of the Temple, he built a partition with cedar planks, from the floor all the way up. This created the inner sanctuary, which is the Holy of Holies, as an inner space within the Temple of the Lord.
1 Kings 6:17 The main sanctuary in front of the Holy of Holies measured forty cubits in length.
1 Kings 6:18 The entire interior of the Temple was cedar, carved with intricate designs and ornamental flower buds. No stone was visible at all; everything was covered with wood.
1 Kings 6:19 And he prepared the Holy of Holies in the innermost part of the Temple, so that the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord could be placed there.
1 Kings 6:20 The Holy of Holies itself was twenty cubits long, twenty cubits wide, and twenty cubits high. He covered it with pure gold plates, and he placed an altar in front of this inner sanctuary.
1 Kings 6:21 Solomon covered the entire interior of the Temple with the purest gold. He hung gold chains across the front of the Holy of Holies and also covered it with gold.
1 Kings 6:22 There was nothing in the Temple that was not covered with gold; even the entire altar belonging to the Holy of Holies he covered with gold.
1 Kings 6:23 And in the Holy of Holies, he made two cherubim from olive wood, each ten cubits high.
1 Kings 6:24 One wing of a cherub was five cubits long, and the other wing of the cherub was also five cubits long. This means that from the tip of one wing to the tip of the other wing, each cherub measured ten cubits across.
1 Kings 6:25 The other cherub also was ten cubits high; its measurements were the same, and the craftsmanship for both cherubim was identical.
1 Kings 6:26 That is to say, each cherub measured ten cubits in height.
1 Kings 6:27 And he placed the two cherubim in the middle of the inner Temple, which is the Holy of Holies. The cherubim spread out their wings, so that one wing of the first cherub touched one wall, and a wing of the other cherub touched the opposite wall. Their other two wings met in the middle of the Holy of Holies, joining one another.
1 Kings 6:28 He also covered the cherubim with gold.
1 Kings 6:29 And all the walls of the Temple around its perimeter, both within and without, he decorated. He carved various designs and sculptures upon them, including cherubim, palm trees, and ornate open flower carvings, all around.
1 Kings 6:30 He also covered the floor of the Temple with gold, both inside the inner sanctuary and in the outer sanctuary.
1 Kings 6:31 And for the entrance to the Holy of Holies, he made doors from olive wood, with doorposts and doorframes forming five distinct angles.
1 Kings 6:32 These two olive wood doors were carved with cherubim, palm trees, and carved open flower designs. He covered all of them with gold—both the cherubim and the palm trees and the other carvings.
1 Kings 6:33 And for the entrance to the main Temple sanctuary, he made doorposts of olive wood, shaped into a four-angled frame.
1 Kings 6:34 And there were two doors of cypress wood, each consisting of two folding panels that could swing open or fold back.
1 Kings 6:35 And he carved cherubim, palm trees, and intricate flower designs on these doors. He covered all of them entirely with gold plates.
1 Kings 6:36 He also built the inner courtyard with three courses of finely cut stones and one course of cedar beams.
1 Kings 6:37 In the fourth year, in the month of Ziph, the foundation of the Temple of the Lord was laid.
1 Kings 6:38 And in the eleventh year, in the month of Bul—which is the eighth month—the Temple was completely finished in all its work and in all its preparation. Solomon built it in seven years.
1 Kings 6:1 Now it was in the four hundred and eightieth year after the sons of Israel had departed from the land of Egypt, in the fourth year of Solomon’s reign over Israel, in the month of Ziph (which is the second month of the year), that King Solomon began to build the sacred dwelling for the Lord.
1 Kings 6:2 The sacred dwelling that King Solomon was building for the Lord was sixty cubits (approximately 18 inches or 45 centimeters per cubit) in length, twenty cubits in width, and thirty cubits in height.
1 Kings 6:3 And the porch in front of the Temple building was twenty cubits long, matching the width of the Temple building itself, and it extended ten cubits in width in front of the main façade of the Temple.
1 Kings 6:4 And King Solomon made windows with latticework within the Temple building.
1 Kings 6:5 And he built side chambers surrounding the wall of the Temple, against the walls of the sacred dwelling all around, both for the main sanctuary and for the inner oracle, creating additional structures along the perimeter.
1 Kings 6:6 The lowest side chamber was five cubits wide, the middle one six cubits wide, and the third seven cubits wide. This was because he had made ledges on the outside wall of the sacred dwelling all around, so that the supporting beams would not have to be fastened into the Temple walls themselves.
1 Kings 6:7 And when the sacred dwelling was being built, the stones were brought to the site already hewn and perfectly shaped. No hammer, no axe, and no iron tool of any kind was heard at the building site while the Temple was being constructed.
1 Kings 6:8 The entrance to the middle side chamber was on the right side of the sacred dwelling, and a winding staircase led up to the middle chamber, and from the middle chamber up to the third.
1 Kings 6:9 So King Solomon built the sacred dwelling and brought it to completion. He then covered the roof of the sacred dwelling with ceiling beams and boards made of cedar wood.
1 Kings 6:10 And he built the entire upper story, which was five cubits in height, connecting it to the main structure with cedar planks.
1 Kings 6:11 Then the word of the Lord came to Solomon, saying:
1 Kings 6:12 “Regarding this sacred dwelling that you are building: if you walk in My precepts, and you execute My judgments, and you keep all My commandments by walking in them, then I will establish My promise with you, which I spoke to David your father.
1 Kings 6:13 And I will dwell in the midst of the sons of Israel, and I will not forsake My people, Israel.”
1 Kings 6:14 Therefore, Solomon continued to build the sacred dwelling, and he brought it to completion.
1 Kings 6:15 And he built the inner walls of the sacred dwelling with cedar planks, from the floor of the dwelling up to the upper parts of the roof; he covered the interior with wood and laid the floor of the sacred dwelling with planks of fir wood.
1 Kings 6:16 And he built twenty cubits from the back part of the Temple building with cedar planks, from the floor up to the top, and he made an inner sanctuary there, which is to say, the Holy of Holies.
1 Kings 6:17 And the main hall of the Temple, in front of the inner oracle, was forty cubits long.
1 Kings 6:18 And the entire interior of the sacred dwelling was covered with cedar planks, having carved mouldings and various projecting sculptures; there was absolutely nothing inside but cedar wood.
1 Kings 6:19 And he prepared the inner oracle in the middle of the sacred dwelling, in its interior part, so that he might place there the ark of the covenant of the Lord.
1 Kings 6:20 Furthermore, the inner oracle was twenty cubits in length, and twenty cubits in width, and twenty cubits in height. He covered it with pure gold, and he fashioned an altar from cedar planks.
1 Kings 6:21 And Solomon overlaid the sacred dwelling's interior with pure gold. He placed golden panels all around the sanctuary and prepared a golden veil.
1 Kings 6:22 And he covered the entire altar of the inner oracle with pure gold; and he overlaid the whole sacred dwelling with gold until all was completed. Indeed, he also covered the altar of the oracle with gold.
1 Kings 6:23 And in the inner oracle, he made two cherubim from olive wood, each ten cubits in height.
1 Kings 6:24 One wing of a cherub was five cubits long, and the other wing of the cherub was five cubits long; that is, it was ten cubits from the tip of one wing to the tip of the other wing.
1 Kings 6:25 The second cherub was also ten cubits long. Both cherubim had the same measurement and the same workmanship.
1 Kings 6:26 The height of one cherub was ten cubits, and similarly, the other cherub also had a height of ten cubits.
1 Kings 6:27 And he placed the two cherubim in the middle of the inner Temple sanctuary. The cherubim spread out their wings, and one wing of a cherub touched one wall, and the wing of the other cherub touched the other wall; and their other two wings met each other in the middle of the Temple.
1 Kings 6:28 And he also overlaid the cherubim with gold.
1 Kings 6:29 And all the walls of the sacred dwelling, all around, he carved with various engravings and carvings, making cherubim, and palm trees, and he carved various pictures, as if projecting from the wall and extending beyond it.
1 Kings 6:30 Moreover, he covered the floor of the sacred dwelling with gold, both inside and outside.
1 Kings 6:31 And for the entrance to the inner oracle, he made doors of olive wood, with doorposts and doorframes forming five angles.
1 Kings 6:32 And the two doors were made of olive wood. On them he carved cherubim and palm trees and greatly projecting images. He covered all of these with gold, overlaying both the cherubim and the palm trees with gold.
1 Kings 6:33 And for the entrance to the main Temple hall, he made doorposts of olive wood, shaped squarely.
1 Kings 6:34 And there were two doors of fir wood; each door was double, and they folded back upon each other.
1 Kings 6:35 And he carved on them cherubim, and palm trees, and many carvings that seemed to project outward. And he covered all of these with gold.
1 Kings 6:36 And he built the inner court with three courses of hewn stones and one course of cedar timbers.
1 Kings 6:37 In the fourth year, the foundation of the sacred dwelling for the Lord was laid, in the month of Ziph.
1 Kings 6:38 And in the eleventh year, in the month of Bul (which is the eighth month of the year), the sacred dwelling was finished in all its work and in all its construction. So Solomon built it in seven years.
1 Kings 6:39 I did not enclose the entire sacred dwelling with the side structures' paneling.
1 Kings 6:40 And the exterior of the sacred dwelling, and its interior, and the ceilings, and all the woodwork, were made of cedar wood.
1 Kings 7:1 Now, Solomon built his own royal palace for thirteen years, until he completed all the buildings in his complex.
1 Kings 7:2 He also built a palace known as 'the House of the Forest of Lebanon.' It was one hundred cubits long, fifty cubits wide, and thirty cubits high. This structure had four rows of cedar columns, supporting cedar beams for the ceiling above the columns.
1 Kings 7:3 The colonnade was made of cedar columns, supporting thirty cedar beams above them. These beams were precisely fitted to the columns, and the capitals of the columns were adorned with carvings all around.
1 Kings 7:4 There were dining hall windows arranged in three rows all around. Above these, there were additional sets of windows, also in three layers.
1 Kings 7:5 All the doorways, windows, and doorframes were designed with square frames, each matching the other, arranged in three consistent rows.
1 Kings 7:6 He also built a colonnade, fifty cubits long and thirty cubits wide, formed by columns. There was a second portico in front of this larger one, complete with its own columns and supporting architraves placed upon them.
1 Kings 7:7 He made a throne room for judgment, where he would sit to pass decrees, known as 'the Portico of Judgment.' This entire room, from the floor to the ceiling, was covered all around with cedar paneling.
1 Kings 7:8 Solomon's own dwelling, where he lived, was constructed with a different design, set outside this judgment portico. It was similar in style to the House of the Forest of Lebanon. He also built a palace of the same craftsmanship for Pharaoh's daughter, whom he had married.
1 Kings 7:9 All these structures were built using expensive, precisely cut stones, sawn with a saw, both on their interior and exterior faces. These stones extended from the foundation up to the roof-level, and on the outside, they reached all the way to the great courtyard.
1 Kings 7:10 The foundations themselves were laid with costly, large stones: some were eighteen cubits, and others were twelve cubits in size.
1 Kings 7:11 Above these large foundation stones, there were more costly stones, precisely cut to measure, along with cedar timbers.
1 Kings 7:12 The great courtyard all around was constructed with three rows of cut stones and one row of cedar wood. The inner courtyard of the Lord's Temple and the portico of the Temple were built similarly.
1 Kings 7:13 So King Solomon sent for and brought Hiram from Tyre.
1 Kings 7:14 Hiram was the son of a widowed woman from the tribe of Naphtali, but his father was a man from Tyre, a skilled bronze-worker. Hiram possessed exceptional knowledge for executing every kind of bronze work. When he arrived before King Solomon, he carried out all the work entrusted to him.
1 Kings 7:15 He cast two columns out of bronze. Each column was eighteen cubits in height, and the circumference of each column was twelve cubits, measured around it.
1 Kings 7:16 He also made two bronze capitals, cast in a mold, to be placed on the tops of the columns. Each capital was five cubits high.
1 Kings 7:17 On the capitals, which were on top of the columns, he crafted decorations resembling netting and intertwined chains. There were seven such ornate layers on one capital and seven layers on the other capital.
1 Kings 7:18 He finished the columns, designing two rows of pomegranates all around on one capital, concealing them within the netting that was above the column tops. Similarly, one hundred pomegranates were arranged in two rows all around the other capital.
1 Kings 7:19 The capitals on top of the columns, in the portico, were shaped like polished lilies, extending for four cubits.
1 Kings 7:20 Again, there were other capitals on the two columns, extending around above the netting. Two hundred pomegranates were arranged in rows all around the second capital.
1 Kings 7:21 He set up these columns in the portico of the Temple. He erected the right-hand column and named it 'Jachin.' In the same way, he erected the left-hand column and named it 'Boaz.'
1 Kings 7:22 On top of the columns, there was a decorative design resembling lilies. This completed the work on the columns.
1 Kings 7:23 He also made the great bronze basin, referred to as 'the Sea.' It measured ten cubits from rim to rim, perfectly round in its circumference. It was five cubits high, and a measuring line of thirty cubits could encircle its entire perimeter.
1 Kings 7:24 Under its rim, there were sculpted decorations encircling it, ten sections per cubit, appearing as if two rows of carvings had been cast as one piece.
1 Kings 7:25 The basin stood upon twelve bronze oxen. Three of them faced north, three faced west, three faced south, and three faced east. The great basin rested upon them from above, with the rear parts of the oxen facing inward.
1 Kings 7:26 The thickness of the bronze basin was four fingers. Its rim was shaped like the rim of a cup, or like a spreading lily petal. It had a capacity of two thousand baths.
1 Kings 7:27 He also made ten bronze stands. Each stand was four cubits long, four cubits wide, and three cubits high.
1 Kings 7:28 Between the panels on the stands, there were sculpted figures of lions, oxen, and cherubim. Similar decorations were also placed on the sections above and below these figures.
1 Kings 7:29 Beneath the feet of each stand were four wheels, and their axles were made of bronze. On all four sides, there were shoulder-like supports, cast in bronze, positioned opposite each other beneath the rim.
1 Kings 7:30 The four sides of each stand were adorned with wave-like carvings and hand-like sculptures all around.
1 Kings 7:31 The opening for the basin in the middle, at the top, was one cubit. All around the opening, there were engraved connections. The work was square, not round, measuring one and a half cubits in width.
1 Kings 7:32 And there were four wheels on each side, positioned beneath the connecting structures. The height of each wheel was one and a half cubits.
1 Kings 7:33 The wheels were similar to chariot wheels; their axles, spokes, felloes, and hubs, were all cast in bronze.
1 Kings 7:34 There were four shoulder-like supports on each stand, extending downwards. They were cast in bronze and positioned opposite each other.
1 Kings 7:35 At the very top of each stand, there was a round feature, one and a half cubits in circumference, with carvings on each small column and on its square panels.
1 Kings 7:36 He carved lions, oxen, and cherubim onto the panels and square surfaces. On the hinges, there were also sculpted decorative additions.
1 Kings 7:37 In this manner, he made ten stands. All of them had the same casting, the same measurements, and the same carvings.
1 Kings 7:38 He also made ten bronze basins. Each basin had a capacity of forty baths, and each basin measured four cubits. One basin was placed upon each of the stands.
1 Kings 7:39 He placed the ten stands, five on the right side of the Temple and five on the left. The great bronze basin, the Sea, he placed on the right side of the Temple, towards the southeast.
1 Kings 7:40 Furthermore, Hiram made the pots, shovels, and bowls. He completed all the work for King Solomon in the House of the Lord.
1 Kings 7:1 But Solomon built his own royal palace, a large complex, over the course of thirteen years, and he finally finished all the construction of it.
1 Kings 7:2 He also built a palace structure known as 'the House of the Forest of Lebanon'—a massive building one hundred cubits long, fifty cubits wide, and thirty cubits high. It was supported by four rows of wooden columns, for all the timber was cedar.
1 Kings 7:3 A cedar roof was built above this structure, extending over the porticos, supported by thirty-five columns. Each of these columns was perfectly aligned in its proper order.
1 Kings 7:4 There was also a specific portico with thirty columns, and upon these columns rested heavy cedar beams.
1 Kings 7:5 All the doors and windows, and every single doorpost, were perfectly square in their design, and each was spaced evenly and symmetrically.
1 Kings 7:6 He then constructed a portico of columns fifty cubits long and thirty cubits wide. Directly in front of it, he built another portico, also with timber and columns, and a vestibule leading to it.
1 Kings 7:7 He also built the 'Portico of the Throne,' where he would sit to pronounce judgments, naming it the 'Portico of Judgment.' This entire space was paneled throughout with cedar wood, from the floor all the way up to the roof rafters.
1 Kings 7:8 His personal residence, where he lived, was of a different architectural style, located beyond this portico, similar in construction to the House of the Forest of Lebanon. He also built a similar palace, with the same craftsmanship, for Pharaoh's daughter, whom he had married.
1 Kings 7:9 All these structures were built with expensive, sawed stone blocks, both inside and out, from the foundations all the way up to the roof; this extended outward to the great courtyard.
1 Kings 7:10 The very foundations were made of precious, large stone blocks—some ten cubits long, and others eight cubits long.
1 Kings 7:11 Above these foundation stones were more precious stones, precisely cut to measure, interspersed with cedar wood.
1 Kings 7:12 The great courtyard surrounding these buildings had three courses of hewn stones, topped by one course of cedar beams. The inner courtyard of the Lord's Temple and the temple porch also followed this same construction pattern.
1 Kings 7:13 So King Solomon sent for Hiram from Tyre.
1 Kings 7:14 Hiram was the son of a widow from the tribe of Naphtali, but his father was a Tyrian, a skilled bronze worker. Hiram was filled with wisdom, understanding, and knowledge for all kinds of bronze work. When he arrived before King Solomon, he undertook and completed all the work assigned to him.
1 Kings 7:15 He cast two columns out of bronze, each one eighteen cubits high. A circumference of twelve cubits encircled each of them.
1 Kings 7:16 He also cast two capitals out of bronze, to be placed on top of the columns; each capital was five cubits high.
1 Kings 7:17 Each capital for the columns was intricately adorned with bronze lattice-work, and chain-work wonderfully connected, and sculpted lily designs.
1 Kings 7:18 He crafted two rows of pomegranates encircling each lattice-work, designed to cover the capitals that were on the top of the columns. He did the same for the second capital.
1 Kings 7:19 The capitals that were placed on the tops of the columns were shaped like lilies, a work of art, measuring four cubits high in the portico area.
1 Kings 7:20 There were additional capitals above each column, around the lattice-work, with two hundred pomegranates arranged in two rows all around. He made the second capital in the very same manner.
1 Kings 7:21 Then he erected the columns in the portico of the Temple. When he had set up the right-hand column, he named it Jachin. Likewise, when he set up the left-hand column, he named it Boaz.
1 Kings 7:22 The tops of the columns were adorned with capitals shaped like lilies. With this, the work of the columns was completed.
1 Kings 7:23 He also cast a large bronze basin, which was called 'the Sea.' It measured ten cubits from rim to rim, perfectly round in its circumference, and five cubits in height. A measuring cord of thirty cubits could encompass its entire circumference.
1 Kings 7:24 Below its rim, all around the circumference, there were decorations resembling gourds, and other various sculptures, carved in bronze. There were two rows of these cast decorations, extending ten cubits around the entire basin.
1 Kings 7:25 This great basin stood upon twelve bronze oxen. Three of these oxen faced north, three faced west, three faced south, and three faced east. The basin itself rested on top of them, and their hindquarters were turned inward, hidden beneath the basin.
1 Kings 7:26 The thickness of the basin's bronze wall was three fingers wide. Its rim was shaped like the rim of a cup or a blossoming lily petal. It was capable of holding two thousand baths of water.
1 Kings 7:27 He then constructed ten bronze stands for the washing basins, each four cubits long, four cubits wide, and three cubits high.
1 Kings 7:28 The structure of these stands was intricately paneled with engraved designs, and between the joints were panels depicting various figures.
1 Kings 7:29 On the panels, between the upper and lower borders, were sculpted lions, oxen, and cherubim. Above and below these joints, near the base, and beneath the lions and oxen, were more cast bronze figures, hanging like decorative armor plates.
1 Kings 7:30 Each stand had four bronze wheels with bronze axles. There were also extensions like arms cast beneath the four corners of each stand, designed to support the washing basin. These extensions were cast as a single piece with the stands, facing each other in pairs.
1 Kings 7:31 The opening for the washing basin, on the top, extended one cubit inward. Around this opening, another cubit was decorated with carvings and figures. All these parts were square, not round, around their circumference.
1 Kings 7:32 Furthermore, there were four wheels at the lower part of the stands, and their axles were part of the stands themselves. The height of each wheel was one and a half cubits.
1 Kings 7:33 The wheel assembly was like that of a chariot, and all parts, individually, were made of cast bronze.
1 Kings 7:34 And at each of the four corners of every stand, there were four shoulder-like projections, cast as part of the base itself.
1 Kings 7:35 At the very top of each stand, there was a round platform, six cubits in circumference, with interwoven designs and sculptures, all cast as part of the stand.
1 Kings 7:36 On the panels of the stands and on their joints, he carved cherubim, lions, and palm trees, depicting them in high relief. Around the edges, he added decorative borders.
1 Kings 7:37 In this manner, he made all ten stands; they were all of the same casting, the same measurements, and the same sculpted designs.
1 Kings 7:38 He also made ten bronze washing basins, each holding forty baths of water. Each basin was four cubits high and was designed to sit on one of the ten stands.
1 Kings 7:39 He placed five of the stands on the right side of the Temple and five on the left side. The great bronze basin, 'the Sea,' he placed on the right side of the Temple, facing eastward, towards the south.
1 Kings 7:40 So Hiram made the pots, the shovels, and the basins. He thus completed all the work for King Solomon concerning the house of the Lord.
1 Kings 8:1 Then Solomon gathered all the chief men of Israel, and all the leaders of the tribes, and the heads of the family lines of the sons of Israel to King Solomon in Jerusalem, to bring the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord from the City of David—also known as Zion.
1 Kings 8:2 All the men of Israel gathered together to King Solomon in the month of Ethanim, for the Feast—which is the seventh month.
1 Kings 8:3 All the elders of Israel came, and the priests carried the Ark.
1 Kings 8:4 and the Tent of Meeting—and all the sacred vessels that were kept in the Tent. The priests and Levites carried these items.
1 Kings 8:5 King Solomon and all the multitude of Israel who had gathered to him, in the presence of the Ark, sacrificed sheep and oxen without number or estimation, because there were so many.
1 Kings 8:6 Then the priests brought the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord to its proper place, into the innermost sanctuary of the Temple, into the Holy of Holies, beneath the wings of the cherubim.
1 Kings 8:7 Indeed, the cherubim spread their wings over the place of the Ark, protecting the Ark and its carrying poles from above.
1 Kings 8:8 When the carrying poles were extended, their ends were visible outside the innermost sanctuary, in front of the entrance to the Holy of Holies, but they were not visible from outside the sanctuary itself. They have remained there until the present day.
1 Kings 8:9 There was nothing in the Ark except for the two stone tablets that Moses had placed there at Horeb, when the Lord gave the law to the sons of Israel after they had come out of the land of Egypt.
1 Kings 8:10 Now it happened that when the priests came out of the Sanctuary, a cloud filled the house of the Lord.
1 Kings 8:11 The priests could not stand there and minister because of the cloud, for the glory of the Lord had filled the house of the Lord.
1 Kings 8:12 Then Solomon said: “The Lord said He would dwell in the cloud.
1 Kings 8:13 Building, I have built a house as Your dwelling place—a very firm throne for You forever.”
1 Kings 8:14 The king then turned his face and blessed the entire assembly of Israel, for the whole assembly of Israel was standing.
1 Kings 8:15 And he said: “Blessed be the Lord God of Israel, who spoke with His own mouth to my father David, and has fulfilled with His own hands what He said, saying:
1 Kings 8:16 ‘From the day I brought My people Israel out of Egypt, I did not choose a city from all the tribes of Israel where a house might be built for My name to be there. But I chose David to be over My people Israel.’
1 Kings 8:17 My father David desired to build a house for the name of the Lord God of Israel.
1 Kings 8:18 But the Lord said to my father David: ‘Because you desired in your heart to build a house for My name, you did well in having this very thought in your mind.
1 Kings 8:19 Nevertheless, you shall not build the house, but your son who will come forth from your body—he shall build the house for My name.’
1 Kings 8:20 The Lord has fulfilled His word which He spoke. For I have risen in place of my father David and sit on the throne of Israel, just as the Lord promised. And I have built a house for the name of the Lord God of Israel.
1 Kings 8:21 And I have prepared a place there for the Ark, which contains the Covenant of the Lord that He made with our fathers when they came out of the land of Egypt.”
1 Kings 8:22 So Solomon stood before the altar of the Lord, in the presence of the entire assembly of Israel, and he spread out his hands toward the created universe.
1 Kings 8:23 And he said: “O Lord, God of Israel, there is no God like You, in the created universe above or on the earth below. You keep Your covenant and show mercy to Your servants who walk before You with their whole heart.
1 Kings 8:24 You have kept what You promised to Your servant, my father David. You spoke with Your mouth, and You have fulfilled with Your hands, as this present day proves.
1 Kings 8:25 Now therefore, O Lord, God of Israel, keep for Your servant my father David what You promised him, saying: ‘There shall not fail you a man from My sight to sit upon the throne of Israel, provided that your sons keep their way, to walk before Me as you have walked.’
1 Kings 8:26 And now, O God of Israel, may Your words which You spoke to Your servant, my father David, be confirmed.
1 Kings 8:27 Can it be truly believed that God would actually dwell on earth? If the created universe and even the highest created heavens cannot contain You, how much less can this temple I have built?
1 Kings 8:28 Yet, look upon the prayer of Your servant and his supplications, O Lord my God. Hear the hymn and the prayer that Your servant prays before You today.
1 Kings 8:29 May Your eyes be open toward this house night and day—this house of which You said, ‘My Name shall be there’—so that You may hear the prayer which Your servant prays to You in this place.
1 Kings 8:30 Hear the supplication of Your servant and of Your people Israel, whoever prays in this place. Hear in the created universe, in Your dwelling place. And when You hear, be merciful.
1 Kings 8:31 If a man sins against his neighbor, and he is bound by an oath to testify, and he comes to Your altar in this house to swear the oath,
1 Kings 8:32 then hear from the created universe, and act, and judge Your servants. Condemn the wicked, repaying his actions upon his own head, and justify the righteous, returning to him according to his righteousness.
1 Kings 8:33 If Your people Israel are defeated by their enemies because they have sinned against You, yet they return to You in repentance, confess Your name, and come and pray and make supplication to You in this house,
1 Kings 8:34 then hear from the created universe, and forgive the sin of Your people Israel, and bring them back to the land which You gave to their fathers.
1 Kings 8:35 If the created universe is shut up and there is no rain because of their sins, yet they pray in repentance in this place, and confess Your name, and turn from their sins because You have afflicted them,
1 Kings 8:36 then hear in the created universe, and forgive the sins of Your servants and of Your people Israel, and show them the good way in which they should walk. Then send rain upon Your land, which You have given to Your people as an inheritance.
1 Kings 8:37 If there is famine in the land, or plague, or blight, or mildew, or locusts, or caterpillars; if their enemy besieges them in the land of their cities, or any other affliction, any sickness,
1 Kings 8:38 then any supplication or prayer that is made by any person among Your people Israel, each recognizing the affliction of his own heart, and spreading out his hands toward this house,
1 Kings 8:39 then hear in the created universe, from Your most firm throne, and be merciful. Act to render to each person according to all his ways, as You know his heart—for You alone know the heart of all the sons of men.
1 Kings 8:40 May they fear You all the days they live upon the face of the earth, which You gave to our fathers.
1 Kings 8:1 Then King Solomon gathered all the elders of Israel. He also gathered all the tribal leaders and the heads of the families of the sons of Israel. They all came to King Solomon in Jerusalem. This assembly was to bring the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord from the City of David, which is Zion.
1 Kings 8:2 And all the men of Israel gathered to King Solomon in the month of Ethanim, which is the seventh month of the year.
1 Kings 8:3 All the elders of Israel came, and the priests carried the Ark.
1 Kings 8:4 And they brought up the Ark of the Lord, and the Tent of Meeting (also known as the Tabernacle of Testimony), and all the vessels of the Sanctuary that were in the Tabernacle. The priests and the Levites carried them.
1 Kings 8:5 King Solomon, and all the multitude of Israel who had gathered to him, sacrificed sheep and oxen before the Ark. There were so many sacrificial animals that they could not be numbered, so vast was the multitude of these offerings.
1 Kings 8:6 And the priests brought the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord to its proper place. This was into the inner sanctuary of the house, the Holy of Holies, beneath the wings of the cherubim.
1 Kings 8:7 Indeed, the cherubim spread out their wings over the place of the Ark. They covered the Ark and its carrying poles from above.
1 Kings 8:8 The poles were so long that their ends could be seen from the Holy Place in front of the inner sanctuary, but they were not visible from outside. They remained there even until the present day.
1 Kings 8:9 There was nothing in the Ark except the two stone tablets that Moses had placed there at Horeb. This was when the Lord made a covenant with the sons of Israel after they had come out of the land of Egypt.
1 Kings 8:10 Now it happened, when the priests came out of the Sanctuary, a cloud filled the house of the Lord.
1 Kings 8:11 And the priests could not stand to minister because of the cloud. This was because the glory of the Lord, the visible manifestation of God's presence and power, had filled the house of the Lord.
1 Kings 8:12 Then Solomon said, 'The Lord said that He would dwell in a cloud.'
1 Kings 8:13 I have indeed built a house as a dwelling place for You, a most firm and eternal place for Your glorious presence.
1 Kings 8:14 And the king turned his face, and blessed all the assembly of Israel. For all the assembly of Israel was standing.
1 Kings 8:15 And he said, 'Blessed be the Lord, the God of Israel. He spoke with His own mouth to David my father, and by His works, He has brought it to pass, saying:'
1 Kings 8:16 'From the day that I brought My people Israel out of Egypt, I did not choose a city from all the tribes of Israel for a house to be built in My name there. But I chose David to be over My people Israel.'
1 Kings 8:17 'And it was the intention of David my father to build a house for the name of the Lord, the God of Israel.'
1 Kings 8:18 'The Lord said to David my father: Because it was in your heart to build a house for My name, you did well in conceiving this very thing in your mind.'
1 Kings 8:19 'Nevertheless, you shall not build the house. But your son, who will come out from your loins, he shall build the house for My name.'
1 Kings 8:20 'The Lord has established His word which He spoke. For I have risen up in place of David my father, and I sit on the throne of Israel, just as the Lord promised. And I have built the house for the name of the Lord, the God of Israel.'
1 Kings 8:21 'And there I have established a place for the Ark, in which is the Covenant of the Lord. This is the Covenant He made with our fathers when they came out of the land of Egypt.'
1 Kings 8:22 Therefore, Solomon stood before the altar of the Lord, in the presence of all the assembly of Israel, and he spread out his hands towards heaven, the dwelling place of God.
1 Kings 8:23 And he said, 'O Lord, God of Israel, there is no God like You, above in heaven or below on earth. You keep covenant and show mercy to Your servants who walk before You with all their heart.'
1 Kings 8:24 'You have kept what You promised to Your servant David my father. And You have fulfilled Your words, as is proven this very day.'
1 Kings 8:25 'Now therefore, O Lord, God of Israel, keep for Your servant David my father what You spoke, saying: There shall not fail you a man in My sight to sit on the throne of Israel. Nevertheless, this is true if your sons will keep their way, and walk before Me as you have walked.'
1 Kings 8:26 'And now, O Lord, God of Israel, let Your words be confirmed, these words You spoke to David my father, Your servant.'
1 Kings 8:27 'But will God indeed dwell on the earth? For if the universe, and even the heaven of heavens, cannot contain You, how much less this house which I have built?'
1 Kings 8:28 'Yet, look upon the prayer of Your servant and his supplication, O Lord my God. Hear the hymn and the prayer which Your servant prays before You today.'
1 Kings 8:29 'That Your eyes may be open toward this house night and day. Toward the house of which You said, My Name shall be there, meaning My presence and authority will reside there.'
1 Kings 8:30 'That You may hear the prayer of Your servant and of Your people Israel, whenever anyone prays in this place. And You shall hear them in the place of Your dwelling, in heaven. And when You hear, You will be merciful.'
1 Kings 8:31 'If a man sins against his neighbor, and an oath is laid upon him because of it, and he comes to swear before Your altar in this house:'
1 Kings 8:32 'Then You, in heaven, will hear and act and judge Your servants. You will condemn the wicked and bring his way upon his own head, and You will justify the righteous, rendering to him according to his righteousness.'
1 Kings 8:33 'If Your people Israel are defeated by their enemies (because they have sinned against You), and they turn back, perform penance, supplicate You in this house, and confess Your name, acknowledging Your power and authority:'
1 Kings 8:34 'Then You will hear in heaven, and will be merciful to the sins of Your people Israel, and You will bring them back to the land which You gave to their fathers.'
1 Kings 8:35 'If the sky is shut up and there is no rain because of their sins, and they pray in this place, and perform penance to Your name, and they turn from their sins because of their afflictions:'
1 Kings 8:36 'Then hear You in heaven, and be merciful to the sins of Your servants and of Your people Israel. And teach them the good way in which they should walk. And give rain upon Your land, which You have given to Your people as an inheritance.'
1 Kings 8:37 'If there is famine in the land, or pestilence, or mildew, or blight, or locusts, or caterpillars, and if their enemy besieges them in the gates of their cities, whatever plague, whatever wound they suffer:'
1 Kings 8:38 'Whatever prayer, whatever supplication is made by any man, or by all Your people Israel, each one knowing the affliction of his own heart, and spreading out his hands toward this house:'
1 Kings 8:39 'Then You will hear in heaven, in the place of Your dwelling, and will be merciful, and will act. And You will render to each one according to all his ways, as You see his heart. For You alone know the heart of all the sons of men.'
1 Kings 8:40 'So that they may fear You all the days that they live upon the surface of the earth, which You gave to our fathers.'
1 Kings 8:1 Then King Solomon gathered together all the elders of Israel, and all the chiefs of the tribes, and all the heads of the households of the sons of Israel, to King Solomon in Jerusalem, so that they might bring the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord from the City of David, which is Zion, the fortress part of Jerusalem.
1 Kings 8:2 And all of Israel gathered to King Solomon in the month of Ethanim, on the seventh festival period. This is the seventh month of the Hebrew calendar.
1 Kings 8:3 And all the elders of Israel came, and the priests carried the Ark.
1 Kings 8:4 And the priests and the Levites brought the Ark of the Lord, and the tent of the Covenant, and all the sacred vessels that were in the tent.
1 Kings 8:5 King Solomon and all the multitude of Israel who had gathered to him, in the presence of the Ark, sacrificed so many sheep and oxen that they could not be counted.
1 Kings 8:6 And the priests brought the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord to its place, into the inner sanctuary of the house, into the Holy of Holies, beneath the wings of the cherubim.
1 Kings 8:7 For the cherubim spread out their wings over the place of the Ark, and protected the Ark and its carrying poles from above.
1 Kings 8:8 And the Ark remained there until this present day.
1 Kings 8:9 There was nothing else in the Ark except the two stone tablets which Moses had placed there in Horeb, when the Lord gave the law to the sons of Israel, when they came out of the land of Egypt.
1 Kings 8:10 And it came to pass that when the priests came out of the sanctuary, a cloud filled the house of the Lord.
1 Kings 8:11 And the priests were not able to stand and minister because of the cloud, for the glory of the Lord had filled the house of the Lord.
1 Kings 8:12 Then Solomon said: 'The Lord said that He would dwell in deep darkness, which He manifests in a cloud.'
1 Kings 8:13 Building, I have built a house as a dwelling place for You, and Your firm throne for all eternity.
1 Kings 8:14 And the king turned his face and blessed all the assembly of Israel, for all the assembly of Israel was standing.
1 Kings 8:15 And he said: 'Blessed be the Lord God of Israel, who spoke with His own mouth to David my father, and with His own hands, He has fulfilled what He promised, saying: '
1 Kings 8:16 'From the day when I led My people Israel out of Egypt, I did not choose a city out of all the tribes of Israel, so that a house might be built there for My Name; but I chose David to be over My people Israel.'
1 Kings 8:17 'And David my father desired to build a house for the Name of the Lord God of Israel;'
1 Kings 8:18 'But the Lord said to David my father: "Because you desired to build a house for My Name, you have done well in this very thing;"'
1 Kings 8:19 'Nevertheless, you will not build the house, but your son, who will come forth from your body, he himself will build the house for My Name."'
1 Kings 8:20 The Lord has fulfilled His word which He spoke, for I have risen in place of David my father, and I sit upon the throne of Israel, just as the Lord spoke. And I have built the house for the Name of the Lord God of Israel.
1 Kings 8:21 And I have prepared a place there for the Ark, in which is the covenant of the Lord which He made with our fathers, when they came out of the land of Egypt.
1 Kings 8:22 Therefore, Solomon stood before the altar of the Lord in the presence of all the assembly of Israel, and he spread out his hands towards the sky.
1 Kings 8:23 And he said: 'Lord God of Israel, there is no God like You, neither in the sky above, nor on the earth below. You keep covenant and show mercy to Your servants who walk before You with their whole heart.'
1 Kings 8:24 'You who have kept for Your servant David my father what You spoke to him; You spoke with Your mouth, and with Your own hands You have fulfilled it, just as it is this very day.'
1 Kings 8:25 'Now therefore, Lord God of Israel, keep for Your servant David my father what You spoke to him, saying: "There shall not fail you a man from the throne of Israel." Only if your sons will guard their way and walk before Me as you yourself have walked.'
1 Kings 8:26 'And now, Lord God of Israel, let Your word be confirmed, which You spoke to Your servant David my father.'
1 Kings 8:27 'But truly, if God can dwell on the earth— the sky and the highest heavens cannot contain You, much less this house which I have built!'
1 Kings 8:28 'Yet, look upon the prayer of Your servant and upon his supplications, O Lord my God! Hear the cry and the prayer with which Your servant prays before You today;'
1 Kings 8:29 'So that Your eyes may be open toward this house, night and day— toward the house of which You said: "My Name shall be there"— so that You may hear the supplication which Your servant prays to You in this place.'
1 Kings 8:30 'So that You may hear the supplication of Your servant and of Your people Israel, whatever they pray in this place. And You will hear in the place of Your dwelling in the universe— the uncreated realm beyond the created sky— and when You have heard, You will be merciful.'
1 Kings 8:31 'If a man has sinned against his neighbor, and he has taken an oath to swear, and one comes before Your altar in this house and confesses to You;'
1 Kings 8:32 'You will hear in the universe beyond created things, and You will act and judge Your servants, condemning the wicked, and returning his way upon his own head, and justifying the righteous, and repaying him according to his righteousness.'
1 Kings 8:33 'If Your people Israel flee before their enemies (because they will have sinned against You), and they turn and do penance, and they pray to You in this house, confessing Your Name;'
1 Kings 8:34 'You will hear in the uncreated universe, and You will be merciful to the sins of Your people Israel, and You will bring them back to the land which You gave to their fathers.'
1 Kings 8:35 'If the sky is shut up and there is no rain because of their sins, and they pray in this place and do penance to Your Name, and they turn from their sins because of their affliction;'
1 Kings 8:36 'You will hear in the uncreated universe, and You will be merciful to the sins of Your servants and of Your people Israel, and You will show them the good way in which they should walk, and You will give rain upon Your land, which You gave to Your people as a possession.'
1 Kings 8:37 'If there is famine in the land, or plague, or blight, or mildew, or locusts, or rust, and if an enemy besieges them in their cities' gates— any plague, any sickness;'
1 Kings 8:38 'Whatever supplication, whatever prayer is made by any man, or by all of Your people Israel, when each one acknowledges the wound of his own heart, and spreads out his hands in this house;'
1 Kings 8:39 'You will hear in the uncreated universe, from Your firm throne, and You will be merciful and You will act. And You will repay each one according to all his ways, just as You alone see his heart, You who know the hearts of all the sons of men;'
1 Kings 8:40 'So that they may fear You all the days that they live upon the face of the earth which You gave to our fathers.'
1 Kings 9:1 It came to pass after Solomon had finished building the Lord's Temple and his own royal palace. He had completed everything he desired and had wanted to do.
1 Kings 9:2 The Lord appeared to Solomon a second time, just as He had appeared to him in Gibeon before.
1 Kings 9:3 And the Lord said to him: "I have heard your prayer and your petition, which you presented before Me. I have consecrated this Temple that you have built so that I may establish My presence there for all time. My divine attention and My love will be there always.
1 Kings 9:4 As for you, if you will walk before Me with sincerity of heart and in uprightness, just as your father David walked, and if you will do everything that I have commanded you, and keep My statutes and My judgments,
1 Kings 9:5 then I will establish the throne of your kingdom over Israel forever, just as I promised your father David when I said: 'A man from your lineage shall not be cut off from the throne of Israel.'
1 Kings 9:6 But if you and your sons turn away from Me, not keeping My commandments and My ceremonies which I have set before you, but instead go and serve foreign gods and worship them,
1 Kings 9:7 then I will cast Israel from the face of the land which I have given them. And this Temple, which I have consecrated for My name, I will cast out of My sight. Then Israel will become a proverb and a byword among all peoples.
1 Kings 9:8 And this house will become an example of desolation. Everyone who passes by it will be astonished and will hiss in dismay, saying: 'Why has the Lord done such things to this land and to this Temple?'
1 Kings 9:9 And they will respond: 'Because they abandoned the Lord their God, who led their fathers out of the land of Egypt. And they followed foreign gods, and worshipped them, and served them. Therefore, the Lord has brought all this evil upon them.'
1 Kings 9:10 Now it came to pass after twenty years, during which Solomon had built the two houses: that is, the Lord's Temple and the royal palace.
1 Kings 9:11 So King Hiram of Tyre had supplied Solomon with cedar wood, fir wood, and gold, according to all his desire.
1 Kings 9:12 In return, Solomon then gave Hiram twenty cities in the land of Galilee.
1 Kings 9:13 When Hiram went out from Tyre to see the cities which Solomon had given him, they did not please him at all.
1 Kings 9:14 And he said: "What kind of cities are these which you have given me, my brother?" And he called them the land of Cabul—meaning 'worthless land'—a name it kept until this very day.
1 Kings 9:15 This is the summary of the tribute which King Solomon imposed for building the Lord's Temple, and his own royal palace, and Millo, and the wall of Jerusalem, and Hazor, and Megiddo, and Gezer.
1 Kings 9:16 Pharaoh, king of Egypt, had gone up and taken Gezer, and burned it with fire. He killed the Canaanites who lived in the city. Then he gave it as a dowry to his daughter, who became Solomon's wife.
1 Kings 9:17 So Solomon rebuilt Gezer and Lower Beth Horon.
1 Kings 9:18 He also rebuilt Baalath and Tamar, which was in the desert wilderness.
1 Kings 9:19 And he built all the store-cities that belonged to Solomon, along with the cities for his chariots and the cities for his horsemen. He also built everything else that pleased him to build in Jerusalem, and in Lebanon, and in all the land under his dominion.
1 Kings 9:20 All the people who were left of the Amorites, and Hittites, and Perizzites, and Hivites, and Jebusites—these were the peoples who were not of the children of Israel.
1 Kings 9:21 Their children, who were left in the land and whom the children of Israel had not been able to utterly destroy, Solomon forced their descendants to be his bondservants and laborers, a practice that continued until this day.
1 Kings 9:22 However, Solomon did not make any of the children of Israel to be bondservants. Instead, they served as warriors, his personal attendants, his princes, his captains, and the commanders of his chariots and horsemen.
1 Kings 9:23 These were the chief officers over Solomon's work: five hundred and fifty men who presided over the people and those who performed the labor.
1 Kings 9:24 But Pharaoh's daughter went up from the City of David to her house which Solomon had built for her. It was then that he built Millo.
1 Kings 9:25 Solomon also offered burnt offerings and peace offerings three times each year upon the altar which he had built for the Lord. And he also burned incense upon the incense altar which he had dedicated to the Lord. Thus, the construction of the Temple was completed.
1 Kings 9:26 King Solomon also built a fleet of ships in Ezion-geber, which is near Elath, on the shore of the Red Sea, in the land of Edom.
1 Kings 9:27 And King Hiram of Tyre sent his ships with the fleet, and his servants who were experienced sailors and mariners who knew the sea, along with Solomon's servants.
1 Kings 9:28 When they had come to Ophir, they obtained from there four hundred and twenty talents of gold, and brought it back to King Solomon.
1 Kings 9:29 Now the Queen of Sheba, having heard of the fame of Solomon and his relationship with the Lord, came to test him with difficult riddles.
1 Kings 9:30 And she entered Jerusalem with a great company and with camels bearing spices, and a very large amount of gold, and precious stones. She came to Solomon and spoke to him all that was in her heart.
1 Kings 9:31 And Solomon answered all the questions she proposed. There was no word hidden from the king that he could not answer for her.
1 Kings 9:32 But when the Queen of Sheba saw all the wisdom of Solomon, and the house which he had built,
1 Kings 9:33 and the food on his table, and the dwellings of his servants, and the attendance of his ministers and their apparel, and his cupbearers, and the burnt offerings which he offered in the house of the Lord, she was utterly overwhelmed and breathless.
1 Kings 9:34 And she said to the king: "The report which I heard in my own land about your deeds and about your wisdom is true.
1 Kings 9:35 And I did not believe those who told me until I myself came and saw with my own eyes. Now I have proved that not even half had been told to me. Your wisdom and your works are far greater than the report I heard."
1 Kings 9:36 "Blessed are your men, and blessed are these servants of yours, who stand before you always and hear your wisdom.
1 Kings 9:37 Blessed be the Lord your God, with whom you were pleased, and who set you upon the throne of Israel. This is because the Lord loved Israel and desired that there be a king, and that you should render judgment and justice."
1 Kings 9:38 So she gave the king one hundred and twenty talents of gold, and a very large amount of spices, and precious stones. Never again were so many spices brought as those which the Queen of Sheba gave to King Solomon.
1 Kings 9:39 Moreover, Hiram's fleet of ships, which brought gold from Ophir, also brought from Ophir an enormous amount of almug wood—also known as algum or thyine wood—along with many precious stones.
1 Kings 9:40 And from the almug wood, the king made supports for the house of the Lord and for the royal house, and lyres and harps for the singers. No such almug wood has been brought or seen until this present day.
1 Kings 9:1 Now it came to pass when Solomon had completed the construction of the Lord's Temple and the king's palace, and everything else he had desired and wished for,
1 Kings 9:2 the Lord appeared to him a second time, just as He had appeared to him previously in Gabaon.
1 Kings 9:3 And the Lord said to him: "I have heard your prayer and your petition, which you prayed before Me. I have sanctified this Temple which you have built, so that My Name may be placed there forever. My eyes and My heart will be there for all time."
1 Kings 9:4 "You, too, if you walk before Me, just as your father David walked with integrity of heart and in righteousness, and if you do everything I have commanded you, and keep My statutes and My ordinances,
1 Kings 9:5 I will establish the throne of your kingdom over Israel forever, just as I promised your father David, saying: 'There shall not fail a man of your line to sit on the throne of Israel.'"
1 Kings 9:6 "But if you, or your children, turn away from Me, and do not keep My commandments and My ceremonies, which I have set before you, but instead go and serve foreign gods and worship them,
1 Kings 9:7 then I will cut off Israel from the face of the earth which I have given to them. And this Temple, which I have sanctified for My Name, I will cast away from My presence. Israel will then become a proverb and a byword among all peoples.
1 Kings 9:8 This Temple, even in its ruin, will serve as a warning. Everyone who passes by it will be astonished and will hiss in dismay, saying: 'Why has the Lord done this to this land and to this Temple?'
1 Kings 9:9 And they will answer: 'Because they abandoned the Lord their God, who led their fathers out of the land of Egypt, and they followed foreign gods, and worshipped them, and served them. Therefore, the Lord has brought all this evil upon them.'"
1 Kings 9:10 Now, at the end of twenty years, after Solomon had built the two structures — that is, the Lord's Temple and the king's palace —
1 Kings 9:11 (Hiram, king of Tyre, had supplied Solomon with cedar, pine wood, and gold, according to all that he needed.) Then Solomon gave Hiram twenty cities in the land of Galilee.
1 Kings 9:12 But when Hiram came from Tyre to inspect the cities which Solomon had given him, they displeased him.
1 Kings 9:13 So he said: "What kind of cities are these that you have given me, my brother?" And he called that land 'Cabul' — which means 'good for nothing' — even to this present day.
1 Kings 9:14 Moreover, Hiram had sent Solomon one hundred and twenty talents of gold.
1 Kings 9:15 This is an account of the levy King Solomon raised to build the Lord's Temple, his own palace, the Millo, the wall of Jerusalem, Hazor, Megiddo, and Gezer.
1 Kings 9:16 Pharaoh, the king of Egypt, had gone up and captured Gezer, and burned it with fire. He had killed the Canaanites who lived in the city, and then he gave it as a dowry to his daughter, Solomon's wife.
1 Kings 9:17 So Solomon rebuilt Gezer, and Lower Beth Horon,
1 Kings 9:18 and Baalath, and Tamar (Palmyra) in the desert land.
1 Kings 9:19 He also built all the storage cities that were around these cities, as well as the chariot cities, and the cavalry cities. He built everything that Solomon desired to build in Jerusalem, and in Lebanon, and throughout all the land of his kingdom.
1 Kings 9:20 All the people who remained of the Amorites, the Hittites, the Perizzites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites — who were not of the children of Israel —
1 Kings 9:21 their descendants who remained in the land after them, whom the children of Israel could not completely destroy — these Solomon made subject to forced labor, a tribute, even to this present day.
1 Kings 9:22 But Solomon did not make any of the children of Israel his forced laborers. Instead, they were his warriors, his servants, his officials, his commanders, and the officers over his chariots and his cavalry.
1 Kings 9:23 These were the chief officers overseeing Solomon's work, five hundred and fifty in number, who ruled over the people and over those who performed the work.
1 Kings 9:24 But Pharaoh's daughter went up from the City of David to her own palace, which Solomon had built for her. It was after this that Solomon built the Millo.
1 Kings 9:25 Also, three times each year, Solomon offered burnt offerings and peace offerings upon the altar that he had built for the Lord. He burned incense there before the Lord. And so, the Temple was completed with its regular sacrifices.
1 Kings 9:26 King Solomon also built a fleet of ships in Ezion-geber, which is near Elath, on the shore of the Red Sea, in the land of Edom.
1 Kings 9:27 And Hiram sent his own experienced sailors, men skilled in the sea, to be on the fleet with Solomon's servants.
1 Kings 9:28 When they arrived in Ophir, they brought back gold from there, four hundred and twenty talents of gold, and presented it to King Solomon.
1 Kings 9:29 At that time, the Queen of Sheba heard of Solomon's fame, specifically regarding his wisdom from the Lord, and she came to test him with difficult questions and riddles.
1 Kings 9:30 She arrived in Jerusalem with a very large entourage, with riches, and with camels carrying spices, an immense amount of gold, and precious gems. When she came to King Solomon, she spoke with him about everything that was on her mind and in her heart.
1 Kings 9:31 And Solomon answered all the questions she put to him. There was no matter hidden from the king that he could not explain to her.
1 Kings 9:32 When the Queen of Sheba saw all of Solomon's wisdom, and the palace that he had built,
1 Kings 9:33 and the food on his table, and the residences of his servants, and the organization of his attendants, and their uniforms, and his cupbearers, and the burnt offerings which he offered in the Lord's Temple, she was completely overwhelmed; she was left breathless.
1 Kings 9:34 And she said to the king: "The report that I heard in my own land concerning your words and your wisdom is truly accurate.
1 Kings 9:35 I did not believe those who told me, until I myself came and saw with my own eyes. And I have confirmed that even half of it had not been reported to me. Your wisdom and your achievements are greater than the rumor I heard.
1 Kings 9:36 Blessed are your men, and blessed are your servants, who always stand before you and hear your wisdom.
1 Kings 9:37 Blessed be the Lord your God, in whom you found favor, who has placed you upon the throne of Israel. This is because the Lord loved Israel and desired to save them forever. And for that reason, He has made you king over them, so that you may execute justice and righteousness.
1 Kings 9:38 Then she gave the king one hundred and twenty talents of gold, and an extremely large quantity of spices, and precious gems. Never again was such a vast quantity of spices brought in as the Queen of Sheba gave to King Solomon.
1 Kings 9:39 King Solomon, for his part, gave the Queen of Sheba everything she desired and asked of him, in addition to what he had already given her freely.
1 Kings 9:40 Then she returned and went back to her own land, along with her servants.
1 Kings 10:1 The Queen of Sheba, having heard of Solomon's great fame and the wisdom he displayed in all his works for the Lord, came to Jerusalem to test him with intricate riddles.
1 Kings 10:2 She arrived in Jerusalem with a large company of attendants and camels, laden with fragrant spices, a truly immense quantity of gold, and many precious jewels. When she met King Solomon, she spoke to him everything that was in her mind and heart.
1 Kings 10:3 King Solomon then answered all the difficult questions she had proposed to him; there was no word or concept hidden from the King that he could not explain.
1 Kings 10:4 So the Queen of Sheba saw for herself all of Solomon's wisdom, and she beheld the splendid royal palace he had built,
