1 Kings 10:5 and the lavish food upon his table, and the well-ordered arrangement of his servants' dwellings, and the orderly service of his ministers, and their fine apparel, and his cupbearers, and the burnt offerings which he regularly presented in the house of the Lord. She was utterly overwhelmed and left breathless by it all.
1 Kings 10:6 She then said to the King: “The report I heard in my own land concerning your great sayings and your profound wisdom is true.
1 Kings 10:7 I did not believe those who told me, until I myself came here and saw it with my own eyes. I can now confirm that not even half was told to me. Your wisdom and your accomplishments are far greater than the grand report I heard.”
1 Kings 10:8 “Blessed are your own men, and truly blessed are these servants of yours, who constantly stand before you and hear your profound wisdom.
1 Kings 10:9 May the Lord your God be blessed, in whom you have found favor and who has placed you upon the throne of Israel. This is because the Lord has loved Israel eternally, and He has established you as king, so that you might execute true judgment and administer perfect justice.”
1 Kings 10:10 Then she presented the King with one hundred twenty talents of gold, an exceedingly great quantity of aromatic spices, and many precious gems. There were never again brought such an abundance of spices as the Queen of Sheba gave to King Solomon.
1 Kings 10:11 Furthermore, Hiram's fleet of ships, which regularly brought gold from Ophir, also brought from Ophir an exceedingly large quantity of very rare almug wood, and many precious gems.
1 Kings 10:12 From this almug wood, the King fashioned supports for the Temple of the Lord and for the royal palace. He also had lyres and harps made for the singers. No such almug wood has ever been brought or seen in Israel until this present day.
1 Kings 10:13 Thus, King Solomon gave the Queen of Sheba everything she desired and requested from him, in addition to the royal gifts which he had generously offered her. After this, she returned and journeyed back to her own land with her servants.
1 Kings 10:14 Now the weight of the gold that was brought to King Solomon each year amounted to six hundred sixty-six talents of pure gold,
1 Kings 10:15 this was besides what was regularly brought to him by the tax-collectors, and by the traders, and by all the merchants, and from all the kings of Arabia, and from all the governors of the lands.
1 Kings 10:16 King Solomon also made two hundred large shields of refined pure gold; six hundred shekels of gold were used for the plating of each individual shield.
1 Kings 10:17 And he made three hundred smaller shields of beaten, refined gold; three minas of gold covered each individual shield. The King placed these shields in the House of the Forest of Lebanon, a royal armory.
1 Kings 10:18 The King also constructed a great royal throne made of ivory, which he overlaid with an exceedingly brilliant, gleaming gold.
1 Kings 10:19 There were six steps leading up to the throne, and the back of the throne was rounded at the top. On either side, two arms supported the seat, and two carved lions stood beside these arms.
1 Kings 10:20 And twelve smaller carved lions stood upon the six steps, six on each side. No such masterful work had ever been made in all the kingdoms of the earth.
1 Kings 10:21 Furthermore, all of King Solomon's drinking vessels were made of solid gold, and all the furnishings of the House of the Forest of Lebanon were of the purest gold. Silver was not considered valuable at all, nor was it esteemed as anything of worth in the days of Solomon.
1 Kings 10:22 For the King's fleet of ships, sailing the sea together with Hiram's fleet, went to Tarshish once every three years. From there, they brought back gold, and silver, and ivory tusks, and apes, and peacocks.
1 Kings 10:23 Thus, King Solomon became greater than all the kings of the earth in both his immense wealth and his profound wisdom.
1 Kings 10:24 And the entire world desired to behold Solomon, so that they might hear the extraordinary wisdom which God had placed in his heart.
1 Kings 10:25 And each person brought him gifts, vessels of silver and of gold, fine garments, and weapons, and aromatic spices, horses, and mules, year after year without fail.
1 Kings 10:26 Solomon also amassed chariots and cavalry; he acquired fourteen hundred chariots and twelve thousand horsemen. He stationed them in garrison cities designated for chariots and also kept some with the King in Jerusalem.
1 Kings 10:27 The King caused silver to be as plentiful in Jerusalem as ordinary stones. And he made cedar wood as abundant as the sycamore trees that grow in the lowlands.
1 Kings 10:28 The horses for Solomon were brought out of Egypt and from Coa. The King's merchants bought them from Coa at a fixed price, and then transported them.
1 Kings 10:29 A four-wheeled chariot was valued at six hundred shekels of silver, and a horse at one hundred fifty shekels. By this same arrangement, horses and chariots were sold to all the kings of the Hittites and the kings of Syria through Solomon's intermediaries.
1 Kings 11:1 King Solomon, however, began to fall deeply in love with many foreign women—women who did not worship the true God. These included the daughter of Pharaoh, and women from Moab, Ammon, Edom, Sidon, and the Hittite lands.
1 Kings 11:2 These were women from the nations about whom the Lord had strictly commanded the children of Israel: 'You must not go among them, and they must not come among you, for they will most certainly turn your hearts away to follow their false gods.' Despite this divine warning, Solomon became joined to these women because of his intense love for them.
1 Kings 11:3 Solomon had seven hundred royal wives and three hundred concubines, for a total of one thousand women. These women then turned his heart away from his true devotion to God.
1 Kings 11:4 Indeed, when he was already an old man, his heart was corrupted by these women, so that he began to follow their foreign gods. His devotion to the Lord his God was not complete, as was the devotion of David his father.
1 Kings 11:5 Instead, Solomon worshipped Ashtart, the false goddess of the Sidonians, and Moloch, the detestable idol of the Ammonites.
1 Kings 11:6 Solomon thus did what was evil in the sight of the Lord, and he did not fully commit to following the Lord, as David his father had done.
1 Kings 11:7 It was then that Solomon built a high place, a temple, for Chemosh, the detestable idol of the Moabites, on the hill that faces Jerusalem. He also built one for Moloch, the detestable idol of the children of Ammon.
1 Kings 11:8 He built these places of idolatry for all his foreign wives, who burned incense and offered sacrifices to their false gods.
1 Kings 11:9 Therefore, the Lord's wrath was kindled against Solomon, because his devotion had turned away from the Lord, the God of Israel. This was the same God who had appeared to him twice before—
1 Kings 11:10 —and had specifically commanded him regarding this very thing: not to follow foreign gods. But Solomon did not keep what the Lord had commanded him.
1 Kings 11:11 So the Lord said to Solomon: 'Because you have done this, and have not kept My covenant and My commandments which I entrusted to you, I will surely tear your kingdom apart and give it to one of your servants.'
1 Kings 11:12 'However, I will not do this during your lifetime, out of respect for David your father. Instead, I will tear it out of the hand of your son.'
1 Kings 11:13 'Yet, I will not take away the entire kingdom. I will leave one tribe for your son, for the sake of David My servant, and for Jerusalem, the city which I have chosen.'
1 Kings 11:14 So the Lord raised up an adversary against Solomon: Hadad the Edomite, a descendant of the royal lineage of Edom.
1 Kings 11:15 This occurred when David was in Edom, and Joab, the commander of the army, had gone up to bury those slain in battle, and had struck down every male in Edom.
1 Kings 11:16 Joab had remained in Edom for six months until he had completely eliminated every male there.
1 Kings 11:17 Hadad himself, along with some Edomite men who had been servants of his father, fled with him to enter Egypt. At that time, Hadad was still a very young boy.
1 Kings 11:18 When they set out from Midian, they came to Paran, and took men from Paran with them. They then entered Egypt, going to Pharaoh, the king of Egypt. Pharaoh gave Hadad a house, provided him with food, and assigned him land.
1 Kings 11:19 Hadad found such great favor in the eyes of Pharaoh, that Pharaoh even gave him his own sister-in-law, the sister of Queen Tahpenes, as a wife.
1 Kings 11:20 The sister of Queen Tahpenes bore Hadad a son named Genubath. Tahpenes raised Genubath in Pharaoh's own palace, and Genubath grew up there among Pharaoh's own sons.
1 Kings 11:21 When Hadad heard in Egypt that David had died and was resting with his ancestors, and that Joab, the commander of the army, was also dead, Hadad said to Pharaoh: 'Allow me to leave, so that I may return to my own land.'
1 Kings 11:22 Pharaoh asked him, 'What do you lack here with me, that you seek to return to your own land?' Hadad replied, 'Nothing at all, but only let me go.'
1 Kings 11:23 God also raised up another adversary against Solomon: Rezon, the son of Eliada, who had fled from his master, Hadadezer, the king of Zobah.
1 Kings 11:24 Rezon had gathered men around himself and became the leader of a raiding band. This occurred when David was defeating those from Zobah. Rezon and his men went to Damascus, settled there, and began to rule in Damascus.
1 Kings 11:25 Rezon became an adversary to Israel throughout all the days of Solomon's reign. This was in addition to the harm caused by Hadad, and Rezon's intense hatred against Israel. He reigned over Syria.
1 Kings 11:26 Jeroboam also, the son of Nebat, an Ephrathite from Zeredah, who was a servant of Solomon (and whose mother was a widow named Zeruah), raised his hand against the king.
1 Kings 11:27 This was the reason for his rebellion: Solomon had built the Millo fortress and had closed up the breach in the City of David, his father.
1 Kings 11:28 Jeroboam was a strong and capable man. When Solomon saw that the young man was diligently prepared for work, he put him in charge of all the forced labor from the house of Joseph.
1 Kings 11:29 It happened at that time that Jeroboam went out of Jerusalem, and the prophet Ahijah the Shilonite met him on the way. Ahijah was wearing a new cloak. It happened that there were only the two of them in the field.
1 Kings 11:30 Ahijah then took hold of his new cloak that he was wearing and tore it into twelve pieces.
1 Kings 11:31 And he said to Jeroboam: 'Take ten pieces for yourself, for thus says the Lord, the God of Israel: 'Behold, I will tear the kingdom away from the hand of Solomon, and I will give you ten tribes.'
1 Kings 11:32 'However, one tribe will remain for Solomon's son, for the sake of David My servant, and for Jerusalem, the city which I have chosen out of all the tribes of Israel.'
1 Kings 11:33 'I will do this because Solomon has forsaken Me and has worshipped Ashtart, the false goddess of the Sidonians; Chemosh, the false god of the Moabites; and Moloch, the false god of the children of Ammon. He has not walked in My ways, to do what is right in My sight, nor kept My commandments and My judgments, as David his father did.'
1 Kings 11:34 'Nevertheless, I will not take the entire kingdom from his hand. Instead, I will let him remain ruler all the days of his life, for the sake of David My servant, whom I chose, and who kept My commandments and My precepts.'
1 Kings 11:35 'But I will take the kingdom from the hand of his son, and I will give ten tribes to you.'
1 Kings 11:36 'To his son, however, I will give one tribe, so that a lamp for David My servant may remain before Me always in Jerusalem, the city which I have chosen, so that My name may be there.'
1 Kings 11:37 'Therefore I will take you, and you shall reign over all that your soul desires, and you shall be king over Israel.'
1 Kings 11:38 'If, therefore, you listen to all that I command you, and walk in My ways, and do what is right in My sight, keeping My commandments and My precepts, just as My servant David did, then I will be with you. I will build you a lasting dynasty, a faithful house, just as I built for David, and I will give Israel to you.'
1 Kings 11:39 'And I will afflict the descendants of David because of this, but not for all time.'
1 Kings 11:40 Therefore, Solomon sought to kill Jeroboam. But Jeroboam arose and fled to Egypt, to Shishak, the king of Egypt, and he remained in Egypt until Solomon's death.
1 Kings 11:1 King Solomon passionately loved many foreign women. This included Pharaoh’s daughter, along with women from Moab, Ammon, Edom, Sidon, and the Hittite people.
1 Kings 11:2 These were women from nations about whom the Lord had strictly warned the children of Israel: 'You shall not marry them, nor shall they marry you. For they will most certainly turn your hearts away from Me, causing you to follow their false gods.' But King Solomon, in his deep affection, became joined to these women.
1 Kings 11:3 He had seven hundred wives who were princesses, and three hundred concubines. And these women turned his heart away from God.
1 Kings 11:4 When he became old, his heart was corrupted by these women, so that he followed other gods. His heart was not perfectly devoted to the Lord his God, unlike the heart of his father David.
1 Kings 11:5 Instead, Solomon began to worship Astaroth, the goddess of the Sidonians, and Moloch, the idol of the Ammonites.
1 Kings 11:6 Solomon did what was evil in the sight of the Lord. He did not fully obey the Lord, as his father David had done.
1 Kings 11:7 Then Solomon built a high place for Chemosh, the idol of Moab, on the hill facing Jerusalem. He also built a high place for Moloch, the idol of the Ammonite people.
1 Kings 11:8 In this manner, he did the same for all his foreign wives, who burned incense and offered sacrifices to their own gods.
1 Kings 11:9 Therefore, the Lord was angry with Solomon, because his mind had turned away from the Lord, the God of Israel. This was especially grievous because the Lord had appeared to Solomon twice before.
1 Kings 11:10 And the Lord had specifically commanded him not to follow other gods. But Solomon did not keep the commands that the Lord had given him.
1 Kings 11:11 So the Lord said to Solomon: 'Because you have done this, and have not kept My covenant and My commands which I entrusted to you, I will surely tear your kingdom apart and give it to your servant.'
1 Kings 11:12 'However, for the sake of your father David, I will not do this during your lifetime. I will tear it out of the hand of your son.'
1 Kings 11:13 'Nevertheless, I will not take away the entire kingdom. I will leave one tribe for your son, for the sake of My servant David and for the sake of Jerusalem, which I have chosen.'
1 Kings 11:14 So the Lord raised up an adversary against Solomon: Hadad the Edomite, who was of the royal line in Edom.
1 Kings 11:15 For when David was in Edom, and Joab, the commander of the army, had gone up to bury the slain, and had struck down every male in Edom—
1 Kings 11:16 Joab and all Israel remained there for six months, until they had completely wiped out every male in Edom.
1 Kings 11:17 So Hadad himself fled, along with some Edomite men who were servants of his father, in order to enter Egypt. At that time, Hadad was just a small boy.
1 Kings 11:18 When they set out from Midian, they came to Paran. They took men with them from Paran and then entered Egypt, presenting themselves to Pharaoh, the king of Egypt. Pharaoh gave Hadad a house, provided him with provisions, and even assigned him land.
1 Kings 11:19 Hadad found such great favor with Pharaoh that Pharaoh gave him as wife the sister of his own queen, Queen Tahpenes.
1 Kings 11:20 The sister of Tahpenes bore him a son named Genubath. Tahpenes raised Genubath in Pharaoh’s house, and Genubath remained in Pharaoh’s household with Pharaoh’s own sons.
1 Kings 11:21 When Hadad heard in Egypt that King David had died and was resting with his ancestors, and that Joab, the commander of the army, was also dead, he said to Pharaoh: 'Allow me to leave, so I can return to my own land.'
1 Kings 11:22 Pharaoh asked him: 'What, then, do you lack with me, that you seek to return to your own land?' But Hadad replied: 'Nothing at all. I only beg you to let me go.'
1 Kings 11:23 God also raised up another adversary for Solomon: Rezon, the son of Eliada, who had fled from his lord, Hadadezer, the king of Zobah.
1 Kings 11:24 Rezon gathered men around him and became the leader of a raiding band, at the time when David defeated Hadadezer. They then went to Damascus, settled there, and began to rule in Damascus.
1 Kings 11:25 Rezon was an adversary to Israel throughout all the days of Solomon's reign. This was in addition to the trouble caused by Hadad, and Rezon hated Israel, reigning in Syria.
1 Kings 11:26 Jeroboam, the son of Nebat, an Ephraimite from Zeredah, also lifted his hand in rebellion against the king. He was a servant of Solomon, and his mother was a widow named Zeruah.
1 Kings 11:27 And this was the reason for his rebellion: Solomon had built the Millo, and had closed up the breach in the city of his father David.
1 Kings 11:28 Now Jeroboam was a strong and capable man. When Solomon saw that the young man was diligent and industrious, he appointed him over all the forced labor of the house of Joseph.
1 Kings 11:29 It happened at that time, as Jeroboam was leaving Jerusalem, that the prophet Ahijah the Shilonite met him on the road. Ahijah was wearing a new cloak, and they were the only two people in the open field.
1 Kings 11:30 Ahijah then took his new cloak that he was wearing and tore it into twelve pieces.
1 Kings 11:31 And Ahijah said to Jeroboam: 'Take ten pieces for yourself. For this is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says: "Behold, I am about to tear the kingdom away from the hand of Solomon, and I will give you ten tribes."
1 Kings 11:32 'But one tribe will remain for Solomon's son, for the sake of My servant David and for the sake of Jerusalem, the city which I have chosen from all the tribes of Israel.'
1 Kings 11:33 'This judgment comes because Solomon has abandoned Me. He has worshipped Astaroth, the goddess of the Sidonians; Chemosh, the god of Moab; and Moloch, the god of the Ammonite people. He has not walked in My ways, nor done what is right in My sight, nor kept My commands and My judgments, as his father David did.'
1 Kings 11:34 'However, I will not take the entire kingdom from his hand during his lifetime. Instead, I will let him remain ruler for all the days of his life, for the sake of My servant David, whom I chose, and who kept My commands and My precepts.'
1 Kings 11:35 'But I will take the kingdom from the hand of his son, and I will give ten tribes to you.'
1 Kings 11:36 'And to his son, I will give one tribe, so that My servant David may always have a lamp burning before Me—meaning a continuous royal line and presence—in Jerusalem, the city which I have chosen for My name to be there forever.'
1 Kings 11:37 'As for you, take power. You will reign over all that your heart desires, and you will be king over Israel.'
1 Kings 11:38 'If you listen to all that I command you, and walk in My ways, and do what is right in My sight, keeping My commands and My precepts, just as My servant David did, then I will be with you. I will build you a lasting dynasty, just as I built for David, and I will give Israel to you.'
1 Kings 11:39 'And I will afflict the descendants of David because of this, though not forever.'
1 Kings 11:40 Therefore, Solomon sought to kill Jeroboam. But Jeroboam rose up and fled to Egypt, to King Shishak of Egypt, and remained in Egypt until Solomon's death.
1 Kings 11:1 Now, King Solomon loved many foreign women, even Pharaoh's daughter who he had previously married, along with women from Moab, Ammon, Edom, Sidon, and the Hittites.
1 Kings 11:2 These were from the nations about whom the Lord had strictly warned the children of Israel, saying: 'Do not mix with them, nor let them mix with you, for they will most certainly turn your heart away to follow their false gods.' Yet Solomon joined himself to these women with burning love.
1 Kings 11:3 He had seven hundred royal wives and three hundred concubines. And these women did turn his heart away.
1 Kings 11:4 When he was old, his heart was corrupted by these women, so that he began to follow their foreign, false gods. His heart was not wholly devoted to the Lord his God, as was the heart of his father David.
1 Kings 11:5 For Solomon began to worship Astarte, the false goddess of the Sidonians, and Molech, the vile idol of the Ammonites.
1 Kings 11:6 Solomon did what was evil in the sight of the Lord. He did not fully follow the Lord, as his father David had done.
1 Kings 11:7 Then Solomon built a high place for Chemosh, the idol of the Moabites, on the hill that faces Jerusalem, and also for Molech, the idol of the children of Ammon.
1 Kings 11:8 And in this same manner, he built cultic sites for all his foreign wives who burned incense and offered sacrifices to their own false gods.
1 Kings 11:9 The Lord became angry with Solomon, because his mind and heart had turned away from the Lord God of Israel, who had appeared to him twice before this time,
1 Kings 11:10 and had commanded him concerning this very matter: that he should not follow foreign gods. But Solomon did not keep what the Lord had commanded him.
1 Kings 11:11 Therefore, the Lord said to Solomon: 'Because this has happened within you, and you have not kept My covenant and My commandments which I gave to you, I will surely tear your kingdom apart and give it to one of your servants.'
1 Kings 11:12 'Nevertheless, I will not do this during your days, for the sake of your father David. Instead, I will tear it out of the hand of your son.'
1 Kings 11:13 'But I will not take away the entire kingdom. I will give one tribe to your son, for the sake of My servant David, and for the sake of Jerusalem, which I have chosen as My holy city.'
1 Kings 11:14 So the Lord raised up an adversary against Solomon—Hadad the Edomite, who was of the royal lineage in Edom.
1 Kings 11:15 For when David was in Edom, and Joab the commander of the army had gone up to bury the slain, he struck down every male in Edom,
1 Kings 11:16 for Joab and all of Israel remained there for six months until they had cut off every male in Edom.
1 Kings 11:17 But Hadad himself fled, along with some Edomite men who were servants of his father. They headed for Egypt, because Hadad was still a small boy at that time.
1 Kings 11:18 When they had risen up from Midian, they came to Paran. They took men with them from Paran and then entered Egypt to Pharaoh, the King of Egypt. Pharaoh gave Hadad a house, provided him with food, and assigned him land.
1 Kings 11:19 And Hadad found such great favor with Pharaoh that Pharaoh gave him as wife the sister of his own wife, Queen Tahpenes.
1 Kings 11:20 And Queen Tahpenes's sister bore him a son, Genubath. Tahpenes raised Genubath in Pharaoh's house, so Genubath was in Pharaoh's household with Pharaoh's own sons.
1 Kings 11:21 When Hadad heard in Egypt that David had fallen asleep with his fathers—meaning he had died—and that Joab the commander of the army was also dead, Hadad said to Pharaoh, 'Let me go, so that I may return to my own land.'
1 Kings 11:22 Pharaoh said to him, 'What do you lack with me that you seek to go to your own land?' He replied, 'Nothing, but only let me go.'
1 Kings 11:23 God also raised up another adversary against Solomon: Rezon, the son of Eliada, who had fled from his lord, Hadadezer, the king of Zobah.
1 Kings 11:24 Rezon gathered men around him and became a leader of raiders when David defeated Hadadezer. They went to Damascus and lived there, and Rezon reigned in Damascus.
1 Kings 11:25 Rezon was an adversary to Israel all the days of Solomon. This was the harm caused by Hadad, and Rezon's hatred against Israel, and he reigned over Syria.
1 Kings 11:26 Jeroboam also, the son of Nebat, an Ephraimite from Zeredah, was a servant of Solomon. His mother was a widow named Zeruah. And he lifted up his hand, meaning he rebelled, against the king.
1 Kings 11:27 This was the cause of his rebellion: Solomon was building the Millo, and he had joined up the city of his father David—referring to the expansion of Jerusalem.
1 Kings 11:28 Now Jeroboam was a strong and mighty man. And Solomon, seeing that the young man was diligently prepared for work, appointed him over all the labor force of the house of Joseph—meaning the tribes of Ephraim and Manasseh.
1 Kings 11:29 It happened then, at that time, that Jeroboam went out from Jerusalem, and Ahijah the prophet from Shiloh met him on the way. Ahijah was wearing a new cloak, and they were the only two men in the open field.
1 Kings 11:30 Ahijah took hold of his new cloak which he was wearing and tore it into twelve pieces.
1 Kings 11:31 And he said to Jeroboam: 'Take ten pieces for yourself, for thus says the Lord, the God of Israel: 'Behold, I will tear the kingdom out of the hand of Solomon and will give ten tribes to you.'
1 Kings 11:32 'But one tribe shall remain for him—meaning for Solomon's lineage—for the sake of My servant David, and for the sake of Jerusalem, the city which I have chosen out of all the tribes of Israel.'
1 Kings 11:33 'This will happen because Solomon has forsaken Me and has worshipped Astarte, the false goddess of the Sidonians, and Chemosh, the false god of the Moabites, and Molech, the vile god of the children of Ammon. And he has not walked in My ways, to do what is just before Me, nor kept My commandments and My judgments, as his father David did.'
1 Kings 11:34 'I will not take the entire kingdom out of his hand, but I will make him a ruler for all the days of his life, for the sake of My servant David, whom I chose because he kept My commandments and My precepts.'
1 Kings 11:35 'But I will take the kingdom out of the hand of his son, and I will give ten tribes to you.'
1 Kings 11:36 'And to his son I will give one tribe, so that a lamp—meaning a lineage and kingship—may remain for My servant David for all days before Me in Jerusalem, the city which I have chosen for My name to be there.'
1 Kings 11:37 'Therefore, I will take you, and you shall reign over all that your soul desires, and you shall be king over Israel.'
1 Kings 11:38 'If, therefore, you will listen to all that I command you, and walk in My ways, and do what is right before Me, keeping My commandments and My precepts, just as My servant David did, then I will be with you. I will build for you a lasting house—meaning a dynasty—just as I built for David, and I will give Israel to you.'
1 Kings 11:39 'And I will afflict the descendants of David because of this—meaning because of Solomon's sin—but not for all days.'
1 Kings 11:40 Therefore, Solomon sought to kill Jeroboam. But Jeroboam arose and fled to Egypt, to Shishak, the king of Egypt, and remained in Egypt until Solomon's death.
1 Kings 12:1 And Rehoboam went to Shechem, because all of Israel had gathered there to make him their king.
1 Kings 12:2 When Jeroboam, son of Nebat, heard this news, he was still in Egypt, because he had fled there from King Solomon and was living in Egypt at the time.
1 Kings 12:3 So the people sent for Jeroboam and called him back. Jeroboam and all the multitude of Israel came, and they spoke to Rehoboam, saying:
1 Kings 12:4 Your father oppressed us with a very harsh rule. So now, you should lighten some of your father's harsh control and ease the very heavy burden he placed on us, and we will serve you.
1 Kings 12:5 Rehoboam said to them: "Go away for three days, and then return to me with your answer." And when the people had left,
1 Kings 12:6 Rehoboam consulted with the elder advisors who had served before his father Solomon when he was still alive. He said: "What counsel do you give me so that I may answer these people?"
1 Kings 12:7 The elder advisors said to him: "If today you show obedience to these people, and serve them, and speak gentle words to them, they will serve you all your days."
1 Kings 12:8 But Rehoboam abandoned the wise counsel of the elders, which they had given him. Instead, he consulted with the young men who had grown up with him and were now his royal attendants.
1 Kings 12:9 He said to them: "What counsel do you give me so that I may answer these people, who spoke to me, saying: 'Lighten the heavy burden that your father imposed on us' ?"
1 Kings 12:10 The young men who had grown up with him answered, saying: "You shall speak to these people, who spoke to you, saying: 'Your father made our burden heavy, you relieve us.' This is what you shall say to them: 'My little finger is thicker than my father's loins, meaning I am more powerful than him.'"
1 Kings 12:11 "My father placed a heavy burden upon you, but I will make your burden even heavier. My father punished you with whips, but I will punish you with scourges armed with barbs—'scorpions' as they are called."
1 Kings 12:12 So Jeroboam and all the people came to Rehoboam on the third day, just as the king had instructed, saying: "Return to me on the third day."
1 Kings 12:13 So the king answered the people more harshly, having ignored the wise counsel of the elders, which they had given him.
1 Kings 12:14 And he spoke according to the counsel of the young men, saying: "My father made your burden heavy, but I will make your burden even heavier. My father punished you with whips, but I will punish you with scourges armed with barbs."
1 Kings 12:15 The king did not listen to the people's pleas, because the Lord had turned his heart away from doing so. This was done to fulfill God's own word, which He had spoken through the prophet Ahijah the Shilonite to Jeroboam, son of Nebat.
1 Kings 12:16 Therefore, when all Israel saw that the king had not listened to them, the people answered the king, saying: "What share do we have any longer in David's lineage? We have no inheritance in the son of Jesse's house, meaning we reject the royal line! To your tents, O Israel! Look to your own house, David—we disown your authority!" And so, the tribes of Israel went to their own encampments.
1 Kings 12:17 However, Rehoboam continued to reign over the children of Israel who lived in the cities of Judah, specifically the tribes of Judah and Benjamin.
1 Kings 12:18 Therefore King Rehoboam sent Adoram, who was in charge of collecting the forced labor and tribute payments, to the rebellious tribes. But all Israel stoned him to death. Then King Rehoboam quickly mounted his royal chariot and fled to Jerusalem to escape.
1 Kings 12:19 And so, the ten northern tribes of Israel permanently separated from the house of David's rule, a separation that continues to this very day.
1 Kings 12:20 Now all Israel heard that Jeroboam had returned from Egypt. So they sent for him and called him to a gathering of all the people, and they made him king over all the tribes of Israel, except for the tribe of Judah alone, which remained loyal to Rehoboam.
1 Kings 12:21 But Rehoboam came to Jerusalem and gathered all the house of Judah and the tribe of Benjamin, a total of one hundred eighty thousand chosen warriors, intending to fight against the house of Israel—the northern tribes—and bring the kingdom back under his control.
1 Kings 12:22 But the word of the Lord came to Shemaiah, a prophet of God, saying:
1 Kings 12:23 Speak to Rehoboam, son of Solomon, king of Judah, and to all the house of Judah and Benjamin, and to the rest of the people who are with him, saying:
1 Kings 12:24 "Thus says the Lord: 'You shall not go up to fight against your brothers, the children of Israel. Let each one return to his own house, because this division has been done by My will and My word.'" They heard the word of the Lord, and they turned back from their journey, just as the Lord had commanded them.
1 Kings 12:25 Now Jeroboam rebuilt the city of Shechem in the hill country of Ephraim and established his residence there. And going out from there, he also rebuilt Penuel.
1 Kings 12:26 And Jeroboam said in his heart: "Now, if things continue as they are, the loyalty of the kingdom will revert to the house of David."
1 Kings 12:27 "If these people continue to go up to Jerusalem to offer sacrifices in the house of the Lord, then the hearts of these people will turn back to their lord, Rehoboam, king of Judah. They will kill me, and return their allegiance to Rehoboam, king of Judah."
1 Kings 12:28 So, after careful deliberation, Jeroboam made two golden calves. Then he said to the people: "You have traveled enough to Jerusalem. Look, O Israel, these are your gods who brought you out of the land of Egypt!"
1 Kings 12:29 He placed one golden calf in Bethel, and the other he placed in Dan, two cities at opposite ends of his kingdom.
1 Kings 12:30 And this action became a great sin for Israel, for the people went to worship the golden calf even as far as Dan, engaging in idolatry.
1 Kings 12:31 Jeroboam also made temples on the high places, meaning shrines on hills and mountains, and appointed priests from the lowest ranks of the people who were not from the priestly tribe of Levi.
1 Kings 12:32 And Jeroboam appointed a feast day in the eighth month, on the fifteenth day of the month, mimicking the solemn feast that was celebrated in Judah, the Feast of Tabernacles. And going up to the altar, he did likewise in Bethel, to sacrifice to the golden calves which he had made, and he appointed priests of the high places which he had established in Bethel.
1 Kings 12:33 And he went up to the altar which he had made in Bethel on the fifteenth day of the eighth month—a feast day which he had devised from his own heart, not according to God's law. He made a solemn feast for the children of Israel, and he went up to the altar to burn incense.
1 Kings 12:38 The Lord fulfilled this word which He had spoken to Jeroboam concerning the division of the kingdom.
1 Kings 12:39 And because of this sin of Jeroboam, and the sin of his entire household, through which they sinned and caused all Israel to sin with idolatry, the Lord turned away Israel from Himself and delivered them into the hands of those who would plunder them.
1 Kings 12:40 Now the rest of the acts of Jeroboam, and all that he did, and his mighty deeds, how he fought wars, and how he reigned as king, behold, these things are written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel.
1 Kings 12:1 Rehoboam, the son of King Solomon, then went to Shechem. For all of the tribes of Israel had gathered there to declare him their king.
1 Kings 12:2 When Jeroboam, the son of Nebat, heard this news—he was in Egypt at the time because he had fled there from King Solomon and was living in Egypt—
1 Kings 12:3 they sent word and called him back. So Jeroboam and the entire assembly of Israel came and spoke to Rehoboam, saying:
1 Kings 12:4 “Your father, King Solomon, put a very heavy burden of forced labor on us. Now, therefore, lighten the harsh rule of your father and the heavy burden he placed on us, and we will be your loyal subjects.”
1 Kings 12:5 Rehoboam replied to them: “Go away for three days, and then return to me for my decision.” So the people left.
1 Kings 12:6 King Rehoboam then consulted with the elders, his oldest advisors, who had served before his father Solomon when he was still alive. He asked: “What counsel do you give me, that I may respond to these people?”
1 Kings 12:7 They replied to him: “If today you are a servant to these people, and serve them well, and speak kind words to them, then they will be loyal subjects to you for all of your days.”
1 Kings 12:8 But Rehoboam rejected the counsel of the elders, which they had given him. Instead, he consulted with the young men who had grown up with him and were now his closest companions.
1 Kings 12:9 He said to them: “What counsel do you give, or what should we answer to these people who have spoken to me, saying: ‘Take away from us the heavy burden that your father imposed on us’?”
1 Kings 12:10 The young men who had grown up with him replied to him, saying: “This is how you should speak to these people who have said to you: ‘Your father made our burden heavy, but you should lighten it for us.’ This is what you should say to them: ‘My little finger is thicker than my father’s loins.’ This means that I am even stronger and more demanding than he was.”
1 Kings 12:11 “Now, my father placed a heavy burden on you, but I will add to your burden. My father beat you with whips, but I will beat you with scorpions—a much harsher instrument.”
1 Kings 12:12 So Jeroboam and all the people came to Rehoboam on the third day, just as the king had instructed, saying: “Return to me on the third day.”
1 Kings 12:13 And the king gave the people a harsh answer, ignoring the wise counsel that the elders had given him.
1 Kings 12:14 He spoke according to the counsel of the young men, saying: “My father made your burden heavy, but I will add even more to your burden. My father beat you with whips, but I will truly beat you with scorpions.”
1 Kings 12:15 The king did not listen to the people because the Lord had turned him away from doing so. This was to fulfill His word, which He had spoken through His prophet Ahijah the Shilonite to Jeroboam, the son of Nebat.
1 Kings 12:16 So when all of Israel saw that the king would not listen to them, the people answered the king, saying: “What share do we have in David's lineage? We have no inheritance in the son of Jesse! To your tents, O Israel! Now, let David—that is, Rehoboam, and the house of Judah—look to his own household!” So Israel departed to their tents, that is, to their homes.
1 Kings 12:17 But Rehoboam continued to reign over the sons of Israel who lived in the cities of Judah.
1 Kings 12:18 King Rehoboam then sent Adoram, who was in charge of collecting the forced labor tribute. But all the people of Israel stoned him with rocks, and he died. King Rehoboam, for his part, quickly mounted his chariot and fled to Jerusalem.
1 Kings 12:19 Thus, Israel—meaning the ten northern tribes—separated from the house of David's dynasty and the tribe of Judah, a division that remains to this very day.
1 Kings 12:20 Now, when all of Israel heard that Jeroboam had returned from Egypt, they sent for him and called him to a general assembly. They then made him king over all of Israel, with only the tribe of Judah and the tribe of Benjamin remaining loyal to Rehoboam.
1 Kings 12:21 When Rehoboam arrived in Jerusalem, he gathered all the house of Judah and the tribe of Benjamin—a force of one hundred eighty thousand chosen warriors—intending to wage war against the house of Israel to restore the kingdom to himself.
1 Kings 12:22 But the word of the Lord came to Shemaiah, a man of God, saying:
1 Kings 12:23 “Speak to Rehoboam, the son of Solomon, the king of Judah, and to all the house of Judah and Benjamin, and to the rest of the people, saying:”
1 Kings 12:24 “Thus says the Lord: You shall not go up, nor shall you fight against your brothers, the sons of Israel. Let each one return to his own house, for this word, this division, has been brought about by My will.” Hearing the word of the Lord, they turned back from their journey and went away according to the Lord’s command.
1 Kings 12:25 Jeroboam then built up the city of Shechem in the mountains of Ephraim and lived there. After leaving there, he also built up the city of Penuel.
1 Kings 12:26 Jeroboam said in his heart, that is, to himself: “Now the kingdom will certainly return its loyalty to the house of David, the family of Rehoboam.”
1 Kings 12:27 “If these people continue to go up to Jerusalem to offer sacrifices in the house of the Lord, then the hearts of these people will turn back to their Lord, Rehoboam, the king of Judah. They will kill me and return to Rehoboam, the king of Judah.”
1 Kings 12:28 So, after careful consideration, Jeroboam made two golden calves and said to the people: “You have been going up to Jerusalem for too long. Behold your gods, O Israel, who brought you up out of the land of Egypt!” This was an idolatrous reference to the golden calf made at Sinai.
1 Kings 12:29 He placed one golden calf in Bethel, and the other in Dan, establishing new worship centers at the northern and southern extremes of his kingdom.
1 Kings 12:30 And this action became a great sin, for the people went to worship the golden calf even as far as Dan.
1 Kings 12:31 He also built temples on high places, and appointed priests from among all the people, even those who were not from the tribe of Levi, which was against God’s law.
1 Kings 12:32 Jeroboam instituted a feast day in the eighth month, on the fifteenth day of the month, corresponding to the feast day that was celebrated in Judah. He went up to the altar himself, just as he did in Bethel, to offer sacrifice to the calves he had made. He also appointed priests for the high places he had made in Bethel.
1 Kings 12:33 He went up to the altar which he had made in Bethel on the fifteenth day of the eighth month—a month he had arbitrarily chosen for himself, not one appointed by God. He instituted this feast for the sons of Israel and went up to the altar to burn incense.
1 Kings 12:34 Therefore, according to this word, this was done, and on that day, he went up to the altar to burn incense.
1 Kings 13:1 A man of God came from Judah to Bethel, commissioned by the Lord to deliver a message. He arrived just as King Jeroboam was standing before his altar, offering sacrifices to his false gods.
1 Kings 13:2 The man of God then cried out against the altar, speaking a message directly from the Lord. He declared: 'Altar, altar! This is what the Lord says: Listen! A son will be born to the house of David, named Josiah, who will slaughter the priests of the high places—the very priests who are now burning incense on you—and he will burn human bones upon you in desecration.'
1 Kings 13:3 And on that very day, the man of God gave a sign to prove the prophecy, saying: 'This is the sign that the Lord has truly spoken this: Watch! The altar will be split apart, and all the ashes on it will be scattered and spilled.'
1 Kings 13:4 When King Jeroboam heard the man of God's message, which was cried out against the altar in Bethel, the king stretched out his hand from the altar and commanded: 'Seize him!' But at that instant, the hand he had stretched out withered, and he could not pull it back to himself.
1 Kings 13:5 Also, at that very moment, the altar itself was split apart, and the ashes were spilled from it, just as the man of God had declared as a sign by the word of the Lord.
1 Kings 13:6 Then the king said to the man of God: 'Please, pray to the Lord your God for mercy, and intercede for me, so that my hand may be restored to me.' The man of God earnestly prayed to the Lord, and the king’s hand was restored to him, becoming as it was before.
1 Kings 13:7 The king then spoke to the man of God: 'Come home with me so you can eat and refresh yourself, and I will give you gifts as a reward.'
1 Kings 13:8 But the man of God answered the king: 'Even if you were to give me half of your royal house, I would not go with you, nor would I eat bread or drink water in this specific place of idolatry.'
1 Kings 13:9 'For the Lord specifically commanded me in His word, saying: “You shall not eat bread, nor drink water, nor shall you return by the same way you came.”'
1 Kings 13:10 So he departed by another road, and did not return by the same way he had come to Bethel.
1 Kings 13:11 Now there was a certain old prophet living in Bethel. His son came and told his father all the works the man of God had performed that day in Bethel, and they recounted to their father the words he had spoken to the king.
1 Kings 13:12 And their father asked them, saying: 'Which way did he go?' His sons showed him the road by which the man of God, who had come from Judah, had departed.
1 Kings 13:13 Then he told his sons: 'Saddle the donkey for me.' When they had saddled it, the old prophet mounted it.
1 Kings 13:14 He went after the man of God and found him sitting under a terebinth tree. He said to him: 'Are you the man of God who came from Judah?' The man of God replied: 'I am he.'
1 Kings 13:15 Then the old prophet said to him: 'Come home with me, so you can eat bread.'
1 Kings 13:16 But the man of God replied: 'I cannot return with you, nor can I come with you; neither will I eat bread nor drink water in this particular place, as it is forbidden by the Lord.'
1 Kings 13:17 'For the Lord spoke to me by His word, commanding: “You shall not eat bread nor drink water there, nor shall you return by the way you came.”'
1 Kings 13:18 Then the old prophet said to him: 'I too am a prophet like you, and an Angel spoke to me by the word of the Lord, saying: “Bring him back with you to your house, that he may eat bread and drink water.”' However, the old prophet was lying to him.
1 Kings 13:19 So the man of God turned back with the old prophet, and he ate bread in the old prophet's house and drank water.
1 Kings 13:20 While they were sitting at the table, the word of the Lord came to the prophet who had brought him back.
1 Kings 13:21 And the old prophet cried out to the man of God who had come from Judah, saying: 'This is what the Lord says: Because you did not obey the command of the Lord, and did not keep the instruction that the Lord your God commanded you,'
1 Kings 13:22 'and instead you returned to eat bread and drink water in the very place where I commanded you not to eat bread or drink water, therefore your dead body shall not be brought to the tomb of your fathers for burial.'
1 Kings 13:23 After the man of God had finished eating and drinking, the old prophet saddled his own donkey for the man of God whom he had brought back.
1 Kings 13:24 As the man of God went on his way, a lion met him on the road and killed him. His body lay cast out on the road, with his donkey standing beside it, and the lion also stood by the dead body, not harming the donkey.
1 Kings 13:25 Then, behold, men passing by saw the body lying on the road and the lion standing beside it. They went and reported what they saw in the city where the old prophet lived.
1 Kings 13:26 When the old prophet, who had brought the man of God back from the road, heard this, he said: 'It is the man of God who did not believe the word of the Lord! So the Lord delivered him to a lion, and it crushed him and killed him, just as the Lord had spoken through His own word to him.'
1 Kings 13:27 Then he said to his sons: 'Saddle the donkey for me.' When they had saddled it, he mounted it.
1 Kings 13:28 He went and found the man of God's body lying on the road, with the donkey and the lion still standing by the body. The lion had not eaten from the body, nor had it harmed the donkey, which was a miraculous sign of God's direct involvement.
1 Kings 13:29 So the old prophet picked up the body of the man of God, placed it upon his donkey, and brought him back to his own city. The old prophet then mourned for him.
1 Kings 13:30 He laid the man of God’s body in his own tomb, and they mourned over him, crying: 'Alas, my brother!'
1 Kings 13:31 After they had mourned him, the old prophet said to his sons, telling them: 'When I die, bury me in this same tomb where the man of God is buried. Place my bones beside his bones.'
1 Kings 13:32 'For the word of the Lord that he spoke by the Lord's command against the altar in Bethel, and against all the shrines of the high places which are in the cities of Samaria, will surely come true.'
1 Kings 13:33 Even after these events, Jeroboam did not turn from his evil way. Instead, he continued to appoint priests for the high places from the lowest ranks of the people. Whoever desired it, he consecrated them to serve, and they became priests of the high places, which was a grave sin against God.
1 Kings 13:34 Because of this sin, this became the cause of the downfall of Jeroboam’s house, leading to its complete destruction and utter removal from the face of the earth.
