1 Kings 13:1 And behold, a man of God from Judah arrived in Bethel with a message from the Lord. This happened while King Jeroboam was standing at the altar to offer sacrifice.
1 Kings 13:2 And the man of God cried out against the altar with a message from the Lord, saying: "O Altar, O Altar, this is what the Lord says: 'Behold, a son will be born to the house of David, named Josiah. He will sacrifice upon you the priests of the high places who are now offering sacrifices on you, and he will burn the bones of men upon you.'"
1 Kings 13:3 And on that same day, the man of God gave a sign, saying: "This will be the proof that the Lord has spoken: 'Behold, this very altar will be torn apart, and the ashes that are on it will be poured out.'"
1 Kings 13:4 Now, when the king heard the message of the man of God, which he had cried out against the altar in Bethel, King Jeroboam stretched out his hand from the altar, ordering: "Seize him!" But his hand, which he had stretched out against the man of God, immediately withered, and he was unable to pull it back to himself.
1 Kings 13:5 Furthermore, the altar itself was torn apart, and the ashes were poured out from it, exactly as the man of God had prophesied with a message from the Lord.
1 Kings 13:6 Then the king said to the man of God: "Please intercede with the Lord your God and pray for me, so that my hand may be restored to me." So the man of God interceded with the Lord, and the king's hand was restored to him, becoming as it had been before.
1 Kings 13:7 The king then spoke to the man of God, inviting him: "Come home with me to eat a meal, and I will give you gifts."
1 Kings 13:8 But the man of God replied to the king: "Even if you were to give me half of your royal house, I would not go with you, nor will I eat bread or drink water in this place."
1 Kings 13:9 For this is the commandment I received in a message from the Lord, who said: 'You shall not eat bread, nor drink water, nor return by the same road you came.'"
1 Kings 13:10 So the man of God departed by a different road and did not return by the way he had come to Bethel.
1 Kings 13:11 Now there was an old prophet living in Bethel. His sons came to him and told him all the deeds that the man of God had performed that day in Bethel, and they recounted to their father the words he had spoken to the king.
1 Kings 13:12 Their father then asked them: "Which road did he take?" And his sons showed him the road by which the man of God, who had come from Judah, had departed.
1 Kings 13:13 And he said to his sons: "Saddle a donkey for me." When they had saddled it, the old prophet mounted the donkey.
1 Kings 13:14 He rode after the man of God and found him sitting under an oak tree. The old prophet asked him: "Are you the man of God who came from Judah?" And the man of God replied: "I am."
1 Kings 13:15 Then the old prophet said to him: "Come home with me to eat bread."
1 Kings 13:16 But the man of God replied: "I cannot return or go with you. I will not eat bread or drink water in this place."
1 Kings 13:17 Because the Lord spoke to me in a message, saying: 'You shall not eat bread or drink water there, nor shall you return by the way you came.'"
1 Kings 13:18 And the old prophet said to him: "I too am a prophet like you, and an Angel spoke to me with a message from the Lord, saying: 'Bring him back with you to your house, so he may eat bread and drink water.'" The old prophet was lying to him.
1 Kings 13:19 So the man of God returned with him, and ate bread in his house, and drank water.
1 Kings 13:20 While they were sitting at the table, a message from the Lord came to the prophet who had brought him back.
1 Kings 13:21 And the old prophet cried out to the man of God who had come from Judah, saying: "This is what the Lord says: 'Because you did not obey the word of the Lord, and did not keep the commandment that the Lord your God commanded you,"
1 Kings 13:22 —but instead you returned and ate bread and drank water in the very place where I commanded you not to eat bread or drink water—therefore your corpse shall not be brought into the tomb of your fathers.'"
1 Kings 13:23 Now it happened that after the man of God had eaten bread and drunk water, the old prophet saddled his own donkey for the man of God whom he had brought back.
1 Kings 13:24 When the man of God departed, a lion found him on the road and killed him. His corpse lay cast out on the road, with his donkey standing beside it, and the lion also stood beside the corpse.
1 Kings 13:25 And behold, some men passing by saw the corpse lying on the road and the lion standing next to it. They came and reported what they saw in the city where the old prophet lived.
1 Kings 13:26 When the old prophet who had brought him back from the road heard this, he said: "It is the man of God who did not obey the Lord's command! And the Lord delivered him to the lion, and it tore him and killed him, just as the Lord had spoken to him in His message."
1 Kings 13:27 And he said to his sons: "Saddle a donkey for me." When they had saddled it,
1 Kings 13:28 The old prophet went and found the corpse of the man of God lying on the road, with the donkey and the lion still standing beside the corpse. The lion had not eaten from the corpse, nor had it harmed the donkey.
1 Kings 13:29 So the old prophet picked up the corpse of the man of God and placed it upon the donkey and brought it back. He came to the city where the old prophet lived to mourn for him and to bury him.
1 Kings 13:30 And he laid the man of God's corpse in his own tomb, and they mourned over him, crying: "Alas, my brother!"
1 Kings 13:31 And it came to pass after he had buried him, the old prophet said to his sons, instructing them: "When I die, bury me in this very tomb where the man of God is buried. Lay my bones beside his bones."
1 Kings 13:32 For truly the message will come to pass which he spoke with a message from the Lord, against the altar that is in Bethel, and against all the shrines of the high places that are in the cities of Samaria."
1 Kings 13:33 After these events, King Jeroboam did not turn back from his evil way. Instead, he continued to appoint priests for the high places from the lowest of the people; anyone who desired it could consecrate himself and become a priest of the high places.
1 Kings 13:34 And because of this cause, the house of Jeroboam sinned, and it was utterly destroyed and wiped from the face of the earth.
1 Kings 14:1 At that particular time, Abijah, the son of Jeroboam, became sick.
1 Kings 14:2 Jeroboam then told his wife, "Get up and change your clothes, so no one will recognize that you are Jeroboam's wife. Then go to Shiloh, where Ahijah the prophet lives—the same man who told me that I would rule over these people of Israel."
1 Kings 14:3 "Take with you five loaves of bread, a cake, and a jar of honey, and go to him. He will tell you what will happen to the boy—your son."
1 Kings 14:4 So Jeroboam's wife did as she was told. She arose, went to Shiloh, and arrived at Ahijah's house. But Ahijah could not see, because his eyes were dim with old age.
1 Kings 14:5 But the Lord had spoken to Ahijah, saying, "Look, Jeroboam's wife is coming to consult you about her son, because he is sick. You are to tell her exactly these things." So when she entered and pretended to be someone else,
1 Kings 14:6 Ahijah heard the sound of her feet as she came through the door, and he said, "Come in, wife of Jeroboam. Why do you pretend to be another woman? I, however, am sent on a mission to you with a harsh message from God."
1 Kings 14:7 "Go and tell Jeroboam: 'Thus says the Lord, the God of Israel: For as much as I exalted you from among the people, and made you a leader over My people Israel—"
1 Kings 14:8 "—and I tore the kingdom away from the house of David and gave it to you. Yet you have not been like My servant David, who kept My commandments and followed Me with his whole heart, doing only what was pleasing in My eyes."
1 Kings 14:9 "But you have done worse evil than all who were before you. You have made for yourself foreign gods, and molten images, to provoke Me to anger, and you have cast Me aside, behind your back."
1 Kings 14:10 "Therefore, behold, I will bring evil upon the house of Jeroboam. I will cut off from Jeroboam every male—every male, whether confined or completely free in Israel. I will utterly cleanse the remnant of Jeroboam's house, just as one cleanses dung until it is completely gone."
1 Kings 14:11 "Anyone belonging to Jeroboam who dies in the city, dogs will devour him. And anyone who dies in the open country, the birds of the sky will eat him. For the Lord Himself has spoken it."
1 Kings 14:12 "You, therefore, rise up and go to your house. And the very moment your feet enter the city, the boy will die."
1 Kings 14:13 "And all Israel will mourn for him, and they will bury him. For he alone among all of Jeroboam's family will be brought to a burial place, because some good was found in him towards the Lord, the God of Israel, in the house of Jeroboam."
1 Kings 14:14 "Furthermore, the Lord will raise up for Himself a king over Israel who will utterly cut off the house of Jeroboam, and that will happen on this very day and at this very time."
1 Kings 14:15 "And the Lord will strike Israel, causing them to sway like a reed that is moved by water. He will uproot Israel from this good land that He gave to their fathers, and He will scatter them beyond the River Euphrates, because they made for themselves Asherah poles to provoke the Lord to anger."
1 Kings 14:16 "And the Lord will abandon Israel because of the sins of Jeroboam, who sinned and caused Israel to sin."
1 Kings 14:17 So Jeroboam's wife arose and departed. She came to Tirzah, and as she was crossing the threshold of the house, the boy died.
1 Kings 14:18 They buried him, and all Israel mourned for him, just as the Lord had spoken through His servant Ahijah the prophet.
1 Kings 14:19 Now the rest of the acts of Jeroboam, how he fought, and how he reigned, behold, they are written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel.
1 Kings 14:20 The days that Jeroboam reigned were twenty-two years. Then he slept with his fathers—a euphemism for dying. And Nadab, his son, reigned in his place.
1 Kings 14:21 Rehoboam, the son of Solomon, reigned in Judah. Rehoboam was forty-one years old when he began to reign, and he reigned seventeen years in Jerusalem, the city which the Lord had chosen out of all the tribes of Israel to put His name there. Now his mother's name was Naamah, an Ammonitess.
1 Kings 14:22 And Judah did evil before the Lord. They provoked Him to jealousy with all the sins that their fathers had committed.
1 Kings 14:23 For they also built for themselves high places, and sacred pillars, and Asherah poles on every high hill and under every leafy tree.
1 Kings 14:24 Furthermore, there were male cult prostitutes in the land, and they committed all the abominable practices of the nations that the Lord had driven out before the children of Israel.
1 Kings 14:25 Now in the fifth year of King Rehoboam's reign, Shishak, the king of Egypt, marched against Jerusalem.
1 Kings 14:26 And he took away the treasures of the house of the Lord, and the treasures of the king's house. He plundered everything, including the golden shields that Solomon had made.
1 Kings 14:27 In place of these, King Rehoboam made bronze shields and committed them to the care of the captains of the guard, who stood watch at the entrance of the king's house.
1 Kings 14:28 And whenever the king entered the house of the Lord, the guards carried them, and then they returned them to the guardroom of the shield-bearers.
1 Kings 14:29 Now the rest of the acts of Rehoboam, and all that he did, behold, they are written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Judah.
1 Kings 14:30 There was also continuous warfare between Rehoboam and Jeroboam throughout all their days.
1 Kings 14:31 Then Rehoboam slept with his fathers—he died—and was buried with them in the city of David. His mother's name was Naamah, an Ammonitess. And Abijah, his son, reigned in his place.
1 Kings 14:1 At that time, Abijah, who was the son of King Jeroboam, fell ill.
1 Kings 14:2 And King Jeroboam said to his wife: "Go now, and disguise yourself by changing your clothes, so no one will recognize that you are the wife of King Jeroboam. Then go to Shiloh, where Ahijah the prophet lives—the same prophet who told me I would be king over this people."
1 Kings 14:3 "Also, take with you ten loaves of bread, some cakes, and a jar of honey. Go to him, and he will tell you what will happen to the boy."
1 Kings 14:4 So King Jeroboam's wife did as he had told her. She got up and went to Shiloh, and came to Ahijah's house. But the prophet could not see, because his eyes had become dim from old age.
1 Kings 14:5 But the Lord had said to Ahijah: "Look, King Jeroboam's wife is coming to consult you about her son, who is sick. Tell her exactly these things." So when she came in, pretending to be someone else,
1 Kings 14:6 Ahijah heard the sound of her feet as she entered through the door, and he said: "Come in, wife of King Jeroboam! Why are you pretending to be someone you are not? I have been sent to you with a harsh message."
1 Kings 14:7 "Go and tell King Jeroboam: 'This is what the Lord God of Israel says: I elevated you from among the common people and made you a leader over My people, Israel."
1 Kings 14:8 'I tore the kingdom away from the house of David and gave it to you. Yet you have not been like My servant David, who kept My commandments and followed Me with his whole heart, doing only what was pleasing in My sight.
1 Kings 14:9 'Instead, you have done more evil than all who were before you. You have made for yourself foreign gods, idols cast from metal, to provoke My wrath, and you have cast Me aside, forgetting about Me completely.
1 Kings 14:10 'Therefore, behold, I will bring disaster upon the house of Jeroboam. I will cut off from Jeroboam every male descendant, whether slave or free, the lowest and the last in Israel. I will utterly sweep away the remnant of Jeroboam's house, just as one sweeps away dung until it is completely gone.'
1 Kings 14:11 'Those of Jeroboam's family who die in the city will be eaten by dogs, and those who die in the open country will be devoured by the birds of the sky. This is because the Lord Himself has spoken it.'"
1 Kings 14:12 Ahijah continued, "As for you, get up and go back to your house. The very moment your feet enter the city, the boy will die."
1 Kings 14:13 "All of Israel will mourn him and bury him. For he alone among Jeroboam's family will be laid in a proper grave, because in him alone, in the house of Jeroboam, a good word concerning the Lord God of Israel was found."
1 Kings 14:14 "Moreover, the Lord will raise up a king over Israel for Himself, who will cut off the house of Jeroboam—and this will happen quickly, at the appointed time."
1 Kings 14:15 "And the Lord will strike Israel, shaking them like a reed is shaken in water. He will uproot Israel from this good land that He gave to their ancestors, and scatter them beyond the great river, because they made for themselves sacred poles, provoking the Lord to anger."
1 Kings 14:16 "And the Lord will abandon Israel because of the sins of Jeroboam, who sinned and led Israel into sin."
1 Kings 14:17 So Jeroboam's wife got up and left, and came to Tirzah. And as she stepped across the threshold of the house, the boy died.
1 Kings 14:18 They buried him, and all Israel mourned for him, just as the Lord had declared through His servant, Ahijah the prophet.
1 Kings 14:19 Now, the rest of the acts of Jeroboam—how he fought wars and how he reigned—behold, these are written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel.
1 Kings 14:20 The length of King Jeroboam's reign was twenty-two years. He then died and was laid to rest with his ancestors, and his son Nadab reigned in his place.
1 Kings 14:21 Rehoboam, Solomon's son, was ruling in Judah at this time. Rehoboam was forty-one years old when he began to reign, and he reigned for seventeen years in Jerusalem, the city that the Lord had chosen from all the tribes of Israel to establish His presence there. His mother's name was Naamah, an Ammonite woman.
1 Kings 14:22 And Judah did evil in the sight of the Lord, provoking Him more than all that their ancestors had done through the sins they committed.
1 Kings 14:23 For they also built for themselves high places, pillars, and sacred groves upon every high hill and under every lush tree, engaging in idolatry.
1 Kings 14:24 Moreover, there were also male prostitutes for cultic purposes in the land, and they committed all the detestable practices of the pagan nations whom the Lord had driven out before the people of Israel.
1 Kings 14:25 Now, in the fifth year of King Rehoboam's reign, Shishak king of Egypt marched up against Jerusalem.
1 Kings 14:26 He carried off the treasures of the Lord's house and the treasures of the royal palace. He plundered everything, including the golden shields that King Solomon had made.
1 Kings 14:27 In place of these, King Rehoboam made bronze shields and entrusted them to the care of the commanders of the guards, who protected the entrance of the royal palace.
1 Kings 14:28 And whenever the king went into the house of the Lord, the guards who walked before him would carry these shields, and then return them to the guardroom.
1 Kings 14:29 Now, the rest of the acts of Rehoboam, and all that he did, are these not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Judah?
1 Kings 14:30 There was continuous warfare between King Rehoboam and King Jeroboam throughout all their days.
1 Kings 14:31 And Rehoboam died and was laid to rest with his ancestors in the City of David. His mother's name was Naamah, an Ammonite woman. And his son Abijam reigned in his place.
1 Kings 14:1 At that time—while Jeroboam was reigning as king—his son, Abijah, became very ill.
1 Kings 14:2 And King Jeroboam said to his wife, "Get up, change your clothing so that no one will recognize that you are the queen, King Jeroboam's wife. Then go to Shiloh. Ahijah the prophet lives there—he's the one who told me that I would be king over this people, Israel."
1 Kings 14:3 "Take ten loaves of bread with you, along with some cakes and a jar of honey, and go to him. He will tell you what will happen to the child."
1 Kings 14:4 So Jeroboam's wife did as her husband instructed. She got up, went to Shiloh, and arrived at Ahijah's house. Ahijah, however, could not see anything, because his eyes were dim and clouded due to his old age.
1 Kings 14:5 But the Lord God had already spoken to Ahijah, saying, "Look, Jeroboam's wife is coming to consult you about her son, who is sick. You are to tell her exactly this and this—all that I am about to reveal to you." So when she came in, she pretended to be someone else, to hide her identity.
1 Kings 14:6 As Ahijah heard the sound of her footsteps entering through the door, he said, "Come in, wife of Jeroboam! Why are you pretending to be someone else? I have been sent by God to you with a harsh message for your husband."
1 Kings 14:7 "Go, and tell Jeroboam this: 'This is what the Lord God of Israel says: Because I lifted you up from among the common people and made you a leader over My people Israel—"
1 Kings 14:8 "—and I tore the kingdom away from the house of David and gave it to you, yet you have not been like My servant David, who kept My commandments and followed Me with all his heart, doing only what was pleasing in My sight—"
1 Kings 14:9 "—instead, you have done more evil than all who were before you. You have made other, false gods for yourself, and molten images, simply to provoke Me to anger. You have completely cast Me behind your back, disregarding My authority and My Law."
1 Kings 14:10 "Therefore, behold, I will bring evil upon the house of Jeroboam. I will cut off from Jeroboam every male, whether slave or free, even the last remaining one in Israel. I will thoroughly cleanse the remnants of Jeroboam's house, just as one cleans away dung until nothing is left."
1 Kings 14:11 "Anyone belonging to Jeroboam who dies in the city will be eaten by dogs. And anyone of his family who dies in the open country will be devoured by the birds of the sky. This will happen because the Lord God Himself has spoken it."
1 Kings 14:12 "So you, get up and go to your house. The very moment your feet enter the city, the boy, your son, will die."
1 Kings 14:13 "All of Israel will mourn for him, and they will bury him with honor. For of all Jeroboam's family, only this child will be brought to a proper burial, because in him alone was found some good intention toward the Lord God of Israel, even within the wicked house of Jeroboam."
1 Kings 14:14 "Moreover, the Lord God will raise up for Himself a new king over Israel, who will completely cut off the house of Jeroboam—this will happen on that very day, at that very moment."
1 Kings 14:15 "And the Lord God will strike Israel, causing them to tremble and shake like a reed swaying in the water. He will uproot Israel from this good land that He gave to their fathers, and scatter them beyond the Euphrates River, because they have made sacred groves and Asherah poles—symbols of idolatry—to provoke the Lord God to anger."
1 Kings 14:16 "The Lord God will abandon Israel because of the sins of Jeroboam, who himself sinned, and who also caused all of Israel to sin."
1 Kings 14:17 So Jeroboam's wife got up and left, and she came to Tirzah. And as she stepped over the threshold of her house, the boy died—just as the prophet had foretold.
1 Kings 14:18 They buried him, and all of Israel mourned for him, exactly as the Lord God had spoken through His servant, Ahijah the prophet.
1 Kings 14:19 The rest of the acts of Jeroboam—how he fought wars and how he reigned as king—behold, they are written in the Book of the Annals of the Kings of Israel.
1 Kings 14:20 The days during which Jeroboam reigned were twenty-two years. Then he rested with his fathers—that is, he died and was buried. And his son, Nadab, began to reign in his place.
1 Kings 14:21 Now Rehoboam, Solomon's son, reigned over Judah. Rehoboam was forty-one years old when he began to reign, and he reigned for seventeen years in Jerusalem, the city which the Lord God had chosen out of all the tribes of Israel to establish His Name there, as a place of true worship. His mother's name was Naamah, an Ammonitess.
1 Kings 14:22 And Judah did evil in the sight of the Lord God. They provoked Him to anger even more than all the sins their fathers had committed, through their own sins and their fervent idolatry.
1 Kings 14:23 For they also built for themselves high places, sacred pillars, and Asherah poles for false worship upon every high hill and under every lush, green tree.
1 Kings 14:24 There were also male cult prostitutes, referred to as 'sodomites' by their pagan practices, in the land. They committed all the abominations of the pagan nations whom the Lord God had driven out from before the children of Israel.
1 Kings 14:25 Now, in the fifth year of King Rehoboam's reign, Shishak, the king of Egypt, marched against Jerusalem.
1 Kings 14:26 He plundered the treasures of the house of the Lord God, and the royal palace treasures, and he carried off everything. He even took away the golden shields that King Solomon had made.
1 Kings 14:27 In place of the golden shields, King Rehoboam made bronze shields and entrusted them to the care of the captains of the guard, who protected the entrance of the royal palace.
1 Kings 14:28 Whenever the king would go into the house of the Lord God, the guards would carry the bronze shields before him, and then they would return them to the guardroom.
1 Kings 14:29 The rest of the acts of Rehoboam, and all that he did, behold, they are written in the Book of the Annals of the Kings of Judah.
1 Kings 14:30 And there was continuous warfare between Rehoboam and Jeroboam throughout all their days.
1 Kings 14:31 Then Rehoboam rested with his fathers—meaning, he died and was buried with them in the City of David. His mother's name was Naamah, an Ammonitess. And his son, Abijam, began to reign in his place.
1 Kings 15:1 In the eighteenth year of the reign of Jeroboam, the son of Nabat, Abiam began his reign over the kingdom of Judah.
1 Kings 15:2 He reigned in Jerusalem for three years. His mother's name was Maacha, and she was the daughter of Absalom.
1 Kings 15:3 Abiam persisted in all the sins that his father had committed before him. His heart was not entirely dedicated to the Lord his God, unlike the heart of his ancestor, King David.
1 Kings 15:4 Nevertheless, because of His servant David, the Lord his God granted Abiam a lasting dynasty in Jerusalem, so that He would raise up a son to succeed him and ensure that Jerusalem remained steadfast.
1 Kings 15:5 This was because David had done what was right in the sight of the Lord God and had not turned aside from anything the Lord had commanded him all the days of his life, with the single exception of the matter involving Urias the Hethite.
1 Kings 15:6 There was continuous warfare between Roboam, Abiam's father, and Jeroboam throughout all their days.
1 Kings 15:7 As for the rest of Abiam's acts and all that he did, are these not written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Judah? There was also ongoing war between Abiam and Jeroboam.
1 Kings 15:8 Abiam died and was buried with his ancestors in the city of David. Then his son Asa became king in his place.
1 Kings 15:9 In the twentieth year of Jeroboam's reign over Israel, Asa began to reign as king over Judah.
1 Kings 15:10 He reigned for forty-one years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Maacha, the daughter of Absalom.
1 Kings 15:11 Asa did what was right in the sight of the Lord God, just as his ancestor David had done.
1 Kings 15:12 He expelled the male cult prostitutes from the land and purified Judah of all the abominable idols that his ancestors had made.
1 Kings 15:13 Furthermore, he even removed his queen mother Maacha from her position of authority because she had made a most abominable idol in a sacred grove. Asa cut down this idol and burned it in the Kidron Valley.
1 Kings 15:14 However, he did not remove the high places, the unauthorized altars for worship. Nevertheless, Asa's heart was entirely devoted to the Lord God throughout his entire life.
1 Kings 15:15 Asa also brought into the house of the Lord the silver, gold, and vessels that his father had consecrated through vows, as well as those he himself had consecrated.
1 Kings 15:16 There was continuous warfare between Asa and Baasa, the king of Israel, throughout their reigns.
1 Kings 15:17 Baasa, the king of Israel, went up against Judah and fortified the city of Rama. His intention was to prevent anyone from going out or coming in from Asa's kingdom.
1 Kings 15:18 So Asa took all the remaining silver and gold from the treasuries of the house of the Lord and from the royal palace's treasuries. He entrusted it to his servants and sent them with a message to Benadad, the son of Tabremon, son of Hezion, who was king of Syria and resided in Damascus. Asa's message was:
1 Kings 15:19 Let there be an alliance between you and me, just as there was between my father and your father. I have sent you a gift of silver and gold for this reason: come and break your alliance with Baasa, king of Israel, so that he will withdraw his forces from me.
1 Kings 15:20 Benadad agreed to King Asa's proposal. He sent the commanders of his army to attack the cities of Israel, striking Aion, Dan, Abeldomum Maacha, the entire region of Cineorth, and all the land of Nephthali.
1 Kings 15:21 When Baasa heard this news, he ceased fortifying Rama and returned to Thersa.
1 Kings 15:22 Then King Asa issued a proclamation throughout all Judah, commanding that no one was to be excused from participating. They dismantled the stones and timbers from Rama, which Baasa had used for construction, and King Asa used those materials to fortify Geba of Benjamin and Mizpah.
1 Kings 15:23 As for the rest of Asa's acts, his full strength, all that he accomplished, and the cities he built, are these not written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Judah? However, in his old age, he suffered from a severe disease in his feet.
1 Kings 15:24 Asa died and was buried with his ancestors in the city of David, his forefather. Then his son Josaphat became king in his place.
1 Kings 15:25 Nadab, the son of Jeroboam, began to reign over Israel in the second year of King Asa's reign over Judah. He reigned over Israel for two years.
1 Kings 15:26 He did what was evil in the sight of the Lord God. He walked in the sinful ways of his father Jeroboam and perpetuated the sins by which his father had caused Israel to fall into idolatry.
1 Kings 15:27 Baasa, the son of Ahia, from the tribe of Issachar, conspired against Nadab and struck him down in Gebbethon, a city belonging to the Philistines. At that time, Nadab and all of Israel were besieging Gebbethon.
1 Kings 15:28 So Baasa killed Nadab in the third year of King Asa's reign over Judah and became king in his place.
1 Kings 15:29 Once Baasa became king, he struck down the entire household of Jeroboam. He did not leave alive a single member of Jeroboam's lineage until he had utterly destroyed them all. This was in fulfillment of the word of the Lord God, which He had spoken through His servant Ahia the Shilonite.
1 Kings 15:30 This destruction came about because of the sins Jeroboam had committed, and by which he had caused Israel to sin, and because of the great anger with which he had provoked the Lord God of Israel.
1 Kings 15:31 As for the rest of Nadab's acts and all that he accomplished, are these not written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel?
1 Kings 15:32 There was continuous warfare between Asa and Baasa, the king of Israel, throughout their reigns.
1 Kings 15:33 In the third year of King Asa's reign over Judah, Baasa, the son of Ahia, began to reign over all Israel from Thersa. He reigned for twenty-four years.
1 Kings 15:34 He did what was evil in the sight of the Lord God, walking in the sinful ways of Jeroboam and perpetuating the sins by which Jeroboam had caused Israel to fall into idolatry.
1 Kings 15:1 In the eighteenth year that Jeroboam, the son of Nabat, was king, Abiam began his reign over Judah.
1 Kings 15:2 He reigned for three years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Maacha, daughter of Abessalom.
1 Kings 15:3 He followed all the sinful ways that his father had established before him. His heart was not completely faithful to the Lord his God, unlike the heart of his ancestor David.
1 Kings 15:4 But because of David, His servant, the Lord his God gave him a lamp in Jerusalem—meaning He allowed his lineage to continue after him, ensuring Jerusalem's stability.
1 Kings 15:5 For David had done what was right in the eyes of the Lord and had not turned aside from anything the Lord had commanded him all the days of his life, except in the matter concerning Uriah the Hittite.
1 Kings 15:6 There was also continuous war between Rehoboam and Jeroboam throughout their lives.
1 Kings 15:7 Now, the rest of the acts of Abiam, and all that he did—are these not written in the Book of the Annals of the Kings of Judah? There was also war between Abiam and Jeroboam.
1 Kings 15:8 Abiam then rested with his ancestors—meaning he died—and they buried him in the City of David. His son Asa became king in his place.
1 Kings 15:9 In the twentieth year that Jeroboam was king of Israel, Asa began his reign as king of Judah.
1 Kings 15:10 He reigned for forty-one years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Maacha, daughter of Abessalom —this refers to his queen mother, who was his grandmother.
1 Kings 15:11 Asa did what was right in the sight of the Lord, just as his ancestor David had done.
1 Kings 15:12 He expelled the male cult prostitutes from the land and purified it from all the filthy idols that his ancestors had made.
1 Kings 15:13 Moreover, he removed Maacha, his own queen mother, from her position of power concerning the sacred rites, because she had made an abominable idol for the Asherah grove. Asa then cut down her idol and burned it in the Kidron Valley.
1 Kings 15:14 However, he did not remove the high places of worship. Nevertheless, Asa's heart was completely faithful to the Lord throughout all his days.
1 Kings 15:15 He brought into the House of the Lord the silver, gold, and sacred vessels that his father had consecrated, along with his own consecrated gifts.
1 Kings 15:16 But there was constant warfare between Asa and Baasha, the king of Israel, throughout their lives.
1 Kings 15:17 Baasha, the king of Israel, marched against Judah and began to fortify Ramah, intending to prevent anyone from leaving or entering Asa's kingdom.
1 Kings 15:18 So Asa took all the silver and gold that remained in the treasuries of the House of the Lord and in the king's treasuries. He sent it by the hand of his servants to Ben-Hadad, son of Tabremon, son of Hezion, the king of Syria, who lived in Damascus, saying:
1 Kings 15:19 There is a treaty between me and you, just as there was between my ancestor and your ancestor. Therefore, I have sent you a gift of silver and gold. Come, break your alliance with Baasha, the king of Israel, so that he will withdraw from me.
1 Kings 15:20 Ben-Hadad agreed to King Asa's request and sent the commanders of his army against the cities of Israel. He attacked Ijon, Dan, Abel-Beth-Maachah, and all of Chinneroth, along with the entire land of Naphtali.
1 Kings 15:21 When Baasha heard of this, he stopped fortifying Ramah and returned to Tirzah.
1 Kings 15:22 King Asa then summoned all of Judah, leaving no one behind. They carried away the stones and timber from Ramah that Baasha had been using for construction. King Asa then used these materials to fortify Geba of Benjamin and Mizpah.
1 Kings 15:23 Now, the rest of all the acts of Asa, and all his might, and all that he did, and the cities that he built—are these not written in the Book of the Annals of the Kings of Judah? However, in the time of his old age, he suffered from a severe foot disease.
1 Kings 15:24 Asa then rested with his ancestors—meaning he died—and was buried with them in the City of David, his ancestor. His son Jehoshaphat became king in his place.
1 Kings 15:25 Nadab, the son of Jeroboam, became king over Israel in the second year of King Asa of Judah. He reigned over Israel for two years.
1 Kings 15:26 He did what was evil in the sight of the Lord and walked in the ways of his father, and in the sins by which he had caused Israel to sin.
1 Kings 15:27 Baasha, the son of Ahijah, from the house of Issachar, conspired against him. Baasha struck him down in Gibbethon, a city belonging to the Philistines; for Nadab and all Israel were at that time besieging Gibbethon.
1 Kings 15:28 So Baasha killed Nadab in the third year of King Asa of Judah and became king in his place.
1 Kings 15:29 When Baasha began his reign, he struck down everyone in the house of Jeroboam. He did not leave a single living soul until he had utterly destroyed them all, according to the word of the Lord which He had spoken through His servant Ahijah the Shilonite.
1 Kings 15:30 This was because of Jeroboam's sins, which he had committed and by which he had led Israel into sin. It was also because of the offense by which he had provoked the Lord, the God of Israel, to anger.
1 Kings 15:31 Now, the rest of the acts of Nadab, and all that he did—are these not written in the Book of the Annals of the Kings of Israel?
1 Kings 15:32 There was also continuous warfare between Asa and Baasha, the king of Israel, throughout their lives.
1 Kings 15:33 In the third year of King Asa of Judah, Baasha, the son of Ahijah, began his reign over all Israel in Tirzah. He reigned for twenty-four years.
1 Kings 15:34 He did what was evil in the sight of the Lord and walked in the ways of Jeroboam, and in the sins by which he had caused Israel to sin.
1 Kings 15:35 Then the word of the Lord came to Jehu, the son of Hanani, concerning Baasha, saying:
1 Kings 15:36 Because I elevated you from the dust and appointed you as leader over My people Israel, yet you walked in the ways of Jeroboam and caused My people Israel to sin, provoking Me to anger with their sins:
1 Kings 15:37 Behold, I will utterly sweep away the descendants of Baasha and the descendants of his house. I will make your house like the house of Jeroboam, the son of Nabat.
1 Kings 15:38 Whoever belonging to Baasha dies in the city, dogs will devour him; and whoever belonging to him dies in the open country, the birds of the sky will consume him.
1 Kings 15:39 Now, the rest of the acts of Baasha, and all that he did, and his mighty deeds—are these not written in the Book of the Annals of the Kings of Israel?
1 Kings 15:40 Baasha then rested with his ancestors—meaning he died—and was buried in Tirzah. His son Elah became king in his place.
1 Kings 16:1 Therefore, the Lord God gave His message to Jehu, the son of Hanani, a prophet, directly against King Baasha, saying:
1 Kings 16:2 “I raised you up from nothing, and I made you the ruler over My people, Israel. But you have behaved exactly like King Jeroboam.
1 Kings 16:3 You have caused My people, Israel, to sin, and you have provoked My anger with their sins. Because of this, I will utterly wipe out Baasha and his entire family line.
1 Kings 16:4 I will make your family like the family of Jeroboam, the son of Nebat. Those who die from Baasha’s family in the city will be eaten by dogs, and those who die in the field will be eaten by the birds of the sky.”
1 Kings 16:5 All the other events concerning King Baasha, everything he did, and all his battles — these are recorded in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel, are they not?
1 Kings 16:6 So Baasha died and was buried in Tirzah. Then his son, Ela, became king after him.
1 Kings 16:7 Indeed, the Lord’s message had come through the prophet Jehu, son of Hanani, against Baasha and his household. This was because of all the evil he had done in the sight of the Lord, provoking Him to anger with the work of his hands, making his house become like the house of Jeroboam. For this very reason, Jehu, the son of Hanani the prophet, had struck him down.
1 Kings 16:8 In the twenty-sixth year of King Asa’s reign in Judah, Ela, the son of Baasha, began to reign over Israel in Tirzah. He reigned for two years.
1 Kings 16:9 Then Zambri, one of his officials who commanded half his chariots, conspired against him. One day, Ela was in Tirzah, drinking himself drunk in the house of Arsa, who was in charge of the palace there.
1 Kings 16:10 Zambri entered and struck him down, killing him. This happened in the twenty-seventh year of King Asa’s reign in Judah. Then Zambri became king in Ela’s place.
1 Kings 16:11 As soon as Zambri began to reign and was seated on Ela’s throne, he wiped out Baasha’s entire family line. He left no male alive, nor any of his relatives or friends.
1 Kings 16:12 So Zambri destroyed Baasha’s entire family, exactly as the Lord God had spoken to Baasha through the prophet Jehu.
1 Kings 16:13 This was for all the sins of Baasha and the sins of his son Ela. They had sinned and had led Israel into sin, provoking the Lord God of Israel with their empty idols.
1 Kings 16:14 All the other events concerning King Ela and everything he did — these are recorded in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel, are they not?
1 Kings 16:15 In the twenty-seventh year of King Asa’s reign in Judah, Zambri reigned for seven days in Tirzah. At this time, the Israelite army was besieging Gibbethon, a city belonging to the Philistines.
1 Kings 16:16 When the army and all Israel heard that Zambri had rebelled and had killed the king, all Israel proclaimed Amri, the commander of the army, as their king right there in the camp on that very day.
1 Kings 16:17 So Amri and all Israel with him marched up from Gibbethon and besieged Tirzah.
1 Kings 16:18 When Zambri saw that the city was about to be captured, he went into the royal palace. He then set fire to the palace and burned himself to death inside it.
1 Kings 16:19 He died because of the sins he had committed. He had done evil in the sight of the Lord, following the path of Jeroboam and the sins by which Jeroboam had caused Israel to sin.
1 Kings 16:20 All the other events concerning King Zambri and his conspiracy — these are recorded in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel, are they not?
1 Kings 16:21 At that time, the people of Israel were divided into two factions. One half of the people followed Thebni, the son of Gyneth, wanting him to be king, while the other half followed Amri.
1 Kings 16:22 However, the people supporting Amri eventually became stronger than the people supporting Thebni, son of Gyneth. So Thebni died, and Amri became the sole king.
1 Kings 16:23 In the thirty-first year of King Asa’s reign in Judah, Amri began to reign over Israel for a total of twelve years. He reigned in Tirzah for six of those years.
1 Kings 16:24 Amri bought the hill of Samaria from Semer for two talents of silver. He built a city on this hill and named the city he built Samaria, after Semer, the original owner of the hill.
1 Kings 16:25 Amri did evil in the sight of the Lord God. He acted with greater wickedness than all the kings who had been before him.
1 Kings 16:26 He walked in every way of Jeroboam, the son of Nebat, and in his sins by which Jeroboam had caused Israel to sin. This was so he would provoke the Lord God of Israel to anger with their worthless idols.
1 Kings 16:27 All the other events concerning King Amri, and the battles he fought — these are recorded in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel, are they not?
1 Kings 16:28 So Amri died and was buried in Samaria. Then his son, Achab, became king after him.
1 Kings 16:29 Achab, the son of Amri, began to reign over Israel in the thirty-eighth year of King Asa’s reign in Judah. Achab, the son of Amri, reigned over Israel in Samaria for twenty-two years.
1 Kings 16:30 Achab, the son of Amri, did even more evil in the sight of the Lord God than all the kings who had been before him.
1 Kings 16:31 It was not enough for him merely to follow in the sins of Jeroboam, the son of Nebat. Additionally, he married Jezabel, the daughter of Ethbaal, king of the Sidonians. Then he went and served Baal, even worshipping him.
1 Kings 16:32 He even erected an altar for Baal in the temple of Baal, which he had built in Samaria.
1 Kings 16:33 He also set up a sacred pole for Asherah. Achab did more to provoke the Lord God of Israel to anger than all the kings of Israel who had been before him.
1 Kings 16:34 In Achab’s days, Hiel of Bethel rebuilt Jericho. He laid its foundation at the cost of his firstborn son Abiram, and he set up its gates at the cost of his youngest son Segub. This happened exactly as the Lord God had spoken through Joshua, the son of Nun, many years before.
