1 Kings 16:1 The Lord’s message then came to Jehu, who was a prophet and the son of Hanani. This message was against Baasa, and it said:
1 Kings 16:2 “I raised you from obscurity and appointed you as leader over my people, Israel. But you followed the ways of Jeroboam, and you caused my people Israel to sin, thereby provoking My anger with your sins.
1 Kings 16:3 Behold, I will wipe out all of Baasa’s descendants and his entire household. I will make your household like that of Jeroboam, the son of Nebat.
1 Kings 16:4 Anyone from Baasa’s household who dies in the city will be eaten by dogs. And anyone from his household who dies in the open country will be eaten by the birds of the sky.”
1 Kings 16:5 The rest of Baasa’s deeds, all that he accomplished, and his battles—are these not all written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel?
1 Kings 16:6 Baasa then rested with his ancestors and was buried in Thirsa. Then his son Ela reigned in his place.
1 Kings 16:7 Indeed, through the prophet Jehu, son of Hanani, the Lord’s message also came against Baasa and against his household. This was because of all the evil he had done before the Lord, provoking Him to anger with the works of his own hands, so that his household would become like the household of Jeroboam. For this reason, the Lord struck him down, as declared by Jehu, the prophet and son of Hanani.
1 Kings 16:8 In the twenty-sixth year of King Asa of Judah’s reign, Ela, Baasa’s son, began to reign over Israel in Thirsa. He reigned for two years.
1 Kings 16:9 Then his servant Zamri conspired against him. Zamri was the commander of half of Ela’s chariots. Ela, meanwhile, was in Thirsa, drinking and getting drunk in the house of Arsa, who was in charge of Thirsa’s palace.
1 Kings 16:10 So Zamri rushed in, attacked, and killed Ela in the twenty-seventh year of King Asa of Judah’s reign. Then Zamri reigned in Ela’s place.
1 Kings 16:11 As soon as Zamri began to reign and was seated on Ela’s throne, he struck down Baasa’s entire household. He did not leave alive a single male from Baasa’s family, nor any of his relatives or friends.
1 Kings 16:12 So Zamri completely destroyed Baasa’s entire household, just as the Lord had declared against Baasa through the prophet Jehu.
1 Kings 16:13 This destruction was for all the sins of Baasa and the sins of his son Ela, which they committed and which they caused Israel to commit, thereby provoking the Lord, the God of Israel, to anger with their worthless idols.
1 Kings 16:14 The rest of Ela’s deeds, and all that he accomplished—are these not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel?
1 Kings 16:15 In the month of Theboth, in the twenty-seventh year of King Asa of Judah’s reign, Zamri reigned for seven days in Thirsa. Meanwhile, the army of Israel was besieging Gabathon, a city of the Philistines.
1 Kings 16:16 When the people who were besieging Gabathon heard that Zamri had conspired and killed the king, all the people of Israel appointed their army commander, Amri, as king over Israel that very day.
1 Kings 16:17 So Amri and all Israel with him marched up from Gabathon and besieged Thirsa.
1 Kings 16:18 When Zamri saw that the city was about to be captured, he went into the king’s palace and set fire to himself along with the palace. Thus he died.
1 Kings 16:19 He died because of his sins, which he had committed by doing evil in the Lord’s sight, by following the way of Jeroboam, and by the sins with which he had caused Israel to sin.
1 Kings 16:20 The rest of Zamri’s deeds, his conspiracy, and his acts of tyranny—are these not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel?
1 Kings 16:21 Then the people of Israel were divided into two factions. Half of the people followed Thebni, son of Gineth, wanting him to be king, while the other half followed Amri.
1 Kings 16:22 However, Amri’s supporters proved stronger than the supporters of Thebni, son of Gineth. So Thebni died, and Amri began to reign.
1 Kings 16:23 In the thirty-first year of King Asa of Judah’s reign, Amri began to reign over Israel for twelve years. He reigned in Thirsa for six of those years.
1 Kings 16:24 He bought the hill of Samaria from Shemer for one hundred talents of silver. He built a city on this hill and named the city he founded Samaria, after Shemer, the original owner of the hill.
1 Kings 16:25 Amri did evil in the Lord’s sight, acting more wickedly than all who had come before him.
1 Kings 16:26 He followed the path of Jeroboam, son of Nebat, and continued in his sins, which caused Israel to sin. This provoked the Lord, the God of Israel, to anger with their worthless idols.
1 Kings 16:27 The rest of Amri’s deeds, and the battles he fought—are these not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel?
1 Kings 16:28 Amri then rested with his ancestors and was buried in Samaria. His son Achab reigned in his place.
1 Kings 16:29 Achab, Amri’s son, began to reign over Israel in the thirty-eighth year of King Asa of Judah’s reign. Achab, Amri’s son, reigned over Israel in Samaria for twenty-two years.
1 Kings 16:30 Achab, Amri’s son, did more evil in the Lord’s sight than all who had come before him.
1 Kings 16:31 It was not enough for him to follow the sins of Jeroboam, son of Nebat. Additionally, he took Jezabel, the daughter of Ethbaal, king of the Sidonians, as his wife. Then he went and served Baal and worshipped him.
1 Kings 16:32 He even built an altar for Baal in the temple of Baal, which he had constructed in Samaria.
1 Kings 16:33 Achab also made an idolatrous pole and continued to do more to provoke the Lord, the God of Israel, to anger than all the kings of Israel who had come before him.
1 Kings 16:34 In Achab’s days, Hiel of Bethel rebuilt Jericho. He laid its foundation at the cost of his firstborn son, Abiram, and he set up its gates at the cost of his youngest son, Segub. This happened exactly as the Lord had declared through Josue, son of Nun, many years before.
1 Kings 16:1 Now, the word of the Lord came to Jehu, the son of Hanani, who was a prophet. It was a word against Baasa, saying:
1 Kings 16:2 Because I raised you up from the dust, and I appointed you as a leader over my people, Israel, yet you walked in the ways of Jeroboam. You made my people, Israel, commit sin, thus provoking me to anger with their sins.
1 Kings 16:3 Therefore, behold, I will completely sweep away Baasa's descendants, and the descendants of his household. I will make your household like the household of Jeroboam, the son of Nabat.
1 Kings 16:4 Those of Baasa's family who die within the city will be devoured by dogs. And those of his family who die out in the countryside will be consumed by the birds of the sky.
1 Kings 16:5 Now, the rest of the acts of Baasa, and all that he accomplished, and his battles—are these not recorded in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel?
1 Kings 16:6 So Baasa passed away and was buried in Thersa. Then his son Ela became king in his place.
1 Kings 16:7 Indeed, it was through the hand of Jehu, the son of Hanani, the prophet, that the word of the Lord came against Baasa and against his household. It was against all the wickedness he had done before the Lord, provoking Him to anger with the works of his own hands—so that his house would become like the house of Jeroboam. It was for this very reason that the Lord's judgment brought about his end, as pronounced by Jehu, the son of Hanani, the prophet.
1 Kings 16:8 In the twenty-sixth year of Asa, king of Judah, Ela, the son of Baasa, began to reign over Israel in Thersa. He reigned for two years.
1 Kings 16:9 And Zambri, his servant and the captain of half his chariots, rebelled against him. Now, Ela was in Thersa, drinking excessively and indulging himself in the house of Arsa, who was the governor of Thersa.
1 Kings 16:10 Zambri went in, struck him down, and killed him. This happened in the twenty-seventh year of Asa, king of Judah, and then Zambri became king in Ela's place.
1 Kings 16:11 As soon as Zambri began his reign and took his seat on the throne, he struck down the entire household of Baasa. He did not leave alive a single male descendant, nor any of his relatives or friends.
1 Kings 16:12 So Zambri completely destroyed the entire household of Baasa. This was exactly according to the word of the Lord, which He had spoken through Jehu the prophet, against Baasa.
1 Kings 16:13 This destruction was on account of all the sins of Baasa, and the sins of his son Ela. They sinned themselves and also caused Israel to sin, provoking the Lord, the God of Israel, to anger with their worthless idols.
1 Kings 16:14 Now, the rest of the acts of Ela, and all that he accomplished—are these not recorded in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel?
1 Kings 16:15 In the twenty-seventh year of Asa, king of Judah, Zambri reigned for only seven days in Thersa. At that time, the Israelite army was besieging Gebbethon, a city of the Philistines.
1 Kings 16:16 When the army besieging the city, and all of Israel, heard that Zambri had taken the kingdom by force and had murdered the king, all of Israel, on that very day, in the military camp, appointed Omri, the commander of the army, as king over Israel.
1 Kings 16:17 So Omri, with all of Israel who were with him, marched up from Gebbethon and laid siege to Thersa.
1 Kings 16:18 When Zambri saw that the city was being captured and that he himself was about to be overcome, he went into the royal palace, to the inner citadel of the king's house. He then set the king's house on fire around himself, and he died in the flames.
1 Kings 16:19 This was due to his sins, which he committed by doing evil in the sight of the Lord. He walked in the way of Jeroboam, and in his sin, he led Israel to sin.
1 Kings 16:20 Now, the rest of the acts of Zambri, and his conspiracy and his tyrannical rule—are these not recorded in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel?
1 Kings 16:21 At that time, the people of Israel were divided into two factions. Half of the people followed Thebni, the son of Gineth, wanting him to be king, while the other half followed Omri.
1 Kings 16:22 However, the people who were with Omri proved stronger than the people who followed Thebni, the son of Gineth. So Thebni died, and Omri began to reign.
1 Kings 16:23 In the thirty-first year of Asa, king of Judah, Omri became king over Israel. He reigned for twelve years in total, and for six of those years, he reigned in Thersa.
1 Kings 16:24 He then purchased the hill of Samaria from Semer for four hundred talents of silver. He built a city on that hill, and he named the city he had constructed Samaria, after Semer, the original owner of the hill.
1 Kings 16:25 Omri did evil in the sight of the Lord, and he acted more wickedly than all those who had been kings before him.
1 Kings 16:26 He walked in every way of Jeroboam, the son of Nabat, and in the sins by which Jeroboam had caused Israel to sin. Omri did all of this to provoke the Lord, the God of Israel, to anger with their worthless idols.
1 Kings 16:27 Now, the rest of the acts of Omri, and all the works he accomplished, and his battles—are these not recorded in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel?
1 Kings 16:28 So Omri passed away and was buried in Samaria. Then his son Achab became king in his place.
1 Kings 16:29 Achab, the son of Omri, became king over Israel in the thirty-eighth year of Asa, king of Judah. Achab, the son of Omri, reigned over Israel in Samaria for twenty-two years.
1 Kings 16:30 Achab, the son of Omri, did more evil in the sight of the Lord than all the kings who had been before him.
1 Kings 16:31 It was not enough for him merely to walk in the sins of Jeroboam, the son of Nabat. In addition, he took Jezabel, the daughter of Ethbaal, king of the Sidonians, as his wife. Then he went and served Baal, and he worshipped that false god.
1 Kings 16:32 He even erected an altar for Baal inside the temple of Baal, which he had built in Samaria.
1 Kings 16:33 He also made an Asherah pole—a pagan idol dedicated to a goddess. Achab added even more wicked deeds, surpassing all the kings of Israel who had been before him, all in order to provoke the Lord, the God of Israel, to anger.
1 Kings 16:34 In Achab's days, Hiel of Bethel rebuilt Jericho. He laid its foundation at the cost of his firstborn son, Abiram, and he set up its gates at the cost of his youngest son, Segub. This happened according to the word of the Lord, which He had spoken through Joshua, the son of Nun, many centuries earlier.
1 Kings 17:1 And Elijah the Tishbite, one of the settlers from Gilead, said to King Ahab: "As the Lord God of Israel lives, in whose presence I serve, there will be no dew or rain for the coming years, unless I command it by my word."
1 Kings 17:2 And the word of the Lord came to Elijah, saying:
1 Kings 17:3 "Leave this place, and go east. Hide yourself in the Cherith Ravine, which is on the eastern side of the Jordan River."
1 Kings 17:4 "And there you will drink from the ravine. I have commanded ravens to feed you there."
1 Kings 17:5 So Elijah went and did as the Lord had commanded him. He went and stayed by the Cherith Ravine, which faces the Jordan River.
1 Kings 17:6 Ravens brought him bread and meat in the morning, and bread and meat in the evening. And he drank from the ravine.
1 Kings 17:7 And it happened after a number of days that the ravine dried up, because no rain had fallen on the land.
1 Kings 17:8 Then the word of the Lord came to him, saying:
1 Kings 17:9 "Arise and go to Zarephath, which belongs to Sidon, and stay there. For I have commanded a widow woman there to provide for you."
1 Kings 17:10 So Elijah arose and went to Zarephath. When he came to the city gate, he saw a widow woman there gathering sticks. He called out to her and said, "Please bring me a little water in a cup, so I can drink."
1 Kings 17:11 As she was going to get it, Elijah called after her, saying, "Please, also bring me a small piece of bread with you."
1 Kings 17:12 She answered, "As the Lord your God lives, I have no bread, only a handful of flour in a jar and a little oil in a jug. Look, I am gathering two sticks so I can go home and prepare it for myself and my son, so we can eat it and then die."
1 Kings 17:13 Elijah said to her, "Do not be afraid. Go and do as you have said, but first make a small flat cake for me from your flour and bring it to me. Afterwards, you can prepare some for yourself and your son."
1 Kings 17:14 "For this is what the Lord God of Israel declares: 'The jar of flour will not be emptied, and the jug of oil will not run dry, until the day the Lord sends rain upon the face of the earth.'"
1 Kings 17:15 So she went and did as Elijah told her. And she, and her household, and Elijah, had enough to eat for many days.
1 Kings 17:16 And the jar of flour did not run out, nor did the jug of oil diminish, just as the Lord had promised through Elijah.
1 Kings 17:17 Now it happened after these events that the son of the woman, who owned the house, became ill. His sickness was so severe that he stopped breathing and no life remained in him.
1 Kings 17:18 So she said to Elijah, "What have you done to me, O man of God? Have you come to remind me of my sins and to cause the death of my son?"
1 Kings 17:19 And Elijah said to her, "Give me your son." He took the boy from her arms, carried him up to the upper room where he was staying, and laid him on his own bed.
1 Kings 17:20 Then he cried out to the Lord, "O Lord my God, have You brought this tragedy upon the widow with whom I am staying, by causing her son to die?"
1 Kings 17:21 Then Elijah stretched himself out on the boy three times. And he cried out to the Lord, "O Lord my God, please let the life breath of this boy return to his body!"
1 Kings 17:22 And the Lord listened to Elijah's prayer. The life breath of the boy returned to him, and he revived.
1 Kings 17:23 Then Elijah took the boy and brought him down from the upper room into the house below. He gave him to his mother and said, "See, your son is alive!"
1 Kings 17:24 And the woman said to Elijah, "Now I know by this that you truly are a man of God, and that the word of the Lord spoken through you is true."
1 Kings 18:1 After many days—specifically, in the third year of the drought—a message from the Lord came to Elijah, saying: "Go and present yourself to King Ahab, so that I may send rain upon the earth."
1 Kings 18:2 So Elijah went to present himself to Ahab. There was a severe famine throughout Samaria, the capital city of Israel and its surrounding region.
1 Kings 18:3 King Ahab had called Obadiah, who was the chief steward of his royal household. Obadiah, for his part, greatly feared and reverenced the Lord.
1 Kings 18:4 For when Jezebel, the queen, was slaughtering the prophets of the Lord—who spoke truly for God—Obadiah had taken one hundred of these prophets and hidden them, fifty in one cave and fifty in another, and he had secretly provided them with food and water.
1 Kings 18:5 So King Ahab said to Obadiah: "Go throughout the land to all the springs of water and to all the valleys. Perhaps we will find enough grass to save the horses and mules, so that all the animals do not perish entirely."
1 Kings 18:6 Then they divided the land between themselves to search for water: Ahab went one way alone, and Obadiah went another way alone.
1 Kings 18:7 While Obadiah was on his way, Elijah suddenly met him. When Obadiah recognized Elijah, he fell on his face and said, "Is it really you, my master Elijah?"
1 Kings 18:8 And Elijah responded: "It is I. Go and tell your master, 'Behold, Elijah is here!'
1 Kings 18:9 Obadiah then said: "What sin have I committed, that you would hand over your servant into the hand of Ahab, so that he may kill me?"
1 Kings 18:10 "As the Lord your God lives, there is no nation or kingdom where my master, King Ahab, has not sent messengers to search for you. And when they replied, 'He is not here,' he made those kingdoms and nations swear an oath that you could not be found, so determined was he to find you or confirmation of your absence."
1 Kings 18:11 "And now you tell me: 'Go and tell your master: Behold, Elijah is here!'"
1 Kings 18:12 "For as soon as I leave you, the Spirit of the Lord will carry you away to a place I do not know. Then, when I go and report to Ahab that you are here, and he doesn't find you, he will kill me. And I, your servant, have feared the Lord since my youth!"
1 Kings 18:13 "Has it not been reported to you, my master, what I did when Jezebel was slaughtering the prophets of the Lord? How I hid a hundred men of the Lord's prophets, fifty by fifty in caves, and fed them with bread and water?"
1 Kings 18:14 "And now you tell me: 'Go and tell your master: Behold, Elijah is here!' This will surely result in him killing me."
1 Kings 18:15 Then Elijah said: "As the Lord of hosts lives, in whose presence I stand—meaning I am His servant ready to do His will—I tell you for certain that today I will appear before King Ahab."
1 Kings 18:16 So Obadiah went to meet Ahab and informed him. And Ahab then went to meet Elijah.
1 Kings 18:17 When Ahab saw Elijah, he said: "Is it really you, the one who troubles Israel by causing this famine and distress?"
1 Kings 18:18 And Elijah replied: "I have not troubled Israel, but you and the house of your father have troubled it, because you have forsaken the Lord, the true God, and have followed the false gods known as the Baalim."
1 Kings 18:19 "Nevertheless, now send word and gather all Israel to me on Mount Carmel. Also gather the four hundred and fifty prophets of Baal, and the four hundred prophets of the Asherah poles—idols of a false goddess—who are supported and eat at Jezebel's table."
1 Kings 18:20 Ahab sent out word to all the children of Israel and gathered the prophets to Mount Carmel.
1 Kings 18:21 Then Elijah approached all the people and said: "How long will you waver and limp between two opinions, unable to make a choice? If the Lord is truly God, then follow Him! But if Baal is god, then follow him!" And the people did not answer him a single word.
1 Kings 18:22 Elijah then said to the people: "I alone remain as a prophet of the Lord, whereas the prophets of Baal are four hundred and fifty men."
1 Kings 18:23 "Let two oxen be given to us. Let them choose one ox for themselves, cut it into pieces, and place it on the wood, but let them not put fire underneath it. Then I will prepare the other ox, and I will place it on the wood, and I will not put fire underneath it."
1 Kings 18:24 "You are to call upon the names of your gods, and I will call upon the name of my Lord. And the God who answers by sending fire—He is truly God." And all the people answered and said, "This is an excellent proposal!"
1 Kings 18:25 So Elijah said to the prophets of Baal: "Choose one ox for yourselves and prepare it first, since there are many of you. And call upon the names of your gods, but do not put fire underneath."
1 Kings 18:26 When they had taken the ox that had been given to them, they prepared it. And they called upon the name of Baal from morning until noon, saying: "Baal, hear us!" But there was no voice, nor anyone who answered. And they kept leaping around the altar that they had made in a frenzied dance.
1 Kings 18:27 And when it was already noon, Elijah mocked them, saying: "Cry out with a louder voice! For he is a god, surely, and perhaps he is speaking to someone, or he is in a private place, or he is on a journey, or perhaps he is sleeping and needs to be awakened."
1 Kings 18:28 So they cried out with a loud voice, and, according to their custom, they cut themselves with knives and lances until they were drenched with their own blood.
1 Kings 18:29 After noon, and when the regular hours for their prophecy had passed, they continued their prophetic frenzy according to their custom until the time of the evening sacrifice. But there was no voice, no one who answered, and no one who paid any attention.
1 Kings 18:30 Then Elijah said to all the people: "Come closer to me." And all the people came closer to him. And he repaired the altar of the Lord that had been torn down.
1 Kings 18:31 Elijah took twelve stones, according to the number of the tribes of the sons of Jacob—to whom the word of the Lord had come, saying, "Israel shall be your name."
1 Kings 18:32 And with these stones, he built an altar in the name of the Lord. He then made a trench around the altar, large enough to contain two measures of grain.
1 Kings 18:33 He arranged the wood, and cutting the ox into pieces, he placed it on the wood.
1 Kings 18:34 And he said: "Fill four jars with water and pour it over the burnt offering and over the wood." Again he said: "Do it a second time." And when they had done it a second time, he said: "Do it a third time also." And they did it a third time.
1 Kings 18:35 The water flowed all around the altar and even filled the trench completely.
1 Kings 18:36 And when it was time to offer the evening burnt offering, Elijah the prophet approached and said: "O Lord, God of Abraham, Isaac, and Israel, today let it be known that You are God in Israel, and that I am Your servant, and that I have done all these things at Your command."
1 Kings 18:37 "Hear me, O Lord, hear me! Let this people know today that You, O Lord, are the true God, and that You have turned their hearts back to You once more."
1 Kings 18:38 Then the fire of the Lord fell from heaven and consumed the burnt offering, the wood, the stones, and even the dust, and licked up all the water that was in the trench.
1 Kings 18:39 And when all the people saw this, they fell on their faces and exclaimed: "The Lord—He alone is God! The Lord—He alone is God!"
1 Kings 18:40 Elijah then said to them: "Seize the prophets of Baal! Let not one of them escape!" And when they had seized them, Elijah led them down to the Brook Kishon and killed them there, executing judgment on false prophets according to the Law of Moses.
1 Kings 19:1 Achab then told Jezabel everything that Elias had done, and how he had killed all the prophets with a sword.
1 Kings 19:2 So Jezabel sent a messenger to Elias, saying: "May the gods strike me down and do more if, by this time tomorrow, I do not make your life like the life of one of those prophets you killed."
1 Kings 19:3 Therefore Elias was afraid, and he arose and went wherever his will led him. He came to Bersabee, which belongs to Juda, and left his servant there.
1 Kings 19:4 But Elias himself went a day's journey into the wilderness. When he arrived, he sat down under a juniper tree and prayed that he might die, saying: "It is enough, O Lord. Take my life, for I am no better than my ancestors."
1 Kings 19:5 He then laid down and fell asleep in the shade of the juniper tree. And behold, an angel touched him and said: "Arise, and eat."
1 Kings 19:6 He looked up and saw, right by his head, a cake baked on hot stones and a jar of water. He ate, drank, and then lay down to sleep again.
1 Kings 19:7 Then the angel of the Lord returned a second time and touched him, saying: "Arise and eat, for you have a long journey ahead of you."
1 Kings 19:8 So Elias arose, ate, and drank. And strengthened by that food, he walked for forty days and forty nights until he reached Horeb, the mount of God.
1 Kings 19:9 When he arrived there, he stayed in a cave. And behold, the word of the Lord came to him, saying: "What are you doing here, Elias?"
1 Kings 19:10 Elias responded: "I am consumed with zeal for the Lord, God of all creation's armies, because the children of Israel have abandoned your covenant. They have torn down your altars and killed your prophets with the sword. I alone am left, and they are seeking to take my life."
1 Kings 19:11 Then the Lord said to him: "Go out and stand on the mountain before the Lord." And behold, the Lord was passing by. A great and strong wind tore the mountains apart and broke rocks before the Lord, but the Lord was not in the wind.
1 Kings 19:12 After the wind came an earthquake, but the Lord was not in the earthquake. After the earthquake came fire, but the Lord was not in the fire. And after the fire, there was the whisper of a gentle breeze.
1 Kings 19:13 And when Elias heard it, he covered his face with his cloak and went out, standing at the entrance of the cave. And behold, a voice came to him, saying: "What are you doing here, Elias?"
1 Kings 19:14 Elias responded: "I am consumed with zeal for the Lord, God of all creation's armies, because the children of Israel have abandoned your covenant. They have torn down your altars and killed your prophets with the sword. I alone am left, and they are seeking to take my life."
1 Kings 19:15 Then the Lord said to him: "Go, return on your way through the wilderness to Damascus. When you arrive there, you are to anoint Hazaël as king over Syria."
1 Kings 19:16 You shall also anoint Jehu, the son of Namsi, as king over Israel. And Eliseus, the son of Saphat, from Abelmeula, you shall anoint as prophet in your place.
1 Kings 19:17 And it shall be that whoever escapes the sword of Hazaël, Jehu will put him to death. And whoever escapes the sword of Jehu, Eliseus will put him to death.
1 Kings 19:18 Yet I will preserve for myself seven thousand in Israel: all the knees that have not bowed to Baal, and every mouth that has not worshipped him.
1 Kings 19:19 So Elias departed from that place and found Eliseus, the son of Saphat, plowing with twelve pairs of oxen. He himself was with the twelfth pair. And when Elias came to him, he threw his cloak over him — a symbolic gesture of calling and succession.
1 Kings 19:20 Immediately, Eliseus left the oxen and ran after Elias. He said: "Please let me kiss my father and my mother, and then I will follow you." Elias replied: "Go, and return. For what was my part, I have done to you."
1 Kings 19:21 So Eliseus returned from Elias, took a pair of oxen, and sacrificed them. He cooked their meat using the wooden parts of the plows as fuel, and gave it to the people, and they ate. Then he arose, went after Elias, and served him.
1 Kings 19:1 And Ahab told Jezebel everything Elijah had done, and how Elijah had executed all the false prophets with a sword.
1 Kings 19:2 So Jezebel sent a messenger to Elijah with a message: 'May my gods do to me and more also if, by this time tomorrow, I do not make your life like the life of one of those prophets he killed.'
1 Kings 19:3 Elijah was afraid, so he got up and went wherever he felt led to flee. He came to Beersheba in Judah and left his servant there.
1 Kings 19:4 Then he himself traveled into the desert, a day's journey. When he arrived, he sat down under a single juniper tree. He prayed for himself to die and said, 'I have had enough, Lord. Take my life, for I am no better than my ancestors.'
1 Kings 19:5 He lay down and fell asleep in the shade of the juniper tree. Suddenly, an angel touched him and said to him, 'Get up and eat!'
1 Kings 19:6 He looked, and there by his head was a freshly baked loaf of bread and a jar of water. So he ate and drank, and then lay down and fell asleep again.
1 Kings 19:7 And the angel of the Lord returned a second time and touched him and said to him, 'Get up and eat, for you have a long journey ahead of you.'
1 Kings 19:8 So he got up, ate, and drank. And he walked for forty days and forty nights, sustained by the strength of that food, until he reached Horeb, the mountain of God.
1 Kings 19:9 When he arrived there, he stayed in a cave. And behold, the word of the Lord came to him and said to him, 'What are you doing here, Elijah?'
1 Kings 19:10 He answered, 'I have been very zealous for the Lord, the God of Hosts, because the children of Israel have abandoned Your covenant. They have torn down Your altars, and they have executed Your prophets with a sword. And I am left all alone, and they are seeking to take my life away.'
1 Kings 19:11 And He said to him, 'Go out and stand on the mountain before the Lord.' And behold, the Lord is about to pass by. And a great and powerful wind began to tear apart the mountains and shatter rocks before the Lord, but the Lord was not in the wind.
1 Kings 19:12 After the wind, there was an earthquake, but the Lord was not in the earthquake. After the earthquake, there was a fire, but the Lord was not in the fire. And after the fire, there was the soft sound of a gentle breeze.
1 Kings 19:13 And when Elijah heard it, he covered his face with his cloak, and went out and stood at the entrance of the cave. And behold, a voice came to him saying, 'What are you doing here, Elijah?'
1 Kings 19:14 He answered, 'I have been very zealous for the Lord, the God of Hosts, because the children of Israel have abandoned Your covenant. They have torn down Your altars, and they have executed Your prophets with a sword. And I am left all alone, and they are seeking to take my life away.'
1 Kings 19:15 And the Lord said to him, 'Go, and return by your path through the desert toward Damascus. And when you arrive there, you are to anoint Hazael as king over Syria.'
1 Kings 19:16 You are also to anoint Jehu, the son of Nimshi, as king over Israel. And Elisha, the son of Shaphat, who is from Abel-meholah, you are to anoint as prophet in your place.
1 Kings 19:17 And it shall come to pass that whoever escapes Hazael's sword, Jehu will kill them. And whoever escapes Jehu's sword, Elisha will kill them.
1 Kings 19:18 And I will preserve for Myself in Israel seven thousand people, all whose knees have not bowed down before Baal, and every mouth that has not worshiped him.
1 Kings 19:19 So Elijah departed from there and found Elisha, the son of Shaphat, plowing with twelve teams of oxen; he himself was guiding the twelfth team. When Elijah came to him, he threw his cloak over him.
1 Kings 19:20 Immediately, he left the oxen and ran after Elijah and said, 'Please allow me to go kiss my father and mother goodbye, and then I will follow you.' And Elijah said to him, 'Go and return! For what have I done to hinder you?'
1 Kings 19:21 So Elisha returned from him. He took a yoke of oxen and slaughtered them as a sacrifice, and with the plowing equipment, he cooked the meat and gave it to the people, and they ate. Then he got up, went, followed Elijah, and served him.
1 Kings 19:1 And Ahab informed Jezebel about everything Elijah had done, including how he had killed all the false prophets of Baal with a sword.
1 Kings 19:2 So Jezebel sent a messenger to Elijah, saying: 'May *my* pagan gods do this to me, and even more severe punishment add to it, if by this time tomorrow I do not make your life like the life of one of those false prophets Elijah killed!'
1 Kings 19:3 So Elijah was afraid, and rising, he left and went wherever his spirit carried him. He came to Beer-sheba in Judah, and he left his servant boy there.
1 Kings 19:4 And he himself went a day's journey into the wilderness. When he arrived, and sat under a broom tree, he asked for his life to end, and he said: 'It is enough for me now, O Lord; take away my life, for I am no better than my ancestors!'
1 Kings 19:5 And he lay down and fell asleep in the shade of the broom tree. And behold, an angel of the Lord touched him and said to him: 'Rise and eat.'
1 Kings 19:6 He looked, and behold, at his head was a hearth-cake—bread baked on hot stones—and a jar of water. And he ate and drank, and lay down to sleep again.
1 Kings 19:7 And the angel of the Lord returned a second time and touched him, and said to him: 'Rise and eat, for a long journey still awaits you.'
1 Kings 19:8 So he rose, and ate and drank, and he walked in the strength of that food for forty days and forty nights, all the way to Horeb, the mountain of God.
1 Kings 19:9 When he arrived there, he stayed in a cave. And behold, the word of the Lord came to him, and said to him: 'What are you doing here, Elijah?'
1 Kings 19:10 He responded: 'I have been very zealous for the Lord, the God of armies and heavenly hosts, because the children of Israel have abandoned your covenant. They have destroyed your altars, and they have killed your prophets with the sword. And I alone am left, and they seek to take my life away.'
1 Kings 19:11 And He said to him: 'Go out and stand on the mountain before the Lord.' And behold, the Lord passed by, and a great and strong wind tore down the mountains and shattered rocks before the Lord. But the Lord was not in that violent wind.
1 Kings 19:12 And after the wind, there was an earthquake, but the Lord was not in the earthquake. And after the earthquake, there was a fire, but the Lord was not in the fire. And after the fire, there was the sound of a gentle, soft whisper.
1 Kings 19:13 When Elijah heard it, he covered his face with his mantle, and went out and stood at the entrance of the cave. And behold, a voice came to him, saying: 'What are you doing here, Elijah?'
1 Kings 19:14 He responded: 'I have been very zealous for the Lord, the God of armies and heavenly hosts, because the children of Israel have abandoned your covenant. They have destroyed your altars, and they have killed your prophets with the sword. And I alone am left, and they seek to take my life away.'
1 Kings 19:15 And the Lord said to him: 'Go, and return on your way through the wilderness to Damascus. And when you arrive there, you shall anoint Hazael as king over Aram (Syria).'
1 Kings 19:16 And you shall anoint Jehu, the son of Nimshi, as king over Israel. And Elisha, the son of Shaphat, who is from Abel-meholah, you shall anoint as a prophet in your place.
1 Kings 19:17 And it shall come to pass: whoever escapes the sword of Hazael, Jehu shall kill him. And whoever escapes the sword of Jehu, Elisha shall effectively cause his death through divine judgment.
1 Kings 19:18 Yet I will leave for myself in Israel seven thousand people, all whose knees have not bowed before Baal, and every mouth that has not worshipped him.
1 Kings 19:19 So Elijah departed from there and found Elisha, the son of Shaphat, plowing with twelve yokes of oxen, and Elisha himself was with the twelfth yoke. And when Elijah came to him, he threw his mantle over him, signifying the passing of prophetic authority.
1 Kings 19:20 Elisha immediately left the oxen, ran after Elijah, and said: 'Please let me kiss my father and my mother goodbye, and then I will follow you.' And Elijah said to him: 'Go back to your family, and then return; for what have I done to you? (My action was a clear call to prophetic duty, not something to be lightly taken).'
1 Kings 19:21 So he returned from Elijah, took a yoke of oxen, and sacrificed them. And he cooked their meat using the plowing equipment as fuel, and gave it to the people, and they ate. Then he arose, went, and followed Elijah, and served him as his attendant.

1 Kings 20:1 Ben-hadad, the king of Syria, gathered his entire army, and thirty-two other kings were with him. He had many horses and chariots. He marched and fought against the city-state of Samaria and began to besiege it.
1 Kings 20:2 Then he sent messengers to King Ahab of Israel, into the city of Samaria.
1 Kings 20:3 Ben-hadad's message said: 'This is what Ben-hadad says: Your silver and your gold are mine. And your finest wives and your children are mine as well.'
1 Kings 20:4 The king of Israel responded, 'As you have said, my lord king, I am yours, and everything I possess belongs to you.'
1 Kings 20:5 The messengers returned and said, 'This is what Ben-hadad says: I sent word to you, saying, "You shall hand over your silver and your gold, your wives and your children to me."
1 Kings 20:6 Therefore, tomorrow at this time, I will send my servants to you. They will search your house and the houses of your servants, and they will seize and take away with their own hands whatever pleases them.'
1 Kings 20:7 So Ahab called together all the elders of the land and said, 'Notice this, and see that he is seeking trouble with us. He sent to me for my wives and my children, and for my silver and gold, and I did not refuse him.'
1 Kings 20:8 Then all the elders and all the people said to him, 'Do not consent, and do not listen to his demands.'
1 Kings 20:9 So Ahab responded to Ben-hadad's messengers, saying, 'Tell my lord the king: All that you first sent to me, your servant will do. But this second demand, I cannot do.' The messengers returned and reported this to Ben-hadad.
1 Kings 20:10 Then Ben-hadad sent a message to Ahab, saying, 'May the pagan gods do this to me, and more also, if the dust of Samaria is enough to fill the hands of all the people who are following me to battle!'
1 Kings 20:11 The king of Israel responded, saying, 'Tell him: Let not him who puts on his armor boast as much as he who takes it off after victory.'
1 Kings 20:12 Now it happened that when Ben-hadad heard this word, he was drinking with the other kings in their tents. He said to his servants, 'Prepare for attack!' And they positioned the army against the city.
1 Kings 20:13 Then, behold, a prophet approached King Ahab of Israel and said, 'This is what the Lord says: Have you seen all this great multitude? Behold, I will deliver them into your hand today, and you shall know that I am the Lord, the one true God.'
1 Kings 20:14 Ahab asked, 'By whom will you do this?' The Lord replied to him, 'By the young men who are the servants of the provincial governors.' And Ahab asked, 'Who will begin the battle?' The prophet answered him, 'You will.'
1 Kings 20:15 So Ahab mustered the young men of the provincial governors and found their number to be two hundred and thirty-two. After them, he mustered all the common people of the sons of Israel, seven thousand in total.
1 Kings 20:16 They marched out at noon. Ben-hadad, meanwhile, was drunk in his tents, along with the thirty-two kings who had been summoned to him.
1 Kings 20:17 The young men of the provincial governors went out first. Ben-hadad sent out scouts who reported to him, 'Men have come out from Samaria!'
1 Kings 20:18 Ben-hadad then said, 'Whether they have come out for peace, seize them alive; or if they have come out to fight, seize them alive.'
1 Kings 20:19 So the young men of the provincial governors went out, and the rest of the army followed behind them.
1 Kings 20:20 Each man struck down the opponent who came against him. The Syrians fled, and Israel pursued them. Ben-hadad, the king of Syria, also fled on his horse with his horsemen.
1 Kings 20:21 So the king of Israel went out and struck down the horses and chariots, and he inflicted a great defeat on Syria.
1 Kings 20:22 Then the prophet approached the king of Israel and said to him, 'Go, strengthen yourself, and take note and see what you must do. For when the year comes around again, the king of Syria will march up against you.'
1 Kings 20:23 Now the servants of the king of Syria said to him, 'Their gods are gods of the mountains; that is why they overpowered us. But if we fight against them on the plains, we will surely overpower them.'
1 Kings 20:24 Therefore, do this: remove all the other kings from your army, and put military commanders in their places.
1 Kings 20:25 Then rebuild the number of soldiers, according to the previous army, and the horses as before, and the chariots as before. Then we will fight them on the plains, and we will see if we do not overpower them.' Ben-hadad believed their counsel and acted accordingly.
1 Kings 20:26 And so, after seven years, Ben-hadad mustered the Syrians and marched to Aphek to fight against Israel.
1 Kings 20:27 But the sons of Israel were also mustered and, having taken provisions, went out to confront them. They appeared like two small flocks of goats, while the Syrians, in contrast, filled the entire land.
1 Kings 20:28 Then a man of God approached the king of Israel and said, 'This is what the Lord says: Because the Syrians declared, 'The Lord is a god of the mountains, and not a god of the valleys,' I will give all this great multitude into your hand, and you shall know that I am the Lord, the one true God.'
1 Kings 20:29 They camped opposite each other for seven days. On the seventh day, the battle began. The sons of Israel struck down one hundred thousand Syrian foot soldiers in a single day.
1 Kings 20:30 The remaining soldiers fled into the city of Aphek, and the city wall collapsed upon twenty-seven thousand of the men who were left. Ben-hadad himself fled and entered the city, hiding in an inner chamber.
1 Kings 20:31 His servants said to him, 'Behold, we have heard that the kings of the house of Israel are merciful. Let us therefore put sackcloth on our bodies and ropes around our heads, and go out to the king of Israel. Perhaps he will save our lives.'
1 Kings 20:32 So they put sackcloth on their bodies and ropes around their heads. They came to the king of Israel and said, 'Your servant Ben-hadad says, 'Please let my life be spared!'' Ahab replied, 'If he is still alive, he is my brother.'
1 Kings 20:33 The men took this as a good omen, quickly seizing upon his words, and said, 'Your brother Ben-hadad!' Ahab then said, 'Go and bring him here.' So Ben-hadad came out to him, and Ahab had him come up into his chariot.
1 Kings 20:34 Ben-hadad said to him, 'The cities that my father took from your father, I will restore. And you may establish trading quarters for yourself in Damascus, just as my father established them in Samaria.' Ahab said, 'I will make a covenant with you and then release you.' So Ahab made a covenant with him and released him.
1 Kings 20:35 Then one of the sons of the prophets, according to a command from the Lord, said to his companion, 'Strike me!' But his companion refused to strike him.
1 Kings 20:36 The prophet then said, 'Because you refused to obey the voice of the Lord, behold, a lion will kill you!' And indeed, a lion found him and killed him.
1 Kings 20:37 Then he went to another man and said, 'Strike me!' And the man struck him and wounded him.
1 Kings 20:38 So the prophet went and waited for the king by the road, disguising himself as if wounded, with his eyes covered by dust.
1 Kings 20:39 As the king passed by, the prophet cried out to him and said, 'Your servant went out into the midst of the battle. And behold, when a man had turned aside, he brought a man to me and said, 'Guard this man. If he escapes in any way, your life will be taken for his life, or you will pay a talent of silver.''
1 Kings 20:40 'While your servant was distracted and busy here and there, the man suddenly disappeared.' The king of Israel said to him, 'That is your judgment, for you have decreed it yourself.'
1 Kings 20:1 Ben-Hadad, the king of Syria, gathered his entire army, which included thirty-two kings with their horses and chariots. He then marched up to Samaria and besieged it, preparing to fight against the city.
1 Kings 20:2 He sent messengers to King Ahab of Israel, who was inside the city.
1 Kings 20:3 The message from Ben-Hadad said: 'Your silver and gold, your wives, and the best of your children are all mine.'
1 Kings 20:4 The king of Israel replied: 'As you say, my lord king, I am yours, and all that I possess is yours.'
1 Kings 20:5 The messengers returned to Ben-Hadad and delivered his response. But Ben-Hadad sent them back with a new message: 'I sent to you earlier, stating that you must give me your silver, your gold, your wives, and your children.'
1 Kings 20:6 'Therefore, by this time tomorrow, I will send my servants to you. They will search through your house and the houses of your officials, and they will take away whatever they desire.'
1 Kings 20:7 King Ahab called together all the elders of the land and said: 'Notice how this man is seeking to destroy us. He first sent for my wives and children, and my silver and gold, and I did not refuse him.'
1 Kings 20:8 All the elders and all the people told him: 'Do not agree to this, nor listen to his demands.'
1 Kings 20:9 So Ahab responded to Ben-Hadad’s messengers: 'Tell my lord the king: Everything you first demanded, I will do. But this latest demand I cannot fulfill.'
1 Kings 20:10 The messengers returned and reported this to Ben-Hadad. Ben-Hadad then sent a message to Ahab, saying: 'May the gods punish me severely and even more if the dust of Samaria is enough to fill the handfuls of all the people who follow me!' —meaning, 'My army is so vast, Samaria will be utterly destroyed and turn to dust, and there won't even be enough dust to fill their hands.'
1 Kings 20:11 The king of Israel responded to Ben-Hadad: 'Tell him this: One who is putting on his armor for battle should not boast as if he were taking it off after victory.'
1 Kings 20:12 Meanwhile, Ben-Hadad and the other kings were drinking in their temporary shelters when this message was delivered. Ben-Hadad then said to his servants: 'Surround the city for attack!' So they surrounded Samaria.
1 Kings 20:13 Then a prophet approached King Ahab of Israel, saying: 'The Lord says this: 'See this immense multitude? Indeed, I will deliver them into your hand today, so you will know that I am the Lord.''
1 Kings 20:14 Ahab asked: 'By whose hand will this be done?' The prophet replied: 'The Lord says this: 'Through the young men who serve the provincial governors.'' Ahab then asked: 'Who will begin the battle?' And the prophet said: 'You will.'
1 Kings 20:15 So Ahab counted the young men who served the provincial governors, and found two hundred and thirty-two of them. After them, he counted all the people, all the sons of Israel, totaling seven thousand.
1 Kings 20:16 They marched out at noon. Ben-Hadad, however, was in his temporary shelter, drinking heavily with the thirty-two kings who had come to aid him.
1 Kings 20:17 The young men serving the provincial governors were the first to march out. Ben-Hadad had sent scouts, who reported to him: 'Men are coming out from Samaria.'
1 Kings 20:18 Ben-Hadad said: 'If they come out for peace, take them alive. If they come out to fight, capture them alive.'
1 Kings 20:19 So the young men from the provincial governors' retinues marched out of the city, with the main Israelite army following behind them.
1 Kings 20:20 Each Israelite soldier struck down his opponent. The Syrians fled in disarray, and Israel pursued them. Ben-Hadad, the king of Syria, also fled on horseback with his cavalry.
1 Kings 20:21 The king of Israel then rode out and struck down the Syrian horses and chariots, inflicting a great slaughter upon Syria.
1 Kings 20:22 The prophet again approached the king of Israel and said to him: 'Go and strengthen yourself. Take note and consider carefully what you must do, because at the turn of the year, the king of Syria will return to fight against you.'
1 Kings 20:23 The servants of the king of Syria said to him: 'Their gods are gods of the mountains; that is why they overpowered us. But it is better that we fight against them on the plains, and then we will surely defeat them.'
1 Kings 20:24 'Therefore, do this: Remove the kings from their positions, each from his own post, and appoint governors in their place.'
1 Kings 20:25 'Also, restore the number of soldiers who fell from your ranks, and replace the horses with their former number, and the chariots as they were before. Then we will fight against them on the plains, and you will see that we will surely defeat them.' Ben-Hadad believed their words and acted accordingly.
1 Kings 20:26 So, at the turn of the year, Ben-Hadad assembled the Syrians and went up to Aphek to fight against Israel.
1 Kings 20:27 Meanwhile, the sons of Israel were also assembled, and after taking provisions, they marched out to meet them. The sons of Israel encamped opposite them, appearing like two small flocks of goats, while the Syrians filled the entire land.
1 Kings 20:28 Then a man of God approached the king of Israel and said: 'The Lord says this: 'Because the Syrians said, 'The Lord is a God of the mountains, and not a God of the valleys,' I will give this entire great multitude into your hand, and you will know that I am the Lord.''
1 Kings 20:29 For seven days, they encamped opposite one another. On the seventh day, the battle began, and the sons of Israel struck down one hundred thousand Syrian foot soldiers in a single day.
1 Kings 20:30 The remaining Syrian soldiers fled into the city of Aphek. And the city wall collapsed upon the twenty-seven thousand men who had survived. Ben-Hadad, however, fled and entered the city, hiding in an inner chamber within a room.
1 Kings 20:31 His servants said to him: 'Look, we have heard that the kings of the house of Israel are merciful kings. Therefore, let us put on sackcloth around our waists and ropes around our heads, and go out to the king of Israel. Perhaps he will spare our lives.'
1 Kings 20:32 So they girded sackcloth around their waists and placed ropes around their heads. They came to the king of Israel and said to him: 'Your servant Ben-Hadad says: 'Please let me live!'' And Ahab replied: 'If he is still alive, he is my brother.'
1 Kings 20:33 The men took this as a good omen, and seized upon his words, saying: 'Yes, your brother Ben-Hadad is alive!' Ahab then told them: 'Go and bring him here.' So Ben-Hadad came out to him, and Ahab had him get into his own chariot.
1 Kings 20:34 Ben-Hadad said to him: 'The cities that my father took from your father, I will restore to you. And you may establish marketplaces for yourself in Damascus, just as my father established them in Samaria. I will make a treaty with you, and then I will release you.' So Ahab made a treaty with him and set him free.
1 Kings 20:35 Then one of the sons of the prophets said to his companion, by the word of the Lord: 'Strike me!' But his companion refused to strike him.
1 Kings 20:36 So the prophet said to him: 'Because you refused to obey the voice of the Lord, behold, as soon as you leave me, a lion will strike you down.' And when he had left the prophet, a lion found him and struck him dead.
1 Kings 20:37 The prophet then found another man from the sons of the prophets and said: 'Strike me!' And that man struck him, wounding him.
1 Kings 20:38 So the prophet went and waited for the king by the roadside. He disguised himself by putting dust on his face and covering his eyes and forehead, hiding his identity.
1 Kings 20:39 As the king passed by, the prophet cried out to him, saying: 'Your servant went out into the midst of the battle. And when a man turned aside and brought another man to me, he said to me: 'Guard this man. If he escapes in any way, you will forfeit your own life for his life, or you will weigh out a talent of silver.''
1 Kings 20:40 'While your servant was busy here and there, the man suddenly disappeared.' The king of Israel said to him: 'This is your judgment, which you yourself have decided.'
1 Kings 20:1 So Ben-Hadad, the king of Syria, gathered his entire army. He had thirty-two other kings with him, along with their cavalry forces and chariots. They advanced, besieged Samaria, and began to wage war against it.
1 Kings 20:2 He sent messengers into the city to Ahab, the king of Israel,
1 Kings 20:3 saying: "Ben-Hadad declares this: All your silver and all your gold are mine. Your finest wives and your children are also mine."
1 Kings 20:4 The king of Israel responded: "As you have said, my lord king, I am your servant, and all that I have is yours."
1 Kings 20:5 But the messenger returned again and said to Ahab: "Ben-Hadad declares this: I sent word to you saying, 'You must give me your silver, your gold, your wives, and your children.'
1 Kings 20:6 Therefore, tomorrow at this time, I will send my servants to you. They will search through your palace and the treasuries of your officials. Everything that seems desirable to them, they will take and carry away."
1 Kings 20:7 Then Ahab summoned all the elders of the land and said: "Notice and consider how this man is plotting against us. For when he sent for my wives, my children, my silver, and my gold, I did not refuse him."
1 Kings 20:8 All the elders and all the people told him: "Do not consent, nor listen to his demand."
1 Kings 20:9 So Ahab replied to Ben-Hadad’s messengers: "Tell my lord the king: Everything that you first demanded from your servant, I will do. But this latest demand, I cannot fulfill." The messengers returned and reported this to Ben-Hadad.
1 Kings 20:10 Then Ben-Hadad sent word to Ahab, saying: "May the gods deal with me, and add even more punishments, if there is enough dust in Samaria for each of my followers to fill their hands! This means Samaria will be utterly destroyed by my vast army."
1 Kings 20:11 The king of Israel replied: "Tell him this proverb: 'Let not the one who puts on his armor boast as much as the one who takes it off.' In other words, don't boast before the battle is won."
1 Kings 20:12 When Ben-Hadad heard this message, he was drinking with the other kings in their tents. He then ordered his servants: "Surround the city!" So they began to besiege the city.
1 Kings 20:13 Then, a prophet approached Ahab, the king of Israel, and declared: "Thus says the Lord God: 'Have you seen this vast multitude? Behold, I will deliver them into your hand today, so that you may know that I am the Lord God.'"
1 Kings 20:14 Ahab asked: "By whom will you do this?" The prophet replied: "Thus says the Lord God: 'By the young men who serve the provincial governors.'" Ahab then asked: "Who will begin the attack?" The prophet answered: "You, yourself."
1 Kings 20:15 So Ahab counted the young men who served the provincial governors, and there were two hundred and thirty-two of them. After them, he numbered all the people, the sons of Israel, who were seven thousand strong.
1 Kings 20:16 They marched out at noon. Meanwhile, Ben-Hadad and the thirty-two kings who had come to assist him were drinking themselves drunk in their tents.
1 Kings 20:17 The young men of the provincial governors went out first. Ben-Hadad sent out scouts, who reported back to him, saying: "Some men have come out of Samaria!"
1 Kings 20:18 He commanded: "Whether they have come out to seek peace, capture them alive. Or if they have come out to fight, capture them alive as well!"
1 Kings 20:19 So the young men of the provincial governors went out, and the rest of the Israelite army followed behind them.
1 Kings 20:20 Each one struck down the man who confronted him. The Syrians fled, and Israel pursued them. Ben-Hadad, the king of Syria, also fled on horseback with his cavalry.
1 Kings 20:21 The king of Israel went out and struck down the Syrian horses and chariots, inflicting a great defeat upon Syria.
1 Kings 20:22 Then the prophet came to the king of Israel and told him: "Go now, strengthen your forces, take note, and consider what you must do, because at the turn of the year, the king of Syria will come up against you again."
1 Kings 20:23 But the servants of the king of Syria said to him: "Their gods are gods of the mountains; that is why they have overpowered us. But it is better that we fight against them on the plains, and then we will surely defeat them."
1 Kings 20:24 Take this counsel: Remove all the kings from their positions in your army, and appoint commanders in their place.
1 Kings 20:25 Then, restore the number of soldiers that you lost, and replace the horses with new horses, and the chariots with new chariots, just as you had before. We will fight against them on the plains, and you will see that we will surely prevail." Ben-Hadad trusted their advice and acted accordingly.
1 Kings 20:26 So, after a year had passed, Ben-Hadad mustered the Syrians and went up to Aphek to fight against Israel.
1 Kings 20:27 Meanwhile, the sons of Israel were also mustered. They took provisions and marched out to confront the Syrians. The sons of Israel encamped opposite them, looking like two small flocks of goats, while the Syrians completely covered the surface of the land.
1 Kings 20:28 Then a man of God approached the king of Israel and declared: "Thus says the Lord God: 'Because the Syrians have said, 'The Lord is a god of the mountains, but not a god of the valleys,' I will deliver this entire vast multitude into your hand. Then you will know that I am the Lord God.'"
1 Kings 20:29 They encamped opposite one another for seven days. On the seventh day, the battle began. And the sons of Israel struck down one hundred thousand Syrian foot soldiers in a single day.
1 Kings 20:30 Those who remained alive fled into the city of Aphek, but the wall collapsed upon twenty-seven thousand of the remaining men. Ben-Hadad, however, fled and entered the city, hiding in an inner chamber within a room.
1 Kings 20:31 His servants said to him: "Behold, we have heard that the kings of the house of Israel are merciful. Let us, therefore, put sackcloth around our waists and ropes upon our heads, and go out to the king of Israel. Perhaps he will spare our lives."
1 Kings 20:32 So they girded themselves with sackcloth around their waists and ropes upon their heads. They came to the king of Israel and said to him: "Your servant Ben-Hadad says: 'Please, let my life be spared.'"
1 Kings 20:33 Ahab replied: "If he is still alive, he is my brother." The men took this as a favorable sign and quickly seized upon his word, confirming: "Indeed! Your brother Ben-Hadad!"
1 Kings 20:34 Ahab then commanded: "Go and bring him here." So Ben-Hadad came out to him, and Ahab invited him to step into his own chariot.
1 Kings 20:35 Ben-Hadad then said to him: "The cities that my father took from your father, I will restore. You may also establish marketplaces for yourself in Damascus, just as my father established them in Samaria. I will make a treaty with you." Ahab replied: "Therefore, I will make a treaty with you and then release you." So Ahab made a treaty with Ben-Hadad and set him free.
1 Kings 20:36 At that time, a certain man from among the sons of the prophets said to his companion, by the word of the Lord: "Strike me!" But his companion refused to strike him.
1 Kings 20:37 So the prophet said to him: "Because you refused to obey the voice of the Lord, behold, as soon as you leave me, a lion will strike you down." And when he departed from him, a lion found him and struck him down.
1 Kings 20:38 He then found another man and said: "Strike me!" And this man struck him and wounded him severely.
1 Kings 20:39 So the prophet went and waited for the king by the road, disguising himself with ashes on his face and over his eyes to appear wounded.
1 Kings 20:40 As the king passed by, the prophet called out to him and said: "Your servant went out to the front lines of the battle, and behold, a man turned aside and brought a prisoner to me, saying: 'Guard this man. If he escapes, you shall pay with your own life for his life, or else you must pay a talent of silver.'"
1 Kings 21:1 After these events, a certain time came to pass: Naboth, from Jezreel, owned a vineyard which was next to the royal palace of King Ahab, who reigned in Samaria.
1 Kings 21:2 So King Ahab spoke to Naboth, saying to him: 'Give me your vineyard, so I can make it into a vegetable garden for myself, because it's so close to my royal house. I will give you a better vineyard for it, or, if you prefer, I will pay you its worth in silver.'
1 Kings 21:3 But Naboth answered him: 'May the Lord be merciful to me! I will not give you the inheritance I received from my ancestors.'
1 Kings 21:4 So Ahab returned to his house, gloomy and indignant because of the words Naboth the Jezreelite had said: 'I will not give you the inheritance from my fathers.' He threw himself onto his bed, turned his face toward the wall, and refused to eat any food.
1 Kings 21:5 Then Jezebel, his wife, came in to him and said to him: 'What is this, that your spirit is so sad, and you are not eating any food?'
1 Kings 21:6 He answered her: 'I spoke to Naboth the Jezreelite and said to him: 'Give me your vineyard for money, or if you prefer, I will give you another vineyard in its place.' But he said, 'I will not give you my vineyard.'
1 Kings 21:7 Then Jezebel said to him: 'Are you truly reigning as king over Israel with confidence right now? Get up, eat your food, and cheer up! For I will certainly give you the vineyard of Naboth the Jezreelite!'
1 Kings 21:8 So Jezebel wrote letters in Ahab's name and sealed them with his royal signet ring. She then sent these letters to the elders and nobles, who lived in Naboth's city and with him.
1 Kings 21:9 And this is what she wrote in the letters: 'Proclaim a fast, and seat Naboth in a prominent place among the people.'
1 Kings 21:10 'Then bring two worthless men, 'sons of Belial,' to accuse him, who will testify against him, saying: 'He cursed God and the king!' Then take him outside the city, stone him to death, and let him die.'
1 Kings 21:11 So the men of Naboth's city—the elders and nobles who lived there with him—did as Jezebel had commanded them, just as it was written in the letters she had sent to them.
1 Kings 21:12 They proclaimed a fast, and they seated Naboth in a prominent place among the people.
1 Kings 21:13 Then two worthless men, 'sons of Belial,' were brought in and seated opposite him. They testified against him before the assembled crowd, saying: 'Naboth cursed God and the king!' So they dragged him outside the city and killed him with stones.
1 Kings 21:14 Then they sent a message to Jezebel, saying: 'Naboth has been stoned, and he is dead.'
1 Kings 21:15 When Jezebel heard that Naboth had been stoned to death, she spoke to Ahab, saying: 'Get up, and take possession of the vineyard of Naboth the Jezreelite, who refused to agree with you and give it to you for money. For Naboth is no longer alive; he is dead.'
1 Kings 21:16 When Ahab heard that Naboth was dead, he got up and went down to the vineyard of Naboth the Jezreelite, so that he could take possession of it.
1 Kings 21:17 Now the word of the Lord came to Elijah the Tishbite, saying:
1 Kings 21:18 'Get up and go down to meet Ahab, the king of Israel, who is in Samaria. Look, he is in Naboth's vineyard, where he has gone down to take possession of it.'
1 Kings 21:19 'And you shall speak to him, saying: 'Thus says the Lord: 'Have you murdered, and then also taken possession?' And then you shall add: 'Thus says the Lord: 'In this very place where dogs licked up Naboth's blood, there will dogs also lick up your blood—yours, King Ahab!''
1 Kings 21:20 And Ahab said to Elijah: 'Have you found me, my enemy?' Elijah replied: 'I have found you, because you have sold yourself to do evil in the sight of the Lord.'
1 Kings 21:21 'Behold, I will bring disaster upon you, and I will utterly sweep away your descendants, and I will cut off from Ahab every male, even the lowest, a 'pisser against a wall', both bond and free, every last one in Israel.'
1 Kings 21:22 'And I will make your house like the house of Jeroboam, the son of Nebat, and like the house of Baasha, the son of Ahijah, because you have provoked Me to anger and have made Israel sin.'
1 Kings 21:23 'Concerning Jezebel also, the Lord has spoken, saying: 'Dogs will devour Jezebel in the open field near Jezreel.'
1 Kings 21:24 'If any of Ahab's family dies within the city, dogs will eat him. But if any of them dies in the open country, the birds of the sky will eat him.'
1 Kings 21:25 Indeed, there was no one like Ahab, who had sold himself to do evil in the sight of the Lord; for his wife, Jezebel, incited him and drove him to it.
1 Kings 21:26 He became truly abominable because he followed idols, and he practiced all the detestable things that the Amorites had done, whom the Lord had destroyed and removed from the presence of the children of Israel.
1 Kings 21:27 Now when Ahab heard these words, he tore his clothes, and he put on sackcloth over his skin, and he fasted, and he slept in sackcloth, and he walked around with a bowed head.
1 Kings 21:28 And the word of the Lord came to Elijah the Tishbite, saying:
1 Kings 21:29 'Have you seen how Ahab has humbled himself before Me? Because he has humbled himself on My account, I will not bring this disaster in his own lifetime, but in the days of his son, I will bring the disaster upon his house.'
