1 Kings 21:1 Some time after these events, Naboth, a man from Jezreel, owned a vineyard in Jezreel, right next to the palace of Ahab, the king who ruled Samaria.
1 Kings 21:2 So King Ahab spoke to Naboth, saying: "Give me your vineyard so I can turn it into a vegetable garden, because it is very close to my palace. In exchange, I will give you either a better vineyard, or, if you prefer, I will pay you its full value in silver."
1 Kings 21:3 Naboth replied to him, saying: "May the Lord forbid me from ever giving you the inheritance of my ancestors." The ancestral land was a sacred trust, not to be sold outside the family.
1 Kings 21:4 So Ahab went home, sad and indignant because of what Naboth the Jezreelite had said: "I will not give you the inheritance of my ancestors." King Ahab then threw himself onto his bed, turning his face to the wall, and refused to eat anything.
1 Kings 21:5 Then his wife Jezebel came in to him and asked: "Why are you so sad? Why aren't you eating anything?"
1 Kings 21:6 He answered her: "I spoke to Naboth the Jezreelite and said to him: 'Give me your vineyard for money, or if you prefer, I will give you a better vineyard in exchange.' But he replied: 'I will not give you my vineyard.'"
1 Kings 21:7 Then his wife Jezebel said to him: "Are you really the great king of Israel? Get up, eat something, and cheer up! I will personally make sure you get the vineyard of Naboth the Jezreelite."
1 Kings 21:8 So Jezebel wrote letters in Ahab's name, sealed them with his royal signet ring, and sent them to the elders and nobles who lived in Naboth's city and who knew him.
1 Kings 21:9 In these letters, she commanded: "Declare a public fast, and make sure Naboth is seated prominently among the people." A fast was often called in times of public distress or when investigating a serious sin, setting the stage for a false accusation.
1 Kings 21:10 "Then, bring two wicked men—sons of Belial, meaning utterly worthless men—to testify against him, saying: 'You blasphemed God and the king!' After their testimony, take him outside the city, stone him to death, and ensure he dies."
1 Kings 21:11 The citizens of Jezreel, including the elders and nobles who lived in Naboth's city, did exactly as Jezebel had commanded them and as it was written in the letters she had sent.
1 Kings 21:12 They declared a public fast and seated Naboth prominently among the people.
1 Kings 21:13 Then the two evil men, those wicked sons of the devil, were brought in and made to sit opposite Naboth. They testified against him before all the people, falsely declaring: "Naboth blasphemed God and the king!" Because of this false accusation, they dragged him outside the city and stoned him to death.
1 Kings 21:14 They then sent word to Jezebel, saying: "Naboth has been stoned, and he is dead."
1 Kings 21:15 When Jezebel heard that Naboth had been stoned and was dead, she said to Ahab: "Get up, go and take possession of the vineyard of Naboth the Jezreelite, the one who refused to give it to you for money. For Naboth is no longer alive; he is dead."
1 Kings 21:16 As soon as Ahab heard this, he got up and went down to the vineyard of Naboth the Jezreelite, intending to take possession of it.
1 Kings 21:17 Then the word of the Lord came to Elijah the Tishbite, saying:
1 Kings 21:18 "Go now, and meet Ahab, the king of Israel who lives in Samaria. Look, you will find him in Naboth's vineyard, where he has gone down to take possession of it."
1 Kings 21:19 "And you shall speak to him, saying: 'Thus says the Lord: Have you not both committed murder and seized possession? And beyond this, you must add: In the very place where dogs licked up the blood of Naboth, there also shall dogs lick up your blood.'"
1 Kings 21:20 Ahab said to Elijah: "Have you found me, my enemy?" Elijah replied: "Yes, I have found you, because you have completely sold yourself out to do evil in the sight of the Lord."
1 Kings 21:21 "Behold, I will bring disaster upon you. I will utterly sweep away your descendants, and I will cut off from Ahab every male in Israel—both slave and free, the weakest and the strongest—leaving no one."
1 Kings 21:22 "And I will make your house like the house of Jeroboam, son of Nebat, and like the house of Baasha, son of Ahijah: because you have provoked me to anger and have caused Israel to sin."
1 Kings 21:23 "Moreover, concerning Jezebel, the Lord has spoken, saying: 'Dogs shall devour Jezebel in the open field of Jezreel.'"
1 Kings 21:24 "If any of Ahab's family dies within the city, dogs will eat his body. If any of them dies in the open country, the birds of the sky will devour his body."
1 Kings 21:25 Indeed, there was no one else like Ahab, who completely sold himself to do evil in the sight of the Lord; his wife Jezebel constantly incited him to do so.
1 Kings 21:26 He became utterly detestable, because he followed idols, just as the Amorites had done—those whom the Lord had destroyed from the presence of the children of Israel.
1 Kings 21:27 When Ahab heard these words, he tore his clothes, put sackcloth directly over his bare skin, fasted, and even slept in sackcloth. He walked about with his head bowed down in deep humility and sorrow.
1 Kings 21:28 Then the word of the Lord came to Elijah the Tishbite, saying:
1 Kings 21:29 "Have you not seen how Ahab has humbled himself before me? Therefore, because he has humbled himself for my sake, I will not bring this disaster in his own lifetime. Instead, I will bring the disaster upon his household in the days of his son."
1 Kings 21:1 After these events, it came to pass that Naboth the Jezreelite owned a vineyard near the palace of Ahab, king of Samaria.
1 Kings 21:2 So King Ahab spoke to Naboth, saying: 'Give me your vineyard, so I can make a vegetable garden there, because it is close and near my own house. In exchange, I will give you a better vineyard; or, if it seems more convenient to you, I will buy it from you for its price in silver.'
1 Kings 21:3 But Naboth answered him: 'May the Lord forbid me from giving you the inheritance of my fathers.'
1 Kings 21:4 So Ahab came into his house, angry and indignant because of the refusal Naboth the Jezreelite had given him, saying: 'I will not give you the inheritance of my fathers.' And he threw himself onto his bed, turned his face to the wall, and refused to eat any food.
1 Kings 21:5 His wife Jezebel came in to him and said: 'Why is your spirit so troubled, and why are you refusing to eat food?'
1 Kings 21:6 He answered her: 'I spoke to Naboth the Jezreelite, and I said to him: "Give me your vineyard for money; or if you prefer, I will give you a better vineyard in exchange." But he answered: "I will not give you my vineyard."'
1 Kings 21:7 So Jezebel his wife said to him: 'Are you the King of Israel, and you allow yourself to act this way? Get up, eat your food, and be cheerful! I will secure for you the vineyard of Naboth the Jezreelite.'
1 Kings 21:8 So she wrote letters in Ahab's name and sealed them with his signet ring. She sent them to the elders and to the nobles who lived in Naboth's city and resided with him.
1 Kings 21:9 And she wrote this in the letters: 'Proclaim a fast, and make Naboth sit in a prominent place among the people;'
1 Kings 21:10 'and set two men, worthless scoundrels, against him to give false testimony and say: "You cursed God and the king!" Then, take him outside, stone him to death, and let him die.'
1 Kings 21:11 So the men of his city, the elders and the nobles who lived with him in the city, did as Jezebel had commanded them and as it was written in the letters she had sent to them.
1 Kings 21:12 They proclaimed a fast and made Naboth sit in a prominent place among the people.
1 Kings 21:13 Then they brought two worthless scoundrels, who sat opposite him and bore false testimony against him before the assembly, saying: 'Naboth cursed God and the king!' As a result, they led him outside the city and killed him with stones.
1 Kings 21:14 And they sent word to Jezebel, saying: 'Naboth has been stoned, and he is dead.'
1 Kings 21:15 When Jezebel heard that Naboth had been stoned and was dead, she spoke to Ahab, saying: 'Get up and take possession of the vineyard of Naboth the Jezreelite, who refused to agree with you and sell it to you; for Naboth is no longer alive, but is dead.'
1 Kings 21:16 When Ahab heard that Naboth was indeed dead, he got up and went down to the vineyard of Naboth the Jezreelite, to take possession of it.
1 Kings 21:17 Then the word of the Lord came to Elijah the Tishbite, saying:
1 Kings 21:18 'Get up, and go down to meet Ahab, king of Israel, who is in Samaria. Look, he is now going down to Naboth's vineyard to take possession of it.
1 Kings 21:19 And you shall speak to him, saying: 'Thus says the Lord: "Have you murdered, and also taken possession?" And after this you shall add: 'Thus says the Lord: "In the very place where dogs licked Naboth's blood, there also will dogs lick your own blood."
1 Kings 21:20 And Ahab said to Elijah: 'Have you found me, O my enemy?'
1 Kings 21:21 And he answered: 'I have found you, because you have sold yourself to do evil in the sight of the Lord.'
1 Kings 21:22 'Look, I will bring evil upon you and will cut off your descendants. I will destroy from Ahab everyone who urinates against a wall, both bond and free, and the very last in Israel.
1 Kings 21:23 'And I will make your house like the house of Jeroboam, son of Nebat, and like the house of Baasha, son of Ahijah, because you have provoked me to anger and have made Israel sin.'
1 Kings 21:24 Also, concerning Jezebel, the Lord has spoken, saying: 'Dogs shall devour Jezebel in the field of Jezreel.'
1 Kings 21:25 If Ahab dies in the city, dogs will eat him; but if he dies in the open field, the birds of the sky will eat him.
1 Kings 21:26 Indeed, there was no one else like Ahab, who sold himself to do evil in the sight of the Lord; for his wife Jezebel incited him to do so.
1 Kings 21:27 He became utterly detestable by following idols and all the abominable practices that the Amorites had committed, whom the Lord had destroyed before the children of Israel.
1 Kings 21:28 When Ahab heard these words, he tore his garments and put on sackcloth over his flesh. He fasted, and slept in sackcloth, and walked with his head bowed down.
1 Kings 21:29 Then the word of the Lord came to Elijah the Tishbite, saying: 'Have you not seen how Ahab has humbled himself before me? Therefore, because he has humbled himself for my sake, I will not bring the evil in his own days. Instead, in the days of his son, I will bring the evil upon his house.'
1 Kings 22:1 And three years passed without any war between Syria and Israel.
1 Kings 22:2 Then, in the third year, Jehoshaphat, the king of Judah, went down to visit the king of Israel.
1 Kings 22:3 The king of Israel then said to his servants, "Are you not aware that Ramoth-Gilead rightfully belongs to us, and yet we remain silent, allowing it to be taken from our hands?"
1 Kings 22:4 He then asked Jehoshaphat, "Will you come with me to battle at Ramoth-Gilead?" Jehoshaphat replied, "I am with you, just as you are with me; my people are with your people; my horses are with your horses." This means they are fully allied.
1 Kings 22:5 Jehoshaphat then said to the king of Israel, "Please, let us inquire today for a word from the Lord."
1 Kings 22:6 So the king of Israel gathered four hundred prophets and asked them, "Should I go to Ramoth-Gilead to fight, or should I hold back?" They all responded, "Go up, and the Lord will deliver it into the king's hand."
1 Kings 22:7 Jehoshaphat then asked, "Is there not also a prophet of the Lord here, so that we may inquire through him?"
1 Kings 22:8 The king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, "There is one man through whom we can inquire of the Lord, but I hate him, because he never prophesies anything good for me, only evil. His name is Micaiah, the son of Imlah." Jehoshaphat replied, "Do not speak such words, my king."
1 Kings 22:9 So the king of Israel called one of his eunuchs and told him, "Go quickly and bring Micaiah, the son of Imlah."
1 Kings 22:10 Now, the king of Israel and Jehoshaphat, the king of Judah, were both sitting on their thrones, dressed in their royal robes, in the threshing floor area near the entrance of the gate of Samaria. All the other prophets were delivering their prophecies before them.
1 Kings 22:11 And Zedekiah, the son of Chenaanah, had made for himself horns of iron and declared, "Thus says the Lord: 'With these horns, you will gore and scatter Syria until you have utterly destroyed them.'"
1 Kings 22:12 All the other prophets were also prophesying similarly, saying, "Go up to Ramoth-Gilead, and you will succeed, for the Lord will deliver it into the king's hand."
1 Kings 22:13 So the messenger who had gone to summon Micaiah spoke to him, saying, "Look, the words of all the prophets are unanimously declaring good things for the king. Therefore, let your words be like theirs, and speak good tidings."
1 Kings 22:14 Micaiah replied to him, "As the Lord lives, whatever the Lord tells me to say, that is what I will speak." This shows his unwavering commitment to God's true message.
1 Kings 22:15 So he came to the king. The king asked him, "Micaiah, should we go to Ramoth-Gilead to fight, or should we hold back?" Micaiah replied to him, "Go up, and you will succeed; the Lord will deliver it into the king's hand."
1 Kings 22:16 The king then said to him, "I adjure you, again and again, that you speak nothing to me but what is true, in the name of the Lord." The king knew Micaiah was being sarcastic.
1 Kings 22:17 Micaiah then said: "I saw all of Israel scattered on the mountains like sheep without a shepherd. And the Lord said: 'These people have no master now. Let each one return to his home in peace.'" This was a prophecy of the king's death.
1 Kings 22:18 So the king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, "Did I not tell you that he never prophesies anything good for me, but always evil?"
1 Kings 22:19 Micaiah then said, "Therefore, hear the word of the Lord: I saw the Lord sitting on His throne, with all the host of heaven standing by Him on His right and on His left." This describes a heavenly council.
1 Kings 22:20 And the Lord said, "Who will entice Ahab, the king of Israel, to go up and fall at Ramoth-Gilead?" And one spirit said one thing, and another spirit said another.
1 Kings 22:21 Then a certain spirit came forward and stood before the Lord and said, "I will entice him." The Lord asked him, "How will you do it?"
1 Kings 22:22 And the spirit said, "I will go out and become a lying spirit in the mouths of all his prophets." And the Lord said, "You will entice him, and you will succeed. Go out and do as you have said." This means God allowed the deception.
1 Kings 22:23 "So now, behold, the Lord has put a lying spirit in the mouths of all these prophets of yours, and the Lord has decreed evil concerning you."
1 Kings 22:24 Then Zedekiah, the son of Chenaanah, approached and struck Micaiah on the cheek, saying, "Which way did the Spirit of the Lord pass from me to speak to you instead?"
1 Kings 22:25 Micaiah replied, "You will see on that day when you go into an inner room from chamber to chamber to hide yourself."
1 Kings 22:26 The king of Israel then said, "Take Micaiah and lead him to Amon, the governor of the city, and to Joash, the son of Amelech."
1 Kings 22:27 "And tell them: 'Thus says the king: Put this man in prison and feed him with the bread of affliction and the water of distress until I return in peace.'"
1 Kings 22:28 Micaiah said, "If you ever return in peace, then the Lord has not spoken through me." And he added, "Hear this, all you peoples!"
1 Kings 22:29 So the king of Israel and Jehoshaphat, the king of Judah, went up to Ramoth-Gilead.
1 Kings 22:30 The king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, "I will disguise myself and go into battle, but you wear your royal robes." So the king of Israel disguised himself and went into battle.
1 Kings 22:31 Now the king of Syria had commanded his thirty-two chariot commanders, saying, "Do not fight with anyone, neither small nor great, except with the king of Israel alone."
1 Kings 22:32 So when the chariot commanders saw Jehoshaphat, they assumed he was the king of Israel and turned to attack him.
1 Kings 22:33 But Jehoshaphat cried out, and the Lord turned them away from him, causing them to turn from pursuing Jehoshaphat.
1 Kings 22:34 However, a certain man drew his bow with careful aim and by chance struck the king of Israel between his lung and stomach. The king then said to his chariot driver, "Turn around and take me out of the battle, for I am severely wounded."
1 Kings 22:35 The battle raged on throughout that day, and the king of Israel remained standing in his chariot facing the Syrians. He died that evening, as the blood from his wound flowed into the floor of the chariot.
1 Kings 22:36 And a herald cried out throughout the entire army before sunset, saying, "Every man to his own city, and every man to his own land!"
1 Kings 22:37 So the king died and was brought to Samaria, and they buried the king in Samaria.
1 Kings 22:38 And they washed the chariot in the pool of Samaria, where the dogs licked up his blood, and the harlots washed themselves, just as the Lord had prophesied.
1 Kings 22:39 As for the rest of the acts of Ahab, and everything he did, and the ivory house that he built, and all the cities that he constructed—are these not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel?
1 Kings 22:40 So Ahab rested with his ancestors, and his son Ahaziah reigned in his place.
1 Kings 22:1 Now, there were three years of peace between Syria and Israel.
1 Kings 22:2 But in the third year, Jehoshaphat, the king of Judah, went down to visit the king of Israel.
1 Kings 22:3 The king of Israel said to his servants, "Don't you realize that Ramoth in Gilead belongs to us? Why do we remain silent and not take it back from the king of Syria?"
1 Kings 22:4 Then he said to Jehoshaphat, "Will you come with me to battle in Ramoth-Gilead?" Jehoshaphat replied, "I am as you are, and my people are as your people, and my horsemen are as your horsemen. We are allies."
1 Kings 22:5 Jehoshaphat then said to the king of Israel, "Please, let us inquire of the Lord today to hear His word."
1 Kings 22:6 So the king of Israel gathered the prophets—about four hundred men—and asked them, "Should I go to Ramoth-Gilead to wage war, or should I hold back?" They all answered, "Go up, and God will give it into the king's hand."
1 Kings 22:7 Jehoshaphat asked, "Is there no other prophet of the Lord here, so that we may inquire through him?"
1 Kings 22:8 The king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, "There is one man through whom we could inquire of the Lord, but I hate him, because he never prophesies anything good for me, only evil. That man is Micaiah, the son of Imlah." Jehoshaphat responded, "The king should not speak like that."
1 Kings 22:9 So the king of Israel called one of his officials and ordered him, "Quickly, bring Micaiah, the son of Imlah."
1 Kings 22:10 The king of Israel and Jehoshaphat, the king of Judah, were sitting, each on his throne, dressed in their royal robes, in the open space at the entrance to the gate of Samaria. All the other prophets were prophesying before them.
1 Kings 22:11 Then Zedekiah, the son of Chenaanah, made himself iron horns and declared, "Thus says the Lord: 'With these, you will gore the Syrians until you utterly destroy them.'"
1 Kings 22:12 All the other prophets prophesied similarly, saying, "Go up to Ramoth-Gilead! You will succeed in everything, and the Lord will deliver it into the king's hand."
1 Kings 22:13 The messenger who had gone to summon Micaiah spoke to him, saying, "Look, the words of the prophets are uniformly favorable for the king. So let your words be like theirs, and speak favorably."
1 Kings 22:14 Micaiah replied, "As the Lord lives, I will speak only what the Lord tells me to say."
1 Kings 22:15 When he came to the king, the king asked him, "Micaiah, should we go to Ramoth-Gilead to wage war, or should we hold back?" Micaiah answered him, "Go up, and you will succeed in everything, and the Lord will deliver it into the king's hand." This was said with sarcasm.
1 Kings 22:16 The king said, "How many times must I make you swear by God that you will tell me nothing but the truth in the name of the Lord?"
1 Kings 22:17 Micaiah then said, "I saw all Israel scattered on the mountains like sheep without a shepherd. And the Lord said, 'These people have no leader. Let each one return to his house in peace.'"
1 Kings 22:18 The king of Israel then said to Jehoshaphat, "Didn't I tell you that he never prophesies anything good for me, but always evil?"
1 Kings 22:19 Micaiah continued, "Therefore, hear the word of the Lord. I saw the Lord sitting on His throne, and all the host of heaven standing by Him on His right and on His left."
1 Kings 22:20 And the Lord said, "Who will entice Ahab, the king of Israel, so that he goes up and falls in Ramoth-Gilead?" One spirit suggested one thing, and another suggested a different method.
1 Kings 22:21 Then a spirit came forward and stood before the Lord, saying, "I will entice him." The Lord asked him, "How will you do it?"
1 Kings 22:22 The spirit replied, "I will go out and become a lying spirit in the mouths of all his prophets." The Lord said, "You will entice him, and you will succeed. Go out and do so."
1 Kings 22:23 Now therefore, behold, the Lord has put a lying spirit in the mouths of all these prophets of yours who are here. And the Lord has spoken disaster against you.
1 Kings 22:24 Then Zedekiah, the son of Chenaanah, came up and struck Micaiah on the cheek, saying, "Which way did the Spirit of the Lord leave me to speak to you?"
1 Kings 22:25 Micaiah answered, "You will see on that day when you go into an inner room, hiding from everyone, trying to escape."
1 Kings 22:26 The king of Israel then ordered, "Take Micaiah and lead him back to Amon, the governor of the city, and to Joash, the king's son."
1 Kings 22:27 And tell them, "The king says: 'Put this man in prison and feed him only meager rations of bread and water until I return victorious and in peace.'"
1 Kings 22:28 Micaiah declared, "If you ever return in peace, then the Lord has not spoken through me." And he added, "Listen, all you people!"
1 Kings 22:29 So the king of Israel and Jehoshaphat, the king of Judah, went up to Ramoth-Gilead.
1 Kings 22:30 The king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, "I will disguise myself before I enter the battle, but you wear your royal robes." So the king of Israel disguised himself and went into battle.
1 Kings 22:31 The king of Syria had commanded his thirty-two chariot commanders, saying, "Do not fight with anyone, small or great, except for the king of Israel alone."
1 Kings 22:32 So when the chariot commanders saw Jehoshaphat, they assumed he was the king of Israel, and they turned to attack him. But Jehoshaphat cried out.
1 Kings 22:33 The chariot commanders realized that he was not the king of Israel, so they turned away from pursuing him.
1 Kings 22:34 But a certain man drew his bow at random, without aiming, and struck the king of Israel between his lung and his stomach. The king said to his chariot driver, "Turn your hand, and take me out of the battle line, because I am severely wounded."
1 Kings 22:35 The battle intensified throughout that day. The king of Israel remained propped up in his chariot facing the Syrians. He died in the evening, and the blood from his wound flowed into the bottom of the chariot.
1 Kings 22:36 At sunset, a proclamation was made throughout the entire army, saying, "Every man return to his city, and every man to his own land!"
1 Kings 22:37 So the king died, and he was brought to Samaria. They buried the king in Samaria.
1 Kings 22:38 When they washed the chariot in the pool of Samaria, the dogs licked up his blood, and the harlots bathed in that very water—just as the Lord had prophesied would happen.
1 Kings 22:39 Now, the rest of the acts of Ahab, and all that he did, and the ivory palace he built, and all the works he accomplished, are they not written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel?
1 Kings 22:40 So Ahab slept with his fathers—meaning he died—and Ahaziah, his son, reigned in his place.
1 Kings 22:1 And three years passed without any war between the kingdom of Syria and the kingdom of Israel.
1 Kings 22:2 Then, in the third year, Josaphat, who was the king of Judah, went down to visit the king of Israel.
1 Kings 22:3 Now, the king of Israel spoke to his servants, saying: "Do you not know that the city of Ramoth Galaad belongs to us? Yet we remain silent, doing nothing to prevent it from being taken from our hands!"
1 Kings 22:4 And the king of Israel then asked Josaphat: "Will you come with me to fight in battle against Ramoth Galaad?"
1 Kings 22:5 Josaphat replied to the king of Israel: "I am with you as if I were you. My people are with you as if they were your people, and my horses are with you as if they were your horses—we are united as one." This was Josaphat's promise of military alliance.
1 Kings 22:6 Josaphat then said to the king of Israel: "Please, I beg you, let us inquire today for a word from the Lord."
1 Kings 22:7 So the king of Israel gathered about four hundred of his own prophets and asked them: "Should I go to Ramoth Galaad to fight, or should I hold back?" They all answered him: "Go up into battle! The Lord will give the city into the king's hand."
1 Kings 22:8 But Josaphat asked: "Is there no other true prophet of the Lord here through whom we can inquire further?"
1 Kings 22:9 The king of Israel replied to Josaphat: "There is one more man by whom we could inquire of the Lord, but I hate him. He never prophesies anything good for me, only evil. His name is Michæas, the son of Jemla." Josaphat responded, saying: "The king should not speak like that!"
1 Kings 22:10 So the king of Israel called one of his eunuchs and ordered him: "Hurry and bring Michæas, the son of Jemla, here!"
1 Kings 22:11 Now the king of Israel and Josaphat, the king of Judah, were sitting, each on his own throne. They were dressed in their royal robes in the open area near the gate of Samaria, and all the prophets were prophesying before them, delivering their messages.
1 Kings 22:12 Indeed, Sedecias, the son of Chanana, had made himself horns of iron and declared: "This is what the Lord says: With these horns you will push Syria until you completely destroy them."
1 Kings 22:13 And all the other prophets prophesied similarly, saying: "Go up to Ramoth Galaad, and you will be successful! The Lord will give it into the king's hand."
1 Kings 22:14 But the messenger who had gone to summon Michæas spoke to him, saying: "Look, the words of the prophets are all proclaiming good things to the king with one voice. So let your words be like theirs, and speak favorably."
1 Kings 22:15 Michæas responded to the messenger: "As the Lord lives, I will speak only whatever the Lord tells me."
1 Kings 22:16 So when he came before the king, the king asked him: "Michæas, should we go to Ramoth Galaad to wage war, or should we hold back?"
1 Kings 22:17 Michæas answered him, speaking sarcastically: "Go up, and you will be successful! The Lord will give it into the king's hand!"
1 Kings 22:18 The king then said: "How many times must I warn you and adjure you under oath, that you speak to me nothing but the truth in the name of the Lord?"
1 Kings 22:19 Michæas replied: "I saw all of Israel scattered on the mountains, like sheep without a shepherd. And the Lord said: 'These people have no master. Let each one return to his own home in peace.'" This was a prophecy of the king's death.
1 Kings 22:20 Then the king of Israel said to Josaphat: "Did I not tell you that he never prophesies good for me, but always evil?"
1 Kings 22:21 But Michæas continued, saying: "Therefore, hear the word of the Lord. I saw the Lord sitting upon His throne, and all the host of heaven standing by Him on His right hand and on His left."
1 Kings 22:22 And the Lord asked: 'Who will deceive Achab, the king of Israel, so that he will go up to Ramoth Galaad and fall there?' And one spirit spoke these words, and another spoke other words.
1 Kings 22:23 Then a certain spirit came forth and stood before the Lord and said: 'I will deceive him.' The Lord asked him: 'How will you do it?'
1 Kings 22:24 And the spirit said: 'I will go out and be a lying spirit in the mouth of all his prophets.' The Lord then said: 'You will deceive him, and you will prevail. Go out and do it in this manner.'
1 Kings 22:25 Now therefore, behold, the Lord has put a lying spirit in the mouth of all these prophets of yours, and the Lord has spoken evil concerning you.
1 Kings 22:26 Then Sedecias, the son of Chanana, approached and struck Michæas on the cheek, saying: "By what way did the Spirit of the Lord depart from me to speak to you instead?"
1 Kings 22:27 Michæas responded: "Behold, you will see on that day, when you go from chamber to inner chamber to hide yourself—fleeing from the battle."
1 Kings 22:28 And the king of Israel commanded: "Take Michæas and lead him to Amon, the governor of the city, and to Joas, the son of Amelech."
1 Kings 22:29 And say: 'This is what the king says: Put this man in prison and feed him with the bread of affliction and the water of distress, until I return victorious and in peace.'"
1 Kings 22:30 Michæas then declared: "If you indeed return victorious and in peace, then the Lord has not spoken through me." And he added: "Hear this, all you peoples!"
1 Kings 22:31 So the king of Israel and Josaphat, the king of Judah, went up to Ramoth Galaad.
1 Kings 22:32 And the king of Israel said to Josaphat: "You, disguise yourself by putting on other clothes. But I will disguise myself in a different manner and then go into battle." So the king of Israel changed his royal attire and went into the war.
1 Kings 22:33 Now the king of Syria had commanded his thirty-two chariot captains, saying: "Do not fight against anyone, neither small nor great, except against the king of Israel alone."
1 Kings 22:34 When the chariot captains saw Josaphat, they assumed and said: "This must be the king of Israel!" So they turned to attack him in battle, and Josaphat cried out for help.
1 Kings 22:35 And the chariot captains realized that it was not the king of Israel, so they turned away from pursuing him.
1 Kings 22:36 However, a certain man drew his bow and, shooting an arrow randomly, struck the king of Israel between the shoulder armor and the breastplate. The king then cried out to his chariot driver: "Turn around and take me out of this battle, because I have been seriously wounded!"
1 Kings 22:37 And the battle raged fiercely throughout that day. The king of Israel remained standing in his chariot, facing the Syrians, until he died at evening. The blood from his wound flowed out onto the floor of the chariot.
1 Kings 22:38 After his body was brought to Samaria, they buried the king in Samaria.
1 Kings 22:39 His chariot was then washed in the pool of Samaria. The dogs licked up his blood, and the harlots washed themselves there. This happened exactly according to the word of the Lord, which He had spoken through His prophet Michæas.
1 Kings 22:40 As for the rest of the acts of Achab, and all that he did, including the ivory house he built and all the cities he constructed, are these not written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel?
2 Kings 1:1 After Ahab died, the nation of Moab revolted against Israel.
2 Kings 1:2 Ahaziah fell through the lattice of his upper chamber, which he had in Samaria, and he became very ill. He then sent messengers, telling them: "Go, consult Beelzebub, the idol-god of Ekron, to see if I will recover from this sickness."
2 Kings 1:3 However, the Angel of the Lord spoke to Elijah the Tishbite, saying: "Get up and go meet the messengers of the king of Samaria. Then you shall say to them: 'Is there truly no God in Israel that you must go to consult Beelzebub, the idol-god of Ekron?'"
2 Kings 1:4 Therefore, this is what the Lord says: 'You will not leave the bed upon which you have climbed, but you will surely die.' And Elijah then departed.
2 Kings 1:5 And the messengers returned to Ahaziah. He asked them: "Why have you returned?"
2 Kings 1:6 They answered him: "A man met us and spoke to us, saying: 'Go, and return to the king who sent you, and speak to him: Thus says the Lord: "Is there truly no God in Israel that you send to consult Beelzebub, the idol-god of Ekron? Therefore, from the bed upon which you have climbed, you shall not descend, but you will surely die."'
2 Kings 1:7 Ahaziah asked them: "What was the appearance and manner of that man who met you and spoke these words to you?"
2 Kings 1:8 And they told him: "He was a hairy man, with a leather belt wrapped around his waist." The king immediately knew and said: "It is Elijah the Tishbite!"
2 Kings 1:9 So the king sent a captain of fifty soldiers with his fifty men to Elijah. The captain went up to him, and Elijah was sitting on the top of a mountain. And the captain spoke to him: "Man of God, the king commands that you come down!"
2 Kings 1:10 And Elijah responded, saying to the captain of fifty: "If I am a man of God, then let fire descend from the sky and consume you and your fifty men." And immediately fire descended from the sky, and it consumed him and the fifty men who were with him.
2 Kings 1:11 Again, the king sent to him a second captain of fifty soldiers with his fifty men. He spoke to Elijah: "Man of God, this is what the king says: 'Hurry, come down!'"
2 Kings 1:12 And Elijah responded, saying: "If I am a man of God, then let fire descend from the sky and consume you and your fifty men." And immediately fire descended from the sky, and it consumed him and the fifty men who were with him.
2 Kings 1:13 Again, the king sent a third captain of fifty soldiers with his fifty men. When he came, he knelt before Elijah and pleaded with him, saying: "Man of God, please do not despise my life, nor the lives of these fifty servants of yours."
2 Kings 1:14 He continued: "Behold, fire has descended from the sky and consumed the first two captains of fifty and the fifty men who were under each of them. But now, I beg you, have mercy on my life!"
2 Kings 1:15 And the Angel of the Lord spoke to Elijah, saying: "Go down with him, do not be afraid." So Elijah rose up and went down with him to the king.
2 Kings 1:16 And Elijah spoke to the king: "Thus says the Lord: 'Because you sent messengers to consult Beelzebub, the idol-god of Ekron, as if there were no God in Israel whose word could be inquired of, therefore you will not leave the bed upon which you have climbed, but you will surely die.'"
2 Kings 1:17 So Ahaziah died according to the word of the Lord which Elijah had spoken. And Joram, his brother, reigned in his place in the second year of Jehoram, son of Jehoshaphat, king of Judah, because Ahaziah had no son.
2 Kings 1:18 As for the rest of the deeds of Ahaziah, and what he accomplished, are these not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel?

2 Kings 1:1 After King Ahab died, the kingdom of Moab rebelled against the kingdom of Israel.
2 Kings 1:2 Now King Ahaziah fell through the lattice of his upper chamber, which he had in Samaria, and he became very sick. He then sent messengers, telling them, 'Go, inquire of Baal-Zebub, the god of Ekron, whether I will recover from this illness.'
2 Kings 1:3 But the Angel of the Lord spoke to Elijah the Tishbite, saying, 'Arise, and go up to meet the messengers of the king of Samaria, and you shall say to them: Is there no God in Israel, that you go to inquire of Baal-Zebub, the god of Ekron?'
2 Kings 1:4 Therefore, this is what the Lord says: 'From the bed upon which you have climbed, you shall not descend, but you will surely die.' And Elijah went away to deliver this message.
2 Kings 1:5 So the messengers returned to King Ahaziah. And he said to them, 'Why have you returned so quickly?'
2 Kings 1:6 And they answered, 'A man met us and said to us: 'Go, and return to the king who sent you, and you shall tell him: This is what the Lord says: Is there no God in Israel, that you send to inquire of Baal-Zebub, the god of Ekron? Therefore, from the bed upon which you have climbed, you shall not descend, but you will surely die.''
2 Kings 1:7 And the king said to them, 'What kind of man was he who met you and spoke these words?'
2 Kings 1:8 And they described him, saying, 'He was a hairy man, with a leather belt fastened around his waist.' And the king immediately realized, 'It is Elijah the Tishbite.'
2 Kings 1:9 So the king sent a captain of fifty men, with his fifty soldiers who were under him, to Elijah. The captain went up to Elijah; and behold, Elijah was sitting on the top of a mountain. And the captain spoke to him, saying, 'Man of God, the king commands that you come down.'
2 Kings 1:10 And Elijah answered the captain of fifty, 'If I am a man of God, let fire come down from the sky and consume you and your fifty men.' So fire came down from the sky and consumed him and the fifty men who were with him.
2 Kings 1:11 Again, King Ahaziah sent another captain of fifty men and fifty with him. And that captain spoke to Elijah, 'Man of God, the king says this: 'Hurry, come down!''
2 Kings 1:12 And Elijah answered him, 'If I am a man of God, let fire come down from the sky and consume you and your fifty men.' Therefore, fire came down from the sky and consumed that captain and the fifty men who were with him.
2 Kings 1:13 Again, King Ahaziah sent a third captain of fifty men, with the fifty who were with him. When this captain came, he knelt down before Elijah, and pleaded with him, and spoke: 'Man of God, please do not despise my life, nor the lives of these fifty servants of yours.'
2 Kings 1:14 'For behold, fire has come down from the sky and consumed the two former captains of fifty and the fifty men who were with them. But now, I beg you, have mercy on my life.'
2 Kings 1:15 Then the Angel of the Lord spoke to Elijah, saying, 'Go down with him; do not be afraid.' So Elijah arose and went down with the captain to the king,
2 Kings 1:16 and he spoke to King Ahaziah: 'This is what the Lord says: 'Because you sent messengers to inquire of Baal-Zebub, the god of Ekron, as if there were no God in Israel whose word you could inquire of, therefore, from the bed upon which you have climbed, you shall not descend, but you will surely die.''
2 Kings 1:17 So King Ahaziah died according to the word of the Lord which Elijah had spoken. And his brother Jehoram (Joram) reigned in his place in the second year of Jehoram, the son of King Jehoshaphat of Judah, because Ahaziah had no son.
2 Kings 1:18 Now the rest of the acts of Ahaziah, all that he did, are they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel?
2 Kings 1:19 Now it came to pass, when the Lord was about to take Elijah up to the sky in a whirlwind, that Elijah and Elisha were going from Gilgal.
2 Kings 1:20 And Elijah said to Elisha, 'Please stay here, for the Lord has sent me as far as Bethel.' Elisha replied to him, 'As the Lord lives, and as your soul lives, I will not leave you.' And when they had gone down to Bethel,
2 Kings 1:21 the sons of the prophets who were in Bethel came out to Elisha and said to him, 'Do you know that today the Lord is taking your master from you?' And Elisha responded, 'Yes, I know; be silent about it.'
2 Kings 1:22 And Elijah said to Elisha, 'Elisha, please stay here, for the Lord has sent me as far as Jericho.' And Elisha replied, 'As the Lord lives, and as your soul lives, I will not leave you.' And when they had come to Jericho,
2 Kings 1:23 the sons of the prophets who were in Jericho approached Elisha and said to him, 'Do you know that today the Lord is taking your master from you?' And Elisha replied, 'Yes, I know; be silent about it.'
2 Kings 1:24 And Elijah said to him, 'Please stay here, for the Lord has sent me as far as the Jordan River.' Elisha replied, 'As the Lord lives, and as your soul lives, I will not leave you.' So both of them continued on their journey.
2 Kings 1:25 Furthermore, fifty men from the sons of the prophets followed them; and they stood facing them, from a distance, while Elijah and Elisha both stood by the Jordan.
2 Kings 1:26 Then Elijah took his mantle, rolled it up, and struck the waters of the Jordan, which then divided to both sides. And both Elijah and Elisha crossed over on dry ground.
2 Kings 1:27 When they had crossed, Elijah said to Elisha, 'Ask what you desire for me to do for you, before I am taken from you.' And Elisha said, 'I beg you, let a double portion of your spirit be upon me.'
2 Kings 1:28 Elijah answered, 'You have asked a difficult thing. Nevertheless, if you see me when I am taken from you, it shall be granted to you as you have asked; but if you do not see me, it will not be granted.'
2 Kings 1:29 As they walked on and talked together, behold, a fiery chariot and fiery horses appeared and separated the two of them. And Elijah ascended by a whirlwind into the sky.
2 Kings 1:30 But Elisha, seeing this, cried out, 'My father, my father! The chariot of Israel and its horsemen!' And he saw Elijah no longer. Then Elisha took hold of his own clothes and tore them into two pieces.
2 Kings 1:31 And Elisha picked up the mantle of Elijah that had fallen from him. Then he returned and stood by the bank of the Jordan River.
2 Kings 1:32 And with the mantle of Elijah, which had fallen from him, Elisha struck the waters, but they did not divide. Then he said, 'Where is the God of Elijah now?' And again he struck the waters, and they divided to one side and to the other; and Elisha crossed over.
2 Kings 1:33 Now when the sons of the prophets who were in Jericho saw him from a distance, they said, 'The spirit of Elijah rests upon Elisha.' And coming to meet him, they bowed down to the ground before him,
2 Kings 1:34 and they said to him, 'Behold, we have fifty strong men with us who can go and search for your master. Perhaps the Spirit of the Lord has taken him up and cast him upon one of the mountains, or into one of the valleys.' But Elisha replied, 'Do not send them.'
2 Kings 1:35 But they urged him until he consented, saying, 'Send them.' So they sent fifty men, who searched for three days but did not find Elijah.
2 Kings 1:36 When they returned to Elisha, who was still waiting in Jericho, he said to them, 'Did I not tell you: 'Do not send them?'
2 Kings 1:37 Now the men of the city of Jericho also said to Elisha, 'Behold, the dwelling place of this city is excellent, as you yourself, our lord, perceive. But the waters are very bad, and the land is barren.'
2 Kings 1:38 And Elisha said, 'Bring me a new jar and put salt in it.' So when they brought it to him,
2 Kings 1:39 he went out to the spring of the waters, and cast the salt into it, and said: 'This is what the Lord says: 'I have healed these waters, and there shall be no more death or barrenness in them from now on.''
2 Kings 1:40 So the waters were healed to this very day, according to the word of Elisha, which he had spoken.
2 Kings 1:1 But after King Ahab died, the kingdom of Moab rebelled against Israel.
2 Kings 1:2 But King Ahaziah fell through the lattice of his upper room, which he had in Samaria, and became gravely ill. So he sent messengers, telling them, 'Go, consult Beelzebub, the pagan god of Ekron, to see if I will recover from this illness.'
2 Kings 1:3 However, the Angel of the Lord spoke to Elijah the Tishbite, instructing him: 'Go now, ascend to meet the messengers of the king of Samaria, and say to them: "Is there no God in Israel, that you must go and consult Beelzebub, the pagan god of Ekron?"'
2 Kings 1:4 Therefore, the Lord declares this: 'You shall not get up from the sickbed you are on; instead, you will certainly die.' With this message, Elijah departed.
2 Kings 1:5 When the messengers returned to King Ahaziah, he asked them, 'Why have you come back?'
2 Kings 1:6 They answered him, 'A man met us and told us, "Go back to the king who sent you, and tell him: 'This is what the Lord says: Is there no God in Israel, that you must send to consult Beelzebub, the pagan god of Ekron? Because of this, you will not get up from the sickbed you are on; instead, you will certainly die.'"'
2 Kings 1:7 He then asked them, 'What kind of man was it who met you and spoke these words to you?'
2 Kings 1:8 They replied, 'He was a man dressed in a rough, hairy garment, with a leather belt around his waist.' The king then realized, 'It is Elijah the Tishbite!'
2 Kings 1:9 So the king sent to him a captain of fifty men with his fifty soldiers. The captain went up to Elijah, who was sitting on the top of a mountain, and addressed him, 'Man of God, the king commands you: "Come down!"'
2 Kings 1:10 Elijah answered the captain of fifty, 'If I am a man of God, then let fire come down from the sky and consume both you and your fifty men.' Immediately, fire descended from the sky and consumed him and all fifty of his soldiers.
2 Kings 1:11 Again, the king sent another captain of fifty with his fifty soldiers. This captain addressed Elijah, 'Man of God, this is what the king says: "Hurry, come down!"'
2 Kings 1:12 Elijah answered him, 'If I am a man of God, then let fire come down from the sky and consume both you and your fifty men.' Immediately, fire descended from the sky and consumed him and his fifty soldiers.
2 Kings 1:13 Once more, the king sent a third captain of fifty with his fifty soldiers. When this captain arrived, he humbly knelt before Elijah and pleaded with him, saying, 'Man of God, please do not disregard my life, nor the lives of these fifty servants of yours.'
2 Kings 1:14 Behold, fire has already come down from the sky and consumed the first two captains of fifty with their fifty men. Now, I beg you, spare my life.
2 Kings 1:15 Then the Angel of the Lord spoke to Elijah, saying, 'Go down with him; do not be afraid.' So Elijah rose, and went down with the captain to the king.
2 Kings 1:16 Elijah then spoke to the king, saying, 'This is what the Lord declares: Because you sent messengers to consult Beelzebub, the pagan god of Ekron, as if there were no God in Israel from whom you could seek a prophetic word, you will not get up from the sickbed you are on; instead, you will certainly die.'
2 Kings 1:17 So King Ahaziah died according to the word of the Lord that Elijah had spoken. His brother Joram then reigned in his place, because Ahaziah had no son. This occurred in the second year of Joram, son of King Jehoshaphat of Judah.
2 Kings 1:18 As for the rest of the acts of King Ahaziah, and all that he did, are they not indeed written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel?
2 Kings 2:1 Now it came about, when the Lord was about to take Elijah up into glory by means of a whirlwind, that Elijah and Elisha departed from Gilgal.
2 Kings 2:2 And Elijah said to Elisha: 'Stay here, I beg you, because the Lord has sent me on a mission to Bethel.' And Elisha replied: 'As the Lord lives, and as your soul lives, I will not leave you.' So they both went down to Bethel.
2 Kings 2:3 Then the sons of the prophets who were in Bethel came out to Elisha and said to him: 'Do you know that today the Lord is taking your master from you?' And he answered: 'Yes, I know; be silent.'
2 Kings 2:4 And Elijah said to Elisha: 'Stay here, I beg you, because the Lord has sent me on a mission to Jericho.' But he replied: 'As the Lord lives, and as your soul lives, I will not leave you.' So they both went to Jericho.
2 Kings 2:5 Then the sons of the prophets who were in Jericho approached Elisha and said to him: 'Do you know that today the Lord is taking your master from you?' And he replied: 'Yes, I know; be silent.'
2 Kings 2:6 And Elijah said to him: 'Stay here, I beg you, because the Lord has sent me on a mission as far as the Jordan River.' But he replied: 'As the Lord lives, and as your soul lives, I will not leave you.' So they both continued on their way.
2 Kings 2:7 And fifty men from the sons of the prophets followed them and stood at a distance, watching them. But Elijah and Elisha both stood by the Jordan River.
2 Kings 2:8 Then Elijah took his cloak, rolled it up, and struck the waters of the river. And the waters divided to both sides, so that both of them crossed over on dry ground.
2 Kings 2:9 And when they had crossed over, Elijah said to Elisha: 'Ask what you wish me to do for you before I am taken from you.' And Elisha replied: 'I beg that a double portion of your spiritual power may come upon me.'
2 Kings 2:10 He answered: 'You have asked a difficult thing. Nevertheless, if you see me when I am taken from you, then what you have asked will be granted to you. But if you do not see me, it will not be.'
2 Kings 2:11 And as they continued on their way, speaking together as they walked, behold, a chariot of fire and horses of fire separated the two of them. And Elijah ascended into glory by means of a whirlwind.
2 Kings 2:12 But Elisha saw it, and he cried out: 'My father, my father! The chariot of Israel and its horsemen!' And he saw him no more. Then he took hold of his own clothes and tore them into two pieces.
2 Kings 2:13 And he picked up the cloak of Elijah, which had fallen from him. Then he returned and stood on the bank of the Jordan River.
2 Kings 2:14 And with the cloak of Elijah, which had fallen from him, he struck the waters, but they did not divide. Then he said: 'Where is the God of Elijah now?' And he struck the waters again, and they divided to both sides. So Elisha crossed over.
2 Kings 2:15 Now when the sons of the prophets who were in Jericho saw him from across the river, they said: 'The spiritual power of Elijah rests upon Elisha.' And they came to meet him, bowing down to the ground before him.
2 Kings 2:16 And they said to him: 'Behold, there are fifty strong men among your servants, who could go and search for your master. Perhaps the Spirit of the Lord has taken him up and cast him upon one of the mountains or into one of the valleys.' But he said: 'Do not send anyone.'
2 Kings 2:17 But they urged him until he consented and said: 'Send them.' So they sent fifty men, and after they had searched for three days, they did not find him.
2 Kings 2:18 And when they returned to Elisha, who was sitting in Jericho, he said to them: 'Did I not tell you, 'Do not send anyone?'
2 Kings 2:19 Then the men of the city said to Elisha: 'Behold, the situation of this city is excellent, as you yourself, my master, can see. But the waters are bad, and the land is barren.'
2 Kings 2:20 And he said: 'Bring me a new bowl and put salt in it.' And when they had brought it to him,
2 Kings 2:21 he went to the spring of waters and cast the salt into it, and said: 'Thus says the Lord: I have healed these waters. From now on, there will be no more death or barrenness in them.'
2 Kings 2:22 So the waters were healed to this very day, according to the word of Elisha, which he had spoken.
2 Kings 2:23 And from there he went up to Bethel. And as he was going up by the way, some small boys came out of the city and mocked him, saying: 'Go up, you bald head! Go up, you bald head!'
2 Kings 2:24 When he looked back, he saw them and cursed them in the name of the Lord. And two she-bears came out of the forest and mauled forty-two of the boys.
2 Kings 2:25 And he went from there to Mount Carmel, and from there he returned to Samaria.
2 Kings 2:1 When the Lord was about to take Elijah up into the heavens by means of a whirlwind, Elijah and Elisha were traveling from Gilgal.
2 Kings 2:2 And Elijah said to Elisha, 'Please, stay here, because the Lord has sent me as far as Bethel.' To which Elisha replied, 'As the Lord lives, and as your very self lives, I will not leave you.' So they both went down to Bethel.
2 Kings 2:3 Then the company of prophets who were in Bethel came out to meet Elisha, and they asked him, 'Do you know that today the Lord is taking your master from you?' And he replied, 'Yes, I know that also; be silent.'
2 Kings 2:4 Then Elijah said to Elisha again, 'Elisha, please stay here, because the Lord has sent me as far as Jericho.' But Elisha insisted, 'As the Lord lives, and as your very self lives, I will not leave you.' So they both went on to Jericho.
2 Kings 2:5 And the company of prophets who were in Jericho came to Elisha and asked him, 'Do you know that today the Lord is taking your master from you?' He replied, 'Yes, I know that also; be silent.'
2 Kings 2:6 Then Elijah said to him, 'Please, cross the Jordan, and stay here, because the Lord has sent me as far as the Jordan River.' But Elisha affirmed again, 'As the Lord lives, and as your very self lives, I will not leave you.' So both of them continued on their way.
2 Kings 2:7 And fifty men from the company of prophets followed them and stood watching from a distance, directly opposite them. But Elijah and Elisha themselves stood by the Jordan River.
2 Kings 2:8 Then Elijah took his mantle, rolled it up, and struck the waters of the Jordan. The waters parted to both sides, and both Elijah and Elisha crossed over on dry ground.
2 Kings 2:9 When they had crossed over, Elijah said to Elisha, 'Ask what you wish for me to do for you, before I am taken from you.' Elisha then replied, 'I beg you, let a double portion of your prophetic spirit be upon me.'
2 Kings 2:10 Elijah responded, 'You have asked a difficult thing. Nevertheless, if you see me when I am taken from you, then what you have asked will be granted to you. But if you do not see me, it will not be.'
2 Kings 2:11 And as they continued on their way, still talking, behold, a chariot of fire and horses of fire appeared and separated the two of them. Then Elijah went up into the heavens by means of a whirlwind.
2 Kings 2:12 But Elisha saw it, and he cried out, 'My father, my father! The chariot of Israel and its horseman!' —a declaration of Israel's strength and Elijah's importance. And he saw Elijah no more. Then, in his grief, Elisha took hold of his own clothes and tore them into two pieces.
2 Kings 2:13 Then Elisha picked up Elijah’s mantle, which had fallen from him. He turned back and stood by the bank of the Jordan River.
2 Kings 2:14 And with Elijah’s mantle, which had fallen from him, he struck the waters of the Jordan, but they did not part. So Elisha cried out, 'Where is the Lord, the God of Elijah, now?' He then struck the waters again, and they parted to both sides, and Elisha crossed over.
2 Kings 2:15 When the company of prophets from Jericho, who had been watching from across the river, saw this, they declared, 'The spirit of Elijah rests upon Elisha!' And they came to meet him, bowing down before him with their faces to the ground.
2 Kings 2:16 And they said to him, 'Behold, your servants have fifty strong men with us who could go and search for your master. Perhaps the Spirit of the Lord has taken him up and cast him upon one of the mountains or into one of the valleys.' But Elisha said, 'Do not send them.'
2 Kings 2:17 But they urged him so persistently that he finally gave in and said, 'Send them.' So they sent fifty men, who searched for three days but did not find him.
2 Kings 2:18 When they returned to Elisha — for he was staying in Jericho — he said to them, 'Did I not tell you, 'Do not send them?'
2 Kings 2:19 Then the men of the city of Jericho said to Elisha, 'Behold, the situation of this city is excellent, as you yourself, our master, can see. But its waters are very bad, and the land is unproductive.'
2 Kings 2:20 But Elisha said, 'Bring me a new jar, and put salt in it.' So they brought it to him.
2 Kings 2:21 Then Elisha went out to the spring of the waters, and he cast the salt into it, declaring, 'Thus says the Lord: 'I have now healed these waters. From this moment on, there will be no more death nor barrenness from them.'' 
2 Kings 2:22 And the waters have remained healed to this very day, according to the prophetic word that Elisha spoke.
2 Kings 2:23 From there, Elisha went up towards Bethel. As he was going up by the road, some young lads came out from the city and began to mock him, shouting, 'Go up, bald head! Go up, bald head!' — a taunt challenging his authority and connection to Elijah's ascent.
2 Kings 2:24 And when Elisha turned and looked at them, he saw them and cursed them in the name of the Lord. Immediately, two she-bears came out of the nearby forest and attacked them, tearing apart forty-two of the boys.
2 Kings 2:25 Then Elisha went from there to Mount Carmel, and from Mount Carmel, he returned to Samaria.
2 Kings 3:1 Moab, however, rebelled against Israel after Ahab's death.
2 Kings 3:2 And Joram, Ahab's son, became king over Israel in Samaria during the twelfth year of Jehoshaphat, who was king of Judah. Joram reigned for twelve years.
2 Kings 3:3 He did what was evil in the Lord's sight, though not to the same extent as his father Ahab or his mother Jezebel. For Joram removed the stone pillars of Baal that his father had set up.
2 Kings 3:4 Now Mesha, the king of Moab, was a sheep breeder, and he used to pay tribute to the king of Israel: a hundred thousand lambs and a hundred thousand rams with their wool.
2 Kings 3:5 But after Ahab died, Moab broke the treaty they had with the king of Israel.
2 Kings 3:6 So King Joram left Samaria that day and took a census of Israel's fighting men.
2 Kings 3:7 He then sent a message to Jehoshaphat, the king of Judah, saying, 'The king of Moab has rebelled against me. Will you come with me to fight against Moab?' Jehoshaphat replied, 'I will go up with you. My forces are like your forces, my people like your people, and my horses like your horses.'
2 Kings 3:8 Then Joram asked, 'By what route should we advance?' And Jehoshaphat answered, 'By way of the desert of Edom.'
2 Kings 3:9 So the king of Israel, the king of Judah, and the king of Edom set out. They marched for seven days, but there was no water for their army or for the animals that followed them.
2 Kings 3:10 Then the king of Israel cried out, 'Oh no! Has the Lord called these three kings together only to deliver them into the hand of Moab?'
2 Kings 3:11 But Jehoshaphat asked, 'Is there no prophet of the Lord here through whom we might consult the Lord?' One of the servants of the king of Israel replied, 'Elisha, the son of Shaphat, is here. He used to pour water on Elijah's hands'—meaning he was Elijah's personal assistant and successor.
2 Kings 3:12 Jehoshaphat then declared, 'The Lord's message is indeed with him.' So the king of Israel, Jehoshaphat, and the king of Edom went down to meet Elisha.
2 Kings 3:13 Elisha said to the king of Israel, 'What business do you and I have together? Go to the prophets of your father and your mother!' The king of Israel answered him, 'No, for the Lord has called these three kings together to deliver them into the hand of Moab.'
2 Kings 3:14 Elisha declared, 'As the Lord of hosts lives, before whom I stand, if I did not respect the presence of Jehoshaphat, the king of Judah, I would not even look at you or acknowledge you.'
2 Kings 3:15 But now, bring me a harpist. And as the harpist played, the hand of the Lord came upon Elisha.
2 Kings 3:16 And he said, 'Thus says the Lord: Dig many trenches in this dry streambed.'
2 Kings 3:17 For thus says the Lord: 'You will neither see wind nor rain, yet this streambed will be filled with water, so that you, your troops, and your animals may drink.'
2 Kings 3:18 And this is but a small thing in the Lord's sight. He will also deliver Moab into your hands.
2 Kings 3:19 You will strike every fortified city and every excellent city. You will cut down every fruit tree, stop up every spring of water, and ruin every good field with stones.
2 Kings 3:20 So it happened in the morning, at the time when the sacrifice was offered, that behold, water came by way of Edom, and the land was filled with water.
2 Kings 3:21 Now all the Moabites, hearing that the kings had come up to fight against them, gathered everyone who could put on a belt for battle and stood at their border.
2 Kings 3:22 When they rose early in the morning, and the sun was shining opposite them, the Moabites saw the water in the distance, appearing to them like blood.
2 Kings 3:23 And they said, 'This is blood! The kings must have fought with their swords and killed each other. Now, Moab, to the plunder!'
2 Kings 3:24 But when the Moabites came to the camp of Israel, the Israelites rose up and struck the Moabites, who fled before them. The Israelites pursued them and continued to strike Moab.
2 Kings 3:25 They destroyed their cities and filled every good field with stones by throwing them. They stopped up every spring of water and cut down every fruit tree. So only the walls of stones were left in Kir-hareseth. Then the forces surrounded the city with slingers and attacked it.
2 Kings 3:26 When the king of Moab saw that the battle was too fierce for him, he took with him seven hundred swordsmen to break through to the king of Edom's position, but they were unable.
2 Kings 3:27 Then he took his eldest son, who was to succeed him as king, and offered him as a burnt offering upon the city wall. This act caused great wrath to fall upon Israel. Immediately, they withdrew from him and returned to their own land.
2 Kings 3:1 Joram, the son of Ahab, began to rule over Israel in Samaria during the eighteenth year of Jehoshaphat, the king of Judah. He reigned for twelve years.
2 Kings 3:2 He did evil in the sight of the Lord, but not to the extent of his father and mother, for he removed the stone column of Baal that his father had made.
2 Kings 3:3 Nevertheless, he clung to the sins of Jeroboam, the son of Nabat, who had caused Israel to sin, and he did not turn away from them.
2 Kings 3:4 Now Mesa, the king of Moab, was a sheep breeder. He used to pay the king of Israel a tribute of one hundred thousand lambs, and one hundred thousand rams with their wool.
2 Kings 3:5 But when Ahab died, the king of Moab rebelled against the king of Israel.
2 Kings 3:6 So King Joram left Samaria that very day and reviewed all the men of Israel.
2 Kings 3:7 He went and sent a message to Jehoshaphat, the king of Judah, saying: 'The king of Moab has rebelled against me. Will you come with me to fight against Moab?' Jehoshaphat replied: 'I will go up with you. My people are like your people, and my horses are like your horses.'
2 Kings 3:8 Joram then asked: 'By which way should we march up?' Jehoshaphat answered: 'Through the way of the desert of Edom.'
2 Kings 3:9 So the king of Israel, the king of Judah, and the king of Edom went forth. They marched in a roundabout way for seven days, and there was no water for the army or for the animals that followed them.
2 Kings 3:10 The king of Israel cried out: 'Alas, alas! Has the Lord called these three kings together only to deliver them into the hand of Moab?'
2 Kings 3:11 Then Jehoshaphat asked: 'Is there no prophet of the Lord here, that we may inquire of the Lord through him?' One of the servants of the king of Israel answered: 'Elisha, the son of Shaphat, is here, he who poured water over the hands of Elijah.'
2 Kings 3:12 And Jehoshaphat said: 'The word of the Lord is with him.' So the king of Israel, Jehoshaphat, and the king of Edom went down to him.
2 Kings 3:13 Elisha said to the king of Israel: 'What concern have I with you? Go to the prophets of your father and your mother.' The king of Israel replied to him: 'No, because the Lord has called these three kings together to deliver them into the hand of Moab!'
2 Kings 3:14 Then Elisha said: 'As the Lord of hosts lives, before whom I stand, if it were not for my respect for Jehoshaphat, the king of Judah, I would not even give you attention or look at you.'
2 Kings 3:15 Now, bring me a harpist. And when the harpist played, the hand of the Lord came upon Elisha.
2 Kings 3:16 And he said: 'Thus says the Lord: Make this valley full of ditches, dig many ditches.'
2 Kings 3:17 For thus says the Lord: 'You will not see wind, nor will you see rain, yet this valley will be filled with water, and you, your livestock, and your flocks will drink.'
2 Kings 3:18 And this is but a small thing in the sight of the Lord: He will also deliver Moab into your hands.
2 Kings 3:19 You will strike every fortified city and every excellent city. You will cut down every fruitful tree, and you will stop up all springs of water, and you will ruin every good field with stones.
2 Kings 3:20 So it came to pass in the morning, at the time when the sacrifice is usually offered, that suddenly water came by the way of Edom, and the land was filled with water.
2 Kings 3:21 Now all the Moabites, hearing that the kings had come up to fight against them, gathered together everyone who could put on armor, from young men to old, and they stood at their borders.
2 Kings 3:22 Rising early in the morning, as the sun rose opposite the water, the Moabites saw the water from afar, red like blood.
2 Kings 3:23 And they said: 'This is the blood of the sword! The kings must have fought against each other and killed one another. Now, Moab, to the plunder!'
2 Kings 3:24 But when they came to the camp of Israel, the Israelites rose up and struck the Moabites, who fled before them. They pursued them, striking down and devastating Moab.
2 Kings 3:25 They also destroyed the cities, and every good field they filled with stones by each man throwing a stone. They stopped up all the springs of water and cut down every fruitful tree, so that only the walls of the city of Kir Haraseth remained. The slingers surrounded it and struck it.
2 Kings 3:26 When the king of Moab saw that the battle was too fierce for him, he took with him seven hundred men who drew swords to break through to the king of Edom, but he could not.
2 Kings 3:27 Then he took his firstborn son, who was to reign in his place, and offered him as a burnt offering upon the wall. And there was great indignation in Israel. Immediately, they withdrew from him and returned to their own land.
2 Kings 3:1 Moab rebelled against Israel after King Achab died.
2 Kings 3:2 Now Joram, son of Achab, began his reign over Israel in Samaria during the eighteenth year of Josaphat's kingship in Judah, and Joram reigned for twelve years.
2 Kings 3:3 And he did what was evil in the sight of the Lord, yet not to the same degree as his father and mother had done, for he had removed the idols of Baal that his father had erected.
2 Kings 3:4 Now Mesa, the king of Moab, was a wealthy sheep breeder, and he was required to pay the king of Israel a tribute of one hundred thousand lambs and one hundred thousand rams with their wool.
2 Kings 3:5 But when King Achab had died, Mesa, the king of Moab, openly rebelled against the king of Israel.
2 Kings 3:6 So King Joram marched out from Samaria at that time and mustered all the fighting men of Israel.
2 Kings 3:7 And Joram sent a message to Josaphat, the king of Judah, saying: 'The king of Moab has rebelled against me. Will you come with me to Moab to wage war?' Josaphat replied: 'I will indeed go with you. My resources are entirely at your disposal, my people are your people, and my horses are your horses.'
2 Kings 3:8 Then Joram asked, 'By what route should our army advance?' And Josaphat replied, 'We should go through the desert route of Edom.'
2 Kings 3:9 So the king of Israel, the king of Judah, and the king of Edom began their march. After they had traveled for seven days, there was no water left for their army or for the animals that accompanied them.
2 Kings 3:10 Then the king of Israel cried out, 'Oh no! Has the Lord truly brought these three kings together just to deliver us into the hand of Moab?'
2 Kings 3:11 Then Josaphat asked, 'Is there no prophet of the Lord present here, through whom we might inquire of the Lord's will?' One of the servants of the king of Israel answered, saying: 'Elisha, the son of Saphat, is here. He is the one who used to pour water on Elijah’s hands, serving him as a disciple.'
2 Kings 3:12 Josaphat then declared, 'The Lord's message is truly with him.' So the king of Israel, Josaphat, and the king of Edom went down to Elisha.
2 Kings 3:13 Then Elisha said to the king of Israel, 'What business do I have with you? Go to the prophets of your father and your mother, the prophets of Baal!' But the king of Israel pleaded with him, 'It is because the Lord has truly called these three kings together only to deliver us into the hand of Moab!'
2 Kings 3:14 Then Elisha declared: 'As the Lord of hosts lives, before Whom I stand in service, if it were not for my respect for Josaphat, the king of Judah, I would not even look at you nor acknowledge your presence!'
2 Kings 3:15 Now, therefore, bring me a musician to play a stringed instrument.' And while the musician played, the power of the Lord came upon Elisha.
2 Kings 3:16 And Elisha declared: 'Thus says the Lord: "Dig many ditches and trenches throughout this dry valley!"'
2 Kings 3:17 For thus says the Lord: 'Even though you will see no wind or rain, this valley will be filled with water, so that you, your families, and your animals can drink.'
2 Kings 3:18 And this miracle alone is but a small thing in the sight of the Lord; He will also deliver Moab, your enemy, into your hands.
2 Kings 3:19 And you will conquer every fortified city and destroy every important town. You will cut down every fruit-bearing tree, stop up every spring of water, and ruin every fertile field by covering it with stones.
2 Kings 3:20 So it came to pass the next morning, at the hour when the daily sacrifice was customarily offered, and behold, water began to flow from the direction of Edom, and the land was quickly filled with water.
2 Kings 3:21 Now all the Moabites, hearing that the allied kings had come up to fight against them, called together every man who was able to bear arms, from the youngest to the oldest, and they took their stand at their borders.
2 Kings 3:22 And they rose early in the morning, and when the sun had fully risen, shining on the water, the Moabites looked and saw the water appearing as red as blood.
2 Kings 3:23 And they exclaimed, 'This is blood! The allied kings must have fought fiercely and slaughtered each other with their swords! Everyone must have slain his neighbor! Now, therefore, Moab, let us go for the plunder!'
2 Kings 3:24 But when the Moabites approached the camp of Israel, the men of Israel suddenly rose up and struck down the Moabites, who then fled in panic before them. As the Israelites pursued and struck down the Moabites, they continued to lay waste to the entire region.
2 Kings 3:25 And the allied armies continued to destroy the cities, filling every fertile field with stones. They stopped up every spring of water and cut down every fruit-bearing tree, leaving only the stone walls of the final stronghold. They surrounded this last remaining city with siege works and relentlessly attacked it with sling stones from above.
2 Kings 3:26 Now when the king of Moab saw that the battle was completely lost to his enemies, he took with him seven hundred men who drew swords, hoping to break through the lines towards the king of Edom; but they were unable to succeed.
2 Kings 3:27 Then, in a desperate act, he took his eldest son, who was destined to succeed him as king, and offered him as a burnt offering upon the city wall. This act caused great moral indignation among the allied forces, who immediately withdrew from the city and returned to their own land.
2 Kings 4:1 A certain woman, one of the wives of your prophet-disciples, cried out to Elisha, saying: 'My husband, your servant, is dead. And you know that your servant was a man who truly feared the Lord—a devout man. But now, a creditor is coming to take my two sons to be his slaves, to settle their father's debt!'
2 Kings 4:2 Elisha then asked her: 'What do you want me to do for you, my child? Tell me, what do you have in your house?' She replied: 'Your servant has absolutely nothing left in my house, except a tiny bit of oil, just enough for personal anointing.'
2 Kings 4:3 And he said to her: 'Go now, and borrow empty vessels from all your neighbors—and make sure to get many of them, not just a few!'
2 Kings 4:4 Then go inside, and close the door upon yourself and your sons. Begin to pour your existing oil into all these empty vessels. And as each vessel becomes full, set it aside.'
2 Kings 4:5 So the woman went and did as Elisha commanded. She closed the door upon herself and her sons. Her sons began bringing her the empty vessels, and she continued pouring from her small jar.
2 Kings 4:6 When all the vessels were full, she said to her son: 'Bring me another vessel.' But he responded: 'There are no more!' At that very moment, the flow of oil stopped completely.
2 Kings 4:7 So she went and told the man of God what had happened. He said: 'Go, sell the oil, and repay your creditor. You and your sons can then live on the rest of the money.'
2 Kings 4:8 It happened one day that Elisha was passing through Shunem. There was a prominent and wealthy woman there, who urged him to come and eat bread with her. So whenever he passed through, he would turn aside to her house to eat bread.
2 Kings 4:9 She said to her husband: 'I perceive that this is a holy man of God who frequently passes by our house.'
2 Kings 4:10 She continued: 'Let us make a small room on the roof for him, and furnish it with a bed, a table, a chair, and a lamp. Then, whenever he comes to us, he can stay there.'
2 Kings 4:11 So it happened one day that when Elisha came, he went to that room and rested there.
2 Kings 4:12 Then he said to Gehazi, his servant: 'Call this Shunammite woman.' When Gehazi called her, and she stood before Elisha,
2 Kings 4:13 Elisha said to Gehazi: 'Speak to her and tell her: “Behold, you have diligently provided for us and shown us every kindness. What do you wish that I do for you in return? Do you want me to speak on your behalf to the king, or to the commander of the army?”' She replied: 'I dwell among my own people—I lack nothing.'
2 Kings 4:14 And Elisha asked: 'What then can be done for her?' Gehazi replied: 'She has no son, and her husband is an old man.'
2 Kings 4:15 So Elisha commanded that she be called again. When she was called, and stood in the doorway, he said:
2 Kings 4:16 'At this very time, in this same season, in the coming year, you shall embrace a son.' But she exclaimed: 'No, my lord, man of God, do not lie to your handmaid!'
2 Kings 4:17 And indeed, the woman conceived and bore a son at the very time and in the season that Elisha had promised her.
2 Kings 4:18 The boy grew up. And it happened one day that he went out to his father, who was with the reapers in the field,
2 Kings 4:19 and he cried out to his father: 'My head, my head aches! My head, my head aches!' His father then said to one of the servants: 'Carry him home, and take him to his mother.'
2 Kings 4:20 So the servant carried him and brought him to his mother. She held him on her knees until midday, and then he died.
2 Kings 4:21 Then she went up to the room, placed him on the bed of the man of God, closed the door, and left.
2 Kings 4:22 She called her husband, saying: 'Please send me one of the young men and a donkey, so I can hurry to the man of God and return quickly.'
2 Kings 4:23 He asked: 'For what reason are you going to him today? Is it the New Moon festival or the Sabbath day?' She replied, cryptically: 'It is well.' —meaning 'All is fine, I will explain later.'
2 Kings 4:24 So she saddled the donkey and instructed her servant: 'Drive quickly; do not slow down the pace unless I tell you to.'
2 Kings 4:25 Thus she went and arrived at the man of God, Elisha, on Mount Carmel. When the man of God saw her from a distance, he said to his servant Gehazi: 'Look, it is that Shunammite woman!'
2 Kings 4:26 'Run now to meet her,' he instructed, 'and ask her: “Is all well with you? Is all well with your husband? Is all well with your son?”' She replied, again briefly: 'All is well.'
2 Kings 4:27 But when she reached the man of God on the mountain, she grasped his feet. Gehazi approached to push her away. But the man of God said: 'Leave her alone, for her soul is in bitterness. The Lord has hidden it from me and has not revealed it to me.'
2 Kings 4:28 And she cried out: 'Did I ask for a son from my lord? Did I not say to you: “Do not deceive me”?'
2 Kings 4:29 Elisha then said to Gehazi: 'Gird up your loins, take my staff in your hand, and go. If you meet anyone on the way, do not greet them; and if anyone greets you, do not answer them. Place my staff upon the face of the boy.'
2 Kings 4:30 But the mother of the boy declared: 'As the Lord lives, and as your soul lives, I will not leave you!' So Elisha arose and followed her.
2 Kings 4:31 Meanwhile, Gehazi had gone ahead of them and had placed the staff upon the boy's face. But there was no voice, nor any sign of life. So he returned to meet Elisha and reported to him, saying: 'The boy has not awakened.'
2 Kings 4:32 Then Elisha entered the house, and behold, the boy was lying dead on his own bed.
2 Kings 4:33 He went in and closed the door behind himself and the boy, and he prayed to the Lord.
2 Kings 4:34 Then he went up and lay upon the boy, putting his mouth upon his mouth, and his eyes upon his eyes, and his hands upon his hands. He stretched himself out upon him, and the boy's flesh began to grow warm.
2 Kings 4:35 Elisha then went down and walked around in the house once more. Then he went up again and stretched himself out upon the boy once more. And the boy sneezed seven times, and then opened his eyes.
2 Kings 4:36 Elisha called Gehazi and told him: 'Call this Shunammite woman.' When she was called, she came in to him. He said: 'Take up your son!'
2 Kings 4:37 She came in, fell at his feet, and prostrated herself on the ground in worship. Then she took up her son and went out.
2 Kings 4:38 Elisha then returned to Gilgal. There was a severe famine in the land, and the prophet-disciples were sitting before him. He said to one of his servants: 'Put a large pot on the fire, and cook a stew for the prophet-disciples.'
2 Kings 4:39 One of them went out into the field to gather herbs. He found a wild plant and gathered enough of its fruit to fill his cloak, —like wild gourds—. He came back and chopped them into the pot of stew, for they did not know what it was.
2 Kings 4:40 So they served it to the men to eat. But when they tasted the stew, they cried out, saying: 'There is death in the pot, O man of God! There is death in the pot!' And they could not eat it.
2 Kings 4:1 A certain woman, one of the wives of the prophets, cried out to Elisha, saying: “Your servant, my husband, is dead. You know that your servant lived in holy fear of the Lord. And now a creditor has come to take my two sons to be his slaves to pay off the debt.”
2 Kings 4:2 And Elisha said to her: “What do you want me to do for you? Tell me, what do you have in your house?” And she responded: “Your handmaid has nothing in my house, except a small amount of oil.”
2 Kings 4:3 He said: “Go and borrow many empty vessels from all your neighbors. Make sure there are not just a few.”
2 Kings 4:4 Then go inside and shut the door behind you and your sons. Pour the oil into all these vessels. And when they are full, set them aside.”
2 Kings 4:5 So the woman went away and shut the door upon herself and upon her sons. They brought the vessels to her, and she kept pouring.
