2 Kings 4:6 And when all the vessels were full, she said to her son: “Bring me still another vessel.” He responded: “There are no more.”
2 Kings 4:7 And at that moment, the oil stopped flowing.
2 Kings 4:8 So she came and told the man of God. He said: “Go, sell the oil, and pay the creditor. You and your sons can then live on the rest of the money.”
2 Kings 4:9 Now it happened that Elisha was passing through Shunem. And there was a wealthy and influential woman there, who urged him to eat bread with her. So whenever he passed by, he would turn aside to her house to eat bread.
2 Kings 4:10 And she said to her husband: “I perceive that this man, who passes by us so frequently, is a holy man of God.”
2 Kings 4:11 “Let us make a small upper room for him and put in it a small bed, and a table, and a chair, and a lamp. So that when he comes to us, he may stay there.”
2 Kings 4:12 So it happened one day that Elisha came, and he turned aside to the upper room and rested there.
2 Kings 4:13 And he said to Gehazi, his servant: “Call this Shunammite woman.” And when he had called her, and she stood before him,
2 Kings 4:14 Elisha said to his servant: “What do you want me to do for her?” Gehazi responded: “Indeed, she has no son, and her husband is old.”
2 Kings 4:15 So he commanded: “Call her.” And when he had called her, she stood in the doorway.
2 Kings 4:16 And he said to her: “At this time next year, you will hold a son in your womb.” But she responded: “No, my lord, man of God, do not deceive your handmaid.”
2 Kings 4:17 So the woman conceived and bore a son at that very time, and at the same hour, as Elisha had said.
2 Kings 4:18 And the boy grew up. And it happened one day that he went out to his father among the reapers in the field.
2 Kings 4:19 He said to his father: “My head hurts, my head hurts!” And his father said to a servant: “Take him and bring him to his mother.”
2 Kings 4:20 And when the servant had taken him and brought him to his mother, the boy sat on her knees until midday, and then he died.
2 Kings 4:21 But she went up and laid him upon the bed of the man of God, shut the door, and went out.
2 Kings 4:22 And she called her husband, saying: “Send me one of the servants and one of the donkeys, so that I may quickly go to the man of God and return.”
2 Kings 4:23 He said: “For what reason are you going to him? It is not the new moon, nor the Sabbath.” These were the customary times people visited prophets. She responded: “It is well.”
2 Kings 4:24 So she saddled the donkey and sat upon it. And she said to her servant: “Drive fast and hurry. Do not speak to me unless I tell you.”
2 Kings 4:25 So she went, and came to the man of God on Mount Carmel. And when the man of God saw her from a distance, he said to Gehazi, his servant: “Behold, there is that Shunammite woman!”
2 Kings 4:26 “Go to meet her and ask: ‘Is all well? Is your husband well? Is your son well?’” And she responded: “All is well.”
2 Kings 4:27 But when she came to the man of God on the mountain, she took hold of his feet. And Gehazi came near to push her away. But the man of God said: “Leave her alone, for her soul is in bitterness. The Lord has hidden it from me and has not revealed it to me.”
2 Kings 4:28 And she said: “Did I ask for a son from my lord? Did I not say to you: ‘Do not deceive me?’”
2 Kings 4:29 And Elisha said to Gehazi: “Gird up your loins and prepare for urgent travel. Take my staff in your hand and go. If you meet anyone, do not greet him. And if anyone greets you, do not answer him. Lay my staff upon the face of the boy.”
2 Kings 4:30 And the mother of the boy said: “As the Lord lives, and as your soul lives, I will not leave you.” So he arose and went with her.
2 Kings 4:31 But Gehazi had gone ahead of them and had laid the staff upon the face of the boy. And there was no voice, nor any sign of life. So he returned and met Elisha, and announced to him, saying: “The boy has not awoken.”
2 Kings 4:32 So Elisha went into the upper room, and behold, the dead boy lay upon his own bed.
2 Kings 4:33 And having entered, he shut the door upon himself and upon the boy, and prayed to the Lord.
2 Kings 4:34 Then he went up and lay upon the boy. He put his mouth upon his mouth, and his eyes upon his eyes, and his hands upon his hands. And he stretched himself upon him, and the flesh of the boy grew warm.
2 Kings 4:35 And he turned away and walked through the house once within, and then went up again. He stretched himself upon him, and the boy sneezed seven times, and then opened his eyes.
2 Kings 4:36 And he called Gehazi, and said to him: “Call this Shunammite woman.” And when he had called her, and she had come in to him, Elisha said: “Take your son.”
2 Kings 4:37 She came, and fell at his feet, and bowed deeply in reverence towards the ground. Then she took her son and went out.
2 Kings 4:38 Now Elisha returned to Gilgal. There was a famine in the land, and the community of prophets were sitting before him. And he said to one of his servants: “Put on the large pot and cook stew for the community of prophets.”
2 Kings 4:39 But one went out into the field to gather wild herbs. He found something like a wild vine and gathered wild gourds from it, filling his cloak. And when he returned, he cut them into the pot of stew, for they did not know what it was. These gourds were poisonous.
2 Kings 4:40 And they poured it out for their companions to eat. But when they had eaten of that stew, they cried out, saying: “Death is in the pot, O man of God!” And they could not eat it.
2 Kings 4:1 A certain woman, one of the wives of the prophets, cried out to Elisha, saying, "Your servant, my husband, has died, and you know that your servant truly feared the Lord. Now, look, a creditor has come to take my two sons as slaves for himself to settle the debt."
2 Kings 4:2 Then Elisha said to her, "What do you want me to do for you? Tell me, what do you have in your house?" She answered, "Your maidservant has nothing at all in the house, except a single small jar of oil."
2 Kings 4:3 He said, "Go now and borrow empty vessels from all your neighbors. Make sure there are not just a few of them, but many."
2 Kings 4:4 Then, go inside and shut the door behind you and your sons. Pour the oil from your jar into all these borrowed vessels. When they are full, set them aside."
2 Kings 4:5 So the woman went away and shut the door behind herself and her sons. They brought her the vessels, and she continued to pour the oil.
2 Kings 4:6 When all the vessels were full, she said to her son, "Bring me another vessel." He responded, "There isn't another vessel left." And then the oil stopped flowing.
2 Kings 4:7 Then she went and told the man of God what had happened. He said, "Go now, sell the oil, and pay your creditor. After that, you and your sons can live on the rest of the money."
2 Kings 4:8 It came to pass one day that Elisha was passing through Shunem. There was a prominent woman there who urged him to eat bread. And whenever he passed by frequently, he would turn aside to her house to eat bread.
2 Kings 4:9 She said to her husband, "Look, I perceive that this man who passes by us so often is a holy man of God."
2 Kings 4:10 "Let us make a small room for him on the roof, and put a bed in it for him, and a table, and a chair, and a lampstand. Then, whenever he comes to us, he can stay there."
2 Kings 4:11 So it came to pass one day that Elisha came, turned aside to the room on the roof, and rested there.
2 Kings 4:12 He said to Gehazi, his servant, "Call this Shunammite woman." When Gehazi had called her, and she stood before Elisha,
2 Kings 4:13 Elisha said to Gehazi, "Tell her: 'Behold, you have gone to great trouble for us with all your hospitality. What do you want me to do for you in return? Do you have any request you want me to speak to the king about, or to the commander of the army?'" She responded, "I live among my own people; I am content with my position in life and have no need of royal connections."
2 Kings 4:14 Elisha then said, "What then can be done for her?" And Gehazi answered, "She has no son, and her husband is old."
2 Kings 4:15 So he commanded that she be called. When she had been called and stood in the doorway, Elisha said,
2 Kings 4:16 "At this same time next year, when life returns in its cycle, you will be holding a son in your arms." But she responded, "No, my lord, man of God, do not lie to your maidservant about such a hope."
2 Kings 4:17 And indeed, the woman conceived and gave birth to a son at that very time, at the exact hour Elisha had told her.
2 Kings 4:18 So the boy grew up. And it happened one day that he went out to his father among the reapers in the field.
2 Kings 4:19 He said to his father, "My head hurts, my head hurts!" So his father said to a servant, "Carry him and take him to his mother."
2 Kings 4:20 When the servant had carried him and brought him to his mother, she laid him on her lap until noon, and then he died.
2 Kings 4:21 But she went up to the room on the roof and laid him on the bed of the man of God. Then she shut the door and went out.
2 Kings 4:22 She called her husband, saying, "Send me one of the young men and a donkey, so I can ride quickly to the man of God and return."
2 Kings 4:23 Her husband said to her, "Why are you going to him today? It is not the New Moon festival, nor is it the Sabbath day, when people typically seek out prophets." She responded, "All is well," keeping her son's death a secret.
2 Kings 4:24 So she saddled the donkey and instructed her servant, "Drive steadily and hurry. Do not stop speaking to me on the way unless I tell you to."
2 Kings 4:25 So she set out and came to the man of God on Mount Carmel. When the man of God saw her coming from a distance, he said to Gehazi, his servant, "Look, there is that Shunammite woman."
2 Kings 4:26 "Therefore, go meet her and ask: 'Are you well? Is your husband well? Is the boy well?'" She responded, "All is well."
2 Kings 4:27 When she came to the man of God on the mountain, she grasped his feet. And Gehazi came near to push her away. But the man of God said, "Leave her alone, for her soul is in bitterness and anguish, and the Lord has hidden it from me and not revealed it to me."
2 Kings 4:28 And she said, "Did I ask my lord for a son? Did I not say to you, 'Do not deceive me with false hope' (by promising a son)?"
2 Kings 4:29 Then Elisha said to Gehazi, "Gird up your loins and take my staff in your hand. Go quickly! If you meet anyone on the way, do not greet them with conversation, and if anyone greets you, do not answer them. Then, place my staff on the boy's face."
2 Kings 4:30 But the boy's mother said, "As the Lord lives, and as your soul lives, I will not leave you and go without you." So Elisha rose and went with her.
2 Kings 4:31 Meanwhile, Gehazi had gone ahead of them and had placed the staff on the boy's face. But there was no voice, and no sign of life or consciousness. So he returned to meet Elisha and reported to him, saying, "The boy has not awakened."
2 Kings 4:32 Then Elisha entered the room on the roof, and behold, the dead boy was lying on his bed.
2 Kings 4:33 So he went out, closed the door behind him, and prayed to the Lord.
2 Kings 4:34 Then he went up onto the bed and lay stretched out over the boy. He put his mouth on the boy's mouth, his eyes on the boy's eyes, and his hands on the boy's hands. As he remained bowed over the boy, the boy's flesh grew warm.
2 Kings 4:35 Then Elisha returned and walked around the house once or twice. After that, he went up again and stretched out over him. The boy then sneezed seven times, and he opened his eyes.
2 Kings 4:36 Elisha called Gehazi and said to him, "Call that Shunammite woman." So she was called and came in to him. Elisha said, "Take up your son."
2 Kings 4:37 She came, fell at his feet, and prostrated herself on the ground in worship and profound gratitude. Then she took up her son and went out.
2 Kings 4:38 Elisha returned to Gilgal, as there was a severe famine in the land. The sons of the prophets were sitting before him for instruction. He said to one of his servants, "Put a large pot on, and boil some stew for the sons of the prophets."
2 Kings 4:39 Then one of them went out into the field to gather herbs. He found a wild plant and gathered from it wild gourds, filling his cloak. He returned and cut them into the pot of stew, without anyone knowing what they were.
2 Kings 4:40 When the stew was poured out for the men to eat, as they ate, they cried out, saying, "There is death in the pot, O man of God!" And they could not eat it.
2 Kings 5:1 Naaman, the commander of the Syrian army, was a very rich, noble, and powerful man. However, he was a leper.
2 Kings 5:2 Syrian raiders had previously gone out into Israel, and they had captured a young girl. This girl was now serving Naaman’s wife.
2 Kings 5:3 The young girl said to her mistress, “If only my master Naaman would go to the prophet who lives in Samaria, he would certainly be cured of his leprosy.”
2 Kings 5:4 Naaman then went to his king and reported what the girl from the land of Israel had said.
2 Kings 5:5 The king of Syria told Naaman, “Go now, and I will send a letter to the king of Israel.” So Naaman departed, taking with him ten talents of silver, six thousand shekels of gold, and six changes of fine clothing as gifts.
2 Kings 5:6 He brought the letter to the king of Israel. The letter read: “When you receive this letter, know that I have sent my servant Naaman to you so that you may cure him of his leprosy.”
2 Kings 5:7 When the king of Israel read the letter, he tore his clothes and exclaimed, “Am I God, able to kill and to give life, that this man sends someone to me to be cured of leprosy? This is obviously a pretext; he is looking for a reason to attack me.”
2 Kings 5:8 However, when Elisha, the man of God, heard that the king of Israel had torn his clothes, he sent a message to the king, saying: “Why have you torn your clothes? Let Naaman come to me, and he will know that there is a true prophet in Israel.”
2 Kings 5:9 So Naaman came with his horses and chariots and stood at the entrance of Elisha’s house.
2 Kings 5:10 Elisha sent a messenger out to Naaman, telling him, “Go and wash yourself seven times in the Jordan River. Your flesh will be restored, and you will be clean.”
2 Kings 5:11 Naaman departed in anger, saying, “I thought he would come out to me personally, and stand, and call on the name of the Lord his God, and wave his hand over the place of my leprosy, and cure me.”
2 Kings 5:12 He continued, “Are not the rivers of Damascus, Abana and Pharphar, better than all the waters of Israel? Could I not wash in them and be clean?” He then turned and went away in a rage.
2 Kings 5:13 His servants approached him and reasoned with him, saying, “Father, if the prophet had commanded you to do some difficult thing, you would certainly have done it. How much more, then, when he simply tells you: ‘Wash, and you will be clean’?”
2 Kings 5:14 So Naaman went down and washed himself seven times in the Jordan, just as the man of God had instructed. His flesh was restored, becoming like the flesh of a young child, and he was completely clean.
2 Kings 5:15 Then Naaman returned to the man of God with all his company. He came and stood before Elisha and declared, “Now I truly know that there is no other God in all the earth except in Israel. Therefore, I beg you, please accept a gift from your servant.”
2 Kings 5:16 Elisha replied, “As the Lord lives, before whom I stand, I will accept nothing from you.” Naaman urged him, but Elisha refused.
2 Kings 5:17 Then Naaman said, “If you will not accept a gift, then please, let me, your servant, be given two mule-loads of this Israelite earth. For from now on, your servant will no longer offer burnt offerings or sacrifices to foreign gods, but only to the Lord.”
2 Kings 5:18 Naaman continued, “But in this one thing, I ask the Lord to forgive your servant: when my king enters the temple of Rimmon to worship there, and he leans on my arm, and I bow down in the temple of Rimmon along with him, may the Lord forgive me, your servant, for this act of bowing.”
2 Kings 5:19 Elisha said to him, “Go in peace.” So Naaman departed from him, and had traveled only a short distance.
2 Kings 5:20 Gehazi, the servant of Elisha the man of God, said to himself, “Look, my master has spared this Naaman the Syrian, by not accepting from his hand what he brought. As the Lord lives, I will surely run after him and get something from him!”
2 Kings 5:21 So Gehazi pursued Naaman. When Naaman saw him running after him, he quickly dismounted from his chariot to meet him and asked, “Is everything all right?”
2 Kings 5:22 Gehazi replied, “Yes, everything is well. My master sent me, saying, ‘Look, two young men, members of the prophets’ community, have just arrived from the hill country of Ephraim. Please give them a talent of silver and two changes of clothing.’”
2 Kings 5:23 Naaman said, “By all means, take two talents!” He urged Gehazi to accept them, and then tied up two talents of silver in two bags, along with two changes of clothing. He gave them to two of his servants, who carried them ahead of Gehazi.
2 Kings 5:24 When Gehazi reached the hill, he took the gifts from their hands and put them away in the house. Then he sent the men away, and they departed.
2 Kings 5:25 He then went in and stood before his master. Elisha asked him, “Where have you come from, Gehazi?” He answered, “Your servant has not been anywhere.”
2 Kings 5:26 But Elisha replied, “Was not my spirit present when the man turned from his chariot to meet you? Is this the time to accept money, and to accept clothes, and olive groves, and vineyards, and sheep, and oxen, and male and female servants?” This rhetorical question from Elisha implies that it was a time of spiritual significance, not personal gain.
2 Kings 5:27 Elisha concluded, “Therefore, the leprosy of Naaman will cling to you and to your descendants forever.” And immediately, Gehazi departed from Elisha, a leper, white as snow.
2 Kings 5:1 Naaman was the commander of the Syrian king’s army. He was a great man and highly esteemed by his master, because the Lord had granted the Syrians victory through him. He was also a powerful and wealthy man, but he was suffering from leprosy.
2 Kings 5:2 Now some raiders had gone out from the land of Syria, and they had taken captive a young girl from the land of Israel, who now served Naaman’s wife.
2 Kings 5:3 She said to her mistress, 'If only my master would go to the prophet who is in Samaria, he would certainly cure him of the leprosy he has.'
2 Kings 5:4 So Naaman went in and told his master, saying, 'The girl from the land of Israel said these things.'
2 Kings 5:5 And the king of Syria said to him, 'Go, and I will send letters to the king of Israel.' When Naaman departed, he took with him ten talents of silver, six thousand shekels of gold, and six changes of garments.
2 Kings 5:6 And he brought the letters to the king of Israel, saying, 'When you receive this letter, know that I have sent my servant Naaman to you, so that you may cure him of his leprosy.'
2 Kings 5:7 When the king of Israel read the letters, he tore his clothes in grief and alarm, and said, 'Am I God, that I can kill and make alive, that this man sends to me to cure a person of his leprosy? Observe and see that he is seeking an opportunity for conflict against me.'
2 Kings 5:8 When Elisha, the man of God, heard that the king of Israel had torn his clothes, he sent a message to the king, saying, 'Why have you torn your clothes? Let him come to me, and he will know that there is a prophet in Israel, a man of God who can intercede.'
2 Kings 5:9 So Naaman came with his horses and chariots, and he stopped at the door of Elisha’s house.
2 Kings 5:10 And Elisha sent a messenger to him, saying, 'Go, and wash seven times in the Jordan River, and your flesh will be restored to health, and you will be clean from your leprosy.'
2 Kings 5:11 Naaman departed in anger, saying, 'I thought that he would surely come out to me, and stand and call on the name of the Lord his God, and wave his hand over the place of the leprosy, and cure me.'
2 Kings 5:12 'Are not the rivers of Damascus, Abana and Pharpar, better than all the waters of Israel, that I might wash in them and be clean?' And when he had turned away and was going off in indignation, his servants approached him.
2 Kings 5:13 His servants approached him and spoke to him, saying, 'My father, even if the prophet had told you to do something difficult, you would surely have done it. How much more now that he has said to you, ‘Wash, and you will be clean’?'
2 Kings 5:14 So he went down and washed seven times in the Jordan, according to the word of the man of God. And his flesh was restored like the flesh of a little child, and he was made clean.
2 Kings 5:15 And he returned to the man of God with all his company. He came and stood before him, and said, 'Now I truly know that there is no other God in all the earth, except only in Israel. Therefore, I beg you to accept a gift from your servant.'
2 Kings 5:16 Elisha answered, 'As the Lord lives, before whom I stand, I will not accept it.' And though Naaman urged him, he refused to take the gift.
2 Kings 5:17 Naaman then said, 'If you will not accept a gift, then please, let two mule-loads of earth be given to your servant. For your servant will no longer offer burnt offering or sacrifice to other gods, but only to the Lord, the one true God.'
2 Kings 5:18 But for this one thing alone I pray to the Lord, that when my king enters the temple of Rimmon to worship there, and he leans on my arm, and I bow myself in the temple of Rimmon while he worships in that place — may the Lord forgive your servant for this action, understanding that it is out of duty to my king, not true worship of an idol.
2 Kings 5:19 And Elisha said to him, 'Go in peace.' So Naaman had traveled only a short distance from him.
2 Kings 5:20 But Gehazi, the servant of the man of God, said, 'Behold, my master has let this Naaman, this Syrian, depart without accepting from him what he brought. As the Lord lives, I will run after him and take something from him!'
2 Kings 5:21 So Gehazi pursued Naaman. When Naaman saw him running after him, he dismounted from his chariot to meet him, and said, 'Is everything well?'
2 Kings 5:22 And Gehazi said, 'All is well. My master sent me, saying: Behold, just now two young men from the hill country of Ephraim, from the sons of the prophets, have come to me. Please give them a talent of silver and two changes of garments.'
2 Kings 5:23 Naaman said, 'No, rather take two talents of silver!' And he urged him to take it. Then Naaman tied up two talents of silver in two bags, along with two changes of garments, and put them on two of his servants, who then carried them ahead of Gehazi.
2 Kings 5:24 When Gehazi arrived at the hill, he took the gifts from their hands and stored them in his house. Then he sent the men away, and they departed.
2 Kings 5:25 And he went in and stood before his master. Elisha said to him, 'From where have you come, Gehazi?' He answered, 'Your servant went nowhere.' He was attempting to deceive his master.
2 Kings 5:26 But Elisha said, 'Was not my spirit present when the man turned from his chariot to meet you? Is this the time now to receive money, and to receive garments, and to buy olive groves, and vineyards, and sheep, and oxen, and male servants, and female servants?'
2 Kings 5:27 'Therefore, the leprosy of Naaman will cling to you and to your descendants forever.' And Gehazi went out from his presence, a leper, as white as snow.
2 Kings 6:1 And the disciples of the prophets spoke to Elisha, saying, "Look, this place where we are living with you is too small for all of us."
2 Kings 6:2 They continued, "Let's go down to the Jordan River, and each of us can cut down a tree trunk or log so we can build a larger dwelling place for ourselves there."
2 Kings 6:3 And Elisha responded, "Go ahead."
2 Kings 6:4 Then one of the prophets' disciples said to Elisha, "Please come with us, your servants."
2 Kings 6:5 Elisha replied, "I will come with you." So he went with them. When they arrived at the Jordan, they began cutting down trees and logs.
2 Kings 6:6 As one of them was cutting down a log, the iron axe-head flew off the handle and sank into the water. He cried out in dismay, "Oh no, my master! And I borrowed this axe!"
2 Kings 6:7 The man of God, Elisha, asked, "Where did it fall?" The disciple showed him the exact spot. So Elisha cut off a small piece of wood, threw it into the water at that spot, and the iron axe-head immediately floated to the surface.
2 Kings 6:8 At that time, the King of Syria was at war with Israel. He consulted with his military commanders, saying, "I will set up an ambush at this particular place."
2 Kings 6:9 But the man of God, Elisha, sent a message to the King of Israel, warning him, "Be careful not to pass through that specific location, because the Syrian army has set an ambush there."
2 Kings 6:10 So the King of Israel sent a scouting party to the place Elisha had warned him about and had already given him a heads-up. Because he took precautions, he and his army were saved from danger, not just once or twice, but many times.
2 Kings 6:11 The King of Syria became greatly disturbed by these repeated failures. He called his military commanders together and demanded, "Why aren't you telling me which one of you is betraying us to the King of Israel?"
2 Kings 6:12 One of his commanders answered, "It's not that at all, my Lord King. It is Elisha, the prophet in Israel, who reveals to the King of Israel every single word you speak, even those uttered in the privacy of your innermost chamber!"
2 Kings 6:13 The King of Syria commanded, "Go and find out where he is, so I can send men to capture him!" His scouts reported back to him, saying, "He is in the city of Dothan."
2 Kings 6:14 So the King of Syria dispatched a large army there, with horses and chariots, a truly powerful force. They marched all night and arrived at Dothan before dawn, completely surrounding the city.
2 Kings 6:15 When Elisha's personal servant woke up early and went outside, he saw a vast army, with horses and chariots, completely surrounding Dothan. He rushed back to Elisha and cried out, "Oh no, my master! What are we going to do?"
2 Kings 6:16 But Elisha replied, "Do not be afraid; for there are more with us than there are with them!"
2 Kings 6:17 Then Elisha prayed, "O Lord, open his eyes so that he may see!" And the Lord immediately opened the servant's eyes, and he looked up and saw, and there, on the mountains surrounding Elisha, was a magnificent sight: the mountain was completely full of horses and chariots made of fire, encircling Elisha.
2 Kings 6:18 As the Syrian soldiers came down the mountain toward Elisha, Elisha prayed to the Lord, "Please strike these people with blindness!" And the Lord struck them with complete blindness, just as Elisha had prayed.
2 Kings 6:19 Then Elisha said to them, "This is not the right road, and this isn't the city you're looking for. Follow me, and I will lead you to the man you are searching for." So Elisha led them, still blind, all the way to Samaria—the capital city of Israel.
2 Kings 6:20 Once they had entered Samaria, Elisha prayed, "O Lord, open the eyes of these men so they may see!" And the Lord opened their eyes, and they could see again. And they realized with shock that they were right in the middle of Samaria, surrounded by their enemies.
2 Kings 6:21 When the King of Israel saw the Syrian army suddenly appear in the heart of his capital city, he asked Elisha, "Shall I kill them, my father?"
2 Kings 6:22 Elisha answered, "No, do not kill them! Would you normally kill captives you have taken with your own sword and bow? Instead, give them food and water, so they can eat and drink, and then send them back to their master, the King of Syria."
2 Kings 6:23 So the King of Israel prepared a magnificent feast for the Syrian soldiers. They ate and drank, and then he sent them away, and they returned to their master. After this event, the Syrian raiding parties stopped invading the land of Israel for a significant time.
2 Kings 6:24 However, sometime later, after these events, Ben-Hadad, the King of Syria, gathered his entire army, marched to Samaria, and laid siege to the city.
2 Kings 6:25 A terrible famine gripped Samaria during the siege. The siege lasted so long that a donkey's head, normally considered unclean food, was sold for eighty pieces of silver, and even a quarter-kab of dove's droppings, a truly repulsive and desperate measure, was sold for five pieces of silver.
2 Kings 6:26 As the King of Israel was walking along the city wall to inspect the defenses, a woman cried out to him desperately, "Help me, my Lord King!"
2 Kings 6:27 The king replied, "If the Lord won't help you, how can I possibly help you? Do I have grain from the threshing floor, or wine from the winepress to give you?"
2 Kings 6:28 Then the king asked her, "What is your trouble?" She answered, "This woman here said to me: 'Give up your son, so we can eat him today,' and then tomorrow we will eat my son."
2 Kings 6:29 So we cooked my son, and we ate him. But the next day, when I told her, 'Now it's your turn, give us your son so we can eat him!' she hid her son.
2 Kings 6:30 When the king heard the woman's story, he tore his clothes in a powerful display of grief and repentance. As he continued along the wall, all the people saw that beneath his royal robes, he was wearing sackcloth against his skin—a sign of deep mourning and humility before God.
2 Kings 6:31 He then swore an oath, saying, "May God punish me severely and even more if I allow Elisha, the son of Shaphat, to live through this day!"
2 Kings 6:32 Elisha was sitting in his house at the time, and the elders of Israel were sitting with him. The King of Israel had sent an executioner to behead Elisha. But before the king's messenger arrived, Elisha, knowing by divine revelation, said to the elders, "Do you see how this son of a murderer—referring to the king—has sent someone to cut off my head? When he arrives, make sure the door is shut and hold him back with the doors! For listen, the sound of his master's footsteps—the king himself—is right behind him!"
2 Kings 6:33 While Elisha was still speaking, the king's messenger arrived at the door. And immediately after him, the king himself ascended and began to speak, saying, "This terrible evil—this famine—comes directly from the Lord! Why should I continue to hope or wait for any help from the Lord?"
2 Kings 6:1 Then the sons of the prophets said to Elisha, "Look, this place where we gather and stay with you is now too small for us."
2 Kings 6:2 So let's go down to the Jordan River, and each of us will cut down a log there. Then we can build ourselves a larger place to live in. Elisha replied, "Go ahead."
2 Kings 6:3 But one of them said, "Please, come with your servants." He answered, "I will come."
2 Kings 6:4 So he went with them. When they arrived at the Jordan, they began to cut down trees.
2 Kings 6:5 But as one of them was cutting down a log, the iron head of his axe fell into the water. He cried out, "Oh no, my master! And it was borrowed!"
2 Kings 6:6 The man of God asked, "Where did it fall?" He showed him the place. So Elisha cut off a piece of wood and threw it into the water at that spot, and the axe head floated to the surface.
2 Kings 6:7 Elisha said, "Pick it up." The man reached out his hand and took it.
2 Kings 6:8 Now the King of Syria was at war with Israel. He consulted with his officers, saying, "I will set up an ambush at such and such a place."
2 Kings 6:9 But the man of God — Elisha — sent a message to the King of Israel, saying, "Be careful not to pass through that specific place, because the Syrians are hiding there in ambush."
2 Kings 6:10 So the King of Israel sent a warning to the place which the man of God had told him about and had forewarned him against. The king saved his army there not just once or twice.
2 Kings 6:11 The King of Syria's heart was greatly troubled by this, so he called his officers together and asked them, "Why don't you tell me which of us is betraying us to the King of Israel?"
2 Kings 6:12 One of his officers replied, "By no means, my lord and king. It is Elisha the prophet, who is in Israel, who tells the King of Israel all the words you speak even in your secret bedchamber."
2 Kings 6:13 The king said to them, "Go and find out where he is, so I can send men to capture him." They reported to him, saying, "Look, he is in Dothan."
2 Kings 6:14 So the king sent horses and chariots and a great army there. They arrived at night and surrounded the city.
2 Kings 6:15 When the servant of the man of God rose early in the morning and went out, he saw an army surrounding the city with horses and chariots. The servant said to him, "Oh no, my master! What shall we do?"
2 Kings 6:16 But Elisha said, "Do not be afraid. For there are more with us than there are with them."
2 Kings 6:17 Then Elisha prayed and said, "Lord, open this young man's eyes so he may see." And the Lord opened the eyes of the young man, and he saw! Behold, the mountain was full of horses and chariots of fire all around Elisha.
2 Kings 6:18 When the Syrians came down toward him, Elisha prayed to the Lord, saying, "Strike this nation with blindness, I beg You." And the Lord struck them with blindness, just as Elisha had requested.
2 Kings 6:19 Then Elisha said to them, "This is not the right road, nor is this the city you're looking for. Follow me, and I will lead you to the man you seek." So he led them into Samaria, the capital of Israel.
2 Kings 6:20 When they had entered Samaria, Elisha said, "Lord, open the eyes of these men so they may see." And the Lord opened their eyes, and they looked around. Behold, they realized they were in the middle of Samaria!
2 Kings 6:21 When the King of Israel saw them, he asked Elisha, "My father, shall I strike them down? Shall I strike them down?"
2 Kings 6:22 Elisha answered, "You must not strike them down. Do you strike down even those you have taken captive with your sword and bow? Set food and water before them, so they may eat and drink, and then return to their master, the King of Syria."
2 Kings 6:23 So the King of Israel prepared a great feast for them. After they had eaten and drunk, he sent them away. They returned to their master, and the raiding parties of the Syrians did not come into the land of Israel again.
2 Kings 6:24 However, after this, Ben-Hadad, the King of Syria, gathered his entire army, marched up, and besieged Samaria.
2 Kings 6:25 There was a great famine in Samaria. The city was under such a long siege that a donkey's head was sold for eighty pieces of silver, and a quarter of a cab (a small measure) of dove's dung for five pieces of silver. People were desperate for any food.
2 Kings 6:26 As the King of Israel was walking along the city wall, a woman cried out to him, saying, "Help me, my lord and king!"
2 Kings 6:27 He replied, "If the Lord does not save you, where can I get help for you? From the threshing floor, or from the winepress? I have no food to give."
2 Kings 6:28 Then the king asked her, "What is your trouble?" She answered, "This woman said to me, 'Give up your son so we can eat him today, and we will eat my son tomorrow.'"
2 Kings 6:29 So we cooked my son and ate him. Then I said to her the next day, 'Give up your son so we can eat him.' But she hid her son away.
2 Kings 6:30 When the king heard the woman's words, he tore his clothes. As he walked along the wall, all the people saw that he was wearing sackcloth underneath, against his skin.
2 Kings 6:31 Then the king said, "May God do so to me, and even more, if the head of Elisha, the son of Shaphat, remains on his shoulders this very day!"
2 Kings 6:32 Now Elisha was sitting in his house, and the elders were sitting with him. The king had sent a messenger to behead Elisha. But before the messenger arrived, Elisha said to the elders, "Do you see that this son of a murderer has sent someone to take off my head? Look, when the messenger comes, shut the door and hold it fast against him with the door bar. For indeed, the sound of his master's footsteps is right behind him!"
2 Kings 6:33 While Elisha was still speaking with them, the messenger appeared. And the messenger said, "Look, this disaster is from the Lord! Why should I wait for the Lord any longer?"
2 Kings 6:1 The sons of the prophets—that is, the disciples under Elisha's guidance—told Elisha: "Look, the place where we are staying with you is too small for us."
2 Kings 6:2 "Let's go all the way to the Jordan River, and each of us will take a single log from the trees there, so we can build ourselves a new dwelling place." Elisha replied: "Go ahead."
2 Kings 6:3 Then one of them said, "Please, come with your servants as well." He answered: "I will come."
2 Kings 6:4 So he went with them. And when they arrived at the Jordan River, they began to cut down trees.
2 Kings 6:5 It happened that as one of them was cutting down a tree, the iron axe-head fell into the water. He cried out in distress and said: "Oh no, my master! And I even borrowed this axe-head."
2 Kings 6:6 And the man of God—that is, Elisha—asked: "Where did it fall?" The man showed him the spot. So Elisha cut off a piece of wood and threw it toward that place, and the axe-head floated to the surface.
2 Kings 6:7 And Elisha said: "Pick it up." So he reached out his hand and took it.
2 Kings 6:8 Now the king of Syria was making war against Israel, and after taking counsel with his servants, he said: "In such and such a place I will set an ambush."
2 Kings 6:9 Therefore, the man of God—Elisha—sent word to the king of Israel, saying: "Be careful not to pass through that specific place, because the Syrians are lying in ambush there."
2 Kings 6:10 And the king of Israel sent men to the place that the man of God had told him about and had warned him of. And the king of Israel took precautions there, not just once or twice.
2 Kings 6:11 The heart of the king of Syria was greatly troubled by this matter. He called his servants together and said: "Why don't you tell me who among us is a traitor to the king of Israel?"
2 Kings 6:12 And one of his servants said: "By no means, my lord king. It is not a traitor among us, but rather Elisha the prophet, who is in Israel, who tells the king of Israel all the words that you speak even in your private bedchamber."
2 Kings 6:13 So the king said: "Go and see where he is, so that I may send and capture him." And it was reported to him by those who said: "Look, he is in Dothan."
2 Kings 6:14 Therefore, he sent horses and chariots and a strong army there. When they arrived by night, they surrounded the city.
2 Kings 6:15 So at dawn, the servant of the man of God arose and went out, and he saw the army encircling the city, with horses and chariots. And he reported to Elisha, saying: "Oh no, my master, what shall we do?"
2 Kings 6:16 But Elisha answered: "Do not be afraid, for those who are with us are more numerous than those who are with them."
2 Kings 6:17 And Elisha prayed and said: "Lord, open this young man's eyes so that he may see." And the Lord opened the eyes of the young man, and he saw, and behold, the mountain was full of horses and chariots of fire all around Elisha.
2 Kings 6:18 Now as the Syrians came down toward him, Elisha prayed to the Lord, saying: "Please, strike this people with blindness." And the Lord struck them with blindness, according to Elisha's word.
2 Kings 6:19 And Elisha said to them: "This is not the way, nor is this the city you're looking for. Follow me, and I will lead you to the man you are seeking." So he led them to Samaria.
2 Kings 6:20 And when they had entered Samaria, Elisha said: "Lord, open the eyes of these men so that they may see." And the Lord opened their eyes, and they saw, and behold, they were in the middle of Samaria—the capital city of Israel, deep within enemy territory.
2 Kings 6:21 And the king of Israel, seeing them, said to Elisha: "Should I strike them down, my father?"
2 Kings 6:22 Elisha replied: "You shall not strike them down. For you would not strike down even those you captured with your sword and your bow in battle. Instead, set bread and water before them, so that they may eat and drink, and then return to their master."
2 Kings 6:23 So the king prepared a great meal for them. And they ate and drank, and he sent them away, and they returned to their master. And the raiding parties of Syria did not come into the land of Israel any more.
2 Kings 6:24 But it came to pass after these events that Ben-hadad, the king of Syria, gathered all his army, and marched up and besieged Samaria.
2 Kings 6:25 And there was a great famine in Samaria. And it was besieged for so long that an ass's head was sold for eighty pieces of silver—an exorbitant price for an unclean animal—and a quarter of a measure of dove's dung was sold for five pieces of silver—a sign of extreme desperation.
2 Kings 6:26 As the king of Israel was passing by on the wall, a woman cried out to him, saying: "Help me, my lord king!"
2 Kings 6:27 And he said: "May the Lord help you! How can I help you? Is it from the threshing floor or from the winepress?"—implying he had no provisions from either.
2 Kings 6:28 And the king asked her: "What is your trouble?" And she replied: "This woman said to me: 'Give your son, so that we may eat him today, and then tomorrow we will eat my son.'"
2 Kings 6:29 "So we cooked my son and ate him. And the next day, I said to her: 'Give your son, so that we may eat him.' But she hid him."
2 Kings 6:30 When the king heard the words of the woman, he tore his garments, and as he walked along the wall, all the people saw that he was wearing sackcloth underneath, next to his skin, as a sign of mourning and repentance.
2 Kings 6:31 And he said: "May God do to me and add to it more punishment, if the head of Elisha, the son of Shaphat, remains on him this day!"—meaning he swore to execute Elisha.
2 Kings 6:32 Elisha, however, was sitting in his house, and the elders were sitting with him. So the king sent a man from his presence. But before the messenger could arrive, Elisha said to the elders: "Do you see that this son of a murderer—meaning the king—has sent someone to take off my head? Look, when the messenger comes, shut the door and hold him back with it. For behold, the sound of his master's feet is right behind him."
2 Kings 6:33 While he was still speaking—Elisha, that is—the messenger who was coming to him appeared. And the messenger said: "Behold, such great evil has come from the Lord! Why should I wait any longer for the Lord's help?"

2 Kings 7:1 Then Elisha, the prophet, said: 'Listen now to the word of the Lord! This is what the Lord says: Tomorrow, at this same time of day, within the gates of Samaria, the famine will be over. Then, two measures of fine flour will be sold for just one silver coin, and four measures of barley will be sold for one silver coin.'
2 Kings 7:2 But the royal officer, upon whose arm the king leaned (indicating his high trust and authority), answered the man of God, saying: 'Even if the Lord were to open floodgates in the sky and make food rain down, could this possibly happen?' And Elisha, the prophet, replied: 'You will see it with your own eyes, but you will not partake in the abundance that follows.'
2 Kings 7:3 Now there were four men afflicted with leprosy near the entrance of the city gate. They said to one another, 'Why are we sitting here until we die?'
2 Kings 7:4 If we decide to go into the city, we will die there from starvation. If we remain here, we will also die. So come, let us desert and go over to the camp of the Syrians. If they spare our lives, we will live. But if they kill us, then we will simply die.
2 Kings 7:5 So they rose up in the evening to go to the camp of the Syrians. But when they came to the edge of the camp, they found no one there.
2 Kings 7:6 For the Lord had caused the Syrian army in the camp to hear the sound of chariots and of horses, and the sound of a very large army approaching. And they had said to one another: 'Look! The king of Israel has hired the kings of the Hittites and the kings of the Egyptians to attack us and come against us.'
2 Kings 7:7 Therefore, rising up, they fled in silence, abandoning their tents, their horses, their donkeys, and the entire camp, exactly as it was. They simply fled for their lives.
2 Kings 7:8 So when those lepers came to the edge of the camp, they entered one tent, and they ate and drank. They took from there silver, gold, and clothing, and they went away and hid them. Then they returned to another tent, and from there they took more things and hid them too.
2 Kings 7:9 Then they said to one another: 'What we are doing is not right. This is a day of good news, and if we remain silent and do not report it until morning, we will be found guilty of a terrible crime. Come, let us go and report it in the king's palace.'
2 Kings 7:10 So when they arrived at the city gate, they called out, saying: 'We came to the camp of the Syrians, and we found no one there! There was no sound of people, but only horses and donkeys tied up, and the tents just as they were left.'
2 Kings 7:11 Therefore, they reported it to the gatekeepers of the city, who immediately announced it in the king's palace.
2 Kings 7:12 Then the king rose up in the night and said to his servants: 'I will tell you what the Syrians have done to us. They know that we are suffering from famine, and that is why they have left their camp and hidden themselves in the fields, thinking: When the people come out of the city looking for food, we will capture them alive, and then we will enter the city ourselves.'
2 Kings 7:13 One of his servants answered him: 'Let us take five of the remaining horses in the city. Indeed, the entire multitude of Israel that remains here is already like those who have perished (meaning, they are near death from starvation). Let us send them out, and see what is happening.'
2 Kings 7:14 So they sent two horses and chariots (presumably carrying men), and they went out after them, saying: 'Go and see!'
2 Kings 7:15 They followed the Syrians all the way to the Jordan River. And behold, the entire road was full of clothing and equipment, which the Syrians had thrown away in their haste to flee. And returning, they reported it to the king.
2 Kings 7:16 Then the people went out and plundered the camp of the Syrians. And just as the Lord had declared, two measures of fine flour were sold for one silver coin, and four measures of barley were sold for one silver coin.
2 Kings 7:17 Now the king had appointed that very royal officer (who was his close advisor) to be in charge of the gate. But the crowd trampled him in the gateway as they rushed out, and he died, just as the man of God had prophesied when the king came to him (earlier, during the famine).
2 Kings 7:18 For it happened exactly according to the word of the man of God, who had said to the king: 'Two measures of fine flour will be sold for one silver coin, and four measures of barley will be sold for one silver coin, by this time tomorrow in the gate of Samaria.'
2 Kings 7:19 When that officer had also responded to the man of God, saying: 'Even if the Lord were to open floodgates in the sky, could this possibly happen?' And Elisha had said to him: 'You will indeed see it with your own eyes, but you will not partake in that abundance.'
2 Kings 7:20 And it happened to him just as Elisha had foretold: for the people trampled him in the gateway, and he died there.
2 Kings 7:1 It happened that the king was dwelling securely in his own house, and the Lord had given him rest on every side from all his enemies,
2 Kings 7:2 he then said to Nathan the prophet: “Look, I am living in a house built with cedar wood, but the Ark of God, which represents the Lord's presence, is placed only inside curtains.”
2 Kings 7:3 And Nathan said to the king: “Go and do everything that is in your heart, for the Lord is with you in this endeavor.”
2 Kings 7:4 However, it happened that in that very night, behold, the word of the Lord came to Nathan, saying:
2 Kings 7:5 “Go and speak to My servant David: ‘Thus says the Lord: Are you the one who will build a house for Me to dwell in?’”
2 Kings 7:6 “For I have not lived in a permanent house from the day I brought the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt until this very day; instead, I have moved about in a tabernacle, which is a portable sanctuary, and in a tent.”
2 Kings 7:7 “In all the places through which I have passed with all the children of Israel, did I ever speak a word to any one of the tribes of Israel, to whom I commanded to feed My people Israel, saying: ‘Why have you not built Me a cedar house?’”
2 Kings 7:8 “And now, you shall say this to My servant David: ‘Thus says the Lord of hosts: I took you from the pastures, from following the flock, so that you would be a leader over My people Israel.’”
2 Kings 7:9 “And I have been with you in all places wherever you have walked, and I have destroyed all your enemies from before you; and I have made for you a great name, like the name of the great ones who are on the earth.”
2 Kings 7:10 “And I will appoint a place for My people Israel, and I will plant them there, and they will live securely under their own rule, and they will not be disturbed any longer; nor will the sons of wickedness oppress them again, as they did at the first,”
2 Kings 7:11 “from the day that I appointed judges over My people Israel. And I will give you rest from all your enemies. Furthermore, the Lord proclaims to you that He Himself will make a house for you—a dynasty and a lasting lineage.”
2 Kings 7:12 “And when your days are completed, and you sleep with your fathers, I will raise up your offspring after you, who will come from your body, and I will establish his kingdom firmly.”
2 Kings 7:13 “He himself will build a house for My name, a temple of worship, and I will establish the throne of his kingdom forever.”
2 Kings 7:14 “I will be to him a father, and he himself will be to Me a son. If he does anything wickedly, I will discipline him with the rod of men, and with the scourges of the sons of men, as a father would correct his child.”
2 Kings 7:15 “But My mercy I will not take away from him, as I took it away from Saul, whom I removed from My presence.”
2 Kings 7:16 “And your house shall be faithful, and your kingdom shall endure forever before you; and your throne shall be firm perpetually.”
2 Kings 7:17 According to all these words, and according to all this vision, so Nathan spoke to David.
2 Kings 7:18 Then King David entered and sat before the Lord, and he said: “Who am I, Lord God, and what is my house, that you have brought me to this point of favor?”
2 Kings 7:19 “But even this is a small thing in Your sight, Lord God, unless You have also spoken concerning the house of Your servant for a long time to come; this is the law and decree of man, Lord God, that such a promise would be made.”
2 Kings 7:20 “Therefore, what more can David add by speaking to You? For You know Your servant, Lord God, and all his thoughts.”
2 Kings 7:21 “Because of Your word, and according to Your own heart's desire, You have done all these great things, so that You might make them known to Your servant.”
2 Kings 7:22 “For this reason, You are magnified, Lord God, for there is none like You, nor is there any God besides You, in all that we have heard with our own ears.”
2 Kings 7:23 “And what other nation on earth is like Your people Israel, whom You went to redeem for Yourself as a people, and to make a name for Yourself, and to perform great and terrible things for them on the earth, delivering them from the face of Your nation whom You redeemed for Yourself out of Egypt, from their peoples and their false worship?”
2 Kings 7:24 “And You have established Your people Israel for Yourself as a people forever; and You, O Lord, have become their God.”
2 Kings 7:25 “Now therefore, Lord God, the word that You have spoken concerning Your servant and concerning his house, fulfill it eternally; and do as You have spoken.”
2 Kings 7:26 “So that Your name may be magnified forever, and people may say: ‘The Lord of hosts is God over Israel,’ and the house of Your servant David may be established before You.”
2 Kings 7:27 “For You, Lord of hosts, God of Israel, have revealed to Your servant, by whispering in his ear, saying: ‘I will build a house for you.’ Because of this, Your servant has found the courage in his heart to pray this prayer to You.”
2 Kings 7:28 “Now therefore, Lord God, You are God, and Your words will be true; for You have spoken these good things to Your servant.”
2 Kings 7:29 “Begin therefore and bless the house of Your servant, so that it may be forever before You; for You, Lord God, have spoken, and with Your blessing, the house of Your servant will be blessed eternally.”

2 Kings 7:1 Then Elisha said, "Hear the word of the Lord! This is what the Lord says: At this very hour tomorrow, a seah (a measure) of fine flour will be sold for three shekels (a unit of silver currency), and two seahs of barley for four shekels, right at the market gate of Samaria."
2 Kings 7:2 However, one of the king's officers, who was responsible for the king's personal safety and whose arm the king leaned upon, answered the man of God, saying, "Even if the Lord were to open the floodgates of the sky, could such a thing actually happen?" And Elisha said, "You will see it with your own eyes, but you will not eat any of it."
2 Kings 7:3 Now there were four men who had leprosy sitting near the entrance of the city gate. They said to each other, "Why are we sitting here until we die?"
2 Kings 7:4 If we go into the city, we will die there because of the famine. If we stay here, we will surely die. So come on, let's desert to the camp of the Arameans (Syrians). If they spare our lives, we will live. If they kill us, then we will simply die.
2 Kings 7:5 So they got up in the evening to go to the camp of the Arameans. When they came to the edge of the Aramean camp, they found no one there.
2 Kings 7:6 For the Lord had made the Aramean army hear the sound of chariots, horses, and a very large army. So they said to one another, "Look, the king of Israel has hired the kings of the Hittites and the kings of Egypt to come and attack us!"
2 Kings 7:7 Because of this, they got up and fled silently in the evening, abandoning their tents, their horses, their donkeys in the camp, and everything just as it was. They simply fled for their lives.
2 Kings 7:8 So when those men with leprosy came to the edge of the camp, they went into one tent and ate and drank. They took silver, gold, and clothing from there, and went and hid them. Then they returned to another tent and likewise took things from there and hid them.
2 Kings 7:9 Then they said to one another, "What we are doing is not right. This is a day of good news, and if we keep silent and do not report it until morning, we will be held accountable for our wickedness. Come now, let's go and report it to the king's palace."
2 Kings 7:10 So they went and called out to the gatekeepers of the city, saying, "We went to the camp of the Arameans, and we found no one there, nor any sound of a human, but only horses and donkeys tied up, and the tents just as they were left."
2 Kings 7:11 The gatekeepers then went and announced the news inside the king's palace.
2 Kings 7:12 The king rose up in the night and said to his servants, "I will tell you what the Arameans have done to us. They know that we are suffering from famine, and that is why they have left their camp and hidden themselves in the fields. They are thinking, 'When they come out of the city, we will capture them alive and then enter the city.'"
2 Kings 7:13 One of his servants answered him and said, "Let's take five of the remaining horses in the city, because the entire population of Israel remaining in it will be like those who are already dead. Indeed, the entire population of Israel is almost consumed by the famine. Let us send them out and see what is happening."
2 Kings 7:14 So they took two chariots with horses, and the king sent them to the Aramean camp, saying, "Go and see."
2 Kings 7:15 They went after them as far as the Jordan River. And behold, the entire road was full of garments and equipment that the Arameans had thrown away in their haste when they were in a panic. The messengers returned and reported this to the king.
2 Kings 7:16 Then the people went out and plundered the camp of the Arameans. So a seah of fine flour was sold for three shekels, and two seahs of barley for four shekels, exactly as the Lord had spoken.
2 Kings 7:17 Now the king had put that officer, on whose arm he leaned, in charge of the city gate. But the crowd trampled him in the gate, and he died, just as the man of God had prophesied when the king came down to speak with him.
2 Kings 7:18 So it happened exactly according to the word of the man of God, which he had spoken to the king when he said: "Two seahs of barley will be sold for four shekels, and a seah of fine flour for three shekels, tomorrow at the gate of Samaria."
2 Kings 7:19 And when that officer had answered him and said, "What if the Lord were to open the floodgates of the sky, could such a thing actually happen?" Elisha had said to him, "You will see it with your own eyes, but you will not eat any of it."
2 Kings 7:20 And it happened to him just as it had been said, because the people trampled him in the gate, and he died.
2 Kings 8:1 Eliseus then spoke to the woman whose son he had restored to life, telling her: 'Get up, and go, you and your entire household, and reside as a foreigner wherever you can; for the Lord has commanded a devastating famine upon this land, and it will last for seven years.'
2 Kings 8:2 So the woman got up, and she left with all of her household, and they resided as foreigners in the land of the Philistines for the entire seven years.
2 Kings 8:3 And when the seven years were finished, the woman returned from the land of the Philistines. And she went to appeal to the king about her house and her fields, which had likely been taken by others.
2 Kings 8:4 Now, the king was speaking with Giezi, the servant of the man of God, Eliseus. The king was saying: 'Tell me all the great things Eliseus has done.'
2 Kings 8:5 As Giezi was telling how Eliseus had raised the dead boy back to life, the very woman whose son Eliseus had restored to life appeared, crying out to the king concerning her house and her fields. Then Giezi said: 'My lord the king, this is the woman, and this is her son, whom Eliseus brought back to life.'
2 Kings 8:6 And the king questioned the woman, and she told him her story. Then the king gave her an official, saying: 'Restore to her all that is hers, and all the income from her fields, from the day she left the land until now.'
2 Kings 8:7 Eliseus also went to Damascus, and Benadad, the king of Syria, was sick. And it was announced to him, with people saying: 'The man of God has come here!'
2 Kings 8:8 And the king said to Hazaël, one of his officials: 'Take gifts with you, and go to meet the man of God, and consult the Lord through him, asking: "Will I recover from this illness?"'
2 Kings 8:9 So Hazaël went to meet him, bringing gifts with him—all the good things of Damascus, a load for forty camels. And when he arrived, he stood before Eliseus and said: 'Your son Benadad, the king of Syria, has sent me to you, asking: "Will I recover from this illness?"'
2 Kings 8:10 And Eliseus said to him: 'Go, tell him: "You will surely recover"— but the Lord has shown me that he will certainly die.'
2 Kings 8:11 And Eliseus stood with him, staring intently. Hazaël became troubled and embarrassed, and then the man of God, Eliseus, wept.
2 Kings 8:12 To him, Hazaël said: 'Why is my lord weeping?' Eliseus answered: 'Because I know what evils you will inflict upon the children of Israel: you will set their fortified cities on fire, you will kill their young men with the sword, you will dash their little ones to pieces, and you will rip open their pregnant women.'
2 Kings 8:13 And Hazaël said: 'What is your servant, a mere dog, that I should do such a great evil?' And Eliseus said: 'The Lord has shown me that you will be king over Syria.'
2 Kings 8:14 And when he had departed from Eliseus, he came to his master. Who said to him: 'What did Eliseus say to you?' And he answered: 'He told me: "You will surely recover."
2 Kings 8:15 But the very next day, Hazaël took a thick cloth, soaked it in water, and spread it over Benadad’s face, smothering him. And when he was dead, Hazaël reigned in his place.
2 Kings 8:16 In the fifth year of Joram, son of Achab, king of Israel, while Josaphat was king of Juda, Joram, son of Josaphat, king of Juda, began to reign.
2 Kings 8:17 He was thirty-two years old when he began to reign, and he reigned for eight years in Jerusalem.
2 Kings 8:18 And he walked in the ways of the kings of Israel, just as the house of Achab had walked, because a daughter of Achab was his wife. And he did evil in the sight of the Lord.
2 Kings 8:19 However, the Lord would not destroy Juda, for the sake of David, His servant, just as He had promised him by speaking, and by giving him a lamp—a continuous line of descendants—and to his sons for all days.
2 Kings 8:20 In his days, Edom revolted so that it would no longer be under the rule of Juda, and it appointed a king for itself.
2 Kings 8:21 So Joram went to Seira, and all the chariots with him. And he rose up in the night and attacked the Idumeans who had surrounded him, along with the commanders of their chariots; but the people fled to their tents.
2 Kings 8:22 Therefore Edom revolted from being under Juda, and it remains so to this present day. At that same time, Libna also revolted.
2 Kings 8:23 Now, the rest of the acts of Joram, and all that he did, are these not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Juda?
2 Kings 8:24 And Joram slept with his fathers, and he was buried with them in the City of David. And Ochozias, his son, reigned in his place.
2 Kings 8:25 In the twelfth year of Joram, son of Achab, king of Israel, Ochozias, son of Joram, king of Juda, began to reign.
2 Kings 8:26 Ochozias was twenty-two years old when he began to reign, and he reigned for one year in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Athalia, daughter of Amri, king of Israel.
2 Kings 8:27 And he walked in the ways of the house of Achab, and he did evil in the sight of the Lord, just like the house of Achab, for he was a son-in-law of Achab.
2 Kings 8:28 He also went with Joram, son of Achab, to war against Hazaël, king of Syria, in Ramoth Galaad; and the Syrians wounded Joram.
2 Kings 8:29 So Joram returned to be healed in Jezraël because of the wounds that the Syrians had inflicted on him in Ramoth, when he fought against Hazaël, the king of Syria. And Ochozias, son of Joram, king of Juda, went down to visit Joram, son of Achab, who was sick in Jezraël.
2 Kings 8:1 But Elisha spoke to the woman whose son he had restored to life, saying, "Rise up, you and your household, and go live as a foreigner wherever you can; for the Lord has called a famine upon the land, and it will last for seven years."
2 Kings 8:2 So she rose up and went with all her household, and lived as a foreigner in the land of the Philistines for seven years.
2 Kings 8:3 When the seven years were finished, the woman returned from the land of the Philistines, and she went out to appeal to the king concerning her house and her fields.
2 Kings 8:4 Now the king was speaking with Gehazi, the servant of the man of God, saying, "Tell me all the great works that Elisha has done."
2 Kings 8:5 As Gehazi was telling the king how Elisha had raised the dead, the very woman whose son Elisha had restored to life appeared, crying out to the king concerning her house and her fields. And Gehazi said, "My lord king, this is the woman, and this is her son whom Elisha raised from the dead!"
2 Kings 8:6 The king then questioned the woman, and she told him her story. So the king gave her an official, saying, "Restore to her all that belonged to her, and all the income from her fields, from the day she left the land until now."
2 Kings 8:7 Now Elisha came to Damascus, and Ben-hadad king of Syria was sick. They reported to him, saying, "The man of God has come here!"
2 Kings 8:8 And the king said to Hazael, "Take gifts with you, and go meet the man of God, and inquire of the Lord through him, saying, 'Will I recover from this sickness?'"
2 Kings 8:9 So Hazael went to meet Elisha, carrying gifts with him, all the good things of Damascus, a load for forty camels. When he came, he stood before him and said, "Your son Ben-hadad, king of Syria, has sent me to you, saying, 'Will I recover from this sickness?'"
2 Kings 8:10 And Elisha said to him, "Go, tell him, 'You will certainly recover.' However, the Lord has shown me that he will surely die a different death."
2 Kings 8:11 Then Elisha stared fixedly until Hazael was confused and ashamed; and the man of God wept.
2 Kings 8:12 And Hazael said, "Why does my lord weep?" He answered, "Because I know the evil that you will do to the children of Israel: you will burn their fortified cities with fire, and you will kill their young men with the sword, and you will dash their little ones to pieces, and rip open their pregnant women."
2 Kings 8:13 To which Hazael said, "Who is your servant, my lord, but a dog, that I should do this great evil?" And Elisha said, "The Lord has shown me that you will be king of Syria."
2 Kings 8:14 So he departed from Elisha and came to his master. And Ben-hadad said to him, "What did Elisha say to you?" And Hazael answered, "He told me, 'You will recover your health.'"
2 Kings 8:15 But the next day, Hazael took a thick blanket, soaked it in water, and spread it over Ben-hadad's face, so he suffocated. When Ben-hadad was dead, Hazael reigned in his place.
2 Kings 8:16 In the fifth year of Joram, son of Ahab, king of Israel—while Jehoshaphat was still king of Judah—Jehoram, son of Jehoshaphat, began to reign as king of Judah.
2 Kings 8:17 He was thirty-two years old when he began to reign, and he reigned for eight years in Jerusalem.
2 Kings 8:18 And he walked in the ways of the kings of Israel, just as the house of Ahab had walked, for the daughter of Ahab was his wife; and he did evil in the sight of the Lord.
2 Kings 8:19 However, the Lord was unwilling to destroy Judah for the sake of David His servant, just as He had promised him that He would give him a lamp, a line of descendants, for all days.
2 Kings 8:20 In his days, Edom revolted from being under the rule of Judah and appointed a king for themselves.
2 Kings 8:21 So Jehoram went to Zair, and all his chariots with him; and he rose up by night and struck the Edomites who had surrounded him and the captains of the chariots. Then the people fled to their tents.
2 Kings 8:22 Thus Edom revolted from being under Judah to this present day. At that time, Libnah also revolted.
2 Kings 8:23 Now the rest of the acts of Jehoram, and all that he did, are they not written in the Book of the Annals of the Kings of Judah?
2 Kings 8:24 And Jehoram rested with his fathers and was buried with them in the City of David; and Ahaziah, his son, reigned in his place.
2 Kings 8:25 In the twelfth year of Joram, son of Ahab, king of Israel, Ahaziah, son of Jehoram, king of Judah, began to reign.
2 Kings 8:26 Ahaziah was twenty-two years old when he began to reign, and he reigned for one year in Jerusalem. The name of his mother was Athaliah, the daughter of Omri, king of Israel.
2 Kings 8:27 And he walked in the ways of the house of Ahab, and did evil in the sight of the Lord, just like the house of Ahab, for he was a son-in-law of Ahab's house.
2 Kings 8:28 He also went with Joram, son of Ahab, to fight against Hazael, king of Syria, in Ramoth-gilead; and the Syrians wounded Joram.
2 Kings 8:29 So Joram returned to Jezreel to recover from the wounds with which the Syrians had struck him at Ramoth, when he fought against Hazael, king of Syria. And Ahaziah, son of Jehoram, king of Judah, went down to visit Joram, son of Ahab, in Jezreel, because he was sick.

2 Kings 8:2 So she got up and left with all her household, and lived as a foreigner in the land of the Philistines for seven years.
2 Kings 8:3 And when the seven years were completed, the woman returned from the land of the Philistines. She went out to appeal to the king concerning her house and her fields, seeking their restoration.
2 Kings 8:4 Meanwhile, the king was speaking with Gehazi, the servant of the man of God, saying: "Tell me all the great and powerful things that Elisha has done."
2 Kings 8:5 And just as Gehazi was telling how Elisha had brought a dead person back to life, the very woman appeared, whose son Elisha had restored to life, crying out to the king about her house and her fields. Gehazi then said: "My lord king, this is the woman, and this is her son whom Elisha restored to life."
2 Kings 8:6 And the king questioned the woman, and she told him her story. So the king gave her an official, saying: "Restore to her all that belongs to her, and all her fields from the day she left the land until now."
2 Kings 8:7 Elisha also came to Damascus, when Ben-Hadad, the king of Syria, was sick. And they announced to the king, saying: "The man of God has come here."
2 Kings 8:8 And the king said to Hazael: "Take gifts with you, and go to meet the man of God. Consult the Lord through him, saying: 'Will I be able to recover from this illness?'"
2 Kings 8:9 So Hazael went to meet Elisha, carrying gifts with him, and all the good things of Damascus, a load for forty camels. And when he stood before him, he said: "Your son Ben-Hadad, the king of Syria, has sent me to you, saying: 'Will I be able to recover from this illness?'"
2 Kings 8:10 And Elisha said to him: "Go and tell him: 'You will certainly recover.' However, the Lord has shown me that he will nevertheless surely die by other means."
2 Kings 8:11 And the man of God stood there, troubled, and then wept.
2 Kings 8:12 Hazael said to him: "Why does my lord weep?" And Elisha said: "Because I know the evils you will inflict upon the children of Israel: you will burn their strongholds with fire, you will kill their young men with the sword, you will dash their little ones to pieces, and you will rip open their pregnant women."
2 Kings 8:13 And Hazael said: "But what am I, your servant, a mere dog, that I should do such a great deed?" And Elisha said: "The Lord has shown me that you will be king of Syria."
2 Kings 8:14 And when he had departed from Elisha, he came to his master, who asked him: "What did Elisha say to you?" And Hazael responded: "He told me: 'You will certainly recover.'"
2 Kings 8:15 However, the next day, Hazael took a thick cloth, soaked it in water, and spread it over Ben-Hadad's face, so that he suffocated and died. And Hazael reigned in his place.
2 Kings 8:16 In the fifth year of Joram, son of Ahab, king of Israel, and while Jehoshaphat was king of Judah, Joram, son of Jehoshaphat, became king of Judah.
2 Kings 8:17 He was thirty-two years old when he began to reign, and he reigned for eight years in Jerusalem.
2 Kings 8:18 And he walked in the ways of the kings of Israel, just as the house of Ahab had walked, for the daughter of Ahab was his wife. And he did evil in the sight of the Lord.
2 Kings 8:19 Yet the Lord was unwilling to destroy Judah, for the sake of His servant David, just as He had promised him that He would always give him and his sons a lamp, meaning a perpetual lineage on the throne.
2 Kings 8:20 In those days, Edom revolted and separated from the control of Judah, and set up a king for themselves.
2 Kings 8:21 So Joram went to Zair, and all his chariots with him. And he rose up by night and struck the Edomites who had surrounded him; but the rest of the Edomite people had already fled to their tents.
2 Kings 8:22 And Edom remained separate from the control of Judah until this present day. At that time, Libnah also revolted.
2 Kings 8:23 The rest of the acts of Joram, and all that he did, are they not written in the Book of the Annals of the Kings of Judah?
2 Kings 8:24 And Joram rested with his ancestors and was buried with them in the City of David. Then Ahaziah, his son, reigned in his place.
2 Kings 8:25 In the twelfth year of Joram, son of Ahab, king of Israel, Ahaziah, son of Joram, king of Judah, began to reign.
2 Kings 8:26 Ahaziah was twenty-two years old when he began to reign, and he reigned for one year in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Athaliah, daughter of Omri, king of Israel.
2 Kings 8:27 And he walked in the ways of the house of Ahab, and did evil in the sight of the Lord, just as the house of Ahab did; for he was allied by marriage to the house of Ahab.
2 Kings 8:28 He also went with Joram, son of Ahab, to fight against Hazael, king of Syria, in Ramoth-Gilead. And the Syrians wounded Joram.
2 Kings 8:29 Joram then returned to Jezreel to recover, because the Syrians had wounded him in Ramah when he fought against Hazael, king of Syria. Ahaziah also, son of Joram, king of Judah, went down to Jezreel to visit Joram, son of Ahab, because he was sick.
2 Kings 9:1 Elisha the prophet called one of the disciples of the prophets and said to him, 'Prepare yourself for travel, and take this small jar of oil with you in your hand, then go to Ramoth Gilead.'
2 Kings 9:2 When you arrive there, find Jehu, the son of Jehoshaphat, who is the son of Nimshi. When you find him, take him away from his companions and lead him into a hidden private chamber.
2 Kings 9:3 Then, take the jar of oil and pour it over his head, saying: 'This is what the Lord says: I have anointed you to be king over Israel.' After you have done this, open the door, flee immediately, and do not delay.
2 Kings 9:4 So the young man, the prophet's disciple, went to Ramoth Gilead.
2 Kings 9:5 When he arrived, behold, the commanders of the army were sitting together. He said, 'I have a message for you, commander.'
2 Kings 9:6 Jehu asked, 'Which of us are you speaking to?'
2 Kings 9:null He replied, 'To you, commander.'
2 Kings 9:7 So Jehu got up and went into the private chamber. The young man poured the oil over his head and said to him, 'This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says: I have anointed you king over the Lord's people, Israel.'
2 Kings 9:8 'You are to strike down the household of Ahab your master, so that I may avenge the blood of My servants, the prophets, and the blood of all the Lord's servants, at the hand of Jezebel.'
2 Kings 9:9 'I will destroy the house of Ahab. I will cut off from Ahab every male, both slave and free, in Israel.'
2 Kings 9:10 'I will make the house of Ahab like the house of Jeroboam, the son of Nebat, and like the house of Baasha, the son of Ahijah.'
2 Kings 9:11 'As for Jezebel, dogs will devour her body in the field of Jezreel, and no one will bury her.'
2 Kings 9:12 Then he opened the door and fled, just as Elisha commanded.
2 Kings 9:13 When Jehu came out to the servants of his master, they asked him, 'Is everything all right? What did that madman want with you?'
2 Kings 9:14 He answered them, 'You know the man and what he said.'
2 Kings 9:15 But they insisted, 'That's not true! Tell us what he said!'
2 Kings 9:null He then told them, 'He said such and such to me, saying: 'This is what the Lord says: I have anointed you king over Israel.''
2 Kings 9:16 They quickly took off their cloaks, and each man spread his own under Jehu's feet, forming an impromptu royal carpet. Then they sounded the trumpet and shouted, 'Jehu is king!'
2 Kings 9:17 So Jehu plotted against Joram. Now Joram, along with all of Israel, was guarding Ramoth Gilead against Hazael, the king of Syria.
2 Kings 9:18 King Joram had returned to Jezreel to recover from the wounds the Arameans had inflicted upon him when he fought against Hazael, the king of Syria.
2 Kings 9:null Jehu then said, 'If you are with me, let no one escape from the city to go and report this news in Jezreel.'
2 Kings 9:19 So Jehu mounted his chariot and rode to Jezreel, for Joram was lying there wounded. Ahaziah, the king of Judah, had also come down to visit Joram.
2 Kings 9:20 Now the watchman was standing on the tower in Jezreel. He saw Jehu approaching with his company and exclaimed, 'I see a chariot approaching!'
2 Kings 9:21 Joram said, 'Harness my chariot!'
2 Kings 9:null So they harnessed his chariot, and King Joram of Israel, along with King Ahaziah of Judah, each in their own chariots, went out to meet Jehu. They encountered him in the field of Naboth the Jezreelite.
2 Kings 9:22 When Joram saw Jehu, he asked, 'Is it peace, Jehu?'
2 Kings 9:null Jehu replied, 'What peace can there be? The harlotries of your mother Jezebel and her many sorceries are still flourishing!'
2 Kings 9:23 Then Joram turned his chariot around to flee, crying out to Ahaziah, 'Treachery, Ahaziah!'
2 Kings 9:24 But Jehu drew his bow with his own hand and shot Joram between his shoulders. The arrow pierced his heart, and he immediately collapsed in his chariot.
2 Kings 9:25 Jehu then said to Bidkar, his captain, 'Pick him up and throw him into the field of Naboth the Jezreelite. Remember how, when you and I were riding in chariots behind Ahab his father, the Lord pronounced this sentence against him, saying:'
2 Kings 9:26 'Surely I saw the blood of Naboth and the blood of his sons yesterday,' says the Lord, 'and I will repay you in this very field,' says the Lord. 'So now, take him and throw him into the field, according to the word of the Lord.'
2 Kings 9:27 When Ahaziah, the king of Judah, saw this, he fled by the road of the garden house. Jehu pursued him and said, 'Strike him down too, in his chariot!'
2 Kings 9:null They struck him down at the ascent of Gur, which is by Ibleam. He fled to Megiddo and died there.
2 Kings 9:28 His servants carried him in his chariot to Jerusalem and buried him in his tomb with his ancestors in the City of David.
2 Kings 9:29 In the eleventh year of Joram, son of Ahab, Ahaziah began to reign over Judah.
2 Kings 9:30 So Jehu came to Jezreel. When Jezebel heard about his arrival, she painted her eyes with dark makeup, arranged her hair, and looked out a window.
2 Kings 9:31 As Jehu entered the city gate, she called out, 'Is it peace, you Zimri, murderer of your master?'
2 Kings 9:32 Jehu looked up to the window and called out, 'Who is on my side? Who?'
2 Kings 9:null Two or three eunuchs looked out to him.
2 Kings 9:33 He said to them, 'Throw her down!' So they threw her down. Her blood splattered on the wall and on the horses, and she was trampled underfoot.
2 Kings 9:34 After Jehu went in, and had eaten and drunk, he said, 'Go and look after that cursed woman and bury her, for she was a king's daughter.'
2 Kings 9:35 But when they went to bury her, they found nothing but her skull, her feet, and the palms of her hands.
2 Kings 9:36 When they returned and reported this to him, Jehu said, 'This is the word of the Lord, which He spoke through His servant Elijah the Tishbite, saying: 'In the field of Jezreel, dogs will devour the flesh of Jezebel.''
