2 Kings 23:11 He removed the horses that the kings of Judah had dedicated to the sun god, at the entrance to the Temple of the Lord, near the chamber of Nathan-melech, the eunuch who was in charge of the courtyards. And the chariots of the sun god he burned with fire.
2 Kings 23:12 The altars that were on the roof of the upper chamber of Ahaz, which the kings of Judah had made, and the altars that Manasseh had made in the two courtyards of the Temple of the Lord—these the king destroyed. He quickly ran and broke them down from that place and brought their ashes to the Kidron torrent.
2 Kings 23:13 The high places that were in Jerusalem, on the right side of the Mount of Offense, which Solomon, king of Israel, had built for Ashtoreth, the idol of the Sidonians, and for Chemosh, the idol of the Moabites, and for Milcom (Moloch), the idol of the Ammonites—these the king desecrated.
2 Kings 23:14 He broke the sacred pillars into pieces and cut down the Asherah poles. Then he filled their places with the bones of the dead.
2 Kings 23:15 Furthermore, the altar that was in Bethel, and the high place that Jeroboam, the son of Nebat, had made—he who caused Israel to sin—both that altar and that high place Josiah destroyed. He burned it, crushed it to powder, and burned the Asherah pole as well.
2 Kings 23:16 Then Josiah turned and saw the tombs that were there on the mountain. He sent men, took the bones from the tombs, and burned them on the altar, thereby desecrating it, just as the word of the Lord had declared through the man of God who had proclaimed these words long ago.
2 Kings 23:17 And he asked, 'What is that monument I see there?' The men of the city replied to him, 'It is the tomb of the man of God who came from Judah and announced these very things that you have done against the altar of Bethel.'
2 Kings 23:18 Josiah said, 'Leave him alone. Let no one disturb his bones.' So his bones remained untouched, along with the bones of the prophet who had come from Samaria.
2 Kings 23:19 Moreover, all the shrines of the high places that were in the cities of Samaria, which the kings of Israel had made to provoke the Lord to anger, Josiah removed. He did to them exactly as he had done in Bethel.
2 Kings 23:20 He sacrificed all the priests of the high places who were there on the altars, and he burned human bones upon them. Then he returned to Jerusalem.
2 Kings 23:21 The king commanded all the people, saying, 'Celebrate the Passover to the Lord your God, as it is written in this covenant book.'
2 Kings 23:22 For such a Passover had not been celebrated since the days of the judges who judged Israel, nor in all the days of the kings of Israel or the kings of Judah.
2 Kings 23:23 But in the eighteenth year of King Josiah's reign, this Passover was celebrated to the Lord in Jerusalem with great devotion.
2 Kings 23:24 Furthermore, Josiah abolished the mediums and spiritists, the household gods and idols, and all the abominations that were found in the land of Judah and in Jerusalem. He did this to uphold the words of the law that were written in the book which Hilkiah the priest found in the Temple of the Lord.
2 Kings 23:25 There was no king like him before him, who turned to the Lord with all his heart, with all his soul, and with all his might, according to all the Law of Moses. Nor did any like him arise after him.
2 Kings 23:26 Nevertheless, the Lord did not turn away from the fierceness of His great wrath, with which His anger burned against Judah because of all the provocations by which Manasseh had provoked Him.
2 Kings 23:27 And the Lord said, 'I will also remove Judah from my presence, just as I removed Israel. I will cast away this city of Jerusalem, which I chose, and the house about which I said, 'My Name shall be there.''
2 Kings 23:28 Now the rest of the acts of Josiah, and all that he did, are they not written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Judah?
2 Kings 23:29 In his days, Pharaoh Neco, king of Egypt, went up to attack the king of Assyria by the Euphrates River. King Josiah went out to meet him in battle, and when Josiah saw him, he was killed at Megiddo.
2 Kings 23:30 His servants carried his dead body from Megiddo, brought him to Jerusalem, and buried him in his own tomb. Then the people of the land took Jehoahaz, Josiah's son, anointed him, and made him king in place of his father.
2 Kings 23:31 Jehoahaz was twenty-three years old when he began to reign, and he reigned for three months in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Hamutal, daughter of Jeremiah, from Libnah.
2 Kings 23:32 He did what was evil in the sight of the Lord, just as all his fathers had done.
2 Kings 23:33 Pharaoh Neco imprisoned him at Riblah, in the land of Hamath, so that he could not reign in Jerusalem. He also imposed a fine on the land: one hundred talents of silver and one talent of gold.
2 Kings 23:34 Pharaoh Neco made Eliakim, Josiah's son, king in place of Josiah his father, and changed his name to Jehoiakim. As for Jehoahaz, Pharaoh took him away to Egypt, and he died there.
2 Kings 23:35 Jehoiakim gave the silver and gold to Pharaoh after he had levied the amount from each person according to their means. He exacted the silver and gold from the people of the land to give to Pharaoh Neco.
2 Kings 23:36 Jehoiakim was twenty-five years old when he began to reign, and he reigned for eleven years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Zebidah, daughter of Pedaiah, from Rumah.
2 Kings 23:37 He did what was evil in the sight of the Lord, just as all his fathers had done.
2 Kings 23:38 In his days, Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, came up, and Jehoiakim became his servant for three years. Then he rebelled against him again.
2 Kings 23:39 The Lord sent against him raiding bands of Chaldeans, bands of Syrians, bands of Moabites, and bands of the Ammonites' sons. He sent them against Judah to destroy it, according to the word of the Lord, which He had spoken through His servants the prophets.
2 Kings 23:40 For indeed, this happened in Judah according to the word of the Lord, that He might remove them from His presence because of all the sins of Manasseh and all that he had done.
2 Kings 23:1 So King Josiah sent out orders, and all the elders of Judah and Jerusalem were gathered to him.
2 Kings 23:2 The king then went up to the Temple of the Lord, God’s holy dwelling, and with him were all the men of Judah, and everyone who was found in Jerusalem—the priests, the prophets, and all the people, from the youngest to the oldest. He read aloud for all to hear all the words of the book of the covenant, the rediscovered ancient law of God, which had been found in the Temple of the Lord.
2 Kings 23:3 The king stood by the pillar and made a solemn covenant before the Lord, promising that he and his people would walk after the Lord, and would keep His commandments, and His testimonies, and His sacred rites with all their heart and with all their soul. They vowed to confirm all the words of this covenant which were written in this book. And all the people confirmed their agreement to the covenant.
2 Kings 23:4 The king then commanded Hilkiah the high priest, the priests of the second rank who assisted him, and the Temple doorkeepers, to remove from the Temple of the Lord all the items that had been made for the worship of Baal, and for the goddess Asherah, and for the worship of all the celestial bodies—the host of heaven. Josiah had these items burned outside Jerusalem in the Kidron Valley, a place of defilement, and had their ashes carried to Bethel, a site historically associated with Israelite idolatry.
2 Kings 23:5 He then removed the pagan priests whom the kings of Judah had appointed to burn incense on the high places, in the cities of Judah, and in the areas around Jerusalem. These priests had burned incense to Baal, to the sun, to the moon, to the twelve constellations of the zodiac, and to all the celestial bodies—the host of heaven.
2 Kings 23:6 He brought the Asherah pole, an idolatrous cult object, out from the Temple of the Lord to the Kidron Valley in Jerusalem. There he burned it, ground it into dust, and scattered the dust over the graves of the common people, further defiling it.
2 Kings 23:7 He also tore down the living quarters of the male cult prostitutes, which were located within the Temple of the Lord, where women wove hangings for the Asherah.
2 Kings 23:8 Josiah then brought all the priests from the cities of Judah to Jerusalem. He defiled the high places where these priests had offered sacrifices, from Geba in the north all the way to Beersheba in the south. He also demolished the altars at the entrance of the gate of Joshua, the governor of the city, which was to the left of the city gate.
2 Kings 23:9 However, those priests who had served at the high places were not permitted to ascend to the altar of the Lord in Jerusalem; instead, they were only allowed to eat unleavened bread among their fellow priests, but not participate in the sacred Temple rituals.
2 Kings 23:10 He also defiled Topheth, which is in the Valley of the Son of Hinnom, to prevent anyone from consecrating their son or daughter by passing them through fire as a sacrifice to the pagan god Moloch. This practice of child sacrifice was abolished.
2 Kings 23:11 He removed the horses that the kings of Judah had dedicated to the sun god, which were at the entrance of the Temple of the Lord, near the chamber of Nathan-Melech, the eunuch who was in charge of the sacred courtyard. He also burned the chariots of the sun with fire.
2 Kings 23:12 The altars that were on the roof of the upper chamber of Ahaz, which the kings of Judah had built, and the altars that Manasseh had built in the two courtyards of the Temple of the Lord, these the king tore down. He quickly broke them into pieces and scattered their dust into the Kidron Valley.
2 Kings 23:13 King Josiah also defiled the high places that were opposite Jerusalem, to the right of the Mount of Offence—also known as the Mount of Olives. These had been built by Solomon, the king of Israel, for Ashtoreth, the detestable idol of the Sidonians; for Chemosh, the detestable idol of Moab; and for Milcom, the detestable idol of the Ammonites. Josiah rendered these sites unusable for worship.
2 Kings 23:14 He smashed the sacred pillars, cut down the Asherah poles, and filled their places with the bones of the dead, further desecrating these pagan sites.
2 Kings 23:15 Furthermore, Josiah destroyed the altar at Bethel and the high place that Jeroboam son of Nebat had made, the very one who led Israel into sin. He pulled down that altar and the high place, burned them, crushed them to dust, and also burned the Asherah pole.
2 Kings 23:16 As Josiah turned around, he saw the tombs that were on the mountain nearby. He sent and took the bones from those tombs, then burned them on the altar, thus defiling it. This action fulfilled the word of the Lord that had been spoken by the man of God, the prophet who had foretold these very events.
2 Kings 23:17 And Josiah asked: 'What is that monument I see there?' The people of the city answered him: 'It is the tomb of the man of God, a prophet who came from Judah and foretold these very things that you have done against the altar of Bethel.'
2 Kings 23:18 So Josiah said: 'Leave him be; let no one disturb his bones.' Thus, his bones were left undisturbed, along with the bones of the prophet who had come from Samaria.
2 Kings 23:19 Josiah also removed all the shrines of the high places in the cities of Samaria, which the kings of Israel had built to provoke the Lord to anger. He dealt with them in the same manner as all the things he had done in Bethel, thoroughly destroying them.
2 Kings 23:20 He sacrificed all the priests of the high places who were there, offering them on their own altars. He also burned human bones on those altars, further desecrating them. After these purifications, Josiah returned to Jerusalem.
2 Kings 23:21 Then King Josiah commanded all the people, saying: 'Celebrate the Passover to the Lord your God, exactly as it is written in this book of the covenant.'
2 Kings 23:22 Indeed, such a Passover had not been celebrated from the days when the judges ruled Israel, nor during all the days of the kings of Israel and the kings of Judah.
2 Kings 23:23 It was in the eighteenth year of King Josiah’s reign that this Passover was celebrated for the Lord in Jerusalem, a celebration of unparalleled devotion.
2 Kings 23:24 Moreover, Josiah removed all the mediums who consulted the dead, the spiritists, the household idols known as teraphim, the detestable false gods, and all the other abominations that had been present in the land of Judah and in Jerusalem. He did this to establish the words of the Law that were written in the book which Hilkiah the priest had found in the Temple of the Lord.
2 Kings 23:25 No king before him had turned to the Lord with all his heart, with all his soul, and with all his strength, according to all the Law of Moses. Nor did any like him arise after him. Josiah’s devotion was truly exceptional.
2 Kings 23:26 Nevertheless, the Lord did not turn away from the great fierceness of His burning anger, with which His wrath had been kindled against Judah because of all the provocations that Manasseh, a former king, had caused.
2 Kings 23:27 So the Lord said: 'I will also remove Judah from My presence, just as I removed Israel, the northern kingdom. I will cast away this city of Jerusalem, which I chose, and the Temple, about which I said: My Name shall be there.' This signified a complete rejection due to the people's persistent sin.
2 Kings 23:28 Now the rest of the acts of Josiah, and all that he did, are these not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Judah?
2 Kings 23:29 In those days, Pharaoh Necho, the king of Egypt, went up to attack the king of Assyria by the Euphrates River. King Josiah went out to confront him, and was killed at Megiddo as soon as he saw him in battle.
2 Kings 23:30 His servants carried his dead body from Megiddo and brought him to Jerusalem, where they buried him in his own tomb. Then the people of the land took Jehoahaz, Josiah’s son, anointed him, and made him king in place of his father.
2 Kings 23:31 Jehoahaz was twenty-three years old when he began to reign, and he reigned for three months in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Hamutal, the daughter of Jeremiah, from Libnah.
2 Kings 23:32 He did evil in the sight of the Lord, just as all his predecessors, his fathers, had done.
2 Kings 23:33 Then Pharaoh Necho imprisoned him at Riblah, which is in the land of Hamath, to prevent him from reigning in Jerusalem. The Pharaoh also imposed a tribute on the land: one hundred talents of silver and one talent of gold.
2 Kings 23:34 Pharaoh Necho then made Eliakim, Josiah’s son, king in place of his father Josiah, and changed Eliakim’s name to Jehoiakim. As for Jehoahaz, Necho took him away to Egypt, and he died there.
2 Kings 23:35 Jehoiakim paid Pharaoh the silver and gold he demanded, collecting it by imposing a tax on each person according to their means. He exacted the money from the people of the land and gave it to Pharaoh Necho.
2 Kings 23:36 Jehoiakim was twenty-five years old when he began to reign, and he reigned for eleven years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Zebidah, the daughter of Pedaiah, from Rumah.
2 Kings 23:37 He did evil in the sight of the Lord, just as all his predecessors, his fathers, had done.
2 Kings 23:38 In his days, Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, came up against Jerusalem. Jehoiakim became his servant for three years, but then he rebelled against him.
2 Kings 23:39 And the Lord sent against him raiding parties of the Chaldeans, and raiding parties of the Syrians, and raiding parties of the Moabites, and raiding parties of the Ammonites. He sent them against Judah to destroy it, according to the word of the Lord, which He had spoken through His servants the prophets.
2 Kings 23:40 Indeed, this came upon Judah by the anger of the Lord, so that He might remove them from His presence because of the sins of Manasseh, according to all that he had done.
2 Kings 24:1 In those days, King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon marched on Judah, and Jehoiakim, king of Judah, became his vassal for three years, but then Jehoiakim rebelled against him.
2 Kings 24:2 And the Lord God sent against Jehoiakim raiding parties of Chaldeans, and raiding parties of Syrians, and raiding parties of Moabites, and raiding parties of the Ammonites. He sent them into Judah to destroy it, just as the Lord God had declared through His servants, the prophets.
2 Kings 24:3 This happened in Judah precisely as the Lord God had declared: He removed them from His sight because of all the sins of Manasseh, everything that Manasseh had done,
2 Kings 24:4 and because of the innocent blood that Manasseh had shed, filling Jerusalem with innocent blood. Because of this, the Lord God refused to forgive them.
2 Kings 24:5 All the other deeds of Jehoiakim, and everything he did, are they not written in the Book of the Annals of the Kings of Judah?
2 Kings 24:6 Jehoiakim died and was buried with his ancestors. Then his son Jehoiachin reigned in his place.
2 Kings 24:7 And the king of Egypt never again left his own territory, because the king of Babylon had taken all the lands that once belonged to the king of Egypt, from the Brook of Egypt all the way to the Euphrates River.
2 Kings 24:8 Jehoiachin was eighteen years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem for three months. His mother's name was Nehushta, daughter of Elnathan, from Jerusalem.
2 Kings 24:9 And Jehoiachin did evil in the sight of the Lord God, just as his father had done.
2 Kings 24:10 At that time, the army of the king of Babylon marched up to Jerusalem, and the city was put under siege.
2 Kings 24:11 King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon himself came to the city while his servants were besieging it.
2 Kings 24:12 So Jehoiachin, the king of Judah, surrendered to the king of Babylon—he, his mother, his servants, his princes, and his eunuchs all surrendered. The king of Babylon accepted his surrender in the eighth year of his own reign.
2 Kings 24:13 Nebuchadnezzar carried away all the treasures from the House of the Lord God and all the treasures from the king's palace. He also cut into pieces all the golden vessels that King Solomon of Israel had made for the Temple of the Lord God, just as the Lord God had declared.
2 Kings 24:14 He deported all of Jerusalem's inhabitants, all the leaders, and all the mighty warriors—ten thousand of them into captivity. He also took every craftsman and every blacksmith, leaving behind only the poorest people of the land.
2 Kings 24:15 Nebuchadnezzar also deported Jehoiachin to Babylon, along with the king's mother, the king's wives, his eunuchs, and all the powerful men of the land were taken captive from Jerusalem to Babylon.
2 Kings 24:16 And all the strong men, numbering seven thousand, and a thousand craftsmen and blacksmiths—all of them strong and capable warriors—the king of Babylon brought them as captives to Babylon.
2 Kings 24:17 And the king of Babylon then made Mattaniah, Jehoiachin's uncle, king in his place, changing his name to Zedekiah.
2 Kings 24:18 Zedekiah was twenty-one years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem for eleven years. His mother's name was Hamutal, daughter of Jeremiah, from Libnah.
2 Kings 24:19 And Zedekiah did evil in the sight of the Lord God, just as Jehoiakim had done.
2 Kings 24:20 For the Lord God was so angry with Jerusalem and with Judah that He eventually cast them out from His sight. Zedekiah also rebelled against the king of Babylon.
2 Kings 25:1 It happened in the ninth year of King Sedecias’ reign, on the tenth day of the tenth month. Nebuchadnezzar, the king of Babylon, came to Jerusalem with his entire army. They surrounded the city and built siege works all around it.
2 Kings 25:2 The city remained under siege until the eleventh year of King Sedecias’ reign.
2 Kings 25:3 On the ninth day of that month, a severe famine gripped the city, and the people of the land had no bread left to eat.
2 Kings 25:4 The city’s defenses were breached, and all the fighting men fled by night through the gate between the two walls that led to the king’s garden. The Chaldeans were surrounding the city at this point. The king himself escaped by way of the plain.
2 Kings 25:5 The Chaldean army pursued the king and captured him in the desert plains near Jericho. All the soldiers who had been with him were scattered away from him.
2 Kings 25:6 So, the captured king was brought to the king of Babylon in Riblah, which is in the land of Hamath. There, Nebuchadnezzar pronounced judgment against him.
2 Kings 25:7 Nebuchadnezzar then killed Sedecias’ sons right before his eyes. After that, he gouged out Sedecias’ eyes, bound him with bronze chains, and took him to Babylon.
2 Kings 25:8 In the fifth month, on the seventh day of the month—which was the nineteenth year of the reign of Nebuchadnezzar, the king of Babylon—Nabuzardan, the commander of the royal guard and a servant of the king of Babylon, came to Jerusalem.
2 Kings 25:9 He set fire to the Temple of the Lord, the king’s palace, and all the houses of Jerusalem. Every important building was burned down.
2 Kings 25:10 The entire Chaldean army, who were with the commander of the royal guard, tore down the walls of Jerusalem all around the city.
2 Kings 25:11 Nabuzardan, the commander of the royal guard, carried away into exile the rest of the people who had remained in the city, along with those who had deserted to the king of Babylon, and all the other common people.
2 Kings 25:12 However, the commander of the royal guard left behind some of the poorest people of the land to be vine dressers and farmers.
2 Kings 25:13 The Chaldeans also broke into pieces the bronze pillars that were in the Temple of the Lord, as well as the movable stands and the great bronze basin known as the Sea, which was also in the Lord's Temple. They carried all the bronze from these items away to Babylon.
2 Kings 25:14 They also took away the bronze pots, shovels, snuffers, ladles, and all the other bronze vessels used in the Temple service.
2 Kings 25:15 The commander of the royal guard also took away the fire pans and the sprinkling bowls, distinguishing those made of solid gold and those made of solid silver.
2 Kings 25:16 As for the two pillars, the one great Sea, and the movable stands that Solomon had made for the Temple of the Lord, the amount of bronze in all these vessels was immeasurable.
2 Kings 25:17 Each pillar was eighteen cubits high, with a bronze capital three cubits high on top. Over the capital, there was bronze lattice work and pomegranates, all made of bronze. The second pillar was identical to this one.
2 Kings 25:18 The commander of the royal guard also took away Saraias, the chief priest, Sophonias, the second priest, and the three doorkeepers.
2 Kings 25:19 From the city, he took one eunuch who was in charge of the fighting men; five men who served as the king's close advisors, whom he found in the city; Sopher, the commander of the army; and sixty men from the common people of the land, who were also found in the city.
2 Kings 25:20 Nabuzardan, the commander of the royal guard, took all these men and brought them to the king of Babylon in Riblah.
2 Kings 25:21 There, in Riblah, in the land of Hamath, the king of Babylon struck them down and put them to death. So, Judah was carried away from its own land into exile.
2 Kings 25:22 As for the people who had been left behind in the land of Judah, those whom Nebuchadnezzar, the king of Babylon, had permitted to remain, he appointed Godolias, the son of Ahicam, the son of Saphan, over them.
2 Kings 25:23 When all the army commanders—they and their men—heard that the king of Babylon had appointed Godolias as governor, they came to Godolias in Maspha. These were Ismael, son of Nathanias; Joanan, son of Caree; Sarea, son of Thanehumeth the Netophathite; and Jezonias, son of Maachati, along with their companions.
2 Kings 25:24 Godolias swore an oath to them and their companions, saying: 'Do not be afraid of serving the Chaldeans. Stay in the land and serve the king of Babylon, and it will go well for you.'
2 Kings 25:25 However, in the seventh month, Ismael, the son of Nathanias, the son of Elisama, who was of royal lineage, came with ten men. They struck down Godolias, who died, and also killed the Jews and Chaldeans who were with him in Maspha.
2 Kings 25:26 Then all the people, from the least to the greatest, along with the army commanders, were afraid. So they rose up and went to Egypt, fearing the Chaldeans’ retaliation.
2 Kings 25:27 It happened in the thirty-seventh year of the exile of Joachin, the king of Judah, in the twelfth month, on the twenty-seventh day of the month. Evilmerodach, the king of Babylon, in the first year of his reign, released Joachin, the king of Judah, from prison.
2 Kings 25:28 Evilmerodach spoke kindly to him and set his throne above the thrones of the other kings who were with him in Babylon.
2 Kings 25:29 Joachin was allowed to change out of his prison clothes, and he was given food to eat continually in the king’s presence for the rest of his life.
2 Kings 25:30 The king also provided him with a regular daily allowance of food for the remaining days of his life, until his death.
1 Chronicles 1:1 Adam, Seth, Enos,
1 Chronicles 1:2 Cainan, Mahalalel, Jared,
1 Chronicles 1:3 Enoch, Methuselah, Lamech,
1 Chronicles 1:4 Noah, Shem, Ham, and Japheth.
1 Chronicles 1:5 The sons of Japheth were Gomer, Magog, Madai, Javan, Tubal, Meshech, and Tiras.
1 Chronicles 1:6 And the sons of Gomer were Ashkenaz, Riphath, and Togarmah.
1 Chronicles 1:7 And the sons of Javan were Elishah, Tarshish, Kittim, and Dodanim.
1 Chronicles 1:8 The sons of Ham were Cush, Mizraim, Put, and Canaan.
1 Chronicles 1:9 And the sons of Cush were Seba, Havilah, Sabtah, Raamah, and Sabteca. The sons of Raamah were Sheba and Dedan.
1 Chronicles 1:10 Furthermore, Cush was the father of Nimrod; he was the first to become a mighty one on earth.
1 Chronicles 1:11 Mizraim was the father of Ludim, Anamim, Lehabim, and Naphtuhim,
1 Chronicles 1:12 and Pathrusim, and Casluhim—from whom the Philistines came—and Caphtorim.
1 Chronicles 1:13 And Canaan was the father of Sidon, his firstborn, and Heth,
1 Chronicles 1:14 and the Jebusites, and the Amorites, and the Girgashites,
1 Chronicles 1:15 and the Hivites, and the Arkites, and the Sinites,
1 Chronicles 1:16 and the Arvadites, and the Zemarites, and the Hamathites.
1 Chronicles 1:17 The sons of Shem were Elam, Asshur, Arphaxad, Lud, Aram, Uz, Hul, Gether, and Mash.
1 Chronicles 1:18 And Arphaxad was the father of Shelah, and Shelah was the father of Eber.
1 Chronicles 1:19 Furthermore, two sons were born to Eber: one was named Peleg—because in his days the earth was divided—and his brother's name was Joktan.
1 Chronicles 1:20 And Joktan was the father of Almodad, Sheleph, Hazarmaveth, and Jerah,
1 Chronicles 1:21 and Hadoram, and Uzal, and Diklah,
1 Chronicles 1:22 and Obal, and Abimael, and Sheba,
1 Chronicles 1:23 as well as Ophir, and Havilah, and Jobab. All these were the sons of Joktan.
1 Chronicles 1:24 Shem, Arphaxad, Shelah,
1 Chronicles 1:25 Eber, Peleg, Reu,
1 Chronicles 1:26 Serug, Nahor, Terah,
1 Chronicles 1:27 Abram, who is Abraham.
1 Chronicles 1:28 And the sons of Abraham were Isaac and Ishmael.
1 Chronicles 1:29 And these were their generations: Ishmael's firstborn was Nebaioth, then Kedar, Adbeel, and Mibsam,
1 Chronicles 1:30 and Mishma, and Dumah, Massa, Hadad, and Tema,
1 Chronicles 1:31 Jetur, Naphish, and Kedemah. These were the sons of Ishmael.
1 Chronicles 1:32 And the sons of Keturah, Abraham's concubine, whom she bore to him, were Zimran, Jokshan, Medan, Midian, Ishbak, and Shuah. And the sons of Jokshan were Sheba and Dedan.
1 Chronicles 1:33 And the sons of Midian were Ephah, Epher, Hanoch, Abidah, and Eldaah. All these were the sons of Keturah.
1 Chronicles 1:34 Abraham was the father of Isaac. And Isaac's sons were Esau and Israel.
1 Chronicles 1:35 The sons of Esau were Eliphaz, Reuel, Jeush, Jaalam, and Korah.
1 Chronicles 1:36 The sons of Eliphaz were Teman, Omar, Zepho, Gatam, Kenaz, Timna, and Amalek.
1 Chronicles 1:37 The sons of Reuel were Nahath, Zerah, Shammah, and Mizzah.
1 Chronicles 1:38 The sons of Seir were Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, Anah, Dishon, Ezer, and Dishan.
1 Chronicles 1:39 The sons of Lotan were Hori and Homam. Lotan's sister was Timna.
1 Chronicles 1:40 The sons of Shobal were Alian, Manahath, Ebal, Shephi, and Onam. The sons of Zibeon were Aiah and Anah.
1 Chronicles 2:1 These are the sons of Israel—who was also known as Jacob: Reuben, Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Zebulun,
1 Chronicles 2:2 Dan, Joseph, Benjamin, Naphtali, Gad, and Asher.
1 Chronicles 2:3 The sons of Judah were Er, Onan, and Shelah. These three were born to him from the daughter of Shua, a Canaanite woman. Er, Judah's firstborn, was wicked in the sight of the Lord, and the Lord brought about his death.
1 Chronicles 2:4 Moreover, his daughter-in-law Tamar bore him Perez and Zerah. Thus, Judah had a total of five sons.
1 Chronicles 2:5 The sons of Perez were Hezron and Hamul.
1 Chronicles 2:6 The sons of Zerah were Zimri, Ethan, Heman, Calcol, and Dara—a total of five sons.
1 Chronicles 2:7 The son of Carmi was Achar, who brought trouble upon Israel by sinning against the things devoted to destruction by God's ban.
1 Chronicles 2:8 The son of Ethan was Azariah.
1 Chronicles 2:9 The sons of Hezron who were born to him were Jerahmeel, Ram, and Caleb.
1 Chronicles 2:10 Furthermore, Ram fathered Amminadab. Amminadab in turn fathered Nahshon, who was a prince among the sons of Judah.
1 Chronicles 2:11 Nahshon fathered Salma, and Salma fathered Boaz.
1 Chronicles 2:12 Boaz also fathered Obed, and Obed fathered Jesse.
1 Chronicles 2:13 Jesse fathered his firstborn, Eliab; his second son, Abinadab; and his third son, Shimea.
1 Chronicles 2:14 His fourth son was Nethanel, and his fifth was Raddai.
1 Chronicles 2:15 His sixth son was Ozem, and his seventh was David.
1 Chronicles 2:16 Their sisters were Zeruiah and Abigail. The sons of Zeruiah were Abishai, Joab, and Asahel—three men.
1 Chronicles 2:17 Abigail bore Amasa, whose father was Jether the Ishmaelite.
1 Chronicles 2:18 Caleb, the son of Hezron, took a wife named Azubah, who bore him Jerioth. Azubah's sons by Caleb were Jesher, Shobab, and Ardon.
1 Chronicles 2:19 After Azubah died, Caleb took another wife named Ephrath, who bore him Hur.
1 Chronicles 2:20 Furthermore, Hur fathered Uri, and Uri fathered Bezalel.
1 Chronicles 2:21 After these events, Hezron went in to the daughter of Machir, the father of Gilead, and took her as his wife when he was sixty years old. She bore him Segub.
1 Chronicles 2:22 Segub also fathered Jair, who possessed twenty-three cities in the land of Gilead.
1 Chronicles 2:23 Jair captured Geshur and Aram, as well as the towns bearing Jair's name, and Kenath with its sixty villages. All these men were descendants of Machir, the father of Gilead.
1 Chronicles 2:24 After Hezron died in Caleb-Ephrathah, his wife Abiah bore him Ashur, the father of Tekoa.
1 Chronicles 2:25 The sons born to Jerahmeel, Hezron's firstborn son, were Ram—who was Jerahmeel's firstborn—then Bunah, Oren, Ozem, and Ahijah.
1 Chronicles 2:26 Jerahmeel also took another wife, named Atarah, who was the mother of Onam.
1 Chronicles 2:27 Furthermore, the sons of Ram, Jerahmeel's firstborn, were Maaz, Jamin, and Eker.
1 Chronicles 2:28 The sons of Onam were Shammai and Jada. The sons of Shammai were Nadab and Abishur.
1 Chronicles 2:29 The name of Abishur's wife was Abihail, who bore him Ahban and Molid.
1 Chronicles 2:30 The sons of Nadab were Seled and Appaim. Seled died without having any children.
1 Chronicles 2:31 The son of Appaim was Ishi. The son of Ishi was Sheshan. The son of Sheshan was Ahlai.
1 Chronicles 2:32 The sons of Jada, Shammai's brother, were Jether and Jonathan. Jether died without having any children.
1 Chronicles 2:33 Furthermore, the sons of Jonathan were Peleth and Ziza. These are the sons of Jerahmeel.
1 Chronicles 2:34 Sheshan had no sons, only daughters. He also had an Egyptian servant named Jarha.
1 Chronicles 2:35 So Sheshan gave his daughter to Jarha as his wife, and she bore him Attai.
1 Chronicles 2:36 Furthermore, Attai fathered Nathan, and Nathan fathered Zabad.
1 Chronicles 2:37 Zabad also fathered Ephlal, and Ephlal fathered Obed.
1 Chronicles 2:38 Obed fathered Jehu, and Jehu fathered Azariah.
1 Chronicles 2:39 Azariah fathered Helez, and Helez fathered Eleasa.
1 Chronicles 2:40 Eleasa fathered Sismai, and Sismai fathered Shallum.
1 Chronicles 3:1 The sons of David who were born to him in Hebron were: The firstborn was Amnon, whose mother was Ahinoam from Jezreel; the second son was Daniel, whose mother was Abigail from Carmel.
1 Chronicles 3:2 The third son was Absalom, whose mother was Maachah, daughter of Talmai, king of Geshur; the fourth son was Adonijah, whose mother was Haggith.
1 Chronicles 3:3 The fifth son was Shephatiah, whose mother was Abital; the sixth son was Ithream, whose mother was Eglah, David’s wife.
1 Chronicles 3:4 Therefore, these six sons were born to David in Hebron, where he reigned for seven years and six months. He then reigned in Jerusalem for thirty-three years.
1 Chronicles 3:5 These are the sons who were born to him in Jerusalem: Shammua, Shobab, Nathan, and Solomon. These four sons were born from Bath-shua, daughter of Ammiel.
1 Chronicles 3:6 Also, Ibhar, Elishama, and Eliphelet.
1 Chronicles 3:7 And Nogah, Nepheg, and Japhia.
1 Chronicles 3:8 In addition, Elishama, Eliada, and Eliphelet. These were nine sons in total.
1 Chronicles 3:9 All these were the sons of David, not including the sons he had with his concubines. They also had a sister named Tamar.
1 Chronicles 3:10 The son of Solomon was Rehoboam. Rehoboam’s son was Abijah. Abijah’s son was Asa. Asa’s son was Jehoshaphat.
1 Chronicles 3:11 Jehoshaphat’s son was Ahaziah. Ahaziah’s son was Joash. Joash’s son was Amaziah. Amaziah’s son was Azariah. Azariah’s son was Jotham.
1 Chronicles 3:12 Jotham’s son was Ahaz. Ahaz’s son was Hezekiah. Hezekiah’s son was Manasseh.
1 Chronicles 3:13 Manasseh’s son was Amon. Amon’s son was Josiah.
1 Chronicles 3:14 The sons of Josiah were: The firstborn was Johanan; the second son was Jehoiakim; the third son was Zedekiah; the fourth son was Shallum.
1 Chronicles 3:15 The sons of Jehoiakim were: His son was Jeconiah, and his son was Zedekiah.
1 Chronicles 3:16 From Jeconiah, his son Salathiel was born.
1 Chronicles 3:17 Also from Jeconiah, his other sons were Malchiram, Pedaiah, Shenazzar, Jekamiah, Hoshama, and Nedabiah.
1 Chronicles 3:18 The sons of Pedaiah were Zerubbabel and Shimei. The sons of Zerubbabel were Meshullam, Hananiah, and their sister Shelomith.
1 Chronicles 3:19 Also, the other sons of Zerubbabel were Hashubah, Ohel, Berechiah, Hasadiah, and Jushab-hesed. These were five additional sons.
1 Chronicles 3:20 The sons of Hananiah were Pelatiah and Jeshaiah. Jeshaiah was the father of Rephaiah, who was the father of Arnan, who was the father of Obadiah, who was the father of Shecaniah.
1 Chronicles 3:21 The son of Shecaniah was Shemaiah. And the sons of Shemaiah were Hattush, Igal, Bariah, Neariah, and Shaphat. These were six sons.
1 Chronicles 3:22 The sons of Neariah were Elioenai, Hezekiah, and Azrikam. These were three sons.
1 Chronicles 3:23 The sons of Elioenai were Hodaviah, Eliashib, Pelaiah, Akkub, Johanan, Delaiah, and Anani. These were seven sons.
1 Chronicles 3:24 The sons of Elioenai were Hodaviah, Eliashib, Pelaiah, Akkub, Johanan, Delaiah, and Anani. These were seven sons.
1 Chronicles 4:1 The sons of Judah were Phares, Hesron, Charmi, Hur, and Sobal.
1 Chronicles 4:2 Raia's son was Jaath, from whom Ahiud and Laad were born. These are the families of Sarai.
1 Chronicles 4:3 And these are the descendants of Etam: Jezrahel, Jesema, and Jedebos, whose family name was 'Father of his brother'. Also listed are Nomina and Sarrhae.
1 Chronicles 4:4 Phanuel was the father of Gedor, and Ezer was the father of Hosa. These men were the sons of Hur, the firstborn of Ephratha, who was the father of Bethlehem.
1 Chronicles 4:5 Assur, the father of Thecue, had two wives, Helea and Naara.
1 Chronicles 4:6 Naara bore him Oza, Hepher, Themani, and Ahastari. These are the sons of Naara.
1 Chronicles 4:7 The sons of Helea were Zereth, Sohar, and Ethnan.
1 Chronicles 4:8 Furthermore, Cos fathered Anob and Sobeba, and the families of Aharhel, the son of Harum.
1 Chronicles 4:9 Now there was a man of noble birth whose name was Jabes, more honorable than all his brothers. His mother called his name Jabes, saying, 'Because I bore him in sorrows.'
1 Chronicles 4:10 Therefore, Jabes called upon the God of Israel, saying, 'If You truly bless me, and expand my territories, and if Your hand is with me, and You keep me from evil so that I do not suffer.' And God granted what he prayed for.
1 Chronicles 4:11 Furthermore, Caleb, the brother of Sua, fathered Mehir, who was the father of Esthon.
1 Chronicles 4:12 Esthon fathered Bethrapha, Phasea, and Tehinna, who was the father of the city of Naas. These are the men of Recab.
1 Chronicles 4:13 The sons of Cenez were Othoniel and Saraia. The sons of Othoniel were Hathath and Maonathi.
1 Chronicles 4:14 Maonathi fathered Ophra, and Saraia fathered Joab, the father of the Valley of Craftsmen, for they were indeed craftsmen.
1 Chronicles 4:15 The sons of Caleb, the son of Jephone, were Hir, Ela, and Naham. The sons of Ela were Cenez.
1 Chronicles 4:16 The sons of Jahaleleel were Ziph, Zipha, Thiria, and Asareel.
1 Chronicles 4:17 The sons of Esra were Jether, Mered, Epher, and Jalon. He fathered Miriam, Sammai, and Jesba, the father of Esthamo.
1 Chronicles 4:18 His Jewish wife bore Jared, the father of Gedor, and Heber, the father of Socho, and Jecuthiel, the father of Zanoe. These are the sons of Bechia, the daughter of Pharaoh, whom Mered took as his wife.
1 Chronicles 4:19 The sons of his wife Odaia, the sister of Naham, the father of Ceila, were Garmita and Esthamo, who was a Machathite.
1 Chronicles 4:20 The sons of Simon were Amnon and Rina, and Hanan's son, and Thilon. And the sons of Jesi were Zoheth and Benzoheth.
1 Chronicles 4:21 The sons of Sela, the son of Judah, were Her, the father of Lecha, and Laada, the father of Maresa. Also, the families of the house of those who worked fine linen in Bethsan.
1 Chronicles 4:22 And these are the men of Lying, and the men of Soham, and the men of Chozeba, and those who were among the leaders, and those who returned to Bethlehem. These are the ancient records.
1 Chronicles 4:23 These were potters who lived in plantations and among hedges. They remained with the king for his works.
1 Chronicles 4:24 The sons of Simeon were Namuel, Jamin, Jarib, Zara, and Saul.
1 Chronicles 4:25 Sallum was his son, Mabsam was his son, Masma was his son.
1 Chronicles 4:26 The sons of Masma: Amus was his son, Misma was his son. The repetition of 'Misma filius ejus' in the Latin may indicate a distinct, repeated name, or it could be a scribal duplication in the original text.
1 Chronicles 4:27 The sons of Amus: Zechur was his son, Semei was his son. Semei had sixteen sons and six daughters. His brothers did not have many children, and their entire family could not equal the number of the sons of Judah.
1 Chronicles 4:28 They lived in Bersabee, Molada, and Hasarsual,
1 Chronicles 4:29 And Bala, Asom, and Tholad,
1 Chronicles 4:30 And Bathuel, Horma, and Siceleg,
1 Chronicles 4:31 And Bethmarchaboth, Hasarsusim, Bethberai, and Saarim. These were their cities until the reign of King David.
1 Chronicles 4:32 Their villages also included Etam, Ain, Remmon, Thochen, and Asan: five cities.
1 Chronicles 4:33 And all their surrounding hamlets of these cities up to Baal. This was their dwelling place, and their tribal division.
1 Chronicles 4:34 Masobab, Jemlech, and Josa, the son of Amasias,
1 Chronicles 4:35 And Johel, and Jehu, the son of Josabia, the son of Saraia, the son of Asiel,
1 Chronicles 4:36 And Elioenai, Jacoba, Isuhaia, Asaia, Adiel, Ismiel, and Banaia,
1 Chronicles 4:37 And Ziza, the son of Sephei, the son of Allon, the son of Idaia, the son of Semri, the son of Samaia.
1 Chronicles 4:38 These men, who were listed by name, were leaders in their families, and their ancestral houses were numerous.
1 Chronicles 4:39 They went out, as commanded, to Gad, as far as Gador and to the eastern limits of the open country, to seek pasture for their flocks.
1 Chronicles 4:40 And they found very rich and excellent pastures, and a very wide, peaceful, and fertile land, where people of the lineage of Cham had lived before them.
1 Chronicles 5:1 The sons of Reuben, Israel's firstborn son. Even though Reuben himself was the firstborn of Jacob, because he defiled his father's marriage bed, his birthright was given to the sons of Joseph, the son of Israel. Therefore, Reuben was not reckoned as the firstborn in terms of the blessings of the birthright.
1 Chronicles 5:2 The reason for this change in the birthright was that from Judah came mighty men, and from him arose the leader of the people—the royal family, that is—and he was not reckoned as the firstborn according to his genealogy, but according to God's choice for leadership.
1 Chronicles 5:3 Now, the actual sons of Reuben, Israel's firstborn, were Enoch, Pallu, Hezron, and Carmi.
1 Chronicles 5:4 The sons of Joel were Shemaiah, his son; Gog, his son; Shimei, his son;
1 Chronicles 5:5 Michah, his son; Reaiah, his son; Baal, his son;
1 Chronicles 5:6 And Beerah, his son. Beerah was one of the leaders of the tribe of Reuben, whom Tiglath-Pileser, the king of Assyria, carried away captive to Babylon.
1 Chronicles 5:7 His brothers, along with their entire clan, were counted according to their families. The chief men were Jeiel and Zechariah.
1 Chronicles 5:8 Bela, the son of Azaz, the son of Shema, the son of Joel, lived in Aroer, stretching as far as Nebo and Baal-Meon.
1 Chronicles 5:9 Eastward, they extended their dwelling places all the way to the entrance of the desert, to the River Euphrates. This was because they owned a vast number of livestock in the land of Gilead.
1 Chronicles 5:10 During the days of King Saul, they waged war against the Hagrites and defeated them. Afterward, they lived in the Hagrites' tents throughout the entire region east of Gilead.
1 Chronicles 5:11 The sons of Gad lived opposite them, in the land of Bashan, as far as Salecah.
1 Chronicles 5:12 Joel was the chief, and Shapham was second in command. Then Janai and Shaphat lived in Bashan.
1 Chronicles 5:13 Their brothers, according to their families, were seven: Michael, Meshullam, Sheba, Jorai, Jacan, Zia, and Heber.
1 Chronicles 5:14 These were the sons of Abihail, the son of Huri, the son of Jaroah, the son of Gilead, the son of Michael, the son of Jeshishai, the son of Jahdo, the son of Buz.
1 Chronicles 5:15 Also, their brothers, the sons of Abihail, were chiefs of their families: Jahdo and Buz.
1 Chronicles 5:16 These men lived in Gilead, in Bashan and its surrounding villages, and in all the open pasturelands of Sharon, up to their borders.
1 Chronicles 5:17 All these men were recorded in the genealogies during the reigns of Jotham, king of Judah, and Jeroboam, king of Israel.
1 Chronicles 5:18 The sons of Reuben, the Gadites, and the half-tribe of Manasseh were all valiant men, capable warriors. They carried shields and swords, were skilled archers, and knew how to fight in battle. Those who went out to war numbered forty-six thousand seven hundred and thirty.
1 Chronicles 5:19 They fought against the Hagrites, along with the Jeturites, Naphishites, and Nodabites.
1 Chronicles 5:20 They received help against these enemies. The Hagrites and all who were with them were delivered into their hands. This victory occurred because the Israelite warriors cried out to the Lord during the battle, and He heard their prayers, for they trusted in Him.
1 Chronicles 5:21 They carried away as plunder their livestock: fifty thousand camels, two hundred fifty thousand sheep, two thousand donkeys, and one hundred thousand people as captives.
1 Chronicles 5:22 Many of their enemies were killed because the battle was fought under God's righteous judgment. And the Reubenites, Gadites, and the half-tribe of Manasseh lived in their place until the time of the exile.
1 Chronicles 5:23 The sons of the half-tribe of Manasseh possessed the land from Bashan to Baal-Hermon, Senir, and Mount Hermon, for they had become very numerous.
1 Chronicles 5:24 These were the chiefs of their family divisions in the half-tribe of Manasseh: Epher, Ishi, Eliel, Azriel, Jeremiah, Hodaviah, and Jahdiel. They were brave and powerful men, well-known leaders of their respective families.
1 Chronicles 5:25 However, these tribes committed spiritual adultery against the God of their fathers. They prostituted themselves by following the gods of the peoples of the land, whom God had removed from before them.
1 Chronicles 5:26 Therefore, the God of Israel stirred up the spirit of Pul, king of Assyria, also known as Tiglath-Pileser, king of Assyria. He carried away the Reubenites, the Gadites, and the half-tribe of Manasseh, bringing them to Halah, Habor, Hara, and to the river Gozan, where they remain to this very day.
1 Chronicles 5:27 The sons of Levi were Gershon, Kohath, and Merari.
1 Chronicles 5:28 The sons of Kohath were Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel.
1 Chronicles 5:29 The sons of Amram were Aaron, Moses, and Miriam. The sons of Aaron were Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.
1 Chronicles 5:30 Eleazar fathered Phinehas, and Phinehas fathered Abishua.
1 Chronicles 5:31 Abishua fathered Bukki, and Bukki fathered Uzzi.
1 Chronicles 5:32 Uzzi fathered Zerahiah, and Zerahiah fathered Meraioth.
1 Chronicles 5:33 Meraioth fathered Amariah, and Amariah fathered Ahitub.
1 Chronicles 5:34 Ahitub fathered Zadok, and Zadok fathered Ahimaaz.
1 Chronicles 5:35 Ahimaaz fathered Azariah, and Azariah fathered Johanan.
1 Chronicles 5:36 Johanan fathered Azariah. This Azariah was the one who served as priest in the Temple that King Solomon built in Jerusalem.
1 Chronicles 5:37 Azariah fathered Amariah, and Amariah fathered Ahitub.
1 Chronicles 5:38 Ahitub fathered Zadok, and Zadok fathered Shallum.
1 Chronicles 5:39 Shallum fathered Hilkiah, and Hilkiah fathered Azariah.
1 Chronicles 5:40 Azariah fathered Seraiah, and Seraiah fathered Jehozadak.
1 Chronicles 6:1 The children of Levi were Gerson, Caath, and Merari.
1 Chronicles 6:2 The children of Caath were Amram, Isahar, Hebron, and Oziel.
1 Chronicles 6:3 The children of Amram were Aaron, Moyses, and Maria. The children of Aaron were Nadab, Abiu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.
1 Chronicles 6:4 Eleazar was the father of Phinees, and Phinees was the father of Abisue.
1 Chronicles 6:5 Abisue was the father of Bocci, and Bocci was the father of Ozi.
1 Chronicles 6:6 Ozi was the father of Zarahiæ, and Zarahiæ was the father of Meraioth.
1 Chronicles 6:7 Meraioth was the father of Amariam, and Amariam was the father of Achitob.
1 Chronicles 6:8 Achitob was the father of Sadoc, and Sadoc was the father of Achimaas.
1 Chronicles 6:9 Achimaas was the father of Azariam, and Azariam was the father of Johanan.
1 Chronicles 6:10 Johanan was the father of Azariam. This Azarias was the priest who ministered in the house which Solomon built in Jerusalem.
1 Chronicles 6:11 Azarias was the father of Amariam, and Amariam was the father of Achitob.
1 Chronicles 6:12 Achitob was the father of Sadoc, and Sadoc was the father of Sellum.
1 Chronicles 6:13 Sellum was the father of Helcias, and Helcias was the father of Azariam.
1 Chronicles 6:14 Azarias was the father of Saraiam, and Saraiam was the father of Josedec.
1 Chronicles 6:15 Moreover, Josedec went into exile when the Lord allowed Nabuchodonosor to carry away the people of Judah and Jerusalem.
1 Chronicles 6:16 The children of Levi were Gerson, Caath, and Merari.
1 Chronicles 6:17 And these are the names of the children of Gerson: Lobni and Semei.
1 Chronicles 6:18 The children of Caath were Amram, Isahar, Hebron, and Oziel.
1 Chronicles 6:19 The children of Merari were Moholi and Musi. Now these are the descendants of Levi according to their family groups.
1 Chronicles 6:20 From Gerson: his son Lobni, his son Jahath, his son Zamma.
1 Chronicles 6:21 His son Joah, his son Addo, his son Zara, his son Jethrai.
1 Chronicles 6:22 The children of Caath were: his son Aminadab, his son Core, his son Asir.
1 Chronicles 6:23 His son Elcana, his son Abiasaph, his son Asir.
1 Chronicles 6:24 His son Thahath, his son Uriel, his son Ozias, his son Saul.
1 Chronicles 6:25 The children of Elcana were Amasai and Achimoth.
1 Chronicles 6:26 His son Elcana, his son Sophai, his son Nahath.
1 Chronicles 6:27 His son Eliab, his son Jeroham, his son Elcana.
1 Chronicles 6:28 The children of Samuel were: his firstborn, Vasseni, and Abia.
1 Chronicles 6:29 The children of Merari were: Moholi, his son Lobni, his son Semei, his son Oza.
1 Chronicles 6:30 His son Samaa, his son Haggia, his son Asaia.
1 Chronicles 6:31 These are the men whom David appointed to oversee the singers in the house of the Lord, from the time the ark was placed there.
1 Chronicles 6:32 And they ministered before the tabernacle of testimony with singing, until Solomon built the house of the Lord in Jerusalem; they stood in their service according to their appointed order.
1 Chronicles 6:33 Now these are the men who assisted with their sons, from the children of Caath: Hemam, the singer, son of Johel, son of Samuel.
1 Chronicles 6:34 Son of Elcana, son of Jeroham, son of Eliel, son of Thoë.
1 Chronicles 6:35 Son of Suph, son of Elcana, son of Maath, son of Amasai.
1 Chronicles 6:36 Son of Elcana, son of Johel, son of Azariæ, son of Sophoniæ.
1 Chronicles 6:37 Son of Thahath, son of Asir, son of Abiasaph, son of Core.
1 Chronicles 6:38 Son of Isaar, son of Caath, son of Levi, son of Israel.
1 Chronicles 6:39 And his brother Asaph, who stood at his right hand, was Asaph, son of Barachiæ, son of Samaa.
1 Chronicles 6:40 Son of Michaël, son of Basaia, son of Melchiæ.
1 Chronicles 7:1 Now the sons of Issachar were Tola, Phua, Jasub, and Somer—a total of four sons.
1 Chronicles 7:2 The sons of Tola were Uzzi, Raphaia, Jerihel, Jemai, Jebsem, and Samuel. These men became the heads of their families, mighty warriors from their ancestral lines. Their total number, as recorded in the days of King David, was two hundred twenty thousand six hundred.
1 Chronicles 7:3 The son of Uzzi was Izrahia. And Izrahia's sons were Michaël, Abdia, Joel, and Jesia—a total of five, all of whom became family heads.
1 Chronicles 7:4 With these men and their extended families, according to their relationships and households, there were thirty-six thousand mighty men ready for battle, because they had many wives and many sons.
1 Chronicles 7:5 Their brothers, from all the families of Issachar, were mighty men for battle, totaling ninety-seven thousand.
1 Chronicles 7:6 The sons of Benjamin were Bela, Becher, and Jadihel—a total of three.
1 Chronicles 7:7 The sons of Bela were Esbon, Uzzi, Uziel, Jerimoth, and Uri—five in total. These were the heads of families, mighty warriors. Their number was twenty-two thousand thirty-four.
1 Chronicles 7:8 The sons of Becher were Zamira, Joas, Eliezer, Elioenai, Omri, Jerimoth, Abia, Anathoth, and Almath. All these were the sons of Becher.
1 Chronicles 7:9 The count of these men, by their families, who were heads of families and mighty in battle, was twenty thousand two hundred.
1 Chronicles 7:10 The son of Jadihel was Balan. And the sons of Balan were Jehus, Benjamin, Aod, Chanana, Zethan, Tharsis, and Ahisahar.
1 Chronicles 7:11 All these, the sons of Jadihel, were heads of families and mighty men of war, numbering seventeen thousand two hundred who were ready for battle.
1 Chronicles 7:12 Also Sepham and Huppham were the sons of Hir. And Husim was a son of Aher.
1 Chronicles 7:13 The sons of Nephthali were Jasiel, Guni, Jezer, and Sellum—these were the sons of Bala.
1 Chronicles 7:14 The sons of Manasseh: Asrihel. And his Syrian concubine bore Machir, who became the father of Galaad.
1 Chronicles 7:15 Machir took wives for his sons Hupphim and Supphim. He also had a sister named Maacha. The name of his second son was Salphaad, who had only daughters.
1 Chronicles 7:16 Maacha, Machir's wife, bore a son and called his name Phares. His brother's name was Sares. His sons were Ulam and Recem.
1 Chronicles 7:17 The son of Ulam was Badan. These were the sons of Galaad, the son of Machir, the son of Manasseh.
1 Chronicles 7:18 His sister, Regina, bore Isod, Abihi, and Mahela.
1 Chronicles 7:19 The sons of Semida were Ahian, Sechem, Leci, and Aniam.
1 Chronicles 7:20 The sons of Ephraim: Suthela, whose son was Bared; whose son was Ruhapha; whose son was Reseph; whose son was Thale; whose son was Aran.
1 Chronicles 7:21 His son was Badam; whose son was Zathan; whose son was Eden. His brother was Berad, and Thaha. The men who were native to Geth killed them because they had gone down to plunder their livestock.
1 Chronicles 7:22 Ephraim, their father, was struck with grief for many days, and his brothers came to comfort him.
1 Chronicles 7:23 Then he went to his wife, who conceived and bore a son, and he called his name Beria because he was born during a time of evil in his household.
1 Chronicles 7:24 His daughter was Sara, who built the lower and upper Bethoron, and Uzzen Sara.
1 Chronicles 7:25 His son was Rapha, and Reseph, and Thale, from whom Taan was born.
1 Chronicles 7:26 Taan begot Laadan; Laadan's son was Ammiud; Ammiud's son was Elisama.
1 Chronicles 7:27 Elisama's son was Nun; Nun's son was Josue.
1 Chronicles 7:28 Their possessions and dwellings were Bethel with its villages, and to the east, Noran; to the west, Gazer with its villages; also Sichem with its villages, all the way to Azam and its villages.
1 Chronicles 7:29 Alongside the sons of Manasseh, their territory included Bethsan with its villages, Thanach with its villages, Mageddo with its villages, and Gezer with its villages. In these places the sons of Joseph, the sons of Israel, lived.
1 Chronicles 7:30 The sons of Aser were Jemna, Jesua, Jessui, and Beria, with Sara as their sister.
1 Chronicles 7:31 The sons of Beria were Heber and Melchiel. Melchiel was the father of Barsaith.
1 Chronicles 7:32 Heber begot Jephlat, Somer, Hotham, and Suaa, their sister.
1 Chronicles 7:33 The sons of Jephlat were Phosech, Bamaal, and Asoth. These were Jephlat's sons.
1 Chronicles 7:34 The sons of Somer were Roaga, Haba, and Aram.
1 Chronicles 7:35 And the sons of Hotham were Supha, Jemna, Seles, and Amal.
1 Chronicles 7:36 The sons of Aser: from Supha were Sue, Harnapher, Sual, Beri, and Jamra.
1 Chronicles 7:37 And Bosor, and Hod, and Sama, and Selesa, and Jethran, and Bera.
1 Chronicles 7:38 The sons of Jether were Jephone, Phaspha, and Ara.
1 Chronicles 7:39 The sons of Ulla were Arah, Hanniel, and Resia.
1 Chronicles 7:40 All these were the sons of Aser, heads of families, chosen as mighty leaders among the chiefs. The number of men who were prepared to be led into battle was twenty-six thousand.
1 Chronicles 8:1 Now Benjamin fathered his firstborn son, Bala. His second son was Asbel, and his third was Ahara.
1 Chronicles 8:2 His fourth son was Noha, and his fifth was Rapha.
1 Chronicles 8:3 The sons of Bala were Addar, Gera, and Abihud.
1 Chronicles 8:4 Also, Abishua, Naaman, and Ahiah.
1 Chronicles 8:5 And Gera, Sephuphan, and Huram.
1 Chronicles 8:6 These were the sons of Ehud, who were the chiefs of the families living in Geba. They were moved and settled in Manahath.
1 Chronicles 8:7 These were Naaman, Ahiah, and Gera. It was Gera himself who relocated them, and he fathered Uzza and Ahihud.
1 Chronicles 8:8 Furthermore, Shaharaim fathered children in the region of Moab after he had sent away his wives Hushim and Baara.
1 Chronicles 8:9 Now, by his wife Hodes, he fathered Jobab, Zebiah, Mesha, and Malcam.
1 Chronicles 8:10 Also Jeus, Sachia, and Mirma. These are his sons, who were chiefs of families.
1 Chronicles 8:11 From Hushim, however, he fathered Ahitub and Elpaal.
1 Chronicles 8:12 Now the sons of Elpaal were Heber, Misham, and Shemed. It was Shemed who built Ono and Lod, along with their surrounding villages.
1 Chronicles 8:13 Also, Beriah and Shema were chiefs of families who lived in Aijalon. These were the ones who drove out the inhabitants of Gath.
1 Chronicles 8:14 Ahio, Shashak, and Jeremoth.
1 Chronicles 8:15 Zebadiah, Arad, and Eder.
1 Chronicles 8:16 Michael, Ishpah, and Joha were the sons of Beriah.
1 Chronicles 8:17 Zebadiah, Meshullam, Hizki, and Heber.
1 Chronicles 8:18 Also Ishmerai, Izliah, and Jobab were sons of Elpaal.
1 Chronicles 8:19 Jakim, Zichri, and Zabdi.
1 Chronicles 8:20 Elienai, Zilthai, and Eliel.
1 Chronicles 8:21 Adaiah, Beraiah, and Shimrath were the sons of Shimei.
1 Chronicles 8:22 Ishpan, Heber, and Eliel.
1 Chronicles 8:23 Abdon, Zichri, and Hanan.
1 Chronicles 8:24 Hananiah, Elam, and Antothiah.
1 Chronicles 8:25 Iphedeiah and Penuel were the sons of Shashak.
1 Chronicles 8:26 Shamsherai, Shehariah, and Athaliah.
1 Chronicles 8:27 Jereshiah, Eliah, and Zichri were the sons of Jeroham.
1 Chronicles 8:28 These were the chiefs of the families and their lineages. These chiefs dwelt in Jerusalem.
1 Chronicles 8:29 Now, in Gibeon, the father, or founder, of Gibeon dwelt, and the name of his wife was Maachah.
1 Chronicles 8:30 And his firstborn son was Abdon, then Zur, Kish, Baal, and Nadab.
1 Chronicles 8:31 Also Gedor, Ahio, and Zecher.
1 Chronicles 8:32 And Mikloth fathered Shimeah. These lived alongside their relatives in Jerusalem, within the community of their brothers.
1 Chronicles 8:33 Furthermore, Ner fathered Kish. Kish fathered Saul. And Saul fathered Jonathan, Malchishua, Abinadab, and Esh-baal.
1 Chronicles 8:34 And Jonathan's son was Meribbaal. And Meribbaal fathered Micah.

1 Chronicles 8:37 And Moza fathered Binea, who was the father of Rapha. And Rapha fathered Eleasah. And Eleasah fathered Azel.
1 Chronicles 8:38 Now Azel had six sons. Their names were Azrikam, Bocheru, Ishmael, Sheariah, Obadiah, and Hanan. All these were the sons of Azel.
1 Chronicles 8:39 Now the sons of Eshek, his brother, were Ulam his firstborn, Jeush his second, and Eliphelet his third.
1 Chronicles 8:40 Now the sons of Ulam were exceptionally strong men and skilled archers. They had many sons and descendants, up to one hundred and fifty in number. All these were from the sons of Benjamin.
1 Chronicles 9:1 And all of Israel was counted and their records are found in the books of the kings of Judah and Israel; and they were taken away as exiles to Babylon because of their sins.
1 Chronicles 9:2 The first people to resettle in their cities and lands were these leaders: the Israelites, the priests, the Levites, and the Nethinim.
1 Chronicles 9:3 In Jerusalem itself, the following groups lived: some from the children of Judah, and some from the children of Benjamin, and some from the children of Ephraim and Manasseh.
1 Chronicles 9:4 Uthai, son of Ammiud, son of Omri, son of Bana, from the children of Perez, son of Judah.
1 Chronicles 9:5 And from the line of Shelah, there was Asaiah the firstborn, and his sons.
1 Chronicles 9:6 From the children of Zerah, there was Jeuel, and his six hundred and ninety brothers.
1 Chronicles 9:7 And from the children of Benjamin: Sallu, son of Meshullam, son of Hodaviah, son of Hassenuah.
1 Chronicles 9:8 And Ibneiah, son of Jeroham; and Elah, son of Uzzi, son of Michri; and Meshullam, son of Shephathiah, son of Reuel, son of Ibnijah.
1 Chronicles 9:9 And their brothers, according to their family lines, numbered nine hundred and fifty-six. All these were heads of households, according to their family units.
1 Chronicles 9:10 And among the priests were: Jedaiah, Jehoiarib, Jachin.
1 Chronicles 9:11 And Azariah, son of Hilkiah, son of Meshullam, son of Zadok, son of Meraioth, son of Ahitub, who was the ruler of the House of God.
1 Chronicles 9:12 Also Adaiah, son of Jeroham, son of Pashhur, son of Malchijah; and Maasai, son of Adiel, son of Jahzerah, son of Meshullam, son of Meshillemith, son of Immer.
1 Chronicles 9:13 And their brothers, who were heads of households, numbered one thousand seven hundred and sixty. They were very mighty in strength for the work of the service of the House of God.
1 Chronicles 9:14 Now from the Levites: Shemaiah, son of Hasshub, son of Azrikam, son of Hashabiah, from the children of Merari.
1 Chronicles 9:15 Bakbakkar, Heresh, Galal; Mattaniah, son of Micah, son of Zichri, son of Asaph.
1 Chronicles 9:16 And Obadiah, son of Shemaiah, son of Galal, son of Jeduthun; and Berechiah, son of Asa, son of Elkanah, who lived in the settlements of Netophah.
1 Chronicles 9:17 Now the gatekeepers were: Shallum, Akkub, Talmon, and Ahiman. And their brothers; Shallum was their chief.
1 Chronicles 9:18 Until now, they were the gatekeepers at the King's Gate, which is to the east, serving in their assigned shifts, these sons of Levi.
1 Chronicles 9:19 Furthermore, Shallum, son of Kore, son of Ebiasaph, son of Korah—with his brothers and his father's household, the Korahites—they were in charge of the work of the ministry, as guardians of the thresholds of the tabernacle. And their family lines, in their assigned shifts, were responsible for guarding the Lord's encampment.
1 Chronicles 9:20 Now Phinehas, son of Eleazar, was their leader before the Lord.
1 Chronicles 9:21 And Zechariah, son of Meshelemiah, was the gatekeeper of the entrance to the Tabernacle of the Covenant.
1 Chronicles 9:22 All these chosen gatekeepers for the entrances numbered two hundred and twelve. They were assigned to their own villages, whom David and Samuel the prophet had appointed in their faithfulness to God.
1 Chronicles 9:23 Both they themselves and their sons were responsible for guarding the entrances to the Lord's tabernacle.
1 Chronicles 9:24 The gatekeepers were stationed at the four cardinal directions: to the east, west, north, and south.
1 Chronicles 9:25 Their brothers lived in their own villages so that they could come every seven days and take their shift with them.
1 Chronicles 9:26 For these were the chief gatekeepers from the Levitical lineage, holding their positions by trust. They were also in charge of the treasuries, and of the sacred treasures.
1 Chronicles 9:27 It was also their duty to open the doors every morning.
1 Chronicles 9:28 Some of them were also responsible for the vessels of ministry, and these were brought in and taken out by count.
1 Chronicles 9:29 Others among them were entrusted with the sacred vessels, and all the vessels for the ceremonial rites, as well as the fine flour, wine, oil, incense, and spices.
1 Chronicles 9:30 But it was the sons of the priests who prepared the mixtures of ointments.
1 Chronicles 9:31 And Mattithiah, a Levite, the firstborn of Shallum the Korahite, was entrusted with the preparation of the offerings baked on griddles.
1 Chronicles 9:32 And some of their brothers, from the children of Kohath, were responsible for the bread of the Presence, making sure new loaves were prepared every Sabbath.
1 Chronicles 9:33 These are the singers, who were heads of Levitical households, and they lived in special chambers. They were continually serving in their ministry both day and night.
1 Chronicles 9:34 These were the heads of the Levitical households, according to their generations and dwelling places. These were the chief men.
1 Chronicles 9:35 Now in Gibeon, Jeiel, the father of Gibeon, lived there; and the name of his wife was Maacah.
1 Chronicles 9:36 His firstborn son was Abdon, then Zur, Kish, Baal, Ner, and Nadab.
1 Chronicles 9:37 Also Gedor, Ahio, Zechariah, and Mikloth.
1 Chronicles 9:38 Mikloth begot Shimeam. These also lived alongside their relatives in Jerusalem, with their brothers.
1 Chronicles 9:39 Ner begot Kish; Kish begot Saul; and Saul begot Jonathan, Malchishua, Abinadab, and Eshbaal.
1 Chronicles 9:40 And the son of Jonathan was Meribbaal; and Meribbaal begot Micah. And the sons of Micah were Pithon, Melech, Tahrea, and Ahaz.
1 Chronicles 10:1 So then, the Philistines were fighting against Israel. The Israelite soldiers fled from the Philistines and fell, wounded, on Mount Gilboa.
1 Chronicles 10:2 The Philistines pursued Saul and his sons, and they struck down Jonathan, Abinadab, and Malchisua, who were Saul's sons.
1 Chronicles 10:3 The battle intensified against Saul, and the archers found him and wounded him with their arrows.
1 Chronicles 10:4 Saul then said to his armor-bearer: 'Draw your sword and run me through, so that these uncircumcised enemies (the Philistines, viewed with religious contempt by the Israelites) don't come and mock me.' But his armor-bearer refused, utterly terrified.
1 Chronicles 10:5 So Saul took his own sword and fell upon it.
1 Chronicles 10:6 When his armor-bearer saw that Saul was dead, he also fell upon his own sword and died.
1 Chronicles 10:7 Now all the Israelites who lived in the valleys, upon seeing that the Israelite soldiers had fled and that Saul and his sons were dead, abandoned their cities and every location, and fled. Then the Philistines came and settled there.
1 Chronicles 10:8 So on the next day, the Philistines came to strip the dead, and they found Saul and his sons lying on Mount Gilboa.
1 Chronicles 10:9 They cut off his head and stripped him of his armor, and sent them throughout the land of the Philistines (to publicly announce their victory), to be displayed among the temples of their idols and to be shown to their own people.
1 Chronicles 10:10 They placed Saul's armor in the temple of Astaroth (a pagan goddess), and fastened his head in the temple of Dagon (a pagan god).
1 Chronicles 10:11 When all the inhabitants of Jabesh-Gilead heard this about everything the Philistines had done to Saul (their former deliverer),
1 Chronicles 10:12 All the bravest men rose up and took the bodies of Saul and his sons. They brought them to Jabesh and buried their bones under the oak tree that was in Jabesh. And they fasted for seven days (in mourning).
1 Chronicles 10:13 So Saul died because of his sins: because he had transgressed the command of the Lord, which he had not kept, and moreover, he had even consulted a witch (a diviner, a practice forbidden by God).
1 Chronicles 10:14 and had not trusted in the Lord. Therefore, the Lord killed him and transferred his kingdom to David, the son of Jesse.
1 Chronicles 11:1 So then, all of Israel gathered to David in Hebron, saying, "Behold, we are your bone and your flesh," meaning we are your family and kin.
1 Chronicles 11:2 Even long ago, while Saul was still reigning, you were the one who led Israel out to battle and brought them back. And the Lord your God told you: "You shall shepherd My people Israel, and you shall be their chosen leader."
1 Chronicles 11:3 So then, all the elders of Israel came to the king in Hebron. And David made a covenant with them in Hebron before the Lord. And they anointed him king over Israel, just as the Lord had spoken through Samuel.
1 Chronicles 11:4 Then David and all of Israel went to Jerusalem—which is also called Jebus, where the Jebusites were living in the land.
1 Chronicles 11:5 But the inhabitants of Jebus said to David, "You shall not enter here!" Nevertheless, David captured the stronghold of Sion, which is now known as the City of David.
1 Chronicles 11:6 David had said earlier, "Whoever strikes down a Jebusite first will be made chief and a commander." So Joab, the son of Sarvia, went up first, and he became the chief.
1 Chronicles 11:7 And David lived in that stronghold, which is why it was called the City of David.
1 Chronicles 11:8 And David built up the city all around, from Millo and extending in a circle. Meanwhile, Joab restored the rest of the city.
1 Chronicles 11:9 And David became very great, continually growing and becoming more prominent, for the Lord of hosts was with him.
1 Chronicles 11:10 These also are the chiefs of David's mighty men, who helped him become king over all of Israel, in accordance with the word of the Lord.
1 Chronicles 11:11 And this is the number of David's mighty men: Jasobaam, the son of Hachamoni, who was chief among the thirty. He lifted his spear against three hundred men and wounded them all at one time.
1 Chronicles 11:12 After him was Eleazar, the son of his uncle Dodo the Ahohite, who was among the three most powerful.
1 Chronicles 11:13 He was with David at Pas Dammim, when the Philistines gathered for battle. And the field was full of Philistines, and there was a field of barley there.
1 Chronicles 11:14 When the people had fled from the Philistines, Eleazar stood in the middle of the field and delivered it from the enemy. He struck down the Philistines, and the Lord saved them with a great salvation through Eleazar's action.
1 Chronicles 11:15 Moreover, three of the thirty chiefs went down to the rock where David was, in the cave of Adullam, while the Philistines were camped in the Valley of Rephaim.
1 Chronicles 11:16 David was then in the stronghold, and a garrison of Philistines was in Bethlehem.
1 Chronicles 11:17 So David longed for something and said, "Oh, if only someone would give me water from the well of Bethlehem, which is by the gate!"
1 Chronicles 11:18 And the three mighty men broke through the middle of the Philistine camp and drew water from the well of Bethlehem, which was by the gate, and brought it to David. But he refused to drink it. Instead, he poured it out as a libation to the Lord.
1 Chronicles 11:19 David said, "Far be it from me to do this in the sight of my God! Shall I drink the blood of these men? For at the risk of their very lives they brought this water to me." And for this reason, he refused to drink it. These were the acts of the three most mighty men.
1 Chronicles 11:20 Abisai, Joab's brother, was also chief of the three. He himself lifted his spear against three hundred men and killed them, and he had as great a reputation among the three as the others.
1 Chronicles 11:21 Among the three, he was second and more renowned, and he was like a leader to them. Nevertheless, he did not attain to the fame of the first three.
1 Chronicles 11:22 Banaias, the son of Jojada, a most courageous man from Cabseel, accomplished many great deeds. He struck down two lion-like men of Moab, and he himself went down into a pit and killed a lion on a snowy day.
1 Chronicles 11:23 He also killed an Egyptian of incredible stature, who had a spear in his hand like a weaver's beam. Banaias went down to him with only a staff, took the spear from him, and killed him with his own spear.
1 Chronicles 11:24 These things Banaias, the son of Jojada, accomplished, and he was renowned among the three most powerful men.
1 Chronicles 11:25 He was chief among the thirty, yet he did not attain to the fame of the first three. But David appointed him to his inner circle, meaning he became a close and trusted advisor.
1 Chronicles 11:26 Now the bravest men of the army were Asahel, Joab's brother, and Elchanan, the son of his uncle Dodo from Bethlehem,
1 Chronicles 11:27 Sammoth the Harorite, Helles the Pelonite,
1 Chronicles 11:28 Ira, the son of Acces the Tekoite, Abiezer the Anathothite,
1 Chronicles 11:29 Sobochai the Hushathite, Ilai the Ahohite,
1 Chronicles 11:30 Maharai the Netophathite, Heled, the son of Baana the Netophathite,
1 Chronicles 11:31 Ittai, the son of Ribai, from Gibeah of the sons of Benjamin, Banaia the Pirathonite,
1 Chronicles 11:32 Hurai from the brooks of Gaash, Abiel the Arbathite,
1 Chronicles 11:33 Azmoth the Baharumite, Eliaba the Shaalbonite,
1 Chronicles 11:34 The sons of Assan the Gizonite, Jonathan, the son of Sage the Hararite,
1 Chronicles 11:35 Ahiam, the son of Sachar the Hararite, Eliphal, the son of Ur,
1 Chronicles 11:36 Hepher the Mecherathite, Ahia the Pelonite,
1 Chronicles 11:37 Hesro the Carmelite, Naarai, the son of Azbai,
1 Chronicles 11:38 Joel, Nathan's brother, Mibahar, the son of Hagri,
1 Chronicles 11:39 Selec the Ammonite, Naharai the Beerothite, who was the armor-bearer for Joab, the son of Sarvia,
1 Chronicles 11:40 Ira the Ithrite, Gareb the Ithrite.
1 Chronicles 12:1 These are the ones who came to David in Ziklag while he was still fleeing King Saul, the son of Kish. These men were very strong and excellent fighters.
1 Chronicles 12:2 They were skilled with the bow and could sling stones and shoot arrows with either hand. These men were even from Saul’s own kinsmen, from the tribe of Benjamin.
1 Chronicles 12:3 The chief Aheizer, and Joas, sons of Samaa, from Gibeah; also Jaziel and Pheleth, sons of Azmoth; and Baracha and Jehu from Anathoth.
1 Chronicles 12:4 There was also Samaia from Gibeon, who was the strongest among the thirty, and even above them in command. From Gederah were Jeremias, Jeheziel, Johanan, and Jozabad.
1 Chronicles 12:5 Eluzai, Jerimuth, Baalia, Samaria, and Sephatia, all Haruphites.
1 Chronicles 12:6 Celcana, Jesia, Azareel, Joezer, and Jasabaam, all Carithites.
1 Chronicles 12:7 And Joela and Zabadia, the sons of Jeroham, from Gedor.
1 Chronicles 12:8 And from the tribe of Gad, men also deserted to David when he was hiding out in the desert. They were very strong men and excellent warriors, bearing shields and spears. Their faces were as fierce as lions, and they were as swift as gazelles on the mountains.
1 Chronicles 12:9 Ezer was their chief, Obadias was second in command, and Eliab was third.
1 Chronicles 12:10 Masmana was fourth, and Jeremias was fifth.
1 Chronicles 12:11 Ethi was sixth, and Eliel was seventh.
1 Chronicles 12:12 Johanan was eighth, and Elzebad was ninth.
1 Chronicles 12:13 Jeremias was tenth, and Machbanai was eleventh.
1 Chronicles 12:14 These men from the sons of Gad were commanders in the army. The least capable among them commanded a hundred soldiers, and the greatest among them commanded a thousand.
1 Chronicles 12:15 These were the men who crossed the Jordan River in the first month of the year, when the waters overflowed its banks due to the spring floods. They drove away everyone who was dwelling in the valleys, on both the eastern and western sides.
1 Chronicles 12:16 Some men also came from Benjamin and Judah to the strongholds where David was staying.
1 Chronicles 12:17 David went out to meet them and said: "If you have come to me peacefully to help me, then my heart will be united with you. But if you are here to betray me to my adversaries—even though I have done no wrong—then may the God of our fathers see it and judge you."
1 Chronicles 12:18 Then the Spirit of God empowered Amasai, who was a chief among the thirty, and he said: "We are yours, O David, and we are with you, son of Jesse! Peace, peace to you, and peace to all who help you, for your God truly helps you." So David received them and made them commanders of his troops.
1 Chronicles 12:19 Furthermore, some men from the tribe of Manasseh also deserted to David when he was coming with the Philistines to fight against Saul. But David did not actually fight with the Philistines, because the Philistine princes, after careful deliberation, sent him away, saying, "He will surely turn back to his master Saul at the cost of our lives, endangering us."
1 Chronicles 12:20 Therefore, when David returned to Ziklag, men from Manasseh deserted to him: Ednas, Jozabad, Jediel, Michael, Jozabad, Eliu, and Silthai. These were commanders of thousands within the tribe of Manasseh.
1 Chronicles 12:21 These men helped David against the marauders, for they were all very strong men and became commanders in David's army.
1 Chronicles 12:22 And indeed, day by day, more men came to David, as if to offer help, until his army became very great—as numerous and formidable as the army of God Himself.
1 Chronicles 12:23 This is the number of the commanders of the army who came to David in Hebron to transfer the kingdom from Saul to him, just as the Lord had promised.
1 Chronicles 12:24 From the sons of Judah, bearing shield and spear, there were six thousand eight hundred men, ready for battle.
1 Chronicles 12:25 From the sons of Simeon, seven thousand one hundred very strong men, ready for battle.
1 Chronicles 12:26 From the sons of Levi, four thousand six hundred.
1 Chronicles 12:27 And Jojada, a chief from the family of Aaron, and with him three thousand seven hundred men.
1 Chronicles 12:28 And also Zadok, an excellent young man, came from the household of his father, bringing with him twenty-two commanders.
1 Chronicles 12:29 And from the sons of Benjamin, who were Saul's kinsmen, three thousand men came. This was significant because many more of the Benjaminites were still loyal to Saul’s household.
1 Chronicles 12:30 Furthermore, from the sons of Ephraim, there were twenty thousand eight hundred very strong men, each one distinguished by his reputation.
1 Chronicles 12:31 And from the half-tribe of Manasseh, eighteen thousand men came, each one specifically named and recognized, to make David king.
1 Chronicles 12:32 From the sons of Issachar, there were men who understood the times, so that they knew exactly what Israel ought to do. Their commanders were two hundred, and the rest of their tribe followed their command.
1 Chronicles 12:33 Furthermore, from the tribe of Zebulun, there were fifty thousand men, ready to go out to battle and stand in formation, fully equipped with all military weapons. They helped David with sincere and undivided hearts.
1 Chronicles 12:34 And from Naphtali, there were one thousand commanders, and with them thirty-seven thousand armed men ready for battle.
1 Chronicles 12:35 And from Dan also, twenty-eight thousand six hundred men, ready for battle.
1 Chronicles 12:36 And from Asher, forty thousand men who were going out to battle and prepared for war.
1 Chronicles 12:37 From beyond the Jordan River, from the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh, there were one hundred twenty thousand men, fully equipped with all the weapons of war.
1 Chronicles 12:38 All these warriors, ready for battle and fighting in formation, came to Hebron with complete devotion to make David king over all Israel. Indeed, all the rest of Israel were of one accord and unanimous in their decision to make David king.
1 Chronicles 12:39 They were there with David for three days, eating and drinking, for their brethren in the region had prepared an abundant feast for them.
1 Chronicles 12:40 Moreover, even those who lived near them, reaching as far as the tribes of Issachar, Zebulun, and Naphtali, were bringing provisions on donkeys, camels, mules, and oxen for them to eat: an abundance of flour, figs, raisins, wine, oil, cattle, and sheep. For there was indeed great joy throughout Israel.
1 Chronicles 13:1 Then David consulted with all the leaders of Israel: the commanders of thousands and the commanders of hundreds.
1 Chronicles 13:2 He spoke to the entire assembly of Israel, saying: "If it pleases you, and if this plan is truly from the Lord our God, let us send messengers to the rest of our brothers throughout all the lands of Israel. Let us also send for the priests and Levites who live in the outlying settlements of the cities, so they may gather to us."
