Ezra 10:1 So, while Ezra was praying and confessing his sins, weeping and lying prostrate before God’s Temple, a very large crowd from Israel gathered around him—men, women, and children alike. And all the people wept with deep sorrow.
Ezra 10:2 Then Shechaniah, son of Jehiel, from the family of Elam, spoke to Ezra. He said: 'We have certainly sinned against our God by marrying foreign women from the surrounding nations. But even in this state, there remains hope for Israel to be restored.'
Ezra 10:3 'So let us make a solemn covenant with our God. We must send away all these foreign wives and the children born from them. This must be done according to the clear will of the Lord and the desire of those who truly reverence the commandment of our Lord God. Let it be done strictly according to God’s Law.'
Ezra 10:4 'Ezra, arise! This task is primarily yours, but we are with you to help. Be strong in the Lord, and carry out this command.'
Ezra 10:5 So Ezra stood up. He then put all the leaders of the priests, the Levites, and everyone in Israel under oath to carry out this command. And they all took the oath.
Ezra 10:6 Ezra then rose from his place before the Temple of God. He went to the living chamber of Johanan, son of Eliashib. While he stayed there, he refused to eat any bread or drink any water. He did this because he was deeply mourning the great sin committed by those who had returned from their captivity.
Ezra 10:7 A proclamation was then sent throughout Judah and Jerusalem to all the sons of Israel. They were commanded to gather together in Jerusalem.
Ezra 10:8 It was decreed that anyone who failed to come within three days, following the counsel of the leaders and elders, would have all their possessions confiscated. Furthermore, that person would be permanently cut off from the entire community of those who had returned from captivity.
Ezra 10:9 So, within the specified three days, all the men from Judah and Benjamin gathered in Jerusalem. This was on the twentieth day of the ninth month. All the people sat in the open square before the House of God, shivering from both their sin and the heavy rains that were falling.
Ezra 10:10 Then Ezra the priest stood up and addressed them directly. He said: 'You have indeed transgressed God’s Law by marrying foreign women. By doing so, you have only added to the already great sin of Israel.'
Ezra 10:11 'Now, confess your sins truly to the Lord God of your ancestors. Do His will exactly as He commands. Separate yourselves completely from the surrounding nations and from these foreign wives.'
Ezra 10:12 Then the entire assembly responded to Ezra, shouting with one voice: 'What you have spoken to us, let it be done exactly as you say!'
Ezra 10:13 They added: 'However, there are many of us here, and it is the rainy season, so we cannot remain standing outside in these conditions. This is a task that cannot be completed in just one or two days, for many of us have committed this great sin.'
Ezra 10:14 'Let leaders be appointed from among the whole assembly. Then, let all who have married foreign women throughout our cities come forward at a set time, on a specific appointed day. They should come with the elders and judges of their respective cities. This process must continue until the fierce wrath of our God concerning this grave sin is finally turned away from us.'
Ezra 10:15 However, Jonathan, son of Asahel, and Jahzeiah, son of Tikvah, openly opposed this course of action. Meshullam and Shabbethai, a Levite, actively supported their opposition.
Ezra 10:16 Despite the opposition, the sons of Israel proceeded with the plan. Ezra the priest, along with the designated heads of each family, assembled at the ancestral house. Each man was called by his name. They began to investigate this serious matter on the first day of the tenth month.
Ezra 10:17 By the first day of the first month of the new year, they had completed the investigation concerning all the men who had married foreign women.
Ezra 10:18 Among the descendants of the priests, these were found to have married foreign women: From the line of Jeshua, son of Jozadak, and his brothers, these were: Maaseiah, Eliezer, Jarib, and Gedaliah.
Ezra 10:19 They swore an oath, giving their hands in agreement, to send away their wives. Furthermore, as an atonement for their great sin, they committed to offering a ram from the flocks.
Ezra 10:20 From the family of Immer: Hanani and Zebadiah.
Ezra 10:21 From the family of Harim: Maaseiah, Elijah, Shemaiah, Jehiel, and Uzziah.
Ezra 10:22 From the family of Pashhur: Elioenai, Maaseiah, Ishmael, Nethanel, Jozabad, and Elasah.
Ezra 10:23 Among the Levites: Jozabad, Shimei, Kelaiah (also known as Kelita), Pethahiah, Judah, and Eliezer.
Ezra 10:24 Among the Temple singers: Eliashib. Among the gatekeepers: Shallum, Telem, and Uri.
Ezra 10:25 From the rest of Israel, specifically from the family of Parosh: Ramiah, Jeziah, Malchiah, Mijamin, Eleazar, Malchiah (again), and Benaiah.
Ezra 10:26 From the family of Elam: Mattaniah, Zechariah, Jehiel, Abdi, Jeremoth, and Elijah.
Ezra 10:27 From the family of Zattu: Elioenai, Eliashib, Mattaniah, Jeremoth, Zabad, and Aziza.
Ezra 10:28 From the family of Bebai: Johanan, Hananiah, Zabbai, and Athlai.
Ezra 10:29 From the family of Bani: Meshullam, Malluch, Adaiah, Jashub, Sheal, and Ramoth.
Ezra 10:30 From the family of Pahath-Moab: Edna, Chelal, Benaiah, Maaseiah, Mattaniah, Bezalel, Binnui, and Manasseh.
Ezra 10:31 From the family of Harim: Eliezer, Isshiah, Malchiah, Shemaiah, and Simeon.
Ezra 10:32 Also, Benjamin, Malluch, and Shemariah.
Ezra 10:33 From the family of Hashum: Mattanai, Mattathah, Zabad, Eliphelet, Jeremai, Manasseh, and Shimei.
Ezra 10:34 From the family of Bani: Maadai, Amram, and Uel.
Ezra 10:35 Also Benaiah, Bedeiah, and Cheluhi.
Ezra 10:36 Vaniah, Meremoth, and Eliashib.
Ezra 10:37 Mattaniah, Mattanai, and Jaasai.
Ezra 10:38 Bani, Binnui, and Shimei.
Ezra 10:39 Shelemiah, Nathan, and Adaiah.
Ezra 10:40 Machnadebai, Shashai, and Sharai.
Ezra 10:1 When all these things were taking place, Ezra was praying, confessing the sins of the people, weeping, and lying prostrate before God’s temple. A very large assembly of men, women, and children from all of Israel gathered around him, and the people wept with great and loud lamentation.
Ezra 10:2 Then Shecaniah, the son of Jehiel, one of the sons of Elam, spoke to Ezra and said: “We have sinned greatly against our God and have taken foreign wives from the peoples of the land. But even in this, there is still hope for Israel.”
Ezra 10:3 “Therefore, let us now make a covenant with our God to send away all these wives and their children, according to the will of the Lord and of those who fear the commandments of our God. Let it be done according to the Law.”
Ezra 10:4 “Rise up, Ezra, for this task is yours, and we are with you. Be strong, and carry it out.”
Ezra 10:5 So Ezra rose up and made the chief priests, the Levites, and all the people of Israel swear an oath that they would do according to this command. And they all swore the oath.
Ezra 10:6 Then Ezra went from before the house of God and entered the chamber of Johanan, the son of Eliashib. When he went in there, he ate no bread and drank no water, for he was still mourning over the unfaithfulness of those who had returned from captivity.
Ezra 10:7 And they sent out a proclamation throughout all of Judah and Jerusalem to all the exiles, calling them to gather in Jerusalem.
Ezra 10:8 Whoever did not come within three days, according to the decision of the leaders and elders, would have all his possessions confiscated, and he himself would be excluded from the assembly of the exiles.
Ezra 10:9 So all the men of Judah and Benjamin gathered in Jerusalem within three days. It was the ninth month, on the twentieth day of the month. All the people sat in the open square before the house of God, trembling both because of their sin and because of the heavy rain.
Ezra 10:10 Then Ezra the priest stood up and said to them: “You have trespassed and have taken foreign wives, thus adding to the guilt of Israel.”
Ezra 10:11 “Now, therefore, give confession to the Lord, the God of your fathers, and do His will. Separate yourselves from the peoples of the land and from your foreign wives.”
Ezra 10:12 Then all the assembly answered with a loud voice, saying: “As you have said to us, so let it be done!”
Ezra 10:13 “However, because there are many who have sinned in this matter, and it is the rainy season, we cannot stand outside. This work cannot be finished in just one or two days, for indeed, many of us have sinned grievously in this matter.”
Ezra 10:14 “Therefore, let our leaders be appointed for the entire assembly. Let all those in our cities who have taken foreign wives come at appointed times, along with the elders and judges of each city, until the fierce wrath of our God concerning this sin is turned away from us.”
Ezra 10:15 Only Jonathan, the son of Asahel, and Jahzeiah, the son of Tikvah, opposed this plan; and Meshullam and Shabbethai the Levite supported them in their opposition.
Ezra 10:16 The exiles did as they had agreed. Ezra the priest and certain men, heads of ancestral households, all designated by name, went to their homes. They began their investigation on the first day of the tenth month to examine the matter.
Ezra 10:17 By the first day of the first month, they had finished dealing with all the men who had taken foreign wives.
Ezra 10:18 Among the sons of the priests who had taken foreign wives were these: From the sons of Jeshua, son of Jozadak, and his brothers: Maaseiah, Eliezer, Jarib, and Gedaliah.
Ezra 10:19 They gave their hands in solemn agreement to send away their wives, and for their guilt, they offered a ram from the flock as a sin offering.
Ezra 10:20 From the sons of Immer: Hanani and Zebadiah.
Ezra 10:21 From the sons of Harim: Maaseiah, Elijah, Shemaiah, Jehiel, and Uzziah.
Ezra 10:22 From the sons of Pashhur: Elioenai, Maaseiah, Ishmael, Nethanel, Jozabad, and Elasah.
Ezra 10:23 From the Levites: Jozabad, Shimei, Kelaiah (who is also Kelita), Pethahiah, Judah, and Eliezer.
Ezra 10:24 From the singers: Eliashib. And from the gatekeepers: Shallum, Telem, and Uri.
Ezra 10:25 From the common people of Israel: From the sons of Parosh: Ramiah, Izziah, Malchijah, Mijamin, Eleazar, Malchijah, and Benaiah.
Ezra 10:26 From the sons of Elam: Mattaniah, Zechariah, Jehiel, Abdi, Jeremoth, and Elijah.
Ezra 10:27 From the sons of Zattu: Elioenai, Eliashib, Mattaniah, Jeremoth, Zabad, and Aziza.
Ezra 10:28 From the sons of Bebai: Jehohanan, Hananiah, Zabbai, and Athlai.
Ezra 10:29 From the sons of Bani: Meshullam, Malluch, Adaiah, Jashub, Sheal, and Jeremoth.
Ezra 10:30 From the sons of Pahath-Moab: Adna, Chelal, Benaiah, Maaseiah, Mattaniah, Bezalel, Binnui, and Manasseh.
Ezra 10:31 From the sons of Harim: Eliezer, Ishijah, Malchijah, Shemaiah, Simeon,
Ezra 10:32 Benjamin, Malluch, and Shemariah.
Ezra 10:33 From the sons of Hashum: Mattenai, Mattattah, Zabad, Eliphelet, Jeremai, Manasseh, and Shimei.
Ezra 10:34 From the sons of Bani: Maadai, Amram, and Uel,
Ezra 10:35 Benaiah, Bedeiah, Cheluhi,
Ezra 10:36 Vaniah, Meremoth, Eliashib,
Ezra 10:37 Mattaniah, Mattenai, and Jaasai,
Ezra 10:38 Bani, Binnui, Shimei,
Ezra 10:39 Shelemiah, Nathan, and Adaiah,
Ezra 10:40 Machnadebai, Shashai, Sharai,
Nehemiah 1:1 This is the account of Nehemiah, the son of Hilkiah. It happened in the month of Chislev—the ninth month of the Jewish calendar—in the twentieth year of King Artaxerxes' reign, and I was in the citadel of Susa.
Nehemiah 1:2 And Hanani, one of my brothers, came to me with some men from Judah. I questioned them about the Jews who had escaped and survived the exile, and about Jerusalem.
Nehemiah 1:3 And they said to me: 'The remaining exiles there in the province of Judah are in great distress and public shame. The wall of Jerusalem has been torn down, and its gates have been burned to ashes by fire.'
Nehemiah 1:4 As soon as I heard these words, I sat down, wept, and mourned for many days. I fasted and prayed in the presence of the God of Heaven.
Nehemiah 1:5 And I said: 'I implore You, Lord God of Heaven, O mighty, great, and awesome God, who keeps His covenant and shows mercy to those who love Him and obey His commands!'
Nehemiah 1:6 May Your ears be open and Your eyes attentive, that You may hear the prayer of Your servant, which I am praying before You today, day and night, for Your servants, the children of Israel. I confess the sins of the children of Israel, which they have committed against You—my father's household and I have also sinned.
Nehemiah 1:7 We have acted corruptly and strayed from You, for we have not kept Your commandments, Your statutes, and Your ordinances, which You commanded through Your servant Moses.
Nehemiah 1:8 Remember the word that You gave to Your servant Moses, saying: 'If you transgress, I will scatter you among the nations.
Nehemiah 1:9 But if you return to Me, and keep My commands, and do them—even if you have been carried away to the furthest reaches of the universe—from there I will gather you and bring you to the place which I have chosen, that My Name may reside there.'
Nehemiah 1:10 These are Your servants and Your people, whom You redeemed with Your great power and Your mighty hand.
Nehemiah 1:11 I implore You, Lord, incline Your ear to the prayer of Your servant, and to the prayer of Your servants who desire to revere Your Name. Grant success to Your servant today, and grant him favor in the sight of this man—for I was the king's cupbearer.
Nehemiah 1:1 These are the historical accounts of Nehemiah, son of Helchia. This occurred in the month of Casleu, during the twentieth year of the king's reign, while I was residing in the citadel of Susa.
Nehemiah 2:1 Now it came to pass in the month of Nisan, in the twentieth year of King Artaxerxes, that the wine was placed before him. I, Nehemiah, then took the wine and gave it to the king. Before this day, I had not shown any sadness in his presence, for it was forbidden to approach the king with a sorrowful demeanor.
Nehemiah 2:2 And the king said to me, 'Why is your face sad, seeing that I see no sign of illness in you? This can only be sorrow within your heart.' And at this question, I became greatly afraid.
Nehemiah 2:3 And I said to the king, 'O king, live forever! Why should my face not show sorrow, seeing that the city where my fathers are buried—Jerusalem—lies desolate, and its gates have been consumed by fire?'
Nehemiah 2:4 And the king said to me, 'What do you wish to request?' And at that very moment, I prayed to the God of the universe.
Nehemiah 2:5 And I said to the king, 'If it seems good to the king, and if your servant finds favor in your sight, I request that you send me to Judea, to the city where my fathers are buried, so that I may rebuild it.'
Nehemiah 2:6 And the king said to me (with the queen sitting beside him), 'For what period of time will your journey be, and when will you return?' And the matter pleased the king, and he sent me. I also set a specific time for my return for him.
Nehemiah 2:7 And I said to the king, 'If it is good in the sight of the king, let letters be given to me for the governors of the region beyond the river Euphrates, so that they may grant me safe passage until I come to Judea.'
Nehemiah 2:8 'And also a letter to Asaph, the keeper of the king's forest, so that he may give me timber to cover the gates of the fortress that belongs to the temple, and the walls of the city of Jerusalem, and the house into which I will enter.' And the king granted me all these things, because the good hand—the favor—of my God was upon me.
Nehemiah 2:9 So I came to the governors of the region beyond the river, and I delivered the king's letters to them. The king had also sent with me captains of the army and horsemen for protection and escort.
Nehemiah 2:10 Now when Sanaballat the Horonite and Tobias, the Ammonite official, heard of this, they were greatly displeased. They were greatly distressed that a man had come seeking the prosperity of the children of Israel.
Nehemiah 2:11 And I came to Jerusalem, and I was there for three days.
Nehemiah 2:12 Then I arose in the night, I and a few men with me, and I did not tell anyone what my God had put into my heart to do for Jerusalem. There was no animal with me, except for the animal on which I was riding.
Nehemiah 2:13 And I went out by night through the Valley Gate, and proceeded towards the Dragon's Spring, and to the Dung Gate. As I went, I carefully inspected the broken-down walls of Jerusalem and its gates that had been consumed by fire.
Nehemiah 2:14 Then I passed on to the Fountain Gate and to the King's Pool. But there was no place for the animal on which I was riding to pass through, because of the debris.
Nehemiah 2:15 So I went up by the torrent in the night, and again inspected the wall. After completing my survey, I returned and came back to the Valley Gate.
Nehemiah 2:16 And the officials of the city did not know where I had gone or what I was doing, because up to that time I had not yet told the Jews, or the priests, or the nobles, or the officials, or the rest of those who were to do the work, of my intentions.
Nehemiah 2:17 Then I said to them, 'You see the deep affliction in which we are, because Jerusalem lies desolate and its gates are burned with fire. Come, let us rebuild the walls of Jerusalem, so that we may no longer be an object of shame and reproach.'
Nehemiah 2:18 And I recounted to them how the hand—the favor—of my God had been good upon me, and also the words of the king which he had spoken to me. And they said, 'Let us arise and build!' And their hands were strengthened for the good work.
Nehemiah 2:19 But when Sanaballat the Horonite, and Tobias the Ammonite official, and Gosem the Arab heard of it, they ridiculed us and despised us, and they said, 'What is this thing that you are doing? Are you intending to rebel against the king?'
Nehemiah 2:20 And I answered them, saying, 'The God of the universe Himself will help us, and we, His servants, will build. But as for you, you have no portion, nor right, nor memorial in Jerusalem.'
Nehemiah 2:1 It happened in the month of Nisan, the first month of the Jewish calendar, in the twentieth year of the reign of King Artaxerxes. The wine was before the king, and it was my duty to take the wine and give it to him. I was not normally sad or downcast in his presence.
Nehemiah 2:2 And the king said to me, 'Why is your face so sad, seeing that I do not see you to be physically ill? This can only be a deep sadness in your heart.' And I was greatly afraid.
Nehemiah 2:3 Then I said to the king, 'May the king live forever! How could my face not be sad, given that the city—the place where my ancestors are buried—lies in ruins, and its gates have been consumed by fire?'
Nehemiah 2:4 Then the king said to me (with the queen sitting beside him), 'What is it you are requesting, then, with such a look on your face?' At that very moment, I prayed silently to the God of Heaven.
Nehemiah 2:5 And I said to the king, 'If it pleases the king, and if your servant has found favor in your sight, I request that you send me to Judea, to the city where my ancestors are buried—Jerusalem—so that I may rebuild it.'
Nehemiah 2:6 Then the king said to me (with the queen still sitting beside him), 'How long will your journey take, and when will you return?' The king was pleased with my request, and he sent me. I specified a time for my return to him.
Nehemiah 2:7 And I also said to the king, 'If it pleases the king, please provide me with letters of passage addressed to the governors of the province Beyond the River—the region west of the Euphrates—so that they will allow me to travel through their territories until I reach Judea.'
Nehemiah 2:8 And also a letter addressed to Asaph, the keeper of the king's forest, instructing him to provide me with timber. This wood will be used to construct the gates for the fortress connected to the Temple, for the city walls, and for the house where I will reside. The king granted all my requests, for the good hand of my God was upon me and guided him.
Nehemiah 2:9 So I traveled to the governors of the province Beyond the River and presented them with the king's letters. The king had also provided me with an escort of army officers and cavalrymen.
Nehemiah 2:10 When Sanballat the Horonite and Tobiah the Ammonite official heard about my arrival, they were deeply displeased and greatly troubled, because a man had come to seek the welfare and prosperity of the children of Israel.
Nehemiah 2:11 Finally, I arrived in Jerusalem, and I remained there for three days.
Nehemiah 2:12 Then, during the night, I arose with only a few men accompanying me. I had not told anyone what God had inspired me to do for Jerusalem. There was no pack animal with us, only the animal I myself was riding.
Nehemiah 2:13 I went out through the Valley Gate at night, proceeding towards the Dragon's Well and then to the Dung Gate. As I went, I carefully inspected the walls of Jerusalem, observing how they lay in ruins, and how its gates had been completely destroyed by fire.
Nehemiah 2:14 From there, I went on to the Fountain Gate and the King's Pool. But at that point, there was so much rubble and damage that there was no room for the animal I was riding to pass through.
Nehemiah 2:15 So I continued my inspection by ascending the valley at night, carefully examining the wall. Afterward, I returned by way of the Valley Gate.
Nehemiah 2:16 The local officials, however, did not know where I had gone or what I was doing. Indeed, I had not yet revealed anything to the Jewish people, the priests, the nobles, the other officials, or anyone else who would be involved in the work, keeping my plans secret until the proper time.
Nehemiah 2:17 Then I said to them, 'You yourselves see the terrible condition we are in: Jerusalem lies in ruins, and its gates have been completely burned down by fire. Come, let us rebuild the walls of Jerusalem, so that we may no longer suffer this shame and disgrace.'
Nehemiah 2:18 I also told them about the gracious hand of my God that had been upon me, and repeated the words the king had spoken to me. Immediately, they responded, 'Let us rise up and build!' And their resolve was greatly strengthened for this good work.
Nehemiah 2:19 But when Sanballat the Horonite, Tobiah the Ammonite official, and Geshem the Arab heard of our plans, they mocked us and scorned us. They said, 'What is this thing you are doing? Are you actually rebelling against the king?'
Nehemiah 2:20 I answered them directly and said, 'The God of Heaven Himself will give us success! We, His servants, will rise up and build. But as for you, you have no share, no right, and no historical claim in Jerusalem.'
Nehemiah 3:1 And Eliashib, the high priest, along with his priestly brethren, began building the Sheep Gate. They consecrated this section of the wall and installed its doors, continuing to consecrate the wall as far as the Tower of the Hundred, and then all the way to the Tower of Hananeel.
Nehemiah 3:2 Next to them, the men of Jericho built their section of the wall. And after them, Zachur, the son of Amri, built his portion.
Nehemiah 3:3 The Sons of Senaa were responsible for building the Fish Gate. They covered and reinforced it, then installed its doors, along with its locks and sturdy bars.
Nehemiah 3:4 Next to them, Marimoth, the son of Uria, son of Accus, built his section. And next to him, Mosollam, the son of Barachia, son of Mazabel, built his part. And next to him, Sadoc, the son of Baana, also built.
Nehemiah 3:5 And next to these, the Thecoites built their portion of the wall. However, their nobles did not apply themselves to the work of their Lord, refusing to do their part.
Nehemiah 3:6 Jojada, the son of Phasea, and Mosollam, the son of Besodia, built the Old Gate. They covered and strengthened it, then installed its doors, its locks, and its bars.
Nehemiah 3:7 Next to them, Melatias the Gabaonite and Jadon the Meronathite, men from Gabaon and Maspha, built their section. This was by the tribunal of the governor who oversaw the region beyond the river Euphrates.
Nehemiah 3:8 And next to him, Eziel, son of the Goldsmiths, built his part. And next to him, Hananias, son of the Perfume-makers, also built. They continued the rebuilding in Jerusalem all the way to the Broad Wall.
Nehemiah 3:9 Next to him, Raphaia, the son of Hur, a leader of a district, built his section.
Nehemiah 3:10 Next to him, Idaias, the son of Haromaph, built a section directly opposite his own house. And next to him, Hattus, the son of Hasebonia, built his part.
Nehemiah 3:11 Melchias, the son of Haram, son of Phaath Moab, built the next section, which included the Tower of the Furnaces.
Nehemiah 3:12 Next to him, Sellum, the son of Alohes, a leader of half of the district of Jerusalem, built his section, along with his daughters, who also participated in the work.
Nehemiah 3:13 Hanun and the inhabitants of Zanoë built the Valley Gate. They built it and installed its doors, its locks, and its bars. They then continued building the wall for a thousand cubits, reaching all the way to the Dung Gate.
Nehemiah 3:14 Melchias, the son of Rechab, a leader of the district of Bethacarem, built the Dung Gate. He built it and installed its doors, its locks, and its bars.
Nehemiah 3:15 Sellum, the son of Colhoza, a leader of the district of Maspha, built the Fountain Gate. He built it, covered and strengthened it, then installed its doors, its locks, and its bars. He also built the wall of the pool of Siloë by the king’s garden, extending as far as the steps that lead down from the city of David.
Nehemiah 3:16 After him, Nehemias, the son of Azboc, a leader of half the district of Bethsur, built his section. This extended opposite the tomb of David, as far as the pool that had been constructed, and then to the House of the Mighty.
Nehemiah 3:17 After him, the Levites built, specifically Rehum, the son of Bani. Next to him, Hasebias, a leader of half the district of Ceila, built his section in his own district.
Nehemiah 3:18 After him, their brethren built, specifically Bavai, the son of Enadad, a leader of half the district of Ceila.
Nehemiah 3:19 And next to him, Aser, the son of Josua, a leader of Maspha, built a second section, directly opposite the strong ascent at the corner of the wall.
Nehemiah 3:20 After him, Baruch, the son of Zachai, zealously built a second, full section. This stretched from the corner all the way to the entrance of the house of Eliashib, the high priest.
Nehemiah 3:21 After him, Marimoth, the son of Uria, son of Accus, built a second section. This extended from the entrance of Eliashib’s house all the way to the end of Eliashib’s house.
Nehemiah 3:22 And after him, the priests, men from the surrounding plains, also built their section.
Nehemiah 3:23 After this, Benjamin and Hassub built directly opposite their own houses. And after them, Azarias, the son of Maasæ, son of Ananias, built his section opposite his own house.
Nehemiah 3:24 After this, Banna, the son of Henadad, built a second section. This extended from Azarias’ house all the way to the bend in the wall, and then to the corner.
Nehemiah 3:25 Phalel, the son of Ozi, built opposite the bend in the wall, and by the tower that projects from the royal palace, specifically from the court of the prison. Next to him, Pedeia, the son of Pharos, built.
Nehemiah 3:26 (The Nethinim, the temple servants, lived in Ophel.) They also built the section opposite the Water Gate to the east, and the tower that projects out.
Nehemiah 3:27 After them, the Thecoites built a second section, from the great projecting tower all the way to the wall of Ophel.
Nehemiah 3:28 Above the Horse Gate, the priests built, each one directly opposite his own house.
Nehemiah 3:29 After them, Sadoc, the son of Emmer, built opposite his own house. And after him, Semeia, the son of Sechenia, the keeper of the East Gate, built his section.
Nehemiah 3:30 After him, Hananias, the son of Selemia, and Hanun, the sixth son of Seliph, built a second section. After this, Mosollam, the son of Barachia, built opposite his own treasury.
Nehemiah 3:31 After him, Melchias, the son of the Goldsmith, built all the way to the house of the Nethinim, and the merchants, opposite the Judgment Gate, and then to the upper chamber at the corner.
Nehemiah 3:32 And between the upper chamber at the corner and the Sheep Gate, the goldsmiths and merchants completed their work.
Nehemiah 3:1 Then Eliashib, the high priest, along with his fellow priests, rose up and began the work. They rebuilt the Sheep Gate and consecrated it, setting its doors in place. They continued rebuilding the wall from there, reaching as far as the Tower of the Hundred, and then further, up to the Tower of Hananel.
Nehemiah 3:2 Next to them, the men from Jericho carried out their part of the rebuilding. And beside them, Zaccur, the son of Imri, rebuilt his section.
Nehemiah 3:3 The sons of Hassenaah rebuilt the Fish Gate. They laid its beams, set its doors, and installed its bolts and bars.
Nehemiah 3:4 Next to them, Meremoth, the son of Uriah, the son of Hakkoz, worked. Beside him, Meshullam, the son of Berechiah, the son of Meshezabel, rebuilt his section. And next to him, Zadok, the son of Baana, also repaired a section.
Nehemiah 3:5 Beside him, the Tekoites repaired their part of the wall. However, their nobles did not put their shoulders to the work of their Lord, refusing to participate in God’s divinely appointed task.
Nehemiah 3:6 Joiada, the son of Paseah, and Meshullam, the son of Besodeiah, rebuilt the Old Gate. They laid its beams, set its doors, and installed its bolts and bars.
Nehemiah 3:7 Next to them, Melatiah the Gibeonite and Jadon the Meronothite rebuilt their section. These were men from Gibeon and Mizpah, working on the wall up to the seat of the governor of the region beyond the River Jordan.
Nehemiah 3:8 Next to him, Uzziel, the son of Harhaiah, one of the goldsmiths, worked. And next to him, Hananiah, one of the perfumers, repaired his section. They rebuilt Jerusalem's wall all the way to the Broad Wall.
Nehemiah 3:9 Beside him, Rephaiah, the son of Hur, the ruler of half of the district of Jerusalem, rebuilt his section.
Nehemiah 3:10 Next to him, Jedaiah, the son of Harumaph, rebuilt the wall opposite his own house. And next to him, Hattush, the son of Hashabneiah, also worked.
Nehemiah 3:11 Malchijah, the son of Harim, and Hasshub, the son of Pahath-Moab, rebuilt another section, which included the Tower of the Ovens.
Nehemiah 3:12 Next to him, Shallum, the son of Hallohesh, the ruler of half of the district of Jerusalem, rebuilt his section, along with his daughters, who also participated in the work.
Nehemiah 3:13 Hanun and the inhabitants of Zanoah rebuilt the Valley Gate. They built it, set its doors in place, and installed its bolts and bars. They then continued for a thousand cubits—about 1,500 feet—along the wall, all the way to the Dung Gate.
Nehemiah 3:14 Malchijah, the son of Rechab, the ruler of the district of Beth Haccherem, rebuilt the Dung Gate. He built it and set its doors, bolts, and bars in place.
Nehemiah 3:15 Shallun, the son of Col-Hozeh, the ruler of the district of Mizpah, rebuilt the Fountain Gate. He rebuilt it, laid its beams, and set its doors, bolts, and bars in place. He also rebuilt the wall of the Pool of Siloam near the king's garden, and continued all the way to the steps that lead down from the City of David.
Nehemiah 3:16 After him, Nehemiah, the son of Azbuk, the ruler of half of the district of Beth-Zur, rebuilt his section. This ran opposite the tombs of David, as far as the artificial pool, and then further, to the House of the Mighty Men.
Nehemiah 3:17 After him, the Levites repaired their sections. Rehum, the son of Bani, worked there. Next to him, Hashabiah, the ruler of half of the district of Keilah, rebuilt his section within his own district.
Nehemiah 3:18 After him, their brethren rebuilt their sections: Bavvai, the son of Henadad, the ruler of half of the district of Keilah.
Nehemiah 3:19 Next to him, Ezer, the son of Jeshua, the ruler of Mizpah, rebuilt another section opposite the ascent to the Armory, a very strong point on the wall.
Nehemiah 3:20 After him, Baruch, the son of Zabbai, rebuilt another section of the wall, located on the hill, extending from the area opposite the house of Eliashib, the high priest.
Nehemiah 3:21 After him, Meremoth, the son of Uriah, the son of Hakkoz, rebuilt another section, extending from the entrance of Eliashib's house to the far side of Eliashib's house.
Nehemiah 3:22 And after him, the priests, men from the plains of the Jordan, also rebuilt their sections.
Nehemiah 3:23 After him, Benjamin and Hasshub rebuilt their sections opposite their own houses. And after them, Azariah, the son of Maaseiah, the son of Ananiah, rebuilt the wall next to his own house.
Nehemiah 3:24 After him, Binnui, the son of Henadad, rebuilt another section, from Azariah's house up to the buttress and the corner.
Nehemiah 3:25 Palal, the son of Uzai, rebuilt the wall opposite the buttress and the tower that projects from the upper house of the king, which is by the court of the guard. After him, Pedaiah, the son of Parosh, rebuilt his section.
Nehemiah 3:26 The temple servants (Nethinim) who lived in Ophel repaired their sections, working opposite the Water Gate toward the east and the projecting tower.
Nehemiah 3:27 After him, the Tekoites repaired another section, from the great projecting tower all the way to the wall of the Temple.
Nehemiah 3:28 Above the Horse Gate, the priests rebuilt their sections, each working opposite his own house.
Nehemiah 3:29 After them, Zadok, the son of Immer, rebuilt his section opposite his own house. And after him, Shemaiah, the son of Shecaniah, the keeper of the East Gate, rebuilt his section.
Nehemiah 3:30 After him, Hananiah, the son of Shelemiah, and Hanun, the sixth son of Zalaph, rebuilt another section. After him, Meshullam, the son of Berechiah, rebuilt his section opposite his own chamber (or treasury).
Nehemiah 3:31 After him, Malchijah, one of the goldsmiths, rebuilt his section as far as the house of the Nethinim (temple servants) and the merchants, working opposite the Muster Gate (or Inspection Gate), and all the way to the upper room at the corner.
Nehemiah 3:32 Between the upper room at the corner and the Sheep Gate, the goldsmiths and the merchants rebuilt their sections.
Nehemiah 3:33 Now it came to pass that when Sanballat heard that we were rebuilding the wall, he became very angry and greatly disturbed. He then began to mock the Jews.
Nehemiah 3:34 He then spoke before his brethren and the leading men of Samaria, saying: 'What are these feeble Jews doing? Will their leaders permit them to continue? Will they offer sacrifices? Will they finish the work in a single day? Will they revive the stones from these heaps of burnt rubbish?'
Nehemiah 3:35 Tobiah the Ammonite, who was standing beside him, also spoke, saying: 'Even if they build, if a fox goes up on their wall, it will break down their stone wall!'
Nehemiah 3:36 Hear us, O our God, because we have become an object of contempt! Turn their scorn back upon their own heads, and deliver them into disgrace in the land of their captivity.
Nehemiah 3:37 Do not cover their iniquity, and let their sin not be blotted out from before Your sight, because they have provoked You in the presence of those who are rebuilding.
Nehemiah 3:38 So we rebuilt the wall, and the entire wall was joined together up to half of its intended height. For the people had a mind to work, and their hearts were fully committed to the task.
Nehemiah 3:39 Now it came to pass that when Sanballat, Tobiah, the Arabs, the Ammonites, and the Ashdodites heard that the damage to the walls of Jerusalem was being closed up, and that the breaches had begun to be repaired, they became exceedingly angry.
Nehemiah 3:40 And they all conspired together to come and fight against Jerusalem, intending to cause confusion and disrupt the work.
Nehemiah 4:1 It happened that when Sanballat heard we were rebuilding the wall, he became extremely angry. He was deeply provoked and mocked the Jewish people.
Nehemiah 4:2 He then spoke before his brothers and the leaders of the Samaritans, saying: "What are these weak Jews doing? Will the nations leave them alone? Will they offer sacrifices? Will they finish the work in a single day? Will they build from the dusty stones that have been burned?"
Nehemiah 4:3 Now Tobiah the Ammonite was standing next to him, and he added: "Let them build! If even a fox goes up, it will jump over their stone wall."
Nehemiah 4:4 Nehemiah prayed: "Hear us, O our God, because we have become despised. Turn their scorn back onto their own heads, and hand them over as plunder in a land of captivity—a land where they themselves are enslaved."
Nehemiah 4:5 "Do not cover their iniquity, and let their sin not be erased from Your sight, because they have deeply disturbed those who are building."
Nehemiah 4:6 So we rebuilt the wall, and the entire wall was joined up to half its original height. The people had returned their hearts and minds fully to the work.
Nehemiah 4:7 Now it came to pass that when Sanballat, Tobiah, the Arabs, the Ammonites, and the Ashdodites heard that the extensive damage to the wall of Jerusalem was being repaired and that the broken places had begun to be closed up, they became exceedingly angry.
Nehemiah 4:8 They all gathered together with a common purpose: to come and fight against Jerusalem, intending to spread malicious rumors and cause great trouble.
Nehemiah 4:9 But we prayed to our God, and we also set up guards on the wall, day and night, against these enemies.
Nehemiah 4:10 Meanwhile, the people of Judah said among themselves: "The strength of those carrying loads is diminished. There is too much rubble, and we will not be able to finish building the wall."
Nehemiah 4:11 And our enemies said: "They will not know or understand our plan until we come right into their midst, kill them, and make the work stop completely."
Nehemiah 4:12 It also happened that the Jews who lived near them came and told us ten times, from all the places where they lived, warnings that the enemies were coming to attack us.
Nehemiah 4:13 Therefore, I stationed people in the lowest parts of the area, behind the wall, at strategic intervals around it. I placed the people there with their swords, spears, and bows.
Nehemiah 4:14 And I saw their fear, so I stood up and spoke to the nobles, the officials, and the rest of the people: "Do not be afraid of them. Remember the Lord, Who is great and awesome, and fight for your brothers, your sons and your daughters, your wives, and your homes."
Nehemiah 4:15 So it happened that when our enemies heard it had been reported to us, and that God had thwarted their evil plan, we all returned to the wall, each man to his own work.
Nehemiah 4:16 From that day onward, half of the young men among our people were doing the construction work, and the other half held spears, shields, bows, and armor. The leaders were stationed behind all the house of Judah to supervise.
Nehemiah 4:17 Those who were building the wall, and those who were carrying burdens and loading them onto the wall, worked with one hand and held a sword in the other.
Nehemiah 4:18 And each of the builders wore his sword strapped to his side as he built. The trumpeter stood next to me, ready to sound the alarm.
Nehemiah 4:19 Then I said to the nobles, the officials, and the rest of the people: "The work is extensive and spread out, and we are separated on the wall, far from one another."
Nehemiah 4:20 "Wherever you hear the sound of the trumpet, rush to us there. Our God will fight for us."
Nehemiah 4:21 So they continued the work, and half of them held spears from the first appearance of dawn until the stars came out in the evening.
Nehemiah 4:22 At that same time, I also said to the people: "Let each man and his servant remain within Jerusalem, so that they can be our guards both day and night."
Nehemiah 4:23 As for me, my brothers, my personal servants, and the guards who were with me, we did not take off our clothes—each man only removed them for washing.
Nehemiah 5:1 Then a great outcry began among the people, and their wives joined them in raising their voices against their fellow Jewish brothers.
Nehemiah 5:2 Some of the people began to say: 'We have so many sons and daughters, and we need grain for them to eat and for us all to survive.'
Nehemiah 5:3 Other people said: 'We are being forced to pledge our fields, our vineyards, and our houses as collateral to get grain because of this severe hunger.'
Nehemiah 5:4 And yet other people were saying: 'We had to borrow money using our fields and vineyards as collateral just to pay the king's taxes.'
Nehemiah 5:5 And now, though we are of the same flesh as our brothers, and our children are just like their children, we are forced to subjugate our own sons and daughters into slavery. Some of our daughters are already serving as female slaves, and we have no way to buy them back, because other people have taken possession of our fields and our vineyards.
Nehemiah 5:6 And I became extremely angry when I heard their desperate outcry and these specific grievances.
Nehemiah 5:7 I considered the situation carefully within my own heart, and then I publicly rebuked the nobles and the officials. I asked them: 'Are each of you truly demanding excessive interest from your own brothers?' Afterwards, I called a large public assembly to confront them.
Nehemiah 5:8 I also spoke to them, saying: 'You all know that we have made every effort to buy back our Jewish brothers who were sold into slavery to foreign nations. And now, you yourselves are selling your own brothers, forcing us to buy them back again into our own community?' They remained completely silent, unable to find any words to justify themselves.
Nehemiah 5:9 Then I continued, saying: 'What you are doing is absolutely not right! Why are you not living your lives in the reverent fear of our God, so that our enemy nations do not have reason to mock and condemn us?'
Nehemiah 5:10 Even I, my brothers, and my servants have generously lent both money and much grain to these very people. Therefore, let us now all agree to stop demanding this excessive interest from them.
Nehemiah 5:11 Today, you must return to them their fields, their vineyards, their olive groves, and their houses. Furthermore, you must also give back to them the one-hundredth part of the money, grain, wine, and oil—which represents the excessive interest you have been accustomed to demanding from them.
Nehemiah 5:12 And the nobles replied: 'We will restore everything, and we will demand nothing further from them; we will indeed do exactly as you have spoken.' So, I called for the priests and had them administer an oath, ensuring that the nobles would do precisely what I had instructed.
Nehemiah 5:13 Then, as an additional warning, I shook out the fold of my garment, and I declared: 'May God likewise shake out every man who fails to fulfill this solemn promise, stripping him of his house and all his possessions derived from his labor! May he be completely emptied and left with nothing!' The entire assembly responded with 'Amen!' and then they praised God. So, the people who had made the promise carried out what had been spoken.
Nehemiah 5:14 Now, from the very day that the king appointed me to serve as governor over the land of Judah—which spanned from the twentieth year to the thirty-second year of King Artaxerxes, a full twelve years—neither I nor my brothers ever took the food allowance or salary that was due to governors.
Nehemiah 5:15 However, the governors who were before me had been a severe burden to the people. They continually took from them forty shekels of silver daily, along with generous provisions of bread, wine, and money. Even their own servants were allowed to domineer over the people. But I, for my part, did not act in this way, because of my reverent fear of God.
Nehemiah 5:16 Instead, I threw myself into the work of rebuilding this wall. I did not purchase any land for myself, and all my servants were likewise engaged in the work alongside everyone else.
Nehemiah 5:17 Moreover, a hundred and fifty Jewish people and officials regularly ate at my table, in addition to those who came to us from the Gentile nations residing around our borders.
Nehemiah 5:18 Even though my daily provision included one ox, six choice sheep, and various birds were also supplied to me, along with a wide selection of wine served once each day—despite all this abundance, I did not demand the official robes or lavish clothing due to governors. This was because the burden of servitude resting upon these people was already exceedingly heavy.
Nehemiah 5:19 Remember me, O my God, for good, in consideration of all the benevolent actions I have carried out for this people.
Nehemiah 5:1 A great cry arose from the people, and even from their wives, against their own Jewish brothers.
Nehemiah 5:2 And there were some who said: "We have many sons and daughters, and we must buy wheat so that we can eat and live."
Nehemiah 5:3 And others said: "We must mortgage our fields, our vineyards, and our houses to get money, so we can buy wheat because of the famine."
Nehemiah 5:4 And still others said: "We had to borrow money to pay the king's taxes, and we had to pledge our fields and our vineyards as collateral."
Nehemiah 5:5 "And now, our flesh is like the flesh of our brothers—we are all human beings, yet our children are no different from theirs. Look, we are forced to sell our sons and daughters into slavery to pay our debts. Some of our daughters are already enslaved as servants. We have nothing left, because our fields and vineyards are already taken by others to whom we owe money."
Nehemiah 5:6 I, Nehemiah, became exceedingly angry when I heard their outcry and these words.
Nehemiah 5:7 I thought about it carefully, and then I rebuked the nobles and the officials, saying to them: "You are each demanding usury—excessive interest—from your own brothers!" Then I gathered a large assembly against them, and I spoke to them further:
Nehemiah 5:8 "We, as you know, have redeemed our Jewish brothers who had been sold to the Gentiles, doing so according to our ability to pay. And now you yourselves are selling your own brothers, so that we have to buy them back again?" They were silent, having no answer to give.
Nehemiah 5:9 And I said to them: "What you are doing is not good. Why do you not walk in the fear of our God, so that you do not bring reproach upon us from our Gentile enemies?"
Nehemiah 5:10 "I myself, along with my brothers and my servants, have also lent them money and grain. Let us now release them from these debts of usury."
Nehemiah 5:11 "Return to them this very day their fields, their vineyards, their olive groves, and their houses. And also release them from the hundredth part of the money, grain, wine, and oil that you customarily demand from them as interest."
Nehemiah 5:12 And they said: "We will restore everything, and we will demand nothing from them. We will do exactly as you say." Then I called the priests and made them swear an oath that they would act according to this promise.
Nehemiah 5:13 Furthermore, I shook out the fold of my garment and said: "Thus may God shake out from his house and from his possessions every man who does not keep this promise. May he be shaken out and emptied!" And the entire assembly said: "Amen!" And they praised God. So the people did as they had promised.
Nehemiah 5:14 Now, from the day that the king commanded me to be their governor in the land of Judah, from the twentieth year until the thirty-second year of King Artaxerxes—a total of twelve years—neither I nor my brothers ate the food rations that were due to me as governor.
Nehemiah 5:15 In contrast, the former governors who were before me had burdened the people severely. They had taken from them bread and wine, in addition to forty shekels of silver. Moreover, even their servants lorded it over the people. But I did not do so, because I acted out of reverence for God.
Nehemiah 5:16 Instead, I dedicated myself to the work on this wall, building it with my own hands, and I did not purchase any land for myself. All my servants also worked alongside everyone else on the wall.
Nehemiah 5:17 Furthermore, one hundred and fifty men, comprising Jews and officials, along with those who came to us from the surrounding Gentile nations, regularly ate at my table.
Nehemiah 5:18 And for me, each day, one ox was prepared, along with six chosen sheep, not counting the poultry. And every ten days, wine of all kinds, and many other provisions, were supplied. Yet, despite all this, I never demanded the governor's allowance that was due to me, because the famine was pressing heavily upon the people.
Nehemiah 5:19 Remember me, my God, for good, because of all that I have done for this people.
Nehemiah 6:1 It happened that Sanballat, Tobiah, Geshem the Arab, and our other enemies heard that I had completed rebuilding the city wall, and that there were no gaps left in it for a gate. So, Sanballat and Geshem sent a message to me, saying: 'Come, let us meet together in the villages on the plain of Ono.'
Nehemiah 6:2 They were plotting to harm me.
Nehemiah 6:3 I sent messengers back to them, saying: 'I am doing a great work, and I cannot come down. If I leave this work to meet you, it will be interrupted.'
Nehemiah 6:4 So they sent the same message to me four times, and each time I responded to them with the same answer.
Nehemiah 6:5 Then, on the fifth time, Sanballat sent his servant to me with an open letter in his hand.
Nehemiah 6:6 It was written in the letter: 'It has been reported among the nations, and Geshem confirms it, that you and the Judeans are plotting to rebel. That is why you are rebuilding the wall, and you intend to make yourself king, according to these rumors.'
Nehemiah 6:7 'Furthermore, you have appointed prophets to proclaim concerning you in Jerusalem, saying: “There is a king in Judea!” Now, therefore, I am reporting these matters to the king. So come now, let us meet and discuss this together.'
Nehemiah 6:8 But I sent word back to him, saying: 'None of these things you are talking about are actually happening; you are simply inventing these things from your own mind.'
Nehemiah 6:9 For all of them wanted to frighten us, thinking that our hands would become weak from the work, and that we would cease our labor. Because of this, I strengthened my resolve even more.
Nehemiah 6:10 Then I went into the house of Shemaiah, son of Delaiah, son of Mehetabel, who was confined at home. He said: 'Let us go and shut ourselves inside the temple of God, and close the temple doors; for they are coming to kill you, and they will surely come at night to murder you.'
Nehemiah 6:11 But I said: 'Should a man like me flee? And who is there, a man like me, who would enter the temple to save his life? I will not go in.'
Nehemiah 6:12 Then I understood that God had not sent him, but that he had spoken this 'prophecy' to me because Tobiah and Sanballat had hired him.
Nehemiah 6:13 They had hired him to intimidate me, to make me sin by seeking refuge in the temple, and then they would have a scandal to publicly accuse me with.
Nehemiah 6:14 Remember them, O my God, for these actions of Tobiah and Sanballat. Also remember the prophetess Noadiah and the other prophets who kept trying to frighten me.
Nehemiah 6:15 So the entire wall was completed on the twenty-fifth day of the month Elul, which was within fifty-two days of starting the work.
Nehemiah 6:16 When all our enemies heard about it, and all the nations around us saw it, they were humbled and realized that this work had been accomplished by God Himself.
Nehemiah 6:17 Moreover, in those days, many letters from the nobles of Judah were being sent to Tobiah, and letters from Tobiah were coming to them in return.
Nehemiah 6:18 For many in Judah were bound to him by oath, because he was the son-in-law of Shecaniah, son of Arah. And his son Jehohanan had married the daughter of Meshullam, son of Berechiah, so they were connected by family alliances.
Nehemiah 6:19 They even spoke of Tobiah's good deeds to me, and they reported my words back to him. Meanwhile, Tobiah kept sending letters to try and frighten me.
Nehemiah 7:1 After the city wall was rebuilt, I set up the doors in the gates. I then organized and registered the gatekeepers, the singers, and the Levites.
Nehemiah 7:2 I put my brother Hanani, along with Hananiah, the commander of the Jerusalem fortress, in charge of the city. Hananiah was a man of great integrity, who feared God more than most people.
Nehemiah 7:3 I told them: 'Do not open the gates of Jerusalem until the sun is high in the sky. And while the guards are still on duty, they are to close and bar the gates.' I also appointed guards from among the residents of Jerusalem, with each one serving in his turn and standing watch over the area directly in front of his own house.
Nehemiah 7:4 The city itself was very large and spacious, but there were few people living in it, and many houses still had not been rebuilt.
Nehemiah 7:5 Then God put it into my heart to gather the nobles, the officials, and the common people so I could register them by their family lines. I found the record of the family lines of those who had returned first from exile, and this is what was written in it:
Nehemiah 7:6 These are the people of the province who came up from the captivity of the exile, whom Nebuchadnezzar, the king of Babylon, had taken away. They returned to Jerusalem and to Judah, each to his own town.
Nehemiah 7:7 Those who came with Zerubbabel were Jeshua, Nehemiah, Azariah, Raamiah, Nahamani, Mordecai, Bilshan, Mispereth, Bigvai, Nahum, and Baanah. The number of the men of the people of Israel was as follows:
Nehemiah 7:8 The descendants of Parosh: two thousand one hundred seventy-two.
Nehemiah 7:9 The descendants of Shephatiah: three hundred seventy-two.
Nehemiah 7:10 The descendants of Arah: six hundred fifty-two.
Nehemiah 7:11 The descendants of Pahath-Moab, through the line of Jeshua and Joab: two thousand eight hundred eighteen.
Nehemiah 7:12 The descendants of Elam: one thousand two hundred fifty-four.
Nehemiah 7:13 The descendants of Zattu: eight hundred forty-five.
Nehemiah 7:14 The descendants of Zaccai: seven hundred sixty.
Nehemiah 7:15 The descendants of Binnui: six hundred forty-eight.
Nehemiah 7:16 The descendants of Bebai: six hundred twenty-eight.
Nehemiah 7:17 The descendants of Azgad: two thousand three hundred twenty-two.
Nehemiah 7:18 The descendants of Adonikam: six hundred sixty-seven.
Nehemiah 7:19 The descendants of Bigvai: two thousand sixty-seven.
Nehemiah 7:20 The descendants of Adin: six hundred fifty-five.
Nehemiah 7:21 The descendants of Ater, through Hezekiah: ninety-eight.
Nehemiah 7:22 The descendants of Hashum: three hundred twenty-eight.
Nehemiah 7:23 The descendants of Bezai: three hundred twenty-four.
Nehemiah 7:24 The descendants of Hariph: one hundred twelve.
Nehemiah 7:25 The descendants of Gibeon: ninety-five.
Nehemiah 7:26 The men of Bethlehem and Netophah: one hundred eighty-eight.
Nehemiah 7:27 The men of Anathoth: one hundred twenty-eight.
Nehemiah 7:28 The men of Beth-Azmaveth: forty-two.
Nehemiah 7:29 The men of Kiriath-Jearim, Chephirah, and Beeroth: seven hundred forty-three.
Nehemiah 7:30 The men of Ramah and Geba: six hundred twenty-one.
Nehemiah 7:31 The men of Michmash: one hundred twenty-two.
Nehemiah 7:32 The men of Bethel and Ai: one hundred twenty-three.
Nehemiah 7:33 The men of the other Nebo: fifty-two.
Nehemiah 7:34 The descendants of the other Elam: one thousand two hundred fifty-four.
Nehemiah 7:35 The descendants of Harim: three hundred twenty.
Nehemiah 7:36 The descendants of Jericho: three hundred forty-five.
Nehemiah 7:37 The descendants of Lod, Hadid, and Ono: seven hundred twenty-one.
Nehemiah 7:38 The descendants of Senaah: three thousand nine hundred thirty.
Nehemiah 7:39 The priests: The descendants of Jedaiah, from the house of Jeshua: nine hundred seventy-three.
Nehemiah 7:40 The descendants of Immer: one thousand fifty-two.
Nehemiah 7:1 After the wall was finished, and I had set up the city gates, I then appointed the gatekeepers, the singers, and the Levites for their duties.
Nehemiah 7:2 I gave orders to my brother Hanani, and to Hananiah, the commander of the fortress of Jerusalem—because he was a trustworthy man, and feared God more than anyone else there.
Nehemiah 7:3 And I told them: 'Do not open the gates of Jerusalem until the sun's full heat has arrived. While the guards are still on duty, they are to close and bar the gates tightly. Also, appoint guards from the citizens of Jerusalem, each for his own shift, and each one standing guard opposite his own house.'
Nehemiah 7:4 Now the city itself was very large and expansive, but there were few people living within it, and many houses had not yet been rebuilt. God put it into my heart to gather the nobles, the officials, and the common people so I could register them. I found the register of those who had first returned from exile, and in it was written:
Nehemiah 7:5 'These are the descendants of the province who came up from the captivity, from the exile, whom Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, had carried away. They returned to Jerusalem and to Judea, each to his own city.'
Nehemiah 7:6 Those who came with Zerubbabel, Jeshua, Nehemiah, Azariah, Raamiah, Nahamani, Mordecai, Bilshan, Mispereth, Bigvai, Nahum, Baanah. The number of the men of the people of Israel:
Nehemiah 7:7 The descendants of Parosh, 2,172.

Nehemiah 8:1 So all the people gathered as one, assembling in the public square that stood before the Water Gate. They asked Ezra the scribe to bring out the Book of the Law of Moses, which the Lord had commanded to Israel, for them to hear.
Nehemiah 8:2 So Ezra the priest brought the Book of the Law before the assembly, including men, women, and all the children old enough to understand. He did this on the first day of the seventh month—the beginning of the civil year.
Nehemiah 8:3 And Ezra read from the book aloud and clearly in the public square, before the Water Gate, from early morning until midday. He read in the presence of the men, women, and those children who were able to understand. The entire assembly listened with focused attention to the Book of the Law.
Nehemiah 8:4 Ezra the scribe stood on a wooden platform that had been built for the purpose of speaking to the assembly. Standing beside him on his right were Mattathiah, Shema, Anaiah, Uriah, Hilkiah, and Maaseiah. On his left stood Pedaiah, Mishael, Malchijah, Hashum, Hashbaddana, Zechariah, and Meshullam.
Nehemiah 8:5 Ezra then opened the Book of the Law in the sight of all the people, for he was standing on the platform above everyone. As soon as he opened it, all the people rose to their feet in reverence.
Nehemiah 8:6 Ezra blessed the Lord, the great God of all. And all the people responded, 'Amen, Amen,' raising their hands in agreement and praise. Then, bowing their heads, they prostrated themselves with their faces to the ground and adored the Lord.
Nehemiah 8:7 Then the Levites—Joshua, Bani, Sherebiah, Jamin, Akkub, Shabbethai, Hodiah, Maaseiah, Kelita, Azariah, Jozabad, Hanan, and Pelaiah—ensured silence among the people so they could hear the Law. And all the people remained standing attentively.
Nehemiah 8:8 They read from the Book of the Law of God, clearly explaining its meaning so the people could understand what was being read. And as they read, the people comprehended the teachings.
Nehemiah 8:9 Then Nehemiah, who was the governor, and Ezra the priest and scribe, along with the Levites who were instructing the people, said to everyone: 'This day is consecrated to the Lord our God. Do not mourn, and do not weep.' For all the people were weeping as they heard the words of the Law, realizing their past transgressions.
Nehemiah 8:10 And Nehemiah said to them: 'Go, enjoy rich foods and sweet drinks, and share some with those who have nothing prepared, for this is a holy day for our Lord. Do not be sorrowful, for the joy of the Lord is our strength and our protection.'
Nehemiah 8:11 And the Levites quieted all the people, saying: 'Be silent, because this is a holy day. Do not grieve, but rejoice.'
Nehemiah 8:12 So all the people went away to eat and to drink, and to share their provisions, and to rejoice with great gladness. They did this because they had understood the words that had been taught to them from the Law of God.
Nehemiah 8:13 On the second day, the heads of the families of all the people, along with the priests and Levites, gathered with Ezra the scribe. They came so he could further explain the words of the Law to them, seeking deeper understanding.
Nehemiah 8:14 And they found it written in the Law that the Lord had commanded through Moses, that the children of Israel should dwell in temporary shelters, or booths, during the solemn feast of the seventh month.
Nehemiah 8:15 And that they should proclaim and make known throughout all their cities, and especially in Jerusalem, saying: 'Go out to the hill country and bring branches of olive trees, and branches of beautiful trees, branches of myrtle, and branches of palm trees, and branches of leafy trees, so that you may make booths,' just as it is written in the Law.
Nehemiah 8:16 So the people went out and brought the branches. And they made booths for themselves, each person on the roof of his house, and in their courtyards, and in the courtyards of the house of God, and in the public square by the Water Gate, and in the square by the Gate of Ephraim.
Nehemiah 8:17 Thus, the entire congregation of those who had returned from captivity made booths and lived in them. Indeed, the children of Israel had not done so in this manner since the days of Joshua the son of Nun, until that very day. And there was exceedingly great rejoicing.
Nehemiah 8:18 Ezra also read from the Book of the Law of God each and every day, from the first day of the feast until the last. They celebrated the solemnity for seven days, and on the eighth day, there was a solemn assembly according to the prescribed ritual of the Law.
Nehemiah 8:2 So Ezra, the priest, brought the book of the Law before the great multitude of men and women and all those who could listen and understand. This happened on the first day of the seventh month.
Nehemiah 8:3 And he read from it in the public square that was in front of the Water Gate, from the early morning until midday. He read in the presence of the men and women, and those who were able to understand, and the words of the book resonated in the ears of all the people, as they listened intently.
Nehemiah 8:4 Now Ezra, the scribe, stood on a wooden platform which he had made for speaking. And beside him stood Mattithiah, Shema, Anaiah, Uriah, Hilkiah, and Maaseiah, to his right. And to his left were Pedaiah, Mishael, Malchijah, Hashum, Hashbaddana, Zechariah, and Meshullam.
Nehemiah 8:5 And Ezra opened the book before all the people, for he stood high above all of them. And when he opened it, all the people stood up in reverence.
Nehemiah 8:6 And Ezra blessed the Lord, the great God. And all the people answered, "Amen! Amen!" raising their hands in agreement. Then they bowed down and worshiped God with their faces to the ground.
Nehemiah 8:7 Furthermore, Jeshua, Bani, Sherebiah, Jamin, Akkub, Shabbethai, Hodiah, Maaseiah, Kelita, Azariah, Jozabad, Hanan, and Pelaiah, who were Levites, made the people remain silent so they would listen to the Law. And all the people remained standing in their place.
Nehemiah 8:8 And they read from the book of the Law of God, explaining it distinctly and clearly so that it could be understood. And the people understood the Law as it was being read to them.
Nehemiah 8:9 Then Nehemiah himself, and Ezra the priest and scribe, and the Levites who were instructing all the people, said to them, "This day is consecrated to the Lord our God. Do not mourn and do not weep, for all the people were weeping when they heard the words of the Law."
Nehemiah 8:10 And he said to them, "Go now, eat rich food and drink sweet wine, and send portions to those who have not prepared anything for themselves. For this day is holy to our Lord; do not be grieved, for the joy of the Lord is our strength."
Nehemiah 8:11 And the Levites calmed all the people, saying, "Be silent, for this day is holy, and do not be grieved."
Nehemiah 8:12 So all the people went away to eat and drink, and to send portions, and to make great rejoicing. For they had understood the words that had been taught to them, and they were filled with joy.
Nehemiah 8:13 And on the second day, the heads of the families of all the people, along with the priests and the Levites, gathered to Ezra the scribe, so that he might interpret for them more about the words of the Law.
Nehemiah 8:14 And they found written in the Law, that the Lord had commanded through Moses for the children of Israel to dwell in booths during the solemn feast of the seventh month.
Nehemiah 8:15 And that they should proclaim and spread the word throughout all their cities and in Jerusalem, saying, "Go out to the mountain, and bring branches of olive, and branches of beautiful trees, branches of myrtle, and palm branches, and branches of leafy trees, so that booths may be made, as it is written."
Nehemiah 8:16 And the people went out and brought them. And they made booths for themselves, each one on his own housetop, and in their courtyards, and in the courtyards of the house of God, and in the public square of the Water Gate, and in the public square of the Gate of Ephraim.
Nehemiah 8:17 So the entire assembly of those who had returned from captivity made booths, and they dwelt in them. For the children of Israel had not done so from the days of Joshua the son of Nun until that very day. And there was great rejoicing.
Nehemiah 8:18 And Ezra read from the volume of the Law of God each and every day, from the first day until the very last day of the feast. And they kept the feast for seven days, and on the eighth day there was a solemn assembly, according to the prescribed custom.

Nehemiah 9:1 Now on the twenty-fourth day of this month, the sons of Israel gathered together, in a state of fasting, dressed in sackcloth, and with ashes sprinkled upon them.
Nehemiah 9:2 And the people of Israel separated themselves from all foreign influence and people. They then stood publicly to confess their sins, acknowledging also the grave sins of their ancestors.
Nehemiah 9:3 Then the Levites—Jeshua, Bani, Kadmiel, Shebaniah, Bunni, Sherebiah, Bunni, and Chenani—stood and read aloud from the Book of the Law of their Lord God for a full quarter of the day. For another full quarter of the day, they engaged in solemn confession and fervent worship of their Lord God.
Nehemiah 9:4 Jeshua, Bani, Kadmiel, Shebaniah, Bunni, Sherebiah, and Chenani stood on the platform designated for the Levites and cried out with a loud voice to the Lord their God in prayer.
Nehemiah 9:5 And the Levites—Jeshua, Kadmiel, Bunni, Hashabneiah, Sherebiah, Hodiah, Shebaniah, and Pethahiah—exhorted the people, saying, 'Stand up and bless the Lord your God, from everlasting to everlasting! May they bless Your glorious Name, which is exalted above all blessing and praise!'
Nehemiah 9:6 You alone, O Lord, are God. You created the universe and the highest heavens, and all the celestial beings within them. You made the earth and everything upon it, the seas and everything within them. You give life to all of them, and all the celestial beings worship You.
Nehemiah 9:7 You alone are the Lord God, Who chose Abram and brought him forth from Ur of the Chaldees, and changed his name to Abraham.
Nehemiah 9:8 You found his heart faithful before You, and You made a covenant with him to give the land of the Canaanites, the Hittites, the Amorites, the Perizzites, the Jebusites, and the Girgashites to his descendants. And You fulfilled Your promises, because You are just.
Nehemiah 9:9 You saw the suffering of our ancestors in Egypt, and You heard their cry for help by the Red Sea.
Nehemiah 9:10 And You performed great signs and wonders against Pharaoh, and against all his servants, and against all the people of that land, because You knew they had acted with arrogant cruelty against our people. Thus, You established Your Name as it is known even to this day.
Nehemiah 9:11 You divided the sea before them, and they passed through the midst of the sea on dry ground. But their pursuers You cast into the depths, like a stone plunged into raging waters.
Nehemiah 9:12 You were their guide by day in a pillar of cloud, and by night in a pillar of fire, to show them the way they should go.
Nehemiah 9:13 You also descended upon Mount Sinai and spoke with them from the sky. You gave them righteous judgments and a true law, along with good ceremonies and commandments.
Nehemiah 9:14 You made Your holy Sabbath known to them, and through Your servant Moses, You commanded them to obey Your precepts, Your ceremonies, and Your Law.
Nehemiah 9:15 You gave them bread from the sky in their hunger, and brought forth water from the rock for them when they were thirsty. You commanded them to go in and take possession of the land concerning which You had sworn an oath to give it to them.
Nehemiah 9:16 However, they—our ancestors—acted arrogantly and stubbornly resisted Your commands, refusing to listen to Your precepts.
Nehemiah 9:17 They refused to obey and did not remember the marvelous works You had done for them. They hardened their necks and appointed a leader to return to their bondage in Egypt, as if in defiance of You. But You are a God of pardon, gracious and merciful, patient, and full of great compassion, and You did not abandon them.
Nehemiah 9:18 Even when they made for themselves a molten calf and said, 'This is your god who brought you up out of Egypt!'—they committed great blasphemies.
Nehemiah 9:19 Yet, in Your great mercies, You did not abandon them in the desert. The pillar of cloud did not depart from them by day to lead them on the way, nor the pillar of fire by night to show them the path they should take.
Nehemiah 9:20 You also gave Your good Spirit to instruct them. You did not withhold Your manna from their mouths, and You gave them water when they were thirsty.
Nehemiah 9:21 For forty years You nourished them in the desert, and they lacked nothing. Their clothes did not wear out, and their feet did not swell or become sore.
Nehemiah 9:22 You gave them kingdoms and peoples, and You allotted territories to them. They took possession of the land of Sihon, the land of the king of Heshbon, and the land of Og, the king of Bashan.
Nehemiah 9:23 You multiplied their children like the stars of the sky, and brought them into the land about which You had told their ancestors they should enter and possess.
Nehemiah 9:24 So the children came and possessed the land. You humbled before them the Canaanite inhabitants of the land, and You delivered them—their kings and the peoples of the land—into their hands, so that they could do with them as they pleased.
Nehemiah 9:25 They captured fortified cities and fertile land. They took possession of houses filled with all kinds of good things: wells already dug, vineyards, olive groves, and many fruit trees. They ate, were satisfied, grew fat, and reveled in Your great abundance.
Nehemiah 9:26 But they became disobedient and provoked Your anger. They cast Your Law behind their backs and murdered Your prophets who testified against them to bring them back to You. They committed great blasphemies.
Nehemiah 9:27 Therefore, You delivered them into the hands of their enemies, who afflicted them. But in the time of their distress, they cried out to You, and You heard them from the sky. According to Your many mercies, You gave them saviors who rescued them from the hand of their enemies.
Nehemiah 9:28 But as soon as they had rest, they returned to doing evil in Your sight. So You abandoned them to the hand of their enemies, and they were subjected to them. Yet, when they turned back and cried out to You, You heard from the sky and, in Your mercies, delivered them many times.
Nehemiah 9:29 You testified against them, urging them to return to Your Law. But they acted arrogantly and would not listen to Your commandments. They sinned against Your ordinances, which a person must obey to live by them. They defiantly turned their backs and stiffened their necks, refusing to listen.
Nehemiah 9:30 You bore with them for many years and testified against them by Your Spirit through the hands of Your prophets. Yet, they would not listen, so You delivered them into the hands of the peoples of the lands.
Nehemiah 9:31 Nevertheless, in Your abundant mercies, You did not utterly destroy them nor abandon them, for You are a gracious and merciful God.
Nehemiah 9:32 Now therefore, our God, great, mighty, and terrible, Who keeps covenant and mercy, do not let all the trouble that has come upon us seem insignificant in Your sight. This trouble has afflicted our kings, our princes, our priests, our prophets, our ancestors, and all Your people, from the days of the kings of Assyria until this very day.
Nehemiah 9:33 You are just in all that has come upon us, for You have acted faithfully, but we have acted wickedly.
Nehemiah 9:34 Our kings, our princes, our priests, and our ancestors did not follow Your Law. They did not pay attention to Your commandments or to Your testimonies by which You warned them.
Nehemiah 9:35 For even in their kingdoms, and despite Your great goodness that You had given them, and in the very spacious and fertile land that You had delivered before them, they did not serve You. Nor did they turn from their wicked practices.
Nehemiah 9:36 Behold, we ourselves are servants today. And in the very land You gave to our ancestors, for them to eat its fruit and enjoy its good things, we ourselves are servants.
Nehemiah 9:37 Its abundant produce now goes to the kings You have placed over us because of our sins. They dominate our bodies and our livestock according to their own will, and we are in great distress.
Nehemiah 9:38 Because of all this, we ourselves are making a firm covenant and writing it down. Our princes, our Levites, and our priests are putting their seals upon it.
Nehemiah 9:1 On the twenty-fourth day of this particular month, the children of Israel gathered together. They were engaged in fasting, dressed in sackcloth, and had ashes on their heads as a sign of repentance.
Nehemiah 9:2 And the children of Israel separated themselves from all foreign people. They stood up and publicly confessed their own sins and the wickedness that their ancestors had committed.
Nehemiah 9:3 Then they stood up, and for one quarter of the day they read from the book of the Law of the Lord their God. For another quarter of the day, they confessed their sins and worshipped the Lord their God.
Nehemiah 9:4 Then Josue, Bani, Kadmiel, Shebaniah, Bunni, Sherebiah, Bani, and Chenani stood on the platform designated for the Levites. They then cried out with a loud voice to the Lord their God.
Nehemiah 9:5 And the Levites—Josue, Kadmiel, Bani, Hashabneiah, Sherebiah, Hodiah, Shebaniah, and Pethahiah—said: “Rise up and bless the Lord your God from everlasting to everlasting. May they bless Your glorious Name, which is exalted above every blessing and praise!
Nehemiah 9:6 You alone are the Lord. You created the universe and all the heavens within it, with all their hosts of stars and celestial bodies. You created the earth and everything that is in it: the seas and all that is in them. You give life to all of them, and the heavenly hosts worship You.
Nehemiah 9:7 You, O Lord God, are the One who chose Abram. You brought him out from the Ur of the Chaldeans, which was a place of idolatry and evil. You then changed his name to Abraham.
Nehemiah 9:8 You found his heart to be faithful before You, and You made a covenant with him. You promised to give him the land of the Canaanites, the Hittites, the Amorites, the Perizzites, the Jebusites, and the Girgashites, and to his descendants. You kept Your promises because You are just.
Nehemiah 9:9 You saw the affliction of our ancestors in Egypt. You heard their cry for help by the Red Sea.
Nehemiah 9:10 You performed signs and wonders against Pharaoh, against all his servants, and against all his land. For You knew that they had dealt proudly and oppressively against our ancestors. You made a name for Yourself that is still revered to this very day.
Nehemiah 9:11 You divided the sea before them, and they passed through the middle of the sea on dry ground. But their pursuers You cast into the deep, like a stone thrown into mighty waters.
Nehemiah 9:12 You led them by a pillar of cloud during the day and by a pillar of fire at night, so that You might show them the way they should go.
Nehemiah 9:13 You also descended upon Mount Sinai and spoke with them from the heavens. You gave them righteous judgments and the Law of truth, good statutes, and commandments.
Nehemiah 9:14 You made known to them Your holy Sabbath, and You commanded them precepts, statutes, and the Law through the hand of Moses, Your servant.
Nehemiah 9:15 You gave them bread from the sky during their hunger, and You brought forth water for them from the rock when they were thirsty. And You told them to go in and possess the land, which You had sworn to give them by raising Your hand.
Nehemiah 9:16 But they, our ancestors, acted proudly. They stiffened their necks in rebellion and refused to listen to Your commandments.
Nehemiah 9:17 They refused to obey and did not remember the wonderful things You had done for them. They stiffened their necks and appointed a leader to return to their slavery in Egypt, as if through contention. But You, O God, are forgiving, gracious, and merciful. You are patient and abounding in compassion. You did not abandon them.
Nehemiah 9:18 Indeed, they even made a molten calf for themselves and said, 'This is your god who brought you out of Egypt!' And they committed great blasphemies.
Nehemiah 9:19 Yet, in Your abundant mercies, You did not abandon them in the desert. The pillar of cloud did not depart from them by day, guiding them on their way, nor did the pillar of fire by night, showing them the path they should take.
Nehemiah 9:20 You also gave Your good Spirit to instruct them. You did not withhold Your manna from their mouths, and You gave them water when they were thirsty.
Nehemiah 9:21 For forty years You nourished them in the desert, and they lacked nothing. Their clothes did not wear out, and their feet did not swell.
Nehemiah 9:22 You gave them kingdoms and peoples, and You allotted them territories. So they possessed the land of Sihon, the land of the king of Heshbon, and the land of Og, the king of Bashan.
Nehemiah 9:23 You multiplied their children like the stars of the sky. You brought them to the land of which You had told their ancestors, so that they might go in and possess it.
Nehemiah 9:24 And the children came and possessed the land. You humbled before them the Canaanite inhabitants of the land. You delivered the Canaanites into their hand, along with their kings and the peoples of the land, so that our ancestors might do with them as they pleased.
